Some experts have suggested that there are probably far more cases of the illness than China’s authorities have disclosed.</p>, <h2 class="css-3ez4hu eoo0vm40" id="link-4a634744">How Boeing’s role in a deadly crash ‘got buried’</h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">When a Boeing 737 crashed near Amsterdam in 2009, killing nine people, the accident was blamed on Dutch pilots. But Boeing’s mistakes also contributed, including its design choices and faulty safety assessments.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">A review by The New York Times of evidence from the 2009 accident, some of it previously confidential, <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/20/business/boeing-737-accidents.html" title="">reveals striking parallels with recent Boeing crashes</a> that killed hundreds — and resistance by a team of Americans, including Boeing and federal officials, to a full airing of findings that later proved relevant to Boeing’s Max plane.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">An expert commissioned by the Dutch Safety Board to analyze the 2009 crash said it “represents such a sentinel event that was never taken seriously.” His study was never made public.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Comparisons: </strong>In the 2009 and Max accidents, the failure of a single sensor caused systems to misfire, with catastrophic results, and Boeing did not provide pilots with information that could have helped them react to the malfunction.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Quotable: </strong>The Turkish Airlines crash “should have woken everybody up,” said one aviation safety expert.</p>, <h2 class="css-3ez4hu eoo0vm40" id="link-6971d658">Times editorial board endorses two candidates</h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The board, which is <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/13/reader-center/editorial-board-explainer.html" title="">separate from the Times newsroom</a>, announced that it’s supporting both Amy Klobuchar and Elizabeth Warren for the Democratic presidential nomination.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The dual endorsement is a departure from convention. The board says that it is meant to address the party’s “realist” and “radical” models.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">While arguing that President Trump must be defeated, the board did not take a position on which was the best path forward for Democrats, writing that both “warrant serious consideration.” <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2020/01/19/opinion/amy-klobuchar-elizabeth-warren-nytimes-endorsement.html" title="">Read the endorsement here</a>, which distills the themes and challenges of the election coming in November.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Background:</strong> The board’s 15 members met with nine candidates and released <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2020/01/13/opinion/election-nytimes-the-choice.html" title="">full transcripts of their interviews</a>.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Behind the scenes: </strong>The endorsement process has typically been opaque, but this year, our TV show “The Weekly” was invited in. Our deputy editorial page editor <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/13/reader-center/political-endorsements.html" title="">explained the process and the decision to open it up</a> to cameras.</p>, <h2 class="css-3ez4hu eoo0vm40" id="link-6f22816a">Australia can’t catch a break</h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Thousands of people were left without power as <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/20/world/australia/weather-hail-sydney-canberra.html" title="">baseball-size hailstones pummeled major cities</a> in the country’s southeast over the past two days, the latest turn in a summer of extreme weather.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Although a drought — along with the devastating wildfires it has fed — is far from over, thunderstorms have lashed Sydney, Canberra and Melbourne.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">What’s next:</strong> Meteorologists warned that the storms would continue for the next few days. Hot and windy conditions are expected to return to many parts of New South Wales later this week.</p>, <h3 class="css-1b8te77 e1gnsphs0" id="link-6933ce2f">If you have 20 minutes, this is worth it</h3>, <h2 class="css-3ez4hu eoo0vm40" id="link-67b33e41">Helping to exploit Angola’s wealth</h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Isabel dos Santos, above center, Africa’s richest woman, often took cuts of her country’s wealth through decrees signed by her father. Global banks, bound by strict rules about politically connected clients, largely declined to work with her family.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/19/world/africa/isabel-dos-santos.html" title="">But global consulting firms embraced her business</a>, helping her amass a fortune in a country hobbled by corruption and park it abroad, according to a trove of documents obtained by the International Consortium of Investigative Journalists and shared with The Times. The vast empire stretches from Hong Kong to the U.S.</p>, <h3 class="css-1b8te77 e1gnsphs0" id="link-554e6082">Here’s what else is happening</h3>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">India: </strong>As the country seeks to rein in foreign technology companies and international news outlets, <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/20/technology/india-amazon-bezos-washington-post.html" title="">its leaders have pressured Jeff Bezos</a>, who owns one of each: Amazon and The Washington Post.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">How warm was your town?:</strong> Scientists said that 2019 was the second-warmest year on record, and an AccuWeather database of 3,500 cities around the world showed that more than 80 percent experienced higher-than-normal average temperatures last year. <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2020/world/year-in-weather.html" title="">See how your city compares</a>.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">China:</strong> Video of a pig being tied up and shoved off a bungee tower at a theme park in Chongqing <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/20/world/europe/pig-china-bungee-jump.html" title="">has sparked outrage</a> in a country where animal rights activism is a relatively new phenomenon.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Snapshot: </strong>Above, mounds of plastic junk on the outskirts of Beijing. In an effort to combat waste, <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/20/world/asia/china-plastic.html" title="">China is banning</a> the use of disposable foam cutlery and nonbiodegradable plastic bags in major cities by the end of this year, with broader bans to follow.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">What we’re reading: </strong><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.tastecooking.com/god-save-lard-bread/" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">This piece in Taste</a> about a food specialty familiar to only a small subset of Italian-Americans. “It has come to my attention that some of you do not know the first blessed thing about lard bread," tweeted our food critic Pete Wells. “Max [Falkowitz] is here to guide you into the light of lardy knowledge.”</p>, <h3 class="css-1b8te77 e1gnsphs0" id="link-7ded7ef4">Now, a break from the news</h3>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Cook: </strong><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://cooking.nytimes.com/recipes/1017704-vegetarian-skillet-chili" title="">Vegetarian skillet chili</a> is one of those pantry meals that you’ll memorize. (Our <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/newsletters/five-weeknight-dishes" title="">Five Weeknight Dishes newsletter</a> has more recommendations.)</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Read: </strong>The Chilean poet Pablo Neruda helped save over 2,000 refugees. Isabel Allende’s latest book, <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/20/books/review/a-long-petal-of-the-sea-isabel-allende.html" title="">“A Long Petal of the Sea,”</a> imagines two of them.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Smarter Living: </strong>Should you live out of a suitcase when you travel, or unpack your things? There are <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/17/travel/unpack-vacation.html" title="">arguments for both</a>.</p>, <h3 class="css-1b8te77 e1gnsphs0" id="link-15767e9b">And now for the Back Story on …</h3>, <h2 class="css-3ez4hu eoo0vm40" id="link-3cd23f6c">Cocktails</h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">A hundred years ago this month, the U.S. embarked on a 13-year official prohibition on the “manufacture, sale or transportation of intoxicating liquors” anywhere within the country.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/01/us/100-years-ago-the-booziest-january-suddenly-dried-up.html" title="">It didn’t go well.</a></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Bootlegging liquor operations proliferated, as did the illicit bars known as speakeasies. And the drink of choice: the cocktail, which spread out the hooch or disguised its sometimes bad flavors. The boom far outlasted Prohibition. <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://punchdrink.com/recipes/joaquin-simos-sidecar/" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">Sidecar,</a> anyone?</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.grubstreet.com/2015/04/david-wondrich-knows-the-origins-of-cocktail.html" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">Dave Wondrich, a drinks historian, tracked down the source of the word “cocktail.”</a> In the second edition of his landmark reconstruction of mixed drinks, “Imbibe!,” he notes that prospective horse sellers in England would give old or droopy specimens a rectal dose of ginger to make them cock their tails for a younger, zippier appearance.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">From there it was just a short jump to the zingy drinks that made humans perk up, at least at the start of their alcoholic forays.</p>, <p class="css-ma92ss evys1bk0">That’s it for this briefing. See you next time.</p>, <p class="css-ma92ss evys1bk0">— Melina</p>, <p class="css-jwz2nf etfikam0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Thank you</strong><br/>To Mark Josephson and Eleanor Stanford for the break from the news. Andrea Kannapell, the Briefings editor, wrote today’s Back Story. You can reach the team at <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="mailto:briefing+pm@nytimes.com?subject=Briefing%20Feedback" title="">briefing@nytimes.com</a>.</p>, <p class="css-jwz2nf etfikam0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">P.S.</strong><br/>• “The Daily” is off for the Martin Luther King holiday in the U.S. Try listening to the latest <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/15/style/modern-love-podcast-rebecca-hall.html" title="">“Modern Love,”</a> in which the actress Rebecca Hall reads an essay about dating while bipolar, the inspiration behind one of the episodes in the Modern Love TV series.<br/>• Here’s our <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/crosswords/game/mini" title="">Mini Crossword</a>, and a clue: Point of a fable (five letters). <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/crosswords" title="">You can find all our puzzles here</a>.<br/>• The Times is always looking for talent. Check out our <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://nytimes.wd5.myworkdayjobs.com/INYT" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">international</a> and <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://nytimes.wd5.myworkdayjobs.com/NYT" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">U.S. job postings</a>.</p>, <p>Advertisement</p>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd" id="site-index-label">Site Index</h2>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-0">news</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-1">opinion</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-2">arts</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-3">living</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-4">more</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-subscribe-label">Subscribe</h3>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd">Site Information Navigation</h2>]
[<p>Advertisement</p>, <p>Supported by</p>, <h1 class="css-1s4ffep e1h9rw200" id="link-54c5a410" itemprop="headline"><span>Coronavirus: Symptoms, Treatments and Science</span></h1>, <p class="css-1ifw933 e1wiw3jv0" id="article-summary">A respiratory virus that originated in China has infected tens of thousands of people and is spreading to other countries. </p>, <p class="css-1fv7b6t e1jsehar1" itemprop="author" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">By<!-- --> <a class="css-brehiz e1jsehar0" href="https://www.nytimes.com/by/roni-caryn-rabin"><span class="css-1baulvz last-byline" itemprop="name">Roni Caryn Rabin</span></a></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">A novel respiratory virus that originated in Wuhan, China, has spread quickly around the world, leaving many experts <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/02/02/health/coronavirus-pandemic-china.html" title="">to fear the pneumonialike illness may become a pandemic</a>. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">So far, most of those infected with the virus — a type of coronavirus whose scientific designation is 2019-nCoV — have been in China. Most of the deaths have been there as well. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Both the World Health Organization and the United States have declared public health emergencies, and both have offered China technical assistance and expertise to investigate and contain the outbreak.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Much is still unknown about the virus, including two factors that are pivotal to predicting the global human toll: how easily the virus spreads from person to person, and how many of those infected develop severe disease that can lead to death. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">In late January, W.H.O. officials said that about 20 percent of reported patients in China had developed severe illness, including respiratory failure and pneumonia, and that about 2 percent had died. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">But many infected people may have developed only mild symptoms and not sought medical care. That would mean the overall fatality rate could be considerably lower than 2 percent. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Experts cannot yet say who is at greatest risk for developing severe or life-threatening disease, and what factors may be protective against the illness. Children <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/02/05/health/coronavirus-children.html" title="">seem much less likely to develop severe illnesses</a> than middle-aged and older men. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The United States is barring entry by most foreign nationals who have recently visited China. Americans returning from Wuhan and Hubei Province, the epicenter of the outbreak, are to be quarantined for two weeks. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Federal health officials are urging Americans to avoid all travel to China.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“This is a very serious public health situation, and the C.D.C. and federal government have and will continue to take aggressive action to protect the public,” said Dr. Nancy Messonnier, director of the National Center for Immunization and Respiratory Diseases. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">There are just a handful of cases in the United States, however, and for now the risk to Americans is low. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Here’s what scientists have learned so far about the virus and the outbreak.</p>, <h2 class="css-3ez4hu eoo0vm40" id="link-5fa06c1b">What is a coronavirus?</h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Coronaviruses are named for the spikes, which resemble a crown or the sun’s corona, that protrude from their surfaces. They can infect both animals and people, and can cause illnesses of the respiratory tract. The infections can range from the common cold to dangerous conditions like Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome, or SARS, <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2003/04/27/world/the-sars-epidemic-the-path-from-china-s-provinces-a-crafty-germ-breaks-out.html" title="">which sickened thousands of people around the world</a> — and killed nearly 800 — during an outbreak in 2003. Middle East Respiratory Syndrome, or MERS, first reported in Saudi Arabia in 2012, is also caused by a coronavirus.</p>, <h2 class="css-3ez4hu eoo0vm40" id="link-332e2fc9">How dangerous is it?</h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">It is hard to accurately assess the lethality of a new virus, and some scientists said initially that the new virus appeared to be less severe than SARS or MERS. </p>, <h1 class="g-headline" id="g-inlineguide-headline">The Coronavirus Outbreak</h1>, <h2 class="g-inlineguide-list-header g-optimize-type">What do you need to know? Start here.</h2>, <p class="g-inlineguide-date">Updated Feb. 10, 2020</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">But recent news reports indicate that the Chinese authorities muzzled doctors who were first to recognize the new infection, and they may not <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/22/business/china-coronavirus-censorship.html" title="">have been fully transparent about the number of infections and deaths</a> even after the alarm was raised. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">It is also not clear whether cases and deaths in China are being carefully tracked and reported. Diagnostic kits and other health resources <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/02/02/world/asia/china-coronavirus-wuhan.html" title="">have been in short supply in the affected regions</a>. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Scientists don’t know who is most susceptible to the new coronavirus. Does it pose a risk to young healthy people? Or, like seasonal flu, is it primarily a threat to the frail and elderly, and those with underlying health problems?</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“Whenever a new virus comes out, it takes a while to learn about it,” said Dr. Julie Vaishampayan, chairwoman of the public health committee of the Infectious Diseases Society of America.<span class="css-8l6xbc evw5hdy0"> </span>Right now, she said, “The information about coronavirus is changing rapidly.” </p>, <h2 class="css-3ez4hu eoo0vm40" id="link-4233383d">How is the new coronavirus transmitted?</h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Most respiratory viruses are transmitted through coughing and sneezing.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Though the Chinese authorities initially played down the likelihood of human-to-human transmission, it has now become clear there is significant and sustained transmission among people. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Chinese scientists have warned that some infected people may transmit the virus to others even before they develop illness or experience any symptoms, although a published report documenting asymptomatic transmission in Germany has been criticized as flawed.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">If people with no symptoms at all or mild symptoms unrelated to respiratory illness — like headache or back ache — can transmit the virus, that’s “bad news,” said Dr. William Schaffner, an expert in infectious diseases at Vanderbilt University Medical Center. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">When people don’t know they are infected, “they’re up and about, going to work or the gym or to religious services, and breathing on or near other people,” Dr. Schaffner said. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">A major concern is that with both SARS and MERS, a few patients inexplicably became “superspreaders” who infected huge numbers of people. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Health care workers are particularly vulnerable. At a hospital in Seoul in 2015, one man with MERS transmitted it to 82 patients. </p>, <h2 class="css-3ez4hu eoo0vm40" id="link-525ab252">Where did the new coronavirus outbreak start?</h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">On Jan. 8, The New York Times reported that Chinese researchers had <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/08/health/china-pneumonia-outbreak-virus.html" title="">identified a new coronavirus</a> as the pathogen behind a mysterious illness that had sickened 59 people in Wuhan.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The cases were linked to a market that sold live fish, animals and birds. The market was later shut down and disinfected. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Past outbreaks of similar illnesses, including SARS, also are believed to have emerged from live animal markets. The coronavirus that causes MERS is transmitted to humans by camels.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The animal that was the source of the new coronavirus is still not known, and the destruction of the Wuhan meat market has made the question nearly impossible to investigate. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/28/science/bats-coronavirus-Wuhan.html" title="">Bats are considered a possible source</a>, because they have evolved to coexist with many viruses, including coronaviruses. But it is very possible the virus was transmitted from bats to an intermediate animal, and then to humans.</p>, <h2 class="css-zd32qr">Coronavirus Map: Tracking the Spread of the Outbreak</h2>, <p class="css-1uuihdo">The virus has sickened more than 40,600 people in China and 24 other countries.</p>, <h2 class="css-3ez4hu eoo0vm40" id="link-5cda2f4b">What symptoms should I look out for?</h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Symptoms of this virus include fever, severe cough and difficulty breathing or shortness of breath. The illness causes lung lesions and pneumonia. Milder cases may resemble the flu or a bad cold, making detection difficult.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Patients may exhibit other symptoms, too, such as gastrointestinal problems or diarrhea. The incubation period — the time from exposure to the onset of symptoms — is believed to be anywhere from 10 days to two weeks.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">If you have a fever or cough and recently visited China, or spent time with someone who did, see your health care provider. Call first, so they can prepare for your visit and take steps to protect other patients and staff from potential exposure.</p>, <h2 class="css-3ez4hu eoo0vm40" id="link-7c7b4f38">Is there a test for the virus? What is the treatment? </h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">There is a diagnostic test that can tell if you are infected. It was developed by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, based on genetic information about the virus provided by the Chinese authorities. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Right now, tests are done by the C.D.C. in Atlanta, but the test has been approved by the Food and Drug Administration and will be distributed to state laboratories. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The main treatment for coronavirus is supportive care, including making sure the patient is getting enough oxygen, and using a ventilator to push air into the lungs if necessary, Dr. Vaishampayan said. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Patients should rest and drink plenty of fluids “while the immune system does its job and heals itself,” she said.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">No drugs have been approved for any coronavirus diseases, including the new coronavirus, though an antiviral medication called remdesivir appears to be effective in animals and was used to treat a patient in Washington State. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Chinese officials are experimenting with other antiviral drugs to treat the infection. </p>, <h2 class="css-3ez4hu eoo0vm40" id="link-b710cce">How long will it take to develop a vaccine?</h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">A coronavirus vaccine is still months away — and perhaps years. While new technology, advancements in genomics and improved global coordination have allowed researchers to move at unprecedented speed, vaccine development remains an expensive and risky process.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">With each new outbreak, scientists typically have to start from scratch. After the SARS outbreak in 2003, it took researchers about 20 months to get a vaccine ready for human trials. (The vaccine was never needed, because the disease was eventually contained.) </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">By the time of the Zika outbreak in 2015, researchers had brought the vaccine development timeline down to six months.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Now, they hope that work from past outbreaks will help cut the timeline further.<span class="css-8l6xbc evw5hdy0"> </span>Scientists at the National Institutes of Health and several companies <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/28/health/coronavirus-vaccine.html" title="">are working on vaccine candidates</a>.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Dr. Anthony Fauci, director of the National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases, said a preliminary clinical trial may get off the ground in as little as three months. But researchers would still need to conduct extensive testing to prove a vaccine is safe and effective. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Even under the best circumstances, it could take at least a year — maybe longer — for a vaccine to become available.</p>, <h2 class="css-3ez4hu eoo0vm40" id="link-af8807b">Should I wear a surgical mask to protect myself?</h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">If you have a respiratory infection, wearing a mask <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/23/health/coronavirus-surgical-masks.html" title="">helps protect the people around you from illness</a> by reducing the risk that you will spread the infection. And wearing a surgical mask may somewhat protect you from infection in a crowd if there is an outbreak. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">But, generally, surgical masks are not closefitting enough to filter all the air you are breathing in, and heavy-duty N95 respirators are extremely uncomfortable.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Experts recommend <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/28/opinion/coronavirus-prevention-tips.html" title="">washing your hands frequently</a> throughout the day. Avoid touching your face, and maintain a distance from anyone who is coughing or sneezing.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">At the moment, the risk of infection with the new coronavirus in the United States<span class="css-8l6xbc evw5hdy0"> </span>“is way too low for the general public to start wearing a face mask,” said Dr. Peter Rabinowitz, co-director of the University of Washington MetaCenter for Pandemic Preparedness and Global Health Security. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">But, he added, “if you have symptoms of a respiratory illness, wearing a mask reduces the risk of infecting others.”</p>, <h2 class="css-3ez4hu eoo0vm40" id="link-6211b58">I have a trip planned to China. Should I go?</h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Probably not. The State Department has warned Americans not to go to China unless it is absolutely essential.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">If travelers must go, the C.D.C. urges enhanced precautions: avoiding contact with anyone who is sick, as well as with animals and the markets in which they are sold; and refraining from eating raw or undercooked meats. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Anyone who is older or has an underlying health condition, which increases susceptibility to infections, should consult with a health provider before making a trip. Access to medical care in China may be difficult, given the outbreak, and federal officials warned that new travel restrictions could be imposed on return, including quarantine.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Many airlines have canceled flights to China, and <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/02/04/travel/coronavirus-travel-plans.html" title="">many travelers were left in limbo</a> while looking to change or cancel bookings.<span class="css-8l6xbc evw5hdy0"> </span></p>, <h2 class="css-3ez4hu eoo0vm40" id="link-755ffae6">What are health authorities doing to contain the virus? </h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">China has taken drastic actions to bar people from leaving affected areas, though 5 million people departed Wuhan alone before the restrictions went into effect. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Residents have been told to wear masks in public to prevent the spread of the disease. Two new hospitals for coronavirus patients are being erected; the first opened on Monday. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Governments around the world have been screening incoming passengers from China for signs of illness, and some have gone further,<span class="css-8l6xbc evw5hdy0"> </span>barring entry to people from China. Russia and Mongolia have closed most of their borders with China. Australia said it would evacuate citizens from Wuhan and quarantine them for 14 days on Christmas Island.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">C.D.C. teams are also providing assistance with state health investigations of infections, including contact-tracing, which means making sure anyone who may have been in contact with an infected individual is warned of the exposure and<span class="css-8l6xbc evw5hdy0"> </span>is monitored. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The work will enhance the understanding of the virus and how to prevent its spread. C.D.C. teams have also offered to send public health experts to China to help with the investigation and containment efforts.</p>, <p class="css-jwz2nf etfikam0">Reporting was contributed by Knvul Sheikh and Daniel Victor. </p>, <p>Advertisement</p>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd" id="site-index-label">Site Index</h2>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-0">news</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-1">opinion</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-2">arts</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-3">living</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-4">more</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-subscribe-label">Subscribe</h3>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd">Site Information Navigation</h2>]
[<p>Advertisement</p>, <h1 class="interactive-heading css-1s4ffep e1h9rw200" id="interactive-heading" itemprop="headline">Wuhan Coronavirus Map: Tracking the Spread of the Outbreak</h1>, <p class="interactive-byline e1n4ps4i0 css-ua5ckx e1jsehar1" id="interactive-byline" itemprop="author" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">By<!-- --> <a class="css-brehiz e1jsehar0" href="https://www.nytimes.com/by/kk-rebecca-lai"><span class="css-1baulvz" itemprop="name">K.K. Rebecca Lai</span></a>, <a class="css-brehiz e1jsehar0" href="https://www.nytimes.com/by/jin-wu"><span class="css-1baulvz" itemprop="name">Jin Wu</span></a>, <a class="css-brehiz e1jsehar0" href="https://www.nytimes.com/by/allison-mccann"><span class="css-1baulvz" itemprop="name">Allison McCann</span></a>, <a class="css-brehiz e1jsehar0" href="https://www.nytimes.com/by/derek-watkins"><span class="css-1baulvz" itemprop="name">Derek Watkins</span></a>, <a class="css-brehiz e1jsehar0" href="https://www.nytimes.com/by/jugal-k-patel"><span class="css-1baulvz" itemprop="name">Jugal K. Patel</span></a> and <span class="css-1baulvz last-byline" itemprop="name">Richard Harris</span><time class="css-wcxsge">Updated <!-- -->January 31, 2020</time></p>, <p class="g-body ">
	The <a href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/28/world/asia/china-coronavirus.html">Wuhan coronavirus</a> has sickened more than 4,500 people in Asia, according to statements from health officials. Many other cases are suspected but not confirmed. As of Tuesday morning, at least 106 people have died, all in China.
</p>, <h3 class="g-caption_heading ">Confirmed cases</h3>, <p class="g-body ">
	The disease has been detected in at least 13 other countries, almost all involving people who traveled from China.
</p>, <p class="g-body ">
	Five cases have been confirmed in the United States: a woman in her 60s in Chicago, a man in his 30s in Washington state, two people in southern California, and one person in Arizona.
</p>, <p class="g-body ">
	The <a href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/08/health/china-pneumonia-outbreak-virus.html">outbreak began</a> in a seafood and poultry market in Wuhan, a city of 11 million people in central China. But which animal is the source of the virus and how many people are at risk remain unclear. The virus can spread from <a href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/20/world/asia/coronavirus-china-symptoms.html">person to person</a>, but it is not known how easily.
</p>, <p class="g-body g-refer">
<a href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/28/world/asia/china-coronavirus.html">Follow the latest updates</a> on the coronavirus outbreak.
</p>, <h2 class="g-subhed g-optimize-type " id="">
<span class="g-balancer" data-id="9">What’s being done to contain the outbreak?</span>
</h2>, <p class="g-body ">
	The Chinese authorities took the <a href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/22/world/asia/coronavirus-quarantines-history.html">extraordinary step</a> of closing off Wuhan, canceling planes and trains leaving the city and suspending buses, subways and ferries within it. By Friday, at least 12 other cities in Hubei Province had issued travel restrictions, including Huanggang, home to seven million people, and Ezhou, a city of about one million.
</p>, <p class="g-pstyle0">Railway</p>, <p class="g-pstyle0">networks</p>, <p class="g-pstyle1">About 20 million people live</p>, <p class="g-pstyle1">in these three cities.</p>, <p class="g-pstyle2">XIAOGAN</p>, <p class="g-pstyle3">HUANGGANG</p>, <p class="g-pstyle3">WUHAN</p>, <p class="g-pstyle4">EZHOU</p>, <p class="g-pstyle5">CHINA</p>, <p class="g-pstyle6">Wuhan</p>, <p class="g-pstyle0">About 20 million people</p>, <p class="g-pstyle0">live in these three cities.</p>, <p class="g-pstyle1">Railway</p>, <p class="g-pstyle1">networks</p>, <p class="g-pstyle2">WUHAN</p>, <p class="g-pstyle2">HUANGGANG</p>, <p class="g-pstyle3">EZHOU</p>, <p class="g-pstyle4">CHINA</p>, <p class="g-pstyle5">Wuhan</p>, <p class="g-body ">
	The restrictions on trains and other forms of public transportation come just before the Lunar New Year holiday, when hundreds of millions of people travel around and out of the country.
</p>, <p class="g-body ">
	The restrictions also began spreading beyond Hubei. On Saturday, the Beijing city government announced that it would suspend all inter-province buses, effectively limiting road travel into the capital.
</p>, <h2 class="g-subhed g-optimize-type " id="">
<span class="g-balancer" data-id="10">How big could the outbreak be?</span>
</h2>, <p class="g-body ">
	Researchers at <a href="https://www.mobs-lab.org/2019ncov.html">Northeastern University</a> and <a href="https://www.imperial.ac.uk/mrc-global-infectious-disease-analysis/news--wuhan-coronavirus/">Imperial College London</a> estimate that the number of cases may be five or ten times higher than what has been reported. Thousands of suspected cases are yet to be confirmed with tests, and others with the virus may not have sought medical attention.
</p>, <p class="g-body ">
	On Monday, the Northeastern researchers estimated there may be around 25,000 cases. The estimates will change as more cases are reported and more information about the virus becomes known.
</p>, <h3 class="g-caption_heading ">Estimated number of coronavirus cases</h3>, <p>Estimates say there may be about <span class="g-cstyle0">25,000 cases</span> of the virus in Wuhan.</p>, <p class="g-pstyle0">More likely</p>, <p class="g-pstyle1">0</p>, <p class="g-pstyle1">10k</p>, <p class="g-pstyle1">20k</p>, <p class="g-pstyle1">30k</p>, <p class="g-pstyle1">40k</p>, <p class="g-pstyle0">Number of cases</p>, <p>Estimates say there may be about <span class="g-cstyle0">25,000 cases</span> of the virus in Wuhan.</p>, <p class="g-pstyle0">More likely</p>, <p class="g-pstyle1">0</p>, <p class="g-pstyle1">10k</p>, <p class="g-pstyle1">20k</p>, <p class="g-pstyle1">30k</p>, <p class="g-pstyle1">40k</p>, <p class="g-pstyle0">Number of cases</p>, <p class="g-body ">
	These estimates are based on <a href="https://www.mobs-lab.org/2019ncov.html">an analysis</a> of the population of Wuhan, the number of cases detected outside of China and the number of people who travel from Wuhan to other areas. Public health officials still do not know how the disease is transmitted, and experts urged caution in interpreting the estimates.
</p>, <p class="g-body ">
	“These are very early models that make several assumptions based on what evidence is available,” said David Heymann, an epidemiologist at the London School of Hygiene and Tropical Medicine. “They aren’t truth — they’re just one step in trying to better understand this outbreak.”
</p>, <p>Advertisement</p>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd" id="site-index-label">Site Index</h2>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-0">news</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-1">opinion</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-2">arts</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-3">living</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-4">more</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-subscribe-label">Subscribe</h3>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd">Site Information Navigation</h2>]
[<p>Advertisement</p>, <p>Supported by</p>, <h1 class="css-1s4ffep e1h9rw200" id="link-aa6343a" itemprop="headline"><span>First Patient With Wuhan Coronavirus Is Identified in the U.S.</span></h1>, <p class="css-1ifw933 e1wiw3jv0" id="article-summary">A man in Washington State is infected with a new respiratory virus. Federal officials plan to expand screenings for the infection at major airports.</p>, <p class="css-1fv7b6t e1jsehar1" itemprop="author" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">By<!-- --> <a class="css-brehiz e1jsehar0" href="https://www.nytimes.com/by/roni-caryn-rabin"><span class="css-1baulvz last-byline" itemprop="name">Roni Caryn Rabin</span></a></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">A man in Washington State is infected with the Wuhan coronavirus, the first confirmed case in the United States of a mysterious respiratory infection that has killed at least six people and sickened hundreds more in Asia, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention announced on Tuesday.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Federal officials also announced expanded screenings for the infection at major airports in the United States. In addition to New York, Los Angeles and San Francisco, airports in Atlanta and Chicago will begin examining passengers arriving from Wuhan, China, for signs of illness.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The infected man, who is in his 30s and a resident of Snohomish County, Wash., developed symptoms after returning from a trip to the region around Wuhan where the outbreak began.</p>, <h2 class="css-zd32qr">Wuhan Coronavirus Map: Tracking the Spread of the Outbreak</h2>, <p class="css-1uuihdo">The virus has sickened tens of thousands of people in China and a number of other countries.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">He returned from Wuhan on Jan. 15, two days before passenger screening was instituted at three major airports in the United States, but he had no symptoms at the time.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">He read online about the mysterious new virus that causes fever and respiratory illness, and informed his doctors about his recent trip when he sought care on Sunday, federal officials said.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">[</em><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://parenting.nytimes.com/childrens-health/coronavirus-children-pregnant-women" title=""><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">What parents need to know about coronavirus</em></a><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">]</em></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">He was seen at a clinic in Snohomish County and is now hospitalized at Providence Regional Medical Center-Everett. Specimens from the patient were sent to the C.D.C. in Atlanta, and officials confirmed on Monday that he was infected with the Wuhan coronavirus, also called 2019-nCoV.</p>, <h1 class="g-headline" id="g-inlineguide-headline">The Coronavirus Outbreak</h1>, <h2 class="g-inlineguide-list-header g-optimize-type">What do you need to know? Start here.</h2>, <p class="g-inlineguide-date">Updated Feb. 10, 2020</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Health officials declined to identify the patient, but said that he has a mild case of pneumonia, is doing well and has been very cooperative.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Health care workers are also trying to identify people who may have had contact with the infected traveler, and are notifying some of the passengers on his return flight who might have been exposed. They will monitor those fellow passengers for fever and respiratory symptoms.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“We’re very comfortable the patient is isolated and poses little risk to the staff or general public,” said Dr. Chris Spitters, health officer at the Snohomish Health District, adding that the strict isolation practices were implemented in “an abundance of caution.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">News of the first case of the virus in the United States surfaced as officials studied growing evidence that the disease can be transmitted from person to person, although it is not clear how easily.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“There is new information hour by hour, day by day, that we are tracking and following closely,” said Dr. Nancy Messonnier, director of the C.D.C.’s National Center for Immunization and Respiratory Diseases.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The C.D.C. has deployed staff overseas who are working closely with the ministries of health in China and Thailand. “The key issue we all need to understand is how easily and sustainably the virus is spread from human to human,” Dr. Messonnier said.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Federal health officials plan to expand the screening of passengers arriving in the United States from Wuhan to five airports that are major international hubs. All travelers from the city will be funneled through those airports.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Screenings started on Friday and Saturday at New York’s Kennedy International Airport, San Francisco International and Los Angeles International. Now they will be expanded to Hartsfield-Jackson Atlanta International and Chicago O’Hare International over the next few days.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Passengers from Wuhan planning to arrive in other cities will be issued new tickets taking them to one of the five screening airports, officials said.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The outbreak, which began in December in a seafood and poultry market in Wuhan, a city of 11 million, is spreading: Patients have been identified in Beijing, Shanghai and Shenzhen, as well as Taiwan, Japan, Thailand and South Korea.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">On Tuesday, Chinese authorities confirmed that six people have died of the infection in Wuhan. Nearly 300 cases have been reported to date in China, and federal health officials said that number is likely to grow. Many of the patients lived in or traveled to Wuhan.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">In Mexico, President Andrés Manuel López Obrador said Wednesday morning that the Mexican health authorities had identified a possible case in the northeastern state of Tamaulipas. The patient was “under observation,” the president said during a news conference.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The patient with the suspected case of coronavirus is a 57-year-old researcher in a university biotechnology laboratory who lives and works in Reynosa, a border town that abuts McAllen, Texas, according to officials in Tamaulipas. The man traveled to China on Dec. 25 and visited relatives in Wuhan, returning to Mexico on Jan. 10.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">In recent days, the man came down with a dry cough and a runny nose, and decided to report himself to the health authorities, officials said. The man is now isolated in his house, where he lives alone, and test results that could confirm a coronavirus infection are expected in the next few days, said Gloria Molina, the health secretary for Tamaulipas.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The World Health Organization is meeting on Wednesday to decide whether to declare the outbreak an international public health emergency. But information about the new virus is still thin, and it’s not clear whether or how many Americans are at risk.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10"><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">[</em></strong><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10"><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="http://on.fb.me/1paTQ1h" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title=""><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">Like the Science Times page on Facebook.</em></a></strong><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10"><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0"> </em></strong><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">| Sign up for the </em><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10"><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="http://nyti.ms/1MbHaRU" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title=""><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">Science Times newsletter.</em></a></strong><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10"><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">]</em></strong></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“There are still more questions that we don’t know the answers to than things we do know,” said Dr. William Schaffner, a professor of preventive medicine and infectious diseases at Vanderbilt University Medical Center in Nashville.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“For example, what is the source? We don’t know exactly. The location likely was the live animal market, but we don’t know the particular animal.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The more pressing and urgent question, he said: “How frequent is human-to-human transmission?”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“Could people with mild infections transmit this virus from person to person?” he added. “That all remains still under investigation.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The patient in Washington told doctors that he had not visited the animal markets in Wuhan, nor had he come into contact with anyone who was sick.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">On Monday, Vanderbilt University Medical Center in Nashville changed its electronic prompts so that any patients coming in to its hospital, emergency room or clinics with a fever or respiratory symptoms will be asked whether they have been to China recently or have had contact with anyone who has recently traveled to China.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Hospitals around the country are likely taking similar steps, Dr. Schaffner said, in an effort to quickly identify infected patients and place them in isolation so they can be cared for safely by hospital workers, and so specimens can be collected for testing.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Dr. Schaffner cautioned anyone traveling to China to avoid visiting live animal markets and to keep a distance from all live animals, including domesticated farm animals. Travelers to China should practice <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2016/04/21/health/washing-hands.html" title="">lots of good hand hygiene</a>, he added, and do their best to avoid anyone who is coughing or sneezing.</p>, <p class="css-jwz2nf etfikam0">Mike Baker contributed reporting from Seattle, and Kirk Semple from Mexico City.</p>, <p>Advertisement</p>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd" id="site-index-label">Site Index</h2>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-0">news</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-1">opinion</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-2">arts</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-3">living</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-4">more</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-subscribe-label">Subscribe</h3>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd">Site Information Navigation</h2>]
[<p>Advertisement</p>, <p>Supported by</p>, <h1 class="css-1s4ffep e1h9rw200" id="link-14028871" itemprop="headline"><span>The Test a Deadly Coronavirus Outbreak Poses to China’s Leadership</span></h1>, <p class="css-1ifw933 e1wiw3jv0" id="article-summary">The new virus has killed at least nine and infected more than 400 people in China, with confirmed cases in the United States, Taiwan, Thailand, Japan and South Korea.</p>, <p class="css-1fv7b6t e1jsehar1" itemprop="author" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">By<!-- --> <a class="css-brehiz e1jsehar0" href="https://www.nytimes.com/by/javier-c-hernandez"><span class="css-1baulvz last-byline" itemprop="name">Javier C. Hernández</span></a></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">WUHAN, China — Facing growing pressure to contain a deadly viral outbreak that has spread halfway around the world, China’s ruling Communist Party raced on Tuesday to confront the disease, slapping restrictions on the city where it started and warning that anyone who hides infections will be “forever nailed to history’s pillar of shame.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The response by the Chinese leadership, which has come under intensifying criticism that it has been slow to acknowledge the severity of the outbreak, came as fatalities from the disease tripled to at least nine. Infections surged from 200 to 440, and global financial markets were rattled by the possibility of a pandemic emanating from the world’s most populous country during the Lunar New Year — <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/22/world/asia/china-coronavirus-travel.html" title="">Asia’s heaviest travel season</a>.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Already, cases of the <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/08/health/china-pneumonia-outbreak-virus.html" title="">pneumonia-like virus </a>have been found in Taiwan, Japan, Thailand and South Korea, and on Tuesday the first was confirmed in <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/21/health/cdc-coronavirus.html" title="">the United States</a>. Airports in Atlanta and Chicago said they would screen passengers from Wuhan, <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/17/health/china-coronavirus-airport-screening.html" title="">joining airports in New York, Los Angeles, San Francisco</a> and cities around the world in doing so. North Korea<a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.youngpioneertours.com/north-korea-temporarily-closes-border-until-further-notice-coronavirus-precaution/" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title=""> temporarily closed its borders to foreign tours</a>, the vast majority of them from China. The World Health Organization has called a meeting on Wednesday over whether to declare the outbreak an international health emergency.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">In Wuhan, the central Chinese city of 11 million where the outbreak began, the authorities have banned group tours out of the city and ordered vehicles checked for live animals. Nervous residents are buying up face masks and flooding hospitals to report fevers and coughs. Some schools are canceling classes and even Buddhist temples are turning away the faithful.</p>, <h2 class="css-zd32qr">Wuhan Coronavirus Map: Tracking the Spread of the Outbreak</h2>, <p class="css-1uuihdo">The virus has sickened tens of thousands of people in China and a number of other countries.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">At home and abroad, the Chinese authorities are facing demands for greater transparency in their disclosures about the disease, as new cases emerge in other major Chinese cities. As of late Tuesday, there were 440 cases in 13 provinces in China.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The outbreak is testing China’s leader, Xi Jinping, and the party’s penchant for secrecy in moments of crisis, 17 years after Beijing drew widespread criticism for withholding information and acting slowly in handling the outbreak of SARS, which killed more than 800 people and infected more than 8,000 worldwide.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Mr. Xi, who has sought to expand China’s global influence, seems eager to shake the shadow of SARS and show that Beijing can handle a public health crisis like a responsible world power. A top party committee on Tuesday said in stark terms that it would not tolerate any efforts to hide infections.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“Whoever deliberately delays or conceals reporting for the sake of their own interests will be forever nailed to history’s pillar of shame,” the committee said in a post on a popular social media site. The post was later deleted.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">On Monday, China’s health commission said it would respond with measures intended to manage outbreaks of the most virulent diseases, including mandatory reporting of cases. It <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="http://www.nhc.gov.cn/jkj/s7916/202001/44a3b8245e8049d2837a4f27529cd386.shtml" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">classified the virus as a class B infectious disease</a> — a category that includes diseases such as <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2003/04/27/world/the-sars-epidemic-the-path-from-china-s-provinces-a-crafty-germ-breaks-out.html" title="">SARS</a>.</p>, <h1 class="g-headline" id="g-inlineguide-headline">The Coronavirus Outbreak</h1>, <h2 class="g-inlineguide-list-header g-optimize-type">What do you need to know? Start here.</h2>, <p class="g-inlineguide-date">Updated Feb. 10, 2020</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">But the government,<strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10"> </strong>wary of letting fear run rampant,<strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10"> </strong>is also working meticulously to control the narrative about the virus by censoring news articles and social media posts. The police in Wuhan <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="http://www.xinhuanet.com/legal/2020-01/01/c_1125412773.htm" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">investigated eight citizens</a> this month for spreading what it described as rumors on the internet.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Now, even as the government works to isolate sick patients amid travel by millions of people making visits for the Lunar New Year holiday,<span class="css-8l6xbc evw5hdy0"> </span>there is concern that the party’s long-held reluctance to divulge damaging news could hinder the effort to contain the virus.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">For weeks, the government had largely treated the outbreak as <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/10/world/asia/china-virus-wuhan-death.html" title="">a problem isolated</a> to <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/24/health/chicago-coronavirus-cdc.html" title="">Wuhan</a>. It was only after the Hong Kong news media reported that cases of the <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/24/health/chicago-coronavirus-cdc.html" title="">coronavirus</a> had been detected elsewhere that the government began acknowledging, early Monday, that the disease had spread to other cities.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Many wondered why the central government waited until Monday to allow a top health expert to speak publicly about the outbreak. The expert not only corroborated what the Hong Kong news media had already reported but confirmed vital new information: that <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/20/world/asia/coronavirus-china-symptoms.html" title="">the virus spreads between people</a>.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“The response is not fast enough, it’s not strong enough,” said Shen Zhengjiang, 57, a teacher, as he looked for masks at a pharmacy in Wuhan on Tuesday. “The local officials are paying attention to this now only because Xi Jinping spoke up.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The outbreak presents Mr. Xi, who rose to power in 2012, with one of the most serious public health crises of his tenure. It will be a significant test of his leadership at a time when China is seeking to strengthen trust in the party and to project confidence in Mr. Xi’s authoritarian approach.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Any missteps could undermine the party’s credibility in the eyes of the public, experts said.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“This is the sort of thing that could absolutely gnaw at the confidence and legitimacy of the whole regime,” said Kerry Brown, director of the Lau China Institute at King’s College London.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Experts said the challenge for Mr. Xi would be daunting, as the world looks to China to stop the virus before it spreads on a global scale.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Yanzhong Huang, director of the Center for Global Health Studies at Seton Hall University, said that it appeared Mr. Xi was seeking to show that the virus is under control and would not cause social unrest. But he said the government’s initial failure to detail the spread of the virus to mainland cities and to disclose that medical workers had been infected was worrying.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“So far this pattern of a lack of transparency and inaction has unfortunately not changed,” said Professor Huang, an expert on the SARS epidemic. “The politics continue to constrain the government to respond effectively.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The Chinese government, which has been praised by the W.H.O. for its efforts so far, has said it took time to analyze the coronavirus, which experts believe appears to be mostly transmitted to humans by animals.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The delay in reporting the spread of the disease was attributed to technological challenges, but also bureaucratic ones.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Some hospitals lacked testing kits, according to remarks on Monday by Dr. Zhong Nanshan, a prominent scientist who is leading a government-appointed panel of experts helping control the outbreak. The process was also slowed down, he said, because local hospitals were required to submit cases to the central health commission in Beijing for review before going public.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">For weeks, the authorities in Wuhan seemed to play down the threat posed by the virus. The health department said that it had been found only in people who visited a local market that sold live fish, birds and other animals, and that workers had disinfected and shut down the site.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Questions have emerged on Chinese social media about whether the Chinese government has been forthcoming. Many articles and posts, including some using the hashtag #WuhanSARS, were censored.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">After his stepmother died of viral pneumonia last week, Kyle Hui, 32, an architect from Shanghai, turned to Weibo, a Twitterlike site, to report her case. Mr. Hui’s stepmother was never formally tested for the virus, and he was concerned that the Wuhan government was underreporting cases of the illness. But his post soon disappeared from the internet.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“People accuse me of spreading rumors, but I’m just trying to tell my stepmother's story,” he said in an interview at a cafe in Wuhan.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">It was not until Monday that the government changed course, after news outlets in Hong Kong reported over the weekend that there were several potential cases of the illness in Shanghai and Shenzhen, a southern city. The central government dispatched Dr. Zhong, a renowned expert with a reputation for bluntness, to Wuhan.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Dr. Zhong revealed for the first time that the virus could spread from person to person — noting, for example, that one patient had infected 14 medical workers.<span class="css-8l6xbc evw5hdy0"> </span>Dr. Zhong won wide praise from the Chinese public, and memes circulated online contrasting his urgent tone with the calm words of local officials.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The spread of the virus has upended the Lunar New Year holiday this week, when millions of Chinese return to their hometowns to celebrate. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">In Wuhan, some residents have canceled plans to go out to lavish meals for the new year and say they are avoiding enclosed spaces like movie theaters. Some firms have instructed employees to stay home. Many people now wear masks throughout the day, as they make dinner, play cards or chat with friends.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Some residents are packing up and leaving Wuhan, vowing to stay away until the virus is contained.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">At the Wuhan airport on Tuesday, Luo Jie, 62, a retiree, rushed to catch a flight to Beijing that she had booked that morning. She said she wanted to “escape” because the outbreak reminded her of the SARS crisis.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“I hope the government will report the epidemic honestly,” she said. “That’s how to set people’s minds at ease.”</p>, <p class="css-jwz2nf etfikam0">Austin Ramzy and Elaine Yu in Hong Kong contributed reporting. Albee Zhang in Beijing and Elsie Chen in Wuhan contributed research.</p>, <p>Advertisement</p>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd" id="site-index-label">Site Index</h2>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-0">news</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-1">opinion</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-2">arts</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-3">living</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-4">more</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-subscribe-label">Subscribe</h3>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd">Site Information Navigation</h2>]
[<p>Advertisement</p>, <p>Supported by</p>, <h1 class="css-1s4ffep e1h9rw200" id="link-611d45f6" itemprop="headline"><span>Impeachment Trial, Davos, Coronavirus: Your Tuesday Briefing</span></h1>, <p class="css-1fv7b6t e1jsehar1" itemprop="author" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">By<!-- --> <a class="css-brehiz e1jsehar0" href="https://www.nytimes.com/by/christopher-stanford"><span class="css-1baulvz last-byline" itemprop="name">Chris Stanford</span></a></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">(Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/morning-briefing" title="">sign-up</a>.)</p>, <p class="css-ma92ss evys1bk0">Good morning.</p>, <p class="css-ma92ss evys1bk0">We’re covering <strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">President Trump’s impeachment trial</strong> and fears of the spread of <strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">a mysterious disease</strong> from China. We’ve also published a collection of essays about something we’ve all probably thought about at some point: <strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">quitting</strong>.</p>, <h2 class="css-3ez4hu eoo0vm40" id="link-365faa91">Impeachment trial to begin in earnest</h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">After a ceremonial opening last week for the third presidential impeachment proceeding in U.S. history, the Senate gets down to business today, starting with what’s expected to be a partisan debate over the rules. <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/21/us/politics/trump.html" title="">Here’s what to expect</a> when the trial begins at 1 p.m. Eastern.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Senator Mitch McConnell, the Republican majority leader, <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/20/us/politics/mcconnell-pushes-to-speed-impeachment-trial-as-trump-requests-swift-acquittal.html" title="">released draft rules on Monday</a>. They would limit each side’s arguments to 24 hours over two days and permit the Senate to decline to hear new evidence.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Mr. McConnell has said the rules are based on those used during President Bill Clinton’s impeachment trial in 1999, but <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/20/us/politics/mcconnell-impeachment-rules-modify-clinton-precedent.html" title="">there are meaningful differences</a>.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">“The Daily”:</strong> <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/thedaily" title="">Today’s episode</a> is about Mr. Clinton’s trial.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">News analysis:</strong> Mr. Trump’s lawyers have said that the articles of impeachment — for abuse of power and obstruction of Congress — are invalid because they don’t accuse him of an ordinary crime. It’s an argument that plenty of scholars have rejected, <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/20/us/politics/trump-impeachment-legal-defense.html" title="">our Washington correspondent explains</a>.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">The details:</strong> <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.whitehouse.gov/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/Trial-Memorandum-of-President-Donald-J.-Trump.pdf" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">Read the brief that Mr. Trump’s legal team</a> submitted to the Senate on Monday. The House has until noon to file a rebuttal.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Related: </strong><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/21/business/trump-davos.html" title="">The president</a><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10"><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/21/business/trump-davos.html" title=""> </a></strong><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/21/business/trump-davos.html" title="">is in Davos, Switzerland, today</a>, for the World Economic Forum’s annual meeting. He received a frosty reception there in 2018, but this time he’s likely to be accepted, if not embraced, <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/20/business/dealbook/donald-trump-davos.html" title="">writes our DealBook columnist, Andrew Ross Sorkin</a>. (One reason: He may be in office for another four years.)</p>, <h2 class="css-3ez4hu eoo0vm40" id="link-55788dd9">Bracing for climate change (just don’t call it that)</h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">A $16 billion federal program to help states prepare for natural disasters <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/20/climate/climate-change-funding-states.html" title="">reflects the complicated politics of global warming in the U.S.</a>, even as officials are increasingly forced to confront its effects.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">States applying for funding must explain why they need the money and describe their “current and future risks.” When those include flooding, states must account for “continued sea level rise,” a consequence of warming.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">But some conservative states have submitted proposals that mostly avoid mentioning climate change. Texas refers to “changing coastal conditions” and South Carolina talks about the “destabilizing effects and unpredictability” of three major storms in four years.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">One exception is Florida, whose proposal calls climate change “a key overarching challenge.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Related:</strong> Greta Thunberg, the 17-year-old climate activist, is expected to criticize inaction by the world’s business and political leaders during a speech today in Davos, Switzerland. <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/21/climate/greta-thunberg-davos.html" title="">Read a transcript of her planned remarks</a>.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Another angle:</strong> Australia’s biggest mining company announced today that <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/21/world/australia/coal-company-bhp-smoke.html" title="">coal output was down because of smoke</a> from wildfires, a crisis exacerbated by climate change, which is caused in no small part by the burning of coal. The irony was not lost on many Australians.</p>, <h2 class="css-3ez4hu eoo0vm40" id="link-6a012fd3">How Boeing’s role in a crash ‘got buried’</h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">When a Boeing 737 crashed near Amsterdam in 2009, killing nine people, Dutch pilots were blamed. But mistakes by the manufacturer — including design choices and faulty safety assessments — also contributed, documents and interviews show.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/20/business/boeing-737-accidents.html" title="">A Times review of evidence from the accident</a>, some of it previously confidential, revealed striking parallels with two recent crashes of a newer model, the 737 Max, and similar pushback from the company and American safety officials.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">An expert commissioned by the Dutch Safety Board to analyze the 2009 crash said it represented “a sentinel event that was never taken seriously.” His study was never made public.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Response: </strong>Boeing declined to address detailed questions from The Times. In a statement, the company pointed to differences between the 2009 accident and the Max crashes. “These accidents involved fundamentally different system inputs and phases of flight,” the company said.</p>, <h3 class="css-1b8te77 e1gnsphs0" id="link-6933ce2f">If you have 20 minutes, this is worth it</h3>, <h2 class="css-3ez4hu eoo0vm40" id="link-74d4ab90">Stories of walking away</h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Is there a more exciting and complicated phrase than “I quit”?</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2020/01/20/style/quitters.html" title="">Our collection of 21 first-person narratives</a> discusses quitting all sorts of things, including jobs, sex, the presidential campaign and even the task of writing about quitting.</p>, <h3 class="css-1b8te77 e1gnsphs0" id="link-554e6082">Here’s what else is happening</h3>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Fear of pandemic:</strong> Australian officials said today that they would begin screening passengers on flights from Wuhan, the Chinese city where <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/21/world/asia/china-coronavirus-australia-wuhan-travel.html" title="">a deadly coronavirus that has infected more than 250 people</a> originated.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Virginia gun rights rally:</strong> More than 20,000 people, many of them armed, <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/20/us/virginia-gun-rally.html" title="">gathered in Richmond to protest gun control proposals</a>. The authorities had been braced for violence, but the police reported no major incidents.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Snapshot: </strong>Above, the Cosmic Ray Research Station in Armenia. In its heyday, more than 100 scientists worked there tracking high-energy particles from space. Physics has mostly moved on, but <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/21/science/observatory-cosmos-armenia-physics.html" title="">the station persists</a> — a ghost observatory that is maintained for long stretches by two technicians and a cook.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Late-night comedy: </strong>The hosts wondered about the defense strategy for President Trump’s legal team. “Release a live bat in the Senate chamber, then scatter,” <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/21/arts/television/stephen-colbert-trump-impeachment-defense.html" title="">Jimmy Fallon suggested</a>.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">What we’re reading: </strong><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.tastecooking.com/god-save-lard-bread/" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">This piece in Taste</a> about a food specialty familiar to only a small subset of Italian-Americans. “It has come to my attention that some of you do not know the first blessed thing about lard bread,” tweeted our food critic Pete Wells. “Max [Falkowitz] is here to guide you into the light of lardy knowledge.”</p>, <h3 class="css-1b8te77 e1gnsphs0" id="link-7ded7ef4">Now, a break from the news</h3>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Cook: </strong>Turn pantry staples into <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://cooking.nytimes.com/recipes/1017704-vegetarian-skillet-chili" title="">vegetarian skillet chili</a>. (Our <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/newsletters/five-weeknight-dishes" title="">Five Weeknight Dishes newsletter</a> has more recommendations.)</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Go: </strong>“Emojiland” is an Off Broadway musical set inside a smartphone with a cast of, you guessed it, emojis. It’s “big-hearted and comforting,” <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/19/theater/emojiland-review-theres-a-rom-com-in-your-phone-with-music.html" title="">our critic writes</a>.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Watch: </strong>Ruth Negga, an Ethiopian-Irish actress, is set to play Hamlet in Brooklyn. <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/17/theater/ruth-negga-hamlet.html" title="">She spoke to The Times about the role</a> and her next project, a film adaptation of a 1920s novel about passing for white.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Smarter Living: </strong>Should you unpack your suitcase when you travel? Whatever your choice, <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/17/travel/unpack-vacation.html" title="">pack thoughtfully</a>.</p>, <h3 class="css-1b8te77 e1gnsphs0" id="link-15767e9b">And now for the Back Story on …</h3>, <h2 class="css-3ez4hu eoo0vm40" id="link-3cd23f6c">Cocktails</h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">A hundred years ago this month, the U.S. embarked on an official prohibition on the “manufacture, sale or transportation of intoxicating liquors” anywhere within the country.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/01/us/100-years-ago-the-booziest-january-suddenly-dried-up.html" title="">It didn’t go well</a>.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Bootlegging liquor operations proliferated, as did the illicit bars known as speakeasies. The drink of choice: the cocktail, which spread out the hooch and could disguise bad flavors. The boom far outlasted Prohibition, which ended after 13 years. <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://punchdrink.com/recipes/joaquin-simos-sidecar/" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">Sidecar, anyone</a>?</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Dave Wondrich, a drinks historian, <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.grubstreet.com/2015/04/david-wondrich-knows-the-origins-of-cocktail.html" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">tracked down the source of the word “cocktail.”</a> In the second edition of his landmark reconstruction of mixed drinks, “Imbibe!,” he notes that prospective horse sellers in England would give old or droopy specimens a rectal dose of ginger to make them cock their tails for a younger, zippier appearance.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">From there it was just a short jump to the zingy drinks that made humans perk up, at least at the start of their alcoholic forays.</p>, <p class="css-ma92ss evys1bk0">That’s it for this briefing. See you next time.</p>, <p class="css-ma92ss evys1bk0">— Chris</p>, <p class="css-jwz2nf etfikam0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Thank you</strong><br/>“Office Space” provided <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=HyxoLqbFDkI" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">this morning’s soundtrack</a>, and Mark Josephson and Eleanor Stanford provided the break from the news. Andrea Kannapell, the briefings editor, wrote today’s Back Story. You can reach the team at <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="mailto:briefing@nytimes.com" title="">briefing@nytimes.com</a>. </p>, <p class="css-jwz2nf etfikam0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">P.S.</strong><br/>• We’re listening to “<a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/thedaily" title="">The Daily</a>.” Today’s episode is about President Bill Clinton’s impeachment trial.<br/>• Here’s today’s <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/crosswords/game/mini" title="">Mini Crossword</a>, and a clue: Like a tooth that’s almost ready for the tooth fairy (five letters). <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/crosswords" title="">You can find all our puzzles here</a>.<br/>• The Times is always looking for talent. Check out our <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://nytimes.wd5.myworkdayjobs.com/NYT" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">domestic</a> and <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://nytimes.wd5.myworkdayjobs.com/INYT" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">international job postings</a>.</p>, <p>Advertisement</p>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd" id="site-index-label">Site Index</h2>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-0">news</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-1">opinion</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-2">arts</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-3">living</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-4">more</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-subscribe-label">Subscribe</h3>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd">Site Information Navigation</h2>]
[<p>Advertisement</p>, <p>Supported by</p>, <h1 class="css-1s4ffep e1h9rw200" id="link-3b28ebe0" itemprop="headline"><span>Wuhan Coronavirus, Impeachment, Climate Change: Your Wednesday Briefing</span></h1>, <p class="css-1ifw933 e1wiw3jv0" id="article-summary">Here’s what you need to know.</p>, <p class="css-1fv7b6t e1jsehar1" itemprop="author" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">By<!-- --> <a class="css-brehiz e1jsehar0" href="https://www.nytimes.com/by/melina-delkic"><span class="css-1baulvz last-byline" itemprop="name">Melina Delkic</span></a></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">(Want to get this briefing by email?
