Here’s the <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/morning-briefing" title="">sign-up</a>.)</p>, <p class="css-ma92ss evys1bk0">Good morning.</p>, <p class="css-ma92ss evys1bk0">We’re covering the global push to prevent the spread of the <strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Wuhan coronavirus</strong>, the beginning of President Trump’s<strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10"> impeachment trial </strong>in the Senate and what made people throw their hands up and say, <strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">“I quit.”</strong></p>, <h2 class="css-3ez4hu eoo0vm40" id="link-ef19102">The global race to confront a deadly virus</h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Countries around the world are scrambling to <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/21/world/asia/china-coronavirus-wuhan.html" title="">prevent the spread of a deadly outbreak of the coronavirus</a> that started in Wuhan, China, and has spread to Taiwan, Japan, Thailand, South Korea and now the U.S., where a case was <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/21/health/cdc-coronavirus.html" title="">confirmed in Washington State</a>.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">As fatalities doubled to at least six with hundreds more people infected, airports around the world, including in Australia and the U.S., were checking passengers on flights from Wuhan, where the virus began in a seafood and poultry market. North Korea temporarily closed borders to tours from China. Here’s <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/21/health/what-is-coronavirus.html" title="">what else we know.</a></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The World Health Organization called a meeting to decide whether to declare the outbreak an international health emergency as evidence mounted that the virus spreads from person to person. In one case, a patient appeared to have infected 14 medical workers.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Fears:</strong> Many in China recalled the government’s slow response to the 2003 outbreak of the SARS virus, which killed more than 800 people and infected more than 8,000.</p>, <h2 class="css-3ez4hu eoo0vm40" id="link-15126b42">Impeachment trial begins</h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">President Trump’s historic trial <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/live/2020/impeachment-trial-01-21?action=click&amp;module=Top%20Stories&amp;pgtype=Homepage" title="">began in the Senate with a fight between Democrats and Republicans</a> over the rules that will govern it.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Under procedures proposed by the majority leader, Senator Mitch McConnell, each side would have three days to present its case, and <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/live/2020/impeachment-trial-01-21/houses-impeachment-evidence-will-automatically-become-part-of-the-trial-record#live-blog-list" title="">the House’s evidence</a> from its inquiry would be admitted into the Senate record.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Mr. McConnell said he had enough votes to defeat any Democratic changes, and he warned Democrats that the chamber would stay into the wee hours if they offered a long string of proposed changes.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">In the room:</strong> Senators have to give up their cellphones and remain silent at their desks at virtually all times “on pain of imprisonment.”</p>, <h2 class="css-3ez4hu eoo0vm40" id="link-497bcba5">Climate change takes center stage at Davos</h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">As the yearly meeting of global business leaders in Davos, Switzerland, opened with a focus on global warming, many watched for the dynamic between two seemingly opposing figures on the topic: President Trump and Greta Thunberg, the 17-year-old climate activist.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Though Mr. Trump <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/21/business/trump-davos.html?action=click&amp;module=Top%20Stories&amp;pgtype=Homepage" title="">spoke mostly about the economy</a><span class="css-8l6xbc evw5hdy0"> </span>— proclaiming “the American dream is back” — and said that it was “not a time for pessimism,” Ms. Thunberg gave a <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/21/climate/greta-thunberg-davos-transcript.html" title="">characteristically cutting speech</a> to those who had not taken action on climate change.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“Our house is still on fire,” she said, referring to her address at the same conference a year earlier. “Your inaction is fueling the flames by the hour.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Context: </strong>The<strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10"> </strong>Davos forum has for some become a symbol of all that is wrong with the world, our reporter writes, but its proponents <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/19/business/davos-50th-year.html" title="">say it makes businesses more responsible</a>.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Related: </strong>Australia’s biggest mining company announced that <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/21/world/australia/coal-company-bhp-smoke.html" title="">coal output was down over the last six months because of smoke</a> from wildfires, a crisis exacerbated by climate change, which is caused in no small part by the burning of coal. The irony was not lost on many Australians.</p>, <h3 class="css-1b8te77 e1gnsphs0" id="link-fdfe371">If you have some time, this is worth it</h3>, <h2 class="css-3ez4hu eoo0vm40" id="link-74d4ab90">Stories of walking away</h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Is there a more exciting and complicated phrase than “I quit”?</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2020/01/20/style/quitters.html" title="">Our collection of 21 first-person narratives</a> discusses quitting all sorts of things, including jobs, sex, the presidential campaign and even the task of writing about quitting.</p>, <h3 class="css-1b8te77 e1gnsphs0" id="link-554e6082">Here’s what else is happening</h3>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Interpol: </strong>A former senior Chinese police official who served as head of the international crime-fighting body <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/21/world/asia/interpol-china-meng-hongwei.html" title="">was sentenced to 13½ years in prison</a> for bribery. His wife says he is the victim of a political vendetta.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Royals in Canada: </strong>As Prince Harry <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/20/world/americas/harry-meghan-markle-canada.html" title="">reportedly landed on Vancouver Island</a> to join his wife, Meghan, and their son, a survey showed that about half of Canadians say they “don’t care” if the couple moves in. But an overwhelming 73 percent said they do not want Canada to pay royal security costs.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Ancient climate changer: </strong>The <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/21/science/oldest-asteroid-impact-australia.html" title="">planet’s oldest asteroid impact</a>, from 2.2 billion years ago, was found in Western Australia — and researchers suggested the cataclysm might have catapulted the planet out of an ice age.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Snapshot: </strong>Above, people in pajamas. Officials in the eastern Chinese city of Suzhou apologized after publishing surveillance-camera photos to <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/21/business/china-pajamas-facial-recognition.html" title="">shame residents who sport their sleepwear in public</a>. Their attempt to curb “uncivilized behavior” sparked a backlash nationwide.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">What we’re reading: </strong><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.newyorker.com/magazine/2020/01/27/the-long-war-against-slavery" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">This article in The New Yorker.</a> Brent Staples, a Pulitzer Prize winner, calls it “a vivid new history” of “how slave rebellions (not white abolitionists) defeated slavery in the hell that was the Caribbean.”</p>, <h3 class="css-1b8te77 e1gnsphs0" id="link-7ded7ef4">Now, a break from the news</h3>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Cook: </strong>If you’re looking for comfort food, make a batch of <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://cooking.nytimes.com/recipes/1020777-sopa-de-albondigas-mexican-meatball-soup" title="">sopa de albóndigas</a>, a Mexican meatball soup.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Read: </strong>Kyle Chayka’s new book, <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/21/books/review-longing-for-less-minimalism-kyle-chayka.html" title="">“The Longing for Less,”</a> explores minimalism as a manifestation of civilization’s discontents, among other things.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Watch: </strong>Ruth Negga, an Ethiopian-Irish actress, is set to play Hamlet in Brooklyn. <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/17/theater/ruth-negga-hamlet.html" title="">She spoke to The Times about the role</a> and her part in an upcoming film adaptation of a 1920s novel about passing for white.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Smarter Living: </strong>Organize your fridge the way pros do. <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/20/smarter-living/wirecutter/organize-your-fridge-and-keep-it-neat.html" title="">It saves both food and time.</a></p>, <h3 class="css-1b8te77 e1gnsphs0" id="link-15767e9b">And now for the Back Story on …</h3>, <h2 class="css-3ez4hu eoo0vm40" id="link-4b89f22f">Too much attention</h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">One of the reasons Prince Harry and his wife, Meghan, cited in their decision <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/13/world/europe/queen-elizabeth-harry-meghan.html" title="">to step back from their royal duties</a> is the need for a more private life.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The desire is understandable. Paparazzi hound celebrities of all kinds, and the prince’s mother, Diana, died in Paris as her car raced away from chasing photographers.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Fifty-one years ago, another hounded Brit took a very different approach.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">John Lennon had become a global star as the Beatles rose to extravagant heights of popularity, but in 1969, the band was <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-features/why-the-beatles-broke-up-113403/" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">inexorably breaking up</a>. The other Beatles’ lack of enthusiasm for Lennon’s devotion to the conceptual artist Yoko Ono added to the tension — and further whetted the public appetite for gossipy details.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">After the two married in March of that year, in a hastily arranged ceremony in Gibraltar, they knew there was no way to avoid being set upon by reporters and photographers.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.artsy.net/article/artsy-editorial-john-lennon-yoko-ono-invited-bed" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">So they invited them in.</a> They took up residence for days at a hotel in Amsterdam, holding open hours from 9 a.m. to 9 p.m., and later did the same in Montreal, using the “bed-ins” to promote global peace.</p>, <p class="css-ma92ss evys1bk0">That’s it for this briefing. See you next time.</p>, <p class="css-ma92ss evys1bk0">— Melina</p>, <p class="css-jwz2nf etfikam0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Thank you</strong><br/>To Mark Josephson and Eleanor Stanford for the break from the news. Chris Stanford and Andrea Kannapell, on the Briefings team, wrote today’s Back Story. You can reach the team at <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="mailto:briefing+pm@nytimes.com?subject=Briefing%20Feedback" title="">briefing@nytimes.com</a>.</p>, <p class="css-jwz2nf etfikam0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">P.S.</strong><br/>• We’re listening to “<a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/thedaily" title="">The Daily</a>.” Our latest episode is about President Bill Clinton’s impeachment trial.<br/>• Here’s our <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/crosswords/game/mini" title="">Mini Crossword</a>, and a clue: Like a tooth that’s almost ready for the tooth fairy (five letters). <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/crosswords" title="">You can find all our puzzles here</a>.<br/>• Nicole Perlroth, who covers cybersecurity for The Times, <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://t.co/K5OoeLUoUT" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">answered readers’ questions on Russian hacking</a> and the coming U.S. election in a Reddit AMA (Ask Me Anything).</p>, <p>Advertisement</p>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd" id="site-index-label">Site Index</h2>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-0">news</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-1">opinion</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-2">arts</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-3">living</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-4">more</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-subscribe-label">Subscribe</h3>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd">Site Information Navigation</h2>]
[<p>Advertisement</p>, <p>Supported by</p>, <h1 class="css-1s4ffep e1h9rw200" id="link-555b6a0d" itemprop="headline"><span>North Korea Bans Foreign Tourists Over Coronavirus, Tour Operator Says</span></h1>, <p class="css-1ifw933 e1wiw3jv0" id="article-summary">The spread of the virus from China is bad news for Kim Jong-un; North Korea depends on Chinese tourists for cash.</p>, <p class="css-1fv7b6t e1jsehar1" itemprop="author" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">By<!-- --> <a class="css-brehiz e1jsehar0" href="https://www.nytimes.com/by/choe-sang-hun"><span class="css-1baulvz last-byline" itemprop="name">Choe Sang-Hun</span></a></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">SEOUL, South Korea — North Korea has temporarily barred foreign tourists as a protection against the <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/18/world/asia/china-virus-wuhan-coronavirus.html" title="">mysterious virus</a> from China that has killed at least nine people and sickened more than 400, a leading tour operator reported on Tuesday.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The operator, Young Pioneer Tours, which specializes in taking tourists from China to North Korea, <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.youngpioneertours.com/north-korea-temporarily-closes-border-until-further-notice-coronavirus-precaution/" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">said on its website</a> that the country was closing its border to foreign ​tourists starting on Wednesday. Practically all foreign tours to North Korea come through China, and the vast majority of tourists are Chinese.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Simon Cockerell, general manager of <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://koryogroup.com/" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">Koryo Tours</a>, which also takes tourists to North Korea, said his company had been told that “action was being considered” by the North Korean authorities to prevent the spread of the virus. “We have been informed that we will be told more information in the morning,” he said Tuesday night.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">State-run media in North Korea, which tightly controls information from the outside world, reported on the Chinese outbreak of the coronavirus Wednesday, though the reports did not mention a tourist ban. A television news program said officials were working with the World Health Organization to keep the virus from spreading to the North, according to the South Korean news agency Yonhap, which monitors North Korean media.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/21/health/what-is-coronavirus.html" title="">virus has been spreading</a> rapidly from the central Chinese city of Wuhan. That is bad news for North Korea, where Chinese tourists have become an increasingly important source of cash for the country, hobbled by international sanctions. ​</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Tourism is one of the few North Korean industries not covered by the sanctions, which have been imposed by the United Nations Security Council and the United States in response to the North’s nuclear weapons and missile programs.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">North Korea’s leader, Kim Jong-un, recently declared that his country no longer expected a breakthrough in deadlocked negotiations with Washington over how to denuclearize his country and ease or end the sanctions. Mr. Kim said his country would therefore strengthen its economy without relief from the sanctions, and <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2019/12/03/world/asia/north-korea-resorts-sanctions.html?action=click&amp;module=RelatedLinks&amp;pgtype=Article" title="">boosting tourism is a key part of that strategy.</a></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">To attract foreign tourists, North Korea has recently completed or is building seafront resorts or ski and spa complexes.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The number of Chinese tourists to North Korea has been rapidly rising since​ <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2019/06/20/world/asia/xi-jinping-china-north-korea.html" title="">President Xi Jinping</a> of China visited Pyongyang​ last June. ​China has gone along with Security Council sanctions on North Korea in recent years but does not want the Communist government in Pyongyang to collapse.</p>, <p>Advertisement</p>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd" id="site-index-label">Site Index</h2>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-0">news</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-1">opinion</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-2">arts</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-3">living</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-4">more</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-subscribe-label">Subscribe</h3>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd">Site Information Navigation</h2>]
[<p>Advertisement</p>, <p>Supported by</p>, <h1 class="css-1s4ffep e1h9rw200" id="link-41e47a1a" itemprop="headline"><span>Impeachment, Wuhan, Derek Jeter: Your Tuesday Evening Briefing</span></h1>, <p class="css-1ifw933 e1wiw3jv0" id="article-summary">Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.</p>, <p class="css-1fv7b6t e1jsehar1" itemprop="author" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">By<!-- --> <a class="css-brehiz e1jsehar0" href="https://www.nytimes.com/by/remy-tumin"><span class="css-1baulvz" itemprop="name">Remy Tumin</span></a> and <a class="css-brehiz e1jsehar0" href="https://www.nytimes.com/by/hiroko-masuike"><span class="css-1baulvz last-byline" itemprop="name">Hiroko Masuike</span></a></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">(Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s </em><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="http://www.nytimes.com/newsletters/nyt-now-evening-briefing?module=inline" title=""><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">the sign-up</em></a><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">.) </em></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">Good evening. Here’s the latest.</em></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">1. Day 1 of President Trump’s impeachment trial.</strong></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Bitter partisan clashes<strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10"> </strong>over how to run the trial began in the Senate this afternoon and are likely to go until mid-evening or later. Opening statements begin Wednesday. <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/live/2020/impeachment-trial-01-21" title="">Here’s the latest</a>.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Exactly how many people are watching C-Span’s coverage is not yet clear. But there has been movement: Senator Mitch McConnell, the majority leader, agreed to allow the presentations of the House managers and the defense to unfold over three days rather than two. He also allowed the House’s evidence from its inquiry to be admitted into the Senate record.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">And while debate was robust, senators had to<a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/21/us/politics/senate-impeachment.html" title=""> give up their cellphones and remain silent</a> at their desks at virtually all times “on pain of imprisonment.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">2. And in Davos, Switzerland, </strong>Mr. Trump proclaimed “the American dream is back.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Though Mr. Trump spoke <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/21/business/trump-davos.html?" title="">mostly about the economy</a>, the annual meeting of global business leaders opened with a focus on global warming — and the dynamic between Mr. Trump and Greta Thunberg, the 17-year-old climate activist.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">While Mr. Trump said it was “not a time for pessimism,” Ms. Thunberg gave a <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/21/climate/greta-thunberg-davos-transcript.html" title="">characteristically cutting speech</a> to those who had not taken action on climate change.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“Our house is still on fire,” she said, referring to her address at the same conference a year earlier. “Your inaction is fueling the flames by the hour.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">3. The first U.S. case of the Wuhan coronavirus</strong> was <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/21/health/cdc-coronavirus.html" title="">confirmed in Washington State</a>, meaning the virus has now spread to at least four countries beyond China. <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2020/01/21/world/asia/china-coronavirus-maps.html" title="">We mapped it.</a></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The World Health Organization has called a meeting on Wednesday to discuss <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/21/world/asia/china-coronavirus-wuhan.html?" title="">whether to declare the outbreak an international health emergency</a>, since it’s now moving from human to human. In one case, a patient appeared to have infected 14 medical workers. Above, travelers in Beijing.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">At least six people have died and hundreds more are infected, and there are scientific reasons to fear a pandemic. Airports around the world are continuing to check passengers from Wuhan, where the virus began in a seafood and poultry market. North Korea temporarily closed borders to tours from China. <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/21/health/what-is-coronavirus.html" title="">Here’s what else we know.</a></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">4. Quite a day for Bernie Sanders.</strong></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Hillary Clinton <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/21/us/politics/hillary-clinton-bernie-sanders.html?" title="">criticized her former primary rival</a> in a documentary, saying “nobody likes him” and declined to commit to supporting him if he is the nominee. She later stood by her comments in an interview with The Hollywood Reporter.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">In a statement, Mr. Sanders said he was focusing on the impeachment trial.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The Vermont senator, who has been trying to quell a feud with Senator Elizabeth Warren of Massachusetts, also <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/21/us/politics/bernie-sanders-apologizes-joe-biden.html" title="">apologized to Joe Biden</a> after a Sanders campaign surrogate wrote an opinion article accusing the former vice president of having “a big corruption problem.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">5. An architect of the “enhanced interrogation” program</strong> testified at a military court Guantánamo Bay, facing five men on whom the now-outlawed torture tactics were used.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">James E. Mitchell, a former contract psychologist for the C.I.A. who personally waterboarded the man accused of masterminding the Sept. 11 attacks, was <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/21/us/politics/guantanamo-bay-interrogation.html" title="">defiant</a> at the pretrial hearing, saying that he’d been the focus of “untrue and malicious” reports.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The defendants are arguing that the confessions they gave the F.B.I., after sometimes years of detention at black sites and torture, should be thrown out. Above, Dr. Mitchell in 2017.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">6. The return of Boeing’s 737 Max</strong> has been delayed again.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The company said it did not expect <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/21/business/boeing-737-max.html" title="">regulators to approve the jet to fly until June or July</a>. American Airlines, United and Southwest had already taken the Max off their schedules until June.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Boeing shares dropped sharply before trading was temporarily halted.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">And yesterday, a Times report detailed a study critical of Boeing after a deadly 2009 accident that was never published. <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/21/business/boeing-737-crashes.html" title="">Today, Dutch safety authorities made it public</a>.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">7.</strong> <strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Women</strong> <strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">have been doing better</strong> in the labor market, but the numbers conceal a problem: <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/21/upshot/womens-gains-in-the-work-force-conceal-a-problem.html" title="">Their jobs still don’t pay well, and still don’t appeal to men</a>.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The latest jobs report shows that male-dominated occupations (like those in manufacturing) tend be shrinking while those that are growing (like health care and education) are female-dominated. That, our Upshot reporter writes, puts men at a disadvantage and also keeps female-dominated jobs devalued and underpaid.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">And what if women ruled the world? </strong>The artist Judy Chicago posed the question on one of her 21 embroidered banners for <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/20/t-magazine/dior-judy-chicago.html?" title="">Christian Dior’s spring 2020 haute couture show in Paris</a>. Our chief fashion critic pondered that, and the other <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/21/style/chanel-dior-iris-van-herpen-couture-paris.html" title="">themes of the shows</a>.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">8. Derek Jeter</strong> <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/21/sports/baseball/hall-of-fame-vote-derek-jeter.html" title="">was elected into the Baseball Hall of Fame</a>. The longtime captain of the Yankees, above in 2014, fell just one vote short of becoming the second player to be unanimously elected.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Six players on this year’s ballot were part of a remarkable 2001 playoff game between the Yankees and Oakland Athletics when Jeter saved a crucial run in a play baseball fans know simply as The Flip. <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/21/sports/baseball/derek-jeter-alfonso-soriano-hall-of-fame.html" title="">We looked at his most memorable moment in an extraordinary career</a>.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Larry Walker was also elected.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Also happening tonight: </strong><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/21/sports/tennis/naomi-osaka-australian-open.html" title="">Naomi Osaka</a>, the reigning Australian Open champion, is a heavy favorite against Zheng Saisai in a second-round match. If she wins, Osaka could potentially face Coco Gauff in the next round. The match is set for 7 p.m. Eastern.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">9. Researchers have pinpointed</strong> Earth’s oldest extraterrestrial scar in Western Australia. The cause was a large asteroid strike <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/21/science/oldest-asteroid-impact-australia.html" title="">more than 2.2 billion years ago</a>.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">That time frame coincides with the end of one of the planet’s ice ages, and there’s a real possibility that the asteroid actually triggered the change. The impact could have liberated an enormous amount of water vapor — which is a greenhouse gas.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">In other news from the cosmos, </strong>today’s Great Read is about an Armenian research station built decades ago to study cosmic rays. More than 100 scientists worked there in its heyday. Now it’s down to a cook and two technicians, who <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/21/science/observatory-cosmos-armenia-physics.html" title="">watch for the kind of quantum news that could change the universe</a>.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">10. And finally,</strong> what do your eardrums want for dinner?</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Our restaurant critic, Pete Wells, hears a lot from readers about noise levels in restaurants. Often they implore him to do something about it — apparently beyond the impression of acoustics he gives in every review.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Now, he’s taking a stance. He doesn’t have a problem with loud restaurants. In fact, generally speaking, <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/21/dining/restaurant-noise-level-loud.html" title="">he loves them</a>.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“A noisy restaurant is the end product of a business that helps us have a good time, just as purring is the end product of scratching a cat’s chin the right way,” he writes.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">So far, the reader response is … <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/21/dining/restaurant-noise-level-loud.html#commentsContainer" title="">spirited</a>.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Have a lively night.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">Your Evening Briefing is posted at 6 p.m. Eastern.</em></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">And don’t miss Your Morning Briefing. </em><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2018/briefing/global-morning-briefing-newsletter-signup.html" title=""><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">Sign up here</em></a><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0"> to get it by email in the Australian, Asian, European, African or American morning.</em></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">Want to catch up on past briefings? </em><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/series/us-evening-briefing" title=""><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">You can browse them here</em></a><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">.</em></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">What did you like? What do you want to see here? Let us know at </em><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="mailto:briefing@nytimes.com?subject=Evening%20Briefing%20Feedback" title=""><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">briefing@nytimes.com</em></a><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">.</em></p>, <p>Advertisement</p>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd" id="site-index-label">Site Index</h2>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-0">news</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-1">opinion</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-2">arts</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-3">living</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-4">more</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-subscribe-label">Subscribe</h3>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd">Site Information Navigation</h2>]
[<p>Advertisement</p>, <p>Supported by</p>, <p class="css-c2jxua e6idgb70"></p>, <h1 class="css-1j5ig2m e1h9rw200" id="link-135bda90" itemprop="headline"><span>Davos Warms to Trump’s Results (if Not Him Personally)</span></h1>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">Hello from Davos. We’re bringing you the latest from here all week. One tidbit: Bill Gates, who has attended for 30 years, canceled his plans to come this year. (Want this in your inbox? </em><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="http://p.nytimes.com/email/re?&amp;campaign_id=0&amp;instance_id=0&amp;segment_id=0&amp;user_id=f4577a56bcf773214e9a1d55b5fe9d24&amp;regi_id=0nl=dealbook&amp;emc=edit_dk_20180529" title=""><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">Sign up here</em></a><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">.)</em></p>, <h2 class="css-3ez4hu eoo0vm40" id="link-27dcc943">The Davos crowd has come to like Trump’s outcomes</h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">As the 50th annual World Economic Forum — the conclave of global business and political leaders — begins today in Davos, Switzerland, Andrew writes in his latest column that the assembly has <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/20/business/dealbook/donald-trump-davos.html" title="">warmed to President Trump</a>, at least economically.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">• Mr. Trump’s policies are the opposite of Davos doctrine, advocating trade wars and a fragmenting of the global economy.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">• But “to the surprise of many Davos regulars, the economic results have yet to prove as disastrous as they expected — and, at least in the short term, have seemingly proven to be quite positive,” Andrew writes.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">• Maybe it shouldn’t be surprising, the corporate leadership expert Jeff Sonnenfeld tells Andrew: “The Davos crowd are well-respected followers of fashion and love whomever is in power.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">• But they don’t like him personally, says the Trump-friend-turned-foe Anthony Scaramucci: “The unspeakable truth is that C.E.O.s and their staff are horrified.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Mr. Trump took a victory lap</strong> in his speech at the Forum this morning:</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">• “Today I’m proud to say the U.S. is in the midst of an economic boom the likes of which the world has never seen before.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">• Of China, he said, “Under my leadership, America confronted the problem head on.” He also defended his trade war, saying, “Our relationship with China right now has probably never been better.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">• And he criticized the Fed’s unwillingness to cut U.S. interest rates to his liking.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">But much of this year’s event focuses on issues</strong> that Mr. Trump doesn’t like, including:</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">• <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/20/business/energy-environment/davos-climate-change.html" title="">Climate change</a>, which will almost certainly be a big topic, according to Stanley Reed of the NYT (especially since Greta Thunberg is <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/21/climate/greta-thunberg-davos.html" title="">set to speak</a>). Mr. Trump himself said the U.S. would join a major tree-planting initiative, but urged a rejection of “the perennial prophets of doom.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">• <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.pwc.com/gx/en/ceo-agenda/ceosurvey/2020.html" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">Falling economic growth</a>, partly prompted by his trade wars, according to a new study by PwC.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">More: </strong></em><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">The forum’s founder, Klaus Schwab, tells David Gelles of the NYT that the event is </em><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/19/business/davos-50th-year.html" title=""><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">still relevant today</em></a><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">.<span class="css-8l6xbc evw5hdy0"> </span>And here’s </em><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://qz.com/1787763/the-list-of-delegates-to-the-2020-world-economic-forum-in-davos/" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title=""><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">the full list</em></a><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0"> of this year’s attendees.</em></p>, <h2 class="css-3ez4hu eoo0vm40" id="link-297035ad">Counting the cost of low social mobility</h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">To accompany the Davos gathering this week, the World Economic Forum has tallied up what it says is <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.weforum.org/press/2020/01/revealed-why-economies-benefit-from-fixing-inequality" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">the financial incentive</a> for countries to shrink their wealth gaps.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">The report estimates that China could gain an additional $1 trillion</strong> in G.D.P. growth by 2030 if its social inequality is solved over the next decade, while the U.S. could gain $866.7 billion.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">If social inequality remains a problem,</strong> “we will continue to see discontent, with far-reaching consequences for economic growth, the green transition, trade and geopolitics,” said Saadia Zahidi, a World Economic Forum managing director.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10"><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">Related: </em></strong><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">The world’s richest 1 percent have </em><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2020-01-20/2-153-billionaires-are-richer-than-60-of-the-world-says-oxfam?sref=kOA1eblB" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title=""><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">more than twice the wealth of the rest of humanity combined</em></a><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">, according to new research by the British charity Oxfam.</em></p>, <h2 class="css-3ez4hu eoo0vm40" id="link-6a2cbd40">The trade deal helps, and hurts, U.S. tech</h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Provisions in the first phase of the trade deal between China and the U.S. help American tech companies like Micron, a major semiconductor maker. But the pact also causes them a <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/20/business/economy/trump-us-china-deal-micron-trade-war.html" title="">lot of collateral damage</a>, according to Ana Swanson and Cecilia Kang of the NYT.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">• “The deal contains provisions meant to protect American technology and trade secrets and allow companies to challenge China on accusations of theft,” Ms. Swanson and Ms. Kang write.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">• It could help Micron, which accused a Chinese rival of stealing its technology after rebuffing a takeover bid in 2015.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">• But the fight that led to the trade deal prompted China to redouble efforts to <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.wsj.com/articles/the-great-u-s-china-tech-divide-11579542441" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">produce its own advanced tech</a> in areas like semiconductors, driverless cars and artificial intelligence.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">• “It’s like China woke up and said, ‘We’ve relied too much on the United States,’” Robert Atkinson of the Information Technology and Innovation Foundation, an industry think tank, told the NYT.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">• The Trump administration is increasingly putting much of the lucrative Chinese market off limits for American tech companies.</p>, <h2 class="css-3ez4hu eoo0vm40" id="link-4f243d6e">The case against venture capitalists</h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The venture capital industry helped create Apple, Google, Intel and Uber. But Nathan Heller of The New Yorker asks whether the benefits are <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.newyorker.com/magazine/2020/01/27/is-venture-capital-worth-the-risk" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">worth the downsides</a> — citing the rises and catastrophic falls of WeWork and other start-ups.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">“A thriving society needs moon shots</strong>, and, in the absence of a literal space race, only venture capitalists have the mandate to throw cash at an improbable success,” Mr. Heller writes.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">But the financiers earn a lot from fees regardless</strong> of whether the start-ups they invest in thrive, he adds. “If you’re a venture capitalist, you know that you will not be the one to go broke.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">And the industry may have too much money</strong>, leading to bad decisions and excesses: “Venture capital, once a small and chancy field, is now a profit machine for its managers, with all that entails. Poorly designed for its scale, rote and entrenched at the higher echelons, it has become vulnerable to a particular sort of change: disruption by a bright, daring idea.”</p>, <h2 class="css-3ez4hu eoo0vm40" id="link-3b303ffc">How Trump Inc. is entwined with the White House</h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">With the impeachment trial kicking off in earnest in the Senate today, Anita Kumar of Politico takes a look at how President Trump has <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.politico.com/news/2020/01/20/trump-businesses-empire-tied-presidency-100496" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">combined his personal business</a> with the job of running the government’s executive branch.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">• “A Chinese state-owned company was awarded a multimillion contract to help develop a Trump golf course in Dubai, United Arab Emirates, amid a U.S.-China trade war,” Ms. Kumar writes.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">• “T-Mobile executives stayed at Trump’s Washington hotel while seeking a green light from the federal government for a merger.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">• “Even after Congress launched an investigation into his businesses, the Trump administration authorized foreign governments to rent condos in Trump World Tower in New York.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">• “Trump has promoted his properties dozens of times while in office.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Mr. Trump’s decision not to divest his real estate business</strong> “has created a vast web of potential conflicts of interest, accusations about his policies being driven by his business interests and even possible violations of the law, according to documents and interviews,” Ms. Kumar adds.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Democratic lawmakers say they will continue investigating</strong> potential conflicts of interest, though they didn’t include them in the two articles of impeachment now under consideration in the Senate.</p>, <h2 class="css-3ez4hu eoo0vm40" id="link-6c2a2281">Could Brexit harm women in the British workplace?</h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Britain is set to leave the E.U. in a little over two weeks. Some fear that could <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/17/world/brexit-women-impact.html" title="">disproportionately affect women</a>, Alisha Haridasani Gupta of the NYT reports.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">• In 2018, women made up a majority of Britain’s part-time or temporary workers, which would probably be the first kinds of jobs to go in the predicted economic slowdown.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">• Social protections and workplace policies like parental leave and sexual harassment regulations have “a foundation” in E.U. law, according to Roberta Guerrina, a professor at Bristol University in England who specializes in gender politics.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">• “Many of Britain’s standards and protections for women that were once guaranteed by the E.U. can theoretically be repealed,” Ms. Gupta writes.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">• The regulations’ fate depends on whether Prime Minister Boris Johnson’s government keeps the country aligned with some European rules as it seeks to <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.ft.com/content/a96655a4-3b7e-11ea-a01a-bae547046735" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">diverge from others</a>.</p>, <h2 class="css-3ez4hu eoo0vm40" id="link-7c091e00">The speed read</h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Deals</strong></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">• Uber agreed to sell its Uber Eats business in India to a local rival, Zomato, as it continues to exit unprofitable overseas operations. (<a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/20/technology/uber-eats-zomato.html" title="">NYT</a>)</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">• Antitrust regulators are reportedly still investigating Altria’s $12.8 billion investment in the vaping company Juul. (<a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.wsj.com/articles/altria-juul-deal-is-stuck-in-antitrust-review-11579257002" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">WSJ</a>)</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">• JPMorgan Chase is creating a division to invest in development projects in emerging markets. (<a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.cnbc.com/2020/01/20/jp-morgan-says-it-will-fund-100-billion-in-emerging-market-projects.html" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">CNBC</a>)</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">• Twenty top performing hedge funds made $59.3 billion in investment profits last year, their biggest annual gain in at least a decade. (<a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.ft.com/content/81e074cc-3950-11ea-a6d3-9a26f8c3cba4" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">FT</a>)</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Politics and policy</strong></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">• France and the U.S. called off a potential trade war after Paris agreed to freeze plans to tax American internet giants. (<a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.wsj.com/articles/frances-macron-pauses-tech-tax-after-u-s-pressure-11579564974" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">WSJ</a>)</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">• Conservative states are lining up for federal funds to deal with natural disasters — but they’re careful not to use the term climate change. (<a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/20/climate/climate-change-funding-states.html" title="">NYT</a>)</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">• The plastic-bag industry is winning the fight over bans of single-use plastic shopping bags in the U.S. (<a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.politico.com/news/2020/01/20/plastic-bags-have-lobbyists-winning-100587" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">Politico</a>)</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">• Mike Bloomberg’s huge spending on ads for his presidential run are raising rates for political campaigns across the country. (<a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.politico.com/news/2020/01/20/bloomberg-ad-campaign-hikes-tv-prices-100572" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">Politico</a>)</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Tech</strong></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">• Privacy advocates are <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/18/technology/clearview-privacy-facial-recognition.html" title="">worried about Clearview</a>, a facial recognition start-up that has scraped the internet — and that claims to be able to identify almost anyone. Separately, Alphabet’s C.E.O., Sundar Pichai, has called on regulators <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.ft.com/content/0e19e81c-3b98-11ea-a01a-bae547046735" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">to clamp down</a> on facial recognition technology. (NYT, FT)</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">• The trial over whether Canada should extradite Meng Wanzhou, the C.F.O. of Huawei, to the U.S. has begun. (<a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/20/world/canada/meng-wanzhou-huawei-detention-vancouver.html" title="">NYT</a>)</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">• Instagram’s C.E.O., Adam Mosseri, is trying to make the social network a safer place. (<a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/17/business/instagram-likes.html" title="">NYT</a>)</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Best of the rest</strong></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">• American consulting firms like Boston Consulting Group and McKinsey have been accused of helping Africa’s richest woman loot her native Angola and stash that money abroad. (<a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/19/world/africa/isabel-dos-santos-angola.html" title="">NYT</a>)</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">• The mysterious coronavirus behind a growing epidemic in China now appears to be spreading from humans to humans. (<a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/20/world/asia/coronavirus-china-symptoms.html" title="">NYT</a>)</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">• One of Boeing’s top customers has urged the company to rename the 737 Max. (<a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2020-01-20/boeing-told-to-rename-max-to-allay-concerns-once-flights-resume" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">Bloomberg</a>)</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">We’d love your feedback. Please email thoughts and suggestions to </em><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="mailto:business@nytimes.com?subject=Newsletter%20Feedback" title=""><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">business@nytimes.com</em></a><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">.</em></p>, <p>Advertisement</p>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd" id="site-index-label">Site Index</h2>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-0">news</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-1">opinion</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-2">arts</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-3">living</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-4">more</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-subscribe-label">Subscribe</h3>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd">Site Information Navigation</h2>]
[<p>Advertisement</p>, <p>Supported by</p>, <h1 class="css-1s4ffep e1h9rw200" id="link-68d16021" itemprop="headline"><span>Impeachment, China Virus, France: Your Tuesday Briefing</span></h1>, <p class="css-1ifw933 e1wiw3jv0" id="article-summary">Here’s what you need to know.</p>, <p class="css-1fv7b6t e1jsehar1" itemprop="author" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">By<!-- --> <a class="css-brehiz e1jsehar0" href="https://www.nytimes.com/by/mike-ives"><span class="css-1baulvz" itemprop="name">Mike Ives</span></a> and <span class="css-1baulvz last-byline" itemprop="name">Sofia Mitra-Thakur</span></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">(Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/morning-briefing" title="">sign-up</a>.)</p>, <p class="css-ma92ss evys1bk0">Good morning.</p>, <p class="css-ma92ss evys1bk0">We’re covering the start of President Trump’s <strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">impeachment trial</strong>, the spread of a <strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">deadly virus</strong> in Asia and a study of fish oil’s effects on <strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">sperm quality</strong>. </p>, <h2 class="css-3ez4hu eoo0vm40" id="link-39ebaf1d">Trump heads to Davos as impeachment trial starts</h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">President Trump is expected to speak today at the World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland, just as his impeachment trial begins in earnest in Washington.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">U.S. senators are bracing for a rancorous debate over the trial’s ground rules, which will determine how Democrats prosecute Mr. Trump on charges of abuse of power and obstruction of Congress linked to his Ukraine pressure campaign.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Senator Mitch McConnell, the chamber’s top Republican, <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/20/us/politics/mcconnell-pushes-to-speed-impeachment-trial-as-trump-requests-swift-acquittal.html" title="">angered Democrats on Monday</a> by unveiling trial rules that would limit each side’s arguments to 24 hours over two days, and require a separate vote to admit evidence unearthed in the fall by the House of Representatives.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Analysis: </strong>Mr. Trump’s lawyers <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/20/us/trial-memorandum-of-president-trump.html" title="">have not contested</a> the basic facts of the case, and scholars say their central argument — that the impeachment charges are invalid because the president has not been accused of committing an ordinary crime — <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/20/us/politics/trump-impeachment-legal-defense.html" title="">defies a long-established legal consensus</a>.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Go deeper:</strong> The trial will <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/17/us/politics/ken-starr-impeachment-trump-clinton.html" title="">include some of the same faces</a> that animated President Bill Clinton’s impeachment trial 21 years ago. But Mr. Clinton <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/19/us/politics/clinton-impeachment-trial.html" title="">did not command his own party the way Mr. Trump does now</a>.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Related: </strong>The business and political elites who gather each year at Davos appear to be warming to Mr. Trump, even if some may roll their eyes behind his back, <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/20/business/dealbook/donald-trump-davos.html" title="">writes our DealBook columnist, Andrew Ross Sorkin</a>. (One reason? He may be in office for another four years.)</p>, <h2 class="css-3ez4hu eoo0vm40" id="link-6b3fbec1">China says deadly virus spreads from humans to humans</h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">A <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/18/world/asia/china-virus-wuhan-coronavirus.html" title="">new pneumonialike illness</a> that has killed four people in China and infected more than 200 others in the country and elsewhere in Asia is now capable of spreading from person to person, a leading Chinese scientist said on Monday.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The fear is that the virus — which has spread to Japan, South Korea and Thailand — could set off a broader pandemic as millions of Chinese travel for the seven-day Lunar New Year holiday, which begins on Friday. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Experts say the severity of the outbreak will now depend on how many people, on average, a person with the virus could infect. The World Health Organization will hold a meeting on Wednesday to determine whether the virus is a “public health emergency of international concern,” a designation it has given to previous outbreaks of Ebola and other diseases.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Background: </strong>The illness, which started in the Chinese city of Wuhan, is <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/08/health/china-pneumonia-outbreak-virus.html" title="">a coronavirus</a>, a family of viruses that affect the respiratory tract and range from the common cold to severe diseases like SARS. Animals are thought to be the most likely primary source, and complications can include pneumonia, kidney failure or death.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Go deeper: </strong>The current outbreak has echoes of the deadly SARS outbreak of 2002 and 2003 that infected more than 8,000 people — one that <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2003/04/21/world/the-sars-epidemic-epidemic-china-admits-underreporting-its-sars-cases.html" title="">China initially tried to cover up</a>. Experts say the authorities are trying to be more transparent this time, but many in China are skeptical.</p>, <h2 class="css-3ez4hu eoo0vm40" id="link-486a50d7">France declares tax truce (for now) with U.S.</h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">President Emmanuel Macron of France <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/reuters/2020/01/20/business/20reuters-france-usa-tax.html" title="">said on Monday </a>that he and President Trump would work together on a deal to avoid an escalation of tariffs linked to <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/07/business/economy/us-france-digital-tax.html" title="">a French proposal to tax digital services</a> provided by American tech giants.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Mr. Macron wants to avoid retaliatory U.S. tariffs on French products like wine, cheese, handbags and other luxury goods. <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/20/style/brune-poirson-fashion-france.html" title="">We have a timely profile of Brune Poirson</a>, above, France’s de facto fashion minister and a negotiator in the so-called handbag war.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Details: </strong>Mr. Macron and Mr. Trump agreed on Monday to hold off on any tariffs until the end of the year, while negotiators at the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development continue talks on developing a broader framework for digital taxes. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Domestic politics:</strong> Philippe Martinez, the leader of France’s most militant union, has emerged <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/20/world/europe/france-strike-martinez.html" title="">as the face of the country’s longest-ever transport strike</a> — and as a foil to Mr. Macron’s business-friendly vision.</p>, <h2 class="css-3ez4hu eoo0vm40" id="link-87d38f9">‘We do not want her kind in Norway’</h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">A woman from a Norwegian-Pakistani family moved to Syria in 2013, marrying twice in Islamic State territory and having two children. Now she’s back in Norway, <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/20/world/europe/isis-norway.html" title="">and her mere presence threatens to bring down the country’s government</a>.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Prime Minister Erna Solberg has said that the woman, 29, who returned over the weekend after being plucked out of a Kurdish-controlled detention camp in Syria, was allowed to re-enter Norway so her 5-year-old could receive medical treatment. The police have not raised the terrorism threat level as a result.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">But many Norwegians say the woman poses a security threat. And in a gesture of protest, the anti-immigrant Progress Party resigned on Monday from the four-party, center-right coalition that has governed since 2013.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Quotable: </strong>“We do not want her kind in Norway, and we certainly don’t want Norwegian authorities spending enormous resources getting them to Norway,” a Progress Party spokesman, Jon Engen-Helgheim, said last week.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">What’s next: </strong>The Progress Party said it would continue to support <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2017/09/11/world/europe/norway-election.html" title="">the governing coalition</a>. The woman has been charged with “participation in a terrorist organization” and faces up to six years in prison.</p>, <h3 class="css-1b8te77 e1gnsphs0" id="link-537c81e6">If you have 5 minutes, this is worth it</h3>, <h2 class="css-3ez4hu eoo0vm40" id="link-2e46384c">A path to redemption in Afghanistan</h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">An American airstrike in Afghanistan killed the poet Zaheer Ahmad Zindani’s father, and one of his three sisters burned to death when a Taliban roadside bomb hit a bus he was traveling in.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The bomb also robbed Mr. Zindani, above, of his eyesight, prompting the family of his teenage love to reject him. But his mother, a polio vaccinator, was determined to find him a match.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">A correspondent in our Kabul bureau <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/20/world/asia/afghanistan-war-marriage-blindness.html" title="">traveled to Kandahar to hear Mr. Zindani’s story</a>.</p>, <h3 class="css-1b8te77 e1gnsphs0" id="link-554e6082">Here’s what else is happening</h3>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Boeing crash:</strong> <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/20/business/boeing-737-accidents.html" title="">A Times review of evidence</a> from the deadly 2009<span class="css-8l6xbc evw5hdy0"> </span>crash of a 737 in the Netherlands reveals striking parallels with two recent crashes of a newer model of the aircraft — the 737 Max — and similar pushback, from the company and American safety officials, against criticism of Boeing. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Russia: </strong>President Vladimir Putin <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/20/world/europe/Russia-prosecutor-Chaika-Putin.html" title="">prompted new speculation</a> about his future role when he proposed constitutional amendments on Monday that would empower a previously toothless advisory council that he now leads.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Serbia-Kosovo flights: </strong>The two Balkan countries agreed <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/20/world/europe/serbia-kosovo-flights-resume.html" title="">to resume flights</a> between their capitals for the first time in more than two decades, a step toward reconciliation.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">How warm was your town?</strong> Scientists said 2019 was the second-warmest year on record, and an AccuWeather database of 3,500 cities showed that more than 80 percent experienced average temperatures that were higher than normal last year. <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2020/world/year-in-weather.html" title="">See how your city compares</a>.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Snapshot: </strong>Above, Elaine Lau at her noodle shop in Hong Kong. <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/19/world/asia/hong-kong-protests-yellow-blue.html" title="">It’s one of many so-called yellow shops in the restive Chinese territory</a> that openly support the city’s democracy movement. (“Blue” ones, by contrast, support the police.)</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Sperm health: </strong>Young men who took fish oil supplements had higher sperm counts, greater sperm volume and larger average testicular size, <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/17/well/live/fish-oil-supplements-tied-to-sperm-health.html" title="">a study in Denmark found</a>. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">What we’re reading: </strong><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.tastecooking.com/god-save-lard-bread/" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">This piece in Taste</a> about a food specialty known to few outside a small subset of Italian-Americans. “It has come to my attention that some of you do not know the first blessed thing about lard bread,” tweeted our food critic Pete Wells. “Max [Falkowitz] is here to guide you into the light of lardy knowledge.” </p>, <h3 class="css-1b8te77 e1gnsphs0" id="link-7ded7ef4">Now, a break from the news</h3>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Cook: </strong><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://cooking.nytimes.com/recipes/1017704-vegetarian-skillet-chili" title="">Vegetarian skillet chili</a> is one of those pantry meals that you’ll memorize. (Our <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/newsletters/five-weeknight-dishes" title="">Five Weeknight Dishes newsletter</a> has more recommendations.) </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Watch: </strong>Ruth Negga, an Ethiopian-Irish actress, is set to play Hamlet in Brooklyn. Next up for her: a film adaptation of a 1920s novel <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/17/theater/ruth-negga-hamlet.html" title="">about passing for white</a>.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Smarter Living: </strong>Should you live out of a suitcase when you travel, or unpack your things? There are <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/17/travel/unpack-vacation.html" title="">arguments for both</a>.</p>, <h3 class="css-1b8te77 e1gnsphs0" id="link-15767e9b">And now for the Back Story on …</h3>, <h2 class="css-3ez4hu eoo0vm40" id="link-3cd23f6c">Cocktails</h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">A hundred years ago this month, the U.S. embarked on a 13-year official prohibition on the “manufacture, sale or transportation of intoxicating liquors” anywhere within the country.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/01/us/100-years-ago-the-booziest-january-suddenly-dried-up.html" title="">It didn’t go well.</a></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Bootlegging liquor operations proliferated, as did the illicit bars known as speakeasies. And the drink of choice: the cocktail, which spread out the hooch or disguised its sometimes bad flavors. The boom far outlasted Prohibition. <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://punchdrink.com/recipes/joaquin-simos-sidecar/" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">Sidecar,</a> anyone?</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.grubstreet.com/2015/04/david-wondrich-knows-the-origins-of-cocktail.html" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">Dave Wondrich, a drinks historian, tracked down the source of the word “cocktail.”</a> In the second edition of his landmark reconstruction of mixed drinks, “Imbibe!,” he notes that prospective horse sellers in England would give old or droopy specimens a rectal dose of ginger to make them cock their tails for a younger, zippier appearance.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">From there it was just a short jump to the zingy drinks that made humans perk up, at least at the start of their alcoholic forays.</p>, <p class="css-ma92ss evys1bk0">That’s it for this briefing. Bottoms up.</p>, <p class="css-ma92ss evys1bk0">— Mike</p>, <p class="css-jwz2nf etfikam0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Thank you</strong><br/>To Mark Josephson and Eleanor Stanford for the break from the news. Andrea Kannapell, the Briefings editor, wrote today’s Back Story. You can reach the team at <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="mailto:briefing+midnight@nytimes.com?subject=Briefing%20Feedback" title="">briefing@nytimes.com</a>.</p>, <p class="css-jwz2nf etfikam0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">P.S.</strong><br/>“The Daily” is off for the Martin Luther King holiday in the U.S. Try listening to the latest “Modern Love” podcast, in which the actress Rebecca Hall <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/15/style/modern-love-podcast-rebecca-hall.html" title="">reads an essay about dating while bipolar</a>. <br/>• Here’s today’s <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/crosswords/game/mini" title="">Mini Crossword puzzle</a>, and a clue: Overhead (five letters). <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/crosswords" title="">You can find all our puzzles here</a>.<br/>• The Times is always looking for talent. [<p>Advertisement</p>, <p>Supported by</p>, <h1 class="css-1s4ffep e1h9rw200" id="link-466d05f9" itemprop="headline"><span>Wuhan, Center of Coronavirus Outbreak, Is Being Cut Off by Chinese Authorities</span></h1>, <p class="css-1ifw933 e1wiw3jv0" id="article-summary">The sudden restrictions — announced after the official death toll nearly doubled — could upend the travel plans of millions of Chinese citizens, who travel in huge numbers during the Lunar New Year holiday.</p>, <p class="css-1fv7b6t e1jsehar1" itemprop="author" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">By<!-- --> <a class="css-brehiz e1jsehar0" href="https://www.nytimes.com/by/amy-qin"><span class="css-1baulvz" itemprop="name">Amy Qin</span></a> and <a class="css-brehiz e1jsehar0" href="https://www.nytimes.com/by/vivian-wang"><span class="css-1baulvz last-byline" itemprop="name">Vivian Wang</span></a></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">BEIJING — Chinese authorities on Thursday morning closed off <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/24/health/chicago-coronavirus-cdc.html" title="">Wuhan</a> — a city of more than 11 million people and the epicenter of a pneumonia-like virus that has spread halfway around the world — by canceling planes and trains leaving the city, and suspending buses, subways and ferries within it.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The announcement, <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://twitter.com/ChinaDaily/status/1220052882596286465" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">shared on Chinese state media</a> just hours before it was to take effect, was a significant escalation from just the day before, when the authorities had urged people not to travel to or from the central Chinese city but had stopped short of shutting down transportation.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The new virus, which first emerged at the end of December, has killed at least 17 people and sickened more than 570, including in Taiwan, Japan, Thailand, South Korea and the United States. It has raised the specter of a repeat of the SARS epidemic, which broke out in China in 2002 and 2003 and spread rapidly while officials obscured the seriousness of the crisis. That virus eventually killed more than 800 people worldwide.</p>, <h2 class="css-zd32qr">Wuhan Coronavirus Map: Tracking the Spread of the Outbreak</h2>, <p class="css-1uuihdo">The virus has sickened tens of thousands of people in China and a number of other countries.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">In recent days, governments around the world have introduced special screening measures at ports of entry, and the World Health Organization is weighing the declaration of an international emergency.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The Chinese authorities said that the measures in Wuhan were needed to “effectively cut off the transmission of the virus, resolutely curb the spread of the epidemic, and ensure the safety and health of the people.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">They said they would later announce an end date for the restrictions.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The news spread quickly. On Sina Weibo, a Twitter-like Chinese social media site, the hashtag #WuhanLockdown was the top trending topic, with more than 1.6 million views.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Chinese users left comments on the government’s announcement expressing support for the lockdown and concern for the residents of the city. “Go Wuhan,” several posted.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Others wondered how sick residents would get from their homes to hospitals without public transportation. Some who said they lived in Wuhan asked what would happen to them.</p>, <h1 class="g-headline" id="g-inlineguide-headline">The Coronavirus Outbreak</h1>, <h2 class="g-inlineguide-list-header g-optimize-type">What do you need to know? Start here.</h2>, <p class="g-inlineguide-date">Updated Feb. 10, 2020</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“Who will think of the lives of those of us who are healthy in Wuhan? We are also afraid,” wrote one user, who described herself as a designer living in Wuhan. “Even before the city was closed, we protected ourselves and hid at home. Now we are lambs who will still be slaughtered, and we can only leave our fates to the heavens.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Extreme measures during outbreaks have been imposed elsewhere before. During the Ebola epidemic in West Africa in 2014, <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2014/09/20/world/africa/ebola-outbreak.html" title="">Sierra Leone </a>ordered everyone in the nation to stay home for three days as the authorities went door-to-door checking for new cases, retrieving dead bodies and trying to stop the disease from spreading further. In <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2014/08/21/world/africa/ebola-outbreak-liberia-quarantine.html" title="">Monrovia, the capital of Liberia</a>, a sprawling neighborhood with tens of thousands of people was put under strict quarantine by the government and guarded by police officers in riot gear, setting off violent clashes with penned-in residents.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">During the <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2003/04/27/world/the-sars-epidemic-the-path-from-china-s-provinces-a-crafty-germ-breaks-out.html" title="">2003 SARS outbreak</a>, anyone in China who displayed symptoms of the disease was hospitalized, and students were examined daily. In Singapore, people suspected of having SARS were confined to their homes and monitored with webcams and electronic bracelets.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Still, medical experts were startled by the scale of the shutdown in Wuhan, which has more people than the entire country of Sierra Leone. Dr. Tom Inglesby, director of the Johns Hopkins Center for Health Security, said that a city the size of Wuhan has “tens of thousands of connections with the outside world that are coming and going all the time, bringing food and medicine.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">”The complexity and downside cost of that will be potentially very high,” Dr. Inglesby said.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Roughly 30,000 people fly out of Wuhan on an average day, according to air traffic data analyzed by researchers at Northeastern University in Boston. Many more leave using ground transportation like trains and cars. The city is the hub of industry and commerce in central China, home to the region’s biggest airport and deep-water port and sometimes known as the <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.chinadaily.com.cn/regional/2017-11/25/content_34984016.htm" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">Chicago of China</a>. It is popular among tourists for its colonial architecture, spicy noodles and proximity to the Yangtze River.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">In the short term, the sudden restrictions could upend the travel plans of millions of Chinese citizens, who travel in huge numbers during the Lunar New Year holiday, which begins on Friday. The government said it would close Wuhan’s airport and train stations to departures, and it urged residents not to leave the city — a major transportation hub — unless they had an urgent reason to do so.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The Lunar New Year in China is typically the world’s largest annual migration of people, with hundreds of millions of travelers fanning out across the country and the world, and hundreds of billions of dollars spent on hotels, restaurants and shopping. Before the virus emerged, the Chinese government had <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="http://www.xinhuanet.com/english/2020-01/10/c_138694239.htm" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">estimated</a> that domestic travelers would make three billion trips over the holiday period, also known as the Spring Festival.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">But with the new <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/24/health/chicago-coronavirus-cdc.html" title="">coronavirus</a>, the mass migration is also an epidemiologist’s nightmare.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">On Wednesday, a senior Chinese health official delivered a stark warning: The tide of travel during the holiday would make it more difficult to contain the outbreak.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">In addition, “the possibility exists that the virus could mutate, and there are risks that the epidemic could spread further,” said the official, Li Bin, a deputy head of China’s health commission. Chinese officials had already classified the virus as a class B infectious disease, a category that includes SARS.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Before the transportation shutdown, the Wuhan government had also issued a ban on large public gatherings and performances at hotels and sightseeing destinations. They had announced that all locals were required to wear masks in public to help prevent the spread of the virus.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Tour companies had promised penalty-free refunds for hotel bookings and air and train tickets to and from the city. Travel operators had suspended itineraries with stops there.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Outside of Wuhan, many Chinese have also already canceled travel plans, forgoing vacations and what for some is their only chance to return home for family reunions during the year. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“After we heard how bad the situation was on Monday, we held a family meeting and decided that it just wasn’t worth the risk,” said Yan Chaowei, 32, a Shanghai resident who was planning on taking a seven-hour bullet train to her family home in southeastern Jiangxi Province.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“It just wouldn’t be a relaxing trip, especially with a small child,” she added. “When we finally made the decision to stay home, we sighed with relief.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">For Chinese companies, the outbreak could deal yet another blow at a time of slowing economic growth.
