According to official estimates, Chinese spent $74 billion on travel and $145 billion on shopping and food during the Spring Festival holiday last year. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">But this week, the Taiwanese president, Tsai Ing-wen, said that all travel by tour groups between Wuhan and Taiwan would be suspended. North Korea <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/21/world/asia/coronavirus-china-north-korea-tourism-ban.html" title="">also temporarily banned foreign tourists</a>, many of whom come from China, according to a leading tour operator.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Some international health experts, including the World Health Organization, have praised the Chinese government’s response as timely.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">But the government, particularly in Wuhan, has <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/21/world/asia/china-coronavirus-wuhan.html?action=click&amp;module=RelatedLinks&amp;pgtype=Article" title="">drawn public criticism</a> at home for what some see as a delay in the reporting of cases that evoked the memory of the SARS outbreak, in which the Chinese government <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2003/05/23/world/sars-epidemic-health-politics-some-chinese-say-government-s-response-epidemic.html" title="">withheld critical information</a>. A top committee of the ruling Communist Party warned officials on Tuesday in a social media post that anyone who sought to hide infections would be “forever nailed to history’s pillar of shame.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">And new cases were continuing to emerge. In Mexico, President Andrés Manuel López Obrador said Wednesday morning that the Mexican health authorities had identified a possible case in the northern state of Tamaulipas. The patient was “under observation,” the president said during a news conference. Gloria Molina, the health secretary for the state of Tamaulipas, said that the patient is a 57-year-old researcher in a university biotechnology laboratory who had visited Wuhan recently and works in Reynosa, a border town near McAllen, Texas.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Despite the spread of the virus, some experts are urging the public to remain calm.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“This is a SARS-like event but not as severe as SARS,” said <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.duke-nus.edu.sg/directory/detail/wang-linfa" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">Wang Linfa</a>, director of the emerging infectious disease program at Duke-NUS Medical School in Singapore. “During an outbreak like this from an unknown pathogen, overreacting might be better than underreacting, but we still have to be realistic.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Zhu Niancheng, 19, a chemistry major at a university in Wuhan, appeared to be heeding that advice on Wednesday as he sat on a suitcase outside a Beijing train station smoking a cigarette.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“Don’t worry, I’m not going to Wuhan,” he said, as a phalanx of People’s Liberation Army soldiers in green uniforms and black face masks marched behind him.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Asked if he was concerned about his classmates back in Wuhan, the teenager laughed and said, “I’m not really afraid. We just make fun of each other on WeChat, like ‘Yo, you still alive?’”</p>, <p class="css-jwz2nf etfikam0">Amy Qin reported from Beijing and Vivian Wang from New York. Reporting was contributed by Christopher Buckley from Beijing, Roni Caryn Rabin in New York, Kirk Semple from Mexico City, and Tiffany May, Ezra Cheung and Elaine Yu from Hong Kong, and Allison McCann from London. Zoe Mou contributed research from Beijing, and Claire Fu contributed research from Chengdu, China.</p>, <p>Advertisement</p>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd" id="site-index-label">Site Index</h2>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-0">news</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-1">opinion</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-2">arts</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-3">living</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-4">more</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-subscribe-label">Subscribe</h3>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd">Site Information Navigation</h2>]
[<p>Advertisement</p>, <p>Supported by</p>, <h1 class="css-1s4ffep e1h9rw200" id="link-64ab71d7" itemprop="headline"><span>As New Virus Spreads From China, Scientists See Grim Reminders</span></h1>, <p class="css-1ifw933 e1wiw3jv0" id="article-summary">Epidemics of related viruses, like SARS, killed hundreds. But the W.H.O. has postponed a decision on whether the new outbreak is a global emergency.</p>, <p class="css-1fv7b6t e1jsehar1" itemprop="author" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">By<!-- --> <a class="css-brehiz e1jsehar0" href="https://www.nytimes.com/by/denise-grady"><span class="css-1baulvz last-byline" itemprop="name">Denise Grady</span></a></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Less than a month after the first few cases of a new respiratory illness were reported in <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/23/us/united-states-coronavirus-cases.html" title="">Wuhan, China</a>, travelers have carried the <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/23/us/united-states-coronavirus-cases.html" title="">virus</a> to at least four other countries, including the United States. More than 500<strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10"> </strong>people are known to have been infected, at least 17<strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10"> </strong>have died — and the world is bracing itself for what might come next.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">On Wednesday, experts at <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.who.int/docs/default-source/coronaviruse/situation-reports/20200121-sitrep-1-2019-ncov.pdf" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">the World Health Organization</a> decided to postpone until Thursday a decision on whether the current outbreak constitutes a “public health emergency of international concern,” a label given to serious public health events that endanger international public health” and “potentially require a coordinated international response.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">A vote by W.H.O.’s emergency committee was split down the middle, its chairman said, and the group concluded that it did not have enough information to make a decision.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“The decision about whether or not to declare a public health emergency of international concern is one I take extremely seriously, and one I am only prepared to make with appropriate consideration of all the evidence,” Dr. Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus, W.H.O.’s director general, said at news briefing.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Adding that a W.H.O. team was in China gathering information, he said, “We will have much more to say tomorrow</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">But even as the W.H.O. debated its decision, officials in China <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/22/world/asia/china-coronavirus-travel.html" title="">began closing transportation links from and within Wuhan, China, the epicenter of the outbreak</a>. The move was a significant escalation in the country’s attempts to contain the spread of the virus as the Lunar New Year approaches and holiday travel commences.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Dr. Tedros and W.H.O. officials at the briefing said they had not advised China to close Wuhan, but nonetheless expressed support for the decision, saying it could protect other parts of China and other countries.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Public health officials around the world are on alert because the new infection is caused by a coronavirus, from the same family that caused outbreaks of SARS and MERS, killing hundreds of people in dozens of countries.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The W.H.O. has already advised governments to be prepared for the disease, to be vigilant and ready to test anyone with symptoms like cough and fever who has traveled to affected regions. Air travel is expected to surge as the Lunar New Year approaches this weekend.</p>, <h1 class="g-headline" id="g-inlineguide-headline">The Coronavirus Outbreak</h1>, <h2 class="g-inlineguide-list-header g-optimize-type">What do you need to know? Start here.</h2>, <p class="g-inlineguide-date">Updated Feb. 10, 2020</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">More important than an emergency declaration is the need for more data on the outbreak, said Jennifer B. Nuzzo of the Johns Hopkins Center for Health Security.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Scientists still do not have enough information about the severity of the disease, she said.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“I want to see from the emergency committee all the information on the table and an assessment of what the risk really is,” Dr. Nuzzo said. “To me, that’s far more important than their declaration.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">One purpose of an emergency declaration is to draw world attention to an outbreak, so that governments can prepare and also provide needed help.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“There’s already a high level of global attention,” Dr. Nuzzo said, adding that she was not sure how much a declaration would have changed things.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Several countries have already begun screening travelers from China for fever and cough. Airports in Los Angeles, New York and San Francisco last week started to screen arriving flights from Wuhan, and airports in Atlanta and Chicago will begin doing so this week.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“Data shows that entry screening requires a tremendous amount of resources and is not tremendously effective,” Dr. Nuzzo said.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">North Korea has suspended tourism because of the outbreak, <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.reuters.com/article/us-china-health-pneumonia-northkorea/north-korea-to-suspend-foreign-tourism-over-coronavirus-fears-tour-company-idUSKBN1ZK1PK" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">according to Reuters</a>.</p>, <h2 class="css-zd32qr">Wuhan Coronavirus Map: Tracking the Spread of the Outbreak</h2>, <p class="css-1uuihdo">The virus has sickened tens of thousands of people in China and a number of other countries.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Important questions about the outbreak are still unanswered, and W.H.O.’s expert committee now must grapple with significant unknowns.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“We don’t know how many people are infected,” said Tarik Jasarevic, a spokesman for the W.H.O. “The more you test, the more you will find people who are infected. We don’t know if there are asymptomatic cases. If they are asymptomatic, are they contagious?”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Broad studies to test for evidence of infection, past and present, would give a true picture of how many people have been exposed to the virus.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The virus causes a pneumonialike illness, with coughing and fever in some people but not all. The severity matters: If there are cases with mild illness or no symptoms at all, they may go undetected, and those people will keep working, shopping and traveling, possibly infecting others.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">A milder illness has the potential to spread farther and cause longer-lasting outbreaks than one with more obvious symptoms, according to Dr. Mark R. Denison, an infectious disease specialist at the Vanderbilt University School of Medicine who studies coronaviruses.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Compared to SARS and MERS, the Wuhan illness so far does seem less severe, he said.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">SARS, which began in live-animal markets in China in 2002, quickly spread to dozens of countries, infecting more than 8,000 people and killing nearly 800. The virus is thought to have originated in bats and spread to civet cats that were being sold for consumption.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The civets spread the virus to humans, who infected one another through respiratory secretions and also exposure to feces.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">SARS often caused severe illness, so cases were detectable, Dr. Denison said; aggressive public health measures, including quarantines and travel restrictions, helped stamp out the epidemic.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">But the travel bans, not to mention widespread fear and distrust, took a heavy economic toll on China, and since then international authorities have become hesitant about taking drastic steps to quell outbreaks.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">MERS cases have been occurring in the Middle East since 2012, mainly in people who have been exposed to camels, which were most likely infected by bats. Human-to-human transmission does occur, and some spread has happened in hospitals.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">As of November, there had been 2,494 cases of MERS in the last seven years, mostly in Saudi Arabia. The death rate is 34 percent, but may actually be lower if there are mild cases of the disease that have not been detected or counted.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Dr. Denison described the new Wuhan coronavirus as “sort of a first cousin of SARS,” more closely related to it than to MERS, based on its genetic sequence.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Researchers do not know just how contagious the Wuhan coronavirus is. The first people to be infected are thought to have contracted it at a market in Wuhan that sold meat, fish and live animals.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">That market has been shut down and disinfected. Which animal might have been carrying the virus is not yet known.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10"><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">[</em></strong><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10"><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="http://on.fb.me/1paTQ1h" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title=""><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">Like the Science Times page on Facebook.</em></a></strong><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10"><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0"> </em></strong><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">| Sign up for the </em><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10"><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="http://nyti.ms/1MbHaRU" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title=""><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">Science Times newsletter.</em></a></strong><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10"><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">]</em></strong></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Initially, the illness appeared to spread only from animals to people. Then, experts said there was evidence of “limited” human-to-human transmission. Now, more cases are emerging among people with no known exposure to the animal markets, and in medical staff members caring for infected patients.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“Now that you have a cluster of 14 health care workers infected, it suggests that the potential for spread is much greater,” said Dr. Ian W. Lipkin, director of the Center for Infection and Immunity at Columbia University’s Mailman School of Public Health in New York, who has researched SARS and MERS.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“I saw film footage of a hospital lobby in Wuhan, and they are wearing full personal protective equipment from head to toe,” he said. “They are taking it very seriously. I still don’t think this is as bad as SARS, but it’s worse than they originally portrayed it.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Dr. Denison said that with both SARS and MERS, there were episodes in which individual patients became “super-spreaders” who infected many other people, for unknown reasons.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“That’s a wild card we don’t know, the capacity to have multiple transmissions from one person,” Dr. Denison said. “There was no evidence they had dramatically different virus.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">It is possible, he said, that super-spreaders had received a high dose of the virus and had more of it to transmit. Alternatively, their immune systems might have not been able to control the virus, allowing it to multiply and spread extensively in their bodies, making them more contagious.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Although no drugs have been approved specifically to treat coronavirus diseases, Dr. Denison said that in animal studies, an antiviral called remdesivir appeared effective. He has been working with other researchers to develop treatments.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Mr. Jasarevic said that antivirals were being tested against MERS, but that none had been approved yet.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">How and why viruses that have peacefully coexisted with their animal hosts for a long time strike out for new territory — us — is not well understood.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Coronaviruses often inhabit bats without harming them, and sometimes move into other animal species and from them to humans.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">In places that bring multiple animal species together with lots of people — like the food markets in Wuhan and in other parts of China that sell live mammals and birds, along with meat and fish — viruses can pass back and forth between species, mutating as they go. Along the way, they may become able to infect humans.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“Coronaviruses have repeatedly shown an ability to probe across species and cause new animal and human diseases,” Dr. Denison said.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">To go successfully from animal hosts to people, the viruses need to adapt in several ways: They must gain the ability to invade human cells, evade the immune system, replicate inside the human body and spread to others.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The move is often described as “jumping” into humans, but that is an oversimplification, Dr. Denison said. “The process it has to go through is more like high hurdles with a thousand hurdles along the way,” he said.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Still, the new outbreak does not greatly surprise him: “This was a matter of not if, but when.”</p>, <p>Advertisement</p>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd" id="site-index-label">Site Index</h2>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-0">news</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-1">opinion</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-2">arts</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-3">living</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-4">more</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-subscribe-label">Subscribe</h3>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd">Site Information Navigation</h2>]
[<p>Advertisement</p>, <p>Supported by</p>, <p class="css-tsacue e6idgb70">The New New World</p>, <h1 class="css-1s4ffep e1h9rw200" id="link-686a0050" itemprop="headline"><span>China Silences Critics Over Deadly Virus Outbreak</span></h1>, <p class="css-1ifw933 e1wiw3jv0" id="article-summary">Beijing has responded faster to the new threat than it did with SARS, but it still silences and punishes those who veer from the official line, with potentially damaging consequences.</p>, <p class="css-1fv7b6t e1jsehar1" itemprop="author" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">By<!-- --> <a class="css-brehiz e1jsehar0" href="https://www.nytimes.com/by/li-yuan"><span class="css-1baulvz last-byline" itemprop="name">Li Yuan</span></a></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The SARS disaster was supposed to drag China into a new era of openness and responsibility. The deadly disease rippled across the world 17 years ago, abetted by a Chinese government that <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2003/04/13/weekinreview/china-discovers-secrecy-is-expensive.html" title="">covered up</a> its spread. As the scope of it became clear, China’s journalists, intellectuals and other critics helped shame Beijing into opening up about the problem.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“SARS has been our country’s 9/11,” said Xu Zhiyuan, then a young newspaper columnist and a fierce critic of the government’s handling of SARS, <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2003/05/13/world/rude-awakening.html" title="">in a 2003 interview</a> with The New York Times. “It has forced us to pay attention to the real meaning of globalization.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Today, China faces the spread of <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/21/world/asia/china-coronavirus-wuhan.html?action=click&amp;module=Top%20Stories&amp;pgtype=Homepage" title="">another mysterious disease</a>, a coronavirus, which so far has killed 17 people and infected more than 570. And while Beijing’s response has improved in some ways, it has regressed in others. It is censoring criticism. It is detaining people for spreading what it calls “rumors.” It is suppressing information it deems alarming.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Though China’s censors are busily scrubbing the Chinese internet, the country’s online community is registering its disappointment and alarm over Beijing’s handling of the new virus that has spread since December from the city of Wuhan to other countries, even <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/21/health/cdc-coronavirus.html" title="">the United States</a>.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“I thought SARS would force China to rethink its governance model,” Mr. Xu, now a video talk show host, wrote on social media on Tuesday, also posting a screenshot of his 2003 quote in The Times. “I was too naïve.”</p>, <h2 class="css-zd32qr">Wuhan Coronavirus Map: Tracking the Spread of the Outbreak</h2>, <p class="css-1uuihdo">The virus has sickened tens of thousands of people in China and a number of other countries.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">In many ways, China has changed for the better since the SARS epidemic. Its economy has grown eightfold. It has built more skyscrapers, subways and high-speed rail lines than any other country. Its tech companies rival Silicon Valley’s giants. A more responsive bureaucracy provides more people with health care, social services and even quality-of-life improvements like parks.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">When it comes to handling diseases, the public health system has greatly improved. <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2020/01/21/world/asia/china-coronavirus-maps.html" title="">Wuhan, the epicenter of the outbreak</a>, is also home to one of the most advanced epidemic disease research <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://twitter.com/ShanghaiEye/status/1093160842638446592" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">laboratories</a> in the world.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Those improvements have come at a price. The government has tightened its grip on the <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/topic/destination/internet-censorship-in-china" title="">internet</a>, the <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2019/07/12/world/asia/china-journalists-crackdown.html" title="">media</a> and <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2017/07/25/magazine/the-lonely-crusade-of-chinas-human-rights-lawyers.html" title="">civil society</a>. It has deeper pockets and a greater ability to control the flow of information across the country.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">As a result, many of the <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2004/01/07/international/asia/7-at-chinese-paper-held-after-articles-on-new-sars-case.html" title="">media outlets</a>, advocacy groups, <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2004/07/21/world/china-releases-the-sars-whistle-blower.html" title="">activists</a> and others who held the government accountable in 2003 have been silenced or sidelined.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“The system is successful in that it destroyed the people with integrity, the institutions with credibility and a society capable of narrating its own stories,” Mr. Xu said on social media. “What’s left is an arrogant power, a bunch of messy information and many fragile, isolated and angry individuals.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Even as the new virus spread through Wuhan, the government took pains to keep up appearances.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The first case was reported Dec. 8. As the disease spread, Wuhan officials insisted that it was controlled and treatable. The police questioned eight people who posted on social media about the virus, saying they had spread “rumors.”</p>, <h1 class="g-headline" id="g-inlineguide-headline">The Coronavirus Outbreak</h1>, <h2 class="g-inlineguide-list-header g-optimize-type">What do you need to know? Start here.</h2>, <p class="g-inlineguide-date">Updated Feb. 10, 2020</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">On Saturday, two days before Wuhan told the world about the severity of the outbreak, <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://m.weibo.cn/status/4462935805605012?" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">it hosted a potluck banquet</a> attended by more than 40,000 families so the city could apply for a world record for most dishes served at an event. On the day it broke the news to the world, it also announced that it was distributing 200,000 free tickets to residents for festival activities during the Lunar New Year holiday, which begins this Saturday.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The central government backed Wuhan’s officials. Wang Guangfa, a prominent government respiratory expert, told the state broadcaster China Central Television on Jan. 10 that the Wuhan pneumonia was “under control” and mostly a “mild condition.” Eleven days later, he <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.weibo.com/2656274875/IqCSrAXel?type=comment#_rnd1579700865617" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">confirmed</a> to Chinese media that he might have contracted the virus himself during an inspection in Wuhan.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Recognizing an outbreak can take time, and China is not the first government caught flat footed by a disease.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">But the choices made by government officials had an impact on a major commercial and transportation hub. Wuhan is a city of 11 million people, including nearly one million college students from across the country. By the time it disclosed the seriousness of the outbreak, the 40-day Lunar New Year travel season, when Chinese people take an estimated <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="http://www.xinhuanet.com/english/2020-01/10/c_138694239.htm" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">three billion trips</a> combined, had already begun.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">People might have made different decisions had websites and headlines described growing worries. Instead, they traveled. On Tuesday, all five confirmed cases in Beijing were people who had traveled to Wuhan in January for business, study or leisure.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Until a week ago, some people in China called it the “patriotic virus." Cases appeared in Hong Kong, Thailand, Vietnam, Japan and elsewhere in Asia. No other Chinese city but Wuhan reported infection cases. It was not until the Hong Kong news media reported over the weekend that the virus had been found in other cities did officials elsewhere come forward.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Some critics see parallels to SARS. In 2003, the Guangzhou newspaper Southern Metropolis Daily first reported the SARS outbreak. A military doctor, Jiang Yanyong, came forward with what he knew. Only then did officials act.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“The way this virus came into the public view is the same as that of SARS 17 years ago,” said Rose Luqiu, an assistant journalism professor who covered SARS as a reporter for the Hong Kong-based Phoenix Television.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Many of those brave voices in 2003 are gone. Like almost all Chinese media outlets that were active in the 1990s and 2000s, the Southern Metropolis Daily has lost its freedom to pursue coverage that holds local governments, if not Beijing, accountable. Only a few mainland news media outlets are covering the current crisis critically, and then only with an analytical tone.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">In 2003, Phoenix Television called Ms. Luqiu, then a star reporter, back from Iraq to report on SARS in Beijing. She shadowed the newly appointed Beijing mayor, Wang Qishan, for a week to cover how the government dealt with the crisis. Mr. Wang later became the vice president of China.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">That kind of openness is unimaginable now. Last week, when a group of Hong Kong journalists went to the Wuhan hospital that took in most coronavirus patients, the police <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="http://news.tvb.com/local/5e1d7dc434b0315b57158f6a/%E6%9C%AC%E6%B8%AF%E5%A4%9A%E5%90%8D%E8%A8%98%E8%80%85%E6%AD%A6%E6%BC%A2%E9%86%AB%E9%99%A2%E6%8E%A1%E8%A8%AA%E6%99%82%E8%A2%AB%E6%89%A3%E6%9F%A5-%E8%A6%81%E6%B1%82%E5%88%AA%E9%99%A4%E6%8B%8D%E6%94%9D%E7%B4%A0%E6%9D%90" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">detained</a> them for a few hours. They were asked to delete their TV footage and hand in their phones and cameras for inspection.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">On Tuesday, Ms. Luqiu wrote an article for qq.com, the news site owned by the internet giant Tencent, about the measures the Hong Kong government has taken in dealing with the virus. The article was deleted 10 hours later.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Dr. Jiang, the military doctor who became a whistle-blower in 2003, has been put under periodic house arrest and <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2007/07/13/world/asia/13doctor.html" title="">forbidden</a> to visit the United States to collect a human rights award. He is also portrayed as a bad role model. A multiple-choice question posed by a test-prep school in 2017 asked about Dr. Jiang’s decision. The correct answer was B: It was wrong because it harmed the interests of the nation, the society and the community and should be subject to legal punishment.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">China’s disclosures have improved in many ways since SARS. The government admitted the problem faster. Beijing officials have shown determination to be more transparent. A top party committee said on Tuesday that it would not tolerate any efforts to hide infections.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“Whoever deliberately delays or conceals reporting for the sake of their own interests will be forever nailed to history’s pillar of shame,” the committee said in a post on WeChat. The post was later deleted.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">But when the government is the only source of information, wise advice and valuable clues can be lost. A police bureau in eastern Shandong Province posted on the Twitter-like social media platform Weibo on Wednesday that it had detained four residents who spread rumors that there was a suspected coronavirus patient in the district. In that environment, others dare not speak out.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“The authorities are sending a signal, which is that only the government agencies can talk about the epidemic,” Yu Ping, a former Southern Metropolis Daily reporter, wrote on his personal blog. “All other people should just shut up.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“It’s not public disclosure,” Mr. Yu added. “It’s a naked information monopoly.”</p>, <p>Advertisement</p>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd" id="site-index-label">Site Index</h2>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-0">news</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-1">opinion</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-2">arts</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-3">living</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-4">more</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-subscribe-label">Subscribe</h3>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd">Site Information Navigation</h2>]
[<p>Advertisement</p>, <p>Supported by</p>, <h1 class="css-1s4ffep e1h9rw200" id="link-2503f9e1" itemprop="headline"><span>Coronavirus, Davos, Impeachment: Your Wednesday Briefing</span></h1>, <p class="css-1ifw933 e1wiw3jv0" id="article-summary">Here’s what you need to know.</p>, <p class="css-1fv7b6t e1jsehar1" itemprop="author" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">By<!-- --> <a class="css-brehiz e1jsehar0" href="https://www.nytimes.com/by/mike-ives"><span class="css-1baulvz" itemprop="name">Mike Ives</span></a> and <span class="css-1baulvz last-byline" itemprop="name">Sofia Mitra-Thakur</span></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">(Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/morning-briefing" title="">sign-up</a>.)</p>, <p class="css-ma92ss evys1bk0">Good morning.</p>, <p class="css-ma92ss evys1bk0">We’re covering China’s handling of a <strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">deadly outbreak</strong>, speculation about <strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Vladimir Putin’s next moves</strong> and an Armenian outpost that tracks <strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">cosmic weather</strong>.</p>, <h2 class="css-3ez4hu eoo0vm40" id="link-39d4ee3b">China’s leader under pressure as deadly virus spreads</h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Experts at the World Health Organization will meet today to determine whether an outbreak of a deadly coronavirus that is radiating outward from the Chinese city of Wuhan is an international health emergency. <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/21/health/what-is-coronavirus.html" title="">Here’s what we know</a>.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/21/world/asia/china-coronavirus-wuhan.html" title="">In a vivid report from Wuhan</a>, population 11 million, our correspondent describes how nervous residents are buying up face masks and flooding hospitals to report fevers and coughs. He also explains why President Xi Jinping, who is eager to expand China’s global influence, is under pressure to show that the world’s most populous nation can responsibly handle a public health crisis.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Details: </strong>The outbreak has already killed at least nine and infected more than 400 people in China, and spread to at least five other countries, <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/21/health/cdc-coronavirus.html" title="">including the United States</a>. The virus is thought to have originated with animals but is now <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/20/world/asia/coronavirus-china-symptoms.html" title="">spreading from person to person</a>.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">What’s next:</strong> The worry is that the outbreak will ripple farther across Asia as many people there travel for the weeklong Lunar New Year holiday that begins on Friday, and possibly turn into a <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2019/06/05/books/review/mark-honigsbaum-pandemic-century.html" title="">pandemic</a>.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Background: </strong>China withheld information during a 2002-2003 outbreak of another coronavirus, SARS, that killed more than 800 people. Mr. Xi’s authoritarian government has vowed to do better this time, but it’s already controlling the narrative about the virus by censoring news articles and social media posts.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Go deeper: </strong>Our graphics editor mapped <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2020/01/21/world/asia/china-coronavirus-maps.html" title="">where cases have been reported so far</a>. Others have most likely gone unreported.</p>, <h2 class="css-3ez4hu eoo0vm40" id="link-12f1a17d">Climate change tops the agenda at Davos</h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">When President Trump swooped into the World Economic Forum in Switzerland on Tuesday, he implicitly criticized Greta Thunberg and other climate change activists, saying that they peddled warnings of doom at a time of <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/21/business/trump-davos.html" title="">economic prosperity for Americans</a>.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">But global warming and sustainability were the meeting’s main themes, and Ms. Thunberg, 17, <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/21/climate/greta-thunberg-trump-davos.html" title="">refused to share Mr. Trump’s optimism</a>. In her own speech, she warned the Davos elite that inaction on climate change was “fueling the flames by the hour,” and<a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/21/climate/greta-thunberg-davos.html" title=""> implored them to stop investing in fossil fuels</a> immediately.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Quotable: </strong>“From a sustainability perspective, the right, the left as well as the center have all failed,” Ms. Thunberg said. “No political ideology or economic structure has been able to tackle the climate and environmental emergency.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Related: </strong>Our correspondent took <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/21/world/australia/fires-size-climate.html" title="">an in-depth look at how climate change contributed to the devastating fires</a> that have so far burned through more than 16 million acres in Australia.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">If you missed it yesterday: </strong>Federal funding to fight natural disasters in the United States is complicated by conservative states that either <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/20/climate/climate-change-funding-states.html" title="">play down or completely avoid mentioning</a> climate change in their applications.</p>, <h2 class="css-3ez4hu eoo0vm40" id="link-46ce3518">Impeachment trial opens with partisan clash</h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Democrats may begin their oral arguments as early as today in the impeachment trial of President Trump, who is expected to return to Washington from Davos hours later.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/21/us/politics/senate-impeachment-republicans-democrats.html" title="">trial began in earnest</a> on Tuesday with partisan fights over its ground rules, and Republicans blocked Democrats’ efforts to subpoena witnesses and documents related to Ukraine. <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/21/us/politics/trump-impeachment-trial-day-1.html" title="">Here are the highlights</a>.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">What’s next: </strong>The White House had wanted to quickly dispense with opening arguments so that Mr. Trump’s team could complete his defense before the weekend. But moderate Republicans insisted on a rules change that would give each side 24 hours over three days — not two, as the Senate majority leader, Mitch McConnell, had proposed — to present its case.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Related: </strong>Mr. Trump’s trial is the second of the mass-media era, but <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/21/business/media/impeachment-trial-media-coverage.html" title="">the news media is not allowed to bring cameras into the chamber</a> to record it. That means cameras and microphones controlled by Senate staff members will dictate what the public sees and hears.</p>, <h2 class="css-3ez4hu eoo0vm40" id="link-a211f9f">Putin keeps Kremlinologists guessing</h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Russia’s chattering classes are busy parsing the surprise constitutional changes that President Vladimir Putin announced last week, changes that could create new avenues for him to rule the country for the rest of his life.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Or perhaps not. On social media, <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/21/world/europe/putin-russia-changes.html" title="">our correspondent writes from Moscow</a>, Russian political analysts “have put forward so many different theories that they paint a picture of a nation in collective befuddlement.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Case in point:<strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10"> </strong><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/15/world/europe/medvedev-putin-russia.html" title="">Mr. Putin’s announcement</a> prompted a string of high-level resignations and unexpected appointments. Yet the new cabinet, announced on Tuesday, includes the most prominent members of the last one.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Background:</strong> Many analysts initially thought that the constitutional changes were intended to allow Mr. Putin, 67, to take up a powerful role when his second presidential term expires in 2024. Now they aren’t so sure.</p>, <h3 class="css-1b8te77 e1gnsphs0" id="link-6cae6ce8">If you have 7 minutes, this is worth it</h3>, <h2 class="css-3ez4hu eoo0vm40" id="link-b4c5f97">Pennies from heaven</h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Scientists see giant particle accelerators, in which protons collide at astonishingly high speeds, as an essential technology for unlocking the secrets of the cosmos.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">But spare a thought for the Aragats Cosmic Ray Research Station, above, a mountaintop research station in Armenia that tracks exploding stars and the cosmic weather they produce.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The station, established by the Soviet Union in 1943, gradually lost influence as particle accelerators and other technologies came online. But its staff members are still churning out papers, <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/21/science/observatory-cosmos-armenia-physics.html" title="">our science reporter writes</a>, and its buildings and instruments have endured “like ghost ships in the cosmic rain.”</p>, <h3 class="css-1b8te77 e1gnsphs0" id="link-554e6082">Here’s what else is happening</h3>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Remembering Auschwitz: </strong>Dozens of world leaders are expected to speak out against anti-Semitism at an event in Jerusalem’s Holy City today for the impending 75th anniversary of the liberation of the infamous death camp in Poland. A philosophy professor <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/21/opinion/auschwitz-bystander-theory.html" title="">drew lessons from the Holocaust</a> in a piece for our Opinion section.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Terrorism crackdown: </strong>Britain said on Tuesday that it would introduce tougher laws that will entail longer prison sentences and end early release for <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/21/world/europe/terrorism-sentences-london-bridge-attack.html" title="">people convicted of terrorism offenses</a>.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Royals abroad: </strong>Prince Harry is said to have arrived on Tuesday in Canada, where he joined his wife and their 8-month-old son, Archie. But <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/20/world/americas/harry-meghan-markle-canada.html" title="">almost nothing is known about their plans</a> to live part time in the country.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Deep sea discovery: </strong>Scientists dropped alligator carcasses deep into the Gulf of Mexico to investigate what scavengers might be lurking at the bottom. They were <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/17/science/alligators-carcasses-scavengers.html" title="">surprised by what they found</a>.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Snapshot: </strong>Above, Lebanese demonstrators face off against the police this morning, a day after <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/21/world/middleeast/lebanon-names-new-cabinet.html" title="">the government announced a new cabinet</a>. The country has been mired in a debt crisis and protests over corruption and mismanagement.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">I quit:</strong> <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2020/01/20/style/quitters.html" title="">Our collection of 21 first-person narratives</a> discusses quitting all sorts of things, including jobs, sex, a famous band — and even the task of writing about quitting.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">What we’re reading: </strong><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.newyorker.com/magazine/2020/01/27/the-long-war-against-slavery" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">This article in The New Yorker.</a> Brent Staples, a Pulitzer Prize-winning member of the Times’s editorial board, calls it “a vivid new history” of “how slave rebellions (not white abolitionists) defeated slavery in the hell that was the Caribbean.”</p>, <h3 class="css-1b8te77 e1gnsphs0" id="link-7ded7ef4">Now, a break from the news</h3>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Cook: </strong>If you’re looking for comfort food, make a batch of <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://cooking.nytimes.com/recipes/1020777-sopa-de-albondigas-mexican-meatball-soup" title="">sopa de albóndigas</a>, a Mexican meatball soup.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Watch:</strong> The Welsh actor <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/20/arts/television/prodigal-son-michael-sheen-fox.html" title="">Michael Sheen</a> discussed his portrayal of a serial killer dad on the show “Prodigal Son” and how he does — and doesn’t — take his role home with him. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Read: </strong>Kyle Chayka’s new book, <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/21/books/review-longing-for-less-minimalism-kyle-chayka.html" title="">“The Longing for Less,”</a> explores minimalism as a manifestation of civilization’s discontents, among other things.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Smarter Living: </strong>Organize your fridge the way pros do. <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/20/smarter-living/wirecutter/organize-your-fridge-and-keep-it-neat.html" title="">It saves both food and time.</a></p>, <h3 class="css-1b8te77 e1gnsphs0" id="link-15767e9b">And now for the Back Story on …</h3>, <h2 class="css-3ez4hu eoo0vm40" id="link-37dc33d3">The media spotlight</h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">One of the reasons Prince Harry and his wife, Meghan, cited in their decision <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/13/world/europe/queen-elizabeth-harry-meghan.html" title="">to step back from their royal duties</a> is the need for a more private life.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The desire is understandable. Paparazzi hound celebrities of all kinds, and the prince’s mother, Diana, died in Paris as her car raced away from photographers.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Fifty-one years ago, another hounded Brit took a very different approach.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">John Lennon had become a global star as the Beatles rose to extravagant heights of popularity, but in 1969, the band was <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-features/why-the-beatles-broke-up-113403/" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">inexorably breaking up</a>. The other Beatles’ lack of enthusiasm for Mr. Lennon’s devotion to the conceptual artist Yoko Ono added to the tension — and further whetted the public appetite for gossipy details.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">After the two married in March of that year, in a hastily arranged ceremony in Gibraltar, they knew there was no way to avoid being set upon by reporters and photographers.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.artsy.net/article/artsy-editorial-john-lennon-yoko-ono-invited-bed" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">So they invited them in.</a> They took up residence for days at a hotel in Amsterdam, holding open hours from 9 a.m. to 9 p.m., and later did the same in Montreal, using the “bed-ins” to promote global peace.</p>, <p class="css-ma92ss evys1bk0">That’s it for this briefing. See you next time. </p>, <p class="css-ma92ss evys1bk0">— Mike and Sofia</p>, <p class="css-jwz2nf etfikam0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Thank you</strong><br/>To Mark Josephson and Eleanor Stanford for the break from the news.Andrea Kannapell, the Briefings editor, wrote today’s Back Story. You can reach the team at <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="mailto:briefing+midnight@nytimes.com?subject=Briefing%20Feedback" title="">briefing@nytimes.com</a>.</p>, <p class="css-jwz2nf etfikam0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">P.S.</strong><br/>• We’re listening to “<a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/thedaily" title="">The Daily</a>.” Our latest episode is about President Bill Clinton’s impeachment trial. <br/>• Here’s today’s <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/crosswords/game/mini" title="">Mini Crossword puzzle</a>, and a clue: Guitarist’s time to shine (four letters). <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/crosswords" title="">You can find all our puzzles here</a>.<br/>• Nicole Perlroth, who covers cybersecurity for The Times, <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://t.co/K5OoeLUoUT" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">answered readers’ questions on Russian hacking</a> and the coming U.S. election in a Reddit AMA (Ask Me Anything).</p>, <p>Advertisement</p>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd" id="site-index-label">Site Index</h2>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-0">news</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-1">opinion</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-2">arts</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-3">living</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-4">more</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-subscribe-label">Subscribe</h3>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd">Site Information Navigation</h2>]
[<p>Advertisement</p>, <p>Supported by</p>, <h1 class="css-1s4ffep e1h9rw200" id="link-26e1be7d" itemprop="headline"><span>Impeachment, Coronavirus, Terry Jones: Your Wednesday Briefing</span></h1>, <p class="css-1fv7b6t e1jsehar1" itemprop="author" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">By<!-- --> <a class="css-brehiz e1jsehar0" href="https://www.nytimes.com/by/christopher-stanford"><span class="css-1baulvz last-byline" itemprop="name">Chris Stanford</span></a></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">(Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/morning-briefing" title="">sign-up</a>.)</p>, <p class="css-ma92ss evys1bk0">Good morning.</p>, <p class="css-ma92ss evys1bk0">We’re covering <strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">a late night in the Senate</strong>, the spread of <strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">the deadly</strong> <strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">coronavirus</strong> from China, and new details about the hacking of <strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Jeff Bezos’ cellphone</strong>.</p>, <h2 class="css-3ez4hu eoo0vm40" id="link-108e2284">Opening arguments at the impeachment trial</h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The House managers will begin their case against President Trump this afternoon, after a marathon Senate debate over rules for the trial ended early this morning. <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/22/us/politics/impeachment-trial.html" title="">Here’s what to watch for</a> when proceedings resume at 1 p.m. Eastern.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The oral arguments follow a series of party-line votes in which Senate Republicans <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/21/us/politics/senate-impeachment-republicans-democrats.html" title="">turned back Democrats’ attempts</a> to subpoena documents and compel White House officials to testify.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The debate lasted more than 12 hours, and became so acrimonious that Chief Justice John Roberts reminded the impeachment managers and the president’s lawyers to “remember where they are” and return to “civil discourse.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">The details:</strong> <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2020/01/22/us/politics/impeachment-articles-arguments.html" title="">Read excerpts from the articles of impeachment</a> and see how the parties diverge on the facts.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Closer look:</strong> The trial camerawork is basic, but <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/21/arts/television/trump-impeachment.html" title="">our TV critic found the ritual striking</a>.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Related:</strong> Mr. Trump criticized his political enemies, including “corrupt” Democrats, during <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/22/world/europe/trump-davos.html" title="">a wide-ranging news conference today</a> before he left Davos, Switzerland.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Another angle:</strong> Mr. Trump’s legal team has argued that abuse of power is not an impeachable offense, a position contradicted by many legal experts, <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/21/us/politics/barr-impeachment-abuse-of-power.html" title="">including, at one point, Attorney General William Barr</a>. In 2018, while in private practice, Mr. Barr wrote a memo saying that presidents who misused their authority were subject to impeachment.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">The Daily:</strong> <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/thedaily" title="">Today’s episode</a> is about last-minute changes in the rules of the trial.</p>, <h2 class="css-3ez4hu eoo0vm40" id="link-3e91edcc">Coronavirus reaches the U.S.</h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/22/health/china-who-coronavirus-sars-mers.html" title="">The World Health Organization is to meet today</a> to determine whether a deadly new respiratory illness should be declared a “public health emergency of international concern.” There is growing evidence that the disease can spread from person to person, although it’s unclear how easily.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The outbreak has killed at least 17 people and infected more than 400 in five countries, including the U.S. <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/21/health/what-is-coronavirus.html" title="">Here’s what we know about the coronavirus</a> and <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2020/01/21/world/asia/china-coronavirus-maps.html" title="">a map of where it has reached</a>.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Yesterday:</strong> A Washington State man who had recently traveled to Wuhan, China, where the virus originated, <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/21/health/cdc-coronavirus.html" title="">became the first confirmed case outside Asia</a>, federal health officials announced. Passengers arriving from Wuhan will now be screened at five U.S. airports.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Background:</strong> The virus is from the same family of viruses that caused outbreaks of SARS and MERS, which killed hundreds of people in dozens of countries. This infection seems less severe, however, according to one specialist.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Another angle:</strong> A Chinese health official warned today that <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/22/world/asia/china-coronavirus-travel.html" title="">the virus could spread further</a> during the weeklong Lunar New Year holiday, which begins Friday.</p>, <h2 class="css-3ez4hu eoo0vm40" id="link-7775504f">What is the U.S. military’s role in Africa?</h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/22/world/africa/shabab-kenya-terrorism.html" title="">A brazen attack by Shabab fighters on a base in Kenya</a> this month killed three Americans, the largest number of U.S. military-related fatalities in Africa in more than two years.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The Jan. 5 assault was largely overshadowed by the crisis with Iran, but it’s now drawing scrutiny from Congress and the Pentagon and raising questions about the American military’s mission in Africa, where it stations more than 5,000 troops.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Background:</strong> The Shabab, an East African terrorist group affiliated with Al Qaeda, have vowed to attack Americans wherever they can, although their campaign has largely been confined to Somalia.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">How we know:</strong> Our article is based on interviews with a dozen American military officials or other people briefed on the attack. Several spoke on the condition of anonymity to discuss a security failure that remains under investigation.</p>, <h2 class="css-3ez4hu eoo0vm40" id="link-7e268381">Channeling Barack Obama in Iowa</h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">With less than two weeks before the state’s caucuses, <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/22/us/politics/pete-buttigieg-iowa-caucus.html" title="">Pete Buttigieg is invoking the former president</a>, who won there in 2008 on his first run for the White House.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“The same state that took a chance on a young guy with a funny name, who a lot of folks didn’t think could win 12 years ago,” Mr. Buttigieg told a crowd in Council Bluffs, “this state could help us make history one more time.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Mr. Buttigieg is crisscrossing Iowa this week while three rivals — Senators Amy Klobuchar, Bernie Sanders and Elizabeth Warren — are in Washington for the impeachment trial.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Related: </strong>In a new documentary series,<strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10"> </strong><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/21/us/politics/hillary-clinton-bernie-sanders.html" title="">Hillary Clinton sharply criticizes Mr. Sanders</a> and declines to say whether she would endorse him if he won the Democratic nomination. “Nobody likes him, nobody wants to work with him, he got nothing done,” she says.</p>, <h3 class="css-1b8te77 e1gnsphs0" id="link-1cdf6cb3">If you have 11 minutes, this is worth it</h3>, <h2 class="css-3ez4hu eoo0vm40" id="link-5213aa4c">Acclaimed chef moves to the woods</h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Iliana Regan, above, created a Michelin-starred restaurant in Chicago and published a celebrated food memoir last summer.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">But her dream lies in northern Michigan, where she and her wife have turned a four-bedroom log cabin into an inn. There, Ms. Regan is attempting to <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/21/dining/iliana-regan-milkweed-inn.html" title="">redefine what it means to be an American chef</a>.</p>, <h3 class="css-1b8te77 e1gnsphs0" id="link-554e6082">Here’s what else is happening</h3>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Remembering Auschwitz: </strong>With the 75th anniversary of the liberation of the Nazi death camp approaching, world leaders including Vice President<strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10"> </strong>Mike Pence gathered in Jerusalem today to remember the Holocaust and speak out against anti-Semitism. <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/22/world/middleeast/auschwitz-liberation-anniversary.html" title="">Here are the latest updates</a>.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Jeff Bezos hacking:</strong> An analysis found with “medium to high confidence” that the Amazon chief’s cellphone was hacked after he <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/21/technology/bezos-phone-hacking.html" title="">received a video from an account reportedly belonging to the crown prince of Saudi Arabia</a>, according to people familiar with the investigation. The Saudi Embassy denied that the government was involved.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Grammys chief speaks:</strong> Deborah Dugan said she was suspended as the head of the Recording Academy, which runs the music awards, as retaliation for <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/21/arts/music/grammys-deborah-dugan-harassment.html" title="">uncovering a “boys’ club” mentality there</a>.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Snapshot: </strong>Above, Toksook Bay, Alaska, a remote village <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/21/us/census-alaska-native.html" title="">where the 2020 census began on Tuesday</a>. The Census Bureau hopes to overcome language barriers, isolation and distrust of government as it tallies minority groups that have long been undercounted.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">In memoriam:</strong> <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/22/arts/television/terry-jones-dead.html" title="">Terry Jones</a> was a member of the British comedy troupe Monty Python and also had success as a director, screenwriter and author. He died on Tuesday at 77.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">A Hall of Fame Yankee:</strong> Derek Jeter fell one vote shy of becoming <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/21/sports/baseball/hall-of-fame-vote-derek-jeter.html" title="">the second player elected unanimously to the Baseball Hall of Fame</a>. Larry Walker, who spent most of his career with the Colorado Rockies, was also voted in.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Late-night comedy: </strong>All eyes were on the Senate:<strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10"> </strong>“It’s a pivotal day in the history of the republic,” <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/22/arts/television/trump-impeachment-senate-clinton.html" title="">Stephen Colbert said</a>. “Soon, we will find out if breaking the law is illegal.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">What we’re reading: </strong><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.newyorker.com/magazine/2020/01/27/the-long-war-against-slavery" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">This article in The New Yorker</a>. Brent Staples, a member of The Times’s editorial board, calls it “a vivid new history” of “how slave rebellions (not white abolitionists) defeated slavery in the hell that was the Caribbean.”</p>, <h3 class="css-1b8te77 e1gnsphs0" id="link-7ded7ef4">Now, a break from the news</h3>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Cook: </strong>Make a batch of <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://cooking.nytimes.com/recipes/1020777-sopa-de-albondigas-mexican-meatball-soup" title="">sopa de albóndigas</a>, a Mexican meatball soup.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Watch:</strong> The actor Michael Sheen <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/20/arts/television/prodigal-son-michael-sheen-fox.html" title="">discussed his portrayal of a serial killer dad</a> on the Fox drama “Prodigal Son.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Listen:</strong> Aidy Bryant, the comedian and star of “Shrill,” shared <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/21/arts/television/aidy-bryant-shrill.html" title="">what she watched, read and listened to last week</a>.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Smarter Living: </strong><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/20/smarter-living/wirecutter/organize-your-fridge-and-keep-it-neat.html" title="">Organizing your fridge like a pro</a> saves both food and time.</p>, <h3 class="css-1b8te77 e1gnsphs0" id="link-15767e9b">And now for the Back Story on …</h3>, <h2 class="css-3ez4hu eoo0vm40" id="link-37dc33d3">The media spotlight</h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Prince Harry and his wife, Meghan, cited the need for a more private life in their decision <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/13/world/europe/queen-elizabeth-harry-meghan.html" title="">to step back from their royal duties</a>.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Paparazzi hound celebrities of all kinds, and the prince’s mother, Princess Diana, died in Paris as her car raced away from photographers.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Fifty-one years ago, another celebrity couple took a very different approach to intrusion.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">John Lennon had become a global star<span class="css-8l6xbc evw5hdy0"> </span>with the Beatles, but in 1969, <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-features/why-the-beatles-broke-up-113403/" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">the band was breaking up</a>. The other Beatles’ lack of enthusiasm for Lennon’s devotion to the conceptual artist Yoko Ono added to the tension — and further whetted the public appetite for gossipy details.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">After the two married in March of that year, in a hastily arranged ceremony in Gibraltar, they knew there was no way to avoid being set upon by reporters and photographers.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.artsy.net/article/artsy-editorial-john-lennon-yoko-ono-invited-bed" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">So they invited them in</a>. They took up residence for days at a hotel in Amsterdam, holding open hours from 9 a.m. to 9 p.m. They later did the same in Montreal, using the “bed-ins” to promote global peace.</p>, <p class="css-ma92ss evys1bk0">That’s it for this briefing. See you next time.</p>, <p class="css-ma92ss evys1bk0">— Chris</p>, <p class="css-jwz2nf etfikam0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Thank you</strong><br/>Mark Josephson and Eleanor Stanford provided the break from the news. Andrea Kannapell, the Briefings editor, wrote today’s Back Story. You can reach the team at <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="mailto:briefing@nytimes.com" title="">briefing@nytimes.com</a>. </p>, <p class="css-jwz2nf etfikam0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">P.S.</strong><br/>• We’re listening to “<a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/thedaily" title="">The Daily</a>.” Today’s episode is about the impeachment trial.<br/>• Here’s today’s <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/crosswords/game/mini" title="">Mini Crossword</a>, and a clue: Guitarist’s time to shine (four letters). <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/crosswords" title="">You can find all our puzzles here</a>.<br/>• Nicole Perlroth, who covers cybersecurity for The Times, <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://t.co/K5OoeLUoUT" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">answered readers’ questions about Russian hacking</a> and the 2020 election on Reddit.</p>, <p>Advertisement</p>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd" id="site-index-label">Site Index</h2>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-0">news</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-1">opinion</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-2">arts</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-3">living</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-4">more</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-subscribe-label">Subscribe</h3>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd">Site Information Navigation</h2>]
[<p>Advertisement</p>, <p>Supported by</p>, <h1 class="css-1s4ffep e1h9rw200" id="link-310e7644" itemprop="headline"><span>Wuhan Coronavirus, Brexit, Australian Open: Your Thursday Briefing</span></h1>, <p class="css-1ifw933 e1wiw3jv0" id="article-summary">Here’s what you need to know.</p>, <p class="css-1fv7b6t e1jsehar1" itemprop="author" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">By<!-- --> <a class="css-brehiz e1jsehar0" href="https://www.nytimes.com/by/melina-delkic"><span class="css-1baulvz" itemprop="name">Melina Delkic</span></a> and <a class="css-brehiz e1jsehar0" href="https://www.nytimes.com/by/andrea-kannapell"><span class="css-1baulvz last-byline" itemprop="name">Andrea Kannapell</span></a></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">(Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/morning-briefing" title="">sign-up</a>.)</p>, <p class="css-ma92ss evys1bk0">Good morning.</p>, <p class="css-ma92ss evys1bk0">We’re covering a transportation shutdown to prevent the spread of the<strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10"> Wuhan coronavirus, </strong>growing evidence of <strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Saudi involvement in the hacking</strong> of Jeff Bezos’s cellphone and a major step for <strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Brexit</strong>.</p>, <h2 class="css-3ez4hu eoo0vm40" id="link-10fed150">To contain virus, China brings Wuhan to a halt</h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">China said it was <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/22/world/asia/china-coronavirus-travel.html" title="">shutting down transportation from the city of Wuhan</a>, the site of an outbreak of a new coronavirus that has killed 17 people, infected hundreds and spread halfway around the world.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">As of 10 a.m. today, planes and trains leaving the city were to be canceled, and buses, subways and ferries within it suspended. Residents were urged not to leave.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The move could upend the plans of millions of Chinese citizens, who travel in huge numbers during the Lunar New Year holiday that officially begins on Friday. Experts have warned that the virus would proliferate during the mass travel period.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">World Health Organization: </strong>The group postponed a decision on whether the outbreak constitutes a <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/22/health/corona-virus-china.html" title="">“public health emergency of international concern.”</a> </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Context:</strong> The disease began in a seafood and poultry market in the city of 11 million, but is unclear from what kind of animal.</p>, <h2 class="css-3ez4hu eoo0vm40" id="link-3433877">Evidence mounts of Saudi hand in Bezos hack</h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Two prominent United Nations experts said that a WhatsApp account belonging to Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman appears to have been used to hack into the cellphone of Jeff Bezos in an effort to <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/22/world/middleeast/bezos-phone-hacked.html" title="">“influence, if not silence” reporting on the kingdom</a> by the newspaper he owns, The Washington Post.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The news came after a forensic analysis found with <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/21/technology/bezos-phone-hacking.html" title="">“medium to high confidence”</a> that the Amazon chief’s device was hacked after he received a video from that WhatsApp account, and that his phone began sending large volumes of data.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Months later, the tabloid publisher American Media Inc., whose head was courting the Saudis, reported that Mr. Bezos had been <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2019/02/07/technology/jeff-bezos-sanchez-enquirer.html" title="">having an extramarital affair</a>. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Response: </strong>After initial reports of the forensic analysis surfaced, the Saudi Embassy denied that the government was involved, calling the idea “absurd.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Pattern: </strong>Recent years have seen documentation that well-known Saudi dissidents have been hacked, and <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2019/03/17/world/middleeast/khashoggi-crown-prince-saudi.html" title="">social media in the kingdom manipulated</a> to amplify voices praising Crown Prince Mohammed and drown out his critics.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">At the time Mr. Bezos’ phone was hacked, The Post was publishing coverage critical of the kingdom. Jamal Khashoggi, the dissident Saudi writer who was later killed by a Saudi hit team in Istanbul, was a regular columnist and often criticized the crown prince.</p>, <h2 class="css-3ez4hu eoo0vm40" id="link-1e7aa373">Brexit: It’s suddenly smooth sailing</h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">If you thought this step in Britain’s yearslong drama over its departure from the European Union would be more complicated, you weren’t alone.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">But without any of the histrionics of the last few years, Parliament finalized a withdrawal bill and <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/22/world/europe/brexit-withdrawal-bill.html" title="">set the stage for Britain’s Jan. 31 departure</a> from the European Union. The Conservative Party’s overwhelming majority made this step essentially a formality.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Queen Elizabeth II is expected to approve the bill, and the European Parliament is expected to pass it with ease next week.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">What’s next: </strong>British and European representatives will have to negotiate a trade deal, something analysts say will be tougher and could take years.</p>, <h2 class="css-3ez4hu eoo0vm40" id="link-7779f2bd">Stock surging, Tesla passes $100 billion valuation</h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Investors have long been divided on Elon Musk’s electric car company, with many betting on its stock to fall. But since October, when the long-troubled company reported an unexpected quarterly profit, its fans have been lifting the price.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Today, their trading <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/22/business/elon-musk-tesla-bonus.html" title="">pushed Tesla’s stock to a record high of more than $590</a> per share, resetting the company’s value beyond $100 billion. That was a signal of faith in electric cars and a humbling moment for automakers with longer histories and greater productivity.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Musk’s reward: </strong>The milestone also started a clock on a huge windfall for Mr. Musk. If the valuation is sustained over at least six months, it could trigger a measure that allows him to buy some 1.69 million shares at about $350 each — a payout that could be worth nearly $400 million.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">A Trump bump: </strong>In a <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.cnbc.com/2020/01/22/trump-likens-elon-musk-to-thomas-edison-as-one-of-our-great-geniuses.html" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">CNBC interview from Davos, Switzerland, on Wednesday</a>, President Trump described Mr. Musk as “one of our great geniuses” and compared him to the inventor Thomas Edison.</p>, <h3 class="css-1b8te77 e1gnsphs0" id="link-60157767">If you have 6 minutes, this is worth it</h3>, <h2 class="css-3ez4hu eoo0vm40" id="link-2cf7ec19">The face of Australia’s climate-change deniers</h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">While observers and scientists around the world have pointed out the connections between climate change and the devastating wildfires in Australia, Craig Kelly, a Parliament member, has used this dark hour to <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/22/world/australia/fires-craig-kelly-climate-denial.html" title="">become the country’s climate-change denier in chief</a>.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">With posts and comments on his increasingly popular Facebook page that cherry-pick data and make unsupported claims, he has amassed a following in wide areas of the country. But even some members of his own party are trying to distance themselves.</p>, <h3 class="css-1b8te77 e1gnsphs0" id="link-554e6082">Here’s what else is happening</h3>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Impeachment: </strong>Seven House impeachment managers <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/22/us/politics/trump-impeachment.html?action=click&amp;module=Top%20Stories&amp;pgtype=Homepage" title="">began to present their cases against President Trump</a> in opening arguments, with Representative Adam Schiff accusing him of using his power “to cheat” in the election.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">South Korea: </strong><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/22/world/asia/south-korea-sex-change-soldier.html" title="">The military will discharge a soldier</a> who had undergone gender-reassignment surgery but wanted to remain in military service as a woman. Byeon Hee-su, a staff sergeant, must leave the army by Friday.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Snapshot: </strong>Above, Naomi Osaka serving at the Australian Open on Wednesday. She goes to tournaments <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/21/sports/tennis/naomi-osaka-australian-open.html" title="">“to win them, not to play finals or semifinals,”</a> her coach told our reporter. Tennis fans will be watching for a showdown between Ms. Osaka and Coco Gauff after Ms. Gauff advanced on Wednesday.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">In memoriam:</strong> <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/22/arts/television/terry-jones-dead.html" title="">Terry Jones</a> was a member of the British comedy troupe Monty Python and also had success as a director, screenwriter and author.
