He died on Tuesday at 77.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">What we’re reading: </strong><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://topics.amcham.com.tw/2020/01/story-of-q/" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">This explainer on a different measure of deliciousness</a>, from Taiwan Business Topics: “Today’s lesson,” writes our food correspondent Kim Severson, “is understanding the Q factor in Taiwanese food. It’s good-chewy.”</p>, <h3 class="css-1b8te77 e1gnsphs0" id="link-7ded7ef4">Now, a break from the news</h3>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Cook: </strong>If tres leches cake is not enough, <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://cooking.nytimes.com/recipes/1020805-seis-leches-cake" title="">add three more milks</a>.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Watch:</strong> The actor Michael Sheen <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/20/arts/television/prodigal-son-michael-sheen-fox.html" title="">discussed his portrayal of a serial killer dad</a> on the Fox drama “Prodigal Son.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Listen:</strong> Aidy Bryant, the comedian and star of “Shrill,” shared <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/21/arts/television/aidy-bryant-shrill.html" title="">what she watched, read and listened to last week</a>.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Smarter Living: </strong>Here’s <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/22/travel/how-to-tip-in-hotels.html" title="">how to tip hotel workers</a> when you travel.</p>, <h3 class="css-1b8te77 e1gnsphs0" id="link-15767e9b">And now for the Back Story on …</h3>, <h2 class="css-3ez4hu eoo0vm40" id="link-503bc80b">The frontline of an outbreak</h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">Javier C. Hernández, a correspondent in our Beijing bureau, is </em><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/21/world/asia/china-coronavirus-wuhan.html" title=""><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">reporting this week from the Chinese city of Wuhan</em></a><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">, the epicenter of the coronavirus outbreak. Mike Ives, on the Briefings team, spoke with Javier via Slack, a messaging service.</em></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Hi, Javier. What’s the mood in Wuhan right now?</strong></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Walking the streets, you definitely feel a sense of urgency is spreading. Lots of people are now wearing masks and avoiding big crowds. All of this is happening in the midst of the Lunar New Year holiday, so it has forced many families to rethink their plans. People are canceling dinners, staying home from work and hunkering down.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">It must be hard to avoid big crowds in a city of 11 million people.</strong></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Yes, it’s almost impossible to avoid crowds in a modern Chinese city. But Wuhan is trying to push people to take more precautions. When you get in a cab now, there are reminders about opening the window and wearing a mask. Some of the famous street markets are now totally empty, surrounded by signs warning about the virus.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Are you hearing any common sentiments in your interviews?</strong></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Several people told me about their memories of the SARS crisis of 2003, which killed hundreds of people in China. They’re worried this could erupt into a full-blown epidemic. Of course, others say they’re not very concerned and have faith that China can beat this. One common theme is people say they want the Chinese government to speak honestly about the severity of the outbreak — something that didn’t happen during SARS.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Are you taking any specific precautions, like wearing a mask?</strong></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Yes, at the advice of experts, my colleague Elsie Chen and I are washing our hands regularly and avoiding meat markets and hospital wards. We are wearing masks all the time. It’s a bit odd having that kind of barrier when you’re interviewing people on the street. But we’ve found that it is quickly becoming the norm in Wuhan. There are even videos now circulating of people giving New Year’s toasts with their masks on!</p>, <p class="css-ma92ss evys1bk0">That’s it for this briefing. See you next time.</p>, <p class="css-ma92ss evys1bk0">— Melina</p>, <p class="css-jwz2nf etfikam0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Thank you</strong><br/>To Mark Josephson and Eleanor Stanford for the break from the news. You can reach the team at <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="mailto:briefing+pm@nytimes.com?subject=Briefing%20Feedback" title="">briefing@nytimes.com</a>.</p>, <p class="css-jwz2nf etfikam0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">P.S.</strong><br/>• We’re listening to “<a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/thedaily" title="">The Daily</a>.” Our latest episode is about changes to the rules of President Trump’s impeachment trial.<br/>• Here’s our <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/crosswords/game/mini" title="">Mini Crossword</a>, and a clue: Guitarist’s time to shine (four letters). <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/crosswords" title="">You can find all our puzzles here</a>.<br/>• The Times <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytco.com/press/new-york-times-documentaries-at-sundance/" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">will premiere two documentaries</a> at the Sundance Film Festival this month.</p>, <p>Advertisement</p>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd" id="site-index-label">Site Index</h2>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-0">news</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-1">opinion</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-2">arts</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-3">living</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-4">more</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-subscribe-label">Subscribe</h3>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd">Site Information Navigation</h2>]
[<p>Advertisement</p>, <p>Supported by</p>, <h1 class="css-1s4ffep e1h9rw200" id="link-473f95e2" itemprop="headline"><span>Impeachment, Jeff Bezos, ‘West Side Story’: Your Wednesday Evening Briefing</span></h1>, <p class="css-1ifw933 e1wiw3jv0" id="article-summary">Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.</p>, <p class="css-1fv7b6t e1jsehar1" itemprop="author" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">By<!-- --> <a class="css-brehiz e1jsehar0" href="https://www.nytimes.com/by/remy-tumin"><span class="css-1baulvz" itemprop="name">Remy Tumin</span></a> and <a class="css-brehiz e1jsehar0" href="https://www.nytimes.com/by/marcus-payadue"><span class="css-1baulvz last-byline" itemprop="name">Marcus Payadue</span></a></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">(Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s </em><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="http://www.nytimes.com/newsletters/nyt-now-evening-briefing?module=inline" title=""><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">the sign-up</em></a><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">.) </em></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">Good evening. Here’s the latest.</em></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">1. Democrats began making their case </strong>for convicting President Trump and removing him from office.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">In the<a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/22/us/politics/impeachment-case-trump.html" title=""> first of their three days of presentations</a>, Representative Adam Schiff, the lead House prosecutor, quoted Alexander Hamilton repeatedly, and played video clips of current and former officials who testified before Congress last year, and a few of Mr. Trump himself.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Lashing out from Davos, Switzerland, Mr. Trump branded Mr. Schiff a “corrupt politician.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Today’s presentation will most likely go late into the night, as did Tuesday’s. <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/22/us/politics/trump-impeachment.html?" title="">Here’s the latest</a>. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Chief Justice John G. Roberts Jr. is presiding, and <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/22/us/chief-justice-john-roberts.html" title="">our Supreme Court correspondent analyzed the tough spot he’s in</a>, trying to “return to his day job with his reputation and that of his court undiminished by accusations of bias.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">2. What do the American people think?</strong></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">A team of our journalists talked to 81 people from nearly 30 states — Democrats, Republicans and independents of various occupations and ages — to find out how the impeachment trial is playing outside of the Beltway and newsrooms.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Refreshingly, <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2020/01/22/us/impeachment-voters.html" title="">not all the views we heard were partisan</a>.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">3. Three of the top presidential candidates </strong>are pinned down in Washington for the impeachment trial: Senators Bernie Sanders, Elizabeth Warren and Amy Klobuchar.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">But <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/22/us/politics/sanders-biden-democratic-polls.html" title="">a new national poll</a> shows Mr. Sanders, above last week in New Hampshire, with a lead. A second national survey conducted by a different pollster shows Joe Biden in front.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">In both polls, Elizabeth Warren finished third with 14 percent support. Pete Buttigieg and Michael Bloomberg traded fourth and fifth places. No other candidates had more than 5 percent in either.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Mr. Buttigieg has been camping out in Iowa, largely below the radar. And looking to <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/22/us/politics/pete-buttigieg-iowa-caucus.html" title="">former President Barack Obama’s playbook</a>.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">4.</strong> <strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">China said it was shutting down</strong> transportation from and within Wuhan, <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/22/world/asia/china-coronavirus-travel.html" title="">the epicenter of a deadly new coronavirus outbreak</a>. Above, the Hankou Railway Station.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">But the W.H.O. has <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/22/health/corona-virus-china.html" title="">postponed a decision</a> on whether the new outbreak is a global emergency.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The virus has killed at least 17 people, infected hundreds and spread halfway around the world.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The shutdown in Wuhan could upend the travel plans of millions of Chinese citizens over the Lunar New Year holiday, officially beginning Friday. Experts have warned that the virus would proliferate during the mass travel period.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">5. Two prominent U.N. rights experts</strong> said that Saudi Arabia’s crown prince <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/22/world/middleeast/bezos-phone-hacked.html" title="">hacked the cellphone of Jeff Bezos</a>, who owns Amazon and The Washington Post, to “influence, if not silence” The Post’s reporting on the Saudis. Above, the two in 2016.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">They were drawing on a forensic analysis done on Mr. Bezos’s behalf that found with <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/21/technology/bezos-phone-hacking.html" title="">“medium to high confidence”</a> that his device was hacked after he received a video in 2018 from Prince Mohammed bin Salman’s WhatsApp account. At the time, Jamal Khashoggi, the dissident Saudi writer who was later killed by a Saudi hit team in Istanbul, was a regular columnist.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">After Mr. Bezos received the video, the analysts said, his phone began sending large volumes of data. The relationship to a tabloid’s exposure of his extramarital affair is an open question.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The Saudi Embassy denied that the government was involved in the hacking, calling the idea “absurd.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">6. Tesla joined the $100 billion club.</strong></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/22/business/elon-musk-tesla-bonus.html" title="">The electric car company’s stock reached a record high — over $590</a> — resetting the company’s value beyond $100 billion. That was a signal of faith in electric cars and a humbling for automakers with longer histories and greater productivity.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The milestone also started a clock on a huge windfall for its founder, Elon Musk. If the valuation is sustained over at least six months, it could trigger a measure that allows him to buy some 1.69 million shares at about $350 each — a payout that could be worth nearly $400 million.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">7. The Department of Transportation </strong>is proposing a regulation overhaul around service animals that would <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/22/travel/service-animal-airplane.html" title="">ban all animals except dogs</a>.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The new rules would no longer force airlines to let animals like horses, above, accompany passengers who say they need them just for emotional support. An animal cannot just be brought aboard to make a passenger “feel better,” an official said.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">And in other animal news, </strong>officials in South Florida this week issued an unusual weather advisory: <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/21/us/frozen-iguanas-miami-weather.html" title="">iguana rain</a>. Overnight cold temperatures stunned the reptiles, which fell from trees, seemingly frozen or dead. Happily, they were reanimated after the sun rose.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">8. The singer and songwriter Yola </strong>describes her music as “genre-fluid” and “out of time.” That could have something to do with her formidable voice.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Her range stretches toward four octaves, “backed by the power to infuse whatever she sings with deep soul,” our music critic writes. Now she’s up for <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/22/arts/music/yola-grammys.html" title="">multiple Grammy Awards</a> on Sunday, including best new artist.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The dozens of categories include many musicians worth discovering. <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/22/arts/music/new-grammy-artists.html" title="">Listen to our critics’ picks here</a>.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The award show has been overshadowed by deep leadership issues. Deborah Dugan, the suspended chief of the Recording Academy, said she had been removed as <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/21/arts/music/grammys-deborah-dugan-harassment.html" title="">retaliation for uncovering a range of misconduct</a> at the academy.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">9. How do you reimagine “West Side Story” for 2020? </strong>By dismantling it and putting it back together again.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The three-year process of reimagining the 1957 musical masterpiece was intricate, physically demanding and sometimes maniacally ambitious.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">From its opening moments, the new production urges you to to discard any expectations, writes the culture editor for The Times Magazine.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/22/magazine/west-side-story.html" title="">She followed the cast and crew from rehearsal to Broadway</a>, where it opens Feb. 20.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">10. And finally, </strong>stress really does make your hair go gray.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">A new study of mice found that exposure to stressful events <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/22/science/gray-hair-stress.html" title="">damages the stem cells responsible for producing hair’s pigment</a>.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The researchers also found that the sympathetic nervous system, which triggers the fight-or-flight response, permanently depleted those same cells.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The takeaway: There are consequences to triggering a survival mechanism when the situation isn’t life-threatening. “Stress is a normal part of life, but there are situations where stress is helpful and situations where it is detrimental,” said a biologist.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Have a worry-free night.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">Your Evening Briefing is posted at 6 p.m. Eastern.</em></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">And don’t miss Your Morning Briefing. </em><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2018/briefing/global-morning-briefing-newsletter-signup.html" title=""><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">Sign up here</em></a><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0"> to get it by email in the Australian, Asian, European, African or American morning.</em></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">Want to catch up on past briefings? </em><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/series/us-evening-briefing" title=""><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">You can browse them here</em></a><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">.</em></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">What did you like? What do you want to see here? Let us know at </em><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="mailto:briefing@nytimes.com?subject=Evening%20Briefing%20Feedback" title=""><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">briefing@nytimes.com</em></a><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">.</em></p>, <p>Advertisement</p>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd" id="site-index-label">Site Index</h2>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-0">news</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-1">opinion</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-2">arts</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-3">living</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-4">more</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-subscribe-label">Subscribe</h3>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd">Site Information Navigation</h2>]
[<p>Advertisement</p>, <p>Supported by</p>, <p class="css-tsacue e6idgb70">Your Lead</p>, <h1 class="css-1s4ffep e1h9rw200" id="link-1f3830ff" itemprop="headline"><span>How Do People Become Homeless?</span></h1>, <p class="css-1ifw933 e1wiw3jv0" id="article-summary">People who have experienced homelessness share their stories. </p>, <p class="css-1fv7b6t e1jsehar1" itemprop="author" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">By<!-- --> <a class="css-brehiz e1jsehar0" href="https://www.nytimes.com/by/jill-cowan"><span class="css-1baulvz" itemprop="name">Jill Cowan</span></a> and <a class="css-brehiz e1jsehar0" href="https://www.nytimes.com/by/marie-tae-mcdermott"><span class="css-1baulvz last-byline" itemprop="name">Marie Tae McDermott</span></a></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">Good morning.</em></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">(Here’s the </em><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/newsletters/california-today" title=""><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">sign-up</em></a><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">, if you don’t already get California Today by email.)</em></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Here’s the latest dispatch from </strong><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10"><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/by/marie-tae-mcdermott" title="">Marie Tae McDermott</a></strong><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">, who is helping us answer readers’ </strong><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10"><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/series/your-lead" title="">questions about inequality in California</a></strong><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">:</strong></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Swati Verma, a reader in Cleveland, asked us, “Were the homeless always homeless? If not, what brought them to the state of homelessness?”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">To get a sense of some of the reasons people fall into homelessness, <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2019/11/14/reader-center/homeless-in-california.html" title="">we asked</a> people who have experienced it.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">In the dozens of responses we received, readers talked about injury, job loss, domestic violence, mental illness and addiction.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">According to <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="http://hsh.sfgov.org/wp-content/uploads/FINAL-PIT-Report-2019-San-Francisco.pdf" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">San Francisco’s 2019 homeless survey</a>, 26 percent of respondents cited job loss as the primary cause of homelessness, followed by drugs and alcohol (18 percent), eviction (13 percent) and mental illness (8 percent).</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">It’s clear that there is no one path to living on the streets. However, <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://docs.google.com/document/d/1DfFlUjoLeokvYRkH0bHalLzG4w0g39ndqoKOcQIDZIA/edit" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">African-Americans are disproportionately affected</a> as a result of institutional racism. Also, last year many unsheltered adults, over half in LA County and 31 percent in San Francisco, said they were homeless for the first time in their lives. As one reader put it: “We were both professional people and it happened to us.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10"><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">Below is a selection of readers’ stories in their own words. These readers were all homeless for a period of time but eventually obtained housing.</em></strong></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10"><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">[</em></strong><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2019/11/27/us/how-to-help-homeless-california.html" title=""><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">Read about what formerly homeless people said helped them</em></a><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">.]</em></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10"><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">Karla lived in her van with her family throughout high school. She later received a full scholarship to attend U.C. Berkeley.</em></strong></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">My father was a carpenter and my mother was an aide at a school library. During the Great Recession, my father was unable to find work and my mother’s hours were cut. They could no longer afford their mortgage. We had to sell most of our things to keep the power on for as long as possible. We lost power, heat and water, and in the end, we were all sleeping in one mattress in an empty home we knew any minute would be repossessed. One afternoon, we came home to discover we were locked out of the house, and that’s when we started living in our van. We went from having a normal life and stable housing, to being homeless. We didn’t always have food, and sometimes my mother would have to choose between gas and food. My parents would take us to the park or to the beach to play all day. In a way, it was a time when I saw my parents and enjoyed them the most.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">— Karla Garcia, 25, San Diego</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10"><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">Conor grew up in Palo Alto and as a result of substance addiction, he resorted to living on the streets for a year and a half.</em></strong></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">I was so caught up in my addictions that a big part of me didn’t want help. After first going to college, my partying got completely out of hand. I eventually was introduced to “harder” substances and became hopelessly addicted. I failed out and went through a series of rehabs to no avail. Eventually my degenerating behavior shut me off from friends and family, and after getting kicked off the last couch, I went to the streets.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">— Conor Kelly, 28, Santa Cruz</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10"><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">John spent a year living on the streets because of depression and a lack of alternatives.</em></strong></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">I have a master's degree in business and marketing. About a decade ago, I was the victim of a hate crime and did not get the treatment I needed. Instead, I self-medicated which led to some poor decisions, the loss of my business and ultimately homelessness. I spent just shy of a year on the streets of San Diego. I used to look at homelessness as a result of personal decisions. Now I see things much more clearly.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The experience of being homeless is the most devastating of my life. I was suffering from major depressive disorder, anxiety and PTSD before I was on the street and those disorders only became worse while homeless. The one thing that kept me alive was the leadership of the <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.voicesofourcity.org/" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">Voices of Our City Choir</a> and their belief in me.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">— John Brady, 54<em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">,</em> San Diego</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10"><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">Ethan used his college campus’s facilities while living out of his car.</em></strong></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">I was enrolled full time at Los Angeles City College and living solely off financial aid because my priority was finishing school as quickly as possible. Rent increased at my building and I had to choose between spending all my aid money on rent and not having money for anything else, or living in my car. I chose to live in my car for a year instead.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">I quickly realized how easy it is for someone to lose housing and how that can eventually lead to losing hope. It was a daily chore to remind myself that homelessness was a temporary situation.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">— Ethan Ward, 37, Los Angeles</p>, <h2 class="css-3ez4hu eoo0vm40" id="link-42fcec18">Here’s what else we’re following</h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">We often link to sites that limit access for nonsubscribers. We appreciate your reading Times coverage, but we also encourage you to support local news if you can.</em></p>, <p class="css-15hwz5e evys1bk0">A deadline extension and aggressive efforts to find victims have <strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">doubled the wildfire damage claims against Pacific Gas &amp; Electric</strong>. The number has reached 80,000. [<a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/21/business/energy-environment/pge-wildfire-victims.html" title="">The New York Times</a>]</p>, <p class="css-15hwz5e evys1bk0">A Washington State resident is infected with the <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2020/01/21/world/asia/china-coronavirus-maps.html" title="">Wuhan coronavirus</a>, the mysterious infection that has killed at least six people in Asia, U.S. officials said. They also announced <strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">expanded screening for the infection at major airports, including in L.A. and San Francisco</strong>. [<a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/21/health/cdc-coronavirus.html" title="">The New York Times</a>]</p>, <p class="css-15hwz5e evys1bk0">The Los Angeles <strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">police union has contributed $1 million to try to defeat George Gascón</strong>, the former San Francisco district attorney now challenging the incumbent Jackie Lacey in L.A. [<a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://theappeal.org/george-gascon-los-angeles-police-union/" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">The Appeal</a>]</p>, <p class="css-15hwz5e evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">In a rare interaction, a mountain lion attacked a 3-year-old boy at a park in Lake Forest,</strong> prompting an evacuation of the park and authorities to kill the lion. The boy’s father said he threw a backpack at the animal to get it to let go. [<a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.ocregister.com/2020/01/20/child-sustains-minor-injuries-in-lake-forest-mountain-lion-attack/" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">The Orange County Register</a>]</p>, <p class="css-15hwz5e evys1bk0">Workers at an <strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Amazon warehouse in</strong> <strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Fresno were seriously injured </strong>at almost three times the national average. [<a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.fresnobee.com/news/local/article238941159.html" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">The Fresno Bee</a>]</p>, <p class="css-15hwz5e evys1bk0">Uber is testing a feature in California that <strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">would allow some drivers to set their own fares</strong>. It’s part of an effort to show drivers have autonomy in response to the <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2019/09/11/technology/california-gig-economy-bill.html" title="">state’s new gig labor law</a>. [<a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.wsj.com/articles/uber-is-testing-a-feature-that-lets-some-california-drivers-set-fares-11579600801?shareToken=st958c869f36c34bfe9385c74fe9787905" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">The Wall Street Journal</a>]</p>, <p class="css-15hwz5e evys1bk0">The Los Angeles City Council passed a <strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">resolution urging Major League Baseball to strip the Astros and the Red Sox of their World Series titles</strong> and award them to … the Dodgers. [<a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.espn.com/mlb/story/_/id/28531536/resolution-urges-mlb-strip-astros-red-sox-world-series-titles-award-dodgers" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">ESPN</a>]</p>, <h2 class="css-3ez4hu eoo0vm40" id="link-1681830d">And Finally …</h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">So the 49ers are headed to the Super Bowl. They’ll be <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.washingtonpost.com/sports/2020/01/19/super-bowl-liv-when-where-what-you-need-to-know/?arc404=true" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">facing the Kansas City Chiefs</a> on Feb. 2 in Miami Gardens, Fla.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Of course — much the way the biggest narratives <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/news-event/awards-season" title="">surrounding the Academy Awards</a> have very little to do with the craft of filmmaking — the most interesting things about the game have little to do with the football.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">For example, I’ll be keeping an eye on the sidelines for the 49ers assistant coach Katie Sowers who is, as <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nbcnews.com/feature/nbc-out/katie-sowers-make-nfl-history-first-openly-gay-female-coach-n1119441" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">NBC News reported</a>, the first female and openly gay coach to go to the Super Bowl.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">And as my colleague <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/by/ken-belson" title="">Ken Belson</a> reported, now that the Niners are good, <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/17/sports/oakland-raiders-49ers.html?" title="">they’re going hard after abandoned Raiders fans</a>.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">California Today goes live at 6:30 a.m. Pacific time weekdays. Tell us what you want to see: </em><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="mailto:CAtoday@nytimes.com" title=""><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">CAtoday@nytimes.com</em></a><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">. Were you forwarded this email? </em><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/newsletters/california-today?module=inline" title=""><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">Sign up for California Today here.</em></a></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">Jill Cowan grew up in Orange County, graduated from U.C. Berkeley and has reported all over the state, including the Bay Area, Bakersfield and Los Angeles — but she always wants to see more. Berkeley.</em></p>, <p>Advertisement</p>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd" id="site-index-label">Site Index</h2>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-0">news</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-1">opinion</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-2">arts</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-3">living</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-4">more</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-subscribe-label">Subscribe</h3>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd">Site Information Navigation</h2>]
[<p>Advertisement</p>, <p>Supported by</p>, <p class="css-c2jxua e6idgb70"></p>, <h1 class="css-1j5ig2m e1h9rw200" id="link-7340c8c2" itemprop="headline"><span>Jeff Bezos’s Lesson: Beware WhatsApp Accounts Tied to M.B.S.</span></h1>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">Hello from Davos, Switzerland, where President Trump spent yesterday and today schmoozing with corporate leaders. More below. Today’s tidbit: Guess who’s in Davos? Wesley Snipes. (Want this in your inbox each morning? </em><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="http://p.nytimes.com/email/re?&amp;campaign_id=0&amp;instance_id=0&amp;segment_id=0&amp;user_id=f4577a56bcf773214e9a1d55b5fe9d24&amp;regi_id=0nl=dealbook&amp;emc=edit_dk_20180529" title=""><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">Sign up here</em></a><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">.)</em></p>, <h2 class="css-3ez4hu eoo0vm40" id="link-611fbcbe">Did the Saudis hack Jeff Bezos?</h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The late-night talk at Davos yesterday was dominated by the explosive revelation that the Amazon chief’s phone might have been hacked using a WhatsApp account tied to Saudi Arabia’s de facto ruler, Prince Mohammed bin Salman.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">People pulled out their phones</strong> at Anthony Scaramucci’s wine-tasting event — a staple of the Davos party circuit — to read <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2020/jan/21/amazon-boss-jeff-bezoss-phone-hacked-by-saudi-crown-prince" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">The Guardian’s report</a> that Mr. Bezos’s device had probably been compromised in 2018 after receiving malware from a WhatsApp account linked to Prince Mohammed.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Mr. Bezos’s phone had begun sending</strong> “<a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/21/technology/bezos-phone-hacking.html" title="">unusually large volumes of data</a>,” the NYT reports, citing a person familiar with the inquiry. Investigators hired by Mr. Bezos believed Prince Mohammed was used as a conduit “because the message would not raise suspicions if it came from him.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Consultants for Mr. Bezos have </strong><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10"><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2019/03/30/technology/jeff-bezos-saudis-hack.html" title="">accused the Saudis</a></strong> of hacking the billionaire’s phone, possibly leading to the seizure of compromising photographs and text messages that later appeared in The National Enquirer.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">The Saudi Embassy to the U.S. called the accusations “</strong><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://twitter.com/SaudiEmbassyUSA/status/1219792870389035008" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title=""><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">absurd</strong></a><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">” </strong> on Twitter last night. U.N. investigators were set to release a statement this morning “addressing serious allegations” about the hacking.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">What’s probably on other corporate leaders’ minds:</strong> Are they compromised, too? Business Insider notes <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.businessinsider.com/tim-cook-peter-thiel-rupert-murdoch-met-with-bin-salman-2020-1" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">the long list of people</a> Prince Mohammed met during his 2018 tour of the U.S., including Tim Cook of Apple, Mike Bloomberg and Rupert Murdoch. (There’s no indication that they’ve been hacked.)</p>, <h2 class="css-3ez4hu eoo0vm40" id="link-2d4f60b3">Trump makes the rounds at Davos</h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">President Trump was a big draw at the World Economic Forum in Switzerland yesterday, and he used the opportunity to <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/21/business/trump-davos.html" title="">glad-hand with corporate chieftains</a>, report Annie Karni, David Gelles and Peter Baker of the NYT.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">• He chatted with C.E.O.s like Brian Moynihan of Bank of America, Sundar Pichai of Alphabet and Marc Benioff of Salesforce, congratulating them on their companies’ stock prices.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">• “After his speech, he met with the International Business Council, and personally greeted every chief executive, according to attendees. The meeting was less about substance than socializing, one attendee said, as Mr. Trump grilled corporate leaders about whether they liked his speech.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">• What didn’t come up: <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/22/us/politics/impeachment-trial.html" title="">the impeachment trial</a> that started in earnest in the Senate yesterday.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">• One bit of gossip: Mr. Trump had breakfast this morning with Tim Cook of Apple and other corporate leaders.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Greta Thunberg rebuked Mr. Trump, albeit indirectly</strong>, in a speech that followed his yesterday. <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/21/climate/greta-thunberg-trump-davos.html" title="">She dismissed critics</a> of her climate-change activism, including those who say, “Don’t be so pessimistic” — a reference to a line in Mr. Trump’s address.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">The Davos roundup:</strong></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">• The Swiss police said they had <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.ft.com/content/98deb6ee-3c38-11ea-a01a-bae547046735" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">detained two Russians</a> in August on suspicions that the men, posing as plumbers, were spies trying to plant surveillance equipment.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">• An official at the gathering urged The Economist to <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.linkedin.com/posts/monck_i-really-hope-the-economist-reconsiders-its-activity-6623318078757355520-S8wS/" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">drop Philip Morris International</a> as the sponsor for one of its events there, saying that “nicotine-peddling death cults” skulked around the edges of the event in search of “reputation laundering opportunities.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">• Mr. Benioff of Salesforce said that “stakeholder capitalism,” in which companies consider more than just shareholder returns in their business decisions, was at a “<a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.cnbc.com/2020/01/21/stakeholder-capitalism-has-reached-a-tipping-point-says-salesforce-ceo-benioff.html" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">tipping point</a>.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">• Meet the man who <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.cnbc.com/2020/01/21/world-economic-forum-meet-the-man-feeding-the-davos-elite.html" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">runs the World Economic Forum’s kitchens</a>.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">• Does Davos have <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/21/opinion/davos-credibility.html" title="">a credibility problem</a>?</p>, <h2 class="css-3ez4hu eoo0vm40" id="link-24992565">The fight over European digital taxes isn’t over</h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">France may have <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/21/business/france-US-digital-tax.html" title="">reached a truce with the U.S.</a> over a proposal to tax American internet companies, but other European countries haven’t, and that could lead to more trans-Atlantic trade battles.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Paris officials suspended their plans for a digital tax</strong> on the likes of Amazon and Facebook. In return, Washington postponed retaliatory tariffs on a range of French goods, including luxury items, in what some had taken to calling the “<a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/20/style/brune-poirson-fashion-france.html" title="">handbag war</a>.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">But France is not the only European country unhappy</strong> with American tech giants’ avoiding taxes on local operations by shifting profits. Britain and Italy appear to be moving ahead with their own digital tariffs, and London <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.ft.com/content/c80079ca-3c61-11ea-a01a-bae547046735" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">plans to introduce one in April</a>. (It’s expected to raise about 500 million pounds, or about $650 million, a year.)</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin </strong><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.wsj.com/articles/mnuchin-warns-u-k-italy-over-digital-tax-plans-11579598943" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title=""><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">warned London and Rome</strong></a> that they would “find themselves faced with President Trump’s tariffs” if they moved ahead, the WSJ reports.</p>, <h2 class="css-3ez4hu eoo0vm40" id="link-25456aad">The 737 Max may not fly again anytime soon</h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Boeing said yesterday that it did not expect regulatory approval for the troubled plane <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/21/business/boeing-737-max.html" title="">until at least June or July</a>, Natalie Kitroeff of the NYT reports. That’s further acknowledgment from the plane maker that its troubles are far from over.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">The announcement came after the discovery of more potential problems</strong> with the 737 Max, including with wiring, on top of the problematic software suspected to have played a role in two deadly crashes.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">But Boeing is being conservative here</strong>, Ms. Kitroeff writes, citing three people familiar with the matter, to placate airline customers who have been annoyed with previous missed deadlines. If the F.A.A. finds no more problems with the 737 Max, the plane could technically start flying again in the spring.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">What needs to happen next for that to materialize:</strong></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">• Flight simulator tests by international regulators.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">• A certification test flight with the F.A.A., which could happen by the end of February.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">• More flight simulator training, even after regulatory approval.</p>, <h2 class="css-3ez4hu eoo0vm40" id="link-3331c850">A teeth-straightening company’s tough legal tactics</h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">SmileDirectClub has gained prominence for its direct-to-consumer teeth-straightening kits, riding its popularity to a $1.3 billion I.P.O. last year. But the company maintains its sterling reputation with <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/21/technology/smiledirectclub-smile-nda.html" title="">hardball legal tactics</a>, Erin Griffith and Peter Eavis of the NYT report.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">• When some customers requested refunds because the company’s devices didn’t work, SmileDirectClub asked them to sign confidentiality agreements.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">• “The agreement prohibited the customers from telling anyone about the refund and required them to delete negative social media comments and reviews,” Ms. Griffith and Mr. Eavis report.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">• “SmileDirectClub’s actions underline the risks of ordering products from young companies that are bringing start-up-style ‘disruption’ to health,” the reporters note.</p>, <h2 class="css-3ez4hu eoo0vm40" id="link-60b03355">A top shareholder activist passes the torch</h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Jeff Ubben, the founder of ValueAct Capital, is <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.ft.com/content/555576a0-3c93-11ea-a01a-bae547046735" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">stepping down as the company’s C.E.O.</a>, Lindsay Fortado of the FT reports. It’s a changing of the guard at one of the biggest activist hedge funds around.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Mr. Ubben will hand off </strong> to his longtime protégé, Mason Morfit. He already gave Mr. Morfit the title of chief investment officer nearly three years ago.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">The departing C.E.O. will still oversee the ValueAct Spring Fund</strong>, a roughly $1 billion fund that promotes social change.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Mr. Ubben is regarded as one of the most influential activist investors</strong>, having taken aim at Citigroup, Microsoft and others. The bankers and lawyers who defend boardrooms against activists have also praised him over the years, telling Michael that they respected his more constructive, less shouty approach.</p>, <h2 class="css-3ez4hu eoo0vm40" id="link-7c091e00">The speed read</h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Deals</strong></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">• Xerox is reportedly considering nominating up to 11 candidates for HP’s 12-member board, in what would be a sharp escalation of its hostile takeover bid. (<a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.wsj.com/articles/xerox-to-nominate-as-many-as-11-directors-to-hp-board-11579661836" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">WSJ</a>)</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">• A C.E.O. of the European tech giant SAP said companies could face more activism from employees and consumers. (<a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2020-01-21/sap-says-companies-will-see-spread-of-activism-from-stakeholders" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">Bloomberg</a>)</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">• The venture capital firm Lux Capital is fighting a court battle against early investors over a deal in which they sold back their stakes in the company. (<a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.ft.com/content/a82e3202-3871-11ea-a6d3-9a26f8c3cba4" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">FT</a>)</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Politics and policy</strong></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">• The Supreme Court denied requests by Democratic lawmakers to speed up the appeals process for challenges to the Affordable Care Act. (<a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.wsj.com/articles/supreme-court-declines-to-fast-track-appeals-on-affordable-care-act-11579617712" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">WSJ</a>)</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">• President Trump said he planned to expand his travel ban to include countries such as Nigeria and Belarus. (<a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/21/us/politics/trump-travel-ban.html" title="">NYT</a>)</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">• Meet Representative David Cicilline, the House Democrat taking on tech giants like Facebook and Google. (<a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.politico.com/news/magazine/2020/01/21/silicon-valley-congress-big-tech-anti-trust-legislation-100217" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">Politico</a>)</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Tech</strong></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">• Britain unveiled tougher regulations for children’s online privacy, overriding objections from internet giants. (<a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/21/business/britain-children-privacy-protection-kids-online.html" title="">NYT</a>)</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">• Netflix’s subscriber increases in the U.S. fell below expectations in the fourth quarter, but international growth exceeded them. (<a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/21/business/media/netflix-q4-2019-earnings-nflx.html" title="">NYT</a>)</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">• The British food delivery service Deliveroo is in limbo as a $575 million investment from Amazon remains under regulatory scrutiny. (<a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.ft.com/content/c20f6848-3c4b-11ea-a01a-bae547046735" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">FT</a>)</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">• Officials in Suzhou, China, used facial recognition software to shame people who wore pajamas in public. (<a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/21/business/china-pajamas-facial-recognition.html" title="">NYT</a>)</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Best of the rest</strong></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">• The <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/21/health/cdc-coronavirus.html" title="">U.S. reported its first case</a> of the coronavirus that has <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/21/world/asia/china-coronavirus-wuhan.html" title="">swept through China and other Asian countries</a>. (NYT)</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">• German prosecutors are investigating Mitsubishi over accusations of cheating on emissions tests. (<a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2020-01-21/tyson-fights-vegan-craze-with-push-for-sustainable-protein" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">Bloomberg</a>)</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">• David Solomon is Goldman Sachs’s C.E.O. [<p class="css-15x8ju0 e6idgb70"></p>, <h1 class="css-1rtkyej e1h9rw200" id="link-26c8e972" itemprop="headline"><span>China’s Battle With a Deadly Coronavirus, in Photos</span></h1>, <p class="css-1npvhc5 e1wiw3jv0">Here are the latest images as the country confronts a major public health crisis.</p>, <p class="css-14xmeol"><span class="css-1f9pvn2 asia">A man believed to be Hong Kong’s first Wuhan coronavirus patient being treated on Wednesday.</span><span class="emkp2hg2 css-1fxp258 e1z0qqy90" itemprop="copyrightHolder"><span class="css-1ly73wi e1tej78p0">Credit...</span><span><span>Lam Yik Fei for The New York Times</span></span></span></p>, <p>Supported by</p>, <p class="css-1fv7b6t e1jsehar1" itemprop="author" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">By<!-- --> <span class="css-1baulvz last-byline" itemprop="name">The New York Times</span></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The spread of a <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/article/what-is-coronavirus.html" title="">mysterious respiratory virus</a> has prompted the authorities to limit travel in cities in China, including Wuhan, where <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/23/world/asia/china-coronavirus.html" title="">the disease was first found</a> last month. It has since spread across the nation and to at least 10 other countries.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The outbreak intensified just before the start of the Lunar New Year holiday on Friday, when hundreds of millions of people were traveling across China. Many people who work and live in Wuhan and the surrounding area are now spending time with their families in other parts of the country. Epidemiologists fear that could make the virus harder to contain.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Here’s a look at the public health crisis in photographs.</p>, <h2 class="css-lsf2nb eoo0vm40" id="link-3293ef27">Tuesday</h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Disinfecting a Thai Airways jet near Suvarnabhumi Airport in Thailand.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Hong Kong’s chief executive, Carrie Lam, center, during a news conference on Tuesday.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Medical workers at a checkpoint near the border of Hubei Province on Tuesday.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Teachers and students at a Chinese school in Quezon City, Philippines. So far, there have been no deaths from coronavirus outside China.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">A hospital under construction in Wuhan that will treat people infected with the coronavirus.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Celebrating the Lunar New Year in Macau.</p>, <h2 class="css-lsf2nb eoo0vm40" id="link-64fb55d">Monday</h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Normally busy roads in Wuhan, a city of 11 million people, have become deserted.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Exercising outside while Wuhan remained on lockdown.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Chinese wearing protective masks during the Lunar New Year festival in Beijing.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The construction site of a hospital being built in Wuhan to treat patients who have contracted the virus.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Security officers standing guard at Tiananmen Gate in Beijing.</p>, <h2 class="css-lsf2nb eoo0vm40" id="link-6a44263">Sunday</h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">A shopping district in Hong Kong. On Sunday, the government said it would bar residents of Hubei Province, which includes Wuhan, from entering Hong Kong until further notice.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Workers making dumplings in Beijing.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">A near-empty street in Beijing. Chinese officials greatly expanded a travel ban in an effort to contain the virus. The youngest confirmed case involved a 9-month-old girl in the capital city.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Riding the subway in Beijing.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">People with masks leaving a store after stocking up on food at a market in Wuhan.</p>, <h2 class="css-lsf2nb eoo0vm40" id="link-282b5074">Saturday</h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Festivities for Lunar New Year at the Wong Tai Sin temple in Hong Kong. The city has canceled new year celebrations.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Health workers waiting to check the temperature of people entering a subway station in Beijing.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Masks were ubiquitous on trains and other public places in Hong Kong.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">China celebrated a somber Lunar New Year in Beijing.</p>, <h2 class="css-lsf2nb eoo0vm40" id="link-677b605">Friday</h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">A site for the construction of a field hospital to treat patients with the coronavirus in Wuhan.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The intensive care unit at Zhongnan Hospital in Wuhan.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Hankou Hospital in Wuhan was overwhelmed by residents and their families.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Lining up in Hong Kong to get free vitamin C tablets and bottles of hand sanitizer.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">As quarantine efforts expanded, health checkpoints were set up on a highway in Wuhan.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">A meat vendor in Wuhan.</p>, <h2 class="css-lsf2nb eoo0vm40" id="link-4bab54ce">Thursday</h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">A railway station in Beijing. China’s expanded restrictions on travel will apply to tens of millions of people.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">A supermarket in Wuhan, where masks are now a part of everyday clothing.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">A mall in Wuhan. The provincial capital of Hubei is usually busy during the holiday season.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">A security guard disinfecting a park in Wuhan.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Security officers guarding an entrance to the closed Hankou Railroad Station in Wuhan. Public transit and outbound trains were to stop service at midnight.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">A train from Shanghai to Wuhan. Services are usually packed as the Lunar New Year approaches.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Staff members checking the temperature of passengers after a train from Wuhan arrived in Hangzhou, in China’s eastern Zhejiang Province.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Arriving at the nearly deserted Wuhan station.</p>, <h2 class="css-lsf2nb eoo0vm40" id="link-673ffddf">Wednesday</h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">A hospital worker washing the entrance to the Wuhan Medical Treatment Center, which handled some coronavirus patients.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Officials screening arrivals in Hazrat Shahjalal International Airport in Dhaka, Bangladesh.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Travelers arriving at Los Angeles International Airport from China.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Visitors at the Venetian casino hotel resort in Macau, after the region reported its first case of coronavirus.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Medical staff members wearing protective suits at Zhongnan Hospital in Wuhan.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Workers producing face masks at a factory in Handan, in China’s northern Hebei Province.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Hankou train station in Wuhan.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The Huanan Seafood Market in Wuhan, above on Jan. 17, has been disinfected and closed after it was linked to the coronavirus outbreak.</p>, <p>Advertisement</p>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd" id="site-index-label">Site Index</h2>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-0">news</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-1">opinion</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-2">arts</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-3">living</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-4">more</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-subscribe-label">Subscribe</h3>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd">Site Information Navigation</h2>]
