itemprop="name">Protesters Are Fleeing Hong Kong. A Secret Network Is Helping Them.</h2>, <p class="css-1adcpyk">3:10</p>, <h2 aria-hidden="true" class="css-svrccc eoo0vm40" itemprop="name">‘I’m Worried That I Will Die:’ Hong Kong Protesters Write Final Goodbyes</h2>, <p class="css-1adcpyk">1:37</p>, <h2 aria-hidden="true" class="css-svrccc eoo0vm40" itemprop="name">More Unrest as Hong Kong Protesters Defy Mask Ban</h2>, <p class="css-1adcpyk">3:22</p>, <h2 aria-hidden="true" class="css-svrccc eoo0vm40" itemprop="name">Hong Kong Police Shot a Protester at Point-Blank Range. We Break Down What Happened.</h2>, <p class="css-1adcpyk">8:01</p>, <h2 aria-hidden="true" class="css-svrccc eoo0vm40" itemprop="name">She’s a Protester, He’s a Police Officer: In Hong Kong, Spouses Spar Too</h2>, <p class="css-1adcpyk">3:09</p>, <h2 aria-hidden="true" class="css-svrccc eoo0vm40" itemprop="name">Examining Li Peng’s Tiananmen Legacy as the ‘Butcher of Beijing’</h2>, <p class="css-1adcpyk">5:12</p>, <h2 aria-hidden="true" class="css-svrccc eoo0vm40" itemprop="name">How Kim Jong-un Smuggled Luxury Mercedes to North Korea</h2>, <p class="css-1adcpyk">1:15</p>, <h2 aria-hidden="true" class="css-svrccc eoo0vm40" itemprop="name">Scenes From the Protest in Hong Kong</h2>, <p>Advertisement</p>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd" id="site-index-label">Site Index</h2>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-0">news</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-1">opinion</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-2">arts</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-3">living</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-4">more</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-subscribe-label">Subscribe</h3>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd">Site Information Navigation</h2>]
[<p>Advertisement</p>, <p>Supported by</p>, <h1 class="css-1s4ffep e1h9rw200" id="link-188275b2" itemprop="headline"><span>Coronavirus Death Toll Climbs in China, and a Lockdown Widens</span></h1>, <p class="css-1ifw933 e1wiw3jv0" id="article-summary">At least 25 people have died and more than 800 have been sickened by the mysterious illness, health officials said. The travel restrictions imposed on Wuhan were extended to at least four more cities. </p>, <p class="css-1fv7b6t e1jsehar1" itemprop="author" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">By<!-- --> <span class="css-1baulvz last-byline" itemprop="name">The New York Times</span></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">This briefing has ended. Read about developments in the </em><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/25/world/asia/china-coronavirus.html" title=""><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">coronavirus outbreak here</em></a><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">. </em></p>, <h3 class="css-k42qd2 e1gnsphs0">Here’s what you need to know:</h3>, <h2 class="css-3ez4hu eoo0vm40" id="link-51ddfd7f">The death toll and number of cases in China spikes.</h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The Chinese National Health Commission reported early Friday that there have been 25 deaths from and 830 cases of the coronavirus, a sharp increase. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The death toll increased by more than a half-dozen in 24 hours, while the number of confirmed cases jumped by more than 200.<span class="css-8l6xbc evw5hdy0"> </span></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Earlier, the first death was confirmed outside the virus epicenter. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">A patient died in the province of Hebei — more than 600 miles north of the city where the outbreak began — after contracting the coronavirus, the provincial authorities <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="http://www.hebwst.gov.cn/index.do?id=394917&amp;templet=content&amp;cid=14" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">announced</a> on Thursday. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The victim was an 80-year-old man who had lived in the city of Wuhan, where the outbreak originated, for more than two months, according to Hebei’s provincial health department. Wuhan is a <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/23/business/wuhan-coronavirus.html" title="">major port city of 11 million</a> in the province of Hubei, where all of the 17 previously reported deaths have taken place. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The victim died on Wednesday, but officials did not confirm that he had died of the coronavirus until Thursday, the Hebei provincial announcement said.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The announcement did not say when the man had returned to Hebei Province from Wuhan, but said that he had developed chest tightness and difficulty breathing after his return. Like many of the other confirmed victims of the virus, he appeared to have <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/23/world/asia/coronavirus-victims-wuhan.html" title="">other underlying health issues</a>: After being admitted to a hospital, he also was treated for high blood pressure, chronic bronchitis and emphysema, the authorities said.</p>, <h2 class="css-3ez4hu eoo0vm40" id="link-7bed71fa">World Health Organization decides not to declare a global health emergency — yet.</h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">After two days of deliberations, an emergency committee convened by the World Health Organization <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/23/health/china-virus-who-emergency.html?action=click&amp;module=Top%20Stories&amp;pgtype=Homepage" title="">decided not to declare a global health emergency</a> — but planned to meet again within 10 days, acknowledging the “urgency” of the situation.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The committee had first planned to issue a recommendation on Wednesday about whether to declare an emergency (the decision ultimately falls to the W.H.O.’s director general). Such a declaration would give the W.H.O. broader authority to shape different countries’ responses. But committee members were split.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">On Thursday, after news of Wuhan’s travel restrictions and the increased death count emerged, the committee met again, and decided not to recommend the declaration. Several members thought it was “still too early,”<span class="css-8l6xbc evw5hdy0"> </span>the W.H.O. <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.who.int/news-room/detail/23-01-2020-statement-on-the-meeting-of-the-international-health-regulations-(2005)-emergency-committee-regarding-the-outbreak-of-novel-coronavirus-(2019-ncov)" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">said in a news release</a>. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Agency officials explained that although the disease has reached beyond China, the number of cases in other countries is still relatively small, and the disease does not seem to be spreading within those countries. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“At this time, there is no evidence of human to human transmission outside China,” Dr. Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus, the W.H.O.’s director general, said at a news conference in Geneva. “That doesn’t mean it won’t happen.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“Make no mistake,” he said. “This is an emergency in China, but it has not yet become a global health emergency. It may yet become one.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Only five global public health emergency declarations have been made in the past. The decisions are fraught, with health authorities wary of causing panic, or of suggesting that governments cannot handle outbreaks on their own.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Still, the W.H.O. called on the Chinese government to share more information on how it was handling the crisis.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"></p>, <h2 class="css-3ez4hu eoo0vm40" id="link-6d4cdae6">The authorities suspend travel from more cities, affecting millions.</h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The authorities expanded travel restrictions to several Chinese cities near Wuhan hours after announcing that the death toll and number of cases had risen sharply. Currently, at least 18 victims have been confirmed dead and more than 600 infected, according to Chinese officials.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The restrictions on train and other forms of travel will apply to tens of millions of people and come just days before the Lunar New Year holiday, when hundreds of millions of people travel around and out of the country. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The Chinese authorities on Thursday morning closed off Wuhan by canceling flights and trains leaving the city, and suspending buses, subways and ferries within it. Late on Thursday, the local authorities also <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://xhpfmapi.zhongguowangshi.com/vh512/share/8824853" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">announced</a> that they would suspend for-hire vehicles and limit taxis, beginning at noon on Friday. </p>, <h1 class="g-headline" id="g-inlineguide-headline">The Coronavirus Outbreak</h1>, <h2 class="g-inlineguide-list-header g-optimize-type">What do you need to know? Start here.</h2>, <p class="g-inlineguide-date">Updated Feb. 10, 2020</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Roughly 30,000 people fly out of Wuhan on an average day, according to air traffic data. Many more leave using ground transportation like trains and cars. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">By evening, officials planned to also close off Huanggang, a city of seven million about 30 miles east of Wuhan, shut rail stations in the nearby city of Ezhou, which has about one million residents, and impose travel restrictions on the smaller cities of Chibi and Zhijiang.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">In Huanggang, public transportation and departing trains stopped at midnight. Residents are not allowed to leave the city without special permission, according to a government statement. In Ezhou, all rail stations were to be closed.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Separately, the provincial authorities in Hubei <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="http://www.hubei.gov.cn/zhuanti/2020/gzxxgzbd/zxtb/202001/t20200123_2014602.shtml" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">announced</a> late Thursday some restrictions for the entire province, not just specific cities. Travel agencies are prohibited from taking customers and organizing tours, for example, and business trips are being suspended. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Schools throughout the province, which have breaks scheduled for the Lunar New Year holiday, will postpone their post-break start dates indefinitely. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The new virus, which first emerged at the end of December, has sickened people in Taiwan, Vietnam, Japan, Thailand, Singapore, South Korea and the United States. It has raised the specter of a repeat of the SARS epidemic, which broke out in China in 2002 and 2003 and spread rapidly while officials obscured the seriousness of the crisis. That virus eventually killed more than 800 people worldwide.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">In Beijing, the government said it would cancel large public gatherings for the holiday, including fairs at temples that usually draw shoulder-to-shoulder crowds, and the Forbidden City, a popular tourist attraction in the heart of the capital, will close starting on Saturday. </p>, <h2 class="css-3ez4hu eoo0vm40" id="link-65cb2ea1">What is a coronavirus and how dangerous is it?</h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/21/health/what-is-coronavirus.html" title="">Coronaviruses</a> are named for the spikes that protrude from their membranes, which resemble the sun’s corona. They can infect both animals and people, and cause illnesses of the respiratory tract, ranging from the common cold to severe conditions like SARS.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Symptoms of infection include a high fever, difficulty breathing and lung lesions. Milder cases may resemble the flu or a bad cold, making detection difficult. The incubation period — the time from exposure to the onset of symptoms — is believed to be about two weeks.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">While the headlines are alarming, health experts cautioned that it was too early to gauge the severity of the outbreak. There are too many unknowns: Where did it start? How easily does it spread? How does it compare to other coronaviruses, like SARS?</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Dr. William Schaffner, a specialist in infectious diseases at Vanderbilt University Medical Center, said the illness should be viewed in perspective. While a new virus spreading internationally gets more attention, the much more common influenza virus is the bigger hazard for most people, he said. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“If I look at this winter respiratory season, influenza is going to cause many more illnesses and more deaths than this coronavirus,” he said. “It’s one of those circumstances where, if familiarity doesn’t breed contempt, it certainly breeds a certain nonchalance.”</p>, <h2 class="css-3ez4hu eoo0vm40" id="link-9aad3f7">Where is the virus spreading?</h2>, <h2 class="css-zd32qr">Wuhan Coronavirus Map: Tracking the Spread of the Outbreak</h2>, <p class="css-1uuihdo">The virus has sickened tens of thousands of people in China and a number of other countries.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">As anxiety about the virus has grown, governments around the world have taken precautions to isolate anyone displaying symptoms, though several cases have proved not to be the coronavirus.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Health officials in the United States said on Thursday that <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/23/us/united-states-coronavirus-cases.html" title="">there could be a second infection</a> in the country, after the authorities in Washington State confirmed earlier this week that a man there had fallen sick with the Wuhan coronavirus. The second possible patient was in Brazos County, Texas, where officials said they were keeping a patient isolated at home while they did additional testing.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Vietnam’s Ministry of Health <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.moh.gov.vn/web/guest/tin-noi-bat/-/asset_publisher/hwUjUacn23Hf/content/hai-ca-duong-tinh-ncov-ang-ieu-tri-tai-bv-cho-ray" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">announced</a> on Thursday that it had confirmed two cases of the coronavirus, in two male Chinese patients.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">In Mexico, two out of five potential coronavirus cases were officially ruled out by the Health Ministry on Thursday after comprehensive tests were conducted, according to state and federal government officials.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">A health official said that one of the patients, a 57-year-old professor, had been diagnosed with a common cold.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The three other cases, in the western state of Jalisco, were under observation and were being tested, according to the Health Ministry report. The patients include a 42-year old man who returned to Mexico from Wuhan on Jan. 10, and two other women who had contact with him.</p>, <h2 class="css-3ez4hu eoo0vm40" id="link-14aa6667">Residents in Wuhan are nervous. Some are also angry.</h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Across Wuhan on Thursday, residents — some wearing masks, some sniffing or coughing — visited hospitals and clinics seeking treatment. In interviews with a New York Times correspondent in the city, some said they were angry about the sudden lockdown. Others said they were confused by the restrictions.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Outside the Wuhan No. 3 Hospital, Yang Lin, said she had come to the hospital to see if a sniffling cold she had might be the coronavirus. After a quick check, the doctors told her not to worry. But she was not reassured.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“They said it was just a common cold, and told me to get some medicine and go home,” Ms. Yang, 28, said. “But how am I to know? They didn’t even take my temperature. It’s just not responsible.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The outbreak is testing Wuhan’s health care system. Several Wuhan residents said on social media websites that they had gone from hospital to hospital, waiting in lines for hours, only to be sent home with medicine and instructions to seek further treatment later if symptoms persisted in a few days.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Doctors told some patients that there was a shortage of hospital beds as well as testing kits, according to posts on Chinese social media sites. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">China’s Ministry of Finance said on Thursday that it would <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="http://m.mof.gov.cn/czxw/202001/t20200123_3463972.htm" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">allocate 1 billion yuan</a>, or about $144 million, to officials in Hubei to fight the virus, though it did not specify how the money would be used.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Wuhan officials also said that they would construct a new hospital specifically for coronavirus patients. The new hospital was ordered built within six days, <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://twitter.com/PDChina/status/1220420937818025989" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">according to People’s Daily</a>, the ruling Communist Party’s main newspaper.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Cheng Shidong, a doctor at the Zhongnan Hospital of Wuhan University, said in an interview that his hospital had set up 100 beds to receive infected patients, but that it didn’t have enough protective material, such as masks and suits, for the medical staff. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">In Wuhan, Ms. Yang said that while she was in a pharmacy buying medicine, another person complained that he thought he had the coronavirus but had not been isolated. The city’s medical system, especially its smaller hospitals, seems unprepared for the influx of patients, she said.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“I’m willing to accept that we have to stay in Wuhan, O.K., but the medical care needs to keep up,” she said. “You shouldn’t tell us we can’t leave, and then give us second-rate medical care. That’s unfair.”</p>, <h2 class="css-3ez4hu eoo0vm40" id="link-d626f9">Who are the victims?</h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">China’s health commission, which has tightly controlled news about the toll of the outbreak, released on Thursday its <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="http://www.nhc.gov.cn/yjb/s3578/202001/5d19a4f6d3154b9fae328918ed2e3c8a.shtml" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">most detailed list of the people who have died of the disease</a>.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The first 17 people were largely older men, many with underlying health problems. All died in Hubei Province, which includes the city of Wuhan.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The first confirmed death was a 61-year-old man who went to a hospital in Wuhan on December 27, weak with a fever and a cough. He was transferred to another hospital as his condition worsened, and he was later attached to a machine that helped oxygenate his blood. But he died on Jan. 9.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Twelve of the other 17 deaths in Hubei were also men, and four were women, officials said. The youngest victim was a 48-year-old woman who died on Monday. The oldest were two 89-year-old men.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Separately on Thursday, the health authorities in Hebei Province, to the north of Hubei Province, announced that an 80-year-old man there had died, bringing the death count to 18.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Many of the victims had underlying conditions like cirrhosis of the liver, hypertension, diabetes and Parkinson’s disease. Most had gone to the hospital with a fever and a cough, though at least three had no fever when they were admitted, according to the health commission.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">While a full picture of the virus is still unknown, medical experts found positive signs in the fact that the disease did not appear to be killing young and otherwise healthy people.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“The majority of fatal cases are elderly and/or have a chronic disease that would increase their susceptibility to infectious diseases,” said Dr. W. Ian Lipkin, an epidemiologist at the Mailman School of Public Health at Columbia University in New York.</p>, <h2 class="css-3ez4hu eoo0vm40" id="link-22895c1e">‘I feel extremely powerless,’ says a SARS expert, raising an alarm.</h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">In an unusually blunt interview, Dr. Guan Yi, a professor of infectious diseases in Hong Kong and expert on SARS, criticized the authorities in Wuhan for acting too slowly and obstructing his efforts to investigate the outbreak.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Dr. Guan, who helped successfully identify the coronavirus that caused SARS during the 2002-2003 outbreak in China, told the influential Chinese magazine Caixin that he was deeply frustrated by the city government’s response to the spread of the virus.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">He and his team had visited Wuhan on Tuesday hoping that they could track the animal that was the source of the coronavirus but were shocked to find that residents at a market were not taking any precautions or wearing masks. No special measures were in place at the airport to disinfect surfaces and floors, either. This showed that the city government was being complacent despite the urgent orders handed down by Beijing, he said.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“I thought at the time, we had to be in a ‘state of war’, but how come the alarm has not been raised?” he told Caixin. “Poor citizens, they were still preparing to ring in the New Year in peace and had no sense about the epidemic.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">He also criticized the local authorities for disinfecting the market where many infections had been traced to, saying that made it difficult for researchers to investigate where the virus came from.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“I consider myself a veteran in battles,” he said, citing his experience with bird flu, SARS, and other outbreaks. “But with this Wuhan pneumonia, I feel extremely powerless.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"></p>, <h2 class="css-3ez4hu eoo0vm40" id="link-31fcbb46">Some residents worry the government is underreporting cases.</h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">There are growing concerns that the Chinese authorities are underreporting the number of people who are ill with the virus. Relatives of patients say that some hospitals, strapped for resources as they deal with an influx of patients, are turning sick people away or refusing to test them for the coronavirus.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Many people remain skeptical of the government’s official statistics, with memories of the effort to cover up the severity of the SARS outbreak still fresh.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">In Wuhan, Kyle Hui, an architect from Shanghai, said that doctors at Tongji Hospital declined to test his stepmother for the virus, even though she was showing symptoms like a cough and a fever. She died on Jan. 15 of “severe pneumonia,” according to a copy of her death certificate.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Mr. Hui said that hospital workers treated his stepmother as if she had the coronavirus, wearing hazmat suits. After she died, the hospital instructed the family to cremate the body immediately. Mr. Hui said that after her death, doctors informed the family that they suspected his stepmother had the coronavirus.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“I’m very sad my stepmother left without any dignity,” Mr. Hui said during an interview this week in a cafe in Wuhan. “There was no time to say goodbye.”</p>, <h2 class="css-3ez4hu eoo0vm40" id="link-67403245">A New York Times reporter travels to the epidemic’s ground zero.</h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Chris Buckley, our chief China correspondent, headed to Wuhan from Beijing to cover the outbreak. He is <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://twitter.com/ChuBailiang/status/1220221489913294848" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">sending live dispatches</a> from his trip.</p>, <p class="css-tmn385 e6idgb70">11 a.m. — Aboard the G79 high speed train</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The G79 high speed train from Beijing to Hong Kong, which stops in Wuhan, was crowded with holiday passengers. The train was a hubbub of conversation, much of it about the deadly coronavirus and the lockdown around Wuhan.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Guo Jing, a worker from northeast China, was headed with two friends for a holiday in Macau. After some hesitation, they had taken off their masks. “They’re too uncomfortable inside,” Mr. Guo said. “My view is we have to be careful but not panic. If you’re the panicky type, then you wouldn’t be on this train.”</p>, <p class="css-tmn385 e6idgb70">1:37 p.m. — Aboard the G79 high speed train</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Half an hour out from Wuhan, the train is quite crowded with passengers. When I explain that I’m getting off at Wuhan, the reactions vary from advice — wear masks, don’t go, drink lots of water — to mordant jokes that I may be there a long time.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“You should know that they probably won’t let people out until the New Year holiday is over,” said one woman, who would only give her family name, Yang. </p>, <p class="css-tmn385 e6idgb70">2:29 p.m. — Wuhan</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Wuhan Railway Station, usually thronging with people in the days before the Lunar New Year holiday, is very empty. An announcement playing on a loop over the speakers tells the few people here that residents cannot leave the city and the station is temporarily closed. </p>, <h2 class="css-3ez4hu eoo0vm40" id="link-6492cc21">Bats, badgers or bamboo rats? Scientists spar over possible causes.</h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Scientists have been scrambling to understand the source of the coronavirus, in particular, the animals from which the virus may have jumped to humans. Many of the cases in Wuhan were connected to a market that sold live poultry and exotic animal meats. The market was closed and disinfected.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Early epidemiological research is indicating that it may have come from wild animals such as bamboo rats and badgers, said Dr. Zhong Nanshan, a prominent Chinese scientist who was the country’s leading expert during the SARS outbreak, during an interview with state media on Monday. Named for its bamboo-heavy diet, the cat-sized <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=siWvJ1Y4LP0" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">bamboo rat</a> has become a somewhat popular delicacy in recent years in China, promoted for its purported health properties.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">A group of Chinese researchers from the eastern city of Tianjin and Nanjing in the south, said the Wuhan coronavirus may have originated from Chinese horseshoe bats, according to a study they published in the Chinese Journal of Bioinformatics on Tuesday.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">China’s National Genomics Data Center said the Wuhan virus was 88 percent genetically similar to a SARS-like coronavirus that was collected from bats in China in 2017.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Still another group of Chinese scientists suggested that snakes were the “most probable wildlife animal reservoir” for the novel coronavirus, then transmitted to humans, in an article published in the Journal of Medical Virology Wednesday.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">But that assessment immediately drew fire from the international health community.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The study’s lead author, Wei Ji of the Peking University Health Science Center School of Basic Medical Sciences, did not actually find the new coronavirus in a snake, noted David Robertson, a professor at the University of Glasgow. Instead, Dr. Ji and his colleagues compared the genomes of an assortment of viruses and hosts and claimed to find a similarity between the genomes of the new virus and snakes.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Dr. Ji did not respond to an email query by the time of publication.</p>, <h2 class="css-3ez4hu eoo0vm40" id="link-25a274b3">Many residents tried to leave the city.</h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The announcement that the city of Wuhan would be temporarily sealed off from the outside world starting at 10 a.m. on Thursday came while most residents were asleep at 2 a.m.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Some decided to flee the city.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Residents were seen hauling their luggage to a train station in the early hours before the citywide lockdown took effect, the Chinese news outlet Caixin reported. Several people said they would buy tickets for any destination as long as they could leave Wuhan, the magazine reported.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Lines of passengers in masks and down jackets, lugging suitcases, formed outside the major Hankou railway station just 20 minutes before the cutoff time, a live video by media outlet The Paper showed.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Han Zhen and Wang Mengkai, two migrant workers from Henan Province, said they had rushed to the railway station in order to leave on Wednesday night, but missed the last train out.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Both said they were frustrated by the sudden lockdown and were scrambling to find a way home.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“It’s serious but not that serious,” said Mr. Wang, who works in an electronics parts factory. “We’re trying to figure out how we can get home. If we can’t get out on a train, we’ll try putting together a car with a driver.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Asked if they were motivated to leave by fear of the virus, Mr. Han said: “No, we are not scared.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“It’s the New Year, we just have to go home,” he said. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"></p>, <p class="css-jwz2nf etfikam0">Reporting was contributed by Amy Qin, Vivian Wang, Russell Goldman, Chris Buckley, Javier Hernández, Austin Ramzy, Gillian Wong, Paulina Villegas, Steven Lee Myers, Tiffany May, Elaine Yu, Denise Grady, Karen Zraick, Roni Caryn Rabin, Carl Zimmer and Rick Gladstone. Amber Wang, Albee Zhang, Claire Fu, Elsie Chen, Yiwei Wang and Zoe Mou contributed research.</p>, <p>Advertisement</p>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd" id="site-index-label">Site Index</h2>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-0">news</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-1">opinion</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-2">arts</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-3">living</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-4">more</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-subscribe-label">Subscribe</h3>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd">Site Information Navigation</h2>]
[<p>Advertisement</p>, <p>Supported by</p>, <h1 class="css-1s4ffep e1h9rw200" id="link-30e59d64" itemprop="headline"><span>Coronavirus Is Spreading, but W.H.O. Says It’s Not a Global Emergency</span></h1>, <p class="css-1ifw933 e1wiw3jv0" id="article-summary">The number of cases outside China is small, and the disease does not seem to be spreading within other countries.</p>, <p class="css-1fv7b6t e1jsehar1" itemprop="author" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">By<!-- --> <a class="css-brehiz e1jsehar0" href="https://www.nytimes.com/by/denise-grady"><span class="css-1baulvz last-byline" itemprop="name">Denise Grady</span></a></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The World Health Organization on Thursday decided not to declare the<a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2020/01/21/world/asia/china-coronavirus-maps.html" title=""> Wuhan coronavirus outbreak</a> a global emergency, despite the spread of the dangerous respiratory infection from China to at least five other countries.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Although the disease has reached beyond China, the number of cases in other countries is still relatively small, and the disease does not seem to be spreading within those countries, agency officials said. Of more than 800 cases now reported, the wide majority — and all the 25 deaths — have been in China, according to Chinese officials.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“At this time, there is no evidence of human-to-human transmission outside China,” Dr. Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus, the W.H.O.’s director general, said at a news conference in Geneva. “That doesn’t mean it won’t happen.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“Make no mistake,” he added. “This is an emergency in China, but it has not yet become a global health emergency. It may yet become one.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The committee weighing the decision was divided, its chairman, Dr. Didier Houssin, said during the briefing. Some members felt the course of the outbreak warranted an emergency declaration now, but others said it that was too soon to decide, citing the limited number of cases in countries outside China as well as the country’s efforts to contain the virus.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Emergency declarations can appear to single out one country as a threat to the rest of the world. Dr. Houssin said the committee also considered the potential impact of its decision on people in China.</p>, <h1 class="g-headline" id="g-inlineguide-headline">The Coronavirus Outbreak</h1>, <h2 class="g-inlineguide-list-header g-optimize-type">What do you need to know? Start here.</h2>, <p class="g-inlineguide-date">Updated Feb. 10, 2020</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Dr. Tedros said he would not hesitate to ask the W.H.O. to reconsider declaring an emergency, even within a matter of days, if more evidence emerges to prove that the outbreak poses a global threat.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">There will probably be more cases of the disease in other parts of China and other countries, and all countries should have measures in place to detect cases, including at health facilities, W.H.O. officials said.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Although several countries, including the United States, have begun screening air travelers arriving from Wuhan, Dr. Tedros said that the W.H.O. prefers exit screening for people leaving affected regions.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“There is still a lot we don’t know,” Dr. Tedros said. “We don’t know the source, we don’t know how easily it spreads, we don’t understand its clinical features or severity.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The new infection is caused by a coronavirus, from the same family that caused epidemics of SARS and MERS, which have killed hundreds of people in dozens of countries.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The first cases of the Wuhan illness occurred in people who had been to a market that sold fish and a variety of live animals for consumption, and researchers think the virus came from one of those animals. But which animal is not known. The market was shut down, and it is not clear whether any of the animals or products there were kept for testing.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Finding the source is important, so sales of that animal and its meat can be halted. China has many such markets, and they were also the origin of SARS.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10"><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">[</em></strong><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10"><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="http://on.fb.me/1paTQ1h" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title=""><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">Like the Science Times page on Facebook.</em></a></strong><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10"><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0"> </em></strong><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">| Sign up for the </em><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10"><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="http://nyti.ms/1MbHaRU" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title=""><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">Science Times newsletter.</em></a></strong><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10"><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">]</em></strong></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">So far, Dr. Tedros said, about a quarter of the people infected had become severely ill, but most others had milder symptoms. Most who died had underlying health problems, and many were older than 60.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">About 830 people have been infected with the virus in China, and at least 25 have died, according to Chinese authorities.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Human-to-human transmission has occurred in China, but so far appears limited to people in close contact with patients: family members and health workers caring for the ill.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Carried by travelers, the virus has reached Japan, South Korea, Thailand, Singapore, Taiwan, Vietnam and the United States. Investigators in other countries, including Mexico, are evaluating suspected cases.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Officials in China have closed transportation links from and within Wuhan, and are imposing travel restrictions on other affected cities. These steps have significantly escalated the country’s efforts to contain the spread of the virus just days before the Lunar New Year holiday, when hundreds of millions travel in and out of the country.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Dr. Tedros said that he hoped that the measures China took would be effective and short-lived.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Only five global public health emergency declarations have been made in the past:</p>, <p class="css-15hwz5e evys1bk0">In 2009, for pandemic influenza;</p>, <p class="css-15hwz5e evys1bk0">In 2014, for a polio resurgence in several countries;</p>, <p class="css-15hwz5e evys1bk0">Again in 2014, for the Ebola epidemic in West Africa;</p>, <p class="css-15hwz5e evys1bk0">In 2016, for the Zika virus epidemic;</p>, <p class="css-15hwz5e evys1bk0">And in 2019, for an Ebola outbreak in the Democratic Republic of Congo.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The decisions are fraught. Health authorities do not want to cry wolf by raising alarms about an illness that turns out not to be severe — or to ignore a real threat. If they act relatively early in an outbreak, as in this case, they may lack key information about the severity and contagiousness of the disease.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">There are political and economic considerations as well. Declaring an emergency signals to governments that the situation is serious and that international help and cooperation are needed to contain the outbreak.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Control measures may save not only lives, but money. The SARS epidemic, caused by a related coronavirus in 2002 and 2003, cost the global economy $30 billion to $100 billion, according to <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://jamanetwork.com/journals/jama/fullarticle/2759815?guestAccessKey=da12c4d9-bed5-4c36-88cf-4db717115947&amp;utm_source=For_The_Media&amp;utm_medium=referral&amp;utm_campaign=ftm_links&amp;utm_content=tfl&amp;utm_term=012320" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">an article published Thursday</a> in the medical journal JAMA.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">But declaring an emergency may stigmatize the country struggling with an outbreak, and spur costly bans on travel and trade by other countries, even if health authorities discourage those actions.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“I think there is a general sense that we need to go back and revisit public health emergencies and what they mean,” said Michael Osterholm, an epidemiologist at the University of Minnesota. “I think it’s not clear — do they or do they not bring more resources, or more controversy?”</p>, <p>Advertisement</p>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd" id="site-index-label">Site Index</h2>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-0">news</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-1">opinion</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-2">arts</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-3">living</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-4">more</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-subscribe-label">Subscribe</h3>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd">Site Information Navigation</h2>]
[<p>Advertisement</p>, <p>Supported by</p>, <p class="css-c2jxua e6idgb70"></p>, <h1 class="css-1j5ig2m e1h9rw200" id="link-447b58c7" itemprop="headline"><span>Fears Over New Coronavirus Grip Davos</span></h1>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">Hello from Davos, Switzerland, where business leaders are worried about the growing coronavirus outbreak. More below. (Want this in your inbox each morning? </em><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="http://p.nytimes.com/email/re?&amp;campaign_id=0&amp;instance_id=0&amp;segment_id=0&amp;user_id=f4577a56bcf773214e9a1d55b5fe9d24&amp;regi_id=0nl=dealbook&amp;emc=edit_dk_20180529" title=""><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">Sign up here</em></a><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">.)</em></p>, <h2 class="css-3ez4hu eoo0vm40" id="link-3e463545">The big worries at Davos: disease and trade</h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Attendees of the World Economic Forum in Davos are fretting about global trade in the face of threats from trade battles, the coronavirus outbreak and more.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">• Executives are <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.cnbc.com/2020/01/22/davos-2020-business-leaders-worried-about-coronavirus-from-china.html" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">worried about China’s coronavirus</a> and how its spread will affect business in the hugely important market. Some expressed their fears yesterday with President Trump, who responded that he wasn’t concerned. (More on the outbreak below.)</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">• Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin is annoyed that European countries are still weighing special taxes on American internet companies, saying this morning that creating a global minimum tax was more important and <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/23/business/tech-taxes-debate.html" title="">more fair</a>.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Mr. Trump appeared more preoccupied </strong>by <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/22/business/trump-boeing-davos-737-max.html" title="">Boeing</a> — “big, big disappointment to me,” he said — and <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/22/world/europe/trump-davos.html" title="">the impeachment trial</a> in the Senate.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">The Davos roundup:</strong></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">• Sheryl Sandberg of Facebook said at a private party that the company would help users <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.businessinsider.com/sheryl-sandberg-revealed-new-facebook-privacy-protections-at-davos-2020-1" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">improve their privacy practices</a> on the social network.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">• Why Davos attendees’ preferred way to fight climate change is <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.buzzfeednews.com/article/bensmith/davos-global-elites-discover-trees-climate-crisis" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">planting trees</a>.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">• <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2020-01-19/pot-industry-heads-to-davos-as-stocks-rebound-cannabis-weekly" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">The cannabis industry</a> is trying to get a piece of the action at Davos.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">• Davos chic sometimes means looking like a “<a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://twitter.com/jonfortt/status/1219982049416810503" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">ski chalet Bond villain</a>.”</p>, <h2 class="css-3ez4hu eoo0vm40" id="link-485f0731">The toll of closing of Chinese cities amid outbreak</h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Chinese officials have <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/22/world/asia/china-coronavirus-travel.html" title="">closed off the city of Wuhan</a>, the epicenter of a growing viral outbreak, and nearby Huanggang and Ezhou. It’s the latest sign of <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/23/world/asia/china-coronavirus.html" title="">how serious matters have become</a>, with at least 17 people dead and 570 sickened in countries around the world.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Wuhan “is the hub of industry and commerce</strong> <strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">in central China</strong>, home to the region’s biggest airport and deepwater port and sometimes known as the Chicago of China,” Amy Qin and Vivian Wang of the NYT write.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">The outbreak could also have economic effects outside China.</strong> Analysts at Goldman Sachs warned clients that it could “<a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.cnbc.com/2020/01/22/coronavirus-could-shave-3-from-oil-prices-goldman-warns.html" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">shave $3 from oil prices</a> thanks to a slowdown in air travel,” Pippa Stevens of CNBC reports.</p>, <h1 class="g-headline" id="g-inlineguide-headline">The Coronavirus Outbreak</h1>, <h2 class="g-inlineguide-list-header g-optimize-type">What do you need to know? Start here.</h2>, <p class="g-inlineguide-date">Updated Feb. 10, 2020</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Beijing is worried about a repeat of the SARS epidemic</strong>, in which Chinese officials initially obscured the seriousness of the crisis, Ms. Qin and Ms. Wang add. That illness ultimately led to 800 deaths worldwide.</p>, <h2 class="css-3ez4hu eoo0vm40" id="link-2d39c827">Report details how Jeff Bezos’ phone was hacked</h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">An alleged plot to infiltrate the Amazon chief’s phone appears to have involved an international cast of hackers and Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman of Saudi Arabia, according to <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.vice.com/en_uk/article/v74v34/here-is-the-technical-report-suggesting-saudi-arabias-prince-hacked-jeff-bezos-phone" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">a report</a> commissioned by Mr. Bezos and endorsed by U.N. investigators. Here’s <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/22/technology/jeff-bezos-hack-iphone.html" title="">how it played out</a>, writes Sheera Frankel of the NYT.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">• Mr. Bezos exchanged phone numbers with Prince Mohammed at a dinner in L.A. in 2018. (<a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.businessinsider.com/jeff-bezos-gave-number-to-saudi-crown-prince-hollywood-dinner-2020-1" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">Here’s who else</a> was at that gathering.)</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">• A WhatsApp account tied to the crown prince then began repeatedly contacting Mr. Bezos, without prompting.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">• On May 1 that year, the WhatsApp account sent Mr. Bezos a video file of about 4.4 megabytes, with about 14 bytes of malicious code. It’s not clear from the report whether Mr. Bezos opened it.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">• Within 24 hours, Mr. Bezos’ iPhone X began sending about 29,000 times its normal data usage.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">• Messages sent by Prince Mohammed’s WhatsApp account later that year indicated that the sender knew Mr. Bezos was discussing divorce with his wife, MacKenzie.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">The report said the spyware probably came from</strong> the NSO Group of Israel and the Hacking Group of Italy.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">U.N. experts </strong><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/22/world/middleeast/bezos-phone-hacked.html" title=""><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">endorsed the report</strong></a> and called on the U.S. and others to investigate the accusations. “The hacking of Jeff Bezos is in a different league,” Agnès Callamard, one of the experts, said in a statement. She added that “his hacking appears to have been driven by his ownership of The Washington Post.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">It’s unclear what the Trump administration will do</strong>, given that it regards Prince Mohammed as an important ally and Mr. Bezos as the owner of a newspaper that irritates President Trump. An unnamed U.S. official told the WSJ that the administration was “<a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.wsj.com/articles/u-n-experts-say-hacking-of-bezoss-phone-suggests-effort-to-influence-news-coverage-11579704647" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">concerned</a>” about the accusations.</p>, <h2 class="css-3ez4hu eoo0vm40" id="link-1f1e44f9">Inside Microsoft’s big fight with the I.R.S.</h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">For years, the tech giant saved on taxes by shifting at least $39 billion in profits to Puerto Rico. The I.R.S. took aim at the arrangement — but, as Paul Kiel of ProPublica reports, the agency <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.propublica.org/article/the-irs-decided-to-get-tough-against-microsoft-microsoft-got-tougher" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">has been bombarded</a> by Microsoft’s money and lobbying.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">• Microsoft’s arrangement involved selling intellectual property to an 85-person factory that it owned in a small Puerto Rican city. Its tax consultants at KPMG had persuaded the government to give the company a tax rate of nearly zero percent.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">• A small I.R.S. team leading an audit of Microsoft “used special powers that the agency had shied away from using in the past,” Mr. Kiel writes. “It took unprecedented steps like hiring an elite law firm to join the government’s side.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">• Microsoft rallied trade groups to its side in the legal fight and lobbied Republicans and Democrats alike to oppose the I.R.S.’s tactics.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">The big picture:</strong> “Microsoft’s war with the I.R.S. offers a rare view into how a giant company maneuvers to avoid taxes — and how it responds when the government tries to crack down.”</p>, <h2 class="css-3ez4hu eoo0vm40" id="link-6237a424">Tesla’s market value hit $100 billion. Now what?</h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Elon Musk’s dream of having the electric carmaker’s market capitalization surpass $100 billion <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/22/business/elon-musk-tesla-bonus.html" title="">has been realized</a>. Yet the hard work continues, Niraj Chokshi of the NYT notes.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Tesla’s stock has been on a strong run</strong> over the past three months, raising the company’s market value above rivals like G.M. and Ford.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">The accomplishment puts Mr. Musk on the cusp of a big payday.</strong> If Tesla’s market cap can stay above $100 billion for six months, including 30 consecutive days, he’s entitled to buy about 1.69 million shares for about $350 each — a payout that would be worth about $370 million before taxes at Wednesday’s price.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">There are plenty of buts.</strong> Tesla is under regulatory scrutiny for crashes involving its vehicles, and questions remain about the stability of its business and its dependence on overseas sales, especially in China.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">And there are still plenty of doubters.</strong> The number of Tesla shares being shorted is equivalent to about 20 percent of its overall stock count.</p>, <h2 class="css-3ez4hu eoo0vm40" id="link-9411210">Fairway files for bankruptcy</h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The New York City grocery chain <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.prnewswire.com/news-releases/fairway-market-secures-financing-for-voluntary-chapter-11-to-facilitate-sale-of-assets-300991918.html" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">filed for Chapter 11 protection</a> last night, the second time in four years it has done so. That puts the fate of the Manhattan institution into question.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">The company said it would hold an auction for its operations</strong>, including its 14 stores. It has a “stalking horse” agreement to sell five stores to Village Super Market, the operator of the rival ShopRite chain, for $70 million, though another bidder could top that offer.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Fairway had disputed </strong><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10"><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://nypost.com/2020/01/21/fairway-planning-to-file-for-chapter-7-bankruptcy-will-close-all-stores/" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">a report</a></strong><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10"> that it would file for Chapter 7</strong> bankruptcy, in which companies liquidate themselves with no hope of a turnaround. “Despite reports, Fairway Market has no intention to file for chapter 7 or liquidate all of its stores,” it said in a statement, though it hinted at an alternative plan.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10"><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/22/nyregion/fairway-market-bankruptcy.html" title="">The context:</a></strong> The company struggled from debt it took on as part of an ambitious plan to expand beyond Manhattan. It also suffered from competition like Whole Foods, Trader Joe’s and Amazon. It filed for Chapter 11 in 2016, though an executive said in 2018 that it had “bounced back.”</p>, <h2 class="css-3ez4hu eoo0vm40" id="link-7c091e00">The speed read</h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Deals</strong></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">• Alphabet’s GV division and other investors have bought out WeWork’s stake in The Wing, a co-working start-up aimed at women. (<a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://fortune.com/2020/01/22/wework-the-wing-google-ventures/" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">Fortune</a>)</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">• John Malone’s Liberty Global is reportedly working on a takeover bid for Univision. (<a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2020-01-22/liberty-media-said-to-partner-with-hemisphere-on-univision-bid" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">Bloomberg</a>)</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">• Permira agreed to sell the consultancy Duff &amp; Phelps to two other buyout firms, Further Global and Stone Point Capital, for $4.2 billion. (<a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.ft.com/content/c94fccc6-3d3e-11ea-b232-000f4477fbca" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">FT</a>)</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">• The production company behind the hit podcast “Serial” is said to be considering a sale. The NYT is reportedly a potential suitor. (<a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.wsj.com/articles/maker-of-hit-podcast-serial-explores-sale-11579717347" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">WSJ</a>)</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Politics and policy</strong></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">• The Fed did not prevent the U.S. economy from growing 4 percent, as President Trump claimed. (<a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/22/business/economy/trump-fed-growth.html" title="">NYT</a>)</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">• Bankers in Europe are increasingly complaining about negative interest rates. (<a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.ft.com/content/b19b3458-3d25-11ea-b232-000f4477fbca" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">FT</a>)</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">• Britain’s Parliament finalized the bill that will take the country out of the E.U. (<a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/22/world/europe/brexit-withdrawal-bill.html" title="">NYT</a>)</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Tech</strong></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">• The popular social network TikTok is becoming a <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.vox.com/the-goods/2020/1/22/21069469/tiktok-memes-funny-ww3-politics-impeachment-fires" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">political battleground</a>. It’s also reportedly searching for a new C.E.O., <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2020-01-22/bytedance-is-seeking-a-new-ceo-for-its-tiktok-business" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">who would be based in the U.S.</a> (Vox, Bloomberg)</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">• Attorney General Bill Barr has threatened to review a law protecting social networks from legal liability for content on their platforms as part of his campaign against big tech. (<a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.theinformation.com/articles/barr-ratchets-up-pressure-on-tech-with-liability-threat" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">Information</a>)</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">• “Mysterious GPS outages are wracking the shipping industry.” (<a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://fortune.com/longform/gps-outages-maritime-shipping-industry/" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">Fortune</a>)</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Best of the rest</strong></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">• Health insurers have pledged to invest $55 million to develop cheaper generic drugs. (<a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/23/health/drug-prices-generics.html" title="">NYT</a>)</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">• Gov. Gavin Newsom of California objected to PG&amp;E’s deal with bondholders to exit bankruptcy. (<a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/22/business/energy-environment/pge-bankruptcy-newsom.html" title="">NYT</a>)</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">• Starbucks says it will encourage customers to try nondairy milk products to reduce its carbon footprint. (<a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2020-01-21/starbucks-says-hold-the-milk-as-it-moves-to-cut-carbon-footprint" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">Bloomberg</a>)</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">• The Giants quarterback Eli Manning is <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/22/sports/football/eli-manning-retirement.html" title="">retiring from the N.F.L.</a> after 16 years. Here’s what many consider <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=CxiHMIM4NWI" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">his greatest moment</a>. [<p>Advertisement</p>, <p>Supported by</p>, <h1 class="css-1s4ffep e1h9rw200" id="link-24b6dad0" itemprop="headline"><span>Many in China Wear Them, but Do Masks Block Coronavirus?</span></h1>, <p class="css-1ifw933 e1wiw3jv0" id="article-summary">They may help, but experts say it’s more important to wash your hands.</p>, <p class="css-1fv7b6t e1jsehar1" itemprop="author" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">By<!-- --> <a class="css-brehiz e1jsehar0" href="https://www.nytimes.com/by/roni-caryn-rabin"><span class="css-1baulvz last-byline" itemprop="name">Roni Caryn Rabin</span></a></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Chinese authorities have encouraged people in the city of Wuhan to wear surgical masks in public to help curb the spread of the new coronavirus.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The question is: do they work?</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Many infectious disease specialists say the cheap disposable masks, which cover the nose and mouth, may help prevent the spread of infections if they are worn properly and used consistently.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">But there isn’t much high-quality scientific evidence on their effectiveness outside health care settings, experts say. Most of the best studies, which are randomized controlled trials, focused on how well surgical masks protect health care workers in hospitals from picking up infections from sick patients, and found that consistent use of them helped.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Dr. Julie Vaishampayan, chairwoman of the public health committee for the Infectious Diseases Society of America, said surgical masks are really “the last line of defense.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“We worry about people feeling they’re getting more protection from the mask than they really are,” she said. “Washing your hands and avoiding people who are ill is way more important than wearing a mask.”</p>, <h1 class="g-headline" id="g-inlineguide-headline">The Coronavirus Outbreak</h1>, <h2 class="g-inlineguide-list-header g-optimize-type">What do you need to know? Start here.</h2>, <p class="g-inlineguide-date">Updated Feb. 10, 2020</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Because surgical masks aren’t fitted or sealed, they leave gaps around the mouth, “so you’re not filtering all of the air that comes in,” she said.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The masks will, however, block most large respiratory droplets from other people’s sneezes and coughs from entering your mouth and nose, said Dr. Amesh Adalja, an infectious disease physician at the Johns Hopkins Center for Health Security. Coronaviruses are primarily spread through droplets, he said.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The bigger problem is that people don’t use the masks properly. “Most people will put their hand underneath the mask to scratch their face or rub their nose,” bringing contaminants in contact with the nose and mouth, said Dr. Adalja. “You can’t take it off when you get a phone call.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Dr. Mark Loeb, an infectious disease specialist at McMaster University in Hamilton, Ontario, said a study during an outbreak of the SARS coronavirus found that any type of protection — whether a mask or a respirator — reduced the risk of infections in health care workers by about 85 percent.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“The most important message was that the risk was lower if they consistently used any mask,” he said.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10"><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">[</em></strong><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10"><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="http://on.fb.me/1paTQ1h" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title=""><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">Like the Science Times page on Facebook.</em></a></strong><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10"><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0"> </em></strong><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">| Sign up for the </em><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10"><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="http://nyti.ms/1MbHaRU" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title=""><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">Science Times newsletter.</em></a></strong><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10"><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">]</em></strong></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">There is general agreement that infected patients who wear surgical masks are less likely to spread infection to others. The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention has instructed hospitals to ask any patients who have a fever or respiratory illness, have recently traveled to Wuhan, or have come in contact with someone who has traveled there, to wear a surgical mask. The C.D.C. also recommends that health care workers wear a respirator, which filters out more particles than a mask, when they are around such patients.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The risk of becoming infected with the coronavirus in the United States — where there is only one confirmed case — is “way too low to start wearing a face mask,” said Dr. Peter Rabinowitz, who is co-director of the University of Washington MetaCenter for Pandemic Preparedness and Global Health Security.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">But <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2016/04/21/health/washing-hands.html" title="">washing hands — frequently and before eating — is universally recommended</a>. Hand sanitizer is effective against respiratory viruses. Experts also recommend washing hands with soap and water for at least 20 seconds, rubbing the hands together and ensuring all parts of the hands — the palms as well as the back of the hands — are washed.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“It’s also important to keep your hands away from your face,” said Dr. Vaishampayan. “Respiratory viruses don’t infect through your skin, they infect through your mucous membranes: the eyes, nose and mouth.”</p>, <p>Advertisement</p>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd" id="site-index-label">Site Index</h2>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-0">news</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-1">opinion</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-2">arts</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-3">living</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-4">more</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-subscribe-label">Subscribe</h3>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd">Site Information Navigation</h2>]
[<p>Advertisement</p>, <p>Supported by</p>, <h1 class="css-1s4ffep e1h9rw200" id="link-30378966" itemprop="headline"><span>A Scramble to Retrace the Steps of the First Wuhan Coronavirus Case in the U.S.</span></h1>, <p class="css-1ifw933 e1wiw3jv0" id="article-summary">Health leaders in Washington State have been working to monitor at least 16 people who may have been in close contact with the man who flew in from China.</p>, <p class="css-1fv7b6t e1jsehar1" itemprop="author" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">By<!-- --> <a class="css-brehiz e1jsehar0" href="https://www.nytimes.com/by/mike-baker"><span class="css-1baulvz last-byline" itemprop="name">Mike Baker</span></a></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">SEATTLE — Health officials scrambled on Wednesday to contact more than a dozen people who may have been exposed to <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/21/health/cdc-coronavirus.html" title="">the United States’ first case of the Wuhan coronavirus</a>, even as regulators sought to assure the public there was little risk from <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/22/health/corona-virus-china.html" title="">an illness that has rapidly spread across Asia</a>, killing at least 17 people.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The patient, a man in his 30s who fell ill after traveling to <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/23/us/united-states-coronavirus-cases.html" title="">China</a>, has cooperated in helping public health workers trace his path from the Wuhan region of China to his home in Snohomish County, Wash., north of Seattle, health officials said.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Officials said they have been working to identify people who had close contact with the patient once his symptoms began to flourish. They do not believe he was symptomatic on his travel home, but the state health department said that out of “an abundance of caution,” the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention would notify passengers on his flight.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The primary focus, however, is trying to contact other patients at the clinic the man visited on Sunday, a hospital official said. He reported then that he was sick and concerned about the prospect of a coronavirus infection.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“We’re really pleased with the progress that we’re making,” John Wiesman, the secretary of health in Washington State, said at a news conference on Wednesday.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Health workers have reached out to 16 people who may have had close contact with the patient, all of them located in either Snohomish County or in Seattle’s King County. That number may grow as the investigation continues, the officials said.</p>, <h1 class="g-headline" id="g-inlineguide-headline">The Coronavirus Outbreak</h1>, <h2 class="g-inlineguide-list-header g-optimize-type">How Is the U.S. Being Affected?</h2>, <p class="g-inlineguide-date">Updated Feb.10, 2020</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">They said they planned to remain in daily contact with those people to monitor any possible symptoms but have not asked them to isolate themselves, under the assumption that this variation of <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/23/us/united-states-coronavirus-cases.html" title="">coronavirus</a>, which researchers are only beginning to understand, operates like other versions that transmit only once someone becomes symptomatic.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Officials believe that the virus is transmitted through the air by coughing and sneezing, by close personal contact such as touching an infected person, and from touching a surface with the virus on it before touching the mouth, nose or eyes.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The new virus emerged in China at the end of December and spread to other countries in Asia. The outbreak, which has sickened more than 540 people and left at least 17 dead, has triggered extensive protections around the globe, including extra screening and protocols for travelers coming from the Wuhan region in China.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">In the United States, passengers from Wuhan are being funneled to airports in Los Angeles, San Francisco, Atlanta, Chicago and New York, where screening stations have been set up.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Chinese authorities escalated their own actions, announcing plans to <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/22/world/asia/china-coronavirus-travel.html" title="">close off the city of Wuhan</a> by canceling planes and trains scheduled to leave the area of more than 11 million people. The World Health Organization has been considering whether to declare an international emergency.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">In Washington State, officials declined to discuss additional details about the patient or the specifics of his travel, saying they would publicly disclose them only if they had trouble making contact with people who might be at risk. While public health leaders said they saw minimal risk to the public, they also said the case in Snohomish County may not end up being the only one.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“We have our first case in the U.S.,” Mr. Wiesman said. “I would expect that at some point we’re going to have more cases in the U.S.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">After the first American patient visited a clinic on Sunday, a few days after returning from China, doctors asked him to stay home and isolated as they worked with the C.D.C. to test whether he had been infected by the new coronavirus.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/21/health/cdc-coronavirus.html" title="">After confirming the illness</a>, officials later coordinated with emergency medical technicians to bring the man to Providence Regional Medical Center in the city of Everett, where a containment unit had been built during the most recent Ebola outbreaks, said Dr. Jay Cook, the hospital’s chief medical officer. The unit has a negative airflow to filter any air coming out of the room, and an adjacent room for workers to put on protective equipment if needed.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Dr. Cook said the patient was doing well under treatment by a team of caregivers that volunteered to handle patients who have illnesses of particular concern or that may be highly contagious. He said he was hopeful the patient could be discharged in the near future.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">As the coronavirus has continued to spread through Asia, and as health officials try to determine how it spreads and how to contain it, regulators in the United States have sought to assure the public that there was little risk — while acknowledging that there may be anxiety about the arrival of an illness that has drawn global attention.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“I think that’s understandable given the amount of uncertainty and the new nature of this virus,” Dr. Cook said.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Symptoms of the virus include runny nose, headache, cough and fever. Officials said that anyone who feels sick should follow the usual protocols of staying home from work, covering coughs and washing hands. They said people who were ill after traveling to the Wuhan region should contact a health care provider.</p>, <p>Advertisement</p>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd" id="site-index-label">Site Index</h2>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-0">news</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-1">opinion</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-2">arts</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-3">living</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-4">more</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-subscribe-label">Subscribe</h3>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd">Site Information Navigation</h2>]
[<p>Advertisement</p>, <p>Supported by</p>, <h1 class="css-1s4ffep e1h9rw200" id="link-339c25b6" itemprop="headline"><span>Texas Student May Have Wuhan Coronavirus, as Dozens in U.S. Are Monitored</span></h1>, <p class="css-1ifw933 e1wiw3jv0" id="article-summary">Health officials said they were keeping the Texas A&amp;M student, who had traveled to China, isolated at home.</p>, <p class="css-1fv7b6t e1jsehar1" itemprop="author" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">By<!-- --> <a class="css-brehiz e1jsehar0" href="https://www.nytimes.com/by/mike-baker"><span class="css-1baulvz last-byline" itemprop="name">Mike Baker</span></a></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">SEATTLE — A Texas A&amp;M University student was being isolated at home on Thursday as health officials said they were examining whether he could be the second known case of Wuhan coronavirus in the United States.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The man had traveled from Wuhan, China, where the outbreak of the respiratory illness began, and health care providers determined that he met the criteria for coronavirus testing, health officials in Brazos County, Texas, said. They said they would promptly announce if testing confirmed the patient’s illness was a case of Wuhan coronavirus.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Texas A&amp;M said <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://today.tamu.edu/2020/01/23/texas-am-confirms-possible-case-of-coronavirus/" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">in a statement</a> that the immediate health risk to those on its campus in College Station was considered low.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The case marked a growing roster of people being monitored around the United States since officials identified the country’s first confirmed <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/21/health/what-is-coronavirus.html" title="">Wuhan coronavirus</a> patient in Washington State this week. Officials have been working to contact people who were on his flight home from the Wuhan region, and on Thursday they increased the number of people they have identified as having had close contact with that patient in recent days to 43. Those people will get daily check-ins from medical personnel to monitor their health.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Separately, the state’s health officer, Dr. Kathy Lofy, said in an interview that officials have started investigating a few other individuals in the state to determine whether they may have the coronavirus strain.</p>, <h1 class="g-headline" id="g-inlineguide-headline">The Coronavirus Outbreak</h1>, <h2 class="g-inlineguide-list-header g-optimize-type">How Is the U.S. Being Affected?</h2>, <p class="g-inlineguide-date">Updated Feb.10, 2020</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">While assuring the public that there was little threat, officials have said the patient in Washington State would most likely <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/22/us/coronavirus-seattle-washington.html" title="">not be the last Wuhan coronavirus case</a> to reach the United States. Dr. Lofy encouraged people to take typical steps that could prevent the spread of illnesses, such as washing hands and avoiding touching their eyes, nose and mouth.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“Currently, we believe the risk to the general public is low,” Dr. Lofy said.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The strain of coronavirus surfaced in December and has spread through parts of Asia, sickening hundreds and killing at least 17 people. The authorities in China have since closed off Wuhan, a city of more than 11 million people, by canceling flights and trains leaving the city, and suspending bus, subway and ferry service within it. <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/23/world/asia/china-coronavirus.html" title="">Travel restrictions have been extended</a> to several cities nearby.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The United States has put travel limits of its own in place, funneling passengers who have traveled recently to Wuhan through a handful of airports, including Los Angeles International, that have special screening processes in place.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">A passenger who arrived at Los Angeles International on an American Airlines flight from Mexico City on Wednesday night was taken to a hospital for a “precautionary medical evaluation,” officials said. Heath Montgomery, an airport spokesman, said he did not know whether the traveler had recently been to China or whether coronavirus was suspected.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">State and county health officials declined to discuss the situation in detail, but said they did not have any confirmed cases of coronavirus. They have been providing healthy travelers arriving from Wuhan with information about symptoms and advising them to seek care if they become ill.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The union that represents more than 27,000 American Airlines flight attendants on Thursday called for airlines to institute immediate emergency measures, including procedures to manage potentially ill people.
