Lori Bassani, the national president of the Association of Professional Flight Attendants, said airlines needed to do everything possible to contain the outbreak and minimize the chances of exposure.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“The health of our crew members and passengers is a top priority for us and we refuse to compromise their health or safety in any way,” Ms. Bassani said.</p>, <p>Advertisement</p>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd" id="site-index-label">Site Index</h2>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-0">news</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-1">opinion</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-2">arts</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-3">living</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-4">more</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-subscribe-label">Subscribe</h3>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd">Site Information Navigation</h2>]
[<p>Advertisement</p>, <p>Supported by</p>, <h1 class="css-fnr6md e1h9rw200" id="link-4ebe856e" itemprop="headline"><span>Wuhan Beyond the Coronavirus: Steel, Cars and Spicy Noodles</span></h1>, <p class="css-1ifw933 e1wiw3jv0" id="article-summary">The Chinese city of 11 million embodies the country’s surge from grinding poverty to industrial powerhouse.</p>, <p class="css-1fv7b6t e1jsehar1" itemprop="author" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">By<!-- --> <a class="css-brehiz e1jsehar0" href="https://www.nytimes.com/by/carlos-tejada"><span class="css-1baulvz last-byline" itemprop="name">Carlos Tejada</span></a></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">If Wuhan could be compared to an American city, it might be Pittsburgh — a much bigger, much hotter Pittsburgh.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Wuhan, an industrial city in central China, straddles a river, the Yangtze. It is home to a troubled and declining steel industry. It is a university town filled with college students.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The comparisons don’t go much further. Wuhan has a population of more than 11 million people, the equivalent of 36 Pittsburghs. In terms of college students alone, roughly one million are enrolled there, according to government figures. Summer temperatures can approach 100 degrees, with heavy humidity. Its traditional dish, and one of China’s favorite noshes, is a pungent pasta concoction called reganmian, or “hot dry noodles.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Wuhan is also the epicenter of a viral outbreak that is worrying the world. On Thursday, Chinese officials <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/22/world/asia/china-coronavirus-travel.html" title="">sharply limited travel</a> to and from the city in an effort <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/22/health/corona-virus-china.html" title="">to contain a coronavirus</a> that so far has killed at least 17 people and infected hundreds more. The restrictions hit the city at the peak of the travel period for the Lunar New Year holiday, meaning many residents may miss their families and loved ones this week.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Wuhan embodies China’s rise as a global economic power, in all its complexities. Disposable income per person soared more than sixfold between 2002 and 2018, according to government figures compiled by CEIC Data, an information provider. The area is home to vast factories making cars <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.gmchina.com/company/cn/en/gm/company/about-gm-china.html" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">for General Motors</a>, <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nissan-global.com/EN/COMPANY/PROFILE/EN_ESTABLISHMENT/ASIA/" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">Nissan</a>, <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://global.honda/newsroom/news/2019/c190412eng.html" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">Honda</a> and other global and local brands. The city has become a popular destination for foreign investment.</p>, <h1 class="g-headline" id="g-inlineguide-headline">The Coronavirus Outbreak</h1>, <h2 class="g-inlineguide-list-header g-optimize-type">What do you need to know? Start here.</h2>, <p class="g-inlineguide-date">Updated Feb. 10, 2020</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The Chinese government thinks so highly of the city’s image that Xi Jinping, the country’s leader, <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2018/04/26/world/asia/narendra-modi-xi-jinping-china-india.html" title="">met Prime Minister Narendra Modi of India there</a> two years ago. The two walked along the city’s East Lake, building what Chinese state-run media <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://news.cgtn.com/news/2019-10-10/Xi-Modi-summit-2-0-Wuhan-spirit-flies-to-Mamallapuram--KE4TVVQxpu/index.html" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">came to call the Wuhan spirit</a> between the two regional rivals.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The boom has come with problems. <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://edition.cnn.com/2019/07/10/asia/china-wuhan-pollution-problems-intl-hnk/index.html" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">Heavy pollution</a> has <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2019/07/05/world/asia/wuhan-china-protests.html" title="">provoked protests</a>. Wuhan’s streets are often clogged with traffic. Its steel factories, long a backbone of the local economy, have struggled along with the rest of the inefficient industry in China with overcapacity and pollution problems, leading Beijing to <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.scmp.com/business/companies/article/2021668/shanghai-baosteel-wuhan-given-green-light-form-chinas-biggest" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">combine the state-owned local giant, Wuhan Steel,</a> with another company.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Wuhan has long been a center of commerce in China thanks to its position along the Yangtze River, a major trade route, and it remains a key transportation hub, leading some in China <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.chinadaily.com.cn/regional/2017-11/25/content_34984016.htm" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">to compare it to Chicago</a>. It was also the site of one formative event in Chinese history: <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/1911/10/12/archives/chinese-rebels-win-big-victory-capture-wuchang-opposite-hankow.html" title="">a military mutiny in 1911</a> that led to the collapse of the Qing dynasty and ushered in the Republic of China.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Wuhan held a special place in the heart of Mao Zedong, <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.scmp.com/magazines/post-magazine/long-reads/article/1999098/chairman-maos-historic-swim-glorified-china" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">who famously took a swim in the Yangtze there</a> in 1966 to show his vitality. This was at the beginning of the Cultural Revolution, which <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.cambridge.org/core/journals/china-quarterly/article/wuhan-incident-local-strife-and-provincial-rebellion-during-the-cultural-revolution/D1C7A1BF2E3F30880006ABEADAAC15B0" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">tore Wuhan apart</a> as it did other cities.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">As China took off in the modern era, local leaders tried to burnish the city’s image and show Wuhan taking part in the country’s rise. They explored adopting a slogan and considered “Great River, Great Lake, Great Wuhan” and “River Capital of the East, Livable Wuhan,” among others.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">They settled on <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="http://en.hubei.gov.cn/news/newslist/201409/t20140916_526479.shtml" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">“Wuhan, Different Everyday!”</a></p>, <p>Advertisement</p>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd" id="site-index-label">Site Index</h2>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-0">news</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-1">opinion</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-2">arts</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-3">living</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-4">more</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-subscribe-label">Subscribe</h3>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd">Site Information Navigation</h2>]
[<p>Advertisement</p>, <p>Supported by</p>, <h1 class="css-1s4ffep e1h9rw200" id="link-7eaf5b68" itemprop="headline"><span>Coronavirus Deaths Are So Far Mostly Older Men, Many With Previous Health Issues</span></h1>, <p class="css-1ifw933 e1wiw3jv0" id="article-summary">As China released details about the first 17 people who have died in the outbreak, a well-known SARS expert raised an alarm about the virus’s spread, saying he felt “powerless.”</p>, <p class="css-1fv7b6t e1jsehar1" itemprop="author" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">By<!-- --> <a class="css-brehiz e1jsehar0" href="https://www.nytimes.com/by/austin-ramzy"><span class="css-1baulvz last-byline" itemprop="name">Austin Ramzy</span></a></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">HONG KONG — When the man finally went to a hospital, he had been sick for a week. It was Dec. 26, and Mr. Zeng, 61, was weak with a cough. He got worse. A day later he was transferred to intensive care, and on Dec. 30 he was put on a ventilator to try to keep him alive.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">He was moved to another hospital and attached to another machine that oxygenated his blood. Still, he got worse, and on Jan. 9 his heart stopped.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Mr. Zeng, whom the authorities have identified only by his surname, became the first confirmed death from the new coronavirus that emerged in the central city of Wuhan and has since spread around the country and beyond.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">China’s health commission, which has tightly controlled news about the toll of the outbreak, on Thursday released details about the first 17 confirmed deaths from the disease. (Several more deaths were announced early Friday, bringing the death toll to 25.) </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The detailed information was released as the authorities <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/23/world/asia/china-coronavirus.html" title="">canceled transportation</a> within Wuhan and several nearby cities and largely blocked residents from leaving. Medical experts have questioned whether <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/22/world/asia/china-coronavirus-travel.html" title="">the measures in Wuhan</a> have come too late to prevent the spread of the coronavirus, which has been found in infected travelers in Washington State, Japan, South Korea, Thailand and Taiwan.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Dr. Guan Yi, a professor of infectious diseases at the University of Hong Kong who visited Wuhan this week, warned that there was a potential for the virus to spread rapidly despite the controls put in place on Thursday morning.</p>, <h1 class="g-headline" id="g-inlineguide-headline">The Coronavirus Outbreak</h1>, <h2 class="g-inlineguide-list-header g-optimize-type">What do you need to know? Start here.</h2>, <p class="g-inlineguide-date">Updated Feb. 10, 2020</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“We have a chance to have a pandemic outbreak,” said Dr. Guan, who was part of the team that identified the coronavirus that caused the deadly SARS outbreak in 2002 and 2003. SARS infected more than 8,000 people and killed nearly 800.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Dr. Guan also told Caixin, an influential Chinese magazine known for investigative reports, that he had traveled to Wuhan hoping to help track the virus’s animal source and control the epidemic. But he left, he said, feeling “powerless, very angry.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Dr. W. Ian Lipkin, an epidemiologist at Columbia University who advised the Chinese government and the World Health Organization during the SARS outbreak, said that infected people outside Wuhan would continue to spread the disease.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“The horse is already out of the barn,” he said.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">An examination of the information provided by the government about the initial deaths show a disease that has thus far largely killed older men, many of who had underlying health problems.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Most had gone to the hospital with a fever and a cough, though at least three did not have fevers when they were admitted, <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="http://www.nhc.gov.cn/yjb/s3578/202001/5d19a4f6d3154b9fae328918ed2e3c8a.shtml" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">according to the health commission’s statement</a>.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Among the first 17 victims were 13 men and four women. All were identified only by their last names. The youngest was a 48-year-old woman, Yin, who died on Monday, more than a month after her symptoms were first recorded. The oldest cases were two 89-year-old men who died on Saturday and Sunday. The median age was 75.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Many had underlying conditions like cirrhosis of the liver, hypertension, diabetes and Parkinson’s disease. Most spent more than a week in hospitals, with some undergoing treatment for a month or longer. But two died just four days after they were admitted.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">While much about the virus remains unknown, medical experts found some positive signs in the fact that the disease did not appear to be killing young and otherwise healthy people.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">It was a somewhat reassuring sign, Dr. Lipkin wrote, that “the majority of fatal cases are elderly and/or have a chronic disease that would increase their susceptibility to infectious diseases.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The Chinese health commission said more than 570 cases had been confirmed in the country by the end of Wednesday, with 95 in grave condition. The outbreak has happened as China was preparing for the Lunar New Year holiday, the biggest travel period of the year, increasing the likelihood of the coronavirus circulating further beyond Wuhan.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Dr. Guan, <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="http://www.caixin.com/2020-01-23/101507670.html" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">in his interview with Caixin</a>, was critical of the local government, saying it had not done enough earlier this week to stop the coronavirus in Wuhan.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“Even though the central authorities have said in the past two days they were attaching a high degree of importance, local health protections had not been upgraded at all,” he said. “At the time I thought this was going to be a ‘state of war.’ Why hadn’t the alarm been sounded?”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Dr. Guan said he was disturbed by the lack of safety measures being put in place. At the airport he saw no disinfection being carried out and only a few random places like a Starbucks had put out liquid hand sanitizer dispensers.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The situation was so surprising, “my jaw dropped,” he said.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">He said he continually ran into obstacles when trying to find researchers to work with on tracing the source of the virus. The seafood and poultry market believed to the source had been thoroughly cleaned, he complained, preventing any effective investigation.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“There’s no crime scene,” he said.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The path of the coronavirus could prove harder to trace and control than SARS, when a small number of highly infectious superspreaders helped transmit the disease to a large number of people, Dr. Guan said.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“I’ve experienced a lot, and I’ve never felt scared, most of these are controllable,” he said, citing previous battles with SARS, avian influenza and other outbreaks. “But this time I’m scared.”</p>, <p class="css-jwz2nf etfikam0">Javier Hernández contributed reporting from Beijing, and Amber Wang contributed research.</p>, <p>Advertisement</p>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd" id="site-index-label">Site Index</h2>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-0">news</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-1">opinion</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-2">arts</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-3">living</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-4">more</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-subscribe-label">Subscribe</h3>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd">Site Information Navigation</h2>]
[<p>Advertisement</p>, <p>Supported by</p>, <h1 class="css-1s4ffep e1h9rw200" id="link-24f8b7a4" itemprop="headline"><span>How China’s Virus Outbreak Could Threaten the Global Economy</span></h1>, <p class="css-1ifw933 e1wiw3jv0" id="article-summary">Markets have tumbled as investors worry that Chinese shoppers will stay home for the Lunar New Year holiday and beyond. Economists say the possible impact isn’t yet clear.</p>, <p class="css-1fv7b6t e1jsehar1" itemprop="author" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">By<!-- --> <a class="css-brehiz e1jsehar0" href="https://www.nytimes.com/by/alexandra-stevenson"><span class="css-1baulvz last-byline" itemprop="name">Alexandra Stevenson</span></a></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">HONG KONG — The outbreak <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/23/world/asia/china-coronavirus.html" title="">of a deadly disease in China</a> has cast a pall over growth prospects for the world’s second largest economy, raising fears about the global outlook if the mysterious coronavirus spreads or worsens.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Financial markets across Asia fell on Thursday, led by sharp drop in stocks in China, as investors pondered the potential impact of the coronavirus. The extent of its severity has become more clear over the past two days, as Chinese officials reported a surge in cases and a jump in the number of deaths to at least 26.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">On Thursday, officials extended limits on movement in and out of Wuhan, the epicenter of the outbreak, to two nearby cities that millions more call home</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The uncertainty has put a palpable damper on Chinese life just before the Lunar New Year holiday — typically a time of travel, shopping and gift-giving — which begins on Friday. Train stations and airports were subdued as travelers changed plans for the weeklong holiday, and seven of the most anticipated film openings of the holiday season were postponed.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The Forbidden City in Beijing — China’s most popular tourist attraction — announced, without giving further information, that it would be closed starting on Saturday.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">On the minds of many in China and around the world right now: Could this new virus cause the same kind of damage as the SARS epidemic, which killed 800 people in 2003?</p>, <h1 class="g-headline" id="g-inlineguide-headline">The Coronavirus Outbreak</h1>, <h2 class="g-inlineguide-list-header g-optimize-type">What do you need to know? Start here.</h2>, <p class="g-inlineguide-date">Updated Feb. 10, 2020</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The question is a crucial one beyond China, because the Chinese economy has for years been one of the world’s most powerful growth engines. A stumble in China could hobble jobs and growth elsewhere.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">China’s growth in 2003 plunged briefly during the height of SARS but came roaring back in a time when global companies were building Chinese factories and exporting more and more goods abroad.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Today, China’s economy is bigger but is growing <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/16/business/economy/china-economy-gdp.html" title="">at its slowest pace in nearly three decades</a>. It is grappling with problems like the trade war with the United States and a campaign to wean local governments and companies off their addiction to borrowing.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">It also depends more on consumers like Mo Chen, 29, who is curtailing her holiday travel plans, to stay on the safe side. In 2003, the worst-hit sectors were transportation, retail and restaurants.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Ms. Mo, who works for an internet company in Shanghai, had been looking forward to traveling home to see her family in Xiangyang, Hubei Province, nearly 200 miles from Wuhan. But given the outbreak, she and her brother, who lives in the city of Hangzhou, decided not to go home. It will be the first time that Ms. Mo has not spent Lunar New Year with her parents.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">She now plans to stock up on supplies and stay home, not even venturing out to meet friends or go to the movies. She also intends to skip a trip to the mall to buy new outfits, because nobody will be around to see her wear them. Her brother, meanwhile, is planning to buy pots and pans.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“He never cooks,” she said. “He always either eats out or eats at the company canteen. But last night our mom asked us to stock up on food, not go out and cook at home.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">For now, the impact is not yet clear. The authorities seem to be responding faster to this outbreak than they did in 2003, but China’s censors are <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/22/business/virus-corona.html" title="">erasing anything</a> that veers from the official narrative. The new coronavirus appears to be less deadly than SARS, but it is difficult to detect, and the authorities started limiting movement out of Wuhan only after many people had set out for their holiday travels.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“It’s going to depend on how China continues to be transparent with the international community,” said Peter Levesque, the managing director of Modern Terminals, a port operator in Hong Kong. “That’s all business can ask for. The rest is unknown.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Wuhan is essential to commerce in its region of China, though the economic impact there is expected to be muted by the advent of the holiday. The city is a major national transport hub and has become a center for auto manufacturing, with factories that build cars for General Motors, Honda and many others, as well as dozens of auto parts makers.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">But the effect on people across the country could be a more important factor.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Over the long term, China wants its consumers to spend more. Beijing has sought to develop a consumer culture similar to that of the United States so that China’s economy becomes less reliant on big construction and infrastructure projects that often receive government financing. But that shift makes China more vulnerable to events that spook shoppers.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Chinese consumer sentiment had already been bruised. Families spent the past year <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2019/10/02/business/china-consumers.html" title="">watching prices rise in grocery stores</a>, increases due largely to <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2019/09/10/business/china-pork-prices.html" title="">the outbreak of a pig disease</a> that depleted much of China’s pork supply. More families are saving rather than spending, and are worrying about the future.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“We will probably see a lot less domestic activity than we would normally see at this time of the year,” said Julian Evans-Pritchard, a senior China economist at Capital Economics.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“The concern is that it encourages people to cancel their travel plans, and it comes at a crucial time in terms of holiday travel and spending,” he said.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The disease has struck during one of the year’s busiest spending seasons. Box office sales during the Lunar New Year holiday last year set a record, reaching $860 million over the first six days of the holiday, according to Maoyan, a ticketing service owned by Alibaba.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">New spending records will be harder to attain this year. Among the film debuts postponed on Thursday was “Boonie Bears: The Wild Life,” a cartoon about clever bears that clash with a hapless logger. In a message to fans on its social media account, the production company wrote, “We don’t want to see audience friends take any health risks,” adding that it did not want to “see that the epidemic may spread further.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Other businesses in some parts of China have been temporarily closed. Major airlines, including Hong Kong’s flagship carrier, Cathay Pacific, have restricted flights to Wuhan. Companies urged employees to wear masks and not to travel.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Companies that were still offering services urged caution. Didi Chuxing, China’s equivalent to Uber, sent a message to passengers saying that “due to the virus, for the health and safety of everyone, both drivers and passengers should wear face masks.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Hong Kong, the semiautonomous Chinese city that has been roiled by anti-Beijing protests, could sustain yet another blow. The region is already in <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2019/11/14/business/hong-kong-protests-recession.html" title="">an economic recession</a> after over half a year of antigovernment protests.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“If you look at those sectors of the economy, the retail and local businesses, they have already been sadly bruised by the protests last year,” said Tara Joseph, the president of the American Chamber of Commerce in Hong Kong. “This would just be an extra kick in the teeth that they don’t need.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">But, she added, “it’s too early to panic.”</p>, <p class="css-jwz2nf etfikam0">Cao Li contributed research.</p>, <p>Advertisement</p>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd" id="site-index-label">Site Index</h2>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-0">news</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-1">opinion</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-2">arts</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-3">living</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-4">more</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-subscribe-label">Subscribe</h3>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd">Site Information Navigation</h2>]
[<p>Advertisement</p>, <p>Supported by</p>, <h1 class="css-1s4ffep e1h9rw200" id="link-3beceb9f" itemprop="headline"><span>Scale of China’s Wuhan Shutdown Is Believed to Be Without Precedent</span></h1>, <p class="css-1ifw933 e1wiw3jv0" id="article-summary">In sealing off a city of 11 million people, China is trying to halt a coronavirus outbreak using a tactic with a complicated history of ethical concerns.</p>, <p class="css-1fv7b6t e1jsehar1" itemprop="author" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">By<!-- --> <a class="css-brehiz e1jsehar0" href="https://www.nytimes.com/by/michael-levenson"><span class="css-1baulvz last-byline" itemprop="name">Michael Levenson</span></a></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">In closing off Wuhan, a city of more than 11 million people, China deployed on Thursday morning a centuries-old public health tactic to prevent the spread of infectious disease — this time, a mysterious respiratory infection caused by a coronavirus.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Experts said the stunning scale of the shutdown, <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/22/world/asia/china-coronavirus-travel.html" title="">isolating a major urban transit hub larger than New York City</a>, was without precedent.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“It’s an unbelievable undertaking,” said Dr. Howard Markel, a professor of the history of medicine at the University of Michigan, adding that he had never heard of so many people being cordoned off as a disease-prevention measure.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Still, “people are going to get out,” he said. “It’s going to be leaky.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">By Thursday evening, China said it planned to extend the shutdown even further. Officials said they would impose travel restrictions on at least four other nearby cities — Huanggang, Ezhou, Chibi and Zhijiang — affecting millions more residents.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">By limiting the movements of millions of people in an attempt to protect public health, China is engaging in a balancing act with a long and complicated history fraught with social, political and ethical concerns.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">James G. Hodge Jr., director of the Center for Public Health Law and Policy at Arizona State University, said the shutdown would almost certainly lead to human rights violations and would be patently unconstitutional in the United States.</p>, <h1 class="g-headline" id="g-inlineguide-headline">The Coronavirus Outbreak</h1>, <h2 class="g-inlineguide-list-header g-optimize-type">What do you need to know? Start here.</h2>, <p class="g-inlineguide-date">Updated Feb. 10, 2020</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“It could very easily backfire,” he said, adding that the restrictions could prevent healthy people from fleeing the city, perhaps exposing them to greater risk of infection. “In general, this is risky business.”</p>, <h2 class="css-3ez4hu eoo0vm40" id="link-38448c2">China’s expanding measures</h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">To combat the spread of the virus, which first appeared at the end of December and has killed at least 17 people and sickened more than 600, the Chinese government said it would <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/22/world/asia/china-coronavirus-travel.html" title="">cancel planes and trains leaving Wuhan</a> beginning Thursday, and suspend buses, subways and ferries within it.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">In Huanggang, a city of seven million about 30 miles east of Wuhan, residents would not be allowed to leave the city without special permission, according to a government statement. In Ezhou, which has about one million residents, all rail stations were to be closed.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The practice of isolating people and goods to halt the spread of disease dates at least to the 14th century, when ships arriving in Venice during the plague epidemic were required to anchor off the coast for 40 days. The isolation period gave rise to the term quarantine, from the Italian quaranta giorni, meaning 40 days, according to the <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.cdc.gov/quarantine/historyquarantine.html" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">Centers for Disease Control and Prevention</a>.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Professor Hodge said quarantines could be effective if they selectively isolate only those who have been infected or are suspected of infection. The response in Wuhan, with the establishment of a “<a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2014/08/13/science/using-a-tactic-unseen-in-a-century-countries-cordon-off-ebola-racked-areas.html" title="">cordon sanitaire</a>”-type boundary, goes much further than that.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“Quarantine would be saying ‘You can’t leave your own home, can’t go to school, work or church,’” he said. But the Chinese authorities “have drawn a line around this city and said, ‘No one in and no one out.’ That type of thing is obviously an excessive response.”</p>, <h2 class="css-3ez4hu eoo0vm40" id="link-6396ad5b">History and ‘the darker side of quarantine’</h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">In recent years, governments have imposed other large-scale measures to prevent the spread of infectious diseases.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Sierra Leone, a country of about seven million people, said <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2014/09/07/world/africa/sierra-leone-to-impose-widespread-ebola-quarantine.html" title="">“everybody” was expected to stay indoors</a> for three days in September 2014, as 7,000 teams of health and community workers went door to door to find hidden Ebola patients.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Earlier that year, Liberian officials placed West Point, a sprawling slum in Monrovia where 60,000 to 120,000 people were crammed into shacks, <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2014/08/29/world/africa/in-liberias-capital-an-ebola-outbreak-like-no-other.html" title="">under an Ebola quarantine</a>. The order led to deadly clashes with soldiers and may have helped to spread the disease, experts said, forcing people to crowd together for basic humanitarian aid.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">During the SARS outbreak of 2003, Canadian health officials asked anyone in Ontario who had even one symptom of the respiratory infection to <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2003/04/18/world/fearing-sars-ontario-urges-wider-quarantines.html" title="">stay home for a few days</a> out of fear that the disease might spread during the Easter holiday weekend.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">In Beijing, at least 4,000 residents who had been exposed to the virus were <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2003/04/25/international/asia/4000-quarantined-in-beijing-as-suspected-sars-cases-climb.html" title="">kept in isolation</a>, and 300 college students who had had contact with infected people were sequestered in a military camp for two weeks.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Historians have noted that quarantines have often targeted marginalized populations.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">During the plague epidemic of the 14th century, European city-states posted armed guards on roads and access points to keep out merchants, people with leprosy and minority groups such as Jews, according to Eugenia Tognotti, a researcher in Italy who has <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3559034/pdf/12-0312.pdf" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">written on the history of quarantine</a>.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">And during a wave of cholera outbreaks in Europe in the 1830s, Naples restricted the movement of prostitutes and beggars, who were thought to be carriers of the contagion, she wrote.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Russian Jews brought typhus fever into the Lower East Side of Manhattan in 1892, Dr. Markel said. It was not only infected people who were rounded up and quarantined on an island off the Bronx, however, but also their neighbors and others whom they had simply greeted on the street.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“That’s the darker side of quarantine — its misuse as a social tool rather than its scientific use as a medical tool,” Dr. Markel said.</p>, <p class="css-jwz2nf etfikam0">Mihir Zaveri contributed reporting.</p>, <p>Advertisement</p>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd" id="site-index-label">Site Index</h2>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-0">news</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-1">opinion</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-2">arts</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-3">living</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-4">more</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-subscribe-label">Subscribe</h3>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd">Site Information Navigation</h2>]
[<p>Advertisement</p>, <p>Supported by</p>, <h1 class="css-1s4ffep e1h9rw200" id="link-608ff111" itemprop="headline"><span>China Expands Virus Lockdown, Encircling 35 Million</span></h1>, <p class="css-1ifw933 e1wiw3jv0" id="article-summary">The new travel restrictions include 12 cities as the death toll climbed to 26. In the epicenter, anxiety prevailed as mistrustful residents crowded into hospitals.</p>, <p class="css-1fv7b6t e1jsehar1" itemprop="author" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">By<!-- --> <a class="css-brehiz e1jsehar0" href="https://www.nytimes.com/by/chris-buckley"><span class="css-1baulvz" itemprop="name">Chris Buckley</span></a> and <a class="css-brehiz e1jsehar0" href="https://www.nytimes.com/by/javier-c-hernandez"><span class="css-1baulvz last-byline" itemprop="name">Javier C. Hernández</span></a></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">WUHAN, China — The authorities drastically expanded a travel lockdown in central China on Thursday, essentially penning in more than 35 million residents to contain a deadly virus that is overwhelming hospitals and fueling fears of a pandemic.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The new limits — abruptly decreed ahead of the Lunar New Year holiday, China’s busiest travel season — were an extraordinary step that underscored the ruling Communist Party’s <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/21/world/asia/china-coronavirus-wuhan.html" title="">deepening fears</a> about the <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2020/01/21/world/asia/china-coronavirus-maps.html" title="">outbreak</a> of a little understood <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/21/health/what-is-coronavirus.html" title="">coronavirus</a>. It has killed at least 26 people and sickened more than 800 in China and at least six other countries, including the United States, according to <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2020/01/21/world/asia/china-coronavirus-maps.html" title="">statistics from health officials</a>.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">In Wuhan, the Hubei provincial capital of 11 million where the outbreak began, anxiety and anger prevailed as worried residents crowded into hospitals and teams of medical workers in hazmat suits sought to identify the infected.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“They can’t take proper care of all the people here,” said Sun Ansheng, a man in his 50s who was waiting outside a hospital while his wife was tested for the coronavirus, so named because of the spiky halo around the microorganism.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“The city government told us there was a virus, but they didn’t explain enough what we should do,” Mr. Sun said. “They left it sounding too minor. Now look.”</p>, <h2 class="css-zd32qr">Wuhan Coronavirus Map: Tracking the Spread of the Outbreak</h2>, <p class="css-1uuihdo">The virus has sickened tens of thousands of people in China and a number of other countries.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Even as the Chinese authorities imposed the new restrictions — blocking expressways, cutting flights and warning residents to stay put — experts warned that the country risked a repeat of the SARS epidemic, which broke out in China in late 2002 and spread for months while officials played down its severity.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The updated death toll, announced early Friday by Chinese officials, jumped by more than a half-dozen in 24 hours.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The World Health Organization’s emergency committee, meeting in Geneva on Thursday for the second consecutive day, <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.who.int/news-room/detail/23-01-2020-statement-on-the-meeting-of-the-international-health-regulations-(2005)-emergency-committee-regarding-the-outbreak-of-novel-coronavirus-(2019-ncov)" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">said</a> it was too early to declare an international health emergency though it would <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/23/health/china-virus-who-emergency.html?action=click&amp;module=Top%20Stories&amp;pgtype=Homepage" title="">reconvene in 10 days or less</a> to reassess the outbreak.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The images in Wuhan offered a jarring contrast to the attempts by Chinese leaders in Beijing to project confident composure. President Xi Jinping led a toast in an ornate hall in Beijing to the Lunar New Year, which begins on Saturday, and he did not mention the crisis in his remarks to the cheerful crowd of officials and guests.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Even so, a sense of anxiety was deepening across China, with hospitals scrambling to cope with an influx of possibly infected patients and people lashing out online at the government. In Beijing, officials announced that they would temporarily close the Forbidden City.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">On Thursday morning, the authorities imposed a travel lockdown in Wuhan, the <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/23/business/wuhan-coronavirus.html" title="">industrial city</a> at the epicenter of the outbreak. Airlines canceled hundreds of flights to Wuhan, leaving thousands of people stranded.</p>, <h1 class="g-headline" id="g-inlineguide-headline">The Coronavirus Outbreak</h1>, <h2 class="g-inlineguide-list-header g-optimize-type">What do you need to know? Start here.</h2>, <p class="g-inlineguide-date">Updated Feb. 10, 2020</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Later in the day, officials said they would also halt public transportation in the nearby cities of Huanggang, Ezhou, Zhijiang and Chibi, which are together home to more than nine million residents. And by Friday, restrictions had extended to Xiantao and Qianjiang, two other cities that include large rural populations.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“This was a very difficult choice,” Wang Xiaodong, the governor of Hubei Province, which includes Wuhan and the other locked-down cities, told <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://news.sina.com.cn/c/2020-01-23/doc-iihnzhha4374343.shtml" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">Chinese state television</a>. “Although Wuhan has taken a series of measures to ease things, there are certainly many hardships.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">An <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="http://news.cnhubei.com/content/2020-01/24/content_12643720.html" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">announcement Friday in the Hubei Daily</a>, the province’s official newspaper, indicated that the restrictions could vary from city to city. In Zhijiang, one of the cities listed, shops and businesses were ordered to close, except for supermarkets, food markets, and other ones essential for daily life.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Some residents in Wuhan spoke speculatively of trying to skirt the blockade by driving on rural back roads to evade police checkpoints.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“It’s serious, but not that serious,” said Wang Mengkai, a worker in an electronics parts factory who was stuck at the Wuhan Railway Station, hoping to figure out a way to join his family in Henan Province for the Lunar New Year celebrations. “If we can’t get out on a train, we’ll try putting together a car with a driver,” he said.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Anger and frustration spread among Wuhan residents lined up at hospitals seeking diagnosis and treatment for coughs and fevers. Most residents interviewed said they could see the logic of travel restrictions. But many accused officials of having failed to ensure that enough medical workers were properly trained, while medical workers reported shortfalls of critical protective gear such as masks and goggles.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“I’m willing to accept that we have to stay in Wuhan, O.K., but the medical care needs to keep up,” said Yang Lin, 28, who had come seeking treatment for what she described as a cold. “You shouldn’t tell us we can’t leave, and then give us second-rate medical care. That’s unfair.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Several residents said they had gone from hospital to hospital and lined up for hours, only to be sent home with medicine and instructions to seek further treatment if symptoms persisted.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Doctors told some patients of insufficient hospital beds and testing kits. Some residents worry officials are underreporting the number of people ill with the virus, although the government has warned of dire consequences for those who hide or delay reporting cases.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“The government did not fulfill its duty,” Du Hanrong, 56, a retiree, said by telephone. “They just are doing things hastily and carelessly.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The Wuhan city government acknowledged that crowds were forming at hospitals, and it came under intensifying criticism from scientists and the public, who described the response as too little, too late.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Experts said that the mass travel restrictions, while understandable, would do little to stop the spread of the virus outside China, as many infected people had already left Wuhan.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“The horse is already out of the barn,” said Dr. W. Ian Lipkin, an epidemiologist at the Mailman School of Public Health at Columbia University, who had assisted the Chinese authorities in the response to SARS.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">In an unusually blunt rebuke, Dr. Guan Yi, a prominent Hong Kong scientist who also assisted in the SARS crisis, said officials had obstructed his efforts to investigate the outbreak during a trip to Wuhan this week.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“I consider myself a veteran in battles,” he said in an interview published Thursday by the influential magazine Caixin, citing his experience with bird flu, SARS, and other outbreaks. “But with this Wuhan pneumonia, I feel extremely powerless.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">On Thursday, in what experts described as a somewhat reassuring sign, the Chinese authorities released details about 18 of the <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/23/world/asia/coronavirus-victims-wuhan.html" title="">people who had died</a> in the outbreak, showing that the disease has so far largely killed older men, many with underlying health problems. But the 18th victim was the first to have died hundreds of miles from the Wuhan epicenter, punctuating the risk of fatal cases far from where the virus was first reported.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Experts said the severity of the outbreak would depend on whether other epicenters develop, as happened during the SARS crisis. But they acknowledged that much remains unknown, including how easily the new virus spreads between people.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Wuhan sits astride the mighty Yangtze River, and the restaurants and hotels along its banks — usually busy in the holiday season — were mostly shut. Retail streets were desolate, and the roads were often eerily empty.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">But cars crowded around seven hospitals across Wuhan that have been designated as reception points for residents with high fevers that may have been caused by the new coronavirus. Some people waiting outside clinics in a drizzly rain said that their family members had lined up for much of the day to be checked by a doctor.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">After SARS broke out nearly 20 years ago, the Chinese government took steps to improve its public health system, including monitoring infectious diseases. But the lingering public distrust created by cover-ups of SARS and other health threats appears to have undercut those achievements.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://political-science.uchicago.edu/directory/dali-yang" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">Dali Yang</a>, a professor of political science at the University of Chicago, said that while the current response has benefited from China’s improved technical capabilities since the SARS crisis, “what I find astounding was how the Wuhan authorities consistently downplayed the seriousness of the situation.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The lessons from SARS, he said in an email, were “that it’s important to let the public know and get the public to modify their behavior.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Still, China’s leaders maintained an unruffled face. The Communist Party’s most influential news outlets did not feature the crisis, choosing instead to promote Mr. Xi’s New Year speech and cheery reports about the holiday season.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">On Thursday, China Central Television, the state broadcaster, treated the situation in Wuhan as a footnote in its evening newscast, one of the most watched television programs in China, airing a roughly one-minute report on the outbreak. Experts said Mr. Xi appeared to be trying to prevent a sense of panic and to limit criticism of the party’s response.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“The top priority will be to keep coverage from asking more probing questions about how China’s institutions have responded, questions that might lead to criticism of the government,” said <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="http://chinamediaproject.org/2020/01/22/party-media-focus-away-from-outbreak/" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">David Bandurski</a>, co-director of the China Media Project, a group affiliated with the University of Hong Kong.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Some internet users found ways around government censorship to criticize the response by local officials, saying on social media that they worried about a repeat of the SARS crisis. Many said they were also concerned about possible food shortages and higher prices on everyday goods.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Mao Shoulong, a professor of public administration at Renmin University in Beijing, said the Wuhan government had made a series of missteps that had eroded public confidence.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“They failed the test,” Professor Mao said. “They just copied the SARS situation, making small things turn into a big problem.”</p>, <p class="css-jwz2nf etfikam0">Chris Buckley reported from Wuhan, China, and Javier C. Hernández from Beijing. Elsie Chen, Yiwei Wang and Zoe Mou contributed research.</p>, <p>Advertisement</p>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd" id="site-index-label">Site Index</h2>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-0">news</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-1">opinion</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-2">arts</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-3">living</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-4">more</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-subscribe-label">Subscribe</h3>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd">Site Information Navigation</h2>]
[<p>Advertisement</p>, <p>Supported by</p>, <h1 class="css-1s4ffep e1h9rw200" id="link-4666fe2d" itemprop="headline"><span>Wuhan Coronavirus, Australia Firefighters, Myanmar Ruling: Your Friday Briefing</span></h1>, <p class="css-1ifw933 e1wiw3jv0" id="article-summary">Here’s what you need to know.</p>, <p class="css-1fv7b6t e1jsehar1" itemprop="author" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">By<!-- --> <a class="css-brehiz e1jsehar0" href="https://www.nytimes.com/by/melina-delkic"><span class="css-1baulvz last-byline" itemprop="name">Melina Delkic</span></a></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">(Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/morning-briefing" title="">sign-up</a>.)</p>, <p class="css-ma92ss evys1bk0">Good morning.</p>, <p class="css-ma92ss evys1bk0">We’re covering a lockdown in China to prevent the spread of the <strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Wuhan coronavirus</strong>, a resurgence in <strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Australia fires</strong> after a brief reprieve and the <strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">gentrification of Paris</strong>.</p>, <h2 class="css-3ez4hu eoo0vm40" id="link-29ee2339">Tens of millions on lockdown in China because of a viral outbreak</h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The authorities <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/23/world/asia/china-coronavirus-outbreak.html" title="">imposed strict travel restrictions</a> on five cities, including Wuhan, the epicenter of a deadly respiratory virus that has already spread to Japan, South Korea, Thailand, Taiwan and the U.S. <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/23/world/asia/china-coronavirus.html" title="">Here are the latest updates</a>.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Experts said the size of the lockdown, which affects roughly 20 million people, was unprecedented. A patient also died in the province of Hebei, 600 miles north of Wuhan, in the first confirmed death outside the epicenter.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The World Health Organization decided not to declare a global health emergency — yet. Several members thought it was “still too early,” the W.H.O. <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.who.int/news-room/detail/23-01-2020-statement-on-the-meeting-of-the-international-health-regulations-(2005)-emergency-committee-regarding-the-outbreak-of-novel-coronavirus-(2019-ncov)" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">said in a statement</a>.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">The details: </strong>The virus has <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/21/health/what-is-coronavirus.html" title="">killed at least 18</a> and sickened more than 600. Here are <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2020/01/21/world/asia/china-coronavirus-maps.html" title="">maps of its spread</a>. The victims are so far <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/23/world/asia/coronavirus-victims-wuhan.html" title="">mostly older men</a>, many of whom had previous health issues.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">What’s next: </strong>The Lunar New Year holiday, when hundreds of millions travel across China, begins today. Epidemiologists fear it could make the outbreak harder to contain.</p>, <h2 class="css-3ez4hu eoo0vm40" id="link-14c6d73a">Three more firefighters die in Australia</h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Several U.S. firefighters were killed on Thursday when a plane carrying fire retardant <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/23/world/australia/plane-crash-fires.html" title="">went down in the mountains south of Canberra</a>. They were not immediately identified.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The fiery crash, on a hill near a wildlife sanctuary, ended a brief lull in the country’s summer of deadly wildfires. Rain had offered a reprieve, but temperatures roared back on Thursday to over 100 degrees.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“We’re devastated because those Americans, they’re not going home,” said Alison Myers, a deputy captain with the Numeralla fire brigade, which covers the surrounding district.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Context: </strong>At least five firefighters have been killed this season, and the death toll from the fires now exceeds 30. More than 2,500 homes have been destroyed, and millions of acres have burned.</p>, <h2 class="css-3ez4hu eoo0vm40" id="link-2125bcdd">Myanmar must protect Rohingya, Hague court rules</h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The International Court of Justice ruled on Thursday that Myanmar must “take all measures within its power” <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/23/world/asia/myanmar-rohingya-genocide.html" title="">to protect Rohingya Muslims</a>, who have been killed and driven from their homes in what the country’s accusers have called a campaign of genocide.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The court said the Rohingya faced “real and imminent risk” as it put Myanmar under judicial oversight. The move essentially rejected the defenses offered by the country’s civilian leader, Daw Aung San Suu Kyi.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Impact: </strong>Some observers noted that because the court did not outline specific steps and does not have enforcement power, it would take more action to protect the ethnic minority group. “The chances of Aung San Suu Kyi implementing this ruling will be zero unless significant international pressure is applied,” said the director of one human rights group.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Background:</strong> In 2017, Myanmar’s military waged a brutal assault against the Rohingya in the western state of Rakhine, prompting more than 700,000 to flee to neighboring Bangladesh.</p>, <h3 class="css-1b8te77 e1gnsphs0" id="link-6cae6ce8">If you have 7 minutes, this is worth it</h3>, <h2 class="css-3ez4hu eoo0vm40" id="link-5fddaee7">The gentrification of Paris</h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">When the brothers Ali and Amar Sitayeb, above, opened a convenience store in 1984 in the Marais, Paris’s historically Jewish quarter, the neighborhood had plenty of textile and metal factories.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Today, their shop is among the independent businesses being <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/22/world/europe/france-paris-marais-gentrification.html?smid=nytcore-ios-share" title="">swept away by gentrification</a>. A Japanese-owned lingerie chain will take the space.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“How is a bra going to replace my orange juice?” asked a retiree who has lived next to the shop for two decades.</p>, <h3 class="css-1b8te77 e1gnsphs0" id="link-554e6082">Here’s what else is happening</h3>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Angola:</strong> Isabel dos Santos, the daughter of the country’s former president, is <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/23/world/africa/angola-santos-embezzlement.html?action=click&amp;module=News&amp;pgtype=Homepage" title="">set to face charges</a> after an investigation into the embezzlement of millions from the state oil company, which she once headed. A banker who managed the company’s account was found dead at his Lisbon home in what was most likely a suicide, a police source said.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Impeachment:</strong> House managers laid out their legal case against President Trump. The Senate is expected to meet for an abbreviated session on Saturday. Follow our <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/live/2020/impeachment-trial-live-01-23?action=click&amp;module=Top%20Stories&amp;pgtype=Homepage" title="">updates here</a>.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Jungle prince, epilogue: </strong>For those of you who were as obsessed as we were with Ellen Barry’s story about a Delhi family that presented itself as royalty, here’s an <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/23/world/asia/jungle-prince-of-delhi.html" title="">update based on leads from readers’ letters and emails</a>.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Snapshot: </strong>Above, world leaders coming together in Israel for the 75th anniversary of the liberation of Auschwitz. They <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/22/world/middleeast/holocaust-jerusalem-auschwitz-leaders-antisemitism.html" title="">talked about rising anti-Semitism</a>.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">What we’re reading: </strong><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-features/lizzo-cover-story-interview-truth-hurts-grammys-937009/" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">This profile of Lizzo in Rolling Stone</a> “reveals how hard the Grammy-nominated singer fought to become a new kind of superstar,” writes Remy Tumin on the Briefings team. “The photos by David LaChapelle alone are worth the read.”</p>, <h3 class="css-1b8te77 e1gnsphs0" id="link-7ded7ef4">Now, a break from the news</h3>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Cook: </strong><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://cooking.nytimes.com/recipes/1019924-pasta-alla-vodka" title="">Pasta alla vodka</a> is a 30-minute dinner that leaves enough time to make a salad and pour a glass of wine. Skip the pancetta to make it vegetarian.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Watch: </strong>Twenty-five years after the release of “Before Sunrise,” <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/22/movies/before-sunrise-ethan-hawke-julie-delpy.html" title="">the film’s stars and creators spoke to The Times</a> about how they made movie magic out of a tiny budget and capricious trains.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Read:</strong> “Leadership Strategy and Tactics,” by the former Navy SEAL Jocko Willink, is a No. 1 debut on our <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/books/best-sellers/advice-how-to-and-miscellaneous/2020/02/02" title="">advice, how-to and miscellaneous best-seller list</a>.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Smarter Living: </strong>Our Climate Fwd: newsletter usually brings us a weekly tip on “One thing you can do for the environment,” but this week, its team is <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/22/climate/nytimes-newsletter-climate-change.html" title="">looking at the bigger picture</a>.</p>, <h3 class="css-1b8te77 e1gnsphs0" id="link-15767e9b">And now for the Back Story on …</h3>, <h2 class="css-3ez4hu eoo0vm40" id="link-273d1282">The impeachment diet</h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Of the many rules that govern the Senate impeachment trial of President Trump, there is none more incongruous than the food and drink allowed on the floor during the marathon proceedings: water, milk and candy. That’s it.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The candy is thanks to the “<a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Candy_Desk" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">candy desk</a>,” a historical relic that is currently assigned to Senator Patrick Toomey of Pennsylvania. It’s on the Republican side of the chamber, in the back row on the aisle.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The tradition of the candy desk started in 1965 with Senator George Murphy, a sweet-toothed California Republican, and in recent years has been controlled by lawmakers from Pennsylvania, which has the country’s biggest confectionary industry. It’s <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://nypost.com/2020/01/21/impeachment-senators-will-stomach-trial-thanks-to-candy-desk/" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">currently stocked</a> with Hershey bars with almonds, Rolo caramels, Milky Ways, 3 Musketeers bars, Palmer Peanut Butter Cups and Goldenberg’s Peanut Chews.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">As for beverages, only water is permitted — either still or sparkling — though a <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.govinfo.gov/app/details/GPO-RIDDICK-1992/GPO-RIDDICK-1992-1/context" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">legislative rule book</a> does refer to a lawmaker being <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://twitter.com/AmeliaFrappolli/status/1219675683858894849?s=20" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">permitted to ask for a glass of milk in 1966</a>. Unfortunately for everyone involved in the proceedings, which have so far made for some very long days, coffee is not allowed.</p>, <p class="css-ma92ss evys1bk0">That’s it for this briefing. See you next time.</p>, <p class="css-ma92ss evys1bk0">— Melina</p>, <p class="css-jwz2nf etfikam0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Thank you</strong><br/>Mark Josephson, Eleanor Stanford and Chris Harcum provided the break from the news. Adam Pasick, on the Briefings team, wrote today’s Back Story. You can reach the team at <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="mailto:briefing+pm@nytimes.com?subject=Briefing%20Feedback" title="">briefing@nytimes.com</a>.</p>, <p class="css-jwz2nf etfikam0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">P.S.</strong><br/>• We’re listening to “<a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/thedaily" title="">The Daily</a>.” Our latest episode is about the Duke and Duchess of Sussex.<br/>• New York Magazine <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="http://nymag.com/intelligencer/2020/01/michael-barbaro-the-daily-podcast-new-york-times.html" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">profiled Michael Barbaro and the team behind “The Daily.”</a><br/>• Here’s our <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/crosswords/game/mini" title="">Mini Crossword</a>, and a clue: Presidential candidate Klobuchar (three letters). <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/crosswords" title="">You can find all our puzzles here</a>.</p>, <p>Advertisement</p>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd" id="site-index-label">Site Index</h2>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-0">news</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-1">opinion</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-2">arts</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-3">living</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-4">more</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-subscribe-label">Subscribe</h3>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd">Site Information Navigation</h2>]
[<p>Advertisement</p>, <p>Supported by</p>, <h1 class="css-1s4ffep e1h9rw200" id="link-65186c4e" itemprop="headline"><span>Your Thursday Briefing</span></h1>, <p class="css-1ifw933 e1wiw3jv0" id="article-summary">Brexit, Coronavirus, Terry Jones: Here’s what you need to know.</p>, <p class="css-1fv7b6t e1jsehar1" itemprop="author" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">By<!-- --> <a class="css-brehiz e1jsehar0" href="https://www.nytimes.com/by/mike-ives"><span class="css-1baulvz" itemprop="name">Mike Ives</span></a> and <span class="css-1baulvz last-byline" itemprop="name">Sofia Mitra-Thakur</span></p>, <p class="css-ma92ss evys1bk0">Good morning.</p>, <p class="css-ma92ss evys1bk0">We’re covering China’s latest move to contain a <strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">deadly virus</strong>, a shake-up in <strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Italian politics </strong>and the life and times of <strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Terry Jones.</strong></p>, <h2 class="css-3ez4hu eoo0vm40" id="link-51d7fb70">China seals off city at the center of an outbreak</h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The authorities in China are taking an unsubtle approach to containing the pneumonia-like virus that originated in the city of Wuhan: essentially <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/22/world/asia/china-coronavirus-travel.html" title="">shutting the place down</a>.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Wuhan, population 11 million, is a hub for industry, commerce and transport in central China. But as of today, flights and trains out of the city are canceled, and bus, subway and ferry services within it are suspended.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The restrictions, which don’t yet have an end date, are intended to stop <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/21/health/what-is-coronavirus.html" title="">an outbreak of a mysterious coronavirus</a> that emerged in late December, killing at least 17 people in China so far and sickening hundreds there and elsewhere. Many fear a repeat of the SARS epidemic 17 years ago, which began in China and killed more than 800 people worldwide.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Today: </strong><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/23/world/asia/china-coronavirus.html" title="">We have a live briefing</a> on the latest developments.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Visual: </strong>Here’s a map of <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2020/01/21/world/asia/china-coronavirus-maps.html" title="">where the virus has spread</a>.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Related: </strong>Li Yuan, our New New World columnist, <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/22/business/virus-corona.html" title="">has a mixed view of China’s initial response to the virus</a>.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">What’s next: </strong>The weeklong Lunar New Year holiday starts on Friday, and epidemiologists warn that mass travel across China over the next few days could make it harder to contain the outbreak.</p>, <h2 class="css-3ez4hu eoo0vm40" id="link-53ff21b8">Political crisis looms again for Italy</h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Italy’s political system faces another potential U-turn: The leader of the anti-establishment Five Star Movement has resigned, raising the prospect that the hard-right politician Matteo Salvini <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/22/world/europe/italy-salvini-elections-emilia-romagna-calabria.html" title="">could begin making a comeback</a>, starting with regional elections this weekend.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The Five Star leader who quit on Wednesday, Luigi Di Maio, <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/22/world/europe/italy-di-maio-five-star.html" title="">became the face of a party in disarray</a> that has faced months of plummeting poll numbers, defections and infighting.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Background:</strong> Mr. Salvini’s anti-migrant League party was pushed out of power over the summer by Five Star, a one-time ally that later formed a coalition with the center-left Democratic Party. Victories for the League on Sunday would make the collapse of the governing coalition more probable, and potentially bring on national elections well before they are due, in 2023.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Catch up: </strong>Analysts say <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/18/world/europe/italy-five-star.html" title="">Five Star’s standing fell</a> because it failed to evolve from an angry protest movement into an effective governing party.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Looking ahead</strong>: Polls suggest that the League will win Sunday’s elections in the northern region of Emilia-Romagna, which has long been synonymous with the Italian left, and in Calabria in the country’s south, which the League once denigrated as a leech on the resources of the more prosperous north.</p>, <h2 class="css-3ez4hu eoo0vm40" id="link-225851e9">Brexit could become law today</h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">A bill that <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/22/world/europe/brexit-withdrawal-bill.html" title="">paves the way for Britain’s departure from the European Union</a> next week could become law today. The next step would be at the European Parliament, where the withdrawal agreement is expected to pass with ease.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The bill’s smooth ride marks a departure from the yearslong Brexit drama and acrimony that gripped British politics before Prime Minister Boris Johnson’s landslide election victory last month.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">What’s next:</strong> British and E.U. representatives are <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/08/world/europe/brexit-united-kingdom.html" title="">preparing to negotiate a comprehensive trade deal</a>. Mr. Johnson wants a deal by the end of 2020, but the E.U. says that’s unrealistic.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Northern Ireland: </strong>The restoration of a coalition government has prompted relief, but the region’s leadership faces an uphill struggle to <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/22/world/europe/northern-ireland-schools-hospitals.html" title="">save declining health and education services</a>.</p>, <h2 class="css-3ez4hu eoo0vm40" id="link-3977b0f4">Impeachment trial scrambles the 2020 race</h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">President Trump’s impeachment trial is keeping some of his top Democratic rivals for the presidency glued to their chairs in the Senate chamber — <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/22/us/politics/trump-impeachment-democratic-candidates.html" title="">at the exact moment they’d prefer to be out campaigning</a>.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The six-day-a-week trial, in which House Democrats <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/22/us/politics/impeachment-case-trump.html" title="">began making their case against the president</a> on Wednesday, may last for weeks. That could put Senators <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2020/us/elections/bernie-sanders.html" title="">Bernie Sanders</a>, <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2020/us/elections/amy-klobuchar.html" title="">Amy Klobuchar</a> and <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2020/us/elections/elizabeth-warren.html" title="">Elizabeth Warren</a> at a competitive disadvantage in the 2020 election’s early nominating contests.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The upshot? Two candidates who aren’t senators, <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2020/us/elections/joe-biden.html" title="">Joe Biden</a> and <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2020/us/elections/pete-buttigieg.html" title="">Pete Buttigieg</a>, have carte blanche to campaign hard in Iowa ahead of its first-in-the-nation caucuses on Feb. 3.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Related: </strong>We asked 81 Americans from nearly 30 states what they thought about impeachment. <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2020/01/22/us/impeachment-voters.html" title="">Here’s what they said</a>.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Go deeper: </strong>Mr. Sanders is <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/22/us/politics/sanders-biden-democratic-polls.html" title="">attacking Mr. Biden</a> and <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/18/us/politics/bernie-sanders-elizabeth-warren.html" title="">trying to downplay a spat</a> with Ms. Warren, just as <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/21/us/politics/hillary-clinton-bernie-sanders.html" title="">Hillary Clinton attacks him</a> and <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/22/upshot/polls-bernie-sanders-chances.html" title="">his poll numbers rise in Iowa</a>. (Long story.)</p>, <h3 class="css-1b8te77 e1gnsphs0" id="link-6cae6ce8">If you have 7 minutes, this is worth it</h3>, <h2 class="css-3ez4hu eoo0vm40" id="link-185499b1">Gentrification in Paris</h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">When the Moroccan immigrants Ali and Amar Sitayeb, above, opened a convenience mart in Paris’s historic Jewish quarter, the neighborhood still had plenty of textile and metal factories.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">That was 1984. Today, their store in the Marais is just one of many independent shops being <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/22/world/europe/france-paris-marais-gentrification.html?smid=nytcore-ios-share" title="">swept away by a wave of moneyed gentrification</a> in Paris and other French cities. It’s soon to be replaced by a lingerie outlet run by a Japanese retail giant.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“How is a bra going to replace my orange juice?” asked a retiree who has lived next to the shop for two decades.</p>, <h3 class="css-1b8te77 e1gnsphs0" id="link-554e6082">Here’s what else is happening</h3>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Digital tax truce: </strong><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/22/business/france-us-digital-tax.html" title="">French and American officials</a> seemed to strike a truce on Wednesday in a spat over France’s plan to impose a 3 percent tax on the revenues that technology companies earn from providing digital services.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Jeff Bezos hacking:</strong> The Amazon chief’s iPhone was apparently compromised when he<a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/22/technology/jeff-bezos-hack-iphone.html" title=""> received a video from a WhatsApp account belonging to Saudi Arabia’s crown prince</a>, according to a forensic analysis. The Saudi Embassy in Washington denied that the kingdom was involved.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Royals vs. tabloids:</strong> In the latest skirmish over privacy between the British royal family and the country’s press, lawyers representing Prince Harry and his wife, Meghan, <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/22/world/canada/meghan-and-archie-photos.html" title="">threatened some British publications with legal action</a> after they published pictures of her walking with her son in a Canadian public park.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Child prodigy: </strong>A 3-year-old <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/22/world/europe/haryz-nadzim-mensa.html" title="">has been invited to join Mensa</a>, a British society whose membership rules require an I.Q. in the top 2 percent of the population.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Snapshot: </strong>Iliana Regan, above, created a Michelin-starred restaurant in Chicago and published a celebrated food memoir last summer. Now she and her wife have turned a four-bedroom log cabin into an inn, and she’s trying to<a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/21/dining/iliana-regan-milkweed-inn.html" title=""> redefine what it means to be an American chef</a>.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">In memoriam:</strong> <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/22/arts/television/terry-jones-dead.html" title="">Terry Jones</a>, a director, screenwriter and (most famously) member of the British comedy troupe Monty Python, died on Tuesday in London. He was 77.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">What we’re reading: </strong><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://topics.amcham.com.tw/2020/01/story-of-q/" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">This explainer on a different measure of deliciousness</a>, from Taiwan Business Topics: “Today’s lesson,” writes our food correspondent Kim Severson, “is understanding the Q factor in Taiwanese food.
