It’s good-chewy.”</p>, <h3 class="css-1b8te77 e1gnsphs0" id="link-7ded7ef4">Now, a break from the news</h3>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Cook: </strong>If tres leches cake is not enough, <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://cooking.nytimes.com/recipes/1020805-seis-leches-cake" title="">add three more milks</a>.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Watch: </strong>“<a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/22/movies/before-sunrise-ethan-hawke-julie-delpy.html" title="">Before Sunrise</a>” was released 25 years ago. The stars and creators shared<span class="css-8l6xbc evw5hdy0"> </span>how they made movie magic out of a tiny budget and capricious Viennese trains.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Listen:</strong> Yola, an English singer and songwriter, talked about her <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/22/arts/music/yola-grammys.html" title="">“genre-fluid” country-soul music</a>, which has received four Grammy Award nominations.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Smarter Living: </strong>Here’s <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/22/travel/how-to-tip-in-hotels.html" title="">how to tip hotel workers</a> when you travel.</p>, <h3 class="css-1b8te77 e1gnsphs0" id="link-15767e9b">And now for the Back Story on …</h3>, <h2 class="css-3ez4hu eoo0vm40" id="link-503bc80b">The frontline of an outbreak</h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">Javier C. Hernández, a correspondent in our Beijing bureau, is </em><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/21/world/asia/china-coronavirus-wuhan.html" title=""><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">reporting this week from the Chinese city of Wuhan</em></a><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">, the epicenter of the coronavirus outbreak. Mike spoke with Javier via Slack, a messaging service.</em></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Hi, Javier. What’s the mood in Wuhan right now?</strong></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Walking the streets, you definitely feel a sense of urgency is spreading. Lots of people are now wearing masks and avoiding big crowds. All of this is happening in the midst of the Lunar New Year holiday, so it has forced many families to rethink their plans. People are canceling dinners, staying home from work and hunkering down.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">It must be hard to avoid big crowds in a city of 11 million people.</strong></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Yes, it’s almost impossible to avoid crowds in a modern Chinese city. But Wuhan is trying to push people to take more precautions. When you get in a cab now, there are reminders about opening the window and wearing a mask. Some of the famous street markets are now totally empty, surrounded by signs warning about the virus.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Are you hearing any common sentiments in your interviews?</strong></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Several people told me about their memories of the SARS crisis of 2003, which killed hundreds of people in China. They’re worried this could erupt into a full-blown epidemic. Of course, others say they’re not very concerned and have faith that China can beat this. One common theme is people say they want the Chinese government to speak honestly about the severity of the outbreak — something that didn’t happen during SARS.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Are you taking any specific precautions, like wearing a mask?</strong></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Yes, at the advice of experts, my colleague Elsie Chen and I are washing our hands regularly and avoiding meat markets and hospital wards. We are wearing masks all the time. It’s a bit odd having that kind of barrier when you’re interviewing people on the street. But we’ve found that it is quickly becoming the norm in Wuhan. There are even videos now circulating of people giving New Year’s toasts with their masks on!</p>, <p class="css-ma92ss evys1bk0">That’s it for this briefing. See you next time.</p>, <p class="css-ma92ss evys1bk0">— Mike and Sofia</p>, <p class="css-jwz2nf etfikam0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Thank you</strong><br/>To Mark Josephson and Eleanor Stanford for the break from the news. You can reach the team at <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="mailto:briefing+midnight@nytimes.com?subject=Briefing%20Feedback" title="">briefing@nytimes.com</a>.</p>, <p class="css-jwz2nf etfikam0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">P.S.</strong><br/>• We’re listening to “<a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/thedaily" title="">The Daily</a>.” Our latest episode is about changes to the rules of President Trump’s impeachment trial.<br/>• Here’s today’s <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/crosswords/game/mini" title="">Mini Crossword puzzle</a>, and a clue: Jumping the gun (five letters). <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/crosswords" title="">You can find all our puzzles here</a>.<br/>• The Times <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytco.com/press/new-york-times-documentaries-at-sundance/" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">will premiere two documentaries</a> at the Sundance Film Festival this month.</p>, <p>Advertisement</p>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd" id="site-index-label">Site Index</h2>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-0">news</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-1">opinion</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-2">arts</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-3">living</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-4">more</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-subscribe-label">Subscribe</h3>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd">Site Information Navigation</h2>]
[<p>Advertisement</p>, <p>Supported by</p>, <p class="css-tsacue e6idgb70">Fashion review</p>, <h1 class="css-fnr6md e1h9rw200" id="link-60a0a31f" itemprop="headline"><span>Of Ball Gowns and the Subconscious</span></h1>, <p class="css-1ifw933 e1wiw3jv0" id="article-summary">At Valentino, Pierpaolo Piccioli plays with expectations.</p>, <p class="css-1fv7b6t e1jsehar1" itemprop="author" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">By<!-- --> <a class="css-brehiz e1jsehar0" href="https://www.nytimes.com/by/vanessa-friedman"><span class="css-1baulvz last-byline" itemprop="name">Vanessa Friedman</span></a></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">PARIS — It’s been a strange, discombobulating dance at the couture, sneaking glances between shows at <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/22/us/politics/impeachment-case-trump.html" title="">the impeachment proceedings</a> going on in the United States, the spread of <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/22/world/asia/china-coronavirus-travel.html" title="">coronavirus</a> in China, and the plutocrats <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/video/multimedia/100000002662453/davos-dilemma-help-not-harm-recovery.html" title="">talking sustainability at Davos</a>. World events have a way of raising the stakes on a collection; what can a designer do to really merit any attention at all?</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Some, like Viktor Horsting and Rolf Snoeren of Viktor &amp; Rolf, do it by engaging with the broader conversation: using small squares of lavishly toned fabric samples as haute patchwork on Laura Ingalls Wilder-worthy babydolls and ball gowns, often worn under enormous crushed metallic hats. Some, like <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/22/style/fashion-bouchra-jarrar-couture-paris.html" title="">Bouchra Jarrar</a> and Julie de Libran, do it with intimacy: inviting guests into their homes to see how pared-down suiting and pretty little party dresses might matter in the actual world.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">And some, like Pierpaolo Piccioli of Valentino, do it with dreams.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The master colorist of the couture and its anti-cynic, whose clothes often seem built on generosity of spirit, Mr. Piccioli was riffing on the subconscious backstage. There, Edgar Allan Poe and Carl Jung were on his mood board and layers — of fabric and understanding — were on the table.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Or catwalk, rather. Narrowing his signature billowing silhouette, bringing it closer to the body in trumpet skirts and high-neck, long-sleeve embroidered columns, he played games with construction, so what looked like a gown with a peplum was actually three easy pieces — a long skirt hung from a light-as-air tank, plus a little vest atop that, plus a detachable ruffled belt — and what looked like a skirt and top was a single garment. Strips of satin at the hip of a three-tone bustier gown hid sweatshirt pockets, and tuxedos shifted over translucent panels.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">What you thought you saw was not, in fact, what was actually there. Sound familiar?</p>, <p>Advertisement</p>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd" id="site-index-label">Site Index</h2>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-0">news</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-1">opinion</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-2">arts</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-3">living</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-4">more</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-subscribe-label">Subscribe</h3>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd">Site Information Navigation</h2>]
[<p>Advertisement</p>, <p>Supported by</p>, <h1 class="css-1qskr30 e1h9rw200" id="link-4b0a32c0" itemprop="headline"><span>Is China Setting Itself Up for Another Epidemic?</span></h1>, <p class="css-1ifw933 e1wiw3jv0" id="article-summary">The Wuhan outbreak shows that the Chinese government didn’t learn enough from the SARS epidemic.</p>, <p class="css-1fv7b6t e1jsehar1" itemprop="author" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">By<!-- --> <span class="css-1baulvz last-byline" itemprop="name">Yanzhong Huang</span></p>, <p class="css-cpkn1d e1wtpvyy1">Mr. Huang is a global-health expert specializing in China.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">On Sunday, a friend of mine in China wrote an ominous, two-word post on WeChat: “Broke out.” He meant that a mysterious surge in cases of pneumonia in Wuhan, a city in central China, was, in fact, an outbreak of something more serious.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The first case of the Wuhan virus was detected on Dec. 12. Until last Thursday, <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="http://wjw.wuhan.gov.cn/front/web/showDetail/2020011809064" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">only 45 cases</a>, with two deaths, all in Wuhan, had been reported, and no <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://arstechnica.com/SCIENCE/2020/01/WUHAN-OUTBREAK-TRIPLES-AS-NEW-CORONAVIRUS-FOUND-TO-SPREAD-HUMAN-TO-HUMAN/" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">health care workers</a> were said to have been infected. The virus was mild, we were told then, with no evidence of human-to-human transmission; all confirmed cases seemed to originate from a food market where live animals are sold. On Jan. 11, local health authorities even suggested that the outbreak was over because they hadn’t registered any new case <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://arstechnica.com/SCIENCE/2020/01/WUHAN-OUTBREAK-TRIPLES-AS-NEW-CORONAVIRUS-FOUND-TO-SPREAD-HUMAN-TO-HUMAN/" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">since Jan. 3</a>.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">By Wednesday, though, 17 deaths and more than 470 cases had been confirmed. Cases of ill travelers from Wuhan have been reported in Hong Kong, Taiwan, Thailand, Japan, South Korea and the United States. Disease-modeling experts at Imperial College, in London, have estimated that as many as 4,000 to 9,700 people could be infected just in Wuhan, a city of more than 11 million people.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">According to Guan Yi, a virologist based in Hong Kong, the trajectory of the Wuhan virus parallels the early spread of SARS, the virus that spread to 29 countries, sickened thousands and killed 774 people in 2002 and 2003. Perhaps just as worrisome: The government’s response today seems remarkably similar to its response back then.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The Chinese government’s initial response to SARS was, at least at the national level, a combination of inaction, denial and deception. The earliest case of SARS occurred in mid-November 2002; it’s clear that by late January of 2003 the Health Ministry was aware of a dangerous new type of pneumonia in Guangdong Province.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Yet the government did not issue a nationwide bulletin to hospitals with instructions for preventing the spread of the disease until April 3. And it was not until mid-April that it formally listed SARS as a disease to be closely monitored, with daily reports.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">In the wake of that debacle, the Chinese government does seem to have become more willing to share disease-related information with both its people and international health organizations. But the government continues its top-down, state-dominated approach in disease surveillance, reporting and response.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Global health experts have pointed out that this time around, the government was tight-lipped for two weeks after the onset of the Wuhan virus. Yes, it shared the virus’s genetic sequence, but only under increasing pressure from the international scientific community. For a time, the government tried to restrict the release of any information related to the disease. Local police departments threatened to punish anyone who spread “false information” about the outbreak.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Only two quasi-independent media outlets in China, Caijing and Caixin, provided extensive coverage on the disease, and there was little discussion of the virus on Chinese social media. According to Caixin, 15 health care workers were infected in Wuhan between Jan. 12 and Jan. 21. Yet the local health authorities — presumably in an attempt to play down the seriousness of the situation — chose not to report that fact until after Monday, after the government warned that any official who tried to cover up information about the virus, or delay reporting, would be “nailed on the pillar of shame for eternity.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">As a result, people in China were poorly informed about the outbreak in its early days, when its spread might have been contained more easily. When I mentioned the Wuhan virus to some of my high school classmates in a WeChat group last week, one of them, who happens to live in Wuhan, was offended. “Our country’s disease prevention and control system has been very well developed and is transparent,” he responded. “Only overseas people are panicking for us.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">That could be part of the problem: On Monday, 40,000 families in the city held potluck banquets to celebrate the coming Lunar New Year. The next day, municipal authorities were trying to lure more tourists to the city by distributing 200,000<span class="css-8l6xbc evw5hdy0"> </span>coupons for free events. Needless to say, encouraging large groups of people to come together in the epicenter of a potential outbreak is not an effective health strategy.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Along with its information semi-blackout, the government has failed to respond effectively. Yes, the Chinese Center for Disease Control and Prevention started an investigation immediately after the first cases of the mysterious pneumonia were identified. The Wuhan health authorities also conducted epidemiological investigations.<span class="css-8l6xbc evw5hdy0"> </span>On Jan. 1, they closed down the market where the first cases of infection were traced. And this week they halted travel to or from Wuhan.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Then again, back when SARS broke out, China’s health authorities also responded relatively well at the very beginning. The problems started when the government then failed to undertake effective measures to prevent the disease from spreading further.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Both the Wuhan and the central health authorities could already have done much more to stem the spread of this new virus, including asking people to take precautions like wearing masks. Many suspected cases in Wuhan reportedly were not tested for the disease or quarantined; some people were simply sent home from the hospital without having been screened.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Outside Wuhan, even as the number of patients with pneumonialike symptoms has increased, the authorities may have been reluctant to report cases because the three-step confirmation procedure set out by the central government is so cumbersome. As a result, <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.taiwannews.com.tw/en/news/3860486" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">no new cases</a> were reported in China beyond Wuhan between Dec. 12 and Monday, and yet cases were surfacing overseas. Some Chinese sarcastically took to calling the virus “patriotic” — a disease more interested in infecting people overseas than in China.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">But this virus is anything but patriotic. It is exploding in China and spreading to other countries, much as SARS did in 2003. Has the Chinese government fundamentally changed its response to a possible epidemic since then? It appears not, or at least not enough. And to my surprise, people in China, including some in the know, seem to agree. “From 2003 to 2020,” according to one article shared by a government adviser on a WeChat group, Beijing’s “conduct has not changed at all.”</p>, <p class="css-jwz2nf etfikam0">Yanzhong Huang is a senior fellow for global health at the Council on Foreign Relations and a professor at Seton Hall University’s School of Diplomacy and International Relations.</p>, <p class="css-jwz2nf etfikam0"><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">The Times is committed to publishing </em><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2019/01/31/opinion/letters/letters-to-editor-new-york-times-women.html" title=""><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">a diversity of letters</em></a><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0"> to the editor. We’d like to hear what you think about this or any of our articles. Here are some </em><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://help.nytimes.com/hc/en-us/articles/115014925288-How-to-submit-a-letter-to-the-editor" title=""><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">tips</em></a><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">. And here’s our email: </em><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="mailto:letters@nytimes.com" title=""><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">letters@nytimes.com</em></a><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">.</em></p>, <p class="css-jwz2nf etfikam0"><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">Follow The New York Times Opinion section on </em><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.facebook.com/nytopinion" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title=""><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">Facebook</em></a><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">, </em><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="http://twitter.com/NYTOpinion" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title=""><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">Twitter (@NYTopinion)</em></a><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0"> and </em><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.instagram.com/nytopinion/" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title=""><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">Instagram</em></a><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">.</em></p>, <p>Advertisement</p>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd" id="site-index-label">Site Index</h2>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-0">news</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-1">opinion</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-2">arts</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-3">living</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-4">more</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-subscribe-label">Subscribe</h3>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd">Site Information Navigation</h2>]
[<p>Advertisement</p>, <p>Supported by</p>, <h1 class="css-1s4ffep e1h9rw200" id="link-2ed93a24" itemprop="headline"><span>Wuhan, Impeachment, Lizzo: Your Thursday Evening Briefing</span></h1>, <p class="css-1ifw933 e1wiw3jv0" id="article-summary">Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.</p>, <p class="css-1fv7b6t e1jsehar1" itemprop="author" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">By<!-- --> <a class="css-brehiz e1jsehar0" href="https://www.nytimes.com/by/remy-tumin"><span class="css-1baulvz" itemprop="name">Remy Tumin</span></a> and <a class="css-brehiz e1jsehar0" href="https://www.nytimes.com/by/marcus-payadue"><span class="css-1baulvz last-byline" itemprop="name">Marcus Payadue</span></a></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">(Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s </em><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="http://www.nytimes.com/newsletters/nyt-now-evening-briefing?module=inline" title=""><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">the sign-up</em></a><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">.) </em></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">Good evening. Here’s the latest.</em></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">1. Twenty million people</strong> are on <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/23/world/asia/china-coronavirus-outbreak.html" title="">lockdown as China tries to contain a deadly virus</a>.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The authorities imposed strict travel restrictions on five cities, including Wuhan, the epicenter of a coronavirus outbreak that has already spread to Japan, South Korea, Thailand, Taiwan and the United States. Above, a thermometer screening checkpoint near Wuhan.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Experts said the size of the lockdown was unprecedented. The respiratory virus has killed at least 18 people and sickened more than 600. The World Health Organization decided not to declare a global health emergency — yet. Several members thought it was “still too early,” the W.H.O. <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.who.int/news-room/detail/23-01-2020-statement-on-the-meeting-of-the-international-health-regulations-(2005)-emergency-committee-regarding-the-outbreak-of-novel-coronavirus-(2019-ncov)" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">said in a statement</a>.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">U.S. health officials are investigating <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/23/us/united-states-coronavirus-cases.html" title="">a second suspected case of the virus</a> in Brazos County, Texas.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">2. Day 2 of the Senate impeachment trial.</strong></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">House impeachment managers, above, focused their argument on the abuse-of-power charge against President Trump. They also made a strategic decision to home in on the actions of former Vice President Joe Biden and his son Hunter Biden, a move Mr. Trump’s defenders jumped on. <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/live/2020/impeachment-trial-live-01-23?" title="">Here’s the latest</a>.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The managers and Mr. Trump’s defense team sit at curved tables built before President Bill Clinton’s impeachment trial. They were brought out of storage last week. <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2020/01/23/us/politics/impeachment-senate-chamber-diagram.html" title="">Here’s a 3-D tour of how the Senate was transformed for this trial</a>.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The ripple effects of the impeachment trial — and its strict rules —<a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/22/us/politics/trump-impeachment-democratic-candidates.html" title=""> are being felt in Iowa,</a> where senators campaigning for the Democratic presidential nomination have put their campaign needs in the hands of their young field organizers and political surrogates.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">3. The Trump administration </strong>removed pollution controls for streams and wetlands.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">A new rule will allow landowners and property developers to <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/22/climate/trump-environment-water.html" title="">dump pollutants such as pesticides and fertilizers</a> directly into many waterways, and destroy or fill in wetlands for construction. Above, farmland abutting wetlands in North Dakota.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">One lawyer described it as “the biggest loss of clean water protection the country has ever seen.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">In other regulatory moves, </strong>pregnant women may be <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/23/us/politics/trump-birth-tourism.html" title="">denied visas</a> if officials think they plan to give birth in the U.S. to make their babies citizens, the State Department said.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">4. World leaders gathered in Jerusalem </strong>to commemorate the <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/23/world/middleeast/holocaust-auschwitz-liberation.html" title="">75th anniversary of the liberation of Auschwitz</a>, in a demonstration of resolve to fight anti-Semitism.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The kings of Spain, Belgium and the Netherlands, Britain’s Prince Charles and the presidents of Russia, France, Germany, Italy and Ukraine were among those leading nearly 50 delegations attending the events, which culminated with a visit to Yad Vashem, the hillside memorial to the Holocaust.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">A formal ceremony at the former Nazi death camp is scheduled for Monday.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Our At War column is documenting lesser-known stories from World War II. The first dispatch is about a family who fled Nazi Germany just <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/23/magazine/holocaust-remembrance-grandmother.html" title="">weeks before Adolf Hitler invaded Poland</a>.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">5. Pope Francis replaced a conservative archbishop</strong>, a sign that the pontiff is still intent on changing the church’s ideological direction in the U.S.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/23/us/pope-francis-chaput-philadelphia.html?" title="">Archbishop Charles Chaput</a>, who was appointed to the position in Philadelphia by Pope Benedict XVI in 2011, was often at odds with Francis’ mission to move beyond the culture wars. Above, Francis and the archbishop in 2015.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The move shifts one of its most traditionalist dioceses toward a more pastoral approach. Bishop Nelson Perez of Cleveland, a former Philadelphian and relative newcomer to the national scene, will assume the role.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">6. Wells Fargo’s ex-C.E.O. </strong>agreed to a lifetime ban from banking and will pay $17.5 million over the bank’s fake account scandal — <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/23/business/wells-fargo-ceo-fine.html?" title="">a rare case of a leader being held accountable</a> for a bank’s misdeeds.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">In addition to John Stumpf, two other former executives were also fined, and Wells Fargo’s chief federal regulator, the Office of the Comptroller of the Currency, said it would seek penalties against five others.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Wells Fargo’s pattern of foisting unwanted products and sham bank accounts on millions of customers erupted into public view in late 2016.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">7. Harvey Weinstein’s accusers </strong>are <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/23/nyregion/harvey-weinstein-annabella-sciorra-trial.html?" title="">taking the stand for the first time</a> at his long-awaited criminal trial.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The actress Annabella Sciorra fought back tears as she told a rapt courtroom, in excruciating detail, about the night she said the former movie producer raped her. The searing testimony in State Supreme Court in Manhattan is just the beginning; five more accusers are expected to testify that Mr. Weinstein attacked them.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">8. The Eli Manning era is officially over. </strong>Will he make the Pro Football Hall of Fame?</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">With the Giants quarterback, above in 2012, set to hold a news conference on Friday to confirm his retirement, the debate about his accomplishments, which has simmered for years, will have closure. <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/23/sports/football/eli-manning-hall-of-fame.html" title="">Our reporter weighs the odds of his being enshrined in the Hall</a>.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Looking ahead to the next generation of greats, we previewed the <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/23/sports/tennis/coco-gauff-naomi-osaka.html" title="">rematch between Coco Gauff and Naomi Osaka</a> at the Australian Open on Friday and detailed the much-anticipated <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/23/sports/zion-williamson-pelicans.html" title="">N.B.A. debut of Zion Williamson</a>. A blitz of 17 points in about three minutes showed flashes of a bright future.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">9. Lizzo has eight Grammy nominations</strong>, a performance slot during the awards show and the devotion of fiercely loyal fans (here’s looking at you, Lizzbians).</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">What’s behind the Lizzo moment? <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/23/arts/music/lizzo-grammys.html" title="">Our music and culture critics discuss</a>.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“What’s exhilarating about her as an artist: She’s got nerve,” says Wesley Morris. “And the nerve is what’s made her a hit.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">10. And finally, </strong>a talking mummy.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Nesyamun was an Egyptian priest who lived in Thebes. Now, some 3,000 years into the afterlife, Nesyamun can once again be heard<span class="css-8l6xbc evw5hdy0">  </span>— sort of.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Scientists used a CT scanner to create a 3-D-printed version of the mummy’s mouth and throat, and combined it with an electronic larynx to make, as one researcher put it, “the sound that would come out of his vocal tract if he was in his coffin and his larynx came to life again.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Their work may lay the groundwork for recreating and listening to an ancient person’s voice</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/23/science/mummy-voice.html" title="">Listen to it here.</a> (Spoiler alert: It sounds like what you think a mummy would sound like.)</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Have an animated night.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">Your Evening Briefing is posted at 6 p.m. Eastern.</em></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">And don’t miss Your Morning Briefing. </em><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2018/briefing/global-morning-briefing-newsletter-signup.html" title=""><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">Sign up here</em></a><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0"> to get it by email in the Australian, Asian, European, African or American morning.</em></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">Want to catch up on past briefings? </em><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/series/us-evening-briefing" title=""><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">You can browse them here</em></a><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">.</em></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">What did you like? What do you want to see here? Let us know at </em><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="mailto:briefing@nytimes.com?subject=Evening%20Briefing%20Feedback" title=""><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">briefing@nytimes.com</em></a><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">.</em></p>, <p>Advertisement</p>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd" id="site-index-label">Site Index</h2>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-0">news</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-1">opinion</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-2">arts</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-3">living</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-4">more</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-subscribe-label">Subscribe</h3>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd">Site Information Navigation</h2>]
[<p>Advertisement</p>, <p>Supported by</p>, <h1 class="css-1s4ffep e1h9rw200" id="link-7c1d82fc" itemprop="headline"><span>China, Rohingya Muslims, Eli Manning: Your Thursday Briefing</span></h1>, <p class="css-1fv7b6t e1jsehar1" itemprop="author" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">By<!-- --> <a class="css-brehiz e1jsehar0" href="https://www.nytimes.com/by/christopher-stanford"><span class="css-1baulvz last-byline" itemprop="name">Chris Stanford</span></a></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">(Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/morning-briefing" title="">sign-up</a>.)</p>, <p class="css-ma92ss evys1bk0">Good morning.</p>, <p class="css-ma92ss evys1bk0">We’re covering expanding <strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">travel restrictions in China</strong>, a ruling by the United Nations’ top court to protect <strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Rohingya Muslims</strong>, and the retirement of <strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Eli Manning</strong>, the Giants quarterback.</p>, <h2 class="css-3ez4hu eoo0vm40" id="link-63745296">The continuing case against President Trump</h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">House impeachment managers will resume their arguments against the president this afternoon, a day after they accused him of pressuring Ukraine in an effort “to cheat” in the 2020 election. <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/23/us/politics/impeachment.html" title="">Here’s what to watch for</a> when the managers take the Senate floor around 1 p.m. Eastern.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">On Wednesday, Representative Adam Schiff <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/22/us/politics/impeachment-case-trump.html" title="">argued that Mr. Trump’s conduct</a> was exactly what the framers of the Constitution had in mind when they devised impeachment.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Related:</strong> Democrats rejected a suggestion that they might call Joe Biden’s son, Hunter, to testify in exchange for an appearance by John Bolton, the former national security adviser.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">News analysis: </strong>In the trial’s opening days, “the House managers have focused on the facts,” <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/22/us/politics/impeachment-legal-strategy.html" title="">one of our Washington correspondents writes</a>. “The defense team has focused instead on the process.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Closer look:</strong> The Times asked 81 Americans from nearly 30 states what they thought. Most grasped the basics of the case and had strong opinions, <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2020/01/22/us/impeachment-voters.html" title="">if not always the ones you’d expect</a>.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">What’s next:</strong> The House managers have used about a third of their allotted 24 hours for opening arguments, after which the White House team gets its turn. If senators later vote to subpoena witnesses and documents, the trial could go deep into February. If they don’t, it could be over before Mr. Trump’s State of the Union speech on Feb. 4.</p>, <h2 class="css-3ez4hu eoo0vm40" id="link-65c6b96f">Travel shutdown affects millions in China</h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The authorities today imposed restrictions on five cities, including Wuhan, the epicenter of a deadly respiratory virus that has spread to at least five other countries, including the U.S. <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/23/world/asia/china-coronavirus.html" title="">Here are the latest updates</a>.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Experts said the scale of the shutdown was unprecedented. The cities involved have a combined population of about 20 million.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">The details: </strong>The virus has killed at least 17 and sickened more than 570. Here are <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2020/01/21/world/asia/china-coronavirus-maps.html" title="">maps of its spread</a>.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">What’s next: </strong>The Lunar New Year holiday, when hundreds of millions travel across China, begins Friday. Epidemiologists fear it could make the outbreak harder to contain.</p>, <h2 class="css-3ez4hu eoo0vm40" id="link-26af195e">U.S. to lift water pollution controls</h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The Trump administration is set to finalize a rule today <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/22/climate/trump-environment-water.html" title="">that would remove Obama-era protections</a> for streams, wetlands and other bodies of water.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">For the first time in decades, landowners and property developers could dump pollutants such as pesticides and fertilizers directly into many waterways, and destroy or fill in wetlands for construction.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Last month, a government advisory board of scientists said the new rule “neglects established science,” but farmers and fossil fuel groups supported the change.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Go deeper:</strong> The measure, to be implemented in the coming weeks, is the latest step in the Trump administration’s push to <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2019/climate/trump-environment-rollbacks.html" title="">repeal or weaken environmental regulations</a>.</p>, <h2 class="css-3ez4hu eoo0vm40" id="link-4d12462c">How Jeff Bezos’ iPhone was hacked</h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">A message sent in 2018 from an account belonging to the Saudi crown prince <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/22/technology/jeff-bezos-hack-iphone.html" title="">concealed code that probably let hackers into the Amazon chief’s device</a>, according to an analysis that Mr. Bezos commissioned.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Mr. Bezos has sought to find out who penetrated the phone since early 2019, when he said The National Enquirer’s parent company had threatened to release private photographs and texts.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Yesterday:</strong> Two United Nations experts said the hacking <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/22/world/middleeast/bezos-phone-hacked.html" title="">was an effort to “influence, if not silence” critical coverage of Saudi Arabia</a> by The Washington Post, which Mr. Bezos owns. Jamal Khashoggi, the dissident writer killed by Saudi agents in 2018, was a Post columnist.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Response: </strong>The Saudi Embassy in Washington called the accusations about Mr. Bezos’ cellphone “absurd.”</p>, <h3 class="css-1b8te77 e1gnsphs0" id="link-6cae6ce8">If you have 7 minutes, this is worth it</h3>, <h2 class="css-3ez4hu eoo0vm40" id="link-5fddaee7">The gentrification of Paris</h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">When the brothers Ali and Amar Sitayeb, above, opened a convenience store in 1984 in the Marais, Paris’s historic Jewish quarter, the neighborhood had plenty of textile and metal factories.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Today, their shop is among the independent businesses being <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/22/world/europe/france-paris-marais-gentrification.html?smid=nytcore-ios-share" title="">swept away by gentrification</a>. A Japanese-owned lingerie chain will take the space.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“How is a bra going to replace my orange juice?” asked a retiree who has lived next to the shop for two decades.</p>, <h3 class="css-1b8te77 e1gnsphs0" id="link-554e6082">Here’s what else is happening</h3>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Air tanker crash in Australia: </strong><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/23/world/australia/plane-crash-fires.html" title="">Three firefighters from the U.S. were killed today</a> when an aircraft being used to battle bush fires crashed south of the capital, Canberra.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Ruling for Rohingya:</strong> The International Court of Justice at The Hague said today that Myanmar <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/23/world/asia/myanmar-rohingya-genocide.html" title="">must take action to protect Rohingya Muslims</a> after what the country’s accusers have called a campaign of genocide.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Trump at March for Life:</strong> President Trump <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/22/us/politics/trump-march-for-life.html" title="">plans to address the annual rally of anti-abortion demonstrators</a> in person on Friday in Washington. He would be the first sitting president to do so.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Only dogs allowed:</strong> The Department of Transportation is proposing <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/22/travel/service-animal-airplane.html" title="">to ban all service animals except dogs</a> aboard U.S. flights. Airlines would also no longer have to accommodate emotional support animals.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Snapshot: </strong>Above, Eli Manning in 2008, after leading the New York Giants to an upset victory over the New England Patriots in Super Bowl XLII. After 16 seasons with the Giants, the quarterback <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/22/sports/football/eli-manning-retirement.html" title="">is scheduled to announce his N.F.L. retirement</a> on Friday.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Child prodigy:</strong> A 3-year-old in Britain <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/22/world/europe/haryz-nadzim-mensa.html" title="">has become the youngest current member of Mensa</a>, a society whose membership rules require an I.Q. in the top 2 percent of the population. (The youngest ever was 2 years and 4 months.)</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Late-night comedy: </strong>Representative Adam Schiff repeatedly invoked the nation’s founders at the impeachment trial. “Schiff quoted Hamilton so many times today, he was nominated for five Tony Awards,” <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/23/arts/television/trevor-noah-trump-impeachment-late-night.html" title="">Jimmy Kimmel said</a>.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">What we’re reading: </strong><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://topics.amcham.com.tw/2020/01/story-of-q/" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">This explainer on a measure of deliciousness</a>, from Taiwan Business Topics: “Today’s lesson,” writes our food correspondent Kim Severson, “is understanding the Q factor in Taiwanese food. It’s good-chewy.”</p>, <h3 class="css-1b8te77 e1gnsphs0" id="link-7ded7ef4">Now, a break from the news</h3>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Cook: </strong>If tres leches cake is not enough, <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://cooking.nytimes.com/recipes/1020805-seis-leches-cake" title="">add three more milks</a>.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Watch: </strong>Twenty-five years after the release of “Before Sunrise,” <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/22/movies/before-sunrise-ethan-hawke-julie-delpy.html" title="">the film’s stars and creators spoke to The Times</a> about how they made movie magic out of a tiny budget and capricious trains.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Read:</strong> “Leadership Strategy and Tactics,” by the former Navy SEAL Jocko Willink, is a No. 1 debut on our <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/books/best-sellers/advice-how-to-and-miscellaneous/2020/02/02" title="">advice, how-to and miscellaneous best-seller list</a>.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Smarter Living: </strong>Here’s <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/22/travel/how-to-tip-in-hotels.html" title="">how to tip hotel workers</a>.</p>, <h3 class="css-1b8te77 e1gnsphs0" id="link-15767e9b">And now for the Back Story on …</h3>, <h2 class="css-3ez4hu eoo0vm40" id="link-503bc80b">The front line of an outbreak</h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">Javier C. Hernández, a correspondent in our Beijing bureau, </em><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/21/world/asia/china-coronavirus-wuhan.html" title=""><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">is reporting this week from Wuhan</em></a><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">, the Chinese city at the center of the coronavirus outbreak. Mike Ives, on the Briefings team, spoke with Javier via Slack, a messaging service.</em></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Hi, Javier. What’s the mood in Wuhan right now?</strong></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Walking the streets, you definitely feel a sense of urgency is spreading. Lots of people are wearing masks and avoiding big crowds. All of this is happening in the midst of the Lunar New Year holiday, so it has forced many families to rethink their plans. People are canceling dinners, staying home from work and hunkering down.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">It must be hard to avoid big crowds in a city of 11 million.</strong></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Yes, it’s almost impossible to avoid crowds in a modern Chinese city. But Wuhan is trying to push people to take more precautions. When you get in a cab now, there are reminders about opening the window and wearing a mask. Some of the famous street markets are totally empty, surrounded by signs warning about the virus.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Are you hearing any common sentiments in your interviews?</strong></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Several people told me about their memories of the SARS crisis of 2003, which killed hundreds of people in China. They’re worried this could erupt into a full-blown epidemic. Of course, others say they’re not very concerned and have faith that China can beat this. One common theme is people say they want the Chinese government to speak honestly about the severity of the outbreak — something that didn’t happen during SARS.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Are you taking any specific precautions, like wearing a mask?</strong></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Yes, at the advice of experts, my colleague Elsie Chen and I are washing our hands regularly and avoiding meat markets and hospital wards. We are wearing masks all the time. It’s a bit odd having that kind of barrier when you’re interviewing people on the street. But we’ve found that it is quickly becoming the norm in Wuhan. There are even videos now circulating of people giving New Year’s toasts with their masks on!</p>, <p class="css-ma92ss evys1bk0">That’s it for this briefing. See you next time.</p>, <p class="css-ma92ss evys1bk0">— Chris</p>, <p class="css-jwz2nf etfikam0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Thank you</strong><br/>Mark Josephson, Eleanor Stanford and Chris Harcum provided the break from the news. You can reach the team at <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="mailto:briefing@nytimes.com" title="">briefing@nytimes.com</a>. </p>, <p class="css-jwz2nf etfikam0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">P.S.</strong><br/>• We’re listening to “<a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/thedaily" title="">The Daily</a>.” Today’s episode is about the Duke and Duchess of Sussex.<br/>• Here’s today’s <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/crosswords/game/mini" title="">Mini Crossword</a>, and a clue: Presidential candidate Klobuchar (three letters). <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/crosswords" title="">You can find all our puzzles here</a>.<br/>• The Times <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytco.com/press/new-york-times-documentaries-at-sundance/" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">will premiere two documentaries</a> at the Sundance Film Festival this month.</p>, <p>Advertisement</p>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd" id="site-index-label">Site Index</h2>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-0">news</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-1">opinion</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-2">arts</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-3">living</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-4">more</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-subscribe-label">Subscribe</h3>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd">Site Information Navigation</h2>]
[<p>Advertisement</p>, <p>Supported by</p>, <h1 class="css-1s4ffep e1h9rw200" id="link-63dfe8b2" itemprop="headline"><span>Panic and Criticism Spread on Chinese Social Media Over Coronavirus</span></h1>, <p class="css-1ifw933 e1wiw3jv0" id="article-summary">Chinese citizens are overcoming a lack of reporting on the crisis in the state-run media by sharing their own videos and information about the coronavirus outbreak.</p>, <p class="css-1fv7b6t e1jsehar1" itemprop="author" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">By<!-- --> <a class="css-brehiz e1jsehar0" href="https://www.nytimes.com/by/daniel-victor"><span class="css-1baulvz last-byline" itemprop="name">Daniel Victor</span></a></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">HONG KONG — While China’s state-run media has urged calm and praised the official <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/23/world/asia/china-coronavirus-outbreak.html" title="">response to the coronavirus outbreak</a>, a different story is playing out across the country’s tightly controlled social media networks. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">In the digital world, China’s citizens are expressing panic and frustration. They are overcoming a lack of reporting in the official media by sharing their own videos and information — sometimes inaccurately. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Some are even evading censors, who commonly stifle criticism of the government, to register complaints about how officials have handled the crisis. They have criticized officials for failing to contain the initial outbreak in Wuhan, the capital of the central province of Hubei; for limiting residents to overcrowded facilities in the region; and for not visiting the affected areas. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“Let’s not interrupt the leaders while they listen to songs and go abroad for interviews,” one commenter wrote sarcastically.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Though some barbs have slipped through, <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/22/health/virus-corona.html" title="">the censors are still scrubbing material</a> critical of the government, or information deemed alarming. It has <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.poynter.org/fact-checking/2020/the-2019-coronavirus-virus-lands-in-the-u-s-after-killing-17-and-taking-eight-to-prison/" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">detained at least eight people</a> for spreading what the government has called “rumors.” </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">But residents are still using social networks and messaging platforms to offer on-the-ground accounts of the crisis that are difficult to find elsewhere.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Users have shared experiences of waiting in lines at hospitals for hours, shuttling sick loved ones from hospital to hospital, only to be sent home without being tested for the coronavirus. Some videos, like one taken on an unknown date at Wuhan No. 7 Hospital, have made their way from China’s closed-off internet onto networks like Twitter.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Several hospitals in affected cities have sent out pleas for donations online, saying they were running short of surgical masks, gloves and other supplies. Some health workers spoke of the challenge of getting to hospitals in cities where public transportation has been shut down and taxi services suspended. </p>, <h1 class="g-headline" id="g-inlineguide-headline">The Coronavirus Outbreak</h1>, <h2 class="g-inlineguide-list-header g-optimize-type">What do you need to know? Start here.</h2>, <p class="g-inlineguide-date">Updated Feb. 5, 2020</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Videos circulating in chat groups and social networks show patients in Wuhan being loaded into an ambulance by <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://twitter.com/xinyanyu/status/1220226571128266752" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">workers wearing full-body protective suits</a> outside a primary school, or <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://twitter.com/RFA_Chinese/status/1219536974362472450" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">transported in a plastic tube</a> in Huizhou, a city in the southeastern province of Guangdong. Several videos have emerged of a patient being wheeled through an airport in <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://twitter.com/MissXQ/status/1220226081632014336" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">a sealed-off cage</a>.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The videos often lack crucial identifying information, including when they were filmed, but many have spread rapidly in recent days among Chinese internet users in the absence of more official information. The state-run media has largely played down the crisis, focusing instead on the encouragement of government officials and the heroism of medical workers. Only a few news outlets have reported critically on the handling of the outbreak by the health care system and the government.<span class="css-8l6xbc evw5hdy0"> </span></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">In the vacuum, misinformation has flourished. One article claimed to cite a health expert as recommending that people counter the virus by rinsing their mouths with salt water, but the expert never said it and the tactic is ineffective. Another widely read but completely false post claimed that setting off fireworks would sterilize germs in the air.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">China’s National Health Commission even went so far as to debunk popular reports saying that drinking a traditional Chinese medicine herb known as indigowoad root, mixed with smoked vinegar, could prevent infection by the coronavirus. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Still, the digital networks have proven useful in conveying the human toll of the virus. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“Save my life, doctor, I have the fever too,” a woman in a mask wailed in <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/video/world/asia/100000006936419/coronavirus-china-wuhan.html" title="">a widely circulated video</a>, as hospital workers in protective suits walked in and out of what appeared to be a crowded waiting room.</p>, <p class="css-jwz2nf etfikam0">Tiffany May and Elaine Yu contributed reporting.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"></p>, <p>Advertisement</p>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd" id="site-index-label">Site Index</h2>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-0">news</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-1">opinion</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-2">arts</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-3">living</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-4">more</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-subscribe-label">Subscribe</h3>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd">Site Information Navigation</h2>]
[<p>Advertisement</p>, <p>Supported by</p>, <h1 class="css-1s4ffep e1h9rw200" id="link-6c23b601" itemprop="headline"><span>Chicago Woman Is Second Patient in U.S. With Wuhan Coronavirus</span></h1>, <p class="css-1ifw933 e1wiw3jv0" id="article-summary">Federal health officials are monitoring 63 other people in 22 states for signs of infection.</p>, <p class="css-1fv7b6t e1jsehar1" itemprop="author" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">By<!-- --> <a class="css-brehiz e1jsehar0" href="https://www.nytimes.com/by/denise-grady"><span class="css-1baulvz last-byline" itemprop="name">Denise Grady</span></a></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">A second patient in the United States has been found to be infected with the Wuhan coronavirus, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention announced on Friday.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The patient is a woman in her 60s who had traveled to Wuhan, China — the epicenter of the outbreak — and returned to Chicago on Jan. 13. She did not become ill until several days after arriving in Chicago, so officials do not think there is much risk to others who were on her flight home.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">She did not take public transportation, attend any large gatherings or have close contact with anyone outside her home after returning, officials said. Members of her household are being monitored.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The woman was taken to a hospital, but she is doing well and is being kept there primarily to keep the infection from spreading, officials said at a news briefing. They declined to name the woman or the hospital.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The first known case in the United States, of a man in Washington State who had traveled to Wuhan, was reported on Tuesday.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“The immediate risk to the American public is low at this time, but the situation continues to evolve rapidly,” Dr. Nancy Messonnier, the director of the National Center for Immunization and Respiratory Diseases, said at a news briefing held by the C.D.C. More cases are expected in the United States, she said.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Sixty-three other people in 22 states are being monitored for possible infection, the C.D.C. said. They are people with respiratory symptoms who may have been exposed to the virus through their own travels or by contact with a patient. So far, 11 of the 63 have tested negative for the infection.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The people being tested, called “patients under investigation,” were reported to the C.D.C. by state health officials. Samples from the patients — respiratory fluids and blood — have to be sent to the C.D.C., which tests them for genetic material from the virus.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The testing takes four to six hours. The C.D.C. is developing kits that officials will send out to the states so that local authorities can do the testing themselves and get results faster.</p>, <h1 class="g-headline" id="g-inlineguide-headline">The Coronavirus Outbreak</h1>, <h2 class="g-inlineguide-list-header g-optimize-type">What do you need to know? Start here.</h2>, <p class="g-inlineguide-date">Updated Feb. 5, 2020</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Following a briefing in Washington by officials from the C.D.C. and the National Institutes of Health on Friday, senators said it was most likely that more cases would be identified in the United States.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“The idea is to identify and then contain it,” said Senator John Barrasso, Republican of Wyoming.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“We’re trying to stop and prevent anyone from coming to the United States that may have it,” he added.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The C.D.C. is sending a team to talk to the patient and her family in Chicago, according to Senators Richard J. Durbin and Tammy Duckworth, both Democrats of Illinois.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Coronaviruses are worrying because epidemics caused by other members of the viral family, SARS and MERS, have had high death rates: 10 percent for SARS, and about 35 percent for MERS. It is too soon to know the death rate for the new virus.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Although influenza kills more people every year, its overall mortality rate is only about 0.1 percent. The number of the deaths is high because so many people become infected. The death rate of the Spanish flu in 1918 was about 2 percent.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Because of the higher death rates, widespread coronavirus epidemics could take a heavy toll, so the health authorities scramble to stamp them out.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">A major concern is that with both SARS and MERS, a few patients inexplicably became “superspreaders” who infected huge numbers of other people. At a hospital in Seoul, South Korea, in 2015, one man with MERS transmitted it to 82 patients.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The C.D.C. now recommends avoiding nonessential travel to Wuhan.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Because the disease has spread beyond Wuhan, travelers to other parts of China should avoid contact with people who are sick, stay away from markets that sell live wild animals — believed to be the source of the virus — and wash their hands frequently.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Federal health officials are asking people with possible exposure to the virus and who develop symptoms like shortness of breath, cough and fever to call health care providers first, rather than just showing up at a doctor’s office, clinic or emergency room.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">With advance notice, doctors can take steps to prevent the spread of the virus, like isolating patients and putting masks on themselves and the patients. The woman in Chicago followed those instructions, officials said.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">There is no antiviral drug to treat coronavirus infection, but a medicine called remdesivir has shown promise in animal studies and would be a good candidate for trials in humans, according to Dr. Mark R. Denison, an infectious disease expert at Vanderbilt University.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/28/health/coronavirus-vaccine.html" title="">There is also no vaccine to prevent the disease</a>, but researchers at the National Institutes of Health reported on Thursday that it might be possible to develop one ready for testing in people within a few months.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The incubation period of the disease — the time it takes for symptoms to develop after a person has been exposed to the virus — is thought to be about two weeks, Dr. Messonnier said.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Nearly 1,300 people are infected in China, and a handful of cases have turned up in at least seven other countries. All were travelers who brought home the infection from China. At least 41 people have died.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">On Thursday, the World Health Organization declined to declare the outbreak a global emergency, but it “may yet become one,” said Dr. Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus,<strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10"><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0"> </em></strong>the W.H.O.’s director general. It is certainly an emergency within China, he added.</p>, <h2 class="css-zd32qr">Wuhan Coronavirus Map: Tracking the Spread of the Outbreak</h2>, <p class="css-1uuihdo">The virus has sickened tens of thousands of people in China and a number of other countries.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Five major airports in the United States are screening passengers arriving from Wuhan for signs of infection with coronavirus.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The screenings are imperfect. The illness may resemble a common cold or the flu. Some infected travelers, like the two who have been found to have the disease, may have arrived in the United States before symptoms were evident or before screenings were implemented.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">People being screened are also given cards with instructions about what symptoms to look out for and how to seek health care if they develop them.</p>, <p class="css-jwz2nf etfikam0">Emily Cochrane contributed reporting from Washington.</p>, <p>Advertisement</p>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd" id="site-index-label">Site Index</h2>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-0">news</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-1">opinion</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-2">arts</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-3">living</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-4">more</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-subscribe-label">Subscribe</h3>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd">Site Information Navigation</h2>]
[<p>Advertisement</p>, <p>Supported by</p>, <h1 class="css-1s4ffep e1h9rw200" id="link-6d62f836" itemprop="headline"><span>Coronavirus Outbreak Sours Japan on Chinese Tourist Boom</span></h1>, <p class="css-1ifw933 e1wiw3jv0" id="article-summary">Asia’s two largest economies have been drawing closer. But as the Lunar New Year holiday starts, some Japanese say they cannot help but regard Chinese visitors warily.</p>, <p class="css-1fv7b6t e1jsehar1" itemprop="author" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">By<!-- --> <a class="css-brehiz e1jsehar0" href="https://www.nytimes.com/by/motoko-rich"><span class="css-1baulvz last-byline" itemprop="name">Motoko Rich</span></a></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">TOKYO — Just as Japan and China have been taking tentative steps toward moving past old animosities, a fast-spreading virus threatens to push them apart.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">A <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/article/what-is-coronavirus.html" title="">deadly coronavirus outbreak in China</a>, which has spawned fears of a pandemic across Asia, is raising concern in Japan that public sentiment could be damaged as Chinese citizens have become an increasingly visible part of daily life.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The alarm over the virus is unlikely to hurt formal government relations. After years of mounting tensions over history and territory, the two largest Asian economies have been <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2017/11/16/world/asia/seeing-us-in-retreat-under-trump-japan-and-china-move-to-mend-ties.html?searchResultPosition=1" title="">drawing closer</a>, with Japan planning a state visit for the Chinese leader, Xi Jinping, this spring.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">But with the start of the weeklong Lunar New Year holiday ushering in one of the busiest travel seasons for Chinese tourists, some Japanese say they cannot help but regard Chinese visitors warily. It is a view shared in many Asian countries that have experienced an influx of Chinese tourists — and their money — in recent years.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“I’m worried about the epidemic spreading here,” said Naho Imajima, 34, who works at a tobacco shop in the Kabukicho entertainment district in Tokyo, which is popular with Chinese visitors. “Even people who cough, most of them aren’t wearing masks. It could just be a cold, but I never know. I get nervous when a foreign tourist passes by and they’re coughing.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Chinese travelers have fueled a tourism boom in Japan, increasing fourfold in the last five years to more than 9.5 million annually, and now representing about a third of all foreign visitors. In addition, more Chinese students are enrolling in Japanese universities, and in some cases they make up a majority in graduate programs.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Many shops and restaurants around Japan now cater to Chinese travelers, posting signs in Chinese and accepting payment systems from China like Alipay or WeChat Pay.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">But after two visitors from Wuhan, the epicenter of the new outbreak, were hospitalized in Japan for coronavirus infections over the past week, nerves have been on edge.</p>, <h1 class="g-headline" id="g-inlineguide-headline">The Coronavirus Outbreak</h1>, <h2 class="g-inlineguide-list-header g-optimize-type">What do you need to know? Start here.</h2>, <p class="g-inlineguide-date">Updated Feb. 10, 2020</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">This month, a shop owner in Hakone, a popular hot-springs resort town, posted a sign reading, “Chinese are not allowed to enter the store.” A photo of it was widely shared on social media in both Japan and China, and some began to wonder if the new coronavirus would amplify an anti-Chinese undercurrent that persists in Japan.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Others applauded the shop owner’s move, saying that Chinese tourists often exhibited “bad manners,” a common theme in online complaints and news reports.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Masanari Iida, a former candidate for public office in Kanagawa Prefecture, argued on Twitter that the owner was acting in “self-defense.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“I don’t understand why this is a problem,” <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://twitter.com/masanari_iida/status/1220578471669186560?s=20" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">Mr. Iida wrote</a>. “The store has a right to choose its customers.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Fears have spiraled across Asia as China reported that the virus has caused at least 41 deaths and sickened nearly 1,300 people. The Chinese government <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/24/world/asia/china-coronavirus.html?campaign_id=60&amp;instance_id=0&amp;segment_id=20602&amp;user_id=b6a9f6b7854f15308544c8d1a4d9b070&amp;regi_id=60810331" title="">has put a dozen cities</a> in the central part of the country on a travel lockdown, effectively corralling 35 million residents.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The Japanese prime minister, Shinzo Abe, said on Friday that Japan would increase efforts to quarantine visitors who showed symptoms of the coronavirus. The government also recommended that Japanese citizens refrain from visiting Wuhan for “unnecessary or nonurgent trips.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">All Nippon Airways canceled all flights to and from Wuhan until Feb. 1. JalPak, a package tour operator owned by Japan Airlines, said that 50 customers had canceled trips to China in the past week because of news of the virus.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">At a cabinet meeting, Mr. Abe said he hoped that the public would not “worry excessively” and would act calmly, and he called for people to take the same precautions that they would for the common cold, including washing their hands and <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/23/health/coronavirus-surgical-masks.html?action=click&amp;module=Top%20Stories&amp;pgtype=Homepage" title="">wearing surgical masks</a>.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">With tourism from China such an important segment of the Japanese economy, some business owners said they did not want the coronavirus to affect views of customers from China.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“Seeing the news, we worry about the disease a little, but I cannot say ‘please don’t come,’” said Setsuko Yoshizawa, 70, the owner of a shop in the Tokyo district of Asakusa, the site of a temple that is often mobbed with Chinese tourists. “We cannot survive without customers visiting us. I welcome Chinese visitors.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Japanese public sentiment about China has improved since the lows seen when the <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2012/08/22/world/asia/dispute-over-islands-reflect-japanese-fear-of-chinas-rise.html?searchResultPosition=5" title="">two countries were locked in an intense territorial dispute</a> over islands in the East China Sea, but it is still not terribly high.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">According to an annual survey by Japan’s central cabinet office, just over 5 percent of those polled in 2014 said they felt “an affinity with China.” Last year, the figure was about 23 percent.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Komaki Lee, a Chinese-born naturalized Japanese citizen who has twice run unsuccessfully for public office, said he had often experienced discrimination because of his Chinese heritage.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">When he was a candidate four years ago and again last year, he said, people defaced his campaign posters with the words “Go home!” or trolled him with similar sentiments online or in person.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“Now it’s the season for a lot of Chinese tourists to visit Japan, and there is this pandemic happening,” Mr. Lee said. “So I think that Japanese people will try to avoid Chinese people more, and I think that’s when discrimination might worsen.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Still, the more hostile strains of anti-Chinese expression in Japan are met with pushback. When Tsuyoshi Iida tried to run for office in Kanagawa last year, his party declined to endorse him because its leaders said he had repeatedly posted hate speech online directed at Chinese and Koreans.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">This month, the University of Tokyo <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="http://www.iii.u-tokyo.ac.jp/news/2019112911060" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">fired an associate professor</a> of artificial intelligence, Shohei Ohsawa, who made anti-Chinese comments on Twitter, including saying that he would never hire Chinese students at a company for which he was doing research.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Japanese attitudes about China may be shaped more by criticism of the Chinese government than its people, said Atsushi Kondo, a professor of immigration policy studies at Meijo University in Nagoya.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“More people question human rights and democracy over the Chinese government’s policy against the Uighurs or Hong Kong,” said Mr. Kondo, referring to the Chinese government’s detention of <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2019/11/16/world/asia/china-xinjiang-documents.html" title="">Muslim ethnic minorities in internment camps</a> and its repression of <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/news-event/hong-kong-protests" title="">the pro-democracy movement</a> in Hong Kong.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“There might be some cases where some people experience trouble over the manners of tourists and have bad feelings,” Mr. Kondo added. “But I don’t think anti-Chinese sentiment is growing in general.”</p>, <p class="css-jwz2nf etfikam0">Eimi Yamamitsu, Makiko Inoue and Hisako Ueno contributed reporting.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"></p>, <p>Advertisement</p>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd" id="site-index-label">Site Index</h2>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-0">news</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-1">opinion</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-2">arts</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-3">living</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-4">more</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-subscribe-label">Subscribe</h3>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd">Site Information Navigation</h2>]
[<p>Advertisement</p>, <p>Supported by</p>, <h1 class="css-1s4ffep e1h9rw200" id="link-c40802" itemprop="headline"><span>Toll From Outbreak Climbs in China as Infections Reach Europe and Australia</span></h1>, <p class="css-1ifw933 e1wiw3jv0" id="article-summary">Shanghai Disneyland shut down, hospitals pleaded for help, France reported three cases and the youngest victim so far was identified. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">This briefing has ended. Read about developments in the </em><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/25/world/asia/china-coronavirus.html" title=""><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">coronavirus outbreak here</em></a><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">.</em></p>, <h3 class="css-k42qd2 e1gnsphs0">A deadly outbreak is growing. Here's what you need to know.</h3>, <h2 class="css-3ez4hu eoo0vm40" id="link-3d496873">Fifteen new deaths were reported in Wuhan, the epicenter of the outbreak.</h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Fifteen more people have died in the city of <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2020/01/21/world/asia/china-coronavirus-maps.html" title="">Wuhan, the Hubei provincial capital and epicenter of the outbreak</a>, <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="http://wjw.hubei.gov.cn/fbjd/dtyw/202001/t20200125_2014854.shtml" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">the health authorities in Hubei said.</a></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The new figures, announced early Saturday, represented a nearly 60 percent jump from the previous death toll of 26. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Just three of the 41 deaths reported over all have taken place outside of Wuhan: one in another city in Hubei Province, one in Hebei Province, and one in Heilongjiang, near the Russian border.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The new victims ranged from 55 to 87 years old. Eleven were male, and four female.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Nationwide, more than 400 new cases of the virus were diagnosed, officials said early Saturday, bringing the total number of confirmed cases in China to nearly 1,300.<span class="css-8l6xbc evw5hdy0"> </span></p>, <h2 class="css-zd32qr">Wuhan Coronavirus Map: Tracking the Spread of the Outbreak</h2>, <p class="css-1uuihdo">The virus has sickened tens of thousands of people in China and a number of other countries.</p>, <h2 class="css-3ez4hu eoo0vm40" id="link-1d0933b3">China restricts travel for 35
