million people as the death toll rises.</h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The authorities on Friday greatly expanded a travel lockdown in central China to include 12 cities near the center of the outbreak, effectively penning in 35 million residents — nearly the population of Canada — in an effort to contain the dangerous coronavirus.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The new travel limits — abruptly decreed ahead of the Lunar New Year holiday, China’s busiest travel season — were an extraordinary step that underlined the governing Communist Party’s <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/21/world/asia/china-coronavirus-wuhan.html" title="">deepening fears</a> about the outbreak of <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/article/what-is-coronavirus.html" title="">a little-understood coronavirus</a>.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Just one day after China restricted travel in and from the center of the outbreak, Wuhan, a city of 11 million and the capital of Hubei Province, and four nearby towns, the government announced plans to suspend public transportation services covering more than half the population of the province.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The rapidly expanding outbreak has overwhelmed the Chinese province’s hospitals and fueled fears of a global pandemic. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">All the deaths reported so far have been in China. Most have been older patients, but included a 36-year-old man.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">On Thursday morning, the authorities imposed a travel lockdown in Wuhan, and airlines canceled hundreds of flights to the city, leaving thousands of people stranded.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Later in the day, officials said they would also halt public transportation in the nearby cities of Huanggang, Ezhou, Zhijiang and Chibi, which are together home to more than nine million residents. By Friday, restrictions had been announced in eight other cities.</p>, <h2 class="css-3ez4hu eoo0vm40" id="link-5a4c4599">New cases are confirmed in the United States, France and Australia.</h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/24/health/chicago-coronavirus-cdc.html" title="">announced on Friday</a> that a second case of the coronavirus had been confirmed in the United States: a woman in her 60s in Chicago who had recently traveled to Wuhan, China, the center of the outbreak. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The other case, a man in his 30s, was<a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/21/health/cdc-coronavirus.html?action=click&amp;module=Top%20Stories&amp;pgtype=Homepage" title=""> in Washington State. </a></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The unidentified woman returned to Chicago on Jan. 13, officials said. She became ill days later. As of Friday, she was still hospitalized but was doing better. Officials at a news briefing declined to name the hospital.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The C.D.C. told reporters that 63 patients in 22 states were under investigation for the coronavirus; 11 have tested negative. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">France became the first country in Europe to report the infections. The Health Ministry<a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://solidarites-sante.gouv.fr/actualites/presse/communiques-de-presse/article/cp-coronavirus" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title=""> reported three confirmed cases </a>— two in Paris and one in Bordeaux. All three people had spent time in China. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Agnès Buzyn, the health minister, told reporters earlier Friday that France reported the first European cases “because we were very quick in establishing the test and identifying the cases.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Australia reported its first confirmed case on Saturday: a man in his 50s visiting from China, who was being treated in a Melbourne hospital. The authorities there said he had been in Wuhan before falling ill, and that he had arrived in Melbourne on Sunday, on a flight from Guangzhou.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">American officials have announced expanded screenings for the infection at major airports in the United States. In addition to New York, Los Angeles and San Francisco, airports in Atlanta and Chicago began examining passengers arriving from Wuhan for signs of illness.</p>, <h2 class="css-3ez4hu eoo0vm40" id="link-46c299c1">Anger and mistrust spill over online.</h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">On Chinese social media, people across the country expressed mounting mistrust and resentment of the authorities in Wuhan, whom they blamed for mishandling the outbreak.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Some users called for Wuhan leaders to be removed. Others mocked the failure of the Communist Party’s newspapers to treat the epidemic with front-page urgency. Most of those posts were quickly removed by censors.</p>, <h1 class="g-headline" id="g-inlineguide-headline">The Coronavirus Outbreak</h1>, <h2 class="g-inlineguide-list-header g-optimize-type">What do you need to know? Start here.</h2>, <p class="g-inlineguide-date">Updated Feb. 10, 2020</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">On the Twitter-like platform Weibo, Li Haipeng, a former journalist, wrote: “What is happening in Wuhan is really outrageous. Can it be hollow to this extent, incompetent to this degree?” </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">His post was shared more than 41,000 times and received more than 5,000 comments. One commenter wrote, “I hope the central government can take over before dawn. It’s almost like anarchy.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Another wrote, “Wuhan’s party secretary and governor cannot soothe the people’s anger.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">In another post, a woman whose profile said she worked at a Hubei hospital shared a photo of instant noodles, lamenting that it was the only food she was given after working late on the night before Lunar New Year — traditionally time for a large meal shared with family.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The post was shared more than 30,000 times, and received more than 25,000 comments. “The Wuhan government is not worthy of such good medical staff,” one person replied.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Still, at least one person was decidedly complimentary: President Trump, who <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/15/business/economy/china-trade-deal.html" title="">reached a trade truce with China last week</a> and has sought to cool tensions with the Chinese government.<span class="css-8l6xbc evw5hdy0"> </span>“China has been working very hard to contain the Coronavirus,” Mr. Trump<a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://twitter.com/realDonaldTrump/status/1220818115354923009" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title=""> wrote on Twitter on Friday.</a> “The United States greatly appreciates their efforts and transparency.”<span class="css-8l6xbc evw5hdy0"> </span></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Mr. Trump especially singled out China’s leader, Xi Jinping: “In particular, on behalf of the American People, I want to thank President Xi!”</p>, <h2 class="css-3ez4hu eoo0vm40" id="link-686599a0">Anxiety hangs over residents on Lunar New Year’s Eve.</h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The Lunar New Year is the most important holiday in the traditional Chinese calendar, and celebrations start on the eve, which this year falls on Friday. Chinese were expected to travel home in time to help wrap dumplings or fry sticky rice cakes for all-important reunion dinners with their extended families. At midnight, families around the country usually set off firecrackers and fireworks.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">But these celebrations are set to be far more muted this year, particularly in Wuhan and other parts of Hubei Province where the authorities have imposed travel restrictions.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">In Wuhan, people waited anxiously on Friday outside Hankou Hospital, one of the medical facilities designated to test for the coronavirus, as their relatives sought treatment inside.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Several said the Lunar New Year would pass without the usual celebrations or vacation travel. They and other residents said that the city was now also confronting food supply problems because so many shops and markets had closed, adding to the hardships caused by the city shutdown.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“We won’t have a new year celebration tonight. There’s no feeling for it, and no food,” Wu Qiang, a resident in his 50s who was waiting outside the hospital entrance for word about his son, told a New York Times correspondent.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Mr. Wu said he understood the need to close off the city, but added that city authorities should ensure that enough shops and markets were selling fresh food. He said his son had been sneezing, setting off alarm at home.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“I think he’s O.K., but now even an ordinary sneeze makes you worry,” Mr. Wu said. “You start to think every cough or sneeze might be the virus.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Chen Yanming, 47, who said her father might have contracted the coronavirus, said she was melancholic and anxious as the Lunar New Year came. She said her father had suffered a high fever for a few days and was being treated in the hospital.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“Today should be the Chinese people’s happiest day,” she said, “but this sickness has destroyed that feeling.”</p>, <h2 class="css-3ez4hu eoo0vm40" id="link-6b5f85f9">China reports two deaths far from the outbreak’s center.</h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The official death toll from the mysterious coronavirus increased by more than a half-dozen in 24 hours, to 26, while the number of confirmed cases jumped by more than 200.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The majority of the deaths have occurred in Hubei Province, in central China, but two deaths have been confirmed outside the center of the outbreak.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">One patient died in Hebei Province, more than 600 miles north of Wuhan, the authorities <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="http://www.hebwst.gov.cn/index.do?id=394917&amp;templet=content&amp;cid=14" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">announced</a> on Thursday. Another death was confirmed in Heilongjiang, a province near the border with Russia, more than 1,500 miles from Wuhan.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The youngest victim of the outbreak so far has been identified as a 36-year-old man identified only as Li. He died on Thursday after being admitted to the hospital on Jan. 9, the Hubei Health Commission said. He suffered a cardiac arrest less than two hours before he died, officials said.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The disease has now been detected in Australia, Malaysia, Nepal, Vietnam, Singapore, Japan, South Korea, Taiwan, Thailand, France and the United States. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">On Friday, the authorities in Nepal said a student who had returned to the country from China had been confirmed to be infected with the coronavirus. He has already been treated and released.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Dr. Anup Bastola, a spokesman for the government-run Sukraraj Tropical and Infectious Diseases Hospital, said a 32-year-old doctoral student was admitted to the hospital on Jan. 13 after having some respiratory problems.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Concerned over his symptoms, the doctors sent samples of his blood and sputum for testing. Later, he was found to be infected with the<span class="css-8l6xbc evw5hdy0"> </span>virus that emerged from Wuhan, China.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">After spending four days in the hospital, the student was discharged on Jan. 17.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">In the aftermath, Nepal’s Health Ministry has activated health screenings at Tribhuvan International Airport.</p>, <h2 class="css-3ez4hu eoo0vm40" id="link-1f797d90">Experts are preparing for an outbreak that could last months.</h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Dr. Gauden Galea, the representative of the World Health Organization in Beijing, said in an interview on Friday that while much was uncertain, health officials were preparing for an outbreak that could last for months. He said that eventually thousands of people would most likely be infected, citing models produced by public health experts.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“My own office is gearing up for a number of months,” Dr. Galea said. “We do not expect it to disappear in a number of days.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">He said much would depend on the patterns of infection over the holiday travel season. He said there was little precedent for the travel restrictions imposed by the Chinese authorities but that public health experts were hopeful that they could help contain the virus, along with efforts to expand screening, promote the use of masks and isolate sick patients.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Still, he acknowledged, health officials were being forced to improvise. “Part is science and part is hope,” he said.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Dr. Galea, who visited Wuhan this week before the lockdown, defended how Chinese officials had handled the outbreak, saying they had been transparent in sharing data. He said the Chinese authorities faced a daunting challenge.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“With the number of cases,” he said, “one would expect health systems to be stretched.”</p>, <h2 class="css-3ez4hu eoo0vm40" id="link-6894b5bb">Overrun hospitals turn away residents, some displaying symptoms.</h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">As Wuhan residents waited in long lines at hospitals to be checked for possible coronavirus infections, some residents complained they were not able to get the treatment they needed.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Xiao Shibing, 51, has had a fever for 15 days and finds it difficult to breathe. When he went to a hospital, he was not tested for the coronavirus, said his daughter, Xiao Hongxia. He was told he had a viral chest infection and was sent home.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Mr. Xiao’s family has continued to seek treatment, visiting other hospitals, but has been turned away by at least three because of a shortage of beds, his wife, Feng Xiu, said. “It is like kicking a ball from here to there,” she said.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Cai Pei, 41, said his wife began coughing and developed a fever three days ago. He wrote on Weibo that hospitals would not admit her, and he had difficulty finding masks and cold medicine in pharmacies.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">They still do not know if she is infected with the coronavirus or some more common ailment.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“Sometimes I can only hide and cry, but I couldn’t tell her and had to reassure her that it is not the virus,” Mr. Cai said by phone. “It is very scary. If it’s real, we have a child and elderly parents at home. What if we all get sick?”</p>, <h2 class="css-3ez4hu eoo0vm40" id="link-7f2b5ee2">Wuhan hospitals make urgent appeals for supplies and help.</h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Hospitals and medical workers at the center of the outbreak in Wuhan made urgent appeals for supplies, as stocks of surgical masks and other equipment quickly flew off shelves.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“Shortage of medical supplies, request help!!!” the Wuhan Children’s Hospital said on Thursday in a post on <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.weibo.com/6449404416/IqQIGBlTT?" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">Weibo</a>, the Chinese social network.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The hospital asked for donations of surgical masks, disposable garments, protective goggles and gloves.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Several others, including Hubei General Hospital, Renmin Hospital of Wuhan University and the Central Hospital of Wuhan, posted similar notices.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The central government on Thursday acknowledged the severe strain on resources, and the Ministry of Finance<a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="http://m.mof.gov.cn/czxw/202001/t20200123_3463972.htm" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title=""> announced an urgent allocation</a> of one billion renminbi, about $144 million, for epidemic prevention and control work.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">State news media also carried reports of people volunteering to help ease the strain on health workers. Young doctors at the Renmin Hospital of Wuhan University volunteered to take on additional shifts or to take over from colleagues with children, the state broadcaster CCTV reported.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">A team of 30 volunteers in Wuhan mobilized to drive doctors to and from hospitals, while others have offered to help the local Red Cross answer phone calls and publicize requests for help from hospitals, according to a report by the China Business Journal.</p>, <h2 class="css-3ez4hu eoo0vm40" id="link-34642d9a">Britain and the U.S. warn citizens to avoid the outbreak zone.</h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The American and British governments on Friday urged travelers to avoid the city of Wuhan and the surrounding area amid growing signs that the outbreak of the<span class="css-8l6xbc evw5hdy0"> </span>coronavirus was worsening.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The American Embassy in Beijing advised travelers from the United States <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://china.usembassy-china.org.cn/health-alert-012420/" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">to avoid Hubei Province</a>, where Wuhan is the capital. It said the State Department had already ordered nonemergency government personnel to leave the city. It further warned that the Chinese government might prevent travelers from arriving or leaving.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The State Department notice was a Level 4 advisory, the sternest warning the United States government issues regarding travel. <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://travelmaps.state.gov/TSGMap/" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">Other Level 4 warnings</a> issued by the State Department cover travel to Syria, North Korea, Afghanistan, Iraq, Venezuela and Yemen, among other places. The warning is a step up from Washington’s earlier cautions. Just a day before, the American government had been advising travelers to <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://china.usembassy-china.org.cn/health-alert-update-novel-coronavirus-in-china-5/" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">“exercise extreme caution”</a> when traveling to the Wuhan area.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The British government, in a notice dated Thursday, similarly advised against <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/china" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">all but essential travel</a> to Wuhan. The warning came a day before the government’s Cobra committee was to meet in Downing Street to discuss the threat posed by coronavirus to Britain, <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.itv.com/news/2020-01-24/coronavirus-uk-highly-likely-tests-china-lockdown/" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">according to local news reports</a>.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Fourteen people in Britain were tested for the disease, and all came back negative, the chief medical officer, Chris Whitty, <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://twitter.com/SkyNews/status/1220731968117182465" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">announced on Friday.</a> But checks on others were continuing.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Some British universities <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.theguardian.com/science/2020/jan/24/coronavirus-uk-universities-issue-quarantine-warning-china-chinese-students-in-slugs" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">have also warned students </a>considering traveling home to China that they could face quarantine on their return. The University of Chester had warned its Chinese students that if they return to their homeland, they would not be readmitted without a quarantine period, <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.theguardian.com/science/2020/jan/24/coronavirus-uk-universities-issue-quarantine-warning-china-chinese-students-in-slugs" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">The Guardian reported</a>.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">In a statement on Friday, however, a spokeswoman for the university said in an email: “The University of Chester has a relatively small Chinese student cohort and they are being appropriately supported. All students have been advised they must not interrupt their studies to return to China at this point.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Universities UK, which represents 136 universities in England, Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland, said in an emailed statement on Friday<strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">:</strong> “U.K. universities have been monitoring the coronavirus situation as it unfolds and universities with students in affected areas are working to identify appropriate actions. Universities will continue to follow the latest FCO advice and to monitor the situation, which is evolving rapidly.”</p>, <h2 class="css-3ez4hu eoo0vm40" id="link-bdab571">Shanghai Disneyland and other major attractions will shut down.</h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Shanghai Disneyland, one of the biggest tourist attractions in China, will shut down on Saturday as the Chinese authorities and others look for ways to reduce crowds to stop the spread of the<span class="css-8l6xbc evw5hdy0"> </span>coronavirus.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">In <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.shanghaidisneyresort.com/en/" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">a notice on its website</a> on Friday, Shanghai Disney Resort, the arm of the Walt Disney Company that runs Shanghai Disneyland, blamed the outbreak for the shutdown and said it would reopen at an unspecified date.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The shutdown adds to the tourist and cultural attractions closing across China at the beginning of the Lunar New Year holiday, when many families head out of the house to spend quality time together.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The authorities operating the Badaling section of the Great Wall of China, a popular tourist destination north of Beijing, said it would temporarily close beginning on Saturday. Shanghai Huangpu River Cruise, the company that operates boat tours along Shanghai’s scenic Bund area, said the same. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Shanghai’s movie theaters will be closed throughout the Lunar New Year holidays, a state media outlet said. Film companies said this week that they would pull new releases planned for the peak film-going period.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">A prolonged Shanghai Disneyland shutdown could add to the problems in the region for Disney, the American entertainment giant. Attendance at its Hong Kong Disneyland theme park has been battered by anti-Beijing protests that have swept through Hong Kong’s streets in recent months, frightening away many tourists from mainland China.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Disney <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2016/06/15/business/international/china-disney.html" title="">owns a 43 percent stake</a> in Shanghai Disney Resorts, while state-owned Shanghai Shendi Group holds a majority stake.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The closings at a peak spending time could come <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/23/world/asia/wuhan-coronavirus-china-economy.html" title="">at a considerable cost</a> to the Chinese economy, though it isn’t clear how big that toll might be.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The Economist Intelligence Unit projects that the coronavirus could reduce China’s growth by 0.5 percent to 1 percent, compared with its projected growth rate of 5.9 percent before the outbreak, if the disease worsens on the level of SARS, the outbreak that killed hundreds in 2003.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">That hit would be smaller than the blow from SARS. On the other hand, China’s growth is already slowing, unlike during the SARS outbreak, adding to Beijing’s problems.</p>, <h2 class="css-3ez4hu eoo0vm40" id="link-361ffbc5">Masks may help, but experts say it’s more important to wash your hands.</h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Many infectious disease specialists say that cheap, disposable masks that cover the nose and mouth <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/23/health/coronavirus-surgical-masks.html?action=click&amp;module=Top%20Stories&amp;pgtype=Homepage" title="">can help prevent the spread of infections</a> if they are worn properly and used consistently.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">But there isn’t much high-quality scientific evidence on their effectiveness outside health care settings, experts say.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Dr. Julie Vaishampayan, chairwoman of the public health committee for the Infectious Diseases Society of America, said surgical masks are “the last line of defense.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The masks will, however, block most large respiratory droplets from other people’s sneezes and coughs from entering your mouth and nose, said Dr. Amesh Adalja, an infectious disease physician at the Johns Hopkins Center for Health Security. Coronaviruses are primarily spread through droplets, he said.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Dr. Mark Loeb, an infectious disease specialist at McMaster University in Hamilton, Ontario, said a study during an outbreak of the SARS coronavirus found that any type of protection — whether a mask or a respirator — reduced the risk of infections in health care workers by about 85 percent.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“The most important message was that the risk was lower if they consistently used any mask,” he said.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">But washing hands — <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2016/04/21/health/washing-hands.html" title="">frequently and before eating</a> — is universally recommended. Hand sanitizer is effective against respiratory viruses.</p>, <h2 class="css-3ez4hu eoo0vm40" id="link-b95c66f">China’s propaganda arm features smiles and praises sacrifices as the disease spreads.</h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">China’s propaganda machine has ramped into overdrive as the authorities fight the spread of the coronavirus, praising the sacrifices of responders and everyday people amid <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/22/health/virus-corona.html" title="">continued criticism online</a> of the government’s efforts to address the disease.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Mainstream Chinese news outlets have covered the outbreak closely, though censorship prohibits them from taking a critical look, while official news media like CCTV and The People’s Daily newspaper have played it down. State news media issued <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.weibo.com/tv/v/IqWEdbxSh?fid=1034:4464219383332903" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">herograms</a> to the patriotic Chinese citizens who canceled their trips home to Wuhan and would spend the Lunar New Year holiday alone. It praised <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://m.weibo.cn/2656274875/4464028421990289" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">doctors heading</a> off to Wuhan.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“People of Wuhan are making sacrifices,” <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2019/07/31/world/asia/hu-xijin-global-times-us-china-tensions.html" title="">Hu Xijin, the editor of The Global Times</a>, a nationalist tabloid controlled by the Communist Party, <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://twitter.com/HuXijin_GT/status/1220216412716691456" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">wrote </a>on Twitter. “No matter how all of this happened, I want to express my sympathy and salute to them.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"> </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">On what may be the most watched television show on earth, the Spring Festival Gala, the Chinese government<span class="css-8l6xbc evw5hdy0"> </span>on Friday<span class="css-8l6xbc evw5hdy0"> </span>cheered on Wuhan and<span class="css-8l6xbc evw5hdy0"> </span>praised the country’s leader, Xi Jinping.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Each year, on the eve of the Lunar New Year, the state broadcaster China Central Television shows the gala, a four-hour marathon of speeches, skits and song and dance, all conducted at a stately pace to accommodate a graying audience. Watching the gala while making dumplings — or falling asleep in front of it — is a tradition for many families across the country.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">On Friday night’s broadcast, China’s propaganda minders addressed the coronavirus outbreak head on. During the first half of the broadcast, six prominent CCTV anchors stood onstage and praised the instructions of Mr. Xi and the Communist Party.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">They showed images of doctors and nurses treating patients, of trucks of supplies festooned with banners that said, roughly translated, “Go, Wuhan!”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">They cited the example of Wang Qiang, the Chinese tennis player who earlier on Friday upset Serena Williams in the Australian Open. “As long as we’re not afraid and dare to confront challenges,” said<span class="css-8l6xbc evw5hdy0"> </span>Hai Xia, a longtime CCTV anchor, “we will win.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Then they declared that the fight against the coronavirus was open, transparent and a testament to the competence of the government. Ms. Hai cited “the most transparent information disclosure, the strong leadership of the party’s Central Committee, the efforts of the whole nation.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">By featuring the response on the gala, the government gave its message a broad platform. The anchors ended their presentation with their own cheer: “Go, Wuhan!”</p>, <p class="css-jwz2nf etfikam0">Reporting was contributed by Chris Buckley, Javier Hernández, Vivian Wang, Austin Ramzy, Elaine Yu, Tiffany May, Carlos Tejada, Russell Goldman, Gillian Wong, Paulina Villegas, Steven Lee Myers, Denise Grady, Karen Zraick, Roni Caryn Rabin, Carl Zimmer, Rick Gladstone, Yonette Joseph, Bhadra Sharma, Alexandra Stevenson, Adam Nossiter, Livia Albeck-Ripka and Aurelien Breeden. Research was contributed by Amber Wang, Albee Zhang, Claire Fu, Elsie Chen, Yiwei Wang and Zoe Mou.</p>, <p>Advertisement</p>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd" id="site-index-label">Site Index</h2>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-0">news</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-1">opinion</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-2">arts</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-3">living</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-4">more</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-subscribe-label">Subscribe</h3>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd">Site Information Navigation</h2>]
[<p>Advertisement</p>, <p>Supported by</p>, <h1 class="css-1qskr30 e1h9rw200" id="link-5dc904d3" itemprop="headline"><span>Is America Ready for Another Outbreak?</span></h1>, <p class="css-1ifw933 e1wiw3jv0" id="article-summary">No. But there are clear steps the government needs to take.</p>, <p class="css-1fv7b6t e1jsehar1" itemprop="author" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">By<!-- --> <span class="css-1baulvz last-byline" itemprop="name">Saad B. Omer</span></p>, <p class="css-cpkn1d e1wtpvyy1">Dr. Omer is the director of the Yale Institute for Global Health.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The last time the world heard about a coronavirus outbreak in China, in early 2003, it ended up spreading to more than two dozen countries in the Americas, Europe and Asia, sickening about 8,000 people and killing almost 800.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The illness was named severe acute respiratory syndrome, more commonly known as SARS and still remembered as a near miss. It could have been much worse, we were told — no thanks to severe mismanagement by health authorities in China and elsewhere.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The memory of SARS explains why reports of a newly identified coronavirus originating in China are concerning. The outbreak, originating in the city of Wuhan, has resulted in at least 25 deaths and rapidly spread to several countries, including, in one case, the United States. The World Health Organization has convened an emergency meeting and has been considering declaring the outbreak a “public health emergency of international concern.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Responses to emerging viral threats such as SARS and, later, Ebola have been controversial. During the SARS outbreak, many political leaders were caught unprepared. The mayor of Toronto, a city disproportionately affected by SARS, <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.theglobeandmail.com/news/national/lastmans-on-air-gaffes-add-to-torontos-woes/article1013974/" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">publicly acknowledged</a> his unfamiliarity with basic infection control measures — he didn’t even know what the World Health Organization was.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">In 2015, Donald Trump heavily criticized the Obama administration’s response to the Ebola crisis. Mr. Trump, then a presidential candidate, urged <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://twitter.com/realdonaldtrump/status/495379061972410369?lang=en" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">maximalist measures</a>, such as not allowing Ebola-infected American aid workers back into the country. While there’s little chance that such an extreme step will be required this time, there’s also little evidence that Mr. Trump is taking the potential threat from the virus seriously enough.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Fortunately, there are clear lessons to be applied from both the SARS and Ebola experiences.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">First, be ready for anything, and leave it to the experts. A measured, evidence-based response to this novel coronavirus would involve a series of rapid decisions requiring technical expertise. As the outbreak emerges, new — often contradictory — information will have to be incorporated into outbreak control measures. Fortunately, such expertise exists within the government.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The major public health and biomedical agencies, such as the National Institutes of Health and its constituent institutes, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention and the Food and Drug Administration, are led by well-respected scientists and public health professionals.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The American response should be led by these agencies, rather than politicians. Decisions such as border screenings, travel restrictions and potential quarantine have major public health consequences, and they should be driven by science and emerging biological and epidemiological evidence.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">During the Ebola outbreak, the C.D.C. took several useful measures, including providing guidance to domestic health care providers and sending Ebola response teams out to work with local health authorities in different parts of the country. The C.D.C.’s efforts were credited with preventing further spread of Ebola within the United States.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Second, public health authorities should be candid with the public about the uncertainty that inevitably surrounds a new virus. At this point, we know very little about this new coronavirus, including its source, mortality rate and potential to spread. In order to avoid public panic, health authorities often end up providing false assurances in the face of genuine uncertainty. This “<a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://theconversation.com/listen-up-health-officials-heres-how-to-reduce-ebolanoia-33637" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">panic about panic</a>” can lead public health authorities to unduly play down the risks associated with an outbreak, which can undermine public trust.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Instead, public health officials should recognize that some level of concern is <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="http://www.psandman.com/col/Ebola-2.htm" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">within the range of normal and expected human responses</a> to emerging threats; they should clearly convey what is known, what is unknown and what is unknowable.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Third, the spread of rumors through social media during public health emergencies is, by now, a well-recognized concern. What is appreciated to a lesser extent is the push within the scientific community to rapidly share study results during emergencies by posting them online. Even for the current coronavirus outbreak, several analyses have been posted online by scientific teams around the world.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">While this is a positive trend that can make critical information available in a timely manner, direct sharing of scientific results bypasses the peer review process essential for ensuring the quality of scientific evidence. Interim and sometimes half-baked results can be rapidly amplified through social media.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">We know from experience that initial scientific insights often end up being incomplete and, in some cases, outright incorrect. One option for quality control of scientific output in a public health emergency is a rapid peer review entity — perhaps co-managed by major research institutes and funded by global health funding entities such as the Wellcome Trust and the Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation. We need such rapid information and insight, but even more important, we need it to be right.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">We are once again faced with the outbreak of an emerging pathogen with potentially global implications. We don’t know how bad it will get. But there is no excuse for not getting ready for the worst. We already know the consequences of inaction.</p>, <p class="css-jwz2nf etfikam0"><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="http://www.saadomer.org" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">Saad B. Omer</a> (<a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://twitter.com/SaadOmer3?ref_src=twsrc%5Egoogle%7Ctwcamp%5Eserp%7Ctwgr%5Eauthor" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">@SaadOmer3</a>) is the director of the Yale Institute for Global Health and a professor of internal medicine and epidemiology at the Yale School of Medicine and the Yale School of Public Health.</p>, <p class="css-jwz2nf etfikam0"><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">The Times is committed to publishing </em><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2019/01/31/opinion/letters/letters-to-editor-new-york-times-women.html" title=""><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">a diversity of letters</em></a><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0"> to the editor. We’d like to hear what you think about this or any of our articles. Here are some </em><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://help.nytimes.com/hc/en-us/articles/115014925288-How-to-submit-a-letter-to-the-editor" title=""><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">tips</em></a><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">. <span class="byline last-byline" itemprop="author creator" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
      By <span class="byline-author" data-byline-name="TOBY BILANOW" itemprop="name">TOBY BILANOW</span>

<time class="dateline" content="2020-01-24" datetime="2020-01-24" itemprop="dateModified">JAN. 24, 2020</time>

</p>, <p>As temperatures dropped into the 30s in South Florida, the National Weather Service in Miami warned residents to keep an eye out for these cold-stunned animals falling from trees:</p>, <p>Anacondas</p>, <p>Pythons</p>, <p>Fruit bats</p>, <p>Iguanas</p>, <p>The first confirmed case in the United States of the potentially deadly new Chinese coronavirus was identified in a man in his 30s who had traveled to Wuhan and returned to his home in this state:</p>, <p>Virginia</p>, <p>Minnesota</p>, <p>Washington</p>, <p>Texas</p>, <p>Young Danish men who took these dietary supplements had healthier sperm and larger average testicular size:</p>, <p>Maca root</p>, <p>Fish oil</p>, <p>Ginseng</p>, <p>Zinc</p>, <p>Every  minute you’re not treated for a stroke you lose about how many brain cells?</p>, <p>2,000</p>, <p>20,000</p>, <p>200,000</p>, <p>2 million</p>, <p>True or false? Stress can make hair turn gray.</p>, <p>True</p>, <p>False</p>, <p>School-age children in the United States sit, on average, for at least how many hours a day?</p>, <p>Four hours</p>, <p>Six hours</p>, <p>Eight hours</p>, <p>12 hours</p>, <p>About what percentage of American children are obese?</p>, <p>5 percent</p>, <p>10 percent</p>, <p>20 percent</p>, <p>30 percent</p>, <h2 class="section-heading"></h2>, <h2 class="story-heading">Weekly Health Quiz: Running, Body Temperature and a Deadly New Virus</h2>, <h2 class="story-heading">Weekly Health Quiz: Migraine, Fruit and a Mysterious Illness</h2>, <p>Advertisement</p>, <h2 class="visually-hidden">Site Information Navigation</h2>, <h2 class="visually-hidden">Site Information Navigation</h2>]
[<p>Advertisement</p>, <p>Supported by</p>, <h1 class="css-1s4ffep e1h9rw200" id="link-5ab3e077" itemprop="headline"><span>Stocks Fall as Second Virus Case in U.S. Spooks Investors</span></h1>, <p class="css-1ifw933 e1wiw3jv0" id="article-summary">Airline stocks, exposed to the impact of travel restrictions related to China’s coronavirus outbreak, were hard hit.</p>, <p class="css-1fv7b6t e1jsehar1" itemprop="author" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">By<!-- --> <a class="css-brehiz e1jsehar0" href="https://www.nytimes.com/by/matt-phillips"><span class="css-1baulvz last-byline" itemprop="name">Matt Phillips</span></a></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Stocks in the United States suffered their worst decline since early October, amid concern that a dangerous new virus could hurt the global economy.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">On Wall Street, the S&amp;P 500 and the Nasdaq composite index both dropped 0.9 percent on Friday. The declines picked up steam after officials said a second case of the virus, <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/24/world/asia/china-coronavirus.html?action=click&amp;module=Top%20Stories&amp;pgtype=Homepage#link-2aaadc4c" title="">the coronavirus</a>, had been diagnosed in the United States. The patient, a woman in her 60s in Chicago, had recently traveled to Wuhan, China, the center of the outbreak.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Earlier Friday, the Chinese authorities broadened a travel lockdown in central China to 12 cities near Wuhan. The orders effectively pen in 35 million residents to try to contain the virus, which had led to at least <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/24/world/asia/china-coronavirus.html" title="">41 deaths by Friday evening</a> and more than 1,000 infections worldwide.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Airline shares — exposed to the impact of travel restrictions related to the virus — dropped sharply, American Airlines by 4 percent and United Airlines by 3.5 percent.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The news also battered shares of companies with significant exposure to the Chinese market. Shares of the casino company Wynn Resorts, which is heavily reliant on revenue from Chinese gamblers in Macau, fell more than 3 percent.</p>, <h1 class="g-headline" id="g-inlineguide-headline">The Coronavirus Outbreak</h1>, <h2 class="g-inlineguide-list-header g-optimize-type">What do you need to know? Start here.</h2>, <p class="g-inlineguide-date">Updated Feb. 5, 2020</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Commodities markets also reflected a downbeat view of the outlook for global growth on Friday, with prices for oil and copper falling.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Energy and materials stocks also slumped during Friday’s trading session. Chevron fell more than 1 percent, while Exxon Mobil dropped 0.7 percent.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Financial shares faltered after some regional banks reported lackluster demand for commercial lending in recent days. Huntington Bancshares fell 3.8 percent, while KeyCorp and Regions Financial both fell more than 2.5 percent. JPMorgan Chase fell 2.5 percent.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The stumble in financial stocks mirrored a sharp drop in bond yields, which serve as the foundation for commercial lending rates and can have an impact on the profitability of loans. The yield on the 10-year Treasury note fell to 1.68 percent.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Updates on the spreading virus overshadowed bright spots for investors throughout the day. Surveys of activity in the American manufacturing and services sectors both showed growth in January.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">And on Thursday, after the close of trading, Intel announced better-than-expected profit and sales results for the fourth quarter, citing strong growth in sales of chips for data centers. Intel’s shares rose more than 8 percent.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Before the start of trading on Friday, American Express reported better-than-expected profits and provided an optimistic outlook for results in 2020. Its shares rose 2.8 percent.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">At times, Friday’s sell-off was a steeper slide than investors had experienced in a while, with stocks down more than 1.2 percent at some points in the afternoon.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Had the S&amp;P 500 closed at that level, the decline would have been the index’s first of more than 1 percent since Oct. 8, when a flare-up of tensions between the United States and China sent shares down 1.6 percent.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Ultimately, the market pared back some of its deepest losses before the close of trading. Even after the drop, the S&amp;P 500 remains up 2 percent in January, a strong start after the market’s 28.9 percent rise in 2019.</p>, <p>Advertisement</p>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd" id="site-index-label">Site Index</h2>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-0">news</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-1">opinion</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-2">arts</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-3">living</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-4">more</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-subscribe-label">Subscribe</h3>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd">Site Information Navigation</h2>]
[<p>Advertisement</p>, <p>Supported by</p>, <h1 class="css-1s4ffep e1h9rw200" id="link-1326fa16" itemprop="headline"><span>Fear of Virus Ruins the ‘Happiest Day’ for Millions of Chinese</span></h1>, <p class="css-1ifw933 e1wiw3jv0" id="article-summary">In the city at the center of the epidemic, Lunar New Year celebrations were subdued while residents worried about sick family members and life under lockdown.</p>, <p class="css-1fv7b6t e1jsehar1" itemprop="author" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">By<!-- --> <a class="css-brehiz e1jsehar0" href="https://www.nytimes.com/by/chris-buckley"><span class="css-1baulvz last-byline" itemprop="name">Chris Buckley</span></a></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">WUHAN, China — The Lunar New Year festivities were just hours away, but instead of helping to prepare a joyous family banquet, Chen Yanming stood anxiously outside a hospital where her father was being tested for a dangerous new virus.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“Today should be the Chinese people’s happiest day,” Ms. Chen, 47, said here in Wuhan, the riverside city of 11 million in central China where the outbreak began. “But this sickness has destroyed that feeling. It came suddenly and unexpectedly. We should have been better prepared.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The emergence of the mysterious coronavirus could hardly come at a worse time for China, turning its biggest holiday into a time of deepening fear, restrictions and frustration.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The pneumonia-like illness linked to the virus has, by official count, stricken nearly 1,300 people in mainland China. At least 41 people have been killed, including 15 new deaths in Wuhan reported by officials on Saturday morning alone. More than 20 other cases have been confirmed elsewhere, including five in Hong Kong, two in the United States, three in France and, on Saturday, one in Australia.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Hundreds of millions of people in China travel during the holiday, increasing the risk of spreading the virus. For many migrant workers from the countryside, the Lunar New Year break is the only opportunity to spend extended time with their children. For growing numbers of Chinese people, it is a time for tourism to Beijing and other cities, or to foreign destinations.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">But this year, desperate to contain the disease, the Chinese authorities have shut down transportation or imposed travel restrictions in 13 cities in Hubei, the province at the center of the outbreak, hemming in 35 million people.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The streets across Wuhan were eerily empty on Friday, except near hospitals. The city has been largely shut down: Departures are mostly barred, and subways, buses and ferries within Wuhan are suspended. Many residents lined up at hospitals to check for the illness or stayed indoors, rather than reuniting with family.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">At the entrance to the hospital where Ms. Chen waited, cars and bicycles arrived with frail older people to be checked. Residents said it had become nearly impossible to find taxis following the ban on public transportation. Doctors and medical workers struggled to cope with the surge of people worried that they had symptoms of the virus.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">At another hospital taking in possible cases of infection, an old man sat in a wheelchair outside the building. It was too crowded and unhealthy inside, he said. Another patient shuffled across the street, holding a drip in his arm and its stand, so he could stay away from the crowd inside the hospital.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“We won’t have a New Year celebration tonight. There’s no mood for it,” said Wu Qiang, a middle-aged Wuhan resident waiting outside a hospital for word about his son, who had a fever. “I think he’s O.K., but now even an ordinary sneeze makes you worry. You start to think every cough or sneeze might be the virus.”</p>, <h1 class="g-headline" id="g-inlineguide-headline">The Coronavirus Outbreak</h1>, <h2 class="g-inlineguide-list-header g-optimize-type">What do you need to know? Start here.</h2>, <p class="g-inlineguide-date">Updated Feb. 10, 2020</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">For many families in Wuhan, the Lunar New Year holiday now promises to be a week of anxious waiting — for medical resources and clarity about when they will be free of the virus and able to travel.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“The government announced there were thousands of beds, but everywhere is crammed with people,” said Xiao Hongxia, a Wuhan resident who said that her father, Xiao Shibing, was not getting full care for what might be illness from the virus. At one hospital, she said, “the doctors were crying that they were helpless to do anything.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Thirty of China’s 31 provinces and regions have confirmed cases, and two deaths have occurred far from the outbreak’s epicenter, one of them nearly 1,500 miles away. Cases have also been detected in Thailand, Vietnam, Singapore, Japan, South Korea, Nepal and Taiwan.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Officials at Shanghai Disneyland, one of the biggest tourist attractions in China, and at the Badaling section of the Great Wall of China, a popular tourist destination north of Beijing, said they would temporarily close beginning Saturday.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Beijing canceled public events, including two popular temple fairs, and closed the Forbidden City, the capital’s most famous tourist attraction, until further notice. Many cities shuttered movie theaters, bars and cafes in an effort to limit the spread of the virus.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Dr. Gauden Galea, the representative of the World Health Organization in Beijing, said in an interview on Friday that thousands of people would likely be infected, and that the outbreak could be long.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“My own office is gearing up for a number of months,” Dr. Galea said. “We do not expect it to disappear in a number of days.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Here in Wuhan, supermarkets seemed well stocked, but some residents said that prices had gone up or that fresh vegetables and fruit had become harder to buy because so many local markets had closed.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">More pressing are shortages of protective gowns, masks, gloves and other equipment to keep medical workers as safe as possible. Supplies have grown scarce in Wuhan under the weight of the epidemic, hospital employees in Wuhan said.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Outside the No. 4 Hospital in Wuhan, two medical workers taking boxes of protective gowns from a truck said the gowns did not give maximum protection from the virus, but would have to do because better supplies were lacking. Some doctors and medical workers have bought their own maximum protection masks because hospitals were running short, one of them said.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“Shortage of medical supplies, request help!!!” the Wuhan Children’s Hospital said Thursday in a post on <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.weibo.com/6449404416/IqQIGBlTT?" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">Weibo</a>, a Chinese social network.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The Wuhan government on Friday ordered that a new hospital be constructed in a matter of days to treat the victims.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The hospital, modeled on one constructed in Beijing for the SARS epidemic in 2003, will have room for 1,000 beds and is expected to be finished by Feb. 3, according to a <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="http://www.wh.gov.cn/2019_web/whyw/202001/t20200124_304126.html" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">local media repor</a>t posted to the Wuhan government’s website.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Dr. Galea, who visited Wuhan this week before the lockdown, defended how Chinese officials had handled the outbreak, saying they had been transparent in sharing data.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“With the number of cases,” he said, “one would expect health systems to be stretched.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">But online and in interviews, people around China have been unusually critical of their government, arguing that officials are reluctant to disclose bad news that might sully the Communist Party’s image of triumphant progress.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">In posts on Chinese social media platforms, some users called for Wuhan leaders to be dismissed. Others mocked the failure of the Communist Party’s flagship media to treat the epidemic with front-page urgency. Most of those posts were quickly removed.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">In a sign of how far the outbreak has scrambled the Communist Party’s messages, the annual Lunar New Year variety show on the main national broadcaster — which usually gives a cheerful face to the party’s themes — made nods to the crisis.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The show broadcast images of doctors and nurses treating patients, of trucks of supplies festooned with banners that said, roughly translated, “Go Wuhan!” The presenters declared that the fight against the coronavirus was open, transparent and a testament to the abilities of the Chinese government.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“For Wuhan people, tonight the table should be filled with dishes of fish and meat,” said Ms. Chen. “But with my father sick, we’ll have a few simple dishes.”</p>, <p class="css-jwz2nf etfikam0">Reporting was contributed by Russell Goldman and Alexandra Stevenson from Hong Kong; Ray Zhong from Shanghai; and Javier C. Hernández from Beijing. Yiwei Wang, Amber Wang, Claire Fu and Lin Qiqing contributed research.</p>, <p>Advertisement</p>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd" id="site-index-label">Site Index</h2>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-0">news</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-1">opinion</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-2">arts</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-3">living</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-4">more</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-subscribe-label">Subscribe</h3>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd">Site Information Navigation</h2>]
[<p>Advertisement</p>, <p>Supported by</p>, <h1 class="css-1s4ffep e1h9rw200" id="link-1a409331" itemprop="headline"><span>Stronger Growth, With Caveats, Is Predicted for Global Economy</span></h1>, <p class="css-1ifw933 e1wiw3jv0" id="article-summary">Top policymakers said easing trade tensions had raised prospects, but low interest rates leave central banks few options if problems develop.</p>, <p class="css-1fv7b6t e1jsehar1" itemprop="author" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">By<!-- --> <a class="css-brehiz e1jsehar0" href="https://www.nytimes.com/by/keith-bradsher"><span class="css-1baulvz last-byline" itemprop="name">Keith Bradsher</span></a></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">DAVOS, Switzerland — Top economic policymakers and business leaders from around the world made fairly upbeat predictions for global economic growth this year at the World Economic Forum on Friday, but cautioned that already low interest rates meant there was limited room to respond if new problems arose.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Kristalina Georgieva, the managing director of the International Monetary Fund, said the global economy’s prospects had improved noticeably even in the three months since the fund’s annual meeting with the World Bank.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">That improvement was partly a result of a recent easing of trade tensions, including the <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/15/business/economy/china-trade-deal.html" title="">agreement this month between the United States and China</a>, she said. She also cited interest rate cuts by 49 central banks and signs that industrial production around the world was starting to bottom out.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Ms. Georgieva predicted that the global economy would grow 3.3 percent this year and 3.4 percent next year, but cautioned that “3.3 percent is not a fantastic growth — it is sluggish.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">She warned that with interest rates already very low or even negative in many places, it would not be easy to respond if new difficulties emerged. In what appeared to be a veiled reference to possible <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/23/world/asia/wuhan-coronavirus-china-economy.html" title="">economic consequences from a new virus in China</a> and <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/13/business/australia-economy-wildfires.html" title="">bush fires in Australia</a>, Ms. Georgieva said that January had already produced events that posed new risks, and that policymakers would need to be able to respond more quickly than in the past when things went wrong.</p>, <h1 class="g-headline" id="g-inlineguide-headline">The Coronavirus Outbreak</h1>, <h2 class="g-inlineguide-list-header g-optimize-type">What do you need to know? Start here.</h2>, <p class="g-inlineguide-date">Updated Feb. 10, 2020</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin alluded indirectly to the new coronavirus that has led Beijing to <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/24/world/asia/china-coronavirus.html" title="">quarantine more than a dozen cities</a> in China this week, saying that health challenges need to be watched closely. Problems at Boeing — which has <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2019/12/16/business/boeing-737-max.html" title="">temporarily halted production of its 737 Max jets</a> after two crashes — could trim American economic growth by as much as one-half to three-quarters of a percentage point in the short term, he said, while adding that the United States still has a “very robust economic outlook through 2020.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Europe and Japan have been at the center of concerns that negative interest rates leave little room for policymakers to ease monetary policy and stimulate growth if needed. The top central bankers from both places acknowledged on Friday the dangers of negative interest rates even as they said they saw no immediate opportunity to tighten monetary policy.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Christine Lagarde, the president of the European Central Bank, said she welcomed figures showing lower unemployment in Europe and wages rising at a rate of 2.5 percent a year. But she warned that inflation had not yet risen to the point that the central bank could tighten monetary policy — which would push up short-term interest rates and leave room to cut them later.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“We are seeing inflation moving a teeny tiny bit,” she said.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Haruhiko Kuroda, the governor of the Bank of Japan, said the Japanese economy was likely to keep growing at its recent pace of 1 to 1.5 percent a year. While that has been enough to keep unemployment very low, inflation is also so low — well below 1 percent — that the central bank “will continue accommodative monetary policy for some time,” he said.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Vice Chancellor Olaf Scholz of Germany, who is also the finance minister, defended his country’s fiscal policies against recent international criticism that it was too tight. He said Germany has cut taxes and increased infrastructure spending, and planned large investments in its electricity grid and wind energy as it started to shift away from coal-fired electricity as a way to address climate change.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">In a clear reference to this month’s Phase 1 trade agreement between the United States and China, Ms. Lagarde said the European Central Bank would be watching for whether recent pacts diverted trade from previous patterns. The Phase 1 agreement requires China to increase very sharply its purchases of American manufactured products, farm goods, energy and services, <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/23/business/economy/china-us-trade-deal-allies.html" title="">raising worries particularly in Europe</a> that China will shift its orders away from them and toward American suppliers.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The European Central Bank is looking at “who will lose out from that rediversion in various agreements,” Ms. Lagarde said.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The only person from China on the stage was the moderator, Zhu Min, who is a former deputy governor of the People’s Bank of China and a former deputy managing director of the International Monetary Fund. He did not offer predictions about the Chinese economy.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">In interviews on the sidelines of the World Economic Forum, corporate executives tended to share the general optimism of policymakers while echoing their worries about the difficulty of cutting interest rates to stimulate growth if something goes wrong.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“The dangers of something has increased,” said Thomas Buberl, the chief executive of Paris-based AXA, which is one of the world’s largest insurers. “The instruments that we have to react to that are much more limited.”</p>, <p>Advertisement</p>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd" id="site-index-label">Site Index</h2>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-0">news</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-1">opinion</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-2">arts</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-3">living</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-4">more</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-subscribe-label">Subscribe</h3>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd">Site Information Navigation</h2>]

<span class="byline-author" data-byline-name="WILL DUDDING" itemprop="name">WILL DUDDING</span> and

<span class="summary-text">Did you follow the headlines this week? Take our quiz to find out.<br/>
<br/>
<a href="https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2020/01/17/briefing/iran-taal-volcano-oscar-nominations-news-quiz.html" target="_blank">Last week</a>, 92 percent of respondents correctly answered the question about the former chief executive Dennis Muilenburg. Only 70 percent knew about Mayor Bill de Blasio’s unorthodox New York City food preference.<br/>
<br/>
The quiz is published on Fridays. <a href="https://www.nytimes.com/spotlight/news-quiz" target="_blank">Click here for other weeks’ quizzes</a>.
