[<p>Advertisement</p>, <p>Supported by</p>, <h1 class="css-1s4ffep e1h9rw200" id="link-e987cbf" itemprop="headline"><span>Impeachment Trial, Coronavirus, Australian Open: Your Friday Briefing</span></h1>, <p class="css-1fv7b6t e1jsehar1" itemprop="author" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">By<!-- --> <a class="css-brehiz e1jsehar0" href="https://www.nytimes.com/by/christopher-stanford"><span class="css-1baulvz last-byline" itemprop="name">Chris Stanford</span></a></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">(Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/morning-briefing" title="">sign-up</a>.)</p>, <p class="css-ma92ss evys1bk0">Good morning.</p>, <p class="css-ma92ss evys1bk0">We’re covering the latest from <strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">the impeachment trial</strong> (including a view of the Senate you probably haven’t seen) and the results of some high-profile matches at <strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">the Australian Open</strong> (spoilers ahead). It’s also Friday, so there’s <strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">a new news quiz</strong>.</p>, <h2 class="css-3ez4hu eoo0vm40" id="link-24027049">The next stage of the impeachment trial</h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">House impeachment managers are expected to wrap up their opening statements today, before yielding the floor to President Trump’s defense team, which is scheduled to begin its presentation on Saturday. (Senate rules dictate a six-day schedule during impeachment proceedings.)</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/24/us/politics/impeachment.html" title="">Here’s what to expect</a> when the trial resumes around 1 p.m. Eastern.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">On Thursday, the Democrats <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/23/us/politics/democrats-trump-impeachment-trial.html" title="">tried to undercut Mr. Trump’s defense</a>, arguing that his pressure campaign on Ukraine was not merely an effort to root out corruption but an abuse of power that warranted his removal. They also took a calculated risk by discussing the targets of Mr. Trump’s efforts: Joe Biden and his son, Hunter Biden.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">News analysis:</strong> Prevented so far from presenting witnesses, the managers have focused on using the president’s own words against him, a strategy that “seeks to capitalize on Mr. Trump’s astonishingly unfiltered approach,” <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/23/us/politics/trump-videos-impeachment-trial.html" title="">our chief White House correspondent writes</a>.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Related: </strong>For<strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10"> </strong>Joe Biden, questions about his son represent a potential vulnerability in his presidential campaign and <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/23/us/politics/joe-hunter-biden-ukraine.html" title="">a fine line to navigate</a>.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Closer look:</strong> Photos of the Senate chamber are limited, so we’ve produced <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2020/01/23/us/politics/impeachment-senate-chamber-diagram.html" title="">a three-dimensional diagram</a>.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Perspective:</strong> In our Opinion section, legal experts examined <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/23/opinion/donald-trump-impeachment.html" title="">the strongest and weakest points of Mr. Trump’s defense</a>.</p>, <h2 class="css-3ez4hu eoo0vm40" id="link-2d553e9d">China expands travel lockdown to 35 million</h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The authorities today extended restrictions to 12 cities near Wuhan, the epicenter of the outbreak of a deadly coronavirus, doubling the number of cities on lockdown.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">They also raised the death toll to 26, including two people who died hundreds of miles from Wuhan. <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/24/world/asia/china-coronavirus.html" title="">Here are the latest updates</a> and <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2020/01/21/world/asia/china-coronavirus-maps.html" title="">maps of the virus’s spread</a>.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Related:</strong> Health officials said they were examining whether a Texas A&amp;M University student could be <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/23/us/united-states-coronavirus-cases.html" title="">the second known case of the virus in the U.S.</a></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Yesterday:</strong> The World Health Organization said it was <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/23/health/china-virus-who-emergency.html" title="">too early to declare an international health emergency</a>, in part because there are so far relatively few cases outside China.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Another angle:</strong> The cheap, disposable masks that the Chinese authorities have promoted may help prevent the spread of infections, but there’s little evidence on <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/23/health/coronavirus-surgical-masks.html" title="">their effectiveness outside health care settings</a>, experts say.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Watch: </strong><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/video/world/asia/100000006936419/coronavirus-china-wuhan.html" title="">Video from</a><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10"><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/video/world/asia/100000006936419/coronavirus-china-wuhan.html" title=""> </a></strong><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/video/world/asia/100000006936419/coronavirus-china-wuhan.html" title="">Wuhan</a>, population 11 million, shows a city on edge.</p>, <h2 class="css-3ez4hu eoo0vm40" id="link-1346b739">What makes a ‘real’ New Yorker?</h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Eric Adams, the Brooklyn borough president and a possible candidate for mayor of New York, prompted a fierce debate this week when he said that newcomers to the city were “hijacking” apartments from longtime residents.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“Go back to Iowa,” Mr. Adams, who was born in Brooklyn, said on Monday. “You go back to Ohio. New York City belongs to the people that was here and made New York City what it is.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">He later walked back his comments, but they speak to “the broader problem of the invasion narrative in American politics and social thought,” <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/24/nyregion/eric-adams-gentrification.html" title="">our columnist writes</a>.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Another angle:</strong> Andy Byford, the New York City subway chief who earned praise (and a nickname, “Train Daddy”) for improving the antiquated transit system, <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/23/nyregion/andy-byford-resigns-mta.html" title="">resigned on Thursday</a>. He had increasingly clashed with Gov. Andrew Cuomo, who has final say over the subway.</p>, <h3 class="css-1b8te77 e1gnsphs0" id="link-1d2b8d6c">If you have 45 minutes, this is worth it</h3>, <h2 class="css-3ez4hu eoo0vm40" id="link-2fff0a54">9/11, the F.B.I. and the Saudi connection</h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">F.B.I. agents spent years trying to understand Saudi Arabia’s connections to the Sept. 11, 2001, terrorist attacks.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Now a joint investigation by The Times Magazine and ProPublica explores <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/23/magazine/9-11-saudi-arabia-fbi.html" title="">what some agents discovered</a>: a series of missed opportunities by the agency to resolve questions about the link to one of Washington’s closest allies.</p>, <h3 class="css-1b8te77 e1gnsphs0" id="link-554e6082">Here’s what else is happening</h3>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Middle East peace plan:</strong> President Trump said he would <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/23/world/middleeast/israel-peace-plan-kushner.html" title="">soon release his long-awaited peace plan</a> and invited Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel and his chief rival, Benny Gantz, to the White House next week to discuss it. Palestinian officials reiterated that they would treat any American proposal as dead on arrival.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">“Jungle Prince of Delhi” update:</strong> After publishing <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2019/11/22/world/asia/the-jungle-prince-of-delhi.html" title="">an investigation last year</a> about a reclusive family in India, The Times received tips from readers that <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/23/world/asia/jungle-prince-of-delhi.html" title="">helped unearth more information</a>.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Snapshot: </strong>Above,<strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10"> </strong>part of the excavation of Herculaneum, an ancient Roman city that was destroyed in 79 A.D. in the eruption of Mount Vesuvius, which also buried Pompeii. Two studies published on Thursday <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/23/science/vesuvius-eruption-brains-glass.html" title="">offered new details about the victims</a>.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">In memoriam: </strong><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/23/business/media/jim-lehrer-dead.html" title="">Jim Lehrer</a>, a PBS newsman for 36 years, gave viewers an alternative to network evening news programs, with in-depth interviews and news analysis. He died on Thursday at 85.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Australian Open results:</strong> Coco Gauff, 15, <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/aponline/2020/01/24/sports/tennis/ap-ten-australian-open-gauff-vs-osaka.html" title="">upset the reigning champion, Naomi Osaka</a>, today, and Serena Williams <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/23/sports/tennis/serena-williams-australian-open.html" title="">was ousted by the 27th-seeded Wang Qiang of China</a>.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">News quiz:</strong> Did you follow the headlines this week? <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2020/01/24/briefing/coronavirus-impeachment-davos-news-quiz.html" title="">Test yourself</a>.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Modern Love:</strong> <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/24/style/modern-love-in-the-time-of-low-expectations.html" title="">This week’s column</a> is by a woman whose father advised her, “Never count on a man.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Late-night comedy: </strong><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/24/arts/television/stephen-colbert-trump-impeachment-late-night.html" title="">Trevor Noah said</a>, “If you didn’t want to be bored at work, you shouldn’t have become a senator, O.K.? You should have stuck with racecar driving, Mitch McConnell.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">What we’re reading: </strong><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-features/lizzo-cover-story-interview-truth-hurts-grammys-937009/" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">This profile of Lizzo in Rolling Stone</a> “reveals how hard the Grammy-nominated singer fought to become a new kind of superstar,” writes Remy Tumin of the Briefings team.</p>, <h3 class="css-1b8te77 e1gnsphs0" id="link-7ded7ef4">Now, a break from the news</h3>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Cook: </strong><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://cooking.nytimes.com/recipes/1019924-pasta-alla-vodka" title="">Pasta alla vodka</a> is a quick, flavorful dish that leaves enough time to make a salad.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Watch: </strong>“The Gentlemen,” from the British director Guy Ritchie, features villains and supervillains, crime and punishment, winks and splatter-happy schtick, <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/22/movies/the-gentlemen-review.html" title="">our film critic writes</a>.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Read: </strong>A collection of reviews and essays by the New Yorker critic James Wood is among <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/23/books/review/12-new-books-we-recommend-this-week.html" title="">12 books we recommend this week</a>.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Smarter Living: </strong>Our Climate Fwd: newsletter usually offers a weekly tip on something you can do for the environment, but this week it’s <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/22/climate/nytimes-newsletter-climate-change.html" title="">looking at the bigger picture</a>.</p>, <h3 class="css-1b8te77 e1gnsphs0" id="link-15767e9b">And now for the Back Story on …</h3>, <h2 class="css-3ez4hu eoo0vm40" id="link-273d1282">The impeachment diet</h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Of the many rules that govern the Senate impeachment trial of President Trump, there is none more incongruous than the one covering what food and drink is allowed on the floor during the proceedings: water, milk and candy. That’s it.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The candy is thanks to the “<a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Candy_Desk" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">candy desk</a>,” a relic now assigned to Senator Patrick Toomey of Pennsylvania. It’s on the Republican side of the chamber, in the back row on the aisle.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The tradition of the candy desk started in 1965 with Senator George Murphy, a sweet-toothed California Republican, and in recent years it has been controlled by lawmakers from Pennsylvania, which has the country’s biggest confectionery industry. <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://nypost.com/2020/01/21/impeachment-senators-will-stomach-trial-thanks-to-candy-desk/" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">The desk is currently stocked</a> with Hershey bars with almonds, Rolo caramels, Milky Ways, 3 Musketeers bars, Palmer Peanut Butter Cups and Goldenberg’s Peanut Chews.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">As for beverages, only water is permitted — both still and sparkling — though a <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.govinfo.gov/app/details/GPO-RIDDICK-1992/GPO-RIDDICK-1992-1/context" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">legislative rule book</a> does refer to a lawmaker who was <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://twitter.com/AmeliaFrappolli/status/1219675683858894849?s=20" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">permitted to ask for a glass of milk in 1966</a>. Even though the proceedings have so far <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/23/us/politics/senators-impeachment-scene.html" title="">made for some very long days</a>, coffee is not allowed.</p>, <p class="css-ma92ss evys1bk0">That’s it for this briefing. See you next time.</p>, <p class="css-ma92ss evys1bk0">— Chris</p>, <p class="css-jwz2nf etfikam0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Thank you</strong><br/>Mark Josephson and Eleanor Stanford provided the break from the news. Adam Pasick of the Briefings team wrote today’s Back Story. You can reach us at <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="mailto:briefing@nytimes.com" title="">briefing@nytimes.com</a>.</p>, <p class="css-jwz2nf etfikam0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">P.S.</strong><br/>• We’re listening to “<a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/thedaily" title="">The Daily</a>.” Today’s episode is about fracking natural gas, an issue that could win the swing state of Pennsylvania.<br/>• New York Magazine <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="http://nymag.com/intelligencer/2020/01/michael-barbaro-the-daily-podcast-new-york-times.html" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">profiled Michael Barbaro and the team behind “The Daily.”</a><br/>• Here’s today’s <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/crosswords/game/mini" title="">Mini Crossword</a>, and a clue: Use a stencil (five letters). <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/crosswords" title="">You can find all our puzzles here</a>.<br/></p>, <p>Advertisement</p>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd" id="site-index-label">Site Index</h2>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-0">news</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-1">opinion</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-2">arts</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-3">living</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-4">more</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-subscribe-label">Subscribe</h3>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd">Site Information Navigation</h2>]
[<p>Advertisement</p>, <p>Supported by</p>, <h1 class="css-1s4ffep e1h9rw200" id="link-513a2645" itemprop="headline"><span>Coronavirus, Impeachment, Isabel dos Santos: Your Friday Briefing</span></h1>, <p class="css-1ifw933 e1wiw3jv0" id="article-summary">Here’s what you need to know.</p>, <p class="css-1fv7b6t e1jsehar1" itemprop="author" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">By<!-- --> <a class="css-brehiz e1jsehar0" href="https://www.nytimes.com/by/mike-ives"><span class="css-1baulvz" itemprop="name">Mike Ives</span></a> and <span class="css-1baulvz last-byline" itemprop="name">Sofia Mitra-Thakur</span></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">(Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/morning-briefing" title="">sign-up</a>.)</p>, <p class="css-ma92ss evys1bk0">Good morning.</p>, <p class="css-ma92ss evys1bk0">We’re covering the impacts of a <strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">viral epidemic in China</strong>, the Democratic strategy at <strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">President Trump’s impeachment trial</strong> and a landmark ruling on <strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">violence in Myanmar.</strong></p>, <h2 class="css-3ez4hu eoo0vm40" id="link-366eb92c">Outbreak disrupts China and spooks markets </h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">In China, the all-important Lunar New Year holiday begins today, but <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/23/world/asia/china-coronavirus-outbreak.html" title="">the outbreak of a deadly virus is overwhelming hospitals</a> and raising fears of a pandemic akin to one fueled by SARS, a similar disease that originated in China in 2002 and killed more than 800 people worldwide.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Here are the <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/24/world/asia/china-coronavirus.html" title="">latest updates</a> and <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2020/01/21/world/asia/china-coronavirus-maps.html" title="">a map</a> of where the virus, which has killed at least 26 people and sickened more than 600 people in Asia, has spread.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Experts from the World Health Organization said on Thursday that it was <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.who.int/news-room/detail/23-01-2020-statement-on-the-meeting-of-the-international-health-regulations-(2005)-emergency-committee-regarding-the-outbreak-of-novel-coronavirus-(2019-ncov)" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">too early to declare the outbreak</a> an international health emergency, even as China took the apparently unprecedented move of keeping millions of people in Wuhan and nearby cities on a <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/22/world/asia/coronavirus-quarantines-history.html" title="">travel lockdown</a>.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Looking ahead: </strong>The outbreak has <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/23/world/asia/wuhan-coronavirus-china-economy.html" title="">dampened growth prospects</a> for the world’s second-largest economy during what is normally a busy spending season. Financial markets fell across Asia on Thursday, led by a sharp drop in stocks in China.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Details:</strong> Many of the first 18 victims were men who <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/23/world/asia/coronavirus-victims-wuhan.html" title="">skewed older and had underlying health issues</a>. But the 18th was the first to die outside the city of Wuhan, the virus’s epicenter.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Go deeper: </strong><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/23/world/asia/wuhan-coronavirus.html" title="">Wuhan</a>, population 11 million, is an industrial and manufacturing hub that embodies China’s rise as a global economic power. <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/video/world/asia/100000006936419/coronavirus-china-wuhan.html" title="">Here’s a video</a> of the city on edge.</p>, <h2 class="css-3ez4hu eoo0vm40" id="link-251e5930">Solemnity, and politics, in Jerusalem</h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Prince Charles of Britain is due to meet in Bethlehem today with Mahmoud Abbas, the president of the Palestinian Authority, on the heels of <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/23/world/middleeast/auschwitz-liberation-anniversary.html" title="">an event in Jerusalem</a> that marked the coming 75th anniversary of the liberation of the Nazi death camp Auschwitz.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Speaking days before the anniversary on Monday, world leaders at the event discussed the importance of remembering the Holocaust and speaking out against anti-Semitism. Some also <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/23/world/middleeast/holocaust-auschwitz-liberation.html" title="">used the opportunity to score political points on Iran</a>.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Why this matters: </strong>The presence of several global leaders at Israel’s biggest-ever political gathering was a public relations boon for Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel, who is campaigning ahead of a March election even as he <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/01/world/middleeast/israel-netanyahu-immunity.html" title="">awaits trial on corruption charges</a>. </p>, <h2 class="css-3ez4hu eoo0vm40" id="link-2a2ab008">The Democrats’ strategy on impeachment </h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">House Democrats are expected today to wrap up their opening arguments at the impeachment trial of President Trump by arguing that he obstructed Congress by concealing his behavior and withholding documents and witnesses. Here’s a roundup of our <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/live/2020/impeachment-trial-live-01-23" title="">latest impeachment coverage</a>.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">On Thursday, the Democrats tried to disprove Mr. Trump’s claims that he was merely trying to root out corruption in Ukraine when he sought to enlist officials in that country to investigate former Vice President <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/23/us/politics/joe-hunter-biden-ukraine.html" title="">Joe Biden and his son</a> Hunter Biden, who served on the board of a Ukrainian energy company.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Analysis:</strong> Bringing up the Bidens is risky for Democrats, <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/23/us/politics/democrats-trump-impeachment-trial.html" title="">our congressional correspondent writes</a>, because some Republicans are threatening to call them as witnesses.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Related: </strong>No witnesses have been allowed at the trial yet, but Democrats are essentially using Mr. Trump as one — by quoting from <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/23/us/politics/trump-videos-impeachment-trial.html" title="">his astonishingly unfiltered public remarks</a> on Ukraine and other subjects.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">What’s next: </strong>Mr. Trump’s lawyers are scheduled to begin delivering their opening arguments on Saturday, and the trial could be over before the president’s State of the Union speech on Feb. 4. But if senators vote to subpoena witnesses and documents, it could go deep into February.</p>, <h2 class="css-3ez4hu eoo0vm40" id="link-de22ca0">Climate change and the banking sector</h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/23/business/climate-change-central-banks.html" title="">Climate change is expected to figure prominently</a> in a strategic review that the European Central Bank began on Thursday —<span class="css-8l6xbc evw5hdy0"> </span>on the same day that an umbrella organization for the world’s central banks warned that the issue could lead to the next global financial crisis.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Christine Lagarde, the E.C.B. president, acknowledged on Thursday that some members of its governing council questioned whether fighting climate change was a central bank’s job. Still, she added, “I’m also aware of the danger of doing nothing.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Why this matters:</strong> Global gross domestic product could plunge by nearly a quarter by the end of the century because of the effects of climate change, according to some estimates.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Analysis:</strong> “Think the subprime crisis in 2008 was bad?” our business correspondent writes. “Imagine a real estate crisis caused by rising sea levels and coastal flooding that renders thousands of square miles of land uninhabitable or useless for farming.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Related: </strong>Business and political leaders made a flurry of commitments on carbon emissions at the World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland, this week. But <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/23/business/corporate-climate-davos.html" title="">few provided details</a> on how companies could rapidly transition away from an economy based on fossil fuels.</p>, <h3 class="css-1b8te77 e1gnsphs0" id="link-1d2b8d6c">If you have 45 minutes, this is worth it</h3>, <h2 class="css-3ez4hu eoo0vm40" id="link-2fff0a54">9/11, the F.B.I. and the Saudi connection</h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">In a case that divided the F.B.I., agents spent years trying to understand Saudi Arabia’s connections to the worst terror attack in America’s history.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Now a joint investigation by The Times Magazine and ProPublica explores <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/23/magazine/9-11-saudi-arabia-fbi.html" title="">what some agents discovered</a>: A series of missed opportunities by the agency to resolve questions about the link between one of Washington’s closest allies and the attack.</p>, <h3 class="css-1b8te77 e1gnsphs0" id="link-554e6082">Here’s what else is happening</h3>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Ruling for Rohingya:</strong> The International Court of Justice at The Hague said on Thursday that Myanmar<a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/23/world/asia/myanmar-rohingya-genocide.html" title=""> must take action to protect Rohingya Muslims</a> after what many experts have called a campaign of genocide by the country’s security forces along the border with Bangladesh.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Storm moves north: </strong>A huge storm that has killed 10 people in Spain and left hundreds of thousands of residents temporarily without electricity was<strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10"> </strong>moving north on Thursday, <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/23/world/europe/storm-gloria-spain-floods.html" title="">setting off weather alerts for parts of France</a>.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Poisoning charges: </strong>Bulgarian prosecutors on Thursday announced <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/23/world/europe/bulgaria-russian-agents-poison.html" title="">charges against three Russian spies</a>, accusing them of using poison in a failed attempt “to deliberately kill” a prominent arms dealer, his son and an executive in 2015. A Times investigation last month identified the suspects as <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2019/12/22/world/europe/bulgaria-russia-assassination-squad.html" title="">operatives of an elite military unit</a> involved in the 2018 poisoning of a Russian spy in Britain.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Angola:</strong> Isabel dos Santos, the daughter of the country’s former president, is<a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/23/world/africa/angola-santos-embezzlement.html?action=click&amp;module=News&amp;pgtype=Homepage" title=""> set to face charges</a> after an investigation into the embezzlement of millions from the state oil company, which she once led. A banker who managed the company’s account was found dead at his Lisbon home in what was most likely a suicide, a police source said.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Subway chief quits: </strong>Andy Byford,<strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10"> </strong>a self-described subway nerd from Britain who has worked on the London, Sydney and Toronto transit networks, <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/23/nyregion/andy-byford-resigns-mta.html" title="">resigned as chief of the state agency that runs New York City’s subways</a>. He had quarreled with the state’s governor over plans to fix a major line between Manhattan and Brooklyn.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Snapshot: </strong>Above, a display of Benin Bronzes at the British Museum in London. The artifacts were looted by British troops in the 19th century, but two British police officers have <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/23/arts/design/benin-bronzes.html" title="">made it their mission to return them</a>.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">What we’re reading: </strong><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-features/lizzo-cover-story-interview-truth-hurts-grammys-937009/" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">This profile of Lizzo in Rolling Stone</a> “reveals how hard the Grammy-nominated singer fought to become a new kind of superstar,” writes Remy Tumin on the Briefings team, and the photos alone make it worth reading.</p>, <h3 class="css-1b8te77 e1gnsphs0" id="link-7ded7ef4">Now, a break from the news</h3>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Cook: </strong><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://cooking.nytimes.com/recipes/1019924-pasta-alla-vodka" title="">Pasta alla vodka</a> is a 30-minute dinner that leaves enough time to make a salad and pour a glass of wine. Skip the pancetta to make it vegetarian.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Watch: </strong>“The Gentlemen,” the latest movie from the British director Guy Ritchie, features villains and supervillains, crime and punishment, winks and splatter-happy schtick, <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/22/movies/the-gentlemen-review.html" title="">our film critic writes</a>.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Smarter Living: </strong>Our Climate Fwd: newsletter usually brings us a weekly tip on one thing you can do for the environment, but this week its team is <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/22/climate/nytimes-newsletter-climate-change.html" title="">looking at the bigger picture</a>.</p>, <h3 class="css-1b8te77 e1gnsphs0" id="link-15767e9b">And now for the Back Story on …</h3>, <h2 class="css-3ez4hu eoo0vm40" id="link-273d1282">The impeachment diet</h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Of the many rules that govern the Senate impeachment trial of President Trump, there is none more incongruous than the food and drink allowed on the floor during the marathon proceedings: water, milk and candy. That’s it.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The candy is thanks to the “<a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Candy_Desk" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">candy desk</a>,” a historical relic that is now assigned to Senator Patrick Toomey of Pennsylvania. It’s on the Republican side of the chamber, in the back row on the aisle.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The tradition of the candy desk started in 1965 with Senator George Murphy, a sweet-toothed California Republican, and in recent years has been controlled by lawmakers from Pennsylvania, which has the country’s biggest confectionary industry. It’s <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://nypost.com/2020/01/21/impeachment-senators-will-stomach-trial-thanks-to-candy-desk/" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">currently stocked</a> with Hershey bars with almonds, Rolo caramels, Milky Ways, 3 Musketeers bars, Palmer Peanut Butter Cups and Goldenberg’s Peanut Chews.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">As for beverages, only water is permitted — either still or sparkling — though a <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.govinfo.gov/app/details/GPO-RIDDICK-1992/GPO-RIDDICK-1992-1/context" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">legislative rule book</a> does refer to a lawmaker who was <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://twitter.com/AmeliaFrappolli/status/1219675683858894849?s=20" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">permitted to ask for a glass of milk in 1966</a>. Unfortunately for everyone involved in the proceedings, which have so far made for some very long days, coffee is not allowed.</p>, <p class="css-ma92ss evys1bk0">That’s it for this briefing. See you next time. </p>, <p class="css-ma92ss evys1bk0">— Mike and Sofia</p>, <p class="css-jwz2nf etfikam0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Thank you</strong><br/>To Mark Josephson and Eleanor Stanford for the break from the news. Adam Pasick, on the Briefings team, wrote today’s Back Story. You can reach the team at <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="mailto:briefing+midnight@nytimes.com?subject=Briefing%20Feedback" title="">briefing@nytimes.com</a>.</p>, <p class="css-jwz2nf etfikam0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">P.S.</strong><br/>• We’re listening to “<a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/thedaily" title="">The Daily</a>.” Our latest episode is on the Duke and Duchess of Sussex.<br/>• New York Magazine <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="http://nymag.com/intelligencer/2020/01/michael-barbaro-the-daily-podcast-new-york-times.html" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">profiled Michael Barbaro and the team behind “The Daily.”</a><br/>• Here’s our <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/crosswords/game/mini" title="">Mini Crossword</a>, and a clue: Use a stencil (five letters). <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/crosswords" title="">You can find all our puzzles here</a>.<br/><br/></p>, <p>Advertisement</p>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd" id="site-index-label">Site Index</h2>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-0">news</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-1">opinion</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-2">arts</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-3">living</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-4">more</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-subscribe-label">Subscribe</h3>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd">Site Information Navigation</h2>]

W. IAN LIPKIN</a>, an epidemiologist at the Mailman School of Public Health at Columbia University, referring to China’s use of travel restrictions to try to contain the outbreak of a deadly coronavirus.</p>, <p>Advertisement</p>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd" id="site-index-label">Site Index</h2>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-0">news</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-1">opinion</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-2">arts</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-3">living</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-4">more</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-subscribe-label">Subscribe</h3>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd">Site Information Navigation</h2>]
[<p>Advertisement</p>, <p>Supported by</p>, <h1 class="css-1s4ffep e1h9rw200" id="link-36bb798e" itemprop="headline"><span>Impeachment, March for Life, Serena Williams: Your Friday Evening Briefing</span></h1>, <p class="css-1ifw933 e1wiw3jv0" id="article-summary">Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.</p>, <p class="css-1fv7b6t e1jsehar1" itemprop="author" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">By<!-- --> <a class="css-brehiz e1jsehar0" href="https://www.nytimes.com/by/remy-tumin"><span class="css-1baulvz" itemprop="name">Remy Tumin</span></a> and <a class="css-brehiz e1jsehar0" href="https://www.nytimes.com/by/marcus-payadue"><span class="css-1baulvz last-byline" itemprop="name">Marcus Payadue</span></a></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">(Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s </em><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="http://www.nytimes.com/newsletters/nyt-now-evening-briefing?module=inline" title=""><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">the sign-up</em></a><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">.) </em></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">Good evening. Here’s the latest.</em></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">1. After three days of arguments against President Trump, </strong>his defense team is warming up.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The president’s lawyers will make their first appearance in the Senate impeachment trial on Saturday, but they will be relatively brief, using only a few hours to begin to lay out their case on a day when few people are watching. Then on Monday, Mr. Trump will get his made-for-television presentation. One of his lawyers called tomorrow <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/live/2020/impeachment-trial-live-01-24/sekulow-compares-saturday-defense-to-a-coming-attraction#live-blog-list" title="">“a trailer, coming attractions.”</a></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Opening arguments begin around 10 a.m. <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/live/2020/impeachment-trial-live-01-24?" title="">Here’s the latest</a>.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">House managers wrapped up their case with an <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/live/2020/impeachment-trial-live-01-24/citing-ambassadors-ouster-schiff-challenges-gop-senators#live-blog-list" title="">impassioned speech from Representative Adam Schiff</a>, above, that tried to put the Ukraine pressure campaign in the context of the Trump presidency. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">But it may not be enough: Democrats were not optimistic that enough Republicans had been persuaded to support hearing from <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/live/2020/impeachment-trial-live-01-24/democrats-may-not-have-enough-votes-to-call-for-witnesses#live-blog-list" title="">new witnesses in the trial</a>.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">2. China expanded travel restrictions, </strong>penning in 35 million people<strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10"> </strong>in an effort to contain an outbreak of a little-understood coronavirus.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The virus has now killed at least 41 people and infected more than 900. A second case was confirmed in the U.S. and three cases were confirmed in France, as health officials prepared for an outbreak that could last months. <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/24/world/asia/china-coronavirus.html?" title="">Here’s the latest</a>.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The emergence of the mysterious virus during China’s biggest holiday, the Lunar New Year, <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/24/world/asia/wuhan-virus.html?" title="">couldn’t have come at a worse time</a>.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“Today should be the Chinese people’s happiest day,” one woman told our reporter in Wuhan, the epicenter of the outbreak. “But this sickness has destroyed that feeling. It came suddenly and unexpectedly. We should have been better prepared.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">3. President Trump became the first sitting president </strong>to<strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10"> </strong>address March for Life, a prominent <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/24/us/politics/trump-abortion-march-life.html?" title="">anti-abortion rally</a>.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“Unborn children have never had a stronger defender in the White House,” he told a crowd of religious school groups and activists on the National Mall, speaking behind a plate of bulletproof glass.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">As he spoke, his administration announced plans to<a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/24/health/abortion-california-insurance.html" title=""> withhold federal money from California</a> if the state did not drop a requirement that private insurers cover abortions.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">4. Yesterday </strong>we told you about the Trump administration’s efforts<strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10"> </strong>to strip clean-water protections. <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/24/climate/epa-sewage-rivers.html?" title="">Today’s rollback: sewage regulations</a>.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Raw sewage from cities will keep flowing into the nation’s rivers for years to come under an Environmental Protection Agency policy that gives cities a pass on cleanups. The move allows municipal governments to delay or otherwise change federally imposed fixes to their sewer systems.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Cities have long complained about the cost of meeting federal requirements to upgrade aging sewer systems. The Trump administration has rolled back nearly 95 other environmental rules that it has said are too costly for industry or taxpayers.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">5. We’re 10 days out</strong> from the Iowa caucus and the state is still very much in play.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The state’s caucuses often come down to the wire, but with the polling picture in flux and the impeachment trial slanting the playing field, this year’s contest is especially uncertain.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/24/us/politics/latest-democratic-polls.html" title="">Here are four reasons anything could happen in Iowa</a>. And keep an eye out: We’ll have a new New York Times/Siena College poll out on Saturday morning. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The Democratic Party’s voters are splintered across generational, racial and ideological lines, and <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/24/us/politics/democratic-party-unity-primary.html" title="">the lack of a united front has many party leaders anxious</a>. We spoke with 50 voters across three early voting states and found that even the goal of defeating President Trump isn’t enough for some voters to commit to backing the eventual Democratic nominee.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">6. London police </strong>will begin using <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/24/business/london-police-facial-recognition.html" title="">facial recognition technology</a> to identify people in real time.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The decision adopts a level of surveillance that is rare outside China. The Metropolitan Police said the technology will help “tackle serious crime.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">In a country with a history of terrorist attacks, CCTV cameras line the streets and police surveillance has traditionally been more accepted than in other Western countries. But privacy groups have vowed to take legal action to try to stop its deployment.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">7. A scheme </strong>run by hundreds of bankers, lawyers and investors<strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10"> </strong>may be the biggest tax heist ever. <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/23/business/cum-ex.html" title="">And Europe wants justice</a>.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Stock traders are accused of siphoning $60 billion from state coffers of European countries through “cum-ex trading,” a monetary maneuver that purportedly avoids double taxation of investment profits. A former participant labeled it “the devil’s machine.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Germany was hardest hit, with an estimated $30 billion in losses, and is the first country to try to get its money back.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Separately, </strong>art experts and law enforcement officials are seeing <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/24/arts/design/fake-art-prints.html" title="">a surge of fake prints</a> coming to the market, presented as the work of major artists.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">8. Serena Williams’s loss </strong>in the third-round of the Australian Open to Wang Qiang was an uncharacteristic faltering for the best player of her era. <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/23/sports/tennis/serena-williams-australian-open.html" title="">Is the end close?</a></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">She has not won a Grand Slam title since 2017 and her competition is getting stiffer. But you never know with Williams: This loss could be “another setback on the path to a momentous comeback befitting her aura,” our tennis reporter writes.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Hours after Williams and the reigning Australian Open champion, Naomi Osaka, suffered stunning defeats (<a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/24/sports/tennis/coco-gauff-osaka-australian-open.html" title="">Osaka lost to the teen phenom Coco Gauff</a>), Roger Federer <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/24/sports/tennis/roger-federer-australian-open.html" title="">rallied in a gripping tiebreaker</a> to reach the fourth round.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">9. The Comedy Store </strong>in Los Angeles launched the careers of comics like Robin Williams, David Letterman, Jay Leno and Sandra Bernhard. And watching them all was Pauly Shore.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Shore, the son of the club’s owner, Mitzi Shore, was a witness to the greatest minds in comedy. Now 51 and performing a one-man show about his childhood, <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/24/arts/television/pauly-mitzi-shore-comedy-store.html" title="">Shore dished on what it was like growing up a kid of comedy</a>.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">When the comedian John Mulaney isn’t hiding his Sour Patch Kids habit from his wife, the “Saturday Night Live” alum is all about pleasing his dog — and his therapist. <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/24/nyregion/john-mulaney.html" title="">Here’s how he spends his Sundays in New York</a>.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">10. And finally, </strong><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/24/business/haggis-smuggling.html" title="">the haggis black market</a>.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">On Saturday, Scots across the world will dine on haggis to celebrate the birthday of Robert Burns, the 18th-century Scottish poet. A U.S. federal agency bans the sale of sheep lungs, a key ingredient for the distinctive Scottish dish. Haggis lovers have found ways around that.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">For decades, a small but impassioned contingent of die-hard traditionalists has resorted to illicit methods to bring authentic haggis onto American soil — smuggling it through customs or crossing the border into Canada. One butcher in Toronto planned to send it in boxes labeled “clothing” or “gifts” to relatives in Florida.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Have a poetic weekend.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">Your Evening Briefing is posted at 6 p.m. Eastern.</em></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">And don’t miss Your Morning Briefing. </em><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2018/briefing/global-morning-briefing-newsletter-signup.html" title=""><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">Sign up here</em></a><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0"> to get it by email in the Australian, Asian, European, African or American morning.</em></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">Want to catch up on past briefings? </em><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/series/us-evening-briefing" title=""><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">You can browse them here</em></a><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">.</em></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">What did you like? What do you want to see here? Let us know at </em><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="mailto:briefing@nytimes.com?subject=Evening%20Briefing%20Feedback" title=""><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">briefing@nytimes.com</em></a><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">.</em></p>, <p>Advertisement</p>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd" id="site-index-label">Site Index</h2>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-0">news</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-1">opinion</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-2">arts</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-3">living</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-4">more</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-subscribe-label">Subscribe</h3>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd">Site Information Navigation</h2>]
[<p>Advertisement</p>, <p>Supported by</p>, <p class="css-c2jxua e6idgb70"></p>, <h1 class="css-1j5ig2m e1h9rw200" id="link-a41edbd" itemprop="headline"><span>Goldman’s Playbook for More Diverse Corporate Boards</span></h1>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">Hello from Davos, Switzerland, where the World Economic Forum is wrapping up. (Want this in your inbox each morning? </em><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="http://p.nytimes.com/email/re?&amp;campaign_id=0&amp;instance_id=0&amp;segment_id=0&amp;user_id=f4577a56bcf773214e9a1d55b5fe9d24&amp;regi_id=0nl=dealbook&amp;emc=edit_dk_20180529" title=""><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">Sign up here</em></a><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">.)</em></p>, <h2 class="css-3ez4hu eoo0vm40" id="link-4ed7b92f">Goldman issues an ultimatum to drive corporate diversity</h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Goldman Sachs’s C.E.O., David Solomon, prompted chatter on Wall Street yesterday about his plan to require I.P.O. clients to have <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.cnbc.com/2020/01/23/goldman-wont-take-companies-public-that-dont-have-at-least-one-diverse-board-candidate-ceo-says.html" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">at least one “diverse” board candidate</a> before the bank helped them list in the public markets.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">• “We’re not going to take a company public unless there’s at least one diverse board candidate, with a focus on women,” Mr. Solomon told CNBC at the World Economic Forum in Davos.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">• The mandate starts July 1 for U.S. and European clients, and starting next year, Goldman will require two diverse board members.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">• “We might miss some business, but in the long run, this I think is the best advice for companies that want to drive premium returns for their shareholders over time,” Mr. Solomon added.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">It’s a big deal in the I.P.O. world</strong>, given that Goldman was <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://news.bloomberglaw.com/corporate-law/goldman-leads-u-s-ipo-underwriting-in-2019" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">the top underwriter</a> of U.S. offerings last year.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">And it’s </strong><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10"><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2020-01-24/goldman-rule-adds-to-death-knell-of-the-all-white-male-board" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">the latest push</a></strong><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10"> for diversity within Corporate America</strong>, Jeff Green of Bloomberg notes. The money-management firms BlackRock and State Street plan to vote against directors at companies without a female director. And California-based public companies with all-male boards face a $100,000 fine.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Mr. Solomon’s decision is a </strong><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10"><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://twitter.com/lizrhoffman/status/1220373687741960192" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">change for Goldman</a></strong>, Liz Hoffman of the WSJ points out. The firm had previously argued, as an underwriter of WeWork’s I.P.O., that it would simply let investors decide if they liked a company’s board.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">The big questions:</strong> Will rivals like Morgan Stanley and JPMorgan Chase follow suit? And how firmly will Goldman stick to this new rule?</p>, <h2 class="css-3ez4hu eoo0vm40" id="link-5bf22be7">At Davos, Big Business is eager to appear woke</h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Goldman’s announcement was just one of several initiatives that companies announced at the World Economic Forum to show that they were committed to social change.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Business leaders sought to demonstrate </strong>their <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/23/business/corporate-climate-davos.html" title="">environmental credentials</a>, with many announcing plans to sharply cut their companies’ carbon footprints. BlackRock’s Larry Fink even wore a scarf representing the pace of global warming.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10"><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/23/opinion/sunday/davos-2020-capitalism-climate.html" title="">“Revolutionary sentiments”</a></strong><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10"> erupted</strong> in unexpected places at the forum, Tim Wu writes in an NYT opinion column: At times he thought he “had mistakenly wandered into a business-casual Bernie Sanders rally.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">But there are reasons to be skeptical:</strong></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">• Many companies haven’t outlined how they will fulfill their climate pledges.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">• Phumzile Mlambo-Ngcuka, executive director of the U.N.’s gender-equality program, warned against “<a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.politico.eu/article/davos-woke-green-climate-sustainability-donald-trump-greta-thunberg-angela-merkel-gender-equality/" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">the illusion of change</a>” at the forum, Politico reported.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">The Davos roundup:</strong></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">• George Soros <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.wsj.com/articles/soros-commits-1-billion-to-educational-initiative-11579819163" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">pledged $1 billion</a> to create an international network of universities to promote an appreciation of “personal autonomy.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">• The investor Bill Browder, an outspoken critic of President Vladimir Putin of Russia, said he was warned of <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.axios.com/putin-foe-bill-browder-davos-russian-spies-f3bd65f1-6609-42a5-bedb-629f87bd6427.html" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">potential threats to his safety</a> before he left for Davos.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">• Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin said that Greta Thunberg should take a <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/23/climate/greta-thunberg-steve-mnuchin.html" title="">college economics class</a> before resuming her climate change activism. She <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://twitter.com/GretaThunberg/status/1220355420600008704" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">clapped back</a> on Twitter.</p>, <h2 class="css-3ez4hu eoo0vm40" id="link-2faf4f24">The Wuhan coronavirus crisis is getting worse</h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The Chinese authorities reported <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/23/world/asia/china-coronavirus.html" title="">a sharp increase</a> in the death toll from the outbreak this morning, while more countries are investigating potential cases of infection. It’s stoking fears of another SARS-like disaster.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Here’s the latest:</strong></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">• The Chinese National Health Commission has reported at least 25 deaths — up by more than a half-dozen in 24 hours — and 830 confirmed cases.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">• Beijing expanded travel restrictions to <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/24/world/asia/china-coronavirus.html" title="">a total of 12 cities</a>, while Wuhan, the center of the epidemic, remains almost completely locked down.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">• But experts say that <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/23/world/asia/china-coronavirus-outbreak.html" title="">the travel restrictions</a> will do little to stop the virus’s spread outside China, Chris Buckley and Javier Hernández of the NYT report.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">The </strong><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/23/world/asia/wuhan-coronavirus-china-economy.html" title=""><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">economic effects</strong></a><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10"> are still being felt</strong>, Alexandra Stevenson of the NYT writes. The Hang Seng Index in Hong Kong was down 2 percent this morning, while Asian markets fell broadly yesterday. And the outbreak may hurt consumer confidence in what’s normally a busy spending season.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">It’s still unknown<span class="css-8l6xbc evw5hdy0"> </span>how quickly China can contain the outbreak.</strong> While the World Health Organization <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/23/health/china-virus-who-emergency.html" title="">declined to label it</a> a global health emergency yesterday, it will revisit that decision in 10 days.</p>, <h2 class="css-3ez4hu eoo0vm40" id="link-57d20d17">Wells Fargo’s ex-C.E.O. is fined over fake accounts</h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The bank’s onetime chief, John Stumpf, is among several former executives to be <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/23/business/wells-fargo-ceo-fine.html" title="">fined millions for their roles</a> in promoting a toxic culture that led to sham accounts for customers and other problems, Stacey Cowley and Emily Flitter of the NYT report.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Mr. Stumpf was fined $17.5 million</strong> — “the largest individual fine in the history of the bank’s main federal regulator,” the Office of the Comptroller of Currency — and received a lifetime ban from the banking industry. Two other former executives also paid fines, and five others were charged.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">The bank regulator also released fresh details</strong> about Wells Fargo’s “relentless pressure on employees to meet its unrealistic goals, which included ‘hazing-like abuse,’ ” Ms. Cowley and Ms. Flitter write. “Many employees said they felt they had only two options: Cheat or get fired.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">• One employee wrote to Mr. Stumpf and another senior executive that he had faced “less stress in the 1991 Gulf War than working for Wells Fargo.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">The big picture:</strong> “The settlements were a rare instance of personal consequences for those at the highest echelons of the banking industry,” Ms. Cowley and Ms. Flitter write.</p>, <h2 class="css-3ez4hu eoo0vm40" id="link-5da57fe4">A reminder: Jeff Bezos is a celebrity now</h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Public accusations that Saudi Arabia hacked Jeff Bezos’ phone and learned about his divorce are only the latest indication that the once publicity-shy Amazon chief has become <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/23/technology/jeff-bezos-tabloids.html" title="">an unlikely tabloid fixture</a>, Karen Weise of the NYT notes.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">• Remember when Mr. Bezos gushed over “Star Trek”? Or joked that washing dishes every night was “the sexiest thing I do”? Or said he hated to travel because he felt disconnected from the office?</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">• That all changed in recent years, particularly after revelations that he had been having an affair with Lauren Sanchez, a former TV personality — and when he then accused The National Enquirer of trying to blackmail him.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">• What has happened since: Mr. Bezos and Ms. Sanchez have been seen at Wimbledon and in St. Tropez, and were featured in gossip columns for hosting a party in New York for one of Meghan Markle’s “BFFs.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Worth noting:</strong> A report on the phone hacking <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/23/business/media/national-enquirer-jeff-bezos-saudi-hack.html" title="">shows no evidence</a> that The National Enquirer had obtained Mr. Bezos’s photographs and texts from the Saudis.</p>, <h2 class="css-3ez4hu eoo0vm40" id="link-79002da8">Revolving door</h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Intel named <strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Omar Ishrak</strong> as <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.wsj.com/articles/intel-names-new-chairman-11579646961" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">its new chairman</a>, replacing Andy Bryant.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Bill Abbott</strong> is <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.wsj.com/articles/hallmark-says-crown-media-family-networks-ceo-bill-abbott-is-stepping-down-11579723063" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">stepping down as C.E.O.</a> of the Hallmark Channel, weeks after the network was criticized for temporarily pulling an ad featuring a same-sex wedding.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">BP promoted <strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Murray Auchincloss</strong>, the finance chief of its oil and gas division, <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2020-01-21/bp-names-auchincloss-as-cfo-as-gilvary-plans-to-retire" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">to C.F.O.</a> He’ll replace <strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Brian Gilvary</strong>, who is retiring.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">G/O Media hired <strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Jim Rich</strong>, a former editor of The Daily News, to <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/23/business/media/deadspin-editor-jim-rich.html" title="">lead Deadspin</a>, the sports news site.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The DNA testing service 23andMe said it was <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2020-01-23/23andme-cuts-100-jobs-as-consumer-dna-testing-growth-slows" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">cutting 100 jobs</a> as its business slowed.</p>, <h2 class="css-3ez4hu eoo0vm40" id="link-7c091e00">The speed read</h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Deals</strong></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">• Xerox said it planned to nominate 11 candidates for HP’s 12-member board, escalating its hostile takeover bid for the computer maker. (<a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.reuters.com/article/us-hp-m-a-xerox-hlngs/xerox-nominates-new-hp-board-after-buyout-rebuffs-idUSKBN1ZM24P" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">Reuters</a>)</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">• The greeting card retailer Papyrus filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy and plans to close all its stores after failing to find a buyer. (<a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.wsj.com/articles/greeting-cards-retailer-papyrus-files-for-bankruptcy-plans-to-close-stores-11579819638" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">WSJ</a>)</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">• Britain’s competition regulator announced an 11th-hour review of the $7.9 billion proposed merger of the food-delivery services Just Eat and Takeaway.com. (<a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.ft.com/content/97a62cfa-3e07-11ea-a01a-bae547046735" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">FT</a>)</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Politics and policy</strong></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">• The Trump administration reportedly plans a crackdown on the importing of counterfeit goods that are sold online. (<a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.wsj.com/articles/u-s-signals-crackdown-on-counterfeit-goods-sold-online-11579820400" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">WSJ</a>)</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">• The European Central Bank left interest rates unchanged yesterday, keeping them in negative territory. (<a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.wsj.com/articles/ecb-leaves-rates-on-hold-as-eurozone-economy-struggles-11579784179" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">WSJ</a>)</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">• The British chancellor of the Exchequer, Sajid Javid, sought to placate worried businesses by saying that his country wouldn’t diverge from E.U. regulations just for the sake of doing so. (<a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.ft.com/content/14879014-3df0-11ea-a01a-bae547046735" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">FT</a>)</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Tech</strong></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">• Inside the I.R.S.’s fight to force Facebook to pay more in taxes on its international operations. (<a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.propublica.org/article/whos-afraid-of-the-irs-not-facebook" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">ProPublica</a>)</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">• Meet Tony Blevins, Apple’s cost cutter in chief. (<a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.wsj.com/articles/jobs-cook-iveblevins-the-rise-of-apples-cost-cutter-11579803981" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">WSJ</a>)</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">• Tech companies are offering free or low-cost cybersecurity services for presidential campaigns. (<a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.wsj.com/articles/tech-companies-volunteer-to-beef-up-presidential-campaigns-cybersecurity-11579770002" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">WSJ</a>)</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">• British officials recommended that the country adopt Huawei technology for a part of the country’s 5G network. (<a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.ft.com/content/ee293c76-3ded-11ea-a01a-bae547046735" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">FT</a>)</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Best of the rest</strong></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">• Your weekend long read: “It May Be the Biggest Tax Heist Ever. And Europe Wants Justice.” (<a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/23/business/cum-ex.html" title="">NYT</a>)</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">• A federal judge sentenced the founder of the opioid maker Ins to five and a half years in prison over a racketeering scheme tied to the opioid epidemic. (<a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/23/health/opioids-insys-kapoor-prison.html" title="">NYT</a>)</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">• Changes to how the FICO credit score is calculated could make it harder for some consumers to get loans. (<a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.wsj.com/articles/fico-changes-could-lower-your-credit-score-11579780800" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">WSJ</a>)</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">• The veteran TV news anchor Jim Lehrer died yesterday. He was 85. (<a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/23/business/media/jim-lehrer-dead.html" title="">NYT</a>)</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">We’d love your feedback. Please email thoughts and suggestions to </em><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="mailto:business@nytimes.com?subject=Newsletter%20Feedback" title=""><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">business@nytimes.com</em></a><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">.</em></p>, <p>Advertisement</p>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd" id="site-index-label">Site Index</h2>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-0">news</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-1">opinion</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-2">arts</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-3">living</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-4">more</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-subscribe-label">Subscribe</h3>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd">Site Information Navigation</h2>]
[<p>Advertisement</p>, <p>Supported by</p>, <h1 class="css-1s4ffep e1h9rw200" id="link-2151f08f" itemprop="headline"><span>Coronavirus Spurs China to Suspend Tours Abroad and Xi to Warn of a ‘Grave Situation’</span></h1>, <p class="css-1ifw933 e1wiw3jv0" id="article-summary">Concern over the outbreak has crept closer to central government offices and the ruling Communist Party’s seat of power.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">This briefing has ended. Read about developments in the </em><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/27/world/asia/china-coronavirus.html" title=""><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">coronavirus outbreak here</em></a><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">.</em></p>, <h2 class="css-3ez4hu eoo0vm40" id="link-31b38a76">China moves to restrict travel, including tours abroad.</h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/02/10/world/asia/xi-jinping-coronavirus.html" title="">China</a> said on Saturday that it would suspend all tour groups and the sale of flight and hotel packages for its citizens headed overseas, starting on Monday.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The association for China’s travel agencies said tour groups that were in the middle of their trips could proceed with their itineraries but should closely monitor the health of their travelers.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">This measure may come as welcome news to countries that have been gearing up to screen travelers from China for fevers and other signs of infection.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The Beijing city government also announced on Saturday that it would suspend all inter-province buses from Sunday, effectively limiting road travel into the capital.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The measures, taken hundreds of miles from Wuhan, where the outbreak of a novel coronavirus began, were a sign that concerns over the spread of the outbreak have crept close to central government offices and the ruling Communist Party’s seat of power.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Wuhan also tightened its restrictions further on Saturday with a ban on vehicle traffic in the city center, to begin at midnight.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The local government said some vehicles would be exempted, including shuttle buses and trucks moving supplies. Residents responded with frustration on social media. One woman, who said she was pregnant and near her due date, asked if she was supposed to walk to her gynecologist’s office.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">All the reported deaths from the outbreak have been in mainland China, but travelers have spread the virus to numerous other places. Cases have been confirmed in Australia, Malaysia, Nepal, Vietnam, Singapore, Japan, South Korea, Taiwan, Hong Kong, Thailand, France and the United States.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The authorities in Wuhan said they would also speed up the customs process for donated supplies, as hospitals in the city raise the alarm about a shortage of hospital gowns, surgical masks and other necessities.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">A notice posted Saturday <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="http://www.customs.gov.cn/wuhan_customs/506378/506379/2851956/index.html?from=singlemessage&amp;isappinstalled=0" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">on the website</a> of the city’s customs agency said that new channels were being put in place to ensure that donations were put to immediate use. Overseas donations will be exempted from tax duties, the notice said.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">During past crises, the authorities in China have been criticized for their reluctance to accept overseas assistance, apparently preferring to project a sense of control. As China has grown more affluent, it has become <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2015/12/05/world/africa/china-pledges-60-billion-to-aid-africas-development.html" title="">a provider of aid</a> rather than a recipient, particularly to regions like Africa.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">China has made exceptions during some past disasters, including <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2008/05/16/world/asia/16china.html" title="">a devastating earthquake</a> centered on Sichuan Province in 2008.</p>, <h2 class="css-3ez4hu eoo0vm40" id="link-354d41c">Schools in Hong Kong and the mainland postpone classes</h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">On Saturday, Hong Kong’s leader, Carrie Lam, declared a health emergency in the semiautonomous Chinese city and said schools would be closed until mid-February.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Two American universities with campuses in China also postponed their start dates. Duke Kunshan University, a partnership between Duke University in North Carolina and Wuhan University, said it would <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://dukekunshan.edu.cn/en/news/special-message-novel-coronavirus" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">not resume classes until Feb. 17</a>.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Classes had originally been scheduled to resume Feb. 3, after the Lunar New Year vacation. (Duke Kunshan University is not in Wuhan, but in Jiangsu Province, more than 400 miles away.)</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">New York University also announced that its Shanghai campus would start its spring semester <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nyu.edu/about/news-publications/news/2020/january/2019-nCoV_Statement.html" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">one week later than planned</a>, at the request of municipal authorities.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Schools in Hubei Province, where Wuhan is and where the outbreak has hit the hardest, had already decided to delay the start dates at all schools, from kindergarten through college.</p>, <h2 class="css-3ez4hu eoo0vm40" id="link-159b854d">Fifteen more deaths are reported, including one in Shanghai.</h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">China on Sunday morning announced 15 more deaths from the new coronavirus, including one in Shanghai, the first to be reported so far in the metropolis. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Thirteen more deaths were also announced in Hubei Province, where the outbreak began, and one was announced in Henan Province. The latest deaths brought the toll in China to 56.</p>, <h1 class="g-headline" id="g-inlineguide-headline">The Coronavirus Outbreak</h1>, <h2 class="g-inlineguide-list-header g-optimize-type">What do you need to know? Start here.</h2>, <p class="g-inlineguide-date">Updated Feb. 10, 2020</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Across the country, 688 cases of the new virus were diagnosed on Saturday, the government said early Sunday. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">That brings the total number of confirmed cases to 1,975. Deaths from the coronavirus had previously been reported outside of Hubei, the outbreak’s epicenter. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">But the death in Shanghai, which is among China’s most populous cities and a major commercial hub, is likely to add to anxieties about the disease’s spread.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Shanghai’s municipal health commission said on Sunday that the patient who died was an 88-year-old man.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Travel restrictions in Wuhan and 12 other cities have essentially penned in 35 million people on the country’s biggest holiday, normally a time for traveling to visit family.</p>, <h2 class="css-3ez4hu eoo0vm40" id="link-2aeec53b">Why is there so much panic?</h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Though the number of coronavirus cases and deaths is alarming, public health experts have so far warned against mass anxiety. After all, the common flu kills roughly 35,000 people a year and hospitalizes about 200,000 in the United States alone.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">It is too soon to know the mortality rate of the virus in the new outbreak.
