But there are signs that this outbreak could be far more serious than the common flu. For one, the virus has been identified as a coronavirus, named for the spikes that protrude from its membrane. Other coronaviruses have far higher mortality rates than the common flu, and have also led to global outbreaks.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Chinese citizens are also haunted by the memory of the SARS epidemic in 2002 and 2003, a coronavirus outbreak that also started in China and eventually killed more than 800 people worldwide. During that epidemic, Beijing at first played down the crisis and withheld information, eventually drawing widespread criticism.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">And conclusive evidence about how the outbreak started is lacking. While officials in Wuhan first traced it to a seafood market, some patients who have fallen ill never visited the market. Researchers have also offered disparate explanations for what animals may have transmitted the virus to humans.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The Chinese government has promised far more transparency than in the SARS crisis, and the World Health Organization has praised its cooperation with the scientific community.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Still, mistrust of the local and national authorities is evident on <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/24/world/asia/china-social-media-coronavirus.html" title="">Chinese social media</a>. And China’s health system has already struggled under the new virus’s strain, with hospitals in Wuhan issuing urgent requests for help and donations.</p>, <h2 class="css-3ez4hu eoo0vm40" id="link-709121e2">Xi Jinping, China’s leader, says the nation will ‘beat the epidemic.’</h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">In a sign of how the spread of the coronavirus has deeply shaken China, the nation’s top leader, <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/02/10/world/asia/xi-jinping-coronavirus.html" title="">Xi Jinping</a>, convened a meeting of the Communist Party leadership on Saturday to begin an offensive to stanch the spread of the outbreak, improve treatment of victims and speed supplies to areas under lockdown.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“We’re sure to be able to win in this battle to beat the epidemic through prevention and control,” Mr. Xi said, according to an official summary delivered on Chinese television.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Until now, Mr. Xi had said little publicly about the growing crisis, even as confirmed cases of infection with the new and little understood coronavirus multiplied over the past week and Wuhan — the city in central China where the virus first spread — and nearby areas came under a net of travel restrictions intended to contain the outbreak.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Mr. Xi issued brief orders about the emerging epidemic five days ago. Now, though, he has ordered mobilization across the country and drastic measures to hold back the virus, which is linked to pneumonia symptoms that can be deadly.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The China television report showed Mr. Xi speaking to the six other members of the Politburo Standing Committee, the Communist Party’s topmost decision-making body, and a circle of other grave-faced officials. The leadership meeting took place on the first full day of China’s weeklong Lunar New Year holiday, a time when the entire country, including party leaders, usually take time off for family get-togethers and relaxation.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“Confronted with the grave situation of this accelerating spread of pneumonia from infections with the novel coronavirus, we must step up the centralized and united leadership under the party central” leadership, Mr. Xi said.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The Communist Party will establish a top-level team, called a leadership small group, to grapple with the crisis, the meeting said, giving efforts to fight the outbreak greater urgency and centralized coordination. Here are some of the other measures and main points announced:</p>, <p class="css-15hwz5e evys1bk0">Mr. Xi demanded strong efforts to provide medicine and other supplies, a point of anger among many doctors and medical workers in Wuhan who have complained about a shortage of protective masks, gowns and other safety equipment.</p>, <p class="css-15hwz5e evys1bk0">Officials in Hubei Province, where the outbreak began, received an implicit telling off. Residents and many other Chinese people have said that officials did not respond seriously enough. Hubei, the meeting said, “must make containment and control of the epidemic its topmost priority, adopting even stricter measures to prevent it expanding within and spreading outward.”</p>, <p class="css-15hwz5e evys1bk0">The meeting called for concentrating resources, experts and treatment to cope with the surge of infections, including sending patients with serious symptoms to designated medical units. This suggests that there may be more hospitals built or modified to deal solely with the outbreak.</p>, <p class="css-15hwz5e evys1bk0">Local and military medical resources are to be pooled for the response.</p>, <p class="css-15hwz5e evys1bk0">Public spaces across China, including railway stations, airports, and ports, were told to step up measures to deter the spread of the virus, including ventilation, disinfection, and body temperature checks for people. “When suspected cases are found they must be held for observation locally,” the meeting ordered.</p>, <h2 class="css-3ez4hu eoo0vm40" id="link-54d6963a">Beijing’s response highlights longstanding tensions between national and local officials.</h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">In his remarks on Saturday, Mr. Xi also seemed to address Chinese citizens’ growing dissatisfaction with the official response. On Chinese social media, users have asked whether the authorities have accurately reported the number of cases or taken enough steps to rein in their spread.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Commenters have especially condemned the perceived absence of the local, provincial and even national authorities in the heart of the outbreak. Mr. Xi had made few public remarks about the disease before Saturday, when he called for officials to “stand at the front line to safeguard social stability.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“Where is that person? He is not on the front line,” one user wrote on Weibo, a Twitterlike platform, an apparent reference to Mr. Xi. The posts were quickly deleted.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">A professor of infectious diseases in Hong Kong who helped identify SARS, Guan Yi, <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/23/world/asia/china-coronavirus.html" title="">has accused</a> Chinese authorities of delaying action and of obstructing his efforts to investigate the outbreak.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Local officials in China have long had incentives to avoid revealing problems that might invite the wrath of party bosses. But Mr. Xi’s efforts to centralize power in Beijing have further weakened local authorities and increased their incentive to deny problems.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">It’s part of a longstanding pattern that can make both levels of government slow to acknowledge problems, then blame each other once a problem is revealed.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">State media has maintained a steady drumbeat of positive news as the outbreak has spread, praising the sacrifices of responders and everyday people.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“This is a continuous theme in central-local relations in China. You do not want to be the one to bring bad news,” said Vivienne Shue, a prominent China scholar at Oxford University.</p>, <h2 class="css-3ez4hu eoo0vm40" id="link-3db7b2fe">U.S. orders the evacuation of American consulate employees.</h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The State Department has ordered all American employees at the United States Consulate in Wuhan to leave the city, as a lockdown imposed on central China expanded, the United States Embassy said on Saturday.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">It said the evacuation of its American staff members and their families was necessary because of the spreading outbreak of the coronavirus, the disruptions caused by the restrictions on transportation in Wuhan and the overwhelming of hospitals.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The evacuation order, made on Thursday, according to a statement from the United States Embassy, was a sign that the measures imposed by the Chinese authorities to try to contain the outbreak of the mysterious coronavirus may be escalating alarm and confusion.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Lines have formed at hospitals and residents have complained that the traffic restrictions have made it nearly impossible to seek timely medical help.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The United States government is arranging a charter flight to evacuate American diplomats and citizens on Sunday, according to a person familiar with the plan. The plane would likely take evacuees to the West Coast of the United States, this person said.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Medical staff would be aboard the plane to screen passengers, and evacuees who were not American diplomatic officers would be responsible for the cost of the flight, according to the person briefed on the plan.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The French Consulate in Wuhan also told its citizens on Friday that it was considering setting up bus rides for those who wished to leave the city, in cooperation with the Chinese authorities, according to France’s Foreign Ministry.</p>, <h2 class="css-3ez4hu eoo0vm40" id="link-25fa1185">Hong Kong declares a state of emergency and shuts schools.</h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">On Saturday, Hong Kong’s leader, Carrie Lam, declared a health emergency in the semiautonomous Chinese city and said schools would be closed until mid-February.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The city is treating five coronavirus patients connected to Wuhan, and more than 100 others are suspected of having the viral pneumonia.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Hong Kong is also suspending flights and train services to Wuhan and will cancel all Lunar New Year celebrations. The Hong Kong Marathon, originally scheduled for early February, has also been called off.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Masks and hand sanitizers have sold out in most pharmacies in the city as residents have stocked up on supplies in a panic since last week. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Yuen Kwok-yung, a leading expert in infectious diseases who discovered the agent causing the coronavirus, had called for schools and universities to remain closed beyond the Lunar New Year holiday in an effort to contain the infection’s reach.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Recent cases have shown that people who do not show symptoms could transmit the disease, according to a <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.thelancet.com/journals/lancet/article/PIIS0140-6736(20)30154-9/fulltext" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">study published in The Lancet</a> on Friday of which he was a co-author.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“If there are local cases in Hong Kong that is not directly connected to Wuhan, this is a big issue,” Dr. Yuen said in a phone interview. “It would mean that this epidemic has reached another level of severity.”</p>, <h2 class="css-3ez4hu eoo0vm40" id="link-678343ca">People without symptoms could be spreading the virus.</h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The medical journal <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.thelancet.com/pb-assets/Lancet/pdfs/S0140673620301549.pdf" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">The Lancet published a study</a> on Friday suggesting that people infected with the coronavirus might be able to spread it even if they do not have flu symptoms.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Researchers studied a family of seven in the Chinese city of Shenzhen, five of whom had traveled to Wuhan, the center of the outbreak. Two of them came into contact with an infected relative in a hospital there. Testing conducted days later, after they flew home, found that six members of the family had the coronavirus, including one who had not gone to Wuhan.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">One infected family member, a child, had no symptoms, suggesting that people with the virus might be spreading it without knowing that they have it, the study found.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“It shows this new coronavirus is able to transfer between person to person, in a hospital setting, a family home setting, and also in an intercity setting,” Yuen Kwok-yung, an author of the study, said in an interview. “This is exactly what makes this new disease difficult to control.” Dr. Yuen characterized the disease as “asymptomatic walking pneumonia.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The researchers cautioned that the study was limited to early cases of the virus, and that it was difficult to assess risk factors at this stage. But they stressed the importance of quarantining patients as early as possible, given the early signs of asymptomatic transmission.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Another <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.thelancet.com/pb-assets/Lancet/pdfs/S0140673620301835.pdf" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">study in The Lancet</a> found that symptoms of early coronavirus cases showed similarities to SARS. Those symptoms included fever, dry cough and shortness of breath.</p>, <h2 class="css-3ez4hu eoo0vm40" id="link-592f84eb">China is building two hospitals to fight the outbreak. Projected completion times: 10 and 15 days.</h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The streets of Wuhan were largely empty on Saturday, the first full day of China’s Lunar New Year holiday.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">By contrast, the site for a new hospital to treat victims of the coronavirus was a mosh pit of activity. Earthmovers, trucks and hundreds of construction workers dug and scraped to build a new facility that, if completed within days as scheduled, could do more than treat the ailing.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The government vowed on Friday that it would finish building the hospital in 10 days, a feat recalling the SARS epidemic of 2003, when Beijing built a hospital with similar speed.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Besides treating infected people at the center of the coronavirus outbreak, the facility would also serve as a potent symbol of the government’s drive to do what needs to be done. If Beijing built a hospital in a few short days, in other words, Wuhan can do it too.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">On Saturday, officials announced that a second hospital was in the works to treat people infected by the virus. It would have a capacity for 1,300 beds. They plan to complete the facility, called Leishenshan Hospital, in 15 days.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">China is virtually unsurpassed in its capacity to finish in mere months the sort of factories, bridges and other projects that could take many years in other countries. The dozens of earthmovers gouging the soil on the outskirts of Wuhan attested to that strength.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">But some workers at the site of the first planned hospital, called Huoshenshan, said there was a severe need for skilled workers. Many are at home or elsewhere, to keep from catching the coronavirus.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Yuan Banfu, a worker from neighboring Henan Province, said a call had gone out on Chinese social media for volunteers to help at the site. He had proudly signed up.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“This is the new Tangshan Hospital,” he said, referring to the hospital that Beijing built in 2003.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Mr. Yuan, a wiry 46-year-old, said he had not been able to go home for the Lunar New Year break because the authorities had closed the routes out of Wuhan.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“I’m glad to be of help for the people of Wuhan,” he said. “My family is worried, but I told them I’m here anyway and we have to help.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Some workers at the site said they had volunteered, while others said they had received calls from their employers urging them to turn up. Nearly all the workers at the site, an expanse of brown mud in the drizzling rain, wore protective masks.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“I’m not too scared,” Mr. Yuan said. “I work outdoors and my heart and lungs are strong</p>, <h2 class="css-3ez4hu eoo0vm40" id="link-4a39e862">A 2-year-old girl is infected, Chinese officials say.</h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Officials in a southern Chinese city said on Saturday that a 2-year-old girl suffering from the coronavirus had been admitted to a hospital and was in stable condition. That would make her the youngest person confirmed to have been infected, according to <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://m.weibo.cn/status/4464583193945626?" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">a social media account run by the People’s Daily</a> newspaper, the mouthpiece of the ruling Communist Party.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Health officials in the city of Hechi, in the southern region of Guangxi, <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="http://wjw.hechi.gov.cn/gggs/20200125-2385199.shtml" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">said that the girl</a> was surnamed Zhong and lived in Wuhan. She had flown from Wuhan to the city of Nanning, which is also in Guangxi, on Tuesday. From there, she was driven to Hechi.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The next day, she developed a fever and began sneezing. She was admitted to Hechi People’s Hospital and put in isolation, officials said. Officials did not disclose who she was traveling with or what condition they might be in.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Medical experts are watching closely to see who the coronavirus infects and who might be most vulnerable to it. Most of those killed by the coronavirus so far <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/23/world/asia/coronavirus-victims-wuhan.html" title="">have been older men</a>, many with chronic health issues. The youngest fatality disclosed so far <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/24/world/asia/china-coronavirus.html?action=click&amp;pgtype=Article&amp;state=default&amp;module=STYLN_wuhan_coronavirus_menu&amp;variant=1_wuhan_coronavirus_menu&amp;region=header&amp;context=menu" title="">was 36 years old</a>.</p>, <h2 class="css-3ez4hu eoo0vm40" id="link-ab318c0">Another doctor collapses and dies of heart failure.</h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">State news media reported on Saturday that a doctor had died of a heart failure while tending to patients with the coronavirus in fever wards at a hospital in eastern China. It was unclear whether he had showed signs of the virus.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The doctor, Jiang Jianjun, who specialized in infectious diseases, suffered the heart attack on Thursday while making rounds at the fever wards in Jiangsu Taizhou People’s Hospital, according to an online tribute posted on the hospital’s social media account.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“He collapsed at his beloved workplace,” the statement read. It has since been deleted, but it said that Dr. Jiang had also treated patients during the outbreaks of the avian flu and swine flu.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">News of his death, along with that of a retired physician in Wuhan who was suspected of having the virus, drew much sympathy online, even as frustration brewed over the crowds at hospitals and the shortage of supplies. Several internet users questioned whether Dr. Jiang had died of fatigue.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">As footage and photos appeared to show medical workers in white coats wailing from the stress of working several consecutive shifts, many social media users used forums to accuse the government of failing to provide adequate support to physicians working on the front lines of the outbreak.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Many also blamed officials for failing to supply new protective gear and testing kits to hospitals facing shortages.</p>, <h2 class="css-3ez4hu eoo0vm40" id="link-42dd700f">Chinese-Americans are scrambling to help.</h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">For people in the United States with close ties to China, the outbreak has brought unexpected worry, disappointment and scrutiny. <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/24/us/wuhan-coronavirus-united-states-washington-texas.html" title="">Some in the Chinese-American community</a> have had their Lunar New Year holiday plans waylaid, as travel schedules for the coming week and beyond get interrupted.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Some are gearing up for the outbreak to get worse. Hardware stores and pharmacies around the United States are selling out of masks that could help prevent the spread of the disease. In the New York City neighborhood of Flushing, masks have been sold out for much of the week.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Chinese-Americans networking with their friends and family in China have scrambled to send aid. One woman in Los Angeles has amassed 20,000 masks to ship overseas.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Sean Shi, of Issaquah, Wash., said he shipped several boxes of masks to China in a friend’s luggage, with hopes that the masks could reach friends in the Wuhan area as soon as possible. Later in the day, Mr. Shi was back at a local hardware store, buying another 46 masks for some of his former peers at Wuhan University.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“We understand it’s a tough situation over there — the panic, the shortage of equipment,” Mr. Shi said. “We just realized the situation is very serious — more serious than we thought.”</p>, <p class="css-jwz2nf etfikam0">Reporting was contributed by Tiffany May, Steven Lee Myers, Vivian Wang, Chris Buckley, Raymond Zhong, Carlos Tejada, Rick Gladstone, Mike Baker, Jeffrey E. Singer and Elian Peltier. Yiwei Wang and Claire Fu contributed research.</p>, <p>Advertisement</p>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd" id="site-index-label">Site Index</h2>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-0">news</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-1">opinion</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-2">arts</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-3">living</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-4">more</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-subscribe-label">Subscribe</h3>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd">Site Information Navigation</h2>]
[<p>Advertisement</p>, <p>Supported by</p>, <h1 class="css-1s4ffep e1h9rw200" id="link-68c8f344" itemprop="headline"><span>Effects of Coronavirus Begin Echoing Far From Wuhan Epicenter</span></h1>, <p class="css-1ifw933 e1wiw3jv0" id="article-summary">Hong Kong closed its schools for several weeks, Beijing began limiting bus travel in and out of the capital and China’s travel association suspended tour groups of citizens heading overseas.</p>, <p class="css-1fv7b6t e1jsehar1" itemprop="author" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">By<!-- --> <a class="css-brehiz e1jsehar0" href="https://www.nytimes.com/by/chris-buckley"><span class="css-1baulvz" itemprop="name">Chris Buckley</span></a> and <a class="css-brehiz e1jsehar0" href="https://www.nytimes.com/by/tiffany-may"><span class="css-1baulvz last-byline" itemprop="name">Tiffany May</span></a></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">WUHAN, China — The repercussions from a mysterious virus that has sickened hundreds of people began reverberating far from its epicenter in central China on Saturday, as Hong Kong closed its schools for several weeks, Beijing began restricting buses in and out of the capital, and the country’s travel association suspended Chinese tour groups heading overseas.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The new measures, coming on top of previous travel restrictions that had effectively penned in tens of millions of people in Hubei, the<strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10"> </strong>province<strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10"> </strong>at the heart of the outbreak, are certain to further dampen celebrations of the Lunar New Year, which began on Saturday.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">They came, too, as China’s top leader, Xi Jinping, who had said little publicly about the crisis despite growing criticism of the response, pledged Saturday that officials would “stand at the front line to safeguard social stability.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The illness linked to the virus has killed at least 56 people and sickened more than 1,300 in China, according to official reports. Cases have been confirmed in all but one of China’s provinces and autonomous regions, as well as in at least 11 other countries as the virus has spread to Europe, the United States Australia and, most recently, Canada.</p>, <h2 class="css-zd32qr">Wuhan Coronavirus Map: Tracking the Spread of the Outbreak</h2>, <p class="css-1uuihdo">The virus has sickened tens of thousands of people in China and a number of other countries.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Among the newest victims in China was a 62-year-old ear, nose and throat specialist, who died on Saturday, according to state news media. It was unclear whether the doctor, who had retired last year, had treated patients with the disease.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">And officials in the southern city of Hechi said on Saturday that a 2-year-old girl suffering from the coronavirus had been admitted to a hospital, becoming the youngest person known to be infected.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">In a sign of how the coronavirus has shaken China, Mr. Xi convened a meeting of Communist Party leaders on Saturday to try to stem the outbreak.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“We’re sure to be able to win in this battle to beat the epidemic,” said Mr. Xi, according to a summary of his remarks by state media, offering some of his most extensive remarks to date on the crisis.</p>, <h1 class="g-headline" id="g-inlineguide-headline">The Coronavirus Outbreak</h1>, <h2 class="g-inlineguide-list-header g-optimize-type">What do you need to know? Start here.</h2>, <p class="g-inlineguide-date">Updated Feb. 5, 2020</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Mr. Xi called for stronger efforts to provide medicine and other supplies to affected areas. Shortages have angered doctors and medical workers, particularly in Wuhan, the Hubei provincial capital where the outbreak began. Hospitals have issued pleas for donated supplies.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Party leaders also directed railway stations, airports and ports to step up measures to deter the spread of the virus, through ventilation, disinfection and body temperature checks. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Chinese officials announced later Saturday that more than 1,200 medical personnel would be sent to Wuhan and over 10,000 beds in 24 local hospitals would be requisitioned for treating confirmed and suspected cases of the virus.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">But the official response so far has drawn stinging rebukes on social media, where people are questioning whether the authorities are accurately reporting the number of cases or doing enough to rein in the outbreak. In particular, people have denounced the perceived indifference of local, provincial and even national authorities.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“Where is that person? He is not on the front line,” one user wrote on Weibo, a Twitter-like platform, in an apparent reference to Mr. Xi. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">State media has maintained a steady drumbeat of positive news about the outbreak, praising the sacrifices of responders and everyday people. But there was little doubt<span class="css-8l6xbc evw5hdy0"> </span>the disease had derailed celebrations of the Lunar New Year, the country’s biggest holiday and busiest travel period.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Travel constraints imposed earlier in Wuhan and 12 nearby cities have effectively penned in 35 million people. Wuhan tightened its restrictions further on Saturday, with a ban on most vehicle traffic in the city center.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The restrictions began spreading far beyond Wuhan, too: In Beijing, the city government said it would halt all inter-province buses beginning on Sunday, effectively limiting road travel into the capital.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The association of China’s travel agencies said that it would suspend all tour groups and the sale of flight and hotel packages for citizens headed overseas, starting on Monday. Groups already on their trips were allowed to continue, with the directive that travelers’ health be closely monitored.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The move to cut off group tours could have a ripple effect across countries that depend on Chinese tourists. While China is now home to an increasingly sophisticated population ready to hit the tourist routes by themselves, a large number of Chinese do not feel comfortable traveling abroad unless they are with a group.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">New measures were also imposed in Hong Kong, where its leader, Carrie Lam, declared a health emergency. Five coronavirus patients connected to Wuhan are being treated in Hong Kong, and more than 100 others are suspected of having the viral pneumonia.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Lunar New Year celebrations are being canceled in Hong Kong, schools will be closed until mid-February and the Hong Kong Marathon has been called off. The city is also suspending flights and train services to Wuhan.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">A study by the <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.thelancet.com/pb-assets/Lancet/pdfs/S0140673620301549.pdf" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">medical journal The Lancet</a>, published on Friday, raised new concerns that people infected with the coronavirus might be able to spread it even if they do not have flu-like symptoms.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Researchers studied a family in the Chinese city of Shenzhen, five of whom had traveled to Wuhan and two of whom had come in contact with an infected relative in a hospital there. Testing conducted after the family flew home found that six members had the coronavirus, including one who had not gone to Wuhan.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">One infected family member, a child, had no symptoms, suggesting that people with the virus might be spreading it without knowing that they have it, the study found.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“It shows this new coronavirus is able to transfer between person to person, in a hospital setting, a family home setting, and also in an intercity setting,” Yuen Kwok-yung, an author of the study, said in an interview. “This is exactly what makes this new disease difficult to control.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The United States Embassy said on Saturday that all American employees at its consulate in Wuhan have been ordered to leave. The United States government is arranging a charter flight to evacuate American diplomats and citizens on Sunday, according to a person familiar with the plan.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">For people in the United States with close ties to China, the outbreak has brought worry, disappointment and scrutiny. <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/24/us/wuhan-coronavirus-united-states-washington-texas.html" title="">Some Chinese-Americans </a> have had their Lunar New Year plans waylaid, as travel schedules for the coming week and beyond are interrupted.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Chinese-Americans have scrambled, though, to send aid to their friends and family in China.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Sean Shi, of Issaquah, Wash., said he shipped several boxes of masks to China in a friend’s luggage, hoping that they could reach friends in the Wuhan area. Later in the day, Mr. Shi was back at a hardware store, buying another 46 masks for some of his former peers at Wuhan University.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“We understand it’s a tough situation over there — the panic, the shortage of equipment,” Mr. Shi said. “We just realized the situation is very serious — more serious than we thought.”</p>, <p class="css-jwz2nf etfikam0">Christopher Buckley reported from Wuhan, and Tiffany May from Hong Kong. Reporting was contributed by Steven Lee Myers, Vivian Wang, Raymond Zhong, Carlos Tejada, Rick Gladstone, Mike Baker, Jeffrey E. Singer and Elian Peltier. Yiwei Wang and Claire Fu contributed research.</p>, <p>Advertisement</p>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd" id="site-index-label">Site Index</h2>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-0">news</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-1">opinion</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-2">arts</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-3">living</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-4">more</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-subscribe-label">Subscribe</h3>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd">Site Information Navigation</h2>]
[<p>Advertisement</p>, <p>Supported by</p>, <p class="css-tsacue e6idgb70">The interpreter</p>, <h1 class="css-fnr6md e1h9rw200" id="link-51c5caf3" itemprop="headline"><span>Coronavirus Exposes Core Flaws, and Few Strengths, in China’s Governance</span></h1>, <p class="css-1ifw933 e1wiw3jv0" id="article-summary">While China can mobilize a huge national response to the outbreak, its response to the crisis is also a lesson in how the country’s political weak points can carry grave consequences for world health.</p>, <p class="css-1fv7b6t e1jsehar1" itemprop="author" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">By<!-- --> <a class="css-brehiz e1jsehar0" href="https://www.nytimes.com/by/max-fisher"><span class="css-1baulvz last-byline" itemprop="name">Max Fisher</span></a></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">It was the initial news reports that first suggested China’s political system might be getting in the way of its ability to confront the coronavirus outbreak.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The outbreak seemed to already be a <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/08/health/china-pneumonia-outbreak-virus.html" title="">full-blown crisis</a>, infecting dozens in China and <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/15/world/asia/coronavirus-japan-china.html" title="">even some abroad</a>, by the time it became widely reported.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">This seeming delay was of a familiar pattern in China, one suggesting that local officials may have played down early warning signs or simply did not coordinate enough to see the problem’s scope.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">While outsiders might suspect an attempted cover-up as the cause, experts see something much more worrying: weaknesses at the very heart of the Chinese system.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Its rigidly hierarchical bureaucracy discourages local officials from raising bad news with central bosses whose help they might need. And it silos those officials off from one another, making it harder to see, much less manage, the full scope of spiraling crises.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“That’s why you never really hear about problems emerging on a local scale in China,” said John Yasuda, who studies China’s approach to health crises at Indiana University. “By the time that we hear about it, and that the problem reaches the central government, it’s because it’s become a huge problem.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">While much remains unknown about the outbreak, a common theme is emerging.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Any political system is better at solving some problems than others. But the coronavirus, like other health crises before it, is bringing out some of the deepest flaws and contradictions in a Chinese system that, for all its historic feats, remains a work in progress.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Those flaws, which have long frustrated Chinese leaders, appear to have played a role in everything from the pace at which officials responded to the coronavirus outbreak, to China’s yearslong inability to address the health risks that experts have long warned could lead to an outbreak just like this one.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">While the country is now mobilizing a nationwide response — one of the system’s strengths — the incident is already a lesson in the political weak points that can bring grave consequences for China and, as infections spread, the world.</p>, <h1 class="g-headline" id="g-inlineguide-headline">The Coronavirus Outbreak</h1>, <h2 class="g-inlineguide-list-header g-optimize-type">What do you need to know? Start here.</h2>, <p class="g-inlineguide-date">Updated Feb. 10, 2020</p>, <h2 class="css-1320w4z eoo0vm40" id="link-5cde1a83">A System at Odds With Itself</h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“When you look at the coronavirus, it looks a lot like what happened with SARS. It involves a very similar template,” Mr. Yasuda said.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The SARS epidemic, which killed hundreds of people in 2002 and 2003, initially spread unchecked when local Chinese officials minimized early reports.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Their fear was not public unrest, it later emerged, but getting in trouble with the party bosses who controlled their careers.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Guan Yi, a professor of infectious diseases in Hong Kong who helped identify SARS, <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/23/world/asia/china-coronavirus.html" title="">has accused</a> Chinese authorities of once more delaying action, including by obstructing his own efforts to investigate the outbreak.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“This is a continuous theme in central-local relations in China. You do not want to be the one to bring bad news,” said Vivienne Shue, a prominent China scholar at Oxford University.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">That gulf between central leaders in Beijing and local officials who run the country day-to-day, Ms. Shue said, is “the core conundrum in how that system works.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">It leads officials on both sides of the center-local divide “to do many counterproductive, irrational things,” she said, in their efforts to manage and manipulate one another.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">That has included holding back reports of potential crises, in the hopes of solving things without the bosses finding out.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">At the same time, China’s quasi-imperial system leaves the top party bosses in Beijing with little direct power over what happens in the provinces — policy proclamations are sometimes ignored or defied — other than promoting or punishing subordinates.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The two ends of the system are engaged in a constant push-pull dynamic, putting them occasionally at odds — particularly in moments of crisis, when each is looking to blame the other.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">This has been an issue throughout China’s modern history, Ms. Shue said, with power fluctuating between the center and the periphery. Xi Jinping, China’s current leader, has sought to centralize power, setting up Beijing-based working groups to exert more control outside the capital.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">But the system’s underlying contradiction remains. Mr. Xi’s tightening grip may make local leaders all the more wary of releasing information that could invite his wrath.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">As China modernizes, integrating its once-disparate provinces and cities, local mistakes can become national crises before Beijing is even aware that something has happened, as may have happened with the coronavirus outbreak.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“As logistics and the distribution systems have expanded, you really see how the local and national have been linked together,” Mr. Yasuda said, referring to the hastening rate at which health, environmental and economic crises can now spread.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">That is not all downside. The central government has enormous capacity to mobilize in a crisis, as it is doing now, locking down several major cities to slow the disease’s spread.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“Once a clear problem has emerged, it’s very good at diverting resources,” Mr. Yasuda said of China’s political system. “But it’s not good at dealing with emerging problems. So it’s built to be reactive instead of proactive.”</p>, <h2 class="css-1320w4z eoo0vm40" id="link-6a985ff9">When China’s Strengths Become a Source of Peril</h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">In some ways, China’s system has been a source of strength.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Party bosses set priorities, then reward the institutions and officials who best carry them out.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">And since the days of Mao Zedong, China has operated under a system known as fragmented authoritarianism, in which even the most local leaders have near-absolute authority over their remit.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">That has led to a culture of what Elizabeth J. Perry, a Harvard University scholar, has called “guerrilla governance,” in which results take precedence over procedure or accountability, and in which it is all leaders for themselves.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">This approach is seen as crucial in having enabled China to lift hundreds of millions of citizens out of poverty and turn itself from global backwater into world power.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">But it can be disastrous when it comes to managing health and environmental issues.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Disease and pollution don’t respect provincial or municipal borders. And because of the way they spread, it often takes a unified, nationwide policy to prevent or stop them — something for which guerrilla governance is ill-suited.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“It’s very difficult to come together to create a clear actionable plan,” Mr. Yasuda said, adding that, for any health or environmental regulation to work, “you want it to be standardized, you want it to be transparent, you want it to be accountable.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">But China’s system de-emphasizes those concerns, sometimes <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2008/09/27/world/asia/27milk.html" title="">to disastrous effect</a>.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">In the mid-2000s, Beijing demanded a drastic increase in milk production. When factory farms were unable to meet their targets, officials conscripted vast numbers of rural farmers. Some of the farmers, struggling to meet their quotas, watered down their milk, then added an industrial chemical known as melamine to fool quality sensors. The <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2008/09/27/world/asia/27milk.html" title="">tainted milk poisoned thousands</a> of infants.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Experts fear a similar regulatory failure may have enabled the coronavirus outbreak: the longstanding inability to clean up so-called <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/25/world/asia/china-markets-coronavirus-sars.html" title="">wet markets</a>, which are stuffed with livestock living and dead, domesticated and wild. Though the outbreak’s cause is still being studied, Wuhan’s wet market is considered a prime suspect.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The markets have long been considered a major threat to public health, particularly as a vector for transmitting diseases from animals to humans. And they are a lesson in the perils of patchwork, decentralized regulations like China’s: While some markets are more carefully policed than others, all it takes is one to cause an outbreak.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">In another echo of the tainted milk scandal, top-down political priorities provide an incentive to look the other way. Taking down the markets, which are popular, would risk a public outcry. Local officials had every reason to fear that their bosses, who have not made the markets a priority, would punish them for causing trouble.</p>, <h2 class="css-1320w4z eoo0vm40" id="link-6d023ea6">Aligning With Public Good, Or Not</h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">A foundational mission of any political system is to align its leaders’ incentives with the needs and desires of the wider public.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Democracies seek to do this through “the competition of interests,” Ms. Shue said, on the belief that inviting everyone to participate will naturally pull the system toward the common good. This system, like any, has flaws, for example by handing more power to those with more money.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Within China, Ms. Shue added, the common good “is seen as something that should be designed from above, like a watch being engineered to run perfectly.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">But sometimes the watch can be designed in ways that harm the public good.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">In 2001, for instance, Beijing ordered provincial officials to reduce water pollution from factories. Many provinces simply <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/abs/pii/S0095069615000030" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">moved the factories to their borders</a>, ensuring pollutants would flow into the next district. Nationwide, water pollution worsened.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">So far, the coronavirus outbreak seems to highlight both the strengths and perils of China’s model. Beijing, apparently having learned from the SARS epidemic, has pushed for faster and more drastic action.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">But the same systemic problems, from gun-shy local officials to weak health regulations, appear to be recurring as well — a reminder that the system remains, Ms. Shue said, “a work in progress.”<br/></p>, <p>Advertisement</p>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd" id="site-index-label">Site Index</h2>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-0">news</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-1">opinion</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-2">arts</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-3">living</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-4">more</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-subscribe-label">Subscribe</h3>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd">Site Information Navigation</h2>]
[<p>Advertisement</p>, <p>Supported by</p>, <h1 class="css-1s4ffep e1h9rw200" id="link-382d511e" itemprop="headline"><span>As Coronavirus and Fear Spread to the U.S., Chinese-Americans Rush to Help</span></h1>, <p class="css-1ifw933 e1wiw3jv0" id="article-summary">Facing the brunt of scrutiny in the United States, Chinese-Americans have also scrambled to help friends and family in China.</p>, <p class="css-1fv7b6t e1jsehar1" itemprop="author" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">By<!-- --> <a class="css-brehiz e1jsehar0" href="https://www.nytimes.com/by/mike-baker"><span class="css-1baulvz" itemprop="name">Mike Baker</span></a> and <a class="css-brehiz e1jsehar0" href="https://www.nytimes.com/by/jeffrey-e-singer"><span class="css-1baulvz last-byline" itemprop="name">Jeffrey E. Singer</span></a></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Amy Lee-Ludovicy’s children and their classmates were supposed to be on a chartered bus into New York City on Friday morning, destined for a visit to Chinatown ahead of the Lunar New Year celebrations.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">But on the eve of their departure, Ms. Lee-Ludovicy, a native of Hong Kong, got some jarring news: The school district was canceling the trip, worried about <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/article/what-is-coronavirus.html" title="">the Wuhan coronavirus</a> that has spread across Asia — though there have so far been only <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/22/us/coronavirus-seattle-washington.html" title="">two documented cases</a> in the United States.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">She and her husband, Bruce, said the decision, in the midst of the outbreak, seemed to be rooted in a new and unfounded fear of Asians.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“I’m absolutely flabbergasted at this stupidity,” Bruce Ludovicy said. “My kids are half Asian and feel ostracized over this.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Dozens of people in 22 states are now being <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/23/us/united-states-coronavirus-cases.html" title="">monitored with possible signs of the virus</a>, with cases confirmed in <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/21/health/cdc-coronavirus.html" title="">Washington State</a> and <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/24/health/chicago-coronavirus-cdc.html" title="">Illinois</a>.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">For people in the United States with close ties to China, the Wuhan outbreak has brought unexpected worry, disappointment and scrutiny. Some in the Chinese-American community have had their <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/24/world/asia/wuhan-virus.html" title="">Lunar New Year holiday</a> plans waylaid, as travel schedules for the coming week and beyond get interrupted.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Some are gearing up for the outbreak to get worse. Hardware stores and pharmacies around the United States are selling out of <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/23/health/coronavirus-surgical-masks.html" title="">masks that could help</a> prevent the spread of the disease. In the New York City neighborhood of Flushing, masks have been sold out for much of the week.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Chinese-Americans networking with their friends and family in China have scrambled to send aid. One woman in Los Angeles has amassed 20,000 masks to ship overseas.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Sean Shi, of Issaquah, Wash., said he shipped several boxes of masks to China in a friend’s luggage, with hopes that the masks could reach friends in the Wuhan area as soon as possible. Later in the day, Mr. Shi was back at a local hardware store, buying another 46 masks for some of his former peers at Wuhan University.</p>, <h1 class="g-headline" id="g-inlineguide-headline">The Coronavirus Outbreak</h1>, <h2 class="g-inlineguide-list-header g-optimize-type">How Is the U.S. Being Affected?</h2>, <p class="g-inlineguide-date">Updated Feb.10, 2020</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“We understand it’s a tough situation over there — the panic, the shortage of equipment,” Mr. Shi said. “We just realized the situation is very serious — more serious than we thought.”</p>, <h2 class="css-3ez4hu eoo0vm40" id="link-5f373b90">Fears Spread</h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Through messages on the WeChat messaging service, Chinese-Americans have a personal window into the <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/24/world/asia/china-social-media-coronavirus.html" title="">fears and uncertainty</a> spreading through the Wuhan region.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The virus, which emerged in December, has now spread to other countries. But the majority of the nearly 1,300 infections reported, and all 41 of the deaths from the illness, <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2020/01/21/world/asia/china-coronavirus-maps.html" title="">have been in China</a>. Authorities shut down transportation out of Wuhan, hoping to contain the spread of the virus, and have since expanded the lockdown to other cities, covering a total population of about 35 million.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The Lunar New Year celebration often sends families traveling within China and around the globe. Mr. Shi said the illness had disrupted some of those plans, keeping families apart.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Long Wu, a 68-year-old retiree in Pasadena, Calif., said she had bought tickets to fly back to China in March. But she has now canceled her plans.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“It’s better to put your health first,” Ms. Wu said. “My whole family canceled their tickets.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Jack Huang, a 76-year-old businessman in Rowland Heights, Calif., said he was worried about how easily the virus could spread in the United States.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“I am really hesitant on meeting clients coming in directly from China, especially hearing about the mass quarantines,” Mr. Huang said.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">In New York, Ms. Lee-Ludovicy said her children had been excited at the prospect of the field trip to Chinatown, planning to go with a group of other students who are studying Mandarin.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">With the trip canceled, Ms. Lee-Ludovicy said, she and her family planned to drive to the celebrations on their own.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">But she worried that her two children, a daughter in middle school and a son in high school, were facing discrimination in ways they had not before. And she wondered what other students were taking away from the experience.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“Kids are not being educated,” she said. “They are being taught, ‘Let’s just stay away from them.’”</p>, <h2 class="css-3ez4hu eoo0vm40" id="link-219c1735">‘They’re Sold Out’</h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">In Flushing, the streets and storefronts this week were lined with vendors selling Chinese wall hangings and red envelopes decorated with images celebrating the Year of the Rat. Hurrying through the crowds was a woman with a brown fur hat and a white paper face mask in search of masks for her relatives in Fujian Province.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">She stopped at one drugstore after another, repeatedly asking, “Do you carry face masks?”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“Everywhere I go they’re sold out,” said the woman, who identified herself only by her surname, Zheng. “How could this be?”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Ms. Zheng, 68, said she was worried that her family in Fuzhou, Fujian — though far from the epicenter of the outbreak — could be in danger.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">At the fifth pharmacy she visited, Ms. Zheng finally found surgical masks for $2. She bought five.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Scenes like this unfolded across Chinese enclaves around New York. Some store managers said wholesalers were not able to keep up with demand.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Daniel Xu, a pharmacist and manager at Starside Drugs in Flushing, said a customer came in on Monday and completely bought out his stock.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“All of a sudden we were out, and then hundreds of people started coming in asking for face masks,” Mr. Xu said. He said they restocked as much as they could before their distributor started rationing.</p>, <h2 class="css-3ez4hu eoo0vm40" id="link-7dda7471">Thousands of Masks</h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Mr. Xu is partnered with Jointown Pharmaceutical Group, based in Wuhan, and has been working to help colleagues in China secure sources of much-needed protective gear for medical caregivers there — surgical face masks, coveralls, eye shields and other medical coverings, including caps and shoe covers.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“Now the problem is not the money,” he said. “Now we need to get the supplies.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">On Thursday, he was in his basement office, juggling phone calls, social media and email to organize efforts from various donor groups, including the Association of Chinese American Physicians.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Mr. Xu had already secured free shipping through a Chinese airline, he said, and was working on an official channel with the Hubei Province Red Cross to accept and distribute donations of supplies. Struggling to find suppliers, he was brokering deals with factories and importers to secure supplies that had originally been bound for overseas superstores. But resources were still scarce.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“Now China has to borrow from America,” he joked.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">On the West Coast, June Liao, the owner of a baby formula export company based in Los Angeles, had amassed 20,000 masks from various sources to donate to Wuhan via the Red Cross. She set up two growing WeChat groups that have collectively raised $48,000 in under 24 hours, she said.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">In Washington State, Mr. Shi said he and a handful of others, working as part of a group called the United Chinese Americans of Washington, have established a team to coordinate help. He has ordered 100 masks online. But in the meantime, he has been buying from stores, reading the labels to ensure the masks offer what he deemed to be sufficient protection.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">In his WeChat app, he called up a bulletin from officials in Wuhan describing what was needed. While he was not sure if private shipping to China would get through the quarantines, he was hopeful that aid groups would be able to bring in the supplies they are managing to gather.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“In the long run, they will figure out how to supply and deliver to there,” he said. In the meantime, he said, “It’s always good if we can send something to them.”</p>, <p class="css-jwz2nf etfikam0">Angela Chen contributed reporting.</p>, <p>Advertisement</p>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd" id="site-index-label">Site Index</h2>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-0">news</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-1">opinion</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-2">arts</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-3">living</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-4">more</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-subscribe-label">Subscribe</h3>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd">Site Information Navigation</h2>]
[<p>Advertisement</p>, <p>Supported by</p>, <h1 class="css-1s4ffep e1h9rw200" id="link-97ba81a" itemprop="headline"><span>China’s Omnivorous Markets Are in the Eye of a Lethal Outbreak Once Again</span></h1>, <p class="css-1ifw933 e1wiw3jv0" id="article-summary">The coronavirus that has spread from Wuhan has been linked to the sale of live wildlife at a market that experts describe as a perfect incubator for novel pathogens.</p>, <p class="css-1fv7b6t e1jsehar1" itemprop="author" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">By<!-- --> <a class="css-brehiz e1jsehar0" href="https://www.nytimes.com/by/steven-lee-myers"><span class="css-1baulvz last-byline" itemprop="name">Steven Lee Myers</span></a></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">LANGFANG, China — The typical market in China has fruits and vegetables, butchered beef, pork and lamb, whole plucked chickens — with heads and beaks attached — and live crabs and fish, spewing water out of churning tanks. Some sell more unusual fare, including live snakes, turtles and cicadas, guinea pigs, bamboo rats, badgers, hedgehogs, otters, palm civets, even wolf cubs.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The markets are fixtures in scores of Chinese cities, and now, for at least the second time in two decades, they are the source of an epidemic that has spread fear, <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/25/world/asia/coronavirus-crisis-china-response.html" title="">taxed the Communist Party bureaucracy</a> and exposed the epidemiological risks that can spawn in places where humans and wildlife converge. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The novel <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/article/what-is-coronavirus.html" title="">coronavirus</a> that has already killed at least 56 and sickened more than 1,370 in China and around the world <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/21/health/what-is-coronavirus.html?searchResultPosition=7" title="">is believed to have spread</a> from exactly one of these places: a wholesale market in Wuhan, a city in central China, where vendors legally sold live animals from stalls in close quarters with hundreds of others.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“This is where you get new and emerging diseases that the human population has never seen before,” said Kevin J. Olival, a biologist and vice president of research with EcoHealth Alliance, a nonprofit research organization, who has tracked previous outbreaks.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">While the exact path of the pathogen has not yet been established, government officials and scientists said the new contagion had ominous similarities with the outbreak of SARS, or severe acute respiratory syndrome, in late 2002, which killed nearly 800 people and sickened thousands more around the world.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Now, as the government struggles <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/23/world/asia/china-coronavirus-outbreak.html?searchResultPosition=4" title="">to contain public anger over the outbreak</a>, it is facing calls to do more to regulate or even ban the sale of wildlife — and growing questions about why so little has changed in the 17 years since SARS.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">That <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2003/04/27/world/the-sars-epidemic-the-path-from-china-s-provinces-a-crafty-germ-breaks-out.html" title="">disease</a> was ultimately traced to a coronavirus that jumped from bats to Asian palm civets, a catlike creature prized as a delicacy in southern China, and then to humans involved in the wildlife trade there. According to officials and scientists, <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/28/science/bats-coronavirus-Wuhan.html" title="">the new virus also appears to have originated in bats</a> and made the jump to another mammal, though which one is not yet clear.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The latest outbreak — the scope of which is still unfolding — has led to calls inside and outside of China for better regulations or even an end to this kind of culinary adventurism. While turtle and boar meat are not uncommon in Chinese restaurants, game meats such as civet cats, snakes or pangolins tend to be considered specialties only in some regions. Their consumption is driven as much by the desire to flaunt wealth as by a mix of superstition and belief about the health benefits of wildlife.</p>, <h1 class="g-headline" id="g-inlineguide-headline">The Coronavirus Outbreak</h1>, <h2 class="g-inlineguide-list-header g-optimize-type">What do you need to know? Start here.</h2>, <p class="g-inlineguide-date">Updated Feb. 10, 2020</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Once the Huanan Seafood Wholesale Market in Wuhan was identified as the most likely source of this outbreak in December, the authorities promptly closed it, though it was not clear what happened to the animals that had been for sale there. Officials announced only on Wednesday that they had banned the sale of wild animals throughout the province. Two other provinces, Henan and Inner Mongolia, also <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="http://m.xinhuanet.com/2020-01/23/c_1125495548.htm" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">imposed</a> suspensions on the trade this past week.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">On Friday, officials from three national agencies announced tighter controls, including a suspension nationally of the sale and transport of animals possibly linked to the new coronavirus. The statement specified only badgers and bamboo rats, a species of rodent found in southern China that lives in (and eats) bamboo thickets. Both had been advertised for sale in the market in Wuhan.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The flurry of government action came after an unusual outpouring of public sentiment against the trade of live animals. A campaign on Weibo, the social media platform, drew 45 million views with the hashtag #rejectgamemeat.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“Eating game does not cure impotence or have healing powers,” Jin Sichen, a television presenter in Nanjing, a city in southeastern China, wrote <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.weibo.com/1863716232/IqGcXwuXm?from=page_1005051863716232_profile&amp;wvr=6&amp;mod=weibotime&amp;type=comment" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">on his Weibo page</a> on Wednesday. “Game not only doesn’t cure disease, it can also make you, your family, friends and even more people sick.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“One must be mentally sick to eat game in order to show off and flaunt,” Mr. Jin added.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">A group of 19 Chinese scholars also called on the government to do more to regulate the trade and the public to stop eating wild animals.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The Wildlife Conservation Society, an advocacy organization based in New York, called for a global ban on the commercial sale of wildlife, especially in markets like those in China, saying that the latest outbreak proved the public health threat.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Christian Walzer, the organization’s executive director of health, said that the astonishing diversity of wild animals in markets like these, packed in small cages in crowded market stalls, created a perfect laboratory for the unintentional incubation of new viruses that can enter human cells. Viruses can be spread through saliva, blood or feces.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“Each animal is a package of pathogens,” he said in a telephone interview.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">But some Chinese consumers ascribe traditional medicinal benefits to the animals. Vendors and even officials in state news media have touted wildlife as alternative sources of protein and sources of revenue in impoverished regions.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">An article by the Xinhua news agency last fall, for example, said that farming bamboo rats was helping to lift people out of poverty in Guangxi, another southern province.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Worries about meat supplies surged last year over the outbreak of African swine fever, which led to the killing of 40 percent of the country’s pigs. Production of domesticated livestock on the country’s farms is, compared to the sale of wildlife, subjected to far more regulation and inspection. Outbreaks still occur, but they are identified more quickly.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Part of the problem with the wildlife trade is that there is far less regulation, despite the greater risk of live animals’ infecting each other and people, especially in markets that can be unsanitary.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Mr. Walzer said that one problem with the legal production of some species is that it can blur the lines between those raised in captivity and those captured in the wild, where unknown viruses have existed for years without contact with humans.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“It’s a public health hazard, not only in China but everywhere,” he said.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">At the peak of the SARS outbreak in 2003, the authorities banned the sale of civets and culled the existing stocks, but within months they <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2004/01/06/world/who-urges-china-to-use-caution-while-killing-civet-cats.html" title="">ended the ban</a> and trade had resumed as before.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“It is driven by interests,” Qin Xiaona, president of the Capital Animal Welfare Association, an advocacy organization in Beijing, said of the current outbreak. “Many people profit from the wildlife trade today.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The trafficking of some wildlife is prohibited, including endangered pangolins, which are prized for their scales and meat, but China’s National Forestry and Grassland Administration allows people to raise 54 different animals, birds, reptiles and insects, including muskrat, chipmunks, ostriches, emus and centipedes.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">On Taobao, a popular Chinese online shopping platform, all manner of live wildlife can be had. A baby badger costs 1,300 renminbi, or $187. A farmer from Hunan, the province directly south of Hubei, sells civets, the source of SARS, for the equivalent of $215 each — discounted to $200 if one buys 500 or more.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">At the sprawling, semi-enclosed market in Langfang, an electronics manufacturing hub south of Beijing, one vendor advertised a live crocodile ($550) and a porcupine ($115). </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">In Wuhan, the authorities have not given details about all the animals that were on sale in the market linked to the new coronavirus. People on social media circulated a photograph of a price list for a variety of animals purported to be sold by a vendor in the market, but its authenticity could not be confirmed. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">According to a <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://mp.weixin.qq.com/s/_ZgkquIlUYnix2y7WmKPew" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">medical blog posted</a> on WeChat, the health authorities in Wuhan visited the market in September and inspected eight vendors selling frogs, snakes and hedgehogs, among other animals. All were licensed to sell wildlife, and no violations were found.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Despite the spread of the virus around the country, a Hong Kong television network, I-Cable News Channel, found scores of wild animals still for sale on Wednesday at a market in Qingyuan, a city in Guangdong, the province where SARS originated. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The epidemic has now put sellers on the defensive.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“Are you sure it is eating wild animals that has caused the epidemic?” said Zheng Ming, the sales manager of <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://shop1429548772861.1688.com/page/offerlist.htm?spm=a2615.7691456.autotrace-topNav.3.7b3573957CJiZ4" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">a company</a> selling<span class="css-8l6xbc evw5hdy0"> </span>animals in Yichang, a city 180 miles west of Wuhan. Until the ban on sales announced this past week, he sold porcupines, civets, guinea pigs and bamboo rats among others.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“We observe the law,” he said. “This is a completely legal business.”</p>, <p class="css-jwz2nf etfikam0">James Gorman contributed reporting from New York. Zoe Mou in Beijing and Claire Fu in Chengdu contributed research.</p>, <p>Advertisement</p>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd" id="site-index-label">Site Index</h2>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-0">news</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-1">opinion</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-2">arts</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-3">living</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-4">more</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-subscribe-label">Subscribe</h3>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd">Site Information Navigation</h2>]
[<p>Advertisement</p>, <p>Supported by</p>, <h1 class="css-fnr6md e1h9rw200" id="link-313fd960" itemprop="headline"><span>The Coronavirus: What Travelers Need to Know</span></h1>, <p class="css-1ifw933 e1wiw3jv0" id="article-summary">Airlines are suspending direct flights to mainland China, and U.S. health officials are warning travelers to avoid all nonessential trips to the country, the center of the outbreak.</p>, <p class="css-1fv7b6t e1jsehar1" itemprop="author" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">By<!-- --> <span class="css-1baulvz" itemprop="name">Mike Arnot</span> and <a class="css-brehiz e1jsehar0" href="https://www.nytimes.com/by/tariro-mzezewa"><span class="css-1baulvz last-byline" itemprop="name">Tariro Mzezewa</span></a></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The death toll from a <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/26/world/china-coronavirus.html" title="">novel coronavirus</a> has now reached 170 people, with most of the more than 7,700 cases reported in the central Chinese province of Hubei, the epicenter of the disease. At least <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2020/01/21/world/asia/china-coronavirus-maps.html" title="">19 other countries</a> have also reported cases, and the virus has been diagnosed in five people in the United States; all had recently returned from China.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Airlines are suspending flights to mainland China, and on Monday, the United States Centers for Disease Control and Prevention advised avoiding all nonessential travel to China. On Thursday, the World Health Organization declared that the outbreak was a global health emergency and the United States set its advisory level on China at 4, its highest level, advising Americans not to travel to China. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"> Here’s what travelers making their way to or from China can expect.</p>, <h2 class="css-1320w4z eoo0vm40" id="link-7650292c">Where was the disease first discovered?</h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The outbreak of the deadly coronavirus is centered in Wuhan, a city of 11 million and the capital of Hubei Province in China. Wuhan is a major manufacturing center, but not known as a tourist destination.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Travelers to Wuhan are likely visiting friends and family, or are business travelers connected to that city’s manufacturing industry. Most business travelers will have already returned home as the factories recently closed for the Lunar New Year — as is tradition. Last week, the Chinese authorities imposed <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/22/world/asia/coronavirus-quarantines-history.html" title="">a blanket travel ban on Wuhan</a> and surrounding cities in Hubei Province, a population of 35 million people. No planes, trains or buses are going in and out.</p>, <h2 class="css-1320w4z eoo0vm40" id="link-2de24369">What are airlines doing?</h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">All flights in and out of Wuhan have been suspended. Several airlines have canceled flights to other cities in China or announced reductions in their service.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">This week, British Airways said it was canceling all flights to mainland China, the first major carrier to do so. On the heels of that announcement, Air Canada said it would suspend all flights to China until Feb. 29 and Lufthansa Group (which includes Lufthansa, SWISS and Austrian) said it would suspend all flights until Feb. 9 and would no longer accept bookings until the end of February. Those airlines are all offering full refunds.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.united.com/ual/en/us/fly/travel/notices.html" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">United Airlines</a> announced Thursday that it would suspend all but 12 daily flights to Beijing, Shanghai and Hong Kong from its United States hubs (Newark, Chicago, Washington and San Francisco).<span class="css-8l6xbc evw5hdy0"> </span>The suspensions start Feb. 2 and last through March 28. United also said it would offer full refunds for flights to Beijing and Shanghai where travel hadn’t yet started, even for nonrefundable fares.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.delta.com/us/en/advisories/other-alerts/coronavirus-situation-in-china" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">Delta Air Lines</a> announced Wednesday that it was reducing the frequency of its flights to China to 21 from 42 per week.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The airlines are allowing passengers who were planning to travel to, from or through Beijing or Shanghai, and in some cases Chengdu, to rebook their itineraries without a change fee, though the policies differ and passengers are advised to contact their carrier.</p>, <h1 class="g-headline" id="g-inlineguide-headline">The Coronavirus Outbreak</h1>, <h2 class="g-inlineguide-list-header g-optimize-type">What do you need to know? Start here.</h2>, <p class="g-inlineguide-date">Updated Feb. 10, 2020</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.delta.com/us/en/advisories/other-alerts/coronavirus-situation-in-china" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">Delta Air Lines</a> said that no refunds would be issued and that rebooked travel must begin before May 31 to avoid change fees and the difference in fare; after that date, the change fee will be waived but passengers will be assessed any applicable difference in fare. Passengers may cancel their itineraries in exchange for a travel credit (but with payment of any difference in fare and the applicable change fee).</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.aa.com/i18n/travel-info/travel-alerts.jsp" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">American Airlines</a> will permit travelers to delay their trips for up to one year from the original ticket date without change fees (but with payment of any difference in fare). Refunds are offered only for flights to Wuhan. <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.emirates.com/cn/english/help/travel-updates.aspx/" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">Emirates passengers</a> may request a refund if they no longer wish to travel to Shanghai, Beijing or Guangzhou (for travel up to Feb. 6) or change their travel dates (for travel up to Feb. 29).</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">United will allow passengers to rebook without penalty (but with payment of any difference in fare) for trips after March 31.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.cathaypacific.com/cx/en_US/travel-information/travel-preparation/travel-advisories/special-ticketing-guidelines-for-mainland-china.html" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">Cathay Pacific</a>, the Hong Kong-based carrier, and Cathay Dragon, its regional subsidiary which operates in mainland China, are permitting passengers to rebook or reroute flights without charge to mainland China, so long as passengers travel on or before May 31. The airline has announced that it is reducing its number of flights to mainland China by up to half.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">In a first since the SARS crisis in 2002 and 2003, Cathay Pacific is permitting its crew and staff to wear surgical masks at work, and has announced in-flight service changes such as eliminating hot towels, pillows, blankets and magazines. Likewise, American Airlines: “While it is not medically recommended, American will allow flight attendants to wear masks on flights to and from Shanghai, Beijing and Hong Kong,” said Curtis Blessing, an American spokesman, in a statement.
