The masks are ubiquitous across Asia, but not common in North America.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Dr. Paulo Alves, the global medical director at MedAire, a Phoenix provider of in-flight, virtual medical care to airlines and their passengers worldwide, said masks are meant to contain the droplets that someone emits when sneezing or coughing. Passengers are not being issued surgical masks by airlines. </p>, <h2 class="css-1320w4z eoo0vm40" id="link-16213913">What should travelers expect at airports in the U.S. and in China?</h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Foreign and domestic airlines typically operate dozens of daily flights from the United States to China, primarily to Hong Kong, Beijing and Shanghai. China Southern operated direct flights between John F. Kennedy International Airport, San Francisco International and Wuhan. Before the travel lockdown, passengers could have connected in China to Wuhan through code-share partners such as Cathay Pacific, Air China, China Eastern Airlines and China Southern Airlines.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The decision behind <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/28/health/airports-screening-coronavirus.html" title="">which American airports screen passengers</a> is made by the C.D.C., which last week began scanning passengers for signs of infection at Kennedy, San Francisco International, Chicago’s O’Hare International Airport, Los Angeles International and Hartsfield-Jackson Atlanta International Airport.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">At a news briefing in Washington on Tuesday, C.D.C. officials said <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/28/health/airports-screening-coronavirus.html" title="">they were expanding the number of entry ports</a> that would screen passengers, to 20 from five. These include ports for both land and air.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Screenings will now take place at <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.cdc.gov/quarantine/quarantinestations.html" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">existing C.D.C. quarantine stations</a>, most of which are at airports. These include the current five airports as well as other ports in Anchorage, Boston, Dallas, Detroit, El Paso, Honolulu, Houston, Miami, Minneapolis-St. Paul, Philadelphia, San Diego, Seattle and San Juan in Puerto Rico. Washington Dulles International Airport and Newark Liberty International Airport will also have screening facilities.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">In Asia and the United States, passengers are scanned with thermal devices to measure their temperature. Passengers with symptoms such as high fever may undergo additional screening, and even off-site monitoring at specialized facilities.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">In a statement released Tuesday, the C.D.C. said that the Customs and Border Protection agency would identify all travelers from the affected areas and provide them with a printed health alert notice. The notice provides travelers with information on what to do if they experience coronavirus symptoms within 14 days after arriving in the United States. Immigration officials will refer ill travelers with symptoms specific to novel coronavirus and a connection to China to C.D.C. staff members at the airport for evaluation.</p>, <h2 class="css-1320w4z eoo0vm40" id="link-750765d9">Should travelers to China cancel their flights?</h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">On Monday, the C.D.C. said that Americans should avoid all nonessential travel to China.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“Chinese officials have closed transport within and out of Wuhan and other cities in Hubei Province, including buses, subways, trains and the international airport,” it said in an updated notice. “Additional restrictions and cancellations of events may occur.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“There is limited access to adequate medical care in affected areas,” it added.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The agency <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://wwwnc.cdc.gov/travel/notices/warning/novel-coronavirus-china" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">maintains a websit</a><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://wwwnc.cdc.gov/travel/destinations/traveler/none/china" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">e</a> that travelers can check to get the latest recommendations.</p>, <h2 class="css-1320w4z eoo0vm40" id="link-2833b786">Are tourist destinations in China closed?</h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Some of the most popular tourist destinations, including the National Museum of China and the Forbidden City (both in Beijing), were closed over the weekend.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The Badaling section of the Great Wall of China, a popular attraction about 40 miles outside of Beijing, was also closed, as were the Shanghai Disney Resort and Hong Kong Disneyland Park (the hotels at the Hong Kong Disneyland Resort remain open). No date has been announced for reopening any of these sites. In addition, multiday celebrations for the Lunar New Year have been canceled in Beijing, Shanghai and Hong Kong.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Wuhan, at the center of the outbreak, lies on the Yangtze River. The river is a popular multi-night cruise route that includes visits to the Three Gorges Dam, which is in Hubei Province. No official announcements on the status of these river cruises have been announced, so travelers who have booked cruises should contact their travel agencies.</p>, <h2 class="css-1320w4z eoo0vm40" id="link-6e7efcdc">What are cruise operators doing in response?</h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Some cruise lines are rescheduling and canceling trips, while others are increasing screening procedures for travelers embarking at Chinese ports.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Costa Cruises, MSC, Royal Caribbean and Victoria Cruises canceled a combined 18 sailings to China, according to <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.cruisecritic.com/news/5016/" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">Cruise Critic,</a> a cruise review website. Costa Cruises, a subsidiary of Carnival Corporation, canceled four cruises scheduled to travel to China, and four of its ships are now docked in Chinese ports. Passengers can choose alternative sailing dates before the end of 2020 with a $50 onboard credit, or they can get a full refund.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Royal Caribbean canceled a Spectrum of the Seas cruise, scheduled to sail from Shanghai on Monday, as well as another departure on Friday. The Spectrum of the Seas is one of the largest cruise ships in the world. MSC canceled its Splendida ship from sailing on Tuesday. Both companies said passengers on the canceled sailings were eligible for refunds.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Holland America Line, which is owned by Carnival, changed the disembarkation port for its Feb. 1 sailing on the Westerdam ship, from Hong Kong to Yokohama.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Crystal, Norwegian, Regent Seven Seas Cruises and Silversea added preboarding health requirements for passengers. Norwegian is using “nontouch” temperature screenings for passengers departing from Chinese ports and will not allow anyone with a temperature of 100.4 degrees Fahrenheit or higher to board.</p>, <h2 class="css-1320w4z eoo0vm40" id="link-6fc216ad">What precautions can travelers take?</h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“Those universal things like washing your hands are always recommended,” Dr. Alves said. He also suggested passengers avoid touching their faces, practice coughing etiquette and not cough into the environment.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“Keep some distance from people who are obviously sick and maintain good personal hygiene,” he added.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The advice mirrors that given to travelers during cold and flu season. While seat backs and tray tables on long-haul aircraft like those flying to China from the United States are individually wiped down by ground crew between flights, passengers may wish to bring their own wipes for a second pass.</p>, <p>Advertisement</p>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd" id="site-index-label">Site Index</h2>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-0">news</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-1">opinion</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-2">arts</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-3">living</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-4">more</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-subscribe-label">Subscribe</h3>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd">Site Information Navigation</h2>]
[<p>Advertisement</p>, <p>Supported by</p>, <p class="css-tsacue e6idgb70"></p>, <h1 class="css-1s4ffep e1h9rw200" id="link-2f18f1de" itemprop="headline"><span>More U.S. Coronavirus Cases Emerge, as China’s Death Toll Rises</span></h1>, <p class="css-1ifw933 e1wiw3jv0" id="article-summary">The number of dead climbed to at least 80, while in the United States, five cases were confirmed.</p>, <p class="css-1fv7b6t e1jsehar1" itemprop="author" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">By<!-- --> <span class="css-1baulvz last-byline" itemprop="name">The New York Times</span></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">This briefing has ended. Read about developments our </em><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/29/world/asia/coronavirus-china.html" title=""><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">live coronavirus outbreak coverage here</em></a><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">.</em></p>, <h2 class="css-3ez4hu eoo0vm40" id="link-65c86e3">The death toll rises to at least 80, and Wuhan may have 1,000 more cases.</h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The mayor of Wuhan, which is at the center of the viral outbreak, said on Sunday that there could be about 1,000 more confirmed cases of the mysterious illness in the city — a sign that China’s monumental efforts to halt the disease may only just be starting.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">In a news conference, the mayor, Zhou Xianwang, said that the estimate was based on the assumption that around half of the city’s nearly 3,000 suspected cases of the coronavirus would eventually test positive for the disease. The youngest confirmed case involved a 9-month-old girl in Beijing, according to The People’s Daily, a state newspaper.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Mr. Zhou also said that five million people had left Wuhan before travel out of the city was restricted, leaving nine million people still living there. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">As of Monday morning, the official count of confirmed cases across China stood at 2,744. The authorities in Hubei Province put the death toll at 76 there, bumping the overall deaths to at least 80.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">On Sunday China announced 15 more deaths from the new coronavirus, including one in Shanghai, the first reported there. Thirteen deaths were announced in Hubei Province, where the outbreak began, and one in Henan Province. Across the country, 688 new cases were diagnosed on Saturday, the government said early Sunday.</p>, <h2 class="css-zd32qr">Wuhan Coronavirus Map: Tracking the Spread of the Outbreak</h2>, <p class="css-1uuihdo">The virus has sickened tens of thousands of people in China and a number of other countries.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Deaths from the coronavirus had previously been reported outside of Hubei. But the death in Shanghai, which is among China’s most populous cities and a major commercial hub, is likely to fuel anxieties about the disease’s spread.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Shanghai’s municipal health commission said on Sunday that the patient who died was an 88-year-old man.</p>, <h2 class="css-3ez4hu eoo0vm40" id="link-6131399e">A fifth U.S. case has been confirmed.</h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Three more cases of the coronavirus were reported on Sunday in the United States, two in California and one in Arizona, bringing the country’s total to five, according to the C.D.C.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">All three had recently been in Wuhan, health officials said. The three patients were all being kept in isolation.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">A patient in Los Angeles County passed through Los Angeles International Airport from Wuhan on the way to a vacation elsewhere, Barbara Ferrer, the director of the county’s Department of Public Health, said at a news conference. The traveler returned to LAX on Jan. 22, wearing a mask, and approached airport staff about possibly having the virus.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The other California patient, in neighboring Orange County, was identified by the county health agency as a traveler from Wuhan.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The patient in Maricopa County in Arizona is an adult member of the Arizona State University community, health officials said.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Other cases have been found in Washington State and <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/24/health/chicago-coronavirus-cdc.html" title="">Chicago</a>. The C.D.C. has sent teams to each of the states to help trace and follow up on contacts of the infected patients.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The C.D.C. said that just over 100 “patients under investigation” from 26 states were being monitored because they had traveled to Wuhan, or had contact with patients, and had symptoms like fever, cough or shortness of breath that could be caused by the virus.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">So far, 25 of those under investigation have tested negative for the virus.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The risk to the general public is considered low, Dr. Nancy Messonnier, director of the National Center for Immunization and Respiratory Diseases, said Sunday at a news briefing. “But the threat is serious,” she said.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The C.D.C. is urging the public to get flu shots, to help reduce the number of people seeking treatment for symptoms that might be mistaken for the new coronavirus.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The agency is also preparing test kits to be sent to state health departments so that they can test for the virus instead of having to send samples to the C.D.C. for testing, but it will be a few more weeks before the kits are ready, Dr. Messonnier said.</p>, <h2 class="css-3ez4hu eoo0vm40" id="link-2f2f68ca">‘The epidemic has entered a more serious and complex period.’</h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The head of China’s National Health Commission, Ma Xiaowei, warned on Sunday that people who carried the disease but did not show flu symptoms could still infect others. That would be a major difference between the new virus and SARS, a coronavirus that spread in China and around the world nearly two decades ago, killing 800 people.</p>, <h1 class="g-headline" id="g-inlineguide-headline">The Coronavirus Outbreak</h1>, <h2 class="g-inlineguide-list-header g-optimize-type">What do you need to know? Start here.</h2>, <p class="g-inlineguide-date">Updated Feb. 10, 2020</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“The epidemic has entered a more serious and complex period,” said Dr. Ma, the director of China’s National Health Commission.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">He also <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://xhpfmapi.zhongguowangshi.com/vh512/share/8827546?channel=weixin" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">said on Sunday</a> that the new coronavirus’s incubation period was about 10 to 14 days, and that the period is contagious.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“There have been mild cases where observation has shown that the patients were contagious during the incubation period. The incubation period is around 10 days,” he said. “The shortest time before the disease’s onset was one day. The longest was 14 days. This is very different from SARS.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The rate of the current epidemic is accelerating, he added, and is “likely to continue for some time.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">A study by the <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.thelancet.com/pb-assets/Lancet/pdfs/S0140673620301549.pdf" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">medical journal The Lancet</a>, published on Friday, had raised concerns that people infected with the coronavirus might be able to spread it even if they do not have flulike symptoms.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Health officials in the United States expressed some caution on Sunday.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“We at the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention don’t have any clear evidence of patients’ being infectious before symptom onset,” Dr. Messonnier of the National Center for Immunization and Respiratory Diseases said at a news briefing on Sunday. “We are actively investigating that possibility.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Spread of the virus by people with no symptoms would make the disease harder to control — if that really is occurring, said Dr. Thomas R. Frieden, a former C.D.C. director who is now president of Resolve to Save Lives, a public health organization. “We don’t know,” he said.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Dr. Michael Osterholm, director of the Center for Infectious Disease Research and Policy at the University of Minnesota, said he had seen no data to indicate that people with no symptoms were contagious.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“We surely haven’t seen that with any of the other coronaviruses, MERS or SARS,” Dr. Osterholm said. “When we could document transmission, patients were ill.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">He added, “Mother Nature is throwing us a curveball with this outbreak, but we shouldn’t accept every claim like this until we see the data.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Dr. Julie Gerberding, another former C.D.C. director and now chief patient officer at Merck, said the spread by asymptomatic people was not impossible. Seemingly asymptomatic people could have the sniffles, she said, which might go unnoticed but spread the virus.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“The U.S. has faced multiple pandemics before,” Dr. Messonnier said. “We need to be preparing as if this is a pandemic, but I hope it’s not.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">If people with no signs or symptoms of illness can spread the infection, that “offers many more opportunities for spread, and increases the difficulty of curtailing the spread greatly, because you can’t just focus on sick individuals,” said Dr. William Schaffner, an infectious disease expert at Vanderbilt University.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“If an exposed person becomes contagious before they become sick, you can almost think of them as a secret spreader,” he said. “They’re healthy. Nobody suspects they’re sick. Nobody’s avoiding them, and they’re not staying home with their illness.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">He added: “SARS was largely transmitted from people who were already sick. Ebola was the same. If you were exposed, you were of no risk to anyone until you became sick, and even in the early day or two or three of illness you were not of risk to anyone.”</p>, <h2 class="css-3ez4hu eoo0vm40" id="link-71fc5df3">Hong Kong bars residents from the center of the outbreak.</h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">In Hong Kong — which was badly hit by the SARS coronavirus in 2003, with nearly 300 deaths — worries about the spread of infectious diseases run deep. On Sunday, the government said it would bar residents of Hubei Province, which includes Wuhan, and people who had been to the province in the past 14 days from entering Hong Kong until further notice.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The rule does not apply to Hong Kong residents, according to a government statement.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Six cases of the new coronavirus have been confirmed in the city, already hobbled by months of antigovernment protests.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Its efforts to contain the virus have been met with resistance. A plan to convert an unused public housing block into a quarantine site incited protests on Sunday, with demonstrators setting fires in the lobbies of two of the buildings.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The government condemned the fires set at the public housing complex, in Hong Kong’s New Territories. But it also backed away from its plan to use the buildings for quarantine, saying that it would use government-owned sites first.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The unrest came a day after Carrie Lam, the leader of the semiautonomous territory, declared a health emergency and said Hong Kong schools would be closed until February. She also said trains and flights between Wuhan and Hong Kong would be halted.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Calls had circulated in the past week for new arrivals from the mainland to be barred. Mrs. Lam initially said that would be “inappropriate and impractical” but on Sunday the government changed course on residents of Hubei Province.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/24/world/asia/wuhan-virus.html?action=click&amp;module=RelatedLinks&amp;pgtype=Article" title="">The weeklong Lunar New Year holiday</a>, which began on Saturday, is usually a peak travel period in China. CCTV, the Chinese state broadcaster, reported that the State Council would extend the holiday three days, until Feb. 2. That would keep people away from workplaces, schools and other public buildings for a longer period.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Fears about the virus are affecting tourism in the city, whose economy depends significantly on money spent by visitors at malls, hotels and restaurants, and which is now in a recession.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Two of Hong Kong’s biggest attractions, Disneyland and Ocean Park, said on Sunday that they were closing until further notice. <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.hongkongdisneyland.com/" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">A notice on Hong Kong Disneyland’s website</a> called it a “precautionary measure.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Shanghai’s Disneyland park had earlier been shut indefinitely. China said on Saturday that it would suspend all tour groups and the sale of flight and hotel packages for its citizens headed overseas starting on Monday.</p>, <h2 class="css-3ez4hu eoo0vm40" id="link-51350ba0">China halts the trade in wildlife across the country.</h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">China has banned the wildlife trade nationwide until the epidemic passes, three government departments said on Sunday.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The outbreak has drawn fresh attention <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/25/world/asia/china-markets-coronavirus-sars.html" title="">to China’s animal markets</a>, where the sale of exotic wildlife has been linked to epidemiological risks. The Wuhan virus is believed to have spread from one such market in the city. The SARS outbreak nearly two decades ago was also traced back to the wildlife trade.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">A statement issued by China’s markets regulator, agriculture ministry and forestry bureau said that all transactions of wildlife would be forbidden immediately in wholesale markets, supermarkets, restaurants and e-commerce platforms. It also encouraged consumers to understand the health risks of eating wild animals.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The consumption of exotic creatures has been driven partly by beliefs about their supposed health benefits, although such ideas are starting to lose their grip, particularly on younger people.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">A popular travel blogger, Wang Mengyun, apologized recently for eating bat soup in a video from a few years ago. Ms. Wang, who has more than two million followers on the social platform Weibo, said that she had been unaware of the <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/28/science/bats-coronavirus-Wuhan.html" title="">health risks of eating bats</a> when she made the video in the Pacific island nation of Palau. She said she had been trying to highlight the local cuisine.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">In her post, Ms. Wang emphasized that the bat had been locally raised and was not wild. “Many countries around the world eat these,” she wrote.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Her post has since been deleted.</p>, <h2 class="css-3ez4hu eoo0vm40" id="link-4c111ae6">Americans in Wuhan will be evacuated to San Francisco.</h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The United States government offered details on a plan to evacuate American diplomats and other citizens from Wuhan, saying on Sunday that it was arranging a flight to leave Tuesday bound for San Francisco.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The State Department has ordered all American employees at the United States Consulate in Wuhan to leave the city. In an email sent on Sunday to Americans living in China, the department asked all other citizens who wanted a spot on the plane to contact the embassy. Capacity will be “extremely limited,” the message said, and priority will be given to people at greater risk from the virus.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">It is unclear who will fall into that category.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Jonny Dangerfield, 30, an American who went to Wuhan to celebrate the Lunar New Year with his wife and children, said he hoped his family might be given priority because his three children are all under 5.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“If it weren’t for them, we maybe would not have much worry at all,” Mr. Dangerfield, who works in finance in Phoenix and whose in-laws live in Wuhan, said in a telephone interview.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"> “Just to keep ourselves sane,” he said, “we have low expectations about getting on that plane.”</p>, <h2 class="css-3ez4hu eoo0vm40" id="link-6da498ba">Global concern grows as the outbreak spreads.</h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Around the world, health officials worked to minimize the risks for their citizens. France’s health minister, Agnes Buzyn, said Sunday that several hundred natives of France in the Wuhan area would be flown home in the middle of the week but would have to undergo 14 days in quarantine.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The Russian Embassy was also working with the Chinese authorities <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://radiosputnik.ria.ru/20200125/1563869649.html" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">to evacuate</a> Russian citizens from the area, and Prime Minister Shinzo Abe of Japan told reporters on Sunday that his government would help repatriate all citizens wishing to leave Wuhan, “by charter planes and all other means.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Public health officials in Toronto on Saturday night announced test results showing that Canada had its first “presumptive” case of the coronavirus.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Dr. Barbara Yaffe, Ontario’s associate chief medical officer of health, said the patient was a man in his 50s who returned to Toronto on Jan. 22 after visiting Wuhan. The next day, he was admitted to a hospital with a respiratory infection.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Dr. David Williams, Ontario’s chief medical officer of health, said that additional tests were expected to confirm that the man, who was in stable condition, had been infected with the virus.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Taiwan, which on Sunday confirmed its fourth case, said it would <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.cdc.gov.tw/Bulletin/Detail/nfwwGG0nBmQE-W5gBxUTPQ?typeid=9" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">bar all visitors from Hubei Province</a>. Taiwan’s government also said it would suspend applications from Chinese citizens for travel permits except in special cases, such as disease control or humanitarian medical assistance.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Macau announced that starting from Monday, it would restrict travelers from Wuhan.</p>, <h2 class="css-3ez4hu eoo0vm40" id="link-3583ed4f">Public health experts warn against mass anxiety.</h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Despite the rising number of coronavirus cases and the dozens of deaths, public health experts say there is no cause for panic. The common flu kills roughly 35,000 people a year and hospitalizes about 200,000 in the United States alone.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Yet the unknowns around the current outbreak are causing widespread worry. And there are signs that this outbreak could be more serious than the common flu. Other coronaviruses have far higher mortality rates than the flu, and have led to global outbreaks.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">In addition, conclusive evidence about how this outbreak started is lacking. Although officials in Wuhan first traced it to a seafood market, some who have fallen ill never visited it. Researchers have also offered disparate explanations about which animals may have transmitted the virus to humans.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">China’s record doesn’t help. During the SARS epidemic in 2002 and 2003, officials covered up the extent of the crisis, delaying the response. The Chinese government has promised far more transparency this time, and the World Health Organization has praised its cooperation with scientists.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">But mistrust of the local and national authorities, compounded by missteps and mistakes in handling the illness, runs deep. Though China’s initial delay in reporting cases of the new virus may suggest a cover-up, experts see something more worrying: <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/25/world/asia/coronavirus-crisis-china-response.html" title="">weaknesses at the heart of the Chinese political system</a>.</p>, <h2 class="css-3ez4hu eoo0vm40" id="link-18f34ccc">China’s central government deploys hundreds of workers.</h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">In a sign that the central government is bolstering its effort to contain the outbreak, China’s National Health Commission <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="http://www.nhc.gov.cn/xcs/yqfkdt/202001/290e602792b745f2a305ed5836570973.shtml" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">said it would send</a> 1,230 medical experts to Wuhan to assist in treatment.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The army has sent 450 other people from three military medical universities, according to a state media article that the health commission <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="http://www.nhc.gov.cn/xcs/yqfkdt/202001/a940fa5300ef4e46995e3644f043ce85.shtml" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">shared on its website</a>. And the air force sent military transport aircraft to the cities of Shanghai, Xi’an and Chongqing to pick up emergency airlifts of medical teams and supplies for Wuhan.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">In Wuhan, health officials said that they would assign 24 hospitals to treat potential coronavirus patients only, <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://twitter.com/PDChina/status/1221175912818823168" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">according to People’s Daily</a>, the Communist Party’s main newspaper. National officials had called for patients to be concentrated in specialized hospitals, and new hospitals were being built specifically to treat patients.</p>, <h2 class="css-3ez4hu eoo0vm40" id="link-1166b676">A minister pleads for hundreds of thousands more masks.</h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">A top Chinese official warned on Sunday that the nation needs many more masks and protective suits than it can currently produce.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">His remarks, in a news conference, came as more local governments around the country mandated that citizens wear masks in public as the coronavirus outbreak grows. On Sunday, the government in Guangdong, China’s most populous province, became the latest to require people to wear masks in public.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Wang Jiangping, China’s vice minister of industry and information technology, said that Hubei Province alone needed 100,000 protective suits a day to fight the illness, but that Chinese manufacturers could supply only 30,000 suits each day.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The Lunar New Year holiday is also making it hard for factories to produce at full capacity, Mr. Wang said.</p>, <h2 class="css-3ez4hu eoo0vm40" id="link-5b8757bb">‘Every village around here is now putting up barriers.’</h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Roads were quiet. Where cars, trucks and motorbikes once roared and honked, there was the sound of birds tweeting and dogs barking. Shoppers mostly hauled their baskets home by foot or on bicycle.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Wuhan, the city at the center of China’s viral outbreak, has been subdued since the government put it under a smothering net of travel restrictions on Thursday. It was even quieter on Sunday, after the city announced heavy restrictions on the use of cars, even within the urban limits.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">But along with general silence, there was confusion.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The announcements about which vehicles were allowed on the roads were murky, leaving even police officers befuddled.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">First, the Wuhan authorities said that most cars <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://mp.weixin.qq.com/s?src=11&amp;timestamp=1580035588&amp;ver=2120&amp;signature=SxuKbIMYjrZ4tw2dH2Sf-41vvxx9SlwFgJfynxcr6wjvcfvE4FyGoNh50zGorYJ7JeaFWmsNZELIGwOekOTIi98jPNkDdjwEKebM*JE3TAIdS17Ax5-oi0gQ14Fa6mYW&amp;new=1" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">should stay off the roads</a> and that a fleet of 6,000 taxis <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="http://www.chinanews.com/gn/2020/01-26/9069778.shtml" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">would be on call</a> to transport people in need and deliver food and medicine. Then, the authorities said drivers would be <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://baijiahao.baidu.com/s?id=1656737257191494058&amp;wfr=spider&amp;for=pc" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">notified by text message</a> if they had to stay off the roads. Nobody seemed to receive text messages on Sunday.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“My understanding,” a police officer said, “is that you can drive in your district if you don’t get a text message telling you that you can’t. But you should check that with the transport authorities.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">In the end, most drivers stayed off the streets. But as the day went on, more ventured out, and the police did not seem to do much about it.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">For some residents, it was another exasperating fumble by Wuhan officials who many believe have mishandled the epidemic. But most seemed to accept the restrictions with the same stoicism that many have shown since the city imposed bans on leaving for all but a select few.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">On Sunday morning, many groceries in Wuhan were crowded with residents stocking up, especially on fresh vegetables, fruit and meat, in case even tighter rules might be announced that impeded food supplies or that deterred them from leaving home.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“Because it’s the New Year, a lot of stores close anyway, and now we have the disease and now this,” said Ai Wenjun, who had lined up to pay for a basket of turnips, cabbage and beans. “Each extra thing makes me worry more.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">So far, shops still have supplies, though some residents said prices had risen despite government warnings to keep them steady.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“If we can’t bring in produce, it will become more expensive, or we might even have to close up,” said Zuo Qichao, who was selling piles of cucumbers, turnips and tomatoes. As he spoke, a woman accused him of unfairly raising the turnips’ price.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“Every county, every village around here is now putting up barriers, worried about that disease,” Mr. Zuo said. “Even if the government says it wants food guaranteed, it won’t be easy — all those road checks.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">For now, the Wuhan city authorities have the benefit of a population willing to endure restrictions to slow the epidemic. But that mood could shift if the measures hamper food supplies and worsen medical shortages.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“Now is not the time for recriminations,” said Li Xiandu, a retired business manager. “The local government wasn’t forthcoming with information and didn’t take vigorous enough measures. But we need to get through this first, and then we can assign blame.”</p>, <p class="css-jwz2nf etfikam0">Reporting was contributed by Raymond Zhong, Chris Buckley, Motoko Rich, Austin Ramzy, Denise Grady, Roni Rabin, Ezra Cheung,<strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10"> </strong>Max Fisher, Vivian Wang, Ian Austen, Josh Keller, Yonette Joseph, Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs and Aurelien Breeden. Claire Fu and Wang Yiwei contributed research.</p>, <p>Advertisement</p>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd" id="site-index-label">Site Index</h2>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-0">news</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-1">opinion</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-2">arts</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-3">living</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-4">more</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-subscribe-label">Subscribe</h3>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd">Site Information Navigation</h2>]
[<p>Advertisement</p>, <p>Supported by</p>, <h1 class="css-1s4ffep e1h9rw200" id="link-24ec392e" itemprop="headline"><span>California Confirms Coronavirus Patient, Marking Third U.S. Case</span></h1>, <p class="css-1ifw933 e1wiw3jv0" id="article-summary">The other two cases were in Washington State and Chicago.</p>, <p class="css-1fv7b6t e1jsehar1" itemprop="author" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">By<!-- --> <span class="css-1baulvz last-byline" itemprop="name">The New York Times</span></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The United States has confirmed a third case of the <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/26/world/china-coronavirus.html" title="">novel coronavirus</a>, after a traveler from China tested positive for the disease in Orange County, Calif.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The Orange County Health Care Agency, which received confirmation of the case in California from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://mailchi.mp/ochca/novelcoronavirus" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">said in a statement on Saturday</a> that the person had been sent to the hospital and was in “good condition.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The patient is a traveler from Wuhan, China, and “there is no evidence that person-to-person transmission has occurred in Orange County,” according to the agency. “The current risk of local transmission remains low,” the statement said.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/26/world/china-coronavirus.html" title="">As China struggles to contain the outbreak</a> of the deadly pneumonialike virus, global authorities are grappling with a rising number of cases at their borders. Canada and Portugal both announced suspected cases this weekend.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">In China, 1,975 people have been infected with the coronavirus since the outbreak began last year in Wuhan. The death toll in China has risen to 56.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">World authorities are taking their own precautions to keep the virus from spreading. Taiwan said on Sunday that it would <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.cdc.gov.tw/Bulletin/Detail/nfwwGG0nBmQE-W5gBxUTPQ?typeid=9" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">bar all visitors from China’s Hubei Province</a> to the self-governing island, where a few cases have been confirmed.</p>, <h1 class="g-headline" id="g-inlineguide-headline">The Coronavirus Outbreak</h1>, <h2 class="g-inlineguide-list-header g-optimize-type">What do you need to know? Start here.</h2>, <p class="g-inlineguide-date">Updated Feb. 5, 2020</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The United States has limited passengers who have recently visited Wuhan to a handful of <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/28/health/airports-screening-coronavirus.html" title="">airports that have special screening processes</a> in place. A number of people around the United States are being monitored for potential cases of the respiratory illness.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The person in California brings to three the number of confirmed case in <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/24/health/chicago-coronavirus-cdc.html" title="">the United States</a>. The others are a woman in her 60s in Chicago and a man in his 30s in Washington State.</p>, <p>Advertisement</p>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd" id="site-index-label">Site Index</h2>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-0">news</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-1">opinion</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-2">arts</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-3">living</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-4">more</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-subscribe-label">Subscribe</h3>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd">Site Information Navigation</h2>]
[<p>Advertisement</p>, <p>Supported by</p>, <h1 class="css-1s4ffep e1h9rw200" id="link-5ed2e015" itemprop="headline"><span>As Coronavirus Fears Intensify, Effectiveness of Quarantines Is Questioned</span></h1>, <p class="css-1ifw933 e1wiw3jv0" id="article-summary">Amid news the coronavirus is spreading at an accelerating rate, concern is growing that China’s lockdown of cities may not only have come too late but could even make the situation worse.</p>, <p class="css-1fv7b6t e1jsehar1" itemprop="author" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">By<!-- --> <a class="css-brehiz e1jsehar0" href="https://www.nytimes.com/by/chris-buckley"><span class="css-1baulvz" itemprop="name">Chris Buckley</span></a>, <a class="css-brehiz e1jsehar0" href="https://www.nytimes.com/by/raymond-zhong"><span class="css-1baulvz" itemprop="name">Raymond Zhong</span></a>, <a class="css-brehiz e1jsehar0" href="https://www.nytimes.com/by/denise-grady"><span class="css-1baulvz" itemprop="name">Denise Grady</span></a> and <a class="css-brehiz e1jsehar0" href="https://www.nytimes.com/by/roni-caryn-rabin"><span class="css-1baulvz last-byline" itemprop="name">Roni Caryn Rabin</span></a></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">WUHAN, China — A top Chinese health official warned on Sunday that the <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/27/world/asia/china-coronavirus.html" title="">spread of the dangerous new coronavirus</a>, already extraordinarily rapid, is accelerating further, deepening global fears about an illness that has sickened more than 2,700 people worldwide and killed at least 80 people in China.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The grim diagnosis came amid concerns that China’s efforts to contain the spread of the disease, despite a <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/23/world/asia/china-coronavirus-outbreak.html" title="">lockdown of unprecedented scope</a> affecting 56 million people, may not only have come too late but could even make the situation worse, including by exacerbating shortages of medical supplies.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Adding to the growing global alarm, people who are carrying the virus but not showing symptoms may still be able to infect others, according to the Chinese official, Ma Xiaowei, the director of China’s National Health Commission. Such asymptomatic transmissions would make the disease much more difficult to control, as seemingly healthy people travel and interact with others.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“The epidemic is now entering a more serious and complex period,” Mr. Ma said during a Sunday news conference in Beijing. “It looks like it will continue for some time, and the number of cases may increase.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">China’s attempts to curb the disease’s spread — essentially cordoning off the major cities in the province of Hubei, including its capital, Wuhan, a city of 11 million people — are a “public health experiment, the scale of which has not been done before,” said Dr. William Schaffner, an infectious disease expert at Vanderbilt University. “Logistically, it’s stunning, and it was done so quickly.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Whether the lockdowns will succeed in stemming the spread of the virus is a matter of debate by experts in public health and epidemiology. Some said the lockdowns would help, at least in theory.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“Anything that is done that increases social distancing can help decrease the spread of the virus,” said Dr. Thomas R. Frieden, a former director of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. “If you do it right, it’s not impossible it will have positive impact.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">But doing it right at this scale has never been tried before anywhere in the world.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“To put a ring around cities of this size and population is unprecedented,” said Dr. Howard Markel, a professor of the history of medicine at the University of Michigan and author of the book “Quarantine.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Maintaining the lockdown will pose tremendous challenges, starting with the provision of food, fuel and medical care to millions of people. “It’s enormously difficult to do effectively, and also difficult to assess the effectiveness,” said Dr. Schaffner.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Other experts were skeptical that the travel restrictions would prove at all effective because they had probably come too late and the barriers would prove too permeable. Five million people had left Wuhan before travel out of the city was restricted, said the city’s mayor, Zhou Xianwang. It was a stunning disclosure that intensified questions about the government’s delayed response.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“You can’t board up a germ. A novel infection will spread,” said Lawrence O. Gostin, a law professor at Georgetown University and director of the World Health Organization Collaborating Center on National and Global Health Law. “It will get out; it always does.”</p>, <h1 class="g-headline" id="g-inlineguide-headline">The Coronavirus Outbreak</h1>, <h2 class="g-inlineguide-list-header g-optimize-type">What do you need to know? Start here.</h2>, <p class="g-inlineguide-date">Updated Feb. 10, 2020</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">In China, it was a weekend of grim new warnings about the little-understood virus and a rising tally of infections and deaths. The official number of confirmed infections across China jumped significantly within a span of 24 hours, building to 2,744 by Monday from around 1,975 the day before.</p>, <h2 class="css-zd32qr">Wuhan Coronavirus Map: Tracking the Spread of the Outbreak</h2>, <p class="css-1uuihdo">The virus has sickened tens of thousands of people in China and a number of other countries.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Among the most recent announced fatalities from the coronavirus was an 88-year-old man in Shanghai — the first death to be reported in the commercial hub, and one likely to fuel anxieties about the disease’s spread.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">New cases cropped up in Hong Kong, Taiwan and Orange County, Calif., bringing to five the number of confirmed cases in the United States. The virus had already been found in Thailand, France, Japan, South Korea, Australia and beyond.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.imperial.ac.uk/mrc-global-infectious-disease-analysis/news--wuhan-coronavirus/" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">Epidemiologists at Imperial College London </a>estimated that each case infected an average of between 1.5 and 3.5 other people in the early stages of the crisis. For seasonal flu, it’s about 1.3.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">That number could drop as the authorities take more stringent measures to halt the spread. But if it holds up, the number of infected could rise sharply.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">In Wuhan, the city at the center of the outbreak, the streets were eerily quiet as the authorities had ordered people not to drive, forcing some to walk to hospitals. Mr. Zhou, the mayor, said that health officials were likely to confirm an additional 1,000 cases of the illness in the city. He said that the estimate was based on the assumption that around half of the city’s nearly 3,000 suspected cases of the coronavirus would eventually test positive.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">China’s top leader, Xi Jinping, has promised drastic measures to contain the virus.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">In a signal of the gravity of the crisis, and its likely disruption to China’s short-term growth, the <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://news.sina.com.cn/c/2020-01-27/doc-iihnzahk6491235.shtml" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">government announced on Monday</a> that the annual weeklong Lunar New Year Holiday would be extended. For now, at least, many workers will get another three days off, and go back to work on Feb. 3.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Even before that notice, Suzhou, a big manufacturing hub in eastern China, declared that factories there should not start back at work any earlier than Feb. 8.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The national government on Sunday also banned the wildlife trade until the epidemic passes. The outbreak had drawn fresh attention <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/25/world/asia/china-markets-coronavirus-sars.html" title="">to China’s animal markets</a>, where the sale of exotic creatures has been linked to epidemiological risks.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">In Hong Kong — which was badly hit by the SARS coronavirus in 2003, with nearly 300 deaths, more than any city in the world — worries about the spread of infectious diseases run deep. On Sunday, the government said it would bar residents of Hubei Province, which includes Wuhan, and people who had been to the province in the past 14 days from entering Hong Kong until further notice.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Six cases of the new coronavirus have been confirmed in the city, already hobbled by months of antigovernment protests.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Health officials in the United States, in what could turn out to be a positive development in stemming the disease, said there was no “clear evidence” that asymptomatic transmissions of the disease were happening.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“We at the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention don’t have any clear evidence of patients’ being infectious before symptom onset,” Dr. Nancy Messonnier of the National Center for Immunization and Respiratory Diseases said at a news briefing on Sunday. “We are actively investigating that possibility.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Some global health experts said China’s focus, and resources, going forward should not be devoted to closing off cities.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Michael T. Osterholm, director of the Center for Infectious Disease Research and Policy at the University of Minnesota, thought China’s approach to the crisis could easily “backfire,” comparing it to the so-called cordons sanitaires that were imposed to seal off swaths of West Africa during the 2014-2016 Ebola epidemic. Those cordons left people starving and spurred violent uprisings. Others routinely found ways to sneak around or through the boundaries.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“It was a disaster,” Dr. Osterholm said.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Dr. Tom Inglesby, an infectious diseases specialist and director of the Johns Hopkins Center for Health Security, also expressed concern.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“If you continue to quarantine more and more places in China, you’re going to start to really break normal societal interaction, normal movement of goods and people and medical supplies and food and medicine,” Dr. Inglesby said. “At a macro level, it seems to me that it’s more likely to be harmful than helpful in controlling the epidemic.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Instead, Dr. Inglesby, Dr. Osterholm and other health experts suggested China should concentrate on traditional public health measures that have stopped other outbreaks, like identifying and monitoring contacts and making sure medical care is available to everyone.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Even as the highest echelons of China’s government mobilize to fight the illness, much of the task of preventing contagion still falls on local officials, who can be unsure of how to respond to crises and uneven about following through on policies.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">On Sunday in Wuhan, for example, police officers were flummoxed by new restrictions on driving within the city limits.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">First, the city authorities said that most cars <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://mp.weixin.qq.com/s?src=11&amp;timestamp=1580035588&amp;ver=2120&amp;signature=SxuKbIMYjrZ4tw2dH2Sf-41vvxx9SlwFgJfynxcr6wjvcfvE4FyGoNh50zGorYJ7JeaFWmsNZELIGwOekOTIi98jPNkDdjwEKebM*JE3TAIdS17Ax5-oi0gQ14Fa6mYW&amp;new=1" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">should stay off the roads</a>, and that a fleet of 6,000 taxis <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="http://www.chinanews.com/gn/2020/01-26/9069778.shtml" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">would be on call</a> to deliver food and medicine. Then, the authorities said drivers would be <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://baijiahao.baidu.com/s?id=1656737257191494058&amp;wfr=spider&amp;for=pc" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">notified by text message</a> if they had to stay off the roads. Nobody seemed to receive the text messages on Sunday.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“My understanding,” one police officer said, “is that you can drive in your district if you don’t get a text message telling you that you can’t. But you should check that with the transport authorities.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">In the end, most drivers stayed off the streets. But as the day went on, more ventured out, and the police did not seem to do much about it.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">For some residents, it was another exasperating fumble by Wuhan officials, who many believe have mishandled the epidemic.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Health experts said the government’s ability to keep the trust of the public was a key element in any successful quarantine, and never easy to do.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Dr. Inglesby said that previous, much smaller scale lockdown efforts — including closing off the Amoy Gardens housing complex in Hong Kong during the SARS outbreak 17 years ago — show that residents may become fearful and lose confidence in the government.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“You need people to willingly present themselves for diagnosis,” he said. “If they don’t understand what the government’s doing or they feel in some way their bond with the government has been broken, that’s another key process that’s being interrupted by the quarantine.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">For now, in Wuhan, the restrictions seem to be mostly accepted with the same stoic fortitude that many residents showed over the past several days as the city imposed bans on outbound travel for all but a select few.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">That mood could shift, however, if, for example, food prices rise. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“Now is not the time for recriminations,” said Li Xiandu, a retired business manager. “The local government wasn’t forthcoming with information and didn’t take vigorous enough measures. But we need to get through this first, and then we can assign blame.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">While the government has pledged to build at least two new hospitals with thousands of beds in Wuhan — and to do so in<a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/25/world/asia/china-coronavirus.html" title=""> just a few days</a> — the city’s existing hospitals remain intensely crowded, a condition that does not bode well for stopping the disease.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“If you wanted to create the perfect mixing vessel for a coronavirus,” Dr. Osterholm said, “you’d create the emergency rooms in Wuhan right now.”</p>, <p class="css-jwz2nf etfikam0">Chris Buckley reported from Wuhan, China, Raymond Zhong from Shanghai, and Denise Grady and Roni Caryn Rabin from New York. Sheri Fink contributed reporting from New York, and Claire Fu and Wang Yiwei contributed research.</p>, <p>Advertisement</p>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd" id="site-index-label">Site Index</h2>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-0">news</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-1">opinion</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-2">arts</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-3">living</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-4">more</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-subscribe-label">Subscribe</h3>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd">Site Information Navigation</h2>]
[<p>Advertisement</p>, <p>Supported by</p>, <h1 class="css-1s4ffep e1h9rw200" id="link-2117ee38" itemprop="headline"><span>In Coronavirus, a ‘Battle’ That Could Humble China’s Strongman</span></h1>, <p class="css-1ifw933 e1wiw3jv0" id="article-summary">With Xi Jinping firmly in control, the Chinese government has stepped up its response to the Wuhan crisis, but the effort has been plagued by bureaucracy and a lack of transparency.</p>, <p class="css-1fv7b6t e1jsehar1" itemprop="author" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">By<!-- --> <a class="css-brehiz e1jsehar0" href="https://www.nytimes.com/by/steven-lee-myers"><span class="css-1baulvz" itemprop="name">Steven Lee Myers</span></a> and <a class="css-brehiz e1jsehar0" href="https://www.nytimes.com/by/chris-buckley"><span class="css-1baulvz last-byline" itemprop="name">Chris Buckley</span></a></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">BEIJING — It took thousands of infections and scores of deaths from a <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/25/world/asia/china-wuhan-coronavirus.html" title="">mysterious virus</a> for China’s authoritarian leader to publicly say what had become glaringly obvious to many in recent weeks: The country is facing a grave public health crisis.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">After <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/25/world/asia/china-coronavirus.html" title="">his declaration</a>, the leader, <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/02/10/world/asia/xi-jinping-coronavirus.html" title="">Xi Jinping</a>, put <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/02/10/world/asia/xi-jinping-coronavirus.html" title="">China</a> on a virtual war footing to cope with the unfolding epidemic of the <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/02/10/world/asia/xi-jinping-coronavirus.html" title="">coronavirus</a>. He convened an extraordinary session of the Communist Party’s top political body, issuing orders for handling the crisis with the crisp, somber stoicism of a field marshal.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“We’re sure to be able to win in this battle,” he proclaimed on Saturday before his six grim-faced colleagues on the party’s Politburo Standing Committee.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Compared to the very low bar set by the Chinese leadership’s secrecy and inaction during the SARS epidemic in 2002 and 2003, Mr. Xi has responded with speed and alacrity to the latest health emergency, <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/26/world/china-coronavirus.html?action=click&amp;module=Top%20Stories&amp;pgtype=Homepage" title="">a pneumonialike virus</a> that at last official count has killed at least 80, sickened thousands in China and <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/26/world/asia/26california-coronavirus.html" title="">spread around the world</a>.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">But there are also signs that the government, especially at the regional level in Hubei Province, the source of the outbreak, was slow to recognize the danger and is continuing to mishandle the crisis. Some public health experts have asked whether the sweeping travel restrictions that have been imposed are leaving people without access to medical care, while many Chinese remain unconvinced the government is being completely forthcoming about the toll of the disease.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“Substantively, the response this time is more or less the same,” said Minxin Pei, a professor of government at Claremont McKenna College in California. “Local officials downplayed the outbreak at the initial, but crucial, stage of the outbreak. The media was muzzled. The public was kept in the dark. As a result, valuable time was lost.”</p>, <h2 class="css-zd32qr">Wuhan Coronavirus Map: Tracking the Spread of the Outbreak</h2>, <p class="css-1uuihdo">The virus has sickened tens of thousands of people in China and a number of other countries.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The turnaround from complacency to nationwide mobilization <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/25/world/asia/coronavirus-crisis-china-response.html" title="">typifies how China can respond to unexpected crisis</a> like a lumbering giant, reluctant to stir, but then capable of shattering urgency. It represents both sides of the authoritarian political bargain under Mr. Xi.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">A fear of upsetting the party’s protocols and leaders’ desire for unruffled stability can deter even officials who want to do well by the public. Conversely, the government can operate with brutal efficiency when it wants.</p>, <h1 class="g-headline" id="g-inlineguide-headline">The Coronavirus Outbreak</h1>, <h2 class="g-inlineguide-list-header g-optimize-type">What do you need to know? Start here.</h2>, <p class="g-inlineguide-date">Updated Feb. 10, 2020</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">It was only after a brief written statement under Mr. Xi’s name on Jan. 20, when he was touring a military base and shopping exposition in Yunnan Province, that the vast Chinese state bureaucracy began to shudder into action.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Officials then quickly acknowledged the dangers of the coronavirus and ordered drastic measures to stop the spread — perhaps, experts said, belatedly — including the lockdown of much of the province where the epidemic emerged, penning in 56 million people. The government also ordered the construction of two hospitals in Wuhan to deal exclusively with patients afflicted with the coronavirus, which are expected to open within days, not months or years.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“The thing about China is that they can mobilize agencies and resources faster than anybody else can,” said Richard McGregor, a senior fellow at the Lowy Institute in Sydney and author of “<a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.lowyinstitute.org/publications/xi-jinping-backlash" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">Xi Jinping: The Backlash</a>.” “The other side is that they can conceal things.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“In China there is no independent entity that can get on the front foot and disseminate information,” he added.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">From a localized medical mystery a few weeks ago, the coronavirus has erupted as one of the most complex and unpredictable tests for Mr. Xi since he came to power more than seven years ago. Over that time, he has by some measures established himself as the most formidable Chinese leader since Mao Zedong.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The epidemic and the effectiveness of the government’s response remain subject to many unknowns, but the outbreak comes at a time when Mr. Xi has already been facing quiet whispers about his political acumen. In the past year, he has experienced repeated setbacks on some of the most vital issues on his agenda.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Protests against China’s tightening grip continue to <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/01/world/asia/hong-kong-protest.html" title="">convulse Hong Kong</a>. Rancor with Washington was only partly eased <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/15/business/economy/china-trade-deal.html" title="">by a trade deal</a> that some said required China to promise too many concessions. Two weeks ago, <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/11/world/asia/taiwan-election-china.html" title="">voters in Taiwan,</a> the island democracy that Mr. Xi has made clear should join a greater China, resoundingly re-elected a president despised by Beijing.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Mr. Xi’s sheer dominance, according to several experts and political insiders, may be contributing to his problems by hampering internal debate that could help avoid misjudgments. Beijing, for example, has underestimated the staying power of the protesters in Hong Kong and the public support behind them.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“It’s a paradox,” said Rong Jian, an independent scholar of Chinese politics in Beijing. “It’s precisely because Xi is so powerful that policy problems often arise — nobody dares disagree, and problems are spotted too late.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">While state and local officials <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/27/technology/china-coronavirus-censorship-social-media.html" title="">have been criticized</a>, the public health system has been credited with responding effectively, particularly compared to the response to the SARS crisis.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">In that case, officials covered up the extent of the viral outbreak for months, almost certainly abetting its spread and exacerbating the death toll, which reached nearly 800.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">This time, even as officials in Wuhan said nothing publicly, government scientists <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.who.int/westernpacific/emergencies/novel-coronavirus" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">shared information</a> with the World Health Organization on the last day of 2019, isolated the virus, and posted details about it on an <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="http://virological.org/t/novel-2019-coronavirus-genome/319" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">international database</a> 10 days later.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">That allowed experts from around the world to quickly conclude that the new coronavirus, like the one from SARS, had very likely originated in bats and made the leap to humans through infection of another mammal in a market in Wuhan.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The Lancet, one of the leading medical journals, praised China’s handling of the outbreak so far in <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.thelancet.com/journals/lancet/article/PIIS0140-6736(20)30186-0/fulltext" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">an editorial</a>.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“The lessons from the SARS epidemic — where China was insufficiently prepared to implement infection control practices — have been successfully learned,” it wrote. “By most accounts, Chinese authorities are meeting international standards and isolating suspected cases and contacts, developing diagnostic and treatment procedures, and implementing public education campaigns.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The journal went on to emphasize that the ultimate success of the response would “depend on maintaining trust between the authorities and the local population.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Mr. Xi’s government, despite its call to arms, may have already undercut that trust.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">On the local level in Wuhan, people have vented anger and frustration, which is percolating on social media despite censorship. In widely circulated, and then censored, comments, a senior journalist with The Hubei Daily, the province’s main party newspaper, called for a change of leadership in Wuhan.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“With this extraordinarily grim situation worsening and expanding by the day, those currently in office lack that commanding leadership,” the journalist, Zhang Ouya, wrote on Sina.com Weibo, a popular Chinese social media service.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">There is evidence, too, that the local authorities kept a lid on the crisis in the first days of January so as not to upset the cheerful tone for a provincial legislative session that is a highlight of the local political cycle.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“This year will be a major landmark year,” Wang Xiaodong, the provincial governor, told the legislative members. “Let us unite even more closely around the party central leadership with Comrade Xi Jinping at the core.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Mr. Wang is now widely accused of underplaying the virus threat.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“China is a much more decentralized place than it appears,” said David Cowhig, a former American diplomat who served 10 years in China and monitored health and science issues.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“Local officials have great discretion; China is a coalition of ‘little’ Big Brothers,” he said. “Xi realizes this and is trying to re-centralize China.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Yanzhong Huang, a senior fellow for global health at the Council on Foreign Relations who studies China, said that the centralization of power since the SARS crisis did not appear to have strengthened expertise at the local level or the willingness of underequipped regional hospitals to report.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“I think the central health authorities are trying to be more transparent,” he said, “but the local government remains loath to share disease related information in a timely and accurate manner.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Not all the blame can fall on the officials in Wuhan.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The central authorities still control the political and propaganda apparatus, which has sought to minimize the severity of the crisis. Before the standing committee’s meeting on Saturday, Mr. Xi and other senior officials went about their business as if there were no crisis, appearing at a banquet on Thursday in the Great Hall of the People to celebrate the Lunar New Year.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">When he did speak, Mr. Xi emphasized the need for preserving public stability.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The phrase alludes to the fear of popular unrest boiling over, which is, as ever, the party state’s highest priority. It could become a reality if the epidemic, as predicted, inflicts sustained hardship on the economy and people’s livelihood.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“The truth is in a public-health emergency, it’s not just the medical professionals who matter,” Mr. McGregor said. “It’s the management of it in the government and in the public that matters, too. It’s hard to argue that they’ve done that well.”</p>, <p class="css-jwz2nf etfikam0">Steven Lee Myers reported from Beijing, and Chris Buckley from Wuhan, China. Claire Fu contributed research.</p>, <p>Advertisement</p>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd" id="site-index-label">Site Index</h2>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-0">news</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-1">opinion</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-2">arts</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-3">living</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-4">more</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-subscribe-label">Subscribe</h3>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd">Site Information Navigation</h2>]
[<p>Advertisement</p>, <p>Supported by</p>, <h1 class="css-1s4ffep e1h9rw200" id="link-528caadc" itemprop="headline"><span>Impeachment, Coronavirus, Grammy Awards: Your Weekend Briefing</span></h1>, <p class="css-1ifw933 e1wiw3jv0" id="article-summary">Here’s what you need to know about the week’s top stories.</p>, <p class="css-1fv7b6t e1jsehar1" itemprop="author" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">By<!-- --> <a class="css-brehiz e1jsehar0" href="https://www.nytimes.com/by/remy-tumin"><span class="css-1baulvz" itemprop="name">Remy Tumin</span></a> and <a class="css-brehiz e1jsehar0" href="https://www.nytimes.com/by/stephen-reiss"><span class="css-1baulvz last-byline" itemprop="name">Stephen Reiss</span></a></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">(Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the </em><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/morning-briefing" title=""><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">sign-up</em></a><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">.) </em></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">Here are the week’s top stories, and a look ahead.</em></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">1. President Trump’s legal team </strong>began its aggressive defense in the Senate impeachment trial.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">His lawyers, above, <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/25/us/politics/trump-impeachment-defense.html" title="">dismissed the House impeachment inquiry</a> as a partisan ploy that ignored the facts to cast Mr. Trump’s actions in the worst possible light. Democrats, they argued, were “asking you to tear up the ballots” by finding Mr. Trump guilty of high crimes and misdemeanors.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/25/us/politics/trump-lawyers-defense-team-impeachment.html" title="">The president’s legal team</a> on Saturday used only two of the 24 hours allotted to them to present their defense. Arguments will resume Monday afternoon. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The Democratic House managers <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/24/us/politics/democrats-impeachment-trial.html" title="">concluded their arguments</a> on Friday, saying that allowing Mr. Trump to stay in office would endanger the country.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The question of whether the Senate would compel witnesses and documents was <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/25/us/politics/lamar-alexander-witnesses-impeachment.html" title="">still up in the air</a>, even as new evidence became public: a recording of Mr. Trump <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/25/us/politics/trump-ukraine-donors.html" title="">ordering the U.S. ambassador’s firing</a>. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">2. Bernie Sanders </strong>has <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/25/us/politics/democratic-iowa-poll-sanders.html?" title="">seized the lead in Iowa</a>, a new Times/Siena College poll found. Pete Buttigieg and Joe Biden trail him, and Elizabeth Warren lost ground.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The changing fortunes of the two liberal candidates — Mr. Sanders and Ms. Warren — underscored the volatile nature of the Democratic primary a little over a week before the Iowa caucuses. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Last spring we asked a large pool of Democratic candidates to answer the same set of questions. We did it again, this time with a much smaller group<span class="css-8l6xbc evw5hdy0"> </span>and 20 new questions — on everything from foreign policy to celebrity crushes. <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2020/us/politics/democratic-candidates-20-questions.html" title="">Here’s what they said</a>.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">3. Against the backdrop </strong>of impeachment and the 2020 election,<strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10"> </strong>the nation’s glaring divisions were on display in the streets.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/24/us/gun-rally-march-for-life-womens-march.html?" title="">Our reporter went to three protests in one week</a> — the Women’s March, above, a pro-gun rally in Virginia and the anti-abortion March for Life — to find out how polarized politically engaged Americans were. In more than 50 interviews, activists reflected a kind of cultural panic at the thought of the other side winning the presidential election this year.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">So how did we get here? The answer is more about psychology than policy, experts say.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">4. The coronavirus outbreak </strong>that has spread <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2020/01/21/world/asia/china-coronavirus-maps.html?" title="">to several continents</a> has killed at least 56 and sickened about 2,000 in China and around the world. <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/26/world/china-coronavirus.html?action=click&amp;module=Top%20Stories&amp;pgtype=Homepage" title="">Here’s the latest</a>. <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/26/world/china-coronavirus.html?action=click&amp;module=Top%20Stories&amp;pgtype=Homepage" title="">Here’s the latest</a>.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Hong Kong announced that it was <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/25/world/asia/china-wuhan-coronavirus.html" title="">closing its schools</a> for several weeks, further dampening celebrations of the Lunar New Year, above, which began on Saturday.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The disease has been linked to a wholesale market in Wuhan, China, where vendors legally sold live animals from stalls in close quarters with hundreds of others, creating what <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/25/world/asia/china-markets-coronavirus-sars.html" title="">experts described as a perfect incubator for novel pathogens</a>.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Government officials and scientists said the new contagion had ominous similarities to the 2003 SARS outbreak. And yet little has changed in the 17 years since: The government now faces increasing criticism and calls to do more to regulate or even ban the sale of wildlife.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">5. Of the Big Three in men’s tennis, </strong>Roger Federer is the pleaser and Rafael Nadal is the fighter.
