Call Novak Djokovic the searcher.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">In <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/25/sports/novak-djokovic-australian-open.html" title="">a rare interview</a>, the reigning Australian Open champion said he was no longer playing tennis to prove himself but rather to improve himself and the lives of those around him. He beat Diego Schwartzman in the fourth round overnight.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Next up, Daniil Medvedev plays Stan Wawrinka, and Rafael Nadal, who is <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/23/sports/tennis/nadal-australian-open.html" title="">closing in on his 20th Grand Slam title</a>, faces off against the hometown favorite, <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/24/sports/tennis/nick-kyrgios-australian-open.html" title="">Nick Kyrgios</a>.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">On the women’s court, Coco Gauff lost to a fellow American, Sofia Kenin. And <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/24/sports/wang-qiang.html" title="">Wang Qiang</a>, who defeated Serena Williams in the third round, lost to Ons Jabeur.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">6. “It is important to distinguish </strong>between good and evil, and seek out the good. Find your faith.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">That’s Batsheva Dagan, above. Born in Lodz, Poland, in 1925, Ms. Dagan is a survivor of the Auschwitz-Birkenau Nazi death camp and one of a handful of survivors photographed for a <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2020/01/24/opinion/auschwitz-anniversary-holocaust.html" title="">project in Opinion</a>.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">World leaders and dignitaries will gather for a solemn ceremony at Auschwitz on Monday to commemorate the 75th anniversary of the liberation of the camp. But amid a surge of anti-Semitism and a rise in dehumanizing political rhetoric, <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/25/world/europe/auschwitz-liberation-75th-anniversary.html" title="">there is fear that the horrific lessons of the death camp are being lost</a>.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">7. Jeanine Cummins </strong>wrote one of this year’s biggest, buzziest books. <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/25/arts/american-dirt-jeanine-cummins.html" title="">And then she became the story</a>.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Even before “American Dirt” — her novel about a desperate Mexican mother and son who flee for the U.S. border after a drug cartel massacres their family — hit bookshelves, a growing chorus accused Ms. Cummins, <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/13/books/jeanine-cummins-american-dirt.html?" title="">who was born in Spain and grew up in Maryland</a>, of having exploited the experience of migrants.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The controversy has grown into a perfect storm of industry hype and accusations of cultural appropriation amid an increasingly charged debate over immigration.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">8. Will Lizzo rule the Grammys as she owned 2019?</strong></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">She has eight nominations Sunday night, a performance slot and the devotion of fiercely loyal fans. What’s behind this Lizzo momentum? <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/23/arts/music/lizzo-grammys.html?" title="">Our critics discuss</a>.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The show starts at 8 p.m. We’ll have live coverage at <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/" title="">nytimes.com</a>.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Seven nominated artists opened their voice notes, hard drives, text messages and memories to our Diary of a Song team. <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/25/arts/music/grammys-diary-of-a-song.html" title="">Watch them all here</a>.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">But overshadowing the event are allegations of behind-the-scenes misbehavior. That should have everyone in the music business asking one question, one critic says: <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/25/arts/music/grammys-controversy.html" title="">Can the Grammys be trusted?</a></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">9. Bowen Yang </strong>is the first Chinese-American cast member on “Saturday Night Live.” He is also one of the first openly gay comedians. He is revered by his peers and, according to our columnist, <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/25/style/bowen-yang-snl.html" title="">entirely too sane to be on the legendary comedy show</a>.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">She talked to him about Chinese identity, the influence of Sandra Oh, gay conversion therapy and the audition that earned him a spot on “S.N.L.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The show returned last night from its winter hiatus. Adam Driver hosted. <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/26/arts/television/saturday-night-live.html" title="">Here’s the recap</a>.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">10. And finally, </strong>introducing <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/weekender" title="">The Weekender.</a></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">We’re bringing you the same roundup of great journalism but with a more immersive experience. This week we looked at how 17 portraits rattled a small Southern town, the Saudi connection to the 9/11 attacks, why the American bathroom is the stage set of the moment, and more.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">For more ideas on what to read, watch and listen to, may we suggest these <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/23/books/review/12-new-books-we-recommend-this-week.html" title="">12 new books our editors liked</a>, a glance at the latest small-screen recommendations from <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/23/arts/television/david-lynch-netflix-work-in-progress-showtime.html" title="">Watching</a>, and our music critics’ latest <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/24/arts/music/playlist-pearl-jam-megan-thee-stallion.html" title="">playlist</a>.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Have you been keeping up with the headlines? Test your knowledge with our <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2020/01/24/briefing/coronavirus-impeachment-davos-news-quiz.html" title="">news quiz</a>. And here’s the front page of our <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://static01.nyt.com/images/2020/01/26/nytfrontpage/scan.pdf" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">Sunday paper</a>, <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/section/opinion/sunday" title="">the Sunday Review</a> from Opinion and our <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/crosswords" title="">crossword puzzles</a>.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Have a lovely week.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">Your Weekend Briefing is published Sundays at 6 a.m. Eastern.</em></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">You can </em><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2018/briefing/global-morning-briefing-newsletter-signup.html" title=""><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">sign up here</em></a><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0"> to get our Morning Briefings by email in the Australian, Asian, European or American morning, or </em><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/newsletters/evening-briefing" title=""><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">here</em></a><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0"> to receive an Evening Briefing on U.S. weeknights.</em></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">Browse our full range of Times newsletters </em><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/newsletters" title=""><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">here</em></a><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">.</em></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">What did you like? What do you want to see here? Let us know at </em><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="mailto:briefing@nytimes.com?subject=Weekend%20Briefing%20Feedback" title=""><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">briefing@nytimes.com</em></a><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">.</em></p>, <p>Advertisement</p>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd" id="site-index-label">Site Index</h2>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-0">news</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-1">opinion</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-2">arts</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-3">living</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-4">more</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-subscribe-label">Subscribe</h3>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd">Site Information Navigation</h2>]
[<p>Advertisement</p>, <p>Supported by</p>, <h1 class="css-1s4ffep e1h9rw200" id="link-f26a8ab" itemprop="headline"><span>Wuhan Coronavirus, Iran Cover-Up, Kobe Bryant: Your Monday Briefing</span></h1>, <p class="css-1ifw933 e1wiw3jv0" id="article-summary">Here’s what you need to know.</p>, <p class="css-1fv7b6t e1jsehar1" itemprop="author" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">By<!-- --> <a class="css-brehiz e1jsehar0" href="https://www.nytimes.com/by/melina-delkic"><span class="css-1baulvz last-byline" itemprop="name">Melina Delkic</span></a></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">(Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/morning-briefing" title="">sign-up</a>.)</p>, <p class="css-ma92ss evys1bk0">Good morning.</p>, <p class="css-ma92ss evys1bk0">We’re covering a new stage in the <strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">spread of the Wuhan coronavirus</strong>, developments in the<strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10"> impeachment trial </strong>and the death of the basketball legend <strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Kobe Bryant</strong>.</p>, <h2 class="css-3ez4hu eoo0vm40" id="link-2de017cb">Coronavirus cases grow while answers remain elusive</h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The outbreak<strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10"> </strong>that has spread <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://nl.nytimes.com/f/a/u8iom3h3XZVBvN3zf1SYtA~~/AAAAAQA~~~" title="">to several continents</a> has killed at least 56 and sickened more than 2,000. And Wuhan, the virus’s epicenter, may have about 1,000 more confirmed cases of the mysterious illness, the city’s mayor said. <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/26/world/china-coronavirus.html" title="">Here’s the latest</a>.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The head of China’s National Health Commission said that <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/26/world/asia/coronavirus-wuhan-china-hubei.html" title="">people carrying the virus but not showing symptoms</a> could still infect others and warned that the “epidemic is now entering a more serious and complex period.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Measures taken:</strong> Hong Kong barred residents from the center of the outbreak and closed major tourist attractions. China banned the wildlife trade nationwide, deployed hundreds of medical workers and assigned dozens of hospitals to focus on treating the virus alone.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Scope: </strong>Cases have been confirmed in Thailand, Vietnam, Singapore, Japan, South Korea, Nepal, Taiwan, Hong Kong, Malaysia, France, Australia and the U.S.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Perspective from Beijing:</strong> The Chinese government <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/26/world/asia/china-coronavirus-xi-jinping.html" title="">has stepped up its response</a> to the Wuhan crisis, but the effort has been plagued by bureaucracy and a lack of transparency.</p>, <h2 class="css-3ez4hu eoo0vm40" id="link-35d4605a">How Iran covered up the downing of an airliner</h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">For three days, Iranian military officials knew they had shot down a Ukrainian jetliner while the government issued false statements, denying any responsibility.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">When they finally told President Hassan Rouhani, he told them to come clean or he would resign. Only then did Iran’s supreme leader, Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, step in and order the government to acknowledge its fatal mistake.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The Times <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/26/world/middleeast/iran-plane-crash-coverup.html?action=click&amp;module=Top%20Stories&amp;pgtype=Homepage" title="">pieced together a chronology of those three days</a> by interviewing Iranian officials, members of the Islamic Revolutionary Guards Corps and people close to the supreme leader’s inner circle and by examining official public statements and state media reports.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Takeaway:</strong> There was a behind-the-scenes debate over covering up Iran’s responsibility for the crash, as the Revolutionary Guards effectively sidelined the elected government.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Perspective:</strong> Since August, at least 16 Iranian students have been turned away at airports, losing their chances to study at prestigious universities. They <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/25/us/iran-students-deported-border.html?action=click&amp;module=Top%20Stories&amp;pgtype=Homepage" title="">told us their stories</a>.</p>, <h2 class="css-3ez4hu eoo0vm40" id="link-6e99cf34">Impeachment trial switches to White House perspective</h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">In a Saturday session, President Trump’s legal team<strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10"> </strong>began its aggressive defense in the Senate impeachment trial.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">They <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/25/us/politics/trump-impeachment-defense.html" title="">dismissed the House impeachment inquiry</a> as a partisan ploy that ignored the facts to cast Mr. Trump’s actions in the worst possible light. Democrats, they argued, were “asking you to tear up all of the ballots” by convicting Mr. Trump of high crimes and misdemeanors.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/25/us/politics/trump-lawyers-defense-team-impeachment.html" title="">The president’s legal team</a> used only two of the 24 hours allotted to them to present their defense. Arguments will resume Monday afternoon.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Another angle: </strong>New evidence became public this weekend: a 2018 recording of Mr. Trump <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/25/us/politics/trump-ukraine-donors.html" title="">ordering the firing</a> of the U.S. ambassador to Ukraine. </p>, <h2 class="css-3ez4hu eoo0vm40" id="link-736c2d7d">Kobe Bryant dies</h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The basketball legend, 41, <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/26/sports/basketball/kobe-bryant-dead.html" title="">died in a helicopter crash</a> in Calabasas, Calif., on Sunday. He was among five people traveling in the helicopter.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The National Basketball Association sent a confirmation of Bryant’s and his daughter Gianna’s, 13, deaths to all teams and league employees Sunday afternoon, according to two people familiar with the document.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The 18-time All-Star and five-time champion retired in 2016, having won Olympic gold medals as a member of Team U.S.A. He was scheduled to headline the 2020 N.B.A. Hall of Fame nominees.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Legacy: </strong>The crash came a day after the former Los Angeles Lakers superstar congratulated LeBron James, currently on the team, for <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/aponline/2020/01/25/sports/basketball/ap-bkn-james-nba-scoring-list.html" title="">moving past him on the N.B.A.’s career scoring list</a>.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“Continuing to move the game forward @KingJames. Much respect my brother 💪🏾 #33644,” <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://twitter.com/kobebryant/status/1221276426164269056" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">Bryant tweeted.</a></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Fans:</strong> People were already gathering to pay their respects near the site of the crash. “He’s a figure. He’s a legend. He brought L.A. back. He’s an L.A. icon. He was a competitor. His drive, shooting in the gym at 4 in the morning. He’s what everyone wants to be,” one man said.</p>, <h3 class="css-1b8te77 e1gnsphs0" id="link-10467732">If you have 10 minutes, this is worth it</h3>, <h2 class="css-3ez4hu eoo0vm40" id="link-cdea2a7">Remembering Auschwitz</h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">World leaders and dignitaries will gather for a solemn ceremony at Auschwitz on Monday on the 75th anniversary of the liberation of the Nazi death camp. Our Opinion section <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2020/01/24/opinion/auschwitz-anniversary-holocaust.html?te=1&amp;nl=morning-briefing&amp;emc=edit_nn_20200126?campaign_id=9&amp;instance_id=15471&amp;segment_id=20667&amp;user_id=830c70cfae7761a29eee4dd9c5919d12&amp;regi_id=8540951720200126" title="">published portraits of survivors</a>.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Amid a surge of anti-Semitism and a rise in dehumanizing political rhetoric, there is fear that the <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/25/world/europe/auschwitz-liberation-75th-anniversary.html?te=1&amp;nl=morning-briefing&amp;emc=edit_nn_20200126?campaign_id=9&amp;instance_id=15471&amp;segment_id=20667&amp;user_id=830c70cfae7761a29eee4dd9c5919d12&amp;regi_id=8540951720200126" title="">horrific lessons of the death camp are being lost</a>.</p>, <h3 class="css-1b8te77 e1gnsphs0" id="link-554e6082">Here’s what else is happening</h3>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Harry and Meghan:</strong> As the couple leaves full-time royal life, both have vowed to forgo public funding. But in doing so, they have brought a spotlight to the <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/26/world/europe/harry-meghan-charles-duchy-of-cornwall.html" title="">land holdings that the royal family views as private funding</a>, which contain a generous mixture of public giveaways.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">North Korea: </strong>Kim Kyong-hui, aunt of the leader Kim Jong-un, re-emerged in Pyongyang, the capital, <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/25/world/asia/north-korea-kim-jong-un-aunt.html" title="">dispelling rumors that she was purged</a> after her powerful husband was executed.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Snapshot: </strong>Above, Novak Djokovic, who beat Diego Schwartzman this weekend. In <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://nl.nytimes.com/f/newsletter/BxBRb2aG9UAgo93zVe-EOw~~/AAAAAQA~/RgRgEA1uP0TuaHR0cHM6Ly93d3cubnl0aW1lcy5jb20vMjAyMC8wMS8yNS9zcG9ydHMvbm92YWstZGpva292aWMtYXVzdHJhbGlhbi1vcGVuLmh0bWw_dGU9MSZubD1tb3JuaW5nLWJyaWVmaW5nJmVtYz1lZGl0X25uXzIwMjAwMTI2P2NhbXBhaWduX2lkPTkmaW5zdGFuY2VfaWQ9MTU0NzEmc2VnbWVudF9pZD0yMDY2NyZ1c2VyX2lkPTgzMGM3MGNmYWU3NzYxYTI5ZWVlNGRkOWM1OTE5ZDEyJnJlZ2lfaWQ9ODU0MDk1MTcyMDIwMDEyNlcDbnl0QgoAKG6ILV4LGhwhUhltZWxpbmEuZGVsa2ljQG55dGltZXMuY29tWAQAAAAA" title="">a rare interview</a>, the reigning champion said he was no longer playing tennis to prove himself but rather to improve himself and the lives of those around him. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">What we’re reading: </strong>This <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.bostonglobe.com/2020/01/23/metro/is-fda-ready-next-e-coli-outbreak/" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">Boston Globe investigation</a> of the government’s inaction on E. coli outbreaks. The story of a 2-year-old boy who ate some of his father’s salad and developed the illness is “heartbreaking, terrifying and riveting,” writes our Times Insider editor, Jennifer Krauss.</p>, <h3 class="css-1b8te77 e1gnsphs0" id="link-7ded7ef4">Now, a break from the news</h3>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Cook: </strong><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://cooking.nytimes.com/recipes/1020815-slow-cooker-red-beans-and-rice" title="">Slow cooker red beans and rice</a> takes only about 20 minutes to set up in the morning. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Watch: </strong>This trailer of <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/24/movies/taylor-swift-documentary-miss-americana.html" title="">“Miss Americana,”</a> a Netflix documentary about Taylor Swift.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Read: </strong>In her latest comic book endeavor, Roxane Gay adapts a short story, <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/24/arts/roxane-gay-darkness-graphic-novel.html" title="">“The Sacrifice of Darkness,”</a> from her 2017 collection “Difficult Women.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Smarter Living: </strong>Wirecutter recommends five cheap(ish) things to radically <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/22/smarter-living/5-cheap-ish-things-to-radically-make-over-your-closet.html" title="">make over your cluttered closet</a>.</p>, <h3 class="css-1b8te77 e1gnsphs0" id="link-15767e9b">And now for the Back Story on …</h3>, <h2 class="css-3ez4hu eoo0vm40" id="link-10ec9a2c">Bill Clinton’s impeachment</h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">We asked Peter Baker, our chief White House correspondent, to reflect on a major moment in the lead-up to the last presidential impeachment and compare it to the current trial. He has covered both.</em></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Twenty-two years ago this week came a milestone moment in the last presidential impeachment drama. President <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.washingtonpost.com/video/politics/bill-clinton-i-did-not-have-sexual-relations-with-that-woman/2018/01/25/4a953c22-0221-11e8-86b9-8908743c79dd_video.html" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">Bill Clinton was on the defensive</a> after The Washington Post, where I was working then, broke the news that Ken Starr was investigating whether he committed perjury to cover up an affair with a onetime White House intern.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Mr. Clinton took to the microphone at the end of an event, glared angrily at the reporters in the room, wagged his finger and, with Hillary Clinton standing behind him, forcefully said, “I did not have sexual relations with that woman, Miss Lewinsky.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">We were struck by two things: One, that he seemed to briefly blank on her name, referring to her as “that woman,” before summoning it. But the second was the intensity of his denial. He was white-hot mad. At that time, before the DNA and the grand jury testimony, we didn’t know if the story we were pursuing was bogus or if the president of the United States was lying to us and to the country. Of course, later we found out which it was.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Now, as Ken Starr re-emerges as a lawyer for President Trump in the current impeachment trial and the administration’s explanations of what happened continue to fluctuate, it’s <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/19/us/politics/clinton-impeachment-trial.html" title="">hard not to feel déjà vu</a>.</p>, <p class="css-ma92ss evys1bk0">That’s it for this briefing. See you next time.</p>, <p class="css-ma92ss evys1bk0">— Melina</p>, <p class="css-jwz2nf etfikam0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Thank you</strong><br/>To Mark Josephson and Eleanor Stanford for the break from the news. You can reach the team at <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="mailto:briefing+pm@nytimes.com?subject=Briefing%20Feedback" title="">briefing@nytimes.com</a>.</p>, <p class="css-jwz2nf etfikam0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">P.S.</strong><br/>• We’re listening to “<a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/thedaily" title="">The Daily</a>.” Our latest episode is about how the issue of fracking natural gas could win the swing state of Pennsylvania in the 2020 election. <br/>• Here’s our <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/crosswords/game/mini" title="">Mini Crossword</a>, and a clue: Reads but doesn’t comment, in internet lingo (five letters). <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/crosswords" title="">You can find all our puzzles here</a>.<br/>• Monica Mark is <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytco.com/press/our-next-johannesburg-bureau-chief/" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">our next Johannesburg bureau chief</a>. She has covered some of the biggest stories in Africa for Bloomberg News, The Guardian and BuzzFeed News.</p>, <p>Advertisement</p>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd" id="site-index-label">Site Index</h2>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-0">news</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-1">opinion</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-2">arts</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-3">living</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-4">more</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-subscribe-label">Subscribe</h3>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd">Site Information Navigation</h2>]
[<p>Advertisement</p>, <p>Supported by</p>, <p class="css-tsacue e6idgb70">with interest</p>, <h1 class="css-1s4ffep e1h9rw200" id="link-26f63f05" itemprop="headline"><span>This Week in Business: Beware Mysterious Videos on Your Phone</span></h1>, <p class="css-1ifw933 e1wiw3jv0" id="article-summary"></p>, <p class="css-1fv7b6t e1jsehar1" itemprop="author" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">By<!-- --> <span class="css-1baulvz last-byline" itemprop="name">Charlotte Cowles</span></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">My iPhone got hacked once, but the only fallout was that it sent my contacts a bizarre email containing only a fish emoji (really). The billionaire Jeff Bezos apparently wasn’t so lucky — but of course, his phone contents are far juicier than mine. For more on that strange story, and the business and tech news you need to know for the week ahead, read on.</p>, <h2 class="css-3ez4hu eoo0vm40" id="link-5f1091b6">What’s Up? (Jan. 26-Feb. 1)</h2>, <h3 class="css-1ldy5g8 e1gnsphs0" id="link-452fe084">Delete My Number</h3>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">An <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/22/world/middleeast/bezos-phone-hacked.html" title="">investigation</a> commissioned by Jeff Bezos, the chief executive of Amazon and the richest man in the world, found evidence that his iPhone had been hacked after he received messages from an account apparently belonging to Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman of Saudi Arabia. Where to begin? According to the report, the two men exchanged phone numbers at a dinner back in 2018. Then Mr. Bezos <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/22/technology/jeff-bezos-hack-iphone.html" title="">received a weird video</a> from Prince Mohammed containing malware that may have given the Saudis access to his private photos and messages (very awkward, particularly as he was having an extramarital affair at the time). The bad blood is part of a bigger picture: Last year, the prince is said to have ordered the brutal killing of the dissident Saudi journalist Jamal Khashoggi, who was a columnist for The Washington Post, which Mr. Bezos owns. The Saudi royal family has denied these accusations.</p>, <h3 class="css-1ldy5g8 e1gnsphs0" id="link-6c47ea13">Depressing News at Davos</h3>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Global leaders gathered at the World Economic Forum in Switzerland last week to fret about everything from climate change to a <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2017/01/16/world/eight-richest-wealth-oxfam.html" title="">somber new report</a> from the charity Oxfam that the world’s eight richest people (all men) have as much wealth as the bottom half. President Trump gave a speech bemoaning the state of the <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/22/business/trump-boeing-davos-737-max.html" title="">embattled aircraft manufacturer Boeing</a> as well as <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/22/world/europe/trump-davos.html" title="">his impeachment trial</a>. And amid widespread alarm over the rising economic impact of global warming, the 17-year-old climate activist Greta Thunberg <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/21/climate/greta-thunberg-davos.html" title="">implored business leaders</a> to divest from fossil fuels. Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin later <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/23/climate/greta-thunberg-steve-mnuchin.html" title="">dismissed her plea</a>, although many other attendees seemed to take it seriously: The hot trend this year was <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/23/business/corporate-climate-davos.html" title="">corporations pledging</a> to make their business practices greener.</p>, <h3 class="css-1ldy5g8 e1gnsphs0" id="link-62f3ece7">A Bank’s Boss Pays the Price</h3>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">It’s rare for the head of a big company to take the fall for his underlings’ actions, but at Wells Fargo, <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/23/business/wells-fargo-ceo-fine.html" title="">it actually happened</a>. The bank’s former chief executive John G. Stumpf was fined $17.5 million — the largest individual fine in the history of federal banking regulation — for his role in fostering a <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2019/03/09/business/wells-fargo-sales-culture.html" title="">toxic culture</a> that encouraged employees to foist <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2016/09/17/business/dealbook/wells-fargo-warned-workers-against-fake-accounts-but-they-needed-a-paycheck.html" title="">fake accounts and unnecessary financial products</a> on millions of unsuspecting customers. He is one of the bank’s <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2016/09/09/business/dealbook/wells-fargo-fined-for-years-of-harm-to-customers.html" title="">5,300 workers who have lost their jobs</a> over the scandal. He is also barred for life from working in the banking industry.</p>, <h2 class="css-3ez4hu eoo0vm40" id="link-4d122fbe">What’s Next? (Feb. 2-8)</h2>, <h3 class="css-1ldy5g8 e1gnsphs0" id="link-2ea7a607">Fuss Over FICO Scores</h3>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Take a good look at your FICO score: It may be changing soon. The most widely used credit rating in the country is <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/25/business/credit-score-fico-change.html" title="">getting a new set of criteria</a>, said Fair Isaac, the company behind it. And for many people, that’s not great news. Those with rising debt levels and overdue payments will be judged more harshly. The new scoring system will also flag consumers who sign up for personal loans — a category of debt that has skyrocketed in recent years as borrowers use it as a stopgap for ballooning credit card bills. The new system is likely to make it harder for struggling Americans to borrow money. But it will look even more kindly on those whose scores are already high.</p>, <h3 class="css-1ldy5g8 e1gnsphs0" id="link-3d9c4a02">A Plague on the Economy</h3>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The mysterious, deadly coronavirus outbreak in China is causing widespread panic and a significant dip in global markets. And its timing <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/23/world/asia/wuhan-coronavirus-china-economy.html" title="">couldn’t be worse for businesses</a>. Lunar New Year, a weeklong holiday that’s usually full of travel, shopping and gift giving, began on Friday. (It’s technically <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.washingtonpost.com/business/china-will-rack-up-three-billion-trips-during-worlds-biggest-human-migration/2020/01/20/8bbc0f3e-3b52-11ea-afe2-090eb37b60b1_story.html" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">the largest human migration on the planet</a>.) But this year, many people are canceling their plans and staying home because of travel bans and fear of contagion. While the virus is still spreading, it’s hard to gauge its economic impact so far, but a serious blow to China’s consumer market is likely to reverberate around the world.</p>, <h3 class="css-1ldy5g8 e1gnsphs0" id="link-7c488496">Brexit Is Nigh</h3>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">For years, Brexit was a hopeless quagmire of parliamentary rancor, but now it looks as if Britain <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/22/world/europe/brexit-withdrawal-bill.html" title="">will withdraw quite uneventfully</a> from the European Union by next Friday’s deadline. What a difference a few months — and a strong Conservative majority in Parliament — make. The final Brexit plan is expected to be approved by European Union officials within a few days. But that isn’t the end of it. In the coming months, British and European representatives <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/08/world/europe/brexit-united-kingdom.html" title="">still have to hash out a trade deal</a>, which may prove just as difficult to negotiate — if not more so — as Brexit itself.</p>, <h2 class="css-3ez4hu eoo0vm40" id="link-29a05a54">What Else?</h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The executive in charge of Hallmark TV <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/22/business/media/hallmark-channel-ceo.html" title="">stepped down</a> after the network apologized for removing an ad that showed two brides kissing. Boeing has once again <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/21/business/boeing-737-max.html" title="">pushed back the date</a> that the 737 Max jet — which has been grounded since March over safety problems — will be cleared to return to the air. (Now, it’s looking more like mid-2020.) And in London, police are setting off a new privacy debate by <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/24/business/london-police-facial-recognition.html" title="">deploying facial recognition software</a> to identify people on the street, in real time, with video cameras — a level of surveillance that’s rare outside China.</p>, <p>Advertisement</p>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd" id="site-index-label">Site Index</h2>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-0">news</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-1">opinion</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-2">arts</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-3">living</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-4">more</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-subscribe-label">Subscribe</h3>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd">Site Information Navigation</h2>]
[<p>Advertisement</p>, <p>Supported by</p>, <h1 class="css-1s4ffep e1h9rw200" id="link-1d1d0636" itemprop="headline"><span>New York Braces for Coronavirus: ‘It’s Inevitable’</span></h1>, <p class="css-1ifw933 e1wiw3jv0" id="article-summary">In Queens, some who recently returned from China have even self-quarantined. But officials have urged calm.</p>, <p class="css-1fv7b6t e1jsehar1" itemprop="author" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">By<!-- --> <a class="css-brehiz e1jsehar0" href="https://www.nytimes.com/by/joseph-goldstein"><span class="css-1baulvz" itemprop="name">Joseph Goldstein</span></a> and <a class="css-brehiz e1jsehar0" href="https://www.nytimes.com/by/jeffrey-e-singer"><span class="css-1baulvz last-byline" itemprop="name">Jeffrey E. Singer</span></a></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">With isolated cases of the <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/article/what-is-coronavirus.html" title="">dangerous new coronavirus</a> cropping up in a number of states, public health officials say it is only a matter of time before the virus appears in New York City.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">As a result, hospitals have been on the lookout for patients with <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/28/health/airports-screening-coronavirus.html" title="">recent travel involving Wuhan</a>, the Chinese city where the coronavirus is believed to have originated. And they have urged those who recently traveled there — or who have been in contact with someone who has — to quickly seek medical care if they have any respiratory or flulike symptoms.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“It’s inevitable that we will have someone who is positive with coronavirus,” New York City’s health commissioner, Dr. Oxiris Barbot, said Sunday.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Some of the last passengers to arrive at Kennedy International Airport on the last direct flights from Wuhan before they were canceled were quarantining themselves at home. One man told of how he had confined himself to his house in Queens, as friends left special Lunar New Year meals on his doorstep.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">So far, state officials have sought testing for nine patients who were deemed potential cases of the new coronavirus, sending samples to the <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/topic/organization/centers-for-disease-control-and-prevention" title="">Centers for Disease Control and Prevention</a> for testing.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Four of those patients were found not to have the virus, and the tests involving the other five are still pending, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo said Monday in a statement.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">When the first case does arrive, health officials said, that patient may end up in a biocontainment unit in Bellevue Hospital or sent home to ride out the illness in his or her bedroom. That will depend largely on how sick they are, public health officials say.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Some people with the virus, Dr. Barbot said, have limited symptoms: coughing, shortness of breath, a low-grade fever. But in others, the virus can be lethal.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Outside of the city, the state Department of Health has been hosting online seminars about the new coronavirus for medical staff. In particular, health officials have engaged in outreach to university health systems, where international students are likely to seek medical care.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">By and large, the message to the public has been one of reassurance. “We are encouraging New Yorkers to go about their everyday lives and suggest practicing everyday precautions that we do through the flu season,” Dr. Barbot said.</p>, <h1 class="g-headline" id="g-inlineguide-headline">The Coronavirus Outbreak</h1>, <h2 class="g-inlineguide-list-header g-optimize-type">How Is the U.S. Being Affected?</h2>, <p class="g-inlineguide-date">Updated Feb.10, 2020</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">But there is considerable anxiety and debate over the proper precautions within the city’s Chinatowns. That has only grown in the past few days as more alarming news has emerged out of Wuhan about the virus’s spread. So far more than 4,500 people have been sickened and <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/27/world/asia/china-coronavirus-social-media.html" title="">more than 100 people have died</a>.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">In response, the authorities in China have <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/26/world/asia/coronavirus-wuhan-china-hubei.html?action=click&amp;module=Top%20Stories&amp;pgtype=Homepage" title="">imposed a lockdown of some 56 million people</a> in cities in Hubei province, of which Wuhan is the capital, though by the time it was in effect <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/26/world/china-coronavirus.html" title="">some five million people</a> had already traveled from Wuhan, according to Wuhan’s mayor.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Scott Liu, 56, a textile importer who lives in Queens, said he was on the last direct flight from Wuhan to Kennedy Airport before the flights were canceled last week. He and his fellow passengers learned of the city lockdown mid-flight.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">He does not think he is sick, but he knows that symptoms take time to appear — the authorities have said the incubation period is up to two weeks, although symptoms seem to usually appear within a week, Dr. Barbot said.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">In the meantime, Mr. Liu has confined himself at home alone, even at the start of Lunar New Year.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Instead of going out to visit friends and family or sharing holiday meals, Mr. Liu stood behind his door as friends dropped off traditional Hubei dishes for Lunar New Year on his doorstep — lotus root and pork rib soup, salted fish and dumplings.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Mr. Liu said he did not think he was overreacting, just acting responsibly.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“For us, this is very serious,” he said in Mandarin during a phone interview on Friday.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Mr. Liu was among a few hundred members of the New York Yellow Crane Club who had traveled to Wuhan several weeks ago to celebrate the Lunar New Year with relatives.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">As the seriousness of the outbreak became apparent, Mr. Liu, who is the club’s president, and a few others cut short their plans and boarded flights home. Mr. Liu arrived in New York on Wednesday, he said.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">As of Monday, Mr. Liu said he had not experienced any symptoms: “So far, so good.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Last year, the Yellow Crane Club, which has more than 500 members of mainly immigrants from Wuhan and their families, hosted a Lunar New Year celebration at a banquet hall in Flushing, Queens.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">This year, Mr. Liu said, “all the events here are canceled. Everybody is in a state of panic.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">For now, Mr. Liu spends his days staring at his phone, reading the news about the virus and messaging friends. His wife is visiting their daughter in Florida. He worries about his 90-year-old mother, who lives alone in Wuhan.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Most of his friends who had recently returned from Wuhan had also put themselves under quarantine. Some were urged by family members to confine themselves to a single bedroom so as to reduce the risk of transmission should they become ill.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“There are friends and families that require family members to quarantine themselves — that force them,” he said.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Dr. Barbot said that those who have recently traveled from Wuhan are not being urged to self-quarantine or avoid large public gatherings.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“We are very clear: We wish New Yorkers a Happy Lunar New Year and we encourage people to spend time with their families and go about their celebration,” Dr. Barbot said.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">In recent days, Lin Qiurong, 40, who emigrated from China’s Fujian province in 2002, had been weighing messages from friends, urging each other to avoid large crowds. But on Sunday, Ms. Lin and her three teenage children donned surgical face masks and ventured out to a Lunar New Year parade in Sunset Park, home to Brooklyn’s largest Chinatown.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">It’s an event that the community looks forward to every year: Giggling children spray each other with canned silly string while lion dance troupes undulate and swerve to the beat of a pounding drum and clanging cymbals. Traditional New Year’s music blasts from large speakers mounted atop a fleet of passenger vans.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">There was still all that. Though as Ms. Lin walked down Eighth Avenue, ahead of the parade, she sized up the crowd, and could not shake the impression that there were fewer spectators lining up than in years past.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“Look around,” Ms. Lin said, speaking in Mandarin, noting that while there were plenty of vendors standing behind tables of confetti cannons and silly string, actual spectators seemed to be in short supply. “It’s much emptier compared to last year,” she said.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Louie Liu, 47, a member of a neighborhood patrol group, said he was not concerned about the virus — noting that it had not yet arrived in New York.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“I believe the Chinese government will be able to keep it under control,” said Mr. Liu, who emigrated from Fujian province in 1992. He added, also in Mandarin, that “New York State and New York City are also focused and prepared.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">New York health officials pointed out that they have a long history of preparing for unfamiliar viruses. As recently as last month, the city’s public hospital system was running drills for how to handle possible Ebola cases. In these drills, individuals claiming Ebola-like symptoms would enter an emergency room, and mention a recent trip to the Democratic Republic of Congo, <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2019/05/19/world/africa/ebola-outbreak-congo.html" title="">which is currently contending with the second largest Ebola outbreak</a> on record.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Dr. Barbot said that there is not yet a full understanding of how easily the new coronavirus is transmitted.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“All indications are that it’s not nearly as deadly as SARS virus, but the transmissibility is still to be fully elucidated,” Dr. Barbot said, drawing a comparison to another coronavirus outbreak that nearly two decades ago infected more than 8,000 people and killed nearly 800.</p>, <p>Advertisement</p>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd" id="site-index-label">Site Index</h2>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-0">news</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-1">opinion</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-2">arts</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-3">living</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-4">more</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-subscribe-label">Subscribe</h3>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd">Site Information Navigation</h2>]
[<p>Advertisement</p>, <p>Supported by</p>, <p>Supported by</p>, <h1 class="css-1s4ffep e1h9rw200" id="link-3f9e2311" itemprop="headline"><span>Stocks Have Worst Day Since October Over Coronavirus Worries</span></h1>, <p class="css-1ifw933 e1wiw3jv0" id="article-summary">U.S. stocks followed European markets down amid concerns that the coronavirus could hurt the global economy.</p>, <p class="css-1fv7b6t e1jsehar1" itemprop="author" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">By<!-- --> <a class="css-brehiz e1jsehar0" href="https://www.nytimes.com/by/matt-phillips"><span class="css-1baulvz" itemprop="name">Matt Phillips</span></a> and <a class="css-brehiz e1jsehar0" href="https://www.nytimes.com/by/katie-robertson"><span class="css-1baulvz last-byline" itemprop="name">Katie Robertson</span></a></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Just as the world economy appeared to emerge from the uncertainty of the trade war, the spread of the dangerous <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/27/world/asia/china-coronavirus.html" title="">coronavirus</a> in China has pierced the calm that had settled over financial markets.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The S&amp;P 500 closed down 1.6 percent on Monday — its second straight drop, which wiped out much of the market’s gains since the start of the year, and its sharpest decline <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2019/10/02/business/economy/markets-world-trade.html" title="">since Oct. 2</a>, when the trade war was stoking fears of a domestic slowdown.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">President Trump announced the <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2019/10/11/business/economy/us-china-trade-deal.html" title="">“Phase 1” trade agreement</a> with China on Oct. 11, contributing to weeks of placid trading that pushed stocks to a series of records, making the coronavirus-driven slump all the more jarring.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“There was already reason to question whether markets were a bit too buoyant,” said Patrick Chovanec, chief strategist at the investment advisory firm Silvercrest Asset Management. “Sometimes it takes something like this to refocus their attention on potential downsides.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Stocks with close ties to the Chinese market or the travel industry — or both — bore the brunt of the selling.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">American Airlines fell more than 5 percent, and Wynn Resorts, which operates casinos in Macau, a special administrative region of China and a gambling haven for Chinese high rollers, tumbled 8 percent.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Companies with links to China’s key role in the global technology supply chain also slumped.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">IPG Photonics, which makes lasers for cutting and welding and makes a significant share of its sales in China, fell more than 6 percent. Two chip makers, Applied Materials and Skyworks Solutions, which sell heavily in the Chinese market, each fell more than 4 percent.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The S&amp;P’s drop followed declines of more than 2 percent for the major stock benchmarks in Europe. The benchmark Nikkei 225 index in Tokyo also sank 2 percent, while many other markets in Asia — including the Shanghai Stock Exchange — were closed for the Lunar New Year.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">China extended the Lunar New Year holiday by three days until next Sunday in an effort to limit travel and contain the outbreak, which started in the city of Wuhan. </p>, <h1 class="g-headline" id="g-inlineguide-headline">The Coronavirus Outbreak</h1>, <h2 class="g-inlineguide-list-header g-optimize-type">What do you need to know? Start here.</h2>, <p class="g-inlineguide-date">Updated Feb. 5, 2020</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Concerns about travel restrictions — the Chinese government has effectively <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/22/world/asia/coronavirus-quarantines-history.html" title="">sealed off Wuhan</a> and other cities, affecting 56 million people — helped push down oil prices and shares of major oil companies.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Brent crude, the international benchmark, slipped below $60 a barrel, its lowest since October. Prices have declined about 10 percent since Jan. 17, when China confirmed multiple deaths from the virus. On Monday, the S&amp;P 500 energy sector was down 2.8 percent.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The outbreak has come at a crucial period for Chinese business, which could complicate official plans to reinvigorate growth in the aftermath of the trade-war tensions of the last two years.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/23/world/asia/wuhan-coronavirus-china-economy.html" title="">country’s economy</a>, trying to shrug off its worst slowdown in <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2019/07/14/business/china-economy-growth-gdp-trade-war.html" title="">nearly three decades</a>, is already hurting from the virus’s effects on travel and tourism. And consumer spending — which helps fuel the economy over the holiday period — could be dampened as more residents stay home.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The outbreak has China’s leaders <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/26/world/asia/china-coronavirus-xi-jinping.html" title="">under pressure</a>, and some experts have expressed concerns that the government was too slow to respond and <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/26/world/asia/coronavirus-wuhan-china-hubei.html" title="">could even make the situation worse</a>.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The sheer size of the Chinese economy, the second largest in the world after that of the United States, makes any upheaval there a serious factor in the pace of global economic growth. Creeping doubts among investors have already helped drive down bond yields in recent weeks. And on Monday, the yield on the 10-year Treasury note, considered a gauge of investor expectations for economic growth and inflation, sank to 1.60 percent, the lowest level of the year.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">But as long as the spread of the virus remains contained, the economic implications should not be dire for the United States.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The American economy is relatively insulated from trade, and the important consumer sector continues to show signs of strength. Unemployment remains near 50-year lows, and economic growth, while relatively slow, is steady. Inflation and interest rates are low, with signs that those low rates are finally starting to filter through to the broader economy.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">With rates on 30-year fixed mortgages below 4 percent, housing has recently picked up the pace. Sales of previously built homes are at their highest level since early 2018. Homebuilders are reporting strong demand for more affordable offerings.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">On Monday, D.R. Horton — the <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.builderonline.com/builder-100/builder-100-list/2019/" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">largest American homebuilder by house closings</a> — reported better-than-expected earnings and revenue for the first quarter, sending its shares up 2 percent. Lennar, the second-largest builder, reported similarly bright numbers this month.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“Across all of our geographies, we’re feeling pretty good about the traffic, pretty good about the demand in the most recent quarter,” Bill Wheat, chief financial officer of D.R. Horton, said on a conference call with analysts.</p>, <p>Advertisement</p>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd" id="site-index-label">Site Index</h2>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-0">news</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-1">opinion</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-2">arts</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-3">living</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-4">more</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-subscribe-label">Subscribe</h3>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd">Site Information Navigation</h2>]
[<p>Advertisement</p>, <p>Supported by</p>, <h1 class="css-1s4ffep e1h9rw200" id="link-7cb7c5fd" itemprop="headline"><span>‘What if We All Get Sick?’: Coronavirus Strains China’s Health System</span></h1>, <p class="css-1ifw933 e1wiw3jv0" id="article-summary">To fight the expanding outbreak, the country is relying on a medical system that is overburdened even in normal times.</p>, <p class="css-1fv7b6t e1jsehar1" itemprop="author" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">By<!-- --> <a class="css-brehiz e1jsehar0" href="https://www.nytimes.com/by/sui-lee-wee"><span class="css-1baulvz last-byline" itemprop="name">Sui-Lee Wee</span></a></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">After suffering from a fever and breathing problems for more than 15 days, Xiao Shibing, a 51-year-old resident of Wuhan, China, finally sought help at a hospital. Despite the symptoms, he was not tested for the <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/27/world/asia/china-coronavirus.html" title="">new coronavirus</a> — a lapse suggesting that there may be far more cases of the virus than are being officially reported.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Instead, Mr. Xiao was told that he had a viral chest infection, so he went back home. As he grew sicker, he went to three <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/25/world/asia/china-coronavirus-photos.html" title="">other hospitals</a>. But they told him they did not have enough beds.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Like many of the <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/26/world/asia/coronavirus-wuhan-china-hubei.html" title="">thousands of Chinese patients</a> who are concerned about the <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/27/world/asia/china-coronavirus.html" title="">new coronavirus</a>, Mr. Xiao is scrambling to get help from a health care system straining to serve even the basic needs of patients.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“It is like kicking a ball from here to there,” said his wife, Feng Xiu.</p>, <h2 class="css-zd32qr">Wuhan Coronavirus Map: Tracking the Spread of the Outbreak</h2>, <p class="css-1uuihdo">The virus has sickened tens of thousands of people in China and a number of other countries.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Mr. Xiao, who was eventually hospitalized on Sunday — about a week after his initial attempt — still hasn’t been tested for the pneumonialike virus.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">As it struggles to combat a <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/article/what-is-coronavirus.html" title="">coronavirus outbreak</a> that has sickened more than 4,500 people and killed 106, the Chinese government is relying on a medical system that is overburdened and overwhelmed even in normal times. While other parts of everyday life in China have significantly improved in the past decade, the <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2018/11/15/business/china-private-hospitals-putian.html" title="">quality of health care</a> has stagnated.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">In major cities like Beijing and Shanghai, many people have to stand in line in the wee hours of the morning to secure appointments with doctors. When they do get an appointment, patients get only a couple of minutes with a doctor. During flu season, residents set up camp overnight with blankets in hospital corridors.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">China does not have a functioning primary care system, so most people flock to hospitals. On an ordinary day, <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2018/09/30/business/china-health-care-doctors.html" title="">doctors are frustrated</a> and exhausted as they see as many as 200 patients.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Those weaknesses are most pronounced in the poorer areas of China — like Wuhan, the epicenter of the coronavirus. Panicked residents of the city are heading to the hospitals if they have any sign of a cold or cough. Videos circulating on Chinese social media show doctors straining to handle the enormous workload and hospital corridors loaded with patients, some of whom appear to be dead.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Despite having dealt with the SARS coronavirus nearly two decades ago, many Chinese hospitals in smaller cities are not fully prepared to deal with a major outbreak like the current virus. Wuhan hospitals have posted messages online urgently appealing for medical equipment. The situation is even more desperate in poorer, rural areas nearby.</p>, <h1 class="g-headline" id="g-inlineguide-headline">The Coronavirus Outbreak</h1>, <h2 class="g-inlineguide-list-header g-optimize-type">What do you need to know? Start here.</h2>, <p class="g-inlineguide-date">Updated Feb. 10, 2020</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Last week, eight hospitals in Hubei Province — where Wuhan is situated and where most of the cases have appeared — put out a call for N95 masks, goggles, surgical masks and surgical gowns. In the absence of proper equipment, some medical workers have resorted to cutting plastic folders to jury-rig goggles.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Yanzhong Huang, a senior fellow for global health at the Council on Foreign Relations, said that China had invested a lot in building a robust public health infrastructure in the wake of SARS and that many of them were mostly well equipped to deal with infectious diseases.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“But they apparently didn’t anticipate something so sudden, so acute and so tremendous,” he said.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The government’s response to the crisis could <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/26/world/asia/coronavirus-wuhan-china-hubei.html" title="">exacerbate the problems</a>. Across China, the authorities are sealing off cities, closing down schools and checking on residents. But the lockdown — affecting 56 million people — could make it difficult to get medical supplies to hospitals that desperately need them.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Chinese officials have acknowledged that they are struggling to deal with the outbreak. At a news conference last week, the Wuhan health commission said there were long lines and a shortage of beds. In response, it said it had designated hospitals as “fever clinics” for people to go to for treatment.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">With medical facilities in short supply, the local government has also pledged to build a new 1,000-bed hospital in 10 days, and vowed that another new 1,300-bed hospital would be ready by the middle of next month. It is taking a page out of the government’s playbook during SARS, when it built a new hospital in Beijing in just a week.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Yet it is still not clear that there will be sufficient beds to deal with the virus, which remains highly contagious.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Chen Xi, an assistant professor of health policy and economics at the Yale School of Public Health, said it was more important to have a working system of family doctors who can act as gatekeepers for the hospitals.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“Without an efficient screening process,” he said, “these two hospitals would not be very effective.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The central government is under increasing pressure to show that it is adequately coping with the crisis. On Monday, Premier Li Keqiang, who has been assigned to oversee the national response to the outbreak, visited Wuhan to inspect efforts to contain the disease. He pledged to provide local health centers with 20,000 pairs of safety goggles.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">As the government scrambles to contain the outbreak, the sick are just trying to get medical attention.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Cai Pei, 41, of Wuhan, said his wife had begun coughing and developed a fever three days ago. He wrote on Weibo, a popular social media platform, that hospitals would not admit her, and that he had difficulty finding masks and cold medicine in pharmacies.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Making matters worse, three Chinese medical companies have said that they do not have the capacity to make enough test kits for the new coronavirus, according to local news media reports.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Mr. Cai and his wife still do not know whether she is infected with the coronavirus or another more common ailment.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“Sometimes I can only hide and cry, but I couldn’t tell her and had to reassure her that it is not the virus,” Mr. Cai said by telephone. “It is very scary. If it’s real, we have a child and elderly parents at home. What if we all get sick?”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">With no proven drugs to treat the new virus, the health authorities have told doctors to prescribe a combination of treatments — anti-viral H.I.V. drugs as well as traditional Chinese medicine — to patients. Some of the medicines being prescribed are a mixture of ingredients like buffalo horn, jasmine and honeysuckle as well as anti-viral H.I.V. drugs like Lopinavir and Ritonavir.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">As happened with SARS, traditional Chinese medicine — an industry that the government has pledged to develop — is prominently being touted as a way to treat this new coronavirus. But there is no clinical evidence that the gallstones of cattle, the roots of plants and licorice could work in combating it.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Journals have published studies by Chinese scientists saying that traditional Chinese medicine helped alleviate symptoms of SARS. China’s ministry of science and technology said in 2003 that it had found banlangen, the root of the woad plant, as well as a liquid made up of ingredients like cholic acid, jasmine, buffalo horn and honeysuckle to be effective in curing an acute inflammation of the lungs.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“There has never been a good antiviral agent, so that means that people would try things that have some effect,” said Dominic Dwyer, a medical virologist at the University of Sydney. “But there’s no evidence of significant benefits with any antiviral drugs or traditional Chinese medicine.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The problem with finding a drug that can effectively fight an infectious disease like this coronavirus, SARS or Middle East Respiratory Syndrome is that it needs to be tested in sufficient numbers in a randomized way in proper clinical trials. Patients must also give informed consent.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“That is very difficult in an outbreak situation,” said Kanta Subbarao, a senior researcher on respiratory illnesses at the Doherty Institute in Melbourne, Australia.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">In Wuhan, Mr. Xiao’s daughter, Xiao Hongxia, said her father had been diagnosed with severe pneumonia and was now labeled a “highly suspicious case.” He is relying on ordinary fever medicines and anti-inflammatory drugs, she said.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“There is no special medicine for the coronavirus so far,” Ms. Xiao said, “so we can only rely on the patient’s own immunity.”</p>, <p class="css-jwz2nf etfikam0">Amber Wang, Yiwei Wang and Elsie Chen contributed research.</p>, <p>Advertisement</p>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd" id="site-index-label">Site Index</h2>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-0">news</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-1">opinion</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-2">arts</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-3">living</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-4">more</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-subscribe-label">Subscribe</h3>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd">Site Information Navigation</h2>]
[<p>Advertisement</p>, <p>Supported by</p>, <h1 class="css-1s4ffep e1h9rw200" id="link-3199a88c" itemprop="headline"><span>China’s Coronavirus Has Revived Global Economic Fears</span></h1>, <p class="css-1ifw933 e1wiw3jv0" id="article-summary">The spread of the dangerous virus has spooked global markets and threatened prospects for economic growth.</p>, <p class="css-1fv7b6t e1jsehar1" itemprop="author" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">By<!-- --> <a class="css-brehiz e1jsehar0" href="https://www.nytimes.com/by/peter-s-goodman"><span class="css-1baulvz last-byline" itemprop="name">Peter S. Goodman</span></a></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Before a <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/27/world/asia/china-coronavirus.html" title="">mysterious respiratory illness emerged in the center of China</a>, spreading with lethal effect through the world’s most populous nation, concerns about the health of the global economy had been easing, replaced by a measure of optimism.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The United States and China had achieved <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/15/business/economy/china-trade-deal.html" title="">a tenuous pause in a trade war</a> that had damaged both sides. The specter of open hostilities between the United States and Iran had <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/08/world/middleeast/trump-speech.html" title="">reverted to stalemate</a>. Though Europe remained stagnant, Germany — the Continent’s largest economy — had escaped the threat of recession.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Now, the world is worrying anew.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">An outbreak originating in China and reaching beyond its borders has summoned fresh fears, sending markets into a wealth-destroying tailspin. It <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/28/business/coronavirus-financial-markets.html" title="">has provoked alarm</a> that the world economy may be in for another shock, offsetting the benefits of the trade truce and the geopolitical easing, and providing new reason for businesses and households to hunker down.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">On Monday, investors dumped stocks on exchanges from Asia to Europe to North America. They entrusted their money to traditional safe havens, pushing up the value of the yen, the dollar and gold. They pushed down the price of oil over fears that weaker economies would spell less demand for fuel.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">In short, those in control of money took note of a growing crisis in a country of 1.4 billion people, whose consumers and businesses are a primary engine of economic growth around the world, and they chose to reduce their exposure to risk.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">By late Monday, the virus had killed more than 100 people in China. More than 4,500 had been infected — mostly in mainland China, but also in Hong Kong, Japan, Macau, Malaysia, Nepal, Singapore, South Korea, Taiwan, Thailand and Vietnam, and as far away as Australia, Canada and the United States.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The emergence of the virus in China, whose government <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://cpj.org/blog/2019/03/journalists-jailed-china-censored.php" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">jails journalists</a> and tightly controls information, left the world uncomfortably short of facts needed to assess the dangers.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“It’s the uncertainty of how the global economy is going to respond to the outbreak,” said Philip Shaw, chief economist at Investec, a specialist bank in London. That will depend on the severity, the spread and the duration of the outbreak, he said, and “we don’t really know the answers to any of these questions.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">What was left to the imagination resonated as a reason for investors to unload anything less than a sure thing.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Stocks in Japan and Europe fell more than 2 percent. In New York, the S&amp;P 500 was down 1.6 percent, with stocks of companies whose sales are dependent on China especially susceptible. Wynn Resorts, which operates casinos in the gambling haven of Macau, a special administrative region of China, dropped more than 8 percent.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The virus and its attendant unknowns conjured memories of another deadly illness that began in China, the 2002-3 outbreak of severe acute respiratory syndrome, or SARS, which<a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.who.int/csr/sars/country/table2004_04_21/en/" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title=""> killed nearly 800 people</a>.</p>, <h1 class="g-headline" id="g-inlineguide-headline">The Coronavirus Outbreak</h1>, <h2 class="g-inlineguide-list-header g-optimize-type">What do you need to know? Start here.</h2>, <p class="g-inlineguide-date">Updated Feb. 10, 2020</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“In many ways, it looks similar,” said Nicholas R. Lardy, a China expert and senior fellow at the Peterson Institute for International Economics in Washington. “We are seeing fast increases in the number of cases. The hospitals are overwhelmed and are not even able to test people with symptoms. I’m expecting the cases to go way, way up.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">In the end, SARS significantly slowed the Chinese economy, dropping the annual growth rate to 9.1 percent in the second quarter of 2003 from 11.1 percent in the previous quarter, according to Oxford Economics, an independent research institute in London.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The episode is coinciding with the Lunar New Year, a major holiday in which hundreds of millions of Chinese journey to their hometowns to visit relatives.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">With air, rail and road links in central China restricted as the government seeks to block the spread of the virus, hotels, restaurants and other tourism-related businesses are likely to suffer.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Some economists assume that those effects will quickly dissipate, leading to a revival in the consumer economy within months. That is how events played out in 2003.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“Our baseline is that it will be a fairly big impact but relatively short-lived,” said Louis Kuijs, the Hong Kong-based head of Asia economics at Oxford Economics.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">In the hopeful view, economic damage will be contained by the Chinese government’s aggressive response in effectively quarantining the outbreak’s center — Wuhan, a city of 11 million people, and much of the surrounding area in Hubei Province.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">But Wuhan is a hub of industry, sometimes called the Chicago of China, intensifying the quarantine’s implications for the national economy.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“This is really unprecedented,” Mr. Lardy said. “The economic effects may be much larger than SARS. Wuhan is a major industrial city, and if you’re basically shutting it down, it’s going to have a major effect.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Already, China’s government has extended the Lunar New Year holiday by three days, through Feb. 2, ensuring that migrant workers will not return to their factory jobs as soon as anticipated, almost certainly disrupting production. Suzhou, a major industrial city near Shanghai, has extended the holiday until at least Feb. 8.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Given that China’s economy is the source of roughly one-third of world economic growth, the slowdown could be felt widely.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Most directly, China’s neighbors would absorb the effects, especially those dependent on tourists from China — among them Hong Kong, the Philippines, Singapore, Thailand and Vietnam. Over the weekend, China announced that it was <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/25/world/asia/china-coronavirus.html" title="">barring overseas group tours</a> by its citizens.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">If China’s factories are hobbled by additional restrictions on transportation that limit factory production, that could become a global event. It could hit iron ore mines in Australia and India that feed raw materials into China’s smelters. It could limit sales of computer chips and glass panel displays made at plants in Malaysia and South Korea.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">It could trim sales of factory machinery produced in Germany and auto parts made in the Czech Republic, Hungary and Poland. It could even affect the purchases of additional American farm goods that China agreed to under the <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/15/business/economy/china-trade-deal.html" title="">trade deal</a> signed this month.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The shock is hitting just as China contends with its slowest pace of economic growth in decades, reviving fears that its reduced appetite for the goods and services of the world could jeopardize jobs on multiple shores.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“China is obviously slowing down in a structural way,” said Silvia Dall’Angelo, senior economist at Hermes Investment Management in London. “The global economy is clearly more shaky, with sluggish growth. It is clearly more vulnerable to shocks.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The SARS outbreak prompted the government to stimulate the Chinese economy by directing surges of credit that financed huge infrastructure projects. But whatever damage China confronts this time, its willingness to respond will be limited by the government’s concerns about mounting public debt.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“They are much more constrained now,” said Mr. Lardy, the China expert. “I think people underestimate the conviction that the top leadership has, that they really want to reduce financial risk.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">But as global investors try to gauge the outlook, one element is the same as ever in China: Information is scarce. Trust in the authorities is minimal.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">During the SARS outbreak, the government was slow to acknowledge the existence of the virus as local officials actively covered up cases, allowing the threat to multiply.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">This time, the government has sought to project the sense that it is forthrightly reckoning with the crisis. President Xi Jinping has <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/26/world/asia/china-coronavirus-xi-jinping.html?smtyp=cur&amp;smid=tw-nytimes" title="">publicly acknowledged the threat</a>, while warning local officials not to hide reports of trouble.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">But in the current moment of agitation, any perceived lack of information tends to weigh in as bad news.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“This is, of course, still a government system where transparency is not really held up as an important criterion,” Mr. Kuijs of Oxford Economics said. “This is still an overall system in which discretionary decisions by bureaucrats are driving everything instead of very clear rules.”</p>, <p class="css-jwz2nf etfikam0">Clifford Krauss and Matt Phillips contributed reporting.</p>, <p>Advertisement</p>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd" id="site-index-label">Site Index</h2>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-0">news</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-1">opinion</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-2">arts</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-3">living</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-4">more</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-subscribe-label">Subscribe</h3>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd">Site Information Navigation</h2>]
