[<p>Advertisement</p>, <p>Supported by</p>, <h1 class="css-1s4ffep e1h9rw200" id="link-41b51e72" itemprop="headline"><span>Alarm Grows as Markets Tumble and Death Toll Rises</span></h1>, <p class="css-1ifw933 e1wiw3jv0" id="article-summary">Health officials in the United States said more than 100 people were being evaluated for possible infection. Of the nearly 3,000 people who have contracted the virus, the vast majority live in China.</p>, <p class="css-1fv7b6t e1jsehar1" itemprop="author" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">By<!-- --> <span class="css-1baulvz last-byline" itemprop="name">The New York Times</span></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">This briefing has ended. Read the latest developments in our </em><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/29/world/asia/coronavirus-china.html" title=""><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">live coronavirus outbreak coverage here</em></a><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">.</em></p>, <h2 class="css-3ez4hu eoo0vm40" id="link-81de83a">Deaths climb above 100 as China records new cases.</h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">An outbreak of a new coronavirus that began in the Chinese city of Wuhan has already killed at least 106 people in China, according to data released early Tuesday. Infections have been confirmed in many other countries. But of the 4,500 people who have so far contracted the virus, the vast majority live in China.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">◆ All but a small handful of those deaths were in the central province of Hubei, the center of the outbreak.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">◆ Officials in the capital, Beijing, which has a population of about 21 million, announced the first death in the city from coronavirus on Monday. The patient, a 50-year-old man, had traveled to Wuhan on Jan. 8 and developed a fever after returning to Beijing a week later. He was diagnosed on Jan. 22 and died of respiratory failure, the Beijing Municipal Health Commission <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="http://wjw.beijing.gov.cn/wjwh/ztzl/xxgzbd/202001/t20200127_1621454.html" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">announced</a>.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">◆ Across China there have been more than 4,500 confirmed cases. The youngest confirmed case is a 9-month-old girl in Beijing.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">◆ Thailand and Hong Kong have each reported eight cases of infection; the United States, Taiwan, Australia and Macau have five each; Singapore, Japan, South Korea and Malaysia each have reported four; France has three; Canada and Vietnam have two; and Nepal, Cambodia and Germany each have one.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">◆ There have been no deaths from the virus reported outside China.</p>, <h2 class="css-zd32qr">Wuhan Coronavirus Map: Tracking the Spread of the Outbreak</h2>, <p class="css-1uuihdo">The virus has sickened tens of thousands of people in China and a number of other countries.</p>, <h2 class="css-3ez4hu eoo0vm40" id="link-56608a2a">Stocks tumble as investors worry about the impact on global growth.</h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/28/business/coronavirus-financial-markets.html" title="">Stocks tumbled</a> and oil prices <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/27/business/stock-market-today.html" title="">fell on Monday</a> as the virus’s spread worried investors around the globe.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The S&amp;P 500 fell 1.6 percent, with shares of airlines and companies dependent on tourism from China particularly hard hit. It was the sharpest decline <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2019/10/02/business/economy/markets-world-trade.html" title="">since Oct. 2</a>, when the trade war was fanning fears of a slowdown.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">American Airlines dropped more than 4 percent in early trading, and Wynn Resorts, which operates casinos in Macau, a special administrative region of China and a gambling haven for Chinese high rollers, dropped more than 7 percent.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Major stock benchmarks in Europe were down more than 2 percent. While many markets in Asia were closed for the holiday, Tokyo’s benchmark Nikkei 225 index also sank 2 percent.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The price of oil dropped, on fears that demand could slip. China’s currency also fell, while investors moved into safe havens like gold.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">China’s economy, which is experiencing its worst slowdown in <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2019/07/14/business/china-economy-growth-gdp-trade-war.html" title="">nearly three decades</a>, is already hurting from the impact of the outbreak, and there are fears that consumer spending will go down as more residents stay home over the Lunar New Year.</p>, <h2 class="css-3ez4hu eoo0vm40" id="link-28db58a">C.D.C. urges travelers to avoid nonessential trips to China.</h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">American health officials in Washington <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://wwwnc.cdc.gov/travel/notices/warning/novel-coronavirus-china" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">issued new guidance</a> for travelers late Monday afternoon, recommending that they avoid all nonessential trips to China.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The warning, from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, notes that transportation in and out of Hubei Province may be restricted and that there is “limited access to adequate medical care in affected areas.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Health officials also counseled travelers in China to avoid contact with sick people, animal markets and uncooked meats, and to talk to their health care provider and wash hands frequently.</p>, <h2 class="css-3ez4hu eoo0vm40" id="link-13b39ff9">110 people in the United States are being evaluated for infection.</h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Some 110 patients in 26 states are being evaluated for infection with the Wuhan coronavirus, officials at the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention said on Monday.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Five of the 110 have tested positive so far, and 32 have tested negative.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“That is a cumulative number and will only increase,” said Dr. Nancy Messonnier, director of the National Center for Immunization and Respiratory Diseases.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">At the moment, the risk of infection in the United States is low. But Dr. Messonnier cautioned that information about the outbreak is changing rapidly, and the C.D.C.’s response and guidance are constantly revised.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The C.D.C. continues to screen passengers arriving in the United States whose travel originated in Wuhan. Officials are considering broadening the effort and revising official guidance on travel to the region, Dr. Messonnier said.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Dr. Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus, director-general of the World Health Organization, has arrived in Beijing to “understand the latest developments and strengthen our partnership with China in providing further protection against the outbreak,” he said in a <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://twitter.com/DrTedros/status/1221479565043912705" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">tweet</a>.</p>, <h1 class="g-headline" id="g-inlineguide-headline">The Coronavirus Outbreak</h1>, <h2 class="g-inlineguide-list-header g-optimize-type">What do you need to know? Start here.</h2>, <p class="g-inlineguide-date">Updated Feb. 10, 2020</p>, <h2 class="css-3ez4hu eoo0vm40" id="link-3d263b9c">New York City is bracing for the coronavirus: ‘It’s inevitable.’</h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The city’s top health official, Dr. Oxiris Barbot, said that it was only a matter of time <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/27/nyregion/new-york-city-coronavirus.html" title="">before someone in the city tests positive</a> for the virus.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Hospitals have been on the lookout for patients with recent travel involving Wuhan, the Chinese city where the coronavirus is believed to have originated. And they have urged anyone who recently traveled there — or who have been in contact with someone who has — to quickly seek medical care if they have any respiratory or flulike symptoms.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">So far, of nine patients for whom New York State officials have sought testing from the <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/topic/organization/centers-for-disease-control-and-prevention" title="">Centers for Disease Control and Prevention</a>, four were found not to have the virus, and the tests involving the other five are pending, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo said Monday in a statement.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">When the first case in New York does arrive, health officials said, that patient may end up in a biocontainment unit in Bellevue Hospital or sent home to ride out the illness in their bedroom. That will depend largely on how sick they are, public health officials say.</p>, <h2 class="css-3ez4hu eoo0vm40" id="link-2799107a">Canadian officials believe they’ve identified a second case of the new coronavirus</h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Health officials identified a “presumptive” second case of the new virus: the wife of the first identified case, a man who was hospitalized on Jan. 23. The couple had returned to Toronto after visiting Wuhan a day earlier.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The woman’s symptoms were not severe enough to require hospitalization, Dr. Barbara Yaffe, the province’s associate chief medical officer of health, said at a news conference. She was in isolation at home.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The man is in his 50s and is now in stable condition. Laboratory tests confirmed that he was infected with the new coronavirus, and tests are pending for his wife, officials said.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Health officials are now tracking down people who sat near the couple on a flight to Toronto from Guangzhou, and questioning the travel history of people seeking medical help for respiratory problems around Ontario, Dr. Yaffe said.</p>, <h2 class="css-3ez4hu eoo0vm40" id="link-29ab6cb5">Social media users criticize the Chinese government’s response.</h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The Chinese government usually keeps a tight grip on what is said, seen and heard about it. But <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/27/technology/china-coronavirus-censorship-social-media.html" title="">criticism on social media</a> over its handling of the coronavirus outbreak has been difficult to contain.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Some critics of the government have found clever ways to dodge censors, such as referring to Xi Jinping as “Trump” or comparing the outbreak to the Chernobyl catastrophe.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The vitriol has been most intense in Hubei, the home province of Wuhan. After the provincial governor, Wang Xiaodong, gave a news briefing on Sunday, online commenters mocked Mr. Wang for misstating the number of face masks that the province could produce.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">They also circulated a photo from the briefing of him and two other officials, pointing out that one of them did not cover his nose with his mask. Another wore his mask upside down, and Mr. Wang did not wear a mask at all.</p>, <h2 class="css-3ez4hu eoo0vm40" id="link-4060c50">The crisis has turned a spotlight on China’s overburdened health system.</h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The Chinese health care system strains to serve patients even under normal circumstances. Those weaknesses are most pronounced in the poorer areas of China — <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/27/world/asia/27china-coronavirus-health.html" title="">like Wuhan, the epicenter of the coronavirus outbreak.</a></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Panicked residents of the city are heading to the hospitals if they have any sign of a cold or cough.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Videos circulating on Chinese social media show doctors straining to handle the enormous workload and hospital corridors loaded with patients, some of whom appear to be dead. Wuhan hospitals have posted messages online urgently appealing for medical equipment. The situation is even more desperate in nearby rural areas.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Yanzhong Huang, a senior fellow for global health at the Council on Foreign Relations, said China had invested a lot in building infrastructure to deal with infectious diseases.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“But they apparently didn’t anticipate something so sudden, so acute, and so tremendous,” he said.</p>, <h2 class="css-3ez4hu eoo0vm40" id="link-1843ec90">Some public health experts are skeptical of China’s efforts to contain the virus</h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">China’s efforts to contain the spread of the disease by keeping tens of millions of people corralled in the major cities in Hubei Province have drawn skepticism from some experts in public health and epidemiology.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The lockdown will pose tremendous challenges, starting with getting food, fuel and medical care to those affected.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“At this stage of the outbreak, the things that make the most difference are finding people, diagnosing people, and getting them isolated,” said Dr. Tom Inglesby, an infectious diseases specialist and director of the Johns Hopkins Center for Health Security.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“If you isolate the city, then my question and my concern is that you’re making it harder in a number of ways to do those things you need to do,” including getting sick people to the hospital and getting supplies into medical facilities, he said.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Other experts said that the travel restrictions had probably come too late and that the barriers would prove too permeable. Five million people had left Wuhan before travel out of the city was restricted, said the city’s mayor, Zhou Xianwang.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“You can’t board up a germ,” said Lawrence O. Gostin, a law professor at Georgetown University and director of the O’Neill Institute for National and Global Health Law. “A novel infection will spread.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Some experts, however, said the lockdowns could help, at least in theory.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“Anything that is done that increases social distancing can help decrease the spread of the virus,” said Dr. Thomas R. Frieden, a former director of the United States Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. “If you do it right, it’s not impossible it will have positive impact.”</p>, <h2 class="css-3ez4hu eoo0vm40" id="link-44aeed45">Hong Kong hospitals in turmoil as workers prepare for possible coronavirus cases.</h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Hospital workers in Hong Kong are trying to prepare for an outbreak of coronavirus cases — with memories of the SARS epidemic of the early 2000s still fresh.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">In the past week, doctors and nurses have drawn straws to determine when they would work in coronavirus isolation wards for six-week shifts. A hospital rearranged its cafeteria so that all tables faced the walls, a precaution from the SARS era to prevent employees from infecting each other during their meals.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The SARS outbreak killed eight medical workers in the city. Some still suffer from lung damage 17 years later.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Many hospital workers are calling for stricter border checks as Lunar New Year holidays come to a close this week, and a wave of visitors and residents are expected to return from the mainland.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">A new union, HA Employees Alliance, threatened to go on strike if the government did not close its borders to the mainland.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Arisina Ma, the president of the Hong Kong Public Doctors’ Association, called for stricter border checks, and for possibly requiring visitors and residents to stay home for 14 days, the incubation period for the disease, after returning from the mainland.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“We are waiting for the worst to come,” she added. “Of course we will try to stop it but I am not sure if our government is efficient and determined enough to stop the worst to come.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">At the same time, the city’s hospitals are still reeling from the anti-government protests that flooded their wards with patients over the past seven months.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Early Monday morning, hours after protesters set fire to unused public housing units designated to be medical quarantine areas, a handmade bomb exploded inside a hospital toilet cubicle, a police official said. The two small explosions filled the emergency ward with smoke but caused no injuries.</p>, <h2 class="css-3ez4hu eoo0vm40" id="link-15538d14">Wuhan mayor claims responsibility and offers to resign.</h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Wuhan’s top government and Communist Party officials offered to step down on Monday amid growing criticism in the city that the local authorities’ response to the outbreak was too slow.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Mayor Zhou Xianwang said in an interview with the state broadcaster CCTV that he and Ma Guoqiang, the city’s party secretary, would take responsibility for the crisis and resign to “appease public indignation.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“Our names will live in infamy, but as long as it is conducive to the control of the disease and to the people’s lives and safety, Comrade Ma Guoqiang and I will bear any responsibility,” Mr. Zhou said in the interview.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Medical workers in the city have accused the local government of reacting too slowly to the crisis, and residents have used social media to complain about a ban on travel that has made it difficult to get access to food and health care.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The mayor defended the travel ban, which was enacted last week and effectively cut off the city of 11 million people. He called the restriction “unprecedented in human history.”</p>, <h2 class="css-3ez4hu eoo0vm40" id="link-4b8c0af4">China’s No. 2 official visits Wuhan as anger at the government grows.</h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">China’s second-highest ranking official, Premier Li Keqiang, on Monday visited Wuhan to inspect local efforts to contain the disease, the government said.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">In pictures released by the state-run news media, Mr. Li is seen wearing a face mask and a blue protective gown while posing for photos with health workers. He was also seen speaking with a patient in an isolation ward via video conference.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The premier’s visit comes as the central government is under increasing pressure to prove it is adequately coping with the crisis.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">On Saturday, Xi Jinping, China’s leader, convened a meeting of the Politburo’s standing committee, the senior-most executive body of the Chinese Communist Party, as a demonstration of the government’s hands-on approach to the outbreak.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Hospitals in Wuhan have posted messages online urgently appealing for medical equipment. Mr. Li, who has been assigned to oversee the national response to the outbreak, pledged to provide Wuhan’s health centers with 20,000 pairs of safety goggles.</p>, <h2 class="css-3ez4hu eoo0vm40" id="link-e72f7d6">China extends long Lunar New Year holiday to limit travel.</h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Trying to temporarily limit travel, the Chinese government extended the weeklong Lunar New Year holiday by three days, meaning it will go through next Sunday rather than ending on Thursday. Workers will return to work on Feb. 3.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The holiday, China’s biggest annual celebration, began on Friday, the eve of the Lunar New Year.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Hundreds of millions of Chinese people travel during the holiday, either for tourism or to visit family. The week, known in China as Spring Festival, typically includes large public events, but many festivities have been canceled this year.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Many tourist attractions have been shuttered including the Disney theme parks in Shanghai and Hong Kong, along with the Forbidden City and sections of the Great Wall in Beijing.</p>, <h2 class="css-3ez4hu eoo0vm40" id="link-49d58eb2">Wuhan residents venture outside only out of necessity or boredom.</h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Residents of Wuhan have largely hunkered down to quietly wait out the crisis, mostly staying inside their homes, and venturing out only for supplies and food, medical visits and occasional bursts of exercise away from other people.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Cities, towns and even villages have erected checkpoints and roadblocks intended to ward off any outsiders who might carry the coronavirus.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">On Monday, most shops remained closed, but supermarkets, fresh produce stores and pharmacies remained open — although many pharmacies have run out of protective masks, hand disinfectant and other supplies intended to protect against the virus.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Residents with fevers and coughs who worried that they may have contracted the coronavirus continued to line up at clinics and hospitals, but in fewer numbers than on previous days. The streets were mostly free of cars, and many residents walked or rode bicycles to do their shopping.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“It’s possible to live, but it’s not a real New Year,” said Qiu Dongjun, 38, a construction worker from rural Hubei Province who was carrying a bagful of shopping, mostly instant noodles and tins of precooked porridge.</p>, <h2 class="css-3ez4hu eoo0vm40" id="link-72a33225">A dark humor emerges on social media.</h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">As health officials race to contain the dangerous virus, social media users in China are responding to the outbreak with dashes of gallows humor.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">On the messaging platform WeChat, people circulated images of improvised face masks made of plastic water jugs. One video on WeChat and the social platform Weibo showed a group of people playing mah-jongg, the popular tile-based game, while wearing what appeared to be plastic bags over their heads.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Another video on WeChat appeared to show a person emerging from an airport baggage claim clad in a full-body space alien costume, complete with green skin and bulging eyes.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Masks are a common motif in virus-related memes. They have been added to traditional greetings exchanged for the Lunar New Year, and photoshopped into classic paintings like Vermeer’s “Girl With a Pearl Earring.” They appear in propaganda posters done in the style of the Mao era and updated to reflect the times.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">A video on Twitter appeared to show a taxi driver wearing goggles and a hazmat suit while taking a woman to the airport.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The woman asks the driver whether his outfit might scare off potential fares. He replies serenely: “Safety first, right?”</p>, <h2 class="css-3ez4hu eoo0vm40" id="link-128a01a2">Foreign governments make plans to evacuate citizens.</h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Foreign governments with nationals stranded in Wuhan scrambled to evacuate their citizens from the epicenter of the outbreak, even as China imposed official travel bans.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The State Department said it had chartered a flight to take consular staff members and other American citizens to San Francisco from Wuhan on Tuesday. The department said priority would be given to those at greater risk from contracting the virus because of the flight’s “extremely limited” capacity.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">At least one American, a father of three young children, declined the offer after the United States government said his wife, a Chinese national, would not be offered a seat.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">France, Japan, Spain and Sri Lanka also said they would bring home nationals. Once in France, evacuated nationals would be required to spend 14 days in quarantine.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Russia was in talks with China about evacuating its citizens, local news media reported. Russian tour operators have stopped selling trips to China following recommendations from the country’s tourism watchdog and would work only to evacuate travelers, Reuters reported.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"> </p>, <h2 class="css-3ez4hu eoo0vm40" id="link-3dddcf6e">Why is there so much concern?</h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Though the number of coronavirus cases and deaths is alarming, public health experts have so far warned against mass anxiety. After all, the common flu kills roughly 35,000 people a year and hospitalizes about 200,000 in the United States alone.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">It is too soon to know the mortality rate of the virus in the new outbreak. But there are signs that this outbreak could be far more serious than the common flu.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">For one, other coronaviruses have far higher mortality rates than the common flu, and have also led to global outbreaks.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Chinese citizens are also haunted by the memory of the SARS epidemic in 2002 and 2003, a coronavirus outbreak that also started in China and eventually killed more than 800 people worldwide. During that epidemic, Beijing at first played down the crisis and withheld information, eventually drawing widespread criticism.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">And conclusive evidence about how the outbreak started is lacking. While officials in Wuhan first traced it to a seafood market, some patients who have fallen ill never visited the market. Researchers have also offered disparate explanations for what animals may have transmitted the virus to humans.</p>, <h2 class="css-3ez4hu eoo0vm40" id="link-6fdd04bf">Bureaucracy slowed the response to an emerging crisis.</h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The coronavirus outbreak seemed to be a <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/08/health/china-pneumonia-outbreak-virus.html" title="">full-blown crisis</a> by the time the first news reports emerged: Dozens of people had been infected, <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/15/world/asia/coronavirus-japan-china.html" title="">even some abroad</a>.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Though China’s initial delay in reporting cases of the new virus may suggest a cover-up, experts see something more worrying: <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/25/world/asia/coronavirus-crisis-china-response.html" title="">weaknesses at the heart of the Chinese political system</a>.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">China’s rigid bureaucracy discourages local officials from raising bad news with central bosses, and it silos officials off from one another, making it harder to manage, or even see, a crisis in the making.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“That’s why you never really hear about problems emerging on a local scale in China,” said John Yasuda, who studies China’s approach to health crises at Indiana University. “By the time that we hear about it, and that the problem reaches the central government, it’s because it’s become a huge problem.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Those systemic flaws appear to have played a role in the pace at which officials responded to the outbreak, and the country’s inability to address the health risks from its so-called <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/25/world/asia/china-markets-coronavirus-sars.html" title="">wet markets</a>, which are stuffed with livestock living and dead, domesticated and wild.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">China is now mobilizing a nationwide response involving hundreds of personnel, one of the system’s strengths. But the country’s political weaknesses can have serious consequences for the world. Disease and pollution don’t respect borders, so a unified national policy is typically needed to prevent or stop them.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">For any health or environmental regulation to work, Mr. Yasuda said, “you want it to be standardized, you want it to be transparent, you want it to be accountable.”</p>, <p class="css-jwz2nf etfikam0">Reporting was contributed by Elaine Yu, Russell Goldman, Alexandra Stevenson, Tiffany May, Steven Lee Myers, Vivian Wang, Chris Buckley, Raymond Zhong, Denise Grady, Roni Caryn Rabin, Sheri Fink, Katie Robertson, Sui-Lee Wee, Ian Austen and Karen Zraick. Zoe Mou, Albee Zhang, Amber Wang, Yiwei Wang and Claire Fu contributed research.</p>, <p>Advertisement</p>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd" id="site-index-label">Site Index</h2>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-0">news</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-1">opinion</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-2">arts</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-3">living</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-4">more</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-subscribe-label">Subscribe</h3>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd">Site Information Navigation</h2>]
[<p>Advertisement</p>, <p>Supported by</p>, <h1 class="css-1s4ffep e1h9rw200" id="link-607e8ac" itemprop="headline"><span>Chinese Officials Race to Contain Anger Over Virus</span></h1>, <p class="css-1ifw933 e1wiw3jv0" id="article-summary">With public fury rising, the government acted on several fronts to show resolve in the face of the gravest political crisis in years.</p>, <p class="css-1fv7b6t e1jsehar1" itemprop="author" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">By<!-- --> <a class="css-brehiz e1jsehar0" href="https://www.nytimes.com/by/chris-buckley"><span class="css-1baulvz" itemprop="name">Chris Buckley</span></a> and <a class="css-brehiz e1jsehar0" href="https://www.nytimes.com/by/steven-lee-myers"><span class="css-1baulvz last-byline" itemprop="name">Steven Lee Myers</span></a></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">WUHAN, China — The Chinese government scrambled to contain not only the coronavirus epidemic but also growing expressions of public fury over the management of the crisis as the death toll rose on Tuesday to at least 106.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">China’s National Immigration Administration on Tuesday encouraged Chinese citizens to reconsider the timing of overseas travel to curtail the spread of the coronavirus, it said on its WeChat account. That came as the United States Centers for Disease Control and Prevention urged American citizens to <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://wwwnc.cdc.gov/travel/notices/warning/novel-coronavirus-china" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">avoid nonessential travel to China</a>. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Premier Li Keqiang, the prime minister of the Chinese government, flew on Monday into Wuhan, the epicenter of the outbreak, to show support for medical workers and to pledge needed medical supplies — only to be mocked online for leading workers in an encouraging cheer.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Mr. Li’s visit, which featured prominently in state media, came as Wuhan’s mayor, Zhou Xianwang, acknowledged that the local authorities had moved too slowly in the first days of the crisis.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">In an interview with CCTV, the main state television network, the mayor said that information about the coronavirus had not been shared with the public in a timely manner, and that he and the city’s Communist Party secretary, Ma Guoqiang, were prepared to resign to “appease public indignation.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“Our names will live in infamy for shutting the door” of the city, Mr. Zhou said. “But we believe that as long as it helps to control the disease, helps keep people’s lives safe, Comrade Ma Guoqiang and I will shoulder any responsibility,” Mr. Zhou said.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The offer to resign, which was not immediately acted on, suggested that China’s harshly practical party hierarchy could settle on local officials like the mayor and the party secretary as sacrifices to ease public ire over a <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/26/world/asia/china-coronavirus-xi-jinping.html" title="">spiraling public health crisis</a> that also threatens to take a large economic toll.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">With the death toll rising to at least 106, and infections spreading to still more countries, the impacts reverberated globally. <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/27/business/stock-market-today.html?searchResultPosition=1" title="">Stocks tumbled and oil prices fell on Monday</a> as the virus’s spread worried investors worldwide.</p>, <h2 class="css-zd32qr">Wuhan Coronavirus Map: Tracking the Spread of the Outbreak</h2>, <p class="css-1uuihdo">The virus has sickened tens of thousands of people in China and a number of other countries.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The S&amp;P 500 fell 1.6 percent, its sharpest decline in nearly four months, with shares of airlines and companies dependent on tourism from China particularly hard hit.</p>, <h1 class="g-headline" id="g-inlineguide-headline">The Coronavirus Outbreak</h1>, <h2 class="g-inlineguide-list-header g-optimize-type">What do you need to know? Start here.</h2>, <p class="g-inlineguide-date">Updated Feb. 10, 2020</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Major stock benchmarks in Europe were down more than 2 percent. While many markets in Asia were closed for the holiday, Tokyo’s benchmark Nikkei 225 index sank 2 percent.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">China’s currency also fell, while investors moved into safe havens like gold.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">In China, the government announced that it would extend for three days the weeklong holiday for the Lunar New Year, which had been scheduled to end on Thursday. The country’s economy, which is experiencing its worst slowdown in <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2019/07/14/business/china-economy-growth-gdp-trade-war.html" title="">nearly three decades</a>, is already hurting from the impact of the outbreak, and there are fears that consumer spending will fall as residents stay home over the extended holiday.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">In Beijing, where 72 cases had been reported by Monday morning, officials warned that anyone who returned to the city from other parts of China must confine themselves to their homes for 14 days.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">That could significantly reduce the city’s work force even after the extended holiday ends. Hundreds of millions of people travel during the holiday, which began on Saturday, and would normally begin returning in the coming days.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">In Shanghai, the country’s financial center, the authorities ordered businesses to stay closed until midnight on Feb. 9. In nearby Suzhou, a large manufacturing hub, businesses there were ordered to open no sooner than Feb. 8. Some companies, including the internet giant Tencent, also told their workers to stay home until Feb. 10.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The epidemic has already shuttered many major tourist attractions, including the Disney theme parks in Shanghai and Hong Kong, as well as the Forbidden City and sections of the Great Wall outside of Beijing.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Major film studios postponed the opening of movies at what would normally have been a peak viewing season, while <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://supchina.com/2020/01/26/cba-prepares-for-indefinite-hiatus-due-to-coronavirus/" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">several sporting events</a> were canceled or postponed. China’s professional basketball league, the C.B.A., announced that it would suspend its season indefinitely.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The crisis has emerged as an unexpected challenge for the Communist Party leadership, especially for President Xi Jinping, who said nothing in public about the matter until he convened an extraordinary meeting of the party’s Politburo Standing Committee on Saturday.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Mr. Li, an economist who has been premier since 2013, has taken the formal lead of China’s crisis management team for the epidemic. But the much more powerful Mr. Xi, who is also the Communist Party leader, has signaled that he is the real power in charge.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Only days earlier, Mr. Li had reflected less urgency about the viral outbreak when discussing it — without wearing a medical mask — while meeting medical workers in faraway Qinghai province.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">On Monday, by contrast, he made several appearances around Wuhan, visiting a hospital, where he promised to deliver 20,000 surgical masks, and a supermarket, where — now wearing a mask — he led workers in a chant.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“Wuhan,” he said. “Jia you,” they responded in chorus, using a phrase that means “add oil” but is roughly translated as a rousing “Go!”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">On Twitter, which is blocked in China, the gesture was mocked. “Wuhan pneumonia is afraid of slogans,” one user <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://twitter.com/dorjee106/status/1221688326090121221" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">posted</a> in Chinese.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Wuhan’s residents have largely hunkered down to quietly wait out the epidemic. They mostly stay inside their homes, venturing out for supplies and food, medical visits and occasional bursts of exercise.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Still, several said they had heard about Mr. Li’s visit and welcomed it as a sign that the central leadership was committed to supporting the city and surrounding areas, which have been locked down since last week.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“This shows that they’re getting serious,” said Shao Shigui, a retired steelworker from southwest China who was strolling on a promenade by the Yangtze River. He had come to Wuhan with his wife to help their daughter, who is pregnant, and said he was taking a break from the monotony of staying indoors.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“In China, if a leader visits, that shows that all the resources of the government can be mobilized,” he said.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The United States, Japan, France, Russia and other countries, meanwhile, scrambled to get citizens who were trapped in the city out, after the government shut down the major modes of transportation.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Since then the city of 11 million has descended into a surreal quiet — except around the hospitals.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Most shops remained closed, but supermarkets, fresh produce stores and pharmacies opened, although many pharmacies have run out of protective masks, hand disinfectant and other supplies needed to protect against the virus.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Residents with fevers and coughs who worried that they may have contracted the coronavirus continued to line up at clinics and hospitals, but in fewer numbers than previous days. The streets were mostly free of cars, and many residents walked or rode bicycles to do their shopping.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“It’s possible to live, but it’s not a real New Year,” said Qiu Dongjun, a 38-year-old construction worker from rural Hubei who was carrying a bag of groceries. “I’ve been eating so many containers of instant noodles that my mouth and nose are flaming raw.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">He said Mr. Li’s visit was a promising political gesture.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“People in Wuhan have many practical problems,” he said. “How will our wages get paid? What if businesses go under? Who will ensure we get our unpaid wages? These are practical problems,” he said, his voice partly muffled by his protective mask.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“You can’t expect all those problems to be solved in Beijing,” he said before walking off.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The mayor of Wuhan, Mr. Zhou, defended his actions even as he accepted responsibility for falling short. He said he had been hampered from alerting the public sooner because of the reporting rules under the laws governing disease outbreaks. He suggested he had to wait for approval from higher-level officials.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">One woman <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://m.weibo.cn/status/4465451050100687?" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">responded angrily</a> in the comments page below the People’s Daily’s live stream of the mayor’s interview on Weibo, the popular Chinese social media platform. She noted that the government had informed the World Health Organization on Dec. 31, but not the public most directly affected until Jan. 20.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“The Wuhan government will be condemned throughout the ages if it turns the map of China all red,” she wrote, referring to maps depicting the spread of the virus.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">After weeks of limited steps before the gravity of the epidemic was recognized, government agencies have galvanized to fight the crisis, setting aside other priorities for now.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The China Banking and Insurance Regulatory Commission said <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="http://www.cbirc.gov.cn/cn/view/pages/ItemDetail.html?docId=888850&amp;itemId=915" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">in a notice dated Sunday</a> that banks “must not blindly call in loans, cut off lending or hold off on lending” in response to the crisis.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">On Monday, State Grid, the government-controlled electricity provider, said it would halt the shut-off of electricity to residents whose bills fall into arrears while authorities deal with the outbreak.</p>, <p class="css-jwz2nf etfikam0">Chris Buckley reported from Wuhan and Steven Lee Myers from Beijing. Raymond Zhong, Alexandra Stevenson and Katie Robertson contributed reporting. Elsie Chen, Claire Fu, Zoe Mou and Elaine Yu contributed research.</p>, <p>Advertisement</p>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd" id="site-index-label">Site Index</h2>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-0">news</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-1">opinion</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-2">arts</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-3">living</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-4">more</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-subscribe-label">Subscribe</h3>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd">Site Information Navigation</h2>]
[<p>Advertisement</p>, <p>Supported by</p>, <h1 class="css-1qskr30 e1h9rw200" id="link-2756fce0" itemprop="headline"><span>Will the Largest Quarantine in History Just Make Things Worse?</span></h1>, <p class="css-1ifw933 e1wiw3jv0" id="article-summary">The dirty history behind isolating the sick.</p>, <p class="css-1fv7b6t e1jsehar1" itemprop="author" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">By<!-- --> <span class="css-1baulvz last-byline" itemprop="name">Howard Markel</span></p>, <p class="css-cpkn1d e1wtpvyy1">Dr. Markel is a professor of the history of medicine.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">It’s the <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/22/world/asia/coronavirus-quarantines-history.html" title="">largest quarantine in human history</a>, but will it stop the disease?</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">In response to the new and still poorly understood coronavirus that recently emerged in Wuhan, central China, the Chinese government has placed the city and a dozen others in lockdown — in effect quarantining <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/26/world/asia/coronavirus-wuhan-china-hubei.html" title="">an estimated 56 million people</a>.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The cities have been sealed off; transportation in and out of them has stopped. Schools are closed, and traditional celebrations for the Lunar New Year have been suspended. Yet as of Monday, at least 80 people had died, more than 2,740 were confirmed to have been infected and cases had been detected in <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2020/01/21/world/asia/china-coronavirus-maps.html" title="">at least 10 other countries</a>.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Other governments have taken similar measures. Hong Kong has banned the arrival of travelers from Hubei Province, where Wuhan is located, and has set up <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.scmp.com/video/china/3047578/hong-kong-sets-coronavirus-quarantine-centres-two-holiday-villages" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">isolation centers in two holiday villages</a> to monitor people who have had contact with carriers of the virus.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Zhong Nanshan, of China’s National Health Commission, is reported to have said that <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/asia_pacific/chinese-officials-urge-people-not-to-travel-in-and-out-of-city-at-center-of-virus-outbreak/2020/01/21/60680d3e-3c2d-11ea-afe2-090eb37b60b1_story.html" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">the most effective way</a> to stop the virus, which appears to be spread by droplets, was a quarantine.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Is it, though?</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">In Wuhan, a city of 11 million, both patients who believe they have been infected by the coronavirus and people with other medical problems are having difficulty seeing doctors: Shortages are common at such times, and quarantines only compound them. Residents are complaining on social media about <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/24/world/asia/china-social-media-coronavirus.html" title="">inadequate care</a>. Distrust of the health authorities is mounting.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">And then, of course, overcrowding at hospitals, which mixes some presumably sick people with the healthy, increases the risks of transmission.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Some people may have tried to escape the stricken cities for less-infected areas. Others may be hiding from public health workers. A woman from Wuhan, apparently eager to stick to her travel plans for Lunar New Year, reportedly <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.scmp.com/news/china/society/article/3047334/chinese-told-comply-airport-coronavirus-checks-after-woman?utm_content=article&amp;utm_medium=Social&amp;utm_source=Twitter#Echobox=1579763656" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">cheated a health check</a> by taking fever-reducing drugs to bring her temperature down — and then admitted doing so on social media after she had arrived in France.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">An integral failing of most quarantines is that some people, seeing the restrictions as overly strict and an imposition on their rights, will invariably try to bypass them. Their evasion, in turn, can endanger public health.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">So, do quarantines contain a disease or might they actually contribute to spreading it?</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">China’s health authorities will probably eventually argue that there would have been many more cases had they not locked down cities. But that claim is a negative that cannot be proved. And in my opinion, at this stage, the quarantines decreed by the Chinese government will not help end the crisis.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">More often than not, health officials are several steps behind a spreading epidemic. And when they aren’t, the history books show, they tend to act too fast (costing a fortune) or unfairly (discriminating against some populations).</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Quarantine laws — from the Italian “quaranta giorni,” meaning 40 days<em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0"> </em>— were first developed in Venice in 1370, to keep the bubonic plague at bay by banning any ships and goods for the time it seemed to take most epidemics to burn themselves out. The measures’ effectiveness then was never studied, yet the practice was refined over time. During the industrial age, for example, European nations reinforced quarantines with “cordons sanitaires” — a ring of armed guards preventing the entry or exit of anyone deemed or feared ill with an epidemic disease.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">By the 19th century, many major cities in Europe and the United States had a “lazaretto” — a remote island or containment facility to isolate the sick and those suspected of being sick. Before the advent of effective vaccines, intravenous fluids and other medication, the people who were segregated were rarely cared for, and many died. In numerous instances, too, quarantines were used to separate people considered to be dirty or undesirable.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">In January 1892, an epidemic of deadly typhus fever broke out among Russian Jewish immigrants settled in boardinghouses on the Lower East Side in New York City. The local Health Department rounded them up, along with other Jewish residents who happened to live nearby. Hundreds of immigrants — but no other New Yorkers who were ill or suspected of being ill — were quarantined in tents on North Brother Island in the East River. Some contracted typhus as a result of being crowded in with the sick.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Later that year, New York State’s quarantine officer, William Jenkins, diverted to remote islands hundreds of impoverished East European, Jewish passengers coming from Europe and Asia in the steerage section of ships. The measure was designed to forestall the spread of an outbreak of cholera that had originated in Hamburg, Germany, then the largest port in the world — only it did not apply to first-class passengers. Dr. Jenkins was thought to have overshot, was roundly criticized and eventually lost his job.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">In 1900, the San Francisco authorities responded to a bubonic plague epidemic by quarantining buildings in Chinatown mostly occupied by Chinese immigrants. They did not, however, quarantine native-born Americans who lived directly across the street. Some doctors claimed the plague was a disease of “rice eaters,” not “meat eaters.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The 1918-19 influenza pandemic killed an estimated 50 million people worldwide, including up to 750,000 in the United States. In 2007, I led a group of researchers to study <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://scholar.google.com/scholar_url?url=https://jamanetwork.com/journals/jama/articlepdf/208354/joc70085_644_654.pdf&amp;hl=en&amp;sa=T&amp;oi=ucasa&amp;ct=ufr&amp;ei=NyguXpvYFpC-yQSizpWIDA&amp;scisig=AAGBfm0KQ36nMkCSF97NGTYf5wA43hKX5w" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">the use of what we called non-pharmaceutical interventions</a> in America. We looked at 43 large cities that employed some combination of (1) isolating the ill or suspected cases in hospitals or at home, (2) banning public gatherings and, in some cases, shutting down roads and railways, and (3) closing schools.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">We found that in the cities that acted early, for sustained periods, and that simultaneously used more than one measure, rates of morbidity and mortality were lower than in the cities that did not take such measures. <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/17684187" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">We concluded</a> that in the face of a severe influenza pandemic, non-pharmaceutical interventions should be considered to complement vaccines, prophylactic medication and treatment — though only as a last resort and only for a highly lethal infection because they are extremely disruptive to society.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">In 2009, during the first days of an H1N1 influenza outbreak in Mexico, the Health Ministry immediately <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://jamanetwork.com/journals/jama/article-abstract/184560" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">deployed a spate of 1918-style measures</a>. Suspected cases were isolated. Schools were closed. Public gatherings were banned, including a regional soccer tournament.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Although those moves did work to limit new cases of influenza, they were <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3101203/" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">abandoned 18 days later</a>, partly because of the huge social and economic costs. More important, even as the H1N1 influenza virus circulated widely — the outbreak was, indeed, a pandemic — it turned out to not be nearly as <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.cdc.gov/flu/spotlights/pandemic-global-estimates.htm?" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">deadly</a> as <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.cdc.gov/flu/about/burden/index.html" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">a garden-variety seasonal flu</a>. (The common flu kills about 35,000 people a year in the United States alone.) The Mexican government concluded, appropriately, that the stringent measures it had adopted should be lifted given the disease’s relatively limited total toll — <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3202315/" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">between 4,200 and 12,000 dead</a> in the end — even if it might keep spreading.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Early during an epidemic, it may seem reasonable to try to contain it by imposing social-distancing measures as quickly as possible and then release the throttle if evidence suggests those may be overkill. Incremental restrictions, enforced steadily and transparently, tend to work far better than draconian measures, particularly at enlisting the public’s cooperation, which is especially important for properly handling outbreaks in our interconnected, globalized world.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Today, China is adopting classic quarantine measures but on a scale never before seen, let alone studied. Its reaction is perhaps understandable, given the searing memory of the SARS epidemic of 2002-3 and the criticism that was directed at the government for its early attempts to conceal or minimize the extent of the disease. But it may now be overreacting, and after the coronavirus epidemic’s inflection point, imposing an unjustifiable burden on the population.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">In the early days of any epidemic, even as leaders come under great pressure to do something, little critical information is available to make truly informed decisions about the best course of action. At this stage of the Wuhan case, though, the virus has already spread, and according to local authorities, <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.scmp.com/news/china/society/article/3047720/chinese-premier-li-keqiang-head-coronavirus-crisis-team-outbreak" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">some five million people left the city</a> after the beginning of the outbreak and before the lockdown.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Given that, China should be prescribing that its citizens remain calm, stay at home if they are sick, practice good hand-washing and respiratory hygiene, and avoid crowded places, if possible. It must also step up health care measures to tend to both the ill and the worried well.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">With the Wuhan coronavirus, as with other epidemics past, quarantine measures may be too much too late.</p>, <p class="css-jwz2nf etfikam0">Howard Markel is the George E. Wantz Distinguished Professor of the History of Medicine at the University of Michigan and the author of “Quarantine!” and “When Germs Travel.”</p>, <p class="css-jwz2nf etfikam0"><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">The Times is committed to publishing </em><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2019/01/31/opinion/letters/letters-to-editor-new-york-times-women.html" title=""><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">a diversity of letters</em></a><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0"> to the editor. We’d like to hear what you think about this or any of our articles. Here are some </em><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://help.nytimes.com/hc/en-us/articles/115014925288-How-to-submit-a-letter-to-the-editor" title=""><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">tips</em></a><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">. And here’s our email: </em><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="mailto:letters@nytimes.com" title=""><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">letters@nytimes.com</em></a><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">.</em></p>, <p class="css-jwz2nf etfikam0"><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">Follow The New York Times Opinion section on </em><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.facebook.com/nytopinion" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title=""><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">Facebook</em></a><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">, </em><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="http://twitter.com/NYTOpinion" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title=""><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">Twitter (@NYTopinion)</em></a><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0"> and </em><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.instagram.com/nytopinion/" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title=""><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">Instagram</em></a><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">.</em></p>, <p>Advertisement</p>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd" id="site-index-label">Site Index</h2>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-0">news</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-1">opinion</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-2">arts</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-3">living</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-4">more</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-subscribe-label">Subscribe</h3>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd">Site Information Navigation</h2>]
[<p>Advertisement</p>, <p>Supported by</p>, <h1 class="css-1s4ffep e1h9rw200" id="link-3fec7270" itemprop="headline"><span>As Virus Spreads, Anger Floods Chinese Social Media</span></h1>, <p class="css-1ifw933 e1wiw3jv0" id="article-summary">The sheer volume of criticism of the government, and the sometimes clever ways that critics dodge censors, are testing Beijing’s ability to control the narrative.</p>, <p class="css-1fv7b6t e1jsehar1" itemprop="author" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">By<!-- --> <a class="css-brehiz e1jsehar0" href="https://www.nytimes.com/by/raymond-zhong"><span class="css-1baulvz last-byline" itemprop="name">Raymond Zhong</span></a></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">SHANGHAI — Recently, someone following the coronavirus crisis through China’s official news media would see lots of footage, often set to stirring music, praising the heroism and sacrifice of health workers marching off to stricken places.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">But someone following <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/28/business/coronavirus-financial-markets.html" title="">the crisis</a> through social media would see something else entirely: vitriolic comments and mocking memes about government officials, harrowing descriptions of untreated family members and images of hospital corridors loaded with patients, some of whom appear to be dead.</p>, <p dir="ltr" lang="en">137 medical personnel head for Hubei from north China's Shanxi <a href="https://t.co/nxSe01dyEO">pic.twitter.com/nxSe01dyEO</a></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The contrast is almost never so stark in China. The government usually keeps a tight grip on what is said, seen and heard about it. But the sheer amount of criticism — and the often clever ways in which critics dodge censors, such as by referring to Xi Jinping, China’s top leader, as “Trump” or by comparing the outbreak to the Chernobyl catastrophe — have made it difficult for Beijing to control the message.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">In recent days, critics have pounced when officials in the city of Wuhan, the center of the outbreak, wore their protective masks incorrectly. They have heaped scorn upon stumbling pronouncements. When Wuhan’s mayor spoke to official media on Monday, one commenter responded, “If the virus is fair, then please don’t spare this useless person.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The condemnations stand as a rare direct challenge to the Communist Party, which brooks no dissent in the way it runs China. In some cases, Chinese leaders appear to be acknowledging people’s fear, anger and other all-too-human reactions to the crisis, showing how the party can move dramatically, if sometimes belatedly, to mollify the public.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Such criticism can go only so far, however. Some of China’s more commercially minded media outlets have covered the disease and the response thoroughly if not critically. But articles and comments about the virus continue to be deleted, and the government and internet platforms have issued fresh warnings against spreading what they call “rumors.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“Chinese social media are full of anger, not because there was no censorship on this topic, but despite strong censorship,” said Xiao Qiang, a research scientist at the School of Information at the University of California, Berkeley, and the founder of <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://chinadigitaltimes.net/" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">China Digital Times</a>, a website that monitors Chinese internet controls. “It is still possible that the censorship will suddenly increase again, as part of an effort to control the narrative.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">When China’s leaders battled the SARS virus in the early 2000s, social media was only just beginning to blossom in the country. The government <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/22/health/virus-corona.html" title="">covered up the disease’s spread</a>, and it was left to journalists and other critics to shame the authorities into acknowledging the scale of the problem.</p>, <h1 class="g-headline" id="g-inlineguide-headline">The Coronavirus Outbreak</h1>, <h2 class="g-inlineguide-list-header g-optimize-type">What do you need to know? Start here.</h2>, <p class="g-inlineguide-date">Updated Feb. 10, 2020</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Today, smartphones and social media make it harder for mass public health crises to stay buried. But internet platforms in China are just as easily polluted with false and fast-moving information as they are everywhere else. During outbreaks of disease, Beijing’s leaders have legitimate reason to be on alert for quack remedies and scaremongering fabrications, which can cause panic and do damage.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">In recent days, though, Beijing seems to be reasserting its primacy over information in ways that go beyond mere rumor control. At <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="http://www.gov.cn/xinwen/2020-01/25/content_5472188.htm" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">a meeting this past weekend</a> between Mr. Xi and other senior leaders, one of the measures they resolved to take against the virus was to “strengthen the guidance of public opinion.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Wang Huning, the <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2017/11/13/world/asia/china-xi-jinping-wang-huning.html" title="">head of the Communist Party’s publicity department</a> and an influential party ideologue, was also recently named deputy head of <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="http://www.xinhuanet.com/politics/2020-01/26/c_1125504004.htm" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">the team in charge of containing the outbreak</a>, behind only China’s premier, Li Keqiang.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Chinese officials seem to recognize that social media can be a useful tool for feeling out public opinion in times of crisis. WeChat, the popular Chinese messaging platform, said over the weekend that it would crack down hard on <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="http://www.xinhuanet.com/politics/2020-01/26/c_1125503796.htm" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">rumors about the virus</a>. But it also created a tool for users to report tips and information about the disease and the response.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Internet backlash may already have caused one local government in China to change course on its virus-fighting policies. The southern city of Shantou announced on Sunday that it was stopping cars, ships and people from entering the city, in a policy that echoed ones in Wuhan. But then word went around that the decision had led people to panic-buy food, and by the afternoon, the order had been rescinded.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Nowhere has the local government been the target of more internet vitriol than in Hubei Province, where Wuhan is the capital.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">After the Hubei governor, Wang Xiaodong, and other officials there gave a news briefing on Sunday, web users mocked Mr. Wang for misstating, twice, the number of face masks that the province could produce. They circulated a photo from the briefing of him and two other officials, pointing out that one of them did not cover his nose with his mask, that another wore his mask upside down and that Mr. Wang did not wear a mask at all.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">On Monday, social media users were similarly unrelenting toward Wuhan’s mayor, Zhou Xianwang.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">During an interview Mr. Zhou gave to state television, commenters in live streams unloaded on him, with one writing: “Stop talking. We just want to know when you will resign.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Top authorities may be deliberately directing public anger toward officials in Hubei and Wuhan as a prelude to their resigning and being replaced. Many other targets within the Chinese leadership seem to remain off limits.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">This month, as news of the coronavirus emerged but Mr. Xi did not make public appearances to address it, people on the social platform Weibo began venting their frustration in veiled ways, asking, “Where’s that person?”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">But even those comments were deleted. So some users started <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://chinadigitaltimes.net/chinese/2020/01/%e3%80%90%e7%ab%8b%e6%ad%a4%e5%ad%98%e7%85%a7%e3%80%91%e5%9b%a0%e4%b9%a0%e8%bf%91%e5%b9%b3%e4%b8%80%e8%af%8d%e6%95%8f%e6%84%9f-%e5%be%ae%e5%8d%9a%e7%bd%91%e5%8f%8b%e6%80%92%e6%96%a5/" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">replacing Mr. Xi’s name with “Trump.”</a> As in, “I don’t want to go through another minute of this year, my heart is filled with pain, I hope Trump dies.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Other people hungering to express frustration have taken to the Chinese social platform Douban, which has been flooded recently by user reviews for “Chernobyl,” the hit television series about the Soviet nuclear disaster.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“In any era, any country, it’s the same. Cover everything up,” one reviewer wrote on Monday.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“That’s socialism,” wrote another.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Some Chinese news outlets have been able to report incisively on the coronavirus. The influential newsmagazine Caixin has put out rigorous reporting and analysis. <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2016/04/06/business/international/china-media-the-paper-english.html" title="">The Paper</a>, a digital news outlet that is overseen by Shanghai’s Communist Party Committee, published a <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://m.thepaper.cn/newsDetail_forward_5642907" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">chilling video</a> about a Wuhan resident who couldn’t find a hospital that would treat him and ended up wandering the streets.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Mr. Xiao, the Chinese internet expert, said the central authorities long gave such outlets special leeway to cover certain topics in ways that official media cannot. But the outlets should not be viewed as independent of the government, he said, calling their coverage “planned and controlled publicity” from the authorities.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Even outside the digital realm, it is not hard to find people in China who remain unsure of whether to trust what their government is telling them about the outbreak.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Chen Pulin, a 78-year-old retiree, was waiting outside a Shanghai hospital recently while his daughter was inside being tested for the virus. When word of the disease first began trickling out, he immediately had doubts about whether officials were being forthcoming about it.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“Even now, the government seems to be thinking about the economy and social stability,” Mr. Chen said. “Those things are important, but when it comes to these infectious diseases, stopping the disease should come first.”</p>, <p class="css-jwz2nf etfikam0">Li Yuan contributed reporting from Hong Kong. Claire Fu, Lin Qiqing and Wang Yiwei contributed research.</p>, <p>Advertisement</p>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd" id="site-index-label">Site Index</h2>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-0">news</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-1">opinion</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-2">arts</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-3">living</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-4">more</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-subscribe-label">Subscribe</h3>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd">Site Information Navigation</h2>]
[<p>Advertisement</p>, <p>Supported by</p>, <h1 class="css-1s4ffep e1h9rw200" id="link-7e61be1a" itemprop="headline"><span>Wuhan Coronavirus, Impeachment, Kobe Bryant: Your Monday Briefing</span></h1>, <p class="css-1ifw933 e1wiw3jv0" id="article-summary">Here’s what you need to know.</p>, <p class="css-1fv7b6t e1jsehar1" itemprop="author" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">By<!-- --> <a class="css-brehiz e1jsehar0" href="https://www.nytimes.com/by/mike-ives"><span class="css-1baulvz last-byline" itemprop="name">Mike Ives</span></a></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">(Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/morning-briefing" title="">sign-up</a>.)</p>, <p class="css-ma92ss evys1bk0">Good morning.</p>, <p class="css-ma92ss evys1bk0">We’re covering the first cases of the <strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Wuhan coronavirus</strong> in Europe, the results of <strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">a key election in Italy</strong> and the death of the retired basketball star <strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Kobe Bryant.</strong></p>, <h2 class="css-3ez4hu eoo0vm40" id="link-3b060b4f">Coronavirus outbreak intensifies and spreads to France</h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">As of this morning, the outbreak<strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10"> </strong>of a mysterious coronavirus has killed at least 80 people in China, sickened thousands and <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2020/01/21/world/asia/china-coronavirus-maps.html?&amp;te=1&amp;nl=morning-briefing&amp;emc=edit_nn_20200126?campaign_id=9&amp;instance_id=15471&amp;segment_id=20667&amp;user_id=830c70cfae7761a29eee4dd9c5919d12&amp;regi_id=85409517_nn_20200126" title="">spread to at least 10 countries</a>. That includes three confirmed cases in France, the first European country on that growing international roster. <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/27/world/asia/china-coronavirus.html" title="">Here’s the latest</a>.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Almost all of the worldwide infections involve people who traveled from China. A top health official in Beijing <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/26/world/asia/coronavirus-wuhan-china-hubei.html" title="">warned on Sunday</a> that the spread of the disease was accelerating, partly because it was being carried and transmitted by seemingly healthy people.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Yesterday:</strong> Five million people left Wuhan, the Chinese city where the virus originated, before travel was restricted, the city’s mayor said — a stunning disclosure that intensified questions about the government’s delayed response.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Related: </strong>China’s flawed response to the outbreak may be another sign of how President Xi Jinping’s political dominance hampers internal debate over key policy decisions, <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/26/world/asia/china-coronavirus-xi-jinping.html" title="">analysts tell our correspondents</a> based in Beijing.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">What’s next: </strong>The Chinese government has extended the end of the weeklong Lunar New Year holiday by three days, to next Sunday, in an effort to to temporarily limit travel.</p>, <h2 class="css-3ez4hu eoo0vm40" id="link-334dfe49">Italy’s League party loses a key election</h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The party of the nationalist leader Matteo Salvini <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/26/world/europe/italy-election-Salvini.html" title="">lost a regional election on Sunday</a> that he had hoped would set the stage for his return to power — a prospect that once thrilled Europe’s populists and menaced its establishment.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Mr. Salvini had campaigned feverishly before the vote, in the northern region of Emilia-Romagna, in the hope that <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/22/world/europe/italy-salvini-elections-emilia-romagna-calabria.html" title="">a victory would provide ammunition</a> in his calls for early national elections. But voters there, who have typically supported communist and leftist parties, rejected his anti-migrant League party’s candidate by a margin of around five percentage points.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Go deeper: </strong>Five Star, an anti-establishment party in Italy’s governing coalition, was humiliated in the election, raising more questions about its viability in the wake of <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/22/world/europe/italy-di-maio-five-star.html" title="">its leader’s resignation last week</a>.</p>, <h2 class="css-3ez4hu eoo0vm40" id="link-28d377e8">How Iran covered up its deadly mistake</h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Come clean or I’ll resign. That’s what President Hassan Rouhani of Iran told top commanders who had been covering up the accidental downing of a Ukrainian passenger jet over Tehran.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">It was only then — three days after the plane crashed in early January — that the country’s supreme leader ordered the government to acknowledge its fatal mistake.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">We have <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/26/world/middleeast/iran-plane-crash-coverup.html" title="">an in-depth report on the cover-up</a> and its political implications. Key takeaway: The Islamic<strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10"> </strong>Revolutionary Guards Corps, an elite force charged with defending Iran’s clerical rule at home and abroad, effectively sidelined the elected government in a moment of national crisis.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">How we know: </strong>Our reporter interviewed current and former Iranian officials, ranking members of the Revolutionary Guards and people close to the supreme leader’s inner circle.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">In Baghdad:</strong> In a protest organized by an anti-American Shiite cleric and armed groups with ties to Iran, an estimated 200,000 to 250,000 Iraqis gathered on Friday to <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/24/world/middleeast/protests-iraq-baghdad.html" title="">protest the United States military presence in the country</a>. (An American drone strike that killed a top Iranian commander in the Iraqi capital on Jan. 3 has prompted widespread public anger.)</p>, <h2 class="css-3ez4hu eoo0vm40" id="link-271be450">How solid are Europe’s post-Holocaust values?</h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">World leaders and dignitaries will gather today for a solemn ceremony at Auschwitz in Poland to mark the 75th anniversary of the liberation of the former Nazi death camp.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">But these days, <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/25/world/europe/auschwitz-liberation-75th-anniversary.html" title="">our Warsaw bureau chief writes</a>, some worry that Europe’s post-Holocaust values are being eroded amid a surge of anti-Semitism and dehumanizing political rhetoric on the Continent and in the United States.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Even the memory of Auschwitz — where 1.1 million people, mostly Jews, were murdered — has been weaponized. Case in point: A ceremony at a Holocaust memorial in Jerusalem last week was clouded by <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/aponline/2020/01/21/world/europe/ap-eu-poland-russia-wwii-.html" title="">a bitter dispute</a> over World War II history between Poland and Russia.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Yesterday: </strong>Mark Rutte of the Netherlands became the first Dutch prime minister to <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/reuters/2020/01/26/world/europe/26reuters-holocaust-memorial-netherlands.html" title="">apologize for his country’s role during the Holocaust</a> and its lack of action against the persecution of Jews.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Related: </strong>In the first installment of “<a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/24/magazine/beyond-the-world-war-ii-we-know.html" title="">Beyond the World War II We Know</a>,” a new Times series, a United States Navy veteran looks at <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/23/magazine/holocaust-remembrance-grandmother.html" title="">how her family fled Nazi Germany</a> weeks before Hitler invaded Poland.</p>, <h3
