	The outbreak is believed to have began in a <a href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/02/01/world/asia/china-coronavirus.html">seafood and poultry market</a> in Wuhan, a city of 11 million people in central China. The virus is <a href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/02/02/health/coronavirus-pandemic-china.html">readily transmitted</a> from person to person, scientists believe. But how lethal the virus is and and whether it <a href="https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2020/world/asia/china-coronavirus-contain.html">can be contained</a> is unclear.
</p>, <p class="g-body g-refer">
<a href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/02/08/world/asia/coronavirus-china.html">Follow the latest updates</a> on the coronavirus outbreak.
</p>, <h2 class="g-subhed g-optimize-type " id="">
<span class="g-balancer" data-id="17">What’s being done to contain the outbreak?</span>
</h2>, <p class="g-body ">
	The Chinese authorities took the <a href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/22/world/asia/coronavirus-quarantines-history.html">extraordinary step</a> of closing off Wuhan, canceling planes and trains leaving the city and suspending buses, subways and ferries within it. By Jan. 24, at least 12 other cities in Hubei Province had issued travel restrictions, including Huanggang, home to seven million people, and Ezhou, a city of about one million.
</p>, <p class="g-pstyle0">Railway</p>, <p class="g-pstyle0">networks</p>, <p class="g-pstyle1">About 20 million people live</p>, <p class="g-pstyle1">in these three cities.</p>, <p class="g-pstyle2">XIAOGAN</p>, <p class="g-pstyle3">HUANGGANG</p>, <p class="g-pstyle3">WUHAN</p>, <p class="g-pstyle4">EZHOU</p>, <p class="g-pstyle5">CHINA</p>, <p class="g-pstyle6">Wuhan</p>, <p class="g-pstyle0">About 20 million people</p>, <p class="g-pstyle0">live in these three cities.</p>, <p class="g-pstyle1">Railway</p>, <p class="g-pstyle1">networks</p>, <p class="g-pstyle2">WUHAN</p>, <p class="g-pstyle2">HUANGGANG</p>, <p class="g-pstyle3">EZHOU</p>, <p class="g-pstyle4">CHINA</p>, <p class="g-pstyle5">Wuhan</p>, <p class="g-body ">
	A number of countries, including the United States and Australia, are limiting travel to some people who recently traveled to China, and several major airlines said they expect to halt direct service to mainland China for months.
</p>, <p class="g-body ">
	Closing borders to highly infectious pathogens <a href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/02/02/health/coronavirus-pandemic-china.html">never succeeds completely</a>, experts said, because all frontiers are somewhat porous. Nonetheless, closings and rigorous screening may slow the spread, which will buy time for the development of drug treatments and vaccines.
</p>, <h2 class="g-subhed g-optimize-type " id="">
<span class="g-balancer" data-id="18">How big could the outbreak be?</span>
</h2>, <p class="g-body ">
	The true number of cases is almost certainly far larger than the number that have been officially confirmed by lab tests.
</p>, <p class="g-body ">
	Thousands of people in Hubei province, where the outbreak began, are suspected of having been infected but have not been officially diagnosed. Doctors there say there is a <a href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/02/02/world/asia/china-coronavirus-wuhan.html">shortage of testing kits</a> and other medical supplies, and residents say it is nearly impossible to get the health care they need to treat — or even diagnose — the coronavirus.
</p>, <p class="g-body ">
	Various epidemiological models estimate that the real number of cases is <a href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/02/02/health/coronavirus-pandemic-china.html">100,000 or even more</a>. Experts urged caution in interpreting those estimates.
</p>, <p class="g-body ">
	“These are very early models that make several assumptions based on what evidence is available,” said David Heymann, an epidemiologist at the London School of Hygiene and Tropical Medicine. “They aren’t truth — they’re just one step in trying to better understand this outbreak.”
</p>, <p class="g-body g-refer">
<a href="https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2020/world/asia/china-coronavirus-contain.html">How bad will the outbreak get?</a> Here are six key factors.
</p>, <p>Advertisement</p>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd" id="site-index-label">Site Index</h2>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-0">news</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-1">opinion</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-2">arts</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-3">living</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-4">more</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-subscribe-label">Subscribe</h3>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd">Site Information Navigation</h2>]
[<p>Advertisement</p>, <p>Supported by</p>, <h1 class="css-1qskr30 e1h9rw200" id="link-283b806e" itemprop="headline"><span>We Made the Coronavirus Epidemic</span></h1>, <p class="css-1ifw933 e1wiw3jv0" id="article-summary">It may have started with a bat in a cave, but human activity set it loose.</p>, <p class="css-1fv7b6t e1jsehar1" itemprop="author" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">By<!-- --> <span class="css-1baulvz last-byline" itemprop="name">David Quammen</span></p>, <p class="css-cpkn1d e1wtpvyy1">Mr. Quammen is the author of “Spillover: Animal Infections and the Next Human Pandemic.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The latest scary new virus that has captured the world’s horrified attention, caused a <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2020/01/china-expands-coronavirus-outbreak-lockdown-fast-tracks-hospital-200124201635848.html" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">lockdown of 56 million people</a> in China, disrupted travel plans around the globe and sparked <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://edition.cnn.com/2020/01/25/health/coronavirus-masks-shortage-trnd/index.html" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">a run on medical masks</a> from <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/29/business/china-coronavirus-economy.html" title="">Wuhan</a>, Hubei Province, to Bryan, Texas, is known provisionally as “nCoV-2019.” It’s a clunky moniker for a lurid threat.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The name, picked by the team of Chinese scientists who isolated and identified the virus, is short for “novel <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/29/business/china-coronavirus-economy.html" title="">coronavirus</a> of 2019.” It reflects the fact that the virus was first recognized to have infected humans late last year — in a seafood and live-animal market in Wuhan — and that it belongs to the coronavirus family, a notorious group. <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.cdc.gov/sars/about/faq.html" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">The SARS epidemic</a> of 2002-3, which infected 8,098 people worldwide, killing 774 of them, was caused by a coronavirus, and so was <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.who.int/emergencies/mers-cov/en/" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">the MERS outbreak</a> that began on the Arabian Peninsula in 2012 and still lingers (2,494 people infected and 858 deaths as of November).</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Despite the new virus’s name, though, and as the people who christened it well know, nCoV-2019 isn’t as novel as you might think.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Something very much like it was found several years ago in a cave in Yunnan, a province roughly a thousand miles southwest of Wuhan, by a team of perspicacious researchers, who noted its existence with concern. The fast spread of nCoV-2019 — more than <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/27/world/asia/china-coronavirus.html" title="">4,500 confirmed cases</a>, including at least 106 deaths, as of Tuesday morning, and the figures will have risen by the time you read this — is startling but not unforeseeable. That the virus emerged from a nonhuman animal, probably a bat, and possibly after passing through another creature, may seem spooky, yet it is utterly unsurprising to scientists who study these things.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">One such scientist is Zheng-Li Shi, of the Wuhan Institute of Virology, a senior author of <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.biorxiv.org/content/10.1101/2020.01.22.914952v1" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">the draft paper</a> (not yet peer reviewed and so far available only in preprint) that gave nCoV-2019 its identity and name. It was Ms. Shi and her collaborators who, back in 2005, <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/16195424" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">showed that</a> the SARS pathogen was a bat virus that had spilled over into people. Ms. Shi and colleagues have been tracing coronaviruses in bats since then, warning that some of them are uniquely suited to cause human pandemics.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">In a 2017 paper, they set out how, after nearly five years of collecting fecal samples from bats in the Yunnan cave, they had <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://journals.plos.org/plospathogens/article?id=10.1371/journal.ppat.1006698#sec012" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">found coronaviruses in multiple individuals of four different species of bats</a>, including one called the intermediate <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/28/science/bats-coronavirus-Wuhan.html" title="">horseshoe bat</a>, because of the half-oval flap of skin protruding like a saucer around its nostrils. The genome of that virus, Ms. Shi and her colleagues have now announced, is 96 percent identical to the Wuhan virus that has recently been found in humans. And those two constitute a pair distinct from all other known coronaviruses, including the one that causes SARS. In this sense, nCoV-2019 is novel — and possibly even more dangerous to humans than the other coronaviruses.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">I say “possibly” because so far, not only do we not know how dangerous it is, we can’t know. Outbreaks of new viral diseases are like the steel balls in a pinball machine: You can slap your flippers at them, rock the machine on its legs and bonk the balls to the jittery rings, but where they end up dropping depends on 11 levels of chance as well as on anything you do. This is true with coronaviruses in particular: They mutate often while they replicate, and can evolve as quickly as a nightmare ghoul.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Peter Daszak, the president of EcoHealth Alliance, a private research organization based in New York that focuses on the connections between human and wildlife health, is one of Ms. Shi’s longtime partners. “We’ve been raising the flag on these viruses for 15 years,” he told me on Friday with calm frustration. “Ever since SARS.” He was a co-author of the 2005 bats-and-SARS study, and again of the 2017 paper about the multiple SARS-like coronaviruses in the Yunnan cave.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Mr. Daszak told me that, during that second study, the field team took blood samples from a couple of thousand Yunnanese people, about 400 of whom lived near the cave. Roughly 3 percent of them carried antibodies against SARS-related coronaviruses.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“We don’t know if they got sick. We don’t know if they were exposed as children or adults,” Mr. Daszak said. “But what it tells you is that these viruses are making the jump, repeatedly, from bats to humans.” In other words, this Wuhan emergency is no novel event. It’s part of a sequence of related contingencies that stretches back into the past and will stretch forward into the future, as long as current circumstances persist.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">So when you’re done worrying about this outbreak, worry about the next one. Or do something about the current circumstances.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Current circumstances include a perilous trade in wildlife for food, with supply chains stretching through Asia, Africa and to a lesser extent, the United States and elsewhere. That trade has now been outlawed in China, on a temporary basis; but it was outlawed also during SARS, then allowed to resume — with bats, civets, porcupines, turtles, bamboo rats, many kinds of birds and other animals piled together in markets such as the one in Wuhan.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Current circumstances also include 7.6 billion hungry humans: some of them impoverished and desperate for protein; some affluent and wasteful and empowered to travel every which way by airplane. These factors are unprecedented on planet Earth: We know from the fossil record, by absence of evidence, that no large-bodied animal has ever been nearly so abundant as humans are now, let alone so effective at arrogating resources. And one consequence of that abundance, that power, and the consequent ecological disturbances is increasing viral exchanges — first from animal to human, then from human to human, sometimes on a pandemic scale.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">We invade tropical forests and other wild landscapes, which harbor so many species of animals and plants — and within those creatures, so many unknown viruses. We cut the trees; we kill the animals or cage them and send them to markets. We disrupt ecosystems, and we shake viruses loose from their natural hosts. When that happens, they need a new host. Often, we are it.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The list of such viruses emerging into humans sounds like a grim drumbeat: Machupo, Bolivia, 1961; Marburg, Germany, 1967; Ebola, Zaire and Sudan, 1976; H.I.V., recognized in New York and California, 1981; a form of Hanta (now known as Sin Nombre), southwestern United States, 1993; Hendra, Australia, 1994; bird flu, Hong Kong, 1997; Nipah, Malaysia, 1998; West Nile, New York, 1999; SARS, China, 2002-3; MERS, Saudi Arabia, 2012; Ebola again, West Africa, 2014. And that’s just a selection. Now we have nCoV-2019, the latest thump on the drum.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Current circumstances also include bureaucrats who lie and conceal bad news, and elected officials who brag to the crowd about cutting forests to create jobs in the timber industry and agriculture or about <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="http://thenationshealth.aphapublications.org/content/49/3/1.2" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">cutting budgets for public health and research</a>. The distance from Wuhan or the Amazon to Paris, Toronto or Washington is short for some viruses, measured in hours, given how well they can ride within airplane passengers. And if you think funding pandemic preparedness is expensive, wait until you see the final cost of nCoV-2019.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Fortunately, current circumstances also include brilliant, dedicated scientists and outbreak-response medical people — such as many at the Wuhan Institute of Virology, EcoHealth Alliance, the United States Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (C.D.C.), the Chinese C.D.C. and numerous other institutions. These are the people who go into bat caves, swamps and high-security containment laboratories, often risking their lives, to bring out bat feces and blood and other precious evidence to study genomic sequences and answer the key questions.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">As the number of nCoV-2019 cases has increased, and the death toll along with it, one metric, the case fatality rate, has remained rather steady so far: <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.forbes.com/sites/leahrosenbaum/2020/01/23/everything-you-need-to-know-about-the-wuhan-coronavirus-outbreak/#1c27cb756fce" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">at about or below 3 percent</a>. As of Tuesday, less than three out of 100 confirmed cases had died. That’s relatively good luck — <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://jech.bmj.com/content/62/6/555" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">worse than for most strains of influenza</a>, <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nejm.org/doi/full/10.1056/NEJMp2000929" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">better than for SARS</a>.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">This good luck may not last. Nobody knows where the pinball will go. Four days from today, the number of cases may be in the tens of thousands. Six months from today, Wuhan pneumonia may be receding into memory. Or not.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">We are faced with two mortal challenges, in the short term and the long term. Short term: We must do everything we can, with intelligence, calm and a full commitment of resources, to contain and extinguish this nCoV-2019 outbreak before it becomes, as it could, a devastating global pandemic. Long term: We must remember, when the dust settles, that nCoV-2019 was not a novel event or a misfortune that befell us. It was — it is — part of a pattern of choices that we humans are making.</p>, <p class="css-jwz2nf etfikam0">David Quammen is an author and journalist whose books include “Spillover: Animal Infections and the Next Human Pandemic.”</p>, <p class="css-jwz2nf etfikam0"><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">The Times is committed to publishing </em><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2019/01/31/opinion/letters/letters-to-editor-new-york-times-women.html" title=""><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">a diversity of letters</em></a><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0"> to the editor. We’d like to hear what you think about this or any of our articles. Here are some </em><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://help.nytimes.com/hc/en-us/articles/115014925288-How-to-submit-a-letter-to-the-editor" title=""><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">tips</em></a><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">. And here’s our email: </em><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="mailto:letters@nytimes.com" title=""><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">letters@nytimes.com</em></a><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">.</em></p>, <p class="css-jwz2nf etfikam0"><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">Follow The New York Times Opinion section on </em><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.facebook.com/nytopinion" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title=""><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">Facebook</em></a><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">, </em><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="http://twitter.com/NYTOpinion" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title=""><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">Twitter (@NYTopinion)</em></a><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0"> and </em><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.instagram.com/nytopinion/" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title=""><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">Instagram</em></a><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">.</em></p>, <p>Advertisement</p>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd" id="site-index-label">Site Index</h2>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-0">news</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-1">opinion</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-2">arts</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-3">living</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-4">more</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-subscribe-label">Subscribe</h3>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd">Site Information Navigation</h2>]
[<p>Advertisement</p>, <p>Supported by</p>, <h1 class="css-1qskr30 e1h9rw200" id="link-2c1b7589" itemprop="headline"><span>Should You Be Worried About the Coronavirus?</span></h1>, <p class="css-1ifw933 e1wiw3jv0" id="article-summary">Public health experts explain the risks and what we still don’t know.</p>, <p class="css-1fv7b6t e1jsehar1" itemprop="author" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">By<!-- --> <span class="css-1baulvz last-byline" itemprop="name">Spencer Bokat-Lindell</span></p>, <p class="css-cpkn1d e1wtpvyy1">Mr. Bokat-Lindell is a writer in The New York Times Opinion section.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">This article is part of the Debatable newsletter. You can </em><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/newsletters/debatable" title=""><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">sign up here</em></a><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0"> to receive it Tuesdays and Thursdays.</em></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">For <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nejm.org/doi/10.1056/NEJMe2001126" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">the third time</a> this century, a new strain of <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/29/business/china-coronavirus-economy.html" title="">coronavirus</a>, a family of pathogens that cause respiratory illness in birds and mammals, has jumped species and infected humans. Having broken out in the city of Wuhan, the virus, likely spread through coughing and sneezing, has now sickened more than 4,500 people and killed <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/27/world/asia/china-coronavirus.html" title="">at least 106</a> in China. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">On Monday, The New York Times reported that five people in the United States had tested positive for the illness. But how worried should you really be? Here’s what public health experts and others are saying.</p>, <h2 class="css-1320w4z eoo0vm40" id="link-5ccdbe70">‘A cause for caution — not for alarm’</h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The outbreak is believed to have started at a wholesale market in <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/29/business/china-coronavirus-economy.html" title="">Wuhan</a>, where vendors legally sold live animals, including wildlife, in close quarters, <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/28/opinion/coronavirus-china.html" title="">sparking debate</a> about <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://foreignpolicy.com/2020/01/27/dont-blame-bat-soup-for-the-wuhan-virus/" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">China’s game trade</a>. “This is where you get new and emerging diseases that the human population has never seen before,” <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/25/world/asia/china-markets-coronavirus-sars.html" title="">said Kevin J. Olival</a>, a biologist and vice president of research with EcoHealth Alliance, a nonprofit research organization.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">In response to the contagion, China — still carrying the memory of SARS, the century’s first coronavirus to make the leap to humans, which killed nearly 800 people — has temporarily banned the sale of wild animals and effectively placed <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/23/world/asia/china-coronavirus-outbreak.html" title="">more than 35 million people</a> on lockdown, blocking expressways and canceling all flights and trains out of the region.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.scientificamerican.com/article/chinas-citywide-quarantines-are-they-ethical-and-effective1/" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title=""><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">[Related: Are the Quarantines Ethical and Effective?]</em></a></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">It’s the largest quarantine in history, but it’s unlikely to contain the virus,</strong> <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/27/opinion/china-wuhan-virus-quarantine.html" title="">writes Howard Markel</a>, a professor of the history of medicine at the University of Michigan. </p>, <p class="css-15hwz5e evys1bk0">The quarantine has taxed Wuhan’s ability to care for its sick while doing little to prevent the virus’s spread, Dr. Markel notes. Amid the Lunar New Year holiday, China’s busiest travel season, some five million people had already left the city before it was sealed.</p>, <p class="css-15hwz5e evys1bk0">“The more we learn about it, the greater the possibility is that transmission will not be able to be controlled with public health measures,” Dr. Allison McGeer, a Toronto-based infectious disease specialist, <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.statnews.com/2020/01/26/containing-new-coronavirus-may-not-be-feasible-experts-say/" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">told Helen Branswell</a> at STAT News.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">“I think that our first concern can rightly be the people in China,” </strong>the Columbia University epidemiologist <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://slate.com/technology/2020/01/coronavirus-outbreak-china-sars-worry-level.html" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">Simon Anthony told Slate</a>. </p>, <p class="css-15hwz5e evys1bk0">The quality of health care in China has not kept pace with the country’s economic expansion, <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/27/world/asia/27china-coronavirus-health.html" title="">reports The Times’s Sui-Lee Wee</a>. Strained even during ordinary times, doctors are overwhelmed, and both medical equipment and space are in short supply. </p>, <p class="css-15hwz5e evys1bk0">“It is very scary,” one Wuhan resident, whose wife developed a fever but was refused admission to hospitals, told Ms. Wee. “If it’s real, we have a child and elderly parents at home. What if we all get sick?”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">But many experts say people in the United States shouldn’t panic.</strong> The virus is thought to be less lethal than both SARS and MERS, the last zoonotic coronavirus to infect humans, in 2012. And the vast majority of confirmed cases remain in mainland China, <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.vox.com/science-and-health/2020/1/26/21082357/coronavirus-outbreak-us-confirmed-cases" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">as Catherine Kim</a> reported at Vox.</p>, <p class="css-15hwz5e evys1bk0">“Make no mistake, this is an emergency in China. But it has not yet become a global health emergency,” <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/23/health/china-virus-who-emergency.html" title="">said Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus</a>, the director general of the World Health Organization.</p>, <p class="css-15hwz5e evys1bk0">Although the outbreak is a “very serious public-health threat, the immediate risk to the U.S. public is low at this time,” Nancy Messonnier, director of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention’s National Center for Immunization and Respiratory Diseases, <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.washingtonpost.com/health/china-restricts-travel-for-35-million-people-to-halt-spread-of-deadly-virus/2020/01/24/80086bde-3ee4-11ea-8872-5df698785a4e_story.html" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">said Friday</a>.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">For perspective</strong>: The flu kills roughly 35,000 Americans every year. This season, it has already sickened an estimated 15 million Americans and killed 8,200, <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.cdc.gov/flu/weekly/index.htm" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">according to C.D.C. estimates</a>.</p>, <p class="css-15hwz5e evys1bk0">Influenza kills more Americans every year than any other virus, Dr. Peter Hotez, a professor at Baylor College of Medicine, <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://khn.org/news/flu-far-deadlier-than-wuhan-virus/" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">told Liz Sabo</a> at Kaiser Health News. But the flu is rarely paid such attention, and <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.cdc.gov/flu/fluvaxview/coverage-1819estimates.htm" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">fewer than half of adults</a> get a vaccine. </p>, <p class="css-15hwz5e evys1bk0">“When we think about the relative danger of this new coronavirus and influenza, there’s just no comparison,” Dr. William Schaffner, a professor at Vanderbilt University Medical Center, told Ms. Sabo. “Coronavirus will be a blip on the horizon in comparison.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“If Americans aren’t afraid of the flu, perhaps that’s because they are inured to yearly warnings,” Ms. Sabo writes. “For them, the flu is old news. Yet viruses named after foreign places — such as Ebola, Zika and Wuhan — inspire terror.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The Beaverton, a satirical publication, summed up matters thusly: </p>, <h2 class="css-1320w4z eoo0vm40" id="link-589d267d">‘We don’t know how bad it will get’</h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">There’s still a good deal we don’t know about the coronavirus. </strong>It’s too early to determine exactly how deadly or contagious it is, and as the Times columnist <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://messaging-custom-newsletters.nytimes.com/template/oakv2?uri=nyt://newsletter/fd3ef322-8508-4f46-95c9-4496c96791fe&amp;te=1&amp;nl=nicholas-kristof&amp;emc=edit_nk_20200125?campaign_id=45&amp;instance_id=15466&amp;segment_id=20660&amp;user_id=5feb0eea292dc4b269982e39c192c2cf&amp;regi_id=94146631_nk_20200125" title="">Nicholas Kristof has pointed out</a>, the Chinese government seems to have tried to play down the outbreak, perhaps undercounting the number of infections and deaths. A <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://gizmodo.com/how-long-will-it-take-to-develop-a-vaccine-for-the-wuha-1841276022" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">vaccine will probably not be viable</a> until this summer at the earliest.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.who.int/emergencies/diseases/novel-coronavirus-2019" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title=""><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">[Related: Read the W.H.O.’s travel advice and tips for how to protect yourself]</em></a></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">The United States needs to do more to prepare for an epidemic,</strong> <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/23/opinion/coronavirus-wuhan-outbreak.html" title="">writes Dr. Saad B. Omer</a>, the director of the Yale Institute for Global Health. For one thing, he argues, there’s little evidence that President Trump is taking the potential threat from the coronavirus seriously enough. But more broadly, there are clear lessons to heed from the SARS and 2014 Ebola outbreaks:</p>, <p class="css-15hwz5e evys1bk0"> The American response should be led by major public health scientists and agencies, such as the C.D.C. and the National Institutes of Health, rather than politicians: “Decisions such as border screenings, travel restrictions and potential quarantine have major public health consequences, and they should be driven by science and emerging biological and epidemiological evidence,” Dr. Omer writes.</p>, <p class="css-15hwz5e evys1bk0">Congress also <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.washingtonpost.com/opinions/the-coronavirus-has-landed-in-the-us-heres-how-we-can-reduce-the-risk/2020/01/22/afebe9ee-3d53-11ea-baca-eb7ace0a3455_story.html" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">needs to fund the nationwide network</a> of hospitals and treatment facilities established after the 2014 Ebola epidemic, which enables prompt testing and isolation of patients, write Ronald A. Klain, the former White House Ebola response coordinator from 2014 to 2015, and Nicole Lurie, a former assistant secretary for preparedness and response at the Department of Health and Human Services. That funding is set to expire in four months. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">The coronavirus could also threaten the global supply chain of pharmaceuticals, </strong><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.statnews.com/pharmalot/2020/01/27/china-coronavirus-pharmaceutical-ingredients/" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">Ed Silverman reports</a>.</p>, <p class="css-15hwz5e evys1bk0">Roughly 80 percent of active ingredients used by commercial sources to produce finished medicines come from China, he writes. Most ingredient production occurs several hundred miles east of Wuhan, but it’s not hard to imagine the virus and the quarantine spreading in that direction, bringing with them the possibility of shortages.</p>, <p class="css-15hwz5e evys1bk0">“We need a government entity that monitors global supply and demand — and events like this outbreak — to understand our vulnerabilities, predict possibilities and have a plan to prepare, rather than scramble,” Rosemary Gibson, a health care and patient safety expert at the Hastings Center, told Mr. Silverman. “We track food supplies around the world. We do this for energy supplies. We need to do the same thing for medicines.”</p>, <h2 class="css-1320w4z eoo0vm40" id="link-241ec0e5">‘Disease and discrimination are two sides of the same coin’</h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">The first victim of an infectious disease outbreak is often rational decision-making, </strong>write Mr. Klain and Ms. Lurie, which tends to open the door to discrimination in forms both malicious and misguided.</p>, <p class="css-15hwz5e evys1bk0">Ann Coulter, a right-wing commentator, <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://twitter.com/AnnCoulter/status/1219694371995639808" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">beseeched President Trump</a> on Twitter to ban travel from China.</p>, <p class="css-15hwz5e evys1bk0">In New York City, <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/24/us/wuhan-coronavirus-united-states-washington-texas.html" title="">one school district canceled</a> a field trip to Chinatown ahead of the Lunar New Year celebrations. One parent, Amy Lee-Ludovicy, a Hong Kong native, told The Times that she worried her two children were facing discrimination in ways they had not before. “They are being taught, ‘Let’s just stay away from them,’” she said.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">There is a troubled history in predominantly white countries of racializing infectious diseases</strong>, <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.smh.com.au/national/coronavirus-risk-is-more-than-biological-20200126-p53ut5.html" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">writes Alan Zheng</a> in The Sydney Morning Herald.</p>, <p class="css-15hwz5e evys1bk0">“The Ebola outbreak perpetuated images of the ‘Dark Continent’ and exacerbated existing patterns of xenophobia toward black communities,” he writes, also noting how Haitians in the United States were <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.newyorker.com/news/news-desk/trump-reopens-an-old-wound-for-haitians" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">barred from donating blood</a> in the 1980s after being unfairly <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/1985/04/10/us/haitians-removed-from-aids-risk-list.html" title="">labeled a risk group</a> for AIDS.</p>, <p class="css-15hwz5e evys1bk0">“Reporting of the virus latches on to a double anomaly: the fear, speculation and uncertainty inherent in the spread of new diseases, as well as a fascination with the darkened interiors of China — a country which continues to evade mainstream literacy in Australia and whose size and scale conjure fantasy at every turn,” he writes. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2020/jan/27/coronavirus-panic-uk-hostile-environment-east-asians" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title=""><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">[Related: The coronavirus panic is turning the United Kingdom into a hostile environment for East Asians.]</em></a></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">Do you have a point of view we missed? Email us at </em><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="mailto:debatable@nytimes.com" title=""><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">debatable@nytimes.com</em></a><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">. Please note your name, age and location in your response, which may be included in the next newsletter. </em></p>, <h3 class="css-1ldy5g8 e1gnsphs0" id="link-68b95c8c">MORE INFORMATION ON THE CORONAVIRUS AND WHERE IT CAME FROM</h3>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.buzzfeednews.com/article/janelytvynenko/coronavirus-disinformation-spread" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">“A Running List of Disinformation Spreading About The Coronavirus”</a> <em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">[BuzzFeed]</em></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/23/world/asia/wuhan-coronavirus.html" title="">“Wuhan Beyond the Coronavirus: Steel, Cars and Spicy Noodles.”</a> <em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">[The New York Times]</em></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/25/world/asia/china-coronavirus-photos.html" title="">“China’s Battle With a Deadly Coronavirus, in Photos.”</a> <em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">[The New York Times]</em></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/23/opinion/coronavirus-china-wuhan.html" title="">“Is China Setting Itself Up for Another Epidemic?”</a> <em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">[The New York Times]</em></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2020/01/21/world/asia/china-coronavirus-maps.html" title="">“Wuhan Coronavirus Map: Tracking the Spread of the Outbreak”</a> <em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">[The New York Times]</em></p>, <h3 class="css-1ldy5g8 e1gnsphs0" id="link-67a24052">WHAT YOU’RE SAYING</h3>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">Here’s what readers had to say about the last edition: </em><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/23/opinion/donald-trump-impeachment.html" title=""><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">Donald Trump’s impeachment defense.</em></a></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://nyti.ms/30WR6sb#permid=104786339" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">Jim from Missouri</a>: “The most significant aspect of Trump’s defense is not the 110-page smokescreen invented by his lawyers. The single most important thing is that they are doing everything in their power to prevent evidence and witnesses from being brought into the proceeding.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://twitter.com/samuelmoyn/status/1220717622116798464" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">Samuel Moyn, a professor at Yale Law School</a>: “One point of superiority to <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://twitter.com/nikobowie" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">@nikobowie</a>’s article is that it is historicist in order to be presentist. What matters isn’t what past actors decided to do or thought their text meant, but what the best present reasons are for one or another choice.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Larence F. Winthrop, a judge on the Arizona Court of Appeals (via email): “I take slight issue with the statement that the concept of ‘executive privilege’ originated in President Eisenhower’s administration. In reality, the issue of executive privilege was first raised in the trial of Marbury v. Madison in the United States Supreme Court in 1803.” (Mark J. Rozell, the author of a book on executive privilege, has written that <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="http://web1.millercenter.org/reports/MC-executive-privilege.pdf" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">George Washington laid the conceptual foundation</a> for the power, though the term was not a part of common language until the Eisenhower administration.)</p>, <p>Advertisement</p>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd" id="site-index-label">Site Index</h2>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-0">news</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-1">opinion</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-2">arts</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-3">living</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-4">more</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-subscribe-label">Subscribe</h3>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd">Site Information Navigation</h2>]
[<p>Advertisement</p>, <p>Supported by</p>, <h1 class="css-1s4ffep e1h9rw200" id="link-a45f1ac" itemprop="headline"><span>Global Markets Are on Edge as Coronavirus Spreads</span></h1>, <p class="css-1ifw933 e1wiw3jv0" id="article-summary">Investors have been worried that the mysterious epidemic in China could hurt economic growth.</p>, <p class="css-1fv7b6t e1jsehar1" itemprop="author" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">By<!-- --> <a class="css-brehiz e1jsehar0" href="https://www.nytimes.com/by/alexandra-stevenson"><span class="css-1baulvz last-byline" itemprop="name">Alexandra Stevenson</span></a></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">After sharp losses around the world, investors on Tuesday continued to assess the <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/27/business/coronavirus-china-economic-impact.html" title="">long-term economic effects</a> of the <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/28/world/asia/china-coronavirus.html" title="">coronavirus</a> epidemic.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The verdict was mixed. Investors abandoned stocks in Asia, while markets in Europe steadied after the previous day’s sell-off. In the United States, stocks rose at the start of trading, with the S&amp;P 500 up slightly.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Investors could be in for a rocky period as the pneumonialike illness <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/27/world/asia/china-coronavirus-social-media.html" title="">spread</a>s, having killed 132 people and sickening nearly 6,000 to date. Health officials in the United States are warning that travelers should avoid nonessential trips to China, while global businesses are restricting travel. The Chinese government extended the Lunar New Year holiday, which could disrupt production and hurt the country’s growth.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“The coronavirus is the No. 1 threat to financial markets currently as global investors are becoming jittery on the uncertainty,” said Nigel Green, the founder of the investment group deVere Group.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“This is a worrying and serious situation and investors must be vigilant,” he added.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The concern is that the fallout could create a major shock for markets, even as worries about geopolitics and global trade have eased.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Many Asian stock markets were closed for the Lunar New Year holiday, but those that were open, including Japan’s and South Korea’s, fell and futures trading in China slumped. Money poured into safe-haven assets like gold and pushed up the value of the United States dollar. Most European markets were slightly higher.</p>, <h1 class="g-headline" id="g-inlineguide-headline">The Coronavirus Outbreak</h1>, <h2 class="g-inlineguide-list-header g-optimize-type">What do you need to know? Start here.</h2>, <p class="g-inlineguide-date">Updated Feb. 10, 2020</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Japan’s minister of economic and fiscal policy said on Tuesday that the Chinese outbreak would affect the Japanese tourism industry and warned that it could also hurt exports and corporate profits. Chinese tourists traveling to Japan accounted for 30 percent of all tourists in 2019, he said at a news conference.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“There are concerns over the impact to the Chinese and global economy from the spread of infection in China, transportation disruptions, cancellation of group tours from China and an extension in the Lunar holiday,” said the minister, Yasutoshi Nishimura.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">In Tokyo, investors pushed stocks down by 0.6 percent. In Seoul, stocks fell by more than 3 percent. Hong Kong’s stock market will reopen on Wednesday. In China, where authorities have extended the New Year holiday by a week, the major exchanges in Shenzhen and Shanghai said they would remain closed until Feb. 3.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">China’s securities regulator on Tuesday called for investors to “rationally and objectively analyze the impact of the epidemic,” and to “adhere to the concept of long-term investment.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">In Europe, London’s FTSE 100 index gained 0.2 percent in midday trading, while the DAX in Frankfurt was 0.1 percent lower.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The price of oil, which tumbled on Monday amid fears that the virus would dampen demand for fuel, drifted slightly lower on Tuesday.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">China’s appetite for oil has grown at around 5.5 percent annually, making it an important buyer in the global market. The country has already imposed travel restrictions and any extension could further dampen demand.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“The question isn’t whether coronavirus will depress global oil demand,” wrote Ryan Sweet, head of monetary policy research at Moody’s Analytics. “Rather, the question is by how much.”</p>, <p class="css-jwz2nf etfikam0">Claire Fu and Eimi Yamamitsu contributed research.</p>, <p>Advertisement</p>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd" id="site-index-label">Site Index</h2>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-0">news</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-1">opinion</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-2">arts</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-3">living</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-4">more</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-subscribe-label">Subscribe</h3>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd">Site Information Navigation</h2>]
[<p>Advertisement</p>, <p>Supported by</p>, <p class="css-c2jxua e6idgb70"></p>, <h1 class="css-1j5ig2m e1h9rw200" id="link-c30aae9" itemprop="headline"><span>The Coronavirus Is Unwinding Global Economic Gains</span></h1>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">Hello. On today’s agenda: Apple is scheduled to report earnings today. (Want this in your inbox each morning? </em><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="http://p.nytimes.com/email/re?&amp;campaign_id=0&amp;instance_id=0&amp;segment_id=0&amp;user_id=f4577a56bcf773214e9a1d55b5fe9d24&amp;regi_id=0nl=dealbook&amp;emc=edit_dk_20180529" title=""><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">Sign up here</em></a><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">.)</em></p>, <h2 class="css-3ez4hu eoo0vm40" id="link-3d24c557">As virus spreads, investors look for safety</h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Asian stocks fell again today after a global sell-off yesterday, as investors worried that China’s coronavirus outbreak could <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/27/business/coronavirus-china-economic-impact.html" title="">undo months of economic gains</a> around the world.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">• <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.ft.com/content/c15c5316-4164-11ea-bdb5-169ba7be433d" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">Shares in Korea and Singapore fell</a> amid fears that companies in those markets will suffer from a drop in Chinese consumer spending.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">• The S&amp;P 500 declined 1.6 percent yesterday, while the Stoxx Europe index slipped 2.3 percent.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">• Brent crude oil fell below $60 a barrel.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">• The values of the dollar, the yen and gold all rose.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">There’s reason for investors to still be worried</strong>. The death toll from the outbreak has risen to over 100 people, while more than 4,500 infections have been reported worldwide. And this morning, <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/28/world/asia/coronavirus-hong-kong-border.html" title="">Hong Kong restricted travel</a> from mainland China.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">But there’s also </strong><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10"><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/27/business/stock-market-today.html" title="">reason not to panic</a></strong>, at least in the U.S.: “The American economy is relatively insulated from trade, and the important consumer sector continues to show signs of strength,” write Matt Phillips and Katie Robertson of the NYT.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Today is looking a little better, financially.</strong> S&amp;P futures forecast a positive market opening, while <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/28/business/coronavirus-financial-markets.html" title="">European stocks rebounded modestly</a>.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">More:</strong></em><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0"> Beijing is </em><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0"><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/27/world/asia/china-coronavirus-social-media.html" title="">racing to contain anger</a></em><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0"> at the government’s response to the outbreak. The director-general of the World Health Organization </em><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0"><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2020-01-27/who-chief-heads-to-china-as-efforts-to-contain-virus-accelerate" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">met with Chinese officials</a></em><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0"> to assess the response. And the disease is testing China’s </em><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0"><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/27/world/asia/27china-coronavirus-health.html" title="">already-struggling health care system</a></em><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">.</em></p>, <h2 class="css-3ez4hu eoo0vm40" id="link-2b203d39">Nike seeks to stop profiteering after Kobe Bryant’s death</h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The sports gear giant is said to have pulled all items tied to Kobe Bryant from its website, <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.espn.com/nba/story/_/id/28579323/nike-suspends-online-sale-kobe-bryant-related-products" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">Nick DePaula of ESPN reports</a>. One reported reason: to stop flippers from selling merchandise featuring the late N.B.A. star.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Nike is still figuring out a new strategy</strong> for releasing Mr. Bryant’s shoe line, which has been among the company’s best-selling basketball sneakers. A new colorway had been scheduled for release on Feb. 7.</p>, <h1 class="g-headline" id="g-inlineguide-headline">The Coronavirus Outbreak</h1>, <h2 class="g-inlineguide-list-header g-optimize-type">What do you need to know? Start here.</h2>, <p class="g-inlineguide-date">Updated Feb. 10, 2020</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">But it’s also worried about people buying up Kobe products</strong> and then reselling them online at much higher prices. “On some secondary marketplaces, prices for Bryant’s sneakers and memorabilia have seen a 200-300 percent spike over the past 24 hours,” Mr. DePaula writes.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Other retailers have similar concerns.</strong> The online seller Urban Necessities on Sunday moved to limit price increases on consignment sales of Kobe merchandise “out of respect for his family and legacy.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">More:</strong></em> <em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0"><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.wsj.com/articles/the-last-flight-of-kobe-bryants-life-11580158646" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">A reconstruction</a></em><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0"> of Mr. Bryant’s doomed helicopter flight.</em></p>, <h2 class="css-3ez4hu eoo0vm40" id="link-4b14666">The secret market for your browsing history</h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Avast makes money by selling antivirus software. It also profits by <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.vice.com/en_us/article/qjdkq7/avast-antivirus-sells-user-browsing-data-investigation" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">selling the internet history of users</a> to companies like Google, McKinsey &amp; Company, PepsiCo and more, according to Joseph Cox of Motherboard.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">• Leaked documents from an Avast subsidiary, Jumpshot, “show that the Avast antivirus program installed on a person’s computer collects data, and that Jumpshot repackages it into various different products that are then sold,” Mr. Cox writes.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">• “Avast claims to have more than 435 million active users per month, and Jumpshot says it has data from 100 million devices.” Several Avast users said they didn’t know about the sale of their data.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">• The data “includes Google searches, lookups of locations and GPS coordinates on Google Maps, people visiting companies’ LinkedIn pages, particular YouTube videos, and people visiting porn websites.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">• “It’s great data for these companies, because it’s down to the device level with a timestamp,” an unnamed source told Mr. Cox.</p>, <h2 class="css-3ez4hu eoo0vm40" id="link-280fb6c5">How regular investors lose out on billions to ultrafast traders</h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">High-frequency traders earn a total of nearly $5 billion a year by acting on information before anyone else can — effectively a <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.wsj.com/articles/ultrafast-trading-costs-stock-investors-nearly-5-billion-a-year-study-says-11580126036" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">surcharge on regular investors</a>, according to a new study by Britain’s Financial Conduct Authority.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">• The study focused on “latency arbitrage,” in which high-frequency traders use sophisticated computers and other technology to react to market-moving news within milliseconds, writes Alexander Osipovich of the WSJ.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">• Such arbitrage amounts to a tax of about 0.0042 percent on transactions in Britain. Extrapolated worldwide, that means those traders earned about $4.8 billion, the study finds.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">• The findings come as presidential candidates like Senators Bernie Sanders and Elizabeth Warren push for a financial-transaction tax to curb high-frequency trading and exchanges weigh “speed bumps” to limit latency arbitrage.</p>, <h2 class="css-3ez4hu eoo0vm40" id="link-3347564f">Casper isn’t a unicorn anymore</h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The popular online seller of mattresses disclosed yesterday that its I.P.O. may value it at less than $1 billion. It’s a sign that once-highly-valued start-ups are continuing to face a new, more skeptical reality.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Casper currently expects its shares to be priced at $17 to $19 each</strong>, the company said in <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/1598674/000104746920000503/a2240508zs-1a.htm" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">an updated prospectus</a>. At the high end of that range, the business would be valued at about $745 million.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">The company raised money last year at a </strong><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10"><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2019-03-27/mattress-startup-casper-joins-the-unicorn-club-with-new-funding" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">$1.1 billion valuation</a></strong><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">. </strong>It has pitched itself as a leading direct-to-consumer company that understands how to sell to younger customers online — while also striking partnerships with brick-and-mortar retailers like Target.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">That drop reflects investor concerns</strong> about money-losing companies with no clear path to profitability, which took on new urgency with the flameout of WeWork’s I.P.O. effort last fall. Casper lost about $67 million in the first nine months of last year, and said its ability to make profits depends on … spending more money on growth.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">We’ll see what happens</strong> <strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">if Casper follows through</strong> on the I.P.O., which could price as early as next week.</p>, <h2 class="css-3ez4hu eoo0vm40" id="link-6a531728">The bigger issues behind <em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">that</em> viral nanny post</h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Silicon Valley and Twitter were abuzz last week about a job posting from a mother and C.E.O. looking for a nanny with seemingly lofty qualifications. But there’s more to think about than just poking fun at a very specific job posting.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">In case you missed it, the qualifications included:</strong></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">• The ability to “compare and make recommendations regarding using credit card points to booking vacations versus paying cash.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">• The ability to play math games with the C.E.O.’s twins like “‘how much fish should we buy today for five of us?’”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">• Being able to do calisthenics with the kids and have experience driving in the snow.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">The internet mocked the posting</strong>, calling it “bananas” and “<a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2020/jan/24/nanny-viral-ad-california-ceo" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">the most demanding ad for a nanny ever</a>.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">But the unnamed single mother who wrote it disagrees</strong>, <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://slate.com/human-interest/2020/01/meet-the-silicon-valley-ceo-and-mom-who-wrote-the-viral-extremely-detailed-job-listing-for-a-household-manager-cook-nanny.html" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">telling Ruth Graham of Slate</a>, “What I realize now is that, like a lot of working executives and working moms, I’m spending a significant amount of my time doing research and organizing.” (Petula Dvorak of the WaPo agrees, <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.washingtonpost.com/local/a-silicon-valley-ceo-is-looking-for-a-nanny-who-is-a-lifeguard-international-driver-and-vegan-chef/2020/01/27/f03cd21c-412a-11ea-b5fc-eefa848cde99_story.html" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">writing</a>, “It taps into the trap modern motherhood has become.”)</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">“If I were Scott McNealy, former C.E.O. of Sun Microsystems</strong>, and I’d done this ad, nobody would think twice,” the mom also told Slate.</p>, <h2 class="css-3ez4hu eoo0vm40" id="link-7c091e00">The speed read</h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Deals</strong></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">• Boeing has secured $12 billion in loans to build up a financial cushion as it struggles to return its 737 Max plane to service. (<a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.ft.com/content/1a7729dc-414f-11ea-bdb5-169ba7be433d" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">FT</a>)</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">• Antitrust regulators are reportedly investigating a potential takeover of Dean Foods, the bankrupt milk processor, by a big dairy farmer cooperative. (<a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.wsj.com/articles/regulators-probe-potential-dean-foods-merger-11580147236" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">WSJ</a>)</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">• Why MGM, the cinematic home of James Bond, could be a takeover target this year. (<a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.cnbc.com/2020/01/24/mgm-leads-2020-media-acquisition-targets.html" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">CNBC</a>)</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">• Big fees and bad performance are making hedge funds increasingly unattractive to institutional investors. (<a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.ft.com/content/71b5478c-3d40-11ea-b232-000f4477fbca" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">FT</a>)</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Politics and policy</strong></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">• President Trump announced plans to broaden tariffs on imported steel and aluminum, saying that existing levies haven’t done enough to spur domestic production. (<a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/27/business/economy/trump-steel-tariffs.html" title="">NYT</a>)</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">• Democrats in Pennsylvania are worried that calls to ban fracking could hurt their chances of winning the state in November. (<a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/27/us/politics/pennsylvania-democrats-fracking.html" title="">NYT</a>)</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">• How the Republican Party is increasingly becoming the party of poorer Americans. (<a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2020/01/27/business/economy/republican-party-voters-income.html" title="">NYT</a>)</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Tech</strong></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">• The grocery delivery service Instacart is reportedly fighting efforts by some Illinois employees to unionize. (<a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.vice.com/en_us/article/akw3z8/leaked-memos-show-instacart-is-running-a-union-busting-campaign" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">Motherboard</a>)</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">• The food delivery service Grubhub has listed some restaurants on its platform without their consent. (<a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.sfchronicle.com/food/article/SF-restaurant-Kin-Khao-doesn-t-offer-delivery-15005797.php" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">SF Chronicle</a>)</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">• The hacker who uncovered details about the finances of Africa’s richest woman was initially looking for secrets about soccer teams. (<a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/27/sports/soccer/leaks-dos-santos-rui-pinto.html" title="">NYT</a>)</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">• Did you know that tech giants have in-house musical groups, some with names like Cloudy With a Chance of Beatbox? Now you do. (<a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.wsj.com/articles/what-do-amazon-google-and-salesforce-have-in-common-in-house-music-groups-11580148824" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">WSJ</a>)</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Best of the rest</strong></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">• Federal and state regulators accused Martin Shkreli, the former drug executive, of using anticompetitive tactics to maintain a monopoly over a lifesaving drug. (<a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/27/business/martin-shkreli-ftc-lawsuit.html" title="">NYT</a>)</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">• Prince Andrew of Britain has offered “zero cooperation” in a U.S. investigation into Jeffrey Epstein, according to the federal prosecutor for the Southern District of New York. (<a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/27/nyregion/jeffrey-epstein-prince-andrew.html" title="">NYT</a>)</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">• “Americans Will Inherit $764 Billion This Year, Mostly Tax-Free.” (<a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2020-01-28/americans-will-inherit-764-billion-this-year-mostly-tax-free" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">Bloomberg</a>)</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">• There won’t be any more free beer and wine on tap at WeWork locations. (<a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.businessinsider.com/wework-cutting-free-beer-and-wine-tap-us-canada-2020-1" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">Business Insider</a>)</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">We’d love your feedback. Please email thoughts and suggestions to </em><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="mailto:business@nytimes.com?subject=Newsletter%20Feedback" title=""><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">business@nytimes.com</em></a><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">.</em></p>, <p>Advertisement</p>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd" id="site-index-label">Site Index</h2>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-0">news</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-1">opinion</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-2">arts</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-3">living</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-4">more</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-subscribe-label">Subscribe</h3>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd">Site Information Navigation</h2>]
[<p>Advertisement</p>, <p>Supported by</p>, <p class="css-tsacue e6idgb70">The Checkup</p>, <h1 class="css-fnr6md e1h9rw200" id="link-cefce59" itemprop="headline"><span>Leaving Shanghai as the Coronavirus Extended Its Reach</span></h1>, <p class="css-1ifw933 e1wiw3jv0" id="article-summary">There was a getting-out-of-Dodge feeling as we boarded the airplane, although airplanes — with their recycled air — are very effective settings for the spread of respiratory infections.</p>, <p class="css-1fv7b6t e1jsehar1" itemprop="author" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">By<!-- --> <a class="css-brehiz e1jsehar0" href="https://www.nytimes.com/by/perri-klass-md"><span class="css-1baulvz last-byline" itemprop="name">Perri Klass, M.D.</span></a></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">When I flew to China at the beginning of January to <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/20/well/family/bilingual-toddlers-china-learning-english.html" title="">teach a three-week college class</a>, the Wuhan coronavirus was barely on anyone’s radar. By the time I got back to New York last Friday, it was front page news around the world, with more than 800 cases in China and 26 deaths; by Monday, the total was at least 80 deaths.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">My students and I had all arrived a few days after China had reported the first cases of pneumonia in Wuhan to the World Health Organization, and shut down <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/25/world/asia/china-markets-coronavirus-sars.html?action=click&amp;module=RelatedLinks&amp;pgtype=Article" title="">the seafood market</a> that was thought to have been the origin of the epidemic.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">I was teaching students from a wide variety of countries, who were in China for their first time. When they first brought up the question of the virus in Wuhan, I have to admit that my reaction was basically to reassure them, in line with all the official reassurances, and then to ask how many of them had gotten their annual flu shots. Wuhan was more than 500 miles away, and none of them would be going there.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The virus had been identified as a new coronavirus on the first day of our class. By the end of the first week, the first death was reported, followed by the first overseas case. So sometime in the second week, the students, who had presumably been hearing from their anxious faraway parents, started to ask whether there was anything here to worry about. I gave stock answers: the situation is being monitored, no one here has been anywhere near Wuhan — but then again, I acknowledged, you have to take it seriously; you never know what a virus is going to do.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">[<strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10"><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">Read the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention’s </em></strong><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10"><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/index.html" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title=""><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">update on the coronavirus</em></a></strong><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10"><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">.</em></strong>]</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">As a pediatrician who has done a fair amount of traveling and worked in clinics in the United States through a variety of outbreaks (H1N1, SARS, Ebola, measles), I made the usual suggestions, which people find so unsatisfying when they’re scared: Stay as healthy as you can, get lots of sleep, drink lots of water. Wash your hands, wash your hands, wash your hands. That will help keep you safe from all kinds of infections, I said, remembering that students often come down with the standard winter colds and other viral infections during the intense three weeks of the January term.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">And yes, I asked them how many had gotten the annual flu shots that I knew all student health services are anxious to give — and sure enough, many of them had not. So I allowed myself to give a pompous little lecture about all the thousands of <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.cdc.gov/flu/about/burden/preliminary-in-season-estimates.htm" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">people dying of influenza</a> — and the thousands more who will die before the flu season is over. Why didn’t <em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">that</em> scare them, I wanted to know — at least enough to get their flu shots? Why were some cases of pneumonia in Wuhan — and some deaths, but fewer than 10 at that point — so much more terrifying?</p>, <h1 class="g-headline" id="g-inlineguide-headline">The Coronavirus Outbreak</h1>, <h2 class="g-inlineguide-list-header g-optimize-type">What do you need to know? Start here.</h2>, <p class="g-inlineguide-date">Updated Feb. 10, 2020</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">If I had held up a syringe full of some unknown mixture and announced that it was an untested compound that might protect against the Wuhan virus, would people have knocked one another over in the race to get injected?</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Well, things moved fast, and they only got scarier. The students got updates from the university, and more worried messages from their parents, and the news out of Wuhan got worse. I had seen Wuhan as far away, but the parents, much farther away, saw it as very close — and in some ways, they were right. And cases were beginning to be reported from other countries in Asia.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Halfway through the three-week course, I checked and confirmed that no human-to-human transmission had been reported at that point, and explained to the students why that was reassuring — but also, given the history of viruses that have <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/22/health/china-virus.html" title="">jumped from animals to humans, like SARS</a>, why it needed to be monitored, and might change. And sure enough, at the beginning of the third and last week of classes, human-to-human transmission was confirmed.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The students who did get sick with the usual January respiratory illnesses were frightened. They got checked out, they got treated, and they had to sit through another lecture from me about getting that flu shot — not because it would protect them against this new infection, but because anyone who came down with influenza would now be terrified it might be the new coronavirus. And because influenza is also a serious illness, and there will continue to be a lot of it around.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The day before the course ended, as everyone was packing up to leave, the city of Wuhan was closed to air travel and other forms of transport, essentially locked down. What had seemed kind of unimaginable a week before suddenly seemed very close. Was it possible the travel ban would extend to all of China? And was the <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/26/world/asia/coronavirus-wuhan-china-hubei.html?action=click&amp;module=Top%20Stories&amp;pgtype=Homepage" title="">Wuhan quarantine</a> an extreme measure, or was it too little too late?</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The story was changing every day — new information, new anxieties. Chinese New Year celebrations were being scaled down or canceled in many parts of China. New cases were being reported from France, Canada, Australia, the United States. <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.washingtonpost.com/science/2020/01/24/scientists-are-unraveling-chinese-coronavirus-with-unprecedented-speed-openness/" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">Scientific inquiry was proceeding fast</a>, seemingly with good cooperation.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">We were all told to be sure to get to the airport four hours early, since there would be extra screening measures. In fact, since we were traveling on the eve of the lunar New Year, the airport was pretty empty when we got there, as were the roads on the way — the vacation had begun, no one was working, and most people had already done their traveling and were in place for the holiday. There was a sign at the airport informing us that we were walking through a temperature scanner, but the lines moved quickly.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Everyone was wearing masks, from basic surgical masks, which were being handed out in hotels and offices, to much more elaborate closefitting masks with respirators in them. There are reports that the masks don’t help, but it’s probably fair to say that they decrease, but don’t eliminate, the chance of infection. And there was a very definite getting-out-of-Dodge feeling as we boarded the airplane (never mind that airplanes — with their recycled air — are actually very effective settings for the spread of respiratory infections) and took off. Some people took their masks off, others kept them on for the whole 14 hours. No one was coughing on the flight.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">When I left Shanghai on Friday, no deaths from the virus had been reported there. By Sunday, <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/26/world/china-coronavirus.html" title="">the city’s first death had been reported</a>. On the way to the airport, I read the notice from the hospital in New York where I see pediatric patients, giving us the city guidelines for screening patients, checking travel histories, isolating people with fever and lower respiratory symptoms, along with a history of travel from Wuhan, or contact with a person who may have the virus.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">There was something ironic, of course, about the idea of coming back from China to what might be a higher exposure risk (lots of sick people in a hospital). Everyone who works in a health care setting has seen some version of this over and over (we still have the signs up about screening for Ebola). New viruses do appear, and you never know what a virus is going to do, but you have to take the information you have and do your best. (And at least, at the clinic, everyone gets a flu shot.)</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">So there was also something very comforting in the matter-of-fact directions. And oddly, maybe especially in the very matter-of-fact statement, “Please note, all guidance is subject to change as additional information becomes available.”</p>, <p>Advertisement</p>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd" id="site-index-label">Site Index</h2>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-0">news</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-1">opinion</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-2">arts</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-3">living</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-4">more</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-subscribe-label">Subscribe</h3>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd">Site Information Navigation</h2>]
[<p>Advertisement</p>, <p>Supported by</p>, <p class="css-tsacue e6idgb70">New York Today</p>, <h1 class="css-fnr6md e1h9rw200" id="link-1195f412" itemprop="headline"><span>Coronavirus in New York: What We Know So Far </span></h1>, <p class="css-1fv7b6t e1jsehar1" itemprop="author" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">By<!-- --> <a class="css-brehiz e1jsehar0" href="https://www.nytimes.com/by/azi-paybarah"><span class="css-1baulvz last-byline" itemprop="name">Azi Paybarah</span></a></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0"> [Want to get New York Today by email? </em><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/newsletters/newyorktoday" title=""><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">Here’s the sign-up</em></a><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">.]</em></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">It’s Tuesday.</strong> </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Weather: </strong>Breezy and partly sunny, with a high in the low 40s.<span class="css-8l6xbc evw5hdy0"> </span></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Alternate-side parking</strong>: In effect until Feb. 12 (Lincoln’s Birthday). </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">New York City is home to the largest Chinese population of any city outside Asia, officials here say. And people have been celebrating the Lunar New Year, one of China’s biggest holidays, with <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://gothamist.com/arts-entertainment/lunar-new-year-2020-year-rat-festivities-around-nyc" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">events throughout New York</a> and trips to China to visit relatives.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">So, when a new <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/29/business/china-coronavirus-economy.html" title="">coronavirus</a> began spreading in <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/29/business/china-coronavirus-economy.html" title="">Wuhan, China</a>, New York officials took notice.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">In China, the virus has killed more than 100 people and sickened more than 4,500. In affected areas, Chinese officials have closed schools, curtailed bus travel and canceled public gatherings, hoping to prevent the virus from spreading.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Cases of the new coronavirus have also been reported in the United States, including in California, Washington State, Arizona and Chicago.
