All of those patients had <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/article/what-is-coronavirus.html" title="">recently traveled to China</a>, The Times reported.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">[</em><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/27/nyregion/new-york-city-coronavirus.html" title=""><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">New York braces for the coronavirus</em></a><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">.]</em></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">In New York, “it’s inevitable that we will have someone who is positive with coronavirus,” the city’s health commissioner, Dr. Oxiris Barbot, told my colleagues on Sunday.</p>, <h3 class="css-1ldy5g8 e1gnsphs0" id="link-48cb236b">What is the coronavirus?</h3>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">It is a virus that attacks the respiratory system in humans and animals.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Symptoms can include a fever, severe cough, difficulty breathing and lung lesions. Milder cases may seem to be the flu or a bad cold. After a person is infected, it can take up to two weeks for symptoms to appear.</p>, <h1 class="g-headline" id="g-inlineguide-headline">The Coronavirus Outbreak</h1>, <h2 class="g-inlineguide-list-header g-optimize-type">How Is the U.S. Being Affected?</h2>, <p class="g-inlineguide-date">Updated Feb.10, 2020</p>, <h3 class="css-1ldy5g8 e1gnsphs0" id="link-475cc241">How does it spread?</h3>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Officials have not fully determined where exactly the virus started or how it is transmitted.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Though coronavirus has been reported in countries other than China, it does not appear to be spreading within those countries, according to the World Health Organization.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“At this time, there is no evidence of human-to-human transmission outside China,” Dr. Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus, the W.H.O.’s director general, said at a news conference. “That doesn’t mean it won’t happen.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Finding out how the coronavirus spreads may require help from a disease detective (like those who investigated <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2019/04/11/nyregion/newyorktoday/nyc-news-measles-disease-detective.html" title="">the measles outbreak in New York</a> last year).</p>, <h3 class="css-1ldy5g8 e1gnsphs0" id="link-40829e61">The flu is the bigger threat in New York right now</h3>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The mystery surrounding the coronavirus may also overshadow the dangers that New Yorkers face from a more common virus: the flu.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">New York State keeps track of flu cases and reports the totals each week. Starting in October, cases start trickling in. They peak around January and February and usually peter out by August.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The 2017-18 flu season was particularly bad in the state. At its peak, there were more than 10,000 flu cases reported each week for five consecutive weeks, starting toward the end of January.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">This flu season looks as if it may be worse. More than 57,000 flu cases have been reported across the state, according to the <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://nyshc.health.ny.gov/web/nyapd/new-york-state-flu-tracker" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">New York State Flu Tracker</a>.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">There were more than 13,000 cases in the state for the week that ended on Jan. 18, the most recent week for which data was available. Of those, more than 7,000 were in New York City.</p>, <h3 class="css-1ldy5g8 e1gnsphs0" id="link-2336ed71">The reaction to the new coronavirus</h3>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Some people in Queens who recently traveled to China have self-quarantined.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Dr. Barbot, the health commissioner, <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/27/nyregion/new-york-city-coronavirus.html" title="">said New Yorkers should remain calm</a>, take precautions and go about their day normally. Travelers should note that the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention has recommended that people <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/26/travel/Coronavirus-travel.html" title="">avoid all nonessential travel</a> to China.</p>, <h2 class="css-1320w4z eoo0vm40" id="link-62af30bb">From The Times</h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/27/nyregion/jeffrey-epstein-prince-andrew.html" title="">Prince Andrew Offers ‘Zero Cooperation’ in Epstein Case, Prosecutor Says</a></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/27/nyregion/harvey-weinstein-trial-mimi-haleyi.html" title="">Weinstein Trial: ‘I’m Being Raped,’ Recalls ‘Project Runway’ Assistant</a></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/27/dining/spotted-pig-closes-ken-friedman.html" title="">The Spotted Pig, Where Employees Were Sexually Harassed, Closes</a></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/27/nyregion/climate-change-nj-environmental-rules.html" title="">With 130-Mile Coast, New Jersey Marks a First in Climate Change Fight</a></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Want more news? <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/section/nyregion" title="">Check out our full coverage</a>.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">The Mini Crossword:</strong> Here is <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/crosswords/game/mini" title="">today’s puzzle</a>.</p>, <h2 class="css-1320w4z eoo0vm40" id="link-783cf870">What we’re reading</h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Lawmakers will investigate why black and Latino people in New York City are issued a disproportionate number of <strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">jaywalking tickets</strong>. [<a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://nyc.streetsblog.org/2020/01/27/streetsblog-gets-action-council-will-probe-nypds-biased-jaywalking-enforcement/" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">Streetsblog</a>]</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Will a new bookstore open in the space in Manhattan once occupied by <strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Book Culture</strong>? [<a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.westsiderag.com/2020/01/24/__trashed-4" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">West Side Rag</a>]</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">If the mayor can’t reduce the <strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">deer population on Staten Island </strong>with vasectomies, the congressman there would be glad to participate in a cull, he said. [<a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.silive.com/news/2020/01/max-rose-says-hell-start-taking-down-some-of-these-deer-himself-if-controlled-deer-cull-approved.html" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">Staten Island Advance</a>]</p>, <h2 class="css-1320w4z eoo0vm40" id="link-61756fc2">Coming up today </h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Learn about <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://rsecure.metmuseum.org/event/ticket/580927?program=all&amp;location=main%7Cbreuer%7Ccloisters&amp;endDate=1%2F29%2F2020%2011:59:59%20PM&amp;startDate=1%2F26%2F2020%2012:18:38%20PM&amp;page=6" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">paintings inspired by the Indian epic “Ramayana”</a> during a talk at the Metropolitan Museum of Art in Manhattan. 11 a.m. [$30]</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The translators of “The Criminal Child: Selected Essays by Jean Genet” <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.mcnallyjackson.com/event/criminal-child-selected-essays-jean-genet-charlotte-mandell-and-jeffrey-zuckerman-prince" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">discuss their work</a> at McNally Jackson on Prince Street in Manhattan. 7 p.m. [Free]</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“<a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.dromnyc.com/e/jambalaya-brass-monkeys-brass-queens-and-flowmingos-87322388615/" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">JAMbalaya!</a>” is an evening of New Orleans-style jamming with three brass bands at Drom in Manhattan. 8 p.m. [$10]</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">— Alex Traub</em></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">Events are subject to change, so double-check before heading out. For more events, see </em><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/spotlight/arts-listings" title=""><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">the going-out guides</em></a><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0"> from The Times’s culture pages.</em></p>, <h2 class="css-1320w4z eoo0vm40" id="link-431f15e6">And finally: Kobe Bryant, from the archives</h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">Kobe Bryant shooting over Jamal Crawford at Madison Square Garden in 2006 as his Los Angeles Lakers faced off against the Knicks.</em></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Mr. Bryant, who was <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/26/sports/kobe-bryant-obituary.html" title="">killed in a helicopter crash</a> north of Los Angeles on Sunday, had a glittering 20-year career with the Lakers that included many visits to Madison Square Garden to take on the Knicks.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">But when he first played with his team in New York City, <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.basketball-reference.com/boxscores/199611050NYK.html" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">on Nov. 5, 1996</a>, Mr. Bryant didn’t exactly impress onlookers. He started the game on the bench and played just over three minutes. He made one of two free throws. He also had one turnover. By the end, he had scored only 1 point, but the Lakers edged out the Knicks, 98-92.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Mr. Bryant went on, of course, to have a spectacular career that dazzled legions of fans in New York and beyond. His <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.basketball-reference.com/boxscores/201511080NYK.html" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">last game in Manhattan</a> was on Nov. 8, 2015. He started, played more than 32 minutes and scored 18 points — with a pair of 3-pointers, a pair of rebounds, three assists and a steal.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">This time, though, the Knicks won, 99-95.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">It’s Tuesday — stay in the game.</em></p>, <h2 class="css-1320w4z eoo0vm40" id="link-ddd77f2">Metropolitan Diary: Sharing</h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Dear Diary:</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">I was in Vanderbilt Hall at Grand Central Terminal. The couple I was sharing a table with in the food pavilion warmed up to friendly conversation, sharing their recent food discoveries and favorite restaurants.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">After chatting, they returned to their butternut squash soup, and I to my butter and knekkebrod.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The woman received something on her phone.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“Look,” she said to her husband, “he sent a picture.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">She turned to me.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“Our son just shaved his head bald for the first time,” she said.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Maybe it was my raised eyebrows, or the way I said, “Ohhh.” Either way, she felt the need to explain.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“He already lost most of his hair,” she said. “It’s called ‘embracing it.’”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">— Paul Klenk</em></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">New York Today is published weekdays around 6 a.m. </em><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/newsletters/newyorktoday?module=inline" title=""><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">Sign up here</em></a><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0"> to get it by email. You can also find it at </em><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="http://www.nytoday.com/" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title=""><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">nytoday.com</em></a><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">.</em></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">We’re experimenting with the format of New York Today. What would you like to see more (or less) of? Post a comment or email us: </em><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="mailto:nytoday@nytimes.com" title=""><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">nytoday@nytimes.com</em></a><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">.</em></p>, <p>Advertisement</p>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd" id="site-index-label">Site Index</h2>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-0">news</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-1">opinion</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-2">arts</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-3">living</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-4">more</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-subscribe-label">Subscribe</h3>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd">Site Information Navigation</h2>]
[<p>Advertisement</p>, <p>Supported by</p>, <h1 class="css-1s4ffep e1h9rw200" id="link-ac8a5cc" itemprop="headline"><span>Coronavirus: Death Toll Climbs, and So Does the Number of Infections</span></h1>, <p class="css-1ifw933 e1wiw3jv0" id="article-summary">The number of known cases of the new virus rose by nearly a third overnight. A shortage of test kits has led experts to warn that the real number may be higher. </p>, <p class="css-1fv7b6t e1jsehar1" itemprop="author" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">By<!-- --> <span class="css-1baulvz last-byline" itemprop="name">The New York Times</span></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"></p>, <h2 class="css-3ez4hu eoo0vm40" id="link-16be7b31">Death toll climbs above 130, and the number of infections jumps as well.</h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">As the outbreak of the mysterious new <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/02/10/upshot/coronavirus-risk-prevention-advice.html" title="">coronavirus</a> rapidly spreads, the Chinese authorities said on Wednesday that the official count of known cases jumped again overnight, with the death toll now exceeding 130.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">◆ <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/02/10/upshot/coronavirus-risk-prevention-advice.html" title="">China</a> said on Wednesday that 132 people had died from the virus, which is believed to have originated in the <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2020/world/asia/china-wuhan-coronavirus-maps.html" title="">central city of Wuhan and is spreading across the country</a>. The previous count, on Tuesday, was 106.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">◆ The number of confirmed cases increased to 5,974 on Wednesday, up from 4,515 on Tuesday, according to the National Health Commission. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">◆ Most of the confirmed cases have been in the central Chinese province of Hubei, where several cities, including Wuhan, the epicenter of the outbreak, have been placed under what amounts to a lockdown. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">◆ Thailand has reported 14 cases of infection; Hong Kong has eight; the United States, Taiwan, Australia and Macau have five each; Singapore, South Korea and Malaysia each have reported four; Japan has seven; France has four; Canada has three; Vietnam has two; and Nepal, Cambodia and Germany each have one. There have been no deaths outside China.</p>, <h2 class="css-zd32qr">Wuhan Coronavirus Map: Tracking the Spread of the Outbreak</h2>, <p class="css-1uuihdo">The virus has sickened tens of thousands of people in China and a number of other countries.</p>, <h2 class="css-3ez4hu eoo0vm40" id="link-37490f04">The United States is expanding screenings for coronavirus at airports and borders.</h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The United States is <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/28/health/airports-screening-coronavirus.html" title="">expanding the screening of travelers</a> arriving from Wuhan — to 20 airports and land crossings, from five airports, federal officials said on Tuesday.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“Right now, there is no spread of this virus in our communities at home,” said Dr. Robert Redfield, director of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, at a news briefing in Washington.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“The coming days and weeks are likely to bring more cases including the possibility of person-to-person spread,” he said. “Our goal is to contain this virus and prevent sustained spread of the virus in our country.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">[A plane carrying Americans is leaving from Wuhan. If you know anyone on board, or anyone trying to leave Wuhan,</em><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10"><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0"> </em></strong><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">we would like to hear from you for a coming article. Please contact Miriam Jordan at </em><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="mailto:miriam.jordan@nytimes.com" title=""><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">miriam.jordan@nytimes.com</em></a><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0"> to share your story.]</em></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Officials also announced that after repeated offers of assistance, Chinese authorities agreed on Tuesday to allow in teams of international experts, coordinated by the World Health Organization, to help with research and containment.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“Americans should know this is a potentially very serious public health threat, but at this point Americans should not worry for their own safety,” said Alex M. Azar, secretary of health and human services, at the briefing.</p>, <h2 class="css-3ez4hu eoo0vm40" id="link-6cc62093">Scientists race to make a coronavirus vaccine.</h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Scientists in the United States, Australia and at least three companies are working on v<a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/28/health/coronavirus-vaccine.html" title="">accine candidates to stop the spread of the coronavirus.</a></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Government scientists as well as those working at Johnson &amp; Johnson, Moderna Therapeutics and Inovio Pharmaceuticals are all working quickly to develop a vaccine.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The hunt began Jan. 10, when Chinese scientists posted the genetic makeup of the virus on <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/nuccore/MN908947" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">a public database</a>. The next morning, researchers at the National Institutes of Health’s Vaccine Research Center in Maryland went to work. Within hours, they had pinpointed the letters of the genetic code that could be used to make a vaccine.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Historically, vaccines have been one of the greatest public health tools to prevent disease. But even as technology, genomics and global coordination have improved, allowing researchers to move at top speed, vaccine development remains an expensive and risky process. </p>, <h2 class="css-3ez4hu eoo0vm40" id="link-6a326ae9">How the coronavirus is affecting earnings season.</h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The number of infections and deaths related to the outbreak of a mysterious virus in China keeps rising, but economic analysts have counseled caution, saying it’s too soon to ring alarms about the impact on the global economy.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Even so, individually, some American companies with a sizable presence in China are feeling the strain. <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://s22.q4cdn.com/869488222/files/doc_financials/2020/Q1/Q1-FY20-Earnings-Release.pdf" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">Starbucks</a>, for example, announced on Tuesday that it was temporarily shuttering half of its locations there.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“The magnitude of the impact will depend on the duration of store closures as we work with local authorities to manage the situation and protect our partners and customers,” Pat Grismer, chief financial officer, said during an earnings call.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Other companies that closed stores there included McDonald’s and Yum China, the country’s largest restaurant company, which operates the KFC, Pizza Hut and Taco Bell brands in China and also controls its own brands.</p>, <h1 class="g-headline" id="g-inlineguide-headline">The Coronavirus Outbreak</h1>, <h2 class="g-inlineguide-list-header g-optimize-type">What do you need to know? Start here.</h2>, <p class="g-inlineguide-date">Updated Feb. 10, 2020</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Travel restrictions in China and screening at airports in other countries have also disrupted plans. United Airlines announced today that it was suspending some flights. American Airlines stock fell more than 5 percent on Tuesday.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Hotels and resorts with properties in the affected areas, which include Macau, a special administrative region and gambling mecca, like Wynn Resorts, Las Vegas Sands and MGM Resorts International also saw the value of their shares sink. Marriott, Hyatt and Hilton which have several properties in China also saw their stock prices slide.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Other brands that are popular in China, like Estee Lauder, Nike and Tapestry, which sells Coach, Kate Spade and Stuart Weitzman, are likely to see a dent in earnings, bank analysts said.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Anxiety about sales spread to Chinese tech companies including Alibaba, JD.com, and Baidu.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">China is the world’s second largest economy.</p>, <h2 class="css-3ez4hu eoo0vm40" id="link-29114c32">Japan has evacuated some of its citizens.</h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">A charter plane hired by the Japanese government to evacuate citizens from Wuhan landed at a Tokyo airport Wednesday morning. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Outside, tour buses — with drivers in sanitary masks — and some ambulances waited to accept the 206 passengers. Japanese news media reported that one of the passengers had a fever and one was coughing.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">In a news conference late Tuesday, Japanese authorities said that people who showed symptoms would be transferred directly to a hospital, while those who appeared healthy would be tested for the virus and then asked to quarantine themselves for two weeks.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The flight left Tokyo Tuesday night carrying medical supplies requested by the Chinese government to help fight the viral outbreak that has put Wuhan and other cities on lockdown.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">At another news conference, two of the passengers expressed relief at being back in Japan.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Authorities plan to send a second plane Wednesday night to Wuhan, where around 450 Japanese citizens still await evacuation.</p>, <h2 class="css-3ez4hu eoo0vm40" id="link-30001f85">United Airlines suspends some flights from the United States to China.</h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">United Airlines said on Tuesday that it will reduce flights between the United States and Beijing, Hong Kong and Shanghai because of a “significant decline in demand.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">United said in a statement that it would cut flights starting Feb. 1, through Feb. 8. The suspension will affect 24 flights.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“We will continue to monitor the situation as it develops and will adjust our schedule as needed,” United said. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Delta Air Lines and American Airlines have not yet cut flights to China, but have said they are closely monitoring the situation there as the coronavirus spreads.</p>, <h2 class="css-3ez4hu eoo0vm40" id="link-15b9fb41">France confirms fourth case of the virus.</h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">A fourth case of the new coronavirus was confirmed in France, Jérôme Salomon,<span class="css-8l6xbc evw5hdy0"> </span>an official in the health ministry, announced on Tuesday.<span class="css-8l6xbc evw5hdy0"> </span></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The patient is a tourist from Hubei province, Mr. Salomon said. He was in serious condition in the intensive care unit of a Paris hospital,<span class="css-8l6xbc evw5hdy0"> </span>and the authorities were seeking out anyone who had been in close contact with the man, who is in his eighties. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The previously identified cases affected a 48-year-old man in Bordeaux and a 31-year-old man and 30-year-old woman in Paris.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">France is also working with China to repatriate French citizens in Wuhan, with a first flight scheduled for later in the week. Agnès Buzyn, France’s health minister, said on Tuesday that about 500 to 1,000 French citizens could qualify.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Those who return without any symptoms will be quarantined for 14 days, and those who present possible symptoms will be hospitalized. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Other European countries have also asked France to help bring back some of their own citizens on those flights, Ms. Buzyn said.</p>, <h2 class="css-3ez4hu eoo0vm40" id="link-4d2a1ef0">Germany and Japan say the virus has spread in their countries.</h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Health officials on Tuesday reported what appear to be the first known cases of human-to-human transmission of the virus in Europe — specifically, in Germany — and in Japan. Another case was recently reported in Vietnam.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The cases show that countries across the world are now faced with the task of limiting the spread of the disease on their own soil, not just seeking to identify and quarantine ailing patients who had traveled from China.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Japan’s Ministry of Health, Labor and Welfare said the first Japanese national — and the sixth person in Japan overall — to be diagnosed with the coronavirus was a man in his 60s. He had never been to Wuhan, but he had worked as a bus driver earlier this month for two different group tours from that city, officials said. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The man began experiencing symptoms on Jan. 14, was hospitalized on Saturday and was confirmed to have the coronavirus on Tuesday.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The infected German, whose case was also confirmed on Tuesday, is a 33-year-old man from Bavaria who had been in contact with a Chinese woman in Germany, officials said. The woman was diagnosed with the virus after flying home to China. The man was in good condition, German officials said. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“It was to be expected that the virus would come to Germany,” Jens Spahn, Germany’s health minister, said in a statement on Tuesday. “But the Bavarian case shows us that we are well prepared.” </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The World Health Organization said on Friday that there appeared to have been <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.who.int/docs/default-source/coronaviruse/situation-reports/20200124-sitrep-4-2019-ncov.pdf" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">a case of human-to-human transmission in Vietnam</a>, where a person who had never been to China, but who had a relative who had visited Wuhan, was confirmed to have the virus.</p>, <h2 class="css-3ez4hu eoo0vm40" id="link-14f298b0">Hong Kong puts significant limits on travel from the mainland.<span class="css-8l6xbc evw5hdy0"> </span></h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Hong Kong on Tuesday put in place a broad series of restrictions aimed at controlling the spread of the coronavirus by limiting the number of mainland Chinese travelers entering the territory, one of Asia’s busiest travel and financial hubs.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The restrictions — which included the suspension of high-speed and other train services between Hong Kong and the mainland, a 50 percent reduction in the number of flights — and a ban on tourism visas for many travelers — were announced by Carrie Lam, the city’s chief executive.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The regulations, which apply to some plane, rail, bus and ferry arrivals, will begin on Thursday. They follow days of rising pressure from health care workers, epidemiologists and even pro-Beijing politicians who have traditionally supported Mrs. Lam’s government.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Hong Kong has so far recorded eight confirmed cases of the virus.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Tibet, the only region in China that has yet to report any cases, has temporarily closed all tourist sites, state news media reported. Major Chinese cities, including Shanghai and Beijing, have suspended long-distance bus services. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The medical faculty of the Chinese University of Hong Kong called for more restrictions on border checkpoints as the virus spreads across China.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Workers from Hong Kong’s Hospital Authority have planned a strike for next week to demand a law requiring the wearing of masks in public and banning all visitors from entering the city through the mainland.</p>, <h2 class="css-3ez4hu eoo0vm40" id="link-86a4375">Ethiopia and Ivory Coast test suspected cases. </h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Numerous African countries are shoring up coronavirus screening efforts at major airports, and samples from at least five potentially infected patients were being tested. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Ethiopia’s state minister of health <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://twitter.com/lia_tadesse/status/1222146999371300865" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">confirmed</a> on Tuesday that four potential cases were isolated in the capital, Addis Ababa, pending laboratory tests. On Monday, officials in Ivory Coast said they were testing a suspected case related to a female student who had traveled from Beijing to the capital, Abidjan. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The epidemic comes as travel between China and African states has increased at a rapid pace. As Beijing has ramped up its diplomatic, economic and political support for African states, Chinese firms and migrants have been setting up shop in cities from Nairobi to Johannesburg.<span class="css-8l6xbc evw5hdy0"> </span></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Data from the China Africa Research Initiative at Johns Hopkins University <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="http://www.sais-cari.org/data-chinese-workers-in-africa" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">put the number of official Chinese workers</a> as of 2017 at over 202,000. African entrepreneurs have moved to Chinese cities, while African students now <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://theconversation.com/china-tops-us-and-uk-as-destination-for-anglophone-african-students-78967" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">make up a large percentage of the foreign student body</a> in China. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">On Tuesday, Kenya Airways announced that the health authorities had quarantined a passenger who traveled from Guangzhou. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Because of the Chinese New Year celebration, “a good number of African students living in Wuhan or Hubei traveled home before the extent of the virus became clear,” said Hannah Ryder, chief executive of the Beijing-headquartered consultancy Development Reimagined.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“It’s unclear how exposed they may have been and if governments have the resources to check on them,” she said. </p>, <h2 class="css-3ez4hu eoo0vm40" id="link-78081cf">World Health Organization buries updated global risk assessment in a footnote. </h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The World Health Organization revised its global risk assessment for the coronavirus outbreak from “moderate” to “high,” but concealed the change in a footnote buried in a report published on Monday. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The change to the report, which coincided with a visit to China by the organization’s director-general, risked confusing the public about the severity of the outbreak, which has killed more than 100 people in China and been found in at least 14 countries.<span class="css-8l6xbc evw5hdy0"> </span></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">In a statement, the organization said the director-general, Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus, and Chinese officials “discussed measures to protect the health of Chinese and foreigners in outbreak areas, including possible alternatives to evacuation of foreigners if there are ways to accommodate them and protect their health.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Chinese state-run media reported that Dr. Tedros met with President Xi Jinping of China and spoke highly of Chinese efforts. Mr. Xi urged the health organization to assess the epidemic in an “objective, fair, calm and rational manner.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">In Hubei, medical workers have complained about a desperate need for resources to treat thousands of patients who have at times overwhelmed hospitals.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The group, which is a United Nations body, was criticized when it refused twice in recent days to declare the outbreak a global emergency, despite its spread.</p>, <h2 class="css-3ez4hu eoo0vm40" id="link-54fd1342">Shortage of test kits in China prompts concern that cases have been underreported. </h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">A shortage of medical kits in China needed to quickly diagnose the coronavirus has slowed the country’s ability to respond to the outbreak and fueled concerns that the number of cases has been underreported.<span class="css-8l6xbc evw5hdy0"> </span></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">China’s Medical Products Administration said on Sunday that it had approved four new virus detection kits, including one that sequences the genetic makeup of the disease.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">But China’s three leading medical device manufacturers said they did not have the capacity to quickly produce the products, according to state news media reports.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Residents in Wuhan who arrived at hospitals to seek testing were told that medical workers did not have the kits needed to confirm a diagnosis.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“For any new emerging virus, most local hospitals or public health laboratories will not able to make a diagnosis” said Yuen Kwok-yung, the chairman of the infectious diseases department at Hong Kong University.<span class="css-8l6xbc evw5hdy0"> </span>“Thus many cases will not be investigated at all if they are mild.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">A woman in Wuhan told The South China Morning Post that her uncle learned he had viral pneumonia after a CT scan, but that the doctor could not confirm it was the new virus because no testing kits were available. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">China may have to rely on outside technical support as front line responders battle to contain the virus’s spread, experts said. The Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation said Sunday that it would commit $5 million to help China respond to the crisis, including “efforts to identify and confirm cases.”</p>, <h2 class="css-3ez4hu eoo0vm40" id="link-6b48f33c">U.S. health officials recommend avoiding China, and businesses follow suit.</h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">As the outbreak continues to spread, global companies have begun to limit their workers’ travel to mainland China, and China’s biggest companies have urged employees to work from home.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">On Monday, health officials in the United States urged travelers to <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://wwwnc.cdc.gov/travel/notices/warning/novel-coronavirus-china" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">avoid any nonessential travel to China</a>, and many companies cited that as justification for internal travel bans. The <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://wwwnc.cdc.gov/travel/notices/warning/novel-coronavirus-china" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">new guidance</a>, from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, warned that transportation in and out of Hubei Province, the center of the outbreak, is restricted, and that there is “limited access to adequate medical care in affected areas.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Companies with large operations or interest in China, like General Motors, Honeywell, Bloomberg and Facebook, have all warned employees not to travel within mainland China in a flurry of emails in recent days.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Honeywell, which has offices and operations across China, said it had restricted travel to certain regions, without specifying them. A spokesperson for General Motors said the company had issued a global ban on travel to China, under which only “business-critical” travel would be allowed.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Bloomberg told its employees in Hong Kong and mainland China to work remotely until further notice, and it barred other employees from traveling to either place for the next 30 days, according to an email seen by The New York Times. Facebook said it asked all employees to suspend nonessential travel and asked those who had recently been in China to work from home for a period of time.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The authorities in China have extended the Lunar New Year holiday to Feb. 3, and some of China’s biggest cities have gone further, telling businesses not to open until the next week. The country’s biggest technology companies, including Alibaba, Tencent, Bytedance, Sina, Maimai, Netease and Didi, told employees to work from home from Feb. 3 to Feb. 10.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Netease, an internet and entertainment platform, asked employees returning from another city within China to quarantine themselves for 14 days.</p>, <h2 class="css-3ez4hu eoo0vm40" id="link-458f4168">Worries rise about the outbreak’s economic impact.</h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">After sharp losses around the world on Monday, investors on Tuesday continued to assess the <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/27/business/coronavirus-china-economic-impact.html" title="">long-term economic effects</a> of the coronavirus epidemic. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The verdict was mixed. Investors abandoned stocks in Asia, while markets in Europe steadied. In the United States, the S&amp;P 500 was up more than 1 percent on Tuesday.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Many of Asia’s stock markets were closed for the Lunar New Year holiday, but those that were open — Japan’s and South Korea’s — fell as futures trading in China slumped. Money poured into safe-haven assets like gold and pushed up the value of the United States dollar.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><span class="css-8l6xbc evw5hdy0"> </span></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"> </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"> Hong Kong’s stock market will reopen on Wednesday. In China, where authorities have extended the New Year holiday by a week, the major exchanges in Shenzhen and Shanghai said they would remain closed until Feb. 3.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"> “The coronavirus is the No. 1 threat to financial markets currently as global investors are becoming jittery on the uncertainty,” said Nigel Gre, the founder of the investment group deVere Group.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"></p>, <h2 class="css-3ez4hu eoo0vm40" id="link-3ccd93bb">Back in New York from Wuhan … and into a self-imposed quarantine.</h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Some of the last passengers who arrived at Kennedy International Airport before direct flights from Wuhan were canceled have <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/27/nyregion/new-york-city-coronavirus.html" title="">quarantined themselves at home.</a> </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Scott Liu, 56, who leads an association for immigrants from Hubei, said he confined himself to his house in Queens. He said he and his fellow passengers on the Wuhan flight learned of the lockdown in that city mid-flight.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">He said he has not felt sick, but is taking precautions because he knows symptoms take time to appear. His friends have dropped off on his doorstep traditional Lunar New Year dishes like lotus root and pork rib soup, salted fish and dumplings. Last year, they were host to a big New Year celebration at a banquet hall in Flushing.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">This year, Mr. Liu said, “all the events here are canceled.” </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“Everybody is in a state of panic,” he added.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"></p>, <p class="css-jwz2nf etfikam0">Reporting was contributed by Chris Buckley, Russell Goldman, Elaine Yu, Raymond Zhong, Austin Ramzy, Sui-Lee Wee, Alexandra Stevenson, Cao Li, Eimi Yamamitsu, Tiffany May, Joseph Goldstein, Jeffrey E. Singer, Peter S. Goodman, Roni Caryn Rabin, Motoko Rich, Paul Mozur, Christopher F. Schuetze, Abdi Latif Dahir, Simon Marks, Ben Dooley, Eimi Yamamitsu, Patricia Cohen and Aurelien Breeden. Jin Wu, Zoe Mou, Albee Zhang, Amber Wang, Yiwei Wang and Claire Fu contributed research.</p>, <p>Advertisement</p>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd" id="site-index-label">Site Index</h2>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-0">news</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-1">opinion</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-2">arts</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-3">living</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-4">more</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-subscribe-label">Subscribe</h3>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd">Site Information Navigation</h2>]
[<p>Advertisement</p>, <p>Supported by</p>, <h1 class="css-1s4ffep e1h9rw200" id="link-729d16bc" itemprop="headline"><span>China Will Admit International Experts to Help Contain Coronavirus Outbreak</span></h1>, <p class="css-1ifw933 e1wiw3jv0" id="article-summary">As W.H.O. coordinates scientific teams, federal officials plan to expand screening of travelers from China to 20 ports of entry in the U.S.</p>, <p class="css-1fv7b6t e1jsehar1" itemprop="author" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">By<!-- --> <a class="css-brehiz e1jsehar0" href="https://www.nytimes.com/by/roni-caryn-rabin"><span class="css-1baulvz last-byline" itemprop="name">Roni Caryn Rabin</span></a></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">After repeatedly declining assistance from international health officials, Chinese authorities agreed on Tuesday to permit teams of experts coordinated by the World Health Organization to visit China to help contain the growing coronavirus outbreak.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The news arrived as federal health officials announced expanded screening measures for passengers from China at 20 ports of entry to the United States.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Other travel restrictions have not been ruled out, officials said, though so far only five people in the United States are known to have been infected. Americans are now discouraged from traveling to any part of China.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">At a news briefing in Washington on Tuesday, Alex M. Azar II, the secretary of health and human services — who had just reiterated the offer of scientific and logistical assistance — said he was “delighted” that China was accepting.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The Chinese authorities agreed to work with experts from other countries after a meeting between President Xi Jinping and Dr. Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus, director general of the W.H.O.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The W.H.O. praised China’s response to the outbreak, including its rapid identification of the virus and its “openness to sharing information with W.H.O. and other countries.”</p>, <h1 class="g-headline" id="g-inlineguide-headline">The Coronavirus Outbreak</h1>, <h2 class="g-inlineguide-list-header g-optimize-type">What do you need to know? Start here.</h2>, <p class="g-inlineguide-date">Updated Feb. 10, 2020</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Though the outbreak is continuing in China, federal officials maintained that the risk of infection remains low in the United States.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“Right now, there is no spread of this virus in our communities at home,” Dr. Robert Redfield, director of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, said at the news briefing.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“The coming days and weeks are likely to bring more cases, including the possibility of person-to-person spread,” he added. “Our goal is to contain this virus and prevent sustained spread of the virus in our country.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The C.D.C. has already been screening arrivals from Wuhan, China — epicenter of the coronavirus outbreak — for symptoms of infection at five airports.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10"><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">[</em></strong><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10"><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="http://on.fb.me/1paTQ1h" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title=""><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">Like the Science Times page on Facebook.</em></a></strong><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10"><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0"> </em></strong><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">| Sign up for the </em><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10"><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="http://nyti.ms/1MbHaRU" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title=""><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">Science Times newsletter.</em></a></strong><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10"><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">]</em></strong></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">But the agency also <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.cdc.gov/quarantine/quarantinestations.html" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">oversees a comprehensive quarantine system</a>, including permanent quarantine stations at 20 airports and land border crossings that are staffed with medical officers who routinely screen ill passengers and decide whether they can enter the United States.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Those stations will be equipped and staffed to perform screenings specifically for the Wuhan coronavirus, officials said at the briefing.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“Americans should know this is a potentially very serious public health threat, but at this point Americans should not worry for their own safety,” Mr. Azar said. “This is a very fast-moving, constantly changing situation.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">American scientists are eager to review data that Chinese health officials have said indicates the virus may be transmitted from an infected individual to other people even before the patient shows symptoms.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">So far, the C.D.C. has not been able to confirm that transmissions may occur while patients are asymptomatic, Dr. Redfield said.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">It’s a question that could have implications for the spread of the Wuhan coronavirus, and affect screening measures and other public health steps that must be taken, said Dr. Anthony Fauci, the director of the National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Asymptomatic transmission is not believed to be a large factor in viral outbreaks. “The driver of an outbreak has always been a symptomatic person,” Dr. Fauci said. “An epidemic is not driven by asymptomatic carriers.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">There was no evidence that people were contagious before they showed symptoms during outbreaks of other coronavirus diseases, like SARS and MERS, which might suggest that such transmission is unlikely with the new coronavirus.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Dr. Redfield said the C.D.C. could not rule out additional measures as scientists learned more about the new coronavirus.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“All options have to be on the table, including travel restrictions,” he said. “But diseases are not terribly good at respecting borders.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">Denise Grady contributed reporting from New York.</em></p>, <p>Advertisement</p>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd" id="site-index-label">Site Index</h2>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-0">news</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-1">opinion</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-2">arts</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-3">living</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-4">more</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-subscribe-label">Subscribe</h3>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd">Site Information Navigation</h2>]
[<p>Advertisement</p>, <p>Supported by</p>, <h1 class="css-1s4ffep e1h9rw200" id="link-7856b093" itemprop="headline"><span>A Divided Hong Kong Confronts the Arrival of the Coronavirus</span></h1>, <p class="css-1ifw933 e1wiw3jv0" id="article-summary">Hong Kong announced the shutdown of major rail passenger links and limits on flights coming from the mainland. China will stop issuing visas for individual travelers to the territory.</p>, <p class="css-1fv7b6t e1jsehar1" itemprop="author" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">By<!-- --> <a class="css-brehiz e1jsehar0" href="https://www.nytimes.com/by/austin-ramzy"><span class="css-1baulvz last-byline" itemprop="name">Austin Ramzy</span></a></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">HONG KONG — The two Hong Kong protesters were dressed head to toe in black, their faces covered in masks. They smashed their Molotov cocktails into the lobby of a public housing estate, and flames and smoke began spewing out.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">This was no scene from the protest violence last year over Beijing’s dominance of Hong Kong’s affairs. This was on Sunday, and the firebombing was incited by anger over the coronavirus that originated in Wuhan, China — and plans by the Hong Kong government to use the unoccupied housing block as a quarantine area.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Angst and anger fueled by the coronavirus outbreak, which has killed more than 130 people on the mainland and has eight confirmed cases in Hong Kong, are compounding the bitterness from months of protests against Chief Executive Carrie Lam’s leadership. And it has set her government scrambling.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">On Tuesday, she relented after days of heavy pressure to put harder limits on travel from the mainland to Hong Kong.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Speaking at a news conference with a mask over her face, she announced the shutdown of major rail passenger links and limits on flights for people coming from the mainland. The government in Beijing will also stop issuing visas for individual travelers to Hong Kong from the mainland. Those moves were unprecedented, Hong Kong researchers say, and were avoided even during the height of the SARS epidemic in 2003.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The prospect of a new avenue for criticism of Hong Kong’s government, after months of simmering conflict with protesters, has caused alarm among officials as they are trying to appear responsive to the coronavirus outbreak.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">More broadly, the concern over the outbreak is again bringing resentment of the mainland to the fore. As they did during the SARS crisis, which killed nearly 300 people in Hong Kong, and then again during the protests against Beijing’s intervention in the Hong Kong territory’s limited autonomy, people here are expressing distrust over the Chinese leadership’s lack of transparency and arbitrary decision-making.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">And for many, that distrust is extended to Mrs. Lam, Beijing’s handpicked chief executive, who will be under even heavier scrutiny as she tries to bring a divided city together to head off the outbreak.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“We learned the lesson from SARS,” said Wong Hoi-ying, a district council representative in Fanling, the location of a proposed quarantine site in northern Hong Kong. “We put on our masks even before the coronavirus was confirmed to have entered Hong Kong.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Ms. Wong said she was shocked to learn from a news conference on Saturday that the Hong Kong government had identified the unoccupied public housing complex, in Fanling, as a possible quarantine site for the relatives of infected people.</p>, <h1 class="g-headline" id="g-inlineguide-headline">The Coronavirus Outbreak</h1>, <h2 class="g-inlineguide-list-header g-optimize-type">What do you need to know? Start here.</h2>, <p class="g-inlineguide-date">Updated Feb. 10, 2020</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Her constituents “were outraged,” she said. “It’s within 100 meters of residences nearby, there are at least two schools and a few more kindergartens in the vicinity. It’s not a suitable location for quarantine purposes.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Within hours of the protest on Sunday, the authorities said they were delaying plans to use the public housing complex, while moving ahead with the use of remote, government-owned vacation bungalows. On Tuesday, Mrs. Lam said the government would abandon any plans to use the Fanling site.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“The militancy of residents caught them by surprise,” said Ma Ngok, an associate professor of political science at the Chinese University of Hong Kong. He noted that the protesters included not only the contingent that has been rallying against the government for months, but also some people from the pro-establishment camp known as the blue ribbons.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“They ostensibly support the government, but when it came to using their neighborhood for quarantine, they came out and blocked the roads,” Mr. Ma said.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Late Sunday, the government said it would bar residents of Hubei, the province that includes Wuhan, or anyone who had traveled there in the past two weeks from entering Hong Kong. Just a day earlier Mrs. Lam had resisted calls for keeping out mainland visitors, saying it would be “inappropriate and impractical.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">She faced expanded demands to restrict arrivals from the mainland. Some medical workers and epidemiologists, labor unions and even pro-Beijing politicians called for a more complete closure.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">On Tuesday, after a suspected explosive device was found in a trash can at a checkpoint at the mainland border, an anonymous message appeared on social media threatening a campaign to damage roads and railways connecting the city to mainland China.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“If the Hong Kong Communists refuse to close (the border), we will do it for you,” the message said.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Her critics point out that Mrs. Lam did not act to stop entries from Hubei until Macau, the former Portuguese colony that like Hong Kong operates with some autonomy from the central government, did it first. Macau said Sunday that it would only allow residents from Hubei to enter if they provided documentation to show they were not infected.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The heightened restrictions announced Tuesday might still not be enough, as several border crossings and the airport will remain open, Mr. Ma said.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“It shows she can respond to public opinion, but it might be too little too late,” he said.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Many Hong Kong civil servants will work from home for the rest of the week. Officials called for private employers to permit similar working arrangements to keep people off the streets after the end of the Lunar New Year holiday.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Despite the criticism, in many ways, Hong Kong is the best-equipped Chinese city for dealing with an outbreak.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">It was one of the first places in China to begin reporting possible cases of infection from the coronavirus. And it has deep and painfully earned experience from the SARS outbreak, which killed at least eight health care workers. Some of the survivors still have lung damage 17 years later.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Doctors and nurses in Hong Kong have drawn lots to determine when they would work in coronavirus isolation wards for six-week shifts, said Arisina Ma, the president of the Public Doctors’ Association. One hospital rearranged its cafeteria so that all tables faced the walls, a precaution from the SARS era to help prevent employees from infecting each other during their meals.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The health authorities were scrambling to find living quarters for health workers after they had completed duty inside isolation wards. Hotels were also unwilling to accept large numbers of medical workers for fear of public reaction.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Dr. Ma suggested requiring visitors and residents who were returning from the mainland at the close of the Lunar New Year holiday to stay home for 14 days, the incubation period for the disease.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“Once the community outbreak takes place, and we still let sick people from mainland to come in, I can definitely tell you our system cannot cope with all those sick patients,” she said. “We are waiting for the worst to come. Of course we will try to stop it, but I am not sure if our government is efficient and determined enough to stop the worst to come.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">It was unclear, though, whether the upwelling of anger here would give new momentum to a protest movement that in recent weeks had become notably less intense.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Some protesters have called for rallies this week to raise both long-running demands, such as an investigation into police use of force and expanded direct elections, and new ones, such as further limiting mainland arrivals to prevent spread of the coronavirus.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">But other activists have said the complaints about the government’s response to the outbreak are too local and focused on keeping quarantine sites out of neighborhoods to develop into a citywide movement.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Another factor might also keep people off the streets: fear of infection.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“It might make it almost impossible to have a large-scale gathering in Hong Kong,” Mr. Ma said. “Even the protesters might not suggest people come out.”</p>, <p class="css-jwz2nf etfikam0">Tiffany May, Elaine Yu and Ezra Cheung contributed reporting from Hong Kong.</p>, <p>Advertisement</p>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd" id="site-index-label">Site Index</h2>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-0">news</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-1">opinion</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-2">arts</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-3">living</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-4">more</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-subscribe-label">Subscribe</h3>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd">Site Information Navigation</h2>]
[<p>Advertisement</p>, <p>Supported by</p>, <p class="css-tsacue e6idgb70">The New New World</p>, <h1 class="css-1s4ffep e1h9rw200" id="link-2c938fc4" itemprop="headline"><span>Coronavirus Crisis Exposes Cracks in China’s Facade of Unity</span></h1>, <p class="css-1ifw933 e1wiw3jv0" id="article-summary">With anger rising over the response to the coronavirus outbreak, even some with ties to China’s leaders have called for acknowledging divisions, not papering them over.</p>, <p class="css-1fv7b6t e1jsehar1" itemprop="author" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">By<!-- --> <a class="css-brehiz e1jsehar0" href="https://www.nytimes.com/by/li-yuan"><span class="css-1baulvz last-byline" itemprop="name">Li Yuan</span></a></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">From the outside, China’s Communist Party appears powerful and effective. It has tightened its control over Chinese <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2019/10/28/world/asia/china-xi-jinping-communist-party-plenum.html" title="">politics</a> and <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2018/03/21/world/asia/china-communist-party-xi-jinping.html" title="">culture</a>, the <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2018/12/18/world/asia/xi-jinping-speech-china.html" title="">economy</a> and <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2018/11/25/world/asia/china-freedoms-control.html" title="">everyday life</a>, projecting the image of a gradually unifying society.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The coronavirus outbreak has blown up that facade.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Staff members at prestigious Union Hospital in Wuhan, the city at the center of the outbreak, have joined others around China in begging online for medical supplies. Videos show patients in Wuhan beseeching medical staff for treatment. Residents of Wuhan and its province, Hubei, are being chased off planes and ousted from hotels and villages.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Online critics are comparing current leaders unfavorably with past ones, even though the older generation had its own tarnished record on responding to emergencies. Some people have urged local party officials to kill themselves.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">As cracks show in China’s veneer of stability, even some with ties to the party leadership are calling for those in power to shine light on divisions rather than papering them over. The crisis has shown that China remains riddled with vulnerabilities that no amount of censorship or strong-arming can hide.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“The local government’s tolerance level of different online voices is way too low,” wrote Hu Xijin, <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2019/07/31/world/asia/hu-xijin-global-times-us-china-tensions.html" title="">the editor of the Global Times newspaper</a>, a nationalist, party-controlled outlet that fiercely defends Beijing from its critics, in a social media post.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Government agencies have <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2019/07/12/world/asia/china-journalists-crackdown.html" title="">weakened</a> the checks-and-balances function of the Chinese news media, Mr. Hu wrote, citing the example of eight early whistle-blowers who were summoned for talks by the Wuhan police.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/27/world/asia/china-coronavirus.html?action=click&amp;pgtype=Article&amp;state=default&amp;module=STYLN_wuhan_coronavirus_menu&amp;variant=1_wuhan_coronavirus_menu&amp;region=header&amp;context=menu#link-129cc5af" title="">coronavirus outbreak</a> has already killed over 100 people and infected more than 4,000 in China, mostly in Wuhan and elsewhere in Hubei. For online critics of the government’s responses, which at times have been slow or seemingly random, the crisis has prompted a rethinking of the grand trade-off with the party, in which the people have surrendered individual rights for the promise of stability and prosperity.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“The current system looks so vibrant, yet it’s shattered completely by a governance crisis,” one user wrote on the social media site Weibo.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“We gave up our rights in exchange for protection,” the user wrote. “But what kind of protection is it? Where will our long-lasting political apathy lead us?”</p>, <h1 class="g-headline" id="g-inlineguide-headline">The Coronavirus Outbreak</h1>, <h2 class="g-inlineguide-list-header g-optimize-type">What do you need to know? Start here.</h2>, <p class="g-inlineguide-date">Updated Feb. 5, 2020</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The post was shared over 7,000 times and liked 27,000 times before censors deleted it.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Westerners can be easily awed by how quickly and forcefully the Chinese government can mobilize resources and build infrastructure. Even some international public health experts have said they were impressed with the speed and scale of China’s lockdown on more than a dozen cities, which has affected 56 million people. The Chinese propaganda machine has highlighted such abilities as two new Wuhan coronavirus hospitals are built from scratch, to be completed in days.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">This single-minded pursuit of efficiency masks deep problems. Propaganda videos and flashy new buildings don’t show the toll that this relentless drive can take on people, society or the environment.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Many Chinese people are willing to go along. Partly, the state has taught them to think that way. But many are satisfied with the status quo because they believe that the party has kept their interests in mind.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The epidemic now threatens to change some of that thinking.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Officials in Wuhan initially played down the threat and censored information as the disease spread throughout the country and even internationally. The city and the province then abruptly imposed a <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/26/world/asia/coronavirus-wuhan-china-hubei.html?action=click&amp;module=RelatedLinks&amp;pgtype=Article" title="">lockdown</a> on travel, even though millions had already left for China’s Lunar New Year holiday.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Local residents complained that restrictions later imposed on traffic made it difficult for people to get to work and seek medical assistance, perhaps hindering prevention efforts rather than helping them.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Wuhan’s medical system was so overwhelmed that <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/video/world/asia/100000006936419/coronavirus-china-wuhan.html" title="">videos</a> of overworked medical workers having breakdowns and desperate patients pleading for help circulated widely online.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The situation was so dire that Zhang Ouya, a senior reporter at the state-run Hubei Daily, wrote that “Hubei must immediately replace its commanders” on his verified Weibo account. The post was soon deleted, but a screenshot circulated widely. In an official document leaked online, the newspaper apologized to Wuhan officials and promised that its staff would post only positive content.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">For many people in China, the most unexpected revelation came when local hospitals ran out of supplies and had to ask for donations on social media, going around the Chinese bureaucracy. As the crisis expanded, even hospitals in Beijing and other provinces resorted to public appeals for face masks and protective medical gowns.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“I’ve always thought we have the most refined state-run system, which can pool and deploy resources at a moment’s notice,” wrote a Weibo user called Meng Chang, a former journalist in Beijing. But the reality was disappointing, he wrote: “Where is the omnipotent system?”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">National leaders, meanwhile, look out of touch. As the outbreak became a national crisis, the front page of the People’s Daily, the Communist Party’s mouthpiece, last week extolled the leadership but didn't mention Wuhan. “There’re no people in the People’s Daily,” one of my WeChat connections, an economist, messaged me.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">China Central Television, the state broadcaster, featured a banquet held by the leadership to celebrate the country’s successes. On Friday night, the eve of the Lunar New Year, CCTV’s annual holiday broadcast worked in six minutes of praise for Wuhan’s medical workers between the skits and songs. Wuhan’s people went unmentioned.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“I was very sad when watching the Spring Festival gala last night,” a woman named Jiujiu told the podcast <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://podcasts.apple.com/hk/podcast/%E6%95%85%E4%BA%8B-fm/id1256399960?l=en&amp;i=1000463649899" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">Gushi FM</a>. “Wuhan has come to this, yet the whole nation still seemed full of great joy.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Some within China’s institutions appear to be trying to fix the problems.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">While Weibo has censored many posts about the epidemic, it appears to be leaving loopholes for its users to vent. Wang Gaofei, Weibo’s chief executive, posted <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://europepmc.org/article/med/30716139#free-full-text" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">research</a> by scientists at the University of Washington that showed a correlation between greater news coverage and a reduction in infections.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">But in a country where history is often rewritten to serve the party’s interests, the lessons of the past can be forgotten. Discussion of SARS, the outbreak that killed hundreds 17 years ago, has been muted. Even as many Chinese people quietly complain about current leaders, they wax nostalgic about the role that former President Hu Jintao played in the SARS epidemic, apparently forgetting that Beijing tried to cover up that outbreak for three months.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">A video of a CCTV interview with Beijing’s mayor at the time, Wang Qishan, who is now China’s vice president, was viewed over four million times in two hours before it was deleted. The comments were full of praises for his candid and confident answers and yearning for a strong leader like him.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“It’s not that this nation has a bad memory,” wrote one person who pointed out the irony. “It’s because those in power don’t like that you remember.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The police in various parts of China have fined or detained over 40 people in the past few days for spreading “rumors,” many of which claimed that there were confirmed cases of the virus locally, according to a tally by a <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://mp.weixin.qq.com/s/3dYMFTlvXS-WuEJcZDytWw" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">WeChat account</a> based on media reports.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Wang Heyan, an investigative reporter for the magazine Caixin who has written about corruption cases involving top Chinese leaders, lamented on her WeChat timeline that she and her colleagues couldn’t get any medical workers to talk to them in Wuhan. Even after she promised them anonymity, Ms. Wang said, the workers feared reprisals.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“If all medical workers aren’t willing to take a little risk to speak the truth and the media can’t report the truth, in the end everyone, including the doctors, will be victims,” she wrote.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">A reporter from Beijing News also complained on social media that even though he was in the epicenter of the epidemic, he couldn’t write a single word about what he had learned.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Many Chinese still have strong belief in the power of the central government. After Premier Li Keqiang visited Wuhan on Monday, a week after the epidemic became a full-blown crisis, a retiree <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/27/world/asia/china-coronavirus.html?action=click&amp;pgtype=Article&amp;state=default&amp;module=STYLN_wuhan_coronavirus_menu&amp;variant=1_wuhan_coronavirus_menu&amp;region=header&amp;context=menu#link-15538d14" title="">told</a> my colleague Chris Buckley, “In China, if a leader visits, that shows that all the resources of the government can be mobilized.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Li Haipeng, a former journalist, predicted as early as last week that eventually the state would come to Wuhan’s rescue.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“The state will be interpreted, proved and trusted as the only savior,” he wrote on Weibo. “All our stories are the same: They start with the failure of the state and end with its victory.”</p>, <p>Advertisement</p>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd" id="site-index-label">Site Index</h2>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-0">news</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-1">opinion</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-2">arts</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-3">living</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-4">more</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-subscribe-label">Subscribe</h3>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd">Site Information Navigation</h2>]
[<p>Advertisement</p>, <p>Supported by</p>, <h1 class="css-1s4ffep e1h9rw200" id="link-3843d586" itemprop="headline"><span>Containing the Coronavirus: Countries Limit Travel to China</span></h1>, <p class="css-1ifw933 e1wiw3jv0" id="article-summary">With cases spiking in China and early signs of a spread outside Asia, Hong Kong severely cut back transportation to the mainland.</p>, <p class="css-1fv7b6t e1jsehar1" itemprop="author" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">By<!-- --> <a class="css-brehiz e1jsehar0" href="https://www.nytimes.com/by/paul-mozur"><span class="css-1baulvz last-byline" itemprop="name">Paul Mozur</span></a></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">HONG KONG — Countries, cities and businesses across the globe issued new travel warnings on Tuesday, vastly expanding a cordon intended to control the flow of people to and from China, where the authorities are struggling to contain the <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/28/world/asia/china-coronavirus.html" title="">outbreak of the new coronavirus</a>.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">In the most drastic measure to limit travel, the <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/28/world/asia/coronavirus-hong-kong-border.html" title="">Hong Kong</a> authorities reduced by half the number of flights and shut down rail service to mainland China, and they also limited visas — moves that could inspire other governments to follow suit.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Measures to contain the outbreak of the virus to its epicenter in Hubei Province appear to have failed to stop the contagion.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">On Wednesday morning, Chinese officials said the number of cases had increased by nearly a third overnight. Experts warned that the actual number of cases could be significantly higher and growing quickly. The number of deaths attributed to the virus also continued to grow.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The new <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/26/world/asia/coronavirus-wuhan-china-hubei.html" title="">travel restrictions</a> put a deeper freeze on China’s contact with the world, cutting off business and tourism as China’s economy faces a potential slowdown.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">With China’s Lunar New Year holiday nearing its end, companies ordered workers to stay home and avoid travel. The <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/27/business/coronavirus-china-economic-impact.html" title="">economic impact</a> of such measures pointed to a deeper political crisis, with many people accusing the Chinese authorities online of failing to act quickly to contain the virus, even as the government continues to struggle to control its spread.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The travel advisories and bans came as the virus showed early signs of spreading outside China, with cases of transmission to people who had not recently traveled to China reported in Japan, Germany and Vietnam. Countries across the world may now be faced with the task of limiting the spread of the disease on their own soil, not simply seeking to identify and quarantine infected people who had been in China.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Officials at the United States Centers for Disease Control and Prevention <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.cdc.gov/media/releases/2020/s0128-travelers-avoid-china.html" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">warned against nonessential travel to China</a>, noting that there is “limited access to adequate medical care in affected areas.” The United States is <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/28/health/airports-screening-coronavirus.html" title="">expanding the screening of travelers</a> arriving from Wuhan to 20 airports and other ports of entry, from five, federal officials said on Tuesday.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The World Health Organization revised its global risk assessment for the outbreak from “moderate” to “high,” although it noted this shift in a footnote buried in a report published on Monday. The change in the risk assessment, which coincided with a visit to China by the organization’s director general, risked confusing the public about the severity of the outbreak, which has killed more than 130 people in China and been diagnosed in at least 14 countries.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The World Health Organization was criticized after it refused twice in recent days to declare the outbreak a global emergency, despite its spread.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">With other countries scrambling to evacuate their citizens from the locked-down epicenter of the outbreak in central China, the WHO said its director general, Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus, had discussed with Chinese officials “possible alternatives to evacuation of foreigners if there are ways to accommodate them and protect their health.”</p>, <h1 class="g-headline" id="g-inlineguide-headline">The Coronavirus Outbreak</h1>, <h2 class="g-inlineguide-list-header g-optimize-type">What do you need to know? Start here.</h2>, <p class="g-inlineguide-date">Updated Feb. 10, 2020</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Although Chinese medical workers have described a desperate need for more resources to treat thousands of new patients, state-run Chinese media reported that Dr. Tedros had spoken highly of the Chinese efforts to contain the virus. The Chinese authorities agreed on Tuesday to<a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/28/health/airports-screening-coronavirus.html" title=""> allow in teams of international experts</a>, coordinated by the World Health Organization, to help with research and containment.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Chinese officials said Wednesday that 132 people had died from the virus, up from 106 the day before. The total number of confirmed cases rose sharply as well, to 5,974 on Wednesday, according to the National Health Commission.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The youngest confirmed patient is a 9-month-old girl in Beijing.
