While the majority of confirmed cases were in Hubei, where a number of cities have been put under effective lockdown, an additional 1,800 cases have been diagnosed outside the province, the authorities said.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">In Wuhan, medical workers have cited a lack of masks and kits to test for the virus. China’s medical products administration said on Sunday it had approved new virus detection kits to speed detection, but three Chinese medical companies said they did not have the capacity to produce enough of them, according to local news media reports.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Many in Wuhan with symptoms of the virus <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/27/world/asia/27china-coronavirus-health.html" title="">have not been tested</a> or have been told the hospitals did not have enough test kits, some local residents said.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">During a visit to Wuhan on Monday, the Chinese premier, Li Keqiang, promised to provide more equipment, and the local government has begun building new hospitals that it hopes to open in a matter of weeks. But online, <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/27/technology/china-coronavirus-censorship-social-media.html" title="">many people mocked</a> the government’s efforts.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">In indications of the virus’s spread beyond China’s borders, Thailand reported 14 cases of infection, while the United States and Australia have each confirmed five cases. Singapore, South Korea and Malaysia each said they had confirmed four cases.</p>, <h2 class="css-zd32qr">Wuhan Coronavirus Map: Tracking the Spread of the Outbreak</h2>, <p class="css-1uuihdo">The virus has sickened tens of thousands of people in China and a number of other countries.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Japan’s Ministry of Health, Labor and Welfare, which has now confirmed six cases, said that the virus had been found in the first Japanese citizen. The ministry said he had worked as a bus driver for two different tour groups from Wuhan. He had no history of traveling to Wuhan.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The man, who had driven for the tours earlier this month, first reported experiencing chills, a cough and joint pain on Jan. 14. He visited a clinic three days later, but was sent home. On Jan. 22, his joint pain and cough grew worse, and he returned to a health clinic on Saturday, when a chest X-ray showed abnormalities and he was admitted to a hospital. A test confirmed the coronavirus on Tuesday.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">German officials said Tuesday that they had identified what they believed was the first instance of the virus spreading within Europe. They said a man from Starnberg in Bavaria was infected and was being treated and kept in isolation. The health ministry described him as being in “good condition” medically and said it was also monitoring his family and other people who might have been exposed, including in his children’s day care center.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“It was to be expected that the virus would come to Germany,” Jens Spahn, Germany’s health minister, said in a statement on Tuesday. “But the Bavarian case shows us that we are well prepared.” He said the risk to Germans remained low.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Japan planned to send a chartered plane to Wuhan on Tuesday night to bring back the first Japanese citizens who wish to be repatriated. At least 13 countries have said they would evacuate their citizens from Wuhan, where the virus is believed to have been transmitted from animals to humans.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Businesses that operate in China have issued warnings of their own. In a flurry of emails sent in recent days, General Motors, Honeywell, Bloomberg, Facebook and other companies have warned employees not to travel within mainland China.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Honeywell, which has offices and operations across China, said it had restricted travel to some regions, but did not specify which ones. A spokesman for General Motors said the company had issued a global travel ban to China, with only “business-critical” travel allowed and only after clearance from a doctor. Bloomberg told its employees in Hong Kong and mainland China to work remotely until further notice and it restricted travel to China and Hong Kong over the next 30 days, according to an email seen by The New York Times.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The Chinese government has extended the Lunar New Year holiday until Feb. 3, with some of China’s biggest cities telling businesses not to open until the following week. China’s biggest technology companies went further, notifying employees to work from home until Feb. 10. NetEase, an internet and entertainment platform, asked employees who were returning from another city to quarantine themselves for 14 days.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Investors in Asia were gripped on Tuesday with fear about the health of the global economy for a second day, with a widespread sell-off continuing in the markets. Investors dumped stocks in companies thought to be most vulnerable to the effects of the virus.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“The coronavirus is the No. 1 threat to financial markets currently as global investors are becoming jittery on the uncertainty,” said Nigel Green, founder of an investment company, the deVere Group.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">In Hong Kong, medical professionals called for additional border checkpoints.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“The next week or two will be a critical time for the development of the epidemic,” the faculty at the Chinese University of Hong Kong wrote on its Facebook page. “We must closely monitor whether there is a community outbreak outside Hubei Province, especially in Hong Kong’s neighboring regions.”</p>, <p class="css-jwz2nf etfikam0">Reporting was contributed by Chris Buckley, Russell Goldman, Elaine Yu, Raymond Zhong, Austin Ramzy, Sui-Lee Wee, Alexandra Stevenson, Eimi Yamamitsu, Tiffany May, Joseph Goldstein, Jeffrey E. Singer, Peter S. Goodman, Motoko Rich, Christopher Schuetze, and Roni Caryn Rabin. Jin Wu, Zoe Mou, Albee Zhang, Amber Wang, Yiwei Wang and Claire Fu contributed research.</p>, <p>Advertisement</p>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd" id="site-index-label">Site Index</h2>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-0">news</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-1">opinion</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-2">arts</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-3">living</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-4">more</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-subscribe-label">Subscribe</h3>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd">Site Information Navigation</h2>]
[<p>Advertisement</p>, <p>Supported by</p>, <h1 class="css-1s4ffep e1h9rw200" id="link-4ca4f273" itemprop="headline"><span>How Do Bats Live With So Many Viruses?</span></h1>, <p class="css-1ifw933 e1wiw3jv0" id="article-summary">They are considered the probable source of the coronavirus outbreak spreading from China. It turns out that they may have an immune system that lets them coexist with many disease-causing viruses.</p>, <p class="css-1fv7b6t e1jsehar1" itemprop="author" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">By<!-- --> <a class="css-brehiz e1jsehar0" href="https://www.nytimes.com/by/james-gorman"><span class="css-1baulvz last-byline" itemprop="name">James Gorman</span></a></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">If previous outbreaks of coronavirus are any indication, <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/article/what-is-coronavirus.html" title="">the Wuhan strain that is now spreading</a> may eventually be traced back to bats.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Dr. Peter Daszak, president of EcoHealth Alliance, who has been working in China for 15 years studying diseases that jump from animals to people, said, “We don’t know the source yet, but there’s pretty strong evidence that this is a bat origin coronavirus.” He said, “It’s probably going to be the Chinese horseshoe bat,” a common species that weighs up to an ounce.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">If he’s right, this strain will join many other viruses that bats carry. SARS and MERS epidemics were caused by bat coronaviruses, as was a highly destructive viral epidemic in pigs.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">One bat can host many different viruses without getting sick. They are the natural reservoir for the Marburg virus, and Nipah and Hendra viruses, which have caused human disease and outbreaks in Africa, Malaysia, Bangladesh and Australia. They are thought to be the natural reservoir for the Ebola virus. They also carry the rabies virus, but in that case the bats are affected by the disease.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Their tolerance of viruses, which surpasses that of other mammals, is one of their many distinctive qualities. They are the only flying mammals, they devour disease-carrying insects by the ton, and they are essential in the pollination of many fruits, like bananas, avocados and mangoes. They are also an incredibly diverse group, making up about a quarter of all mammalian species.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">But their ability to coexist with viruses that can spill over to other animals, in particular humans, can have devastating consequences when we eat them, trade them in livestock markets and invade their territory.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Learning how they carry and survive so many viruses has been a deep question for science, and new research suggests that the answer may be how the bats’ evolutionary adaptations to flight changed their immune systems.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">In a <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.cell.com/cell-host-microbe/fulltext/S1931-3128(18)30041-6" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">2018 paper in Cell Host and Microbe</a>, scientists in China and Singapore reported their investigation of how bats handle something called DNA sensing. The energy demands of flight are so great that cells in the body break down and release bits of DNA that are then floating around where they shouldn’t be. Mammals, including bats, have ways to identify and respond to such bits of DNA, which might indicate an invasion of a disease-causing organism. But in bats, they found, evolution has weakened that system, which would normally cause inflammation as it fought the viruses.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Bats have lost some genes involved in that response, which makes sense because the inflammation itself can be very damaging to the body. They have a weakened response but it is still there. Thus, the researchers write, this weakened response may allow them to maintain a “balanced state of ‘effective response’ but not ‘over response’ against viruses.”</p>, <h1 class="g-headline" id="g-inlineguide-headline">The Coronavirus Outbreak</h1>, <h2 class="g-inlineguide-list-header g-optimize-type">What do you need to know? Start here.</h2>, <p class="g-inlineguide-date">Updated Feb. 10, 2020</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">How to manage and contain the current outbreak of the virus officially known as 2019-nCoV, is, of course, of paramount importance now. But tracing its origin and taking action to combat further outbreaks may depend partly on knowledge and monitoring of bats. “The outbreak can be contained and controlled,” Dr. Daszak said. “But if we don’t know the origin in the long term then this virus can continue to spill over.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Scientists in China were already studying the bats carefully, well aware that an outbreak like the current one would most likely happen.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Last spring, in an <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.mdpi.com/1999-4915/11/3/210" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">article on bat coronaviruses,</a> or CoVs, a group of Chinese researchers wrote that “it is generally believed that batborne CoVs will re-emerge to cause the next disease outbreak.” They added, “In this regard, China is a likely hot spot.” This wasn’t clairvoyance, but conventional wisdom.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Certainly, rodents, primates and birds also carry diseases that can jump and have jumped to people; bats are far from alone in that regard. But there are reasons they have been implicated in several disease outbreaks and are likely to be implicated in more.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">They are numerous and widespread. While bats account for a quarter of mammalian species, rodents are 50 percent, and then there’s the rest of us. Bats live on every continent except Antarctica, in proximity to humans and farms. The ability to fly makes them wide-ranging, which helps in spreading viruses, and their feces can spread disease.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">People in many parts of the world eat bats, and sell them in live animal markets, which was the source of SARS, and possibly the latest coronavirus outbreak that began in Wuhan. They also often live in huge colonies in caves, where crowded conditions are ideal for passing viruses to one another.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">In a 2017 report in Nature, Dr. Daszak, Kevin J. Olival and other colleagues from EcoHealth Alliance, reported that they had created a database of 754 mammal species and 586 viral species, and analyzed which viruses were harbored by which mammals and how they affected their hosts.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">They confirmed what scientists had thought: “Bats are host to a significantly higher proportion of zoonoses than all other mammalian orders.” Zoonoses are diseases that spill over from animals to humans.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">And they don’t just survive the viruses they harbor. Bats are remarkably long-lived for small mammals. The big brown bat, a common species in the United States, can live nearly 20 years in the wild. Others live closer to 40. One <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="http://www.batcon.org/resources/media-education/bats-magazine/bat_article/152" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">tiny bat in Siberia lived at least 41 years</a>. Animals like house mice live about two years on average.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">While the bats must be studied, their physiology understood, and the viruses they harbor monitored for the sake of public health, that does not mean that the bats are to blame for the outbreak. <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/28/opinion/coronavirus-china.html" title="">As others have pointed out, humans have encroached on the lives of bats, not vice versa.</a></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Dr. Daszak stressed that stopping the sale of wildlife in markets is essential to curtail future outbreaks. But since such outbreaks are inevitable, Dr. Daszak says, monitoring and studying wildlife, like bats, is equally important. He compared the situation to terrorism. Both terrorist attacks and disease outbreaks seem inevitable. To get a jump on them, he said, intelligence is vital.</p>, <p>Advertisement</p>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd" id="site-index-label">Site Index</h2>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-0">news</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-1">opinion</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-2">arts</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-3">living</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-4">more</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-subscribe-label">Subscribe</h3>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd">Site Information Navigation</h2>]
[<p>Advertisement</p>, <p>Supported by</p>, <p class="css-c2jxua e6idgb70"></p>, <h1 class="css-1j5ig2m e1h9rw200" id="link-5f91e701" itemprop="headline"><span>The New Coronavirus: What Is It and How Does It Behave?</span></h1>, <p class="css-1fv7b6t e1jsehar1" itemprop="author" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">By<!-- --> <span class="css-1baulvz last-byline" itemprop="name">Reuters</span></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">LONDON — Here are some key features of new coronavirus that was identified in the central Chinese city of Wuhan in December and is causing an outbreak of disease in China and beyond.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">** Coronaviruses are a family of viruses that get their name from what they look like under a microscope - they are spherical and their surfaces are covered with "crown"-like spikes.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">** Coronavirus infections have a wide range of symptoms, including fever, coughing, shortness of breath and breathing difficulties. Mild cases can cause cold-like symptoms, while severe cases can cause pneumonia, severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS), kidney failure and death.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">** Like other coronaviruses, the newly identified China coronavirus is being transmitted from person-to-person via droplets when an infected person breathes out, coughs or sneezes. It can also spread via contaminated surfaces such as door handles or railings.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">** Infection with the newly identified virus has an incubation period of between one and 14 days, and there are limited accounts that it may also be spreading before symptoms show.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">** Infectious disease and virus specialists say the scale of the current outbreak now points to "self-sustaining" human-to-human transmission. They estimate that each infected person is infecting, on average, two to three more people.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">** Testing for the new China virus involves using a real time polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR), which identifies the viral RNA in a sample. These samples could be from throat swabs, cough samples, or blood samples from patients who are very ill. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"> (Reporting by Kate Kelland; editing by Nick Macfie)</p>, <p>Advertisement</p>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd" id="site-index-label">Site Index</h2>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-0">news</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-1">opinion</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-2">arts</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-3">living</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-4">more</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-subscribe-label">Subscribe</h3>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd">Site Information Navigation</h2>]
[<p>Advertisement</p>, <p>Supported by</p>, <p class="css-c2jxua e6idgb70"></p>, <h1 class="css-1j5ig2m e1h9rw200" id="link-400ed1aa" itemprop="headline"><span>China's Xi Says Coronavirus Is a 'Devil'</span></h1>, <p class="css-1fv7b6t e1jsehar1" itemprop="author" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">By<!-- --> <span class="css-1baulvz last-byline" itemprop="name">Reuters</span></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">BEIJING — Chinese President Xi Jinping told the head of the World Health Organization on Tuesday that the new coronavirus is a "devil" and that China is confident of winning the battle against it.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Xi added that he believes the WHO and international community will give a "calm, objective and rational" assessment of the virus, state television reported.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"> (Reporting by Beijing newsroom; Writing by Ben Blanchard; Editing by Andrew Heavens)</p>, <p>Advertisement</p>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd" id="site-index-label">Site Index</h2>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-0">news</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-1">opinion</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-2">arts</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-3">living</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-4">more</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-subscribe-label">Subscribe</h3>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd">Site Information Navigation</h2>]
[<p>Advertisement</p>, <p>Supported by</p>, <p class="css-c2jxua e6idgb70"></p>, <h1 class="css-1j5ig2m e1h9rw200" id="link-543782da" itemprop="headline"><span>Factbox: The New Coronavirus-What Is It and How Does It Behave?</span></h1>, <p class="css-1fv7b6t e1jsehar1" itemprop="author" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">By<!-- --> <span class="css-1baulvz last-byline" itemprop="name">Reuters</span></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">LONDON — Here are some key features of new coronavirus that was identified in the central Chinese city of Wuhan in December and is causing an outbreak of disease in China and beyond.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">** Coronaviruses are a family of viruses that get their name from what they look like under a microscope - they are spherical and their surfaces are covered with "crown"-like spikes.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">** Coronavirus infections have a wide range of symptoms, including fever, coughing, shortness of breath and breathing difficulties. Mild cases can cause cold-like symptoms, while severe cases can cause pneumonia, severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS), kidney failure and death.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">** Like other coronaviruses, the newly identified China coronavirus is being transmitted from person-to-person via droplets when an infected person breathes out, coughs or sneezes. It can also spread via contaminated surfaces such as door handles or railings.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">** Infection with the newly identified virus has an incubation period of between one and 14 days, and there are limited accounts that it may also be spreading before symptoms show.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">** Infectious disease and virus specialists say the scale of the current outbreak now points to "self-sustaining" human-to-human transmission. They estimate that each infected person is infecting, on average, two to three more people.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">** Testing for the new China virus involves using a real time polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR), which identifies the viral RNA in a sample. These samples could be from throat swabs, cough samples, or blood samples from patients who are very ill.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"> (Reporting by Kate Kelland; editing by Nick Macfie)</p>, <p>Advertisement</p>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd" id="site-index-label">Site Index</h2>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-0">news</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-1">opinion</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-2">arts</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-3">living</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-4">more</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-subscribe-label">Subscribe</h3>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd">Site Information Navigation</h2>]
[<p>Advertisement</p>, <p>Supported by</p>, <p class="css-c2jxua e6idgb70"></p>, <h1 class="css-1j5ig2m e1h9rw200" id="link-48e44ce6" itemprop="headline"><span>Checkpoints, Exclusion Zones and Quarantine: Reporting the Coronavirus</span></h1>, <p class="css-1fv7b6t e1jsehar1" itemprop="author" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">By<!-- --> <span class="css-1baulvz last-byline" itemprop="name">Reuters</span></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">SHANGHAI — A transparent plastic bag dropped at the door of my Shanghai apartment contained a handful of surgical masks along with a "friendly notice" informing me that I was under home quarantine for two weeks.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The reason? I had briefly been inside the widening exclusion zone in China's Hubei province, including a stop on the train as it passed through Wuhan, the city at the epicentre of the new coronavirus. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">"People who returned from or passed through Hubei to enter the (Shanghai) municipality must actively submit to temperature monitoring ... and consciously implement home quarantine or submit to centralised supervision for 14 days," it said.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The notice came from the Xujiahui District Novel Coronavirus-transmitted Pneumonia Epidemic Prevention and Control Leading Working Group.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">I need to report my temperature by phone to a member of the working group twice a day until Feb. 10. It remains normal.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">As a nurse standing at my door explained, the best way was to place a glass thermometer under the armpit for five minutes. As she spoke, a neighbour looked on anxiously.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">A day earlier, there had been a knock on the door from two men from the local residents' committee wearing what looked like clumsy military-issue gas masks.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">When I opened the door, they took a wary step back and asked when I had returned to Shanghai from Wuhan，the source of the coronavirus that has killed more than 100 people and infected over 4,500 in China as of Monday.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">One of the men informed me that I should know there is an "epidemic" going on in Hubei and I should be subject to special control measures, including two weeks of isolation at home.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">At a Shanghai government press conference on Sunday, a health official said the city was now inspecting 95 suspected cases. I wondered if I was included in that statistic.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">LOCK-DOWN</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">As the number of reported coronavirus cases started to multiply last week, a Reuters multi-media team travelled to the city of Xianning, just south of Wuhan, on Friday to report on the effectiveness of Wuhan's day-old transportation lock-down.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">My journey included a 10-minute stop at an eerily empty platform of Wuhan train station. I did not see anyone board there.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">From Xianning, we reached Wuhan's southern border and spoke with the auxiliary police staffing the checkpoint. It became clear that it was relatively easy to get into Wuhan, as long as we didn't have wild animals or a fever, but harder to get out.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Xianning itself was not in lockdown when we arrived, but within hours its major roads and train station were closed and we left in a hired car, escorted by police, as soon as possible.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Police said that if we headed south immediately, we would be able to beat the lockdown.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">On the eve of the Lunar New Year, we sped south along mostly empty highways towards Changsha, watching bursts of fireworks on the horizon.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">At one packed service station, families trying to get out of Hubei ate instant noodles for their new year's dinner. It was a far cry from the traditional reunion feast.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">We arrived in Changsha early the next morning and I was back in Shanghai the same afternoon.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"> (Reporting by David Stanway; Editing by Mike Collett-White)</p>, <p>Advertisement</p>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd" id="site-index-label">Site Index</h2>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-0">news</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-1">opinion</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-2">arts</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-3">living</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-4">more</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-subscribe-label">Subscribe</h3>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd">Site Information Navigation</h2>]
[<p>Advertisement</p>, <p>Supported by</p>, <p class="css-tsacue e6idgb70">current events</p>, <h1 class="css-1s4ffep e1h9rw200" id="link-35fa0129" itemprop="headline"><span>Lesson of the Day: ‘What Is the Coronavirus? Symptoms, Treatment and Risks’</span></h1>, <p class="css-1ifw933 e1wiw3jv0" id="article-summary">In this lesson, students will learn about the coronavirus using Times photographs, graphs and articles.</p>, <p class="css-1fv7b6t e1jsehar1" itemprop="author" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">By<!-- --> <a class="css-brehiz e1jsehar0" href="https://www.nytimes.com/by/natalie-proulx"><span class="css-1baulvz" itemprop="name">Natalie Proulx</span></a> and <a class="css-brehiz e1jsehar0" href="https://www.nytimes.com/by/nicole-daniels"><span class="css-1baulvz last-byline" itemprop="name">Nicole Daniels</span></a></p>, <p class="css-jwz2nf etfikam0"><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/column/learning-article-of-the-day" title="">Find all our Lessons of the Day here.</a></p>, <h2 class="css-3ez4hu eoo0vm40" id="link-3213d39d">Lesson Overview</h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">Featured Article: “</em><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/article/what-is-coronavirus.html" title=""><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">What Is the Coronavirus? Symptoms, Treatment and Risks</em></a><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">” by Roni Caryn Rabin.</em></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Have you heard anything about the coronavirus? Are people in your school or community concerned about contracting it?</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The coronavirus is a respiratory virus named for the spikes that protrude from its membrane, which resemble the sun’s corona. The outbreak began in Wuhan, China, in a live seafood, poultry and wild animal market, but it has now appeared in 11 other countries, including the United States. According to Chinese health authorities, the coronavirus has killed at least 56 people and sickened at least 2,000.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">In this lesson, students will learn more about the virus and how people are reacting to it, both in Asia and in the United States.</p>, <h2 class="css-3ez4hu eoo0vm40" id="link-58c61f7">Warm Up</h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">In the article, “<a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/25/world/asia/china-coronavirus-photos.html" title="">China’s Battle With a Deadly Coronavirus, in Photos</a>,” photographers document the response to the outbreak in China. Look closely at the photograph below and answer the following questions from our partners at <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://vtshome.org/" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">Visual Thinking Strategies</a>:</p>, <p class="css-15hwz5e evys1bk0">What is going on in this picture?</p>, <p class="css-15hwz5e evys1bk0">What do you see that makes you say that?</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Now, using those same close observation skills, look through <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/25/world/asia/china-coronavirus-photos.html" title="">all of the photographs in the article</a>. What observations can you make and what conclusions can you draw?</p>, <p class="css-15hwz5e evys1bk0">What story does the series of photographs tell?</p>, <p class="css-15hwz5e evys1bk0">Are you able to get a sense of how the virus is transmitted? What do you notice people doing to contain the virus?</p>, <p class="css-15hwz5e evys1bk0">Did you notice that the outbreak happened at the time of the Lunar New Year? What do you notice about how the outbreak affected celebrations?</p>, <p class="css-15hwz5e evys1bk0">What other questions do you still have?</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">As you read the featured article, keep these images in mind and see what more information you are able to gather.</p>, <h2 class="css-3ez4hu eoo0vm40" id="link-3d626d30">Questions for Writing and Discussion</h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/article/what-is-coronavirus.html" title=""><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">Read the article</em></a><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">, then answer the following questions:</em></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">1. </strong>In your own words, why has there been so much panic and fear in response to the coronavirus?</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">2. </strong>Why hasn’t the World Health Organization declared a global health emergency? How did some of the physicians quoted in the article explain and support the W.H.O.’s decision? (On Jan. 30, <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/30/health/coronavirus-world-health-organization.html" title="">the W.H.O. declared a Global Health Emergency</a>. What led them to make that decision?)</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">3.</strong> How were scientists able to identify how the virus is transmitted? What conclusions have the Chinese Center for Disease Control and Prevention been able to reach through its observation and study?</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">4. </strong>How is the coronavirus similar and different from other epidemics like SARS and MERS? How does it compare with annual influenza outbreaks? What do these comparisons tell us about how dangerous this new virus is?</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">5.</strong> How did the outbreak initially happen, and why has it been so difficult to contain?</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">6. </strong>What can people do to protect themselves? What role are United States health officials taking to prevent an outbreak?</p>, <h2 class="css-3ez4hu eoo0vm40" id="link-242909b1">Going Further</h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">You started this lesson by looking at photographs to understand the epidemic. Now that you have read more information about what is happening, take some time to analyze one or two graphs or maps from <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2020/01/21/world/asia/china-coronavirus-maps.html" title="">this article</a> and answer the following questions from our <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/column/whats-going-on-in-this-graph" title="">What’s Going On in This Graph?</a> feature:</p>, <p class="css-15hwz5e evys1bk0">What do you notice?<em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0"> If you make a claim, tell us what you noticed that supports your claim.</em></p>, <p class="css-15hwz5e evys1bk0">What do you wonder? <em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">What are you curious about that comes from what you noticed in the graph?</em></p>, <p class="css-15hwz5e evys1bk0">What’s going on in this graph? Write a catchy headline that captures the graph’s main idea.</p>, <p>Advertisement</p>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd" id="site-index-label">Site Index</h2>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-0">news</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-1">opinion</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-2">arts</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-3">living</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-4">more</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-subscribe-label">Subscribe</h3>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd">Site Information Navigation</h2>]
[<p>Advertisement</p>, <p>Supported by</p>, <p class="css-c2jxua e6idgb70"></p>, <h1 class="css-1j5ig2m e1h9rw200" id="link-a770eac" itemprop="headline"><span>Factbox: Latest on the Coronavirus Spreading in China and Beyond</span></h1>, <p class="css-1fv7b6t e1jsehar1" itemprop="author" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">By<!-- --> <span class="css-1baulvz last-byline" itemprop="name">Reuters</span></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">(Reuters) - The coronavirus outbreak that began in the central Chinese city of Wuhan, in the province of Hubei, has killed 106 people in China and infected more than 4,520 globally, most of them in China.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The virus has caused alarm because it is still too early to know how dangerous it is and how easily it spreads between people. Chinese officials say its incubation period could range from one to 14 days, and it is infectious during that time.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Here is what we know:</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">**As of Monday, the death toll in China had risen to 106, with 100 in Hubei province, authorities reported. Another 4,515 people in China had been infected. There were 2,714 confirmed cases in Hubei province, up from 1,423 on Sunday.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">**Thailand and Hong Kong have each reported eight cases of infection; the United States, Australia, Taiwan, Singapore and Macau have five each; Japan, South Korea and Malaysia each have reported four; France three; Vietnam and Canada two each, and one each in Germany, Sri Lanka, Nepal and Cambodia.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">**No fatalities have been reported outside China.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">**The previously unknown coronavirus strain is believed to have emerged late last year from illegally traded wildlife at a market in Wuhan, a city of 11 million people.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">**Premier Li Keqiang visited Wuhan on Monday to encourage medical workers as the government moved to show its determination to tackle the crisis. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">**The World Health Organisation said that while the outbreak was an emergency for China, it was not yet a global health emergency. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">**Severe travel restrictions have been put in place in several Chinese cities. In Wuhan, urban transport is shut and outgoing flights suspended. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">**Tangshan, China's largest steelmaking city in northern Hebei province, suspended all public transit within the city.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">**Beijing suspended most bus services to Hebei province.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">**Among other measures to contain the virus, China halted all group tours, affecting tourism both at home and to other countries. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">**China's Tibet Autonomous Region has temporarily closed all tourist sites to prevent the virus spreading.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">**The United States warned against travel to China, while Canada issued a warning against travel to Hubei province.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">**Asian stocks extended a global selloff the virus raised concerns about a drag on global economic growth.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">**South Korea said it was going "all out" to contain the outbreak and vowed to stabilise financial markets should volatility worsen.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">**Countries including France, Italy, Japan, Australia, South Korea and the United States are working to evacuate citizens from Wuhan.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">**Some experts believe the virus is not as dangerous as the 2002-03 Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome (SARS) that killed nearly 800 people, or the Middle East Respiratory Syndrome (MERS), which has killed more than 700 people since 2012. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"> (Compiled by Stephen Coates; Editing by Kenneth Maxwell, Robert Birsel)</p>, <p>Advertisement</p>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd" id="site-index-label">Site Index</h2>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-0">news</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-1">opinion</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-2">arts</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-3">living</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-4">more</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-subscribe-label">Subscribe</h3>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd">Site Information Navigation</h2>]
[<p>Advertisement</p>, <p>Supported by</p>, <p class="css-c2jxua e6idgb70"></p>, <h1 class="css-1j5ig2m e1h9rw200" id="link-a770eac" itemprop="headline"><span>Factbox: Latest on the Coronavirus Spreading in China and Beyond</span></h1>, <p class="css-1fv7b6t e1jsehar1" itemprop="author" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">By<!-- --> <span class="css-1baulvz last-byline" itemprop="name">Reuters</span></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">(Reuters) - The coronavirus outbreak that began in the central Chinese city of Wuhan, in the province of Hubei, has killed 106 people in China so far and infected more than 4,520 globally, most of them in China.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The virus has caused alarm because it is still too early to know how dangerous it is and how easily it spreads between people. Also because it is new, humans have not been able to build immunity to it. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Here is what we know so far:</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">* As of Jan. 27 the death toll in China had risen to 106, with 100 in Hubei province, authorities reported. Another 4,515 people in China had been infected. There were 2,714 confirmed cases in Hubei province, up from 1,423 on Jan. 26.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">* Thailand and Hong Kong have each reported eight cases of infection; the United States, Australia, Taiwan, Singapore and Macau have five each; Japan, South Korea and Malaysia each have reported four; France three; Vietnam and Canada two each, and one each in Germany, Sri Lanka and Nepal.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">* No fatalities have been reported outside China.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">* The previously unknown coronavirus strain is believed to have emerged late last year from illegally traded wildlife at an animal market in Wuhan, a city of 11 million people.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">* Chinese Premier Li Keqiang visited Wuhan on Monday in an apparent effort to boost morale in the city as Beijing moved to display its intent to tackle the crisis seriously. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">* The World Health Organisation said that while the outbreak was an emergency for China, it was not yet a global health emergency. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">* Severe travel restrictions have been put in place in several Chinese cities. In Wuhan, urban transport is shut and outgoing flights suspended. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">* Tangshan, China's largest steelmaking city in northern Hebei province, suspended all public transit within the city.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">* Beijing suspended most bus services to Hebei province.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">* Among other measures to contain the virus, China halted all group tours, affecting tourism both at home and to other countries, from Jan. 27. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">* China's Tibet Autonomous Region has temporarily closed all tourist sites to prevent the virus spreading.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">* The United States warned against travel to China, while Canada issued a warning against travel to Hubei province.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">* Asian stocks extended a global selloff on Tuesday as China took more drastic steps to combat the virus, raising concerns about a drag on global economic growth.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">* South Korea said it was going "all out" to contain the outbreak and vowed to stabilize financial markets should volatility worsen.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">* Countries including France, Italy, Japan, Australia and the United States are working to evacuate citizens from Wuhan.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">* Some experts believe the virus is not as dangerous as the 2002-03 Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome (SARS) that killed nearly 800 people, or the Middle East Respiratory Syndrome (MERS), which has killed more than 700 people since 2012. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"> (Compiled by Stephen Coates; Editing by Kenneth Maxwell)</p>, <p>Advertisement</p>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd" id="site-index-label">Site Index</h2>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-0">news</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-1">opinion</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-2">arts</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-3">living</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-4">more</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-subscribe-label">Subscribe</h3>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd">Site Information Navigation</h2>]

Chinese officials say its incubation period could range from one to 14 days, and it is infectious during that time.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Here is what we know:</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">* As of Monday, the death toll in China had risen to 106, with 100 in Hubei province, authorities reported. Another 4,515 people in China had been infected. There were 2,714 confirmed cases in Hubei province, up from 1,423 on Sunday.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">* Thailand and Hong Kong have each reported eight cases of infection; the United States, Australia, Taiwan, Singapore and Macau have five each; Japan, South Korea and Malaysia each have reported four; France three; Vietnam and Canada two each, and one each in Germany, Sri Lanka, Nepal and Cambodia.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">* No fatalities have been reported outside China.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">* The previously unknown coronavirus strain is believed to have emerged late last year from illegally traded wildlife at a market in Wuhan, a city of 11 million people.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">* Premier Li Keqiang visited Wuhan on Monday to encourage medical workers as the government moved to show its determination to tackle the crisis. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">* The World Health Organization said that while the outbreak was an emergency for China, it was not yet a global health emergency. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">* Severe travel restrictions have been put in place in several Chinese cities. In Wuhan, urban transport is shut and outgoing flights suspended. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">* Tangshan, China's largest steelmaking city in northern Hebei province, suspended all public transit within the city.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">* Beijing suspended most bus services to Hebei province.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">* Among other measures to contain the virus, China halted all group tours, affecting tourism both at home and to other countries. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">* China's Tibet Autonomous Region has temporarily closed all tourist sites to prevent the virus spreading.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">* The United States warned against travel to China, while Canada issued a warning against travel to Hubei province.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">* Asian stocks extended a global selloff the virus raised concerns about a drag on global economic growth.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">* South Korea said it was going "all out" to contain the outbreak and vowed to stabilize financial markets should volatility worsen.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">* Countries including France, Italy, Japan, Australia, South Korea and the United States are working to evacuate citizens from Wuhan.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">* Some experts believe the virus is not as dangerous as the 2002-03 Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome (SARS) that killed nearly 800 people, or the Middle East Respiratory Syndrome (MERS), which has killed more than 700 people since 2012. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"> (Compiled by Stephen Coates; Editing by Kenneth Maxwell, Robert Birsel)</p>, <p>Advertisement</p>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd" id="site-index-label">Site Index</h2>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-0">news</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-1">opinion</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-2">arts</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-3">living</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-4">more</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-subscribe-label">Subscribe</h3>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd">Site Information Navigation</h2>]
[<h1 class="css-1jrl1ex">Page No Longer Available</h1>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd" id="site-index-label">Site Index</h2>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-0">news</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-1">opinion</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-2">arts</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-3">living</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-4">more</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-subscribe-label">Subscribe</h3>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd">Site Information Navigation</h2>]
[<p>Advertisement</p>, <p>Supported by</p>, <p class="css-c2jxua e6idgb70"></p>, <h1 class="css-1j5ig2m e1h9rw200" id="link-623801f8" itemprop="headline"><span>Coronavirus Infects Asia Stocks With Exposure to China</span></h1>, <p class="css-1fv7b6t e1jsehar1" itemprop="author" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">By<!-- --> <span class="css-1baulvz last-byline" itemprop="name">Reuters</span></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">SYDNEY — Shares of companies highly exposed to China's economy tumbled across Asia on Tuesday on rising concern about the impact of global travel bans associated with a virus outbreak, and even as some stocks involved in preventative health spiked.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">After the United States and Canada warned against travel to China, Australian stocks resumed trading sharply lower after a public holiday. The benchmark S&amp;P/ASX 200 index fell 1.4% weighed by stocks exposed to the illness that has killed more than 100 people and infected more than 2,700.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Shares of airlines and travel agents were sharply lower amid freezes on travel into and out of the world's second largest economy, while companies with an indirect exposure to Chinese consumer spending abroad, such as casinos and luxury retailers, also tumbled.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">"We don't know how long it will go," said Peter Costello, chairman of Australia's $115 billion sovereign wealth fund, the Future Fund, in a media briefing to coincide with a regular portfolio update.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">"Obviously we hope that the measures that have been taken now will contain the virus but it's still far too early. It will have an obvious negative effect on the Australian economy and indeed beyond," added Costello, a former Australian treasurer.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">With Chinese markets closed for the week-long new year holiday, other stock markets in Asia were feeling an outsized impact of investor concerns. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">South Korean cosmetic makers highly dependent on Chinese tourists coming to Seoul stumbled, with Tonymoly and Able C&amp;C losing more than 12% and 15% respectively on Tuesday.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Japanese travel company H.I.S., which owns an amusement park popular with Chinese tourists in Nagasaki, has tumbled more than 14% since early last week.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Shares of Australia's biggest airline Qantas Airways Ltd were down 5% on Tuesday, while travel agent Webjet Ltd fell 11%. South Korea's top two airlines, Korean Air Lines and Asiana Airlines, dropped 6% and 5%. Japan Airlines lost 7.9% and airline ANA Holdings was down 6.0%.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Australia's top two casino companies Crown Resorts Ltd and Star Entertainment Group ltd, which both get a sizeable portion of revenue from vacationing Chinese gamblers, each fell about 5%. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Traders meanwhile pointed to companies which might generate sales from efforts to curb the spread of coronavirus as investment prospects. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The Malaysian Rubber Glove Manufacturers Association (MARGMA) said on Tuesday China had requested more urgent shipments from the world's top producer, and its members were ramping up production. Top Glove Corp has seen its shares surge by a quarter in a week.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">"MARGMA believes that demand for gloves will inevitably shoot up and has urged its members to give priority to those affected areas and countries," association president Denis Low said in a statement. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Shares of South Korean mask producer Monalisa surged 29%, while South Korean pharmaceuticals Kukje Pharma and Woojung Bio added 29% and 21% respectively on Tuesday.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Japan's Kawamoto Corp, which supplies medical products including masks, saw its share prices triple, while Japanese protective clothing maker Azearth rose 53% in the past week.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"> (Reporting by Byron Kaye and Paulina Duran in Sydney; additional reporting by Hayoung Choi in Seoul and Hideyuki Sano in Tokyo; Editing by Lincoln Feast.)</p>, <p>Advertisement</p>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd" id="site-index-label">Site Index</h2>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-0">news</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-1">opinion</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-2">arts</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-3">living</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-4">more</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-subscribe-label">Subscribe</h3>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd">Site Information Navigation</h2>]
[<p>Advertisement</p>, <p>Supported by</p>, <p class="css-c2jxua e6idgb70"></p>, <h1 class="css-1j5ig2m e1h9rw200" id="link-27bb2d13" itemprop="headline"><span>EU Begins Assisting Repatriations From China as Coronavirus Spreads</span></h1>, <p class="css-1fv7b6t e1jsehar1" itemprop="author" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">By<!-- --> <span class="css-1baulvz last-byline" itemprop="name">Reuters</span></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">BRUSSELS — The European Commission said on Tuesday it would start helping repatriate Europeans from the Chinese region hit hardest by the coronavirus after a request from France.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The Commission said in a statement it had activated its EU Civil Protection Mechanism, under which it will co-fund two planes to bring European Union citizens back from Wuhan, the Chinese city at the center of the virus outbreak.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">France had requested assistance to provide consular support to EU citizens in Wuhan.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">"This is a first request for assistance and others may follow in the coming days," the Commission said.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Countries around the world are planning to evacuate diplomatic staff and private citizens from Chinese areas hit by the new coronavirus, which is spreading rapidly in China. A small number of cases have been confirmed elsewhere.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Wuhan, a city of 11 million in the province of Hubei, is in virtual lockdown and much of Hubei, home to nearly 60 million people, is under some kind of travel curb.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The EU will co-finance the transport costs of the aircraft, the first due to depart France early on Wednesday and the second due to leave later this week.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The Commission said around 250 French citizens would be on the first flight back and more than 100 citizens of other EU countries would be on the second. For now, only people showing no signs of the virus would be allowed to travel.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The EU's Emergency Response Centre was in contact with EU governments in order to coordinate returns and possible quarantine periods. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">All EU members are part of the Civil Protection Mechanism, along with Iceland, Norway, Serbia, North Macedonia, Montenegro, and Turkey.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"> (Reporting by John Chalmers and Philip Blenkinsop; Editing by Janet Lawrence)</p>, <p>Advertisement</p>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd" id="site-index-label">Site Index</h2>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-0">news</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-1">opinion</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-2">arts</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-3">living</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-4">more</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-subscribe-label">Subscribe</h3>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd">Site Information Navigation</h2>]

[<p>Advertisement</p>, <p>Supported by</p>, <p class="css-c2jxua e6idgb70"></p>, <h1 class="css-1j5ig2m e1h9rw200" id="link-a9182e5" itemprop="headline"><span>Chinese Embassy Wants Danish Paper to Apologize for Coronavirus Cartoon</span></h1>, <p class="css-1fv7b6t e1jsehar1" itemprop="author" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">By<!-- --> <span class="css-1baulvz last-byline" itemprop="name">Reuters</span></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">COPENHAGEN — China's embassy in Denmark has demanded an apology from daily Jyllands-Posten after it published a cartoon of the Chinese flag with its five yellow stars represented by coronavirus particles. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">In a statement, the embassy said Jyllands-Posten and Danish artist Niels Bo Bojesen should apologize to the Chinese people for publishing the image, captioned "Coronavirus", in Monday's edition of the paper.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">"Without any sympathy and empathy, it has crossed the bottom line of civilized society and the ethical boundary of free speech and offends human conscience," the embassy said on Tuesday. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">In 2005, Jyllands-Posten published satirical drawings of the Prophet Mohammad that caused outrage across the Muslim world.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Editor-in-chief Jacob Nybroe said the paper had not intended to make fun of the situation in China, where the new coronavirus has killed 106 people and infected thousands, but refused to apologize, local newswire Ritzau reported. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">"We cannot apologize for something that we don't believe is wrong," Nybroe told Ritzau. "We have no intention of demeaning or mocking the situation in China and we don't think the drawing does that."</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Danish politicians from across the spectrum said China should not pressure the paper. "Full support for Jyllands-Posten," tweeted Conservative Party leader Soren Pape Poulsen.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"> (Reporting by Andreas Mortensen; Editing by Catherine Evans)</p>, <p>Advertisement</p>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd" id="site-index-label">Site Index</h2>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-0">news</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-1">opinion</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-2">arts</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-3">living</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-4">more</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-subscribe-label">Subscribe</h3>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd">Site Information Navigation</h2>]
[<p>Advertisement</p>, <p>Supported by</p>, <p class="css-c2jxua e6idgb70"></p>, <h1 class="css-1j5ig2m e1h9rw200" id="link-2f06fb47" itemprop="headline"><span>Why the 'Devil' Coronavirus Has Hit European Stocks Hard</span></h1>, <p class="css-1fv7b6t e1jsehar1" itemprop="author" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">By<!-- --> <span class="css-1baulvz last-byline" itemprop="name">Reuters</span></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">LONDON — A whopping $200 billion was wiped from European stocks at the start of this week as the deadly coronavirus prompted investors to cut back exposure to companies with a strong presence in China, the world's fastest-growing consumer market.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The plunge on Monday saw European luxury goods makers, airlines and miners among the stocks hit hardest as the outbreak led to ramped-up travel bans, business shutdowns and extended Lunar New Year holidays.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Hundreds of millions of people have been preparing to travel for the Chinese holidays, stoking concerns infection rates may accelerate during the period - which is also a peak retail season in China and overseas.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The virus - which Chinese President Xi Jinping has described as a "devil" - has had a bigger impact on European companies than their U.S. peers due to their high revenue exposure to China. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Some analysts have drawn comparisons with SARS, a deadly virus in 2002-2003, but the read across is limited as China's share of global gross domestic product has quadrupled since then to 16%. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Investors have singled out the biggest names in Europe's fashion industry, including France's LVMH, Italy's Moncler and Britain's Burberry, as proxies for the coronavirus outbreak. Chinese consumers have become the sector's main growth engine over the past decade.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">In a research note published on Tuesday, UBS analysts said a 30% drop in Chinese demand, their worst-case scenario, was likely to hit the sector's earnings by as much as 7% in 2020. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">(Graphic: Luxury companies exposure to China - https://fingfx.thomsonreuters.com/gfx/buzzifr/15/5647/5647/Pasted%20Image.jpg)</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Meanwhile, early data showed civil air travel in China dropped 41.6% on the first day of Lunar New Year due to travel curbs. In Europe, shares of long-haul operators Air France and Lufthansa were among the worst hit.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">In the hospitality sector, Intercontinental Hotels Group and Accor were also beaten down.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">(Graphic: Airlines and hotels hit hard as Coronavirus spreads fast - https://fingfx.thomsonreuters.com/gfx/buzzifr/15/5648/5648/Pasted%20Image.jpg)</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Topping it all, the non-consumer facing mining sector was the hardest hit in Europe, falling 7% on concerns that the coronavirus will cut China's gigantic appetite for commodities.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The graphic below shows how Europe's miners have among the biggest revenue exposures to China.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">(Graphic: Mining exposure to China - https://fingfx.thomsonreuters.com/gfx/mkt/13/1547/1522/Mining%20exposure%20to%20China.png)</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"> (Reporting by Julien Ponthus, Thyagaraju Adinarayan, Joice Alves and Danilo Masoni; Editing by Pravin Char)</p>, <p>Advertisement</p>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd" id="site-index-label">Site Index</h2>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-0">news</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-1">opinion</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-2">arts</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-3">living</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-4">more</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-subscribe-label">Subscribe</h3>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd">Site Information Navigation</h2>]
[<p>Advertisement</p>, <p>Supported by</p>, <p class="css-c2jxua e6idgb70"></p>, <h1 class="css-1j5ig2m e1h9rw200" id="link-193ab5ad" itemprop="headline"><span>Starbucks' Results Top Estimates but Coronavirus Slows Sales</span></h1>, <p class="css-1fv7b6t e1jsehar1" itemprop="author" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">By<!-- --> <span class="css-1baulvz last-byline" itemprop="name">The Associated Press</span></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">It was a happy holiday at Starbucks, but the company's sales momentum could start to slow due to the coronavirus outbreak in China.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Starbucks said it had intended to raise its full-year earnings guidance Tuesday, but uncertainty about China put that on pause. Starbucks said it has already closed more than half of its stores in China due to coronavirus. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">China's 4,292 Starbucks stores brought in 10% of the company's revenue during the October-December period, so the closure will affect earnings, the company said. But it's not yet clear how much of an impact there will be. Starbucks had expected full-year revenue growth in the 6% to 8% range and same-store sales growth of 3% to 4%.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“We remain optimistic and committed to the long term growth potential in China," Starbucks President and CEO Kevin Johnson said in a conference call Tuesday with analysts.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Starbucks shares fell 1.6% to $87.20 in extended trading following the earnings report.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Johnson said the holiday season was one of the best in the company's history. New drinks like the Pumpkin Cream Cold Brew were a hit with customers. Starbucks' new four-story Reserve Roastery in Chicago — which opened in November — is serving an average of 10,000 visitors each day, he said.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">A combination of new stores and solid foot traffic helped the Seattle-based coffee giant handily beat Wall Street's forecasts in the October-December period. The company opened 539 net new stores in its fiscal first quarter. It now has nearly 32,000 stores worldwide. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Starbucks' earnings rose 16% to $886 million in the fiscal first quarter. Earnings, adjusted for non-recurring items like restructuring charges, were 79 cents per share. That beat Wall Street's forecast of 76 cents. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Starbucks said same-store sales — or sales at stores open at least 13 months — jumped 5% worldwide in the October-December period, ahead of analysts' forecast of 4.4%. Revenue was up 7% to $7.1 billion, in line with analysts' forecasts.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Starbucks Chief Operating Officer Roz Brewer said she's confident the company can sustain that momentum because of new products and technology in the pipeline. Starbucks is adding new equipment to stores to improve its cold brew process, she said. The company also plans to introduce a plant-based sausage sandwich at breakfast and more non-dairy milks based on customer requests, she said.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Starbucks also plans more mobile order and pickup locations in the U.S. after the successful opening of a small-format store in New York during the quarter. Mobile ordering and payment represented 17% of U.S. sales in the first quarter.</p>, <p>Advertisement</p>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd" id="site-index-label">Site Index</h2>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-0">news</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-1">opinion</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-2">arts</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-3">living</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-4">more</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-subscribe-label">Subscribe</h3>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd">Site Information Navigation</h2>]
[<p>Advertisement</p>, <p>Supported by</p>, <p class="css-c2jxua e6idgb70"></p>, <h1 class="css-1j5ig2m e1h9rw200" id="link-3e42e0c6" itemprop="headline"><span>Suspected Chinese Coronavirus Patient Gives Birth to Baby by Caesarian</span></h1>, <p class="css-1fv7b6t e1jsehar1" itemprop="author" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">By<!-- --> <span class="css-1baulvz last-byline" itemprop="name">Reuters</span></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">BEIJING — Chinese doctors have safely delivered a baby boy from a Chinese woman suspected of being infected with the new coronavirus through a caesarian section in the city of Wuhan, the epicenter of the outbreak.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The doctor who performed the caesarian said the 27-year-old mother's condition had been deteriorating and the baby was putting too much pressure on her. At the same time, the woman could not get proper treatment for her illness while carrying the baby.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">But the surgery was extremely dangerous as the mother had a fever and was coughing non-stop while the doctors faced the risk of infection with the coronavirus, state television reported.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The doctor who performed the operation, Zhao Yin, deputy director at the obstetrics and gynecology department at Wuhan Union Hospital, wore two protective suits, a face mask and goggles during the one-hour surgery.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">"I could barely see or hear anything," Zhao told state television. "And I was soaked with sweat."</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The virus has killed 106 people and infected more than 4,500 across China.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The mother, identified only as Xiaoyan, was 37 weeks pregnant when she was suspected of being infected by the coronavirus in early January. Her infection has not been confirmed, state television said.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The 3.1 kg (6.8 lb) baby boy was sent home as quickly as possible to avoid the danger of it being exposed to the virus in hospital, state television said.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">"I just want my baby to be healthy," Xiaoyan told state television. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"> (Reporting by Muyu Xu and Tony Munroe; Editing by Robert Birsel)</p>, <p>Advertisement</p>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd" id="site-index-label">Site Index</h2>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-0">news</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-1">opinion</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-2">arts</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-3">living</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-4">more</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-subscribe-label">Subscribe</h3>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd">Site Information Navigation</h2>]
[<p>Advertisement</p>, <p>Supported by</p>, <p class="css-c2jxua e6idgb70"></p>, <h1 class="css-1j5ig2m e1h9rw200" id="link-5d2c4f65" itemprop="headline"><span>China's Tangshan City Suspends Public Transit to Prevent Spread of Coronavirus</span></h1>, <p class="css-1fv7b6t e1jsehar1" itemprop="author" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">By<!-- --> <span class="css-1baulvz last-byline" itemprop="name">Reuters</span></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">(Reuters) - Tangshan, China's largest steelmaking city in northern Hebei province, announced on Tuesday morning that it is suspending all public transit within the city in an effort to prevent the further spread of the new coronavirus.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The statement was posted on the city government's official Weibo account.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">China is now in the grips of a new coronavirus outbreak that has killed 81 people and has shutdown many of the largest cities in central Hubei province. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"> (Reporting by Huizhong Wu; Writing by Lisa Shumaker; Editing by Sandra Maler)</p>, <p>Advertisement</p>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd" id="site-index-label">Site Index</h2>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-0">news</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-1">opinion</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-2">arts</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-3">living</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-4">more</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-subscribe-label">Subscribe</h3>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd">Site Information Navigation</h2>]
[<p>Advertisement</p>, <p>Supported by</p>, <p class="css-c2jxua e6idgb70"></p>, <h1 class="css-1j5ig2m e1h9rw200" id="link-690a6c80" itemprop="headline"><span>U.S. Government Urges Americans to Reconsider Travel to China Because of Coronavirus</span></h1>, <p class="css-1fv7b6t e1jsehar1" itemprop="author" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">By<!-- --> <span class="css-1baulvz last-byline" itemprop="name">Reuters</span></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">(Reuters) - The U.S. State Department urged Americans on Monday to reconsider going to China because of the coronavirus, after warning against travel to the Hubei province of China, where the respiratory illness is believed to have originated, .</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) said on Monday it had not recorded any new confirmed cases of the illness overnight since its last update of five, but that as many as 110 potential cases were under investigation.The State Department said Americans should reconsider any plans to travel to China during the outbreak. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">In an advisory posted on Friday, the State Department said: </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">"Do not travel to Hubei province, China due to novel coronavirus first identified in Wuhan, China.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">It added: "Chinese authorities have imposed strict travel restrictions in the area around Wuhan. Travelers should be aware that the Chinese government could prevent them from entering or exiting parts of Hubei province," the advisory said. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The coronavirus, which causes respiratory symptoms similar to a cold or flu, has been linked to a seafood market in Wuhan, the largest city in central China, with a population of about 11 million. That market has since been shut down. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The outbreak has killed 81 and infected more than 2,800 in China.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">U.S. President Donald Trump on Monday offered any help China needed to control the outbreak, which has also left tens of millions stranded during the Lunar New Year, the biggest Chinese holiday.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The CDC has said that of the investigated cases across 26 states, 32 people had tested negative, the CDC said.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">There is no evidence so far that the coronavirus is transmitted through imported goods, Nancy Messonnier, director of the CDC's National Center for Immunization and Respiratory Diseases, said in a briefing with reporters.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The CDC raised issued a separate travel alert last week recommending people avoid all nonessential travel to Wuhan.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"> (Reporting by Manas Mishra and Saumya Sibi Joseph in Bengaluru and Dan Whitcomb in Culver City, California; Editing by Peter Cooney)</p>, <p>Advertisement</p>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd" id="site-index-label">Site Index</h2>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-0">news</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-1">opinion</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-2">arts</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-3">living</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-4">more</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-subscribe-label">Subscribe</h3>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd">Site Information Navigation</h2>]
