[<p>Advertisement</p>, <p>Supported by</p>, <p class="css-c2jxua e6idgb70"></p>, <h1 class="css-1j5ig2m e1h9rw200" id="link-382f8577" itemprop="headline"><span>South Korea 'All Out' to Contain Virus Outbreak, Vows to Stabilize Market</span></h1>, <p class="css-1fv7b6t e1jsehar1" itemprop="author" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">By<!-- --> <span class="css-1baulvz last-byline" itemprop="name">Reuters</span></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">SEOUL — South Korea on Tuesday said it was going "all out" to contain the outbreak of the spreading coronavirus and vowed to stabilize financial markets should volatilities worsen as it confirmed the fourth case of the China-linked virus. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">"The government will be all out to protect citizens and minimize its impact on the economy," Finance Minister Hong Nam-ki said in a policy meeting in Seoul.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Hong said the government will fund efforts to contain the virus using the emergency fund from the existing budget, including 20.8 billion won ($17.8 million) set aside for anti-epidemic measures.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">South Korea in 2015 drew up a supplementary budget to help the economy cope with the effects of the outbreak of the Middle East Respiratory Syndrome (MERS).</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The virus, originating in the Chinese central city of Wuhan at the end of last year, has spread to the United States, Japan, Canada, France and Germany among others. It has killed at least 81 people.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"> (Reporting by Joori Roh and Cynthia Kim; Editing by Sandra Maler)</p>, <p>Advertisement</p>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd" id="site-index-label">Site Index</h2>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-0">news</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-1">opinion</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-2">arts</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-3">living</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-4">more</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-subscribe-label">Subscribe</h3>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd">Site Information Navigation</h2>]
[<p>Advertisement</p>, <p>Supported by</p>, <p class="css-c2jxua e6idgb70"></p>, <h1 class="css-1j5ig2m e1h9rw200" id="link-69196e66" itemprop="headline"><span>Louis Vuitton Owner LVMH's Sales Growth Slows in Fourth Quarter</span></h1>, <p class="css-1fv7b6t e1jsehar1" itemprop="author" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">By<!-- --> <span class="css-1baulvz last-byline" itemprop="name">Reuters</span></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">PARIS — Sales growth at luxury goods group LVMH slowed slightly in the fourth quarter, pushed down in part by a sharp drop in revenue in Hong Kong where months of violent protests have scared away many high-end shoppers.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The company, which owns labels including Louis Vuitton and Christian Dior, said the new coronavirus outbreak this month forced it to shutter some stores in the Chinese city of Wuhan, but it believed the peak of the virus would pass in a few weeks, limiting the impact on sales.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">LVMH posted record revenue and profit for the whole of 2019. It said in a statement that fourth quarter sales rose 12% to 15.27 billion euros (13 billion pounds). </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">That marked an 8% increase year-on-year on a like-for-like basis, which strips out currency swings and acquisitions, and compared with forecasts cited by analysts and Reuters estimates of closer to 9% growth. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">But it was less strong when set against like-for-like sales in the previous three months, which had grown 11%.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Speaking to reporters after the results were announced, LVMH Chief Financial Officer Jean-Jacques Guiony said that revenue in Hong Kong was down around 40 percent in the fourth quarter.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">LVMH said though it managed to offset some of the pain through a strong performance at its stores in mainland China.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Hong Kong is a key market for luxury firms. Some of them have had to close stores during street protests against the Beijing-backed government.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">LVMH said the group's sales growth would have kept pace in the fourth quarter were it not for one-off factors. It cited a tax hike in Japan which had led clients to bring forward purchases to the third quarter, and cognac stock shortages in the last three months of the year.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">NO PANIC</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Investors are fretting about the impact of the new coronavirus on China, the world’s second-biggest economy, amid travel bans and a Lunar New Year holiday that has been extended by the authorities to try to limit the spread of infection.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Asked for his projections, LVMH boss Bernard Arnault said it was too early to say how the virus would evolve.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">"The first reaction is: 'Don't panic, let's calmly analyse the situation'," he told reporters.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Citing information passed to him from Chinese authorities, he said it seemed the peak of the virus should pass within weeks and it should peter out by the end of March. He also said the Chinese official response to the outbreak seemed robust.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">"That's the information we have," Arnault said. "If it dies out in two months or two months and a half, it's not terrible. If it takes two years, that's a different story."</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">In LVMH's core fashion and handbags division, home to Louis Vuitton and other big brands such as Christian Dior, sales held up well in the quarter, expanding 15% on a like-for-like basis. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">That was in line or a touch above some analysts' forecasts. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"> (Writing by Sarah White and Christian Lowe; Editing by Alexandra Hudson)</p>, <p>Advertisement</p>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd" id="site-index-label">Site Index</h2>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-0">news</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-1">opinion</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-2">arts</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-3">living</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-4">more</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-subscribe-label">Subscribe</h3>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd">Site Information Navigation</h2>]
[<p>Advertisement</p>, <p>Supported by</p>, <p class="css-c2jxua e6idgb70"></p>, <h1 class="css-1j5ig2m e1h9rw200" id="link-2075bc93" itemprop="headline"><span>Kazakhstan Restricts Visa Regime for Chinese Over Virus</span></h1>, <p class="css-1fv7b6t e1jsehar1" itemprop="author" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">By<!-- --> <span class="css-1baulvz last-byline" itemprop="name">Reuters</span></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">NUR-SULTAN — Kazakhstan will require medical certificates from Chinese citizens seeking visas and has stopped issuing electronic visas to them on arrival as a protective measure against the spread of a new coronavirus, deputy foreign minister Shukhrat Nuryshev said on Tuesday.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Nuryshev told reporters the government has asked Beijing to allow 98 Kazakh students to leave the city of Wuhan, which has been locked down and is considered to be the epicenter of the outbreak.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">There are no plans to completely close the border with neighboring China, he said, as that would stop Kazakh citizens from returning home. Overall, 1,300 Kazakhs remain in China, Nuryshev said, half of them tourists visiting resorts in Hainan.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Out of those who have already returned from China, four people have been hospitalized with suspected respiratory infections and are being tested, healthcare minister Yelzhan Birtanov told the same briefing.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"> (Reporting by Tamara Vaal; Writing by Olzhas Auyezov; Editing by Kim Coghill)</p>, <p>Advertisement</p>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd" id="site-index-label">Site Index</h2>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-0">news</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-1">opinion</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-2">arts</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-3">living</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-4">more</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-subscribe-label">Subscribe</h3>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd">Site Information Navigation</h2>]
[<p>Advertisement</p>, <p>Supported by</p>, <p class="css-c2jxua e6idgb70"></p>, <h1 class="css-1j5ig2m e1h9rw200" id="link-7b5135c3" itemprop="headline"><span>UK Advises Against 'All but Essential' Travel to Mainland China After Virus Outbreak</span></h1>, <p class="css-1fv7b6t e1jsehar1" itemprop="author" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">By<!-- --> <span class="css-1baulvz last-byline" itemprop="name">Reuters</span></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">(Reuters) - Britain on Tuesday advised against "all but essential" travel to mainland China due to the coronavirus outbreak.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">"The FCO continue to advise against all travel to Hubei Province, and now advise against all but essential travel to the rest of mainland China (not including Hong Kong and Macao)", Britain's Foreign and Commonwealth Office (FCO) said on Tuesday.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The Foreign Office also said it was working to arrange for evacuation of British nationals from Hubei, which is under a transport lockdown in a bid to contain the virus.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Sky News reported http://bit.ly/2U4HCtG that about 300 British citizens were still in Wuhan and the surrounding Hubei province, and a charter flight was set to fly them out on Thursday.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The virus has thus far killed 106 people, infected over 4,500 others, stranded tens of millions during the Lunar New Year holiday and rattled global markets.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"> (Reporting by Ann Maria Shibu in Bengaluru; Editing by Chris Reese and Rosalba O'Brien)</p>, <p>Advertisement</p>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd" id="site-index-label">Site Index</h2>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-0">news</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-1">opinion</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-2">arts</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-3">living</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-4">more</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-subscribe-label">Subscribe</h3>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd">Site Information Navigation</h2>]
[<p>Advertisement</p>, <p>Supported by</p>, <p class="css-c2jxua e6idgb70"></p>, <h1 class="css-1j5ig2m e1h9rw200" id="link-4f7921ef" itemprop="headline"><span>Bad Timing: New Virus Poses Threat to Fragile World Economy</span></h1>, <p class="css-1fv7b6t e1jsehar1" itemprop="author" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">By<!-- --> <span class="css-1baulvz last-byline" itemprop="name">The Associated Press</span></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">This should be peak season for a 12-room hotel near the train station in the Chinese industrial hub of Wuhan. The Chinese New Year usually brings in plenty of travelers and delivers profits of around $3,000 a month.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">But the place is empty. Wuhan, the center of a deadly viral outbreak, is on lockdown. “There is not a single customer,’’ said the hotel’s owner, who gave only his surname, Cui. He still has to pay rent and his utility bills. Instead of counting his earnings, he’s expecting to lose $1,500 a month.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The outbreak arrives at a bad time for Wuhan, China and the world economy.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">China, with the world’s No. 2 economy, was decelerating even before the coronavirus hit.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">And the world economy is coping with an unexpectedly sharp slowdown in No. 7 India, which prompted the International Monetary Fund last week to downgrade its outlook for global growth this year.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The coronavirus is drawing comparisons to the SARS outbreak, which paralyzed the economies of China and Hong Kong for weeks in 2003. But what happens in China carries a lot more weight these days: In 2003, China accounted for 4% of global output. Now its share is 16%, according to the World Bank.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“A growth slowdown in China could have sizable ripple effects across Asia and the rest of the world, given the size of China’s economy and its role as the key driver of global growth in recent years,” said Eswar Prasad, a Cornell University economist and former head of the International Monetary Fund's China division. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">No one knows exactly how the outbreak will play out or what its economic impact will be. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Authorities are still trying to better understand the new virus. It is from the coronavirus family, which also can cause the common cold as well as more serious illnesses such as SARS.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">So far, China has confirmed more than 4,500 coronavirus cases and more than 100 deaths. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The Chinese government has locked down Wuhan and 16 other cities in Hubei province, isolating more than 50 million people. The United States and other countries prepared Tuesday to airlift their citizens out of Wuhan. The outbreak has brought every day business to a standstill and closed down such popular tourist attractions as Beijing's former imperial palace, Shanghai Disneyland, Hong Kong Disneyland and the city's Ocean Park.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The significant decline in travel has already caused United Airlines to suspend some flights to Beijing, Hong Kong and Shanghai, the airline said in a statement.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“It’s still too soon to measure what the impact is going to be from an economic perspective,’’ said Jim Baird, chief investment officer at Plante Moran Financial Advisors.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The SARS experience offers some reason for economic optimism. That outbreak, centered in southern China, initially clobbered the Chinese economy. In the April-June quarter of 2003, China’s economic growth dropped to an annual rate of 9.1% from 11.1% the previous quarter, noted economists Tommy Wu and Priyanka Kishore of Oxford Economics. But as the health crisis subsided, growth picked back up, recovering to a 10% annual rate in the second half of the year.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“From what we know, it’s likely to be similar this time,’’ said Andy Rothman, investment strategist at Matthews Asia. “People shouldn’t get panicked that growth is going to slow sharply’’ over a sustained period.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Still, the Chinese economy isn’t the dynamo it was in the early and mid-2000s when growth routinely hit double digits.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The IMF expects China’s growth to drop from 6.1% in 2019, already the slowest since 1990, to 6% this year and 5.8% next. The slowdown reflects China’s difficult transition from fast but unsustainable growth built around often-wasteful investments to steadier but less striking growth built on consumer spending by the country’s growing middle class.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The Chinese economy has also been buffeted by a trade war with the United States. The two countries signed a truce earlier this month that was expected to provide some economic relief. Then the viral outbreak hit.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">As part of the so-called Phase 1 deal, China agreed to increase purchases of U.S. products by $200 billion over this year and next. That goal sounded ambitious even before the viral outbreak isolated tens of millions of Chinese consumers and delivered a wallop to consumer and business confidence.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Rothman suspects the United States might give the Chinese a little leeway. “Both governments really want the deal to work,’’ he said. “Ïf it is clear that (Chinese purchases) are off to a slow start not because the Chinese government is not trying its best but because of the virus, the Trump administration is likely to be sympathetic.’’</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">There has been no immediate impact on China’s vast manufacturing industries because factories already were closed for the Lunar New Year holiday and weren’t due to reopen until this week or later. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“I think the first quarter looks like it will take quite a significant hit,” said Rajiv Biswas, chief Asia economist for IHS Markit. “This still is escalating, so it’s hard to talk about when this will be contained.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"> Further delays in restarting production could send shock waves through Asian suppliers of components and exporters of iron ore, copper and other commodities as far away as Australia, Brazil and Africa.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"> Foreign suppliers usually see a surge in Chinese orders as factories restock after shutting down for 10 days or more during the holiday.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"> “The loss of economic output could be quite substantial, and that has consequences for the Asian manufacturing supply chain, because orders won’t come in the way people expect,” Biswas said.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The impact in other developing Asian countries might reduce their 2020 economic growth by 1.5 to 2 percentage points, according to a forecast by Edward Glossop of Capital Economics.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Growth in Asian emerging markets “will slow sharply in the first quarter of the year,” Glossop said in a report.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Japanese Economy Minister Yasutoshi Nishimura told reporters Tuesday that Japanese exports, production and corporate profits could be pinched by the new virus, stressing that he was closely monitoring the situation. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">A more direct hit is already coming from the decline in tourist traffic from China. Nishimura said Chinese travelers usually account for about a third of tourists from abroad. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Chinese tourists to Japan tend to be relatively big spenders. The virus has hit right at the time when Chinese travel for the lunar new year.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Japan’s economy suffered from the SARS outbreak in 2003, but the damage was limited to several months. The big difference is that Japan has far more Chinese tourists these days. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Now “the impact on the Japanese economy would be far greater,” said Takahide Kiuchi, executive economist at Nomura Research Institute, while adding that much depends on how widespread the outbreak proves to be.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“There is hardly anything good that can be hoped for economically because of the new virus,” he said. Increased sales of masks and other protective gear, he noted, will hardly pick up the slack.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">___</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Wiseman reported from Washington, McDonald from Beijing and Kageyama from Tokyo. AP researcher Yu Bing in Beijing and AP Airlines Writer David Koenig in Dallas contributed to this report.</p>, <p>Advertisement</p>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd" id="site-index-label">Site Index</h2>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-0">news</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-1">opinion</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-2">arts</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-3">living</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-4">more</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-subscribe-label">Subscribe</h3>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd">Site Information Navigation</h2>]
[<p>Advertisement</p>, <p>Supported by</p>, <p class="css-c2jxua e6idgb70"></p>, <h1 class="css-1j5ig2m e1h9rw200" id="link-656da555" itemprop="headline"><span>The Latest: Japanese Relieved, Exhausted After Leaving Wuhan</span></h1>, <p class="css-1fv7b6t e1jsehar1" itemprop="author" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">By<!-- --> <span class="css-1baulvz last-byline" itemprop="name">The Associated Press</span></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">BEIJING — The Latest on the outbreak of a new virus from China:</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">10 a.m.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Two Japanese men evacuated from a virus-hit Chinese city say they felt relieved but also exhausted upon their arrival in Tokyo.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">They were aboard a chartered flight Japan arranged to evacuate 206 Japanese citizens from Wuhan.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Takeo Aoyama who works for Nippon Steel Corp. and Takayuki Kato, who works for Intec, both wore masks but said they felt fine.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Kato said he was not panicking in Wuhan, but “I was shocked when all transportation systems were suspended. That’s when the situation drastically changed."</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">China cut off access to Wuhan and 16 other cities to try to contain the outbreak of the new type of coronavirus that has infected thousands of people.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Aoyama said many people who wish to go home to Japan are still in Wuhan, including workers at a Japanese supermarket chain staying open to supply food.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">He said it is important to step up preventive measures in Japan, but “I hope we can also provide support for the Chinese people, which I think would also help the Japanese people who are still there.”</p>, <p>Advertisement</p>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd" id="site-index-label">Site Index</h2>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-0">news</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-1">opinion</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-2">arts</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-3">living</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-4">more</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-subscribe-label">Subscribe</h3>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd">Site Information Navigation</h2>]
[<p>Advertisement</p>, <p>Supported by</p>, <p class="css-c2jxua e6idgb70"></p>, <h1 class="css-1j5ig2m e1h9rw200" id="link-593a417b" itemprop="headline"><span>Singapore-Listed Sasseur REIT Shuts China Malls as Wuhan Virus Spreads</span></h1>, <p class="css-1fv7b6t e1jsehar1" itemprop="author" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">By<!-- --> <span class="css-1baulvz last-byline" itemprop="name">Reuters</span></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">SINGAPORE — Sasseur Real Estate Investment Trust said on Tuesday it has temporarily closed its four outlet malls in China to help prevent the spread of a coronavirus that has killed over 100 people. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The REIT's units were down 8% on Tuesday morning, while the broader market was down more than 2%. Its malls in China are in Chongqing, Bishan, Hefei and Kunming. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Seven other outlet malls owned or managed by Sasseur Cayman Holding Ltd - Sasseur REIT's majority shareholder - in Hangzhou, Changsha, Nanjing, Lanzhou, Xian, Guiyang and Changchun have also been progressively closed from Jan. 26. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">While local authorities have not imposed any regulations to direct the closures of malls, the manager of the REIT said Sasseur decided the outlets should be temporarily closed due to the severity of virus. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Sasseur said that while it could not ascertain the financial hit of the crisis on its financial performance, the impact should not be material if it was resolved in the short term. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">It said it will aim to re-open the malls as soon as it is appropriate. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"> (Reporting by Aradhana Aravindan in Singapore; Editing by Tom Hogue)</p>, <p>Advertisement</p>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd" id="site-index-label">Site Index</h2>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-0">news</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-1">opinion</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-2">arts</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-3">living</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-4">more</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-subscribe-label">Subscribe</h3>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd">Site Information Navigation</h2>]
[<p>Advertisement</p>, <p>Supported by</p>, <p class="css-c2jxua e6idgb70"></p>, <h1 class="css-1j5ig2m e1h9rw200" id="link-1192a5aa" itemprop="headline"><span>Warren Offers Infectious-Disease Plan Amid China Outbreak</span></h1>, <p class="css-1fv7b6t e1jsehar1" itemprop="author" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">By<!-- --> <span class="css-1baulvz last-byline" itemprop="name">The Associated Press</span></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">DES MOINES, Iowa — Democratic presidential candidate Elizabeth Warren has announced a plan to prevent, contain and treat infectious diseases as a new viral illness spreads in China.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The Massachusetts senator on Tuesday unveiled a plan that includes fully funding the federal Centers for Disease Control and Prevention's pandemic prevention and response programs. The agency has faced stiff budget cuts under President Donald Trump, including to emergency funds and global health programs that were established following West Africa's Ebola epidemic in 2014. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“Like so much else, Trump’s approach to keeping us safe from disease outbreaks is a mess,” Warren wrote in an online post announcing the plan. “But when he’s gone, we can fix it.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Warren's proposal comes as the coronavirus has killed more than 100 people in China and the city at the center of the crisis, Wuhan, remains on lockdown. The U.S. has confirmed cases in Washington state, Illinois, Southern California and Arizona.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The timing of Warren's announcement was no accident — nor is the fact that she's the candidate drawing up the proposal. During more than a year of campaigning, Warren has embraced the reputation of having “a plan” for nearly everything. She remains bunched near the top of the polls with former Vice President Joe Biden, Vermont Sen. Bernie Sanders and former South Bend, Indiana, Mayor Pete Buttigeig, with the Iowa caucuses, which lead off primary voting, looming on Feb. 3. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Warren blamed the Trump administration for proposing “billions in cuts to the agencies responsible for fighting and preventing pandemics, a devastating blow that would put lives at risk." Not all of those reductions have been approved by Congress, though. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">She also promised to push the CDC to develop vaccines against infectious diseases, including a universal immunization against the flu. But it is the National Institutes of Health that has already made a priority of developing a better flu vaccine. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Warren said she can mitigate the spread of disease by fighting climate change and moving the U.S. to a universal, government-funded health system under the “Medicare for All” program. She also wants to increase NIH funding by $100 billion. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Although such a high price tag may make it difficult to survive the appropriations process, Warren plans to help with the funding by creating a “swear jar." That would be a pot of money requiring private companies to pay some of their profits from publicly funded research back to the NIH. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Warren further promises to work with Congress to replenish funding for the Department of Health and Human Services' Public Health Emergency Fund to better respond to outbreaks and to create a Global Health Security Corps that will “ensure that we can get the right expertise to the center of an outbreak before it becomes an epidemic.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“Diseases like coronavirus remind us why we need robust international institutions, strong investments in public health, and a government that is prepared to jump into action at a moment's notice,” Warren wrote. “When we prepare and effectively collaborate to address common threats that don’t stop at borders, the international community can stop these diseases in their tracks.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">___</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Catch up on the 2020 election campaign with AP experts on our weekly politics podcast, “Ground Game.”</p>, <p>Advertisement</p>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd" id="site-index-label">Site Index</h2>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-0">news</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-1">opinion</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-2">arts</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-3">living</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-4">more</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-subscribe-label">Subscribe</h3>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd">Site Information Navigation</h2>]
[<h1 class="css-1jrl1ex">Page No Longer Available</h1>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd" id="site-index-label">Site Index</h2>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-0">news</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-1">opinion</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-2">arts</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-3">living</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-4">more</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-subscribe-label">Subscribe</h3>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd">Site Information Navigation</h2>]
[<p>Advertisement</p>, <p>Supported by</p>, <p class="css-c2jxua e6idgb70"></p>, <h1 class="css-1j5ig2m e1h9rw200" id="link-579af25e" itemprop="headline"><span>Apple Sparks Wall Street Bounce Ahead of Results</span></h1>, <p class="css-1fv7b6t e1jsehar1" itemprop="author" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">By<!-- --> <span class="css-1baulvz last-byline" itemprop="name">Reuters</span></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">NEW YORK — U.S. stocks rebounded on Tuesday, as the S&amp;P 500 bounced back from its worst day in nearly four months, led by a climb in Apple and other names hit by exposure concerns to the coronavirus outbreak in China that sparked a recent sell-off.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Markets across the world stabilized as the head of the World Health Organization (WHO) said he was confident in China's ability to stem the virus outbreak, which has killed 106 people in the country, prompted businesses to close operations and curbed travel.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Still, the U.S. health and human services secretary said new steps were being considered to counter the virus, including travel restrictions to China.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">"Certainly the virus has not gone away, in fact it is only getting worse," said Ken Polcari, senior market strategist at SlateStone Wealth LLC in Jupiter, Florida. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">"But all the excitement now is that nobody thinks Apple is going to miss at all, on any line."</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Sectors that were hit hardest on Monday saw their fortunes reverse, with technology and financials among the best performers in the session. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Helping dampen concerns about a hit to the economy from the virus was data that showed U.S. consumer confidence surged to a five-month high in January.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">(Graphic: Consumer confidence image, https://graphics.reuters.com/USA-STOCKS/0100B59V39H/consconf.png) </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Apple Inc shares led each of the three major indexes higher, up 2.83% ahead of its fourth-quarter results expected after markets closed. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Investors will keep a close watch on Apple's earnings amid concerns of a disruption in iPhone production as the coronavirus spreads across major markets such as China.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Apple's gains helped lift the S&amp;P technology index 1.87% as the best performing sector on the day, while financial stocks gained 1.13% as a climb in Treasury yields helped big banks rebound.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 186.3 points, or 0.65%, to 28,722.1, the S&amp;P 500 gained 32.6 points, or 1.01%, to 3,276.23 and the Nasdaq Composite added 130.37 points, or 1.43%, to 9,269.68.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The Dow snapped a five-session losing streak, its longest drought without a gain since early August. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Expectations for fourth-quarter earnings have been slowly improving and are now expected to show a decline of 0.4%, according to Refinitiv data. Of the 104 companies that have reported so far, 68.3% have topped expectations, lagging the average rate of 74% from the past four quarters.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Results were mixed on Tuesday, with U.S. industrial giant 3M Co sliding 5.73% after it forecast 2020 profit below expectations as weak demand from China dents overall growth.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Pfizer Inc dropped 5.13% after the drugmaker reported a lower-than-expected quarterly profit and said it would no longer rely on share repurchases to help drive growth.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Shares in Xerox Holdings Corp jumped 4.94% after the company's profit beat analysts' estimates as it kept a tight lid on costs.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Advancing issues outnumbered declining ones on the NYSE by a 2.26-to-1 ratio; on Nasdaq, a 2.17-to-1 ratio favored advancers.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The S&amp;P 500 posted 27 new 52-week highs and four new lows; the Nasdaq Composite recorded 66 new highs and 44 new lows. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">About 6.75 billion shares changed hands in U.S. exchanges, compared with the 7.4 billion-share daily average over the last 20 sessions.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"> (Reporting by Chuck Mikolajczak; Editing by Nick Zieminski and Jonathan Oatis)</p>, <p>Advertisement</p>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd" id="site-index-label">Site Index</h2>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-0">news</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-1">opinion</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-2">arts</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-3">living</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-4">more</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-subscribe-label">Subscribe</h3>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd">Site Information Navigation</h2>]
[<h1 class="css-1jrl1ex">Page No Longer Available</h1>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd" id="site-index-label">Site Index</h2>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-0">news</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-1">opinion</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-2">arts</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-3">living</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-4">more</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-subscribe-label">Subscribe</h3>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd">Site Information Navigation</h2>]
[<p>Advertisement</p>, <p>Supported by</p>, <h1 class="css-1s4ffep e1h9rw200" id="link-1ab7be57" itemprop="headline"><span>Your Tuesday Briefing</span></h1>, <p class="css-1ifw933 e1wiw3jv0" id="article-summary">Coronavirus, Kobe Bryant, Auschwitz: Here’s what you need to know.</p>, <p class="css-1fv7b6t e1jsehar1" itemprop="author" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">By<!-- --> <a class="css-brehiz e1jsehar0" href="https://www.nytimes.com/by/mike-ives"><span class="css-1baulvz" itemprop="name">Mike Ives</span></a> and <span class="css-1baulvz last-byline" itemprop="name">Sofia Mitra-Thakur</span></p>, <p class="css-ma92ss evys1bk0">Good morning.</p>, <p class="css-ma92ss evys1bk0">We’re covering a key question at President Trump’s <strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">impeachment trial</strong>, rising alarm over the <strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">coronavirus outbreak</strong> and an expected decision on Huawei’s role in<strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10"> Britain’s 5G network</strong>.</p>, <h2 class="css-3ez4hu eoo0vm40" id="link-3cf115e8">Will Republicans call witnesses?</h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">As President Trump’s lawyers open the third day of their defense today, <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/27/us/politics/john-bolton-impeachment-witness.html" title="">an important question hangs over Washington</a>: Will the Republican-controlled Senate agree to hear testimony from witnesses?</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Some key Republicans seem to be moving closer to subpoenaing John Bolton, Mr. Trump’s ousted national security adviser, to testify. Their apparent new position comes after The Times revealed that Mr. Bolton wrote in an unpublished manuscript that the president had told him that he <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/26/us/politics/trump-bolton-book-ukraine.html" title="">wanted to continue freezing $391 million in aid to Ukraine</a> until officials there investigated Democrats.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Trump’s argument:</strong> The president’s lawyers maintain that the aid holdup was separate from the requests for investigations, and that he insisted on the investigations out of a concern for corruption in Ukraine.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">What’s next:</strong> Mr. Bolton has said he would testify at Mr. Trump’s impeachment trial if he were asked to do so. The Senate will vote on whether to call witnesses after Mr. Trump’s legal team wraps up its defense, very likely this week. <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/live/2020/impeachment-trial-live-01-27" title="">Here are the latest updates</a>.</p>, <h2 class="css-3ez4hu eoo0vm40" id="link-2add6056">Coronavirus spreads to Germany, as China death toll rises</h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Health authorities confirmed today that <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/27/world/asia/china-coronavirus-social-media.html" title="">at least 106 people had died so far from the dangerous coronavirus</a>, a day after Germany reported its first confirmed case. <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/28/world/asia/china-coronavirus.html" title="">Here’s the latest.</a></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The United States has chartered a flight to repatriate consular staff members and other American citizens today from Wuhan, the Chinese city where the virus originated. France is also planning to evacuate its citizens, who will be required to spend 14 days in quarantine once they’re home.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Related: </strong>The virus’s spread <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/27/business/coronavirus-china-economic-impact.html" title="">has spooked global markets</a>, as investors dump stocks and move into traditional safe havens like gold. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Inside China:</strong> <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/27/technology/china-coronavirus-censorship-social-media.html" title="">Anger has flooded China’s social media</a> over the government’s handling of the crisis, as the outbreak <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/27/world/asia/27china-coronavirus-health.html" title="">strains the country’s overburdened health system</a>. Some public health experts say China’s efforts to keep tens of millions of people in lockdown in and around Wuhan came too late.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Another angle:</strong> Many airlines are accommodating travelers who want to modify, delay or cancel China itineraries. <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/26/travel/Coronavirus-travel.html" title="">Here’s what to know</a>.</p>, <h2 class="css-3ez4hu eoo0vm40" id="link-53bc9fff">Asylum seekers head to Cyprus</h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The tiny island of Cyprus, population 850,000, <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/28/world/europe/cyprus-migrant-crisis.html" title="">now hosts the most refugees per capita in Europe</a> thanks to a loophole that has made it a magnet for asylum seekers trying to reach the European Union.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">More than 11,200 people arrived there last year — a fivefold increase since 2015, when the E.U. and Turkey struck a deal at the <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2015/11/01/world/europe/a-mass-migration-crisis-and-it-may-yet-get-worse.html" title="">height of the migration crisis</a> to close off other routes to the continent. The island, where the north is controlled by Turkey, and the ethnically Greek south by the Republic of Cyprus, was left out of that agreement by default.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">What’s happening: </strong>Some migrants travel overland to the north, which does not offer asylum or refugee status, wrongly believing that it is linked to mainland Europe or that it belongs to the Schengen zone of passport-free travel. Others travel to southern Cyprus from Lebanon, Syria or Turkey by air or boat.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">The background: </strong>Cyprus has been divided by a nominal barrier called the green line since the government was overthrown in a coup in 1974.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Quote of note:</strong> “I had no idea about the division of Cyprus,” said Clinton Yebga, a Cameroonian refugee. “I just thought, ‘I need to get to Europe, to be safe from harassment.’”</p>, <h2 class="css-3ez4hu eoo0vm40" id="link-455f0f8">Remembering Kobe Bryant</h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Fans and celebrities around the world are <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/26/sports/basketball/kobe-bryant-helicopter-crash.html" title="">grieving the death of Kobe Bryant</a>, 41, a basketball legend who towered over the sport for more than two decades. <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/27/sports/kobe-bryant-death.html" title="">Here’s the latest</a>.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Thousands have attended memorials for Bryant, his 13-year-old daughter, Gianna, and the seven other <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/27/us/who-died-helicopter-crash-kobe-altobelli-chester-zobayan-mauser.html" title="">people who were aboard a helicopter that crashed</a> on Sunday outside Los Angeles.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The National Basketball Association has postponed a game scheduled for tonight at the home arena of Bryant’s former team, the Los Angeles Lakers. And in Italy, where he lived as a child, the national basketball federation plans to hold a moment of silence during every game this week.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Assessing a tragedy: </strong>Sam Dolnick, a Times editor, <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/27/sports/kobe-bryant-fans.html" title="">writes that Bryant’s death</a> “was a devastating reminder that basketball is only a game, and the real world looms closer than you like.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">On the court: </strong>Bryant’s genius as an offensive player was that he <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/27/sports/basketball/kobe-retirement.html" title="">exhausted opponents before himself</a>, writes Michael Powell, our Sports of The Times columnist.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Complex legacy: </strong>A 2003 sexual assault allegation against Bryant changed how many people saw him, but he <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/26/sports/kobe-bryant-obituary.html?algo=top_conversion&amp;fellback=false&amp;imp_id=554567898&amp;imp_id=5368861&amp;action=click&amp;module=Most%20Popular&amp;pgtype=Homepage" title="">remained hugely popular</a>.</p>, <h3 class="css-1b8te77 e1gnsphs0" id="link-79476269">If you have 8 minutes, this is worth it</h3>, <h2 class="css-3ez4hu eoo0vm40" id="link-1da261eb">The hacker who targeted Isabel dos Santos</h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">For years, the Portuguese hacker behind the platform Football Leaks angered teams, agents and soccer regulators by releasing plundered internal documents and secret agreements.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Unbeknown to his critics, the hacker, Rui Pinto, above, was also preparing to <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/27/sports/soccer/leaks-dos-santos-rui-pinto.html" title="">leak documents related to Isabel dos Santos, Africa’s richest woman</a> and the daughter of Angola’s former president. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">She may now face charges of embezzlement. Mr. Pinto’s lawyers say it’s all thanks to their client, who was arrested in Budapest and extradited to Portugal last year.</p>, <h3 class="css-1b8te77 e1gnsphs0" id="link-554e6082">Here’s what else is happening</h3>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Libya: </strong>Fighting and arms shipments have resumed amid <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/27/world/africa/libya-cease-fire-collapses.html" title="">the collapse of a cease-fire in the country’s civil war</a>, just days after world leaders met in Germany to broker a truce.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Huawei: </strong>Prime Minister Boris Johnson of Britain is scheduled to meet senior ministers today to decide whether to ban or restrict equipment made by the Chinese telecom giant Huawei. He has <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2019/12/27/world/europe/huawei-EU-5G-Europe.html" title="">faced pressure from the United States</a> to ban Huawei outright, but is expected to grant the company a limited role in Britain’s 5G network.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Auschwitz:</strong> A ceremony on Monday commemorated the 75th anniversary of the liberation of Auschwitz, the Nazi death camp in German-occupied Poland. Before the allied forces could arrive, tens of thousands of weakened prisoners <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/27/world/europe/auschwitz-anniversary-death-march.html" title="">were forced to march</a> in the dead of winter, with an estimated 15,000 shot or dying of cold, hunger and illness.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Snapshot: </strong>Alessandro Michele, above center, the lead designer of Gucci. He is among the celebrities <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/27/world/europe/italy-lake-bolsena-castel-giorgio.html" title="">fighting a proposed geothermal plant in the Umbria region</a> of Italy on environmental grounds. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">In memoriam: </strong><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/27/style/michou-dead.html" title="">Michou</a>, 88, who ran France’s most celebrated drag cabaret and dressed habitually in blue, died in Paris on Sunday. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Influencers: </strong>More and more people are turning their personal lives into full-time careers on social media. What happens when <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/27/style/will-you-be-my-content.html" title="">their friends don’t want to be co-stars</a>?</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">What we’re reading: </strong><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.newyorker.com/magazine/2020/02/03/the-magical-thinking-of-the-goop-lab" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">This piece</a> on Gwyneth Paltrow’s new Netflix series, “The Goop Lab.” Our television critic James Poniewozik calls it a “great debut” for The New Yorker’s new TV critic, Doreen St. Félix. </p>, <h3 class="css-1b8te77 e1gnsphs0" id="link-7ded7ef4">Now, a break from the news</h3>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Cook: </strong>A<strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10"> </strong>quick <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://cooking.nytimes.com/recipes/1019925-italian-wedding-soup-with-turkey-meatballs" title="">Italian wedding soup with turkey meatballs</a> is a flavor-packed weeknight meal.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Go: </strong><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/27/arts/design/ceija-stojka-auschwitz-paintings.html" title="">An exhibition at the Museo Reina Sofía</a> in Madrid of paintings by the artist Ceija Stojka that depict her ordeal in the Holocaust.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Read: </strong><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/27/arts/music/grammys-best-worst.html" title="">Our roundup</a> of the best and worst moments from Sunday night’s Grammy Awards. (Aerosmith and Run-D.M.C. made a glorious mess.)</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Smarter Living: </strong>Because small luxuries are sometimes the most essential, we have a <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/27/realestate/shopping-for-bathmats.html" title="">guide to shopping for bathmats</a>.</p>, <h3 class="css-1b8te77 e1gnsphs0" id="link-15767e9b">And now for the Back Story on …</h3>, <h2 class="css-3ez4hu eoo0vm40" id="link-545a9ac7">Halting the Great Plague</h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">For some British readers, news of <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/23/world/asia/china-coronavirus.html" title="">travel restrictions intended to stop the spread of a deadly virus in central China</a> might have brought to mind a somewhat incongruous image: <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.visitpeakdistrict.com/explore/towns-and-villages/eyam-p680381" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">a village in the English Peak District</a>, where <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.visitpeakdistrict.com/whats-on/eyam-well-dressing-p751941" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">the wells are decorated with flowers each summer</a>.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">This village, <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.eyam-museum.org.uk/" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">Eyam</a>, became a symbol of self-sacrifice because of its role in <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nationalarchives.gov.uk/education/resources/great-plague/" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">England’s last major outbreak of bubonic plague, in 1665</a>.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">That autumn, plague-bearing fleas arrived in Eyam in a bale of cloth from London. As deaths began to mount, the rector of the village church, William Mompesson, <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-35064071" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">gathered the villagers and asked them to quarantine themselves</a> to stop the infection from spreading.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Further encouraged by the previous rector, Thomas Stanley, the villagers agreed, and stuck by their agreement, even as <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.eyam-museum.org.uk/assets/files/Eyam-Plague-victims-in-chronological-order.pdf" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">whole families died</a>. (Mr. Mompesson survived, apparently against his expectations, but his wife, Catherine, did not.)</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">When the outbreak ended the following November, 260 people in Eyam had died — by most accounts, that was more than half of the population.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">But the lives they saved, in villages and larger towns nearby, almost certainly numbered in the thousands.</p>, <p class="css-ma92ss evys1bk0">That’s it for this briefing. See you next time.</p>, <p class="css-ma92ss evys1bk0">— Mike and Sofia</p>, <p class="css-jwz2nf etfikam0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Thank you</strong><br/>To Mark Josephson and Eleanor Stanford for the break from the news. Peter Robins, an editor in our London newsroom who grew up about 40 miles from Eyam, wrote today’s Back Story. You can reach the team at <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="mailto:briefing+midnight@nytimes.com?subject=Briefing%20Feedback" title="">briefing@nytimes.com</a>.</p>, <p class="css-jwz2nf etfikam0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">P.S.</strong><br/>• We’re listening to “<a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/thedaily" title="">The Daily</a>.” Our latest episode is about whether American football is too dangerous for children.<br/>• Here’s today’s <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/crosswords/game/mini" title="">Mini Crossword puzzle</a>, and a clue: Perfectly timed, as a stage entrance (five letters). <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/crosswords" title="">You can find all our puzzles here</a>.<br/>• The R&amp;D team at The New York Times is working in collaboration with IBM Garage on the <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.newsprovenanceproject.com/" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">News Provenance Project</a>, an effort to use blockchain to make valid photo information “travel with” images posted to social media.</p>, <p>Advertisement</p>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd" id="site-index-label">Site Index</h2>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-0">news</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-1">opinion</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-2">arts</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-3">living</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-4">more</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-subscribe-label">Subscribe</h3>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd">Site Information Navigation</h2>]
[<p>Advertisement</p>, <p>Supported by</p>, <p class="css-c2jxua e6idgb70"></p>, <h1 class="css-1j5ig2m e1h9rw200" id="link-5b1f1d22" itemprop="headline"><span>Russia Ramps Up Controls, Shuts China Border Crossings Over Virus Fears</span></h1>, <p class="css-1fv7b6t e1jsehar1" itemprop="author" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">By<!-- --> <span class="css-1baulvz last-byline" itemprop="name">Reuters</span></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">MOSCOW — Three Russian regions in the Far East have closed their borders with China until Feb. 7 amid fears over the outbreak of coronavirus there, the TASS news agency cited the governor of Khabarovsk region as saying on Tuesday. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">In Moscow, authorities said they had put in place special safety measures at hotels and tourist sites as the death toll from the flu-like virus rose to 106 in China with more than 4,500 cases confirmed.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Russia has not had any confirmed cases of the new virus, but has direct daily flights to several Chinese cities and officials said last year they expected more than 2 million Chinese tourists to visit in 2019.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">"We have taken special control of hotels and other places where tourists gather en masse," Mayor Sergei Sobyanin wrote on his website.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">"When alarming signs appear, emergency medical teams will be sent to carry out a thorough examination." </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The border closures affect crossings in the Far East in the Jewish Autonomous Oblast, Khabarovsk and Amur regions, TASS said. Russia and China share a 4,300 km (2,670 mile) border. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Nine land border crossings to China are currently not functioning, according to data on the website of a regional branch of the state border management authority.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">And Russian tour operators had stopped selling package holidays to China, Dmitry Gorin, vice president of the Association of Russian Tour Operators, said on Monday. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"> (Reporting by Maria Kiselyova; additional reporting by Gleb Stolyarov; writing by Tom Balmforth)</p>, <p>Advertisement</p>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd" id="site-index-label">Site Index</h2>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-0">news</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-1">opinion</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-2">arts</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-3">living</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-4">more</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-subscribe-label">Subscribe</h3>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd">Site Information Navigation</h2>]
[<p>Advertisement</p>, <p>Supported by</p>, <p class="css-c2jxua e6idgb70"></p>, <h1 class="css-1j5ig2m e1h9rw200" id="link-104a549d" itemprop="headline"><span>Factbox: Countries Evacuating Nationals From China Virus Areas</span></h1>, <p class="css-1fv7b6t e1jsehar1" itemprop="author" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">By<!-- --> <span class="css-1baulvz last-byline" itemprop="name">Reuters</span></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">(Reuters) - Countries around the world are planning to evacuate diplomatic staff and private citizens from Chinese areas hit by the new coronavirus, which is spreading quickly.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Wuhan, a city of 11 million in the province of Hubei and the epicentre of the outbreak is in virtual lockdown and much of Hubei, home to nearly 60 million people, is under some kind of travel curb.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Following are some countries' evacuation plans, and how they are planning to manage the health risk from those who are returning. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">** France's first plane to repatriate nationals from Wuhan will leave Paris on Wednesday and return the next day. The flight will carry people with no symptoms, junior transport minister Jean-Baptiste Djebarri told television channel CNews. "These people will be put under quarantine. And then there will be a second flight, at a yet undefined date, with people showing symptoms ... who will be cared for in Paris," he said.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">** South Korea plans to send charter flights this week to evacuate its citizens from Wuhan, Prime Minister Chung Sye-kyun said on Tuesday. The planes will arrive in the city as early as Thursday, he told a ministerial meeting aimed at discussing efforts to prevent the spread of the new coronavirus.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">** Japan will send a charter flight to Wuhan on Tuesday night. Foreign Minister Toshimitsu Motegi said the flight can carry around 200 passengers, but added about 650 citizens hope to return to Japan. Motegi said Tokyo is making arrangements for extra flights to Wuhan as early as Wednesday. Those with symptoms such as fever will be sent to hospital on landing at Tokyo's Haneda airport, while those with no signs of virus can go home and then to work or school, but will be advised to avoid crowds and take their temperatures twice a day.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">** Kazakhstan has asked Beijing to allow 98 Kazakh students to leave the city of Wuhan, deputy foreign minister Shukhrat Nuryshev said.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">** Germany will evacuate 90 citizens living in China's Wuhan region.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">** Morocco will evacuate 100 citizens, mostly students, from the Wuhan area. Spain's government is working with China and the European Union to repatriate Spanish nationals from the Wuhan area, Foreign Minister Arancha Gonzalez Laya said.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">** The U.S. State Department said it will evacuate personnel from its Wuhan consulate to the United States and offer a limited number of seats to private U.S. citizens on a flight. Some private citizens will be able to board the "single flight" leaving Wuhan on Jan. 28 for San Francisco, it said.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">** Britain is talking to international partners to find solutions to help British and other foreign nationals leave Wuhan, a spokesman for Prime Minister Boris Johnson said. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">** Canada has about 167 nationals in the Wuhan area, Foreign Minister Francois-Philippe Champagne said on Monday, and eight people have sought consular assistance, which is being provided. While the minister did not rule out possible evacuations, he did not indicate there were any planned at the moment, adding that each consular request would be evaluated on a "case by case basis".</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">** Russia has been in talks with China about evacuating its nationals from Wuhan and Hubei province, Russia's embassy in China said.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">** The Dutch government is assessing ways to evacuate 20 Dutch citizens from Wuhan, press agency ANP reported.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">** Authorities in Myanmar said they had cancelled a planned evacuation of 60 students who were studying in Wuhan. Kyaw Yin Myint, a spokesman for the Mandalay municipal government, told Reuters that a "final decision" had been made to send them back after 14 days, once the virus' incubation period had passed.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">(This story refiles to delete reference to students being from Mandalay in last paragraph)</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"> (Reporting by Thu Thu Aung in Yangon, Geert De Clercq in Paris, Kaori Kaneko, Maki Shiraki and Norihiko Shirouzu in Tokyo, Reporting by William James and Elizabeth Piper in London, Inti Landauro and Emma Pinedo in Madrid; Compiled by Toby Chopra, Lisa Shumaker and Kenneth Maxwell)</p>, <p>Advertisement</p>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd" id="site-index-label">Site Index</h2>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-0">news</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-1">opinion</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-2">arts</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-3">living</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-4">more</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-subscribe-label">Subscribe</h3>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd">Site Information Navigation</h2>]

Despite Thomas Cook Collapse Hit</span></h1>, <p class="css-1fv7b6t e1jsehar1" itemprop="author" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">By<!-- --> <span class="css-1baulvz last-byline" itemprop="name">Reuters</span></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">(Reuters) - Saga Plc said on Tuesday it was on track to meet its annual profit outlook even as it flagged a one-off charge of 4 million pounds ($5.26 million) related to the collapse of Thomas Cook last year.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The over-50s tourism and insurance firm, which earlier this year launched an overhaul of its mainstay insurance unit to battle margin pressures, said the insurance business was in a much more stable position than a year ago. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">"Although Saga continues to face challenging markets in insurance and travel, we have a clear focus on improving performance and cost efficiencies within the group," newly appointed Chief Executive Officer Euan Sutherland said.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Shares of the company were 5.3% higher at 43.9 pence in early trade.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">During its half-year results, Saga said it expects annual underlying pretax profit between 105 million pounds and 120 million pounds.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">In the backdrop of growing worries over the spread of the new coronavirus in China, which has raised concerns about travel demand, a Saga spokesperson said on Monday the company did not have any tours to China until later in the year.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The company, which owns Saga Holidays, Saga Cruises, Titan and Destinology, expects annual revenue for Saga's tour operations to be down 5%, but added that it was seeing a "much more resilient picture" in its escorted tours.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Saga's branded home and motor policies are expected to be about 3% lower for the year ended Jan. 31, as the insurance market remained competitive, however, customer retention of 75% was better than last year.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"> (Reporting by Yadarisa Shabong in Bengaluru, additional reporting by Noor Zainab Hussain [<p>Advertisement</p>, <p>Supported by</p>, <p class="css-c2jxua e6idgb70"></p>, <h1 class="css-1j5ig2m e1h9rw200" id="link-12314b29" itemprop="headline"><span>Taiwan Advises Against All China Travel, Releases Mask Stocks</span></h1>, <p class="css-1fv7b6t e1jsehar1" itemprop="author" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">By<!-- --> <span class="css-1baulvz last-byline" itemprop="name">Reuters</span></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">TAIPEI — Taiwan raised its travel warning for China on Tuesday saying that people should avoid going unless absolutely necessary amid an outbreak of the new coronavirus there, and said it had begun to release stocks of face masks but would limit purchases.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Taiwan and China have close economic and cultural ties, and the island has reported seven confirmed cases of the virus so far. All of the more than 100 deaths so far have been in China, centered on Wuhan, the capital of Hubei province.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Taiwan's Central Epidemic Command Centre said it had raised its previous advice and would extend to the rest of China an existing warning not to go to Hubei province unless totally necessary, though Hong Kong and Macau are excluded.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Taiwan also has rolled out strict curbs on Chinese visitors, restricting a vast majority of them.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Last week Taiwan's government announced a one-month ban on the export of specialist masks designed to be used for medical personnel, saying it had to look after the needs of its own people first.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Some pharmacies in Taiwan have reported shortages of face masks since the island reported its first case a week ago, and the government says it is working to ensure supplies. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">In a separate notice on Tuesday, the government said it would until Thursday release more stock of masks, but limit each person to buying a maximum of three.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">However, it also issued a reminder that most healthy people do not need to wear masks all the time.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Taiwan President Tsai Ing-wen, visiting people on Tuesday to extend Lunar New Year wishes, said the government was fully prepared to deal with the virus and people should not panic.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">"Our anti-epidemic work does not take holidays, and is taking place 24 hours a day," the presidential office quoted her as saying.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"> (Reporting by Ben Blanchard, Editing by William Maclean)</p>, <p>Advertisement</p>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd" id="site-index-label">Site Index</h2>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-0">news</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl"
