[<p>Advertisement</p>, <p>Supported by</p>, <p class="css-c2jxua e6idgb70"></p>, <h1 class="css-1j5ig2m e1h9rw200" id="link-3fe8935d" itemprop="headline"><span>North Korea Imposes Month-Long Quarantine on Foreigners Arriving From China Over Virus Fears</span></h1>, <p class="css-1fv7b6t e1jsehar1" itemprop="author" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">By<!-- --> <span class="css-1baulvz last-byline" itemprop="name">Reuters</span></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">SEOUL — North Korea will impose a one-month quarantine on all foreigners arriving from China in a bid to prevent the spread of a new coronavirus, the Russian Embassy in Pyongyang said on Tuesday.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The North Korea Foreign Ministry's protocol department provided the notice in a message to the embassy on Tuesday, the Russian mission said in a post on its Facebook page.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">North Korea has not publicly reported any cases of the new strain of virus, which has killed at least 106 people in China and infected more than 4,500 as of Tuesday.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Although no fatalities have been reported outside China, the growing outbreak has sparked international alarm because there are still many important unknowns surrounding the virus. It can cause pneumonia, which has been deadly in some cases, but it is still unclear how dangerous the virus is.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Tuesday's notice identified several hotels in North Korea as potential quarantine locations, depending on where the foreigners enter, the Russian embassy said.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The protocol department said the measures were to protect the staff of international organisations and diplomatic missions in North Korea, as well as prevent an outbreak, according to the embassy.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">North Korea is taking "high-intensity" measures to prevent the spread of the virus, including distributing hygiene manuals to medical clinics, increasing production of anti-viral medications, and stepping up quarantine efforts in border regions and at airports and sea ports, the ruling party's newspaper Rodong Sinmun reported on Tuesday.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The country is also sending health ministry officials to vulnerable regions, and identifying pneumonia patients in local communities to test and isolate them if necessary, the newspaper said.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Last week Pyongyang informed tour companies that it would be indefinitely banning foreign tourists, which are a major source of hard currency for the sanctions-strapped regime. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"> (Reporting by Josh Smith. Additional reporting by Hyonhee Shin and Sangmi Cha; Editing by Kim Coghill)</p>, <p>Advertisement</p>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd" id="site-index-label">Site Index</h2>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-0">news</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-1">opinion</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-2">arts</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-3">living</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-4">more</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-subscribe-label">Subscribe</h3>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd">Site Information Navigation</h2>]
[<p>Advertisement</p>, <p>Supported by</p>, <p class="css-c2jxua e6idgb70"></p>, <h1 class="css-1j5ig2m e1h9rw200" id="link-63f49482" itemprop="headline"><span>Finland's Kone Talks Up Potential of Thyssenkrupp Combination</span></h1>, <p class="css-1fv7b6t e1jsehar1" itemprop="author" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">By<!-- --> <span class="css-1baulvz last-byline" itemprop="name">Reuters</span></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">HELSINKI — Finland's Kone, one of the contenders to buy the elevator business of its German rival Thyssenkrupp, is very interested in the unit and sees significant "scale advantages," its CEO said on Tuesday.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Chief Executive Henrik Ehrnrooth was speaking after the company revealed quarterly profit that beat expectations, but a weaker sales outlook for 2020 pushed its share price briefly to an eight-week low.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Kone, which is working with private equity firm CVC [CVC.UL] was due to make a bid on Jan. 27 for Thyssenkrupp's elevator business, valued at around 15 billion euros ($16.64 billion).</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Ehrntooth declined to say whether Kone had bid, but said he believed Kone would be "a good owner" and Kone would not be interested in just a minority stake.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">"The joined companies would have very significant scale advantages," he said. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Kone forecast 2020 sales growth of 0–6% at comparable exchange rates, down from 10% growth the firm reached in 2019.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Analysts surveyed by Kone had forecast average sales growth of 5% in 2020 and estimates had ranged from 3% to 7.6% growth.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Ehrnrooth said there were fewer orders for this year compared with 2019 and the outbreak in China of the newly-identified coronavirus added uncertainty.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Ehrnrooth said Kone's two factories in China would remain closed for at least an additional week because of the virus.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">"This will affect our first quarter and we don't know when our clients' construction sites will be reopened," he said. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Kone reported a 15% rise in fourth-quarter adjusted operating profit to 367.5 million euros (£311 million), above the 363.3 million expected by 21 analysts in a poll provided by the company. The company's board proposed a dividend of 1.70 euros per class B share for 2019. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Shares in Kone dropped almost 4% on the results report but later recovered to close 0.2% lower at 58.02 euros. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"> (Reporting by Anne Kauranen and Tarmo Virki; Editing by Barbara Lewis)</p>, <p>Advertisement</p>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd" id="site-index-label">Site Index</h2>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-0">news</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-1">opinion</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-2">arts</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-3">living</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-4">more</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-subscribe-label">Subscribe</h3>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd">Site Information Navigation</h2>]
[<p>Advertisement</p>, <p>Supported by</p>, <p class="css-c2jxua e6idgb70"></p>, <h1 class="css-1j5ig2m e1h9rw200" id="link-c2afa73" itemprop="headline"><span>Oil Gains Amid Assessment of China Virus Impact, Possible OPEC Supply Cuts</span></h1>, <p class="css-1fv7b6t e1jsehar1" itemprop="author" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">By<!-- --> <span class="css-1baulvz last-byline" itemprop="name">Reuters</span></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">TOKYO — Oil prices rose for a second day on Wednesday, standing on firmer ground after a five-day rout on talk that OPEC could extend oil cuts if a new coronavirus hurts demand, while data showing a decline in U.S. stockpiles also helped steady prices.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Brent crude &lt;LCOc1&gt; rose 85 cents, or 1.43%, to $60.36 a barrel by 0418 GMT. U.S. crude was up 75 cents, or 1.4%, at $54.23 a barrel. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Financial markets that have been hit by the spread of the new virus out of China and its rising death toll are taking stock of the economic fallout, helped by comments from the head of the World Health Organization supporting Beijing's efforts to beat the outbreak. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">"It's a correction of a correction," Michael McCarthy, chief market strategist at CMC Markets in Sydney, said of the bounce-back on Wednesday, adding that "at the moment it's all about crowd behavior rather than fundamentals." </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">OPEC wants to extend oil production cuts until at least June from March, and may deepen the reductions should demand for oil in China be significantly reduced by the spread of the virus, OPEC sources said.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries (OPEC) and allies including Russia, have been trying to stabilize prices amid questions over the global demand outlook and rising supplies, particularly out of the United States. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">"A further extension is a strong possibility and a deeper cut is a possibility," one OPEC source told Reuters. Any fallout of the China virus on oil demand is likely to be clearer over the coming week, the source said. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">OPEC and its allies that form a grouping known as OPEC+ will next be meeting in Vienna in March to decide on any further action on its output reduction agreement. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">In the United States, crude oil inventories fell by 4.3 million barrels last week, data from industry group the American Petroleum Institute showed on Tuesday, compared with analysts' expectations of a gain of 482,000 barrels.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Gasoline stocks were up by 3.3 million barrels, compared with forecasts in a Reuters poll of a 1.3 million-barrel gain.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Distillate fuel inventories, which include diesel and heating oil, fell by 141,000 barrels, against expectations of a 1 million barrel drop. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Official figures on oil and products are due out from the Energy Information Administration later on Wednesday.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"> (Reporting by Aaron Sheldrick; Editing by Richard Pullin and Tom Hogue)</p>, <p>Advertisement</p>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd" id="site-index-label">Site Index</h2>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-0">news</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-1">opinion</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-2">arts</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-3">living</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-4">more</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-subscribe-label">Subscribe</h3>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd">Site Information Navigation</h2>]
[<p>Advertisement</p>, <p>Supported by</p>, <p class="css-c2jxua e6idgb70"></p>, <h1 class="css-1j5ig2m e1h9rw200" id="link-14899caf" itemprop="headline"><span>China Vows to Beat 'Devil' Virus as Countries Rush to Evacuate Citizens</span></h1>, <p class="css-1fv7b6t e1jsehar1" itemprop="author" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">By<!-- --> <span class="css-1baulvz last-byline" itemprop="name">Reuters</span></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">BEIJING — President Xi Jinping said on Tuesday that China was sure of defeating a "devil" coronavirus that has killed 106 people, but international alarm was rising as the outbreak spread across the world.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The United States said it was expanding screening of arrivals from China from five to 20 airports and would consider imposing further travel curbs.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">"All options for dealing with infectious disease spread have to be on the table, including travel restrictions," said U.S. Health Secretary Alex Azar.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">From France to Japan, governments were organising evacuations, while Hong Kong - scene of anti-China unrest for months - planned to suspend rail and ferry links with the mainland.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Among countries pulling nationals out of Wuhan, the central Chinese city of 11 million where the outbreak started, the U.S. Embassy in Beijing said a chartered plane would pick up its consular staff on Wednesday. The European Commission said it would help fund two aircraft to fly EU citizens home, with 250 French nationals leaving on the first flight.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">World Health Organization chief Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus and Xi met in Beijing to discuss how to protect Chinese and foreigners in areas affected by the virus and possible evacuation alternatives, a WHO spokesman said.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">"The virus is a devil and we cannot let the devil hide," state television quoted Xi as saying.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">"China will strengthen international cooperation and welcomes the WHO participation in virus prevention ... China is confident of winning the battle against the virus." </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The UN agency said later that China had agreed that the WHO can send a team of international experts "as soon as possible" to increase understanding of the virus and guide the global response.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">GRAPHIC: Tracking the outbreak https://graphics.reuters.com/CHINA-HEALTH-MAP/0100B59S39E/index.html </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">PERSON-TO-PERSON SPREAD</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Investors are fretting about the impact of the crisis on the world's second-biggest economy, though stock markets rebounded on Tuesday following a sharp sell-off the previous day.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">United Airlines said it was suspending some flights between the United States and China for a week from Feb. 1 due to a "significant decline in demand", while Facebook Inc and other global companies restricted employee travel to the country.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The flu-like virus has spread overseas, but none of the 106 deaths has been outside China and all but six were in Wuhan, where the virus emerged last month, probably from illegally traded wildlife.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">However, cases in Germany, Vietnam, Taiwan and Japan where the virus has spread person-to-person - as opposed to a visitor from China arriving - have heightened concern. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">"The reported human-to-human transmission in Germany and Japan is unsurprising to see," said Michael Head, senior research fellow in global health at Britain's University of Southampton.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">"We will continue to see further similar cases outside of China, but the indications are at this stage that onwards transmission will be limited, so there will likely not be too many cases for example across Europe, and on a much lesser scale than we are seeing in China." </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Chinese-ruled Hong Kong said high-speed rail services to the mainland would be suspended from midnight on Thursday, while the number of flights would be halved. Chinese authorities later said they would stop issuing travel permits for mainland tourists to visit Hong Kong and neighbouring Macau.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Britain advised against all but essential travel to mainland China, excluding Hong Kong and Macau.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Thailand confirmed six more infections among visitors from China, taking its tally to 14, the highest outside China. France had a fourth confirmed case, an elderly Chinese tourist who was said to be in a serious condition.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Wuhan is under virtual quarantine, with a lockdown on transport and bans on gatherings. Tens of millions in Hubei province, of which Wuhan is the capital, live under some form of travel curb.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">NO 'INTERNATIONAL EMERGENCY', YET</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The number of confirmed cases in China surged to 4,515 as of Monday from 2,835 the previous day, the government said.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Communist Party-ruled China has been eager to show it is transparent over this outbreak, after initially covering up the extent of the 2002-03 outbreak of Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome (SARS) that killed about 800 people globally. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Known as "2019-nCoV", the newly identified coronavirus can cause pneumonia and, like other respiratory infections, it spreads between people in droplets from coughs and sneezes. It is too early to know what its death rate will be, since there are likely to be many cases of milder disease going undetected. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">It has an incubation of between one and 14 days.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">A WHO panel of 16 independent experts twice last week declined to declare an international emergency.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Confirmation of any sustained human-to-human spread of the virus outside of China, as well as any documented deaths, would bolster the case for reconsidering.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Tedros can reconvene the panel on very short notice as needed, the WHO said. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"> (Reporting by Winni Zhou, Sun Yilei, Cheng Leng, David Stanway and Josh Horwitz in Shanghai; Cate Cadell, Gabriel Crossley, Tony Munroe, Muyu Xu and Yawen Chen in Beijing; Additional reporting by Michelle Nichols at the United Nations, Hideyuki Sano in Tokyo, Stephanie Nebehay in Geneva, Kate Kelland in London, Ben Blanchard in Taipei, Waruna Karunatilake in Colombo, Matthias Blamont in Paris; Writing by Robert Birsel, Nick Macfie, Andrew Cawthorne and Alex Richardson; Editing by Janet Lawrence and Giles; Elgood)</p>, <p>Advertisement</p>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd" id="site-index-label">Site Index</h2>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-0">news</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-1">opinion</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-2">arts</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-3">living</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-4">more</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-subscribe-label">Subscribe</h3>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd">Site Information Navigation</h2>]
[<p>Advertisement</p>, <p>Supported by</p>, <p class="css-c2jxua e6idgb70"></p>, <h1 class="css-1j5ig2m e1h9rw200" id="link-6e69055c" itemprop="headline"><span>Japan Warns About Risks to Economy From China Virus Outbreak</span></h1>, <p class="css-1fv7b6t e1jsehar1" itemprop="author" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">By<!-- --> <span class="css-1baulvz last-byline" itemprop="name">Reuters</span></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">TOKYO — Japanese Economy Minister Yasutoshi Nishimura on Tuesday warned that corporate profits and factory production might take a hit from the coronavirus outbreak in China that has rattled global markets and chilled confidence.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Asian stocks extended a global selloff as the outbreak in China, which has killed 106 people and spread to many countries, fuelled concern over the damage to the world's second largest economy - an engine of global growth.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">"There are concerns over the impact to the global economy from the spread of infection in China, transportation disruptions, cancellation of group tours from China and an extension in the Lunar Holiday," Nishimura told a news conference after a regular cabinet meeting.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">"If the situation takes longer to subside, we're concerned it could hurt Japanese exports, output and corporate profits via the impact on Chinese consumption and production," he said.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">China is Japan's second largest export destination and a huge market for its retailers. The Chinese make up 30% of all tourists visiting Japan and spent nearly 40% of the total sum foreign tourists used last year, an industry survey showed.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The outbreak could hit Japanese department stores, retailers and hotels, which count on a boost to sales from an inflow of Chinese tourists visiting during the Lunar Holiday.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Automaker Honda Motor, which has three plants in Wuhan, the capital of Hubei province and the epicentre of the outbreak, plans to evacuate some staff. Aeon will close its shopping malls in the city until Thursday.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Economists at SMBC Nikko Securities estimate that if a ban China has imposed on overseas group tours lasts another six months, it could hurt Japan's economic growth by 0.05%.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Some expect the potential damage could be much worse.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Hideo Kumano, chief economist at Dai-ichi Life Research Institute, said the decline in tourists from China could hurt Japan's GDP growth by up to 0.2%.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">"The biggest worry is the risk the negative impact from the outbreak persists and hits (the economy) during the Tokyo Olympic Games," when a huge number of Chinese tourists are expected to visit Japan, he said.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">"If the number of visitors decrease rather than increase, the hit to Japan's consumer industry will be quite large."</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Japan will host the 2020 Olymics in July and August. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"> (Reporting by Yoshifumi Takemoto and Kaori Kaneko, writing by Leika Kihara; Editing by Shri Navaratnam)</p>, <p>Advertisement</p>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd" id="site-index-label">Site Index</h2>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-0">news</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-1">opinion</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-2">arts</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-3">living</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-4">more</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-subscribe-label">Subscribe</h3>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd">Site Information Navigation</h2>]
[<p>Advertisement</p>, <p>Supported by</p>, <p class="css-c2jxua e6idgb70"></p>, <h1 class="css-1j5ig2m e1h9rw200" id="link-31b75cc9" itemprop="headline"><span>Germany Confirms 1st Cases of New Virus From China</span></h1>, <p class="css-1fv7b6t e1jsehar1" itemprop="author" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">By<!-- --> <span class="css-1baulvz last-byline" itemprop="name">The Associated Press</span></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">BERLIN — A man confirmed as Germany's first case of the new virus that emerged in central China is believed to have been infected by a Chinese colleague who visited his workplace, authorities said. Another three cases were confirmed later Tuesday, all connected to the first.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The 33-year-old man from the Starnberg area south of Munich was in isolation at a Munich hospital as a precaution, officials in Bavaria said. However, they stressed that his condition is good.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The man took part last Tuesday in a training session at his workplace that also included an employee of the same company visiting from China, said Andreas Zapf, the head of Bavaria's office for health and food safety.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The woman, who hadn't previously shown any symptoms, flew home on Thursday and went to a doctor after feeling ill on the flight, Zapf said. She then tested positive for the new virus. The woman lives in Shanghai, but had been visited a few days earlier by her parents, who come from the worst-affected Wuhan area.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">On Monday, the German company was informed of the positive test, and it notified authorities and employees. An employee who had been at the training session came forward and said he had experienced bronchitis-like symptoms over the weekend, though they had receded and he came to work on Monday.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Authorities decided when they received positive test results Monday evening to admit him to a hospital and put him in isolation for monitoring.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Auto parts supplier Webasto confirmed that it was the company involved and that the man works at its headquarters in Stockdorf, south of Munich. It canceled all travel to and from China for the next two weeks and said employees at Stockdorf are free to work from home this week.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Later Tuesday, Bavaria's state health ministry said another three cases of the virus had been confirmed and all were employees of the same company, news agency dpa reported. Authorities decided to admit those patients to the same Munich hospital, where they were in isolation.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Authorities didn't immediately give further details of the three new cases.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Germany is the second European country to report confirmed cases of the virus. Authorities in France confirmed three cases in recent days — all Chinese citizens who recently traveled there.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The new type of coronavirus has infected thousands of people in China. Nearly all of the cases outside China are among people who recently arrived from there.</p>, <p>Advertisement</p>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd" id="site-index-label">Site Index</h2>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-0">news</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-1">opinion</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-2">arts</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-3">living</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-4">more</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-subscribe-label">Subscribe</h3>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd">Site Information Navigation</h2>]
[<p>Advertisement</p>, <p>Supported by</p>, <p class="css-c2jxua e6idgb70"></p>, <h1 class="css-1j5ig2m e1h9rw200" id="link-42c29fa1" itemprop="headline"><span>U.S. Business Investment Weak; Consumer Confidence at Five-Month High</span></h1>, <p class="css-1fv7b6t e1jsehar1" itemprop="author" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">By<!-- --> <span class="css-1baulvz last-byline" itemprop="name">Reuters</span></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">WASHINGTON — New orders for key U.S.-made capital goods dropped by the most in eight months in December and shipments were weak, suggesting business investment contracted further in the fourth quarter and remained a drag on economic growth.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">For now, however, the longest economic expansion on record looks set to continue, with other data on Tuesday showing consumer confidence surged to a five-month high in January amid optimism over the labor market. That suggests consumer spending could stay fairly strong in the near term and blunt some of the hit on the economy from weak business investment.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Business spending has remained weak even as the Federal Reserve cut interest rate cuts three times last year. Officials from the U.S. central bank started a two-day policy meeting on Tuesday. They are expected to reiterate the Fed's desire to keep rates unchanged at least through this year. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Weak business investment and the resulting slump in manufacturing have been on the radar of Fed officials who have blamed trade tensions, especially the White House's 18-month trade war with China, and an uncertain global economic growth outlook for the malaise.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Though tensions have eased with the signing this month of a "Phase 1" trade deal between Washington and Beijing, Boeing continues to loom over manufacturing. Boeing this month suspended production of its troubled 737 MAX jetliner, which was grounded last March following two fatal crashes.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">"Manufacturing is clearly losing momentum as many of the most extreme tariffs on supply-chain inputs factories need to produce their final goods remain in place," said Chris Rupkeychief economist at MUFG in New York. "When it comes to forecasting the economy in 2020, it's the consumer stupid."</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The Commerce Department said orders for non-defense capital goods excluding aircraft, a closely watched proxy for business spending plans, fell 0.9% last month as demand for machinery, primary metals and electrical equipment, appliances and components declined. That was the largest decrease since April.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Data for November was revised lower to show these so-called core capital goods orders edging up 0.1% instead of gaining 0.2% as previously reported. Economists polled by Reuters had forecast core capital goods would be unchanged in December.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Core capital goods orders rose 0.8% in 2019. Shipments of core capital goods decreased 0.4% last month. Core capital goods shipments are used to calculate equipment spending in the government's gross domestic product measurement. They declined by an unrevised 0.3% in November.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Business investment has contracted for two straight quarters and was likely stuck in the red in the fourth quarter. The latest data also suggest a recovery is unlikely soon.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The Atlanta Fed is forecasting GDP to rise at a 1.9% annualized rate in the fourth quarter. The economy grew at a 2.1% rate in the July-September period. The government will publish its snapshot of fourth-quarter GDP on Thursday.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">In a separate report on Tuesday, the Conference Board said its consumer confidence index increased 3.4 points to a reading of 131.6 in January, the highest reading since August. Economists expected a temporary drop in consumer confidence in February because of the deadly coronavirus, which has killed more than 100 people in China, with cases reported in some countries including the United States, France and Japan.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The survey's so-called labor market differential, derived from data on respondents' views on whether jobs are plentiful or hard to get, increased to 37.4 this month from 33.5 in December.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">That measure closely correlates to the unemployment rate in the Labor Department's employment report. Though the labor market remains strong, there are signs that momentum is slowing. Job growth cooled in December and vacancies recorded their biggest drop in more than four years in November.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">"The good news is that a drop in confidence is unlikely by itself to cause a significant drop in consumer spending," said Ryan Sweet, a senior economist at Moody's Analytics in West Chester, Pennsylvania. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The dollar firmed against a basket of currencies as concerns about the economic fallout from the coronavirus outbreak boosted demand for safe-haven currencies. Stocks on Wall Street were trading higher, while U.S. Treasury prices fell.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">MANUFACTURING SLUMP</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The U.S.-China trade war has hurt business confidence, undercutting capital expenditure and pushing manufacturing, which accounts for 11% of the economy, into recession. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Boeing's biggest assembly-line halt in more than 20 years is expected to wreak havoc with the supply chain. The plane maker's largest supplier, Spirit AeroSystems Holdings, announced early this month that it planned to lay off more than 20% of the workforce at its Wichita, Kansas base. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Economists estimate the production suspension could slice at least half a percentage point from first-quarter GDP growth. The hit to GDP growth would come from a smaller inventory build. Though airlines have continued to submit orders there have been no deliveries, leading to a rise in inventories at factories. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">In December, overall orders for durable goods, items ranging from toasters to aircraft that are meant to last three years or more, rebounded 2.4% after tumbling 3.1% in the prior month.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">They were boosted by a 7.6% surge in orders for transportation equipment, the largest increase since August 2018, which followed an 8.3% drop in November. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Orders for defense aircraft and parts soared 168.3% last month, offsetting a 74.7% plunge in demand for civilian aircraft. Boeing reported on its website that it had received only three commercial aircraft orders in December, down from 63 in November. December is normally a strong month for aircraft orders. Motor vehicles and parts orders fell 0.9% in December.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">"Business spending is set to remain weak in the coming quarters," said Sarah House, a senior economist at Wells Fargo Securities in Charlotte, North Carolina.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"> (Reporting by Lucia Mutikani; Editing by Paul Simao)</p>, <p>Advertisement</p>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd" id="site-index-label">Site Index</h2>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-0">news</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-1">opinion</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-2">arts</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-3">living</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-4">more</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-subscribe-label">Subscribe</h3>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd">Site Information Navigation</h2>]
[<p>Advertisement</p>, <p>Supported by</p>, <p class="css-c2jxua e6idgb70"></p>, <h1 class="css-1j5ig2m e1h9rw200" id="link-c47e55d" itemprop="headline"><span>European Shares Recover From Viral Outbreak Fuelled Sell-Off</span></h1>, <p class="css-1fv7b6t e1jsehar1" itemprop="author" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">By<!-- --> <span class="css-1baulvz last-byline" itemprop="name">Reuters</span></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">(Reuters) - Banks and luxury goods led a recovery in European shares on Tuesday after heightened concerns about the about the potential impact on businesses from the coronavirus outbreak in China saw the main index post its worst day in about four months. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Upbeat earnings pushed lender Swedbank to the top of the pan-region STOXX 600 index, while Virgin Money UK rallied on reporting higher loan book growth.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Marking its best day in almost a month was Italy's lender-heavy index, jumping 2.6% to lead regional peers as its banks index rallied 2.5%. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Luxury goods makers LVMH Burberry Group Plc, Kering and Moncler SpA, which derive a chunk of their demand from China, rose after sliding more than 3% on Monday. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Bolstered also by a recovery on Wall Street, the STOXX 600 ended up 0.8%. Along with most other major country indices, STOXX 600 had lost more than 2% on Monday which had wiped out around 200 billion euros of market capitalisation. [.N]</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Even as the death toll from the outbreak rose to 106, President Xi Jinping said the country was sure of defeating a "devil" virus. In Europe, Germany confirmed its first case of the virus after a 33-year-old man contracted it from a colleague visiting his workplace from Shanghai.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">"Yesterday was just panic selling and then today there is this realization that things are getting worse but they don't seem to be getting exponentially worse," said David Madden, a market analyst at CMC Markets UK in London.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">But he noted that stock markets have only regained some of the ground they lost on Monday, which could be attributed to traders looking for some short-term bargain hunting and short-covering.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Capping gains were shares of Europe's most valuable technology company SAP, which dropped 2.1% as some analysts pointed to the company's slowing cloud revenue growth.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Philips slipped 2.1% after the Dutch health technology company's quarterly sales fell short of estimates. [nL8N29X0X5</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">As the week progresses, investors anticipate central bank meetings with the Federal Reserve's decision on interest rates due on Wednesday and the Bank of England's policy stance expected on Thursday. Financial markets see a nearly 60% chance of a rate cut in Britain.[BOEWATCH]</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Britain is also set to formally leave from the European Union on Friday, followed by a "business as usual" transition that ends next December. The two sides will also start trade talks in the coming days.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"> (Reporting by Medha Singh and Susan Mathew in Bengaluru; Editing by Bernard Orr and Giles Elgood)</p>, <p>Advertisement</p>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd" id="site-index-label">Site Index</h2>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-0">news</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-1">opinion</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-2">arts</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-3">living</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-4">more</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-subscribe-label">Subscribe</h3>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd">Site Information Navigation</h2>]
[<p>Advertisement</p>, <p>Supported by</p>, <p class="css-c2jxua e6idgb70"></p>, <h1 class="css-1j5ig2m e1h9rw200" id="link-7282b5d9" itemprop="headline"><span>OPEC Aims to Extend Oil Output Cuts Through June, Alarmed by China Virus</span></h1>, <p class="css-1fv7b6t e1jsehar1" itemprop="author" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">By<!-- --> <span class="css-1baulvz last-byline" itemprop="name">Reuters</span></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">LONDON/DUBAI — OPEC wants to extend current oil output cuts until at least June, with the possibility of deeper reductions on the table if oil demand in China is significantly impacted by the spread of a new coronavirus, OPEC sources said.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The quick slide in oil prices over the past few days has alarmed OPEC officials, the sources say, as the new virus found in China and several other countries raised concerns about a hit to economic growth and oil demand.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Oil futures were on course for a sixth day of losses with Brent crude staying below $60 per barrel. On Monday it hit a three-month low of $58.50, as the virus outbreak triggered a global selloff of riskier assets. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Saudi Arabia, OPEC's de-facto leader, joined by key oil producers such as the United Arab Emirates, Algeria and Oman, sought to calm market jitters on Monday - urging caution against gloomy expectations on the impact of the virus on the global economy and oil demand.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">But OPEC officials have also started weighing their options and intensified internal discussion on how best to respond to the price slump, the sources said.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">"A further extension is a strong possibility and a deeper cut is a possibility," said one OPEC source, adding that the impact of the China virus on oil demand would be clearer over the coming week.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">"Extension is highly possible ... until June," another source said, adding that an additional preferable option is to extend the pact until end of 2020 and that a deeper cut was "possible" if there was a need for it.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">A source familiar with Russian thinking, said that although Moscow had been keen earlier to exit from cuts, it would stay on board if oil prices continued to trade below $60 a barrel</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">OPEC+, which includes Russia, has been reducing oil supply to support prices, agreeing in December to hold back 1.7 million barrels per day (bpd) of output until the end of March.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Russia had insisted it wanted the current deal to last only until March, while Saudi Arabia has been keener for the deal to last longer, according to OPEC+ sources.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">This year, OPEC expects its world market share to fall further as output booms in non-OPEC rivals including the United States, Brazil, Canada, Australia, Norway and Guyana while global demand is rising.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Saudi Arabia's economy, the largest in the Arab world, remains dominated by hydrocarbon revenues despite plans to diversify. It has suffered in recent years because of low oil prices and austerity measures aimed at reducing a huge budget deficit. The kingdom wants high oil prices to balance its state budget.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Saudi Energy Minister Prince Abdulaziz bin Salman said on Friday all options were open when OPEC+ meets next in Vienna in early March, when asked about the possibility of a further output reduction. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"> (Additional reporting by Olesya Astakhova; writing by Rania El Gamal; editing by Veronica Brown and David Evans)</p>, <p>Advertisement</p>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd" id="site-index-label">Site Index</h2>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-0">news</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-1">opinion</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-2">arts</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-3">living</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-4">more</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-subscribe-label">Subscribe</h3>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd">Site Information Navigation</h2>]
[<p>Advertisement</p>, <p>Supported by</p>, <p class="css-c2jxua e6idgb70"></p>, <h1 class="css-1j5ig2m e1h9rw200" id="link-710aafa9" itemprop="headline"><span>Philips Bids Farewell to Home Appliances to Sharpen Health Focus</span></h1>, <p class="css-1fv7b6t e1jsehar1" itemprop="author" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">By<!-- --> <span class="css-1baulvz last-byline" itemprop="name">Reuters</span></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">AMSTERDAM — Philips will complete its transformation to a health technology business with the sale of its domestic appliances division, which no longer fits with the company's range of hospital equipment and personal health products. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Once a sprawling conglomerate, Amsterdam-based Philips has narrowed its focus in recent years, spinning off the lighting and consumer electronics divisions for which it was previously best known. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Philips said on Tuesday it would carve out the domestic appliances business, which produces coffee machines, vacuum cleaners and airfryers and generated 2.3 billion euros (£1.9 billion) in sales last year, in the coming 12 to 18 months.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">"This business is not a strategic fit for our future as a health technology leader," Chief Executive Officer Frans van Houten said. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">He added that all options remained open for the division, which he said had a double-digit profit margin that was "slightly less" than the average for Philips.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">ING analyst Marc Hesselink said a "quick and dirty" calculation valued the division at around 3 billion euros, assuming a 10% profit margin with a price tag of 12 times gross profit.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">"This was a, in our view, widely expected move...to focus even more on health tech", he said.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">DISAPPOINTING RESULTS </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Philips shares fell 3% in Amsterdam, with analysts pointing to fourth-quarter results that missed expectations, and disappointing sales growth in all sectors.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Comparable sales increased 3% to 6 billion euros from a year earlier, compared with an average forecast in a company poll of analysts for a 4.9% increase.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Adjusted earnings before interest, tax and amortisation (EBITA) rose 10% to 1.07 billion euros, also slightly below expectations.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Philips reaffirmed its 2020 targets for a 100 basis point improvement in adjusted EBITA margin and a 4 to 6% increase in comparable sales, but said it expected a slow start to the year with growth likely to be dented by China's efforts to contain a coronavirus outbreak.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The company has around 8,000 employees in China, many of whom have been ordered by authorities to stay at home.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Philips fell far short of a similar 100 basis point profit margin improvement goal in 2019, having warned in October that it would miss the target as the U.S.-China trade war forced it to shift production and seek new suppliers.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The already struggling connected care business, which specialises in remote patient monitoring, was the hardest hit and Van Houten said that following a significant fall in margins, the division's leader Carla Kriwet would leave the company and be replaced by Philips veteran Roy Jakobs.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Philips expects rising life expectancy and associated chronic diseases to increase demand for devices that allow patients to be monitored at home, but sales at the connected care unit have in recent years lagged those of bigger divisions selling large medical equipment and personal care devices.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"> (Reporting by Bart Meijer; Editing by Louise Heavens, Kirsten Donovan)</p>, <p>Advertisement</p>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd" id="site-index-label">Site Index</h2>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" [<p>Advertisement</p>, <p>Supported by</p>, <p class="css-c2jxua e6idgb70"></p>, <h1 class="css-1j5ig2m e1h9rw200" id="link-6e69055c" itemprop="headline"><span>Japan Warns About Risks to Economy From China Virus Outbreak</span></h1>, <p class="css-1fv7b6t e1jsehar1" itemprop="author" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">By<!-- --> <span class="css-1baulvz last-byline" itemprop="name">Reuters</span></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">TOKYO — Japanese Economy Minister Yasutoshi Nishimura warned on Tuesday that corporate profits and factory production might take a hit from the coronavirus outbreak in China that has rattled global markets and chilled confidence.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Asian stocks extended a global selloff as the outbreak in China, which has killed 106 people and spread to several countries, fuelled concern over the damage to the world's second largest economy - an engine of global growth.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">"There are concerns over the impact to the global economy from the spread of infection in China, transportation disruptions, cancellation of group tours from China and an extension in the Lunar Holiday," Nishimura told a news conference after a regular cabinet meeting.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">"If the situation takes longer to subside, we're concerned it could hurt Japanese exports, output and corporate profits via the impact on Chinese consumption and production," he said.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Automaker Honda Motor, which has three plants in Wuhan, the capital of Hubei province and the epicentre of the outbreak, plans to evacuate some staff. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">China is Japan's second largest export destination. In addition to carmakers, retailers have also become heavily dependent on the country amid Japan's slow economic growth and shrinking demographics. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Fast Retailing, which operates the popular casual clothing chain Uniqlo, said it had temporarily closed about 100 stores in and around Hubei. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Retail giant Aeon said it was keeping its five supermarkets in Wuhan open after local authorities requested they continue their operation, although some of its mall shops were shut. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The outbreak could hit Japanese department stores, retailers and hotels, which count on a boost to sales from an inflow of Chinese tourists visiting during the Lunar Holiday.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The Chinese make up 30% of all tourists visiting Japan and nearly 40% of the total sum foreign tourists spent last year, an industry survey showed.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">"We're worried that sales and the number of shoppers could fall if the outbreak persists," said a public relations official at Isetan Mitsukoshi Holdings, a major Japanese department store operator.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">"It's not just about Chinese tourists. We're also worried that concern over the outbreak may keep Japanese shoppers home."</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Economists at SMBC Nikko Securities estimate that if a ban China has imposed on overseas group tours lasts another six months, it could hurt Japan's economic growth by 0.05%.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Some expect the potential damage could be much worse.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Hideo Kumano, chief economist at Dai-ichi Life Research Institute, said the decline in tourists from China could hurt Japan's GDP growth by up to 0.2%.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">"The biggest worry is the risk the negative impact from the outbreak persists and hits (the economy) during the Tokyo Olympic Games," when a huge number of Chinese tourists are expected to visit Japan, he said.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">"If the number of visitors decrease rather than increase, the hit to Japan's consumer industry will be quite large."</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Japan will host the 2020 Olympics in July and August. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"> (Reporting by Yoshifumi Takemoto, Kaori Kaneko and Ritsuko Ando; Additional reporting by Hiroko Hamada; Writing by Leika Kihara; Editing by Muralikumar Anantharaman &amp; Shri Navaratnam)</p>, <p>Advertisement</p>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd" id="site-index-label">Site Index</h2>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-0">news</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-1">opinion</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-2">arts</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-3">living</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-4">more</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-subscribe-label">Subscribe</h3>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd">Site Information Navigation</h2>]
[<p>Advertisement</p>, <p>Supported by</p>, <p class="css-c2jxua e6idgb70"></p>, <h1 class="css-1j5ig2m e1h9rw200" id="link-7b326515" itemprop="headline"><span>In Grinding Manufacturing Slump, 3M Cuts Another 1,500 Jobs</span></h1>, <p class="css-1fv7b6t e1jsehar1" itemprop="author" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">By<!-- --> <span class="css-1baulvz last-byline" itemprop="name">The Associated Press</span></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">A profound slump in manufacturing and a trade war that has slowed economic growth in China has led to a second round of layoffs at 3M, the Minnesota company that makes Post-it notes as well as industrial coatings and ceramics. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The 1,500 job cuts come on top of the 2,000 jobs the company trimmed less than a year ago. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The latest round represents about 1.5% of 3M's global workforce, and CEO Michael Roman said the cuts will occur across all business groups and geographies.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"> “We continued to face softness in certain end markets, namely China, automotive, and electronics, which impacted overall growth,” Roman said in a conference call discussing 3M's fourth-quarter results with analysts.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Earlier this month, the Institute for Supply Management reported that U.S. manufacturing activity fell to the lowest level in more than a decade. A survey by the association of purchasing managers found that companies are uncertain about trade and are seeing weak demand from abroad.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The manufacturing sector last year was rocked by slower global growth and the escalation of trade tensions between the United States and China. President Donald Trump signed an initial agreement with China this month that may ease some of the drag caused by tariffs and threats of additional import taxes. However, the spread of a new virus in China threatens to hammer the nation's economy, and possibly others. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">3M, a component in the Dow Jones Industrial Average, is also wrestling with the environmental clean-up associated with some of its products, including PFAS. Those chemicals are used in firefighting foam, nonstick pots and pans, water-repellent clothing and many other household and personal items. They are nicknamed "forever chemicals" because they persist in the environment.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Studies have associated certain PFAS chemicals with increased risk of cancer and damage to organs such as the liver and thyroid.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">3M booked a pre-tax charge of $214 million in the fourth quarter related to those environmental efforts. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"> 3M Inc., which is based in St. Paul, Minnesota, earned $969 million, or $1.66 per share, in the fourth quarter. Its adjusted profit was $1.95 per share, far from the per-share earnings of $2.10 that industry analysts had expected, according to a survey by Zacks Investment Research expected.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Revenue totaled $8.11 billion, just shy of Wall Street forecasts.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">3M also makes virus masks and in response to the spreading coronavirus in China, which has now killed at least 106 people, 3M is rapidly increasing production. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The U.S. government chartered a plane to fly out diplomats from the U.S. Consulate in Wuhan, where the outbreak started, and other Americans. China has cut off access to Wuhan and 16 other cities to prevent people from leaving and spreading the virus further.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“We're seeing increased demand for our respiratory protection products and we're ramping up our production worldwide in China, around the world, to meet that demand, Roman said. "At the same time, we're seeing what everybody else is seeing, that there's -- businesses are shutting down, extending their shutdown beyond Lunar New Year so we're really watching day-to-day what that's going to mean for our outlook for China.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Shares of 3M, which have fallen 14% over the past year, ended Tuesday down $10.05, or 5.7%, at $165.58.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">_____</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Portions of this story were generated by Automated Insights (http://automatedinsights.com/ap) using data from Zacks Investment Research. Access a Zacks stock report on MMM at https://www.zacks.com/ap/MMM</p>, <p>Advertisement</p>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd" id="site-index-label">Site Index</h2>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-0">news</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-1">opinion</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-2">arts</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-3">living</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-4">more</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-subscribe-label">Subscribe</h3>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd">Site Information Navigation</h2>]

              </h2>, <h1 class="story-heading interactive-headline" itemprop="headline">Weekly News Quiz for Students: Kobe Bryant, Outbreak in China, Grammys</h1>, <p class="byline-dateline">
<span class="byline" itemprop="author creator" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">

<time class="dateline" content="2020-01-28" datetime="2020-01-28" itemprop="dateModified">JAN. 28, 2020</time>

</p>, <p>Above is an image related to one of the news stories we followed over the past week. Do you know what it shows? At the bottom of this quiz, you’ll find the answer.</p>, <p>Have you been paying attention to the news recently? See how many of these 10 questions you can get right.</p>, <p>Kobe Bryant, the retired <span class="fill-in-blank"></span> star who was one of the greatest to play the game, and his 13-year-old daughter were among the nine people killed in a helicopter crash on Jan. 26 outside Los Angeles. </p>, <p>baseball</p>, <p>basketball</p>, <p>football</p>, <p>hockey</p>, <p>An international outbreak of respiratory illness caused by a deadly <span class="fill-in-blank"></span> has killed at least 56 people and sickened at least 2,000, according to Chinese health authorities.</p>, <p>coronavirus</p>, <p>influenza virus</p>, <p>measles infection</p>, <p>polio virus</p>, <p>A divided Senate began the impeachment trial of President Trump on Jan. 21 in acrimony, as Republicans blocked Democrats’ efforts to <span class="fill-in-blank"></span> and moderate Republicans forced last-minute changes to rules that had been tailored to the president’s wishes.</p>, <p>allow senators who are currently running for president to spend additional time in Iowa and New Hampshire before the primaries </p>, <p>call President Trump to testify</p>, <p>subpoena witnesses and documents related to Ukraine</p>, <p>televise the trial during prime-time hours</p>, <p>At the 62nd annual Grammy Awards on Jan. 26, <span class="fill-in-blank"></span> won five awards, including the four most prestigious and competitive prizes — album, record and song of the year, and best new artist. </p>, <p>Ariana Grande </p>, <p>Billie Eilish </p>, <p>Lil Nas X</p>, <p>Lizzo</p>, <p>The <span class="fill-in-blank"></span> officially began on Jan. 21 in Toksook Bay, an Alaskan village on the edge of the frozen Bering Sea.</p>, <p>Democratic primary</p>, <p>groundbreaking on a controversial oil pipeline</p>, <p>most expensive climate change study</p>, <p>U.S. 2020 census</p>, <p>Zion Williamson played his first regular-season game with the <span class="fill-in-blank"></span>, in the most hyped debut for an N.B.A. player since that of LeBron James. </p>, <p>Boston Celtics</p>, <p>Dallas Mavericks</p>, <p>Memphis Grizzlies</p>, <p>New Orleans Pelicans</p>, <p> On Jan. 24, President Trump became the first sitting president to address the annual <span class="fill-in-blank"></span> in person.</p>, <p>March for Life</p>, <p>Extinction Rebellion protest</p>, <p>Take Back the Vote march</p>, <p>Women’s March</p>, <p>World leaders converged in Jerusalem to mark the 75th anniversary of <span class="fill-in-blank"></span>.</p>, <p>D-Day</p>, <p>the end of World War 2</p>, <p>the founding of Israel</p>, <p>the liberation of Auschwitz</p>, <p>The Department of Transportation is proposing to ban all service animals except <span class="fill-in-blank"></span> aboard U.S. flights, officials said on Jan. 22.</p>, <p>birds</p>, <p>cats</p>, <p>dogs</p>, <p>rabbits</p>, <p>Three of the business-related articles below were recently published in The New York Times. One is from the satirical site The Onion. Which is the fake news story?</p>, <p>“As World Economy Shifts Gears, Trade Growth Slows”</p>, <p>“Boeing Pushes Back 737 Max Return Again”</p>, <p>“Collectors Are Spending Thousands on Video Games They Will Never Play”</p>, <p>“Wall Street Worried About Key Recession Indicator After Ominous Black Storm Clouds Spotted Atop Mount Money”</p>, <h2 class="section-heading">More on NYTimes.com</h2>, <p>Advertisement</p>, <h2 class="visually-hidden">Site Information Navigation</h2>, <h2 class="visually-hidden">Site Information Navigation</h2>]
[<p>Advertisement</p>, <p>Supported by</p>, <p class="css-c2jxua e6idgb70"></p>, <h1 class="css-1j5ig2m e1h9rw200" id="link-44d43206" itemprop="headline"><span>Stocks Open Higher on Wall Street a Day After a Big Drop</span></h1>, <p class="css-1fv7b6t e1jsehar1" itemprop="author" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">By<!-- --> <span class="css-1baulvz last-byline" itemprop="name">The Associated Press</span></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">NEW YORK — Stocks are opening broadly higher on Wall Street a day after the S&amp;P 500 had its biggest drop since early October. Technology companies were putting up some of the biggest gains early Tuesday. Whirlpool and Xerox rose after reporting solid results. Markets remained closed in China for Lunar New Year holidays, while South Korea's benchmark sank as it reopened after its own holidays. The S&amp;P 500 rose 11 points, or 0.3%, to 3,254. The Dow Jones Industrial Average added 62, or 0.2%, to 28,599, and the Nasdaq rose 47, or 0.5%, to 9,184 Bond prices fell. The 10-year Treasury yield rose to 1.62%.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">THIS IS A BREAKING NEWS UPDATE. AP’s earlier story follows below.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">European stock markets and U.S. futures edged higher after another day of losses in Asia on Tuesday amid worries over the expanding outbreak of a new virus in China. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">France's CAC 40 rose 0.5% to 5,893 , while Germany's DAX rose 0.4% to 13,253. Britain's FTSE 100 was up 0.5% at 7,447. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">U.S. shares appeared set to open higher with Dow futures gaining 0.5% and S&amp;P 500 futures rising 0.7%. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">In China, the government said more than 4,500 people have been confirmed ill with the virus and 106 have died in the outbreak of a novel coronavirus centered on the city of Wuhan, an industrial hub along the Yangtze river. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The illness can cause pneumonia and other severe respiratory symptoms, and Chinese authorities have extended the Lunar New Year holiday and ordered Wuhan and some other cities nearby to stop public transport and try to prevent people from traveling to help contain its spread. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The virus has spread to a dozen countries, including the U.S. Besides the threat to people's lives and health, investors are worried about how much damage the virus will do to profits for companies around the world.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Even if they're thousands of miles away from Wuhan, foreign companies have plenty of customers and suppliers in China, the world's second-largest economy. Investors have been rattled by the potential for a wider impact from the outbreak. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“How long and how deep the correction lower will last, depends both on the success of China's efforts to control the viral spread, and the prevalence of its occurrence internationally," Jeffrey Halley of Oanda said in a commentary. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Markets in Hong Kong, Taiwan and mainland China were closed Tuesday for Lunar New Year holidays, while South Korea's benchmark tumbled 3.1% to 2,176.72 as it reopened after its own holidays. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Japan's Nikkei 225 index lost 0.6% to 23,215.71, while Australia's S&amp;P ASX/200 slipped 1.4% to 6,994.50. India's Sensex lost 0.5% to 40,966.86. Singapore's benchmark dropped 1.7%, Jakarta's fell 0.5% and Thailand's erased earlier losses to fall 0.7%. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Overnight, a sell-off on Wall Street gave the Dow its first 5-day losing streak since early August and handed the S&amp;P 500 its worst day since early October.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Investors are also dealing with a heavy week of corporate earnings. Pharmaceutical giant Pfizer reported a loss, though revenue figures were better than expected. Apple will report financial results later Tuesday.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Boeing, McDonald’s, Coca-Cola and Amazon are also among some of the biggest names reporting earnings throughout the week that includes 147 S&amp;P 500 companies.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">ENERGY: Benchmark crude oil rose 30 cents to $53.44 a barrel in electronic trading on the New York Mercantile Exchange. Brent crude oil, the international standard, gained 22 cents to $58.80. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">CURRENCIES: The dollar rose to 109.04 Japanese yen from 108.89 yen on Monday. The euro fell to $1.1005 from $1.1019.</p>, <p>Advertisement</p>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd" id="site-index-label">Site Index</h2>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-0">news</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-1">opinion</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-2">arts</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-3">living</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-4">more</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-subscribe-label">Subscribe</h3>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd">Site Information Navigation</h2>]
[<p>Advertisement</p>, <p>Supported by</p>, <p class="css-c2jxua e6idgb70"></p>, <h1 class="css-1j5ig2m e1h9rw200" id="link-68dac86a" itemprop="headline"><span>Uptick in World Growth, Supply Constraints to Lift Copper Prices-Reuters Poll</span></h1>, <p class="css-1fv7b6t e1jsehar1" itemprop="author" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">By<!-- --> <span class="css-1baulvz last-byline" itemprop="name">Reuters</span></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">LONDON/BENGALURU — The price of copper is expected to climb this year, supported by a recovery in global economic growth and problems with supply, a Reuters poll showed.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The bulk of the poll was conducted between Jan. 8 and Jan. 20, before a coronavirus outbreak in China worsened, knocking financial markets including base metals.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The London Metal Exchange index of six base metals inched up only 1.5% last year while copper added 3.5%, held back by worries about a possible global recession and a trade war between the United States and top metals consumer China.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">"But we think things will be different in 2020," said Caroline Bain, chief commodities economist at Capital Economics in London. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The LME cash copper price is expected to average $6,214 a tonne in 2020, a median forecast of 28 analysts shows, an 8.7% increase from Monday's closing price.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Analysts have upgraded their 2020 consensus forecast by 2.7% from the previous poll in October and see a steady climb during the year, with fourth-quarter forecasts averaging $6,365.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">"A modest revival in global economic growth coupled with a less seamless return of supply than most expect following major disruptions last year should be positive for the price of copper," Bain said.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Analysts expect a market deficit this year of 160,000 tonnes, the poll showed.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">INDONESIA NICKEL BAN</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">A ban on exporting nickel ore by top producer Indonesia at the start of 2020 is expected to support prices, mostly in the second half of the year.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Shipments accelerated ahead of the ban and China is currently well stocked, analysts said.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">"Although Chinese nickel ore port stocks have risen recently, mainly due to surging imports from Indonesia, we do not expect that these stocks will be enough to keep Chinese NPI output at high levels," said Matthew Piggott, head of metals and mining research at S&amp;P Global.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Nickel pig iron (NPI) is an intermediate product widely used in stainless steel production.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The LME cash price of nickel is expected to average $15,325 a tonne this year, up 22% from the latest price.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Shortages are expected to create a market deficit of 31,000 tonnes in 2020, rising to 74,000 tonnes the following year, according the poll.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">ALUMINIUM SURPLUS</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The global aluminium market is seen moving into surplus this year after a deficit in 2019, weighing on prices.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Analysts have pencilled in 350,000 tonnes of oversupply this year, boosting their consensus estimate by 15% from the last poll. Excess supply is due to total 562,000 tonnes in 2021. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">"We expect that aluminium demand will not significantly improve this year. As a consequence, the global market will probably record a surplus in 2020 and LME prices will decline over the year," said analyst Daniela Corsini from Intesa Sanpaolo bank in Milan.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Analysts expect cash LME aluminium to average $1,776 a tonne in 2020, up 1% from Monday's closing price.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">RAMPING UP ZINC OUTPUT </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Rising supply is also expected to have an impact on the zinc market as mines ramp up production.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">A surplus of 108,000 tonnes is forecast for this year, rising to 185,000 tonnes in 2021.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">"Ample availability of concentrate is expected to boost global refined zinc production in 2020 by nearly 3%," said Sanjeeban Sarkar, commodities editor at The Economist Intelligence Unit. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">"As the market reaches a new equilibrium, we expect prices to fall."</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Analysts see the average cash LME zinc price at $2,295 a tonne, up 1.9% from the latest price.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"> (Reporting by Eric Onstad and Brijesh Patel; Additional reporting by Arpan Varghese in Bengaluru; Editing by Jan Harvey)</p>, <p>Advertisement</p>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd" id="site-index-label">Site Index</h2>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-0">news</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-1">opinion</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-2">arts</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-3">living</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-4">more</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-subscribe-label">Subscribe</h3>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd">Site Information Navigation</h2>]
[<p>Advertisement</p>, <p>Supported by</p>, <p class="css-c2jxua e6idgb70"></p>, <h1 class="css-1j5ig2m e1h9rw200" id="link-41b406d4" itemprop="headline"><span>Airlines Cut China Flights as Companies Restrict Travel on Virus Fears</span></h1>, <p class="css-1fv7b6t e1jsehar1" itemprop="author" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">By<!-- --> <span class="css-1baulvz last-byline" itemprop="name">Reuters</span></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">CHICAGO/SHANGHAI/SEOUL — Airlines including United Airlines Holdings Inc said they were canceling some flights to China as demand fell sharply and global companies told their employees not to travel on deepening fears over the spread of a flu-like virus.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The coronavirus that originated in the city of Wuhan has killed 106 people in China and spread across the world, rattling financial markets.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The United States warned that Americans should reconsider visiting China, while Britain advised against all but essential travel to mainland China. South Korea also advised its citizens to stay away.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Facebook Inc became the first major U.S. company to announce a travel suspension after the U.S. government's warning, saying it had asked employees to halt non-essential travel to mainland China and to work from home if they had traveled there.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Chicago-based United said it was suspending 24 U.S. flights to Beijing, Hong Kong and Shanghai between Feb. 1 and Feb. 8 due to a significant drop in demand.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Europe's biggest bank, HSBC Holdings PLC, banned all staff travel to Chinese-ruled Hong Kong for two weeks and to mainland China until further notice, according to an internal memo seen by Reuters.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The British-based lender, which has the largest presence among foreign banks in China, also asked staff who have recently visited the country to undergo a self-imposed 14-day quarantine. The virus has an incubation period of up to 14 days.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">U.S. rival Goldman Sachs Group Inc imposed similar measures, according to a memo seen by Reuters.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">In South Korea, home appliances maker LG Electronics Inc put a complete ban on travel to China and has advised employees on business trips in the country to return home as quickly as possible, a company spokeswoman said.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">South Korean chipmaker SK Hynix Inc said it was urging employees to avoid all non-essential travel to China, while banking group Standard Chartered PLC restricted travel to both mainland China and Hong Kong.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">In Germany, auto supplier Webasto, which has 11 sites in China, including in Wuhan, has halted all corporate travel to and from China after an employee was infected.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Japan's Honda Motor Co Ltd said it recommended employees avoid travel to China, while Nissan Motor Co Ltd said it plans to evacuate its Japanese staff and their families in Wuhan via a government-chartered flight.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">FALLING TRAVEL DEMAND</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Aside from United, other airlines said they were adjusting schedules as companies reassessed the risk of travel to China.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">South Korean budget carrier Air Seoul said it will halt all flights to China, while Taiwan's China Airlines Ltd rescheduled and canceled some flights to China to Feb. 10.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Taiwan's Eva Airways Corp also said some flights to China may be canceled.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Air Canada said it was cancelling some of its 33 weekly flights to China, and Germany's Lufthansa pointed to subdued bookings to and from the country.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Hong Kong's Cathay Pacific Airways Ltd said it would be progressively reducing capacity to and from mainland China by 50% or more from Jan. 30 to the end of March, in line with a government directive as well as market demand. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">International SOS, a medical and travel security services firm that advises companies on travel, said its guidance for now was that business travel to China outside Wuhan's province of Hubei could continue.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">But this could be updated if there were major flight cancellations throughout China and more disruptions to ground transport, International SOS Regional Security Director James Robertson said.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"> (Reporting by Josh Horwitz in Shanghai, Heekyong Yang in Seoul and Tracy Rucinski in Chicago; Additional reporting by Engen Tham in Shanghai, Sumeet Chatterjee in Hong Kong, Jamie Freed in Sydney, Naomi Tatjitsu in Tokyo, Ben Blanchard in Taipei, Joyce Lee in Seoul and Allison Lampert in Montreal; Writing by Jamie Freed and Lawrence White; Editing by Rosalba O'Brien and Christopher Cushing)</p>, <p>Advertisement</p>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd" id="site-index-label">Site Index</h2>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-0">news</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-1">opinion</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-2">arts</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-3">living</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-4">more</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-subscribe-label">Subscribe</h3>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd">Site Information Navigation</h2>]
[<p>Advertisement</p>, <p>Supported by</p>, <p class="css-c2jxua e6idgb70"></p>, <h1 class="css-1j5ig2m e1h9rw200" id="link-60c98e4d" itemprop="headline"><span>Wuhan People Keep Out: Chinese Villages Shun Outsiders as Virus Spreads</span></h1>, <p class="css-1fv7b6t e1jsehar1" itemprop="author" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">By<!-- --> <span class="css-1baulvz last-byline" itemprop="name">Reuters</span></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">BEIJING — In a village in Beijing's far northeastern Shunyi district, residents have set an informal rule: "If you're here, don't leave. If they've left, don't let them come back."</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Red tape was tied across the road at the entrance to the small community Monday. Village committee members wearing face masks and high-visibility vests manned the blockade. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Since last week, a public address system had been broadcasting messages, residents told Reuters, warning people against inviting guests and urging anyone who has been to Wuhan, the epicentre of a spreading coronavirus that has killed 106 people, to register with authorities.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">"We grow our own leeks ... we have a lot of frozen pork, rice and oil. There's no need for us to go outside," villager Lu Weian, who lives in a traditional village house with high walls, told Reuters by phone. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">"Every house is its own quarantine zone," she said. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The village, hundreds of miles from Wuhan, is one of many across China shunning outsiders amid rising panic over the virus that has infected thousands. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">A decision by authorities to lock down travel in Hubei province, of which Wuhan is the capital, has spurred a counter-movement of communities closing their gates to outsiders.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Social media showed dozens of images and videos from across China of similar vigilante efforts.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Some showed villages blocking roads with vehicles, others constructing make-shift barriers out of tape and cinder-blocks. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Zhengding county in Hebei province, outside Beijing, on Monday began offering 1,000 yuan ($145) to tipsters for credible information about unregistered people who may have links to Wuhan.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">"We've done our work very carefully and registered everyone coming from the epidemic regions," said a man surnamed Ye who was manning the tip line at the county's Communist Party office when Reuters called on Tuesday. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">"We haven't got useful tips, though there are people calling offering clues. In most cases they spotted cars with Hubei plates," he said. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">'LIVES COME FIRST'</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The efforts aren't limited to villages. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">In central Beijing, some residents and authorities are tracking and registering people who have been to Wuhan. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">"It's our responsibility to find everyone and enforce safety...
