No one should be afraid to be an informant," said Chen Gang, a retired resident in central Dongcheng district, who is a designated community leader in his neighbourhood.<span class="css-8l6xbc evw5hdy0">  </span></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">On Saturday, Chen went door-to-door helping officials check whether people had recently visited Wuhan or had guests from Hubei. He said several people with Wuhan links were told to stay at home for a quarantine period.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">For people from Wuhan, the stigma is causing emotional strain.<span class="css-8l6xbc evw5hdy0">  </span></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">"I think I'm the loneliest person in the world right now," said 23-year-old Peking University student Carmen Wang, a Wuhan native who cancelled plans to return home from Beijing when news of the virus broke. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Wang said she has been shunned by classmates, who sent messages in a class group chat warning others not to visit her. She orders out for food and watches TV alone. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">"Even if they came and ate food with me or hung out, if I even sneezed, they would accuse me ... it's better this way," said Wang.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Villagers took pains to justify their exclusivity.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">"It's not that we are without human emotions, but lives come first," read a sign attached to an earth-moving machine parked across a road to block traffic in an image posted on social media.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">A man who answered a call from Reuters to the phone number listed on the sign declined to give the location of the village. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">"I don't want to tell you because I don't want you coming here," he said.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"> (Reporting by Cate Cadell and Sophie Yu; Editing by Tony Munroe and Nick Macfie)</p>, <p>Advertisement</p>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd" id="site-index-label">Site Index</h2>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-0">news</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-1">opinion</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-2">arts</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-3">living</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-4">more</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-subscribe-label">Subscribe</h3>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd">Site Information Navigation</h2>]
[<p>Advertisement</p>, <p>Supported by</p>, <p class="css-c2jxua e6idgb70"></p>, <h1 class="css-1j5ig2m e1h9rw200" id="link-52e2f396" itemprop="headline"><span>China Proxies Bear the Brunt of Investor Concerns on Virus</span></h1>, <p class="css-1fv7b6t e1jsehar1" itemprop="author" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">By<!-- --> <span class="css-1baulvz last-byline" itemprop="name">Reuters</span></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">SYDNEY/TOKYO — Stock and currency markets in Thailand, South Korea and Australia are bearing the brunt of investors' scramble to hedge the mounting risks from a new viral outbreak in China during a long holiday on the mainland.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">In the week since the spreading coronavirus became a mainstream market concern, every hour has brought headlines of mounting cases or another Chinese city shutting public transport or a country telling citizens not to travel.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Stock markets from South Korea to Thailand have fallen hard, with transport, tourism, retail and luxury stocks badly hit.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Investors sold the Australian and New Zealand dollars as a proxy for the yuan, while also buying their sovereign bonds and U.S. Treasury debt on wagers central banks globally might have to ease policy to offset the economic drag from the virus. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">It was a shift made all the more prominent by the closure of Chinese markets for the week-long new year holiday, which has forced investors to hedge through proxies.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">"I want to buy Chinese government bonds with around 5-years’ duration. People already believe China's economy will slow down, so there will be more upside for these bonds. I need to wait until China’s markets re-open," said Toshinobu Chiba, chief portfolio manager in the fixed income department at Nissay Asset Management Corp in Tokyo.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Chiba is therefore using the forward curve in the offshore Chinese yuan &lt;CNH=D3&gt; to express his views, while also buying shorter term U.S. Treasury bonds and swapping his lower quality corporate bonds for higher.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">"Normally, in a situation like this, people would want to be long in countries with current account surpluses, like South Korea, Singapore or Taiwan, but you cannot because of their correlation with China," he said, adding that was why he was avoiding the Korean won.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Stock markets in Thailand and Korea have fallen more than 2% in the past week, taking a bigger hit than U.S. and world stocks broadly. A large China ETF - iShares Large-Cap ETF sank nearly 4% on Monday and is now down about 10% since Jan. 17.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The baht &lt;THB=&gt; is Asia's worst performer for the year, with losses against the dollar nearly 3%.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">STRETCHED STOCK VALUATIONS</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Analysts at JPMorgan recommended clients use currency options to hedge cheaply, given how low the measures of expected volatility were. To brace for a negative impact on the tourism sectors in Malaysia and Thailand, JPMorgan said it is changing to neutral an underweight holding in Thai government bonds and an overweight position in Malaysia's ringgit &lt;MYR=&gt;.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">That demand for cheap hedges has seen implied volatility &lt;CNHVOL&gt; on offshore yuan rise by about a percentage point across tenors in the past week.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Chris Rands, Sydney-based portfolio manager for Nikko Asset Management, is tracking the spreads on credit default swaps, which are insurance products used to hedge against default risk, between those on Australia and the United States as one barometer of negative sentiment.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">He hasn't put on a trade yet, though, and many other big fund managers said they are sitting tight. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">"We don't have enough information to know how bad this is so we don't think we should be making huge decisions on the back of that," said Rands.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The panic engulfing markets and the resulting dive in bond yields could help underpin equity valuations, at least in the major developed nations, leaving emerging markets to bear the brunt.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Optimists argue that this episode would not be a repeat of the 2003 outbreak of severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS), in part because Beijing had acted more quickly and radically this time.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">While the SARS outbreak initially caused steep losses for Asian stocks, they rebounded smartly in its wake.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">One hurdle this time is that many equity markets globally are trading at stratospheric valuations. The U.S. S&amp;P 500 index is trading at a price-earnings ratio above 23, last seen in late 2018. Valuations for the MSCI world equities index are also at 2018 highs. "For those looking to play the big rebound, keep in mind in 2003, the entire backdrop was completely different as most risky assets were already at the lows, not highs, after the tech bubble blew up and the U.S. recession," said Stephen Innes, Asia Pacific market strategist at AxiCorp.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">"So the rebound comparison is invalid on many levels." </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"> (Additional reporting by Sonali Desai in Singapore; Writing by Wayne Cole; Editing by Vidya Ranganathan and Muralikumar Anantharaman)</p>, <p>Advertisement</p>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd" id="site-index-label">Site Index</h2>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-0">news</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-1">opinion</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-2">arts</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-3">living</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-4">more</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-subscribe-label">Subscribe</h3>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd">Site Information Navigation</h2>]
[<p>Advertisement</p>, <p>Supported by</p>, <p class="css-c2jxua e6idgb70"></p>, <h1 class="css-1j5ig2m e1h9rw200" id="link-6f4f08c5" itemprop="headline"><span>Services in Spotlight After Apple Stock Market Value Hits $1.4 Trillion</span></h1>, <p class="css-1fv7b6t e1jsehar1" itemprop="author" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">By<!-- --> <span class="css-1baulvz last-byline" itemprop="name">Reuters</span></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">SAN FRANCISCO — When Apple Inc posts quarterly results on Tuesday, investors will be looking for fresh evidence the iPhone maker should be treated as a producer of high-margin, subscription services after its stock market value touched $1.4 trillion and its earnings multiple trades at decade highs.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The Cupertino, California corporation's stock has doubled over the past year, even as iPhone sales contract along with the rest of the global smartphone market. Fueling its stellar run has been Chief Executive Tim Cook's push to turn Apple's loyal client base into a source of steady services revenue, including streaming video and a credit card launched last year with Goldman Sachs. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Also supporting Apple's stock is excitement around an eventual pickup in iPhone demand with the rollout of 5G wireless technology, and low interest rates that have broadly helped Wall Street.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Shares of Apple fell 2.9% on Monday from record highs as fears about the economic fallout of the coronavirus outbreak in China hit Wall Street. Analysts on Apple's quarterly earnings call after the bell on Tuesday will listen for comments concerning the impact on its manufacturing operations in China.Apple's market capitalization briefly exceeded $1.4 trillion last Wednesday for the first time, but it has yet to end a session at that level. Some investors worry that Apple's rally, and surging earnings multiple, may have become overextended. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">"The run-up in the stock is a concern, and I wouldn't be surprised if we see a bit of a pullback in the near future," said People's United Advisors chief equity strategist John Conlon, who added that Apple's services business has become his main reason for owning stock.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Following its recent rally, Apple's stock is trading at the equivalent of 23 times expected earnings, its highest multiple since 2010, according to Refinitiv. Apple's average PE over the past decade was about 14, lagging other high-growth companies with recurring revenue and reflecting its singular dependence on iPhones sales and reliance on persuading consumers to upgrade their phones year after year. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Salesforce.com and Netflix, which rely on recurring revenue, are trading at over 55 times expected earnings. Tech hardware sellers Intel and Cisco Systems are at about 14 times expected earnings.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Apple is on track to reach a goal to double its 2016 services revenue to $48.7 billion by the end of fiscal 2020 as it focuses on selling high-margin subscriptions to its user base. Many investors envision an increasingly rosy future for its earnings, a trend reflected in its soaring earnings multiple.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Adding to existing services including cloud storage, the App Store and music, Apple last year launched an ambitious video streaming service, along with its credit card, a subscription news app and a videogame service. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Apple has also increased the emphasis on its AppleCare, its extended warranty program. For example, the iPhone's "settings" now includes reminders encouraging people to buy or renew their AppleCare plans. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">In the September quarter, Apple said its services revenue hit $12.51 billion, topping analysts expectations of $12.15 billion. Services accounted for 20% of total revenue in that quarter, up from 17% in the same quarter the year before.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Apple also gave cost of sales data showing gross margins for its services segment rose to 64% from a 61% a year earlier. That is far more generous than Apple's overall gross margin of around 38% in recent years.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Still, for a business segment getting the most attention from Wall Street, Apple provides limited details. Apple's quarterly reports break out sales of iPhones, Macs and iPads, but a breakdown of results from products falling within the services category so far has not been released. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Apple's recent strong stock performance has been perpetuated by fund managers buying its shares in order to avoid underperforming their benchmarks, a trend that could reverse when the recent rally ends, Cowen analyst Krish Sankar wrote in a client note last week. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">For the fiscal first quarter, which ended in December, analysts on average expect services revenue to jump 19.7% to $13.0 billion, according to Refinitiv.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Overall quarterly revenue is expected to rise 5.0% to $88.5 billion, with adjusted net income inching up 1.5% to $20.3 billion and earnings per share of $4.55.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"> (Reporting by Noel Randewich, additional reporting by Stephen Nellis; Editing by Tom Brown)</p>, <p>Advertisement</p>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd" id="site-index-label">Site Index</h2>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-0">news</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-1">opinion</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-2">arts</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-3">living</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-4">more</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-subscribe-label">Subscribe</h3>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd">Site Information Navigation</h2>]
[<p>Advertisement</p>, <p>Supported by</p>, <h1 class="css-1s4ffep e1h9rw200" id="link-7b43c4fe" itemprop="headline"><span>New iPhones Fuel Strong Profit for Apple</span></h1>, <p class="css-1ifw933 e1wiw3jv0" id="article-summary">Apple found renewed growth with an increase in phone sales as well as younger products, like the Apple Watch, AirPods and its subscription services.</p>, <p class="css-1fv7b6t e1jsehar1" itemprop="author" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">By<!-- --> <a class="css-brehiz e1jsehar0" href="https://www.nytimes.com/by/jack-nicas"><span class="css-1baulvz last-byline" itemprop="name">Jack Nicas</span></a></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">SAN FRANCISCO — Apple’s profit grew for the first time in a year with the help of an old friend: the iPhone.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Sales of Apple’s flagship product had fallen sharply for the past year, but on Tuesday, Apple said iPhone revenue was growing again. The company said customers spent heavily on its latest models, increasing iPhone sales by 7.7 percent to nearly $56 billion in the latest quarter from a year ago.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">That growth helped lift Apple’s profit by 11.4 percent to $22.3 billion. The numbers easily beat Wall Street expectations and were welcome news to Apple investors, who had watched the company’s typically strong growth suddenly evaporate over the past year.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Before Tuesday, Apple had posted <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2019/10/30/technology/apple-earnings.html" title="">four consecutive quarters of shrinking profit</a>, the longest such streak since 2016.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Luca Maestri, Apple’s finance chief, said in an interview that demand for Apple’s newest iPhones — the iPhone 11 series, released in September — exceeded expectations. He attributed the strong sales to new features, like a better camera and longer battery life, as well as financing options to buy a new phone and a $50 price cut for the cheapest model.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Daniel Ives, a tech analyst at Wedbush Securities, said there was pent-up demand for the new iPhones because many people had waited to upgrade their older devices. “This was a jaw-dropper in terms of how strong phone sales were,” he said. “Even more than the bulls were hoping for.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Apple also was lifted by some of its newer products.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Apple’s services revenue, or sales from its App Store and subscription products, rose by nearly 17 percent to $12.7 billion from the prior year. And sales in its so-called wearables division, which include the Apple Watch and AirPods wireless headphones, grew by 37 percent to just over $10 billion.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The growth in services and wearables “attests to the fact that the company continues to reinvent itself,” said Daniel Flax, an analyst at the investment firm Neuberger Berman.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Apple also showed continued improvement in China, its second-largest market after the United States. A year ago, Apple had to pre-empt<a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2019/01/02/technology/apple-revenue-decline-china.html" title=""> its earnings report</a> with news that its sales in China would come in much lower than forecast.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The news sent its stock sliding and raised fears that the slump was a precursor to global economic decline. Apple <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2019/01/29/technology/apple-earnings-china.html" title="">reported that its sales</a> in the China region fell by nearly 27 percent that quarter, contributing to a slight decline in its overall profit.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">But since then, Apple’s business has rebounded, the global economy has remained largely stable, and the company’s stock has roughly doubled. On Tuesday, Apple said its sales in the China region increased for the first time in five quarters, growing 3.1 percent. Mr. Maestri, the Apple executive, attributed the company’s improving fortunes in China partly to the strengthening economy there.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Apple’s revenue rose by almost 9 percent to $91.8 billion. The company forecast that its revenue would rise 9 percent to 15 percent in the current quarter.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Timothy D. Cook, Apple’s chief executive, said on a call with analysts that Apple’s forecast was less precise than typical because the company was uncertain about the impact from <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/28/world/asia/china-coronavirus.html" title="">the rapidly spreading coronavirus</a>.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">In addition to its large sales presence in China, Apple also assembles most of its products there. Mr. Cook said that some Apple suppliers would remain closed into February as a precaution from the virus, and that traffic into its retail stores in the country had also fallen off.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Apple shares rose about 2 percent in after-hours trading.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Apple’s recent success on the stock market has reflected a number of good signs for its business, including easing trade tensions between China and the United States. Apple is among the companies with the most at risk in a trade war between the two countries, given its enormous manufacturing and sales presence in China.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">In the latest quarter, Apple debuted one of its biggest efforts to expand its services business: Apple TV Plus, a package of exclusive TV shows produced by Apple that costs $5 a month, cheaper than most offerings from rivals.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Still, <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.cnet.com/news/disney-plus-battled-apple-tv-plus-in-2019-first-streaming-war-and-won-big/" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">early market estimates</a> suggest the service has not been a big draw for new paying subscribers over the first several months, in part because Apple is giving a free year subscription to the service to anyone who buys a new iPhone, iPad, Apple TV or Mac computer.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Part of Apple’s strategy to expand its services business is to continue to increase the number of people using its devices. On Tuesday, Apple said there were more than 1.5 billion active Apple devices, including iPhones, iPads and Mac computers, up from about 1.4 billion a year ago.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Still, sales of some of Apple’s older products fell in the quarter. Mac revenue decreased 3.5 percent and, on the week of the iPad’s 10th anniversary, its sales declined 11.2 percent.</p>, <p>Advertisement</p>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd" id="site-index-label">Site Index</h2>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-0">news</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-1">opinion</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-2">arts</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-3">living</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-4">more</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-subscribe-label">Subscribe</h3>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd">Site Information Navigation</h2>]
[<p>Advertisement</p>, <p>Supported by</p>, <p class="css-c2jxua e6idgb70"></p>, <h1 class="css-1j5ig2m e1h9rw200" id="link-613e3b3d" itemprop="headline"><span>US Beefs Up Screening of Travelers for New Virus From China</span></h1>, <p class="css-1fv7b6t e1jsehar1" itemprop="author" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">By<!-- --> <span class="css-1baulvz last-byline" itemprop="name">The Associated Press</span></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">WASHINGTON — U.S. health officials offered a reality check Tuesday about the scary new virus from China: They're expanding screenings of international travelers and taking other precautions but for now, they insist the risk to Americans is very low.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“At this point Americans should not worry for their own safety,” Health and Human Services Secretary Alex Azar told reporters Tuesday.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">China has confirmed more than 4,500 people with the respiratory illness, which in severe cases can cause pneumonia, with dozens more counted in other countries. In the U.S. so far, there are five confirmed patients, all of whom had traveled to the hardest-hit part of China — and no sign that they have spread the illness to anyone around them.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Still, “this is a very fast-moving, constantly changing situation,” Azar added.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Flanked by the government's top infection specialists, Azar listed the biggest unanswered questions of the outbreak and tried to tamp down some of the fear and speculation provoked by China's rising toll:</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">—How deadly is this new virus? China's death toll has passed 100 but the first patients counted in an outbreak “are naturally the most severe cases” and “skew our understanding,” Azar cautioned. Over time, if doctors find many more people had just a mild, cold-like illness, the death rate will change.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">—How easily does it spread? One way to measure that is an estimate of how many people could catch an infection from one contagious patient. Some reports have suggested that number might be between 1.5 and 3.5 for the new coronavirus, but Azar stressed it's too soon to know. For comparison, one patient with measles could spread it to 12 to 18 others, he added. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">—What about silent carriers? Reports from China suggest some people may have spread the virus before showing symptoms. And Germany on Tuesday said a man with the virus near Munich never traveled to China or had close contact with anyone showing symptoms. Instead, he may have been infected by a coworker from China who briefly visited for a company training session and didn't report feeling ill until her flight home. Later authorities confirmed three additional cases from the German company, all connected to the first.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Some viruses, such as the flu, can spread before symptoms are obvious. But there's no evidence it's happened with the new virus in the U.S., where health officials are checking contacts of the sick. And epidemics are driven by the openly sick, said Dr. Anthony Fauci, infectious disease chief of the National Institutes of Health.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Still, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention wants to send its own scientists to visit China for a first-hand look try to answer those questions. On Tuesday, the World Health Organization said it hopes to send in international experts soon.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Without a vaccine or treatments, the world is depending on tried-and-true public health steps to tamp down the outbreak — finding the infected early and isolating them to stem the spread. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">In the U.S., the CDC is beefing up its checks of incoming travelers. It already had been screening for illness among passengers arriving from the epicenter of China's outbreak at five U.S. airports. But people who've visited other parts of China still may be arriving, with stops in other places first. Now, CDC is sending extra staff to other “quarantine stations” to screen arrivals at a total of 18 airports around the country and at two border crossings, in El Paso, Texas, and San Diego.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The State Department has also chartered a plane to evacuate diplomats from the U.S. Consulate in Wuhan, the city where the outbreak started, and some other Americans. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Asked if those evacuees would be quarantined, Azar said there will be doctors on the flight to check all the passengers so health officials can decide if additional steps are needed.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">With an incubation period of anywhere from two to 14 days, travelers may arrive showing no symptoms. But CDC's Dr. Nancy Messonnier said the screenings are an opportunity to educate travelers that if they start feeling sick — with a fever, cough or flu-like symptoms — after returning from an outbreak zone, they should contact their doctor. That's exactly what the first U.S. patients did.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Azar said he has directed $105 million to fight the outbreak. Among the next steps, the CDC developed a test for the virus and aims to make it usable by state health departments, to speed diagnosis of suspected cases. Research also is under way to develop a vaccine or treatment. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Airport screenings were initially done in New York, Los Angeles, San Francisco, Chicago and Atlanta. That has been expanded to Anchorage, Alaska; Boston; Dallas; Detroit; El Paso, Texas; Honolulu; Houston, Miami, Minneapolis; Newark, New Jersey; Philadelphia; San Diego; Seattle; Washington, D.C. (Dulles); and San Juan, Puerto Rico.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"> ___</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">AP Medical Writer Mike Stobbe in New York contributed to this report.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">___</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The Associated Press Health and Science Department receives support from the Howard Hughes Medical Institute's Department of Science Education. The AP is solely responsible for all content.</p>, <p>Advertisement</p>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd" id="site-index-label">Site Index</h2>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-0">news</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-1">opinion</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-2">arts</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-3">living</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-4">more</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-subscribe-label">Subscribe</h3>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd">Site Information Navigation</h2>]
[<h1 class="css-1jrl1ex">Page No Longer Available</h1>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd" id="site-index-label">Site Index</h2>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-0">news</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-1">opinion</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-2">arts</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-3">living</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-4">more</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-subscribe-label">Subscribe</h3>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd">Site Information Navigation</h2>]
[<p>Advertisement</p>, <p>Supported by</p>, <p class="css-c2jxua e6idgb70"></p>, <h1 class="css-1j5ig2m e1h9rw200" id="link-7396a2c9" itemprop="headline"><span>Apple Holiday Season Tops Projections as iPhone Bounces Back</span></h1>, <p class="css-1fv7b6t e1jsehar1" itemprop="author" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">By<!-- --> <span class="css-1baulvz last-byline" itemprop="name">The Associated Press</span></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">SAN FRANCISCO — Apple is still reaping huge profits from the iPhone while mining more moneymaking opportunities from the growing popularity of its smartwatch, digital services and wireless earbuds.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">That combination produced a banner holiday season for a company whose fortunes appeared to be sliding just a year ago amid declining sales for the iPhone, its marquee product for the past decade. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Apple’s fiscal first-quarter results, released Tuesday, provided the latest proof that the fears hanging over the consumer electronics icon might have been unfounded.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Apple’s profit and revenue for the October-December period topped analysts’ projections, providing another boost to a stock that has more than doubled in less than 13 months.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The shares surged more than 1% to $322.14 in extended trading after the numbers came out. That’s up from $142 in January 2019 after Apple warned that consumers weren’t buying as many new iPhones as they once were, especially in China, the company’s biggest market outside the U.S. and Europe. China is also where Apple makes most of its iPhones and several other products.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">If the shares move similarly in Wednesday's regular trading session, they will flirt with a new all-time high for the stock and further cement Apple's position as the most valuable company in the U.S., with a market value of $1.4 trillion.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">A deadly viral outbreak in China, which has curtailed travel and threatens the world economy, looms as a potential concern for Apple. But investors for now are focusing on what looks like an even more prosperous road ahead for a company that turned a $55 billion profit in its past fiscal year.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">In a conference call Tuesday, CEO Tim Cook said the coronavirus outbreak has already caused some of Apple's suppliers in China to delay reopening their factories closed for the Lunar New Year holiday from the end of this month until Feb. 10. And some stores in China selling Apple products already have temporarily closed or reduced their operating hours because fewer customers are shopping as virus worries escalate.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“The situation is emerging and we're still gathering lots of data points and monitoring it very closely," Cook said.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Apple got off to a fast start for fiscal 2020, with a first-quarter profit of $22.2 billion, or $4.99 per share, on revenue of $91.8 billion. Analysts polled by FactSet had predicted earnings of $4.54 per share on revenue of $88.5 billion.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">As usual, the iPhone remained Apple’s marquee attraction. Boosted by the release of the iPhone 11 heading into the holiday season, the product generated sales of $56 billion, an 8% increase from the previous year’s disappointing showing.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Besides rolling out high-end phones with more cameras and a starting price of $1,000, Apple sold a more basic model starting at $700 — a $50 drop from a comparable version released in 2018.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Apple’s division that includes its app store, product warranties, music streaming and a new Netflix-like video service delivered revenue of $12.7 billion, up 17% from the previous year. Apple is hoping its service division will produce revenue of at least $50 billion this year, doubling its output in just four years. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The services division is feeding into all iPhones, iPads, Macs and other Apple products already being used, which the company said Tuesday now totals 1.5 billion devices, up by 100 million from the previous year. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“We see this as a powerful testament to the satisfaction, engagement and loyalty of our customers — and a great driver of our growth across the board," Cook said.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The Apple TV Plus video streaming service, which Apple launched amid great fanfare in October, is supposed to help that cause, but it may not be a huge contributor this year. That’s because Apple is initially selling it for just $5 per month to help drum up interest. That's less than half the price of Netflix’s most popular plan. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">What’s more, Apple is giving away a free year of Apple TV Plus to anyone who buys a new iPhone or several other devices, a promotion that means tens of millions of people aren’t paying anything for the service yet. Apple hasn't released subscription numbers for the video service.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Meanwhile, the Apple Watch, which the company began selling nearly five years ago, continued to gain new converts, and the latest version of its wireless earbuds, AirPods, emerged as a hot commodity during the holiday season.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Apple introduced the AirPods after removing the headphone jack from the iPhone in 2016, but the product picked up more momentum in October with a next-generation set designed to fit better in people’s ears. That version, called AirPods Pro, proved so popular that Apple had trouble keeping it in stock. The AirPods Pro also cost more at $250, compared with $160 to $200 for the previous models.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">All those factors helped Apple’s “wearables, home and accessories” category garner sales totaling $10 billion in the past quarter, a 37% increase from the previous year. That prompted Cook to hail it as a “blowout” quarter for the wearables and accessories division, which is now Apple's fastest growing category.</p>, <p>Advertisement</p>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd" id="site-index-label">Site Index</h2>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-0">news</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-1">opinion</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-2">arts</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-3">living</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-4">more</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-subscribe-label">Subscribe</h3>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd">Site Information Navigation</h2>]
[<p>Advertisement</p>, <p>Supported by</p>, <p class="css-c2jxua e6idgb70"></p>, <h1 class="css-1j5ig2m e1h9rw200" id="link-385bb3a8" itemprop="headline"><span>For Fed,' Material Reassessment' May Be in Eye of Beholder</span></h1>, <p class="css-1fv7b6t e1jsehar1" itemprop="author" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">By<!-- --> <span class="css-1baulvz last-byline" itemprop="name">Reuters</span></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">WASHINGTON — At a glance, the Federal Reserve has set a high bar for any change in interest rates this year: A "material reassessment" of the economic outlook would be required as set forth by U.S. central bank chief Jerome Powell.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Since introducing that idea in October as he called a halt to last year's mini-rate cut cycle, Powell himself has uttered the term at least half a dozen times, and the phrase has peppered remarks from other policymakers as well.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">But a closer listen reveals significant distinctions among the Fed's 17 policymakers as to what "material reassessment" means. And that may complicate efforts to understand what might prompt the next rate move as economic data spool out during the U.S. presidential election campaign this year. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Obvious shocks will matter, and the sharp shift in markets following a coronavirus outbreak in China shows just how fast unexpected events can start to reshape the outlook. Major stock indexes were down sharply on Monday, oil prices and the U.S. dollar rose, and economic analysts saw a potential hit to Chinese and possibly global economic growth as the death toll from the virus rose and a major Chinese city was quarantined. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Carefully watched bond spreads narrowed, and investors started pushing forward their estimates of a Fed rate move, with now roughly even odds the central bank will cut rates again by the end of June.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">What will convince individual policymakers, however, varies widely. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">(GRAPHIC: The Fed's material world - https://fingfx.thomsonreuters.com/gfx/mkt/13/1526/1501/Pasted%20Image.jpg)</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Will consumer behavior be the obvious tell, as Atlanta Fed President Raphael Bostic thinks? That would leave rates on hold as long as people keep spending.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Or, as Minneapolis Fed President Neel Kashkari contends, would the failure of wages to grow faster be a sign the economy is weakening and be enough on its own to warrant more rate cuts?</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">What if inflation remains stuck below the Fed's 2% target? Would that warrant a rate cut in hopes of lifting it? St. Louis Fed President James Bullard suggests so, calling it the Fed's "unifying theme ... That (inflation) has got to get better."</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Not so fast, says Cleveland Fed President Loretta Mester. "I would not at this point want to take deliberate action just to try to get inflation back up," she said in a recent interview.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Mester is concerned last year's three rate cuts could encourage excessive risk taking by households, companies and investors taking advantage of cheap credit. On the other hand, a "deterioration" of public attitudes about inflation might change her mind.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Fed officials will continue their debate when they gather on Tuesday for the first policy meeting of the year. Financial markets do not expect the Fed to change its benchmark overnight lending rate at the end of the meeting on Wednesday.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">'OPEN TO INTERPRETATION'</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Economic data since the Fed's last meeting in December have, if anything, enforced the central bank's consensus view of an economy that will keep motoring along, though some of the numbers have been uneven. December jobs and retail spending were healthy, for example, but the outlook from factory purchasing managers was sour for a fifth straight month. Growth overall is expected to be around 2% for the year.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">As Mester notes, it adds to the dilemma of sorting out just what could change the Fed's current "wait-and-see" approach.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">"I do think our communications could be crisper," she said earlier this month in reference to what "material reassessment" means. "We use words like that, and they are open to interpretation." </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">That may have been the point. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Both "material reassessment" and the need for "persistent" higher inflation were introduced as rate change benchmarks through a less formal channel. Rather than appearing in the Fed's official statement after each policy meeting, they came from Powell himself in press conferences in October and December.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">His comments left open just what could prompt a move lower, and just how high or "persistent" inflation would need to be for the Fed to lean against it with higher rates. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Minutes of the October policy meeting as well as recent interviews with policymakers indicate the aim of the new language was to keep a high bar for further moves while also letting each official see it as consistent with their view of what is needed to move again in either direction.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">So where Mester remains focused on financial stability as a reason not to cut rates, Bullard suggests a quicker trigger if prices remain stuck because "you have to take some risk" with a higher pace of inflation to convince the public the Fed's target is meaningful.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">'BIG-TENT LANGUAGE' </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The Fed has run into problems before when it tried to resolve background disagreements with public remarks outside the official statement. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">In preparing to slow its bond purchases in 2013, policymakers left much of the explaining to then-Fed Chair Ben Bernanke. That ended with a broad sell-off in global bond markets, known as the "taper tantrum," when the Fed's plans came off as more aggressive than intended.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">That lesson learned, when the Fed changed its language in late 2014 to indicate officials would be "patient" in deciding when to raise rates for the first time since the financial crisis, they agreed the word should be explicitly defined by Bernanke's successor, Janet Yellen, in her press conference. She clarified it meant at least a two-meeting wait.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Minutes of the October meeting, when the Fed cut rates for the third and, for now, final time, suggest the phrase "material reassessment" served this time as a sort of handy catch-all. "Most participants" agreed it would describe their sensitivity to upcoming events after that final rate cut, even if they emphasized different things. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">It wasn't unanimous. "A couple" of policymakers on the rate-setting Federal Open Market Committee wanted more explicit language to say no further cuts were coming unless economic data was "consistent with a significant slowdown."</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">But it did offer flexibility for a policymaking body that may have reached a common landing spot for now. No one is openly arguing for a change in rates anytime soon, though they have different ideas about where to go next.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">"It is big-tent language," Bullard said. "It matters that it is not in the statement. The committee did not have to come to a decision to put it in. That probably does mean that different people will have different interpretations."</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"> (Reporting by Howard Schneider; Additional reporting by Ann Saphir; Editing by Dan Burns and Paul Simao)</p>, <p>Advertisement</p>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd" id="site-index-label">Site Index</h2>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-0">news</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-1">opinion</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-2">arts</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-3">living</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-4">more</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-subscribe-label">Subscribe</h3>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd">Site Information Navigation</h2>]
[<p>Advertisement</p>, <p>Supported by</p>, <h1 class="css-1s4ffep e1h9rw200" id="link-78ef9ac0" itemprop="headline"><span>Impeachment, Israel, Roger Federer: Your Tuesday Evening Briefing</span></h1>, <p class="css-1ifw933 e1wiw3jv0" id="article-summary">Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.</p>, <p class="css-1fv7b6t e1jsehar1" itemprop="author" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">By<!-- --> <a class="css-brehiz e1jsehar0" href="https://www.nytimes.com/by/remy-tumin"><span class="css-1baulvz" itemprop="name">Remy Tumin</span></a> and <a class="css-brehiz e1jsehar0" href="https://www.nytimes.com/by/hiroko-masuike"><span class="css-1baulvz last-byline" itemprop="name">Hiroko Masuike</span></a></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">(Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s </em><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="http://www.nytimes.com/newsletters/nyt-now-evening-briefing?module=inline" title=""><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">the sign-up</em></a><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">.) </em></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">Good evening. Here’s the latest.</em></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">1. President Trump’s defense team</strong> wrapped up its oral arguments, urging the Senate to “end the era of impeachment” <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/28/us/politics/trumps-defense-team-discounts-bolton-as-republicans-work-to-hold-off-witnesses.html" title="">by declaring the president not guilty</a>.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">His lawyers, above, derided a new claim by Mr. Trump’s former national security adviser, John Bolton, that Mr. Trump had tied the release of military aid to Ukraine to investigations into the Bidens as an “unsourced allegation” that should be “inadmissible” in the trial.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Over the past three days, the president’s team has focused less on defending Mr. Trump’s actions than on convincing senators that those actions did not rise to impeachable offenses. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Starting Wednesday, senators will spend up to 16 hours over two days questioning each side’s lawyers. A vote on whether to hear witnesses in the trial is expected on Friday. Senator Mitch McConnell is said to have told Republicans that he <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/live/2020/impeachment-trial-live-01-28#mcconnell-democrats-witnesses" title="">does not currently have the votes</a> to block the measure. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">2. President Trump</strong> unveiled his Middle East peace plan in Washington in the presence of only one party in the conflict, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">What Mr. Trump called a “win-win” proposal <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/28/world/middleeast/peace-plan.html" title="">guarantees Israeli control of a unified Jerusalem</a>, does not require it to uproot any West Bank settlements and creates a Palestinian state with limited sovereignty. Analysts saw the document as a distraction offered by a president under impeachment working with a prime minister under criminal indictment.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The Palestinian leadership immediately rejected the proposal, which discards the idea of a full-fledged Palestinian state. <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/28/world/middleeast/israel-west-bank-annex-sovereignty.html" title="">Israel’s government plans a vote on Sunday</a> that would apply Israeli sovereignty to West Bank settlements and the strategic Jordan Valley.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">3. In Britain, </strong>Prime Minister Boris Johnson broke with President Trump over Huawei.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Despite pressure on Britain to bar the Chinese technology giant from its new 5G broadband network, Mr. Johnson <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/28/technology/britain-huawei-5G.html" title="">decided to grant Huawei limited access</a>. It is the latest sign that the U.S. campaign against Huawei is faltering.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The move also creates <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/28/world/europe/johnson-trump-hwawei-rift.html" title="">a possible rift between Mr. Johnson and Mr. Trump</a> at the very moment that Britain is leaving the European Union, and before talks toward a trans-Atlantic trade deal. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">4. The number of known cases</strong> of the coronavirus rose by nearly 60 percent overnight. Above, disinfection in Qingdao, China.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">China said confirmed cases had increased to 4,515, and that 106 people had died. The youngest case is a 9-month-old girl in Beijing. <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/28/world/asia/china-travel-coronoavirus.html" title="">Here’s the latest</a>.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">As infections skyrocketed, officials expanded travel restrictions and screenings. Hong Kong said the territory would strictly limit visitors from mainland China, and the <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/28/health/airports-screening-coronavirus.html" title="">U.S. will screen travelers</a> arriving from Wuhan, the epicenter of the outbreak, at 20 ports of entry, up from five.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">5. In the 2020 race, </strong>we take a look at Pete Buttigieg’s struggle with minority voters — and his campaign staff.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Some staff members of color said working for a candidate with so <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/28/us/politics/buttigieg-campaign-black-hispanic-staff.html" title="">little support from black and Hispanic voters</a> had become demoralizing. One said that people of color felt they were employed in order to help the campaign meet its ambitious diversity targets.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Elsewhere on the campaign trail, President Trump’s impeachment trial is keeping senators far from Iowa for the second week in a row, so <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/28/us/politics/democrats-iowa-aoc.html" title="">their stand-ins have become the main attraction</a>. Among them are Representative Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez, the actress Ashley Judd and Jonathan Van Ness of “Queer Eye.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">6. Kobe Bryant’s impact </strong>was felt far beyond the basketball court.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">We spoke to one of his high school English teachers about their friendship, which endured <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/28/us/kobe-bryant-lower-merion-jeanne-mastriano.html" title="">over more than two decades</a>. “We managed to get through lots of years, and really were there for each other,” Jeanne Mastriano, pictured above with Bryant last year, told us.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/28/sports/kobe-bryant-philadelphia.html" title="">His high school team is set to play tonight</a>. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Our former deputy sports editor reflects on <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/27/sports/kobe-bryant-fans.html" title="">why Bryant’s death means so much to so many</a>, and Talia Caldwell, a professional women’s basketball player, writes in Opinion about <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/27/opinion/kobe-bryant-women-basketball.html" title="">why the W.N.B.A. loved him</a>.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Investigators said they would explore all possible causes of Sunday’s helicopter crash, including mechanical failure. They also said that all nine bodies had now been recovered. <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/28/sports/basketball/kobe-bryant-death.html" title="">Here are the latest developments</a>.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">7. After a second nail-biting victory</strong> in the Australian Open, Roger Federer will face off against Novak Djokovic in the semifinals.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Federer saved seven match points against Tennys Sandgren in the fourth set of their quarterfinal, and will now <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/28/sports/tennis/australian-open-federer-djokovic.html" title="">play Djokovic for the 50th time</a> early Thursday.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Ashleigh Barty is two wins away from winning a Grand Slam title in her home country, which <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/28/sports/tennis/australian-open-ashleigh-barty.html" title="">no Australian woman has done since 1978</a>. She is scheduled to play Sofia Kenin, an American who is seeded 14th, on Thursday for a spot in the final.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">8. Fort Worth </strong>is embracing its cowboy culture with an eye toward the future. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The Texas city of nearly 900,000 people is <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/28/business/fort-worth-dickies-arena-rodeo.html" title="">taking advantage of its longhorn heritage</a> with hopes to become a major sports and entertainment center. Its new $540 million arena will host one of the world’s oldest indoor rodeos, and the city is reinvigorating its stockyards district.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Our architecture critic is thinking about city planning in a different way. For many, the word “density” conjures up overcrowding and congestion. <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/28/arts/density-housing-skyscraper-museum.html" title="">But density is not the enemy, he says</a>.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">9. Pop-ups</strong> were once seen by young chefs as a steppingstone to a restaurant. Now, they are using the temporary eateries as a way to <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/28/dining/pop-up-dinners.html" title="">explore their personal memories and culinary traditions</a>.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“We want to recreate a Sunday night at my grandma’s place,” said Stephanie Bonnin, above, a Colombian-born chef.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">On the beverage scene, we also looked at how mead went from <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/28/nyregion/mead-honey-wine-brooklyn-new-york.html" title="">a medieval honey wine</a> to New York’s next cool drink, and went on a <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/28/travel/costa-rica-coffee-tours.html" title="">four-day coffee tasting journey in Costa Rica</a>. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">10. And finally, </strong>capturing the unexpected. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Wedding photographers usually have a shot list — a must-capture catalog of photos that each couple insists on — but there’s a certain delight in the spontaneous, like a snowy parking lot in Snoqualmie, Wash., above. We asked 12 photographers to <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/28/fashion/weddings/wedding-photographers-share-their-favorite-moments.html" title="">share their most candid shots</a>.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“You always look for these rare moments,” one longtime wedding photographer said. “They don’t always happen, but when they do, it’s magic.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">And if you think you have one that fits the bill, <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/28/fashion/weddings/wedding-album-do-you-have-an-unexpected-photo-from-your-wedding-day.html" title="">you can submit it here</a>.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Have an unexpectedly lovely night.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">Your Evening Briefing is posted at 6 p.m. Eastern.</em></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">And don’t miss Your Morning Briefing. </em><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2018/briefing/global-morning-briefing-newsletter-signup.html" title=""><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">Sign up here</em></a><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0"> to get it by email in the Australian, Asian, European, African or American morning.</em></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">Want to catch up on past briefings? </em><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/series/us-evening-briefing" title=""><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">You can browse them here</em></a><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">.</em></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">What did you like? What do you want to see here? Let us know at </em><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="mailto:briefing@nytimes.com?subject=Evening%20Briefing%20Feedback" title=""><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">briefing@nytimes.com</em></a><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">.</em></p>, <p>Advertisement</p>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd" id="site-index-label">Site Index</h2>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-0">news</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-1">opinion</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-2">arts</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-3">living</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-4">more</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-subscribe-label">Subscribe</h3>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd">Site Information Navigation</h2>]
[<p>Advertisement</p>, <p>Supported by</p>, <p class="css-tsacue e6idgb70">California Today</p>, <h1 class="css-1s4ffep e1h9rw200" id="link-7dceb4bd" itemprop="headline"><span>Young Crash Victims Shared Kobe Bryant’s Passion for Basketball </span></h1>, <p class="css-1ifw933 e1wiw3jv0" id="article-summary">Tuesday: More details emerge about the helicopter crash that killed Kobe Bryant. Also: An early encounter with the star.</p>, <p class="css-1fv7b6t e1jsehar1" itemprop="author" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">By<!-- --> <a class="css-brehiz e1jsehar0" href="https://www.nytimes.com/by/jill-cowan"><span class="css-1baulvz last-byline" itemprop="name">Jill Cowan</span></a></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">Good morning.</em></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">(Here’s </em><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/newsletters/california-today" title=""><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">the sign-up</em></a><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">, if you don’t already get California Today by email.)</em></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">On Monday, as more information emerged about the helicopter crash that killed nine people, including <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/02/06/us/kobe-bryant-island-express-helicopters.html" title="">Kobe Bryant</a> and his 13-year-old daughter, Gianna, the <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/27/sports/basketball/kobe-bryant-confidence.html" title="">sports</a> world grappled with the sudden loss of a towering, complicated figure.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Here’s what to know:</strong></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">While fans — </strong><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10"><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/27/us/kobe-bryant-latino-fans-los-angeles.html" title="">particularly Latinos</a></strong><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">, who embraced Mr. Bryant as one of their own — continued to grieve for him and his daughter, families and friends began to mourn the seven other victims of the crash</strong>, <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/27/us/who-died-helicopter-crash-kobe-altobelli-chester-zobayan-mauser.html?action=click&amp;pgtype=Article&amp;state=default&amp;module=STYLN_kobe_menu&amp;variant=1_kobe_menu&amp;region=header&amp;context=menu" title="">my colleagues reported</a>.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Among the victims were John Altobelli, the longtime coach of Orange Coast College’s baseball team; his wife, Keri; and their daughter, Alyssa, who was scheduled to play in a youth basketball tournament.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Sarah Chester and her daughter Payton, also a 13-year-old basketball player, were remembered as part of a loving Corona del Mar family, “full of mischief and laughter.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Christina Mauser had coached Gianna Bryant at a Newport Beach school, before Mr. Bryant, who crowned her “Mother of Defense,” hired her to coach for a team at his Mamba Academy.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">And the pilot, Ara Zobayan, of Huntington Beach, was remembered as a kind man and an experienced, capable aviator.</p>, <p class="css-15hwz5e evys1bk0">Read more about the lives that ended in the crash. [<a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/27/us/who-died-helicopter-crash-kobe-altobelli-chester-zobayan-mauser.html?action=click&amp;pgtype=Article&amp;state=default&amp;module=STYLN_kobe_menu&amp;variant=1_kobe_menu&amp;region=header&amp;context=menu" title="">The New York Times</a>]</p>, <p class="css-15hwz5e evys1bk0">Also, the <strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Orange Coast College baseball team</strong> is set to continue with its season opener today: “I think ‘Alto’ would want us to play.” [<a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.ocregister.com/2020/01/27/orange-coast-college-baseball-still-grieving-the-death-of-coach-john-altobelli-will-play-its-season-opener-tuesday/" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">The Orange County Register</a>]</p>, <p class="css-15hwz5e evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">The Lakers-Clippers game </strong>scheduled for tonight has been postponed. [<a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/27/sports/kobe-bryant-death.html#link-118e33a5" title="">The New York Times</a>]</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">The helicopter involved in the crash</strong> <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/27/us/kobe-bryant-helicopter-crash.html" title="">had gotten special approval</a> to fly in weather so foggy that a witness nearby said people were having trouble driving.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The pilot was both certified to fly under instrument conditions — meaning he could navigate even with low visibility — and certified to teach others. But if he had switched to instrument conditions, he would have had to land at an airport.</p>, <p class="css-15hwz5e evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Read more</strong> about the luxury helicopter, which Mr. Bryant at one point took to calling the “Mamba Chopper.” [<a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/27/us/kobe-bryant-sikorsky-helicopter.html?" title="">The New York Times</a>]</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Mr. Bryant’s death led to difficult discussions</strong> over how to understand the legacy of a man who was accused of sexual assault, but also was a fiercely loved hero to many.</p>, <p class="css-15hwz5e evys1bk0">Here’s <strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">a look back at the case, which played out long before the #MeToo era</strong>. [<a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/27/sports/basketball/kobe-bryant-rape-case.html" title="">The New York Times</a>]</p>, <p class="css-15hwz5e evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">When the Washington Post reporter Felicia Sonmez tweeted</strong> a link to an article detailing the allegation, she was harassed and threatened by fans of Mr. Bryant. Ms. Sonmez was suspended, prompting a backlash from other journalists, including 200 of her colleagues. [<a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/27/business/media/kobe-bryant-washington-post-felicia-sonmez.html" title="">The New York Times</a>]</p>, <p class="css-15hwz5e evys1bk0">Erika D. Smith wrote in a column that neither <strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Mr. Bryant nor the late rapper Nipsey Hussle was a saint</strong>. But, she contended, they both spent their lives working to demonstrate that “while you can never erase what you have done, personal growth is a thing and that it is within each of us.” [<a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.latimes.com/california/story/2020-01-27/kobe-bryant-nipsey-hussle-death-grammy-tribute" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">The Los Angeles Times</a>]</p>, <p class="css-15hwz5e evys1bk0">Louisa Thomas wrote that <strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Mr. Bryant’s true power was as a storyteller</strong> — and that included how he shaped the world’s view of his ugly chapters and his great ones. [<a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.newyorker.com/sports/sporting-scene/death-of-kobe-bryant-basketballs-great-storyteller" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">The New Yorker</a>]</p>, <p class="css-15hwz5e evys1bk0">Talia Caldwell, a professional women’s basketball player, wrote, “I can’t say that I have reconciled my thoughts about this incident with how I feel about his legacy of support for women’s basketball.” Still, <strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">she hopes Mr. Bryant will be remembered as a powerful ally</strong> whose cerebral style inspired players of all sizes. [<a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/27/opinion/kobe-bryant-women-basketball.html?action=click&amp;module=Opinion&amp;pgtype=Homepage" title="">New York Times Opinion</a>]</p>, <h2 class="css-3ez4hu eoo0vm40" id="link-42fcec18">Here’s what else we’re following</h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">We often link to sites that limit access for nonsubscribers. We appreciate your reading Times coverage, but we also encourage you to support local news if you can.</em></p>, <p class="css-15hwz5e evys1bk0">On Sunday, health officials confirmed <strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">two cases of the dangerous coronavirus in California</strong>, one in Los Angeles County and one in Orange County. That brings the total to <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2020/01/21/world/asia/china-coronavirus-maps.html" title="">five in the U.S.</a> [<a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.ocregister.com/2020/01/26/coronavirus-patients-confirmed-in-los-angeles-and-orange-counties/" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">The Orange County Register</a>]</p>, <p class="css-15hwz5e evys1bk0">And on Monday evening, health officials said <strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">they were looking into a potential new case in San Diego County</strong>. [<a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.sandiegouniontribune.com/news/health/story/2020-01-27/potential-coronavirus-case-under-investigation-in-san-diego-county" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">The San Diego Union-Tribune</a>]</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">Looking to catch up on the international outbreak? </em><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10"><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">Here’s what you need to know.</em></strong><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0"> [</em><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/article/what-is-coronavirus.html" title=""><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">The New York Times</em></a><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">]</em></p>, <p class="css-15hwz5e evys1bk0">Behind-the-scenes communications show <strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">that the private prison operator GEO Group</strong>, in spite of a law effectively barring it from the state, is continuing to expand. Its facility in the city of Adelanto is a case study. [<a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.desertsun.com/in-depth/news/2020/01/24/private-prison-giant-geo-thrives-california-state-wants-out/2589589001/" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">The Desert Sun</a>]</p>, <p class="css-15hwz5e evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">New DNA technology helped officials tie a Delano man</strong> to the gruesome murders of five of his infant children. [<a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/27/us/paul-perez-california-infant-murders.html" title="">The New York Times</a>]</p>, <p class="css-15hwz5e evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">San Francisco’s police union is battling with its new district attorney,</strong> Chesa Boudin, this time over Mr. Boudin’s decision to withdraw charges against a man who was shot by the police, who said the man had attacked officers with a bottle. [<a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.sfchronicle.com/crime/article/SF-police-union-calls-on-feds-to-prosecute-man-15008195.php" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">The San Francisco Chronicle</a>]</p>, <p class="css-15hwz5e evys1bk0">In the impeachment battle, there are <strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Californians on the front lines — for both sides.</strong> [<a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/27/us/Impeachment-california-Adam-Schiff-Devin-Nunes.html?" title="">The New York Times</a>]</p>, <p class="css-15hwz5e evys1bk0">Some residents of <strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Santa Rosa’s two-mile long, 250-resident homeless encampment on the Joe Rodota Trail </strong>were moved into tiny houses at a camp about nine miles east. It was a slow start, but a start. [<a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.pressdemocrat.com/news/10627225-181/clearing-of-santa-rosa-homeless?sba=AAS" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">The Press Democrat</a>]</p>, <h2 class="css-3ez4hu eoo0vm40" id="link-1681830d">And Finally …</h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">We asked you to share any favorite memories of watching Kobe Bryant play basketball, or any encounters off the court.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">We got lots of responses: A grandfather stood next to him as they both waited for their families at the end of “Mr. Toad’s Wild Ride”; a fellow parishioner at Our Lady Queen of Angels in Newport Beach asked for prayers.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">But one story stood out. It came from Celeste Perez, who was 9 years old in 1996, when Mr. Bryant was signed by the Lakers.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Ms. Perez wrote that her Filipino-American family had followed the draft closely that year, and they were surprised when they seemed to be the only ones who recognized Mr. Bryant, hanging out by himself at Universal CityWalk, a short time after he arrived.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“Wearing an all-white ensemble and a beret to top it off, Kobe looked like a lost member of Boyz II Men,” she wrote.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The big group sent its most basketball-savvy cousin to congratulate Mr. Bryant, whose face, Ms. Perez recalled, lit up. He motioned for the rest to come over, too.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">In lieu of a photo or an autograph (the family had run out of film and didn’t have paper handy) and “in true Filipino fashion,” she said, the family invited him to join them for dinner at Bubba Gump Shrimp Co. He politely declined.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">But later, he tracked them down, bearing a postcard signed “Kobe Bryant #8.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“I noticed he had other postcards that he’d practiced his autograph on,” Ms. Perez wrote. “We must have been among the first to ask him.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Ms. Perez’s family promised to watch “every one of his games as a Laker.” They didn’t know they’d be watching for two decades.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">California Today goes live at 6:30 a.m. Pacific time weekdays. Tell us what you want to see: </em><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="mailto:CAtoday@nytimes.com" title=""><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">CAtoday@nytimes.com</em></a><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">. Were you forwarded this email? </em><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/newsletters/california-today?module=inline" title=""><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">Sign up for California Today here.</em></a></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">Jill Cowan grew up in Orange County, graduated from U.C. Berkeley and has reported all over the state, including the Bay Area, Bakersfield and Los Angeles — but she always wants to see more. Follow along here or on Twitter, </em><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://twitter.com/JillCowan" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title=""><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">@jillcowan</em></a><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">.</em></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">California Today is edited by Julie Bloom, who grew up in Los Angeles and graduated from U.C. Berkeley.</em></p>, <p>Advertisement</p>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd" id="site-index-label">Site Index</h2>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-0">news</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-1">opinion</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-2">arts</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-3">living</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-4">more</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-subscribe-label">Subscribe</h3>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd">Site Information Navigation</h2>]
[<p>Advertisement</p>, <p>Supported by</p>, <p class="css-c2jxua e6idgb70"></p>, <h1 class="css-1j5ig2m e1h9rw200" id="link-1e91ed95" itemprop="headline"><span>Wuhan Officials Face Questions, Anger Over Virus Response</span></h1>, <p class="css-1fv7b6t e1jsehar1" itemprop="author" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">By<!-- --> <span class="css-1baulvz last-byline" itemprop="name">The Associated Press</span></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">BEIJING — Last Wednesday evening, top officials in the central Chinese city of Wuhan settled into their seats at an auditorium for a Lunar New Year gala — even as a new virus that originated in their city was spreading rapidly. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Dozens of actors, actresses and musicians performed, some despite having sniffles and sneezes, the Hubei Folk Song and Dance Ensemble said in a now-deleted social media post.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The next morning, residents woke to news that officials had ordered the city sealed, its airport closed and its train and bus stations shut down. Thousands of people flooded Wuhan's hospitals, which pleaded for donations of masks, disinfectant and medical supplies as overworked doctors and nurses grappled with the crowds. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">It wasn’t long before simmering anger exploded online. Hundreds fumed at a report on the festivities on Weibo, a Chinese social media platform, asking why officials were enjoy gala shows instead of dealing with the epidemic or shortages of supplies.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">As China institutes one of the largest quarantines in modern history, locking down more than 50 million people in Wuhan and other cities in Hubei province, questions are swirling about the city and provincial governments’ sluggish initial response to an outbreak that has infected thousands of people and killed more than 100. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">For two weeks, from Jan. 5 to 16, the city reported virtually no new cases, while hundreds of officials gathered in Wuhan, the provincial capital, for Hubei's two biggest political meetings of the year. It was only after a medical team dispatched by the National Health Commission went to investigate on Jan. 19 that the severity of the situation became public.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“Wuhan must immediately change its chief!” Zhang Oufa, a journalist with the government-run Hubei Daily newspaper, thundered in a Weibo post. “Under these abnormal, grave circumstances that keep getting worse by the day, Wuhan’s current leader just doesn’t have what it takes to lead!”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">His comments were swiftly removed. The paper rushed out an apology, saying it was deeply sorry for “disrupting ongoing work on epidemic prevention” and “causing difficulties for leaders at various levels.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Zhang has continued to post thinly veiled criticisms of city officials, and leading business magazine Caixin has published stories from the front lines, interviewing exhausted doctors and nurses and reporting long waits and supply shortages. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The fact that these reports are getting through China's censors is likely a tacit sign of the central leadership’s displeasure.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“Wuhan authorities clearly downplayed or made efforts to hide the situation for an extended period of time,” said Dali Yang, a professor of Chinese politics at the University of Chicago. “It turned out to be one of the worst decisions that they'll regret all their lives.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Wuhan's mayor, Zhou Xianwang, defended his actions in an unusually tough interview with state broadcaster CCTV on Monday, offering to step down over his decision to close the city — not because of any delays in reporting the epidemic. He said the city government was slow to disclose information about the virus due to national regulations.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“As a local government official, I could disclose information only after being authorized,” Zhou said. "A lot of people didn’t understand this.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Phone calls to the Wuhan party committee publicity department rang unanswered Monday and Tuesday, and their fax machines were turned off.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Chinese health officials informed the World Health Organization about the new virus on Dec. 31. By Jan. 8, it had been identified as a new coronavirus, a large family that causes the common cold and more serious illnesses including SARS, which also began in China. By Jan. 12, Chinese scientists had sequenced the virus’ genetic makeup and shared it with WHO, drawing praise for their transparency and swift action.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">In contrast, the Wuhan heath commission reported no new cases from Jan. 5 to 10 and again from Jan. 12 to 16.
