China’s Lunar New Year rush —the world’s largest annual human migration — began to get underway, with millions of people passing through Wuhan, a major transit hub.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">A recently submitted complaint to the National Health Commission alleged that during this period, officials with the Wuhan health commission told doctors they were not allowed to report about the new virus, letting patients wander around freely instead of being isolated.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“We have countless medical workers who, because they weren't aware of the situation, got cut down at the front lines,” said the complaint, whose author said they were a Wuhan doctor. “Because of the coverup of the Wuhan Municipal Health Commission and other leaders, they made unnecessary sacrifices!"</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">A volunteer coordinating donations to hospitals in Wuhan heard from doctors and nurses that in early January, it became apparent that many medical workers treating patients were falling ill themselves. They raised the alarm, but with little effect.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The sluggish response meant that for weeks, medical staff made do without proper protection, the volunteer said, speaking on condition of anonymity for fear of retribution against the doctors and nurses. Even now, some medical staff are using garbage bags and cut-up water bottles as makeshift gowns and masks, the volunteer said. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“When we first discovered it could be transmitted between people, our hospital head, chairman, medical affairs department, they sat and made endless calls to the city government, the health commission,” one nurse, who fell ill and was put in isolation, wrote in messages shared by the volunteer. “They said we still can’t wear protective clothing, because it might stir up panic.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Not all the blame can be placed on local officials, health and governance experts say. The broader issue is that local officials can be punished for reporting bad news to higher officials. The Chinese government’s rigidity, and a lack of transparency and accountability to the general public means problems like the virus epidemic can fester hidden away until it is too late.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“There’s a tendency in terms of the Chinese bureaucratic accountability system to view a governance failure as the fault of a particular government official or group of officials, as opposed to a symptom of a broader governance challenge,” says John Yasuda, an Indiana University professor studying politics and regulatory failures in China. “Officials are likely to be a bit more hesitant to report simply because they don't want to be caught with the hot potato.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">As the National Health Commission team came to Wuhan to investigate on Jan. 19, tens of thousands of people tucked into a mass banquet of 13,986 dishes contributed from neighborhood families. Pictures in state media showed nobody wearing masks while they shared rice cakes, fish, and other Lunar New Year delicacies.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Even after the head of the team announced that the virus could spread from person to person, and the number of reported cases began soaring, crowds of pedestrians thronged the streets of Wuhan early last week. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“I heard about it earlier this month, but I didn’t pay much attention,” said Helen Cao on Jan. 21, pausing after an afternoon shopping on Wuhan’s busiest pedestrian street. “It should be fine. All the sick people are in hospitals, it’s not really an emergency.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Growing anxiety over the virus is evoking memories of the ruling Communist Party’s slow response to the 2002 emergence of SARS, or Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome. Even after SARS had spread globally, China sought to conceal the number of cases by parking patients in hotels and obscure hospital wings, and driving them around in ambulances to avoid detection by World Health Organization experts.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">This time, action from the central government has been swifter. There are signs the central government in Beijing may act against city and provincial-level officials it deems responsible for the crisis.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">China’s cabinet, the State Council, issued a public call Friday for whistleblowers, opening up channels for people to submit complaints about cover-ups or delays in reporting cases. It promised cases would be “dealt with seriously."</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Yanzhong Huang, a senior fellow for the study of global health at the Council of Foreign Relations, believes authorities are being much more responsive, now that the central government has acted. But Huang says the fact that the disease had been allowed to fester for so long shows deep-rooted problems with increasingly strict political controls under President Xi Jinping.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“The atmosphere is such now, we see rapid centralization of political power,” Huang said “That created a political atmosphere where people are afraid to speak up… They are very reluctant to share any useful information, and that is actually becoming a challenge.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">A 63-year-old retiree who would be identified only his last name, Xia, said he had to stay overnight Thursday to get his feverish wife care, waiting in lines with nearly a hundred people for a doctor’s check and a CT scan and staying in the hospital until 7 in the morning. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Xia wondered why there were so few medical staff, and saw a nurse passed out in exhaustion. When he got home, he saw notices online telling sick people to stay home and avoid bothering overworked hospitals.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“I feel very helpless,” he said by phone, despite warnings from a superior not to speak to media. “Who’s going to give us advice or suggestions? I have no friends working in hospitals.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Amid Wuhan's now-empty streets and pharmacies running low on supplies, Xia feels more and more anxious. He hopes help will soon be on the way.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“Ordinary people really hope the government will take action instead of make empty talk,” he said. “I trust the government.”</p>, <p>Advertisement</p>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd" id="site-index-label">Site Index</h2>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-0">news</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-1">opinion</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-2">arts</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-3">living</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-4">more</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-subscribe-label">Subscribe</h3>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd">Site Information Navigation</h2>]
[<p>Advertisement</p>, <p>Supported by</p>, <h1 class="css-1s4ffep e1h9rw200" id="link-143de70b" itemprop="headline"><span>More Than 7,700 Cases of Coronavirus Recorded Worldwide</span></h1>, <p class="css-1ifw933 e1wiw3jv0" id="article-summary">Chinese officials have confirmed over 7,700 cases of the mysterious illness as foreign governments airlifted their citizens out of Wuhan, the outbreak’s epicenter.<span class="css-8l6xbc evw5hdy0"> </span></p>, <p class="css-1fv7b6t e1jsehar1" itemprop="author" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">By<!-- --> <span class="css-1baulvz last-byline" itemprop="name">The New York Times</span></p>, <h2 class="css-3ez4hu eoo0vm40" id="link-555c042f">China now has more cases of coronavirus than it had of SARS. </h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Mainland <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/02/10/upshot/coronavirus-risk-prevention-advice.html" title="">China</a> now has more cases of <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/02/10/upshot/coronavirus-risk-prevention-advice.html" title="">coronavirus</a> than it had of SARS, a respiratory infection that spread across China in 2002 and 2003 and killed 774 people in 17 countries.<span class="css-8l6xbc evw5hdy0"> </span>During the SARS outbreak, China had 5,327 cases and 349 deaths, according to the World Health Organization.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The number of confirmed cases increased to more than 7,700 worldwide by early Thursday, according to Chinese officials and the World Health Organization, with all but 68 of the infections taking place in mainland China. On Wednesday, there were about 6,000 infections worldwide. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">In China, a total of 170 people have now died from the mysterious new coronavirus, according to official Chinese statistics, but <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/28/world/asia/china-coronavirus.html" title="">the real number is likely much higher</a>. A dearth of test kits has hindered health officials ability to accurately diagnose and track the illness. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Here’s what we know about how the disease has spread:<span class="css-8l6xbc evw5hdy0"> </span></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">◆ China said early Thursday that 38 more people had died from the virus, which is <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/article/what-is-coronavirus.html" title="">believed to have originated in the central city of Wuhan</a> and is spreading across the country. The previous count, on Wednesday, was 132. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">◆ Tibet reported its first confirmed case.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">◆ Thailand has reported 14 cases of infection; Hong Kong has 10; the United States, Taiwan, Australia and Macau have five each; Singapore, South Korea and Malaysia each have reported four; Japan has 11; France has five; Germany has four; Canada has three; Vietnam has two; and Nepal, Cambodia, and the United Arab Emirates each have one. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">◆ Cases recorded in Taiwan, Germany, Vietnam and Japan involved patients who had not been to China. There have been no reported deaths outside China.</p>, <h2 class="css-zd32qr">Coronavirus Map: Tracking the Spread of the Outbreak</h2>, <p class="css-1uuihdo">The virus has sickened more than 40,600 people in China and 24 other countries.</p>, <h2 class="css-3ez4hu eoo0vm40" id="link-29cce0a7">Americans evacuated from Wuhan land in Southern California.</h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The 195 Americans who were evacuated from Wuhan, the epicenter of the virus, have been instructed by federal health authorities to remain for three days on the air force base in Southern California where they landed on Wednesday.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The passengers on the flight, which was chartered by the State Department, will be fully evaluated during those three days, according to Christopher R. Braden, a deputy director of the Centers for Disease Control.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Once cleared, the passengers will be allowed to fly home, where they will be monitored for 14 days by medical teams in their area.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“We think we can do the full evaluation in three days. Some of that evaluation is taking tests and flying samples to C.D.C. in Atlanta,” Dr. Braden told a news conference in Riverside, California. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"> “The reason we want to do active monitoring for 14 days is to determine if they can become ill during that period,” Dr. Braden added. “That is the basic public health premise of our action.“ </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The flight carrying the evacuated Americans landed in Southern California, at March Air Reserve Base, shortly after 8 a.m. local time on Wednesday. The flight had stopped in Anchorage for several hours, where the passengers were checked by a team from the Centers for Disease Control. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“The whole plane erupted in cheers when the crew said, ‘Welcome home to the United States,’” said Anne Zink, Alaska’s chief medical officer.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">[For a coming article, The New York Times would like to hear from Americans who flew on the chartered flight from China or their family members. Please contact </em><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="mailto:miriam.jordan@nytimes.com" title=""><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">miriam.jordan@nytimes.com</em></a><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0"> to share your story.]</em></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The evacuees — consisting mainly of consular officials and their families but also including some other Americans who were in China —<span class="css-8l6xbc evw5hdy0"> </span>will be accommodated at the base during the three-day period. But they will not have contact with any military personnel on the base.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The evacuees will undergo a battery of tests. If their results, from the lab of the Centers for Disease Control, come back negative, they will be allowed to travel onward.</p>, <h1 class="g-headline" id="g-inlineguide-headline">The Coronavirus Outbreak</h1>, <h2 class="g-inlineguide-list-header g-optimize-type">What do you need to know? Start here.</h2>, <p class="g-inlineguide-date">Updated Feb. 10, 2020</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">During a news conference, Dr. Braden was peppered with questions about the wisdom of releasing the former residents of Wuhan into communities across the country.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">He said that if a person deemed a danger to the community insisted on leaving before the 72-hour period expired, “we can institute an individual quarantine for that person and we will.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Other countries that have evacuated or plan to evacuate their citizens from Wuhan include France, South Korea, Japan, Morocco, Germany, Kazakhstan, Britain, Canada, Russia, the Netherlands, Myanmar and Australia.<span class="css-8l6xbc evw5hdy0"> </span></p>, <h2 class="css-3ez4hu eoo0vm40" id="link-20012b86">Scientists have grown the new virus in a lab.</h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Researchers at the Peter Doherty Institute for Infection and Immunity in Melbourne, Australia, say they have grown the Wuhan coronavirus in a laboratory. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Scientists in China and other researchers have managed to do so as well, officials at the World Health Organization said on Wednesday.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Isolating and growing viral samples is standard procedure during the outbreak of a novel pathogen, said Dr. Peter J. Hotez, co-director of the Texas Children’s Hospital Center for Vaccine Development at Baylor College of Medicine in Houston.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“Early on in an outbreak, you still need to understand the biology of the new organism that’s causing infections,” Dr. Hotez said.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Scientists collect samples from fluids obtained from the lungs or nasal passages of infected patients. Researchers may use the lab-grown virus to test antiviral drugs or develop experimental vaccines, Dr. Hotez said.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">By growing the novel coronavirus in controlled conditions, researchers also may get a better understanding of why the virus seems to be transmitted more easily than the SARS coronavirus, yet so far seems to have a lower mortality rate.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Scientists at the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention also are trying to grow the coronavirus from patient samples collected in the United States. Once they’ve succeeded, the agency will make samples available to infectious disease researchers through a public repository. Chinese and Australian researchers have already offered to distribute samples.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Scientists are also working quickly to develop<span class="css-8l6xbc evw5hdy0"> </span><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/28/health/coronavirus-vaccine.html" title="">a vaccine capable of stopping the new coronavirus.</a></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Government scientists in China, the United States and Australia, as well as those working at Johnson &amp; Johnson, Moderna Therapeutics and Inovio Pharmaceuticals are all engaged. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Researchers at the National Institutes of Health’s Vaccine Research Center in Maryland have pinpointed the parts of the genetic code that could be used to make a vaccine. But a vaccine could take months, if not years, to develop.</p>, <h2 class="css-3ez4hu eoo0vm40" id="link-7eab2c29">Three new cases are confirmed in Japan.</h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Three Japanese citizens who returned on a government-sponsored charter plane from Wuhan on Wednesday morning tested positive for the coronavirus, bringing the number of confirmed cases in Japan to 11.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Katsunobu Kato, the country’s Health, Labor and Welfare minister, told a session of Parliament on Thursday morning that the two men and one woman who landed in Tokyo on Wednesday had tested positive for the virus.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">On Wednesday, 206 Japanese citizens landed at Haneda airport. All except two agreed to be tested for the virus, and 12 were sent immediately to a hospital for monitoring. The majority of the passengers — 191 — were asymptomatic but are quarantined in a hotel awaiting the results of virus tests. Of the three who tested positive, one exhibited symptoms, while two others were not yet showing symptoms.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Another Japanese chartered flight from Wuhan landed on Thursday morning with 210 passengers aboard.</p>, <h2 class="css-3ez4hu eoo0vm40" id="link-14502ba">W.H.O. will again weigh whether to declare a public health emergency.</h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The World Health Organization will convene a meeting of experts on Thursday in Geneva to vote again on whether to declare the coronavirus epidemic a global health emergency, officials said on Wednesday.<span class="css-8l6xbc evw5hdy0"> </span></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">At a news conference in Geneva on Wednesday, W.H.O. officials said they were<span class="css-8l6xbc evw5hdy0"> </span>particularly concerned about recent cases of person-to-person transmission that have been reported among people who have never been to China.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">On Jan. 23, when there were about 800 confirmed cases and all 25 deaths were in China, the same committee <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/23/health/china-virus-who-emergency.html" title="">recommended that an emergency not be declared at that time</a>. Since then, the infection has spread to people in four countries who have never been to China.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Most patients infected with the virus develop mild symptoms, but about 20 percent become severely ill. The death rate seems to be 2 percent, W.H.O. officials said, though they cautioned that there are many unknown variables.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“This number may change,” said Dr. Maria Van Kerkhove, acting head of emerging diseases at the W.H.O. “It’s early to put a percentage on that.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The director general of the W.H.O., Dr. Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus, praised China’s response to the crisis.<span class="css-8l6xbc evw5hdy0"> </span></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“The fact that to date we have only seen 68 cases outside China and no deaths is due in no small part to the extraordinary steps the government has taken to prevent the export of cases,” he said.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Health officials in China alerted Germany when a Chinese woman returning from Germany developed symptoms and tested positive for the coronavirus. Because of the shared information, at least one infection in Germany was discovered.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“This example is a good illustration of how China is engaging” with the W.H.O. and other countries, Dr. Tedros said. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">But <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/27/technology/china-coronavirus-censorship-social-media.html" title="">some Chinese social media users</a> have strongly criticized the government’s handling of the outbreak, posting harrowing descriptions of untreated family members and images of hospital corridors loaded with patients. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The sheer amount of complaints — and some of the clever ways users have dodged censors, like referring to President Xi Jinping as “Trump” —<span class="css-8l6xbc evw5hdy0"> </span>have made it difficult for the Chinese government to maintain its tight grip on what is said, seen and heard about it.</p>, <h2 class="css-3ez4hu eoo0vm40" id="link-1bbf33dd">Big sports competitions have been disrupted in China.</h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Some international sports events have been postponed or even canceled in China because of the coronavirus outbreak.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The biggest casualty so far is the indoor world athletics championships in Nanjing, which were postponed by a full year on Wednesday.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The international ski federation has canceled the first World Cup races planned for the mountain venue where the sport will be held during the 2022 Beijing Olympics, The Associated Press reported.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The governing body of athletics said the indoor championships will now be held in March 2021 instead of March 13-15 this year.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Nanjing is about 330 miles from Wuhan, where the outbreak started.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Qualifying tournaments for this summers’ Tokyo Olympics have also been affected. Women’s soccer and women’s basketball games were moved to Australia and Serbia. The soccer games had initially been moved from Wuhan to Nanjing. Boxing tournaments for the Asia and Oceania regions will be held in Jordan in March.</p>, <h2 class="css-3ez4hu eoo0vm40" id="link-7e22131b">British Airways and Air Canada cancel all flights to and from China. </h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">British Airways has <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/29/business/china-coronavirus-economy.html" title="">indefinitely suspended all flights to and from China</a>, the airline said on Wednesday, citing advice from Britain’s Foreign Office that cautioned against all nonessential travel to China.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“We apologize to customers for the inconvenience, but the safety of our customers and crew is always our priority,” the company said in an emailed statement.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Other airlines have begun to scale back flights to China as the death toll and number of cases rises, but the British flag carrier, one of the world’s largest international airlines, is the first to cancel all its scheduled flights. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The airline, based in London, makes multiple flights a week to Beijing and Shanghai.<span class="css-8l6xbc evw5hdy0"> </span></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://aircanada.mediaroom.com/2020-01-29-Air-Canada-Suspends-Flights-to-Beijing-Shanghai" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">Air Canada</a> said on Wednesday that it was also suspending all flights to China, from Thursday until Feb. 29.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">And <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://news.delta.com/delta-temporarily-reduce-us-china-flying-continues-offer-fee-waiver-customers" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">Delta</a> announced that it was temporarily reducing its weekly flights between the United States and China, because of declining demand. From Feb. 6 through April 30, the airline will go down to 21 weekly flights, or three to four weekly flights per route.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The low-cost Indonesian carrier Lion Air and Seoul Air of South Korea also suspended all their flights to China, The Associated Press reported. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">United Airlines and Air Canada said on Tuesday that they would reduce flights to China, canceling dozens of scheduled trips over the coming days and weeks because of a sudden drop in demand. Health officials in the United States have also warned against all nonessential travel to China.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">In Hong Kong, the authorities have reduced by half the number of flights coming into the semiautonomous region from mainland China and have also shut down rail services to the mainland. Hong Kong’s flagship carrier, Cathay Pacific, has also suspended all flights to and from Wuhan through March.</p>, <h2 class="css-3ez4hu eoo0vm40" id="link-3bdea937">Rise in number of cases outside China is “very concerning,” expert says.</h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The new coronavirus that was first discovered in China last month is showing early signs of spreading abroad, with people who never visited China during the outbreak falling ill in Germany, Japan, Taiwan and Vietnam.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The overseas cases highlight the ability of the mysterious disease, which is believed to have originated in wild animals, to be transmitted from one person to another, increasing its chances of spreading.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“These reports are concerning, if they stand up to scrutiny, which they certainly sound credible,” said Dr. Arthur Reingold, a professor of epidemiology at the University of California, Berkeley.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Some cases that have spread outside China appear to have been spread between family members, who are at greater risk while caring for sick relatives. Other cases, however, appear to have spread between people with different connections.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">In Japan, a tour bus driver in his 60s who had driven two different groups from Wuhan, China, was confirmed to have the coronavirus, officials said on Tuesday. The driver had no history of traveling to Wuhan, the epicenter of the outbreak.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“I think what that says is, if we can get transmission in such a setting, then we can certainly get it in the waiting room of a clinic or a hospital,” Professor Reingold said. “That’s very concerning.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">German officials said on Tuesday that a 33-year-old man from Starnberg in Bavaria was apparently infected with the coronavirus after a Jan. 21 training event with a Chinese colleague. The Chinese colleague flew home two days later. The German man was being treated under isolation while officials identified other people with whom he might have been in contact.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Late Tuesday, health officials in Germany said three more people from the same company in Bavaria were also infected. The three were admitted to a clinic in Munich, where they were to be isolated and treated. An additional 40 people with close contact to those infected would be tested on Wednesday, officials said.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Taiwan said on Tuesday that a man had become infected after his wife had contracted the virus while working in Wuhan. He became Taiwan’s eighth case and the first known to be transmitted locally.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">In an <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nejm.org/doi/full/10.1056/NEJMc2001272" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">article published by The New England Journal of Medicine</a> on Tuesday, Vietnamese physicians reported that a 65-year-old man from Wuhan appeared to have transmitted the coronavirus to his son, 27, who was living in Long An Province, southwest of Ho Chi Minh City. The father developed a fever on Jan. 17, four days after flying to Hanoi, Vietnam, from Wuhan.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The son met his father on Jan. 17, and by Jan. 20 he had a dry cough and fever. The father’s condition has improved, and the son is stable, the doctors wrote. None of their 28 identified close contacts, including the father’s wife, have developed symptoms of respiratory infection, they said.</p>, <h2 class="css-3ez4hu eoo0vm40" id="link-66932499">A Beijing drugstore gets a big fine for price gouging on masks.<span class="css-8l6xbc evw5hdy0"> </span></h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">With demand for surgical masks on the rise in China, a drugstore in Beijing has been fined more than $400,000 by the government for charging customers roughly six times what the masks are being sold for online.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">State-run media said that the store was charging customers 850 yuan, or $122, for the masks, while they were being sold online for 143 yuan.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Infectious disease specialists say the disposable masks, which cover the nose and mouth, <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/23/health/coronavirus-surgical-masks.html" title="">can help prevent the spread</a> of infections if they are worn properly and used consistently.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The masks have become ubiquitous in cities across China. In Hong Kong, where the outbreak has brought back painful memories of the SARS epidemic in 2002-03, officials said that customs authorities were examining surgical masks being sold in the city for counterfeit labeling and not meeting safety standards.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">In announcing the fine against the Beijing drugstore, a government notice warned that the authorities would “continue to step up enforcement and make every effort to curb the excessive and rapid rise in protective enforcement prices.” </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Surgical masks have become so much in demand that a <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.metamasks.com/" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">website advertising</a> more fashionable versions of them warns that deliveries are at risk of being delayed.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"></p>, <h2 class="css-3ez4hu eoo0vm40" id="link-NaN"></h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"> <em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0"> </em></p>, <h2 class="css-3ez4hu eoo0vm40" id="link-NaN"></h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"></p>, <p class="css-jwz2nf etfikam0">Reporting was contributed by Chris Buckley, Russell Goldman, Elaine Yu, Raymond Zhong, Austin Ramzy, Alexandra Stevenson, Sui-Li Wee, Miriam Jordan, Paul Mozur, Knvul Sheikh, Katie Thomas, James Gorman, Motoko Rich, Ben Dooley, Makiko Inoue, Eimi Yamamitsu, Patricia Cohen, Donald G. McNeil Jr., Roni Caryn Rabin, Motoko Rich and Karen Zraick. Zoe Mou, Albee Zhang, Amber Wang, Yiwei Wang and Claire Fu contributed research.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"></p>, <p>Advertisement</p>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd" id="site-index-label">Site Index</h2>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-0">news</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-1">opinion</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-2">arts</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-3">living</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-4">more</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-subscribe-label">Subscribe</h3>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd">Site Information Navigation</h2>]
[<p>Advertisement</p>, <p>Supported by</p>, <p class="css-c2jxua e6idgb70"></p>, <h1 class="css-1j5ig2m e1h9rw200" id="link-5514c2ef" itemprop="headline"><span>How the Coronavirus Could Hurt Apple and Starbucks</span></h1>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">Want this in your inbox each morning? </em><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="http://p.nytimes.com/email/re?&amp;campaign_id=0&amp;instance_id=0&amp;segment_id=0&amp;user_id=f4577a56bcf773214e9a1d55b5fe9d24&amp;regi_id=0nl=dealbook&amp;emc=edit_dk_20180529" title=""><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">Sign up here</em></a><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">.</em></p>, <h2 class="css-3ez4hu eoo0vm40" id="link-2d44a6e4">Businesses try to defend against coronavirus</h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">More companies are temporarily halting business in parts of China, as the outbreak spreads and the fear of contagion rises.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Here’s the latest:</strong></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">• British Airways <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/29/world/asia/coronavirus-china.html#link-7fb8b172" title="">suspended flights to and from mainland China</a>. Cathay Pacific and United Airlines have reduced the number of flights.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">• Starbucks <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.wsj.com/articles/starbucks-closed-half-of-china-stores-amid-coronavirus-outbreak-11580247048" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">closed more than half of its stores</a> in the country, its second-biggest market.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">• The owner of Uniqlo has closed about 100 stores in the affected Hubei Province.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Apple said the outbreak could </strong><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10"><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/28/technology/apple-iphone-sales-earnings.html" title="">affect its financial forecasts</a></strong><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">.</strong> Tim Cook, its C.E.O., told analysts yesterday that suppliers could be disrupted and that traffic to its stores in China had dropped.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">The moves come as the disease’s toll continues to grow.</strong> <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/29/world/asia/coronavirus-china.html" title=""> The death tally</a> as of this morning was 132 — up from 106 yesterday — and the number of cases jumped 25 percent, to 5,974. And more cases are being reported of people in other countries falling ill, despite having not visited China.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Markets offered a mixed reaction.</strong> <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.ft.com/content/fe7c566e-422d-11ea-bdb5-169ba7be433d" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">Hong Kong stocks fell</a> today, their first day of trading after the Lunar New Year holiday. But S&amp;P futures are indicating a positive opening in the U.S.</p>, <h2 class="css-3ez4hu eoo0vm40" id="link-69315283">U.K. deals a blow to Trump’s fight against Huawei</h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Britain, defying calls from the White House to block Huawei products, said it would not ban the Chinese company from being used in its new high-speed 5G wireless network.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Prime Minister Boris Johnson allowed Huawei technology</strong> to be used in some parts of Britain’s 5G infrastructure, though not in essential ones. And “high risk” vendors who pose potential security risks wouldn’t be allowed to hold more than 35 percent of the country’s overall network.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">The decision dismissed the Trump administration’s claims</strong> that using Huawei products could compromise the security of 5G systems.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Britain is in a tough position:</strong> Washington threatened to <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.wsj.com/articles/u-k-allows-huawei-to-build-parts-of-5g-network-11580213316" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">withhold intelligence</a> if London allowed Huawei into the country’s 5G network, while China threatened economic retaliation if it didn’t.</p>, <h1 class="g-headline" id="g-inlineguide-headline">The Coronavirus Outbreak</h1>, <h2 class="g-inlineguide-list-header g-optimize-type">What do you need to know? Start here.</h2>, <p class="g-inlineguide-date">Updated Feb. 5, 2020</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">The decision could embolden other countries</strong> to use Huawei. Canada and Germany are set to decide this year on whether to block the Chinese company.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">A Trump administration official said the U.S. was “disappointed”</strong> by the move and would work with Britain “on a way forward that results in the exclusion of untrusted vendor components from 5G networks.”</p>, <h2 class="css-3ez4hu eoo0vm40" id="link-34d699fe">Jay Powell is back in the spotlight</h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The Fed is expected to announce a decision on interest rates today after the end of its latest board meeting. That will again <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/28/business/economy/ordinary-or-enemy-how-jay-powell-is-positioning-the-fed-in-a-fraught-era.html" title="">put the focus on Mr. Powell</a>, the chairman, who continues to face pressure from President Trump as he steers the central bank, Jeanna Smialek of the NYT writes.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">• “Everything about him, from the simple language he uses at news conferences to his demeanor on Capitol Hill, conveys that he is relatable, ordinary and decidedly undramatic,” Ms. Smialek writes of the Fed chairman.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">• His quiet approach “is part of a deeper strategy by Mr. Powell, who is trying to convince America that the Fed is a collection of nonpartisan public servants focused on serving the American people — not a temple of elites wielding unchecked power.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">• “To shore up support, Mr. Powell visits Capitol Hill frequently, holding more than 260 meetings with members of Congress since taking over as chair in February 2018.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">That approach is repeatedly tested by Mr. Trump’s criticism </strong>that the Fed has kept interest rates too high. Yesterday, the president tweeted that the central bank “<a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://twitter.com/realDonaldTrump/status/1222186473849544704" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">should get smart</a>” and lower rates.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">But Mr. Powell and the Fed are expected to keep rates steady</strong> and to continue to do so until the economic picture changes.</p>, <h2 class="css-3ez4hu eoo0vm40" id="link-7ed338ce">A new front in the U.S. fight against research theft</h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Prosecutors arrested Charles Lieber, a top scientist at Harvard, charging him with concealing financial ties to China. <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/28/us/charles-lieber-harvard.html" title="">It’s an escalation</a> in a campaign to stamp out the stealing of secrets from U.S. universities, Ellen Barry of the NYT writes.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">• Dr. Lieber, who specializes in nanoscale electronics, is not accused of sharing sensitive information with Chinese officials. But he was charged with hiding how much money Chinese funders were paying him. (It was tens of thousands of dollars a year, according to prosecutors.)</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">• He was ensnared in a two-year push by the Justice Department to find individuals at U.S. universities working with the Chinese government. Massachusetts, with its many universities, is a “target-rich” environment, according to the special agent in charge of the F.B.I.’s Boston field office.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">• The drive has meant “researchers are adjusting to a higher level of scrutiny about foreign funding than they faced in the past,” Ms. Barry writes.</p>, <h2 class="css-3ez4hu eoo0vm40" id="link-71f716c0">Another firm joins the push for climate action and social change</h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The money-management firm State Street plans to <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.ft.com/content/cb1e2684-4152-11ea-a047-eae9bd51ceba" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">vote against directors of companies</a> in major stock indexes that fall behind targets for environmental, social and governance changes.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">“We see that shareholder value is increasingly being driven</strong> by issues such as climate change, labor practices and consumer product safety,” Cyrus Taraporevala, the C.E.O. of the firm’s investment management arm, wrote in <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="http://www.statestreet.com/executive-leader/Taraporevala-cyrus.html" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">a letter to corporate boards</a>.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">State Street will </strong><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10"><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2020-01-28/state-street-tells-companies-esg-moves-are-no-longer-optional" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">start its campaign</a></strong> with companies in the S&amp;P 500 and in major European indexes, and then broaden the effort in 2022.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">The decision matters, given State Street’s size.</strong> Its Global Advisors division oversees $3.1 trillion in assets and is a major investor in companies around the world.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">The big picture:</strong> Increasingly, huge money managers are using their influence to push for changes beyond financial performance. BlackRock, which has over $7 trillion in assets, said this month that it would make climate change a <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/14/business/dealbook/larry-fink-blackrock-climate-change.html" title="">key investment focus</a>.</p>, <h2 class="css-3ez4hu eoo0vm40" id="link-6c2d26a2">Goldman prepares to showcase its new look</h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Today brings a first for the 151-year-old bank: an “investor day” for shareholders, as well as for analysts, the news media and even regulators.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">The event is </strong><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/29/business/goldman-sachs-investor-day.html" title=""><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">an attempt to promote a more open image</strong></a><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10"> </strong>for a company that has traditionally been known as a secretive black box of profits and “an adrenaline-fueled sales-and-trading juggernaut,” Kate Kelly of the NYT writes.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Goldman’s C.E.O., David Solomon, will argue that the bank has evolved. </strong>The firm has jumped into retail banking and credit cards, for example, and it does more mundane tasks like manage cash for corporations.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">But some executives reportedly think the firm is trying too hard.</strong> “They want the investor day to focus more on places where Goldman actually makes money,” <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.ft.com/content/203e5f46-3d0a-11ea-b232-000f4477fbca" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">Laura Noonan of the FT writes</a>, citing unnamed sources.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Mr. Solomon has his work cut out.</strong> Goldman “is to some extent grasping at straws strategically,” one investor specializing in financial stocks told Ms. Noonan.</p>, <h2 class="css-3ez4hu eoo0vm40" id="link-7c091e00">The speed read</h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Deals</strong></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">• The investment firm Platinum Equity has reportedly tried to poach Joe Ianniello, the head of CBS, to lead its takeover bid for Univision. (<a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.wsj.com/articles/univision-suitor-seeks-to-recruit-cbs-chief-to-front-bid-11580256086" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">WSJ</a>)</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">• Two big investors in Deliveroo, the food delivery service, accused British regulators of chilling Britain’s start-up economy by holding up Amazon investment in the company. (<a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.ft.com/content/604484f0-41f4-11ea-bdb5-169ba7be433d" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">FT</a>)</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">• The European Union’s banking authority is encouraging the Continent’s lenders to merge to get stronger. (<a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.wsj.com/articles/european-banking-regulator-encourages-mergers-to-boost-profits-11580218508" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">WSJ</a>)</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Politics and policy</strong></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">• The U.S. deficit is expected to hit $1.7 trillion by 2030, according to the Congressional Budget Office. (<a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/28/business/trillion-budget-deficit-cbo.html" title="">NYT</a>)</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">• House Democrats are expected to unveil a $760 billion infrastructure investment plan today, with a focus on climate change. (<a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.politico.com/news/2020/01/28/infrastructure-house-budget-climate-108396" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">Politico</a>)</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">• Portugal plans to end tax breaks that made the country attractive for wealthy foreigners. (<a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.ft.com/content/88f3b958-41ee-11ea-a047-eae9bd51ceba" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">FT</a>)</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Tech</strong></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">• Apple beat expectations for its most recent financial quarter, thanks to brisk sales of the latest iPhone and AirPods. (<a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/28/technology/apple-iphone-sales-earnings.html" title="">NYT</a>)</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">• Facebook has unveiled a tool that lets users see how the company is tracking their online lives — even outside the company’s apps. (<a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.washingtonpost.com/technology/2020/01/28/off-facebook-activity-page/" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">WaPo</a>)</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">• Bitcoin’s mainstream popularity has dropped. But its appeal to criminals hasn’t. (<a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/28/technology/bitcoin-black-market.html" title="">NYT</a>)</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Best of the rest</strong></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">• Nike denied news reports that it had withdrawn Kobe Bryant merchandise from its website. The products, a spokesman said, simply sold out. (<a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.cnbc.com/2020/01/28/nike-sells-out-of-kobe-bryant-merchandise-online-after-death.html" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">CNBC</a>)</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">• The Massachusetts authorities fined Chipotle $1.4 million for what they said were violations of child labor laws. (<a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/28/business/chipotle-child-labor-laws-massachusetts.html" title="">NYT</a>)</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">• The online shoe seller Zappos has quietly backed away from the often-criticized, decentralized management style known as holacracy. (<a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://qz.com/work/1776841/zappos-has-quietly-backed-away-from-holacracy/" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">Quartz</a>)</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">We’d love your feedback. Please email thoughts and suggestions to </em><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="mailto:business@nytimes.com?subject=Newsletter%20Feedback" title=""><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">business@nytimes.com</em></a><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">.</em></p>, <p>Advertisement</p>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd" id="site-index-label">Site Index</h2>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-0">news</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-1">opinion</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-2">arts</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-3">living</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-4">more</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-subscribe-label">Subscribe</h3>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd">Site Information Navigation</h2>]
[<p>Advertisement</p>, <p>Supported by</p>, <h1 class="css-1qskr30 e1h9rw200" id="link-2568f50" itemprop="headline"><span>How to Avoid the Coronavirus? Wash Your Hands</span></h1>, <p class="css-1ifw933 e1wiw3jv0" id="article-summary">I covered the SARS outbreak as a reporter in China, and I saw that common sense is the best defense against viral illness.</p>, <p class="css-1fv7b6t e1jsehar1" itemprop="author" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">By<!-- --> <a class="css-brehiz e1jsehar0" href="https://www.nytimes.com/by/elisabeth-rosenthal"><span class="css-1baulvz last-byline" itemprop="name">Elisabeth Rosenthal</span></a></p>, <p class="css-cpkn1d e1wtpvyy1">Ms. Rosenthal, a journalist and physician, is a contributing opinion writer.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Americans are watching with alarm as a new <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/29/business/china-coronavirus-economy.html" title="">coronavirus spreads in China</a> and <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2020/world/asia/china-wuhan-coronavirus-maps.html" title="">cases pop up in the United States</a>. They are barraged with information about what kinds of masks are best to prevent viral spread. Students are <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/coronavirus-china-live-updates/2020/01/25/0ca57a5e-3ed7-11ea-afe2-090eb37b60b1_story.html" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">handing out masks</a> in Seattle. Masks <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.kbtx.com/content/news/Local-drug-stores-out-of-face-masks-after-potential-case-of-Coronavirus-detected-567279461.html" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">have run out</a> in Brazos County, Tex.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Hang on.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">I’ve worked as an emergency room physician. And as a New York Times correspondent in China, I covered the <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.who.int/ith/diseases/sars/en/" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">SARS outbreak</a> in 2002 and 2003 during which a novel coronavirus first detected in Guangdong sickened more than 8,000 people and killed more than 800. My two children attended elementary school in Beijing throughout the outbreak.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Here are my main takeaways from that experience for ordinary people on the ground:</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">1. Wash your hands frequently.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">2. Don’t go to the office when you are sick. Don’t send your kids to school or day care when they are ill, either.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Notice I didn’t say anything about masks. Having a mask with you as a precaution makes sense if you are in the midst of an outbreak, as I was when out reporting in the field during those months. But wearing it constantly is another matter. I donned a mask when visiting hospitals where SARS patients had been housed. I wore it in the markets where wild animals that were the suspected source of the outbreak were being butchered, blood droplets flying. I wore it in crowded enclosed spaces that I couldn’t avoid, like airplanes and trains, as I traveled to cities involved in the outbreak, like Guangzhou and Hong Kong. You never know if the guy coughing and sneezing two rows ahead of you is ill or just has an allergy.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">But outdoors, infections don’t spread well through the air. Those photos of people walking down streets in China wearing masks are dramatic but uninformed. And remember if a mask has, perchance, intercepted viruses that would have otherwise ended up in your body, then the mask is contaminated. So, in theory, to be protected maybe you should use a new one for each outing.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The simple masks are better than nothing, but not all that effective, since they don’t seal well. For anyone tempted to go out and buy the gold standard, N95 respirators, note that they are uncomfortable. Breathing is more work. It’s hard to talk to people. On one long flight at the height of the outbreak, on which my few fellow passengers were mostly epidemiologists trying to solve the SARS puzzle, many of us (including me) wore our masks for the first couple of hours on the flight. Then the food and beverage carts came.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Though viruses spread through droplets in the air, a bigger worry to me was always transmission via what doctors call “fomites,” infected items. A virus gets on a surface — a shoe or a doorknob or a tissue, for example. You touch the surface and then next touch your face or rub your nose. It’s a great way to acquire illness. So after walking in the animal markets, I removed my shoes carefully and did not take them into the hotel room. And of course I washed my hands immediately.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Remember, by all indications SARS, <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.washingtonpost.com/health/how-the-new-coronavirus-differs-from-sars-measles-and-ebola/2020/01/23/aac6bb06-3e1b-11ea-b90d-5652806c3b3a_story.html" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">which killed about 10 percent</a> of those infected, was a deadlier virus than the new coronavirus circulating now. So keep things in perspective.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Faced with SARS, many foreigners chose to leave Beijing or at least to send their children back to the United States. Our family stayed, kids included. We wanted them with us and didn’t want them to miss school, especially during what would be their final year in China. But equally important in making the decision was that the risk of getting SARS on an airplane or in the airport seemed greater than being smart and careful while staying put in Beijing.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">And we were: I stopped taking my kids to indoor playgrounds or crowded malls or delicious but densely packed neighborhood Beijing restaurants. Out of an abundance of caution we canceled a family vacation to Cambodia — though my fear was less about catching SARS on the flight than that one of the kids would have a fever from an ear infection upon our return at a border screening, and would be stuck in a prolonged quarantine in China. We instead took a vacation within China, where we carried masks with us but didn’t use them except on a short domestic flight.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">In time, during the SARS outbreak, the government shut down theaters and schools in Beijing, as it is doing now in many Chinese cities because these viruses are more easily transmitted in such crowded places.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">But there was also a lot of irrational behavior: Entering a village on the way to a hike near the Great Wall, our car was stopped by locals who had set up a roadblock to check the temperature of all passengers. They used an oral thermometer that was only minimally cleaned after each use. What a great way to spread a virus.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The International School of Beijing, where my children were students, was one of the few in the capital — perhaps the only one — that stayed open throughout the SARS outbreak, though the classes were emptier, since so many kids had departed to their home countries. It was a studied but brave move, since a parent at the school had gotten SARS at the very beginning of the outbreak on a flight back from Hong Kong. She recovered fine, but it was close to home and families were scared.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The school instituted a bunch of simple precautionary policies: a stern note to parents reminding them not to send a child to school who was sick and warning them that students would be screened for fevers with ear thermometers at the school door. There was no sharing of food at lunch. The teacher led the kids in frequent hand washing throughout the day at classroom sinks, while singing a prolonged “hand washing song” to ensure they did more than a cursory pass under the faucet with water only.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">If a family left Beijing and came back, the child would have to stay at home for an extended period before returning to class to make sure they hadn’t caught SARS elsewhere.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">With those precautions in place, I observed something of a public health miracle: Not only did no child get SARS, but it seemed no student was sick with anything at all for months on end. No stomach bugs. No common colds. Attendance was more or less perfect.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The World Health Organization <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.history.com/this-day-in-history/world-health-organization-declares-sars-contained-worldwide" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">declared the SARS outbreak contained</a> in July 2003. But, oh, that those habits persisted. The best first-line defenses against SARS or the new coronavirus or most any virus at all are the ones that Grandma and common sense taught us, after all.</p>, <p class="css-jwz2nf etfikam0"></p>, <p class="css-jwz2nf etfikam0"><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">The Times is committed to publishing </em><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2019/01/31/opinion/letters/letters-to-editor-new-york-times-women.html" title=""><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">a diversity of letters</em></a><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0"> to the editor. We’d like to hear what you think about this or any of our articles. Here are some </em><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://help.nytimes.com/hc/en-us/articles/115014925288-How-to-submit-a-letter-to-the-editor" title=""><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">tips</em></a><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">. And here’s our email: </em><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="mailto:letters@nytimes.com" title=""><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">letters@nytimes.com</em></a><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">.</em></p>, <p class="css-jwz2nf etfikam0"><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">Follow The New York Times Opinion section on </em><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.facebook.com/nytopinion" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title=""><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">Facebook</em></a><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">, </em><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="http://twitter.com/NYTOpinion" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title=""><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">Twitter (@NYTopinion)</em></a><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0"> and </em><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.instagram.com/nytopinion/" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title=""><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">Instagram</em></a><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">.</em></p>, <p>Advertisement</p>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd" id="site-index-label">Site Index</h2>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-0">news</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-1">opinion</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-2">arts</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-3">living</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-4">more</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-subscribe-label">Subscribe</h3>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd">Site Information Navigation</h2>]
[<p>Advertisement</p>, <p>Supported by</p>, <h1 class="css-1s4ffep e1h9rw200" id="link-ba35ea1" itemprop="headline"><span>Researchers Are Racing to Make a Coronavirus Vaccine. Will It Help?</span></h1>, <p class="css-1ifw933 e1wiw3jv0" id="article-summary">New technology and better coordination have sped up development. But a coronavirus vaccine is still months — and most likely years — away.</p>, <p class="css-1fv7b6t e1jsehar1" itemprop="author" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">By<!-- --> <a class="css-brehiz e1jsehar0" href="https://www.nytimes.com/by/knvul-sheikh"><span class="css-1baulvz" itemprop="name">Knvul Sheikh</span></a> and <a class="css-brehiz e1jsehar0" href="https://www.nytimes.com/by/katie-thomas"><span class="css-1baulvz last-byline" itemprop="name">Katie Thomas</span></a></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">In the early days of January, as cases of a strange, pneumonia-like illness were reported in China, researchers at the National Institutes of Health in Maryland readied themselves to hunt for a vaccine to prevent the new disease.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">They had clues that a <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/article/what-is-coronavirus.html" title="">coronavirus</a>, similar to ones that caused the SARS outbreak in 2003 and MERS in 2012, was the culprit. Dr. Barney Graham, deputy director of the Vaccine Research Center at the N.I.H, urged government scientists in China to share the genetic makeup of the virus so his team could begin its race to develop a vaccine.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">On Friday, Jan. 10, the Chinese scientists posted the information on <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/nuccore/MN908947" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">a public database</a>. The next morning, Dr. Graham’s team was in the lab. And within hours, they had pinpointed the letters of the genetic code that could be used to make a vaccine.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Scientists in Australia and at least three companies — Johnson &amp; Johnson, Moderna Therapeutics and Inovio Pharmaceuticals — are also working on vaccine candidates to stop the spread of the disease, which has infected about 6,000 people and killed more than 130.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“Everybody is trying to move as quickly as possible,” said Jacqueline Shea, the chief operating officer at Inovio.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Inovio received a grant of up to $9 million to develop a coronavirus vaccine from the Coalition for Epidemic Preparedness Innovations, a group whose aim is to speed vaccines to market. Moderna, which is working with Dr. Graham’s team at the N.I.H., <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://cepi.net/news_cepi/cepi-to-fund-three-programmes-to-develop-vaccines-against-the-novel-coronavirus-ncov-2019/" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">received a similar grant</a>, as did researchers at the University of Queensland in Australia.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Historically, vaccines have been one of the greatest public health tools to prevent disease. But even as new technology, advancements in genomics and improved global coordination have allowed researchers to move at unprecedented speed, vaccine development remains an expensive and risky process. It takes months and even years because the vaccines must undergo extensive testing in animals and humans. In the best case, it takes at least a year — and most likely longer — for any vaccine to become available to the public.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“They may not help in the very early stages of an outbreak, but if we’re able to develop vaccines in time, they will be an asset later,” said Richard Hatchett, the chief executive of the epidemic preparedness coalition.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">With each new outbreak, scientists typically have to start from scratch. After the SARS outbreak in 2003, it took researchers about 20 months from the release of the viral genome to get a vaccine ready for human trials. By the time an epidemic caused by the Zika virus occurred in 2015, researchers had brought the timeline down to six months. Now, they hope the joint efforts will cut that time in half.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The morning after the Chinese scientists published their data earlier this month, Dr. Graham’s team got to work checking the sequence and comparing it with what they already had for SARS and MERS. They wanted to focus on the spike protein, which forms the crown of the coronavirus and recognizes receptors, or entry points, on a host cell.</p>, <h1 class="g-headline" id="g-inlineguide-headline">The Coronavirus Outbreak</h1>, <h2 class="g-inlineguide-list-header g-optimize-type">What do you need to know? Start here.</h2>, <p class="g-inlineguide-date">Updated Feb. 10, 2020</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“If you can block the spike protein from binding to a cell, then you’ve effectively prevented an infection,” said Kizzmekia Corbett, the scientific lead for Dr. Graham’s coronavirus team.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Dr. Corbett and others had studied the spike proteins on SARS and MERS viruses in detail, using them to develop experimental vaccines. The vaccines never made it to market because SARS was successfully contained with public health measures before the vaccine was ready and preliminary<a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.thelancet.com/journals/laninf/article/PIIS1473-3099(19)30266-X/fulltext" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title=""> human trials for the MERS vaccine showed success</a> last year.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">But the scientists had a method for developing vaccines that could help them fast-track production for the new coronavirus. They used the template for the SARS vaccine and swapped in just enough genetic code that would make it work for the new virus. “I call it plug and play,” Dr. Corbett said.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Within a few hours, Dr. Corbett was able to prepare the modified sequence that the researchers needed. On Tuesday, Jan. 14, the team held a conference call to discuss the next steps with collaborators in labs across the country, and sent off the sequence to Moderna.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Scientists at the company plan to use the genetic information to create synthetic messenger RNA, which carries instructions for cells’ protein-making machinery. The technology will help induce high levels of antibodies that can identify the spike protein and fight off an infection.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Once Moderna manufactures the messenger RNA in a few weeks, the N.I.H. will run more tests, Dr. Corbett said. Collaborators in academic labs will then test the vaccine in mice infected with the virus and check blood samples from the animals to see how well the experimental vaccine worked.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Dr. Anthony Fauci, director of the National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases at the N.I.H., who oversees Dr. Graham’s team, said he expected the vaccine research to move quickly.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“If we don’t run into any unforeseen obstacles, we’ll be able to get a Phase 1 trial going within the next three months, which will be record speed,” he said, referring to early human trials that test for safety.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Other researchers are using different methods to develop their vaccines.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Inovio, which is also developing a vaccine for MERS, uses a DNA-based technology. Johnson &amp; Johnson delivers vaccines through adenoviruses — which can cause coldlike symptoms but have been made harmless. And researchers at the University of Queensland are testing particles that mimic the structure of a virus.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“We don’t know which vaccine approach will be successful at this stage, so we have to try everything in our arsenal,” said Dr. Gregory Poland, a vaccine expert at the Mayo Clinic in Rochester, Minn.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">In interviews, company executives said that partnerships with governments and philanthropic foundations were essential to developing vaccines for outbreaks because there <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2014/10/24/health/without-lucrative-market-potential-ebola-vaccine-was-shelved-for-years.html" title="">are so many uncertainties</a>.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Dr. Paul Stoffels, Johnson &amp; Johnson’s chief scientific officer, estimated it could take eight to 12 months before his company’s vaccines reach human clinical trials. By then, it is possible the coronavirus outbreak will have been contained. Testing of Johnson &amp; Johnson’s Zika vaccine is currently halted, he said, because new outbreaks of the disease have slowed.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“You have to be brave and you have to be a solid company to do this, because there is no real incentive to do this, no financial incentive,” he said.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Stéphane Bancel, the chief executive of Moderna, said vaccines were necessary, even if an outbreak wanes, because it could always return. “I think it’s important to be prepared,” he said.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Experts believe that the frequency of outbreaks will only increase because of <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2019/06/10/climate/dengue-mosquito-spread-map.html" title="">climate change</a>, urbanization and global travel, among other factors.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“We probably need to start thinking about putting in a special infrastructure for coronavirus infections the same way we have for the flu,” said Dr. Peter Hotez, who is co-director of the Texas Children’s Hospital Center for Vaccine Development and was involved in the production of a SARS vaccine that may be repurposed for the new coronavirus. The detection and monitoring of infections, as well as the development of vaccines, will put an insurance policy in place for future outbreaks, he said.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“We’re just starting to realize that the power of vaccines goes way beyond public health,” he said. “They are also critical to the global economy and global security.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10"><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">[</em></strong><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10"><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="http://on.fb.me/1paTQ1h" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title=""><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">Like the Science Times page on Facebook.</em></a></strong><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10"><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0"> </em></strong><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">| Sign up for the </em><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10"><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="http://nyti.ms/1MbHaRU" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title=""><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">Science Times newsletter.</em></a></strong><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10"><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">]</em></strong></p>, <p>Advertisement</p>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd" id="site-index-label">Site Index</h2>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-0">news</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-1">opinion</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-2">arts</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-3">living</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-4">more</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-subscribe-label">Subscribe</h3>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd">Site Information Navigation</h2>]
[<p>Advertisement</p>, <p>Supported by</p>, <h1 class="css-1s4ffep e1h9rw200" id="link-3b8923d2" itemprop="headline"><span>Coronavirus Outbreak Tests World’s Dependence on China</span></h1>, <p class="css-1ifw933 e1wiw3jv0" id="article-summary">As British Airways cancels flights and automakers close factories, businesses consider how to cope without the country’s vast factories and thriving consumer culture.</p>, <p class="css-1fv7b6t e1jsehar1" itemprop="author" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">By<!-- --> <a class="css-brehiz e1jsehar0" href="https://www.nytimes.com/by/alexandra-stevenson"><span class="css-1baulvz last-byline" itemprop="name">Alexandra Stevenson</span></a></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">HONG KONG — The world is quickly realizing how much it depends on <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/02/10/upshot/coronavirus-risk-prevention-advice.html" title="">China</a>.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Apple is rerouting supply chains. Ikea is closing its stores and paying staff members to stay home. Starbucks is warning of a financial blow. Ford and Toyota will idle some of their vast Chinese assembly plants for an extra week.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">On Wednesday, British Airways and Air Canada suspended all flights to mainland China, and Delta joined the growing number of carriers reducing service. Japan’s leaders are bracing for a possible hit and the Federal Reserve is “very carefully monitoring” the situation. Hotels and tour operators across Asia are watching fearfully as the world’s largest source of tourism dollars tightens its borders.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The mysterious <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/02/10/upshot/coronavirus-risk-prevention-advice.html" title="">coronavirus</a> that has killed more than a hundred people and sickened thousands has virtually shut down one of the world’s most important growth engines. Desperate to slow the fast-moving virus, the Chinese authorities have <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/27/world/asia/china-coronavirus-social-media.html" title="">extended the country’s national holiday</a> to Feb. 3, and crippled land, rail and air transport. Entire cities have shut down.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">An <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2018/11/25/world/asia/china-economy-strategy.html" title="">impoverished nation</a> just four decades ago, China has become an essential part of the modern global industrial machine. It alone accounts for roughly one-sixth of global economic output, and is the world’s largest manufacturer.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">China’s importance goes beyond what it makes. Its consumers buy more cars and smartphones than anybody else. When they go abroad, Chinese tourists spend $258 billion a year, according to the World Tourism Organization, nearly twice what Americans spend.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">But it has become so crucial to the operations of American companies that some members of the Trump administration <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2018/05/16/business/china-us-trade-disengage.html" title="">cited that dependence</a> as a justification for the trade war that began two years ago, an economic conflict that is forcing businesses <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2019/04/05/business/china-trade-trump-jobs-decoupling.html" title="">to consider shifting their factories</a> in China to countries with better relations with Washington.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Global companies were reconsidering their China strategies even before the trade war started. China’s labor costs are rising, local companies are increasingly competitive and the government has become less accommodating. Still, its skilled worker base, extensive highway and rail systems and vast consumer market make China tough to quit.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“What is clear is that businesses were already reeling from multiple sources of uncertainty,” said Sameer Samana, senior global market strategist at Wells Fargo Investment Institute. “It’s one more thing,” he added.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The full extent of the hit to the broader business world is not yet clear. The obvious comparison is to the deadly SARS outbreak 17 years ago, which began in China and killed hundreds globally. In early 2003, SARS slowed China’s growth substantially.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“There will clearly be implications, at least in the near term, for Chinese output,” the Federal Reserve chair, Jerome H. Powell, said during a news conference on Wednesday. “We just have to see what the effect is globally.”</p>, <h1 class="g-headline" id="g-inlineguide-headline">The Coronavirus Outbreak</h1>, <h2 class="g-inlineguide-list-header g-optimize-type">What do you need to know? Start here.</h2>, <p class="g-inlineguide-date">Updated Feb. 10, 2020</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Most of China had already been shut down since at least Friday for the annual Lunar New Year holiday, a weeklong nationwide hiatus. But with the outbreak showing no signs of slowing, many companies are already preparing for a longer slowdown.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“Our members are dealing with varying degrees of disruption in their businesses, including supply chain issues, temporary closings of some retail outlets and factories, and other challenges,” said Jake Parker, the senior vice president of the US-China Business Council, which represents major companies. If travel restrictions and quarantines are expanded or the holiday extended further, he said, “that will amplify these problems.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Many companies are now looking for temporary stopgaps.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Automakers like General Motors and Nissan plan to close their factories until the week of Feb. 3 to comply with the longer mandated holiday, while Toyota and Ford said this week that they would close some of their factories a week longer than that because of virus-related disruptions. Companies like G.M., Honeywell, Facebook and Bloomberg restricted travel for employees in China and established their own self-quarantine measures.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">On Tuesday, the Seattle-based coffee company Starbucks said it had closed more than half of its 4,292 stores in China, its second-biggest market after the United States, and said it would take a quarterly and full-year financial hit.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Tim Cook, the chief executive of Apple, said on Tuesday that the iPhone maker was looking for alternative suppliers to “make up for any expected production loss.” Foxconn, a Taiwanese company with an extensive network of factories in China that make gadgets on behalf of Apple and others, said its factories would continue to follow the new holiday schedule, which in some cases meant keeping operations closed until Feb. 10.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Apple is not the only company that has had to pivot quickly. Just last week, executives of Honeywell, the American engineering company, traveled to Wuhan for a ceremony related to its plans to open an innovation headquarters. Two days later, Wuhan was put under lockdown by the authorities.
