Honeywell has since restricted travel to certain parts of China.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Wuhan in particular appeals to major companies because it is a major national transport hub. The auto industry, including General Motors, Honda, Nissan and many others, have set up shop there, and many of their suppliers have followed. It is the home to <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.tradecommissioner.gc.ca/china-chine/market-facts-faits-sur-le-marche/96289.aspx?lang=eng" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">more than one third</a> of all French investment in China.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">On Monday, PSA Group, the French automaker, said it had set up crisis communications between Wuhan and its Paris headquarters to determine the potential impact on production. The company employs about 2,000 people in Wuhan through its joint venture and was evacuating 38 expatriates.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The Swedish retail giant Ikea, which employs 14,000 people in China, said on Thursday it would temporarily close all of its 30 stores in the country. Employees at the stores will be asked to stay home with paid leave until further notice.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">It is not clear how quickly businesses will bounce back. During the SARS outbreak, some factories paid higher wages to bring workers back and get factories humming again.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Right now, businesses do not know enough to make those kinds of plans.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Cummins, an Indiana company that makes engines and generators, does not know whether it will be able to open its seven sites in Wuhan after the Feb. 3 holiday extension because the city remains under lockdown. The facilities make fuel and power systems for rail and marine industries.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“Literally, we are evaluating on an ongoing basis in real time,” said Jon Mills, a spokesman for Cummins, “and I imagine other places are in the same position as we are.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Ford, which does not have any operations in Wuhan, said several of its major plants would nevertheless be idled until Feb. 10. A spokesman declined to disclose further details. The factories in four cities churn out nearly half a million vehicles a year, or an average of 9,400 cars a week.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Businesses in other countries are also trying to determine the impact.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“If the situation takes longer to subside, we’re concerned it could hurt Japanese exports, output and corporate profits,” Yasutoshi Nishimura, Japan’s minister of state for economic and fiscal policy, told a group of reporters this week. Chinese visitors account for about 30 percent of all foreign tourists, and Chinese companies are major buyers of Japanese-made components, like semiconductors and lenses.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">In Thailand, Chinese sightseers spend nearly $18 billion annually, totaling about a quarter of tourist spending.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“Chinese tourists are the No. 1 tourists to Thailand,” said Yuthasak Supasorn, the governor of the Tourism Authority of Thailand. He added that the government was exploring ways to compensate business owners who had lost money from the drop in tourists over the past few weeks. The government was even considering reducing parking fees for airlines and excise tax on jet fuel to lure more tourists, he said.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Anan Buates, 45, runs a business driving tourists. Chinese tourists are crucial to his business. So he grew alarmed when tour operators started making last-minute cancellations as the coronavirus emerged. Then, last week, China canceled overseas group tours.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“It’s their right and it’s their policy to prevent the spreading of the coronavirus,” Mr. Anan said. Still, he knows he faces a daunting challenge.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“We survive the whole year because they come the whole year.”</p>, <p class="css-jwz2nf etfikam0">Reporting was contributed by Eimi Yamamitsu from Tokyo, Ryn Jirenuwat from Bangkok, Cao Li from Hong Kong, Geneva Abdul from London, Jeanna Smialek from Washington, and Matt Phillips from New York.</p>, <p>Advertisement</p>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd" id="site-index-label">Site Index</h2>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-0">news</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-1">opinion</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-2">arts</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-3">living</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-4">more</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-subscribe-label">Subscribe</h3>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd">Site Information Navigation</h2>]
[<p>Advertisement</p>, <p>Supported by</p>, <h1 class="css-1s4ffep e1h9rw200" id="link-6c452b06" itemprop="headline"><span>Foreigners Airlifted From Chinese City at Heart of Coronavirus Outbreak</span></h1>, <p class="css-1ifw933 e1wiw3jv0" id="article-summary">More than a dozen nations pulled their citizens from Wuhan. But how evacuees were handled once they got home varied country by country.</p>, <p class="css-1fv7b6t e1jsehar1" itemprop="author" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">By<!-- --> <a class="css-brehiz e1jsehar0" href="https://www.nytimes.com/by/miriam-jordan/"><span class="css-1baulvz" itemprop="name">Miriam Jordan</span></a> and <a class="css-brehiz e1jsehar0" href="https://www.nytimes.com/by/austin-ramzy"><span class="css-1baulvz last-byline" itemprop="name">Austin Ramzy</span></a></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">LOS ANGELES — About 200 Americans evacuated from Wuhan, China, landed at a military base in Southern California on Wednesday, as countries around the world began pulling their citizens from the epicenter of the coronavirus outbreak.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“The whole plane erupted in cheers when the crew said, ‘Welcome home to the United States,’” said Dr. Anne Zink, the chief medical officer for Alaska, where the plane stopped en route to California.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">But “home” was not immediately in the cards for the evacuees.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Upon landing at the March Air Reserve Base in Riverside, the passengers were met on the tarmac by personnel in biohazard suits, loaded onto waiting buses and instructed to remain on the base for three days of medical screening. Only when they are cleared will they be allowed to continue on home.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The authorities, however, were at pains to to say it was not a quarantine.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“We are respecting the rights of them as individuals,” said Dr. Nancy Knight, a senior official with the federal Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. “We are doing that in a way that protects their health, the health of uniformed service members and the health of the community.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The passengers, mostly American consular officials and their families, returned to the United States as the coronavirus continued to spread around the globe, with the number of cases spiking dramatically and two major airlines canceling all flights to and from China.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">By early Thursday, there were confirmed reports of infection in at least 16 countries, with more than 7,700 cases in China alone — topping the SARS outbreak there in 2002 and 2003. The official death toll there stood at 170, but the real number is believed to be much higher. On Thursday, the World Health Organization will again take up the question of whether to declare a global health emergency.</p>, <h2 class="css-zd32qr">Wuhan Coronavirus Map: Tracking the Spread of the Outbreak</h2>, <p class="css-1uuihdo">The virus has sickened tens of thousands of people in China and a number of other countries.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">As governments around the world struggle to detect and prevent infection, it was clear on Wednesday that there was no international consensus on the best way to proceed.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">However carefully the health authorities chose their words, the evacuees in the United States, for example, appeared to be, for all practical purposes, quarantined. They will also be monitored for 14 days by medical teams in their own communities when they go home.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">In Australia, Prime Minister Scott Morrison said citizens evacuated from Wuhan would be held for a two-week quarantine on Christmas Island, also the site of an Australian immigration detention center.</p>, <h1 class="g-headline" id="g-inlineguide-headline">The Coronavirus Outbreak</h1>, <h2 class="g-inlineguide-list-header g-optimize-type">What do you need to know? Start here.</h2>, <p class="g-inlineguide-date">Updated Feb. 5, 2020</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">And South Korea’s National Police Agency said that it had instructed its officers that they have the power to detain people who are suspected of carrying the coronavirus and refuse to be quarantined.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">But other countries were taking a less strict approach.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Japan, for example, also evacuated citizens from China, but acquiesced when two evacuees who did not have symptoms declined to see a doctor. A third evacuee who did show symptoms was allowed to wait for test results at home.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">As it spreads globally, the new coronavirus, which was first discovered in China last month, has begun to infect people who never visited China. Some have fallen ill in Germany, Japan, Taiwan and Vietnam.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“We’ve seen it spread between people in Wuhan, in other parts of China, and now these countries,” said Benjamin Cowling, a professor of epidemiology at the University of Hong Kong.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“What we don’t know is how quickly it spreads,” Dr. Cowling said. “We’ve seen small clusters, but we don’t know if those turn into chains of transmission that grow from two to four to eight to 16 — or if it can be controlled and won’t be further transmitted.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">As countries evacuated their citizens from Wuhan — among them France, South Korea, Morocco, Germany, Kazakhstan, Britain, Canada, Russia, the Netherlands and Myanmar — commercial airlines curtailed service to China. British Airways and Air Canada suspended flights altogether.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The Americans who were repatriated on Wednesday landed at the air base shortly after 8 a.m. after the State Department-chartered flight stopped in Anchorage to refuel and for the passengers to be screened — twice — for the virus.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">At a news conference later in Riverside, Christopher R. Braden, a deputy director of the disease control centers, said the Americans would be “fully evaluated.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“We think we can do the full evaluation in three days,” Dr. Braden said. “Some of that evaluation is taking tests and flying samples to the C.D.C. in Atlanta.” The agency has the country’s only laboratory that can test for the coronavirus.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">At a raucous, packed news conference, Dr. Braden and Dr. Knight were peppered with questions about the wisdom of releasing the former Wuhan residents into communities across the country.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Dr. Braden said that if an evacuee deemed a danger to the community insisted on leaving before the 72-hour period expired, “we can institute an individual quarantine for that person — and we will.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">But he also said there was no indication that anyone wanted to leave right away.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Some Americans remained stranded in Wuhan, unable to secure a seat on the plane. Family members were incensed to learn that the Boeing 747 had taken off with empty seats. Some passengers lacked the proper documentation, and others did not show up, Dr. Braden said. In the end, around 200 passengers were evacuated, not the expected 240, he said.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“I don’t even know what to say to those numbers,” said Jiacheng Yu of Dallas, whose mother, Ying Cheng, a 61-year-old American citizen, was visiting her own mother in Wuhan for the Lunar New Year and could not get a seat.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">When asked whether other flights were planned, a State Department official said its embassy in Beijing “continues to work with the Chinese authorities on other options for U.S. citizens in Wuhan to depart Wuhan and/or China.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">At least one American chose not to try to board Wednesday’s flight. Winifred Conrad, a 27-year-old English teacher, had a lingering cough and was afraid she would instead be handed over to Chinese officials, said her mother, Anastasia Coles of Lubbock, Texas.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">But there was another reason: Ms. Conrad’s cat, Lulu.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">In text message to her mother, she said: “Don’t freak out. I was offered a seat and I surrendered it to a 10-year-old girl.” She added, “I was told I can’t bring an animal.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The number of confirmed cases in China increased by nearly 30 percent from Wednesday to Thursday, according to the country’s National Health Commission.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The Chinese health authorities said Thursday that 170 people had died from the virus in the country. The previous count, on Wednesday, was 132.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Wang Xiaodong, the governor of Hubei, the home of province of Wuhan, said Wednesday evening that the fight against the virus was at a crucial point, and that medical supplies were severely insufficient.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">As cases emerged outside China, some appeared to involve infections between family members, who are at greater risk while caring for sick relatives. Others, however, appear to have spread between people with less intimate connections.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">A Japanese tour bus driver in his 60s who had driven two tour groups visiting Japan from Wuhan was confirmed to have the virus, officials said on Tuesday. He had no history of traveling to Wuhan.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“I think what that says is, if we can get transmission in such a setting, then we can certainly get it in the waiting room of a clinic or a hospital,” said Dr. Arthur Reingold, a professor of epidemiology at the University of California, Berkeley. “That’s very concerning.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">On Tuesday, German officials said a 33-year-old man from Starnberg, a town near Munich, was apparently infected with the virus after attending a training event with a Chinese colleague on Jan. 21. The colleague flew home two days later. The German man was being treated in isolation and officials were tracing people who had been in contact with him.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Late Tuesday, health officials in Germany said three more people from the same company had also been infected. They were admitted to a clinic in Munich, where they, too, were to be isolated. Forty other people who came into close contact with the company employees were to be tested on Wednesday, officials said.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The outbreak and the travel restrictions it has led to have already had a big impact on businesses, some of which are temporarily halting operations in parts of China.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Starbucks, for example, said it was temporarily closing half of its stores in the country. Closing were also announced by McDonald’s and Yum China, which operates the KFC, Pizza Hut and Taco Bell brands in China.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">And Apple said the outbreak could disrupt suppliers and its revenues.</p>, <p class="css-jwz2nf etfikam0">Miriam Jordan reported from Los Angeles, and Austin Ramzy from Hong Kong. Reporting was contributed by Russell Goldman from Hong Kong; Motoko Rich, Makiko Inoue and Eimi Yamamitsu from Tokyo; and Choe Sang-Hun from Seoul, South Korea.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"></p>, <p>Advertisement</p>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd" id="site-index-label">Site Index</h2>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-0">news</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-1">opinion</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-2">arts</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-3">living</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-4">more</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-subscribe-label">Subscribe</h3>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd">Site Information Navigation</h2>]
[<p>Advertisement</p>, <p>Supported by</p>, <h1 class="css-1s4ffep e1h9rw200" id="link-117f114a" itemprop="headline"><span>Coronavirus in New York: Lunar New Year Events Canceled Over Fears</span></h1>, <p class="css-1ifw933 e1wiw3jv0" id="article-summary">No confirmed case of the virus has been found in the state. But anxiety is growing in New York City’s Chinese community.</p>, <p class="css-1fv7b6t e1jsehar1" itemprop="author" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">By<!-- --> <a class="css-brehiz e1jsehar0" href="https://www.nytimes.com/by/joseph-goldstein"><span class="css-1baulvz" itemprop="name">Joseph Goldstein</span></a> and <a class="css-brehiz e1jsehar0" href="https://www.nytimes.com/by/jeffrey-e-singer"><span class="css-1baulvz last-byline" itemprop="name">Jeffrey E. Singer</span></a></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The Lunar New Year Chinese Temple Bazaar in Queens typically attracts hundreds of spectators who come to watch an array of dancers and artists.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">But this year, before the event, a paper cutting artist who had recently returned from Wuhan, China, told the organizers she was quarantining herself at home, as a precaution against the new <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/30/podcasts/the-daily/coronavirus.html" title="">coronavirus</a>. A hand puppet company also pulled out, the organizers said in an interview.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">After a series of conversations, the organizers this week <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="http://www.flushingtownhall.org/event/9cb419d1c2bf782683ec24dd3025ae4b" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">canceled the event</a> — scheduled to take place this weekend in Flushing — amid mounting anxiety over the coronavirus.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">While isolated cases have cropped up in other states, so far state public health authorities are unaware of a single case of the illness in New York. But that has not stopped a vigorous debate within the city’s Chinatowns about whether to proceed with Lunar New Year celebrations.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The Temple Bazaar party, which its organizers say attracted between 700 and 1,000 people last year, appears to be the highest-profile event yet canceled in the city. But other smaller local Lunar New Year celebrations and gala dinners <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.singtaousa.com/ny/436-%E7%B4%90%E7%B4%84/2675363-%E5%8F%97%E6%96%B0%E7%96%AB%E6%83%85%E5%BD%B1%E9%9F%BF+%E5%A4%9A%E5%80%8B%E5%83%91%E5%9C%98%E5%8F%96%E6%B6%88%E6%96%B0%E5%B9%B4%E8%81%9A%E6%9C%83/" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">have been canceled or postponed</a>, as well.</p>, <h3 class="css-1if23m2">Listen to ‘The Daily’: A Virus’s Journey Across China</h3>, <p class="css-1qi8px4">transcript</p>, <h2 class="css-9wqu2x">Listen to ‘The Daily’: A Virus’s Journey Across China</h2>, <h3 class="css-eq2co1">Hosted by Michael Barbaro; produced by Neena Pathak, Annie Brown and Eric Krupke; with help from Kelly Prime; and edited by M.J. Davis Lin and Mike Benoist</h3>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">From The New York Times, I’m Michael Barbaro. This is “The Daily.”</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd"></p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">Today: China says it has made lifesaving reforms since the last time it was the source of a public health crisis 17 years ago. So why is the deadly coronavirus spreading so rapidly across the country? My colleague, Javier Hernández, reports from the center of the outbreak.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">It’s Thursday, January 30.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">Javier, how did you first hear about this outbreak?</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">Well, we started hearing reports in early January that there was this mysterious virus that was affecting Wuhan, which is a city in central China.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">Staff at Wuhan Hospital are working around the clock to identify a mystery virus.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">People were falling ill to this kind of pneumonia-like virus, which scientists were calling a coronavirus.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">Experts believe this is a new kind of coronavirus, which typically causes symptoms of the common cold, but in some rare cases, can lead to pneumonia.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">It’s a very frightening virus that spreads from animals to humans. It was believed to be behind some very serious respiratory illnesses, so it sounded pretty scary. But the official narrative was that this strain couldn’t pass from human to human. It would only go from animals to humans.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">The potentially deadly coronavirus is thought to have spread from animals into humans at a live produce market in Wuhan.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">And at that point, they were saying that it was all originating at a single meat market in central China. This meat market sold wild animals, things like bamboo rats, badgers, wolves even. And the assumption was that people had come into contact with these animals and picked up this virus.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">And it sounds like because it was one meat market, and because this virus could only pass from animals to humans, that this is a pretty small problem.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">At this point, the reports were that only about 130 people had been infected and that, of those, only about four had died.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">Chinese officials say the outbreak is under control.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">And so the prognosis was that the outbreak was controllable, that it was treatable and that things would be O.K.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">And Javier, what are you thinking when you hear the Chinese government talking this way, saying that everything is going to be O.K.?</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">We were a bit skeptical. We knew that the Chinese government had a history of downplaying outbreaks like this. And as we saw more and more reports in the international media of this virus spreading, we began to question whether the officials were being totally upfront about what was happening.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">And what do you mean when you say a history of downplaying situations like this?</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">Well before this virus, there was the outbreak of SARS 17 years ago. And it turned into this global health crisis that infected more than 8,000 people. It killed more than 800 people. And a big part of the reason that it spread so violently was because the Chinese government didn’t tell the world. And there was this period of months and months when it was spreading very rapidly in China, and the world just didn’t know about it. And for a lot of Chinese today, that experience with SARS makes them very skeptical of anything that the government says when it comes to public health.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">And I imagine a reporter like you would be similarly skeptical.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">Right. We really wanted to make sure that we got this one right.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">We wanted to double check that this was, in fact, a small scale outbreak as the government was portraying it. And we wanted to talk to people who were getting sick with this virus to get a sense of what it was like for them — how severe it was, whether they were getting the care they needed.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">And so what do you do?</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">So I live in Beijing. So I rushed to our bureau here and grabbed masks, enough to last me a couple days, and then headed to the airport and boarded a flight to Wuhan. And I just remember everyone on board, almost everyone, was wearing a mask. I was just struck by that. You never see people wear masks on this scale. And so it felt like there was this sense of anxiety already in the air even before we landed.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd"></p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">Once I got there, I rushed off to meet an ambulance doctor who had been posting on social media about this outbreak. And we had contacted him because he was challenging the official narrative about what was happening. He was saying he didn’t believe the official numbers. He thought that this could be another SARS-like outbreak.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">And what was happening to his posts once they went online?</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">They lasted for a while, and then they would be taken down, just disappeared. It was clear that the government was cleaning and trying to scrub the internet of any critical questions about official data. And so we wanted to talk to him about what he was seeing on the ground.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">And what did he tell you?</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">He told me that he felt like people weren’t taking enough precautions, that the government wasn’t being urgent enough. And he worked in a hospital and had a lot of interaction with doctors and other medical workers. So he felt like his job could be at stake if he were to come forward publicly.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">So the numbers the Chinese government is providing are relatively small. This ambulance doctor you’re meeting with is saying the problem is bigger. So what do you do to try to reconcile those two pieces of information?</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">We wanted to find the people whose relatives had fallen ill to this virus. And so we were looking online for people who were reporting symptoms of fever, cough, basically anything that was associated with this kind of virus. And we stumbled on a guy from Shanghai. He was a 40-year-old architect, and he told me that his stepmother had died just a couple of days earlier from a mysterious pneumonia-like illness. And so I found him, sent him a message, and we agreed to meet at a cafe. [CHATTER]</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">And what is the story of what happened to his stepmom?</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">He tells me that she was a very healthy, normal 65-year-old woman who, a couple of weeks earlier, had started to feel like she was having a flu. So she had some coughing. She had kind of a sore throat, but it didn’t seem like anything that bad. But it suddenly began to worsen. She was having a fever. She needed a respirator to breathe. And all very suddenly she was sent to a contagious disease ward, and the family was told that she would likely die.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">And what did she or her stepson understand about what was behind her illness?</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">They didn’t really understand much. For days and days, according to Mr. Wei, the family had tried to get her tested for this coronavirus, this mysterious virus that was spreading across Wuhan. And the doctors and other medical workers refused.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">He pulled out his phone and showed me her death certificate, and all it said was that she died of severe pneumonia.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">But why wouldn’t they test her, and what does it tell you that they wouldn’t test her?</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">It became clear to me in that moment that there seemed to be something going on here. Were these hospitals just not prepared? Did they not have enough testing kits? Were they running out of tests? Had they tested so many people that they didn’t have any tests left? Were they just not counting people anymore because they weren’t even diagnosing them? And if she wasn’t diagnosed with this illness, then maybe she wasn’t even included in the official count. And one other thing really stuck with me from my interview with Mr. Wei. And that was that the hospital, according to him, told them that his mother’s body had to be burned immediately, had to be cremated immediately. [CHATTER]</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">And what does that tell you? What does that mean to you that they’re burning these bodies?</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">It began to put in my head the sense that the hospital workers were beginning to think that this illness was contagious. And the fact that they wanted that body burned immediately began to suggest that perhaps they thought it posed a threat to other people.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">Her death got us thinking about whether there were other people like her. And when you went online and search social media, you could quickly find others who were reporting similar experiences — people saying that they went to hospitals, they brought their sick relatives and were simply turned away. We began to kind of add things up, and it seemed like the numbers weren’t right.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">So at this point, it sounds like your skepticism is growing, and it’s sounding pretty warranted. So what do you do next?</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">So I head back to my hotel and start to try to make sense of all of this. And as I’m sitting there in my room, I begin to see these reports emerging on social media —</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">For the first time since the mysterious pneumonia-like illness broke out in China, the country’s health authorities admitted the disease could be contagious.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">— that one of China’s top health experts has acknowledged that this virus is now spreading from person to person, which had never been the case before.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">[SPEAKING CHINESE]</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">We considered risks of this before, but now evidence has confirmed that it is contagious among humans.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">And he’s an 83-year-old guy that they dug out of retirement essentially. He was a renowned expert during the SARS crisis. And suddenly, he’s all over social media, telling people that this crisis is much worse than had been previously known.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">So this doctor is very much validating what you have been hearing.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">Yes. He’s saying that there was even a case where one patient was able to infect 14 medical workers.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">Wow.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">And I begin to see the panic kind of spread across social media.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">Say I have coronavirus. Could I give it to you right now?</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">It’s possible, if you’re coughing and sneezing. If you have a fever, it can be transmitted.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">But the spread of Corona virus is accelerating.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">This is the moment when the world begins to wake up.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">Meanwhile, new cases are being confirmed outside of China as well.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">Thailand has reported the first case of the Wuhan coronavirus found outside of China.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">— because now they’re talking Thailand, Singapore, possibly Scotland. The U.K. is bracing for it to go in there. We have airports here in the United States very concerned about it —</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">That are doing surveillance.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">— here in New York, Chicago and L.A. Every day it seems growing exponentially.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">It is. It’s growing.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">The numbers after that point just keep spiraling and spiraling.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">The number of people who have died —</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">The death toll climbing once again overnight.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">The death toll from a deadly viral outbreak of the new coronavirus —</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">26 deaths so far from the —</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">— has now passed 40.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">[SPEAKING CHINESE]</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">It’s not just Chinese people who are worried. Everyone is worried. They’re all afraid of dying.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">You just hear people wondering whether the virus is ever going to be contained.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">We’ll be right back.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">And Javier, what are you thinking and feeling at this moment? Because you’re in this city. You’re interacting with people who are taking care of those who are sickened and infected by this illness.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">Yeah.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">Are you anxious?</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">Well I’m beginning to feel like this is much worse than I thought. And I think a sense of paranoia can easily settle in sometimes in these situations. I had masks. I was washing my hands all the time. But I couldn’t help but think about every button in the elevator that I touched, every surface and every cough or sniffle that I saw around me. The virus could be anywhere, so I had to be careful.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">I mean, understandably.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">So I finished up my reporting, and I grabbed a flight back to Beijing.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">Just one day before China’s massive Lunar New Year holiday, as hundreds of millions crisscross the country to celebrate with families, an unprecedented act.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">And then the very next day, I hear —</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">Today, the entire city of Wuhan, population 11 million, is on lockdown.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">The Chinese government has placed this entire city under lockdown.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">Wow.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">Trains, flights, buses, and ferries have been canceled. Even public transport within Wuhan has ground to a halt.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">So the city you have just left has basically told everybody else who remains that they’re not going anywhere.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">Right. This city is being closed off in a way that China has never done before — or even any other major modern city, really, hasn’t done it in recent times.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">Across China tonight, an expanding lockdown to contain an epidemic.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">And it was quickly becoming clear to the government that this wasn’t just a local problem.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">Travel bans in over a dozen cities affecting 35 million people.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">They quickly expanded it to not just Wuhan, but to other cities, so that there were tens of millions of people who were essentially forced to stay at home and not allowed to go out. They’ve just put in place the biggest lockdown that we’ve ever seen and what experts are saying is the biggest experiment in public health that they’ve ever seen.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">Despite their efforts, authorities say the virus has not been stopped.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">Much depends on whether the measures set in place by the Chinese government will prove effective.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">It’s hard to imagine most any other country being able to mount that kind of a response. I mean, I’m just trying to fathom an American city somehow being locked down.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">So this is what it looks like when China’s authoritarian system is in full force. There’s no choice for people to leave. Many people are stuck there. They are going to hospitals that are overcrowded, but they can’t get the health care they need. Doctors are complaining about a lack of medical supplies and critical items like masks and goggles. And you get the sense that people are kind of stuck with what they have, and that’s the bargain they’ve made by living in this system. They have no choice but to follow the government’s orders. They can’t push back. They can’t swim against the current here. Everyone’s essentially forced to comply with this mass lockdown.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">You know, from everything we’ve learned about China and its authoritarian government, it seems like it controls every aspect of its citizens’ lives and it surveils every aspect of citizens’ lives. And you’ve just walked us through how they were able to essentially suddenly drop a wall around Wuhan. So knowing all that, shouldn’t China’s government have been able to identify and control this outbreak before it got out of hand?</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">You would think that, because the government is so well known for being able to pull off these massive displays of citizen mobilization — it’s been known to be able to pull off these technological feats. But at the same time, there’s a flip side of this coin, which is that China’s authoritarian culture, in many ways, set the stage for this crisis.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">What do you mean?</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">Well for decades, China has built this system, this ruthless system in which if you are an official in the Communist Party, you are expected to be almost perfect. If anything goes bad, you are the one who is going to take responsibility. You are the one who is going to fall. And this has created an incentive system where local officials fear saying anything about bad news. They worry that if they are found to have done something wrong, that they will lose their power. So in a situation like this, the incentive is to cover up. It’s to conceal. It’s to delay. It’s to try to get a handle on these problems on your own, hoping that perhaps nobody will ever hear about it.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">So by the time something like, say, a medical crisis gets really big, it may be too late for the local officials who have been trying to contain it themselves and keep it from Beijing.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">Exactly. These kinds of dynamics played a huge role in the scale of the SARS outbreak. It was clear in this case that local officials knew exactly what was going on. They knew that people were dying of this illness. But for months and months, they didn’t want to report it up the chain. Instead, they tried to cover it up. They tried to see if they could perhaps deal with it secretly, and maybe nobody would ever find out about it. They hoped that Beijing would know about it. But eventually it broke.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">So did China learn from that experience with SARS, that dynamic that led to that breakdown, that cover-up?</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">China said it would make a lot of changes to its system after the SARS crisis. It said that it would expand its disease reporting system so that these kinds of reports from the local provinces would come to the central government in a more timely fashion. They promised to be more transparent in the release of data and other things. But what they didn’t change was this authoritarian culture, where people fear bringing bad news. And so that has actually gotten worse under President Xi.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">Why?</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">He has made himself out to be the most powerful leader since Mao. He is somebody who’s always speaking about this great ascendant moment for China in which China is going to be this superpower. And anything that goes against Xi’s vision of this harmonious, resurgent China is going to be seen as a problem. And the people who are creating that problem will pay the consequences. And when I was there in Wuhan, I could sense the fear just rippling across all parts of the society. There were people like the ambulance doctor, who was afraid of challenging the official statistics. There were hospitals that seemed to be paralyzed, that didn’t want to test patients for fear of knowing the results. They didn’t want to be seen as speaking out or telling the truth or bringing this unsavory story into public view.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">So that had trickled down all the way to the frontline health care workers, who are supposed to be treating this and sounding the alarm.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">Right. They’re fearful of being seen as responsible for this crisis. They don’t want to stand out. And when you think about where this virus might be headed next — to other provinces, to other cities — you have to wonder if these same dynamics would be playing out again. If people will stay silent, if they will not report official cases, because they fear for their jobs and they fear for their livelihoods.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">So it seems like whatever reforms the Chinese government made after the failures of SARS, that in the end, none of them really matter, because it hasn’t changed the problem that’s at the root of this.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">At the root of all this is a sense of fear that is both the Communist Party’s strength, but it’s also a huge weakness. They can mobilize entire cities to be on lockdown. They can convince people to stay indoors. They can scrub social media of information that counters their narrative. That’s all very effective when you’re trying to get the public behind your policies. But at the end of the day, the fear is also a huge vulnerability. It creates this system where people are unwilling to speak out, unwilling to bring problems that are really important and that affect people’s lives.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">Right. I mean, for the Chinese leadership, that works until it doesn’t, right? Until you very much need for people to stop being afraid and to speak out about something like a public health crisis.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">Exactly.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">And so when you look at the culture, you wonder whether China can actually contain these viruses, whether we will continue to live in a world where the internal politics of the party are going to put lives around the world in danger.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">Javier, thank you.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">Thanks, Michael.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">On Wednesday, the total number of people infected by the coronavirus in mainland China surpassed those infected with the SARS virus during that epidemic. As of Wednesday evening, the virus had infected more than 6,000 people in mainland China. Later today, the World Health Organization will convene its emergency committee to determine whether the outbreak amounts to a public health emergency of international concern, its most severe classification.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">We’ll be right back.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">Here’s what else you need to know today. The Times reports that the White House has sent former national security adviser, John Bolton, a letter, warning him not to publish a book in which he recounts speaking to President Trump about the quid pro quo with Ukraine at the heart of the impeachment trial. In the letter, the White House claims that the book contains significant amounts of classified information that could harm U.S. national security. The letter was sent before The Times published a story describing the book’s contents, a story that has further fueled calls for Bolton to testify in the Senate trial. Senators are expected to vote on whether to call witnesses like Bolton later today.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd"> That’s it for “The Daily.” I’m Michael Barbaro. See you tomorrow.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The cancellations are just one sign of rising anxiety across the city over the coronavirus. In recent days, for instance, the sight of people wearing surgical masks in the subway has become more common. Around the city, some students have shown up to school wearing masks.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">City health officials have urged New Yorkers to go about their lives. They say there is no reason for healthy people to shy away from public gatherings — even those who recently returned from Wuhan, where the virus is believed to have originated.</p>, <h1 class="g-headline" id="g-inlineguide-headline">The Coronavirus Outbreak</h1>, <h2 class="g-inlineguide-list-header g-optimize-type">How Is the U.S. Being Affected?</h2>, <p class="g-inlineguide-date">Updated Feb.10, 2020</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">This week, health officials across New York have sent samples — taken by means of an oral swab, nasal swab and by asking the patient to spit — from at least 10 people to the C.D.C. in Atlanta to be tested for the virus. The results that have come back have all been negative. A few were still pending as of the last update.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Some people on the last direct flights from Wuhan to Kennedy International Airport — before they were canceled last week — <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/27/nyregion/new-york-city-coronavirus.html" title="">have been in self-imposed quarantine</a> at their homes, limiting their contact with their own families.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/29/world/asia/coronavirus-china.html" title="">With more than 6,000 confirmed cases of the virus in China</a>, many local Chinese-American civic and cultural leaders fear that their community will be blamed or face stigma should the illness land in New York.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“I think the Chinese community also doesn’t want to be scapegoated,” said Amy Chin, a genealogist and cultural activist. “Those of us who know our history, there is a sensitivity.” Ms. Chin was referring to a quarantine of San Francisco’s Chinatown <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2019/04/09/health/measles-outbreak-vaccinations-brooklyn.html" title="">more than a century ago</a> amid fears over the plague.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Ms. Chin recalled how in 2003, fear over SARS, another coronavirus, <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2003/05/10/nyregion/fear-not-sars-rattles-south-jersey-school.html" title="">led a New Jersey school </a>to cancel a Chinese cultural program amid concerns from parents that the dancers performing at the event might have the illness.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“There is a lot of anxiety about how we need to work together as a community, and that we need to lower the risk,” said Ya Yun Teng, who was involved in organizing the canceled Temple Bazaar event in Flushing.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">This weekend, Wu Hongguang, chairman of the Wenzhou Association, canceled his group’s Lunar New Year celebration at the <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.facebook.com/RoyalQueenNY/" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">Royal Queen</a> restaurant in Flushing because of the virus.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“We’re afraid!” Mr. Wu exclaimed, in Mandarin, from the association’s headquarters on Northern Boulevard. “A lot of our members are older and we’re afraid many could get sick.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The Royal Queen is a spacious banquet hall — located on the top floor of the New World Mall in the center of Flushing — that can accommodate more than a thousand people.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">On any given evening in the days surrounding the Lunar New Year it’s usually packed with Chinese revelers from large associations. There are festive scenes, sumptuous platters of Chinese delicacies, and the clanking of plates and glasses over the din of people shouting out their toasts and well wishes.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">But the scene was different on Tuesday night. The escalator led onto a floor of empty banquet tables.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The manager, Connie Zhang, sat at a table against the wall. Ms. Zhang acknowledged that there were many cancellations. She had returned all the deposits that groups had paid to secure the space.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">But, she said, weddings were still being booked.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“You can’t cancel weddings,” she said.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">At SkyFoods, a Chinese supermarket on Main Street in Flushing, Mark Zhao, 36, the night manager, said the store had planned to hold their annual New Year’s celebration on Tuesday. As always, they had invited wholesalers, management and members of the staff from both of the store’s locations.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">But last week they canceled the event, which was supposed to be at the Royal Queen. Hundreds were expected to attend.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“We couldn’t go on and have a party while there is still so much happening in China,” Mr. Zhao, who was wearing a mask, said in Mandarin. “At least for now.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">He added: “When things start to settle down we’ll consider it. Maybe next month.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Councilman Peter Koo, who attends many of these events every year, said he understood the concern since the parties are large and people often end up sitting with people they don’t know. But he urged caution.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“We don’t want people to be overly alarmed because there are no confirmed cases,” he said. “We just want everybody to be careful and practice basic hygiene — wash your hands and sneeze into your elbows — and don’t believe everything you see on social media, including Chinese social media. There’s a lot that’s inaccurate.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Despite the many cancellations, several high-profile Lunar New Year events have occurred as planned. Flushing’s largest Lunar New Year parade happened this past weekend.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“People are tough,” said John Choe, the executive director of the Greater Flushing Chamber of Commerce. “We are going to keep doing what we do.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">He acknowledged that parade turnout was lower this year, but noted that it had rained. “There was lower attendance,” he said, “but we don’t know if it was rain or fear of coronavirus.”</p>, <p>Advertisement</p>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd" id="site-index-label">Site Index</h2>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-0">news</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-1">opinion</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-2">arts</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-3">living</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-4">more</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-subscribe-label">Subscribe</h3>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd">Site Information Navigation</h2>]
[<p>Advertisement</p>, <p>Supported by</p>, <p class="css-tsacue e6idgb70">Global health</p>, <h1 class="css-1s4ffep e1h9rw200" id="link-98a2f59" itemprop="headline"><span>Mask Hoarders May Raise Risk of a Coronavirus Outbreak in the U.S.</span></h1>, <p class="css-1ifw933 e1wiw3jv0" id="article-summary">Stores are selling out of masks, and health care workers risk infection if they cannot get the protective gear.</p>, <p class="css-1fv7b6t e1jsehar1" itemprop="author" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">By<!-- --> <a class="css-brehiz e1jsehar0" href="https://www.nytimes.com/by/donald-g-mcneil-jr"><span class="css-1baulvz last-byline" itemprop="name">Donald G. McNeil Jr.</span></a></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Even though there are only five cases of <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/30/podcasts/the-daily/coronavirus.html" title="">Wuhan coronavirus</a> in the United States, the <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.cnn.com/2020/01/28/health/coronavirus-us-masks-prevention-trnd/index.html" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">mask hoarding</a> <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://finance.yahoo.com/news/china-virus-outbreak-triggers-global-082240405.html" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">has begun</a>.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Some pharmacies <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://gothamist.com/news/chinese-new-yorkers-worried-about-coronavirus-are-wearing-masks-do-they-work" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">report being entirely sold out</a> of masks. Some <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.businessinsider.com/amazon-sold-out-sellers-warn-counterfeit-masks-coronavirus-2020-1" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">popular sellers on Amazon</a> say deliveries will be delayed for weeks.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Although masks actually <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/28/opinion/coronavirus-prevention-tips.html?action=click&amp;module=Opinion&amp;pgtype=Homepage" title="">do little to protect healthy people</a>, the prospect of shortages created by panic buying worries some public health experts.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Masks are thought to slow the spread of disease when they are worn by sick people in crowded places like emergency rooms, offices, subways and buses. By containing coughs and sneezes, masks stop virus-laden droplets from being spewed into the air and onto nearby surfaces.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">But hoarding by those who are well means that hospitals, clinics and doctors’ offices could run short. Doctors and nurses treating patients for respiratory infections should wear masks and replace them often — as soon as they become soggy, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention says.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The C.D.C. is now reaching out to manufacturers to head off the possibility of shortages, especially in hospitals, an agency official said.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“We see panic ordering and buying that doesn’t reflect the actual need,” said Dr. Anita Patel, the senior adviser for pandemic medical care in the agency’s influenza coordination unit. “We’re talking to manufacturers. They understand the situation, and I’m confident that they are being responsible. The health care industry is their biggest customer.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">On Tuesday, Alex M. Azar II, the secretary of health and human services, said it was “unnecessary” for Americans to buy masks now.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“In the U.S., the risk to any individual American is extremely low,” he said.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Some experts want the government to step in and educate the public about the dangers of hoarding.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“I worked through the 2009 H1N1 flu epidemic at Yale Hospital, and we ran out of N-95 masks — and being in a high-risk situation without enough masks is not a good feeling,” said Dr. Peter Rabinowitz, co-director of the University of Washington MetaCenter for Pandemic Preparedness and Global Health Security in Seattle.</p>, <h1 class="g-headline" id="g-inlineguide-headline">The Coronavirus Outbreak</h1>, <h2 class="g-inlineguide-list-header g-optimize-type">What do you need to know? Start here.</h2>, <p class="g-inlineguide-date">Updated Feb. 10, 2020</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“There’s no rational reason why everyone needs to run out and get masks,” he added. “Public health officials should be talking about this.”</p>, <h3 class="css-1if23m2">Listen to ‘The Daily’: A Virus’s Journey Across China</h3>, <p class="css-1qi8px4">transcript</p>, <h2 class="css-9wqu2x">Listen to ‘The Daily’: A Virus’s Journey Across China</h2>, <h3 class="css-eq2co1">Hosted by Michael Barbaro; produced by Neena Pathak, Annie Brown and Eric Krupke; with help from Kelly Prime; and edited by M.J. Davis Lin and Mike Benoist</h3>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">From The New York Times, I’m Michael Barbaro. This is “The Daily.”</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd"></p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">Today: China says it has made lifesaving reforms since the last time it was the source of a public health crisis 17 years ago. So why is the deadly coronavirus spreading so rapidly across the country? My colleague, Javier Hernández, reports from the center of the outbreak.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">It’s Thursday, January 30.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">Javier, how did you first hear about this outbreak?</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">Well, we started hearing reports in early January that there was this mysterious virus that was affecting Wuhan, which is a city in central China.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">Staff at Wuhan Hospital are working around the clock to identify a mystery virus.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">People were falling ill to this kind of pneumonia-like virus, which scientists were calling a coronavirus.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">Experts believe this is a new kind of coronavirus, which typically causes symptoms of the common cold, but in some rare cases, can lead to pneumonia.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">It’s a very frightening virus that spreads from animals to humans. It was believed to be behind some very serious respiratory illnesses, so it sounded pretty scary. But the official narrative was that this strain couldn’t pass from human to human. It would only go from animals to humans.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">The potentially deadly coronavirus is thought to have spread from animals into humans at a live produce market in Wuhan.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">And at that point, they were saying that it was all originating at a single meat market in central China. This meat market sold wild animals, things like bamboo rats, badgers, wolves even. And the assumption was that people had come into contact with these animals and picked up this virus.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">And it sounds like because it was one meat market, and because this virus could only pass from animals to humans, that this is a pretty small problem.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">At this point, the reports were that only about 130 people had been infected and that, of those, only about four had died.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">Chinese officials say the outbreak is under control.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">And so the prognosis was that the outbreak was controllable, that it was treatable and that things would be O.K.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">And Javier, what are you thinking when you hear the Chinese government talking this way, saying that everything is going to be O.K.?</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">We were a bit skeptical. We knew that the Chinese government had a history of downplaying outbreaks like this. And as we saw more and more reports in the international media of this virus spreading, we began to question whether the officials were being totally upfront about what was happening.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">And what do you mean when you say a history of downplaying situations like this?</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">Well before this virus, there was the outbreak of SARS 17 years ago. And it turned into this global health crisis that infected more than 8,000 people. It killed more than 800 people. And a big part of the reason that it spread so violently was because the Chinese government didn’t tell the world. And there was this period of months and months when it was spreading very rapidly in China, and the world just didn’t know about it. And for a lot of Chinese today, that experience with SARS makes them very skeptical of anything that the government says when it comes to public health.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">And I imagine a reporter like you would be similarly skeptical.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">Right. We really wanted to make sure that we got this one right.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">We wanted to double check that this was, in fact, a small scale outbreak as the government was portraying it. And we wanted to talk to people who were getting sick with this virus to get a sense of what it was like for them — how severe it was, whether they were getting the care they needed.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">And so what do you do?</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">So I live in Beijing. So I rushed to our bureau here and grabbed masks, enough to last me a couple days, and then headed to the airport and boarded a flight to Wuhan. And I just remember everyone on board, almost everyone, was wearing a mask. I was just struck by that. You never see people wear masks on this scale. And so it felt like there was this sense of anxiety already in the air even before we landed.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd"></p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">Once I got there, I rushed off to meet an ambulance doctor who had been posting on social media about this outbreak. And we had contacted him because he was challenging the official narrative about what was happening. He was saying he didn’t believe the official numbers. He thought that this could be another SARS-like outbreak.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">And what was happening to his posts once they went online?</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">They lasted for a while, and then they would be taken down, just disappeared. It was clear that the government was cleaning and trying to scrub the internet of any critical questions about official data. And so we wanted to talk to him about what he was seeing on the ground.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">And what did he tell you?</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">He told me that he felt like people weren’t taking enough precautions, that the government wasn’t being urgent enough. And he worked in a hospital and had a lot of interaction with doctors and other medical workers. So he felt like his job could be at stake if he were to come forward publicly.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">So the numbers the Chinese government is providing are relatively small. This ambulance doctor you’re meeting with is saying the problem is bigger. So what do you do to try to reconcile those two pieces of information?</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">We wanted to find the people whose relatives had fallen ill to this virus. And so we were looking online for people who were reporting symptoms of fever, cough, basically anything that was associated with this kind of virus. And we stumbled on a guy from Shanghai. He was a 40-year-old architect, and he told me that his stepmother had died just a couple of days earlier from a mysterious pneumonia-like illness. And so I found him, sent him a message, and we agreed to meet at a cafe. [CHATTER]</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">And what is the story of what happened to his stepmom?</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">He tells me that she was a very healthy, normal 65-year-old woman who, a couple of weeks earlier, had started to feel like she was having a flu. So she had some coughing. She had kind of a sore throat, but it didn’t seem like anything that bad. But it suddenly began to worsen. She was having a fever. She needed a respirator to breathe. And all very suddenly she was sent to a contagious disease ward, and the family was told that she would likely die.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">And what did she or her stepson understand about what was behind her illness?</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">They didn’t really understand much. For days and days, according to Mr. Wei, the family had tried to get her tested for this coronavirus, this mysterious virus that was spreading across Wuhan. And the doctors and other medical workers refused.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">He pulled out his phone and showed me her death certificate, and all it said was that she died of severe pneumonia.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">But why wouldn’t they test her, and what does it tell you that they wouldn’t test her?</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">It became clear to me in that moment that there seemed to be something going on here. Were these hospitals just not prepared? Did they not have enough testing kits? Were they running out of tests? Had they tested so many people that they didn’t have any tests left? Were they just not counting people anymore because they weren’t even diagnosing them? And if she wasn’t diagnosed with this illness, then maybe she wasn’t even included in the official count. And one other thing really stuck with me from my interview with Mr. Wei. And that was that the hospital, according to him, told them that his mother’s body had to be burned immediately, had to be cremated immediately. [CHATTER]</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">And what does that tell you? What does that mean to you that they’re burning these bodies?</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">It began to put in my head the sense that the hospital workers were beginning to think that this illness was contagious. And the fact that they wanted that body burned immediately began to suggest that perhaps they thought it posed a threat to other people.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">Her death got us thinking about whether there were other people like her. And when you went online and search social media, you could quickly find others who were reporting similar experiences — people saying that they went to hospitals, they brought their sick relatives and were simply turned away. We began to kind of add things up, and it seemed like the numbers weren’t right.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">So at this point, it sounds like your skepticism is growing, and it’s sounding pretty warranted. So what do you do next?</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">So I head back to my hotel and start to try to make sense of all of this. And as I’m sitting there in my room, I begin to see these reports emerging on social media —</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">For the first time since the mysterious pneumonia-like illness broke out in China, the country’s health authorities admitted the disease could be contagious.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">— that one of China’s top health experts has acknowledged that this virus is now spreading from person to person, which had never been the case before.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">[SPEAKING CHINESE]</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">We considered risks of this before, but now evidence has confirmed that it is contagious among humans.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">And he’s an 83-year-old guy that they dug out of retirement essentially. He was a renowned expert during the SARS crisis. And suddenly, he’s all over social media, telling people that this crisis is much worse than had been previously known.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">So this doctor is very much validating what you have been hearing.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">Yes. He’s saying that there was even a case where one patient was able to infect 14 medical workers.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">Wow.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">And I begin to see the panic kind of spread across social media.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">Say I have coronavirus. Could I give it to you right now?</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">It’s possible, if you’re coughing and sneezing. If you have a fever, it can be transmitted.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">But the spread of Corona virus is accelerating.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">This is the moment when the world begins to wake up.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">Meanwhile, new cases are being confirmed outside of China as well.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">Thailand has reported the first case of the Wuhan coronavirus found outside of China.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">— because now they’re talking Thailand, Singapore, possibly Scotland. The U.K. is bracing for it to go in there. We have airports here in the United States very concerned about it —</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">That are doing surveillance.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">— here in New York, Chicago and L.A. Every day it seems growing exponentially.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">It is. It’s growing.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">The numbers after that point just keep spiraling and spiraling.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">The number of people who have died —</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">The death toll climbing once again overnight.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">The death toll from a deadly viral outbreak of the new coronavirus —</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">26 deaths so far from the —</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">— has now passed 40.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">[SPEAKING CHINESE]</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">It’s not just Chinese people who are worried. Everyone is worried. They’re all afraid of dying.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">You just hear people wondering whether the virus is ever going to be contained.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">We’ll be right back.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">And Javier, what are you thinking and feeling at this moment? Because you’re in this city. You’re interacting with people who are taking care of those who are sickened and infected by this illness.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">Yeah.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">Are you anxious?</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">Well I’m beginning to feel like this is much worse than I thought. And I think a sense of paranoia can easily settle in sometimes in these situations. I had masks. I was washing my hands all the time. But I couldn’t help but think about every button in the elevator that I touched, every surface and every cough or sniffle that I saw around me. The virus could be anywhere, so I had to be careful.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">I mean, understandably.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">So I finished up my reporting, and I grabbed a flight back to Beijing.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">Just one day before China’s massive Lunar New Year holiday, as hundreds of millions crisscross the country to celebrate with families, an unprecedented act.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">And then the very next day, I hear —</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">Today, the entire city of Wuhan, population 11 million, is on lockdown.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">The Chinese government has placed this entire city under lockdown.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">Wow.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">Trains, flights, buses, and ferries have been canceled. Even public transport within Wuhan has ground to a halt.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">So the city you have just left has basically told everybody else who remains that they’re not going anywhere.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">Right. This city is being closed off in a way that China has never done before — or even any other major modern city, really, hasn’t done it in recent times.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">Across China tonight, an expanding lockdown to contain an epidemic.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">And it was quickly becoming clear to the government that this wasn’t just a local problem.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">Travel bans in over a dozen cities affecting 35 million people.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">They quickly expanded it to not just Wuhan, but to other cities, so that there were tens of millions of people who were essentially forced to stay at home and not allowed to go out. They’ve just put in place the biggest lockdown that we’ve ever seen and what experts are saying is the biggest experiment in public health that they’ve ever seen.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">Despite their efforts, authorities say the virus has not been stopped.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">Much depends on whether the measures set in place by the Chinese government will prove effective.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">It’s hard to imagine most any other country being able to mount that kind of a response. I mean, I’m just trying to fathom an American city somehow being locked down.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">So this is what it looks like when China’s authoritarian system is in full force. There’s no choice for people to leave. Many people are stuck there. They are going to hospitals that are overcrowded, but they can’t get the health care they need. Doctors are complaining about a lack of medical supplies and critical items like masks and goggles. And you get the sense that people are kind of stuck with what they have, and that’s the bargain they’ve made by living in this system. They have no choice but to follow the government’s orders. They can’t push back. They can’t swim against the current here. Everyone’s essentially forced to comply with this mass lockdown.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">You know, from everything we’ve learned about China and its authoritarian government, it seems like it controls every aspect of its citizens’ lives and it surveils every aspect of citizens’ lives. And you’ve just walked us through how they were able to essentially suddenly drop a wall around Wuhan. So knowing all that, shouldn’t China’s government have been able to identify and control this outbreak before it got out of hand?</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">You would think that, because the government is so well known for being able to pull off these massive displays of citizen mobilization — it’s been known to be able to pull off these technological feats. But at the same time, there’s a flip side of this coin, which is that China’s authoritarian culture, in many ways, set the stage for this crisis.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">What do you mean?</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">Well for decades, China has built this system, this ruthless system in which if you are an official in the Communist Party, you are expected to be almost perfect. If anything goes bad, you are the one who is going to take responsibility. You are the one who is going to fall. And this has created an incentive system where local officials fear saying anything about bad news. They worry that if they are found to have done something wrong, that they will lose their power. So in a situation like this, the incentive is to cover up. It’s to conceal. It’s to delay. It’s to try to get a handle on these problems on your own, hoping that perhaps nobody will ever hear about it.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">So by the time something like, say, a medical crisis gets really big, it may be too late for the local officials who have been trying to contain it themselves and keep it from Beijing.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">Exactly. These kinds of dynamics played a huge role in the scale of the SARS outbreak. It was clear in this case that local officials knew exactly what was going on. They knew that people were dying of this illness. But for months and months, they didn’t want to report it up the chain. Instead, they tried to cover it up. They tried to see if they could perhaps deal with it secretly, and maybe nobody would ever find out about it. They hoped that Beijing would know about it. But eventually it broke.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">So did China learn from that experience with SARS, that dynamic that led to that breakdown, that cover-up?</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">China said it would make a lot of changes to its system after the SARS crisis. It said that it would expand its disease reporting system so that these kinds of reports from the local provinces would come to the central government in a more timely fashion. They promised to be more transparent in the release of data and other things. But what they didn’t change was this authoritarian culture, where people fear bringing bad news. And so that has actually gotten worse under President Xi.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">Why?</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">He has made himself out to be the most powerful leader since Mao. He is somebody who’s always speaking about this great ascendant moment for China in which China is going to be this superpower. And anything that goes against Xi’s vision of this harmonious, resurgent China is going to be seen as a problem. And the people who are creating that problem will pay the consequences. And when I was there in Wuhan, I could sense the fear just rippling across all parts of the society. There were people like the ambulance doctor, who was afraid of challenging the official statistics. There were hospitals that seemed to be paralyzed, that didn’t want to test patients for fear of knowing the results. They didn’t want to be seen as speaking out or telling the truth or bringing this unsavory story into public view.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">So that had trickled down all the way to the frontline health care workers, who are supposed to be treating this and sounding the alarm.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">Right. They’re fearful of being seen as responsible for this crisis. They don’t want to stand out. And when you think about where this virus might be headed next — to other provinces, to other cities — you have to wonder if these same dynamics would be playing out again. If people will stay silent, if they will not report official cases, because they fear for their jobs and they fear for their livelihoods.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">So it seems like whatever reforms the Chinese government made after the failures of SARS, that in the end, none of them really matter, because it hasn’t changed the problem that’s at the root of this.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">At the root of all this is a sense of fear that is both the Communist Party’s strength, but it’s also a huge weakness. They can mobilize entire cities to be on lockdown. They can convince people to stay indoors. They can scrub social media of information that counters their narrative. That’s all very effective when you’re trying to get the public behind your policies. But at the end of the day, the fear is also a huge vulnerability. It creates this system where people are unwilling to speak out, unwilling to bring problems that are really important and that affect people’s lives.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">Right. I mean, for the Chinese leadership, that works until it doesn’t, right? Until you very much need for people to stop being afraid and to speak out about something like a public health crisis.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">Exactly.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">And so when you look at the culture, you wonder whether China can actually contain these viruses, whether we will continue to live in a world where the internal politics of the party are going to put lives around the world in danger.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">Javier, thank you.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">Thanks, Michael.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">On Wednesday, the total number of people infected by the coronavirus in mainland China surpassed those infected with the SARS virus during that epidemic. As of Wednesday evening, the virus had infected more than 6,000 people in mainland China. Later today, the World Health Organization will convene its emergency committee to determine whether the outbreak amounts to a public health emergency of international concern, its most severe classification.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">We’ll be right back.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">Here’s what else you need to know today. The Times reports that the White House has sent former national security adviser, John Bolton, a letter, warning him not to publish a book in which he recounts speaking to President Trump about the quid pro quo with Ukraine at the heart of the impeachment trial. In the letter, the White House claims that the book contains significant amounts of classified information that could harm U.S. national security. The letter was sent before The Times published a story describing the book’s contents, a story that has further fueled calls for Bolton to testify in the Senate trial. Senators are expected to vote on whether to call witnesses like Bolton later today.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd"> That’s it for “The Daily.” I’m Michael Barbaro.
