[<p>Advertisement</p>, <p>Supported by</p>, <p class="css-c2jxua e6idgb70"></p>, <h1 class="css-1j5ig2m e1h9rw200" id="link-6e8e607b" itemprop="headline"><span>Qantas Could Axe Beijing Route Early as Coronavirus Hits Demand-CEO</span></h1>, <p class="css-1fv7b6t e1jsehar1" itemprop="author" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">By<!-- --> <span class="css-1baulvz last-byline" itemprop="name">Reuters</span></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">SYDNEY — Qantas Airways Ltd Chief Executive Alan Joyce said on Wednesday it was too early for the airline to quantify the financial impact of China's coronavirus epidemic on its business but it was reviewing whether to end Beijing flights early.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Qantas in November said it was axing its underperforming Sydney-Beijing route from March due to stiff competition from Chinese airlines and weak business class demand.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">"We continue to review that, continue to review the loads, and whether we look to do that earlier, or keep it operating until that date," Joyce told reporters at the opening of a new pilot training school in Queensland, according to a transcript provided to Reuters.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">He said the most similar comparison to coronavirus was the SARS epidemic in 2003, which cost the carrier A$55 million (28.61 million pounds) in lost earnings over a six to eight month period and led it to cut some international capacity.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">UBS analysts on Tuesday estimated Qantas could take an earnings hit of A$204 million to A$513 million in the 2021 financial year depending on traffic declines as a result of the coronavirus.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Joyce said he did not comment on analyst reports as a rule but noted that UBS assumed a much worse financial impact than the airline had experienced from SARS.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">He added that a fall in the oil price over the past month was benefiting the airline and the carrier did not expect a material financial impact from widespread bushfires in Australia that have hit the local tourism industry.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"> (Reporting by Jamie Freed; Editing by Shri Navaratnam and Richard Pullin)</p>, <p>Advertisement</p>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd" id="site-index-label">Site Index</h2>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-0">news</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-1">opinion</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-2">arts</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-3">living</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-4">more</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-subscribe-label">Subscribe</h3>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd">Site Information Navigation</h2>]
[<p>Advertisement</p>, <p>Supported by</p>, <p class="css-c2jxua e6idgb70"></p>, <h1 class="css-1j5ig2m e1h9rw200" id="link-2ba45bb9" itemprop="headline"><span>Australia Scientists to Share Lab-Grown Coronavirus to Hasten Vaccine Efforts</span></h1>, <p class="css-1fv7b6t e1jsehar1" itemprop="author" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">By<!-- --> <span class="css-1baulvz last-byline" itemprop="name">Reuters</span></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">MELBOURNE — A team of scientists in Australia said on Wednesday they have successfully developed a lab-grown version of the new coronavirus, the first to be recreated outside of China, in a breakthrough that could help quicken the creation of a vaccine.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The researchers at the Peter Doherty Institute for Infection and Immunity in Melbourne said they would share the sample, which was grown from an infected patient, with the World Health Organisation and laboratories around the world. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">"This is a step, it's a piece of the puzzle that we have contributed," Doherty Institute Deputy Directo Mike Catton told reporters, while noting the development alone would not turn the tide in the battle against the virus.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The flu-like virus broke out in the central Chinese city of Wuhan at the end of 2019. While China has since moved to lock down most of Hubei province, which has a population around the same as Italy, the virus has still spread to more than a dozen countries from France to the United States.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">A laboratory in China had already successfully grown the virus but had released only the genome sequence, not the sample itself, the Australian Broadcasting Corp. reported.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Raina MacIntyre, who runs the Kirby Institute's Biosecurity Research Programme, said the creation and sharing of the virus sample would hasten the development of potential vaccines, as drugs could be tested on animals injected with the disease.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">"More people are able to culture the virus, they can use the information to develop drugs, vaccines, and better characterise the nature of the virus and the transmission," MacIntyre told Reuters by telephone.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">As well as contributing to the creation of a vaccine, the Australia-grown sample could be used to generate an antibody test, which would allow detection of the virus in patients who had not shown symptoms, the Doherty Instite said.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">"Having the real virus means we now have the ability to actually validate and verify all test methods," said Julian Druce, the institute's virus identification laboratory head.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">China confirmed on Tuesday that the national death toll had risen to 132 on Tuesday, with 5,974 confirmed cases. The virus spreads in droplets from coughs and sneezes and has an incubation period of up to 14 days. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The Peter Doherty Institute is a joint venture of the University of Melbourne and Royal Melbourne Hospital. The Kirby Institute is attached to the University of New South Wales.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"> (Reporting by Byron Kaye in Sydney and Melanie Burton in Melbourne; editing by Jane Wardell)</p>, <p>Advertisement</p>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd" id="site-index-label">Site Index</h2>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-0">news</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-1">opinion</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-2">arts</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-3">living</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-4">more</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-subscribe-label">Subscribe</h3>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd">Site Information Navigation</h2>]
[<p>Advertisement</p>, <p>Supported by</p>, <p class="css-c2jxua e6idgb70"></p>, <h1 class="css-1j5ig2m e1h9rw200" id="link-2e3b6a54" itemprop="headline"><span>Morgan Stanley Says Coronavirus Could Drag on Global, Chinese GDP Growth</span></h1>, <p class="css-1fv7b6t e1jsehar1" itemprop="author" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">By<!-- --> <span class="css-1baulvz last-byline" itemprop="name">Reuters</span></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">LONDON — Morgan Stanley said on Wednesday that assuming the coronavirus peaks in February and March, global economic growth could be hit by 0.15 to 0.3 percentage point during the first quarter.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Assuming the same time scale, the bank said China's GDP growth could be cut by 0.5 to 1 percentage point during the quarter.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"> (Reporting by Karin Strohecker and Tom Arnold; Editing by Alison Williams)</p>, <p>Advertisement</p>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd" id="site-index-label">Site Index</h2>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-0">news</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-1">opinion</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-2">arts</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-3">living</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-4">more</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-subscribe-label">Subscribe</h3>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd">Site Information Navigation</h2>]
[<p>Advertisement</p>, <p>Supported by</p>, <p class="css-c2jxua e6idgb70"></p>, <h1 class="css-1j5ig2m e1h9rw200" id="link-4db7c13c" itemprop="headline"><span>Australia Scientists Claim First Re-Creation of Coronavirus Outside China</span></h1>, <p class="css-1fv7b6t e1jsehar1" itemprop="author" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">By<!-- --> <span class="css-1baulvz last-byline" itemprop="name">Reuters</span></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">SYDNEY — A team of scientists in Australia said on Wednesday they have successfully developed a lab-grown version of coronavirus, the first to be recreated outside of China, in a breakthrough that could help combat the global spread of the illness.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The researchers at the Peter Doherty Institute for Infection and Immunity in Melbourne said they would share the sample, which was grown from an infected patient, with the World Health Organization and laboratories around the world. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">A laboratory in China had successfully grown the virus but had released only the genome sequence, not the sample itself, the Australian Broadcasting Corp. reported.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">"Having the real virus means we now have the ability to actually validate and verify all test methods, and compare their sensitivities and specificities", the Doherty Institute's virus indentification laboratory head, Julian Druce, said in a statement.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">"The virus will be used as positive control material for the Australian network of public health laboratories, and also shipped to expert laboratories working closely with the World Health Organization (WHO) in Europe."</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The flu-like virus broke out in the central Chinese city of Wuhan at the end of last year and has killed 106 people and infected more than 2,800 people. It spreads in droplets from coughs and sneezes and has an incubation period of up to 14 days.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The Australia-grown virus sample would be used to generate an antibody test, which would allow detection of the virus in patients who had not shown symptoms, as well as contributing to the creation of a vaccine, the institute said.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The virus was grown from a patient who had arrived at the institute on Jan. 24, it added. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The Peter Doherty Institute is a joint venture of the University of Melbourne and Royal Melbourne Hospital.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"> (Reporting by Byron Kaye; editing by Jane Wardell)</p>, <p>Advertisement</p>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd" id="site-index-label">Site Index</h2>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-0">news</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-1">opinion</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-2">arts</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-3">living</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-4">more</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-subscribe-label">Subscribe</h3>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd">Site Information Navigation</h2>]
[<p>Advertisement</p>, <p>Supported by</p>, <p class="css-c2jxua e6idgb70"></p>, <h1 class="css-1j5ig2m e1h9rw200" id="link-df949cc" itemprop="headline"><span>Factbox: Stores Closed, Employees Evacuated, Travel Restricted as Coronavirus Spreads</span></h1>, <p class="css-1fv7b6t e1jsehar1" itemprop="author" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">By<!-- --> <span class="css-1baulvz last-byline" itemprop="name">Reuters</span></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">(Reuters) - Companies around the globe from Facebook to Japan's Nippon Steel have restricted travel to China, as the outbreak of a new coronavirus, which has killed over 100 people and infected more than 4,000 in the world's most populous country, sparks international alarm. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Here's how companies have responded to the outbreak, which originated in Wuhan, the capital of China's Hubei province:</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">TRAVEL ADVISORIES/EVACUATIONS/QUARANTINES:</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">- Facebook asked employees to halt non-essential travel to mainland China and to work from home if they had travelled there. Chinese tech giants including Alibaba and Tencent have asked staff to work from home for a week after an extended Lunar New Year break ends on Feb. 2.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">- Tiktok owner Bytedance asked employees who travelled during the holidays to quarantine themselves and work from home for 14 days. E-commerce firm Pinduoduo, UBS Group and property developer Country Garden have advised similar action.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">- Standard Chartered banned travel to Hubei and restricted travel to mainland China and Hong Kong, and asked employees returning from Hubei to work from home for 14 days. Commonwealth Bank of Australia said all non-essential employee travel to China should be avoided.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">- LG Electronics and electric car battery maker LG Chem banned travel to China.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">- South Korean chipmaker SK Hynix urged employees to avoid non-essential trips to China as have LG Display and Japanese carmakers Honda and Toyota. Honda evacuated around 30 employees and their families from Wuhan on a government charter flight.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">- Nissan is planning to send back some Japanese staff working at its JV with Dongfeng Motors in Wuhan and their families on the chartered flight as well.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">- Samsung Electronics advised employees who recently visited Hubei to stay at home for seven days.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">- Japanese steelmaker Nippon Steel restricted travel to China.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">- Singaporean conglomerate Keppel Corp, which has 170 staff in Wuhan, advised staff to avoid non-work-related visits to and from mainland China and not to travel to Hubei province. It will monitor staff in China and those who have returned to Singapore from there in the past 14 days.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">- Novartis said it is asking staff in China to work from home until Feb. 10 and has suspended business travel to and from Wuhan. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">- Nestle has deployed additional biosecurity measures at its factories, offices and distribution centres in China. It does not have manufacturing facilities in Wuhan.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">- Volkswagen asked staff at its China unit to work from home between Feb. 3 and Feb. 17.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">- Brazilian miner Vale SA has suspended travel by its employees to and from China indefinitely and said employees in China will work remotely.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">- Goldman Sachs has instructed staff who have been in mainland China to work from home or be out of the office for 14 days since they were last there, according to an internal notice.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">STORES SHUT:</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">- Starbucks Corp warned of a financial hit from the coronavirus outbreak in China, and said it had closed more than half of its stores in the country.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">- McDonald's suspended business in five cities in Hubei including Wuhan. Starbucks closed all shops and suspended delivery services in Hubei.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">- Yum China Holdings Inc temporarily closed some of its KFC and Pizza Hut stores in Wuhan.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">- Luckin Coffee will keep stores closed in Wuhan throughout the Lunar New Year holidays.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">- Japan's Fast Retailing temporarily closed about 100Uniqlo stores in Hubei. IKEA closed its one store in Wuhan.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">- Walt Disney temporarily closed its Shanghai and Hong Kong theme parks and resorts during what is likely the busiest time of the year.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">- Imax delayed film releases in China.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">- H&amp;M has closed 45 stores and suspended business travel to and within China, a spokeswoman said. Staff arriving from China are recommended to stay home for 14 days before returning to work.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">- Swatch has closed five stores in Wuhan and suspended all travel to and from China.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">- Apple Inc Chief Executive Officer Tim Cook said the company has currently closed one of its retail stores in China and reduced hours at others and is restricting employee travel due to the virus.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">AIRLINE REFUNDS/CANCELLATIONS: </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">- Finnish airline Finnair has suspended its routes to Nanjing and Beijing's Daxing International airport until the end of March, the first European airline to cancel flights to the country.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">- Hong Kong's Cathay Pacific and its Cathay Dragon will cut capacity to and from mainland China by 50% or more from Jan. 30 to end-March. The airline will also rebook, reroute or refund tickets booked on or before Jan. 28 for travel by March 31 to or from mainland China. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">- Australia's Qantas Airways said it will offer free refunds for tickets issued worldwide on or before Jan. 24, for journeys to and from mainland China between Jan. 24 and Feb. 29.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">- Air Seoul suspended all flights to China and waived refund penalty. Taiwan's China Airlines rearranged some flights and cancelled others.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">- China's mainland airlines, including Air China, China Southern and China Eastern, are offering free refunds across the mainland for tickets purchased before Jan. 24.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">- Malaysia's AirAsia will offer free refunds for tickets booked before Jan. 24, and for travel to and from mainland China until Feb. 15, and return flights between Feb. 16-29.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">- Air France KLM is offering to exchange or refund tickets issued for travel to or from China up until Feb. 29. BA-owner IAG is offering the same for tickets until Feb 23.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">- United Airlines is cancelling some flights to China.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">HOTELS:</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">- InterContinental Hotels will allow customers to change or cancel stays scheduled up to Feb. 3 across mainland China, Hong Kong, Macau and Taiwan.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">- Hyatt Hotels said guests who had booked stays through its official channels and are cancelling due to the coronavirus outbreak, or are Chinese guests outbound to its Asia Pacific hotels, can cancel stays or change dates for free. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">BOOKING PLATFORMS, AGENCIES:</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">- Ctrip, China's largest online booking platform, said more than 300,000 hotels on its platform had agreed to refund on bookings between Jan. 22 and Feb. 8. Refunds also include flight tickets, cruises and car rents</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">- Fliggy, Alibaba's booking site, offered similar refunds.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">- Some Chinese tour operators such as China International Travel Service offered refunds and many European tour operators cancelled tours to China.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"> (Reporting by Sophie Yu in Beijing, Jamie Freed in Sydney, Ritsuko Ando in Tokyo, Anna Ringstrom in Stockholm, Ben Blanchard in Taipei, Naomi Tajitsu in Tokyo, Heekyong Yang and Jane Chung in Seoul, Josh Horwitz and Brenda Goh in Shanghai, Neil Jerome Morales in Manila, Sumeet Chatterjee in Hong Kong, Paul Arnold and Silke Koltrowitz in Zurich, Laurence Frost in Paris and Uday Sampath in Bengaluru; Writing by Sayantani Ghosh and Josephine Mason; Editing by Shounak Dasgupta, Lisa Shumaker and Maju Samuel)</p>, <p>Advertisement</p>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd" id="site-index-label">Site Index</h2>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-0">news</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-1">opinion</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-2">arts</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-3">living</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-4">more</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-subscribe-label">Subscribe</h3>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd">Site Information Navigation</h2>]
[<p>Advertisement</p>, <p>Supported by</p>, <p class="css-c2jxua e6idgb70"></p>, <h1 class="css-1j5ig2m e1h9rw200" id="link-5ce3ad64" itemprop="headline"><span>For Airlines, China Boom Now Exposes Them to Risk as Coronavirus Slams Market</span></h1>, <p class="css-1fv7b6t e1jsehar1" itemprop="author" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">By<!-- --> <span class="css-1baulvz last-byline" itemprop="name">Reuters</span></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">SYDNEY/CHICAGO — China's growth has helped power a global aviation boom over the last decade, but as the country curtails travel in the face of a new coronavirus, a slowdown could hit the industry harder than ever before.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">United Airlines, American Airlines, Air Canada, Cathay Pacific, Lufthansa and Finnair are among carriers that have cancelled some or all China flights as countries expand travel warnings and demand plummets due to the coronavirus outbreak.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">British Airways has also halted bookings of direct flights from London to Beijing and Shanghai until March, according to its website.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The virus has killed more than 130 people and sickened more than 6,000, the vast majority of them in China.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">U.S. officials said the White House had decided against suspending all flights there for now, but was still considering the measure.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The virus appears to represent the biggest epidemic threat to the airline industry since the SARS outbreak, which at its peak in April 2003 led to a 45% plunge in passenger demand in Asia, analysts said. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The global airline industry has been profitable for the last 10 years, according to the International Air Transport Association (IATA). Airlines are in a stronger financial position than in 2003, but also far more dependent on China.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">"Airlines and airports that are financially strong and well managed are able to overcome a drastic drop in air travel," said Shukor Yusof, head of Malaysia-based aviation consultancy Endau Analytics. "Weak and poorly managed airlines will suffer."</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Margins at many carriers remain narrow, economic growth has been fragile amid a U.S.-China trade war and there are fears that the return of the 737 MAX, expected mid-year, could lead to overcapacity and push down fares. Airbus and Boeing orders have fallen from the peak levels of 2013 and 2014.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The epidemic is particularly concerning to the industry because China is the world's biggest outbound international travel market and the second-largest domestic aviation market. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"> The country accounts for about 25% of global sales for airplane manufacturers Airbus SE and Boeing Co. About 450 million more passengers fly to, from and within China per year compared with a decade ago, according to IATA.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">For Chinese airlines, the biggest of which are state-backed, the impact of the new coronavirus has been swift. On Wednesday, 23% of departures from Shanghai Hongqiao airport had been cancelled, according to FlightRadar24, compared with 8% at the more internationally focused Shanghai Pudong airport.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Overall, almost 9% of Chinese domestic and international flights did not take off as scheduled from Jan. 23 to 27, according to Cirium aviation data reflecting aircraft movements and official cancellations. Besides Wuhan, the worst-affected airports were Beijing, Ghangzhou and Shanghai.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Mike Boyd, head of U.S.-based aviation consultancy Boyd Group International, said he had forecast airport traffic in China to rise 8.1% in 2020 but now sees traffic growing at less than half that rate.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">"It is a real slam," he said.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Cathay Pacific, already battered by a fall in demand because of anti-government protests in its home market of Hong Kong, said on Tuesday evening it would cut flights to mainland China by 50% or more through the end of March.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The fate of Cathay and local rival Hong Kong Airlines could depend on the willingness of travellers to transit through Hong Kong airport, BOCOM International analyst Luya You said. The protests have already led to a collapse in demand from mainland tourists and business travellers, she said.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Asian jet fuel prices have dropped and refiners' profits for the product have slumped to their lowest in more than 2-1/2 years over concerns that the coronavirus will hurt demand, although that will also help unhedged carriers keep a lid on costs.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">U.S. and European carriers have less relative exposure than their Asian rivals. Chinese carriers dominate airline travel between China and long-haul destinations. But they were racking up international losses even before the virus.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Flights to China account for 2%-6% of estimated revenue at United Airlines, Delta Air Lines Inc, American Airlines Group Inc and Air Canada, according to analysts at Cowen, an independent investment bank, although they added there were concerns the virus would not be contained in China given how it was spreading.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Among the Europeans, Lufthansa and Air France-KLM have the most to lose in a China traffic slump, and the Franco-Dutch airline group has so far maintained flights to Beijing and Shanghai. Both groups rely on China for 7% of their capacity, according to UBS data, compared with 3% for BA parent IAG.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Historically, air traffic has returned to normal after health scares. In the case of SARS, it took nine months to recover, according to IATA.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">"It (SARS) meant we did cut back on some international capacity but it rebounded very fast," Qantas Airways Ltd Chief Executive Alan Joyce told reporters on Wednesday, saying that earnings took a A$55 million ($37.61 million) hit from that epidemic.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">"We do now have a lot of experience over the years with MERS, with Zika virus, with volcanoes, with all sorts of activity that's impacted the airlines," he said.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"> ($1 = 1.4622 Australian dollars)</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"> (Reporting by Jamie Freed in Sydney and Tracy Rucinski in Chicago; Additional reporting by Laurence Frost in Paris; Editing by Gerry Doyle and Hugh Lawson)</p>, <p>Advertisement</p>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd" id="site-index-label">Site Index</h2>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-0">news</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-1">opinion</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-2">arts</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-3">living</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-4">more</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-subscribe-label">Subscribe</h3>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd">Site Information Navigation</h2>]
[<p>Advertisement</p>, <p>Supported by</p>, <p class="css-c2jxua e6idgb70"></p>, <h1 class="css-1j5ig2m e1h9rw200" id="link-21e4964c" itemprop="headline"><span>Starbucks Sees Hit as Coronavirus Prompts Over 2,000 China Store Closures</span></h1>, <p class="css-1fv7b6t e1jsehar1" itemprop="author" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">By<!-- --> <span class="css-1baulvz last-byline" itemprop="name">Reuters</span></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">(Reuters) - Starbucks Corp on Tuesday became the first major U.S. company to warn of a financial hit from the new coronavirus outbreak in China, as it closed thousands of restaurants and adjusted operating hours in its biggest growth market. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The world's largest coffee chain delayed a planned update - based on strong quarterly earnings results - to its 2020 financial forecast because of the outbreak, which has caused over 100 deaths and over 4,000 confirmed cases in China.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Shares of the company, which operates 4,292 stores in China, fell 1% in extended trading. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The company, which beat sales estimates during its first quarter, "intended to raise certain aspects of our full-year financial outlook for fiscal 2020," Chief Executive Officer Kevin Johnson said during the earnings call.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">But because of the coronavirus outbreak, it decided not to revise guidance on Tuesday.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The company expects the financial impact to be material but temporary, and it will depend on the number of stores it has to close and for how long. Currently about half of its stores are shuttered in China, which makes up about 10% of global revenue.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">It will not know until March at the earliest what the financial impact will be, but its long-term double-digit growth expectations are intact, executives said. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The virus, which originated in the Chinese city of Wuhan, has spread across the world and prompted companies to close stores and restrict travel to and from the country.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Starbucks' China rival, Luckin Coffee Inc, has said it will keep stores closed in Wuhan throughout the Lunar New Year holidays. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Starbucks is responding to the virus "in a thoughtful and responsible way to protect our partners and support health officials and the government as they work to contain this public health risk," Johnson said. "I am proud of how Starbucks China is navigating a very dynamic situation." </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">GROWTH FROM COLD BREW, LOYALTY MEMBERS </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The Seattle-based company beat first-quarter estimates for same-restaurant sales, growing 5% compared with expectations for a 4.4% increase, according to IBES data from Refinitiv. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Sales at restaurants open for at least 13 months rose 3% in China, where it will continue to concentrate on personalized beverages and its digital push rather than adopt a strategy of offering cheaper drinks like its rivals have used to gain market shares, Johnson said. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Overall, the company has been boosting its cold brew options, adding online ordering options and updating its loyalty rewards programme.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">It also plans to add a breakfast sandwich with a plant-based patty in the United States and Canada this year.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Total net revenue rose 7% to $7.1 billion (5.4 billion pounds), largely in line with analysts' average estimate of $7.11 billion.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Net earnings attributable to the company rose to $885.7 million, or 74 cents per share, from $760.6 million, or 61 cents per share, a year earlier. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Excluding one-time items, the company earned 79 cents per share, above estimates of 76 cents. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Revenues grew 9% in the quarter in the United States, where it added 1.4 million customers to its 90-day active Starbucks Rewards membership, ending the quarter with 18.9 million active members, a 16% increase over prior year.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"> (Reporting by Uday Sampath in Bengaluru; additional reporting by Hilary Russ; Editing by Sriraj Kalluvila and Lisa Shumaker)</p>, <p>Advertisement</p>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd" id="site-index-label">Site Index</h2>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-0">news</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-1">opinion</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-2">arts</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-3">living</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-4">more</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-subscribe-label">Subscribe</h3>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd">Site Information Navigation</h2>]

[<p>Advertisement</p>, <p>Supported by</p>, <p class="css-c2jxua e6idgb70"></p>, <h1 class="css-1j5ig2m e1h9rw200" id="link-6a383974" itemprop="headline"><span>Trump Says He Spoke to China's Xi, U.S. Working Closely With China on Coronavirus</span></h1>, <p class="css-1fv7b6t e1jsehar1" itemprop="author" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">By<!-- --> <span class="css-1baulvz last-byline" itemprop="name">Reuters</span></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">WASHINGTON — U.S. President Donald Trump said on Wednesday he had spoken with Chinese President Xi Jinping and the United States was working very closely with China on the coronavirus outbreak.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">"We're very much involved with them right now on the virus that's going around. ... I spoke to President Xi. [<p>Advertisement</p>, <p>Supported by</p>, <p class="css-c2jxua e6idgb70"></p>, <h1 class="css-1j5ig2m e1h9rw200" id="link-60d7ed03" itemprop="headline"><span>Bosch CEO Warns Coronavirus Could Hit Global Auto Supply Chains</span></h1>, <p class="css-1fv7b6t e1jsehar1" itemprop="author" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">By<!-- --> <span class="css-1baulvz last-byline" itemprop="name">Reuters</span></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">STUTTGART, Germany — The chief executive of Robert Bosch, the world's biggest auto components supplier, warned that coronavirus could impact its global supply chain, which is heavily dependent on China. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">"We are naturally concerned, but on the basis of the facts today, we have no disruption to our business or supply chain," Chief Executive Volkmar Denner said at a meeting with journalists in Fellbach, Stuttgart on Tuesday, in remarks which were embargoed for Wednesday.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Bosch is relying on China as a global manufacturing base for exporting electric motors, transmission and power electronics for electric cars. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">"We need to wait to see how things develop. If this situation continues, supply chains will be disrupted. There are forecasts that predict the peak for infections will drag on until February or March," Denner said. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">"In Wuhan Bosch has two plants making steering systems and thermotechnologies, with around 800 employees. There have been no reports of infections," Denner said.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Bosch's China plants have been shut for Chinese new year and the holiday has been extended to February 3, an extension which will not disrupt Bosch's global business, Denner explained.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Bosch has been in China since 1909 and has 23 automotive manufacturing facilities in more than 60 locations in the world's largest auto market, which is home to the largest Bosch workforce outside of Germany.<span class="css-8l6xbc evw5hdy0">  </span></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Bosch employs 403,000 people globally.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Bosch makes multimedia infotainment systems in Wuhu, brake booster systems in Nanjing, automotive electronics for use in connected and automated driving in Wujin, 48-volt battery systems in Wuxi and builds electric vehicle motors, transmissions, and power electronics in Taicang. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Bosch sales in Asia Pacific reached 22.5 billion euros last year, of which more than 10 billion euros came from China.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Bosch expects global automotive production to fall 2.6% to 89 million cars in 2020 due to a decline in demand in China, the United States and Europe. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"> (Reporting by Edward Taylor; Editing by Michelle Martin)</p>, <p>Advertisement</p>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd" id="site-index-label">Site Index</h2>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-0">news</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-1">opinion</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-2">arts</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-3">living</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-4">more</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-subscribe-label">Subscribe</h3>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd">Site Information Navigation</h2>]
[<p>Advertisement</p>, <p>Supported by</p>, <p class="css-c2jxua e6idgb70"></p>, <h1 class="css-1j5ig2m e1h9rw200" id="link-98ffae6" itemprop="headline"><span>Royal Caribbean Sees Profit Hit After Cancelling Three Cruises Amid Coronavirus Outbreak</span></h1>, <p class="css-1fv7b6t e1jsehar1" itemprop="author" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">By<!-- --> <span class="css-1baulvz last-byline" itemprop="name">Reuters</span></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">(Reuters) - Royal Caribbean Cruises Ltd said on Wednesday its 2020 earnings would be hurt after it canceled three trips of its China-based cruise liner following discussions with health authorities over the coronavirus outbreak.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The U.S. cruise operator said cancellations would trim its earnings by about 10 cents per share, and it would take an additional 10-cent hit if travel restrictions in China continued until the end of February.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The fast-spreading outbreak has killed more than 130 people and infected almost 6,000 in China.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Several countries including Japan and U.S. are trying to evacuate their citizens from the quarantined city of Wuhan, the epicenter of the outbreak.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Airports around the world are screening passengers from China, while foreign companies are curbing travel to the country and airlines are cutting flights.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">"There are still too many variables and uncertainties regarding this outbreak to calculate the overall impact on the business," the company said.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Royal Caribbean added that if the travel restrictions continued for an extended period of time, it could materially impact the company's overall financial performance.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"> (Reporting by Aishwarya Venugopal in Bengaluru; Editing by Shailesh Kuber)</p>, <p>Advertisement</p>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd" id="site-index-label">Site Index</h2>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-0">news</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-1">opinion</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-2">arts</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-3">living</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-4">more</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-subscribe-label">Subscribe</h3>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd">Site Information Navigation</h2>]
[<p>Advertisement</p>, <p>Supported by</p>, <p class="css-c2jxua e6idgb70"></p>, <h1 class="css-1j5ig2m e1h9rw200" id="link-60e47009" itemprop="headline"><span>Many Global Firms, Excluded From Epidemic Insurance, Face Heavy Coronavirus Costs</span></h1>, <p class="css-1fv7b6t e1jsehar1" itemprop="author" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">By<!-- --> <span class="css-1baulvz last-byline" itemprop="name">Reuters</span></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">LONDON/HONG KONG — Many global companies from hotels and airlines to industrial houses are expected to have to foot the bill for disruptions caused by a new coronavirus in China, with epidemics usually excluded from insurance cover, experts said. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">With 132 deaths in China and new cases being reported around the world, companies are set to face billions of dollars in losses linked to events and travel cancellations and closure of businesses, they said. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The virus originated in the city of Wuhan, forcing airlines to cancel flights and companies including Facebook and HSBC to suspend travel to China.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">"For insurers, the bulk of the claims from this outbreak will come from businesses, mainly travel, hospitality and event firms, followed by mortality and healthcare costs," said a Hong Kong-based insurance sector lawyer with a global law firm.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Risk modeling firm RMS said it was too early to estimate insured losses. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">While some large global firms buy coverage for communicable diseases, most "standard insurance policies" exclude such outbreaks to keep costs low, said the lawyer, declining to be identified as he was not authorized to speak to the media.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Global insurers typically cover risks such as earthquakes and plane crashes, but have been paring back exposure to certain risks, such as shipping, to avoid huge losses.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Previous viruses, such as SARS, Ebola and Zika, have also led insurers to be more cautious about exposure, with specific virus exclusions added to most basic coverage policies, industry insiders said.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome pandemic which spread to 37 countries in 2003 caused $4 billion worth of economic losses in Hong Kong, $3-$6 billion in Canada, and $5 billion in Singapore, according to insurance broker Marsh.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Insurance experts also told Reuters that most event cancellation policies would not cover the new virus.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">"A lot of these airlines and hotels are offering refunds to their customers," said Richard Coyle, London-based head of risk financing and non-standard solutions at Miller Insurance. "Without adequate insurance in place, the airlines and hotels are absorbing the financial losses themselves."</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">A standard event cancellation policy issued by firms in the 99-member Lloyd's of London [SOLYD.UL] insurance market and elsewhere has a "communicable disease" exclusion, two underwriters said.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Interactive graphic https://tmsnrt.rs/2U6I2Q3 on human cost of virus outbreaks </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">EXCLUSION</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Companies buy business interruption policies with their property insurance to cover loss of revenue if they are forced to close temporarily, but those policies are also likely to exclude communicable diseases, an underwriter in London and insurance executives said. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">"The Asian hospitality industry is an obvious example of an industry already affected. For many lines of business ... it is common market practice to have epidemic outbreak risk excluded," a Munich Re spokesman said.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">While some firms including Munich Re have developed specific insurance products and policies for infectious diseases, not many firms have bought them, insurers said.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The impact on tourism and transport is also likely to hit supply chains in Asia, Narges Dorratoltaj, senior scientist at catastrophe risk modeling firm AIR, said.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Starbucks Corp on Tuesday became the first major U.S. company to warn of a financial hit from the virus.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The Shanghai government announcement that all companies in the city would not be allowed to start work before Feb. 9 will affect companies including Tesla Inc, General Motors and Volkswagen.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">While most travel insurers are likely to reimburse costs associated with trip cancellations and medical expenses for policies bought before the spread of the virus, some are excluding the coverage for select destinations now, industry officials said.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Insurers Aviva, Allianz and AXA said individual policyholders would be covered if they are impacted by the virus, provided they follow travel advisories from governments.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"> (Reporting by Noor Zainab Hussain in Bengaluru, Carolyn Cohn in London, Sumeet Chatterjee in Hong Kong and Suzanne Barlyn in New York; Editing by Nick Macfie)</p>, <p>Advertisement</p>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd" id="site-index-label">Site Index</h2>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-0">news</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-1">opinion</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-2">arts</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-3">living</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-4">more</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-subscribe-label">Subscribe</h3>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd">Site Information Navigation</h2>]
[<p>Advertisement</p>, <p>Supported by</p>, <h1 class="css-1s4ffep e1h9rw200" id="link-7c267bc4" itemprop="headline"><span>John Roberts, Coronavirus, Mike Pompeo: Your Wednesday Briefing</span></h1>, <p class="css-1fv7b6t e1jsehar1" itemprop="author" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">By<!-- --> <a class="css-brehiz e1jsehar0" href="https://www.nytimes.com/by/christopher-stanford"><span class="css-1baulvz last-byline" itemprop="name">Chris Stanford</span></a></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">(Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/morning-briefing" title="">sign-up</a>.)</p>, <p class="css-ma92ss evys1bk0">Good morning.</p>, <p class="css-ma92ss evys1bk0">We’re covering a new phase in <strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">the impeachment trial</strong>, President Trump’s <strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">peace plan for the Middle East</strong>, and new stars on the campaign trail: <strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">the candidates’ dogs</strong>.</p>, <h2 class="css-3ez4hu eoo0vm40" id="link-cd737f">Q. and A. at the impeachment trial</h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">After more than a week of silently listening to the case involving President Trump, senators will get a chance to participate in the proceedings today, when they’re <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/28/us/politics/impeachment-trial-senate-questions.html" title="">allowed to cross-examine both sides</a>.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Senators will have as many as 16 hours over two days to submit written questions that will be read aloud by Chief Justice John Roberts, who is presiding over the trial. <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/live/2020/impeachment-trial-live-01-29" title="">Here’s what to expect</a> when it resumes around 1 p.m. Eastern.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The session comes a day after Mr. Trump’s lawyers finished with <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/28/us/politics/trumps-defense-team-discounts-bolton-as-republicans-work-to-hold-off-witnesses.html" title="">an appeal to disregard an account by John Bolton</a>, the former national security adviser, that undercuts the president’s defense.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">What’s next:</strong> Senator Mitch McConnell, the majority leader, indicated on Tuesday that he doesn’t yet have the votes to block an expected push to call witnesses, which would require the support of at least four Republicans. A vote is expected on Friday.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Related:</strong> Democrats who once derided Mr. Bolton <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/28/us/politics/bolton-trump.html" title="">now want him to testify</a>, while some of his former Republican friends are tossing him to the curb. John Kelly, the former White House chief of staff, didn’t always get along with Mr. Bolton but said this week, “If John Bolton says that in the book, I believe John Bolton.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">The Daily:</strong> <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/thedaily" title="">Today’s episode</a> is about how the trial is seen by the minority leader, Senator Chuck Schumer.</p>, <h2 class="css-3ez4hu eoo0vm40" id="link-972b111">Evacuees from Wuhan arrive in U.S.</h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">A plane carrying more than 200 Americans from the Chinese city that is the epicenter of a coronavirus outbreak landed in Alaska on Tuesday. The passengers, including diplomats and businesspeople, were to undergo medical screening before continuing on to their final destination in California. <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/29/world/asia/coronavirus-china.html" title="">Here are the latest updates</a>.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Chinese officials said today that at least 132 people had died from the virus and raised the number of confirmed cases to nearly 6,000.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Governments and businesses around the world <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/28/world/asia/china-travel-coronoavirus.html" title="">issued fresh travel warnings</a> on Tuesday, and Americans are now discouraged from visiting China. U.S. officials said the screening of travelers from Wuhan would be expanded to 20 ports of entry.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">The details:</strong> Cases in Germany, Japan, Taiwan and Vietnam involved patients who had not traveled to China. No deaths have been reported outside China. <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/article/what-is-coronavirus.html" title="">Here’s what we know about the virus</a>.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">For perspective</strong>: The flu kills roughly 35,000 Americans every year. This season, it has already sickened an estimated 15 million Americans and killed 8,200, <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.cdc.gov/flu/weekly/index.htm" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">according to C.D.C. estimates</a>.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Another angle:</strong> Bats are considered the probable source of the outbreak. Scientists have long struggled to understand <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/28/science/bats-coronavirus-Wuhan.html" title="">how the mammals carry so many viruses without getting sick</a>.</p>, <h2 class="css-3ez4hu eoo0vm40" id="link-3c0059f3">Middle East peace plan favors Israel</h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/28/world/middleeast/peace-plan.html" title="">President Trump on Tuesday introduced proposals</a> that would give Israel most of what it has sought over decades of conflict and offer Palestinians the possibility of a state with limited sovereignty.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“My vision presents a win-win opportunity for both sides,” Mr. Trump said at a White House ceremony with Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel. Nobody from the Palestinian leadership attended.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">The details:</strong> The plan, three years in the making, would let Israel control a unified Jerusalem as its capital and not require it to uproot West Bank settlements. Mr. Trump promised $50 billion in international investment for the new Palestinian entity.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Response: </strong>The Palestinian Authority president, Mahmoud Abbas, played no substantive role in shaping the plan and immediately denounced it as a “conspiracy deal.” <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/28/world/middleeast/arabs-reaction-trump-mideast-peace-plan.html" title="">None of Washington’s Arab allies formally endorsed it</a>.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">News analysis:</strong> For a president facing an impeachment trial and an Israeli prime minister under criminal indictment, the plan “sounded more like a road map for their own futures than for the Middle East,” <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/28/world/middleeast/trump-netanyahu-peace-plan.html" title="">our national security correspondent writes</a>.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">What’s next:</strong> Mr. Netanyahu said he would move on Sunday to <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/28/world/middleeast/israel-west-bank-annex-sovereignty.html" title="">apply sovereignty over the Jordan Valley</a> and to all Jewish settlements in the West Bank. Most of the world considers those settlements illegal.</p>, <h3 class="css-1b8te77 e1gnsphs0" id="link-60157767">If you have 6 minutes, this is worth it</h3>, <h2 class="css-3ez4hu eoo0vm40" id="link-10e51427">Japan’s skateboarders roll out of the shadows</h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Japan has an Olympic skateboarding team that’s likely to dominate the competition when it makes its Summer Games debut in Tokyo. But on Japan’s streets, the sport is considered a pastime of unruly children.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/26/sports/olympics/skateboarding-olympics-tokyo.html" title="">Olympic success could give its Japanese adherents an acceptance</a> they’ve never had — and maybe never wanted.</p>, <h3 class="css-1b8te77 e1gnsphs0" id="link-554e6082">Here’s what else is happening</h3>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Revised toll in Iran strike: </strong>The Pentagon said <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/28/us/iran-strike-soldier-injuries-pentagon.html" title="">50 U.S. service members sustained brain injuries</a> from airstrikes on a base in Iraq this month, 16 more than it had previously acknowledged.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">A final photo of Kobe Bryant:</strong> A selfie taken by a 13-year-old at his basketball academy on Saturday is perhaps <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/28/us/mamba-sports-academy.html" title="">the last picture of the N.B.A. star before he died</a>.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Snapshot: </strong>Above, Elizabeth Warren’s golden retriever, Bailey, at a campaign office in Cambridge, Mass. Some 2020 presidential candidates have <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/28/us/politics/democratic-candidates-dogs-bloomberg.html" title="">turned their dogs into social media stars</a>.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Perspective:</strong> In <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/28/opinion/mike-pompeo-kelly-interview.html" title="">an opinion piece for The Times</a>, the NPR journalist Mary Louise Kelly says that being called a liar by Mike Pompeo is not what bothered her most about her recent interview with the secretary of state.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Late-night comedy: </strong>Ms. Kelly<strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10"> </strong>has said that Mr. Pompeo swore at her and challenged her to find Ukraine on a map.<strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10"> </strong><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/29/arts/television/seth-meyers-mike-pompeo-late-night-npr.html" title="">Stephen Colbert wondered</a>,<strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10"> </strong>“Why does Mike Pompeo just have unmarked maps at the ready? Is he the secretary of state or an eighth-grade social studies teacher?”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">What we’re looking at: </strong><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.theatlantic.com/photo/2020/01/photos-worst-locust-swarms-decades-hit-east-africa/605653/" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">These photos in The Atlantic</a> of locust swarms in East Africa. “For those keeping track of the plagues hitting the planet,” writes Andrea Kannapell, the Briefings editor.</p>, <h3 class="css-1b8te77 e1gnsphs0" id="link-7ded7ef4">Now, a break from the news</h3>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Cook: </strong><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://cooking.nytimes.com/recipes/1020774-creamy-farro-with-crispy-mushrooms-and-sour-cream" title="">Farro with crispy mushrooms</a> is similar to a risotto, without the constant stirring.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Watch: </strong>Nicolas Cage and Joely Richardson <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/23/movies/color-out-of-space-review.html" title="">confront an evil shade of lilac</a> in the sci-fi horror film “Color Out of Space,” directed by Richard Stanley.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Eat: </strong><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/28/dining/antons-review-pete-wells.html" title="">Our restaurant critic, Pete Wells, visits Anton’s</a>, which serves chopped liver, Ukrainian ham and other immigrant foods that helped form New York’s palate.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Smarter Living: </strong>Breaking up with a therapist can be nerve-racking. But doing it <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/28/magazine/how-to-break-up-with-your-therapist.html" title="">with these tips in mind</a> can make it an opportunity for growth.</p>, <h3 class="css-1b8te77 e1gnsphs0" id="link-15767e9b">And now for the Back Story on …</h3>, <h2 class="css-3ez4hu eoo0vm40" id="link-1ae3c0b5">Our man in Wuhan</h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">Chris Buckley, our chief China correspondent, is reporting this week from the epicenter of the coronavirus outbreak. Mike Ives, on the Briefings team, spoke with him by phone.</em></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">What is it like with these restrictions in place?</strong></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">It may be difficult to envisage just how thoroughly people have retreated from the streets and from public life. I had to cross one of the big bridges across the Yangtze for my reporting. And there I was, on one of these Chinese share bikes that are everywhere, on an almost completely empty bridge, spanning one of China’s biggest cities, crossing its biggest river. And there were just two other people on the bridge.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">A lot of people wonder how long the shutdown can last. Even now, people are worrying about the jobs they may lose, the businesses that will close, the school that they might miss.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">You’ve reported that </strong><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10"><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/27/world/asia/china-coronavirus-social-media.html" title="">the anger on Chinese social media</a></strong><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10"> is intense.</strong></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Yes, and you hear that here as well. People erupt with a kind of anger and exasperation over how it was that this dangerous pathogen was among them but they didn’t understand, in many cases, how serious it was or what was going on until the city was shut down.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">But that’s leavened by a sense among many people that the most pressing thing is to <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://twitter.com/ChuBailiang/status/1222050019835969536" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">get through this crisis </a>— so that as few people die as possible and life can return to a kind of normality as soon as possible.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">What else are you seeing there?</strong></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">You see a combination of reactions when you approach people to talk. First of all, there’s a natural wariness about getting close to anybody. But once you reassure them — you’re outside, at a distance of a good 10 feet — they can be very open and also very generous.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">How does that compare to the response you normally get?</strong></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The reaction you get as a foreign reporter varies quite a bit across China. But I think these circumstances, where people feel that they — and, in a sense, we — are all in this together, and that you’re there somehow experiencing this as well, make it easier to create that connection.</p>, <p class="css-ma92ss evys1bk0">That’s it for this briefing. See you next time.</p>, <p class="css-ma92ss evys1bk0">— Chris</p>, <p class="css-jwz2nf etfikam0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Thank you</strong><br/>Mark Josephson and Eleanor Stanford provided the break from the news. You can reach the team at <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="mailto:briefing@nytimes.com" title="">briefing@nytimes.com</a>. </p>, <p class="css-jwz2nf etfikam0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">P.S.</strong><br/>• We’re listening to “<a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/thedaily" title="">The Daily</a>.” Today’s episode includes an interview with Senator Chuck Schumer, the minority leader.<br/>• Here’s today’s <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/crosswords/game/mini" title="">Mini Crossword</a>, and a clue: It leaves in the spring (four letters). <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/crosswords" title="">You can find all our puzzles here</a>.<br/>• Jason Polan, a New York sketch artist, produced hundreds of illustrations for the print edition of The Times. <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/27/arts/jason-polan-dead.html" title="">He died on Monday at 37</a>.</p>, <p>Advertisement</p>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd" id="site-index-label">Site Index</h2>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-0">news</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-1">opinion</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-2">arts</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-3">living</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-4">more</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-subscribe-label">Subscribe</h3>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd">Site Information Navigation</h2>]
[<p>Advertisement</p>, <p>Supported by</p>, <p class="css-c2jxua e6idgb70"></p>, <h1 class="css-1j5ig2m e1h9rw200" id="link-855a7ea" itemprop="headline"><span>South Korea's Jan. Exports Seen Falling Faster on Lunar New Year, Coronavirus to Add Strains-Reuters Poll</span></h1>, <p class="css-1fv7b6t e1jsehar1" itemprop="author" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">By<!-- --> <span class="css-1baulvz last-byline" itemprop="name">Reuters</span></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">SEOUL — South Korea's exports are expected to fall at a faster pace in January, mainly due to fewer working days around the Lunar New Year holiday and amid concerns the new coronavirus may weigh on a fragile economic recovery, a Reuters poll showed on Wednesday.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Shipments in January were expected to dip 7.8% from a year earlier, extending the contraction to a 14th consecutive month, according to the median forecast of 13 economists polled. Exports fell 5.2% in December.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">There were 21.5 working days in January this year because of the Lunar New Year holiday from Jan. 24 to 27, providing the month with 2.5 fewer working days than last year. The holiday fell in early February last year.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Beyond the calendar effect expected in January's data, however, most economists see exports growth turning positive in February amid signs of recovery in chip sales and Chinese demand.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">"The decline in exports will likely widen in January from the previous month on fewer working days, but the export growth will turn positive in February due to opposite base effect," said Park Sung-woo, economist at DB Financial Investment.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Preliminary data showed South Korea's exports in the first 20 days of January fell 0.2% from a year earlier, marking the smallest decline in a year, on better chip sales.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">But analysts see the contagious virus possibly piling more pressure on the trade-reliant economy.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The virus, originating in the Chinese central city of Wuhan at the end of last year, has spread to the United States, Japan, Canada, France and Germany among others. It has killed more than 100 people.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">"Though we expect exports growth to turn positive in February, the rebound is unlikely to be strong given the possibility of a temporary slowdown in Chinese demand over the virus," said Park Sang-hyun, chief economist at Hi Investment &amp; Securities.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">"The development of the virus will serve as an important variable for recovery in South Korea's exports going further," Park added.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">On Tuesday, South Korea's finance minister vowed to stabilise financial markets should market volatility worsen, adding that the outbreak may hit the nation's exports and economic growth.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">In the same poll, 11 economists separately expect South Korea's consumer prices to rise a median 1.1% in January on-year, faster than a 0.7% gain in December.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Economists also saw industrial output in December rising a seasonally adjusted 0.5% from a month earlier.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Industrial output and trade data are due to be released on Friday and Saturday, respectively, while inflation data will be out on Feb. 4.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"> (Reporting by Joori Roh; Editing by Sam Holmes)</p>, <p>Advertisement</p>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd" id="site-index-label">Site Index</h2>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-0">news</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-1">opinion</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-2">arts</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-3">living</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-4">more</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-subscribe-label">Subscribe</h3>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd">Site Information Navigation</h2>]
[<p>Advertisement</p>, <p>Supported by</p>, <p class="css-c2jxua e6idgb70"></p>, <h1 class="css-1j5ig2m e1h9rw200" id="link-770a9c89" itemprop="headline"><span>Britain to Isolate Anyone Returning From Wuhan, Minister Says</span></h1>, <p class="css-1fv7b6t e1jsehar1" itemprop="author" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">By<!-- --> <span class="css-1baulvz last-byline" itemprop="name">Reuters</span></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">LONDON — Anyone returning to Britain from the Chinese city of Wuhan will be safely isolated for 14 days to prevent the spread of coronavirus, Britain's Health Secretary Matt Hancock said on Wednesday.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Hancock said on Twitter the government was working hard to get British nationals back from Wuhan, epicentre of the outbreak of coronavirus, adding that anyone placed in isolation would receive all necessary medical attention.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"> (Reporting by David Milliken, writing by Estelle Shirbon; editing by Kate Holton)</p>, <p>Advertisement</p>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd" id="site-index-label">Site Index</h2>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-0">news</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-1">opinion</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-2">arts</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-3">living</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-4">more</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-subscribe-label">Subscribe</h3>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd">Site Information Navigation</h2>]
[<p>Advertisement</p>, <p>Supported by</p>, <p class="css-c2jxua e6idgb70"></p>, <h1 class="css-1j5ig2m e1h9rw200" id="link-139cbf37" itemprop="headline"><span>Russia and China Are Working on Virus Vaccine: Consulate</span></h1>, <p class="css-1fv7b6t e1jsehar1" itemprop="author" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">By<!-- --> <span class="css-1baulvz last-byline" itemprop="name">Reuters</span></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">MOSCOW — Russia and China are working to develop a coronavirus vaccine and Beijing has handed over the genome of the virus to Moscow, a Russian diplomatic mission in China said on Wednesday.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The death toll in China from coronavirus rose to 132 on Wednesday with the number of confirmed cases now at nearly 6,000. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">"Russian and Chinese experts have begun developing a vaccine," the Russian consulate in Guangzhou city said in a statement.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">It was not clear if Russian and Chinese scientists were working together or separately. The consulate in Guangzhou could not be reached for comment.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Russia, which has not had any confirmed cases of the virus, on Tuesday began screening all Russian tourists returning from China, the national consumer health watchdog said on Wednesday. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">"The Chinese side handed over the virus genome to Russia, which has allowed our scientists to rapidly develop express-tests that make it possible to identify the virus in the human body within two hours," the consulate said in the statement.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Russia has been in talks with China about evacuating its nationals from Wuhan and Hubei province, the epicenter of the outbreak, the consulate said. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Prime Minister Mikhail Mishustin ordered Russia's consumer safety watchdog to draw up and present a plan to the government later on Wednesday on ways to prevent the spread of coronavirus.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Russian authorities have closed some land border crossings to China in the Russian Far East until Feb. 7. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"> (Reporting by Andrey Kuzmin; writing by Tom Balmforth; editing by John Stonestreet and Angus MacSwan)</p>, <p>Advertisement</p>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd" id="site-index-label">Site Index</h2>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-0">news</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-1">opinion</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-2">arts</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-3">living</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-4">more</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-subscribe-label">Subscribe</h3>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd">Site Information Navigation</h2>]
[<p>Advertisement</p>, <p>Supported by</p>, <p class="css-c2jxua e6idgb70"></p>, <h1 class="css-1j5ig2m e1h9rw200" id="link-67956e" itemprop="headline"><span>United Airlines Suspends Some U.S. Flights to China as Demand Drops Over Virus Fears</span></h1>, <p class="css-1fv7b6t e1jsehar1" itemprop="author" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">By<!-- --> <span class="css-1baulvz last-byline" itemprop="name">Reuters</span></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">CHICAGO — United Airlines Holdings Inc said on Tuesday it was suspending some flights between the United States and Beijing, Hong Kong and Shanghai between Feb. 1 and Feb. 8 due to a "significant decline in demand" as the new coronavirus spreads.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">"We will continue to monitor the situation as it develops and will adjust our schedule as needed," United said in a statement.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The coronavirus that originated in Wuhan, China has killed 106 people in the Asian country and spread across the world, rattling financial markets.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">United's suspension affects a total of 24 flights.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The other two U.S. airlines that fly to China, Delta Air Lines Inc and American Airlines Group Inc, said they had not reduced their flights at this time but were closely monitoring the situation.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"> (Reporting by Tracy Rucinski; Editing by Chris Reese and Bill Berkrot)</p>, <p>Advertisement</p>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd" id="site-index-label">Site Index</h2>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-0">news</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-1">opinion</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-2">arts</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-3">living</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-4">more</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-subscribe-label">Subscribe</h3>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd">Site Information Navigation</h2>]
