Editing by Chris Reese and Bill Berkrot)</p>, <p>Advertisement</p>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd" id="site-index-label">Site Index</h2>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-0">news</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-1">opinion</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-2">arts</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-3">living</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-4">more</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-subscribe-label">Subscribe</h3>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd">Site Information Navigation</h2>]
[<p>Advertisement</p>, <p>Supported by</p>, <p class="css-c2jxua e6idgb70"></p>, <h1 class="css-1j5ig2m e1h9rw200" id="link-39e9f237" itemprop="headline"><span>Foxconn Says Plans in Place to Meet Production Obligations After Virus Outbreak</span></h1>, <p class="css-1fv7b6t e1jsehar1" itemprop="author" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">By<!-- --> <span class="css-1baulvz last-byline" itemprop="name">Reuters</span></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">TAIPEI — Apple Inc supplier Foxconn said it could continue to meet all manufacturing obligations in the wake of a coronavirus outbreak in China even as the iPhone maker flagged uncertainty created by the disease.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">"We do not comment on our specific production practices, but we can confirm that we have measures in place to ensure that we can continue to meet all global manufacturing obligations," Foxconn, formally known as Hon Hai Precision Industry Co Ltd, said in a statement on Tuesday.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">A new coronavirus has killed 132 in China and affected nearly 6,000 people, with several other countries reporting cases as well.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">China extended the Lunar New year Holiday by three days to Feb. 2 to contain spread of the virus.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Foxconn, which has a big facility in Wuhan, the epicentre of the virus outbreak, said its plants in China were following holiday schedules and would continue to do so until all businesses have resumed standard operating hours.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The outbreak has led countries including the United States to advise against all but necessary travel to China, forced food chains such as Starbucks to close stores and airlines to cancel flights.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Apple, which reported holiday quarter sales and profit above Wall Street expectations on Tuesday, offered a wider-than-normal earnings outlook for the March quarter because of the uncertainty created by the coronavirus.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">"The situation is emerging, and we're still gathering lots of data points and monitoring it very closely," Apple Chief Executive Tim Cook told Reuters.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Apple has suppliers in the Wuhan area, but has alternatives, Cook said.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">After the Lunar New Year holiday, factories outside the Wuhan area will not reopen until Feb. 10, Cook said, but Apple built the delayed restart into its wider revenue forecast.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Taiwan's TSMC, the world's largest contract chipmaker which has factories in China's Shanghai and Nanjing, told Reuters its operations had not been affected. The company has asked staff who had visited Hubei within the last 14 days to stay at home and monitor their health. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"> (Reporting by Ben Blanchard in Taipei; Editing by Lincoln Feast.)</p>, <p>Advertisement</p>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd" id="site-index-label">Site Index</h2>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-0">news</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-1">opinion</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-2">arts</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-3">living</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-4">more</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-subscribe-label">Subscribe</h3>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd">Site Information Navigation</h2>]
[<p>Advertisement</p>, <p>Supported by</p>, <p class="css-c2jxua e6idgb70"></p>, <h1 class="css-1j5ig2m e1h9rw200" id="link-154ea3b5" itemprop="headline"><span>UNICEF Sends Six Tonnes of Masks and Other Gear to Help Fight China Virus</span></h1>, <p class="css-1fv7b6t e1jsehar1" itemprop="author" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">By<!-- --> <span class="css-1baulvz last-byline" itemprop="name">Reuters</span></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">GENEVA — A six-tonne shipment of respiratory masks and protective suits for health care workers landed in China on Wednesday for distribution in Wuhan, the epicenter of a spreading coronavirus outbreak, the U.N. Children's Fund (UNICEF) said.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The United States and Japan flew citizens out of the central Chinese city as the death toll rose to 133 and the first case appeared in the Middle East. There have been 5,974 confirmed cases in China.[ nL4N29Y18Z]</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">UNICEF's shipment, weighing six metric tonnes, was sent from its global supply hub in Copenhagen and landed in Shanghai, the agency said in a statement.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“This coronavirus is spreading at a breakneck speed and it is important to put all the necessary resources into halting it,” said Henrietta Fore, UNICEF Executive Director.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">"We may not know enough about the virus’s impact on children or how many may be affected – but we do know that close monitoring and prevention are key. Time is not on our side.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">UNICEF said it was working with other agencies including the World Health Organization on a coordinated response in China and other affected countries. The WHO announced on Tuesday that China had agreed to a team of international experts visiting to help combat the virus but gave no timetable or details.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"> (Reporting by Stephanie Nebehay; Editing by Nick Macfie)</p>, <p>Advertisement</p>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd" id="site-index-label">Site Index</h2>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-0">news</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-1">opinion</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-2">arts</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-3">living</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-4">more</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-subscribe-label">Subscribe</h3>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd">Site Information Navigation</h2>]
[<p>Advertisement</p>, <p>Supported by</p>, <p class="css-c2jxua e6idgb70"></p>, <h1 class="css-1j5ig2m e1h9rw200" id="link-4d923872" itemprop="headline"><span>Global Stock Rally Loses Steam, Virus Keeps Safe-Havens Alive</span></h1>, <p class="css-1fv7b6t e1jsehar1" itemprop="author" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">By<!-- --> <span class="css-1baulvz last-byline" itemprop="name">Reuters</span></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">NEW YORK — Global equity markets closed little changed on Wednesday as strong results from Apple and others provided a lift, but concerns about the coronavirus outbreak in China kept enthusiasm in check and a safe-haven bid in gold and the dollar alive.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The yield on benchmark U.S. Treasuries and German bunds fell as foreign governments evacuated citizens from the virus' epicenter in China and the World Health Organization voiced "grave concern" about person-to-person infection in three countries. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The death toll in China from the virus rose by 27 to 133, and another 1,459 cases were confirmed. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">A Chinese government economist said the outbreak could cut China's first-quarter growth by one point to 5% or lower as the crisis hits sectors from mining to luxury goods.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The Federal Reserve left interest rates unchanged at its first policy meeting of the year. Officials pointed to continued moderate U.S. economic growth and a "strong" job market. Since the Fed cut rates in October, policymakers have kept their target rate in a range of 1.50% to 1.75%.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Treasury yields were little changed after the Fed released its policy statement. Benchmark U.S. stock indexes initially ticked up to the day's highs before paring gains to close at break-even.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The market's muted reaction to the virus' spread, which is close to the number of people infected by the SARS outbreak in 2003, is very positive, said Kristina Hooper, chief global market strategist at Invesco in New York.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">"The fact that stocks have held up today in light of the negative news on the novel coronavirus is a sign that the Fed is a dominant factor in keeping markets calm," Hooper said.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The practice of buying $60 billion every month of U.S. Treasury bills to ensure adequate short-term liquidity in bank funding markets will remain in place at least into April, as will a related offering of repurchase agreements, the Fed said.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Strong results from Santander helped bank stocks in Europe. Gains in Apple Inc and Boeing Co lifted shares on Wall Street, but a spate of disappointing results from AT&amp;T and Advanced Micro Devices Inc, among others, weighed on equities.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">MSCI's gauge of stocks across the globe shed 0.01% as emerging market stocks lost 0.38%. Mexico's bolsa index bucked the downdraft in emerging markets, rising about 0.93%. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">U.S. President Donald Trump signed a new trade agreement with Canada and Mexico into law on Wednesday, replacing the 26-year-old North American Free Trade Agreement.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The pan-European STOXX 600 index rose 0.44%, with the euro-zone banks index gaining 1%.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Santander posted higher quarterly net profit, boosted by a solid underlying performance in Brazil and capital gains. Santander rose 4.4%. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Apple gained 2.1% after reporting earnings for the holiday shopping quarter above analysts' expectations, even as it braced for more supply disruptions in virus-hit China.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 11.6 points, or 0.04%, to 28,734.45. The S&amp;P 500 lost 2.84 points, or 0.09%, to 3,273.4 and the Nasdaq Composite added 5.48 points, or 0.06%, to 9,275.16.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Spot gold prices rose as concerns about economic growth due to the coronavirus buoyed safe-haven demand, but U.S. gold futures settled little changed at $1,570.40 per ounce.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Oil was mixed, weighed by worries about how the coronavirus could affect demand and swelling U.S. crude inventories. Talk that the Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries could extend crude output cuts provided support. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Brent crude gained 30 cents to settle at $59.81 at barrel, while U.S. crude fell 15 cents to settle at $53.33. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Demand strengthened for the dollar index and the safe-haven Japanese yen firmed modestly. A risk-off tone returned to currency markets amid uncertainty about the coronavirus.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The dollar index rose 0.07%, with the euro down 0.14% to $1.1005. The yen strengthened 0.09% versus the greenback at 109.06 per dollar.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Benchmark 10-year U.S. Treasury notes rose 18/32 in price to push down its yield to 1.5805%.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"> (Reporting by Herbert Lash; Editing by Tom Brown and Leslie Adler)</p>, <p>Advertisement</p>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd" id="site-index-label">Site Index</h2>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-0">news</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-1">opinion</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-2">arts</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-3">living</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-4">more</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-subscribe-label">Subscribe</h3>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd">Site Information Navigation</h2>]
[<p>Advertisement</p>, <p>Supported by</p>, <p class="css-c2jxua e6idgb70"></p>, <h1 class="css-1j5ig2m e1h9rw200" id="link-7554ab4b" itemprop="headline"><span>EU Commission Advises Staff to Suspend Non-Essential Travel to China</span></h1>, <p class="css-1fv7b6t e1jsehar1" itemprop="author" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">By<!-- --> <span class="css-1baulvz last-byline" itemprop="name">Reuters</span></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">BRUSSELS — The European Commission is advising its staff to delay "non-essential" travel to China, the top official in charge of crisis management said on Wednesday, as the number of deaths from a new coronavirus leapt.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The advice concerns only European Union staff, as travel bans and recommendations to citizens are issued by national authorities of the bloc's 28 states rather than the EU.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Commission officials and EU diplomats have been advised "to postpone or suspend all non-essential travels to China", Crisis Management Commissioner Janez Lenarcic told a news conference on Wednesday, adding that EU staff in China were also recommended not to return to the EU at this stage.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">On Tuesday, Britain's Foreign Office advised against "all but essential" travel to mainland China due to the coronavirus outbreak.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The EU is helping repatriate Europeans from the Chinese province of Hubei, the hardest hit by an epidemic that has so far killed 132 people.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Eight people infected with the virus have so far been reported in the EU, Health Commissioner Stella Kyriakides said on Wednesday, confirming that four of them were in Germany and the other four in France.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">She said the EU could unlock funds to help develop a vaccine against the new virus if the situation deteriorated, but at the moment there was no need for it. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"> (Reporting by Francesco Guarascio; Editing by Alex Richardson)</p>, <p>Advertisement</p>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd" id="site-index-label">Site Index</h2>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-0">news</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-1">opinion</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-2">arts</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-3">living</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-4">more</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-subscribe-label">Subscribe</h3>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd">Site Information Navigation</h2>]
[<p>Advertisement</p>, <p>Supported by</p>, <p class="css-c2jxua e6idgb70"></p>, <h1 class="css-1j5ig2m e1h9rw200" id="link-4d923872" itemprop="headline"><span>Global Stock Rally Loses Steam, Virus Keeps Safe-Havens Alive</span></h1>, <p class="css-1fv7b6t e1jsehar1" itemprop="author" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">By<!-- --> <span class="css-1baulvz last-byline" itemprop="name">Reuters</span></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">NEW YORK — Global equity markets closed little changed on Wednesday as strong results from Apple and others provided a lift, but concerns about the coronavirus outbreak in China kept enthusiasm in check and a safe-haven bid in gold and the dollar alive.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The yield on benchmark U.S. Treasuries and German bunds fell as foreign governments evacuated citizens from the virus' epicenter in China and the World Health Organization voiced "grave concern" about person-to-person infection in three countries. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The death toll in China from the virus rose by 27 to 133, and another 1,459 cases were confirmed. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">A Chinese government economist said the outbreak could cut China's first-quarter growth by one point to 5% or lower as the crisis hits sectors from mining to luxury goods.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The Federal Reserve left interest rates unchanged at its first policy meeting of the year. Officials pointed to continued moderate U.S. economic growth and a "strong" job market. Since the Fed cut rates in October, policymakers have kept their target rate in a range of 1.50% to 1.75%.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Treasury yields were little changed after the Fed released its policy statement. Benchmark U.S. stock indexes initially ticked up to the day's highs before paring gains to close at break-even.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The market's muted reaction to the virus' spread, which is close to the number of people infected by the SARS outbreak in 2003, is very positive, said Kristina Hooper, chief global market strategist at Invesco in New York.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">"The fact that stocks have held up today in light of the negative news on the novel coronavirus is a sign that the Fed is a dominant factor in keeping markets calm," Hooper said.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The practice of buying $60 billion every month of U.S. Treasury bills to ensure adequate short-term liquidity in bank funding markets will remain in place at least into April, as will a related offering of repurchase agreements, the Fed said.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Strong results from Santander helped bank stocks in Europe. Gains in Apple Inc and Boeing Co lifted shares on Wall Street, but a spate of disappointing results from AT&amp;T and Advanced Micro Devices Inc, among others, weighed on equities.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">MSCI's gauge of stocks across the globe shed 0.01% as emerging market stocks lost 0.38%. Mexico's bolsa index bucked the downdraft in emerging markets, rising about 0.93%. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">U.S. President Donald Trump signed a new trade agreement with Canada and Mexico into law on Wednesday, replacing the 26-year-old North American Free Trade Agreement.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The pan-European STOXX 600 index rose 0.44%, with the euro-zone banks index gaining 1%.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Santander posted higher quarterly net profit, boosted by a solid underlying performance in Brazil and capital gains. Santander rose 4.4%. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Apple gained 2.1% after reporting earnings for the holiday shopping quarter above analysts' expectations, even as it braced for more supply disruptions in virus-hit China.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 11.6 points, or 0.04%, to 28,734.45. The S&amp;P 500 lost 2.84 points, or 0.09%, to 3,273.4 and the Nasdaq Composite added 5.48 points, or 0.06%, to 9,275.16.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Spot gold prices rose as concerns about economic growth due to the coronavirus buoyed safe-haven demand, but U.S. gold futures settled little changed at $1,570.40 per ounce.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Oil was mixed, weighed by worries about how the coronavirus could affect demand and swelling U.S. crude inventories. Talk that the Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries could extend crude output cuts provided support. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Brent crude gained 30 cents to settle at $59.81 at barrel, while U.S. crude fell 15 cents to settle at $53.33. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Demand strengthened for the dollar index and the safe-haven Japanese yen firmed modestly. A risk-off tone returned to currency markets amid uncertainty about the coronavirus.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The dollar index rose 0.07%, with the euro down 0.14% to $1.1005. The yen strengthened 0.09% versus the greenback at 109.06 per dollar.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Benchmark 10-year U.S. Treasury notes rose 18/32 in price to push down its yield to 1.5805%.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"> (Reporting by Herbert Lash; Editing by Tom Brown and Leslie Adler)</p>, <p>Advertisement</p>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd" id="site-index-label">Site Index</h2>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-0">news</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-1">opinion</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-2">arts</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-3">living</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-4">more</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-subscribe-label">Subscribe</h3>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd">Site Information Navigation</h2>]
[<p>Advertisement</p>, <p>Supported by</p>, <p class="css-c2jxua e6idgb70"></p>, <h1 class="css-1j5ig2m e1h9rw200" id="link-7b6849c5" itemprop="headline"><span>China's President Xi Says Containing the Virus Remains a Grim and Complex Task</span></h1>, <p class="css-1fv7b6t e1jsehar1" itemprop="author" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">By<!-- --> <span class="css-1baulvz last-byline" itemprop="name">Reuters</span></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">BEIJING — China's President Xi Jinping said on Wednesday that preventing and containing the new coronavirus remains a grim and complex task, the state television reported.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"> (Reporting by Lusha Zhang and Aizhu Chen; Editing by Toby Chopra)</p>, <p>Advertisement</p>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd" id="site-index-label">Site Index</h2>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-0">news</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-1">opinion</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-2">arts</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-3">living</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-4">more</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-subscribe-label">Subscribe</h3>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd">Site Information Navigation</h2>]
[<p>Advertisement</p>, <p>Supported by</p>, <p class="css-c2jxua e6idgb70"></p>, <h1 class="css-1j5ig2m e1h9rw200" id="link-51ce9118" itemprop="headline"><span>China First Quarter Growth May Dip Below 5% as Virus Spreads: Government Economist</span></h1>, <p class="css-1fv7b6t e1jsehar1" itemprop="author" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">By<!-- --> <span class="css-1baulvz last-byline" itemprop="name">Reuters</span></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">BEIJING — China's economic growth may drop to 5% or even lower due to the coronavirus outbreak, possibly pushing policymakers into introduce more stimulus measures, a government economist said in remarks published on Wednesday.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The fast-spreading outbreak, which has killed more than 130 people and infected almost 6,000 in China, could cut first-quarter GDP growth by about 1 percentage point, Caijing magazine quoted Zhang Ming as saying.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">"GDP growth in the first quarter of 2020 could be about 5.0%, and we cannot rule out the possibility of falling below 5.0%," Zhang said.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Zhang, an economist at the Chinese Academy of Social Sciences - a top government think tank - said his forecast was based on the assumption that the outbreak will peak in early to mid-February and end by the end of March. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">China's growth slowed to a near 30-year low of 6% in the fourth quarter, and analysts have said they expect the epidemic to drag on the economy.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Zhang estimated its impact on China's economy could be significantly bigger than that of Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome (SARS), a coronavirus that originated in China and killed nearly 800 people globally in 2002 and 2003.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The world's second-largest economy was relying more on services and consumption now than then, Zhang said, by way of explanation.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">About 60 cases of the coronavirus, but no deaths, have been reported in 15 other countries, including the United States, France and Singapore.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Airports around the world are screening passengers from China, while foreign companies are curbing travel to China and airlines are cutting flights, with British Airways one of the biggest names to do so.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Domestically, the outbreak has hit sectors including transportation, tourism, catering and entertainment. Zhang said it could weigh on jobs, with the official survey-based unemployment rate likely to exceed 5.3% in the coming months, Zhang said.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">In response, the government is likely to step up policy support, which could boost the annual budget deficit as a share of GDP to over 3% in 2020, he said.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The People's Bank of China could further cut banks' reserve requirement ratios and interest rates, Zhang added.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Economic growth could recover later this year, bringing the full-year expansion to 5.7%, Zhang said. In 2019 growth was 6.1%, the weakest in 29 years.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Speaking before the start of the outbreak, policy sources told Reuters that Beijing planned to set a lower national growth target of around 6% this year from last year's 6-6.5%, relying on increased infrastructure spending to ward off a sharper slowdown.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"> (Reporting by Kevin Yao; editing by John Stonestreet)</p>, <p>Advertisement</p>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd" id="site-index-label">Site Index</h2>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-0">news</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-1">opinion</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-2">arts</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-3">living</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-4">more</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-subscribe-label">Subscribe</h3>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd">Site Information Navigation</h2>]
[<p>Advertisement</p>, <p>Supported by</p>, <p class="css-c2jxua e6idgb70"></p>, <h1 class="css-1j5ig2m e1h9rw200" id="link-2a35565a" itemprop="headline"><span>Malaysia in Talks to Evacuate Its Citizens From Wuhan-PM Mahathir</span></h1>, <p class="css-1fv7b6t e1jsehar1" itemprop="author" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">By<!-- --> <span class="css-1baulvz last-byline" itemprop="name">Reuters</span></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">KUALA LUMPUR — Malaysian Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad said on Wednesday Kuala Lumpur was in talks with China to evacuate its citizens from Wuhan, the Chinese city at the centre of the outbreak of the new coronavirus. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">A total of 78 Malaysians are currently in Wuhan, he said. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"> (Reporting by Joseph Sipalan; Editing by Muralikumar Anantharaman)</p>, <p>Advertisement</p>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd" id="site-index-label">Site Index</h2>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-0">news</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-1">opinion</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-2">arts</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-3">living</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-4">more</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-subscribe-label">Subscribe</h3>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd">Site Information Navigation</h2>]
[<p>Advertisement</p>, <p>Supported by</p>, <p class="css-c2jxua e6idgb70"></p>, <h1 class="css-1j5ig2m e1h9rw200" id="link-2ef39c10" itemprop="headline"><span>Italy Organizing Flight to Evacuate Its Citizens From Chinese City of Wuhan</span></h1>, <p class="css-1fv7b6t e1jsehar1" itemprop="author" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">By<!-- --> <span class="css-1baulvz last-byline" itemprop="name">Reuters</span></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">ROME — Italy is arranging a flight on Thursday to evacuate its citizens from the Chinese city of Wuhan, epicenter of the outbreak of a new coronavirus, the Italian Foreign Ministry said on Wednesday.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">A ministry official said "around 50" Italians were stranded in Wuhan, which has been largely isolated in an effort to prevent the spread of the virus.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"> (Reporting by Crispian Balmer; Editing by Alison Williams)</p>, <p>Advertisement</p>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd" id="site-index-label">Site Index</h2>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-0">news</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-1">opinion</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-2">arts</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-3">living</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-4">more</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-subscribe-label">Subscribe</h3>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd">Site Information Navigation</h2>]
[<p>Advertisement</p>, <p>Supported by</p>, <p class="css-c2jxua e6idgb70"></p>, <h1 class="css-1j5ig2m e1h9rw200" id="link-1836329" itemprop="headline"><span>Virus in China Affects Sports Events, Olympic Qualifiers</span></h1>, <p class="css-1fv7b6t e1jsehar1" itemprop="author" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">By<!-- --> <span class="css-1baulvz last-byline" itemprop="name">The Associated Press</span></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">GENEVA — Amid growing concern about the spread of a new virus in China, international sports in the country have been postponed and Olympic qualifying tournaments have been taken elsewhere.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The indoor world athletics championships in Nanjing were postponed by a year on Wednesday, while the international ski federation canceled the first World Cup races scheduled for the mountain venue where the sport will be held during the 2022 Beijing Olympics. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The governing body of athletics said the indoor worlds will now be held in March 2021 instead of March 13-15 this year. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“We know that China is doing all it can to contain the new Coronavirus and we support them in all their efforts but it is necessary to provide our athletes, Member Federations and partners with a clear way forward in what is a complex and fast-moving set of circumstances,” World Athletics said in a statement. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Nanjing is located about 530 kilometers (330 miles) from Wuhan, where the virus emerged. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">In Alpine skiing, a men's downhill had been scheduled for Feb. 15 in Yanqing to start a two-race weekend.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“Due to the outbreak and continuing spread of the Novel Coronavirus, FIS, the Chinese Ski Association and its Yanqing Local Organizing Committee, have jointly decided to cancel,” FIS said in a statement.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The ski federation said it would advise later if the downhill and super-G races will be be rescheduled.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">That followed a decision by the international field hockey federation to postpone Pro League games in China. Qualifying tournaments for the Tokyo Olympics in soccer, basketball and boxing scheduled for next month have been moved outside of the country.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The biggest upcoming event in China is the Formula One race in Shanghai on April 19, which draws large crowds both for the race and for practice and qualifying. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Olympic qualifying events have been affected in recent days. Women’s soccer and women’s basketball games were moved to Australia and Serbia. The soccer games had already previously moved from Wuhan, at the center of the outbreak, to Nanjing. Boxing tournaments for the Asia and Oceania regions will be held in Jordan in March.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Tokyo Governor Yuriko Koike acknowledged her concern about the virus when speaking Wednesday to the heads of 62 municipalities.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“With only 177 days to go and our preparations accelerating, we must firmly tackle the new coronavirus to contain it, or we are going to regret it,” Koike said. ”I will do the utmost to contain this new problem as we cooperate closely with all of you."</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Tokyo Olympic organizers put out a generic statement on Wednesday and offered no details.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“Countermeasures against infectious diseases constitute an important part of our plans to host a safe and secure games,” the statement said, adding they would “carefully monitor any incidence of infectious diseases and we will review any countermeasures that may be necessary with all relevant organizations.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">More than 130 deaths in China have been recorded because of the disease, including the first in Beijing. On Wednesday, the number of total cases jumped to 5,974.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Cases have been reported in Japan, South Korea, Thailand, Vietnam, the United States, Australia, Canada and Germany.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The coronavirus family includes the common cold but also more severe illnesses. It causes cold- and flu-like symptoms, and in more severe cases, shortness of breath and pneumonia. The virus is thought to have spread to people from wild animals sold at a market in Wuhan, a city of 11 million people which is now in lockdown.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Future sports events in China also include a World Cup soccer qualifying game on March 26 against Maldives, and the China Open golf tournament, part of the European Tour, on April 23-26 in Shenzhen.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Also Wednesday, Danish soccer club Aalborg said it had decided not to play a friendly against Chinese team Wuhan Zall in Spain.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“We are aware that the risk of infection may be microscopic, and little is still known about the virus, but in consultation with the (club), management, staff and the health sector, we have agreed not to expose anyone,” Aalborg managing director Thomas Baelum said.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">___</p>, <p>Advertisement</p>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd" id="site-index-label">Site Index</h2>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-0">news</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-1">opinion</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-2">arts</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-3">living</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-4">more</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-subscribe-label">Subscribe</h3>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd">Site Information Navigation</h2>]
[<p>Advertisement</p>, <p>Supported by</p>, <p class="css-c2jxua e6idgb70"></p>, <h1 class="css-1j5ig2m e1h9rw200" id="link-5c6798d8" itemprop="headline"><span>White House Did Not Ask for a Suspension of U.S.-China Flights-Official</span></h1>, <p class="css-1fv7b6t e1jsehar1" itemprop="author" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">By<!-- --> <span class="css-1baulvz last-byline" itemprop="name">Reuters</span></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">WASHINGTON — The White House has not asked for a suspension of flights between the United States and China over concerns about the coronavirus outbreak, a senior Trump administration official said on Tuesday.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The official's comment followed a report by CNBC that the White House had told airline executives it was considering a suspension of U.S.-China flights. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"> (Reporting by Steve Holland; Writing by Eric Beech; Editing by Doina Chiacu)</p>, <p>Advertisement</p>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd" id="site-index-label">Site Index</h2>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-0">news</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-1">opinion</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-2">arts</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-3">living</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-4">more</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-subscribe-label">Subscribe</h3>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd">Site Information Navigation</h2>]

[<p>Advertisement</p>, <p>Supported by</p>, <p class="css-c2jxua e6idgb70"></p>, <h1 class="css-1j5ig2m e1h9rw200" id="link-180b8c65" itemprop="headline"><span>Chinese Family in UAE Diagnosed as First Virus Cases in Middle East</span></h1>, <p class="css-1fv7b6t e1jsehar1" itemprop="author" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">By<!-- --> <span class="css-1baulvz last-byline" itemprop="name">Reuters</span></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">DUBAI — Four members of a Chinese family who arrived in the United Arab Emirates from Wuhan have been diagnosed with the new coronavirus, the first known cases in the Middle East, the UAE health ministry said on Wednesday.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The virus originated in the city, capital of Hubei province, and has killed more than 130 people in China. The UAE is a major international air transport hub and its airport in Dubai is one of the world's busiest.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The four were visitors and arrived in the country on Jan 16, health ministry official Hussein al-Rand told Reuters. One family member, feeling unwell, attended a clinic on Jan 23 where they were diagnosed with the coronavirus.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The other three members were subsequently tested and also diagnosed with the virus. The family comprises a wife and husband, both 36, a child aged nine, and a grandmother aged 63, Rand said. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">All four are in a stable condition and under medical observation, the ministry said in an earlier statement carried by the state news agency.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Rand said the government had traced those the family had come into contact with since arriving, and all had tested negative for the virus.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">He declined to say which of the UAE's seven emirates the family were being treated in or had visited, or at which airport they arrived.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Nearly 60 cases have been reported in 15 countries outside China, including the United States, France and Singapore.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Fears of the spreading virus have pushed airlines to reduce flights to China. Emirates, the UAE's biggest airline, said on Wednesday its flights were operating normally, and Rand said there were no plans to suspend flights between the UAE and China.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The Gulf Cooperation Council's (GCC) health committee met on Wednesday in the Saudi capital Riyadh to discuss the virus and to unify Gulf efforts to prevent its spread, Bahrain's state news agency BNA said.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"> (Reporting by Nafisa Eltahir, Alexander Cornwell, Lisa Barrington and Nayera Abdallah; Editing by Janet Lawrence and John Stonestreet)</p>, <p>Advertisement</p>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd" id="site-index-label">Site Index</h2>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-0">news</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-1">opinion</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-2">arts</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-3">living</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-4">more</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-subscribe-label">Subscribe</h3>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd">Site Information Navigation</h2>]
[<p>Advertisement</p>, <p>Supported by</p>, <p class="css-c2jxua e6idgb70"></p>, <h1 class="css-1j5ig2m e1h9rw200" id="link-5d4c849f" itemprop="headline"><span>Governments Should Decide on Any Evacuations From Virus Zones: WHO</span></h1>, <p class="css-1fv7b6t e1jsehar1" itemprop="author" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">By<!-- --> <span class="css-1baulvz last-byline" itemprop="name">Reuters</span></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">GENEVA — It is for governments to decide whether to evacuate their nationals from Wuhan, the Chinese city at the epicenter of the coronavirus outbreak, the World Health Organization (WHO) said on Wednesday.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">WHO director-general Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus and senior Chinese officials discussed measures at talks in Beijing this week, including possible alternatives to evacuation of foreigners "if there are ways to accommodate them and protect their health", WHO spokesman Tarik Jasarevic told Reuters.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">"If countries want to evacuate their nationals from Wuhan, WHO’s position is that this is a matter for their governments to decide," Jasarevic said by email in answer to a query.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"> (Reporting by Stephanie Nebehay; Editing by Jon Boyle)</p>, <p>Advertisement</p>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd" id="site-index-label">Site Index</h2>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-0">news</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-1">opinion</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-2">arts</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-3">living</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-4">more</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-subscribe-label">Subscribe</h3>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd">Site Information Navigation</h2>]
[<p>Advertisement</p>, <p>Supported by</p>, <p class="css-c2jxua e6idgb70"></p>, <h1 class="css-1j5ig2m e1h9rw200" id="link-48358352" itemprop="headline"><span>Renault Says Will Reopen Wuhan Plant With Partner Dongfeng on February 10</span></h1>, <p class="css-1fv7b6t e1jsehar1" itemprop="author" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">By<!-- --> <span class="css-1baulvz last-byline" itemprop="name">Reuters</span></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">LONDON — Renault will resume production at the factory it runs with Dongfeng Group in Wuhan, Hubei province and the epicenter of the outbreak of a new flu-like virus, on Feb. 10, a spokeswoman for the French carmaker said on Tuesday.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The reopening of the plant will be eight days after the end of the extended Lunar New Year holiday in China, the world's top car market. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">On Monday, Beijing added three days to the week-long holiday, which will now last until Feb. 2 as it seeks to limit the spread of the coronavirus, which has infected thousands and killed more than 100.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"> (Reporting by Yilei Sun and Josephine Mason)</p>, <p>Advertisement</p>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd" id="site-index-label">Site Index</h2>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-0">news</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-1">opinion</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-2">arts</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-3">living</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-4">more</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-subscribe-label">Subscribe</h3>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd">Site Information Navigation</h2>]
[<p>Advertisement</p>, <p>Supported by</p>, <p class="css-c2jxua e6idgb70"></p>, <h1 class="css-1j5ig2m e1h9rw200" id="link-5f904aaf" itemprop="headline"><span>Asia Jet Fuel Demand Slumps as Airlines Cancel Flights After Virus Outbreak</span></h1>, <p class="css-1fv7b6t e1jsehar1" itemprop="author" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">By<!-- --> <span class="css-1baulvz last-byline" itemprop="name">Reuters</span></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">SINGAPORE — Asian jet fuel demand is taking a beating from an outbreak of a flu-like virus in China that has led airlines to cancel scores of flights during the peak Lunar New Year travel season.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Jet fuel prices have dropped and refiners' profits for the product have slumped to the lowest in more than 2-1/2 years, while industry analysts are cutting their 2020 forecasts for jet fuel and overall oil demand. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Airlines and passengers are on guard against the respiratory coronavirus that originated in the central Chinese city of Wuhan, killing more than 130 people in China so far and spreading to over a dozen countries. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">"Chinese jet demand usually sees a seasonal upside of around 150,000 barrels per day (bpd) ahead of the Lunar New Year in January versus December, and we are likely to be looking at a lower-than-average seasonal uptick for early 2020 given the curtailments on travel," said Kostantsa Rangelova, lead Asia analyst at Vienna-based consultancy JBC Energy. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Many passengers have called off travel plans for the Lunar New Year holiday, prompting airlines to offer refunds. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">"Market participants, already wary of slow demand growth from last year, are weighing the effects on global oil demand of the lockdown in several cities in China, and likely reduced travelling in the broader Asia-Pacific region," Barclays analyst Amarpreet Singh said in a note. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">During the 2002-2003 outbreak of Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome (SARS) - also caused by a coronavirus that originated in China and which killed nearly 800 people globally - air passenger demand in Asia plunged 45%. And now, the travel industry is more reliant on Chinese travellers, and China's share of the global economy has quadrupled. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">"This year, the impact on jet fuel could be more severe, as China's share of global jet demand has risen from 3.8% in 2003 to 12% in 2017," Citi analysts led by Ed Morse said in a note. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">If air passenger traffic in China were to decline by half in the first quarter of this year, it would likely lead to a 300,000 barrels-per-day (bpd) decline in jet kerosene demand from China from a year ago, Barclays analyst Singh said. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Several airlines across Asia have suspended flights to Wuhan, and some tour operators are cancelling trips to China. (Graphic: Asia jet fuel margins plummet as global travel demand stalls amid coronavirus outbreak, https://fingfx.thomsonreuters.com/gfx/ce/7/8278/8259/SingaporerefMarginsJan2020.png) </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">"Flight departures from the top five biggest Chinese airports fell by nearly 800 flights this past weekend relative to (the previous) weekend, while traffic in the five airports closest to Wuhan have fallen by nearly 50% over recent days," analysts at RBC Capital Markets said in a note. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Jet fuel demand over the past five years has been a bright spot for global oil demand growth, accounting for some 15% of Chinese demand growth, the analysts said. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Refiners' profits for producing a barrel of jet fuel from Dubai crude &lt;JETSGCKMc1&gt; fell to $9.25 a barrel on Monday, the lowest level since June 2017 and down nearly 40% since the start of this year, Refinitiv Eikon data showed. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">A milder than normal winter in Asia has also weighed on margins for kerosene, which belongs to the same grade of oil products as jet fuel. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"> (Reporting by Koustav Samanta and Jessica Jaganathan; Additional reporting by Seng Li Peng; Editing by Florence Tan and Tom Hogue)</p>, <p>Advertisement</p>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd" id="site-index-label">Site Index</h2>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-0">news</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-1">opinion</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-2">arts</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-3">living</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-4">more</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-subscribe-label">Subscribe</h3>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd">Site Information Navigation</h2>]
[<p>Advertisement</p>, <p>Supported by</p>, <p class="css-c2jxua e6idgb70"></p>, <h1 class="css-1j5ig2m e1h9rw200" id="link-28ecb52e" itemprop="headline"><span>Kazakhstan Suspends Transport Links With China Over Virus</span></h1>, <p class="css-1fv7b6t e1jsehar1" itemprop="author" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">By<!-- --> <span class="css-1baulvz last-byline" itemprop="name">Reuters</span></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">ALMATY — Kazakhstan is suspending all forms of passenger travel to and from neighboring China, the Central Asian nation's government said on Wednesday as an outbreak of a new coronavirus continued to widen.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The government has also suspended the issuance of visas to Chinese citizens, it said in a statement.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Bus routes to and from China have already been halted, while passenger train movement will stop on Feb. 1 and all flights will be suspended from Feb. 3, the government said.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Kazakhstan has registered no cases of the new virus, but has isolated dozens of people with respiratory infection symptoms upon return from China and is carrying out additional tests.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"> (Reporting by Olzhas Auyezov; Editing by Alison Williams)</p>, <p>Advertisement</p>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd" id="site-index-label">Site Index</h2>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-0">news</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-1">opinion</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-2">arts</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-3">living</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-4">more</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-subscribe-label">Subscribe</h3>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd">Site Information Navigation</h2>]
[<p>Advertisement</p>, <p>Supported by</p>, <p class="css-c2jxua e6idgb70"></p>, <h1 class="css-1j5ig2m e1h9rw200" id="link-405f1559" itemprop="headline"><span>WHO Panel to Reconvene on Thursday to Decide if Virus Global Emergency</span></h1>, <p class="css-1fv7b6t e1jsehar1" itemprop="author" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">By<!-- --> <span class="css-1baulvz last-byline" itemprop="name">Reuters</span></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">GENEVA — The World Health Organization's Emergency Committee will meet on Thursday, the third time in a week, to evaluate whether the new coronavirus spreading from China now constitutes an international emergency, the WHO said.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">"The Committee will advise the Director-General on whether the outbreak constitutes a Public Health Emergency of International Concern (PHEIC), and what recommendations should be made to manage it," the WHO said in a statement issued in Geneva ahead of a news briefing by senior WHO expert Mike Ryan on return from China.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The Emergency Committee, composed of 16 independent experts, twice last week declined to declare a global emergency.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"> (Reporting by Stephanie Nebehay; Editing by Alison Williams)</p>, <p>Advertisement</p>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd" id="site-index-label">Site Index</h2>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-0">news</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-1">opinion</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-2">arts</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-3">living</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-4">more</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-subscribe-label">Subscribe</h3>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd">Site Information Navigation</h2>]
[<p>Advertisement</p>, <p>Supported by</p>, <p class="css-c2jxua e6idgb70"></p>, <h1 class="css-1j5ig2m e1h9rw200" id="link-674dbe8e" itemprop="headline"><span>Mobile World Congress to Go Ahead Despite China Virus Spread: GSMA</span></h1>, <p class="css-1fv7b6t e1jsehar1" itemprop="author" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">By<!-- --> <span class="css-1baulvz last-byline" itemprop="name">Reuters</span></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">BERLIN — The Mobile World Congress, an annual telecoms industry event that draws more than 100,000 visitors to Barcelona, will go ahead as planned on Feb. 24-27 despite the international spread of a virus that has killed 132 people in China.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">"The upcoming Mobile World Congress Barcelona event will proceed as planned," the GSMA telecoms industry group that organizes the event said in a statement issued in response to a Reuters inquiry.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The GSMA said it was monitoring and assessing the potential impact of the coronavirus outbreak. It would adhere to safety recommendations from the World Health Organization and governments, and provide additional medical support on site.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"> (Reporting by Douglas Busvine; Editing by Riham Alkousaa)</p>, <p>Advertisement</p>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd" id="site-index-label">Site Index</h2>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-0">news</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-1">opinion</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-2">arts</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-3">living</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-4">more</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-subscribe-label">Subscribe</h3>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd">Site Information Navigation</h2>]
[<p>Advertisement</p>, <p>Supported by</p>, <p class="css-c2jxua e6idgb70"></p>, <h1 class="css-1j5ig2m e1h9rw200" id="link-d7e5950" itemprop="headline"><span>China's Women's Olympic Soccer Team Quarantined in Australia</span></h1>, <p class="css-1fv7b6t e1jsehar1" itemprop="author" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">By<!-- --> <span class="css-1baulvz last-byline" itemprop="name">The Associated Press</span></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">BRISBANE, Australia — China's national women's soccer team has been quarantined in Australia ahead of an Olympic qualifying tournament as fears spread about the outbreak of a new virus that has killed more than 130 people.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Health officials in Queensland state said on Wednesday that 32 people, including players, coaches and staff, traveled through the virus-effected Chinese city of Wuhan a week ago. The team was placed in isolation by border officials after arriving in Brisbane from Shanghai on Tuesday, and will be confined to a Brisbane hotel until Feb. 5.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Queensland Health said the squad was traveling with a team doctor and none has shown symptoms.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The Olympic regional qualifying tournament had been relocated from Wuhan to Nanjing before the Asian Football Confederation moved it to Sydney, Australia, because of concerns over the deadly coronavirus. Now it likely will be delayed.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The tournament had been scheduled to kick off next Monday with a double-header of China against Thailand followed by Australia against Taiwan.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">It's the final stage of regional qualifying for the Tokyo Olympics, which begin in July. The top two teams were supposed to advance to a home-and-away playoff for the last spot at the Olympic tournament.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Football Federation Australia on Wednesday placed a hold on ticket sales for the tournament.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The Chinese team trained in isolation before departing for Australia and players and staff all underwent testing before departure.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">"They went through all the same checks that any Chinese national flying in from China would have gone through," FFA chief executive James Johnson was quoted as saying by Australian Associated Press. "We're confident in the government's checks and balances."</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The FFA said it was notified of the latest advice from Australia’s Chief Medical Officer, Professor Brendan Murphy, that health experts believe the coronavirus is contagious before people show symptoms, and contacts of any confirmed cases must be isolated following exposure.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">China has cut off access to Wuhan and 16 other cities to prevent people from leaving and spreading the virus further. The outbreak has infected more than 6,000 on the mainland and abroad. British Airways and Asian budget carriers Lion Air and Seoul Air have suspended flights to China and other airlines are reducing the number of flights to the country as demand for travel drops because of the outbreak.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">___</p>, <p>Advertisement</p>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd" id="site-index-label">Site Index</h2>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-0">news</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-1">opinion</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-2">arts</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-3">living</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-4">more</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-subscribe-label">Subscribe</h3>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd">Site Information Navigation</h2>]
[<p>Advertisement</p>, <p>Supported by</p>, <p class="css-c2jxua e6idgb70"></p>, <h1 class="css-1j5ig2m e1h9rw200" id="link-2bd18698" itemprop="headline"><span>U.S. Military Won't Be in Contact With Wuhan Evacuees - Pentagon</span></h1>, <p class="css-1fv7b6t e1jsehar1" itemprop="author" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">By<!-- --> <span class="css-1baulvz last-byline" itemprop="name">Reuters</span></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">WASHINGTON — U.S. military personnel won't have any direct contact with U.S. evacuees who are being flown to a U.S. military base in southern California from the Chinese city of Wuhan, the center of an outbreak of the coronavirus, the Pentagon said on Wednesday.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The Pentagon's statement did not say whether the Americans would be quarantined at March Air Reserve Base but did say that the evacuees would have "assigned housing" and would not be able to access any base location other than that housing.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The Pentagon said the U.S. Department of Health and Human Services will handle the evacuees and would transport any ill Americans identified to a local civilian hospital, as opposed to any on-base medical care.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"> (Reporting by Phil Stewart; Editing by Chizu Nomiyama)</p>, <p>Advertisement</p>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd" id="site-index-label">Site Index</h2>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-0">news</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-1">opinion</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-2">arts</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-3">living</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-4">more</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-subscribe-label">Subscribe</h3>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd">Site Information Navigation</h2>]
[<p>Advertisement</p>, <p>Supported by</p>, <h1 class="css-1qskr30 e1h9rw200" id="link-77f86801" itemprop="headline"><span>Beware the Pandemic Panic</span></h1>, <p class="css-1ifw933 e1wiw3jv0" id="article-summary">Coronavirus is scary. How we respond to it may be worse.</p>, <p class="css-1fv7b6t e1jsehar1" itemprop="author" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">By<!-- --> <a class="css-brehiz e1jsehar0" href="https://www.nytimes.com/by/farhad-manjoo"><span class="css-1baulvz last-byline" itemprop="name">Farhad Manjoo</span></a></p>, <p class="css-cpkn1d e1wtpvyy1">Opinion Columnist</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Coronavirus is starting to freak me out — not the illness itself but the amped-up, ill-considered way our frightened world might respond to it.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Yes, the novel virus appears to be <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/28/world/asia/china-coronavirus.html?action=click&amp;pgtype=Article&amp;state=default&amp;module=Coronavirus%20Storyline&amp;variant=show&amp;region=TOP_BANNER&amp;context=Menu#link-196147f3" title="">spreading quickly at the outbreak’s epicenter in the Chinese province of Hubei</a>, but after a late start the Chinese government is now imposing <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/22/world/asia/coronavirus-quarantines-history.html" title="">unprecedented measures to contain it</a>. As the World Health Organization declared last week, it <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.who.int/news-room/detail/23-01-2020-statement-on-the-meeting-of-the-international-health-regulations-(2005)-emergency-committee-regarding-the-outbreak-of-novel-coronavirus-(2019-ncov)" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">remains too early</a> to call the outbreak a global public health emergency.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">So far, the Wuhan coronavirus is not much more frightening than the outbreaks of other recent coronaviruses like <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.who.int/csr/sars/country/table2004_04_21/en/" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">SARS in 2003</a> or <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.who.int/emergencies/mers-cov/en/" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">MERS in 2012</a>, each of which killed fewer than a thousand people around the world. The new virus’s death toll has just exceeded 130; for context, <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.cdc.gov/flu/weekly/index.htm" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">according to the CDC</a>, about 15 million Americans have been sickened by the seasonal flu so far in the 2019-2020 flu season, and 8,200 have died from it. (The <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.cdc.gov/media/releases/2017/p1213-flu-death-estimate.html" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">flu kills</a> between 300,000 and 650,000 people around the world annually.)</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">What worries me more than the new disease is that fear of a vague and terrifying new illness might spiral into panic, and that it might be used to justify unnecessarily severe limits on movement and on civil liberties, especially of racial and religious minorities around the world.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">I also worry that the online world may give rise to dangerous skepticism, and that in the event of an actual pandemic a large number of people may delay treatment or refuse vaccines because they don’t believe the science or are suspicious of the government.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“I predict that the next major outbreak — whether of a highly fatal strain of influenza or something else — will not be due to a lack of preventive technologies,” warned Heidi Larson, the director of the Vaccine Confidence Project, in <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nature.com/articles/d41586-018-07034-4" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">a 2018 article in the journal Nature</a>. “Instead, emotional contagion, digitally enabled, could erode trust in vaccines so much as to render them moot.” Social media, she added, “should be recognized as a global public-health threat.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.washingtonpost.com/technology/2020/01/27/facebook-google-twitter-scramble-stop-misinformation-about-coronavirus/" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">Tech giants have been racing to tamp down conspiracy theories and hoaxes</a> about the Wuhan virus, but I worry that their efforts won’t be very successful, because society seems to have no good answer to the kind of emotional contagion Dr. Larson describes. It’s not just that many people get their news from a medium given to rumor, exaggeration and wild misinformation, <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.ahajournals.org/doi/10.1161/JAHA.118.011838" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">especially on issues about health or science</a> — see the persistence of antivaxers or climate-change deniers. There is also a <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.pewresearch.org/science/2019/08/02/trust-and-mistrust-in-americans-views-of-scientific-experts/" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">growing partisan divide over how Americans interpret scientific expertise</a> and <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://news.gallup.com/opinion/polling-matters/272108/emotional-partisanship-driving-views-healthcare.aspx" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">health polic</a>y, leaving decisions about public health vulnerable to the kind of partisan squabbling you hear on cable news every night.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">I also worry about the hair-trigger state of geopolitics. From Donald Trump to Xi Jinping to Boris Johnson, strongmen with authoritarian tendencies run many of the world’s most powerful governments. It is worth remembering that disease, or the fear of disease, can bring out the worst in humanity — pandemics often <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2009/09/01/health/01plague.html" title="">feed scapegoating</a> (Jews were widely blamed for the Black Death), creating a fertile field for demagogues. When you put all these factors together, you’ve got a dangerous recipe for global repression.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Already, China’s response appears to be driven by political considerations more than epidemiological ones. The government has imposed a travel lockdown on more than 35 million people, which experts say is a quarantine of unprecedented size and scale, yet <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/27/opinion/china-wuhan-virus-quarantine.html" title="">it may not even turn out to be very effective</a>. Experts say that <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/17684187" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">quarantines work best during the earliest stages</a> of an outbreak, but that they can also <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC2267247/" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">backfire</a>, causing medical shortages, corroding trust in health officials and pushing some people to look to evade care to escape any restriction on their rights. China took weeks to mount a full-scale response to the virus. According to Wuhan’s mayor, five<a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.scmp.com/news/china/society/article/3047720/chinese-premier-li-keqiang-head-coronavirus-crisis-team-outbreak" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title=""> million people left the city before restrictions were imposed</a>, suggesting the country is effectively locking the barn door after the horse has run off.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“They’re doing it because people who are in political leadership always think that if you do something dramatic and visible that you’ll gain popular support,” Lawrence O. Gostin, a professor of global health law at Georgetown University, <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.washingtonpost.com/health/unprecedented-chinese-quarantine-could-backfire-experts-say/2020/01/24/db073f3c-3ea4-11ea-8872-5df698785a4e_story.html" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">told The Washington Post</a>. “They couldn’t have any sound public health advice.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">We should keep this sense of caution in mind in case American politicians begin pushing for travel bans, overbroad quarantines or other measures that might not be supported by the science.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">You might wonder what the great harm is — if the government needs to temporarily limit people’s movements or prevent some people from entering the country, shouldn’t it take those measures in the face of dangerous illness? Perhaps, but given the checkered history of quarantines — <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3559034/pdf/12-0312.pdf" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">throughout history,</a> they have been used to persecute the marginalized — lawmakers and the media should rigorously examine the bases for any such restrictions. We should especially make sure any restrictions imposed are indeed temporary and adhere to the science — something <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.aclu.org/issues/privacy-technology/medical-and-genetic-privacy/fear-politics-and-ebola" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">we don’t always do</a>. Consider that 30 years after the AIDS outbreak, men who have sex with men are still restricted from donating blood in the United States, <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC5554671/" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">long after the scientific basis for such a ban has passed</a>.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">So far, President Trump has offered a measured response to the virus. “We have it totally under control,” <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.politico.com/news/2020/01/22/trump-chinese-coronavirus-totally-under-control-102054" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">he said this week</a>. But online, <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.theatlantic.com/technology/archive/2020/01/china-coronavirus-twitter/605644/" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">misinformation about the scale of the virus is already trending</a>. (It is not, as you might have read on Twitter, <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.theatlantic.com/science/archive/2020/01/how-fast-and-far-will-new-coronavirus-spread/605632/" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">“thermonuclear pandemic level bad.”</a>) So <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://foreignpolicy.com/2020/01/27/dont-blame-bat-soup-for-the-wuhan-virus/" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">are racist memes blaming Chinese people and Chinese culture for the virus</a>.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">I fear that the conditions are ripe for a situation similar to what occurred in the summer of 2014, when an outbreak of Ebola overran West Africa. After the Obama administration scrambled to bring home two American health workers who had become infected with the disease in Liberia, <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://thehill.com/homenews/state-watch/386616-how-ebola-entered-the-american-consciousness-a-trump-tweet" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">Trump went on a monthslong Twitter tirade</a> about Ebola.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The future president favored extreme isolationism, seeing no benefit to American help in Africa. “People that go to far away places to help out are great-but must suffer the consequences!” <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://twitter.com/realDonaldTrump/status/495379061972410369" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">he wrote</a> — ultimately sparking a growing partisan movement against the government’s response to the virus.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Today, Trump runs an administration that is <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.washingtonpost.com/climate-environment/science-ranks-grow-thin-in-trump-administration/2020/01/23/5d22b522-3172-11ea-a053-dc6d944ba776_story.html" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">hemorrhaging scientific expertise</a>, and his political agenda is rife with efforts to target immigrants, minorities and the poor. In 2016, a terrorist attack prompted Trump to propose banning Muslims from the country; when he won the White House, he instituted a version of that ban.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">I fear that panic about a foreign virus offers society another chance to target marginalized people. So let’s keep our fear in check; panic will hurt us far more than it’ll help.</p>, <h2 class="css-1320w4z eoo0vm40" id="link-1321c92e">Office Hours With Farhad Manjoo</h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">Farhad wants to </em><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2019/05/16/opinion/farhad-office-hours.html?module=inline" title=""><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">chat with readers on the phone</em></a><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">. If you’re interested in talking to a New York Times columnist about anything that’s on your mind, please fill out this form. Farhad will select a few readers to call.</em></p>, <p class="css-jwz2nf etfikam0"><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">The Times is committed to publishing </em><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2019/01/31/opinion/letters/letters-to-editor-new-york-times-women.html" title=""><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">a diversity of letters</em></a><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0"> to the editor. We’d like to hear what you think about this or any of our articles. Here are some </em><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://help.nytimes.com/hc/en-us/articles/115014925288-How-to-submit-a-letter-to-the-editor" title=""><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">tips</em></a><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">. And here's our email: </em><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="mailto:letters@nytimes.com" title=""><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">letters@nytimes.com</em></a><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">.</em></p>, <p class="css-jwz2nf etfikam0"><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">Follow The New York Times Opinion section on </em><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.facebook.com/nytopinion" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title=""><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">Facebook</em></a><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">, </em><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="http://twitter.com/NYTOpinion" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title=""><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">Twitter (@NYTopinion)</em></a><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0"> and </em><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.instagram.com/nytopinion/" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title=""><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">Instagram</em></a><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">.</em></p>, <p>Advertisement</p>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd" id="site-index-label">Site Index</h2>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-0">news</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-1">opinion</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-2">arts</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-3">living</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-4">more</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-subscribe-label">Subscribe</h3>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd">Site Information Navigation</h2>]
[<p>Advertisement</p>, <p>Supported by</p>, <p class="css-c2jxua e6idgb70"></p>, <h1 class="css-1j5ig2m e1h9rw200" id="link-6ab6baaa" itemprop="headline"><span>WHO Weighs Science and Politics in Global Virus Emergency Decision</span></h1>, <p class="css-1fv7b6t e1jsehar1" itemprop="author" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">By<!-- --> <span class="css-1baulvz last-byline" itemprop="name">Reuters</span></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">GENEVA/LONDON — Most of the World Health Organization's (WHO) criteria for declaring a global emergency have been met, but it is awaiting clear evidence of a sustained spread of the new coronavirus outside China before doing so, some experts and diplomats said.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The U.N. agency is seeking to balance the need to ensure China continues to share information about the virus while also giving sound scientific advice to the international community on the risks, according to several public health experts and a Western diplomat who tracks the WHO's work.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The WHO has declared five global emergencies in the past decade, including the ongoing Ebola epidemic in the Democratic Republic of Congo.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Doing so can hurt host countries because it may lead to flight cancellations and travel or trade restrictions, dragging on the economy.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">In the latest case, the WHO declined to declare China's coronavirus a public health emergency of international concern (PHEIC) twice last week, although its Emergency Committee was split "50-50" over whether to do so.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">"What was lacking for them to declare an international emergency were deaths abroad and human-to-human transmission outside of China," said the Geneva-based diplomat following the agency.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">"If there was proof of human-to-human spread among the 'imported' cases, the panel would lean towards another finding."</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">WHO spokesman Christian Lindmeier declined to comment beyond what he told a news briefing earlier on Tuesday.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">He restated that the WHO's criteria for a global emergency include a "serious or unusual" health situation that affects other countries and may require a coordinated international response.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">In reply to a question, he added: "It is not 'wildly spreading' outside of China."</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">While the vast majority of the 4,500 or so confirmed cases and all 106 deaths so far have been in China, cases in Germany, Vietnam, Taiwan and Japan where the virus has spread person-to-person have heightened concerns.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">"As information is coming in, it seems to be confirming our worst fears," Lawrence Gostin, university professor at Georgetown Law in Washington, DC, told Reuters.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">"So I do believe that the WHO is going to have to declare an emergency and is going to have to take the lead ... You can't leave this to China."</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">'A ROCK AND HARD PLACE'</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The WHO's 16-member expert panel is being "kept in the loop" and could be reconvened at any time to reassess the outbreak.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">"Just because of rising numbers in China now this would not automatically trigger an Emergency Committee," Lindmeier told the briefing.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">A declaration would lead to boosting public health measures, funding and resources to prevent and reduce global spread.
