Jessica Simpson </strong>is ready to talk.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Ahead of her new memoir, “Open Book,” <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/29/style/jessica-simpson-memoir-alcohol-addiction.html" title="">we sat down with the early-aughts pop star </a>to talk about addiction, sexual abuse as a child, dating John Mayer, divorce — and everything else.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“Even though I have been so open about things that I’ve gone through in my life, I’ve never been open about them in an emotional way,” she said.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Our Styles writer says that Ms. Simpson delivers on the promise that stars are just like us, “only richer and prettier and with great, but maybe not greater, expectations.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">10. And finally, </strong>cracking a decades-old C.I.A. mystery.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The Kryptos sculpture has been in a courtyard at the agency’s headquarters in Langley, Va., for almost 30 years. Three of its four passages have been decoded (the first was solved by a team from the National Security Agency). <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2020/01/29/climate/kryptos-sculpture-final-clue.html" title="">Now its creator is offering one final clue</a>: “NORTHEAST.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The puzzle, cut into a sheet of copper, has been a source of delight and consternation to thousands of people. Having a chance to solve a problem, one mathematician said, “gives people great pleasure.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Good luck, and hope you have a breakthrough tonight.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">Your Evening Briefing is posted at 6 p.m. Eastern.</em></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">And don’t miss Your Morning Briefing. </em><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2018/briefing/global-morning-briefing-newsletter-signup.html" title=""><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">Sign up here</em></a><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0"> to get it by email in the Australian, Asian, European, African or American morning.</em></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">Want to catch up on past briefings? </em><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/series/us-evening-briefing" title=""><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">You can browse them here</em></a><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">.</em></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">What did you like? What do you want to see here? Let us know at </em><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="mailto:briefing@nytimes.com?subject=Evening%20Briefing%20Feedback" title=""><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">briefing@nytimes.com</em></a><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">.</em></p>, <p>Advertisement</p>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd" id="site-index-label">Site Index</h2>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-0">news</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-1">opinion</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-2">arts</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-3">living</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-4">more</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-subscribe-label">Subscribe</h3>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd">Site Information Navigation</h2>]
[<p>Advertisement</p>, <p>Supported by</p>, <h1 class="css-1s4ffep e1h9rw200" id="link-65186c4e" itemprop="headline"><span>Your Thursday Briefing</span></h1>, <p class="css-1ifw933 e1wiw3jv0" id="article-summary">Wuhan, Middle East peace deal, impeachment: Here’s what you need to know.</p>, <p class="css-1fv7b6t e1jsehar1" itemprop="author" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">By<!-- --> <a class="css-brehiz e1jsehar0" href="https://www.nytimes.com/by/melina-delkic"><span class="css-1baulvz last-byline" itemprop="name">Melina Delkic</span></a></p>, <p class="css-ma92ss evys1bk0">Good morning.</p>, <p class="css-ma92ss evys1bk0">We’re covering the business impact of the <strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Wuhan coronavirus</strong>, growing ire around President Trump’s <strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Middle East peace deal</strong> and a detailed account of a <strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Uighur family</strong> pulled apart by detention camps.</p>, <h2 class="css-3ez4hu eoo0vm40" id="link-589e933d">Coronavirus tests world’s dependence on China</h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Businesses like Starbucks, Ikea, Ford and Toyota are <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/29/business/china-coronavirus-economy.html" title="">shutting down locations in China</a>, and Apple is rerouting supply chains as the number of people infected by a mysterious flulike virus passes 6,000.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">It’s not clear how quickly these businesses will bounce back.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Tourism is also suffering. British Airways suspended all flights to the mainland, and United Airlines and Air Canada joined a growing number of carriers reducing service. Governments around the world are issuing travel warnings.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">China has been the world’s largest source of tourism dollars, but it appears unlikely that Chinese tourists will spend what they typically do — $258 billion annually, nearly twice the tally of Americans.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">The toll: </strong>China said that <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/29/world/asia/coronavirus-china.html" title="">132 people had died from the virus</a>, which is believed to have originated in Wuhan. There have been no reported deaths outside of China, but cases overseas have been rising.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Answers:</strong> Bats are considered the probable source of the outbreak. They have an immune system that allows them to <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/28/science/bats-coronavirus-Wuhan.html" title="">carry many viruses without getting sick</a>. And here’s a refresher on <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/article/what-is-coronavirus.html" title="">what we know about the disease</a>.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">How to stop it: </strong>Scientists in China, the U.S. and Australia are <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/28/health/coronavirus-vaccine.html" title="">racing to develop a vaccine</a>, a quest that could take months, if not years.</p>, <h2 class="css-3ez4hu eoo0vm40" id="link-41adeb55">A Middle East peace deal draws ire</h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Palestinian leaders <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/29/world/middleeast/peace-plan-explain.html" title="">flatly rejected President Trump’s long-awaited plan</a>, announced alongside Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel on Tuesday.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Mahmoud Abbas, the 84-year-old leader of the Palestinian Authority, called the attempt to resolve generations of conflict between Israelis and Palestinians a “conspiracy” not worthy of serious consideration. “We say a thousand times over: no, no, no,” he said, speaking from Ramallah in the West Bank on Tuesday night. Protests broke out on the streets of Gaza and the West Bank.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Reaction from other Arab governments <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/28/world/middleeast/arabs-reaction-trump-mideast-peace-plan.html" title="">has been mixed</a>, with no U.S. allies in the region formally endorsing the plan or committing to it. Ambassadors from Bahrain, Oman and the United Arab Emirates did attend the announcement.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">The latest: </strong>Israel <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/aponline/2020/01/29/world/middleeast/ap-ml-israel-palestinians.html" title="">postponed a move to annex large parts of the West Bank</a> to explore the legal ramifications, a government minister said, a day after Mr. Netanyahu vowed to quickly act on the plan.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Recap: </strong>Mr. Trump and Mr. Netanyahu, both <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/28/world/middleeast/trump-netanyahu-peace-plan.html?action=click&amp;module=Top%20Stories&amp;pgtype=Homepage" title="">facing turmoil at home and in need of a win</a>, announced a path to peace that heavily favors Israel. Here’s <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/28/world/middleeast/peace-plan.html" title="">a map that outlines the agreement</a>, which proposes a Palestinian state with limited sovereignty and Israeli control of a unified Jerusalem.</p>, <h2 class="css-3ez4hu eoo0vm40" id="link-5f7d22b0">Impeachment could soon come to a close</h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Republican leaders signaled that they were growing more confident they would be able to block new witnesses and documents in President Trump’s impeachment trial — and that they could <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/live/2020/impeachment-trial-live-01-29" title="">call a vote for acquittal as soon as Friday</a>.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The party’s 53 senators appeared to be falling into line, despite recent revelations from John Bolton, the former national security adviser, that undercut the president’s defense.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">But the trial isn’t over yet: On Wednesday, after a week of silently hearing the case, senators began to cross-examine the legal teams representing the president and the House. Both sides used the opportunity to poke holes in their opponents’ cases. Follow along at nytimes.com.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">What’s next: </strong>Should four Republicans <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/27/us/politics/impeachment-witnesses-republican-votes.html" title="">join Democrats to summon witnesses</a> for the trial, it could open a new phase that could continue well into February.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">The argument: </strong>One of Mr. Trump’s lawyers pushed, among other things, an extraordinarily expansive view of executive power, arguing that any action taken by the president to help his own re-election is, by definition, in the public interest.</p>, <h3 class="css-1b8te77 e1gnsphs0" id="link-fdfe371">If you have some time, this is worth it</h3>, <h2 class="css-3ez4hu eoo0vm40" id="link-11170cd">For Uighurs, playing by the rules doesn’t help</h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Zulhumar Isaac, above, a young Uighur woman from Xinjiang Province, grew up in a family of model citizens — her mother was even a midlevel Communist Party member. But when the party started cracking down on Uighurs, her parents were detained.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Our writer spent nearly a year <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/29/magazine/uyghur-muslims-china.html" title="">documenting her story of loss, frustration and dissent</a> as she played a perilous game with the state to get them back.</p>, <h3 class="css-1b8te77 e1gnsphs0" id="link-554e6082">Here’s what else is happening</h3>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Huawei: </strong>In a second victory for the Chinese tech giant this week, the European Union advised its members only <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/29/world/europe/eu-huawei-5g.html" title="">to limit so-called high-risk 5G vendors</a>, a category that includes Huawei, stopping short of recommending a ban urged by the U.S. on security grounds.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Brexit:</strong> The last step in the yearslong lead-up to Britain’s withdrawal from the European Union is complete, as European legislators passed the bill on Wednesday. Our correspondent <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/29/world/europe/brexit-brussels-eu.html" title="">explains what it means for the bloc</a>.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Kobe Bryant:</strong> A blurry selfie taken by a 13-year-old at the former N.B.A. star’s basketball academy on Saturday is perhaps <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/28/us/mamba-sports-academy.html" title="">the last picture of him before he died</a>.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Snapshot: </strong>Above, the Thwaites glacier in Antarctica, where <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/29/climate/thwaites-glacier-melting-antarctica.html" title="">scientists for the first time recorded unusually warm water</a> beneath the ice. The Florida-size glacier is part of a group that act as a brake on part of the much larger West Antarctic Ice Sheet, which, if melted, would raise the world’s oceans by more than a meter over centuries.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Australian Open: </strong>Ashleigh Barty, Australia’s best hope to win the tournament’s single’s title in a decade, plays in a semifinal today. She has avoided the hype around her in Melbourne, and <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/28/sports/tennis/australian-open-ashleigh-barty.html" title="">says she could do without all the attention</a>. On the men’s side, Novak Djokovic and Roger Federer face off. Here’s <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/29/sports/australian-open-matches-wednesday.html" title="">what else to watch</a>.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">What we’re reading: </strong><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.thecut.com/2020/01/does-dopamine-fasting-work.html" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">This account of an attempt to do the Silicon Valley dopamine fast</a> in The Cut, which is hilarious and weird. </p>, <h3 class="css-1b8te77 e1gnsphs0" id="link-7ded7ef4">Now, a break from the news</h3>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Cook: </strong>Take comfort in this recipe for <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://cooking.nytimes.com/recipes/1020775-cheesy-cornbread-muffins-with-hot-honey-butter" title="">cheesy cornbread muffins with hot honey butter</a>.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Watch: </strong>Nicolas Cage and Joely Richardson <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/23/movies/color-out-of-space-review.html" title="">confront an evil shade of lilac</a> in the sci-fi horror film “Color Out of Space,” directed by Richard Stanley.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Go: </strong>After causing a stir on social media, the unveiling of a restored panel of the “Mystic Lamb” kicks off <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/27/arts/design/mystic-lamb-ghent-altarpiece-van-eyck.html" title="">a year celebrating the late-medieval master Jan van Eyck</a> in Ghent, Belgium.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Smarter Living: </strong>If you’re traveling to Japan, <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/29/travel/etiquette-tips-for-japan.html" title="">remember these etiquette tips</a>.</p>, <h3 class="css-1b8te77 e1gnsphs0" id="link-15767e9b">And now for the Back Story on …</h3>, <h2 class="css-3ez4hu eoo0vm40" id="link-549b5492">Gandhi’s mantle</h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">Today is the 72nd anniversary of the death of Mohandas Gandhi, who helped win India’s independence from Britain with a campaign of nonviolence and enshrined protections for all religions. Protesters challenging Prime Minister Narendra Modi’s Hindu-nationalist agenda have been evoking Gandhi’s legacy — but </em><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2019/10/02/opinion/modi-mahatma-gandhi.html" title=""><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">so is Mr. Modi</em></a><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">, to promote nationalism. </em><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://twitter.com/Abihabib?ref_src=twsrc%5Egoogle%7Ctwcamp%5Eserp%7Ctwgr%5Eauthor" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title=""><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">Maria Abi-Habib</em></a><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">, a South Asia correspondent for The Times, spoke with Mike Ives, on the Briefings team, about the clash.</em></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">How have the protests changed since they started a few months ago?</strong></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">They’re <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2019/12/24/world/asia/india-protests-modi.html" title="">a lot broader</a>. It’s not just Muslims or a bunch of liberal students, it’s people who see the India that Gandhi built, one of secularism and religious coexistence, giving way to a government that is bent on a sectarian narrative at a time when the economy is sputtering.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Do any scenes spring to mind?</strong></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Some protesters held a placard that read: “Dear Hindus, We rejected an Islamic state in 1947. Now it’s your turn to reject a Hindu state. Sincerely, Secular India.” That really spoke to me because 1947 was the partition, when Hindus in Pakistan decided to stay or flee to India, and Muslims in India had a similar choice.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">India chose secularism in 1947. It was majority Hindu and said its strength was its diversity, and that it would embrace Christians and Muslims and Sikhs just as much as its Hindu citizens. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Why is one protest in particular — a highway sit-in by Muslim women in Delhi’s Shaheen Bagh neighborhood — seen as so significant?</strong></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Over all, India’s Muslim community has not been well organized in recent decades, but <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/04/world/asia/india-protests-modi-citizenship.html" title="">these protests have mobilized it</a>. Shaheen Bagh has become a symbol of that. And women’s place in Indian Muslim homes has tended to be a conservative stereotype: They don’t come onto the streets, they don’t protest, they don’t mobilize. So Shaheen Bagh has really changed the game.</p>, <p class="css-ma92ss evys1bk0">That’s it for this briefing. See you next time.</p>, <p class="css-ma92ss evys1bk0">— Melina</p>, <p class="css-jwz2nf etfikam0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Thank you</strong><br/>To Mark Josephson and Eleanor Stanford for the break from the news. You can reach the team at <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="mailto:briefing+pm@nytimes.com?subject=Briefing%20Feedback" title="">briefing@nytimes.com</a>.</p>, <p class="css-jwz2nf etfikam0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">P.S.</strong><br/>• We’re listening to “<a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/thedaily" title="">The Daily</a>.” Our latest episode includes an interview with Senator Chuck Schumer, the minority leader.<br/>• Here’s our <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/crosswords/game/mini" title="">Mini Crossword</a>, and a clue: It leaves in the spring (four letters). <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/crosswords" title="">You can find all our puzzles here</a>.<br/>• <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/28/business/media/ben-smith-buzzfeed-new-york-times.html" title="">The Times has named Ben Smith</a>, the editor in chief of BuzzFeed, as its next media columnist.</p>, <p>Advertisement</p>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd" id="site-index-label">Site Index</h2>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-0">news</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-1">opinion</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-2">arts</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-3">living</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-4">more</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-subscribe-label">Subscribe</h3>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd">Site Information Navigation</h2>]
[<p>Advertisement</p>, <p>Supported by</p>, <p class="css-c2jxua e6idgb70"></p>, <h1 class="css-1j5ig2m e1h9rw200" id="link-13078452" itemprop="headline"><span>Health Experts: Human-To-Human Spread of New Virus Worrying</span></h1>, <p class="css-1fv7b6t e1jsehar1" itemprop="author" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">By<!-- --> <span class="css-1baulvz last-byline" itemprop="name">The Associated Press</span></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">BEIJING — World health officials expressed “great concern” Wednesday that a dangerous new virus is starting to spread between people outside of China, a troubling development as China and the world frantically work to contain the outbreak. For a second day, the number of infections grew dramatically.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The new virus has now infected more people in China than were sickened there during the 2002-2003 SARS outbreak. On Wednesday, the number of cases jumped to 5,974, surpassing the 5,327 people diagnosed with SARS. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The death toll, which rose to 170 on Wednesday, is still less than half the number who died in China from SARS, or severe acute respiratory syndrome. Scientists say there are many questions to be answered about the new virus, including just how easily it spreads and how severe it is.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">In a report published Wednesday, Chinese researchers suggested that person-to-person spread among close contacts occurred as early as mid-December. Based on the first 425 confirmed cases, the researchers estimate that each infection led to 2.2 others on average. That’s a bit more than ordinary flu but far less than some other respiratory diseases such as whooping cough and tuberculosis. The rate for SARS, a cousin to this new virus, was estimated to be 3. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“Considerable efforts” will be needed to control the spread if this ratio holds up elsewhere, researchers wrote in the report, published in the New England Journal of Medicine. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">More than half of the cases in which symptoms began before Jan. 1 were tied to a seafood market, but only 8% of cases after that have been, researchers found. They reported the average incubation period was five days.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Meanwhile, the World Health Organization’s emergencies chief said the few cases of human-to-human spread of the virus outside China — in Japan, Germany, Canada and Vietnam — were of “great concern” and were part of the reason the U.N. health agency’s director-general was reconvening a committee of experts on Thursday to assess whether the outbreak should be declared a global emergency. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Dr. Michael Ryan spoke at a news conference in Geneva after returning from a trip to Beijing to meet with Chinese President Xi Jinping and other senior government leaders. He said China was taking “extraordinary measures in the face of an extraordinary challenge" posed by the outbreak. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">To date, about 99% of the nearly 6,000 cases are in China. Ryan estimated the death rate of the new virus at 2%, but said the figure was very preliminary. With fluctuating numbers of cases and deaths, scientists are only able to produce a rough estimate of the fatality rate and it’s likely many milder cases of the virus are being missed. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">In comparison, the SARS virus killed about 10% of people who caught it. The new virus is from the coronavirus family, which includes those that can cause the common cold as well as more serious illnesses such as SARS and MERS. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Ryan noted there were several aspects of the new virus outbreak that are extremely worrying, citing the recent rapid spike in cases in China. He said that while scientists believe the outbreak was sparked by an animal virus, it’s unclear if there are other factors driving the epidemic. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“Without understanding that, it’s very hard to put into context the current transmission dynamics,” he said.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Meanwhile, countries began evacuating their citizens from the Chinese city hardest-hit by the virus. Chartered planes carrying about 200 evacuees each arrived in Japan and the United States as other countries planned similar evacuations from the city of Wuhan, which authorities have shut down to try to contain the virus.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The U.S. plane arrived in California after a refueling stop in Alaska. All 195 passengers, who included diplomats from the U.S. Consulate in Wuhan, passed health screenings in China and Anchorage, and were to undergo three days of monitoring at a Southern California military base to ensure they show no signs of the illness.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“The whole plane erupted into cheers when the crew welcomed them back to the United States," Dr. Anne Zink, Alaska's chief medical officer, told reporters in Anchorage.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Four passengers on the evacuation flight to Japan had coughs and fevers, and two were diagnosed with pneumonia. It wasn't clear whether they were infected with the new virus, which first appeared in Wuhan in December. Its symptoms, including cough and fever and in severe cases pneumonia, are similar to many other illnesses.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Takeo Aoyama, an employee at Nippon Steel Corp.’s subsidiary in Wuhan, told reporters he was relieved to return home.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“We were feeling increasingly uneasy as the situation developed so rapidly and we were still in the city,” Aoyama said, his voice muffled by a white surgical mask. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The first cases in the Middle East were confirmed Wednesday, a family of four from Wuhan that was visiting the United Arab Emirates. Airlines around the world announced they were cutting flights to China, and Hong Kong was suspending rail travel to and from the mainland at midnight.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The number of cases in China rose to 1,459 from the previous day, a smaller increase than the 1,771 new cases reported Tuesday. Australia, Finland and Singapore were among those reporting new cases, as the number outside China topped 70. The vast majority are people who came from Wuhan.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Australia, New Zealand and Britain were among the latest countries to announce they are planning evacuations. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">British health secretary Matt Hancock tweeted that “anyone who returns from Wuhan will be safely isolated for 14 days, with all necessary medical attention.” The measures are a step up from those during the devastating 2014-16 Ebola outbreak, when returning travelers from West Africa were asked to monitor themselves for symptoms.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Mark Woolhouse, a professor of infectious disease epidemiology at the University of Edinburgh, said the steps are justified to prevent the introduction of the virus and its spread. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“There's always a balance between the draconian measures of public health and what people might want to do, and obviously it's regrettable if people who turn out not to have the virus are quarantined unnecessarily," he said.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">In China's Hubei province, 17 cities including Wuhan have been locked down, trapping more than 50 million people in the most far-reaching disease control measures ever imposed. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">During the 2002-2003 SARS epidemic, China was slammed for hiding that outbreak for months, allowing it to spread unchecked before reporting it to the WHO. Even after inviting international experts to investigate the epidemic, SARS patients were moved from hospitals and driven around in ambulances to conceal the true extent of the virus’ spread. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Although the Chinese health minister and others have suggested that the virus is spreading before people get symptoms, data to confirm that has not yet been shared widely beyond China. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“It’s still unclear whether that takes place,” said Malik Peiris, chair in virology at the University of Hong Kong. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“The fortunate thing about SARS, if there was anything fortunate, was that transmission did not take place before symptoms,” he said. If it turns out that the new coronavirus can indeed be spread by people who don’t show any symptoms, “a pandemic is a scenario that we have to consider.” </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">___</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Associated Press writers Maria Cheng and Jill Lawless in London; Marilynn Marchione in Milwaukee, Wisconsin; Mark Thiessen in Anchorage, Alaska; Amy Taxin in Riverside, California; and Christina Larson in Washington contributed to this report.</p>, <p>Advertisement</p>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd" id="site-index-label">Site Index</h2>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-0">news</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-1">opinion</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-2">arts</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-3">living</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-4">more</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-subscribe-label">Subscribe</h3>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd">Site Information Navigation</h2>]
[<p>Advertisement</p>, <p>Supported by</p>, <p class="css-c2jxua e6idgb70"></p>, <h1 class="css-1j5ig2m e1h9rw200" id="link-2a1e932c" itemprop="headline"><span>More Airlines Drop Flights to China as Virus Spreads</span></h1>, <p class="css-1fv7b6t e1jsehar1" itemprop="author" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">By<!-- --> <span class="css-1baulvz last-byline" itemprop="name">The Associated Press</span></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">BANGKOK — British Airways halted all flights to China and American Airlines suspended Los Angeles flights to and from Shanghai and Beijing as efforts to contain a new virus intensifies. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The coronavirus has now infected more people in China than were sickened in the country by the SARS outbreak in 2002-2003. The number of confirmed cases jumped to 7,711, surpassing the 5,327 in mainland China from SARS. The virus has killed 170 people.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The British and U.S. carriers on Wednesday joined several Asian carriers that are either suspending or significantly cutting back service there as fears spread about the coronavirus.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Air India and South Korean budget carrier Seoul Air are also halting all flights to the country, and Indonesia’s Lion Air plans to do the same. Other carriers including Finnair, Hong Kong-based Cathay Pacific, and Singapore-based Jetstar Asia are slashing service.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Beyond disrupting travel, the move is heightening concerns about the broader economic impact of the virus outbreak. Hotels, airlines, casinos and cruise operators are among the industries suffering the most immediate repercussions, especially in countries close to China. The crisis has also begun to ripple through U.S. companies with operations in China. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">In a conference call Tuesday, Apple CEO Tim Cook said the company's suppliers in China have been forced to delay reopening factories that closed for the Lunar New Year holiday until Feb. 10. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Isaac Larian, CEO of MGA Entertainment, the maker of the popular LOL dolls, said he's nervous that many workers won't come back to factories and they may close. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">"I'm very concerned about all consumer goods and retail business in 2020," Larian said. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Starbucks’ shares tumbled 2.5% Wednesday after the company said it will take a financial hit from store closures in China. The Seattle-based coffee giant said more than half of its 4,292 stores in China are now closed. China represented 10% of Starbucks’ revenue during its most recent quarter.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">By contrast, McDonald’s shares were up 2% Wednesday after the company said the financial impact so far has been minimal. McDonald’s President and CEO Chris Kempczinski said the Chicago-based company has closed several hundred restaurants, including all of its properties in Hubei province. But 3,000 remain open elsewhere in the country. China accounts for 4-5% of McDonalds’ revenue, he said.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">British Airways said it was immediately suspending all flights to and from mainland China after the U.K. government warned against unnecessary travel to the country amid a virus outbreak.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The airline operates daily flights from London's Heathrow Airport to Shanghai and Beijing. It took the measure a day after Britain's Foreign Office updated its travel advice on China, warning against “all but essential travel” to the mainland, not including Hong Kong and Macao.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The U.S. has not put into place travel restrictions, though Department of Health and Human Services Secretary Alex Azar said “it’s important to not take anything off the table,” when he was asked about that potential. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">American Airlines said Wednesday it will suspend flights between Los Angeles and both Shanghai and Beijing from Feb. 9 through Mar. 27. The airline cited “the significant decline in demand for travel to and from China.” Flights from Dallas-Fort Worth will continue, the airline said. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">China has cut off access to the central city of Wuhan, epicenter of the outbreak, and 16 other cities to prevent people from leaving and spreading the virus further. That has trapped more than 50 million people in the most far-reaching disease control measures ever imposed. The outbreak has infected more than 6,000 on the mainland and abroad.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Online flight notice boards for the Beijing and Shanghai airports showed numerous cancellations for both domestic and foreign airlines on Wednesday: </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">-Air Seoul, a budget airline, became the first South Korean airline to suspend its fights to mainland Chinese destinations apart from Wuhan, stopping its flights to the cities of Zhangjiajie and Linyi.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">-Indonesia's Lion Air said it has canceled more than 50 flights to China well into February. The flights are from five international airports in Manado, Surabaya, Jakarta, Batam and from Denpasar, in Bali, to 15 airports in China. The suspension will be phased in gradually and continue until further notice.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">-Hong Kong airlines are cutting the number of their flights to the mainland by about half through the end of March in response to government virus-control efforts.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">-Cathay Pacific Group said flights to 24 mainland destinations would be reduced to 240 weekly. The company owns Cathay Pacific Airways, cargo carrier Air Hong Kong, Cathay Dragon and Hong Kong Express.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">-Air India is suspending Delhi-Shanghai flights, which operate six times a week, from Friday until Feb. 14.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">-Finland's Finnair, which has actively promoted its position linking Asian and Western destinations, said it was canceling three weekly flights to Beijing Daxing International Airport through late March, as well as its twice-weekly flights to Nanjing.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">-Jetstar Asia will temporarily suspend flights to the Chinese cities of Hefei, Guiyang and Xuzhou starting Thursday through the end of March due to a drop in demand.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">-South Korea's second-largest carrier, Asiana Airlines, will temporarily suspend flights to the Chinese cities of Guilin, Changsha and Haikou starting next month. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">-Korean Air, South Korea’s biggest airline, said it is also considering grounding some of its flights to mainland China as passenger demand drops. Korean Air had operated four flights a week to the Chinese city of Wuhan, the epicenter of the outbreak, before suspending them on Jan. 23.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">-Taiwan’s Eva Air announced a partial cancellation of flights to and from mainland China for two weeks starting Feb. 2. In addition, the airline also has stopped providing towels, magazines, table clothes, and is limiting use of blankets and pillows on its flights.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">-Kazakhstan, which shares a long border with far western China, announced Wednesday that it plans to suspend all flights, train and bus traffic and to halt issuing visas to Chinese nationals. Before the Wednesday's suspension, there were 24 flights a week from Kazakhstan to China, including a daily flight to Ürümqi, the capital of Xinjiang. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">-Japan's JAL said it had not changed its flight plans, while German carrier Lufthansa said it was monitoring the situation “very closely" and would if necessary make changes in consultation with the authorities. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">-Dutch carrier KLM is cutting a number of flights to Chinese cities for a month because of a drop in bookings. As of Thursday it is suspending direct flights to Chengdu and Hangzhou. Flights to Xiamen will be suspended from Friday. The carrier also is reducing the number of flights to Shanghai from 11 to seven per week. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">-Air Canada, the country's largest carrier, is temporarily suspending all direct flights to Beijing and Shanghai. Flights will be suspended until Feb. 29. Air Canada operates direct flights to Beijing and Shanghai from Toronto, Montreal and Vancouver.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">___</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Associated Press writers Niniek Karmini and Edna Tarigan in Jakarta, Indonesia, Jan Olsen in Copenhagen; Daria Litvinova in Moscow, Mari Yamaguchi in Tokyo, Tong-hyung Kim in Seoul, South Korea, Penny Wang in Bangkok, Sheikh Saaliq in New Delhi, and Joe McDonald in Beijing contributed to this report. AP Airlines Writer David Koenig reported from Dallas. </p>, <p>Advertisement</p>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd" id="site-index-label">Site Index</h2>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-0">news</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-1">opinion</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-2">arts</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-3">living</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-4">more</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-subscribe-label">Subscribe</h3>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd">Site Information Navigation</h2>]
[<p>Advertisement</p>, <p>Supported by</p>, <p class="css-c2jxua e6idgb70"></p>, <h1 class="css-1j5ig2m e1h9rw200" id="link-60c98e4d" itemprop="headline"><span>Wuhan People Keep Out: Chinese Villages Shun Outsiders as Virus Spreads</span></h1>, <p class="css-1fv7b6t e1jsehar1" itemprop="author" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">By<!-- --> <span class="css-1baulvz last-byline" itemprop="name">Reuters</span></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">BEIJING — In a village in Beijing's far northeastern Shunyi district, residents have set an informal rule: "If you're here, don't leave. If they've left, don't let them come back."</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Red tape was tied across the road at the entrance to the small community Monday. Village committee members wearing face masks and high-visibility vests manned the blockade. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Since last week, a public address system had been broadcasting messages, residents told Reuters, warning people against inviting guests and urging anyone who has been to Wuhan, the epicentre of a spreading coronavirus that has killed 106 people, to register with authorities.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">"We grow our own leeks ... we have a lot of frozen pork, rice and oil. There's no need for us to go outside," villager Lu Weian, who lives in a traditional village house with high walls, told Reuters by phone. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">"Every house is its own quarantine zone," she said. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The village, hundreds of miles from Wuhan, is one of many across China shunning outsiders amid rising panic over the virus that has infected thousands. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">A decision by authorities to lock down travel in Hubei province, of which Wuhan is the capital, has spurred a counter-movement of communities closing their gates to outsiders.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Social media showed dozens of images and videos from across China of similar vigilante efforts.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Some showed villages blocking roads with vehicles, others constructing make-shift barriers out of tape and cinder-blocks. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Zhengding county in Hebei province, outside Beijing, on Monday began offering 1,000 yuan ($145) to tipsters for credible information about unregistered people who may have links to Wuhan.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">"We've done our work very carefully and registered everyone coming from the epidemic regions," said a man surnamed Ye who was manning the tip line at the county's Communist Party office when Reuters called on Tuesday. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">"We haven't got useful tips, though there are people calling offering clues. In most cases they spotted cars with Hubei plates," he said. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">'LIVES COME FIRST'</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The efforts aren't limited to villages. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">In central Beijing, some residents and authorities are tracking and registering people who have been to Wuhan. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">"It's our responsibility to find everyone and enforce safety... No one should be afraid to be an informant," said Chen Gang, a retired resident in central Dongcheng district, who is a designated community leader in his neighbourhood.<span class="css-8l6xbc evw5hdy0">  </span></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">On Saturday, Chen went door-to-door helping officials check whether people had recently visited Wuhan or had guests from Hubei. He said several people with Wuhan links were told to stay at home for a quarantine period.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">For people from Wuhan, the stigma is causing emotional strain.<span class="css-8l6xbc evw5hdy0">  </span></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">"I think I'm the loneliest person in the world right now," said 23-year-old Peking University student Carmen Wang, a Wuhan native who cancelled plans to return home from Beijing when news of the virus broke. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Wang said she has been shunned by classmates, who sent messages in a class group chat warning others not to visit her. She orders out for food and watches TV alone. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">"Even if they came and ate food with me or hung out, if I even sneezed, they would accuse me ... it's better this way," said Wang.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Villagers took pains to justify their exclusivity.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">"It's not that we are without human emotions, but lives come first," read a sign attached to an earth-moving machine parked across a road to block traffic in an image posted on social media.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">A man who answered a call from Reuters to the phone number listed on the sign declined to give the location of the village. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">"I don't want to tell you because I don't want you coming here," he said.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"> (Reporting by Cate Cadell and Sophie Yu; Editing by Tony Munroe and Nick Macfie)</p>, <p>Advertisement</p>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd" id="site-index-label">Site Index</h2>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-0">news</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-1">opinion</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-2">arts</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-3">living</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-4">more</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-subscribe-label">Subscribe</h3>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd">Site Information Navigation</h2>]
[<p>Advertisement</p>, <p>Supported by</p>, <p class="css-c2jxua e6idgb70"></p>, <h1 class="css-1j5ig2m e1h9rw200" id="link-3d50a0bb" itemprop="headline"><span>McDonald's Wraps Up Tumultuous Year on a Strong Note</span></h1>, <p class="css-1fv7b6t e1jsehar1" itemprop="author" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">By<!-- --> <span class="css-1baulvz last-byline" itemprop="name">The Associated Press</span></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">McDonald's wrapped up a tumultuous year on a high note after the company's CEO was ousted in November. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The burger giant said Wednesday it surpassed $100 billion in annual sales for the first time, and notched its highest same-store sales in more than a decade, with growth in all of its global regions.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Even as the Chicago company puts a rocky year behind it, potential hurdles have already emerged in 2020. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">McDonald’s new President and CEO Chris Kempczinski said McDonald's has closed several hundred restaurants in China because of the new coronavirus. The number of confirmed cases jumped to 5,974 Wednesday, surpassing the 5,327 in mainland China during the SARS outbreak in 2002-2003. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Kempczinski said 3,000 restaurants remain open in China, including some that are feeding health care workers. He said the outbreak is worrisome, but China only accounts for 4-5% of the company's systemwide revenue. That's less exposure than Starbucks, which said Tuesday that 10% of its revenue comes from China.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“Its actual impact on our business is going to be fairly small assuming it stays contained to China," Kempczinski said during a conference call with analysts.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">That was a relief to investors, who pushed McDonald's stock up more than 2% to $216.25 in morning trading.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Kempczinski said his top priority is improving U.S. customer traffic, which has been falling for more than a year. U.S. same-store sales — or sales at restaurants open at least 13 months — rose 5% in the fourth quarter, but that was driven by higher prices and delivery. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">McDonald's said Dynamic Yield, a system that recommends products on drive-thru menus based on weather and other factors, is also convincing customers to add items like donut sticks to their orders. McDonald's purchased Dynamic Yield last March and has added it to menu boards in the U.S. and Australia.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Kempczinski said it's critical for McDonald's to perform better at breakfast, since that's the only time of day U.S. restaurant traffic is growing. McDonald's is also facing increased competition as Wendy's reintroduces a breakfast menu.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">McDonald's plans menu changes and competitive pricing at breakfast, Kempczinksi said. The company is also testing a new chicken sandwich to better compete with Chick-fil-A and Popeye's.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“Growth in this industry at this point is going to have to come from stealing share," Kempczinski said.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">McDonald's plans to open 1,400 new restaurants this year, including 450 in China. Almost all of those restaurants will be outside the U.S. McDonald's has 38,695 restaurants worldwide; 13,846 are in the U.S.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Delivery was a big driver of the gains this year. Delivery is now available at 25,000 restaurants worldwide and brought in $4 billion in sales. That's up from $1 billion in 2016. The company added DoorDash as a U.S. partner in July, ending its exclusive partnership with UberEats. It partnered with GrubHub in September.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">McDonald's Corp. fourth-quarter net income rose 11% to $1.6 billion, or $2.08 per share. Excluding one-time items like tax benefits, the company earned $1.97 per share. That beat Wall Street's forecast of $1.96, according to FactSet. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Fourth-quarter revenue was up 4% to $5.3 billion, which was in line with estimates.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Same-store sales jumped 5.9% worldwide in the October-December quarter, topping analysts expectations. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">France and the United Kingdom were among the top performers internationally, the company said. The UK saw its 55th consecutive quarter of same-store sales growth, driven by extended breakfast hours and delivery.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Kempczinksi became president and CEO in November after former President and CEO Steve Easterbrook was ousted for violating company policy by having a consensual relationship with an employee. Kempczinski most recently led the company's U.S. operations.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Kempczinski said he has spent the past few months visiting restaurants, talking with franchisees and hosting town halls with employees.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“I continue to have great confidence in our ability to grow and shape our industry," he said.</p>, <p>Advertisement</p>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd" id="site-index-label">Site Index</h2>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-0">news</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-1">opinion</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-2">arts</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-3">living</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-4">more</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-subscribe-label">Subscribe</h3>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd">Site Information Navigation</h2>]
[<p>Advertisement</p>, <p>Supported by</p>, <p class="css-c2jxua e6idgb70"></p>, <h1 class="css-1j5ig2m e1h9rw200" id="link-7b8e9c36" itemprop="headline"><span>Record Sales Push Tesla to 2nd Straight Quarterly Profit</span></h1>, <p class="css-1fv7b6t e1jsehar1" itemprop="author" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">By<!-- --> <span class="css-1baulvz last-byline" itemprop="name">The Associated Press</span></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">DETROIT — Record electric vehicle sales in the fourth quarter helped to push Tesla Inc. to its second-straight quarterly profit, giving bullish investors optimism that sustained black ink lies ahead.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The Palo Alto, California, company said it made a $105 million net profit from October through December, or 56 cents per share, but still posted an annual loss of $862 million.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The fourth-quarter earnings continued Tesla’s meteoric stock appreciation. Shares rose nearly 12% in after-hours trading Wednesday to $648.50 </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The company said in its quarterly investor letter that it is starting to ramp up production of the Model Y small SUV in Fremont, California. The Model Y is a key product for Tesla's future because consumers are buying smaller utility vehicles. Deliveries are to start by the end of March.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The Model Y will be able to go up to 315 miles (507 kilometers) per charge, an increase over Tesla's previous estimate of 280 miles (451 kilometers), according to the letter.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Tesla also expects to “comfortably” exceed production of 500,000 vehicles this year at its factories in Fremont and Shanghai. Model Y production in Shanghai will start in 2021. The company also said it plans to start producing limited numbers of its electric semi truck this year.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">On a conference call Wednesday, CEO Elon Musk said Tesla is making progress on a full self-driving feature that he has said will be deployed this year. But the company still has a long way to go before its vehicles can travel without humans taking the wheel. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Last year, Musk said he expected to start converting Teslas to self-driving in 2020 as part of a plan to create a network of robotic taxis to compete against ride-hailing services. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Critics have said Tesla doesn't have the sensors or proper technology to offer fully self-driving vehicles.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The coronavirus outbreak in China could temporarily delay production at the company's new Shanghai factory, Chief Financial Officer Zachary Kirkhorn said, and that may have a small impact on Tesla's first-quarter profitabilty. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The company hasn't seen any parts-supply disruptions due to the outbreak but is monitoring the situation, he said. “This is an evolving story.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Musk said demand for the company's angular “Cybertruck” pickup has been high, but gave no numbers. “The demand is just far more than we could reasonably make in the space of three or four years, something like that,” he said.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Tesla also said in its investor letter that it's moving ahead with preparations for a factory near Berlin, and the first deliveries from the factory are expected next year.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Tesla expects net profits going forward, with some possible exceptions at times surrounding the launch of new products.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“We continue to believe our business has grown to the point of being self-funding,” the letter said.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Tesla shares have more than tripled in value since May of last year, pushing the company’s market value above giant German automaker Volkswagen as well as the combined values of General Motors and Ford.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The electric vehicle and solar panel maker's fourth-quarter revenue grew 2% to $7.38 billion as Tesla delivered about 112,000 vehicles during the period and a record 367,500 for the full year. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Tesla continued to build its cash balance during the fourth quarter, reporting $6.27 billion available. That’s up from $5.34 billion at the end of the third quarter.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Wedbush analyst Daniel Ives called Tesla's performance “potentially game changing,” and a sign of what could be a new era for CEO Elon Musk and the company. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“We would characterize the fundamental performance as impressive with clear momentum looking ahead as a global inflection in EV (electric vehicle) demand appears on the horizon,” Ives wrote in a note to investors Wednesday.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">___</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">This story has been updated to correct the per-share fourth-quarter net earnings number. It's 56 cents, not 58 cents. </p>, <p>Advertisement</p>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd" id="site-index-label">Site Index</h2>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-0">news</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-1">opinion</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-2">arts</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-3">living</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-4">more</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-subscribe-label">Subscribe</h3>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd">Site Information Navigation</h2>]
[<p>Advertisement</p>, <p>Supported by</p>, <h1 class="css-fnr6md e1h9rw200" id="link-289b1fa4" itemprop="headline"><span>Name That Rash!</span></h1>, <p class="css-1ifw933 e1wiw3jv0" id="article-summary">What a magical, germ-strewn adventure we are all on.</p>, <p class="css-1fv7b6t e1jsehar1" itemprop="author" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">By<!-- --> <a class="css-brehiz e1jsehar0" href="https://www.nytimes.com/by/jessica-grose"><span class="css-1baulvz last-byline" itemprop="name">Jessica Grose</span></a></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">When my older girl was 18 months old, she became grouchy and listless and had a low-grade fever. A day or two later, she broke out in a bright red rash that inflamed her cheeks. “Fifth disease,” her pediatrician said, milliseconds after she walked into the exam room. I had never heard of it, and at first I thought she said “fist disease,” and I pictured a giant fist kneading my baby’s face, leaving that mass of red.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">But it turns out fifth disease — <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.cdc.gov/parvovirusb19/fifth-disease.html" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">which is caused by parvovirus B19</a> — is just one of many weird rash-causing illnesses that are common in children under 6. The illness is named after a number because decades ago, doctors didn’t know what caused once-common childhood conditions like measles, mumps and rubella, so they referred to them sequentially, said Dr. Nanette Silverberg, M.D., chief of pediatric dermatology for the Mount Sinai Health System. Fifth disease retained the number.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“One of the really challenging things about raising children is they almost always have a virus, and most of the time you don’t even know,” said Dr. Rebecca Pellett Madan, M.D., a pediatric infectious disease specialist at N.Y.U. Langone’s Hassenfeld Children’s Hospital. “You could be the most conscientious parent, but they’re going to get viruses, and they’re often shedding them without having any symptoms.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">What a magical, germ-strewn adventure we are all on.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Because rash-causing illnesses are omnipresent, we created an illustrated guide to five common ones that occur in young children: Scarlet fever, fifth disease, roseola, hand, foot and mouth disease and impetigo. <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://parenting.nytimes.com/childrens-health/child-rash-roseola-fifth-disease" title="">Click here to read the whole thing</a>, and please don’t read it during breakfast because I use the word “crust” in a repeated and foul manner!</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">If you’re concerned that your child has one of these maladies (or any unexplained rash), give your pediatrician a call. And always remember to thoroughly wash hands to prevent the spread of, well, most things.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">P.S. Follow us on Instagram </em><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://nl.nytimes.com/f/a/KbjXDcX6H0j8UEI7pPcixg~~/AAAAAQA~/RgRfwNx_P0TIaHR0cHM6Ly93d3cuaW5zdGFncmFtLmNvbS9ueXRwYXJlbnRpbmcvP3RlPTEmbmw9bnl0LXBhcmVudGluZyZlbWM9ZWRpdF9wdGdfMjAxOTExMjc_Y2FtcGFpZ25faWQ9MTE4Jmluc3RhbmNlX2lkPTE0MTI0JnNlZ21lbnRfaWQ9MTkxMzImdXNlcl9pZD04NWJmMjRhZjE2MTk0YTlkZjgxMGQ3OTZhMzU4NmVlZCZyZWdpX2lkPTg5OTQ5NDMxMjAxOTExMjdXA255dEIKABt_V95d7BxQnFIbbWVsb255Y2UubWNhZmVlQG55dGltZXMuY29tWAQAAAAA" title=""><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">@NYTParenting</em></a><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">. Join </em><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://nl.nytimes.com/f/a/vsa5Ga3bcTyDwVsY509i_w~~/AAAAAQA~/RgRfwNx_P0THaHR0cHM6Ly93d3cuZmFjZWJvb2suY29tL255dHBhcmVudGluZy8_dGU9MSZubD1ueXQtcGFyZW50aW5nJmVtYz1lZGl0X3B0Z18yMDE5MTEyNz9jYW1wYWlnbl9pZD0xMTgmaW5zdGFuY2VfaWQ9MTQxMjQmc2VnbWVudF9pZD0xOTEzMiZ1c2VyX2lkPTg1YmYyNGFmMTYxOTRhOWRmODEwZDc5NmEzNTg2ZWVkJnJlZ2lfaWQ9ODk5NDk0MzEyMDE5MTEyN1cDbnl0QgoAG39X3l3sHFCcUhttZWxvbnljZS5tY2FmZWVAbnl0aW1lcy5jb21YBAAAAAA~" title=""><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">us on Facebook</em></a><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">. Find </em><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://nl.nytimes.com/f/a/swlUZzCVQVD_-CDgazvCtw~~/AAAAAQA~/RgRfwNx_P0TCaHR0cHM6Ly90d2l0dGVyLmNvbS9ueXRwYXJlbnRpbmcvP3RlPTEmbmw9bnl0LXBhcmVudGluZyZlbWM9ZWRpdF9wdGdfMjAxOTExMjc_Y2FtcGFpZ25faWQ9MTE4Jmluc3RhbmNlX2lkPTE0MTI0JnNlZ21lbnRfaWQ9MTkxMzImdXNlcl9pZD04NWJmMjRhZjE2MTk0YTlkZjgxMGQ3OTZhMzU4NmVlZCZyZWdpX2lkPTg5OTQ5NDMxMjAxOTExMjdXA255dEIKABt_V95d7BxQnFIbbWVsb255Y2UubWNhZmVlQG55dGltZXMuY29tWAQAAAAA" title=""><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">us on Twitter</em></a><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0"> for the latest updates. Read last week’s newsletter about </em><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://parenting.nytimes.com/work-money/the-joy-and-pain-of-returning-to-work" title=""><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">the emotional push-pull of being a working parent</em></a><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">.</em></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">P.P.S. We want to hear about your experiences with Early Intervention. Submit your responses below.</em></p>, <h2 class="css-1su19vv interactive-headline" id="interactive-headline">We Want to Hear About Your Experiences with Early Intervention</h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10"><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://parenting.nytimes.com/childrens-health/child-rash-roseola-fifth-disease" title="">Click here for the complete illustrated guide to childhood rashes.</a></strong></p>, <h2 class="css-1320w4z eoo0vm40" id="link-4b9eb3b5">Want More on Children’s Health?</h2>, <p class="css-15hwz5e evys1bk0">In case you missed it, <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://parenting.nytimes.com/childrens-health/coronavirus-children-pregnant-women" title="">here’s what parents and pregnant folks need to know about coronavirus</a>. Check out <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/28/world/asia/china-coronavirus.html" title="">the Times live briefing </a>on the virus for the latest news on the outbreak.</p>, <p class="css-15hwz5e evys1bk0">Jolie Kerr, our resident clean person, has <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://parenting.nytimes.com/childrens-health/cleaning-kids-germs" title="">tips for cleaning your home</a> so that hand, foot and mouth disease doesn’t spread.</p>, <p class="css-15hwz5e evys1bk0">Pinworm is another horrifying childhood plague that I had no idea existed until my kid got it. I called it <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://parenting.nytimes.com/childrens-health/pinworm-infection" title="">“the Human Centipede of childhood maladies.”</a> Find out why.</p>, <h2 class="css-1320w4z eoo0vm40" id="link-32f4a744">Tiny Victories</h2>, <p class="css-jwz2nf etfikam0"><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">Parenting can be a grind. Let’s celebrate the tiny victories.</em></p>, <p class="css-ma92ss evys1bk0">We made up a dance and song called “It’s Coffee Time!” that we use when the grinder is making a bunch of racket in the morning. The grinder used to scare our 14-month-old, but now she shakes it with us, which helps us all wake up before the caffeine can get into my bloodstream.</p>, <p class="css-ma92ss evys1bk0">— Melissa Wade, Mobile, Ala.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">If you want a chance to get your Tiny Victory published, find us on Instagram </em><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.instagram.com/nytparenting/" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title=""><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">@NYTparenting</em></a><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0"> and use the hashtag #tinyvictories; </em><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="mailto:parenting_submissions@nytimes.com?subject=Tiny%20Victories" title=""><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">email us</em></a><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">; or </em><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2019/09/24/parenting/tiny-victories.html" title=""><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">enter your Tiny Victory at the bottom of this page</em></a><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">. Include your full name and location. Tiny Victories may be edited for clarity and style.</em> <em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">Your name, location and comments may be published, but your contact information will not. By submitting to us, you agree that you have read, understand and accept the </em><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://nyti.ms/2Q9M7i0" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title=""><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">Reader Submission Terms</em></a><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0"> in relation to all of the content and other information you send to us.</em></p>, <p>Advertisement</p>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd" id="site-index-label">Site Index</h2>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-0">news</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-1">opinion</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-2">arts</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-3">living</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-4">more</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-subscribe-label">Subscribe</h3>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd">Site Information Navigation</h2>]
[<p>Advertisement</p>, <p>Supported by</p>, <p class="css-c2jxua e6idgb70"></p>, <h1 class="css-1j5ig2m e1h9rw200" id="link-7405ca96" itemprop="headline"><span>Russian Federation at Risk of Expulsion Over Doping Offences</span></h1>, <p class="css-1fv7b6t e1jsehar1" itemprop="author" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">By<!-- --> <span class="css-1baulvz last-byline" itemprop="name">Reuters</span></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">(Reuters) - The Athletics Integrity Unit Board on Wednesday called for the expulsion of Russia's suspended athletics federation (RUSAF) after what it described as a "total lack of contrition" in its response to a long list of anti-doping violations.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The AIU's recommendation, made to the council of World Athletics, comes after it assessed the explanations provided by the federation regarding its leadership's involvement in serious breaches of anti-doping rules. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Russia's athletics federation was initially suspended in 2015 after a report commissioned by the World Anti-Doping Agency (WADA) found evidence of mass doping in the sport and had since been trudging toward reinstatement.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">But in November last year, World Athletics, the global governing body of athletics formerly known as the IAAF, halted Russia's reinstatement process and raised the prospect of expelling the federation altogether over doping violations by its president and several of its representatives. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The AIU, the independent unit set up by the sport's governing body in 2017 to manage integrity issues, had provisionally suspended Dmitry Shlyakhtin, the Russian federation's president, and six other people for having provided forged documents to justify a whereabouts violation by high jumper Danil Lysenko.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">In a strong statement on Wednesday, the AIU said the federation had not put "forward any material or evidence that it contends answers the AIU's case against it", despite having been granted three extensions to provide its explanations. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">It said the federation had instead denied its involvement and blamed others.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">"The AIU Board finds it regrettable that, in the face of clear and compelling evidence, RUSAF has chosen not to admit to the acts and omissions of the employees, directors and representatives..." the AIU said in a statement. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">"A responsible member federation in the circumstances would have admitted the charges and shown contrition for its conduct, but RUSAF has chosen to do neither."</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The AIU recommended that World Athletics expel and fine the federation as part of "severest possible consequences" if its the anti-doping breaches are upheld. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">"EXTREMELY SERIOUS"</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Following the AIU's recommendations on Wednesday, World Athletics said the charges brought against the Russian athletics federation were "extremely serious" and that it would review them in the coming days.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">It also suggested that Russia could possibly avoid expulsion if its officials came clean and admitted their involvement in the scandal. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">World Athletics said it would start by sending a letter to the federation's acting president and Oleg Matytsin, Russia's next sports minister, to lay out the country's options before the dispute gets to the Court of Arbitration for Sport (CAS).</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">It said that if federation officials admit the AIU charges, the World Athletics council will decide on the sanctions to impose against the federation, but these would not include expulsion at that stage. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">It will also decide on a new process to clear Russians to compete internationally, World Athletics said. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The AIU last year halted the process used since 2016 to clear some Russian track and field athletes to compete internationally as neutrals, including three-times world high jump champion Maria Lasitskene. It said on Wednesday that the process would remain suspended until the charges against the federation were determined. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">This means that Russia's top track and field athletes are likely to miss the 2020 winter season, that will not include the world indoor championships. The event, which had been scheduled to take place in March in Nanjing, China, has been postponed to 2021 over fears related to the outbreak of the coronavirus in the country. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">But if Russia's federation officials continue to deny involvement, World Athletics said it will "put all necessary resource into presenting the charges to the CAS".</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Russia's athletics federation had no immediate comment. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">In a jab at the federation, world champion pole vaulter Anzhelika Sidorova tagged it in an Instagram story and wrote "good job", accompanied by three flexed biceps emojis.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Russia is also in the process of appealing a four-year ban from competing under its flag at major international sporting events, including this year's Tokyo Olympics, after WADA found Moscow had provided it with doctored laboratory data. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"> (Reporting by Gabrielle Tétrault-Farber in Moscow and Hardik Vyas in Bengaluru, editing by Pritha Sarkar and Ed Osmond)</p>, <p>Advertisement</p>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd" id="site-index-label">Site Index</h2>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-0">news</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-1">opinion</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-2">arts</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-3">living</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-4">more</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-subscribe-label">Subscribe</h3>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd">Site Information Navigation</h2>]
[<p>Advertisement</p>, <p>Supported by</p>, <p class="css-c2jxua e6idgb70"></p>, <h1 class="css-1j5ig2m e1h9rw200" id="link-62d0cb" itemprop="headline"><span>Chinese Farmers, Supermarkets Race to Supply Food to Locked Down Wuhan</span></h1>, <p class="css-1fv7b6t e1jsehar1" itemprop="author" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">By<!-- --> <span class="css-1baulvz last-byline" itemprop="name">Reuters</span></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">BEIJING — China has told farmers to step up vegetable production, opened roads for delivery trucks and is punishing those trying to profit in order to keep feeding residents of the locked down city of Wuhan at the centre of the new coronavirus outbreak.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Authorities cut most transport links to the central Chinese city last week to try to halt the spread of the flu-like virus. Thousands of cases have been reported in China, with a small number in countries including the United States, Thailand and Singapore.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The unprecedented move prompted people in the city of 11 million to rush to supermarkets to stock up on instant noodles, vegetables and whatever else they could put their hands on.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Residents say there has yet to be an acute shortage of food, although shelves are cleared quickly when goods arrive.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Shouguang, the country's biggest vegetable production base, in the eastern Shandong province, has been asked to deliver 600 tons of fresh vegetables to Wuhan every day in the next 10 to 15 days, said an official in Sunjiaji, one of Shouguang's villages. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Sunjiaji, whose main crop is cucumbers, was tasked with sending 60 tons in less than seven hours.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">"We got the order from our city government at 11 p.m. on Monday and we immediately contacted our farmers, asking them to pick cucumbers overnight and bring their harvest to us before 6 a.m.," the official, who only gave her surname, Li, told Reuters by phone. "We sent 70 tons in the end," she said. "We are waiting for the next order."</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">China's largest food and agricultural firm COFCO Group and China Grain Reserves Corporation (Sinograin) Group have stepped up supplies of rice, meat and cooking oil to Hubei province, state media reported on Wednesday. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The Ministry of Agriculture and Rural Affairs issued a notice on Thursday, urging related departments to coordinate to maintain ample supplies of vegetables and stable prices. Other areas like Xinjiang are also sending supplies. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Delivery trucks carrying food are exempt from travel restrictions if they have government permits. Authorities have cracked down on cases of price hikes and publicized them to warn others.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">On Tuesday, a supermarket in Zhengzhou in Henan Province was fined 500,000 yuan ($72,421) for selling Chinese cabbage at 63 yuan, instead of the usual 17 yuan, according to local media.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">"The green channel into Wuhan is smooth," said Chinese Premier Li Keqiang during a visit to the city this week.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">STILL TOUGH</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Others in Wuhan said it was far from smooth. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Worries over how long the city's quarantine might last are spurring many to stockpile, a Wuhan resident said. People across China have been told to stay away from public areas to lower the risk of infection and many stay indoors. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">"In the morning there are vegetables in supermarkets but the shelves are cleared quickly as a lot of people buy large amounts," she said, describing stores as "war zones". "You buy whatever's left on the shelf because that will be gone too."</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Wushang Group, the largest local supermarket in Wuhan with nearly 30 stores, said its biggest challenge was a lack of staff and almost all company employees had become delivery personnel, opting to use their private cars to transport goods.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Their cars are sometimes stopped by police due to the travel restrictions, but are usually let go if they explain that they are transporting supplies, said a company official who would only give her surname as Gan.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">"On the night of Jan. 25, 400 tons of vegetables arrived in Wuhan from Chongqing and we were given 120 tons," she said. About a hundred Wushang employees volunteered to unload and transport the goods, she said. "On average every person unloaded more than a ton of vegetables that night." </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The lack of staff and delivery services is plaguing other parts of the food supply chain in Hubei province, of which Wuhan is the capital, others said. A number of smaller cities in Hubei have also been locked down due to the outbreak. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Wuhan's largest wholesale grocery outlet, the Baishazhou Agricultural Products Market, supplies supermarkets and big restaurants in neighbouring cities in Hubei province, such as Huangshi and Jiujiang, but is seeing fewer customers due to the restrictions. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">"We have plenty of vegetables," said Yuan, an employee in the market's vegetable department. "But a lot are going rotten."</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"> (Reporting by Sophie Yu and Brenda Goh; Additional reporting by Chen Aizhu in Singapore; Editing by Janet Lawrence)</p>, <p>Advertisement</p>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd" id="site-index-label">Site Index</h2>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-0">news</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-1">opinion</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-2">arts</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-3">living</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-4">more</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-subscribe-label">Subscribe</h3>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd">Site Information Navigation</h2>]
