appearance (layered clothing and disheveled hair, for instance), behavior (sleeping on the ground), and condition (refers to a vehicle, perhaps with its windows covered).</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Around me, dozens of volunteers listened, just closely enough to get the idea.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">It was Thursday night, in the basement of Echo Park United Methodist Church, and we were waiting to go out, clipboards in hand, to help perform <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.lahsa.org/news?article=648-city-and-county-leaders-kickoff-annual-homeless-count&amp;ref=hc" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">the annual count of Los Angeles’s homeless</a> population.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Last week, similar point-in-time counts of homeless populations took place around the state.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Like <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/16/us/california-congressional-seat-census.html" title="">the census</a>, the counts are <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.latimes.com/california/story/2020-01-21/homeless-count-los-angeles-county-faq" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">federally mandated and imperfect</a>, and <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2019/06/05/us/los-angeles-homeless-population.html" title="">the results</a> help determine how and where money flows.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Gov. Gavin Newsom participated in the count in San Diego, where he lauded volunteers for “stepping up and being part of the solution.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">This year, the counts took place against the backdrop of a housing emergency that has reshaped life across the Golden State and dominated the attention of policymakers at every level.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">In the Echo Park neighborhood of L.A., near where I live, tensions had been rising over an encampment in a grassy clearing on the northern edge of Echo Park Lake. Though city officials have said the area needs to be cleaned, residents and activists have said <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://la.curbed.com/2020/1/24/21080449/homeless-camp-echo-park-lake" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">unpredictable sweeps and citations</a> are really meant to push the unhoused out of a public space.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Some of the volunteers said they were planning to join residents of the encampment in a protest the next morning. The count, they said, was an important way of ensuring officials confront the full scope of homelessness in their communities.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">More broadly, volunteers told me it was the magnitude of the crisis they saw every day that moved them to spend four hours of their evenings looking for people sleeping in alleys or doorways and counting tents.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Ceraun Loggins, 29, told me they moved from Washington, D.C., in April. They bike to work, and seeing the number of people living on the streets, they said, “was a punch to the gut.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Joining the count seemed like a simple way to help.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“It’s like one of these invisible mechanisms,” they said. “You don’t think about how it has to happen.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">After the short video, there was a mildly chaotic shuffle as the volunteers broke into groups of two to four. Each team was assigned a census tract. Some were walkable. Some, tucked higher into the hills, required a car.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The Los Angeles Homeless Services Authority gathers more specific demographic information about who is experiencing homelessness in <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.lahsa.org/documents?id=3461-2019-homeless-count-demographic-survey.pdf" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">a separate survey</a>.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">This time, though, we were told to count visually — not to engage.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">I tagged along with a group of four, all in our 20s or 30s. We walked to our narrow rectangle tract, which was lined by quiet apartment buildings set back above the street.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">We saw a woman rifle through a trash can before continuing down the sidewalk. She nodded at us and said something quietly as she passed. We nodded back but didn’t ask where she was headed.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">A member of our group, Chloe English, 29, made a mark on the form.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“Well, we got a grand total of one,” she said at the end of our route. She paused. “It’s a nice thing we only encountered one.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Of course, in another tract, that most likely would have been different.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Still, I was struck by how the task felt mundane, and enormous at the same time: There aren’t people living in their cars or sleeping outside on every block in L.A. County. But someone has to check every block to know.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">On Sunday morning, I visited the encampment by the lake at the center of the protest. Residents sat outside their tents and chatted.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">I asked Jasmine Martinez, a 33-year-old Angeleno who said she’s lived in the camp for about four months, whether she’d heard anything about the point-in-time count. She hadn’t.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Ms. Martinez said she had been spending her time struggling to navigate the <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2020/01/28/upshot/administrative-burden-quiz.html" title="">labyrinth of services</a> available to people experiencing homelessness. She was seeking therapy and trying to access housing vouchers.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">In the meantime, she said, she felt safe in the park — safer than she did on Skid Row or in shelters.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“Here, we have a family,” she said. “A lot of us are growing up on our own.”</p>, <h2 class="css-3ez4hu eoo0vm40" id="link-42fcec18">Here’s what else we’re following</h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">We often link to sites that limit access for nonsubscribers. We appreciate your reading Times coverage, but we also encourage you to support local news if you can.</em></p>, <p class="css-15hwz5e evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">San Francisco’s public works director, Mohammed Nuru, has been accused of bribery and corruption</strong> in a number of alleged schemes, including one in which federal authorities say he steered contracts for bathroom trailers and shelters for the homeless to an associate. [<a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://missionlocal.org/2020/01/mohammed-nuru-director-of-san-francisco-public-works-arrested-by-fbi/" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">Mission Local</a>]</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">Also, Mr. Nuru was called “Mr. Clean,” a man whom four San Francisco mayors, including London Breed, could rely on to clean up messes quickly and without question. But there were bright red flags over the decades. [</em><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.sfchronicle.com/local-politics/article/SF-official-arrested-by-FBI-was-go-to-guy-for-15011155.php" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title=""><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">The San Francisco Chronicle</em></a><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">]</em></p>, <p class="css-15hwz5e evys1bk0">A 13-year-old fan took<strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10"> a blurry selfie with Kobe Bryant at the Mamba Sports Academy</strong> on Saturday afternoon. It may have been the last picture taken of one of the world’s most famous athletes. [<a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/28/us/mamba-sports-academy.html" title="">The New York Times</a>]</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">Here are the latest updates on the investigation into the crash. [</em><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/29/sports/basketball/kobe-bryant-death.html" title=""><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">The New York Times]</em></a></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">And here’s a look at how brands are navigating uncharted territory in marking his death. [</em><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/28/business/media/kobe-endorsement-deals.html" title=""><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">The New York Times</em></a><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">]</em></p>, <p class="css-15hwz5e evys1bk0">A chartered plane <strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">leaving the center of China’s coronavirus outbreak was expected to land at March Air Reserve Base in Riverside County</strong>,<strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10"> on Wednesday.</strong> The plane’s 200 passengers include State Department officials and other Americans living in Wuhan, officials said. [<a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/29/world/asia/coronavirus-china.html?" title="">The New York Times</a>]</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">Also, here’s what travelers need to know. [</em><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/26/travel/Coronavirus-travel.html?action=click&amp;module=MoreIn&amp;pgtype=Article&amp;region=Footer&amp;action=click&amp;module=MoreInSection&amp;pgtype=Article&amp;region=Footer&amp;contentCollection=Update" title=""><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">The New York Times</em></a><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">]</em></p>, <p class="css-15hwz5e evys1bk0">After almost three years without a contract, <strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">the bargaining team for about 17,000 health care workers reached a tentative deal with the University of California</strong>, ending one of the institution’s longest-running labor disputes. [<a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.mercedsunstar.com/news/california/article239731733.html" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">The Sacramento Bee</a>]</p>, <p class="css-15hwz5e evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Apple’s profit grew for the first time in a year</strong> with the help of an old friend: the iPhone. [<a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/28/technology/apple-iphone-sales-earnings.html" title="">The New York Times</a>]</p>, <p class="css-15hwz5e evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">A stretch of San Francisco’s Market Street </strong>is set to officially go car-free starting this morning. Here are the answers to seven questions about the change. [<a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://abc7news.com/5874598/" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">ABC7</a>]</p>, <h2 class="css-3ez4hu eoo0vm40" id="link-5fc1af22">Reading fashion </h2>, <p class="css-15hwz5e evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">The Los Angeles-raised pop star Billie Eilish is a style icon.</strong> Here’s what her look signals about Gen Z and shifting femininity. [<a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/28/fashion/Gen-Z-pop-music-billie-eilish-gen-zs-outrageous-fashion-role-model.html" title="">The New York Times</a>]</p>, <p class="css-15hwz5e evys1bk0">Thinking about watching <strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Gwyneth Paltrow’s new Goop Netflix show</strong>? Depending on how you feel about what is essentially soulful sponcon, you might like it. You also might not. At all. [<a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.newyorker.com/magazine/2020/02/03/the-magical-thinking-of-the-goop-lab" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">The New Yorker</a>]</p>, <p class="css-15hwz5e evys1bk0">If you missed it, here’s how an <strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">artist born in New Zealand combined Patagonia vests and Margaret Thatcher to create a visual treatise on inequality</strong> and global capitalism now on display in a San Francisco gallery. [<a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/14/style/Patagonia-vest-margaret-thatcher-art.html" title="">The New York Times</a>]</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">California Today goes live at 6:30 a.m. Pacific time weekdays. Were you forwarded this email? </em><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/newsletters/california-today?module=inline" title=""><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">Sign up for California Today here.</em></a></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">Jill Cowan grew up in Orange County, graduated from U.C. Berkeley and has reported all over the state, including the Bay Area, Bakersfield and Los Angeles — but she always wants to see more. Follow along here or on Twitter, </em><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://twitter.com/JillCowan" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title=""><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">@jillcowan</em></a><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">.</em></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">California Today is edited by Julie Bloom, who grew up in Los Angeles and graduated from U.C. Berkeley.</em></p>, <p>Advertisement</p>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd" id="site-index-label">Site Index</h2>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-0">news</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-1">opinion</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-2">arts</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-3">living</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-4">more</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-subscribe-label">Subscribe</h3>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd">Site Information Navigation</h2>]
[<p>Advertisement</p>, <p>Supported by</p>, <h1 class="css-1qskr30 e1h9rw200" id="link-31e7164a" itemprop="headline"><span>Is the World Ready for the Coronavirus?</span></h1>, <p class="css-1ifw933 e1wiw3jv0" id="article-summary">Distrust in science and institutions could be a major problem if the outbreak worsens.</p>, <p class="css-1fv7b6t e1jsehar1" itemprop="author" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">By<!-- --> <a class="css-brehiz e1jsehar0" href="https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/opinion/editorialboard.html"><span class="css-1baulvz last-byline" itemprop="name">The Editorial Board</span></a></p>, <p class="css-cpkn1d e1wtpvyy1">The editorial board is a group of opinion journalists whose views are informed by expertise, research, debate and certain longstanding<strong class="css-1mg4ay8"> </strong><a class="css-13m58p7" href="https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2018/opinion/editorialboard.html" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">values</a>. It is separate from the newsroom.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/index.html" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">coronavirus outbreak</a>, which began in early December in the Chinese city of Wuhan, had as of Wednesday sickened more than 6,000 people across at least 15 countries and claimed more than 130 lives, all of them in China. Experts don’t yet know how contagious, or how deadly, this new virus is. But the growing crisis has inspired panic. Cities around the world are bracing for a potential wave of infections. Stock and oil prices are tumbling. And experts in just about every global industry are fretting over the many supply chains that could be disrupted — from prescription drugs and surgical masks to rare earth metals — if the outbreak grows into an even wider epidemic.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Given the scope of these anxieties, it’s a wonder more hasn’t been done to prepare for an outbreak like this one. The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention have long warned that the rate at which new pathogens emerge is increasing (partly as a result of global warming). The agency identifies new ones every year, and disease outbreaks — especially those involving viruses that leap from animals to humans, as the coronavirus did — are hardly surprising.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">China, the center of the current outbreak, appears to have learned at least some lessons from the last such crisis it confronted. In 2002, when SARS first emerged, the country’s leaders waited roughly three months before notifying the World Health Organization. By then, the virus was on its way to reaching more than a dozen countries. (SARS is also caused by a coronavirus, variants of which are fairly common around the world but rarely affect humans. When they do, they generally cause upper-respiratory infections.)</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Chinese officials appear to have moved much faster this time around. They alerted the W.H.O. within a month of detecting the first coronavirus cases and moved quickly to sequence the new virus and to contain it: Some <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/27/opinion/china-wuhan-virus-quarantine.html" title="">56 million people</a>, including the entire city of Wuhan, have been placed under quarantine.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">But global health experts say that over all, the country’s response still leaves much to be desired. Officials appear to have withheld <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.thelancet.com/journals/lancet/article/PIIS0140-6736(20)30154-9/fulltext" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">crucial information</a> — including that the virus was spreading between humans and that cases were not confined to the elderly or to people who visited the market believed to be at the outbreak’s epicenter — for weeks. They have also <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.politico.com/news/2020/01/29/officials-praise-china-transparency-virus-108926" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">rebuffed</a> initial offers of help from the C.D.C. and failed to share samples of the virus with the scientific community.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Global health experts are already cautioning other countries to prepare for China’s containment efforts to fail. Part of the problem is that a quarantine of this size is <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/27/opinion/china-wuhan-virus-quarantine.html" title="">inherently difficult</a> to maintain. Another major issue is a lack of public trust: Control measures work only if people abide by them. And people are much less likely to follow orders when they don’t trust that the authorities issuing them have their best interests at heart. In Wuhan and elsewhere in China, trust in officials is <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/21/world/asia/china-coronavirus-wuhan.html" title="">running low</a>, as some citizens <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/27/technology/china-coronavirus-censorship-social-media.html" title="">suspect</a> that the government is more concerned with containing bad press than with defeating the virus.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">In fact, trust may prove at least as important as technology and financial resources in keeping the coronavirus outbreak at bay — as global health workers learned during <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2019/06/19/opinion/ebola-epidemic-congo.html" title="">recent Ebola outbreaks</a> in the Democratic Republic of Congo.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">American officials ought to keep that hard-learned lesson in mind. President Trump said after the first case of coronavirus was confirmed in the United States that the outbreak is “totally under control.” (Since then, such cases have been confirmed in <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/cases-in-us.html" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">at least five people in four states</a>.) One would like to believe the president’s pronouncements. But Mr. Trump has a history of obscuring facts — especially scientific ones — to <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2019/09/06/us/politics/trump-alabama-dorian.html" title="">score political points</a>. Scientists and the public are right to worry about the potential consequences of such duplicity. What happens if people stop trusting the institutions meant to protect them from natural disasters, faulty medical products or disease outbreaks? If the coronavirus proves especially contagious or deadly, that question will no longer be hypothetical.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Nor will the consequences of an “America First” worldview that <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://newrepublic.com/article/153264/rise-right-wing-nationalism-jeopardizing-world-health" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">treats global health security as unnecessary</a>. In only three years, the Trump administration has <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.washingtonpost.com/opinions/the-coronavirus-has-landed-in-the-us-heres-how-we-can-reduce-the-risk/2020/01/22/afebe9ee-3d53-11ea-baca-eb7ace0a3455_story.html" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">eliminated</a> the office of pandemic response, created after the Ebola epidemic of 2014; drastically scaled back the C.D.C.’s overseas <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2018/03/13/us/politics/trump-ebola-disease-cuts-global-health-security-agenda.html" title="">outbreak prevention efforts</a>, from 49 countries to just 10; and discontinued a <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2019/10/25/health/predict-usaid-viruses.html" title="">surveillance program</a> meant to detect new viral threats, like the coronavirus, before they make the leap into humans.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">To its credit, the administration has managed to keep some of the world’s leading infectious disease experts in key roles at top agencies, including the C.D.C., the National Institutes of Health and the Food and Drug Administration. If those professionals are given the resources and authority to respond to the crisis as their experience and the science dictate — if they are empowered to develop vaccines, deploy experts and collaborate with response teams in affected regions — the worst-case scenarios may yet be averted.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">One hopes that will be the case. If so, the United States and the rest of the world will do well to learn from this experience. It will almost certainly not be the last time the world faces such a crisis.</p>, <p class="css-jwz2nf etfikam0"><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">The Times is committed to publishing </em><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2019/01/31/opinion/letters/letters-to-editor-new-york-times-women.html" title=""><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">a diversity of letters</em></a><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0"> to the editor. We’d like to hear what you think about this or any of our articles. Here are some </em><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://help.nytimes.com/hc/en-us/articles/115014925288-How-to-submit-a-letter-to-the-editor" title=""><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">tips</em></a><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">. And here’s our email: </em><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="mailto:letters@nytimes.com" title=""><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">letters@nytimes.com</em></a><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">.</em></p>, <p class="css-jwz2nf etfikam0"><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">Follow The New York Times Opinion section on </em><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.facebook.com/nytopinion" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title=""><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">Facebook</em></a><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">, </em><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="http://twitter.com/NYTOpinion" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title=""><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">Twitter (@NYTopinion)</em></a><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0"> and </em><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.instagram.com/nytopinion/" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title=""><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">Instagram</em></a><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">.</em></p>, <p>Advertisement</p>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd" id="site-index-label">Site Index</h2>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-0">news</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-1">opinion</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-2">arts</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-3">living</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-4">more</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-subscribe-label">Subscribe</h3>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd">Site Information Navigation</h2>]
[<p>Advertisement</p>, <p>Supported by</p>, <h1 class="css-1qskr30 e1h9rw200" id="link-1a972b9" itemprop="headline"><span>To Understand the Wuhan Coronavirus, Look to the Epidemic Triangle</span></h1>, <p class="css-1ifw933 e1wiw3jv0" id="article-summary">We must determine whether the outbreak will turn into a global epidemic.</p>, <p class="css-1fv7b6t e1jsehar1" itemprop="author" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">By<!-- --> <span class="css-1baulvz last-byline" itemprop="name">Dan Werb</span></p>, <p class="css-cpkn1d e1wtpvyy1">Dr. Werb is the author of “City of Omens: A Search for the Missing Women of the Borderlands.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/27/world/asia/china-coronavirus.html#link-13b39ff9" title="">Five cases</a> of the mysterious Wuhan coronavirus have been confirmed in the United States, giving rise to concerns about a potential global pandemic. We’ve seen this story before, as health authorities working with threadbare data try to walk the line between epidemic readiness and needless panic. Is this new outbreak poised to become the next AIDS pandemic or a new SARS, which was stopped in its tracks after 774 deaths? To cut through the headlines, we can use a simple concept called the “epidemic triangle.” Employed by epidemiologists since the discipline’s earliest days, it is indispensable in predicting whether localized outbreaks will transform into full-blown epidemics.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The epidemic triangle is essentially an equation. It posits that every outbreak, regardless of its specific traits, is dependent on the interplay between three factors: the pathogen (the agent causing infection), the host (the organism at risk of infection) and the environment (the setting where the infections occur). Every single epidemic — be it the flu, cholera or even behavioral epidemics like drunken driving — is the result of a dynamic shift in one of these points of the epidemic triangle, which then causes a domino effect leading to a sudden explosion of new cases.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">In one classic example of this phenomenon, we have an environmental shift to thank for the emergence of the global flu pandemic. In the mid-16th century, ducks were introduced to Chinese rice paddies to feed on the insects that were destroying crops. That meant ducks joined another common feature of Chinese farms: pigs. The duck’s unique biology makes it a generous reservoir for a vast number of viruses, while pigs are uncannily efficient at mixing different viruses together into new strains and passing them to humans. Breeding these two animals in proximity quickly led to the combination and transmission of new viral strains. Novel and highly virulent pathogens — hybrid pig-duck influenza strains — then crossed the species barrier and have been tormenting humanity ever since.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The family of coronaviruses (so-called because they resemble glowing crowns) that includes the new Wuhan strain are exceptionally challenging to control. Coronaviruses are responsible for the common cold, pneumonia and bronchitis, but the coronavirus family is sprawling and includes deadlier outliers like Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome and Middle East Respiratory Syndrome (MERS), which have fatality rates of up to 15 percent and 35 percent, respectively. The big question, then, is whether the Wuhan coronavirus is closer to the common cold or to SARS. While its case fatality rate is unknown, as of Wednesday there were more 6,000 confirmed cases worldwide (with about 80 outside of mainland China) and at least 130 people dead. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Last week, the World Health Organization convened a special committee to decide whether to declare a global health emergency. Ultimately, after two days of deliberation, the group decided not to take this major step, though the W.H.O.’s director general, Dr. Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus, noted ominously that “it may yet become one.” That time may have come: Today, the W.H.O. committee <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nasdaq.com/articles/who-panel-to-reconvene-on-thursday-to-decide-if-virus-global-emergency-2020-01-29" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">will convene again</a> to determine if the outbreak has crossed a threshold into warranting a designation of a global emergency. As it considers how to proceed, the W.H.O. committee is grappling with a monumental choice — global health emergencies are legally binding announcements requiring every United Nations member state to take action — with scant data.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">I don’t doubt that the epidemic triangle is critical in helping W.H.O. navigate this process. Is this outbreak because of a substantive shift in the genetic makeup of an old pathogen, a change in the vulnerability of the host population or an alteration of the environment that has shaped the threat emanating from Wuhan? As the Wuhan outbreak continues to expand, applying the calculus of the epidemic triangle remains the most reliable way to chart an effective public health response while avoiding a descent into hysteria.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">First, we need to know how much of a shift this new pathogen is from previous coronavirus strains, based on its infective potential and virulence. Judging from the rapid rise in cases since the first cluster was reported on Dec. 31, the new Wuhan strain could very well be highly infective. For perspective, SARS has a relatively low basic reproductive ratio (or R0) of 0.5, meaning that every two cases of SARS results in only one additional infection. <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.who.int/news-room/detail/23-01-2020-statement-on-the-meeting-of-the-international-health-regulations-(2005)-emergency-committee-regarding-the-outbreak-of-novel-coronavirus-(2019-ncov)" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">Very early estimates</a> shared by the W.H.O. suggest the Wuhan strain’s R0 is 1.4 to 2.5, producing roughly two secondary cases for each initial infection, which places it slightly higher than the seasonal flu (for perspective, measles has a R0 of 12 to 18).</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">If the new coronavirus’s R0 remains low as more data become available, we can be relatively confident that surveillance and quarantine will stem its spread, though these measures become steadily less effective as the R0 increases. With respect to its virulence, early genomic sequencing of the Wuhan virus suggests, thankfully, that it is only distantly related to SARS (they are only 73 percent identical), meaning that it is likely to be less deadly, though it is too early to say with confidence.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Second, we have to ask how this outbreak might be explained by a shift in the vulnerability of its host (human beings). What scientists will be looking for here is an indication that those who have died are older or immune-compromised, consistent with the fatalities we see from other common coronavirus infections.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">That leaves the environment, the last point of the epidemic triangle — and this is where things get complicated. As China’s economy has expanded, the number of Chinese citizens taking to the skies has risen astronomically. Much has been made about this week’s Lunar New Year celebration, and rightly so: it is the world’s largest human migration, with as many as three billion planned trips by car, train and plane within China over a two-week period. The challenges of quarantining during this migration are staggering, though China is better equipped than most countries to carry out draconian public health measures, and has demonstrated its resolve by imposing a lockdown on travel for — at last count — more than 50 million of its citizens.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Where the environment has truly shifted, though, is in China’s connections to the rest of the world. In 2005, two years after the first SARS outbreak, there were only 233 international air routes from mainland China. By 2016, international routes had more than tripled to 739, meaning there were far more routes for the virus to take out of the country. During the same period, the number of international air passengers traveling in and out of China exploded from around three million to over 51 million. In short, China’s increasingly outward-facing stance has greatly expanded the environment within which the Wuhan coronavirus can propagate. This, among all three of the points of the epidemic triangle, makes predicting the scope of the current outbreak exceedingly complex.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">As we face new epidemic threats, no matter what their origin, we can rely on one constant: Each will ultimately be explained by the interaction of the three points of the epidemic triangle. In the case of the Wuhan coronavirus, what should trouble us the most is the rapid expansion of the environment across which the pathogen can infect its hosts, which maps neatly over China’s emergence as a global superpower. It remains to be seen whether the scale of this change is enough to transform it from a SARS-like scare — a blip in epidemic history — and into the next Spanish flu.</p>, <p class="css-jwz2nf etfikam0">Dan Werb is the author of “<a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.bloomsbury.com/us/city-of-omens-9781635572995/" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">City of Omens: A Search for the Missing Women of the Borderlands</a>,” an assistant professor in the division of infectious diseases and global public health at the University of California, San Diego, and the director of the Center on<a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://cdpe.org/" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title=""> Drug Policy Evaluation</a>.</p>, <p class="css-jwz2nf etfikam0"><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">The Times is committed to publishing </em><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2019/01/31/opinion/letters/letters-to-editor-new-york-times-women.html" title=""><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">a diversity of letters</em></a><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0"> to the editor. We’d like to hear what you think about this or any of our articles. Here are some </em><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://help.nytimes.com/hc/en-us/articles/115014925288-How-to-submit-a-letter-to-the-editor" title=""><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">tips</em></a><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">. And here’s our email: </em><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="mailto:letters@nytimes.com" title=""><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">letters@nytimes.com</em></a><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">.</em></p>, <p class="css-jwz2nf etfikam0"><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">Follow The New York Times Opinion section on </em><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.facebook.com/nytopinion" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title=""><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">Facebook</em></a><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">, </em><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="http://twitter.com/NYTOpinion" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title=""><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">Twitter (@NYTopinion)</em></a><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0"> and </em><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.instagram.com/nytopinion/" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title=""><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">Instagram</em></a><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">.</em></p>, <p>Advertisement</p>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd" id="site-index-label">Site Index</h2>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-0">news</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-1">opinion</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-2">arts</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-3">living</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-4">more</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-subscribe-label">Subscribe</h3>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd">Site Information Navigation</h2>]

</h2>, <h1 class="story-heading interactive-headline" itemprop="headline">Weekly Health Quiz: Optimism, Muscles and Coronavirus</h1>, <p class="byline-dateline">
<span class="byline last-byline" itemprop="author creator" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
      By <span class="byline-author" data-byline-name="TOBY BILANOW" itemprop="name">TOBY BILANOW</span>
</span>
<time class="dateline" content="2020-01-30" datetime="2020-01-30" itemprop="dateModified">JAN. 30, 2020</time>
</p>, <p class="interactive-leadin summary">
</p>, <p>Having an optimistic outlook has been tied to which of the following health benefits?</p>, <p>A lower risk of having a heart attack</p>, <p>A higher likelihood of engaging in healthy behaviors</p>, <p>A greater chance of living to age 85 and beyond</p>, <p>All of the above</p>, <p>The life expectancy of Americans ticked up for the first time in four years, in part because of fewer overdose and cancer deaths. The average life expectancy is now:</p>, <p>72.4 years</p>, <p>75.9 years</p>, <p>78.7 years</p>, <p>81.2 years</p>, <p>Middle-aged men who kept their muscles fit were at much lower risk of this ailment in old age:</p>, <p>Prostate cancer</p>, <p>Alzheimer's disease</p>, <p>Heart disease</p>, <p>All of the above</p>, <p>Japanese men and women who ate the most fermented soy products had lower rates of heart disease and tended to live longer than those who ate the least. All of the following are fermented soy products <i>except</i>:</p>, <p>Miso</p>, <p>Natto</p>, <p>Tofu</p>, <p>Tempeh</p>, <p>These animals were identified as the likely source of the coronavirus outbreak that started in China:</p>, <p>Civet cats</p>, <p>Bats</p>, <p>Carp</p>, <p>Ducks</p>, <p>True or false? China has now had more cases of coronavirus than it did of SARS.</p>, <p>True</p>, <p>False</p>, <p>The most practical and effective way to prevent coronavirus infection may be to:</p>, <p>Wear a face mask</p>, <p>Wash your hands frequently</p>, <p>Get vaccinated against coronavirus </p>, <p>All of the above</p>, <h2 class="section-heading"></h2>, <h2 class="story-heading">Weekly Health Quiz: Sperm, Falling Fauna and a New Virus</h2>, <h2 class="story-heading">Weekly Health Quiz: Running, Body Temperature and a Deadly New Virus</h2>, <p>Advertisement</p>, <h2 class="visually-hidden">Site Information Navigation</h2>, <h2 class="visually-hidden">Site Information Navigation</h2>]
[<p>Advertisement</p>, <p>Supported by</p>, <p class="css-tsacue e6idgb70">New York Today</p>, <h1 class="css-fnr6md e1h9rw200" id="link-56b454a6" itemprop="headline"><span>Coronavirus, a Fire and Anxiety in the Chinese Community</span></h1>, <p class="css-1fv7b6t e1jsehar1" itemprop="author" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">By<!-- --> <span class="css-1baulvz last-byline" itemprop="name">Andrea Salcedo</span></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0"> [Want to get New York Today by email? </em><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/newsletters/newyorktoday" title=""><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">Here’s the sign-up</em></a><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">.]</em></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">It’s Thursday.</strong> </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Weather: </strong>Mostly sunny, with a high in the mid-30s.<span class="css-8l6xbc evw5hdy0"> </span></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Alternate-side parking</strong>: In effect until Feb. 12 (Lincoln’s Birthday).</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The Lunar New Year is a 15-day celebration in the Asian community, marked by reunions with family and friends, feasts, parades and more.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">But in New York, the celebrations have taken on a muted feel.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The city’s Asian community is anxious over the potential outbreak of a new strain of coronavirus that began in China and has been spread by travelers across the globe.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">In Flushing, Queens, the site of the city’s biggest Chinatown, the Lunar New Year Temple Bazaar scheduled for this weekend was canceled. The event usually attracts hundreds of spectators.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Adding to the worries, last Thursday <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/24/nyregion/chinatown-museum-fire.html" title="">a fire ripped through a building</a> in Manhattan’s Chinatown that housed archives for the Museum of Chinese in America.</p>, <h3 class="css-1ldy5g8 e1gnsphs0" id="link-73e1f865">The effect of the coronavirus on New York</h3>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Yesterday, people in New York’s Chinatowns were wondering what precautions they should take against the coronavirus, and some celebrations have been called off.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">[</em><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/29/nyregion/coronavirus-nyc.html" title=""><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">Coronavirus and New York: Lunar New Year events were canceled over fears.</em></a><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">]</em></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">City health officials have said it was only a matter of time before the virus appeared in New York State, though no cases had been confirmed so far. They said residents should take the same precautions they would for the flu, such as washing their hands, but should also continue about their lives.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Still, some people are worried that their neighborhoods are being stigmatized.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“It’s mixed emotions right now,” said Wayne Ho, the president and chief executive of the Chinese-American Planning Council. “We’re supposed to be celebrating Lunar New Year.”</p>, <h1 class="g-headline" id="g-inlineguide-headline">The Coronavirus Outbreak</h1>, <h2 class="g-inlineguide-list-header g-optimize-type">How Is the U.S. Being Affected?</h2>, <p class="g-inlineguide-date">Updated Feb.8, 2020</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">He added: “The community feels that there could be racial profiling going on.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Mr. Ho said dozens of people had reached out to his organization to report discrimination. In one case, he said, a Chinese woman who sneezed at a coffee shop overheard someone whisper that she might have the coronavirus. In another case, a man on the subway watched people walk away from him after he coughed.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Scott Liu, who lives in Queens, told my colleagues Joseph Goldstein and Jeffrey E. Singer that he was refusing to leave his house. Mr. Liu said he had been on the last direct flight from Wuhan — the Chinese city where the outbreak began — to Kennedy International Airport, before all flights between the two cities were canceled last week.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Mr. Liu said that he did not believe he was sick, but that he felt responsible to act with caution, even if that meant not visiting his friends and family for Lunar New Year.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“For us, this is very serious,” Mr. Liu, 56, said.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Others, like Lin Qiurong, who emigrated from Fujian Province in China in 2002, said that she ignored messages from her relatives and friends to avoid crowds. This week, Ms. Lin, 40, and her three children put on surgical face masks and headed to a parade in Sunset Park, Brooklyn’s largest Chinatown.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“Look around,” Ms. Lin said at the parade. “It’s much emptier compared to last year.”</p>, <h3 class="css-1ldy5g8 e1gnsphs0" id="link-18095b0c">The aftermath of the museum archives fire</h3>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">About 200 firefighters and emergency personnel responded to a blaze at 70 Mulberry Street, the building in Manhattan’s Chinatown where the archives of the Museum of Chinese in America are situated. Nine firefighters were injured in the fire, which started about 8:40 p.m., as well as a 59-year-old man whom they rescued.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The city-owned building hosts several community organizations. The museum’s archives stored 85,000 items that tell the story of Chinese migration and life in the United States, some of which dated to the 19th century. The museum itself is on Centre Street.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Yesterday, contractors working with the city recovered almost 200 boxes of the museum’s archives from a second-floor room in the Mulberry Street building. Some of the items suffered no damage. It was unclear when the other rooms would be accessible.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Councilwoman Margaret S. Chin, who represents part of Lower Manhattan, said the Lunar New Year was an opportunity for the Chinese community to show resilience.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“We’ve gone through a lot in the past,” Ms. Chin said, “but we always manage to come together to rebuild.”</p>, <h2 class="css-1320w4z eoo0vm40" id="link-62af30bb">From The Times</h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/29/nyregion/nyc-recycling.html" title="">7 Reasons Recycling Isn’t Working in New York City</a></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/29/nyregion/homeless-shelters-services-fraud.html" title="">$500 Million for the Homeless Targeted in Scheme With Bogus Addresses</a></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/29/nyregion/nxivm-lawsuit-keith-raniere.html" title="">Nxivm ‘Sex Cult’ Was Also a Huge Pyramid Scheme, Lawsuit Says</a></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/29/nyregion/harvey-weinstein-trial-tarale-wulff.html" title="">Weinstein Told an Accuser ‘This Is How the Industry Works,’ She Says</a></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Want more news? <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/section/nyregion" title="">Check out our full coverage</a>.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">The Mini Crossword:</strong> Here is <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/crosswords/game/mini" title="">today’s puzzle</a>.</p>, <h2 class="css-1320w4z eoo0vm40" id="link-783cf870">What we’re reading</h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">A <strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">pregnant woman was pronounced dead</strong> after being shoved from a moving car in Brooklyn. [<a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://nypost.com/2020/01/29/pregnant-woman-dead-after-being-pushed-from-car-in-brooklyn/" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">New York Post</a>]</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The <strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">founder of City Bakery </strong>plans to open a cafe focused on hot chocolate. [<a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.grubstreet.com/2020/01/city-bakerys-maury-rubin-returns-with-wonderbon-chocolate.html" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">Grub Street</a>]</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Billy Joel’s Long Island home</strong> was broken into. The burglar damaged 12 motorcycles and a home office. [<a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nydailynews.com/snyde/ny-billy-joel-long-island-motorcycles-20200129-jdnb2qlcdjhhbooknshit3bj64-story.html" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">Daily News</a>]</p>, <h2 class="css-1320w4z eoo0vm40" id="link-61756fc2">Coming up today </h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“<a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.eventbrite.com/e/rediscovering-new-york-revealing-forgotten-landscapes-tickets-86738413931?ct=t%28January+Programs+Week+2+%2801092018%29_COPY_01%29&amp;goal=0_556fa60cc0-0a246c89f5-%5BLIST_EMAIL_ID%5D&amp;mc_cid=0a246c89f5&amp;mc_eid=%5BUNIQID%5D" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">Rediscovering New York: Revealing Forgotten Landscapes</a>” is a panel discussion at the Brooklyn Historical Society. 6:30 p.m. [$15]</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The maritime historian Bill Miller delivers a lecture called “<a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="http://lighthousemuseum.org/event/floating-palaces-the-great-atlantic-liners/?instance_id=6" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">Floating Palaces: The Great Atlantic Liners</a>” at the National Lighthouse Museum in Staten Island. 6 p.m. [$10]</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“<a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.thirteen.org/blog-post/thirteen-screenings-new-york/" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">Independent Lens: First Rainbow Coalition</a>” screens at the Countee Cullen Library in Manhattan. 4:30 p.m. [Free]</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">— <em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">Alex Traub</em></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">Events are subject to change, so double-check before heading out. For more events, see </em><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/spotlight/arts-listings" title=""><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">the going-out guides</em></a><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0"> from The Times’s culture pages.</em></p>, <h2 class="css-1320w4z eoo0vm40" id="link-9dab037">And finally: ‘Unexpected Pairings’</h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">The Times’s Melissa Guerrero writes:</em></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Whether it’s a halal platter, a chocolate babka slice or a bowl of matzo ball soup, comfort food in New York City comes in all different cultures, plates and sizes.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">And <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.mcny.org/event/unexpected-pairings-katzs-delicatessen-teranga" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">a talk tonight</a> at the Museum of the City of New York aims to celebrate that.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">As part of the museum’s “<a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.mcny.org/pairings" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">Unexpected Pairings</a>” series, the event is bringing together Pierre Thiam, a co-founder and the executive chef of the West African restaurant Teranga in Harlem, and Jake Dell, the fifth-generation owner of the 132-year-old Katz’s Delicatessen on the Lower East Side.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">In conversation with Julia Moskin, a Times food reporter, the speakers will discuss the city’s immigrant food culture and how comfort food is defined across the five boroughs.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“Comfort food means different things for different cultures,” Mr. Thiam said. “It’s really the food that you’re nostalgic about, the food that connects with you in a deeper way. The food that you had growing up.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">And an event about food shouldn’t be without it. Visitors will be treated to a post-talk meal featuring samples of beef suya with ndambe from Teranga and matzo ball soup and pastrami from Katz’s.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“What does West African food and Ashkenazi food have in common?” Mr. Dell asked. “It’s comforting to people. To different people.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">He added: “It’s still about bringing you to your roots. Whatever those roots are.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">It’s Thursday — fill your plate.</em></p>, <h2 class="css-1320w4z eoo0vm40" id="link-14e78ac2">Metropolitan Diary: Chinatown street</h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Dear Diary:</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">I was walking through Chinatown when I saw a man I almost used to know.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">He was a quiet, pleasant man who worked as a cleaner at a gym on the Lower East Side where I used to work out. He was there every day, hauling bags of dirty towels and spraying down the free weights.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">I had never learned his name and he had never learned mine, but we would smile at each other when our paths crossed.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">I hadn’t thought about him in years, but seeing him on the street going about his business, made me remember so much about his looks and his mannerisms then. He was grayer now, and still small but strong, like a welterweight boxer.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">I stopped and gazed at him as he walked past me down the street, a ghost from my younger days.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">I thought about my old life on the Lower East Side and all of the things that were happening when I was going to that gym. And I thought about all of the people who were a part of my daily life now whose names I might never learn.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">— Eric Hutchinson</em></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">New York Today is published weekdays around 6 a.m. </em><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/newsletters/newyorktoday?module=inline" title=""><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">Sign up here</em></a><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0"> to get it by email. You can also find it at </em><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="http://www.nytoday.com/" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title=""><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">nytoday.com</em></a><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">.</em></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">We’re experimenting with the format of New York Today. What would you like to see more (or less) of? Post a comment or email us: </em><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="mailto:nytoday@nytimes.com" title=""><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">nytoday@nytimes.com</em></a><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">.</em></p>, <p>Advertisement</p>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd" id="site-index-label">Site Index</h2>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-0">news</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-1">opinion</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-2">arts</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-3">living</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-4">more</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-subscribe-label">Subscribe</h3>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd">Site Information Navigation</h2>]
[<p>Advertisement</p>, <p>Supported by</p>, <h1 class="css-1qskr30 e1h9rw200" id="link-74f82339" itemprop="headline"><span>Coronavirus and the Panic Epidemic</span></h1>, <p class="css-1ifw933 e1wiw3jv0" id="article-summary">The Chinese government is going all-out because it knows the people don’t entirely trust it.</p>, <p class="css-1fv7b6t e1jsehar1" itemprop="author" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">By<!-- --> <a class="css-brehiz e1jsehar0" href="https://www.nytimes.com/by/ian-johnson"><span class="css-1baulvz last-byline" itemprop="name">Ian Johnson</span></a></p>, <p class="css-cpkn1d e1wtpvyy1">Mr. Johnson is a writer based in Beijing.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">BEIJING — The absurdity of the situation hit me on Wednesday when I was coming home from a local bar at 8 p.m. I had ridden my bike a few hours earlier to a park for a walk and then to meet a friend — my first human contact in five days, excluding the cashier at the grocery store.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">But the side gate I’d used to leave the enormous Communist-era compound was now chained shut. What? A notice in <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/02/10/upshot/coronavirus-risk-prevention-advice.html" title="">Chinese</a> said it was locked to prevent the spread of the new <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/02/10/upshot/coronavirus-risk-prevention-advice.html" title="">coronavirus</a>.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">So I headed toward the north entrance. That one is for pedestrians and has two barriers set slightly apart, just wide enough to get through on foot. That’s O.K., I thought, I can squeeze by with my bike and be home in a few minutes.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">I rode around the block, but when I got to the gate I had to slam on the brakes. Someone had taken a dozen ride-share bikes, lashed them together with wire and piled them in between the barriers. Then, for good measure, they’d fastened the heap to the posts with more wire, making it into some sort of postmodern commentary on our hypermobile society.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Laughing, I rode on to the main entrance. It has a car entrance with a big gate and on either side, walkways for pedestrians. One of those was also piled high with ride-share bikes sacrificed for the national good; the other was protected by two security guards I’d never seen before. They blocked my way.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“What do you want?” one of them asked.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“To go home. I live here.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“Have you been to Wuhan recently?”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“I just rode back. I’m exhausted!”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The humor was beyond their pay grade.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“Is anyone in your home from Wuhan or has been there recently?”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">I needed to stop fooling around.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“No, I haven’t been there in four years. I live alone. No fever. I feel fine.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">They silently let me through.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">This felt like the height of foolishness: Why would the gates be open during the day but locked down at night? Do viruses operate like vampires? That’s when I realized the guards’ effort was just part of a <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://memory-alpha.fandom.com/wiki/Borg" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">Borg</a>-like lockdown that the state had put into place with the alacrity of officials in full C.Y.A. mode.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The next day I was cleaning my apartment: No one could enter Beijing anymore, so my one luxury, an hour-a-week house cleaner, was stuck in her village even though the main phase of the Lunar New Year holiday was over. There was a knock on my door. It was the good people from the apartment management office, Mrs. Luo and her assistant.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“Oh, Mr. Zhang, nice to see you,” Mrs. Luo, the henna-haired manager of lease renewals, said, addressing me by my Chinese name. “Is there anyone from Wuhan in your apartment?”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“No. Still not.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“O.K. Take a look at this please.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">She handed me a sheet from the local Communist Party district committee, listing dos and don’ts to follow during the outbreak.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Do seek help. Do listen to the local government. Do keep warm. Do stay at home. Do avoid contact. Do wash your hands. Don’t spit. Don’t exert yourself too much. Don’t associate with people who’ve recently arrived from the infected area around the megacity of Wuhan. On the back was a list of all the Communist Party street committees and their phone numbers.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Finally, after five years of living in this neighborhood and countless failed efforts to register my complaints about illegal construction at night, I had some phone numbers. I filed the sheet for future use.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The German language has, as usual, a hyper-specific word for this phenomenon: “Aktionismus,” literally Actionism, or action for action’s sake. What I was witnessing was Aktionismus in the face of a problem that required a sensitive response involving public trust. But since the Chinese government cannot elicit either of those things, I was seeing the compensatory flailing-around of a state with no other options.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Instead of having an adult conversation with the population about the virus and putting in place reasonable policies that have been used effectively elsewhere, the Chinese state has gone into full lockdown mode. This demonstrates one of those truisms from political science: Authoritarian governments are like people who don’t have any fingers but do possess two thumbs. They can take forceful actions but can’t fine-tune the levers of government.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Actually, I’m not being fair. When the Chinese Communist Party has time, it can come up with and use sophisticated policies — witness <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2019/12/21/opinion/sunday/chinas-religion-xi.html" title="">its co-opting of traditional faiths</a> to fill a spiritual vacuum in society.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">But when faced with a crisis, the party can’t seem to avoid grand gestures: building hospitals from scratch in two weeks, locking down tens of millions of people, banning millions more from traveling to big cities and so on. In some ways, a moment like this one is a technocrat’s dream: When Western health care experts say that this sort of lockdown won’t work, they basically mean it’s never been tried on this scale with this kind of uberefficient government.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Now that it’s being tried, not just in Beijing but also across the country, the effects are kind of thrilling to watch. Apartment compounds like mine are being fumigated. (With what? Who cares!) People are walking around with loudspeakers blaring out warnings against the virus. Villages are closing their gates as if bandits were on the prowl. And going to a restaurant or a bar is almost an act of treason or, at best, foolish selfishness.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The most interesting question is why the party feels the need to carry on like this. I think it knows the people don’t trust it in these cases and assume there has been a cover-up.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Hence one of the most popular figures in the crisis: Zhong Nanshan, the hero of the 2002-3 SARS outbreak, now 83, who is <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="http://global.chinadaily.com.cn/a/202001/23/WS5e28dd3ca310128217272df3.html" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">back in action</a>, treating patients and warning citizens about the need for hygiene. He has been adopted as the incorruptible official — a familiar trope in Chinese history, <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.goodreads.com/quotes/210361-the-green-reed-which-bends-in-the-wind-is-stronger" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">the Confucian official who stands tall despite pressures to bend</a>. And so we read endless profiles of Dr. Zhong in Chinese social media, discussing his family background, upbringing, successes and apolitical pursuit of science-based truth. The clear implication is that he is that rare official capable of such principled conduct.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Behind all this lies the feeling that most other people in the party can’t quite be trusted. This has been reinforced over the past few days by reports that at least eight people who were detained in Wuhan in early January <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.buzzfeednews.com/article/ryanhatesthis/china-is-arresting-people-for-spreading-rumors-online-about" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">on charges of spreading rumors</a> are in fact medical doctors, not fear-mongering ne’er-do-wells. This startling fact is now leaking out in online reports that are sometimes, but not always, being blocked. At some point, the government will have to admit to a partial cover-up.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Considering the underlying distrust, it’s hard for the government to say what many epidemiologists are saying: This outbreak is serious but not catastrophic. Because if the state leveled with the people, it would also have to admit that there is no need for this degree of social control. Some 259 people were reported to have died as of Saturday evening, in a country of nearly 1.4 billion, and there is no indication that we are at the start of a Hollywood disaster-style movie.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The government’s inability to formulate a measured response will turn this outbreak into a direct successor of the SARS epidemic. That hardly was a huge public health disaster — fewer than 800 deaths — yet it has taken on a legendary reputation as a catastrophe of unimaginable proportions, one that should never be allowed to recur.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">But of course a new outbreak has occurred.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Does this mean that the state will suffer? I don’t think so. For despite their mistrust of the system, people over all are going along with the lockdown. In private conversations and on chat rooms, they say it’s impossible not to take drastic action in a country as big as China.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">In this sense, the population has absorbed the government’s narrative of Chinese exceptionalism: Running China requires a strong hand, and these measures, as absurd as they seem, are proof that the government is doing a good job — and portend that the party will come out of this, as always, triumphant.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">This article has been updated to reflect news developments.</em></p>, <p class="css-jwz2nf etfikam0">Ian Johnson (@iandenisjohnson) is the author most recently of “The Souls of China: The Return of Religion After Mao.”</p>, <p class="css-jwz2nf etfikam0"><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">The Times is committed to publishing </em><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2019/01/31/opinion/letters/letters-to-editor-new-york-times-women.html" title=""><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">a diversity of letters</em></a><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0"> to the editor. We’d like to hear what you think about this or any of our articles. Here are some </em><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://help.nytimes.com/hc/en-us/articles/115014925288-How-to-submit-a-letter-to-the-editor" title=""><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">tips</em></a><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">. And here’s our email: </em><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="mailto:letters@nytimes.com" title=""><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">letters@nytimes.com</em></a><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">.</em></p>, <p class="css-jwz2nf etfikam0"><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">Follow The New York Times Opinion section on </em><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.facebook.com/nytopinion" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title=""><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">Facebook</em></a><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">, </em><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="http://twitter.com/NYTOpinion" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title=""><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">Twitter (@NYTopinion)</em></a><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0"> and </em><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.instagram.com/nytopinion/" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title=""><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">Instagram</em></a><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">.</em></p>, <p>Advertisement</p>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd" id="site-index-label">Site Index</h2>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-0">news</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-1">opinion</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-2">arts</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-3">living</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-4">more</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-subscribe-label">Subscribe</h3>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd">Site Information Navigation</h2>]
[<p>Advertisement</p>, <p>Supported by</p>, <h1 class="css-1s4ffep e1h9rw200" id="link-202c8746" itemprop="headline"><span>Wilbur Ross Says Coronavirus Could Bring Jobs Back to the U.S.</span></h1>, <p class="css-1ifw933 e1wiw3jv0" id="article-summary">The commerce secretary said the virus, while “very unfortunate,” could prompt companies to reconsider operating inside China.</p>, <p class="css-1fv7b6t e1jsehar1" itemprop="author" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">By<!-- --> <a class="css-brehiz e1jsehar0" href="https://www.nytimes.com/by/ana-swanson"><span class="css-1baulvz" itemprop="name">Ana Swanson</span></a> and <a class="css-brehiz e1jsehar0" href="https://www.nytimes.com/by/alan-rappeport"><span class="css-1baulvz last-byline" itemprop="name">Alan Rappeport</span></a></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">WASHINGTON — Commerce Secretary Wilbur Ross predicted Thursday morning that a <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/30/world/asia/coronavirus-china.html" title="">deadly virus originating in China</a> would cause companies to reconsider their global supply chains and ultimately “help to accelerate” the return of jobs to the United States.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">In an interview on Fox Business, Mr. Ross said diseases like the Wuhan coronavirus, which has killed more than a hundred people and sickened thousands, were “another risk factor that people need to take into account” when considering where to locate operations.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“Every American’s heart has to go out to the victims of the coronavirus, so I don’t want to talk about a victory lap over a very unfortunate, very malignant disease,” Mr. Ross said. “But the fact is, it does give businesses yet another thing to consider when they go through their review of their supply chain.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">He cited the deadly SARS outbreak that paralyzed China 17 years ago, as well as the African swine fever that has <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2019/12/17/business/china-pigs-african-swine-fever.html" title="">decimated China’s pig farms</a>.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“So I think it will help to accelerate the return of jobs to North America,” Mr. Ross said of the coronavirus. “Some to U.S., probably some to Mexico as well.”</p>, <h1 class="g-headline" id="g-inlineguide-headline">The Coronavirus Outbreak</h1>, <h2 class="g-inlineguide-list-header g-optimize-type">What do you need to know? Start here.</h2>, <p class="g-inlineguide-date">Updated Feb. 10, 2020</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The Trump administration has been waging a global trade war in an attempt to bring jobs back to the United States. That has included steep tariffs on imported goods, which President Trump has wielded as a cudgel to force companies to relocate manufacturing to the United States.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Officials have said that the first-phase trade deal Mr. Trump <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/15/business/economy/china-trade-deal.html" title="">signed with China this month</a> would improve ties between the countries. But they also say that their tariffs — which remain in place on more than $360 billion of Chinese products — will cause American companies with Chinese operations to think about moving their supply chains back home.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Some companies that can move operations out of China have been doing so, in part to avoid the tariffs and in part because of longer-run economic factors, like China’s rising wages. But economists say that few of these factories are moving back to the United States. Instead, competition for factory space in low-wage countries like Vietnam, Mexico and India to make clothes, toys and shoes has been fierce.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">And many companies say they are unable to move their supply chains, often because it is too expensive to shift or because China is the primary manufacturer of their materials. For instance, China remains the global hub of electronics manufacturing, and a huge consumer market in its own right.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The Chinese government has placed entire cities under lockdown to stop the spread of the coronavirus, and encouraged companies to let their workers stay home.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The moves are expected to result in a major dent in the Chinese economy — and are likely spill over to slow global growth. Jerome H. Powell, the Federal Reserve chair, said on Wednesday that “there is likely to be some disruption to activity in China and perhaps globally.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The virus has <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/29/business/china-coronavirus-economy.html" title="">already caused companies including Apple, Ford and Toyota</a> to reroute supply chains and idle factories in China, while Ikea, Starbucks and other businesses have temporarily closed some Chinese stores. British Airways and Air Canada have suspended all flights to mainland China, while other major airlines have reduced the number of flights.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Mr. Ross, <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2017/11/08/business/dealbook/wilbur-ross-forbes.html" title="">a wealthy investor,</a> has been criticized for making controversial or seemingly out-of-touch statements in televised interviews before. In May 2018, he <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.cnbc.com/2018/05/18/commerce-secretary-ross-claim-that-tariffs-wouldnt-hurt-campbells-soup-just-blew-up.html" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">held up a can of Campbell’s soup</a> while arguing that the administration’s metal tariffs would have a minimal effect on consumers. In early 2019, he suggested that workers who had been sent home without pay during the government shutdown <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2019/01/24/business/wilbur-ross-shutdown.html" title="">should take out personal loans</a>.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The Commerce Department, in an emailed statement, said Mr. Ross had made clear that the first step was to bring the virus under control and help victims of the disease. “It is also important to consider the ramifications of doing business with a country that has a long history of covering up real risks to its own people and the rest of the world,” the statement said.</p>, <p>Advertisement</p>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd" id="site-index-label">Site Index</h2>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-0">news</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-1">opinion</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-2">arts</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-3">living</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-4">more</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-subscribe-label">Subscribe</h3>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd">Site Information Navigation</h2>]
[<p>Advertisement</p>, <p>Supported by</p>, <h1 class="css-1qskr30 e1h9rw200" id="link-54eeec30" itemprop="headline"><span>No, Team Trump, the Coronavirus Isn’t Good for America</span></h1>, <p class="css-1ifw933 e1wiw3jv0" id="article-summary">The commerce secretary just flunked microbe economics.</p>, <p class="css-1fv7b6t e1jsehar1" itemprop="author" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">By<!-- --> <a class="css-brehiz e1jsehar0" href="https://www.nytimes.com/by/paul-krugman"><span class="css-1baulvz last-byline" itemprop="name">Paul Krugman</span></a></p>, <p class="css-cpkn1d e1wtpvyy1">Opinion Columnist</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">How frightened should you be about the coronavirus? I’m no epidemiologist, but what I’ve seen looks pretty scary. It doesn’t help that the Trump administration, as part of its general war against science and expertise, has seriously reduced America’s capacity to respond if we do face a dangerous pandemic.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">It also looks quite possible that the virus will inflict a lot of economic damage — even if it doesn’t kill you, it might kill your job. And one special source of concern is that top officials in the Trump administration are <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.washingtonpost.com/business/2020/01/30/wilbur-ross-coronavirus-jobs/" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">talking nonsense</a> about the economic threat.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">So, about that economic threat: Many people are <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/27/business/coronavirus-china-economic-impact.html" title="">drawing parallels</a> between the coronavirus and the 2002-3 outbreak of severe acute respiratory syndrome, or SARS, which also originated in China. Like the current outbreak, SARS led to the imposition of economically disruptive quarantines, which appear to have had a significant if temporary adverse effect on China’s economy, and a modest negative impact on the world economy as a whole.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">We still don’t know whether the coronavirus is more or less dangerous than SARS. What we do know is that the global economic implications of a pandemic in China are likely to be much more severe now than they were then, for the simple reason that China is a vastly bigger player than it used to be.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">In 2002 China was still in the early stages of its great economic surge; it accounted for only around <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://fas.org/sgp/crs/misc/R42135.pdf" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">8 percent</a> of global manufacturing value added, far less than the shares of the U.S., Japan and Europe. Today, however, China is the workshop of the world, accounting for more than a quarter of global manufacturing.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Now, you might think that this implies an upside to China’s troubles, that disrupting China’s vast manufacturing sector would offer opportunities to producers in other countries, including the United States.
