But some protective measures have effectively amounted to racial or ethnic profiling.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">At Bread Box, a banh mi restaurant in central Hoi An, a popular tourist outpost in Vietnam, the owners posted a makeshift sign outside their storefront this month reading, “We can’t service for Chinese, SORRY!” Up the coast, the Danang Riverside Hotel announced on Saturday that it would not accept any Chinese guests because of the virus.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Kwong Wing Catering, a small restaurant chain in Hong Kong, announced in a <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.facebook.com/%E5%85%89%E6%A6%AE%E9%A3%B2%E9%A3%9F-Kwong-Wing-Catering-116149449769292/" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">Facebook post</a> on Wednesday that it would serve only patrons speaking English or Cantonese, the city’s native language — a tongue distinct from the Mandarin spoken on the mainland. The business has been a <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.reuters.com/article/us-hongkong-protests-christmas-dinner/were-all-family-now-protesters-gather-for-free-christmas-dinner-in-hong-kong-idUSKBN1YU03L" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">vocal supporter of the Hong Kong democracy movement</a> that has risen up in defiance of Beijing.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Public health experts said they understood some of the impulses. “In a sense, it’s a natural reaction to try to distance yourself from a potential cause of illness, particularly when there’s no known cure,” said <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://aparc.fsi.stanford.edu/people/karen_eggleston" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">Karen Eggleston</a>, director of the Asia health policy program at the Shorenstein Asia-Pacific Research Center at Stanford University.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">But examples in both mass and social media have clearly crossed a line. In Australia, The Herald Sun, a Murdoch-owned newspaper, published the words “China Virus Panda-monium” over an image of a red mask. More than 46,000 people from the resident Chinese community in Australia signed a <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.change.org/p/herald-sun-strongly-require-the-apologies-from-herald-sun-and-daily-telegraph" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">petition</a> that called the headline “unacceptable race discrimination.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Le Courrier Picard, a regional newspaper in northern France, caused outrage with its “Yellow Alert” headline this month. The newspaper later <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.courrier-picard.fr/id64729/article/2020-01-26/propos-de-notre-une-du-26-janvier" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">apologized</a>.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">On Twitter in Japan, where there has long been unease about the conduct of Chinese tourists, commenters have labeled them “dirty” and “insensitive” and have called them “bioterrorists.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Disinformation is also running high. A much-viewed YouTube video in South Korea claims that a biochemical weapons facility in China leaked the coronavirus, a theory that has gained currency in other corners of the globe. In Australia, a fake post circulating on Instagram warned that shops in Sydney containing items like fortune cookies, rice and “Chinese Red Bull” were contaminated.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The episodes of racism have swept up other people of Asian descent. In France, one Vietnamese woman <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.lemonde.fr/planete/article/2020/01/29/coronavirus-le-racisme-antiasiatique-se-propage-en-france_6027701_3244.html" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">told the newspaper Le Monde</a> that she had been insulted by a car driver who shouted “Keep your virus, dirty Chinese!” and “You are not welcome in France” as he sped away through a puddle, splashing her.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">In Australia, Andy Miao, 24, an ethnic Chinese Australian who returned this month from a trip to China, said that passengers on public transport gave him odd looks if he was not wearing a face mask.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“It makes people like me who are very, very Australian feel like outsiders,” Mr. Miao said. “It’s definitely invoking a lot of past racial stereotypes.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The Chinese — and Asians in general — were subjected to similar xenophobic reactions during the SARS epidemic of 2003. But now far more Chinese are traveling abroad: According to the Ministry of Culture and Tourism, Chinese travelers made about 150 million overseas trips in 2018, up more than 14 percent from the previous year.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">China’s lockdown of tens of millions of people, intended to curb the spread of the virus, may be spurring other governments to overreact, said Koichi Nakano, a political scientist at Sophia University in Tokyo.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“The fact that the Chinese government itself is treating people like that would in some ways enable or encourage some of the other people or governments to take equally draconian measures,” Mr. Nakano said.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Some governments are trying to ease the panic. In Toronto, politicians, a school board and some community groups have issued public appeals to avoid a repetition of the racism that swept the city in 2003, when SARS killed 44 people there.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“While the virus can be traced to a province in China, we have to be cautious that this not be seen as a Chinese virus,” <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="http://www.yrdsb.ca/schools/Repository/NewsEvents/Pages/BoardNews/Message-From-The-Director.aspx" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">the school board in the York Region, a suburb with many Asian residents, said in a statement</a> issued on Monday. “At times such as this, we must come together as Canadians and avoid any hint of xenophobia, which in this case can victimize our East Asian Chinese community.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Although Indonesia has suspended flights from Wuhan, the governor of West Sumatra, Irwan Prayitno, ignored a plea from a citizens group to reject all Chinese tourists. On Sunday, he went to the airport to welcome 174 Chinese visitors from the southwestern city of Kunming.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">In the Ginza shopping district of Tokyo, which is often thronged with Chinese tourists, Michiko Kubota, who runs a clothing boutique, said she hoped the Japanese government might do more to help China, such as by sending masks or other medical supplies.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“Japan and China may be critical of each other sometimes, but the kindness is mutual,” Ms. Kubota said. “I hope we could do more to help eradicate fear in China as well.”</p>, <p class="css-jwz2nf etfikam0">Reporting was contributed by Ian Austen, Hannah Beech, Aurelien Breeden, Jason Gutierrez, Makiko Inoue, Isabella Kwai, Su-Hyun Lee, Tiffany May, Seth Mydans, Katrina Northrop, Jin Wu, Eimi Yamamitsu and Li Yuan.</p>, <p>Advertisement</p>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd" id="site-index-label">Site Index</h2>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-0">news</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-1">opinion</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-2">arts</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-3">living</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-4">more</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-subscribe-label">Subscribe</h3>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd">Site Information Navigation</h2>]
[<p>Advertisement</p>, <p>Supported by</p>, <h1 class="css-1s4ffep e1h9rw200" id="link-51ba4f55" itemprop="headline"><span>Coronavirus Anger Boils Over in China and Doctors Plead for Supplies</span></h1>, <p class="css-1ifw933 e1wiw3jv0" id="article-summary">A man was detained after beating up a doctor in Wuhan, and medical staff members are wearing raincoats to protect against infection. </p>, <p class="css-1fv7b6t e1jsehar1" itemprop="author" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">By<!-- --> <a class="css-brehiz e1jsehar0" href="https://www.nytimes.com/by/chris-buckley"><span class="css-1baulvz" itemprop="name">Chris Buckley</span></a> and <a class="css-brehiz e1jsehar0" href="https://www.nytimes.com/by/amy-qin"><span class="css-1baulvz last-byline" itemprop="name">Amy Qin</span></a></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">WUHAN, China — One week into a lockdown, anger and anxiety deepened in China on Thursday as the central province at the center <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/30/world/asia/coronavirus-china.html?action=click&amp;module=Top%20Stories&amp;pgtype=Homepage" title="">of the coronavirus outbreak</a> endured shortages of hospital beds, medical supplies and doctors. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">In a sign of growing frustration, a relative of a patient infected with the virus beat up a doctor at a hospital in Wuhan, the capital of Hubei Province, the state broadcaster CCTV <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="http://m.news.cctv.com/2020/01/30/ARTIYetcA7cWAzPPqYcWU9Ei200130.shtml" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">reported</a> on Thursday, citing the police. The man was accused of pulling and damaging the doctor’s mask and protective clothing — potentially exposing him to the virus — after his father-in-law died in the hospital. The man was later detained.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">At the same time, hospitals in the region renewed pleas to the public for help to replenish their supplies, which were fast disappearing. The shortages have become especially severe in Huanggang, a city of seven million not far from Wuhan, where some medical staff members were wearing raincoats and garbage bags as shoe covers to protect against infection, <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.yicai.com/news/100483434.html" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">according to Yicai</a>, a financial news site.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Amid growing unease, the World Health Organization <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/30/world/asia/coronavirus-world-health-organization.html" title="">declared</a> a global health emergency,<span class="css-8l6xbc evw5hdy0"> </span>which acknowledges that the disease now represents a risk beyond China. Nations can then decide whether to shut their borders, cancel flights or screen people arriving at ports of entry. Late Thursday, the State Department urged Americans not to travel to China, issuing a Level 4 advisory, which represents the highest safety risk.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Also Thursday, Chinese government agencies announced plans to issue subsidies of up to $43 per day to front-line medical workers and to reopen factories to boost production of medical supplies and protective gear.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“We absolutely cannot let Huanggang become a second Wuhan,” Wang Xiaodong, the governor of Hubei Province, said at a news briefing on Wednesday.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">On Thursday evening, provincial leaders said at a news briefing that the director of Huanggang’s health committee had been fired.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">For many Chinese, such decisive government announcements are too little, too late. Concerns have grown as the death toll from the coronavirus has quickly ticked upward, rising by 43 to hit 213 on Friday. All but one of those recent deaths have occurred in Hubei Province; the other died in the southwestern province of Sichuan.</p>, <h1 class="g-headline" id="g-inlineguide-headline">The Coronavirus Outbreak</h1>, <h2 class="g-inlineguide-list-header g-optimize-type">What do you need to know? Start here.</h2>, <p class="g-inlineguide-date">Updated Feb. 10, 2020</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Fueling the anger on Thursday was the publication this week of <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nejm.org/doi/full/10.1056/NEJMoa2001316?query=featured_coronavirus" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">a new paper about the coronavirus in The New England Journal of Medicine</a> by a team of researchers affiliated with, among other places, the Chinese Centers for Disease Control and Prevention and the Hubei Provincial Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Drawing on data from the first 425 confirmed cases in Wuhan, the paper states that “there is evidence that human-to-human transmission has occurred among close contacts since the middle of December 2019.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Chinese people online were incensed, asking why the government had waited until Jan. 20 to inform the public that the virus was capable of being transmitted from human to human. By Thursday evening, many had seized on the paper as evidence that the authors had purposely withheld valuable information out of academic self-interest.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“I’m about to explode, I need an explanation from the authors!!!!” Wang Liming, a professor at Zhejiang University, wrote in a widely shared social media post that was quickly deleted. “As a researcher with firsthand information, you knew that the virus could be transmitted between humans three weeks before the public did. Did you do what you were supposed to do?”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">As China raced to contain the outbreak, countries grappled with how to <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/29/world/asia/wuhan-china-coronavirus-evacuations.html" title="">evacuate their citizens from Wuhan</a> and how to stop the virus from spreading.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Australia announced a plan to evacuate its citizens in Wuhan to Christmas Island, which has played an important but checkered role in the country’s contentious use of faraway sites to house refugees and other migrants. The announcement drew immediate questions over the implications of using the island as a quarantine site.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Moving people to Christmas Island is not an “appropriate solution,” Dr. Tony Bartone, the president of the Australian Medical Association, said in a <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=5rFUZcKrz1M" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">television news interview</a>. He said the government had other, more suitable facilities, such as military sites.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">In Japan, a furor erupted over the refusal of some evacuees who had returned to submit to medical testing.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Two of the Japanese citizens who have been evacuated from Wuhan refused to be tested for the coronavirus, leading the prime minister to explain that citizens could not be forced to submit to a medical examination.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Japanese social media users said the travelers, who arrived in Tokyo on Wednesday, were putting the country at risk. Some called them terrorists.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“We tried to persuade the two returnees from Wuhan for many hours” to be tested, Prime Minister Shinzo Abe said in Parliament on Thursday, when asked about the government’s treatment of repatriated citizens. “But there is no legally binding force, and that’s a great regret.” Mr. Abe said.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Russia ordered 16 of its approximately 25 crossing points on its 2,600-mile border Chinese border to be closed as of midnight local time as fears about the coronavirus outbreak mounted in Moscow.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“We have to do everything to protect our people,” Prime Minister Mikhail Mishustin said on Thursday in televised<a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="http://government.ru/news/38878/" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title=""> remarks</a> at a cabinet meeting.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Italy blocked thousands of people from leaving a cruise ship that docked there on Thursday over concerns that someone aboard might have the virus. Although a Chinese national with a fever later tested negative for the coronavirus and the Italian authorities said passengers were allowed to disembark, for much of the day the country was gripped by fears that the coronavirus had arrived on its shores. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">That concern proved warranted later Thursday, when the government reported the country’s first two confirmed cases, neither of which were related to the ship.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Prime Minister Giuseppe Conte also announced that Italy had halted all flights to and from China.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"></p>, <h2 class="css-zd32qr">Coronavirus Map: Tracking the Spread of the Outbreak</h2>, <p class="css-1uuihdo">The virus has sickened more than 43,100 people in China and 24 other countries.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">In the United States, health officials on Thursday reported the first case of person-to-person transmission of the coronavirus in the United States. The patient is the husband of a woman who was the first reported case in Chicago, officials said at a news briefing. The woman, who is in her 60s, had returned from Wuhan. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The American commerce secretary, Wilbur Ross, said the United States could see a positive byproduct from China’s woes because the outbreak could prompt employers to move jobs to its shores.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“I don’t want to talk about a victory lap over a very unfortunate, very malignant disease,” Mr. Ross said in an interview on Fox Business. “I think it will help to accelerate the return of jobs to North America. Some to the U.S., probably some to Mexico as well.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">His remarks may be seen as insensitive to a country in crisis, and he has faced such criticism in the past. During the government shutdown in early 2019, Mr. Ross suggested that furloughed workers should take out loans while they went without pay for more than a month.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">With the evacuations and lockdown, Wuhan, a typically bustling metropolis, has been transformed into a ghost town. Since the city was effectively sealed off last week, most shops have shut down. The city government has put restrictions on traffic. The lack of transportation options has made it difficult for medical workers and sick residents to get to hospitals.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">But most residents of Wuhan<span class="css-8l6xbc evw5hdy0"> </span>are not leaving their homes because they are too scared of catching the virus.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“Local Wuhan residents who aren’t worried about being sick aren’t even going on the streets,” Chen Qiushi, a Beijing-based lawyer who has been in Wuhan since the lockdown began, said in a <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=iXozpbomAns" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">video blog</a> posted on Thursday. “The locals are all very scared.” </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">When Wuhan residents step outside, it’s mostly to go to the supermarkets, food stores and pharmacies that stay open as part of a government effort to sustain the city. Senior officials have promised that residents need not worry about vegetables, fruit or other staples.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">While Wuhan residents have been able to buy food, some complained about price increases or expressed fear that a prolonged shutdown might choke off food supplies. And if the shutdown lasts weeks longer, with the rest of China also scrambling to secure food supplies, it could make things more serious, several residents said.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“If we can’t bring in produce, it will become more expensive, or we might even have to close up,” said Zuo Qichao, who was selling piles of cucumbers, turnips and tomatoes. As he spoke, a woman accused him of unfairly raising the turnips’ price.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“Every county, every village around here is now putting up barriers, worried about that disease,” Mr. Zuo said. “Even if the government says it wants food guaranteed, it won’t be easy — all those road checks.”</p>, <p class="css-jwz2nf etfikam0">Amy Qin reported from Beijing, and Christopher Buckley from Wuhan, China. Reporting was contributed by Elaine Yu, Tiffany May, Russell Goldman, Austin Ramzy, Alexandra Stevenson, Motoko Rich, Anton Troianovski, Isabella Kwai, Chris Horton, Makiko Inoue, Daisuke Wakabayashi, Karen Weise, Iliana Magra, Christopher Cameron and Mike Isaac. Research was contributed by Elsie Chen, Zoe Mou, Albee Zhang, Amber Wang, Yiwei Wang and Claire Fu.</p>, <p>Advertisement</p>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd" id="site-index-label">Site Index</h2>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-0">news</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-1">opinion</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-2">arts</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-3">living</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-4">more</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-subscribe-label">Subscribe</h3>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd">Site Information Navigation</h2>]
[<p>Advertisement</p>, <p class="css-1qi8px4">transcript</p>, <h2 class="css-9wqu2x">A Virus’s Journey Across China</h2>, <h3 class="css-eq2co1">Hosted by Michael Barbaro; produced by Neena Pathak, Annie Brown and Eric Krupke; with help from Kelly Prime; and edited by M.J. Davis Lin and Mike Benoist</h3>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">From The New York Times, I’m Michael Barbaro. This is “The Daily.”</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd"></p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">Today: China says it has made lifesaving reforms since the last time it was the source of a public health crisis 17 years ago. So why is the deadly coronavirus spreading so rapidly across the country? My colleague, Javier Hernández, reports from the center of the outbreak.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">It’s Thursday, January 30.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">Javier, how did you first hear about this outbreak?</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">Well, we started hearing reports in early January that there was this mysterious virus that was affecting Wuhan, which is a city in central China.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">Staff at Wuhan Hospital are working around the clock to identify a mystery virus.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">People were falling ill to this kind of pneumonia-like virus, which scientists were calling a coronavirus.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">Experts believe this is a new kind of coronavirus, which typically causes symptoms of the common cold, but in some rare cases, can lead to pneumonia.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">It’s a very frightening virus that spreads from animals to humans. It was believed to be behind some very serious respiratory illnesses, so it sounded pretty scary. But the official narrative was that this strain couldn’t pass from human to human. It would only go from animals to humans.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">The potentially deadly coronavirus is thought to have spread from animals into humans at a live produce market in Wuhan.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">And at that point, they were saying that it was all originating at a single meat market in central China. This meat market sold wild animals, things like bamboo rats, badgers, wolves even. And the assumption was that people had come into contact with these animals and picked up this virus.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">And it sounds like because it was one meat market, and because this virus could only pass from animals to humans, that this is a pretty small problem.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">At this point, the reports were that only about 130 people had been infected and that, of those, only about four had died.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">Chinese officials say the outbreak is under control.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">And so the prognosis was that the outbreak was controllable, that it was treatable and that things would be O.K.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">And Javier, what are you thinking when you hear the Chinese government talking this way, saying that everything is going to be O.K.?</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">We were a bit skeptical. We knew that the Chinese government had a history of downplaying outbreaks like this. And as we saw more and more reports in the international media of this virus spreading, we began to question whether the officials were being totally upfront about what was happening.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">And what do you mean when you say a history of downplaying situations like this?</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">Well before this virus, there was the outbreak of SARS 17 years ago. And it turned into this global health crisis that infected more than 8,000 people. It killed more than 800 people. And a big part of the reason that it spread so violently was because the Chinese government didn’t tell the world. And there was this period of months and months when it was spreading very rapidly in China, and the world just didn’t know about it. And for a lot of Chinese today, that experience with SARS makes them very skeptical of anything that the government says when it comes to public health.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">And I imagine a reporter like you would be similarly skeptical.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">Right. We really wanted to make sure that we got this one right.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">We wanted to double check that this was, in fact, a small scale outbreak as the government was portraying it. And we wanted to talk to people who were getting sick with this virus to get a sense of what it was like for them — how severe it was, whether they were getting the care they needed.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">And so what do you do?</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">So I live in Beijing. So I rushed to our bureau here and grabbed masks, enough to last me a couple days, and then headed to the airport and boarded a flight to Wuhan. And I just remember everyone on board, almost everyone, was wearing a mask. I was just struck by that. You never see people wear masks on this scale. And so it felt like there was this sense of anxiety already in the air even before we landed.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd"></p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">Once I got there, I rushed off to meet an ambulance doctor who had been posting on social media about this outbreak. And we had contacted him because he was challenging the official narrative about what was happening. He was saying he didn’t believe the official numbers. He thought that this could be another SARS-like outbreak.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">And what was happening to his posts once they went online?</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">They lasted for a while, and then they would be taken down, just disappeared. It was clear that the government was cleaning and trying to scrub the internet of any critical questions about official data. And so we wanted to talk to him about what he was seeing on the ground.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">And what did he tell you?</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">He told me that he felt like people weren’t taking enough precautions, that the government wasn’t being urgent enough. And he worked in a hospital and had a lot of interaction with doctors and other medical workers. So he felt like his job could be at stake if he were to come forward publicly.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">So the numbers the Chinese government is providing are relatively small. This ambulance doctor you’re meeting with is saying the problem is bigger. So what do you do to try to reconcile those two pieces of information?</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">We wanted to find the people whose relatives had fallen ill to this virus. And so we were looking online for people who were reporting symptoms of fever, cough, basically anything that was associated with this kind of virus. And we stumbled on a guy from Shanghai. He was a 40-year-old architect, and he told me that his stepmother had died just a couple of days earlier from a mysterious pneumonia-like illness. And so I found him, sent him a message, and we agreed to meet at a cafe. [CHATTER]</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">And what is the story of what happened to his stepmom?</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">He tells me that she was a very healthy, normal 65-year-old woman who, a couple of weeks earlier, had started to feel like she was having a flu. So she had some coughing. She had kind of a sore throat, but it didn’t seem like anything that bad. But it suddenly began to worsen. She was having a fever. She needed a respirator to breathe. And all very suddenly she was sent to a contagious disease ward, and the family was told that she would likely die.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">And what did she or her stepson understand about what was behind her illness?</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">They didn’t really understand much. For days and days, according to Mr. Wei, the family had tried to get her tested for this coronavirus, this mysterious virus that was spreading across Wuhan. And the doctors and other medical workers refused.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">He pulled out his phone and showed me her death certificate, and all it said was that she died of severe pneumonia.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">But why wouldn’t they test her, and what does it tell you that they wouldn’t test her?</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">It became clear to me in that moment that there seemed to be something going on here. Were these hospitals just not prepared? Did they not have enough testing kits? Were they running out of tests? Had they tested so many people that they didn’t have any tests left? Were they just not counting people anymore because they weren’t even diagnosing them? And if she wasn’t diagnosed with this illness, then maybe she wasn’t even included in the official count. And one other thing really stuck with me from my interview with Mr. Wei. And that was that the hospital, according to him, told them that his mother’s body had to be burned immediately, had to be cremated immediately. [CHATTER]</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">And what does that tell you? What does that mean to you that they’re burning these bodies?</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">It began to put in my head the sense that the hospital workers were beginning to think that this illness was contagious. And the fact that they wanted that body burned immediately began to suggest that perhaps they thought it posed a threat to other people.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">Her death got us thinking about whether there were other people like her. And when you went online and search social media, you could quickly find others who were reporting similar experiences — people saying that they went to hospitals, they brought their sick relatives and were simply turned away. We began to kind of add things up, and it seemed like the numbers weren’t right.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">So at this point, it sounds like your skepticism is growing, and it’s sounding pretty warranted. So what do you do next?</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">So I head back to my hotel and start to try to make sense of all of this. And as I’m sitting there in my room, I begin to see these reports emerging on social media —</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">For the first time since the mysterious pneumonia-like illness broke out in China, the country’s health authorities admitted the disease could be contagious.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">— that one of China’s top health experts has acknowledged that this virus is now spreading from person to person, which had never been the case before.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">[SPEAKING CHINESE]</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">We considered risks of this before, but now evidence has confirmed that it is contagious among humans.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">And he’s an 83-year-old guy that they dug out of retirement essentially. He was a renowned expert during the SARS crisis. And suddenly, he’s all over social media, telling people that this crisis is much worse than had been previously known.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">So this doctor is very much validating what you have been hearing.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">Yes. He’s saying that there was even a case where one patient was able to infect 14 medical workers.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">Wow.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">And I begin to see the panic kind of spread across social media.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">Say I have coronavirus. Could I give it to you right now?</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">It’s possible, if you’re coughing and sneezing. If you have a fever, it can be transmitted.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">But the spread of Corona virus is accelerating.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">This is the moment when the world begins to wake up.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">Meanwhile, new cases are being confirmed outside of China as well.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">Thailand has reported the first case of the Wuhan coronavirus found outside of China.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">— because now they’re talking Thailand, Singapore, possibly Scotland. The U.K. is bracing for it to go in there. We have airports here in the United States very concerned about it —</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">That are doing surveillance.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">— here in New York, Chicago and L.A. Every day it seems growing exponentially.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">It is. It’s growing.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">The numbers after that point just keep spiraling and spiraling.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">The number of people who have died —</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">The death toll climbing once again overnight.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">The death toll from a deadly viral outbreak of the new coronavirus —</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">26 deaths so far from the —</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">— has now passed 40.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">[SPEAKING CHINESE]</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">It’s not just Chinese people who are worried. Everyone is worried. They’re all afraid of dying.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">You just hear people wondering whether the virus is ever going to be contained.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">We’ll be right back.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">And Javier, what are you thinking and feeling at this moment? Because you’re in this city. You’re interacting with people who are taking care of those who are sickened and infected by this illness.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">Yeah.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">Are you anxious?</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">Well I’m beginning to feel like this is much worse than I thought. And I think a sense of paranoia can easily settle in sometimes in these situations. I had masks. I was washing my hands all the time. But I couldn’t help but think about every button in the elevator that I touched, every surface and every cough or sniffle that I saw around me. The virus could be anywhere, so I had to be careful.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">I mean, understandably.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">So I finished up my reporting, and I grabbed a flight back to Beijing.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">Just one day before China’s massive Lunar New Year holiday, as hundreds of millions crisscross the country to celebrate with families, an unprecedented act.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">And then the very next day, I hear —</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">Today, the entire city of Wuhan, population 11 million, is on lockdown.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">The Chinese government has placed this entire city under lockdown.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">Wow.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">Trains, flights, buses, and ferries have been canceled. Even public transport within Wuhan has ground to a halt.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">So the city you have just left has basically told everybody else who remains that they’re not going anywhere.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">Right. This city is being closed off in a way that China has never done before — or even any other major modern city, really, hasn’t done it in recent times.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">Across China tonight, an expanding lockdown to contain an epidemic.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">And it was quickly becoming clear to the government that this wasn’t just a local problem.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">Travel bans in over a dozen cities affecting 35 million people.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">They quickly expanded it to not just Wuhan, but to other cities, so that there were tens of millions of people who were essentially forced to stay at home and not allowed to go out. They’ve just put in place the biggest lockdown that we’ve ever seen and what experts are saying is the biggest experiment in public health that they’ve ever seen.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">Despite their efforts, authorities say the virus has not been stopped.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">Much depends on whether the measures set in place by the Chinese government will prove effective.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">It’s hard to imagine most any other country being able to mount that kind of a response. I mean, I’m just trying to fathom an American city somehow being locked down.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">So this is what it looks like when China’s authoritarian system is in full force. There’s no choice for people to leave. Many people are stuck there. They are going to hospitals that are overcrowded, but they can’t get the health care they need. Doctors are complaining about a lack of medical supplies and critical items like masks and goggles. And you get the sense that people are kind of stuck with what they have, and that’s the bargain they’ve made by living in this system. They have no choice but to follow the government’s orders. They can’t push back. They can’t swim against the current here. Everyone’s essentially forced to comply with this mass lockdown.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">You know, from everything we’ve learned about China and its authoritarian government, it seems like it controls every aspect of its citizens’ lives and it surveils every aspect of citizens’ lives. And you’ve just walked us through how they were able to essentially suddenly drop a wall around Wuhan. So knowing all that, shouldn’t China’s government have been able to identify and control this outbreak before it got out of hand?</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">You would think that, because the government is so well known for being able to pull off these massive displays of citizen mobilization — it’s been known to be able to pull off these technological feats. But at the same time, there’s a flip side of this coin, which is that China’s authoritarian culture, in many ways, set the stage for this crisis.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">What do you mean?</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">Well for decades, China has built this system, this ruthless system in which if you are an official in the Communist Party, you are expected to be almost perfect. If anything goes bad, you are the one who is going to take responsibility. You are the one who is going to fall. And this has created an incentive system where local officials fear saying anything about bad news. They worry that if they are found to have done something wrong, that they will lose their power. So in a situation like this, the incentive is to cover up. It’s to conceal. It’s to delay. It’s to try to get a handle on these problems on your own, hoping that perhaps nobody will ever hear about it.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">So by the time something like, say, a medical crisis gets really big, it may be too late for the local officials who have been trying to contain it themselves and keep it from Beijing.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">Exactly. These kinds of dynamics played a huge role in the scale of the SARS outbreak. It was clear in this case that local officials knew exactly what was going on. They knew that people were dying of this illness. But for months and months, they didn’t want to report it up the chain. Instead, they tried to cover it up. They tried to see if they could perhaps deal with it secretly, and maybe nobody would ever find out about it. They hoped that Beijing would know about it. But eventually it broke.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">So did China learn from that experience with SARS, that dynamic that led to that breakdown, that cover-up?</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">China said it would make a lot of changes to its system after the SARS crisis. It said that it would expand its disease reporting system so that these kinds of reports from the local provinces would come to the central government in a more timely fashion. They promised to be more transparent in the release of data and other things. But what they didn’t change was this authoritarian culture, where people fear bringing bad news. And so that has actually gotten worse under President Xi.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">Why?</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">He has made himself out to be the most powerful leader since Mao. He is somebody who’s always speaking about this great ascendant moment for China in which China is going to be this superpower. And anything that goes against Xi’s vision of this harmonious, resurgent China is going to be seen as a problem. And the people who are creating that problem will pay the consequences. And when I was there in Wuhan, I could sense the fear just rippling across all parts of the society. There were people like the ambulance doctor, who was afraid of challenging the official statistics. There were hospitals that seemed to be paralyzed, that didn’t want to test patients for fear of knowing the results. They didn’t want to be seen as speaking out or telling the truth or bringing this unsavory story into public view.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">So that had trickled down all the way to the frontline health care workers, who are supposed to be treating this and sounding the alarm.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">Right. They’re fearful of being seen as responsible for this crisis. They don’t want to stand out. And when you think about where this virus might be headed next — to other provinces, to other cities — you have to wonder if these same dynamics would be playing out again. If people will stay silent, if they will not report official cases, because they fear for their jobs and they fear for their livelihoods.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">So it seems like whatever reforms the Chinese government made after the failures of SARS, that in the end, none of them really matter, because it hasn’t changed the problem that’s at the root of this.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">At the root of all this is a sense of fear that is both the Communist Party’s strength, but it’s also a huge weakness. They can mobilize entire cities to be on lockdown. They can convince people to stay indoors. They can scrub social media of information that counters their narrative. That’s all very effective when you’re trying to get the public behind your policies. But at the end of the day, the fear is also a huge vulnerability. It creates this system where people are unwilling to speak out, unwilling to bring problems that are really important and that affect people’s lives.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">Right. I mean, for the Chinese leadership, that works until it doesn’t, right? Until you very much need for people to stop being afraid and to speak out about something like a public health crisis.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">Exactly.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">And so when you look at the culture, you wonder whether China can actually contain these viruses, whether we will continue to live in a world where the internal politics of the party are going to put lives around the world in danger.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">Javier, thank you.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">Thanks, Michael.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">On Wednesday, the total number of people infected by the coronavirus in mainland China surpassed those infected with the SARS virus during that epidemic. As of Wednesday evening, the virus had infected more than 6,000 people in mainland China. Later today, the World Health Organization will convene its emergency committee to determine whether the outbreak amounts to a public health emergency of international concern, its most severe classification.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">We’ll be right back.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">Here’s what else you need to know today. The Times reports that the White House has sent former national security adviser, John Bolton, a letter, warning him not to publish a book in which he recounts speaking to President Trump about the quid pro quo with Ukraine at the heart of the impeachment trial. In the letter, the White House claims that the book contains significant amounts of classified information that could harm U.S. national security. The letter was sent before The Times published a story describing the book’s contents, a story that has further fueled calls for Bolton to testify in the Senate trial. Senators are expected to vote on whether to call witnesses like Bolton later today.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd"> That’s it for “The Daily.” I’m Michael Barbaro. See you tomorrow.</p>, <h1 class="css-1xbyom1 edye5kn2">A Virus’s Journey Across China</h1>, <h2 class="css-corlih edye5kn3">Government officials thought they could control the disease and cover up its growing death toll. They were wrong.</h2>, <p class="css-1qi8px4">transcript</p>, <h2 class="css-9wqu2x">A Virus’s Journey Across China</h2>, <h3 class="css-eq2co1">Hosted by Michael Barbaro; produced by Neena Pathak, Annie Brown and Eric Krupke; with help from Kelly Prime; and edited by M.J. Davis Lin and Mike Benoist</h3>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">From The New York Times, I’m Michael Barbaro. This is “The Daily.”</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd"></p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">Today: China says it has made lifesaving reforms since the last time it was the source of a public health crisis 17 years ago. So why is the deadly coronavirus spreading so rapidly across the country? My colleague, Javier Hernández, reports from the center of the outbreak.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">It’s Thursday, January 30.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">Javier, how did you first hear about this outbreak?</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">Well, we started hearing reports in early January that there was this mysterious virus that was affecting Wuhan, which is a city in central China.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">Staff at Wuhan Hospital are working around the clock to identify a mystery virus.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">People were falling ill to this kind of pneumonia-like virus, which scientists were calling a coronavirus.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">Experts believe this is a new kind of coronavirus, which typically causes symptoms of the common cold, but in some rare cases, can lead to pneumonia.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">It’s a very frightening virus that spreads from animals to humans. It was believed to be behind some very serious respiratory illnesses, so it sounded pretty scary. But the official narrative was that this strain couldn’t pass from human to human. It would only go from animals to humans.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">The potentially deadly coronavirus is thought to have spread from animals into humans at a live produce market in Wuhan.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">And at that point, they were saying that it was all originating at a single meat market in central China. This meat market sold wild animals, things like bamboo rats, badgers, wolves even. And the assumption was that people had come into contact with these animals and picked up this virus.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">And it sounds like because it was one meat market, and because this virus could only pass from animals to humans, that this is a pretty small problem.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">At this point, the reports were that only about 130 people had been infected and that, of those, only about four had died.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">Chinese officials say the outbreak is under control.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">And so the prognosis was that the outbreak was controllable, that it was treatable and that things would be O.K.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">And Javier, what are you thinking when you hear the Chinese government talking this way, saying that everything is going to be O.K.?</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">We were a bit skeptical. We knew that the Chinese government had a history of downplaying outbreaks like this. And as we saw more and more reports in the international media of this virus spreading, we began to question whether the officials were being totally upfront about what was happening.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">And what do you mean when you say a history of downplaying situations like this?</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">Well before this virus, there was the outbreak of SARS 17 years ago. And it turned into this global health crisis that infected more than 8,000 people. It killed more than 800 people. And a big part of the reason that it spread so violently was because the Chinese government didn’t tell the world. And there was this period of months and months when it was spreading very rapidly in China, and the world just didn’t know about it. And for a lot of Chinese today, that experience with SARS makes them very skeptical of anything that the government says when it comes to public health.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">And I imagine a reporter like you would be similarly skeptical.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">Right. We really wanted to make sure that we got this one right.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">We wanted to double check that this was, in fact, a small scale outbreak as the government was portraying it. And we wanted to talk to people who were getting sick with this virus to get a sense of what it was like for them — how severe it was, whether they were getting the care they needed.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">And so what do you do?</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">So I live in Beijing. So I rushed to our bureau here and grabbed masks, enough to last me a couple days, and then headed to the airport and boarded a flight to Wuhan. And I just remember everyone on board, almost everyone, was wearing a mask. I was just struck by that. You never see people wear masks on this scale. And so it felt like there was this sense of anxiety already in the air even before we landed.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd"></p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">Once I got there, I rushed off to meet an ambulance doctor who had been posting on social media about this outbreak. And we had contacted him because he was challenging the official narrative about what was happening. He was saying he didn’t believe the official numbers. He thought that this could be another SARS-like outbreak.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">And what was happening to his posts once they went online?</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">They lasted for a while, and then they would be taken down, just disappeared. It was clear that the government was cleaning and trying to scrub the internet of any critical questions about official data. And so we wanted to talk to him about what he was seeing on the ground.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">And what did he tell you?</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">He told me that he felt like people weren’t taking enough precautions, that the government wasn’t being urgent enough. And he worked in a hospital and had a lot of interaction with doctors and other medical workers. So he felt like his job could be at stake if he were to come forward publicly.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">So the numbers the Chinese government is providing are relatively small. This ambulance doctor you’re meeting with is saying the problem is bigger. So what do you do to try to reconcile those two pieces of information?</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">We wanted to find the people whose relatives had fallen ill to this virus. And so we were looking online for people who were reporting symptoms of fever, cough, basically anything that was associated with this kind of virus. And we stumbled on a guy from Shanghai. He was a 40-year-old architect, and he told me that his stepmother had died just a couple of days earlier from a mysterious pneumonia-like illness. And so I found him, sent him a message, and we agreed to meet at a cafe. [CHATTER]</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">And what is the story of what happened to his stepmom?</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">He tells me that she was a very healthy, normal 65-year-old woman who, a couple of weeks earlier, had started to feel like she was having a flu. So she had some coughing. She had kind of a sore throat, but it didn’t seem like anything that bad. But it suddenly began to worsen. She was having a fever. She needed a respirator to breathe. And all very suddenly she was sent to a contagious disease ward, and the family was told that she would likely die.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">And what did she or her stepson understand about what was behind her illness?</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">They didn’t really understand much. For days and days, according to Mr. Wei, the family had tried to get her tested for this coronavirus, this mysterious virus that was spreading across Wuhan. And the doctors and other medical workers refused.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">He pulled out his phone and showed me her death certificate, and all it said was that she died of severe pneumonia.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">But why wouldn’t they test her, and what does it tell you that they wouldn’t test her?</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">It became clear to me in that moment that there seemed to be something going on here. Were these hospitals just not prepared? Did they not have enough testing kits? Were they running out of tests? Had they tested so many people that they didn’t have any tests left? Were they just not counting people anymore because they weren’t even diagnosing them? And if she wasn’t diagnosed with this illness, then maybe she wasn’t even included in the official count. And one other thing really stuck with me from my interview with Mr. Wei. And that was that the hospital, according to him, told them that his mother’s body had to be burned immediately, had to be cremated immediately. [CHATTER]</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">And what does that tell you? What does that mean to you that they’re burning these bodies?</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">It began to put in my head the sense that the hospital workers were beginning to think that this illness was contagious. And the fact that they wanted that body burned immediately began to suggest that perhaps they thought it posed a threat to other people.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">Her death got us thinking about whether there were other people like her. And when you went online and search social media, you could quickly find others who were reporting similar experiences — people saying that they went to hospitals, they brought their sick relatives and were simply turned away. We began to kind of add things up, and it seemed like the numbers weren’t right.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">So at this point, it sounds like your skepticism is growing, and it’s sounding pretty warranted. So what do you do next?</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">So I head back to my hotel and start to try to make sense of all of this. And as I’m sitting there in my room, I begin to see these reports emerging on social media —</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">For the first time since the mysterious pneumonia-like illness broke out in China, the country’s health authorities admitted the disease could be contagious.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">— that one of China’s top health experts has acknowledged that this virus is now spreading from person to person, which had never been the case before.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">[SPEAKING CHINESE]</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">We considered risks of this before, but now evidence has confirmed that it is contagious among humans.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">And he’s an 83-year-old guy that they dug out of retirement essentially. He was a renowned expert during the SARS crisis. And suddenly, he’s all over social media, telling people that this crisis is much worse than had been previously known.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">So this doctor is very much validating what you have been hearing.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">Yes. He’s saying that there was even a case where one patient was able to infect 14 medical workers.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">Wow.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">And I begin to see the panic kind of spread across social media.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">Say I have coronavirus. Could I give it to you right now?</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">It’s possible, if you’re coughing and sneezing. If you have a fever, it can be transmitted.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">But the spread of Corona virus is accelerating.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">This is the moment when the world begins to wake up.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">Meanwhile, new cases are being confirmed outside of China as well.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">Thailand has reported the first case of the Wuhan coronavirus found outside of China.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">— because now they’re talking Thailand, Singapore, possibly Scotland. The U.K. is bracing for it to go in there. We have airports here in the United States very concerned about it —</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">That are doing surveillance.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">— here in New York, Chicago and L.A. Every day it seems growing exponentially.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">It is. It’s growing.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">The numbers after that point just keep spiraling and spiraling.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">The number of people who have died —</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">The death toll climbing once again overnight.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">The death toll from a deadly viral outbreak of the new coronavirus —</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">26 deaths so far from the —</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">— has now passed 40.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">[SPEAKING CHINESE]</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">It’s not just Chinese people who are worried. Everyone is worried. They’re all afraid of dying.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">You just hear people wondering whether the virus is ever going to be contained.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">We’ll be right back.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">And Javier, what are you thinking and feeling at this moment? Because you’re in this city. You’re interacting with people who are taking care of those who are sickened and infected by this illness.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">Yeah.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">Are you anxious?</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">Well I’m beginning to feel like this is much worse than I thought. And I think a sense of paranoia can easily settle in sometimes in these situations. I had masks. I was washing my hands all the time. But I couldn’t help but think about every button in the elevator that I touched, every surface and every cough or sniffle that I saw around me. The virus could be anywhere, so I had to be careful.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">I mean, understandably.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">So I finished up my reporting, and I grabbed a flight back to Beijing.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">Just one day before China’s massive Lunar New Year holiday, as hundreds of millions crisscross the country to celebrate with families, an unprecedented act.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">And then the very next day, I hear —</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">Today, the entire city of Wuhan, population 11 million, is on lockdown.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">The Chinese government has placed this entire city under lockdown.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">Wow.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">Trains, flights, buses, and ferries have been canceled. Even public transport within Wuhan has ground to a halt.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">So the city you have just left has basically told everybody else who remains that they’re not going anywhere.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">Right. This city is being closed off in a way that China has never done before — or even any other major modern city, really, hasn’t done it in recent times.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">Across China tonight, an expanding lockdown to contain an epidemic.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">And it was quickly becoming clear to the government that this wasn’t just a local problem.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">Travel bans in over a dozen cities affecting 35 million people.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">They quickly expanded it to not just Wuhan, but to other cities, so that there were tens of millions of people who were essentially forced to stay at home and not allowed to go out. They’ve just put in place the biggest lockdown that we’ve ever seen and what experts are saying is the biggest experiment in public health that they’ve ever seen.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">Despite their efforts, authorities say the virus has not been stopped.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">Much depends on whether the measures set in place by the Chinese government will prove effective.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">It’s hard to imagine most any other country being able to mount that kind of a response. I mean, I’m just trying to fathom an American city somehow being locked down.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">So this is what it looks like when China’s authoritarian system is in full force. There’s no choice for people to leave. Many people are stuck there. They are going to hospitals that are overcrowded, but they can’t get the health care they need. Doctors are complaining about a lack of medical supplies and critical items like masks and goggles. And you get the sense that people are kind of stuck with what they have, and that’s the bargain they’ve made by living in this system. They have no choice but to follow the government’s orders. They can’t push back. They can’t swim against the current here. Everyone’s essentially forced to comply with this mass lockdown.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">You know, from everything we’ve learned about China and its authoritarian government, it seems like it controls every aspect of its citizens’ lives and it surveils every aspect of citizens’ lives. And you’ve just walked us through how they were able to essentially suddenly drop a wall around Wuhan. So knowing all that, shouldn’t China’s government have been able to identify and control this outbreak before it got out of hand?</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">You would think that, because the government is so well known for being able to pull off these massive displays of citizen mobilization — it’s been known to be able to pull off these technological feats. But at the same time, there’s a flip side of this coin, which is that China’s authoritarian culture, in many ways, set the stage for this crisis.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">What do you mean?</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">Well for decades, China has built this system, this ruthless system in which if you are an official in the Communist Party, you are expected to be almost perfect. If anything goes bad, you are the one who is going to take responsibility. You are the one who is going to fall. And this has created an incentive system where local officials fear saying anything about bad news. They worry that if they are found to have done something wrong, that they will lose their power. So in a situation like this, the incentive is to cover up. It’s to conceal. It’s to delay. It’s to try to get a handle on these problems on your own, hoping that perhaps nobody will ever hear about it.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">So by the time something like, say, a medical crisis gets really big, it may be too late for the local officials who have been trying to contain it themselves and keep it from Beijing.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">Exactly. These kinds of dynamics played a huge role in the scale of the SARS outbreak. It was clear in this case that local officials knew exactly what was going on. They knew that people were dying of this illness. But for months and months, they didn’t want to report it up the chain. Instead, they tried to cover it up. They tried to see if they could perhaps deal with it secretly, and maybe nobody would ever find out about it. They hoped that Beijing would know about it. But eventually it broke.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">So did China learn from that experience with SARS, that dynamic that led to that breakdown, that cover-up?</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">China said it would make a lot of changes to its system after the SARS crisis. It said that it would expand its disease reporting system so that these kinds of reports from the local provinces would come to the central government in a more timely fashion. They promised to be more transparent in the release of data and other things. But what they didn’t change was this authoritarian culture, where people fear bringing bad news. And so that has actually gotten worse under President Xi.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">Why?</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">He has made himself out to be the most powerful leader since Mao. He is somebody who’s always speaking about this great ascendant moment for China in which China is going to be this superpower. And anything that goes against Xi’s vision of this harmonious, resurgent China is going to be seen as a problem. And the people who are creating that problem will pay the consequences. And when I was there in Wuhan, I could sense the fear just rippling across all parts of the society. There were people like the ambulance doctor, who was afraid of challenging the official statistics. There were hospitals that seemed to be paralyzed, that didn’t want to test patients for fear of knowing the results. They didn’t want to be seen as speaking out or telling the truth or bringing this unsavory story into public view.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">So that had trickled down all the way to the frontline health care workers, who are supposed to be treating this and sounding the alarm.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">Right. They’re fearful of being seen as responsible for this crisis. They don’t want to stand out. And when you think about where this virus might be headed next — to other provinces, to other cities — you have to wonder if these same dynamics would be playing out again. If people will stay silent, if they will not report official cases, because they fear for their jobs and they fear for their livelihoods.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">So it seems like whatever reforms the Chinese government made after the failures of SARS, that in the end, none of them really matter, because it hasn’t changed the problem that’s at the root of this.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">At the root of all this is a sense of fear that is both the Communist Party’s strength, but it’s also a huge weakness. They can mobilize entire cities to be on lockdown. They can convince people to stay indoors. They can scrub social media of information that counters their narrative. That’s all very effective when you’re trying to get the public behind your policies. But at the end of the day, the fear is also a huge vulnerability. It creates this system where people are unwilling to speak out, unwilling to bring problems that are really important and that affect people’s lives.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">Right. I mean, for the Chinese leadership, that works until it doesn’t, right? Until you very much need for people to stop being afraid and to speak out about something like a public health crisis.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">Exactly.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">And so when you look at the culture, you wonder whether China can actually contain these viruses, whether we will continue to live in a world where the internal politics of the party are going to put lives around the world in danger.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">Javier, thank you.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">Thanks, Michael.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">On Wednesday, the total number of people infected by the coronavirus in mainland China surpassed those infected with the SARS virus during that epidemic. As of Wednesday evening, the virus had infected more than 6,000 people in mainland China. Later today, the World Health Organization will convene its emergency committee to determine whether the outbreak amounts to a public health emergency of international concern, its most severe classification.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">We’ll be right back.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd">Here’s what else you need to know today. The Times reports that the White House has sent former national security adviser, John Bolton, a letter, warning him not to publish a book in which he recounts speaking to President Trump about the quid pro quo with Ukraine at the heart of the impeachment trial. In the letter, the White House claims that the book contains significant amounts of classified information that could harm U.S. national security. The letter was sent before The Times published a story describing the book’s contents, a story that has further fueled calls for Bolton to testify in the Senate trial. Senators are expected to vote on whether to call witnesses like Bolton later today.</p>, <p class="css-8hvvyd"> That’s it for “The Daily.” I’m Michael Barbaro. See you tomorrow.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10"><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">Listen and subscribe to our podcast from your mobile device:</em></strong><br/><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10"><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://itunes.apple.com/us/podcast/the-daily/id1200361736?mt=2" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title=""><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">Via Apple Podcasts</em></a></strong><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10"><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0"> | </em></strong><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10"><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://open.spotify.com/show/3IM0lmZxpFAY7CwMuv9H4g?si=SfuMSC55R1qprFsRZU3_zw" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title=""><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">Via Spotify</em></a></strong><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10"><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0"> | </em></strong><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10"><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="http://www.stitcher.com/podcast/the-new-york-times/the-daily-10" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title=""><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">Via Stitcher</em></a></strong></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Nearly two decades ago, China was at the heart of a public health crisis over a deadly new virus. It said it had made lifesaving reforms since. So why is the Wuhan coronavirus now spreading so rapidly across the world? Our correspondent went to the center of the outbreak to find out.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">On today’s episode:</strong></p>, <p class="css-15hwz5e evys1bk0"><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/by/javier-c-hernandez" title="">Javier C. Hernández</a>, a New York Times correspondent based in Beijing.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Background reading:</strong></p>, <p class="css-15hwz5e evys1bk0"><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/article/what-is-coronavirus.html?action=click&amp;pgtype=Article&amp;state=default&amp;module=styln-coronavirus&amp;variant=show&amp;region=TOP_BANNER&amp;context=Menu" title="">What is the coronavirus</a>? And <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/29/health/china-coronavirus-outbreak.html?action=click&amp;module=Top%20Stories&amp;pgtype=Homepage" title="">why is China struggling</a> to control its spread around the world?</p>, <p class="css-15hwz5e evys1bk0">Unless you are at high risk for catching the disease, it may be a good idea to <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/29/health/coronavirus-masks-hoarding.html?action=click&amp;module=Top%20Stories&amp;pgtype=Homepage" title="">avoid buying a face mask</a>. There is now a shortage of masks, leaving health care workers unprotected and expediting the spread of the disease.</p>, <h2 class="css-zd32qr">Coronavirus Map: Tracking the Spread of the Outbreak</h2>, <p class="css-1uuihdo">The virus has sickened more than 40,600 people in China and 24 other countries.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">Tune in, and tell us what you think. [<p>Advertisement</p>, <p>Supported by</p>, <h1 class="css-1s4ffep e1h9rw200" id="link-67f2f999" itemprop="headline"><span>Deaths Surpass 200, and State Department Urges Against Travel to China</span></h1>, <p class="css-1ifw933 e1wiw3jv0" id="article-summary">The United States set its advisory at Level 4, which represents the highest safety risk. The World Health Organization said the virus represents a risk outside of China. </p>, <p class="css-1fv7b6t e1jsehar1" itemprop="author" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">By<!-- --> <span class="css-1baulvz last-byline" itemprop="name">The New York Times</span></p>, <h3 class="css-k42qd2 e1gnsphs0">Here’s what you need to know:</h3>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">Read the latest developments in the </em><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/31/world/asia/coronavirus-china.html" title=""><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">coronavirus outbreak here. </em></a></p>, <h2 class="css-3ez4hu eoo0vm40" id="link-66831e75">State Department tells Americans not to travel to China.</h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The State Department on Thursday night issued a <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/02/10/business/china-coronavirus-philippines-travel.html" title="">travel advisory</a> telling Americans not to travel to China because of the public health threat posed by the coronavirus. Secretary of State Mike Pompeo <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://twitter.com/SecPompeo/status/1223063868110524417" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">confirmed the travel advisory on Twitter</a>.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The department set the new advisory at Level 4, or Red, its highest caution, which is reserved for the most dangerous situations.</p>, <h2 class="css-3ez4hu eoo0vm40" id="link-55057142">W.H.O. declares the coronavirus outbreak a global health emergency.</h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The World Health Organization declared on Thursday that the new <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/02/10/upshot/coronavirus-risk-prevention-advice.html" title="">coronavirus outbreak</a> was a global health emergency, acknowledging that the disease represents a risk outside of <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/02/10/business/china-coronavirus-philippines-travel.html" title="">China</a>, where it emerged last month.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The declaration — officially called a Public Health Emergency of International Concern —<span class="css-8l6xbc evw5hdy0"> </span>serves notice to all United Nations member states that the world’s top health advisory body rates the situation as serious. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Countries can then decide whether to close their borders, cancel flights, screen people arriving at airports or take other measures.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The decision came as <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/29/health/china-coronavirus-outbreak.html" title="">cases have begun to appear</a> in people who had not traveled to <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/02/10/upshot/coronavirus-risk-prevention-advice.html" title="">China</a> during the outbreak. </p>, <h2 class="css-3ez4hu eoo0vm40" id="link-737210c3">Italy had a false alarm. And it canceled all flights to China. </h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Prime Minister Giuseppe Conte announced in a Thursday night news conference that Italy had blocked all flights to and from China as the country confirmed its first cases of the coronavirus.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The government announced the country’s first two confirmed cases during the news conference. Officials said they would investigate the movements of the two people, Chinese tourists, and try to identify those they may have been in contact with.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The news capped a tense day in Italy, after <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/30/world/europe/italy-coronavirus-cruise.html" title="">thousands of passengers had been blocked</a> from leaving a cruise ship that docked at an Italian port for more than 12 hours over concerns that someone aboard might have had the virus. That episode was ultimately a false alarm.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">A Chinese national with a fever later tested negative for the coronavirus and the Italian authorities said that passengers were allowed to disembark. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><span class="css-8l6xbc evw5hdy0"> </span></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"> </p>, <h2 class="css-3ez4hu eoo0vm40" id="link-11e0e902">American Airlines pilots’ union is suing to stop some flights to China.</h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The American Airlines pilots’ union said on Thursday that it was suing the airline in an attempt to halt all service between the United States and China, citing “a threat to the safety of passengers and flight crew.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">In a statement, the union, the Allied Pilots Association, said it was instructing its members to turn down requests to fly to China. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The airline had previously announced that, because of declining demand, it would suspend flights from Los Angeles to Beijing and Shanghai starting on Feb. 9. Service from Dallas to those cities is expected to continue.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">In another development, United Airlines on Thursday announced a new wave of cancellations affecting hundreds of flights through the end of March. The cutback, a response to declining demand, will reduce the number of daily flights from 12 to four from its United States hubs to Beijing, Hong Kong and Shanghai.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">In all, the reduction includes 332 round trip cancellations between Feb. 9 and March 28. </p>, <h2 class="css-3ez4hu eoo0vm40" id="link-69c13d84">U.S. reports its first case of person-to-person transmission.</h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Health officials on Thursday reported the first case of person-to-person transmission of the new coronavirus in the United States. </p>, <h1 class="g-headline" id="g-inlineguide-headline">The Coronavirus Outbreak</h1>, <h2 class="g-inlineguide-list-header g-optimize-type">What do you need to know? Start here.</h2>, <p class="g-inlineguide-date">Updated Feb. 10, 2020</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The patient is the husband of a woman who was the first reported case in Chicago, officials said at a news briefing. The woman, who is in her 60s, had returned from Wuhan, China, the epicenter of the virus. She was hospitalized but appears to be doing well, said Dr. Jennifer Layden, an epidemiologist at the Illinois Department of Public Health. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Her husband, who had not traveled to China, recently began showing symptoms and was immediately isolated in the hospital. Lab tests have now confirmed that he was infected with the coronavirus, Dr. Layden said.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Health officials are tracking the places visited by both patients and identifying all close contacts to monitor them. The public is at low risk, officials said. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Person-to-person transmission may occur if someone who is sick breathes, talks, coughs or sneezes in the vicinity of others.
