The number of infections there already exceeds those from SARS, a respiratory infection that spread across the country 17 years ago and killed 774 people worldwide, but experts caution that comparing the two diseases is difficult.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Yesterday: </strong>In an effort to stop further transmission of the virus,<strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10"> </strong>British Airways and Air Canada suspended all flights to the Chinese mainland (but not to Hong Kong).</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Closer look: </strong>The outbreak is a stark reminder of how dependent the world’s economy is on China, <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/29/business/china-coronavirus-economy.html" title="">our business correspondent in Hong Kong writes</a>. Global brands like Starbucks, Ikea, Ford and Toyota are shutting down stores and factories, while Apple is rerouting supply chains.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">What’s next: </strong>If efforts to contain an outbreak fail, public health authorities will focus on minimizing the harm done to people and communities. They’re particularly concerned about <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/29/health/china-coronavirus-outbreak.html" title="">the disease spreading in Africa</a>.</p>, <h2 class="css-3ez4hu eoo0vm40" id="link-44932102">Trump’s peace plan puts Palestinians in a bind</h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The Palestinian leadership largely rejected the Israel-friendly Mideast peace plan that President Trump announced on Tuesday, <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/29/world/middleeast/trump-peace-proposal-palestinians.html" title="">but their options for responding are limited</a>.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">They could choose to push back against it — perhaps by unleashing violence or walking away from the security cooperation that has long helped protect Israelis from terrorism. But that’s unlikely if Mahmoud Abbas, the octogenarian president of the Palestinian Authority, decides to prioritize staying in power.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">A safer option for Mr. Abbas, our correspondents say, would be trying to weather the storm and hoping that Mr. Trump or Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel is defeated in upcoming elections.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Details:</strong> Mr. Trump’s plan departs from decades of American support for only modestly adjusting the Israeli borders drawn in 1967. It would <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/29/world/middleeast/trump-peace-plan-explained.html" title="">deprive the Palestinians of nearly everything they wanted</a>, including East Jerusalem as their national capital and the removal of Jewish settlements on the West Bank. It includes no concrete plans for a fully autonomous Palestinian state.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">What’s next: </strong>The Palestinians have a four-year window to decide whether to engage in renewed talks with Israel, during which Mr. Netanyahu’s government has agreed to limit settlement building in parts of the West Bank that the plan has designated for Palestinians.</p>, <h3 class="css-1b8te77 e1gnsphs0" id="link-fdfe371">If you have some time, this is worth it</h3>, <h2 class="css-3ez4hu eoo0vm40" id="link-7a77b9fe">Loyal to China, but locked up anyway</h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">From the Chinese government’s perspective, Zulhumar Isaac, above, a Uighur woman from the far-western Xinjiang region, grew up in a model ethnic-minority family: Her mother was a Communist Party cadre, and her father worked at a newspaper that toed the party line.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">But when President Xi Jinping’s government began cracking down on Uighurs, even her parents were detained. Our writer spent nearly a year documenting <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/29/magazine/uyghur-muslims-china.html" title="">her effort to get them back</a>.</p>, <h3 class="css-1b8te77 e1gnsphs0" id="link-554e6082">Here’s what else is happening</h3>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Huawei: </strong>The European Union on Wednesday <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/29/world/europe/eu-huawei-5g.html" title="">recommended that its members limit, but not ban, Huawei</a> in their 5G rollouts, a day after Britain said it would let the Chinese company develop nonsensitive parts of its next-generation networks. Germany is expected to make a decision on Huawei in the coming months.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Impeachment: </strong>Republican leaders could <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/live/2020/impeachment-trial-live-01-29" title="">call a vote for President Trump’s acquittal as soon as Friday</a>. But if <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/27/us/politics/impeachment-witnesses-republican-votes.html" title="">four or so Republicans</a> agree to call witnesses and documents, his impeachment trial could continue well into February.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Mike Pompeo in Ukraine:</strong> The U.S. secretary of state, whose boss was impeached over dealings with Ukraine, is scheduled to meet in Kyiv today with the country’s president, Volodymyr Zelensky. (Ukraine — and Mr. Trump’s decision to fire the American ambassador there — figured in Mr. Pompeo’s recent <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/25/us/politics/pompeo-mary-louise-kelly.html" title="">clash with a respected American journalist</a>, who later <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/28/opinion/mike-pompeo-kelly-interview.html" title="">wrote a Times Op-Ed</a> about it.)</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Catching rays: </strong>Thermonuclear reactions inside the sun produce a pop, crackle and snap on its surface. <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/29/science/daniel-inouye-solar-telescope-pictures.html" title="">A new telescope in Hawaii is checking that out</a>.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Snapshot: </strong>Above, the Thwaites glacier in Antarctica, where <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/29/climate/thwaites-glacier-melting-antarctica.html" title="">scientists have recorded unusually warm water</a> beneath the ice. The glacier <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2017/10/26/climate/antarctica-glaciers-melt.html" title="">plays a key role</a> in holding back ice that, if melted, would raise the world’s oceans by nearly four feet over centuries, putting many coastal cities underwater.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">In memoriam: </strong><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/29/world/middleeast/lina-ben-mhenni-dead.html" title="">Lina Ben Mhenni</a>, an activist who blogged about the 2010-11 popular uprising in Tunisia that preceded the Arab Spring revolts, died in Tunis on Monday. She was 36 and had suffered from an autoimmune disease.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">What we’re reading: </strong><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.thecut.com/2020/01/does-dopamine-fasting-work.html" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">This account of an attempt to do the Silicon Valley dopamine fast</a> in The Cut. Melina Delkic, on the Briefings team, calls it “hilarious and weird,” adding, “I’m not sure what I just read, but I liked it.”</p>, <h3 class="css-1b8te77 e1gnsphs0" id="link-7ded7ef4">Now, a break from the news</h3>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Cook: </strong>Take comfort in this recipe for <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://cooking.nytimes.com/recipes/1020775-cheesy-cornbread-muffins-with-hot-honey-butter" title="">cheesy cornbread muffins with hot honey butter</a>.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Read: </strong>The actor Antonio Banderas <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/29/movies/antonio-banderas-oscars.html" title="">told our reporter about his recent Oscar nomination</a> and the heart attack that changed his life.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Go:</strong> Here’s <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/29/travel/cheaper-skiing-in-europe.html" title="">how to ski in Europe on a tight budget</a>. (Think Cervinia and Brides les Bains over Zermatt and Courchevel.)</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Smarter Living: </strong>Not everyone develops social skills as a child. <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/23/smarter-living/adults-guide-to-social-skills.html" title="">Here’s a primer for adults</a>.</p>, <h3 class="css-1b8te77 e1gnsphs0" id="link-15767e9b">And now for the Back Story on …</h3>, <h2 class="css-3ez4hu eoo0vm40" id="link-549b5492">Gandhi’s mantle</h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">Today is the 72nd anniversary of the death of Mohandas Gandhi, who helped win India’s independence from Britain with a campaign of nonviolence and enshrined protections for all religions. Protesters </em><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/30/world/asia/india-gandhi-modi-citizenship.html" title=""><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">challenging Prime Minister Narendra Modi’s Hindu-nationalist agenda</em></a><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0"> have been evoking Gandhi’s legacy — but </em><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2019/10/02/opinion/modi-mahatma-gandhi.html" title=""><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">so is Mr. Modi</em></a><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">, to promote nationalism. </em><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://twitter.com/Abihabib?ref_src=twsrc%5Egoogle%7Ctwcamp%5Eserp%7Ctwgr%5Eauthor" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title=""><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">Maria Abi-Habib</em></a><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">, a South Asia correspondent for The Times, spoke with Mike<span class="css-8l6xbc evw5hdy0"> </span>about the clash.</em></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">How have the protests changed since they started a few months ago?</strong></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">They’re <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2019/12/24/world/asia/india-protests-modi.html" title="">a lot broader</a>. It’s not just Muslims or a bunch of liberal students, it’s people who see the India that Gandhi built, one of secularism and religious coexistence, giving way to a government that is bent on a sectarian narrative at a time when the economy is sputtering.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Do any scenes spring to mind?</strong></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Some protesters held a placard that read: “Dear Hindus, We rejected an Islamic state in 1947. Now it’s your turn to reject a Hindu state. Sincerely, Secular India.” That really spoke to me because 1947 was the partition, when Hindus in Pakistan decided to stay or flee to India, and Muslims in India had a similar choice.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">India chose secularism in 1947. It was majority Hindu and said its strength was its diversity, and that it would embrace Christians and Muslims and Sikhs just as much as its Hindu citizens. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Why is one protest in particular — a highway sit-in by Muslim women in Delhi’s Shaheen Bagh neighborhood — seen as so significant?</strong></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Over all, India’s Muslim community has not been well organized in recent decades, but <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/04/world/asia/india-protests-modi-citizenship.html" title="">these protests have mobilized it</a>. Shaheen Bagh has become a symbol of that. And women’s place in Indian Muslim homes has tended to be a conservative stereotype: They don’t come onto the streets, they don’t protest, they don’t mobilize. So Shaheen Bagh has really changed the game.</p>, <p class="css-ma92ss evys1bk0">That’s it for this briefing. See you next time.</p>, <p class="css-ma92ss evys1bk0">— Sofia and Mike</p>, <p class="css-jwz2nf etfikam0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Thank you</strong><br/>To Mark Josephson and Eleanor Stanford for the break from the news. You can reach the team at <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="mailto:briefing+midnight@nytimes.com?subject=Briefing%20Feedback" title="">briefing@nytimes.com</a>.</p>, <p class="css-jwz2nf etfikam0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">P.S.</strong><br/>• We’re listening to “<a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/thedaily" title="">The Daily</a>.” Our latest episode includes an interview with Senator Chuck Schumer, the minority leader.<br/>• Here’s today’s <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/crosswords/game/mini" title="">Mini Crossword puzzle</a>, and a clue: Highly capable (five letters). <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/crosswords" title="">You can find all our puzzles here</a>.<br/>• <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/28/business/media/ben-smith-buzzfeed-new-york-times.html" title="">The Times has named Ben Smith</a>, the editor in chief of BuzzFeed, as its next media columnist.</p>, <p>Advertisement</p>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd" id="site-index-label">Site Index</h2>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-0">news</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-1">opinion</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-2">arts</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-3">living</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-4">more</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-subscribe-label">Subscribe</h3>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd">Site Information Navigation</h2>]
[<p>Advertisement</p>, <p>Supported by</p>, <p class="css-c2jxua e6idgb70"></p>, <h1 class="css-1j5ig2m e1h9rw200" id="link-53f56bb5" itemprop="headline"><span>Philippines Confirms First Case of New Coronavirus: Health Minister</span></h1>, <p class="css-1fv7b6t e1jsehar1" itemprop="author" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">By<!-- --> <span class="css-1baulvz last-byline" itemprop="name">Reuters</span></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">MANILA — Philippine health officials have confirmed the first case of the new coronavirus in the country. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">A 38-year-old Chinese woman, who arrived in the country from Wuhan, China, on Jan. 21, tested positive for the novel coronavirus, Health Secretary Francisco Duque told a news conference. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Duque said the patient, confined in a government hospital, is currently asymptomatic. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"> (Reporting by Karen Lema; Editing by Alison Williams)</p>, <p>Advertisement</p>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd" id="site-index-label">Site Index</h2>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-0">news</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-1">opinion</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-2">arts</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-3">living</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-4">more</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-subscribe-label">Subscribe</h3>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd">Site Information Navigation</h2>]
[<p>Advertisement</p>, <p>Supported by</p>, <p class="css-c2jxua e6idgb70"></p>, <h1 class="css-1j5ig2m e1h9rw200" id="link-57c4821c" itemprop="headline"><span>Ikea Closes All Stores in China Due to Coronavirus Outbreak</span></h1>, <p class="css-1fv7b6t e1jsehar1" itemprop="author" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">By<!-- --> <span class="css-1baulvz last-byline" itemprop="name">Reuters</span></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">BEIJING — Sweden's IKEA said on Thursday that it has temporarily closed all its stores in China because of the outbreak of the new coronavirus.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The decision to close all of its 30 stores follows an announcement from world's biggest furniture retailer on Wednesday that it was closing around half of its stores and shortening the opening hours.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The total number of confirmed deaths from the coronavirus in China has risen by 38 to 170 as of Wednesday, as the number of infected patients rose by more than 1,700.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"> (Reporting by Muyu Xu and Tony Munroe; Editing by Christian Schmollinger)</p>, <p>Advertisement</p>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd" id="site-index-label">Site Index</h2>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-0">news</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-1">opinion</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-2">arts</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-3">living</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-4">more</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-subscribe-label">Subscribe</h3>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd">Site Information Navigation</h2>]
[<p>Advertisement</p>, <p>Supported by</p>, <p class="css-c2jxua e6idgb70"></p>, <h1 class="css-1j5ig2m e1h9rw200" id="link-496933a6" itemprop="headline"><span>Factbox: What Do We Know About the New Coronavirus?</span></h1>, <p class="css-1fv7b6t e1jsehar1" itemprop="author" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">By<!-- --> <span class="css-1baulvz last-byline" itemprop="name">Reuters</span></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">(Reuters) - A new coronavirus that has killed more than 130 people in China is spreading to other countries, alarming health experts.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Here is some of what we know - and don't know - about the virus:</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">WHERE DID THE VIRUS COME FROM?</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The virus is believed to have originated late last year in a food market in the Chinese city of Wuhan that was illegally selling wildlife. Health experts think it may have originated in bats and then passed to humans, possibly via another animal species.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The World Health Organization (WHO) was alerted to several cases of pneumonia in Wuhan at the end of December. Chinese authorities confirmed they had identified a new virus a week later.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">HOW DANGEROUS IS IT?</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The new virus, identified by scientists as 2019-nCoV, is a coronavirus, a family of viruses that include the common cold and more serious diseases such as Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome (SARS).</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Coronavirus infections have a wide range of symptoms, including fever, cough, shortness of breath, and breathing difficulties.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">It is unclear how deadly the new virus is. Although severe cases can cause pneumonia and death, there may be many cases of milder disease going undetected. Many of those who have died had pre-existing medical conditions or were elderly, those with weakened immune systems.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">HOW IS IT TRANSMITTED AND HOW CAN IT BE PREVENTED?</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The new coronavirus can be transmitted from person to person, although it is not clear how easily that happens. Most cases so far are in people who have been in Wuhan, family members of those infected, or medical workers.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Transmission is most likely through close contact with an infected person via particles in the air from coughing or sneezing, or by someone touching an infected person or object with the virus on it and then touching their mouth, nose or eyes.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">In order to reduce the likelihood of transmission, the WHO recommends that people frequently wash their hands, cover their mouth and nose when sneezing or coughing, and avoid close contact with those who are sick.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention says those who develop symptoms such as coughing and fever who have been in China in the last 14 days should call ahead to a healthcare professional to establish if they need to be tested.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">WHERE HAS IT SPREAD TO SO FAR?</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">All but around 70 of the more than 6,000 cases so far identified have been in China, mostly in and around Wuhan. The other countries with confirmed cases include Australia, Cambodia, Canada, France, Germany, Japan, Malaysia, Nepal, Sri Lanka, Singapore, Thailand, South Korea, the UAE, the United States, and Vietnam.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The WHO is looking very closely at cases of person-to-person transmission outside of Wuhan, which would suggest that it may have the potential to spread further.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">WHAT ARE AUTHORITIES DOING?</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The Chinese government has put Wuhan into virtual quarantine to try and stop the spread of the virus. A number of foreign governments have advised against non-essential travel to China and have begun flying their citizens out of Wuhan.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">IS THIS LIKE SARS?</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The new virus is a strain of coronavirus, like SARS, which killed nearly 800 people globally in 2002 and 2003.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Unlike SARS, which also originated in China, it is believed the new virus can spread during the incubation period of one to 14 days, possibly before an infected person is showing symptoms.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">So far, the new virus does not appear to be as deadly as SARS, but there have been more cases overall.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"> (Compiled by Alex Richardson and Rosalba O'Brien; Edited by Bill Berkrot)</p>, <p>Advertisement</p>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd" id="site-index-label">Site Index</h2>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-0">news</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-1">opinion</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-2">arts</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-3">living</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-4">more</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-subscribe-label">Subscribe</h3>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd">Site Information Navigation</h2>]

[<p>Advertisement</p>, <p>Supported by</p>, <p class="css-c2jxua e6idgb70"></p>, <h1 class="css-1j5ig2m e1h9rw200" id="link-42f3a0a1" itemprop="headline"><span>Mondelez Sees First Quarter Revenue Hit on Coronavirus Outbreak</span></h1>, <p class="css-1fv7b6t e1jsehar1" itemprop="author" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">By<!-- --> <span class="css-1baulvz last-byline" itemprop="name">Reuters</span></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">(Reuters) - Oreo maker Mondelez Inc said on Wednesday it expects a hit to its first quarter revenue from a new coronavirus outbreak in China which has killed over 130 people.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Chief Executive Officer Dirk Van de Put said it was still too early to quantify the impact.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The company also said it has imposed some restrictions on employees' travelling within or to China.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"> (Reporting by Uday Sampath in Bengaluru; Editing by Shinjini Ganguli)</p>, <p>Advertisement</p>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd" id="site-index-label">Site Index</h2>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-0">news</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-1">opinion</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-2">arts</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-3">living</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-4">more</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-subscribe-label">Subscribe</h3>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd">Site Information Navigation</h2>]
[<p>Advertisement</p>, <p>Supported by</p>, <p class="css-c2jxua e6idgb70"></p>, <h1 class="css-1j5ig2m e1h9rw200" id="link-4061d4c0" itemprop="headline"><span>China's Hubei Says Coronavirus Deaths Rise to 162 in Province</span></h1>, <p class="css-1fv7b6t e1jsehar1" itemprop="author" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">By<!-- --> <span class="css-1baulvz last-byline" itemprop="name">Reuters</span></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">(Reuters) - The health commission for Hubei, the Chinese province at the centre of the new coronavirus outbreak, said on Thursday that deaths in the province from the disease had risen by 37 to 162 as of the end of Jan. 29.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">There had been a further 1,032 cases detected in Hubei, taking the total to 4,586, it said.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Foreign governments have been flying their citizens out of the area, as the number of deaths jumped and the World Health Organization has voiced "grave concern" about person-to-person spread in three other countries.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"> (Reporting by Pei Li in Beijing, Writing by Rosalba O'Brien; editing by Diane Craft)</p>, <p>Advertisement</p>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd" id="site-index-label">Site Index</h2>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-0">news</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-1">opinion</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-2">arts</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-3">living</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-4">more</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-subscribe-label">Subscribe</h3>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd">Site Information Navigation</h2>]
[<p>Advertisement</p>, <p>Supported by</p>, <p class="css-c2jxua e6idgb70"></p>, <h1 class="css-1j5ig2m e1h9rw200" id="link-535e0668" itemprop="headline"><span>Vietnam Says Three New Cases of Coronavirus Detected: State Media</span></h1>, <p class="css-1fv7b6t e1jsehar1" itemprop="author" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">By<!-- --> <span class="css-1baulvz last-byline" itemprop="name">Reuters</span></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">HANOI — Three new cases of coronavirus have emerged in Vietnam, the official health ministry newspaper said on Thursday, bringing the number of active cases in the Southeast Asian country to four.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Two people are being treated for the virus in the capital Hanoi, the Suc Khoe &amp; Doi Song newspaper said. Another is receiving treatment in the northern province of Thanh Hoa, 160 km (100 miles) from Hanoi, the report said.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">All three recently returned from the Chinese city of Wuhan, where the new virus was first identified, it added.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Last week, the health ministry said two Chinese citizens in Vietnam had tested positive for coronavirus. One has since recovered.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"> (Reporting by Phuong Nguyen and Khanh Vu; Writing by James Pearson; editing by John Stonestreet)</p>, <p>Advertisement</p>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd" id="site-index-label">Site Index</h2>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-0">news</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-1">opinion</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-2">arts</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-3">living</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-4">more</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-subscribe-label">Subscribe</h3>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd">Site Information Navigation</h2>]
[<p>Advertisement</p>, <p>Supported by</p>, <p class="css-c2jxua e6idgb70"></p>, <h1 class="css-1j5ig2m e1h9rw200" id="link-b023eb1" itemprop="headline"><span>Coronavirus Outbreak Poses Risk to U.S. Fed's Economic Outlook</span></h1>, <p class="css-1fv7b6t e1jsehar1" itemprop="author" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">By<!-- --> <span class="css-1baulvz last-byline" itemprop="name">Reuters</span></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">SAN FRANCISCO/WASHINGTON — The outbreak of a new virus that originated in the central-Chinese city of Wuhan is likely to slow China's economic growth at least in the near term and could hurt its trading partners around the world.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The potential effects of the spread of the coronavirus, which has sickened more than 6,000, mostly in China, and killed 133 since its detection early last month, took centre stage in U.S. Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell's news conference on Wednesday following the central bank's widely expected decision to keep interest rates unchanged. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The Fed is "very carefully monitoring the situation," Powell told reporters.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">While Powell noted that it is "too early to say" what the extent of the impact on the United States will be, he said it is "a significant thing which will have some effects on the Chinese economy, at least in the short term."</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">A Chinese government economist earlier on Wednesday projected the outbreak would cut China's first-quarter growth by one percentage point to 5% or lower. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Powell also acknowledged the risks, including to the U.S. economy, from any slowdown in the world's second-biggest economy. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">"China's economy is very important in the global economy now, and when China's economy slows down we do feel that - not as much though as countries that are near China, or that trade more actively with China, like some of the Western European countries," Powell said.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">China has imposed travel restrictions and shut businesses and schools in an attempt to contain the outbreak, but it has not quelled rising concern among companies and governments across the world, some of whom are taking swift action. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Airlines including British Airways, United Airlines and Lufthansa are cutting or suspending flights, tourists are cancelling trips, and businesses including Apple and Starbucks are warning of the potential impact on their supply chains and sales. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Starbucks has closed more than half its cafes in China and Walt Disney shut its resorts and theme parks in Shanghai and Hong Kong during what is usually its busiest time of year. Alphabet Inc's Google has said it is temporarily shutting down its offices in China, Hong Kong and Taiwan. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">"The coronavirus will likely have the largest negative impact on goods and services sectors within and outside of China that rely on Chinese consumers and intermediary products," Moody's analysts said in a report on Wednesday.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The assessments suggest the impact could be larger than that of the 2002-2003 Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome (SARS) epidemic, the last novel virus to cause global alarm.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">That outbreak resulted in about 800 deaths and slowed Asia's economic growth. But the overall effect on the U.S. economy was ultimately limited and short-lived. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">But as the Moody's analysts and others point out, China accounts for a bigger share of global economic growth now than it did then, and the world is more closely connected.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Over the past week, amid news of coronavirus cases in the United States and more than a dozen other countries, trading in U.S. Treasuries reflected rising concern about a spillover effect.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Futures tied to the Fed's target policy rate also moved in the past week, and are now pricing in bets the Fed will cut interest rates again in July.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">CAREFUL COMMENTS</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">In his news conference on Wednesday, Powell gave no hint the central bank plans to lower borrowing costs anytime soon. Indeed, he suggested the global risks from uncertain trade policy and slowing global growth, which prompted the Fed's three rate cuts in 2019, looked to be receding, prompting "cautious optimism" on the U.S. economic outlook this year. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Still, his careful comments about the impact of the coronavirus outbreak likely reflects behind-the-scenes work by Fed staffers, who brief policymakers at each meeting on risks to the economic outlook. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The Fed's May 2003 policy meeting, which occurred as the extent of the SARS epidemic was becoming apparent, began with a briefing on uncertainties, including the effect of the outbreak on various Asian economies and the potential knock-on impact for the U.S. economy, a transcript of the meeting shows.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Staff at the time modelled a worst-case "SARS demand shock" showing a 0.3 percentage point hit to U.S. GDP growth in the second half of 2003, with the impact lasting to the first half of 2004. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"> (Reporting by Ann Saphir and Lindsay Dunsmuir in Washington; Editing by Paul Simao)</p>, <p>Advertisement</p>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd" id="site-index-label">Site Index</h2>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-0">news</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-1">opinion</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-2">arts</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-3">living</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-4">more</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-subscribe-label">Subscribe</h3>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd">Site Information Navigation</h2>]
[<p>Advertisement</p>, <p>Supported by</p>, <p class="css-c2jxua e6idgb70"></p>, <h1 class="css-1j5ig2m e1h9rw200" id="link-221172e8" itemprop="headline"><span>UK Delays Evacuation Flight From Coronavirus Epicenter in China</span></h1>, <p class="css-1fv7b6t e1jsehar1" itemprop="author" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">By<!-- --> <span class="css-1baulvz last-byline" itemprop="name">Reuters</span></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">LONDON — Britain has been forced to delay a planned evacuation of its citizens from the Chinese city of Wuhan, the epicenter of a coronavirus outbreak, because it has not yet got the correct permissions from Chinese authorities for a flight to leave.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Britain had planned to fly back its citizens to a military base but the flight is now unlikely to take off on Thursday. It is hoped that the flight may depart on Friday instead, according to British sources.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">"We are doing everything we can to get British people in Wuhan safely back to the UK," a Foreign Office spokeswoman said.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">"A number of countries’ flights have been unable to take off as planned. We continue working urgently to organize a flight to the UK as soon as possible."</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Those returning to the United Kingdom will be quarantined for 14 days at a National Health Service facility once they return. Those already infected will not be allowed to leave Wuhan.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Countries have begun isolating hundreds of citizens evacuated from Wuhan in an effort to stop the global spread of an epidemic that has killed 170, with South Korea calling for calm in the face of protests at a quarantine center.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Some British citizens have spoken of being told they are unable to bring family members with Chinese passports out of the city. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Natalie Francis, 31, an English teacher in Wuhan, said she was told by the Foreign Office that she could not bring her three-year-old son, Jamie, home because he has a Chinese passport even though he is a British citizen.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">"They said anyone with Chinese nationality or other citizenship is not being allowed to go on," Francis told The Sun newspaper.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">"I'm like, 'So yeah, you want me to just abandon my son in China, and go home?'"</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"> (Writing by Guy Faulconbridge; editing by James Davey)</p>, <p>Advertisement</p>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd" id="site-index-label">Site Index</h2>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-0">news</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-1">opinion</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-2">arts</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-3">living</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-4">more</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-subscribe-label">Subscribe</h3>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd">Site Information Navigation</h2>]
[<p>Advertisement</p>, <p>Supported by</p>, <h1 class="css-1s4ffep e1h9rw200" id="link-2e056b39" itemprop="headline"><span>Coronavirus, India Citizenship Protests, Brexit: Your Friday Briefing</span></h1>, <p class="css-1ifw933 e1wiw3jv0" id="article-summary">Here’s what you need to know.</p>, <p class="css-1fv7b6t e1jsehar1" itemprop="author" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">By<!-- --> <a class="css-brehiz e1jsehar0" href="https://www.nytimes.com/by/melina-delkic"><span class="css-1baulvz last-byline" itemprop="name">Melina Delkic</span></a></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">(Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/morning-briefing" title="">sign-up</a>.)</p>, <p class="css-ma92ss evys1bk0">Good morning.</p>, <p class="css-ma92ss evys1bk0">We’re covering the panic around the <strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Wuhan coronavirus</strong>, a battle for <strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Gandhi’s legacy</strong> and <strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Brad Pitt</strong>’s beauty trap.</p>, <h2 class="css-3ez4hu eoo0vm40" id="link-1840aa83">Coronavirus shuts borders and fuels xenophobia</h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Russia closed off part of its 2,600-mile eastern border to China as the number of confirmed cases worldwide surpassed 7,700, by far the most still in China. <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/30/world/asia/coronavirus-china.html" title="">Here are the latest updates</a>.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">More than a dozen countries, including the U.S., are <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/29/health/china-coronavirus-outbreak.html" title="">isolating patients and screening travelers from China</a>. No deaths from the respiratory disease have been recorded outside mainland China, where the toll rose to 170.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Fears that a sick passenger had the coronavirus led the Italian authorities to <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/30/world/europe/italy-coronavirus-cruise.html" title="">block more than 1,000 people from disembarking</a> a cruise ship in a port town, until the passenger and her husband could be tested. And from Asia to Canada, the panic has <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/30/world/asia/coronavirus-chinese-racism.html" title="">unleashed anti-Chinese sentiment</a>.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">In the U.S.:</strong> The <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/30/world/asia/coronavirus-china.html" title="">first person-to-person transmission</a>, the husband of a woman who recently returned from Wuhan, was documented in Illinois.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">World Health Organization:</strong> Officials <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/30/health/coronavirus-world-health-organization.html" title="">declared the outbreak a global health emergency</a>. The declaration has no force of law or practical effect, but it adds urgency to any W.H.O. appeal for money to fight it.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">The Daily:</strong> <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/thedaily" title="">Our latest episode</a> is about the virus.</p>, <h2 class="css-3ez4hu eoo0vm40" id="link-7adc1c0e">Who gets to claim Gandhi?</h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/30/world/asia/india-gandhi-modi-citizenship.html" title="">The Indian icon is being pulled into</a> the growing tension between Prime Minister Narendra Modi and protesters challenging his Hindu-centric vision for India.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Mr. Modi and his Bharatiya Janata Party have invoked Gandhi in speeches and pamphlets, saying he would have supported a contentious citizenship law.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The protesters — who see the law as discriminatory, <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2019/08/17/world/asia/india-muslims-narendra-modi.html" title="">with the potential to strip Muslims of citizenship</a> — point out that Gandhi sought protections for Muslims.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Where Gandhi stood:</strong> He envisioned the peaceful coexistence of Muslims and Hindus under a secular government. He was killed 72 years ago by a Hindu nationalist nurtured by the same hard-line group that shaped Mr. Modi.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Quotable:</strong> “You can’t have Einstein without relativity,” said a biographer of Gandhi. “You can’t have Darwin without evolution. And you can’t have Gandhi without Hindu-Muslim harmony.”</p>, <h2 class="css-3ez4hu eoo0vm40" id="link-6796e474">Brexit is here (a headline years in the making)</h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Britain is scheduled to formally withdraw from the European Union on Friday, after more than three years of confusion, political division and missed deadlines.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">At 11 p.m. local time, the end of that chapter will arrive, a relief to many Brexiteers.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">But <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/29/business/brexit-scotland-trade-eu.html" title="">a potentially volatile new chapter</a> — in which London and Brussels try to hash out a trade deal by the end of the year — is just beginning as Britain enters a transition phase.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Fun detail:</strong> The E.U.<strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10"> </strong><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/30/world/europe/eu-brexit-decision.html" title="">gave a last seal of approval</a> to the withdrawal agreement on Thursday. The end was <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/30/world/europe/eu-brexit-decision.html" title="">undramatic and bureaucratic</a> (that is, quintessentially Brussels): Four dry, procedural questions were emailed to the 27 nations in the European Council with instructions to respond with “yes,” “no” or “abstain.” You can expect a lot of steps in the process to be this muted.</p>, <h3 class="css-1b8te77 e1gnsphs0" id="link-108b69c0">If you have eight minutes, this is worth it</h3>, <h2 class="css-3ez4hu eoo0vm40" id="link-264d2bcf">Brad Pitt and the beauty trap</h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">William Bradley Pitt was born in 1963. But Brad Pitt, our co-chief film critic writes, sprang forth in a 13-second scene in the 1991 film “Thelma &amp; Louise” in which the camera panned from his chest to his face in an “ode to eroticized masculine beauty.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Ever since, his life has been closely watched and his acting skills undervalued — by the academy, fans, journalists and casting directors alike. But what he’s really done is create <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/30/movies/brad-pitt-oscar.html" title="">complex and understated portrayals of masculinity</a>.</p>, <h3 class="css-1b8te77 e1gnsphs0" id="link-554e6082">Here’s what else is happening</h3>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Carlos Ghosn: </strong>Japan <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/30/business/carlos-ghosn-arrest-warrants.html" title="">issued arrest warrants for three Americans</a> in connection with the escape of the former Nissan chairman, who fled the country while awaiting trial on charges of financial wrongdoing.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Get crackin’: </strong>A sculpture outside C.I.A. headquarters contains an encrypted message that hasn’t been fully decoded for almost 30 years. <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2020/01/29/climate/kryptos-sculpture-final-clue.html" title="">Its creator has offered a new clue</a>.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">The Guardian: </strong>The British newspaper said it was <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/30/business/media/guardian-climate-change-fossil-fuel-advertisements.html" title="">no longer accepting advertisements</a> from oil and gas companies, making it one of the latest institutions to limit financial ties to fossil fuel businesses.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Snapshot: </strong>Above, the surface of the sun in a high-resolution image captured by <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/29/science/daniel-inouye-solar-telescope-pictures.html" title="">a new telescope in Hawaii</a>. The cell-like “kernels,” each about the size of Texas, carry heat from inside the sun to the outside.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Australian Open:</strong> Novak Djokovic defeated Roger Federer on Thursday, putting his eighth Australian single’s title in reach. He will face the winner of today’s match between <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/30/sports/tennis/djokovic-federer-australian-open.html" title="">Dominic Thiem and Alexander Zverev</a> in Sunday’s final.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">What we’re reading: </strong><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://clevelandmagazine.com/in-the-cle/commentary/articles/when-the-lake-freezes" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">This essay in Cleveland Magazine.</a> Stephen Hiltner, an editor on the Travel desk, writes: “Dave Lucas, Ohio’s poet laureate, ruminates on the beauty and the mystery of Lake Erie’s annual freeze.”</p>, <h3 class="css-1b8te77 e1gnsphs0" id="link-7ded7ef4">Now, a break from the news</h3>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Cook: </strong><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://cooking.nytimes.com/recipes/1019818-sausage-and-peppers-pasta-with-broccoli" title="">Sausage and peppers pasta with broccoli</a> riffs on a classic Italian combination.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Watch: </strong>We spoke to <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/28/movies/george-mackay-1917-trench-run.html" title="">the actor George MacKay</a> about how he pulled off the thrilling final run in the film “1917.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Read:</strong> “A Very Stable Genius,” by the Pulitzer Prize-winning journalists Philip Rucker and Carol Leonnig, is a No. 1 debut on our <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/books/best-sellers/hardcover-nonfiction/2020/02/09" title="">hardcover nonfiction</a> and <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/books/best-sellers/combined-print-and-e-book-nonfiction/2020/02/09" title="">combined print and e-book nonfiction</a> best-seller lists.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Smarter Living: </strong>When donating to environmental organizations, it can be hard to figure out who’s actually making a difference. Here’s <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/29/climate/nyt-climate-newsletter-donations.html" title="">what to look for</a>.</p>, <h3 class="css-1b8te77 e1gnsphs0" id="link-15767e9b">And now for the Back Story on …</h3>, <h2 class="css-3ez4hu eoo0vm40" id="link-4e322af3">The ethics of watching the Super Bowl</h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">On Sunday night, around 100 million people are expected to tune in for the ultimate national<span class="css-8l6xbc evw5hdy0"> </span>party: the Super Bowl. But with growing concern over the violence of American football, what are the ethics of watching the biggest sporting event of the year? </em><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/30/arts/television/super-bowl-why-watch.html" title=""><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">Our culture critics have their own take</em></a><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">. Here’s what Ken Belson, who has been reporting on C.T.E., the degenerative brain disease linked to repeated head hits, told our Briefings teammate Remy Tumin.</em></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">What keeps fans coming back?</strong></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">It’s an event that transcends the sport. The N.F.L. has been brilliant in turning it into a spectacle, and there’s nothing like it. That’s partly because of how the league has structured it — one final game, winner takes all, in a neutral city, on the first Sunday of February, every year. Other sports don’t have the same permanency.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">You’ll be watching from the Hard Rock Stadium in Miami. What can you see that viewers can’t?</strong></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Often when there’s an injury timeout, they go to commercial. I’ll be able to see doctors attending players, including a<span class="css-8l6xbc evw5hdy0"> </span>neuro-trauma consultant who’s on the sidelines (they wear a red hat). If you see them get involved, it means someone has had a concussion.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">What would you say to fans who are having moral issues?</strong></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">It’s a collision sport at heart, and if you don’t want see it, turn on something else. If you can’t reconcile that violence, and it is violence, then there are many other sports. I think it’s O.K. to watch it and have misgivings. It’s human nature — you can both admire and be horrified by the same thing.</p>, <p class="css-ma92ss evys1bk0">That’s it for this briefing. I will be out next week on vacation, but you’ll be in great hands with my colleague Penn Bullock.</p>, <p class="css-ma92ss evys1bk0">Have a great weekend.</p>, <p class="css-ma92ss evys1bk0">— Melina</p>, <p class="css-jwz2nf etfikam0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Thank you</strong><br/>Mark Josephson, Eleanor Stanford and Chris Harcum provided the break from the news. You can reach the team at <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="mailto:briefing+pm@nytimes.com?subject=Briefing%20Feedback" title="">briefing@nytimes.com</a>.</p>, <p class="css-jwz2nf etfikam0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">P.S.</strong><br/>• We’re listening to “<a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/thedaily" title="">The Daily</a>.” Our latest episode is about the coronavirus outbreak.<br/>• Here’s our <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/crosswords/game/mini" title="">Mini Crossword</a>, and a clue: Highly capable (five letters). <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/crosswords" title="">You can find all our puzzles here</a>.<br/>• Copies of The New York Times Magazine’s “1619 Project” are back in stock for the final time in <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://store.nytimes.com/products/the-1619-project" title="">our online store</a>.</p>, <p>Advertisement</p>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd" id="site-index-label">Site Index</h2>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-0">news</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-1">opinion</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-2">arts</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-3">living</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-4">more</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-subscribe-label">Subscribe</h3>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd">Site Information Navigation</h2>]
[<p>Advertisement</p>, <p>Supported by</p>, <p class="css-c2jxua e6idgb70"></p>, <h1 class="css-1j5ig2m e1h9rw200" id="link-324bcefc" itemprop="headline"><span>'I'm in an Apocalypse:' American Student Trapped in Coronavirus-Hit Chinese City</span></h1>, <p class="css-1fv7b6t e1jsehar1" itemprop="author" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">By<!-- --> <span class="css-1baulvz last-byline" itemprop="name">Reuters</span></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">(Reuters) - For almost a week, 21-year-old American-born college student Nicholas Schneider has been trying and failing to find a way out of Wuhan, China, the quarantined city at the heart of a fast-spreading coronavirus outbreak.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">An eerie calm has descended on the normally bustling streets of the city of 11 million people, where Schneider has been studying geodesy - a branch of applied mathematics - at Wuhan University, about 10 miles (16 km) from where experts believe the new coronavirus originated in a market illegally trading in wildlife. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">"It's like a ghost town, barely any people and cars. It's a weird feeling. I feel like I'm in an apocalypse somehow," said Schneider in a phone interview with Reuters on Wednesday.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Chinese officials cut most transport links to Wuhan on Jan. 23 in an effort to slow transmission of the virus, which has infected nearly 6,000 people in China - more cases than were recorded in the 2002-2003 SARS outbreak - and killed more than 130 people.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Schneider, who holds dual U.S.-German citizenship, thought of dashing to a train out of the city that morning, but said his parents advised against it. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">"They said that the train station was not the place to be at time like this with the virus," he said. "So I decided to stay ... and that's when I was scared for the first time because I didn't know what to do."</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">He contacted German and American officials seeking a way out. The U.S. embassy offered him a $1,100 seat on a charter flight, he said.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">But an embassy official told him he would have to get himself to the airport on the other side of Wuhan, 30 miles (48 km) away, he said. With most transportation down, he found no way to make the trip, and an embassy staff member told him that they would give his seat to someone else, Schneider said. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">"I couldn't believe what I just heard. That's not how you deal with a citizen in need ... it seemed like she didn't care," Schneider said.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">That flight left Wuhan with 210 Americans aboard. It was due to arrive in California on Wednesday.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">"Priority was given to vulnerable individuals at higher risk from coronavirus: small children, older adults and persons with other health conditions that put them at greater risk," a State Department official said by email on Wednesday.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Schneider, who has lived most of his life in Germany, then turned to German embassy officials, who he said promised him a bus ride to the airport with several other stranded students and seat on a flight to Germany on Saturday. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Representatives of the German government could not be reached for immediate comment.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Until then, Schneider said he will hunker down in his room, heading out only to go to a nearby market for fresh water and food. When he leaves, he plans to wear a black cap with the logo of the Miami Heat basketball team, gloves and a thick cloth mask over his mouth and nose.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">In saying he expects to be on his way out on Saturday, "I hope I haven't jinxed myself."</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"> (Reporting by Brendan O'Brien in Chicago, additional reporting by David Brunnstrom in Washington; Editing by Scott Malone and Bill Berkrot)</p>, <p>Advertisement</p>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd" id="site-index-label">Site Index</h2>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-0">news</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-1">opinion</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-2">arts</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-3">living</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-4">more</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-subscribe-label">Subscribe</h3>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd">Site Information Navigation</h2>]
[<p>Advertisement</p>, <p>Supported by</p>, <p class="css-c2jxua e6idgb70"></p>, <h1 class="css-1j5ig2m e1h9rw200" id="link-7ffb9a75" itemprop="headline"><span>Russia Limits Rail Service With China From Jan. 31 Over Coronavirus</span></h1>, <p class="css-1fv7b6t e1jsehar1" itemprop="author" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">By<!-- --> <span class="css-1baulvz last-byline" itemprop="name">Reuters</span></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">MOSCOW — Russia will limit railway service with China from Jan. 31, leaving only direct trains between Moscow and Beijing, in response to the coronavirus crisis, Deputy Prime Minister Tatiana Golikova said on Wednesday.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">"Under a decision of the emergency response center, we will limit railway service from midnight of (January) 31st, that is from Thursday to Friday. Trains will follow the Moscow-Beijing, Beijing-Moscow route," Golikova said. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Earlier on Wednesday, President Vladimir Putin, speaking about the coronavirus at a meeting with Golikova and Health Minister Mikhail Murashko, said he assumed that the government and Russia's consumer rights watchdog would do everything possible to be ready for unexpected developments.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The coronavirus has killed more than 130 people in China, prompting some countries to evacuate their citizens from the city of Wuhan, the epicenter of the outbreak, while companies have extended Lunar New Year holidays to try to prevent a further spread of the flu-like virus.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Golikova told reporters Russia was preparing measures to bring back its citizens who are currently in China, according to the government website.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Russia will also extend the closure of its land border with China for pedestrians and vehicles in the Far East regions of Jewish Autonomous Oblast, Khabarovsk, Primorsk and Amur, as well as Zabaikalsky Krai, Golikova said.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">A decision on flights between the two countries will be made at the next meeting of the emergency response center on Friday, Golikova said.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">In Moscow, authorities said they had put in place special safety measures at hotels and tourist sites in the face of the rising death toll from the coronavirus.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Russian officials have said there have been no recorded coronavirus infections in the country so far but efforts were under way to get all people with flu-like symptoms to undergo medical checks.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"> (Reporting by Andrey Ostroukh; Editing by Mark Heinrich)</p>, <p>Advertisement</p>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd" id="site-index-label">Site Index</h2>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-0">news</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-1">opinion</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-2">arts</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-3">living</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-4">more</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-subscribe-label">Subscribe</h3>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd">Site Information Navigation</h2>]
[<p>Advertisement</p>, <p>Supported by</p>, <p class="css-c2jxua e6idgb70"></p>, <h1 class="css-1j5ig2m e1h9rw200" id="link-5fa13c42" itemprop="headline"><span>Oreo Maker Mondelez Sees Coronavirus Hurting First-Quarter Sales</span></h1>, <p class="css-1fv7b6t e1jsehar1" itemprop="author" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">By<!-- --> <span class="css-1baulvz last-byline" itemprop="name">Reuters</span></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">(Reuters) - Mondelez International Inc, the maker of Oreos and Chips Ahoy cookies, on Wednesday said it expects first-quarter revenue will be impacted by the coronavirus spreading across China, and it has temporarily closed two factories.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The company reported quarterly revenue that beat estimates, helped by higher demand for its snacks in developing markets. Shares in Mondelez were up 2.6% after the bell.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Mondezlez's chief executive, Dirk Van de Put, said the coronavirus is expected to have only a short-term impact. China accounts for nearly 4.5% of the company's sales.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">"It's really too early to quantify for us at this point," Van de Put said of the expected impact. "We are monitoring the situation closely." Mondelez will update the market as needed, he added. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">"We now have to see in the coming weeks what has happened with the sell-out during Chinese New Year," Van de Put said. The Chinese government has asked Mondelez to keep two factories closed for 10 days to minimize the risk of infection, he said. Wuhan, China, is the epicentre of the virus, which has killed more than 160 people.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">"We also have voluntarily put some travel restrictions to our own people to travel less within China and also for our global people to travel less to China," Van de Put said. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Van de Put also said Brexit is a risk to the company, but he does not expect to see an impact this year. "If there is no deal near the end of the year, that would possibly be a disruptor," he said.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Emerging markets like China - where incomes and demand for e-commerce are rising - have become increasingly important to Mondelez as the consumer goods industry grapples with slowing demand in developed countries.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Mondelez has been pushing hard on investments and can still be in more stores, Van de Put said. He singled out growth in the company's biscuit businesses in India and China, as well as strong chocolate and gum sales in each country, respectively.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The Illinois-based company has invested heavily in both countries in recent years, spending more on marketing and creating products. In China, for instance, Mondelez has been working for years with Alibaba's online marketplace Tmall to expand its reach, creating novelties like wasabi- or hot chicken-flavoured Oreos. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The company reported fourth-quarter revenue on Wednesday that beat estimates, helped by a 4.5% rise in sales from the Asia, Middle East and Africa business.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Net earnings attributable to the company fell to $726 million (552 million pounds), or 50 cents per share, in the quarter ended Dec. 31. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Excluding items, Mondelez earned 61 cents per share, a cent above analysts' estimates, according to IBES data from Refinitiv.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Net revenue rose 2.1% to $6.91 billion, beating analysts' expectations of $6.84 billion.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"> (Reporting by Richa Naidu in Chicago and Uday Sampath in Bengaluru; Editing by Leslie Adler)</p>, <p>Advertisement</p>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd" id="site-index-label">Site Index</h2>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-0">news</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-1">opinion</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-2">arts</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-3">living</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-4">more</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-subscribe-label">Subscribe</h3>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd">Site Information Navigation</h2>]
[<p>Advertisement</p>, <p>Supported by</p>, <p class="css-c2jxua e6idgb70"></p>, <h1 class="css-1j5ig2m e1h9rw200" id="link-72a59b0d" itemprop="headline"><span>Brazil's Petrobras Suspends Travel to China Over Coronavirus, Oil Flows Unchanged</span></h1>, <p class="css-1fv7b6t e1jsehar1" itemprop="author" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">By<!-- --> <span class="css-1baulvz last-byline" itemprop="name">Reuters</span></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">RIO DE JANEIRO — Brazil's state-owned oil company Petroleo Brasileiro SA said on Wednesday that it would suspend employee travel to China amid the coronavirus outbreak as a precautionary measure.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Petrobras, as the company is known, said oil exports to China will continue unchanged, while "eventual logistical adjustments are being studied."</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"> (Reporting by Marta Nogueira; editing by Diane Craft)</p>, <p>Advertisement</p>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd" id="site-index-label">Site Index</h2>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-0">news</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-1">opinion</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-2">arts</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-3">living</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-4">more</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-subscribe-label">Subscribe</h3>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd">Site Information Navigation</h2>]
[<p>Advertisement</p>, <p>Supported by</p>, <p class="css-c2jxua e6idgb70"></p>, <h1 class="css-1j5ig2m e1h9rw200" id="link-6855aaf" itemprop="headline"><span>Euro Zone Business Starts Year Upbeat, Coronavirus May Sour Mood</span></h1>, <p class="css-1fv7b6t e1jsehar1" itemprop="author" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">By<!-- --> <span class="css-1baulvz last-byline" itemprop="name">Reuters</span></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">BRUSSELS — Euro zone economic sentiment jumped as confidence among manufacturers rose while unemployment was at its lowest level in more than a decade, data showed on Thursday, but the mood may quickly turn sour as fears over the coronavirus epidemic mount.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">A European Commission's monthly survey said economic sentiment in the 19 countries sharing the euro rose to 102.8 points in January from 101.3 in December, well above the average forecast of 101.8 points in a Reuters poll of economists.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The improvement was driven by higher confidence in industry, as factory managers were more upbeat on their production expectations and their stocks of finished products.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The sector was hit hard last year by global trade wars and seems to have benefited from an initial trade deal between the United States and China signed in mid-January. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">But economists warned that the recovery in optimism may be short-lived as experts assess the fallout of the outbreak of the new coronavirus which emerged in China last month. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The positive readings on sentiment and unemployment "are signs that the bottom in manufacturing is now getting close", said Bert Colijn, a senior economist at ING bank.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">"One has to be cautious in interpreting these numbers though, as uncertainty around the impact of the coronavirus on the global economy is mounting," he said, adding that was not yet factored into these results released on Thursday.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Among euro zone's largest economies, the industry indicator rose most in Germany, the bloc's top exporter of manufactured goods and the region's biggest economy. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">But the overall industry mood remained below the long-term average both in Germany and in the euro zone. The indicator for the services sector, the largest in the euro zone, dropped slightly after three consecutive monthly rises.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The more positive business mood could be a signal of a stronger economy in the first quarter of 2020, as the euro zone leaves behind a year of weak growth.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Unemployment data supported the upbeat view, as the jobless rate dropped in the euro zone to 7.4% in December, its lowest level since May 2008, when the global financial crisis began to hit the bloc, data from the EU statistics agency Eurostat showed.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">But economists remained cautious.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">"Today's data do not change our view that euro zone economic growth will remain subdued, at least during the first half of this year, and that any subsequent recovery will be weaker than many anticipate," said Melanie Debono, economist at research firm Capital Economics. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">She said she expected the euro zone economy to grow around 0.7% this year, well below EU Commission's forecasts of a 1.2% expansion, and less than 1.1% estimated for last year.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"> (Reporting by Francesco Guarascio; Editing by Philip Blenkinsop and Alison Williams)</p>, <p>Advertisement</p>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd" id="site-index-label">Site Index</h2>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-0">news</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-1">opinion</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-2">arts</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-3">living</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-4">more</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-subscribe-label">Subscribe</h3>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd">Site Information Navigation</h2>]
[<p>Advertisement</p>, <p>Supported by</p>, <p class="css-c2jxua e6idgb70"></p>, <h1 class="css-1j5ig2m e1h9rw200" id="link-565bd75f" itemprop="headline"><span>South Korea's Moon Urges Calm Amid Protests Over Coronavirus Quarantine Sites</span></h1>, <p class="css-1fv7b6t e1jsehar1" itemprop="author" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">By<!-- --> <span class="css-1baulvz last-byline" itemprop="name">Reuters</span></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">SEOUL — South Korean President Moon Jae-in urged residents not to give in to fear as the country prepared to evacuate the first of around 700 citizens from the epicentre of the new coronavirus epidemic in China on Thursday.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The first of up to four planned flights to Wuhan had been due to depart South Korea on Thursday morning, but were delayed for unspecified reasons, Yonhap news agency reported. The flights were still expected to depart by later in the day.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">"The weapons that will protect us from the new coronavirus are not fear and aversion but trust and cooperation," Moon said in a speech on Thursday, decrying "fake news" as creating excessive anxiety.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Protesters used tractors to block access to facilities earmarked as quarantine centres in the cities of Asan and Jincheon, about 80 km (50 miles) south of Seoul, on Wednesday.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The government has proposed to keep the evacuated citizens in isolation at the facilities, usually used as training centres for public servants, for at least two weeks to ensure they do not develop symptoms.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Moon tried to reassure residents, saying the initial evacuees would only be those with no symptoms, and they will be held in isolation.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">"The government will be taking air-tight steps to ensure the residents of areas where the facilities are do not need to be concerned," he said. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">South Korea has reported four cases of the newly identified virus, all of whom arrived after visiting the central Chinese city of Wuhan where the pathogen appeared in humans late last year.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The new strain of coronavirus has an incubation of between one and 14 days and can spread before symptoms show, complicating efforts to screen people at international borders.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">It has created widespread alarm because it is spreading quickly and there are still important unknowns surrounding it, but it is still too early to know what its death rate will be, because there are likely to be many cases of milder infections going undetected.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">South Korea said the inter-Korean liaison office in Kaesong, North Korea, would be closed until the outbreak eased. North Korea would not allow South Korean officials to enter the office when they arrived on Thursday, Yonhap reported, citing South Korea's unification ministry.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"> (Reporting by Josh Smith and Sangmi Cha; Editing by Stephen Coates)</p>, <p>Advertisement</p>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd" id="site-index-label">Site Index</h2>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-0">news</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-1">opinion</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-2">arts</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-3">living</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-4">more</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-subscribe-label">Subscribe</h3>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd">Site Information Navigation</h2>]
[<p>Advertisement</p>, <p>Supported by</p>, <p class="css-c2jxua e6idgb70"></p>, <h1 class="css-1j5ig2m e1h9rw200" id="link-65ee60b8" itemprop="headline"><span>Jaguar-Land Rover Parent Warns of Profit Hit From Coronavirus Outbreak</span></h1>, <p class="css-1fv7b6t e1jsehar1" itemprop="author" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">By<!-- --> <span class="css-1baulvz last-byline" itemprop="name">Reuters</span></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">BENGALURU — The coronavirus outbreak in China could hit profits at luxury car brands Jaguar and Land Rover, parent Tata Motors said on Thursday, the latest company to warn of an impact from the epidemic that has killed 170 people and forced businesses to suspend operations.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">It could hamper JLR production in China as the epidemic has raised concerns that thousands of Chinese factory workers on extended Lunar New Year holidays may struggle to get back to work next week due to extensive travel restrictions.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The Indian carmaker said the outbreak could impact its profit margin forecast of around 3% for the JLR unit in fiscal 2020 at a time when it was making progress on a turnaround plan to improve sales in China.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Several companies including Tesla Inc, Apple and Starbucks have warned of a possible impact from the outbreak.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">"We need to see when people come back and resume work, how soon they can replenish pipeline inventory," Chief Financial Officer PB Balaji said as the company reported its third-quarter results.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">A 24% rise in sales at Jaguar and Land Rover in China in the quarter, however, helped the company beat profit expectations.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Tata Motors said it expects capital spending at JLR to rise to 4 billion pounds ($5.26 billion) in 2021 from 3.6 billion pounds in 2020.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Earlier on Thursday, the company said JLR Chief Executive Officer Ralf Speth will retire from the role in September, but will stay as non-executive chairman.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The carmaker reported net profit of 17.38 billion rupees ($245 million) in the third quarter ended Dec. 31, compared with a loss of 269.93 billion rupees a year earlier, when it booked an impairment charge related to the JLR unit.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Analysts, on average, were expecting a profit of 10.19 billion rupees, according to IBES data from Refinitiv.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Tata Motors last year mapped a revival plan for JLR and decided to cut around 10% of its workforce, following a drop in sales at the unit.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The company's overall revenue from operations fell 6.8% to 716.76 billion rupees in the quarter as its home market, India, faces an economic slowdown. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Tata Motors, like the rest of the auto industry in India, has been struggling with tighter credit and higher insurance costs, which have bruised demand and caused a pile-up of inventory.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"> (Reporting by Chandini Monnappa in Bengaluru; Editing by Saumyadeb Chakrabarty and Arun Koyyur)</p>, <p>Advertisement</p>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd"
