Some test results won't be back for a week, he added.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">While the surroundings are fairly comfortable, Evans said Thursday that he and others are still being cautious about mingling.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“I’m still wearing my mask and I’m still wearing my gloves," he said in a telephone interview. “We’re still not knowing who has it. I’m still taking major precautions. You don't know whether you're in the clear.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“Today a lot of kids were enjoying the weather,” he said, and the base provided scooters, bikes, footballs and soccer balls for them to play with.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">But at dinnertime, Evans added, “everyone’s getting their food and going right back to their rooms.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Those being held at the base 60 miles (96 kilometers) east of Los Angeles arrived Wednesday morning. They aren't required to stay but had agreed to remain for at least 72 hours. Officials also can quarantine any of those evacuated on a case-by-case basis. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">That happened to another American who tried to leave Wednesday night.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Officials in Riverside County ordered the person quarantined for two weeks unless medically cleared sooner, said Jose Arballo Jr., a spokesman for the county's public health agency.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The order was issued “as a result of the unknown risk to the public" because the person had not undergone a complete health evaluation, the agency said.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">It can take up to 14 days for someone who is infected to develop symptoms, health officials believe. None of the Americans housed at base have shown symptoms of the virus since their arrival, Arballo said.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Evans said he would remain until testing shows he is free of the virus. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">He is a professional quarterback who moved to Wuhan several years ago to play in a Chinese football league. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The city of 11 million people felt joyful, he said, with residents getting ready for the Lunar New Year.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Then, in a matter of days, “it turned into chaos" as news broke of the rapidly expanding coronavirus outbreak. Suddenly, Evans said, people were swarming pharmacies and stores to get masks and disinfectant spray. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Friends translated the news for Evans, who speaks no Chinese.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“I stocked up on rice, noodles, water, anything that could help me survive for a week or two,” Evans said.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The Chinese government shut down the city. Buses, trains, taxis, and personal cars were banned. The military patrolled some streets.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“That's when people, honestly, stayed locked in their homes,” Evans said. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">He compared the deserted city to an Old West ghost town.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“I've never experienced anything like this before," he said. “Imagine new York city being shut down. I was completely scared at first, because I didn’t know exactly what was going to happen. I don’t speak the language, and my family is so far away.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Evans holed up in his home for a week and a half until he received the news that the U.S. Embassy was evacuating its diplomats and their families and other U.S. citizens.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">He was notified that a chartered flight was carrying some of the 1,000 or so Americans in Wuhan back to the United States. The flight was coming in the next day.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Evans said he was told, “If you can make it there, you're on the flight.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“It was a race against time," he said.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Evans found an acquaintance who drove him to the airport. The embassy notified Chinese authorities of the license plate number so he could pass through the guarded streets.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Evans said he was No. 171 out of 195 people permitted on board. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">On the plane were two men in full hazardous material suits, who warned them about the seriousness of the outbreak. Nobody appeared sick but all of the passengers decided to wear masks throughout the flight, Evans said.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The plane flew to Anchorage, where the passengers had health screenings, and then landed at March Reserve Air Base on Wednesday morning. The U.S. arrival was joyful, Evans said.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“We were clapping, smiling, laughing ... there were cheers,” he said.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Once he is cleared, Evans intends to visit his family. Then it's on to Switzerland, where is signed to play with the Bern Grizzlies this year. But he would like to return to Wuhan when the coronavirus outbreak recedes.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“The community is amazing, the people in Wuhan are amazing. China is a beautiful place," he said.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">But the threat of the deadly disease has left its mark.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“I’ve never experienced anything like this before," Evans said. “The weirdest thing is the threat of man. You can actually get this virus by shaking hands." </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“I'm a very hands-on person," he said, "And for me to be quiet and not to interact with others has been one of the hurtful things that I have to do. But to protect myself, I have to do it.”</p>, <p>Advertisement</p>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd" id="site-index-label">Site Index</h2>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-0">news</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-1">opinion</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-2">arts</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-3">living</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-4">more</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-subscribe-label">Subscribe</h3>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd">Site Information Navigation</h2>]
[<p>Advertisement</p>, <p>Supported by</p>, <p class="css-c2jxua e6idgb70"></p>, <h1 class="css-1j5ig2m e1h9rw200" id="link-13656621" itemprop="headline"><span>How Well New China Virus Spreads Is Focus of Control Efforts</span></h1>, <p class="css-1fv7b6t e1jsehar1" itemprop="author" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">By<!-- --> <span class="css-1baulvz last-byline" itemprop="name">The Associated Press</span></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Scientists are starting to fill in some key gaps in what's known about the new virus from China. New research suggests it spreads a little easier than regular flu but not as well as some other respiratory diseases like whooping cough or tuberculosis. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Health officials are focusing on person-to-person spread as the virus extends its geographic reach. Nearly 8,000 cases have been confirmed in China, while a much smaller number of people have been reported in more than a dozen other countries. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">WHAT IS KNOWN ABOUT THE VIRUS?</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The new virus comes from a large family of coronaviruses, some causing nothing worse than a cold. In 2002, one called SARS caused an outbreak of severe pneumonia in China and spread to other countries. It infected more than 8,000 people and killed nearly 800 until it was controlled by some of the same public health measures being used in the current outbreak.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">In 2012, another coronavirus dubbed MERS began sickening people in Saudi Arabia. It still causes small numbers of infections each year. The World Health Organization has counted nearly 2,500 cases in the Middle East and beyond, and more than 850 deaths.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The new virus is 75% to 80% identical to SARS, scientists have reported. So far, about 8,000 infections have been confirmed, nearly all in China. About 170 deaths have occurred. Its true mortality rate isn't known, because many infections may be going undetected in people who have mild or no symptoms.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">HOW EASILY DOES IT SPREAD?</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Based on the first 425 cases analyzed, each infected person spread the virus to 2.2 others on average, scientists reported Wednesday in the New England Journal of Medicine. That's a bit more than ordinary flu but far less than some other respiratory diseases such as whooping cough and tuberculosis. The rate for SARS was estimated to be 3.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">On Thursday, officials reported the first U.S. case of person-to-person spread — the husband of a Chicago woman who had traveled to Wuhan, China. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The rate of spread is a key factor in bringing outbreaks under control. It's the reason health officials are focused on finding and isolating new cases and checking on people in close contact with them. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">It's not known whether anyone who is infected but not showing symptoms can spread the virus. But at a news conference earlier this week, the U.S. government's infectious diseases chief, Dr. Anthony Fauci, said outbreaks are not driven by that kind of spread.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">WHERE DO THESE VIRUSES COME FROM?</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">SARS and MERS came from animals, and this newest virus almost certainly did, too. The first people infected had visited or worked at a food market in the Chinese city of Wuhan. In the New England Journal report on the first 425 confirmed cases, Chinese scientists said that 55% of those before Jan. 1 were tied to that market but only 8% of cases after that were.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">SARS initially was traced to civet cats sold in a live animal market, but later scientists decided it probably originated in bats that infected the civets. People can catch MERS from infected camels, although again, bats likely first spread that coronavirus to camels.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Scientists have said the new virus seems similar genetically to some bat viruses, but it's not known if that is the source in nature or if another animal may be involved. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">HOW DOES IT SPREAD? WHO'S MOST AT RISK?</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Unlike SARS, the new virus "looks like it doesn’t transmit through the air very easily and probably transmits through close contact,” said Dr. David Heymann, who headed WHO’s global response to SARS.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">And while it's too soon to be sure, Heymann said the new virus appears most dangerous to older adults who have other health problems. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Few of the early cases occurred in children, and more than half were in adults 60 and older, the New England Journal report this week says. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">IT’S FLU SEASON IN THE NORTHERN HEMISPHERE — HOW WILL PEOPLE KNOW THE DIFFERENCE?</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Since symptoms are similar — fever, cough and in more severe cases shortness of breath or pneumonia — it takes a medical test to tell. There is one, but health authorities in China, the U.S. and elsewhere are working to make it more widely available.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Given that it is flu season in China, too, it's “all the more impressive that they were able to recognize this outbreak quickly,” Dr. Brian Garibaldi of Johns Hopkins University said. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The average incubation period — from infection until symptoms show up — is about five days, the New England Journal study says. However, symptoms have turned up much later, supporting the wisdom of a two-week observation time, the authors wrote. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">HUNTING VACCINES</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">While there is no vaccine — or specific treatment — for SARS or MERS, Fauci said it is technically possible to create a vaccine against this new virus. NIH did develop a potential vaccine candidate for SARS. It proved safe in a small first-step study in people but never was tested further because by then, the outbreak was ending.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">This time around, scientists have more of a head start. Just weeks after the first unusual pneumonias were reported, Chinese scientists mapped the genes of the viral suspect and shared them with world health authorities.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Now, NIH is among several groups working to create a vaccine for the new virus, using newer and faster technology than was available during SARS. Fauci hopes to begin first-step safety tests in about three months, but something ready for real-world use would take far longer.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">___</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The Associated Press Health and Science Department receives support from the Howard Hughes Medical Institute's Department of Science Education. The AP is solely responsible for all content.</p>, <p>Advertisement</p>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd" id="site-index-label">Site Index</h2>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-0">news</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-1">opinion</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-2">arts</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-3">living</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-4">more</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-subscribe-label">Subscribe</h3>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd">Site Information Navigation</h2>]
[<p>Advertisement</p>, <p>Supported by</p>, <p class="css-c2jxua e6idgb70"></p>, <h1 class="css-1j5ig2m e1h9rw200" id="link-7ae63dae" itemprop="headline"><span>After Meager 2019, Samsung's Modest Chip Recovery Outlook Falls Flat</span></h1>, <p class="css-1fv7b6t e1jsehar1" itemprop="author" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">By<!-- --> <span class="css-1baulvz last-byline" itemprop="name">Reuters</span></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">SEOUL — Samsung Electronics Co is counting on a gradual recovery in memory chip demand from data centers and 5G smartphone makers to help it bounce back in 2020 after sliding to its worst operating profit in four years. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">But in a guarded outlook, the world's biggest memory chip and smartphone maker said on Thursday it couldn't rule out the possibility that demand growth may be curbed amid lingering tensions on U.S.-China trade and looming fears of the economic impact of the new coronavirus outbreak in China and beyond.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The conservative forecast failed to satisfy investors hoping for a brighter outlook, and the company's shares ended down 3.2%, having fallen as much as 3.9% at one point, while the Seoul market benchmark was off 1.7%.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Samsung, which counts smartphone rivals Apple Inc and Huawei Technologies Co as customers for its chips and displays, said fourth-quarter operating profit slumped to 7.16 trillion won ($6.13 billion) on weaker chip demand, down 34% from the same period a year earlier.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">That was in line with its own estimate, though net profit for the quarter skidded 38% to 5.2 trillion won, meaning Samsung missed analysts' estimate of 5.6 trillion won.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The October-December quarter marks the end of a year marred by bloated stockpiles of chips that squeezed prices, and the U.S.-China trade war that roiled global supply chains and prospects for consumer demand. For the year, the South Korean conglomerate posted operating profit of 27.8 trillion won, its lowest since 2015.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Samsung said it also expected January-March earnings to fall from the preceding quarter, reflecting low seasonal demand for chips and displays. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Speaking during a conference call, a Samsung chip executive flagged uncertainties in chip demand.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">"The macroeconomic and geopolitical concerns are showing signs of easing recently, but we can't rule out the possibility that the situation would deteriorate," said Han Jin-man, senior vice president at Samsung's semiconductor business unit. He didn't identify specific issues that could affect the company. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">VIRUS OUTBREAK </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">In contrast with Samsung's modest forecast, chip peers like Intel Corp and TSMC earlier offered positive outlooks, fuelling hopes of a rebound in chip prices after a slide that started in late 2018.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">"Samsung offered a conservative outlook for the memory market, and there is a disconnect between market views and the company views when it comes to strength of the recovery," said Park Sung-soon, an analyst at Cape Investment &amp; Securities.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Meanwhile, after posting strong results, Apple earlier this week flagged uncertainty created by the coronavirus outbreak in China which economists fear could hurt the global economy.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">On Thursday Samsung Electronics, which has chip, display and home appliance plants in China, declined to comment on the impact of the outbreak on demand. In a statement to Reuters, it said it had extended a holiday closure for some factories in line with Chinese government guidance. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">But supplier Samsung SDI, which makes phone batteries and materials for chips and displays, said it expects current-quarter earnings to be adversely affected by the virus outbreak.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Fourth-quarter operating profit more than halved to 3.45 trillion won in Samsung's mainstay chip division, while its mobile division profit surged by two-thirds to 2.52 trillion won, thanks to strong sales of flagship models and a revamp of its mid- and lower-end A series line-up. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Samsung said the actual pace of 5G network expansion and its effects on memory demand remains to be seen, although the company sees demand picking up around mass-market 5G models. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">It said it aims to expand its presence in the 5G network equipment market in the United States, while continuing to look at the possibility of entering the European market.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">This week Britain granted Huawei a limited role in developing the country's 5G mobile network, frustrating a global attempt by the United States to exclude the Chinese telecoms giant from the West's next-generation communications.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"> (Reporting by Hyunjoo Jin and Heekyong Yang; Editing by Kenneth Maxwell)</p>, <p>Advertisement</p>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd" id="site-index-label">Site Index</h2>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-0">news</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-1">opinion</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-2">arts</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-3">living</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-4">more</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-subscribe-label">Subscribe</h3>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd">Site Information Navigation</h2>]
[<p>Advertisement</p>, <p>Supported by</p>, <h1 class="css-1s4ffep e1h9rw200" id="link-6579cada" itemprop="headline"><span>Impeachment, Brexit, ‘The Good Place’: Your Thursday Evening Briefing</span></h1>, <p class="css-1ifw933 e1wiw3jv0" id="article-summary">Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.</p>, <p class="css-1fv7b6t e1jsehar1" itemprop="author" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">By<!-- --> <a class="css-brehiz e1jsehar0" href="https://www.nytimes.com/by/remy-tumin"><span class="css-1baulvz" itemprop="name">Remy Tumin</span></a> and <a class="css-brehiz e1jsehar0" href="https://www.nytimes.com/by/marcus-payadue"><span class="css-1baulvz last-byline" itemprop="name">Marcus Payadue</span></a></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">(Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s </em><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="http://www.nytimes.com/newsletters/nyt-now-evening-briefing?module=inline" title=""><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">the sign-up</em></a><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">.) </em></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">Good evening. Here’s the latest.</em></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">1. The Senate impeachment trial </strong>of President Trump is marching toward a swift end.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The second and final day of cross-examination is <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/live/2020/trump-impeachment-trial-01-30?" title="">in its final hours</a>. In one of the tenser moments, Chief Justice John Roberts <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/30/us/politics/impeachment-trial-trump.html" title="">blocked a question</a> from Senator Rand Paul that would have revealed the identity of the whistle-blower whose complaint sparked the impeachment inquiry.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">And Representative Adam Schiff, the lead House impeachment manager, above, jumped on a question about the Trump team’s broad interpretation of executive power.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“What we have seen over the last couple days is a descent into constitutional madness,” Mr. Schiff said.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Senators are expected to vote on Friday about whether to hear new witnesses, and Republicans appeared confident they would have enough support to block any new testimony and ultimately acquit Mr. Trump. But Democrats are hinting at a <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/live/2020/trump-impeachment-trial-01-30#schumer-hints-at-a-tactic-to-delay-votes-to-acquit-trump" title="">gambit to frustrate the Republicans’ plans</a>.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">2. The U.S. issued a “do not travel”</strong> to China advisory, its strongest warning reserved for the most dangerous situations, over the coronavirus outbreak. <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/30/world/asia/coronavirus-china.html?" title="">Here’s the latest</a>. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The warning came hours after the World Health Organization declared the coronavirus spreading from China <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/30/health/coronavirus-world-health-organization.html" title="">a global health emergency</a>. Many countries have already taken emergency measures. Above, Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia. Nearly 10,000 cases have been reported worldwide, including the first U.S. case of <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/30/world/asia/coronavirus-china.html?a" title="">person-to-person virus transmission</a>.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Elsewhere, Russia partly closed its Chinese border and thousands were trapped on a cruise ship in Italy as fears spread about the coronavirus. And from Asia to Australia, Canada and France, the panic has <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/30/world/asia/coronavirus-chinese-racism.html" title="">unleashed anti-Chinese sentiment</a>.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">3. It’s finally happening: </strong>Britain will leave the European Union on Friday night.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The bloc’s 27 remaining member nations <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/30/world/europe/eu-brexit-decision.html" title="">signed off on Britain’s departure</a>, officially ending nearly four years of impassioned wrangling over whether, when and how it would happen. In typically low-key, bureaucratic style, it was completed by email.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">But this is Brexit, so there’s more. <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/29/business/brexit-scotland-trade-eu.html" title="">London and Brussels have to try to hash out a trade deal</a> by the end of the year.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">4. While the impeachment trial continued on Capitol Hill, </strong>it was business as usual at the White House.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The Trump administration continued to weaken a century-old law protecting migratory birds by <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/30/climate/trump-bird-deaths.html" title="">dropping the threat of punishment</a> for companies that kill birds “incidentally” in the course of operations. Above, oil-slicked birds in 2015.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The administration also said it would <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/30/health/medicaid-block-grant-trump.html?" title="">let states cap some Medicaid spending</a>, a long-held conservative goal aimed at curbing federal contributions. The change will most likely diminish the number of people covered. A legal challenge is almost certain.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Separately,</strong> preliminary data released by the Commerce Department showed that U.S. economic growth was <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/30/business/economy/gdp-numbers.html?" title="">steady and in line with expectations</a> last quarter. But overall growth in 2019 was weaker than the previous year, hurt by trade tensions and Boeing’s troubles.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">5. Joe Biden is gambling big on Iowa.</strong></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">His campaign has redirected funds from other early primary states to <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/30/us/politics/joe-biden-fundraising.html" title="">buy nearly $9 million in ads in Iowa</a> ahead of Monday’s caucuses.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">But there are three other Democratic candidates bunched into the top tier there: Bernie Sanders, Pete Buttigieg and Elizabeth Warren. Mr. Biden’s fund-raisers, allies and campaign officials say that a disappointing finish could dampen his online fund-raising at a crucial juncture.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Unsure which candidate best reflects your views and priorities? <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2020/01/30/us/politics/democratic-presidential-candidates-quiz.html?" title="">Take this quiz to see which could be your match</a>. The answer might surprise you.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">6. Life expectancy, </strong>the most basic measure of the health of a society, <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/30/us/us-life-expectancy.html" title="">rose slightly in 2018</a> in the U.S., after a rare and troubling decline driven by the opioid epidemic.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">That dip, from 2015 to 2017, worried demographers, who had not seen an outright decline since 1993, during the AIDS epidemic. They now caution that it’s too early to tell if the country has turned the corner with opioid overdoses.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Improvements in cancer mortality rates represented the single largest share of the life expectancy gain in 2018, at about 30 percent.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">7. There may be no more familiar image</strong> of Los Angeles than the helicopters that buzz constantly overhead. And Kobe Bryant was one of the area’s most frequent fliers.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Back in his playing days, Bryant was known to use helicopters to shuttle between his home in Orange County and the Lakers’ arena downtown to maximize time at home rather than on the freeway. His death on Sunday underscores the <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/30/us/kobe-bryant-crash-helicopters-los-angeles.html" title="">ubiquity of the helicopter in this sprawling and traffic-choked metropolis</a>.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/video/us/100000006946632/kobe-bryant-helicopter.html?" title="">Our video journalists retraced the flight path</a> of Bryant’s last helicopter ride to examine the conditions that may have lead to the crash.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">8. How can one</strong> be a decent person in a fallen world? It’s a question “The Good Place” and “BoJack Horseman” have tried to answer — in very different ways.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">As both shows end this week, our critic reflects on how TV’s two great moral comedies — one about the perils of Hollywood and the other about the afterlife —<a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/29/arts/television/the-good-place-bojack-horseman.html" title=""> showed us that doing the right thing is a group effort</a>.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The creator of NBC’s “The Good Place” (the finale is tonight at 8:30 p.m. Eastern and Pacific, and 7:30 Central), talked to us about political parallels, silly tortures and what the show had to say about<a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/28/arts/television/the-good-place-michael-schur.html" title=""> “the impossibility of being alive.”</a></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">9. The Super Bowl halftime show demands a pop unicorn. </strong>This year, that unicorn is <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/30/arts/music/jennifer-lopez-super-bowl.html" title="">Jennifer Lopez</a>.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">More than 20 years into a music career that doesn’t always get enough credit, and a recent Oscar snub for her work in “Hustlers,” she seems to have finally found validation in her pop career. Taking center stage on Sunday night, alongside Shakira, is a role she was born to play, our writer argues.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Looking back, perhaps the most bizarre halftime show in Super Bowl history happened 25 years ago. It had snakes, it had Indiana Jones, it had Patti LaBelle dressed as a temple goddess. <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/30/sports/football/super-bowl-halftime-1995.html" title="">It was a circus</a>.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">10. And finally,</strong> <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/30/dining/drinks/best-wines-under-20-dollars-winter.html" title="">20 reds under $20</a>.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">As of October, the Trump administration put a 25 percent tax on all wines under 14 percent alcohol from France, Spain and Germany. Sparkling wines are excluded, a leftover from the old distinction between table and dessert wines. The administration has further threatened a 100 percent tariff on all wines from the E.U.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Needless to say, the wine world is anxious. Right now, however, the market is still full of options.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Our wine critic, who has long argued that “the best values are found in the historic wine cultures of Europe,” selected a snapshot of what’s out there, from Chile to Italy. <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.instagram.com/p/B79Wkb3FcPu/" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">Even the wine has something to say about it</a>.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">À votre santé.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">Your Evening Briefing is posted at 6 p.m. Eastern.</em></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">And don’t miss Your Morning Briefing. </em><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2018/briefing/global-morning-briefing-newsletter-signup.html" title=""><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">Sign up here</em></a><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0"> to get it by email in the Australian, Asian, European, African or American morning.</em></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">Want to catch up on past briefings? </em><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/series/us-evening-briefing" title=""><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">You can browse them here</em></a><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">.</em></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">What did you like? What do you want to see here? Let us know at </em><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="mailto:briefing@nytimes.com?subject=Evening%20Briefing%20Feedback" title=""><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">briefing@nytimes.com</em></a><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">.</em></p>, <p>Advertisement</p>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd" id="site-index-label">Site Index</h2>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-0">news</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-1">opinion</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-2">arts</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-3">living</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-4">more</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-subscribe-label">Subscribe</h3>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd">Site Information Navigation</h2>]
[<p>Advertisement</p>, <p>Supported by</p>, <p class="css-c2jxua e6idgb70"></p>, <h1 class="css-1j5ig2m e1h9rw200" id="link-521d350e" itemprop="headline"><span>Stocks, Oil Tumble on Fears Virus to Hurt China's Economy</span></h1>, <p class="css-1fv7b6t e1jsehar1" itemprop="author" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">By<!-- --> <span class="css-1baulvz last-byline" itemprop="name">Reuters</span></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">NEW YORK — Global equity markets tumbled on Thursday as the death toll from the coronavirus outbreak in China hit 170, sending a closely watched bond indicator to invert and oil prices sharply lower on concerns about its impact on the world's second-largest economy.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The safe-haven Japanese yen and the Swiss franc gained as the number of people infected by the virus surpassed 8,100 people globally, or more than the total from the 2002-2003 SARS epidemic in a fast-spreading health crisis.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Damage to the economy is still hard to assess, but Wall Street economists see slower Chinese growth. Fitch Solutions said it maintains its real GDP growth forecast for China at 5.9% for 2020, but said it could drop to 5.4% because of the virus.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The International Monetary Fund said it is closely monitoring the outbreak but that it is too soon to quantify the potential economic impact of the virus, which has halted tourism and commerce throughout China.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 84.24 points, or 0.29 percent, to 28,650.21, the S&amp;P 500 lost 14.59 points, or 0.45 percent, to 3,258.81 and the Nasdaq Composite dropped 44.62 points, or 0.48 percent, to 9,230.54. Yields on U.S. Treasuries dipped to three-month lows and a closely watched part of the yield curve briefly inverted as concerns about the virus' impact weighed on risk appetite.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Investors remain confused as to how much strength the economy has, yet they continue to own stocks because the alternatives do not seem attractive, said Rick Meckler, a partner at Cherry Lane Investments in New Vernon, New Jersey.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">"We continue to vacillate between the view that we're headed toward recession and that we're going to have economic growth," Meckler said. "There are times like today where the virus seems like it could push us back toward weakness."</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Major equity indexes slid across the globe, with the decline sharper in Asia and Europe than on Wall Street. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">MSCI's broadest index of Asia-Pacific shares outside Japan closed 2.51% lower, while emerging market stocks lost 2.61%. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The pan-European STOXX 600 index lost 1.14% while MSCI's gauge of stocks across the globe shed 0.91%. The world index is 55% U.S. weighted.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Shares in London fell 1.43%, extending losses as the pound climbed against the dollar after the Bank of England kept interest rates unchanged. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Disappointing earnings in Europe weighed on blue-chip stocks, adding to the gloom. Royal Dutch Shell fell 4.8% before clawing back some losses after fourth-quarter profit halved to its lowest in more than three years.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">U.S. companies continue to produce earnings that are stronger than European results, leading Wall Street to be better positioned to weather any economic impact, Meckler said.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Yields on the benchmark 10-year U.S. Treasury note &lt;US10YT=RR&gt; fell two basis points to 1.57% and slipped to 1.55% overnight, the lowest since Oct. 10.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The closely watched yield curve between three-month bills and 10-year notes inverted for the second time this week, a bearish signal for the economy.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">German government bond yields fell sharply, with 10-year German bund yields dropping to a three-month low. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The dollar fell on news the U.S. economy posted its slowest annual growth in three years in 2019 and personal consumption weakened dramatically, ending the currency's rally on safe-haven demand from investors nervous about the fallout from the virus.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The dollar index had gained 0.65% in the last two weeks as investors sold off risk assets on coronavirus fears. Those fears continue to persist, boosting the Japanese yen &lt;JPY=&gt; and Swiss franc &lt;CHF=&gt;, but the U.S. economic data was bleak enough to depress the dollar's safe-haven appeal.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The dollar index fell 0.14%, with the euro &lt;EUR=&gt; up 0.18% to $1.1029.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The yen &lt;JPM=&gt; strengthened 0.24% versus the greenback at 108.76 per dollar.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Oil prices fell 2% to the lowest in three months on concerns over the virus' economic impact, while traders also considered the possibility of an early meeting or the Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Brent crude &lt;LCOc1&gt; fell $1.07 to $58.74 a barrel while U.S. crude &lt;CLc1&gt; fell $1.01 to $52.32 a barrel.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"> (Reporting by Tom Wilson in London, Tom Westbrook in Singapore, Swati Pandey in Sydney; Editing by Jacqueline Wong, Andrew Cawthorne,Timothy Heritage and Diane Craft)</p>, <p>Advertisement</p>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd" id="site-index-label">Site Index</h2>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-0">news</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-1">opinion</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-2">arts</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-3">living</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-4">more</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-subscribe-label">Subscribe</h3>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd">Site Information Navigation</h2>]
[<p>Advertisement</p>, <p>Supported by</p>, <p class="css-c2jxua e6idgb70"></p>, <h1 class="css-1j5ig2m e1h9rw200" id="link-4f644a24" itemprop="headline"><span>Canada to Evacuate Citizens From Flu-Hit China Region, Warns Against Travel</span></h1>, <p class="css-1fv7b6t e1jsehar1" itemprop="author" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">By<!-- --> <span class="css-1baulvz last-byline" itemprop="name">Reuters</span></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">OTTAWA — Canada will evacuate about 160 of its citizens from the Chinese region that is the epicentre for the new coronavirus, and the government is urging others to avoid non-essential travel to China, a top official said on Wednesday.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">"We have 160 Canadians who have requested consular assistance in China. We have secured an aircraft to bring those Canadians who wish to leave back to Canada," Foreign Minister Francois-Philippe Champagne said.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Canada is in the process of obtaining diplomatic approval for the flight, and Champagne said he did not know how long it would take to complete the evacuation. Some 250 Canadians have told the government they are in the region, but not everyone has said they want to leave. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Champagne, asked whether any of the Canadians had contracted the virus, said he could not answer that now. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The United States and Japan flew nationals out of the province at the epicentre on Wednesday as the number of deaths leapt by 27 to 133, and the World Health Organization said there was "deeply concerning" evidence of person-to-person transmission in other countries.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The virus emerged last month in a live wild animal market in the central Chinese province of Hubei, the capital of which is Wuhan.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Canada updated its travel advisory to urge Canadians to avoid non-essential travel to China. Previously the government had said to avoid only Hubei province.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Canada's Health Minister Patty Hajdu said the government was still working on protocols for how to deal with people returning to Canada. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">"We are working very closely with our U.S. counterparts who obviously have some experience in this and have set up best practices and we'll be following their lead very closely," she said.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"> (Reporting by Kelsey Johnson and David Ljunggren; writing by Steve Scherer, editing by Diane Craft and Chizu Nomiyama)</p>, <p>Advertisement</p>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd" id="site-index-label">Site Index</h2>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-0">news</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-1">opinion</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-2">arts</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-3">living</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-4">more</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-subscribe-label">Subscribe</h3>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd">Site Information Navigation</h2>]
[<p>Advertisement</p>, <p>Supported by</p>, <p class="css-c2jxua e6idgb70"></p>, <h1 class="css-1j5ig2m e1h9rw200" id="link-68750fb1" itemprop="headline"><span>Boston Symphony Cancels Asia Tour Amid China Virus Outbreak</span></h1>, <p class="css-1fv7b6t e1jsehar1" itemprop="author" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">By<!-- --> <span class="css-1baulvz last-byline" itemprop="name">The Associated Press</span></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">BOSTON — The Boston Symphony Orchestra has canceled its coming tour of Asia amid concerns about the deadly virus in China.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Andris Nelsons, the orchestra's music director, said Thursday that the decision was made out of concern for the “health and well-being” of its musicians.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“Please know that we are all passionately committed to a future visit to East Asia soon,” he said in a statement. "Most importantly, our hearts and prayers are with everyone who has been affected by the coronavirus.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The esteemed orchestra had been scheduled to go on a four-city tour that included Seoul in South Korea, Taipei in Taiwan and Shanghai and Hong Kong in China from Feb. 6 to 16.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Mark Volpe, the orchestra's CEO and president, said the orchestra decided to scrap the entire tour after organizers in China canceled the Shanghai performance.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“Unfortunately, this includes the BSO’s performances in Seoul, Taipei, and Hong Kong — areas much less impacted by the virus — as it remains unclear how travel in and out of these regions will be affected in the coming weeks,” he said in a statement.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">China has reported 170 deaths and at least 7,800 infections have been confirmed worldwide from the virus, which emerged last month in the central city of Wuhan. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Sports and cultural events have been canceled across the country and over 50 million people are under a government lockdown in central China.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The Asia trip was to be the Boston orchestra's 29th international tour and its first visit to Seoul since its founding in 1881.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">But the orchestra said it's not unprecedented for its international performances to be canceled suddenly.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">An appearance in Seoul during its 1960 tour was canceled because of political unrest, and a performance in Beijing in 1999 was canceled due to the accidental bombing of the Chinese embassy in the former Yugoslavia, the orchestra said.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The orchestra said it's considering scheduling concerts and special events in Boston during the time it was supposed to be on tour.</p>, <p>Advertisement</p>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd" id="site-index-label">Site Index</h2>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-0">news</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-1">opinion</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-2">arts</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-3">living</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-4">more</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-subscribe-label">Subscribe</h3>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd">Site Information Navigation</h2>]
[<p>Advertisement</p>, <p>Supported by</p>, <p class="css-c2jxua e6idgb70"></p>, <h1 class="css-1j5ig2m e1h9rw200" id="link-98d2626" itemprop="headline"><span>Unilever Stirs the Pot With Review of Global Tea Business</span></h1>, <p class="css-1fv7b6t e1jsehar1" itemprop="author" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">By<!-- --> <span class="css-1baulvz last-byline" itemprop="name">Reuters</span></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">(Reuters) - Unilever will conduct a review of its global tea business, including the PG Tips and Lipton brands, in an apparent strategy rethink by Chief Executive Alan Jope in the face of slowing group sales growth.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Jope has previously said the company was invested in turning around the tea business over the longer term, but the change of plan could soothe concerns of investors who have lamented a lack of urgency in transforming Unilever's struggling food and refreshment business.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">"We will look at all options for the (tea) business," Unilever finance chief Graeme Pitkethly said after the company's results on Thursday showed group sales grew at their slowest in a decade over the past quarter.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Pitkethly said tea is a good performer in emerging markets and in the premium category but all regions and all parts of the business would be considered for review. Options include a partial or full sale, he said without giving a timeframe.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The company said the review was triggered by the sales slowdown of traditional black tea in developed markets as consumers shift towards herbal tea. Black tea is the dominant part of Unilever's tea business, Pitkethly said, selling in 60 countries and generating 3 billion euros (£2.5 billion) in annual sales. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Unilever has been suffering elsewhere, too, with stuttering growth in India and China, two of its biggest emerging markets, while intense competition in North America and Europe has also hampered efforts to hit full-year growth targets.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">"The decision to launch a strategic review of its tea business reflects an attempt under CEO Alan Jope to reposition the company towards areas of higher potential after a period in which growth has been harder to come by," said AJ Bell investment director Russ Mould. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">SHIFTING TASTES</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The food and refreshment business - which makes Lipton teas and Hellmann's mayonnaise among other products and contributes 40% to group sales - has been hit particularly hard in North America and Europe as consumers reach for healthier options. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">"We are pleased to see some progress on the disposals strategy," Liberum analyst Anubhav Malhotra said of the review, while Jefferies analysts said it could kickstart further moves to unlock value in the food and refreshment division.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Six months after taking the helm in January last year Jope announced his attention to target sustainability even at the cost of losing some revenue. The CEO said he would streamline Unilever's vast portfolio by focusing on what he described as "brands with purpose", adding that these were its fastest-growing assets.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The so-called brands with purpose, including Dove, Knorr and Persil, contributed almost two thirds of revenue and drove 75% of sales growth in the first half of 2019, the company said. Brands thought to be among those that didn't have purpose were Marmite, Magnum Ice Cream and Pot Noodle.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">There have been no disposals as yet, though rivals Nestle and ABInBev have each sold food operations worth billions of dollars over the past year to refocus on their core businesses.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The maker of products as diverse as Dove soap and Ben &amp; Jerry's ice cream reported fourth-quarter underlying sales up by a slightly better than expected 1.5%, though this was still the slowest quarterly growth since at least 2009.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">GROWTH FOCUS</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">"There is no clarity around the two key issues: how will sales growth rise back to the top end of the 3-5% target range, and is this something management are focusing on, or are their 2020 margin targets more of a focus," said Freddie Lait, founder of Unilever shareholder Latitude Investment Management.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Jope's focus, however, is on growth, he said on Thursday after the results from his first full year in charge showed annual turnover grew 2% while underlying sales gained 2.9%.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">"If it does come to a trade-off between margin and growth, we will certainly prioritise growth," he told analysts.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">On its long-term outlook the company said it would step up execution and improve brand awareness and availability while seeking to accelerate innovation in on-trend areas such as plant-based foods.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Shares in Unilever were up 1.5% at 45.06 pounds by 1252 GMT, the second-biggest gainer on the blue-chip FTSE 100 index. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The stock is up 11% over the past year, slightly outperforming the FTSE 100, which has been roiled in recent weeks by growing concerns over the potential economic damage from the coronavirus outbreak in China. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Unilever said the impact of the coronavirus outbreak was too early to quantify but it could affect a fifth of its China professional food service business because fewer people will eat out. China contributes 5% to Unilever's total sales. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The Anglo-Dutch company said it expects a stronger second half in 2020, helping it to achieve full-year underlying sales growth in the lower half of a 3-5% range. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">($1 = 0.9014 euros)</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"> (Reporting by Siddharth Cavale in Bengaluru; Editing by David Goodman)</p>, <p>Advertisement</p>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd" id="site-index-label">Site Index</h2>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-0">news</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-1">opinion</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-2">arts</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-3">living</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-4">more</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-subscribe-label">Subscribe</h3>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd">Site Information Navigation</h2>]
[<p>Advertisement</p>, <p>Supported by</p>, <p class="css-c2jxua e6idgb70"></p>, <h1 class="css-1j5ig2m e1h9rw200" id="link-1d217609" itemprop="headline"><span>Instant View: Fed Holds Rates Steady, Offers No New Guidance on Balance Sheet</span></h1>, <p class="css-1fv7b6t e1jsehar1" itemprop="author" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">By<!-- --> <span class="css-1baulvz last-byline" itemprop="name">Reuters</span></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">NEW YORK — The Federal Reserve held interest rates steady on Wednesday at its first policy meeting of the year, with officials pointing to continued moderate U.S. economic growth and a "strong" job market.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The Fed's policy-setting committee announced its unanimous decision to maintain the key overnight lending rate in a range of between 1.50% and 1.75%.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The Fed's statement was little changed from the one issued after its December meeting, saying that the current federal funds rate was "appropriate to support sustained expansion of economic activity," including ongoing job growth and a rise in inflation to the central bank's 2% target.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">STORY: FOMC STATEMENT TEXT</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">MARKET REACTION: </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">STOCKS: U.S. stocks were steady, with the S&amp;P 500 last 0.4% firmer. BONDS: The 10-year U.S. Treasury note yield was steady at 1.6131 and the 2-year yield was last at 1.4446. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">FOREX: The dollar index was last up 0.09%.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">COMMENTS:</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">KRISTINA HOOPER, CHIEF GLOBAL MARKET STRATEGIST, INVESCO, NEW YORK</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“There wasn’t much that changed from the last statement. One difference was the characterization of household spending, it went from strong to moderate. We want to follow that closely because the consumer really is the engine driving the U.S. economy.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“The much bigger takeaway from this is the continuing repo operations through at least April of 2020. That is really helping to expand the Fed’s balance sheet. While it is not their intention it is creating something akin to the environment we saw during QE. By extending it at least to April, they come one step closer to having a standing repo facility, which I don’t think is a bad thing. But we have to recognise that it could create a bit of euphoria in the markets.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">MICHAEL PURVES, FOUNDER AND CEO, TALLBACKEN CAPITAL ADVISORS, NEW YORK</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">"We're dealing with a very static Fed. The statement was pretty similar to the December statement."</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">"This is what the markets and certainly I (were) expecting, to be reinforcement of a no-hike, no-cut policy. When pressed, it seems like they're going to err on the side of the doves rather than the hawks."</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">GREGORY FARANELLO, HEAD OF U.S. RATES, AMERIVET SECURITIES, NEW YORK:</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">"The Fed statement is pretty much as expected and largely a non-event. We're still going to see balance sheet expansion from until April, which is what we expected. Without question, that extra liquidity is having an impact on risk assets and financial conditions if you just look at the correlation between equities and the Fed's balance sheet."</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">ARTHUR BASS, MANAGING DIRECTOR AT WEDBUSH SECURITIES IN NEW YORK:</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">"What the Fed would like to see is the economy start picking up on an international basis, not just in the US, and then gradually easy off. I think their biggest fear is that they can’t do that before the next recession.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">RICK MECKLER, PARTNER, CHERRY LANE INVESTMENTS, NEW VERNON, NEW JERSEY:</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">"It couldn't be more consistent with what they've said before, and of course they're on hold here. You've got a lot of countervailing economic issues for them to face and the possible impact of the virus slowing some global demand... But, on the other hand, demand remains robust with consumers... There's nothing that indicates inflation is about to take off." </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">ELLEN HAZEN, PORTFOLIO MANAGER AT F.L.PUTNAM INVESTMENT MANAGEMENT IN WELLESLEY, MASSACHUSETTS: </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“The key reaction is going to be in the Q&amp;A at the press conference when they talk about what they are going to do with the balance sheet. It is an open question whether or not the change in the Fed’s balance sheet has directly driven the increase in the S&amp;P 500 since last fall. Certainly, if you overlay those two charts on one another they look very similar.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">"The key question is how much the different Fed members care about managing the S&amp;P 500 because there are certainly those people out there who will say that if you start to shrink the balance sheet you will cause the market to decline and particularly whether the administration believes that. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">"One warning sign, or one negative sign, out of this statement is the change about household spending that it has declined from strong to moderate. I was a little surprised to see that, frankly, so it will be interesting to see what data they have been looking at to draw that conclusion.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">JOSEPH SROKA, CHIEF INVESTMENT OFFICER AT NOVAPOINT IN ATLANTA: </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">"I didn’t notice anything different. There was no expectation that rates were going to change, especially going back to the December minutes which indicated that the Fed had no intention of changing monetary policy unless there was a significant change in the trajectory of the U.S. economy." </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">CANDICE BANGSUND, PORTFOLIO MANAGER, GLOBAL ASSET ALLOCATION, FIERA CAPITAL, MONTREAL.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“There were no surprises in the statement. We continue to believe that the Federal Reserve will remain comfortably on the sidelines through 2020. The global headwinds that were primarily responsible for the Fed’s dovish pivot in 2019 have now largely subsided, with trade tensions de-escalating and recent developments in the UK reducing the likelihood of a disorderly Brexit. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“There are some hopeful signs that the factory-driven slump in global growth may finally be finding a floor, though coronavirus fears could temporarily derail this narrative in the near-term. Policymakers have emphasized that they will tolerate higher, above-target inflation in order to compensate for years of missing the mark. Taken together, this suggests that the threshold for a move in either direction remains high at this time.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">PETER NG, SENIOR FX TRADER AT SILICON VALLEY BANK, SANTA CLARA, CALIFORNIA</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">"Expectations were low going into the FOMC. There weren't many changes, but there was one notable downgrade on the consumer sector in the wording. Household spending rising at a 'strong pace' to a 'moderate pace'. That was notable."</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">"They did raise the interest on excess reserves by 5 basis points. The markets appeared divided on that, but they did come through. It seems like concerns over tightness in short term money markets have subsided for the time being."</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">"They will continue to extend repo operations through the tax period of April, which is a good thing, I believe."</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">CHRIS GAFFNEY, PRESIDENT OF WORLD MARKETS, TIAA BANK, ST. LOUIS</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“The Fed’s going to remain on hold for the foreseeable future, as long as GDP growth and inflation doesn’t move outside of the bands that we’re stuck in, anchored right around 2%. The Fed is not going to get in the way of the markets. They will continue to fuel the equity market rally with lower interest rates, and as we get further into the year, it’s going to become harder and harder for them to make any interest rate moves because then it will be seen as political.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“For markets today, it should be positive. The Fed continues to support the markets with lower interest rates.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">KATHY JONES, CHIEF FIXED INCOME STRATEGIST, SCHWAB CENTER FOR FINANCIAL RESEARCH, NEW YORK</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“This is about as neutral a statement as you could write.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“It might surprise a few people that they’re only talking about extending the repo operations through April. It makes sense because they have to get through tax day. But maybe that was a subtle hint that – don’t expect this to last forever. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“It will be interesting to see if there’s any insight in terms of how (the coronavirus) is affecting their thinking. I’m guessing we’re not going to know too much because they don’t know too much about it yet, so what could they really say with any conviction.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">PETER CARDILLO, CHIEF MARKET ECONOMIST AT SPARTAN CAPITAL SECURITIES IN NEW YORK: </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">"The one thing I was surprised by was that there was no specific mention of the coronavirus which could be a problem for the global economy. And there was no dissent. The vote was unanimous. That implies that the Fed is going to stay on hold here. Of course they always leave the door open."</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><span class="css-8l6xbc evw5hdy0">    </span>"Early in the day when the market was strong we turned around on the news that the number of virus victims in China had jumped. Maybe besides the fact there was no change in monetary policy, the fact the Fed didn't go out of its way to hint at global economic weakness due to the virus could be a relief to the market."</p>, <p>Advertisement</p>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd" id="site-index-label">Site Index</h2>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-0">news</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-1">opinion</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-2">arts</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-3">living</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-4">more</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-subscribe-label">Subscribe</h3>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd">Site Information Navigation</h2>]
[<p>Advertisement</p>, <p>Supported by</p>, <p class="css-c2jxua e6idgb70"></p>, <h1 class="css-1j5ig2m e1h9rw200" id="link-77cddab" itemprop="headline"><span>Wary of Irking China, Trump Offers Rosy Take on Virus Threat</span></h1>, <p class="css-1fv7b6t e1jsehar1" itemprop="author" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">By<!-- --> <span class="css-1baulvz last-byline" itemprop="name">The Associated Press</span></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">WASHINGTON — President Donald Trump regaled a friendly New Jersey campaign crowd with his thoughts about with his thoughts about impeachment, the economy, the border wall, local politics and much more.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">But he was conspicuously quiet Tuesday about one big issue keeping much of the globe on pins and needles: the spread of a deadly new type of coronavirus. It has killed more than 170 people in China, sickened thousands more there and led to a handful of confirmed cases in the U.S., including the first U.S. case of person-to-person transmission reported Thursday by health officials. The State Department on Thursday advised all U.S. citizens against traveling to China.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Trump, a self-described germaphobe, generally has discussed the virus in broad terms, but he offered some of his most extensive comments on the issue to date during an appearance Thursday at a Michigan manufacturing plant. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“Hopefully, it won't be as bad as some people think it could be, but we're working very closely with them (Chinese) and with a lot of other people and a lot of other countries," he said. “We think we have it very well under control.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Trump described the handful of U.S. cases as a “very little problem” and said those people were “recuperating successfully.” </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“But we're working very closely with China and other countries and we think it's going to have a very good ending for us. That I can assure you,” he said.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Trump also has discussed the situation with Chinese President Xi Jinping.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Aides and confidants say Trump's careful approach is part of a political strategy crafted to avoid upsetting the stock market or angering China by calling too much attention to the virus or blaming Beijing for not managing the situation better, according to a White House official and a Republican close to the White House. They spoke on condition of anonymity because they were not authorized to discuss private conversations.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Late Wednesday, Trump tweeted photos from a White House Situation Room briefing on the virus, writing that “we have the best experts anywhere in the world and they are on top of it 24/7!” </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">In keeping with the low-profile approach, the White House announced by email Wednesday night that the meeting included members of a task force that will lead the U.S. response. The 12-person team is chaired by Health and Human Services Secretary Alex Azar and coordinated through the National Security Council.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The president's comments contrast sharply with the fierce criticism he lobbed at his predecessor, President Barack Obama, during the 2014-15 Ebola crisis, which left more than 11,000 dead in three West African nations. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">At the time, Trump ripped into Obama as a “dope” and “incompetent" and called for a travel ban on visitors from Ebola-infected countries. Trump also advocated preventing infected American health care workers from coming home for treatment.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Obama faced some criticism from public health officials for being slow to address the Ebola crisis initially, but also received plaudits for eventually attacking it with vigor. He nudged Congress to make a $5.4 billion emergency appropriation to aid the fight and sent 3,000 U.S. troops to West Africa to help with the international response. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Lawrence Gostin, a professor of global health law at Georgetown University, said he’s taken a measure of comfort in the fact that Trump, so far, hasn't overreacted and has resisted “fanning the flames” as he did with his rhetoric during the Ebola crisis. That leaves room, Gostin said, for public health professionals to take the lead.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">"As long as that continues and as long as there isn’t political interference or mass quarantines in the U.S. or outright travel bans, I will feel comfortable with how the White House is handling it,” Gostin said. He added that he'd like to see Trump ask Congress for a $1 billion emergency appropriation to help agencies battling to contain the virus.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Trump is well aware the virus outbreak in China could create a wild card for the U.S. economy during an election year. And he has long prioritized the U.S. economic relationship with China, especially during trade negotiations, and similarly largely held his tongue during widespread protests in Hong Kong. He also takes enormous pride in the personal relationship he's developed with Xi and has commended him for demonstrating “transparency" as he deals with the crisis.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Asked about the virus while traveling abroad last week, Trump said “we have it totally under control.” In a separate Twitter posting, he offered reassurance but scant detail for his confidence.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“China has been working very hard to contain the Coronavirus," Trump tweeted. “The United States greatly appreciates their efforts and transparency. It will all work out well."</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">But some public health experts say Trump's rosy assessments of the situation don't match the ground truth. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Gostin pointed to Chinese government bureaucratic delays that led to tens of thousands of people traveling outside of Wuhan province, increasing the likelihood that the virus will travel far beyond China.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“It’s not accurate at all,” Gostin said of Trump’s assessment of China’s handling of the outbreak. “China manifestly does not have this under control."</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Trump's budgets have proposed cuts to public health, only to be overruled by Congress, where there's strong bipartisan support for agencies like the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. Indeed, the money government disease detectives are tapping to fight the latest outbreak was a congressional idea.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">___</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Associated Press writers Josh Boak, Lauran Neergaard and Ricardo Alonso-Zaldivar contributed to this report.</p>, <p>Advertisement</p>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd" id="site-index-label">Site Index</h2>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-0">news</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-1">opinion</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-2">arts</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-3">living</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-4">more</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-subscribe-label">Subscribe</h3>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd">Site Information Navigation</h2>]
[<p>Advertisement</p>, <p>Supported by</p>, <p class="css-c2jxua e6idgb70"></p>, <h1 class="css-1j5ig2m e1h9rw200" id="link-288ec124" itemprop="headline"><span>Factbox: Tesla, Apple, Starbucks Warn of Virus Hit; Firms Restrict Travel, Flights Cancelled</span></h1>, <p class="css-1fv7b6t e1jsehar1" itemprop="author" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">By<!-- --> <span class="css-1baulvz last-byline" itemprop="name">Reuters</span></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">(Reuters) - Tesla warned a delay in the output of Shanghai-built Model 3 cars would hurt first-quarter profit after China ordered a shutdown of the factory following a virus outbreak that has killed 170 people and infected thousands.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Companies have shut thousands of stores, restricted travel to China and asked staff there to work from home. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Here's what large companies have said about the outbreak: </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">TRAVEL ADVISORIES/EVACUATIONS/QUARANTINES: </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">*Facebook suspended non-essential travel to mainland China and told employees who had travelled there to work from home. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">*Alibaba extended work-from-home days after a prolonged Lunar New Year break ends on Feb. 2. Novartis and Volkswagen did so as well for China staff.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">*Tencent extended holidays until Feb 9. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">*Tiktok owner Bytedance asked employees who travelled during the holidays to quarantine themselves at home for 14 days. E-commerce firm Pinduoduo and UBS Group have advised similar action. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">*HSBC banned travel to Hong Kong and China, and asked employees who travelled to the mainland recently to quarantine themselves at home. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">*Goldman Sachs and Standard Chartered took similar quarantine measures. Standard Chartered also restricted travel to China, as did Commonwealth Bank of Australia, SK Hynix, LG Display, Honda Motor and Nippon Steel, Roche and Mondelez . </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">*LG Electronics, LG Chemical, Exxon Mobil and Brazilian miner Vale SA suspended travel to China. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">STORE/FACTORY CLOSURES: </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">*Alphabet's Google temporarily shut all offices in China, Hong Kong and Taiwan.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">*Toyota Motor, which restricted China travel, shut factories in the country through Feb. 9. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">*Samsung Electronics, which has chip, display and home-appliance plants in China, extended a suspension of some factories in line with government guidance. It had earlier advised employees who visited Hubei to stay at home for seven days.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">*Samsung supplier Samsung SDI expects the outbreak to hurt current-quarter earnings.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">*AB Inbev suspended production at its Wuhan brewery. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">*Apple closed one of its retail stores in China and reduced hours at others, and restricted employee travel. It said it had baked into its outlook uncertainty related to the outbreak.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">*Walt Disney shut its resorts and theme parks in Shanghai and Hong Kong during what is likely their busiest time of the year. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">*McDonald's shut all stores in Hubei. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">*Starbucks warned results would be hit after it shut over half its cafes in the country.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">*Japan's Fast Retailing temporarily closed about 100 Uniqlo stores in Hubei. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">*IKEA closed all its 30 stores in China. It has restricted China travel. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">*Yum China temporarily closed some KFC and Pizza Hut stores in Wuhan, and Luckin Coffee closed its cafes in the city. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">*Imax delayed film releases in China. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">*H&amp;M closed 45 stores and suspended business travel to and within China. Staff arriving from China are advised to stay home for 14 days. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">*Swatch closed five stores in Wuhan and suspended travel to and from China. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">AIRLINE CANCELLATIONS: </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">*British Airways suspended all direct flights to and from China until at least Jan. 31. Finnair suspended routes to Nanjing and Beijing until end-March. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">*United Airlines, Air Canada, Taiwan's China Airlines, Jetstar Asia, Korean Air and IndiGo cancelled some flights to China. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">*American Airlines, the largest U.S. carrier, said it will suspend flights from Los Angeles to Beijing and Shanghai. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">*Cathay Pacific and Cathay Dragon will cut capacity to and from mainland China by half or more from Jan. 30 to end-March.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">*Air Seoul suspended all flights to China. Indonesia's Lion Air cancelled some this month and all flights to China next month. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">HOTELS, CRUISES:</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">*InterContinental Hotels will allow customers to change or cancel for free stays booked through official channels and scheduled between Jan. 23-Feb. 29 across mainland China, Hong Kong, Macau and Taiwan..</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">*Hyatt Hotels said guests who booked stays through its official channels and are cancelling due to the coronavirus outbreak, or are Chinese guests outbound to its Asia Pacific hotels, can cancel stays or change dates for free. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">*Royal Caribbean Cruises said its 2020 earnings would be hurt after it cancelled three trips of its China-based cruise liner following discussions with health authorities over the coronavirus outbreak. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">BOOKING PLATFORMS, AGENCIES:</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">*Ctrip, China's largest online booking platform, said more than 300,000 hotels on its platform had agreed to refunds on bookings between Jan. 22 and Feb. 8. Refunds also include flight tickets, cruises and car rentals.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">*Fliggy, Alibaba's booking site, offered similar refunds.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">*Some Chinese tour operators such as China International Travel Service offered refunds and many European tour operators cancelled tours to China.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"> (Reporting by Sophie Yu in Beijing, Jamie Freed in Sydney, Ritsuko Ando in Tokyo, Anna Ringstrom in Stockholm, Ben Blanchard in Taipei, Naomi Tajitsu in Tokyo, Heekyong Yang and Jane Chung in Seoul, Josh Horwitz and Brenda Goh in Shanghai, Pei Li in Beijing, Neil Jerome Morales in Manila, Sumeet Chatterjee in Hong Kong, Paul Arnold and Silke Koltrowitz in Zurich, Laurence Frost in Paris; Writing by Sayantani Ghosh and Josephine Mason; Editing by Shounak Dasgupta, Lisa Shumaker, Tom Hogue, Kim Coghill,; Shinjini Ganguli and Aditya Soni)</p>, <p>Advertisement</p>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd" id="site-index-label">Site Index</h2>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-0">news</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-1">opinion</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-2">arts</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-3">living</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-4">more</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-subscribe-label">Subscribe</h3>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd">Site Information Navigation</h2>]
