[<p>Advertisement</p>, <p>Supported by</p>, <p class="css-c2jxua e6idgb70"></p>, <h1 class="css-1j5ig2m e1h9rw200" id="link-6fa0fa19" itemprop="headline"><span>More Japanese Evacuated From China Virus Epicenter as Death Toll Climbs</span></h1>, <p class="css-1fv7b6t e1jsehar1" itemprop="author" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">By<!-- --> <span class="css-1baulvz last-byline" itemprop="name">Reuters</span></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">TOKYO/SHANGHAI — A plane of Japanese evacuees from the virus-hit Chinese city of Wuhan arrived in Tokyo on Thursday as the total number of confirmed deaths from the newly identified pathogen in the country rose by 38 to 170 and infections also jumped.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Chinese health authorities said there were 7,711 confirmed cases of infection as of the end of Wednesday, mostly in Hubei province where the death toll rose by 37 to 162.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Infections have been reported in at least 15 other countries and, with the appearance of the first case in Tibet, in every province and region of mainland China.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The World Health Organization's (WHO) Emergency Committee is set to reconvene behind closed doors in Geneva later on Thursday to decide whether the rapid spread of the virus now constitutes a global emergency.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">"In the last few days the progress of the virus, especially in some countries, especially human-to-human transmission, worries us," WHO Director-General Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus told a news conference on Wednesday, naming Germany, Vietnam and Japan.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">GRAPHIC: The Coronavirus Outbreak - https://graphics.reuters.com/CHINA-HEALTH/0100B59Y39P/index.html</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">"Although the numbers outside China are still relatively small, they hold the potential for a much larger outbreak."</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">A second chartered flight with Japanese evacuees from Wuhan, which is under virtual lockdown, landed in Japan with nine people showing symptoms of fever or coughing, broadcaster NHK reported.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The first flight landed on Wednesday and at least one more is expected in coming days.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Three Japanese who returned on the first flight were confirmed to be infected with the virus, NHK reported on Thursday, citing the health ministry, although two of the three had not shown any symptoms.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The United States flew about 200 Americans out of Wuhan, capital of Hubei where most of the cases are concentrated. They were being screened on arrival in California. France, Britain and Canada also have organized evacuations.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The effects of the virus are already weighing heavily on China's economy, the world's second-biggest, with companies cutting corporate travel and tourists cancelling trips.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Various airlines are cutting flights, from British Airways and Lufthansa to Air Canada and American Airlines.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"> (Reporting by Pei Li in Beijing, Chang-Ran Kim in Tokyo, Samuel Shen in Shanghai, and Se Young Lee; Writing by Rosalba O'Brien and Stephen Coates; editing by Sam Holmes)</p>, <p>Advertisement</p>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd" id="site-index-label">Site Index</h2>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-0">news</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-1">opinion</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-2">arts</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-3">living</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-4">more</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-subscribe-label">Subscribe</h3>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd">Site Information Navigation</h2>]
[<p>Advertisement</p>, <p>Supported by</p>, <p class="css-c2jxua e6idgb70"></p>, <h1 class="css-1j5ig2m e1h9rw200" id="link-44302f6b" itemprop="headline"><span>Samsung Electronics Sees Gradual Chip Rebound in 2020 After Fourth-Quarter Profit Plunge</span></h1>, <p class="css-1fv7b6t e1jsehar1" itemprop="author" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">By<!-- --> <span class="css-1baulvz last-byline" itemprop="name">Reuters</span></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">SEOUL — Samsung Electronics Co Ltd said on Thursday it expects earnings to bounce back in 2020 after a fourth-quarter slump, helped by a gradual recovery in memory chip demand from data centre customers and 5G smartphone makers. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The cautiously optimistic outlook from the world's biggest memory chip and smartphone maker draws a line under its worst year since 2015. It also echoes positive guidance from peers like Intel Corp and TSMC, signalling a rebound in chip prices after a lengthy slide. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The South Korean conglomerate reported operating profit of 7.16 trillion won (4.7 billion pounds), down 34% and in line with its own previous estimate. Net profit fell 38% to 5.2 trillion won, with revenue easing 1% to 59.9 trillion won - also meeting estimates.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">"Looking ahead to 2020, Samsung expects improvements in overall business performance but also sees continued uncertainties in the global business environment," Samsung said in a statement. It didn't identify particular issues that could affect its operations. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The United States and China reached an initial deal late last year to resolve a long-running trade row that had disrupted global business, though some issues remain unresolved. Samsung rival Apple Inc earlier this week used a wider-than-normal prediction range for a revenue forecast citing uncertainty created by the coronavirus outbreak in China which economists fear could hurt the global economy.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">For first-quarter 2020, Samsung said it expected earnings to fall reflecting low seasonal demand.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Fourth-quarter operating profit more than halved to 3.45 trillion won in Samsung's mainstay chip division, while mobile division profit improved nearly 67% to 2.52 trillion won. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Samsung said the pace of 5G smartphone expansion and its effects should be monitored closely, but the company sees demand picking up around mass-market models as major manufacturers expand their 5G lineups. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Shares fell 1.4% by 0125 GMT, trailing the wider market's 0.6% drop. Samsung shares rallied 44% last year, as expectations of an easing of U.S.-China trade tensions fuelled hope of a rebound in the chip industry.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"> (Reporting by Hyunjoo Jin and Heekyong Yang; Editing by Kenneth Maxwell)</p>, <p>Advertisement</p>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd" id="site-index-label">Site Index</h2>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-0">news</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-1">opinion</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-2">arts</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-3">living</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-4">more</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-subscribe-label">Subscribe</h3>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd">Site Information Navigation</h2>]
[<p>Advertisement</p>, <p>Supported by</p>, <p class="css-c2jxua e6idgb70"></p>, <h1 class="css-1j5ig2m e1h9rw200" id="link-76a4ef7a" itemprop="headline"><span>Nintendo Hikes Switch Sales Forecast, Reports Profit at Decade High</span></h1>, <p class="css-1fv7b6t e1jsehar1" itemprop="author" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">By<!-- --> <span class="css-1baulvz last-byline" itemprop="name">Reuters</span></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">OSAKA — Nintendo Co Ltd on Thursday raised the full-year sales forecast for its hit Switch console, after posting its highest quarterly profit in 10 years on strong demand for the device over the year-end shopping season. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Nintendo raised its Switch sales forecast for the year ending March 31 to 19.5 million units from 18 million units in a previous estimate, and hiked its operating profit forecast by 15% to 300 billion yen. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Operating profit for the October-December quarter rose 6% to 168.7 billion yen (1.17 billion pounds), versus 158.6 billion yen a year earlier. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The quarterly profit was its highest since the same period of 2009, but still came in below an average forecast of 175 billion yen from 10 analyst estimates compiled by Refinitiv. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The Kyoto-based gaming company sold 12.6 million units of its hybrid home-portable Switch device in the nine months to December and 5.2 million handheld-only Switch Lite units that went on sale in September. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Nintendo's release of the lower-priced Switch Lite handheld and two new Pokemon titles - the console's fastest-selling game series - have helped drive momentum in the device's third year as hardware from rivals Sony and Microsoft approaches the end of its lifecycle. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Gaming fans have growing opportunities to experience Nintendo's popular roster of characters, from a branded store in Tokyo that has seen long queues, to a Nintendo-themed area due to open in Osaka's Universal Studios Japan park this summer. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Nintendo is pushing into mobile gaming with its latest title, a version of its marquee racing series Mario Kart, which was widely downloaded but disappointed fans with its lack of a multiplayer option that is now undergoing testing. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Revenues from mobile have topped $1 billion, analytics firm Sensor Tower estimates, with Nintendo's home market of Japan and role-playing title Fire Emblem Heroes the biggest drivers.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The company's expansion includes the start of Switch sales in China in December with partner Tencent Holdings Ltd as it tries to shut down a grey market for its products.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">With its family-friendly games, Nintendo is seen as having a better chance of receiving approval for its titles from China's regulators. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Production in China is seeing some impact from the coronavirus epidemic that has hit the country, CEO Shuntaro Furukawa said at a news briefing.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Nintendo's shares closed down 1% ahead of the earnings, with the benchmark index down almost 2%. Its shares are down 4% this year, having climbed 50% last year. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"> (Reporting by Sam Nussey; Editing by Muralikumar Anantharaman and Tom Hogue)</p>, <p>Advertisement</p>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd" id="site-index-label">Site Index</h2>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-0">news</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-1">opinion</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-2">arts</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-3">living</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-4">more</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-subscribe-label">Subscribe</h3>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd">Site Information Navigation</h2>]
[<p>Advertisement</p>, <p>Supported by</p>, <p class="css-c2jxua e6idgb70"></p>, <h1 class="css-1j5ig2m e1h9rw200" id="link-498b79cc" itemprop="headline"><span>Weak Earnings Hit Europe Amid Virus Fears; FTSE Slides as BoE Stands Pat</span></h1>, <p class="css-1fv7b6t e1jsehar1" itemprop="author" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">By<!-- --> <span class="css-1baulvz last-byline" itemprop="name">Reuters</span></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">(Reuters) - European shares fell on Thursday on worries over the economic fallout from a virus epidemic in China and some poor earnings updates, while London stocks hit session lows as the Bank of England held off cutting interest rates.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">A day ahead of Britain's exit from the European Union, the BoE left rates unchanged in Governor Mark Carney's final policy meeting, saying it saw signs of a post-election pick-up in growth. Market participants had been almost evenly split on what the BoE's would do.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">"We continue to expect the BoE to remain dovish - but on hold - in the near-term, before turning more hawkish in mid-2020 as economic activity and inflation rebounds," said Kallum Pickering, a senior economist at Berenberg. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The pound &lt;GBP=&gt; rallied, while London's blue chip index extended losses to close down 1.4% and mid-caps lost 0.8%.[.L][GBP/]</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The pan-European STOXX 600 ended 1% lower to take losses so far this week to 2% - its worst weekly performance in nearly four months.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Global equities and some commodities markets have experienced a sharp sell-off this week as the number of reported cases of people infected with the flu-like coronavirus jumped. It has so far claimed 170 lives in China and spread to more than 16 countries, disrupting global travel and company operations.[MKTS/GLOB]</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">London-listed shares of Royal Dutch Shell were the biggest drag on the benchmark index, shedding 4.4% after the company's quarterly profit halved. The wider energy subsector fell 2.6%, also pressured by lower oil prices. [O/R]</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Shares of watchmaker Swatch Group slipped 3.9% as it reported a marked drop in annual sales and forecast continuing challenges in its key Hong Kong market this year.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Other luxury brands - LVMH, Hermes, Gucci owner Kering, Moncler, Burberry - also slipped between 0.4% and 2.1%.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">British cybersecurity company Avast was the worst performer on the pan-regional index after it announced the closure of the scandal-hit Jumpshot analytics business, which will see it take a charge of $15-$25 million in 2020 in wind-down costs.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Fashion retailer H&amp;M, consumer goods giant Unilever and truck maker Volvo were the biggest boosts to the STOXX 600 after reporting upbeat results.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">As the global growth outlook worsens, Germany's inflation came in below the European Central Bank's target for a ninth month in a row, strengthening the case for the bank's easing bias. Germany's DAX slipped 1.5%.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"> (Reporting by Medha Singh and Susan Mathew in Bengaluru; Editing by Bernard Orr, Editing by Kirsten Donovan)</p>, <p>Advertisement</p>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd" id="site-index-label">Site Index</h2>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-0">news</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-1">opinion</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-2">arts</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-3">living</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-4">more</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-subscribe-label">Subscribe</h3>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd">Site Information Navigation</h2>]
[<p>Advertisement</p>, <p>Supported by</p>, <p class="css-c2jxua e6idgb70"></p>, <h1 class="css-1j5ig2m e1h9rw200" id="link-642c9f28" itemprop="headline"><span>U.S. Economy Misses Trump's 3% Growth Target in 2019</span></h1>, <p class="css-1fv7b6t e1jsehar1" itemprop="author" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">By<!-- --> <span class="css-1baulvz last-byline" itemprop="name">Reuters</span></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">WASHINGTON — The U.S. economy missed the Trump administration's 3% growth target for a second straight year, posting its slowest annual growth in three years in 2019 as the slump in business investment deepened amid damaging trade tensions.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The 2.3% expansion last year reported by the Commerce Department on Thursday suggested the White House and Republicans' massive $1.5 trillion tax cut package, which President Donald Trump had predicted would lift growth above 3%, had provided the economy only a temporary boost. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Moderate growth undercuts the argument by Trump and his fellow Republicans that strong growth would pay for the tax cuts, which are expected to help push the federal budget deficit to $1.02 trillion this year. Growth last year was the slowest since 2016 and followed the 2.9% notched in 2018.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">White House economic adviser Larry Kudlow shrugged off the 2019 performance, telling Fox Business Network "it is a fundamentally healthy economy," and expressed confidence that activity will accelerate this year, a view not widely shared outside the administration.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">While Thursday's snapshot of gross domestic product showed the economy maintaining a moderate pace of growth in the fourth quarter, that was in part because of a smaller import bill, which has since swelled as the year ended. Consumer spending cooled considerably last quarter and scope for a rebound looks limited as wage growth appears to have stalled.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">But the longest expansion in history, now in its 11th year, probably remains on track and a recession is unlikely as the Federal Reserve's three interest rate cuts in 2019 kick in. The Fed kept rates unchanged on Wednesday. Fed Chair Jerome Powell told reporters the U.S. central bank expected "moderate economic growth to continue" but also nodded to some risks, including the recent coronavirus outbreak in China.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The Trump administration's 18-month-long trade war with China last year fueled fears of a recession. Though the economic outlook has improved with this month's signing of a Phase 1 deal with Beijing, economists do not see a boost to the economy as U.S. tariffs remained in effect on $360 billion of Chinese imports, about two-thirds of the total. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Gross domestic product increased at a 2.1% annualized rate in the fourth quarter, matching the third-quarter pace, also as lower borrowing costs encouraged purchases of houses. Growth was also supported by increased government spending on defense. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">That helped to offset the drag from a slower pace of inventory accumulation. Last quarter's rise in GDP growth was in line with economist's expectations.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Economists estimate the speed at which the economy can grow over a long period without igniting inflation at around 1.8%.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Excluding trade, inventories and government spending, the economy grew at a 1.4% rate in the fourth quarter, the slowest in four years. This measure of domestic demand rose at a 2.3% pace in the third quarter.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">"The economy had very few engines left at year end to keep flying high in 2020," said Chris Rupkey, chief economist at MUFG in New York. "The economy is in a good place only because the trade war made imports so expensive that American businesses and consumers cut back their purchases."</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Economists have long disagreed that slashing the corporate tax rate to 21% from 35%, as well as shrinking the trade deficit would boost annual GDP growth to 3.0% on an sustainable basis, because of low productivity and population growth. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">They also argue that historically there has not been a very strong relationship between corporate tax rates and business investment. Some companies including Apple used their tax windfall for share buybacks. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The dollar weakened against a basket of currencies, while U.S. Treasury prices rose. Stocks on Wall Street fell as the coronavirus epidemic heightened concerns about China's economy. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">BUSINESS INVESTMENT SLUMPING</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Business investment fell at a 1.5% rate in the fourth quarter. It was the third straight quarterly decline and the longest such stretch since 2009. There were decreases last quarter in spending on nonresidential structures such as mining exploration, shafts and wells, and industrial equipment.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Spending on nonresidential structures contracted in 2019 by the most since 2016. Trade tensions have eroded business confidence and weighed on capital expenditure. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">With confidence among chief executive officers remaining low in the fourth quarter after dropping to a 10-year low in the prior quarter, a rebound is unlikely soon. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Business investment is also seen pressured by Boeing's suspension this month of the production of its troubled 737 MAX jetliner, which was grounded last March following two fatal crashes. Boeing on Wednesday reported its first annual loss since 1997.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Economists estimate Boeing's biggest assembly-line halt in more than 20 years could slice at least half a percentage point from first-quarter GDP growth. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Growth in consumer spending, which accounts for more than two-thirds of U.S. economic activity, slowed to a 1.8% pace after rising at a brisk 3.2% rate in the third quarter. There was a reduction in spending at restaurants and bars.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Though a separate report from the Labor Department on Thursday showed the number of Americans filing claims for state unemployment benefits fell last week, the tight labor market is not generating a faster pace of wage growth.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">In the fourth quarter, personal income at the disposal of households after adjusting for inflation rose at a 1.5% rate, stepping down from a 2.9% pace in the third quarter.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The decrease in imports in the fourth quarter, in part because of U.S. tariffs on Chinese goods, compressed the trade deficit. That led to trade adding 1.48 percentage points to fourth-quarter GDP growth, the most since 2009. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">"When trade adds more to growth than consumption, you know things are out of whack," said Joel Naroff, chief economist at Naroff Economic Advisors in Holland, Pennsylvania.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Last quarter's decline in imports resulted in businesses almost depleting inventories in warehouses. A 40-day strike at General Motors also weighed on motor vehicle inventories. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Inventories rose at a $6.5 billion rate in the fourth quarter, the smallest gain since the second quarter of 2018, after increasing at a $69.4 billion pace in the July-September quarter. Inventory investment chopped 1.09 percentage points from GDP growth last quarter, the most since 2018.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"> (Reporting by Lucia Mutikani; Editing by Dan Burns and Andrea Ricci)</p>, <p>Advertisement</p>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd" id="site-index-label">Site Index</h2>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-0">news</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-1">opinion</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-2">arts</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-3">living</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-4">more</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-subscribe-label">Subscribe</h3>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd">Site Information Navigation</h2>]
[<p>Advertisement</p>, <p>Supported by</p>, <p class="css-c2jxua e6idgb70"></p>, <h1 class="css-1j5ig2m e1h9rw200" id="link-43d4ae43" itemprop="headline"><span>South Korean Evacuation Flight Arrives From Wuhan Amid Tension Over Quarantine Centers</span></h1>, <p class="css-1fv7b6t e1jsehar1" itemprop="author" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">By<!-- --> <span class="css-1baulvz last-byline" itemprop="name">Reuters</span></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">SEOUL/ASAN, South Korea — A charter flight carrying 368 South Koreans from Wuhan arrived home on Friday as tensions simmered around quarantine centers where they will be isolated, a plan vehemently opposed by nearby residents. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The first of up to four flights planned to evacuate South Koreans from the epicenter of a virus outbreak in China landed at the Gimpo International Airport west of Seoul around 8 a.m. (2300 GMT) after an unexpected half-day delay because China only approved one flight.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The government had said none of the evacuees had any symptoms before departure, but one person could not board the plane due to fever after a final check at Wuhan airport, while 18 were sent to hospitals immediately upon arrival, vice health minister Kim Gang-lip said. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">"There were different screening standards between China and us, and we conducted another check aboard the plane and put those who were showing symptoms in separate space on the second floor of the plane," Kim told a briefing. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">"The other 350 will be sent to temporary lodging facilities where medical staff will provide daily quarantine and medical assistance for 14 days under thorough control without going out or receiving guests."</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The evacuees will be isolated at two facilities in Asan and Jincheon, cities about 80 km (50 miles) south of capital Seoul.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The plan triggered a strong backlash among nearby residents, with some people throwing eggs and expletives on Thursday at senior officials who visited to try to defuse their anger.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Several hundred police officers were on hand at the facilities in Asan and Jincheon. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">In Asan, there was no sign of a major rally on Friday morning, but one angry protestor ripped apart a banner put up by a local civic group to welcome the evacuees. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Around 720 South Koreans have signed up for charter flights, but Seoul's foreign ministry said they might have to reduce the number of flights to one or two.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">South Korea also reported its seventh confirmed case of the coronavirus on Friday, a 28-year-old man who returned from Wuhan via the eastern Chinese port city of Qingdao last week. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The outbreak has prompted North Korea to declare a state emergency, though it is unclear whether there are any confirmed cases in the isolated nation. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The two Koreas opened a new hotline between Seoul and Pyongyang after they agreed to temporarily close their joint liaison office in the North's border city until virus concerns are eased, the South's Unification Ministry said on Friday.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The North also informed the South via the hotline that it has decided to postpone plans to remove South Korean facilities at its Mount Kumgang resort next month to prevent a virus outbreak, the ministry said. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"> (Reporting by Sangmi Cha and Hyonhee Shin in Seoul and Daewoung Kim in Asan; Editing by Sandra Maler and Lincoln Feast.)</p>, <p>Advertisement</p>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd" id="site-index-label">Site Index</h2>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-0">news</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-1">opinion</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-2">arts</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-3">living</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-4">more</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-subscribe-label">Subscribe</h3>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd">Site Information Navigation</h2>]
[<p>Advertisement</p>, <p>Supported by</p>, <p class="css-tsacue e6idgb70">california Today</p>, <h1 class="css-1s4ffep e1h9rw200" id="link-4197a4f3" itemprop="headline"><span>Berkeley Law School Drops Boalt Name Over Racist Legacy</span></h1>, <p class="css-1ifw933 e1wiw3jv0" id="article-summary">Thursday: It’s a rare move within the University of California. Also: The latest on a high-profile housing bill.</p>, <p class="css-1fv7b6t e1jsehar1" itemprop="author" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">By<!-- --> <a class="css-brehiz e1jsehar0" href="https://www.nytimes.com/by/jill-cowan"><span class="css-1baulvz last-byline" itemprop="name">Jill Cowan</span></a></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">Good morning.</em></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">(Here’s </em><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/newsletters/california-today" title=""><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">the sign-up</em></a><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">, if you don’t already get California Today by email.)</em></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The name “Boalt Hall” is set to be removed today from the University of California Berkeley’s law school after a yearslong process that determined, in essence, that the school should no longer honor a man whose most notable work was rooted in racist views.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“We have to remember the racism that John Boalt expressed,” Erwin Chemerinsky, the law school’s dean, told me recently. “But that doesn’t mean we honor him by putting his name on the building.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The move to drop a name that has been used for decades by students and alumni of one of the country’s <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.usnews.com/best-graduate-schools/top-law-schools/law-rankings" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">most prestigious law schools</a> comes as institutions around the country are grappling with what to do with schools, buildings and chair positions that are named for people whose legacies don’t stand up to modern scrutiny.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">[Read more about campus </em><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2016/01/29/education/college-symbol-controversies.html" title=""><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">controversies over historical figures</em></a><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">.]</em></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Mr. Chemerinsky said he became aware of Mr. Boalt’s history in <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.law.berkeley.edu/our-faculty/faculty-profiles/erwin-chemerinsky/" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">mid-2017</a>, after The San Francisco Chronicle published an <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.sfchronicle.com/opinion/openforum/article/The-case-for-renaming-Boalt-Hall-11157382.php" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">opinion piece</a> by the lawyer and Berkeley law lecturer Charles Reichmann, detailing how the law school building came to be named after Mr. Boalt.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Mr. Boalt had come to California from Nevada in 1871, as Chinese immigration was rising in the state.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">In 1877, he gave a speech as the president of <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.britannica.com/topic/The-Bohemian-Club" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">the Bohemian Club</a> called “<a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://chancellor.berkeley.edu/sites/default/files/the_chinese_question-_a_paper_read_by_john_boalt_before_the_berkeley_club.pdf" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">The Chinese Question</a>,” in which he argued that non-assimilated races couldn’t live together in harmony unless one enslaved the other. But as slavery had recently become unconstitutional, he argued that the next best thing was to keep Chinese people out.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">His speech and his subsequent advocacy served as major drivers of the <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.britannica.com/topic/Chinese-Exclusion-Act" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">Chinese Exclusion Act</a>, the nation’s first law banning immigration by a specific group based solely on race or nationality.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Mr. Boalt didn’t attend the Berkeley law school, nor did he teach there. His advocacy for Chinese exclusion was, according to Mr. Reichmann, his most significant legacy.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The law school was named for him out of respect for his wife, Elizabeth Josselyn Boalt, who had contributed to the university after he died in 1901.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">After Mr. Chemerinsky became the dean of the law school in July 2017, he appointed a small committee to research the issue.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The committee found that the naming of the building wasn’t a condition of Ms. Boalt’s gift; if it had been, he said, “it would be a very different situation.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The committee’s report was distributed to the school community for feedback. Unsurprisingly, people had thoughts.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“I’d estimate I got about 800 comments,” he said, about two-thirds of whom favored the change. “I was struck by the almost unanimity of our students, faculty and alumni of color.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">In November 2018, Mr. Chemerinsky said he formally accepted the recommendation to stop using the Boalt name.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">But the process wasn’t over: The campus had started its own <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://chancellor.berkeley.edu/building-name-review-committee/about" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">Building Name Review Committee</a>, which did a shorter review and solicited more campus feedback.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Finally, the change was approved by U.C. Berkeley’s chancellor, Carol Christ, and Janet Napolitano, the president of the U.C. system.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">[Read a conversation with Ms. Napolitano about how the </em><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2019/06/21/us/college-admissions-scandal-napolitano.html" title=""><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">university changed its admissions process</em></a><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0"> following the bribery scandal.]</em></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">All the parties involved agreed that it would be important to tell the Boalt story in some visible way going forward, and plans for that are in the works.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Still, I wondered about the future of naming buildings or schools in honor of donors, particularly in a world where more people feel empowered to come forward about misconduct by the powerful.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The only similar instance of a name being stripped from a school on a U.C. campus came after an investigation <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://news.uci.edu/2018/06/28/uci-proposes-new-name-for-school-of-biological-sciences-science-library-after-internal-investigation-substantiates-sexual-harassment-claims-against-signature-donor/" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">substantiated sexual harassment claims</a> against Francisco J. Ayala, an <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.latimes.com/local/education/la-me-edu-uc-irvine-ayala-sexual-harassment-20180628-story.html" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">acclaimed geneticist and significant donor</a> at U.C. Irvine. The Ayala name was removed from the School of Biological Sciences, as well as from fellowships, scholar programs and endowed chairs.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Mr. Chemerinsky said that, while it’s important to carefully research donors, the idea of not soliciting big donations with names attached is a nonstarter.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“Higher education — public higher education — depends very much on philanthropy,” he said. “It would be naïve and unrealistic to say that we aren’t going to have named gifts.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Michael Emerson Dirda, a spokesman for the U.C. Berkeley chancellor’s office, said that a faculty committee vets naming gifts, <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://policy.ucop.edu/doc/6000434/NamingProperties" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">which require approval</a> from the given campus’s chancellor and the university president.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“But we don’t have a crystal ball,” he said. “So it’s important to have processes in place to facilitate removing the name if it comes to that.”</p>, <h2 class="css-3ez4hu eoo0vm40" id="link-42fcec18">Here’s what else we’re following</h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">We often link to sites that limit access for nonsubscribers. We appreciate your reading Times coverage, but we also encourage you to support local news if you can.</em></p>, <p class="css-15hwz5e evys1bk0">On Wednesday, <strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">state lawmakers failed to move along one of the highest-profile bills aimed at alleviating the housing crisis</strong> — <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2019/05/17/us/california-today-housing-crisis-sb50.html" title="">again</a>. Senate Bill 50 is the latest iteration of legislation that would override local zoning laws to build more apartments in some single-family neighborhoods. But lawmakers could vote on it again today. [<a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/aponline/2020/01/29/business/bc-us-california-housing.html" title="">The Associated Press</a>]</p>, <p class="css-15hwz5e evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Fifteen people were rescued by helicopters off the roof of a burning high-rise</strong> in West Los Angeles on Wednesday. The authorities said they were looking into whether the blaze was intentionally set. [<a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/29/us/la-fire.html?smid=tw-nytimes&amp;smtyp=cur" title="">The New York Times</a>]</p>, <p class="css-15hwz5e evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">About 200 Americans evacuated from Wuhan, China,</strong> landed at a military base in Southern California. Countries around the world have begun pulling their citizens from the center of the coronavirus outbreak. [<a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/29/world/asia/wuhan-china-coronavirus-evacuations.html" title="">The New York Times</a>]</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">Also: What parents need to know about the coronavirus outbreak. [</em><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://parenting.nytimes.com/childrens-health/coronavirus-children-pregnant-women" title=""><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">The New York Times</em></a><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">]</em></p>, <p class="css-15hwz5e evys1bk0">Three leaders of the Kingdom of Jesus Christ, a megachurch based in the Philippines, were <strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">arrested in California and Virginia on charges that they ran a human trafficking ring</strong>. [<a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/29/us/philippines-church-immigration-fraud.html" title="">The New York Times</a>]</p>, <p class="css-15hwz5e evys1bk0">The San Luis Obispo County authorities said on Wednesday they had taken into evidence two trucks belonging to the family of the person who last saw <strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Kristin Smart, a Cal Poly student who disappeared in 1996.</strong> [<a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.sanluisobispo.com/news/local/article239770913.html" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">The Tribune</a>]</p>, <p class="css-15hwz5e evys1bk0">A newly built portion of the <strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">U.S. border wall in El Centro fell over in high winds.</strong> It fell into the Mexico side and landed on several trees. [<a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://kyma.com/news/2020/01/29/portion-of-new-border-wall-falls-in-mexicali/" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">KYMA</a>]</p>, <p class="css-15hwz5e evys1bk0">There used to be<strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10"> millions of western monarch butterflies in California</strong> holing up each winter. The most recent count found there are just 29,000. [<a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.kqed.org/science/1956190/just-29000-western-monarch-butterflies-are-left-in-california-thats-down-from-millions" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">KQED</a>]</p>, <p class="css-15hwz5e evys1bk0">Los Angeles is home to some of the state’s <strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">best vintage diners</strong>. Look at them then and now. [<a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://laist.com/2020/01/28/los-angeles-vintage-diners-then-and-now.php" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">LAist</a>]</p>, <p class="css-15hwz5e evys1bk0">A study found that among major American cities, <strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Daly City has the second most homeowners</strong> who have lived in one house for at least 30 years. Berkeley clocked in at fourth. [<a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://sf.curbed.com/2020/1/28/21083873/cities-longest-tenure-living-homeowners-years-grow-old" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">Curbed San Francisco</a>]</p>, <p class="css-15hwz5e evys1bk0">“Mattress Mack,” a Houston businessman, <strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">could make $1.2 million from a Super Bowl wager.</strong> He’s betting on the 49ers. [<a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.sfchronicle.com/49ers/article/Big-bet-1-million-wager-made-on-49ers-to-win-15015332.php" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">The San Francisco Chronicle</a>]</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">California Today goes live at 6:30 a.m. Pacific time weekdays. [<p>Advertisement</p>, <p>Supported by</p>, <p class="css-c2jxua e6idgb70"></p>, <h1 class="css-1j5ig2m e1h9rw200" id="link-58a6c3c4" itemprop="headline"><span>Three Japanese Evacuees From Wuhan Test Positive for Virus, 2 Had No Symptoms</span></h1>, <p class="css-1fv7b6t e1jsehar1" itemprop="author" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">By<!-- --> <span class="css-1baulvz last-byline" itemprop="name">Reuters</span></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">TOKYO — Two of three Japanese people evacuated from China and found to be infected with a new coronavirus had not shown symptoms, the health ministry said on Thursday, adding to worries about the fast-spreading virus and its economic fallout.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The three cases were among 206 Japanese people who were evacuated to Tokyo on Wednesday from the Chinese city of Wuhan, the epicenter of the epidemic that has killed 170 people in China and infected nearly 8,000.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">While the vast majority of cases have been in China, more than 100 cases have also appeared in about 15 other countries. Later on Thursday, a Chinese man in his 50s, who had previously stayed in Wuhan, was found be infected in the western prefecture of Mie, Kyodo news agency reported, bringing the total number of cases in Japan to 12 including the three evacuees. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The two people who were confirmed as infected but had not shown symptoms were the first such cases in Japan, though suspicion has been rising elsewhere that people who have the virus but no symptoms can infect others.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">That would make the virus much more difficult to control.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Japan on Tuesday classified the virus a "designated infectious disease", which would allow compulsory hospitalization and the use of public funds for treatment.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">But the designation - which takes effect on Feb. 7 after ordinances are issued - does not apply to people without symptoms.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Asked about concern over transmission of the virus from people who have not shown symptoms, a health ministry official said it was not clear whether that had happened.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Shigeru Omi, head of the Japan Community Health Care Organization, told a briefing that there were reports of such transmissions in China.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Chinese National Health Commission Minister Ma Xiaowei said this week the virus was infectious during incubation, which can range from one to 14 days. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">A second charter flight carrying 210 Japanese nationals arrived in Tokyo on Thursday. Chief Cabinet Secretary Yoshihide Suga said 13 of them felt unwell. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">IMPACT WORSE THAN SARS?</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Prime Minister Shinzo Abe, inaugurating a task force to deal with the virus, said the government would take all steps to prevent its spread, including tracking and checking people who had been in Wuhan.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Among Japan's 12 cases is a tour bus driver who was infected after coming into contact with Chinese visitors.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Bank of Japan Deputy Governor Masayoshi Amamiya speaking to investors, said the impact of the virus would depended on its spread but China's global presence was greater than when Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome (SARS), which also originated in China, killed nearly 800 people globally in 2002 and 2003.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">ANA Holdings, Japan's biggest carrier, said its bookings for flights from China in February fell by half, while those for flights to China plunged 60%. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">"The concern is of the impact that the situation could have on China's economy and the knock on that will have on things like air cargo," ANA Executive Vice President Ichiro Fukuzawa told a news conference after the release of quarterly earnings.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Moody's rating service said the economic risk to China's neighbors was likely to be greater than from SARS.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"> (Reporting by Chang-Ran Kim, Ami Miyazaki and Kiyoshi Takenaka, Ju-min Park, Naomi Tajitsu, Tim Kelly, Tetsushi Kajimoto and Elaine Lies; Writing by Linda Sieg; Editing by Sam Holmes, Robert Birsel and Alex Richardson)</p>, <p>Advertisement</p>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd" id="site-index-label">Site Index</h2>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-0">news</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-1">opinion</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-2">arts</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-3">living</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-4">more</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-subscribe-label">Subscribe</h3>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd">Site Information Navigation</h2>]
[<p>Advertisement</p>, <p>Supported by</p>, <p class="css-c2jxua e6idgb70"></p>, <h1 class="css-1j5ig2m e1h9rw200" id="link-3af1c879" itemprop="headline"><span>US Reports 1st Case of Person-To-Person Spread of New Virus</span></h1>, <p class="css-1fv7b6t e1jsehar1" itemprop="author" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">By<!-- --> <span class="css-1baulvz last-byline" itemprop="name">The Associated Press</span></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">NEW YORK — For the first time in the U.S., the new virus from China has spread from one person to another, health officials said Thursday.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The latest case — the sixth in the country — is the husband of a Chicago woman who got sick from the virus after she returned from the epicenter of an outbreak in China. There have been previous cases in China and elsewhere of the virus spreading between people in a household or workplace. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The other five U.S. cases are travelers who developed the respiratory illness after returning to the U.S. from China. The latest patient had not been in China.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The Chicago woman came back from the central China city of Wuhan on Jan. 13, then last week went to a hospital with symptoms and was diagnosed with the viral illness. She and her husband, both in their 60s, are hospitalized. Neither have been identified.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The man began feeling sick Tuesday and was put in isolation that day. Tests confirming that he was infected came back Wednesday night, Illinois health officials said at a Chicago press conference. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Twenty-one people, including health care workers, who may have had close contact with the man are being monitored, the officials said. But they were quick to try to ease any concerns that the case may signal the start of local outbreak. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“The risk to the general public remains low. This person-to-person spread was between two very close contacts, a husband and wife,” said Dr. Ngozi Ezike, director of the Illinois Department of Public Health. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The man generally relies on his car to get around, had not been on any public trains in the Chicago area and had not attended any large gatherings, officials said.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The virus can cause fever, coughing, wheezing and pneumonia. Health officials think it spreads mainly from droplets when an infected person coughs or sneezes, similar to how the flu spreads.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Experts have said they expected additional U.S. cases, and that at least some limited spread of the disease in the country was likely. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“We anticipated this,” said Dr. William Schaffner, a Vanderbilt University infectious diseases expert. “The kind of contact that you have in a household is very close and very prolonged. That’s the kind of circumstance where we would anticipate a virus such as this could be transmitted."</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The quick detection and isolation of the new patient shows, "The system is working,” said Schaffner, adding that he does not expect the virus to become widespread in the country.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The new virus is a member of the coronavirus family that's a close cousin to the SARS and MERS viruses that have caused outbreaks in the past. The new virus has sickened thousands, mostly in China, and killed about 170.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Older people, and those with other health conditions, are believed to be at greater risk for severe illness from the virus. The new patient has a health condition, but health officials did not say what it is.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">An international outbreak caused by the virus first emerged last month in China. Doctors there began seeing the new virus in people who got sick after spending time at a wholesale food market in Wuhan. Officials said the virus probably initially spread from animals to people, as did SARS and MERS.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The other U.S. cases are in Arizona, Southern California and Washington state, according to the U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">___</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">AP reporter Sophia Tareen in Chicago contributed to this report.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">___</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The Associated Press Health and Science Department receives support from the Howard Hughes Medical Institute's Department of Science Education. The AP is solely responsible for all content.</p>, <p>Advertisement</p>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd" id="site-index-label">Site Index</h2>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-0">news</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-1">opinion</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-2">arts</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-3">living</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-4">more</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-subscribe-label">Subscribe</h3>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd">Site Information Navigation</h2>]
[<p>Advertisement</p>, <p>Supported by</p>, <p class="css-c2jxua e6idgb70"></p>, <h1 class="css-1j5ig2m e1h9rw200" id="link-6bc4fb99" itemprop="headline"><span>Commerce Secretary: China Virus Could Bring Jobs Back to US</span></h1>, <p class="css-1fv7b6t e1jsehar1" itemprop="author" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">By<!-- --> <span class="css-1baulvz last-byline" itemprop="name">The Associated Press</span></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">WASHINGTON — Commerce Secretary Wilbur Ross suggested Thursday that the viral outbreak in China might offer an unexpected benefit for the U.S. economy: It could encourage American manufacturers in China to return to the United States.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“I think it will help to accelerate the return of jobs to North America. Some to U.S., probably some to Mexico as well,’’ Ross told Fox Business Network. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The new virus, from the coronavirus family, has paralyzed business in China. The industrial hub of Wuhan and other Chinese cities are on lockdown. China has reported more than 7,700 cases and 170 deaths.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The crisis has also begun to ripple through U.S. companies with operations in China. Apple CEO Tim Cook has said that the company's suppliers in China have been forced to delay reopening factories that closed for the Lunar New Year holiday. More than half of Starbucks’ stores in China are now closed. McDonald’s has closed several hundred restaurants in China.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Ross emphasized that he didn’t “want to talk about a victory lap over a very unfortunate, very malignant disease.’’</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">He added, though, that “the fact is, it does give businesses yet another thing to consider when they go through their review of their supply chain.’’</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Even before the viral outbreak, many U.S. and other foreign companies had been rethinking their presence in China and considering their options for relocating elsewhere, possibly elsewhere in Asia. That is partly because President Donald Trump has imposed tariffs on $360 billion in Chinese imports in a war over Beijing’s economic policies and partly because Chinese labor and other costs have been rising.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">But skeptics doubt that many American companies with deep roots in China might abandon the country purely over the virus. For one thing, no one knows how long the viral outbreak will last or how much damage it may inflict. And it takes significant time for companies to choose suppliers or locations for their factories.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Rosemary Coates, whose Blue Silk Consulting firm helps companies make such decisions, said it was “ridiculous’’ to think the viral outbreak would result in a significant return of business to the United States.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“You can’t snap your fingers,’’ she said. “It can take 18 months or two years to find another supplier. It isn’t easy. It’s complicated.’’</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Wuhan, a center of China’s steel industry, has attracted General Motors and many other foreign manufacturing giants.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"> “You can’t just say General Motors is going to pick up and move away,’’ Coates said. “They have a manufacturing plant there and expertise there. Their supply chain runs through there.’’</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">In fact, U.S. direct investment in China, which includes factories, continued to rise even after the SARS outbreak disrupted the Chinese economy in 2003. And labor costs will continue to remain far higher in the United States than in China and other Asian countries such as Vietnam.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“Companies that are leaving China are not coming to the U.S.,’’ said Coates, who is also executive director of the Reshoring Institute, a nonprofit that researches issues surrounding corporate decisions on whether to return to the United States. “They’re going to other Asian countries .... If low cost is the only goal, then the U.S. is not the answer.''</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">After Ross' comments drew criticism, the Commerce Department issued a statement: “As Secretary Ross made clear, the first step is to bring the virus under control and help the victims of this disease," it said. “It is also important to consider the ramifications of doing business with a country that has a long history of covering up real risks to its own people and the rest of the world.''</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Asked about Ross’ comments, Larry Kudlow, Trump's top economic adviser, declined to endorse the notion that the U.S. economy stands to benefit from China’s health crisis.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"> “This is not about trade, jobs or any of that,’’ Kudlow told reporters. He added: "The president has a lot of compassion for the Chinese situation. The threat of large numbers of people dying is a terrible thing. We just want to help.’’</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">___</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Associated Press writer Darlene Superville contributed to this report.</p>, <p>Advertisement</p>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd" id="site-index-label">Site Index</h2>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-0">news</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-1">opinion</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-2">arts</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-3">living</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-4">more</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-subscribe-label">Subscribe</h3>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd">Site Information Navigation</h2>]
[<p>Advertisement</p>, <p>Supported by</p>, <p class="css-c2jxua e6idgb70"></p>, <h1 class="css-1j5ig2m e1h9rw200" id="link-d9d841a" itemprop="headline"><span>Airlines Suspend, Scale Back Direct Flights to China Amid Virus Fears</span></h1>, <p class="css-1fv7b6t e1jsehar1" itemprop="author" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">By<!-- --> <span class="css-1baulvz last-byline" itemprop="name">Reuters</span></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">LONDON/MONTREAL — Global airlines on Wednesday suspended or scaled back more direct flights to China's major cities amid an increase in travel warnings and decline in demand from passengers due to a growing outbreak of coronavirus. Fears over the spread of the flu-like virus, which originated in the central Chinese city of Wuhan, are increasing as the death toll topped 160.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The virus appears to represent the biggest epidemic threat to the airline industry since the SARS outbreak, which at its peak in April 2003 led to a 45% plunge in passenger demand in Asia, analysts said.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The White House is considering further restrictions on U.S. airlines flying to and from China in addition to voluntary restrictions the companies have put into place, President Donald Trump's economic adviser Larry Kudlow said on Wednesday.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">"The matter is under discussion every day," he said.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">British Airways said it suspended all direct flights to and from mainland China.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">BA.com, the airline's website, shows no direct flights to mainland China available to book in January or February. But the airline said in an email the cancellations were in effect until Jan. 31 while it assesses the situation.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Air Canada, which planned earlier this week to cancel just a select number of its 33 weekly flights to China, said on Wednesday it would suspend all direct flights to Beijing and Shanghai. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The suspension, from Jan. 30 to Feb. 29, came after the government of Canada updated its travel advisory urging its citizens to avoid non-essential travel to China. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">American Airlines Group Inc said on Wednesday it would suspend flights from Los Angeles to Beijing and Shanghai but continue flying from Dallas, and Delta Air Lines said it was halving its U.S.-China schedule to about 21 weekly flights. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">U.S. officials said the White House had decided against suspending all flights to China for now, but it could revisit the decision if events warrant.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Among European carriers, Germany's Lufthansa suspended its own, Swiss and Austrian Airlines flights to and from China until Feb. 9, while Air France said it would reduce its flight schedule to Beijing and Shanghai this week.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Iberia, part of the IAG group along with BA, said it was temporarily suspending all flights to Shanghai. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Asia-Pacific accounts for about 19% of both Air France-KLM and Lufthansa's available seat kilometres and 8% of IAG's in 2019, Goodbody analysts said.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">"The airline industry has proven resilient to shocks in the past," S&amp;P Global Ratings said. "However, the impact on Asia-Pacific airlines and other operators will depend on how quickly the virus is contained and the extent to which it spreads beyond China."</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Indonesia’s Lion Air said on Wednesday it would suspend all direct flights to China. India’s IndiGo is also suspending flights to Chengdu and Hong Kong. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Carriers including Hong Kong's Cathay Pacific Airways said on Wednesday amenities such as hot towels, blankets and magazines would not be offered on flights to and from mainland China from Thursday until further notice.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Cathay Pacific and other airlines are allowing their flight attendants to wear face masks and gloves on flights to protect against fears of contagion.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Wesley Lesosky, president of the Canadian Union of Public Employees unit that represents Air Canada flight attendants, said by email that members have the option of wearing masks and gloves on flights to China. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">But flight attendants remained "concerned with the effects the virus could have if contracted, how to recognise an infected passenger and how to deal with the nervous passengers onboard," Lesosky said.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"> (Reporting by Sarah Young and Allison Lampert, additional reporting by Jessica Jones in Madrid, Tracy Rucinski in Chicago, Jamie Freed in Sydney, David Shepardson and Jeff Mason in Washington and Aradhana Aravindan in Singapore; editing by Kate Holton, Nick Macfie, Jonathan Oatis, Dan Grebler and Lincoln Feast.)</p>, <p>Advertisement</p>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd" id="site-index-label">Site Index</h2>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-0">news</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-1">opinion</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-2">arts</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-3">living</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-4">more</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-subscribe-label">Subscribe</h3>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd">Site Information Navigation</h2>]
[<p>Advertisement</p>, <p>Supported by</p>, <p class="css-c2jxua e6idgb70"></p>, <h1 class="css-1j5ig2m e1h9rw200" id="link-12bff5c6" itemprop="headline"><span>Elon Musk Hits Back at Critics</span></h1>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">Want this in your inbox each morning? </em><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="http://p.nytimes.com/email/re?&amp;campaign_id=0&amp;instance_id=0&amp;segment_id=0&amp;user_id=f4577a56bcf773214e9a1d55b5fe9d24&amp;regi_id=0nl=dealbook&amp;emc=edit_dk_20180529" title=""><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">Sign up here</em></a><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">.</em></p>, <h2 class="css-3ez4hu eoo0vm40" id="link-78ce41ff">Tesla has 105 million more reasons to celebrate</h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The electric carmaker reported a $105 million quarterly profit yesterday, giving boosters of the company more occasion to crow.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">“The numbers suggest that Tesla has </strong><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10"><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/29/business/tesla-earnings.html" title="">overcome the problems</a></strong> that plagued it in the first half of last year, when it lost more than $1 billion and scrambled to raise capital,” writes Niraj Chokshi of the NYT.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">And production of its Model Y compact S.U.V. was ahead of schedule</strong>, the company said. Deliveries of the vehicle would begin in the spring, at least three months earlier than expected.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Shares in Tesla rose 12 percent in after-hours trading</strong>. The company’s market value is currently $104.7 billion, more than double that of traditional rivals like G.M. and BMW. (It also puts Elon Musk closer to fulfilling the requirements for a big bonus.)</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Mr. Musk </strong><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10"><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://twitter.com/PatrickMcGee_/status/1222670676231720960" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">taunted critics</a></strong><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10"> yesterday</strong>, saying, “A lot of retail investors have deeper and more accurate insights than many of the big institutional investors.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">But there’s still plenty of fodder for doubters:</strong></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">• <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.wsj.com/articles/tesla-stock-reaches-ludicrous-speed-11580380380" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">Charley Grant of Heard on the Street</a> notes that revenue for the quarter grew just 2 percent from the same time a year ago, while operating income fell 13 percent.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">• And Tesla warned that car production would outstrip supply this year.</p>, <h2 class="css-3ez4hu eoo0vm40" id="link-9abd762">Markets continue sell-off over coronavirus fears</h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">U.S. stocks are poised to open down today, after Asian and European markets fell amid more signs that the Chinese coronavirus outbreak is continuing to worsen.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Here’s the latest:</strong></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">• <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/30/world/asia/coronavirus-china.html" title="">The death count</a> as of this morning stands at 170, while the number of cases has grown to 7,711 — officially more than in the SARS epidemic.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">• Countries are <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/29/health/china-coronavirus-outbreak.html" title="">quarantining people</a> to prevent mass outbreaks.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">• Google, Microsoft and Ikea are the latest companies to <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/business-51276322" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">temporarily shutter offices</a> or prevent employees from traveling to China.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">S&amp;P futures are down 20 points</strong>, while the Dow is set to fall nearly 140 points at market open today. Stocks in Hong Kong were down 2.6 percent, while those in Europe declined about 1 percent.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">And China’s currency, the renminbi, slipped below 7 to the dollar</strong> for the first time this year.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">It remains hard for businesses and political leaders to figure out their responses</strong> to the crisis. “Literally, we are evaluating on an ongoing basis <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/29/business/china-coronavirus-economy.html" title="">in real time</a>,” said a spokesman for Cummins, an engine maker with operations in China, “and I imagine other places are in the same position as we are.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">More:</strong></em> <em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0"><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/29/health/coronavirus-masks-hoarding.html" title="">Stop hoarding face masks</a></em><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">. That’s doing more harm than good. </em></p>, <h2 class="css-3ez4hu eoo0vm40" id="link-4ce3d15b">Les Wexner, Victoria’s Secret owner, may step down</h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Les Wexner, who has run the retail empire known as L Brands for 57 years, is in talks to <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.wsj.com/articles/victorias-secret-billionaire-in-talks-to-step-aside-and-sell-brand-11580299200" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">relinquish his C.E.O. title</a>, according to the WSJ and other media reports. His run has been dogged recently by both business underperformance and a longtime connection to the late financier Jeffrey Epstein.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">The business angle:</strong> Shares in L Brands fell 29 percent last year, as sales at Victoria’s Secret have dropped amid changing beauty ideals among American women. (The NYT reports that the company is <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/29/business/les-wexner-victorias-secret.html" title="">preparing for layoffs</a>.)</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">The Epstein angle:</strong> Mr. Wexner had employed Mr. Epstein as his longtime financial adviser, giving him broad authority over his billions. Mr. Wexner has denied knowledge of alleged sexual abuse committed by Mr. Epstein.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Mr. Wexner has become an uncomfortable distraction</strong> to L Brands. He has already had to address his ties to Mr. Epstein to shareholders.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">His departure could help L Brands </strong><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10"><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.ft.com/content/42514b20-42be-11ea-a43a-c4b328d9061c" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">sell a stake</a></strong><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10"> in Victoria’s Secret</strong>, raising money for the company, according to the FT. One potential investor is Sycamore Partners, a private equity firm specializing in retailers, the WSJ reports, citing unnamed sources.</p>, <h2 class="css-3ez4hu eoo0vm40" id="link-353610db">Why Wall Street’s climate pledges will fall short</h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Financial giants have made news recently by focusing more on environmental concerns in their investment decisions and threatening to sell shares in some offenders. But Greg Ip of the WSJ presents the argument for why that ultimately <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.wsj.com/articles/no-banks-dont-hold-the-key-to-climate-change-11580299203" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">won’t amount to much</a>.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">• Big oil companies aren’t that dependent on stock market investors, Mr. Ip writes, since they “generate plenty of cash and don’t need to issue new equity or debt to finance capital spending; in fact, most are buying back stock.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">• If the largest banks stop financing oil exploration companies, regional ones would rush to replace them.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">• And many oil producers are owned by sovereign governments and don’t need to bow to public opinion.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">“Divestment isn’t going to shrink the fossil-fuel industry,”</strong> Mr. Ip adds. What will is “changing the underlying economics” through financing cleaner energy producers and governmental measures like carbon taxes.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">More:</strong></em><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0"> Venture capitalists are </em><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0"><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.axios.com/venture-capital-climate-change-corporate-america-fd039df8-55ba-4d57-8b57-7d5353f17663.html" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">conspicuously absent</a></em><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0"> from this round of the climate change fight.</em></p>, <h2 class="css-3ez4hu eoo0vm40" id="link-3c45c868">Facebook’s sales growth hits a speed bump</h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The internet giant yesterday reported a slowdown in revenue growth, something it had warned would happen. But it’s coming at a time when Facebook faces plenty of tough challenges.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">The main points of Facebook’s latest earnings:</strong></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">• Fourth-quarter revenue <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.wsj.com/articles/facebook-reports-25-revenue-growth-in-latest-quarter-11580333926" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">grew 25 percent</a>, to $21.1 billion. That’s the slowest pace in Facebook’s history as a publicly traded company, according to the WSJ.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">• Expenses also rose, reducing Facebook’s operating margin to 42 percent from 46 percent.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">• Daily users of the core Facebook platform grew to 1.66 billion, beating analyst expectations of 1.65 billion.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">But the company also said it would pay $550 million</strong> to <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/29/technology/facebook-privacy-lawsuit-earnings.html" title="">settle a class-action lawsuit</a> over its use of facial-recognition technology. It’s the latest sign of the legal headaches that continue to bedevil Facebook, which also include new regulations around the world.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Shares in Facebook fell 7 percent</strong> in after-hours trading yesterday, with investors worrying that the company has peaked and faces only downside now.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Yet some analysts think there’s reason for optimism.</strong> Rich Greenfield of Lightshed told Bloomberg that Facebook’s business model “<a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2020-01-29/facebook-growth-slows-prompting-concerns-company-has-peaked" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">is not broken</a>.” And Tim Culpan of Bloomberg Opinion thinks the company can <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.bloomberg.com/view/articles/2020-01-29/facebook-earnings-company-leaves-too-much-money-on-global-table" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">make more money</a> from its overseas users.</p>, <h2 class="css-3ez4hu eoo0vm40" id="link-2d205ace">Warren Buffett gives up on newspapers</h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The billionaire announced an end to his 43-year career as a newspaper owner yesterday when Berkshire Hathaway agreed to <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/29/business/media/warren-buffett-newspapers.html" title="">sell its 31 papers</a> to Lee Enterprises for $140 million in cash, Michael de la Merced of the NYT reports.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10"><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.globenewswire.com/news-release/2020/01/29/1976653/0/en/Lee-Enterprises-to-Buy-Berkshire-Hathaway-Newspaper-Operations-Berkshire-Hathaway-to-Finance-All-Debt.html" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">The papers being sold</a></strong><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10"> include The Buffalo News</strong>, which Berkshire bought in 1977, and 30 other papers that Mr. Buffett had acquired over the past decade, including a collection of publishers in Virginia.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Mr. Buffett is bowing to reality.</strong> In an interview last year, he said that most papers were “<a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2019-04-23/warren-buffett-sees-most-newspapers-as-toast-after-ad-decline" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">toast</a>” because of falling ad sales — a sharp turnaround from his declaration in 2012 that he was an “<a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2012/06/18/business/media/newspaper-work-with-warren-buffett-as-the-boss.html" title="">addict</a>” who wanted to keep buying newspapers.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">But he’s still going to profit from the news industry.</strong> Berkshire will lend Lee $576 million, some of which will pay for the newspaper deal, at a 9 percent annual interest rate.</p>, <h2 class="css-3ez4hu eoo0vm40" id="link-17f4da0c">Japanese billionaire isn’t looking for love (on camera) anymore</h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Yusaku Maezawa has <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-asia-51306366" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">backed out of an online documentary</a> detailing his search for a girlfriend to take on his trip around the moon on SpaceX’s inaugural tourism flight.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">“Due to personal reasons, I have informed AbemaTV yesterday</strong> with my decision to no longer participate in the matchmaking documentary,” <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://twitter.com/yousuck2020/status/1222716360888729600" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">he tweeted</a> this morning.</p>, <h2 class="css-3ez4hu eoo0vm40" id="link-7c091e00">The speed read</h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Deals</strong></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">• The casino operator Penn National agreed to buy a 36 percent stake in Barstool Sports, the popular website, for $163 million. (<a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.cnbc.com/2020/01/29/barstool-founder-sets-eyes-on-buying-a-sports-team-after-casino-deal.html" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">CNBC</a>)</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">• AT&amp;T’s latest quarterly results show the company is still trying to justify its $85 billion takeover of Time Warner.
