(<a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.bloomberg.com/opinion/articles/2020-01-29/at-t-earnings-keep-promises-but-hbo-max-may-not-be-enough" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">Bloomberg Opinion</a>)</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">• The investment bank Evercore plans to lay off up to 6 percent of its employees. (<a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2020-01-29/evercore-to-slash-6-of-workforce-is-reviewing-operations?sref=kOA1eblB" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">Bloomberg</a>)</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">• The parent company of MoviePass filed for bankruptcy. (<a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.businessinsider.com/moviepass-owner-helios-and-matheson-files-for-bankruptcy-2020-1" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">Business Insider</a>)</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Politics and policy</strong></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">• President Trump signed into law the new North American free trade deal known as the U.S.M.C.A. (<a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/29/business/economy/usmca-trump.html" title="">NYT</a>)</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">• The European Parliament approved Britain’s withdrawal from the E.U. yesterday. (<a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/29/world/europe/brexit-brussels-eu.html" title="">NYT</a>)</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">• Mike Bloomberg’s latest attack on President Trump: health insurance protections for people with pre-existing conditions. (<a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/29/us/politics/bloomberg-trump-health-care.html" title="">NYT</a>)</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Tech</strong></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">• The E.U. recommended that its members put limits on using Huawei in their 5G wireless networks — but not ban the Chinese company outright. (<a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/29/world/europe/eu-huawei-5g.html" title="">NYT</a>)</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">• Apple and Broadcom were ordered to pay $1.1 billion in damages for infringing on Caltech patents on Wi-Fi technology. (<a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2020-01-29/apple-broadcom-ordered-to-pay-1-1-billion-for-infringement" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">Bloomberg</a>)</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">• The ride-hailing service Lyft plans to lay off employees in its marketing and enterprise sales divisions. (<a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/29/technology/lyft-layoffs-restructuring.html" title="">NYT</a>)</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Best of the rest</strong></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">• Boeing said that it expects costs tied to the 737 Max to surpass $18 billion. (<a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/29/business/boeing-737-max-costs.html" title="">NYT</a>)</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">• U.S. life expectancy rose in 2018 for the first time in four years, in large part because of a decline in fatal drug overdoses. (<a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.politico.com/news/2020/01/30/us-life-expectancy-increases-for-first-time-in-4-years-109397" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">Politico</a>)</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">• Why you don’t need to be an accountant to be a modern C.F.O. (<a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.wsj.com/articles/companies-appointing-fewer-finance-chiefs-with-accounting-skills-11580293801" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">WSJ</a>)</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">• Greta Thunberg wants to trademark her name to prevent commercial misuse. (<a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2020-01-29/greta-thunberg-seeks-trademarks-to-prevent-commercial-misuse" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">Bloomberg</a>)</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">We’d love your feedback. Please email thoughts and suggestions to </em><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="mailto:business@nytimes.com?subject=Newsletter%20Feedback" title=""><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">business@nytimes.com</em></a><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">.</em></p>, <p>Advertisement</p>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd" id="site-index-label">Site Index</h2>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-0">news</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-1">opinion</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-2">arts</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-3">living</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-4">more</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-subscribe-label">Subscribe</h3>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd">Site Information Navigation</h2>]
[<p>Advertisement</p>, <p>Supported by</p>, <p class="css-c2jxua e6idgb70"></p>, <h1 class="css-1j5ig2m e1h9rw200" id="link-3bbc3d28" itemprop="headline"><span>Microsoft Cloud Revenue Regains Momentum, Sending Profit Above Street Estimates</span></h1>, <p class="css-1fv7b6t e1jsehar1" itemprop="author" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">By<!-- --> <span class="css-1baulvz last-byline" itemprop="name">Reuters</span></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">(Reuters) - Microsoft Corp on Wednesday reported quarterly sales and profit that beat Wall Street expectations, driven by the first acceleration of Azure cloud computing revenue growth in eight quarters amid a pitched battle with Amazon.com Inc’s cloud unit.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Shares of the world's largest software company hit an all-time high in after-hours trading. The results reflected the approach of Chief Executive Satya Nadella, who for five years has re-centred Microsoft around the cloud, renting out its computing power and technology to large businesses.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Microsoft said Azure, its primary competitor to Amazon's cloud, grew 62% in the fiscal second quarter ended Dec. 31, down from a 76% revenue growth rate the year before but up from 59% in the fiscal first quarter.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Microsoft's chief financial officer, Amy Hood, said increased consumption of Azure services, which include offerings such as computing power to run applications and data storage services, drove the revenue growth.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">"We did have good usage, which matters a ton to that number," Hood told Reuters. "The core thing that we focused on - which is consumption growth - was quite good."</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Microsoft said revenue for its "commercial cloud" - a combination of Azure and the cloud-based versions of software such as Office - reached $12.5 billion, up from $9 billion the year before.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The commercial cloud gross profit margin - a key measure of cloud profitability that Microsoft has told investors it expects to improve - was 67%, versus 62% the year before.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Microsoft shares rose as much as 4.58% to $175.74 in after-hours trading.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">"This quarter was an absolute 'blow out quarter' across the board with no blemishes and in our opinion speaks to an inflection point in deal flow as more enterprises pick Redmond for the cloud," Wedbush analyst Dan Ives said in a note, referring to Microsoft's headquarters location in Redmond, Washington.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Hood said the company was working to improve margins on its core Azure services, which rely on data centres that can cost billions of dollars to build. She cited "hardware improvements and taking advantage of those hardware improvements."</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Microsoft's revenue and profit for the second quarter were $36.9 billion and $1.51 per share, respectively, compared with analyst estimates of $35.7 billion and $1.32 per share, according to IBES data from Refinitiv.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Microsoft has focused on hybrid cloud computing – in which a business can use a mix of Microsoft’s data centres and its own – as well as on delivering its longstanding productivity programs such as Office via the cloud.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The shift to the cloud has driven Microsoft's shares up more than 50% in the past year, as it gains ground against market leader Amazon and also parries the threats to its classic software programs from newer entrants like Alphabet Inc’s Google.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">In 2019, Microsoft had 22% share of the cloud computing infrastructure market, compared with 45% at Amazon and 5% from Google, according to data from Forrester Research.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">"Azure’s renewed growth doesn’t yet pose a threat to AWS’s supremacy in the cloud market, but it does present an opportunity to further close the gap on Amazon and increase its lead over other cloud providers," said Andrew MacMillen of Nucleus Research.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The company’s Intelligent Cloud unit, which includes Azure, reported revenue that rose 27% to $11.9 billion in the quarter, versus expectations of $11.4 billion. For the fiscal third quarter ending in March, Microsoft forecast revenue with a midpoint of $11.9 billion for the unit, compared with analyst expectations of $11.4 billion.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Its Productivity and Business Process unit, which contains the LinkedIn social network, reported $11.8 billion in revenue compared with estimates of $11.4 billion. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Revenue in the unit that contains Windows was $13.2 billion, compared with estimates of $12.8 billion. Over the past year, Windows sales were hampered by shortages of PC chips from Intel Corp, but the chipmaker said last week it had alleviated most of those supply concerns.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Microsoft forecast revenue of between $10.75 billion (8.2 billion pounds) and $11.15 billion for the unit containing Windows in the fiscal third quarter, a wider-than-normal forecast range that the company said was because of uncertainty surrounding the spread of the coronavirus in China.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"> (Reporting by Stephen Nellis in San Francisco; Additional reporting by Ayanti Bera in Bengaluru; Editing by Matthew Lewis and Leslie Adler)</p>, <p>Advertisement</p>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd" id="site-index-label">Site Index</h2>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-0">news</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-1">opinion</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-2">arts</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-3">living</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-4">more</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-subscribe-label">Subscribe</h3>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd">Site Information Navigation</h2>]
[<p>Advertisement</p>, <p>Supported by</p>, <p class="css-c2jxua e6idgb70"></p>, <h1 class="css-1j5ig2m e1h9rw200" id="link-2aad182" itemprop="headline"><span>H&amp;M Reshuffles at the Top as Recovery Accelerates</span></h1>, <p class="css-1fv7b6t e1jsehar1" itemprop="author" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">By<!-- --> <span class="css-1baulvz last-byline" itemprop="name">Reuters</span></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">STOCKHOLM — Swedish fashion giant H&amp;M appointed company veteran Helena Helmersson as chief executive on Thursday as it reported its first rise in annual profit since 2015 and pleased the market with unexpectedly strong fourth-quarter profit growth. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Helmersson, 46, has been with H&amp;M for over two decades and has held positions from head of sustainability and global head of production to, most recently, chief operating officer. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">She replaces the founder's grandson Karl-Johan Persson, who moves to the chairman role.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Helmersson has been involved in setting strategy in recent years. "I want to continue with the plan that is already on the table, and then of course also keep a close eye on the world around us and tweak the plan as we go along," she told Reuters. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Santander analyst Rebecca McClellan said the succession looked sensible. "Karl-Johan is not going anywhere, in reality he has just got a change of mandate, and Helena has been around for some time," she said.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Karl-Johan will in May move into the role vacated by his father, 72-year-old Stefan Persson - the chairman for more than 20 years - marking a shift to a younger generation at the top of the company.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">RECOVERY ON TRACK</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Shares surged as much as 10% after the world's no. 2 fashion retailer also beat earnings expectations for the fourth quarter.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">H&amp;M is recovering from years of sliding profits and mounting inventories due to slowing footfall at its core H&amp;M-branded stores.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Profit in the September through November quarter was 5.40 billion crowns ($569 million), up from 4.35 billion a year before. Analysts had on average forecast a profit of 4.78 billion crowns, according to Refinitiv data.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Big investments in logistics, digital technology, new store concepts and independent brands to meet changing shopping habits and tougher competition helped push annual net sales 11% higher in Swedish crowns.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">"The ongoing transformation work has contributed to continued positive sales development, with more full-price sales, lower markdowns and increased market share," the company said in a statement.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Outgoing chairman Stefan Persson, who was CEO from 1982 to 1997, said in a rare interview that it was a good time to step down now that the company was in good condition. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">"The industry is struggling with huge problems, and I would say that we have now managed to transform, even though there are still many challenges ahead, in a way that has left us with our financial position more or less intact and able to weather also future challenges," he told Reuters.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">H&amp;M said in its earnings report its financial position was strong. Its net debt to profit before depreciation and amortisation ratio, which it has a target of keeping below 1.0, improved to 0.2 in the quarter. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">NO REVOLUTION</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Stefan said he expected little change to strategy under the new regime. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">"Helena has been with the company for a long time, and in such positions that there will not be any revolution as such. I not least feel confident that she really has placed the issue of sustainability on the map," he said.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Helmersson, who will be H&amp;M's first female CEO, was the group's head of sustainability at the time of the Rana Plaza disaster in Bangladesh that killed 1,135 garment workers.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The incident prompted massive soul-searching in the industry about factory safety. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">H&amp;M's biggest rival, market leader and Zara owner Inditex, also promoted its chief operating officer to chief executive last May. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Both chief executives have a strong sustainability remit, underlining how keen fashion companies are to prioritise their environmental strategies at a time of a public backlash against cheap, throwaway clothing.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">"We want to keep growing, and that's what we'll do. But in future we won't be able to use the natural resources that we depend on today, not in the same way," Helmersson told Reuters.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The outbreak of the newly identified coronavirus in China had a negative impact on sales in that country at the end of January, outgoing CEO Persson said at a press conference to accompany the results in Stockholm on Thursday.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"> (Reporting by Anna Ringstrom; Additional reporting by Colm Fulton, Johannes Hellstron and Johan Ahlander; Writing by Anna Ringstrom and Sonya Dowsett; Editing by Niklas Pollard and Jan Harvey)</p>, <p>Advertisement</p>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd" id="site-index-label">Site Index</h2>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-0">news</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-1">opinion</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-2">arts</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-3">living</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-4">more</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-subscribe-label">Subscribe</h3>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd">Site Information Navigation</h2>]
[<p>Advertisement</p>, <p>Supported by</p>, <p class="css-c2jxua e6idgb70"></p>, <h1 class="css-1j5ig2m e1h9rw200" id="link-7153de08" itemprop="headline"><span>US Economy Grew Modestly Last Quarter Against a Hazy Outlook</span></h1>, <p class="css-1fv7b6t e1jsehar1" itemprop="author" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">By<!-- --> <span class="css-1baulvz last-byline" itemprop="name">The Associated Press</span></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">WASHINGTON — The U.S. economy expanded at a moderate 2.1% annual rate in the final three months of 2019, capping a year when a weak global landscape and a sharp pullback in business investment resulting from President Donald Trump's trade fights combined to slow growth.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The fourth-quarter rise in the gross domestic product — the economy’s total output of goods and services — matched the third-quarter gain, the government said Thursday. For all of last year, economic growth — 2.3% — was the weakest since Trump's election in 2016.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The picture that emerged Thursday from the government's first estimate of growth in the October-December quarter was a mixed one: Consumers kept spending, but they have grown more cautious. Incomes are rising but at a slower pace. Most alarmingly, businesses have been sharply reducing their investment as Trump's ongoing trade fights have heightened uncertainty for corporations. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">At the same time, low interest rates, low inflation and a robust job market have given consumers and home buyers the means to keep fueling steady, if only modest, growth. Global risks — including potentially severe economic damage from China's viral outbreak — will continue to overhang the economy. But they're also likely to persuade the Fed to keep interest rates low and perhaps even further reduce them if the threats to the economy escalate.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Many economists saw Trump's decision to lower trade tensions by signing a Phase One agreement with China as key to lowering the risk of a recession this year.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">'"The economic fundamentals are very solid right now," said Gus Faucher, chief economist at PNC. “Some of the downside risks that the Federal Reserve had been concerned about have faded now that we have a Phase One trade deal.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Lawrence Kudlow, head of the president's National Economic Council, said Thursday he expects GDP growth will be helped in the coming year by the new trade deal with Canada and Mexico, and the commitments by the Chinese to boost purchases of U.S. exports.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“China has to work its way through this health crisis, but I think once that abates, you will see big export" gains, Kudlow told reporters at the White House.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">For the October-December quarter, growth was supported by solid but slower consumer spending and an improvement in the trade deficit. Those factors offset a further drop in business investment in new plants and equipment and a slowdown in businesses' restocking of store shelves.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The full-year 2.3% growth of GDP in 2019 marked a sharp drop from the 2.9% gain in 2018, when the economy enjoyed a boost from Trump’s tax cuts and from billions in increased government spending.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Most economists foresee even slower growth in 2020 of around 1.8%. That assumes no serious damage from the coronavirus or other threats.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Even the U.S. elections for the White House and Congress could end up weakening growth if the campaigns were to further elevate uncertainty among consumers and businesses and thereby lead them to cut back on spending.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Under Trump, GDP growth has so far fallen well short of his campaign pledges. But unemployment has reached a 50-year low during his presidency. And after trade tensions with China began to cool late last year, the stock market rebounded and attained new highs.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Mark Zandi, chief economist at Moody's Analytics, said the presidential election may turn on how the economy is faring in key swing states.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“What really matters is the economy in Pennsylvania, Michigan and Wisconsin,” Zandi said. '"There things are not going well because the trade war has done a lot of damage in those states."</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">For the fourth quarter, consumer spending, which accounts for about 70% of economic activity, slowed to an annual gain of 1.8%. That was down from an annual spending surge of 4.6% in the second quarter and 3.2% in the third quarter. The slowdown was led by a drop-off in new car sales.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Business investment spending fell for a third straight quarter, dropping at an annual rate of 1.5%, a decline that has been blamed on business uncertainty generated by the rising trade tensions. The hope is that business will start investing again now that the Trump administration has declared a trade ceasefire with China.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Trade contributed to growth in the fourth quarter with imports, which subtract from U.S. growth, falling much faster than exports. That trend added 1.5 percentage points to growth in the quarter. But economists see this trend as only temporary: Many U.S. businesses had accelerated their pace of imports in the July-September quarter to get ahead of an expected increase in Trump's import taxes. As a result, they needed fewer imports in the October-December quarter. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Business stockpiling subtracted a full percentage point to growth, with part of that blamed on the General Motors strike that cut into car inventories.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">___</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">AP White House reporter Darlene Superville contributed to this report</p>, <p>Advertisement</p>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd" id="site-index-label">Site Index</h2>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-0">news</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-1">opinion</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-2">arts</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-3">living</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-4">more</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-subscribe-label">Subscribe</h3>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd">Site Information Navigation</h2>]
[<p>Advertisement</p>, <p>Supported by</p>, <p class="css-c2jxua e6idgb70"></p>, <h1 class="css-1j5ig2m e1h9rw200" id="link-e6e1a61" itemprop="headline"><span>Tesla Extends Profit Run, Promises Record Production, Driving Stock Up 13%</span></h1>, <p class="css-1fv7b6t e1jsehar1" itemprop="author" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">By<!-- --> <span class="css-1baulvz last-byline" itemprop="name">Reuters</span></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">(Reuters) - Tesla Inc posted its second quarterly profit in a row as vehicle deliveries hit a record and the company said it would comfortably make more than half a million units this year, pushing its shares to new highs.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The delivery forecast, higher by more than a third than last year's production, suggests Tesla is looking at a steadier chapter after years of steep losses, production troubles and clashes between chief executive Elon Musk and U.S. regulators.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The electric carmaker's stock, which has nearly doubled in the past year, jumped 13% after hours on Wednesday, cracking the $600 mark for the first time.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Tesla said that the manufacturing process at its new Shanghai factory, which started delivering Model 3 sedans a month ago, was running as expected and that it would increase production of the mass-market cars because of strong demand in China.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The $2 billion Shanghai factory is key to Tesla's growth strategy. There it aims to produce 150,000 Model 3 sedans and later increase output to 250,000 a year, including the Model Y.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">But the company warned of a 1-1.5 week delay in the ramp of Shanghai-built Model 3 cars because China ordered a shutdown of the factory after a new coronavirus breakout that has killed 170 people and infected thousands.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">"This may slightly impact profitability for the quarter but is limited as the profit contribution from Model 3 Shanghai remains in the early stages," Tesla's chief financial officer Zachary Kirkhorn said on a post-earnings call. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The company is evaluating whether it will be hurt by the virus and whether the supply chain for cars built in its Fremont, California plant will be affected, he said.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Tesla said it started production of the new electric crossover utility vehicle Model Y at the Fremont factory this month and plans to deliver the first cars by the end of March, ahead of schedule.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Tesla already starting Model Y production was the most notable item in the release, Roth Capital Partners analyst Craig Irwin wrote in a note.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">"For a company that has always been late, this is a big improvement," he said.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Tesla initially did not expect to make the Model Y until late 2020 and then moved up the forecast to this summer, finally beating that deadline by several months.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">COST CONTROL </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The results indicate that Tesla is controlling costs better, a metric that investors have questioned Musk on before and that he was quick to talk about on the call. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">"In 2019, we managed to generate more than $1 billion of free cash flow while building a factory in Shanghai in record time and while building parts of Model Y production," he said.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Tesla's cash balance increased to $6.3 billion and total operating expenses rose less than 1% to $1.03 billion in the December quarter. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">And while its revenue per unit delivered rose by only 3% in the fourth quarter, operating profits per vehicle rose by roughly 19%. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">(Graphic: https://fingfx.thomsonreuters.com/gfx/editorcharts/TESLA-RESULTS/0H001R884BN6/index.html)</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Tesla, which last week overtook Volkswagen as the second-most valuable carmaker behind Japan's Toyota Motor Corp, still trails luxury carmaker rivals on steady profits per vehicle, a key metric. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">(Graphic: https://fingfx.thomsonreuters.com/gfx/editorcharts/TESLA-RESULTS/0H001R87WBMF/index.html)</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Some analysts have questioned the more than $104 billion valuation, but investors are betting that Tesla has overcome its many struggles and can compete with larger, better capitalized rivals to lead the industry in technological innovation for next-generation cars.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The company's debt pile is high as well, amounting to $13.42 billion at the end of 2019.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Tesla reported a 4.9% operating margin in the fourth quarter and said Model Y production and the Shanghai factory ramp-up were likely to weigh on margins temporarily.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Its new initiatives, which also include the construction of its first European factory in Germany, an electric pickup truck, a new generation of the Tesla Roadster and automated driving features, are also likely to put a strain on its cash pile. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Net income attributable to common shareholders fell to $105 million, or 56 cents per share, for the three months ended Dec. 31, from $140 million, or 78 cents per share, a year earlier. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Revenue rose to $7.38 billion from $7.23 billion a year earlier. Analysts had expected revenue of $7.02 billion. (https://bit.ly/2GvolcO)</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">(GRAPHIC-Tesla debt and cash flow - https://fingfx.thomsonreuters.com/gfx/mkt/13/1578/1553/TESLA.jpg)</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"> (Reporting by Akanksha Rana in Bengaluru and Tina Bellon in New York; Editing by Lisa Shumaker, Sayantani Ghosh and Gerry Doyle)</p>, <p>Advertisement</p>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd" id="site-index-label">Site Index</h2>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-0">news</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-1">opinion</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-2">arts</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-3">living</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-4">more</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-subscribe-label">Subscribe</h3>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd">Site Information Navigation</h2>]
[<p>Advertisement</p>, <p>Supported by</p>, <p class="css-c2jxua e6idgb70"></p>, <h1 class="css-1j5ig2m e1h9rw200" id="link-e6e1a61" itemprop="headline"><span>Tesla Extends Profit Run, Promises Record Production, Driving Stock Up 13%</span></h1>, <p class="css-1fv7b6t e1jsehar1" itemprop="author" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">By<!-- --> <span class="css-1baulvz last-byline" itemprop="name">Reuters</span></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">(Reuters) - Tesla Inc on Wednesday posted the second quarterly profit in a row on record vehicle deliveries and said it would produce more than 500,000 units this year, as the electric carmaker's shares surged to new highs.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Shares rose 13% after hours, reaching an all-time high and for the first time cracking the $600 mark as Tesla promised to "comfortably exceed" half a million deliveries, an increase by more than a third from the 367,500 it delivered last year.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Tesla on Wednesday said the manufacturing process at its new Shanghai factory was running as expected and said it would increase production of its mass-market Model 3 due to strong demand in China.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The company also said it has started production of its new Model Y, an electric crossover utility vehicle, at its Fremont, California plant this month and plans to deliver the first models by the end of March, ahead of schedule.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Wednesday's results suggest Tesla is looking at a more steady chapter after several tumultuous years marked by steep losses, production troubles and clashes with U.S. regulators. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">And while Chief Executive Elon Musk made unusual comments during Wednesday's investor call, he avoided any embarrassing episodes that led him to apologize to Wall Street analysts in the past.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Investors overall are betting that Tesla has overcome its many struggles and can compete with larger, better capitalized rivals to lead the industry on technological innovation for the next generation of cars.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Their approval also is a boon to Musk personally after his mercurial behavior and a series of scandals and public outbursts forced him to step down as chairman.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Cost efficiencies and high production volumes should allow Tesla to ultimately reach industry-leading operating margins, the company said on Wednesday. It reported a 4.9% operating margin in the fourth quarter. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">That Tesla is already starting Model Y production in Fremont was the most notable item in the release, Roth Capital Partners analyst Craig Irwin wrote in a note.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">"For a company that has always been late, this is a big improvement," he said.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Tesla initially did not expect to make the Model Y until late 2020 and then moved up its forecast to this summer and then beat even that deadline by several months.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Tesla's cost efficiencies become apparent when comparing revenue and profit on a per-vehicle-basis. A review of Tesla's results showed that even though revenue per unit delivered rose by only 3% on a quarterly basis in the fourth quarter, operating profits per vehicle rose by roughly 19% in the same time.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Tesla is also trailing luxury carmaker rivals on steady profits per vehicle, a key metric closely watched by auto professionals to compare companies across the industry.(Graphic: https://fingfx.thomsonreuters.com/gfx/editorcharts/TESLA-RESULTS/0H001R87WBMF/index.html) </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Tesla's stock has more than doubled in value since the company posted a third-quarter profit, beat estimates for 2019 vehicle deliveries and ramped up production at its Gigafactory in China.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The latest rally pushed the company to a valuation of more than $104 billion (79.12 billion pounds) and some analysts questioned the rationale.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">"It has a fantastic brand, formidable manufacturing capabilities and (by all accounts) a fabulous product; but is it really worth more than Volkswagen," said Hargreaves Lansdown analyst Nicholas Hyett.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Tesla last week overtook the German company as the second most valuable carmaker behind Japan's Toyota Motor Corp. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Key to Tesla's growth strategy is the company's $2 billion Shanghai factory, where it aims to produce 150,000 Model 3 sedans and later increase output to 250,000 a year, including the Model Y.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">But as China tries to contain a rapidly spreading coronavirus, Tesla expects a delay of one and a half weeks in the ramp up of the Shanghai-built Model 3 due to a government-required factory shutdown.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The Model Y production in California and the Shanghai factory ramp-up are also expected to "temporarily weigh on margins." </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">PRESSURE ON CASH PILE</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Tesla on Wednesday said its cash balance increased to $6.3 billion and total operating expenses rose less than 1% to $1.03 billion in the three last three months of 2019.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">At the same time, however, Tesla's debt remains steady, amounting to $13.42 billion as of the end of 2019. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The company has been trying to keep a tight lid on costs but its new initiatives, which also include the construction of its first European factory in Germany, an electric pickup truck, a new generation of the Tesla Roadster and automated driving features, are likely to put a strain on its cash pile. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Musk on Wednesday also said Tesla would focus on ramping up battery production capacities in 2020 to be able to produce more vehicles.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Net income attributable to common shareholders fell to $105 million, or 56 cents per share, for the three months ended Dec. 31, from $140 million, or 78 cents per share, a year earlier. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Revenue rose to $7.38 billion from $7.23 billion a year earlier. Analysts had expected revenue of $7.02 billion. (https://ir.tesla.com/static-files/b3cf7f5e-546a-4a65-9888-c928b914b529)</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">(Graphic: Tesla debt and cash flow, https://fingfx.thomsonreuters.com/gfx/mkt/13/1578/1553/TESLA.jpg) </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"> (Reporting by Akanksha Rana in Bengaluru and Tina Bellon in New York; Editing by Sriraj Kalluvila and Lisa Shumaker)</p>, <p>Advertisement</p>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd" id="site-index-label">Site Index</h2>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-0">news</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-1">opinion</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-2">arts</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-3">living</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-4">more</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-subscribe-label">Subscribe</h3>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd">Site Information Navigation</h2>]
[<p>Advertisement</p>, <p>Supported by</p>, <p class="css-c2jxua e6idgb70"></p>, <h1 class="css-1j5ig2m e1h9rw200" id="link-11745a6a" itemprop="headline"><span>Europe Evacuates Citizens From China, Russia Shuts Border</span></h1>, <p class="css-1fv7b6t e1jsehar1" itemprop="author" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">By<!-- --> <span class="css-1baulvz last-byline" itemprop="name">The Associated Press</span></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">LISBON, Portugal — European countries stepped up efforts Thursday to contain the virus sweeping through central China, sending a chartered airliner there to evacuate hundreds of European citizens, scrapping more commercial flights to Chinese destinations and keeping some 7,000 people on a cruise ship while one possibly infected passenger got tested. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Signaling intensifying international concern, the World Health Organization in Geneva declared the viral outbreak that has sickened more than 7,800 people and caused 170 deaths in China as a global emergency, while Russia closed its long border with the Asian giant.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Russian Prime Minister Mikhail Mishustin issued a decree ordering the temporary closure of the border, which extends for 4,200 kilometers (2,600 miles). In addition, all train traffic between Russia and China was halted except for one train connecting Moscow and Beijing. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">A passenger airliner enlisted for the evacuation took off Thursday morning from a former Portuguese military airport southeast of Lisbon carrying only the pilots and crew. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Capt. Antonios Efthymiou said the flight would stop in Paris to pick up a team of doctors and extra crew members before heading to Hanoi and then China. Efthymiou told Portuguese media it would bring back about 350 Europeans. He said the crew would take special medical precautions but did not elaborate.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Britain said its delayed repatriation flight for 200 U.K. citizens in Wuhan would leave ther Friday, with the returning Britons quarantined for 14 days upon arrival. The U.K.-government chartered plane had been due to return earlier but it was delayed because permissions form the Chinese government had not come through.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">China so far has reported nearly 200 deaths and about 8,000 confirmed cases of the virus on its mainland. Outside China, there are more than 80 infected people in 19 countries. Those include 13 confirmed cases in Europe so far: five in France, five in Germany, two in Italy and one in Finland.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">A scare over a 54-year-old woman with flu-like symptoms led Italian authorities to keep 6,000 passengers and 1,000 crew members on the cruise ship docked north of Rome. The Costa Crociere cruise line said the woman and her partner, who had no symptoms, were put into isolation Wednesday. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The passengers were allowed to disembark on Thursday after tests for the new virus from China came back negative, Italian coast guard Capt. Stefano Varone said. The ship was sailing from Mallorca, Spain, to Civitavecchia on a weeklong Mediterranean cruise. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">While those tests came back negative, two Chinese tourists visiting Rome tested positive for the virus, Premier Giuseppe Conte said Thursday, adding that Italy had barred flights coming from and going to China.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Germany confirmed a fifth case there, all involving employees at Munich-based auto parts maker Webasto, which has facilities in Wuhan. Officials think the virus was transmitted by a Chinese employee who visited Germany for training earlier this month and tested positive on her return to China.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The Czech Republic announced it was stopping issuing visas to Chinese citizens due to the outbreak. More than 600,000 Chinese tourists are estimated to have visited the Czech Republic last year, especially its old-world capital city of Prague.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">On the retail front, Swedish furniture and home goods retailer IKEA announced all its stores in mainland China would remain closed to protect customers and staff from the outbreak. The stores are a favorite haunt of Chinese city dwellers, both for shopping and for just hanging out. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">More European airlines announced halts in service to China, all citing efforts “to protect the health and security of customers and staff.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Air France suspended all its regular passenger flights to and from China until Feb. 9. The French carrier had already suspended flights to Wuhan, the epicenter of the viral outbreak, and reduced traffic to Beijing and Shanghai. Air France said it will run special flights starting Thursday to bring back some customers and employees from Beijing and Shanghai.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Scandinavian Airlines announced it was halting all its flights to Beijing and Shanghai beginning Friday and running through Feb. 9th. SAS has 12 regular weekly flights from Scandinavia to China.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Spain’s Iberia national airline halted the three return flights a week it runs between Madrid and Shanghai due to the virus, a move it said would continue through February.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Finnish national airline Finnair said it has stopped accepting new bookings on its flights to mainland China.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Those announcements followed earlier moves to halt or reduce flights to China by other European airlines, including British Airways, Lufthansa, Austrian Airlines, Swiss and KLM, which after the weekend is adding Beijing and Shanghai to its list of suspended Chinese destinations.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The virus comes from the coronavirus family, which includes the common cold but also more severe illnesses, such as SARS and MERS. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">European passengers escaping Wuhan by air are expected to reach France on Friday. Then they will be quarantined for 14 days, but as compensation they will be put up at a southern vacation resort with a view of the Mediterranean Sea.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">In contrast, American evacuees from China are being kept at a military facility.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The French resort is in the small town of Carry-le-Rouet. Its mayor protested the move, fearing it could keep people away from a local sea urchin culinary festival this weekend, town hall communications director Peggy Molina said. But the French government simply requisitioned the resort, she said.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Underlining EU nations' hasty preparations to respond to the virus, Molina said the town hall was told only Thursday that it would be hosting evacuees starting Friday.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">—-</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Associated Press writers Nicole Winfield in Rome, Ciaran Giles in Madrid, Karel Janicek in Prague, Gianfranco Stara in Civitavecchia, Angela Charlton and Elaine Ganley in Paris and Daria Litvinova in Moscow contributed to this report.</p>, <p>Advertisement</p>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd" id="site-index-label">Site Index</h2>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-0">news</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-1">opinion</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-2">arts</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-3">living</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-4">more</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-subscribe-label">Subscribe</h3>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd">Site Information Navigation</h2>]
[<p>Advertisement</p>, <p>Supported by</p>, <p class="css-c2jxua e6idgb70"></p>, <h1 class="css-1j5ig2m e1h9rw200" id="link-5e9c4576" itemprop="headline"><span>UN Agency Declares Global Emergency Over Virus From China</span></h1>, <p class="css-1fv7b6t e1jsehar1" itemprop="author" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">By<!-- --> <span class="css-1baulvz last-byline" itemprop="name">The Associated Press</span></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">GENEVA — The World Health Organization declared the outbreak sparked by a new virus in China that has spread to more than a dozen countries as a global emergency Thursday after the number of cases spiked more than tenfold in a week. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The U.N. health agency defines an international emergency as an “extraordinary event” that constitutes a risk to other countries and requires a coordinated international response. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">China first informed WHO about cases of the new virus in late December. To date, China has reported more than 7,800 cases including 170 deaths. Eighteen other countries have since reported cases, as scientists race to understand how exactly the virus is spreading and how severe it is. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Experts say there is significant evidence the virus is spreading among people in China and have noted with concern instances in other countries — including the United States, France, Japan, Germany, Canada, South Korea and Vietnam — where there have also been isolated cases of human-to-human transmission. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Speaking to reporters in Geneva, WHO director-general Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus noted the worrisome spread of the virus between people outside China. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“The main reason for this declaration is not because of what is happening in China but because of what is happening in other countries," he said. “Our greatest concern is the potential for this virus to spread to countries with weaker health systems which are ill-prepared to deal with it."</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“This declaration is not a vote of non-confidence in China," he said. “On the contrary, WHO continues to have the confidence in China’s capacity to control the outbreak."</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">A declaration of a global emergency typically brings greater money and resources, but may also prompt nervous governments to restrict travel and trade to affected countries. The announcement also imposes more disease reporting requirements on countries. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">In the wake of numerous airlines cancelling flights to China and businesses including Starbucks and McDonald's temporarily closing hundreds of shops, Tedros said WHO was not recommending limiting travel or trade to China.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“There is no reason for measures that unnecessarily interfere with international travel and trade,” he said. He added that Chinese President Xi Jinping had committed to help stop the spread of the virus beyond its borders.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“During my discussion with the president and other officials, they're willing to support countries with weaker health systems with whatever is possible,” Tedros said. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">On Thursday, France confirmed that a doctor who was in contact with a patient with the new virus later became infected himself. The doctor is now being treated in an isolated room at a Paris hospital. Outbreak specialists worry that the spread of new viruses from patients to health workers can signal the virus is becoming adapted to human transmission.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">China raised the death toll to 170 on Thursday and more countries reported infections, including some spread locally, as foreign evacuees from China's worst-hit region returned home to medical tests and even isolation.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Russia announced it was closing its 2,600-mile border with China, joining Mongolia and North Korea in barring crossings to guard against a new viral outbreak. It had been de facto closed because of the Lunar New Year holiday, but Russian authorities said the closure would be extended until March 1.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Meanwhile, the United States and South Korea confirmed their first cases of person-to-person spread of the virus. The man in the U.S. is married to a 60-year-old Chicago woman who got sick from the virus after she returned from a trip to Wuhan, the Chinese city that is the epicenter of the outbreak. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The case in South Korea was a 56-year-old man who had contact with a patient who was diagnosed with the new virus earlier. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Although scientists expect to see limited transmission of the virus between people with close contact, like within families, the instances of spread to people who may have had less exposure to the virus in Japan and Germany is worrying. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">In Japan, a man in his 60s caught the virus after working as a bus driver for two tour groups from Wuhan. In Germany, a man in his 30s was sickened after a Chinese colleague from Shanghai, whose parents had recently visited from Wuhan, came to his office for a business meeting. Four other workers later became infected. The woman had shown no symptoms of the virus until her flight back to China.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“That’s the kind of transmission chain that we don’t want to see,” said Marion Koopmans, an infectious diseases specialist at Erasmus University Medical Center in the Netherlands and a member of WHO’s emergency committee. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Koopmans said more information was needed about how the virus was spread in these instances and whether it meant the virus was more infectious than previously thought or if there was something unusual in those circumstances. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Mark Harris, a professor of virology at Leeds University, said it appears that the spread of the virus among people is probably easier than initially presumed. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“If transmission between humans was difficult, then the numbers would have plateaued,” he said. Harris said the limited amount of virus spread beyond China suggested the outbreak could still be contained, but that if people are spreading the disease before they show symptoms — as some Chinese politicians and researchers have suggested — that could compromise control efforts. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The new virus has now infected more people in China than were sickened there during the 2002-2003 outbreak of SARS, or severe acute respiratory syndrome, a cousin of the new virus. Both are from the coronavirus family, which also includes those that can cause the common cold.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The latest figures for mainland China show an increase of 38 deaths and 1,737 cases for a total of 7,736 confirmed cases. Of the new deaths, 37 were in Hubei province, of which Wuhan is the capital, and one was in the southwestern province of Sichuan. Outside China, there are 82 infections in 18 countries, according to WHO.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">China extended its Lunar New Year holiday to Sunday to try to keep people home, but the wave of returning travelers could potentially cause the virus to spread further. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">China has been largely praised for a swift and effective response to the outbreak, although questions have been raised about the police suppression of what were early on considered mere rumors — a reflection of the one-party Communist state's determination to maintain a monopoly on information in spite of smart phones and social media. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">That stands in stark contrast to the initial response to SARS, when medical reports were hidden as state secrets. The delayed response was blamed for allowing the disease to spread worldwide, killing around 800 people. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Dr. Jeremy Farrar, director of Britain's Wellcome Trust, welcomed WHO's emergency declaration. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“This virus has spread at unprecedented scale and speed, with cases passing between people in multiple countries across the world,” he said in a statement. “It is also a stark reminder of how vulnerable we are to epidemics of infectious diseases known and unknown.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">___</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Cheng reported from London. Associated Press writers Ken Moritsugu in Beijing, Elaine Ganley in Paris, Frank Jordans in Berlin, Mari Yamaguchi in Tokyo and Kim Tong-hyung in Seoul, South Korea, contributed to this report.</p>, <p>Advertisement</p>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd" id="site-index-label">Site Index</h2>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-0">news</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-1">opinion</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-2">arts</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-3">living</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-4">more</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-subscribe-label">Subscribe</h3>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd">Site Information Navigation</h2>]
[<p>Advertisement</p>, <p>Supported by</p>, <h1 class="css-1qskr30 e1h9rw200" id="link-23ef6ef0" itemprop="headline"><span>Inside the Fight Over Trump’s Israel-Palestine Deal</span></h1>, <p class="css-1ifw933 e1wiw3jv0" id="article-summary">Here are the sticking points.</p>, <p class="css-1fv7b6t e1jsehar1" itemprop="author" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">By<!-- --> <span class="css-1baulvz last-byline" itemprop="name">Spencer Bokat-Lindell</span></p>, <p class="css-cpkn1d e1wtpvyy1">Mr. Bokat-Lindell is a writer in The New York Times Opinion section.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">This article is part of the Debatable newsletter. You can </em><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/newsletters/debatable" title=""><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">sign up here</em></a><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0"> to receive it Tuesdays and Thursdays.</em></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">President Trump <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/28/world/middleeast/peace-plan.html" title="">unveiled his plan</a> to end one of the world’s oldest and most intractable conflicts on Tuesday in what he has called “the deal of the century.” The 180-page proposal, which was drafted without Palestinian input, would grant Israel most of its demands in exchange for the possibility of a future Palestinian state with limited sovereignty. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The plan was predictably greeted with enthusiasm by Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel and condemnation by President Mahmoud Abbas of the Palestinian Authority. Here are the central parts of the plan, why it’s so controversial and how people on different sides of the issue are responding. </p>, <h2 class="css-1320w4z eoo0vm40" id="link-666175c1">‘The borders of Israel will be redrawn’</h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Background: </strong>The state of Israel was forged after the Holocaust in the crucible of the 1948 Arab-Israeli war, which left Israel with control over 78 percent of what had previously been British-controlled Palestine. After the Six-Day War in 1967, Israel took control of the remaining 22 percent of Palestinian land, as well as the Sinai Peninsula from Egypt and the Golan Heights from Syria. </p>, <p class="css-15hwz5e evys1bk0">Today, there are nine million Israeli citizens, about <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.reuters.com/article/us-israel-election-arabs/israels-arab-minority-urged-to-boycott-election-over-divisive-law-idUSKCN1RH0KQ" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">1.9 million of whom are Arab</a>.</p>, <p class="css-15hwz5e evys1bk0">In the occupied territory of the West Bank, where Palestinians are subject to Israeli military law, there are about three million Arabs, most of whom live under the semiautonomous Palestinian Authority.</p>, <p class="css-15hwz5e evys1bk0">Roughly two million Arabs also live in Gaza blockaded by Israel under the rule of Hamas, which the United States and other countries have deemed a terrorist organization.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Some proposals for a two-state solution have looked to the pre-1967 borders as a palimpsest over which the lines of a new Palestinian state might be sketched. Mr. Trump’s plan would allocate roughly <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/trump-set-to-release-long-awaited-mideast-peace-package-seen-as-generous-to-israel/2020/01/28/883e3d50-41d3-11ea-b5fc-eefa848cde99_story.html" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">70 percent</a> of the West Bank for Palestinian control; the cession of Israeli land near Gaza would make up for the remaining 30 percent.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Critical point: The West Bank is populated with Israeli settlements, </strong>which much of the <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2019/11/18/world/middleeast/israel-west-bank-settlements.html" title="">world regards as illegal</a>.<strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10"> </strong></p>, <p class="css-15hwz5e evys1bk0">Under the plan, Israel would freeze the construction of new settlements for four years but annex existing ones, as well as the Jordan River Valley. </p>, <p class="css-15hwz5e evys1bk0">As a result, Palestinian territory would be scattered over a chain of islands in a sea of Israeli territory. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Mr. Trump’s plan endorses the Netanyahu doctrine that, for Israel, “Might is always right,” </strong><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.haaretz.com/middle-east-news/.premium-trump-s-mideast-plan-is-a-recipe-for-war-not-peace-1.8465782" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">writes Diana Buttu</a>, a lawyer and former adviser to the Palestine Liberation Organization. “Rewarding Israel for building settlements sends the clear message to other dictatorships around the world that they, too, can do as they please and that they, too, will be rewarded,” she argues. “Every country under threat around the world will hear that they, too, can be invaded, their land stolen and their people deprived of rights.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">But the plan would reconfigure the conflict, which would present an opportunity for shrinking it, </strong><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/29/opinion/Israel-Peace-Plan-Trump.html" title="">argues Micah Goodman</a>. While it wouldn’t end, he says, it would be different: “The Israeli-Palestinian conflict is a conflict between occupiers and the occupied. But after the plan it would become a conflict between two separate political entities — and that’s an entirely new paradigm.” </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">The recognition of some of Israel’s territorial expansion since 1967 simply reflects changes in political realities as the Palestinians rejected previous peace deals,</strong> <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.wsj.com/articles/art-of-the-deal-palestine-version-11580255641?mod=opinion_lead_pos1" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">writes The Wall Street Journal’s editorial board.</a> “No one serious in Israel expects the major settlement blocks to be demolished,” they say.</p>, <h2 class="css-1320w4z eoo0vm40" id="link-6c547763">‘There shall be no right of return’</h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The 1948 war resulted in the flight or expulsion of some 700,000 Palestinians from their homes, creating a refugee crisis that remains unresolved. Today, those refugees and their descendants, spread out across the region, number around five million. </p>, <p class="css-15hwz5e evys1bk0">Many Palestinians believe they have the right to return to their ancestral properties, <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.un.org/unispal/data-collection/general-assembly/" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">in keeping with the United Nations</a> Resolution 194. </p>, <p class="css-15hwz5e evys1bk0">The plan explicitly rejects this idea. Israel can’t accept the right of return without abandoning either its Jewish or democratic identity, as <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.vox.com/2020/1/28/21083615/trump-peace-plan-map-netanyahu-israel-palestine" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">Alex Ward explains at Vox,</a> since the naturalization of so many non-Jews would endanger the majority status of Jews in a Jewish state. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">The idea of a “right of return” is antithetical to the two-state solution and to peace, </strong><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2018/jul/13/palestinian-right-of-return-peace-uk-israel" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">according</a><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10"><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2018/jul/13/palestinian-right-of-return-peace-uk-israel" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title=""> </a></strong><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2018/jul/13/palestinian-right-of-return-peace-uk-israel" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">to Tzipi Livni</a>, a former Israeli foreign minister.<span class="css-8l6xbc evw5hdy0"> </span>“As the state of Israel is, by definition, the answer to the national aspiration of the Jewish people, as Israel absorbed Jewish refugees that came from all over the world,” she wrote in 2018, “the creation of the Palestinian state, by definition, provides the answer for the entire Palestinian people wherever they may be, including Palestinian refugees.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">But it is precisely Palestinians’ historical claims to Israeli land that makes a two-state solution untenable,</strong> <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.foreignaffairs.com/articles/israel/2019-10-15/there-will-be-one-state-solution" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">argues Yousef Munayyer</a>, the executive director of the U.S. Campaign for Palestinian Rights and a Palestinian citizen of Israel. For the better part of a century, he says, Western powers have repeatedly tried “accommodating the Zionist demand for a Jewish-majority state in a land populated overwhelmingly by Palestinians.” This, he contends, is a circle that cannot be squared. Instead, “Israelis and Palestinians should work together to craft a constitution that would uphold the rights of all.”</p>, <h2 class="css-1320w4z eoo0vm40" id="link-15035b19">‘Jerusalem will remain the sovereign capital of the State of Israel’</h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Under Mr. Trump’s plan, Israel would gain formal sovereignty over an undivided Jerusalem as its capital, while the Palestinian capital would sit on the outer edge of the city beyond an existing wall. The city’s status as a holy site for all three Abrahamic religions has made it a central point of contention in peace negotiations. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Under the United Nations’s 1947 partition plan, Jerusalem was never intended to be the capital of any country, </strong><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.mcall.com/opinion/mc-trump-israel-sanctions-buttu-yv-1209-20171208-story.html" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">Ms. Buttu wrote in 2017</a>, but “rather a shared city under an international regime with sovereignty resting with neither Israel nor Palestinians.” In 1980, the United Nations deemed Israel’s declaration of Jerusalem as its unified capital <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="http://unscr.com/en/resolutions/478" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">a violation of international law. </a></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">But Mr. Trump’s plan stipulates that returning to a divided Jerusalem “would be a grave mistake,”</strong> particularly because it would entail “having two separate security forces in one of the most sensitive areas on earth.” And many Israeli Jews, such as the writer Shmuel Rosner, believe that Jerusalem <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2017/12/05/opinion/jerusalem-capital-israel-trump.html" title="">“is our capital and it always will be.”</a></p>, <h2 class="css-1320w4z eoo0vm40" id="link-67c2b4d8">‘A demilitarized State of Palestine’</h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Mr. Trump’s plan sets aside the goal of a full-fledged Palestinian state; he promised that Palestinians could “achieve an independent state of their very own” but gave few details.<span class="css-8l6xbc evw5hdy0"> </span>Mr. Netanyahu said the deal provided a “pathway to a Palestinian state” under as-yet-unspecified conditions. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">This future entity, however, would lack certain characteristics of a state</strong>, <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.haaretz.com/us-news/.premium-fact-check-trump-did-not-actually-offer-the-palestinians-a-state-1.8466670" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">explains the Israeli reporter Amir Tibon</a>. “The streets of all of its cities, towns and villages, as well as the roads connecting them, will be under the full control of the military of another state — Israel. It will have no control over its borders, which will also be controlled by Israel,” he adds.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">In this regard, Mr. Trump, much like his Democratic and Republican predecessors, is merely giving Israel cover to perpetuate what is known as the status quo, </strong><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/29/opinion/trump-peace-plan.html" title="">argues Nathan Thrall</a>. Namely: “Israel as the sole sovereign controlling the territory between the Jordan River and the Mediterranean Sea, depriving millions of stateless people of <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.hrw.org/sites/default/files/report_pdf/palestine1219_web_0.pdf" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">basic civil rights</a>, restricting their movement, criminalizing speech that may harm ‘public order,’ jailing them in indefinite ‘administrative detention’ without trial or charge, and dispossessing them of their land.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">But The Jerusalem Post’s editorial board believes that the deal </strong><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10"><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.jpost.com/Opinion/Shifting-the-conversation-615871" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">strikes the right balance</a></strong><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10"> between Palestinian aspirations and Israeli security. </strong></p>, <p class="css-15hwz5e evys1bk0">“Hamas must be disarmed, payments to terrorists must cease, corruption must end, and human rights must be respected,” they write. </p>, <p class="css-15hwz5e evys1bk0">As the Israeli journalist <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2019/01/16/opinion/israeli-palestinian-conflict-matti-friedman.html" title="">Matti Friedman has written</a>, “One of Israel’s nightmares is that the fragile monarchy in Jordan could follow its neighbors, Syria and Iraq, into dissolution and into Iran’s orbit, which would mean that if Israel doesn’t hold the West Bank, an Iranian tank will be able to drive directly from Tehran to the outskirts of Tel Aviv.”</p>, <p class="css-15hwz5e evys1bk0">“Critics should respect the painful conclusions Israelis have drawn about just what kind of Palestinian state they can safely accept,” <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/30/opinion/middle-east-peace-plan.html" title="">writes the Times columnist Bret Stephens</a>.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">There is also an economic component of the deal</strong>: what it describes as the “potential to facilitate” $50 billion in investment over 10 years in infrastructure, coupled with a “pro-growth tax structure,” promising to double the Palestinian economy in 10 years, create over one million new jobs, cut poverty in half and reduce the poverty rate by 50 percent. No prior plan, <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://thehill.com/opinion/international/480405-an-arab-case-for-the-trump-peace-plan" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">argues Ahmed Charai</a>, “has gone as far in articulating a plan to foster Palestinian civil and economic vitality.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">But the plan is thin on details, and it’s hard to imagine anyone investing billions of dollars</strong> in big infrastructure and transportation projects for Palestinians in the West Bank and Gaza while the Israeli government continues to annex more territory in the former and <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nbcnews.com/news/world/over-90-rockets-fired-israel-gaza-israel-s-military-n1001991" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">regularly</a> <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2019/11/15/world/middleeast/israel-gaza-civilian-casualties.html" title="">bombs</a> the latter, Mr. Ward writes.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">Do you have a point of view we missed? Email us at </em><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="mailto:debatable@nytimes.com" title=""><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">debatable@nytimes.com</em></a><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">. Please note your name, age and location in your response, which may be included in the next newsletter. </em></p>, <h3 class="css-1ldy5g8 e1gnsphs0" id="link-7770b277">MORE REACTIONS TO THE PLAN</h3>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.jpost.com/Opinion/Why-the-Palestinian-leadership-should-not-reject-Trumps-peace-plan-615537" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">“Why the Palestinian leadership should not reject Trump’s peace plan.”</a> <em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">[The Jerusalem Post]</em></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.972mag.com/israel-peace-palestinian-submission/" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">“For Bibi and Trump, peace means Palestinian submission.”</a> <em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">[+972 Magazine]</em></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.middleeasteye.net/news/countries-around-world-react-donald-trumps-middle-east-plan" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">“World reacts to Donald Trump’s Israel-Palestine plan.”</a> <em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">[Middle East Eye]</em></p>, <h3 class="css-1ldy5g8 e1gnsphs0" id="link-67a24052">WHAT YOU’RE SAYING</h3>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">Here’s what readers had to say about the last debate: </em><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/28/opinion/coronavirus-risk.html" title=""><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">Should you be worried about the coronavirus?</em></a></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Tina from British Columbia (via email): “Since the outbreak, it’s become nearly impossible to be Chinese in a public space. Sneezing or coughing draws skeptical glares that could make you feel as if you really ought to be in quarantine, even if your chances of catching the virus are identical to the person who is slowly inching away from you on the train in disgust.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://nyti.ms/318GlmT#permid=104874074" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">Dave from New Mexico</a>: “Schaffner is overconfident. Predicting the future is a fool’s errand. Sure, it’s not time to panic but there is also the possibility that it will be the reverse. Phony certainty is not what’s needed.”</p>, <p>Advertisement</p>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd" id="site-index-label">Site Index</h2>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-0">news</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-1">opinion</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-2">arts</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-3">living</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-4">more</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-subscribe-label">Subscribe</h3>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd">Site Information Navigation</h2>]
[<p>Advertisement</p>, <p>Supported by</p>, <p class="css-c2jxua e6idgb70"></p>, <h1 class="css-1j5ig2m e1h9rw200" id="link-2cb78e48" itemprop="headline"><span>Do Masks Offer Protection From New Virus? It Depends</span></h1>, <p class="css-1fv7b6t e1jsehar1" itemprop="author" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">By<!-- --> <span class="css-1baulvz last-byline" itemprop="name">The Associated Press</span></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">SEATTLE — People around the world are buying up protective face masks in hopes of keeping the new virus from China at bay. Some companies have required them for employees. Schools in South Korea have told parents to equip their children with masks and hand sanitizer when they return from winter vacation.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">But do the masks work? It depends.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">All viruses are small enough to get through a typical strap-on medical mask, but the germs don't generally spread through the air one at a time, said Dr. Mark Denison of Vanderbilt University Medical Center in Nashville. Denison studies SARS and MERS, which are coronaviruses, the same family as the new virus.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Instead, viruses ride from person to person on droplets from a sneeze or cough. Those droplets land on hands and other surfaces, where they are touched by others, who then touch their own eyes, noses or mouths.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Masks can block large droplets from a sneeze or cough. That means they have some value, Denison said.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Also, someone in a mask can't touch their own nose and mouth. That can prevent the wearer from picking up germs left on surfaces by someone who is sick, he said.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Masks are “a very sensible precaution" while scientists work to study exactly how the new virus is transmitted, said University of Oxford researcher Trudie Lang.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">None of this, however, is based on rigorous research. Nobody has compared groups of masked and unmasked people by exposing them to the new germ, Denison said. A 2017 review of studies in health care workers suggested masks offer some protection against SARS, but the authors noted “existing evidence is sparse and findings are inconsistent.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The best way to avoid getting sick from the new virus is to wash your hands with soap and water. If soap and water aren't available, use an alcohol-based hand sanitizer. That's the same advice for avoiding regular cold and flu viruses.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention does not currently recommend masks for the general public. Health officials announced Thursday a sixth U.S. case, the husband of a woman who got sick after returning from Wuhan, China, and the first instance of the virus spreading person-to-person in the United States. Health officials said the risk to the general public in the U.S. remains low.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The CDC does recommend masks for people being evaluated for the new virus, people confirmed to have it, household members and caregivers. Airline crew should offer a face mask to a sick traveler, the CDC said.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Health care workers treating patients with the new virus are advised by the CDC to take additional precautions such as goggles or face shields.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">UNICEF said Wednesday it has shipped six metric tons of respiratory masks and protective suits to China for use by health workers.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">In Tokyo, 21-year-old hotel employee Hasumi Tsuchida said she wears a mask. “I work in a hotel where many guests are from China," she said. “I worry a bit when foreign guests arrive.” </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Masks have been commonly used in some countries when wearers are sick, fighting allergies or on days when air pollution is bad. The new virus has fueled demand for them around the world.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Respilon, a Czech company that makes its “nanofiber” masks in China, sold 700,000 of them last year worldwide. Since last week, it received orders for 7 million more. The problem: It cannot make any because the Chinese government extended the Lunar New Year holiday in a bid to contain the virus’ spread.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">In Taiwan, where the holiday is over, factories are up and running.
