Premier Su Tseng-chang said the government had already distributed 23 million masks and that Taiwan will be able to produce 4 million more a day.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">A mask factory in Shanghai has gone into overdrive despite the holiday.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“We are now working 24 hours, two shifts a day, 12 hours shift,” said Liao Huolin, president of the mask company. “We violated labor law,” Liao said, “but the workers understand.” </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">___</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">AP journalists Tong-hyung Kim in Seoul; Mari Yamaguchi in Tokyo; Havovi Todd in London; Taijing Wu in Taipei, Taiwan; Erika Kinetz in Shanghai and Karel Janicek in the Czech Republic contributed to this report.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">___</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The Associated Press Health and Science Department receives support from the Howard Hughes Medical Institute's Department of Science Education. The AP is solely responsible for all content.</p>, <p>Advertisement</p>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd" id="site-index-label">Site Index</h2>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-0">news</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-1">opinion</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-2">arts</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-3">living</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-4">more</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-subscribe-label">Subscribe</h3>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd">Site Information Navigation</h2>]
[<p>Advertisement</p>, <p>Supported by</p>, <p class="css-tsacue e6idgb70">letter 142</p>, <h1 class="css-1s4ffep e1h9rw200" id="link-5d6fb7b5" itemprop="headline"><span>An Outbreak of Racist Sentiment as Coronavirus Reaches Australia </span></h1>, <p class="css-1ifw933 e1wiw3jv0" id="article-summary">A newspaper front page called it a “Chinese virus.” Fake posts have warned people to avoid Chinese products. As the outbreak spreads, some worry about xenophobia.</p>, <p class="css-1fv7b6t e1jsehar1" itemprop="author" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">By<!-- --> <a class="css-brehiz e1jsehar0" href="https://www.nytimes.com/by/isabella-kwai"><span class="css-1baulvz last-byline" itemprop="name">Isabella Kwai</span></a></p>, <h3 class="css-1ldy5g8 e1gnsphs0" id="link-NaN"></h3>, <p class="css-jwz2nf etfikam0"><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/series/nyt-australia-newsletter?module=inline" title=""><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">The Australia Letter</em></a><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0"> is a weekly newsletter from our Australia bureau. </em><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/newsletters/australia-letter?module=inline" title=""><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">Sign up</em></a><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0"> to get it by email. This week’s issue is written by </em><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/by/isabella-kwai" title=""><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">Isabella Kwai</em></a><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">, a reporter with the Australia bureau.</em></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Recently, when Andy Miao takes the train to work in Sydney, he has noticed other people’s disapproving looks if he does not wear a face mask. Although he does not have the coronavirus, Mr. Miao, who is of Chinese heritage and grew up in Australia, knows it’s because of one reason: his ethnicity.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“It makes people like me who are very, very Australian feel like outsiders,” said Mr. Miao, 24, who returned from a trip to China earlier this month and has since seen jokes degrading Chinese people. “It’s definitely invoking a lot of past racial stereotypes.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">But as the World Health Organization <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/30/health/coronavirus-world-health-organization.html" title="">declared a global health emergency</a> after the virus spread to countries including Australia, he is worried about an outbreak of misinformation, panic and xenophobia.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The virus has killed more than 200 people, with nearly 10,000 cases reported, though in Australia there are just a handful of cases, and health officials have said that the risk of catching it for many Australians is low.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Still, universities have <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.sbs.com.au/news/australian-universities-defer-exams-increase-response-to-coronavirus-outbreak" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">delayed exams</a>, face masks — used only weeks ago against bush-fire smoke — are a common sight, and the government plans to evacuate Australians from the epicenter of the outbreak in China.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Other responses here in Australia, where the relationship with China is contentious, have taken a more xenophobic bent. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Some far-right lawmakers polled their followers, asking if Australians should ban Chinese people temporarily from the country. A newspaper in Victoria, The Herald Sun, called the coronavirus a “Chinese Virus” on its front page, prompting over 40,000 people to sign a <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.change.org/p/herald-sun-strongly-require-the-apologies-from-herald-sun-and-daily-telegraph" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">petition</a> demanding an apology. On social media, fake announcements are warning people away from Chinese-populated areas, and memes are making light of early reports that the virus jumped from wild animals to humans.</p>, <h1 class="g-headline" id="g-inlineguide-headline">The Coronavirus Outbreak</h1>, <h2 class="g-inlineguide-list-header g-optimize-type">What do you need to know? Start here.</h2>, <p class="g-inlineguide-date">Updated Feb. 10, 2020</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“Racism feeds on fear and anxiety,” said Tim Soutphommasane, a former race-discrimination commissioner and now a professor at the University of Sydney. While the virus originated in China, “viral diseases don’t have ethnic, racial or national characteristics,” he said, adding that the misinformation was “alarming.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">On Wednesday, the government said that it planned to evacuate Australians citizens from the province to Christmas Island, an Australian territory 2,000 miles away from the mainland, to be quarantined for 14 days.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">But many questioned the implications of using Christmas Island, <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2013/11/17/magazine/the-impossible-refugee-boat-lift-to-christmas-island.html" title="">where refugees and asylum seekers have been held</a>, instead of military bases on the mainland. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">It was not an “appropriate” place to quarantine people, Dr. Tony Bartone, president of the Australian Medical Association, said in a <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=5rFUZcKrz1M" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">television news interview</a>. Faced with the decision, many Australians are <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.theguardian.com/world/2020/jan/30/australian-man-in-wuhan-says-he-would-rather-stay-than-go-to-christmas-island" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">opting to stay behind in lockdown.</a></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Some of the rhetoric has been reminiscent of a time when Chinese people were purposely excluded from the country. “You could read a similar article in the goldfields in 1860s Victoria,” said Jon Piccini, a lecturer in history at the Australian Catholic University.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">As scientists race to develop a vaccine, the virus is likely to continue to spread. Many wonder if it will further perpetuate stereotypes — the same ones that once prompted Australia to ban nonwhites from calling the country home.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Mr. Miao said he did not blame people for being ignorant, though he added, “I don’t think it’s very fair.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Have you noticed or been affected by the fear around the coronavirus? Write to me at nytaustralia@nytimes.com. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">You can read more of our coverage<a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/30/world/asia/coronavirus-china.html" title=""> here</a>, or follow our correspondent Chris Buckley, who is reporting from Wuhan, <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://twitter.com/ChuBailiang" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">on Twitter</a>.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Now, on to stories from the week.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">Michelle Elias contributed reporting.</em></p>, <h2 class="css-3ez4hu eoo0vm40" id="link-32daf939"><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/section/world/australia" title="">Australia and New Zealand</a></h2>, <p class="css-15hwz5e evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10"><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/24/us/australia-firefighters-ian-mcbeth-paul-hudson-rick-demorgan.html" title="">These Are the 3 American Firefighters Who Died in the Australia Plane Crash</a></strong><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">: </strong>The three men were all former service members who had traveled to Australia to battle the bush fires charring the country.<span class="css-8l6xbc evw5hdy0"> </span></p>, <p class="css-15hwz5e evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10"><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/25/sports/tennis/australian-open-upsets.html" title="">Round of Upsets at Australian Open as 6 of Top 10 Women’s Seeds Lose</a></strong><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">: </strong>Pliskova, Svitolina and Bencic joined Osaka, Serena Williams and Wozniacki among the high-profile casualties in a previously placid tournament</p>, <p class="css-15hwz5e evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10"><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/26/sports/tennis/australian-open-gauff-kenin.html" title="">Sofia Kenin Emerges as a Fierce Counterpuncher Against Coco Gauff</a></strong><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">: </strong>Reaching her first Grand Slam singles quarterfinal had the No. 14 seed in tears.</p>, <p class="css-15hwz5e evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10"><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/30/world/asia/coronavirus-chinese-racism.html" title="">As Coronavirus Spreads, So Does Anti-Chinese Sentiment</a></strong><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">: </strong>Fears of the outbreak have fueled xenophobia as a wave of panic spreads, sometimes outstripping practical concerns.</p>, <p class="css-15hwz5e evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10"><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/30/sports/tennis/djokovic-federer-australian-open.html" title="">Novak Djokovic Outlasts Roger Federer to Stay Dominant in Australia</a></strong><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">: </strong>Djokovic prevailed in straight sets, extending his lead in head-to-head matches with Federer, to earn a place in the Australian Open final.</p>, <h2 class="css-3ez4hu eoo0vm40" id="link-4252d6fd">Around The Times</h2>, <p class="css-15hwz5e evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10"><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/25/arts/music/grammys-controversy.html" title="">Can the Grammys Be Trusted?</a></strong><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10"> </strong>Younger artists have been suspicious of the music industry’s “biggest night” for years. New allegations of misconduct at the Recording Academy seem to confirm the worst.</p>, <p class="css-15hwz5e evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10"><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/29/world/middleeast/trump-peace-plan-explained.html" title="">What to Know About Trump’s Middle East Plan</a></strong><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">: </strong>The proposal, three years in the making, favored Israeli priorities and was conceived without Palestinian input. Here are the main points and some of the most contested elements.</p>, <p class="css-15hwz5e evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10"><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/29/nyregion/harvey-weinstein-trial-tarale-wulff.html" title="">Weinstein Accuser Says He Told Her, ‘This Is How the Industry Works’</a></strong><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">: </strong>Dawn Dunning, one of two women who testified against Harvey Weinstein, said he sexually assaulted her in the early 2000s</p>, <p class="css-15hwz5e evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10"><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/29/business/china-coronavirus-economy.html" title="">Coronavirus Outbreak Tests World’s Dependence on China</a></strong><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">: </strong>As British Airways cancels flights and automakers close factories, businesses consider how to cope without the country’s vast factories and thriving consumer culture.</p>, <h2 class="css-3ez4hu eoo0vm40" id="link-3a60967a">And Over to You …</h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">Last week, I wrote about </em><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/24/world/australia/swimming-ocean-pool.html" title=""><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">the experience of learning to swim as an adult </em></a><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">and asked you to share your places of refuge in nature. </em></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“I go to the Seaview Dunes, which is a remote area on the Pacific Coast in South-West Washington, just north of the mouth of the Columbia River. One hundred miles from Portland, and there’s a lot of real —<span class="css-8l6xbc evw5hdy0"> </span>but ocean-less —<span class="css-8l6xbc evw5hdy0"> </span>forest in between.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Why all the way to the dunes? If you go into the dunes, there are just no people in there. It’s quiet, except for the Pacific Ocean. The sound of the ocean is there all the time, day and night. The ocean never sleeps. I walk to the water. The water runs to meet you. You can touch it. It’s thousands of miles to the next shore. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Sometimes, at night, the stars come down to the horizon almost all the way around. But I never go in the water there either. Just back into the dunes.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">— Fred Cann</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Enjoying the Australia Letter? <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/newsletters/australia-letter?utm_source=ausend" title="">Sign up here</a> or forward to a friend.</p>, <p class="css-jwz2nf etfikam0">For more Australia coverage and discussion, start your day with your local <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2018/briefing/global-morning-briefing-newsletter-signup.html?utm_source=ausend" title="">Morning Briefing</a> and join us in our <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.facebook.com/groups/nytaustralia/" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">Facebook group</a>.</p>, <p>Advertisement</p>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd" id="site-index-label">Site Index</h2>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-0">news</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-1">opinion</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-2">arts</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-3">living</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-4">more</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-subscribe-label">Subscribe</h3>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd">Site Information Navigation</h2>]
[<p>Advertisement</p>, <p>Supported by</p>, <h1 class="css-1s4ffep e1h9rw200" id="link-737e083f" itemprop="headline"><span>SARS Was Deadly in Canada. Is the Country Ready for Coronavirus?</span></h1>, <p class="css-1ifw933 e1wiw3jv0" id="article-summary">Toronto’s health care system fell into chaos and confusion during the SARS outbreak 17 years ago. Changes stemming from that crisis are now being tested.</p>, <p class="css-1fv7b6t e1jsehar1" itemprop="author" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">By<!-- --> <a class="css-brehiz e1jsehar0" href="https://www.nytimes.com/by/ian-austen"><span class="css-1baulvz last-byline" itemprop="name">Ian Austen</span></a></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">Canada Letter is a weekly newsletter from our Canada bureau, written by Canadian correspondent Ian Austen. </em><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/newsletters/canada-letter?module=inline" title=""><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">Sign up</em></a><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0"> to get it by email.</em></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The SARS virus outbreak in 2003 that infected 375 people in Toronto, killing 44, left behind a widespread physical reminder of that dark time. While they have become often out of order and otherwise neglected in recent years, dispensers for hand sanitizer are still found in most public buildings at their entrances and dotted along their hallways.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The fear that pervaded the Toronto area during SARS resurfaced this week, if to a lesser extent, as the Wuhan coronavirus continued its rapid spread in China and around the world.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Traveling alongside that fear is xenophobia and discrimination against people of Chinese origin or people who simply appear to be from China. The public school board in York Region, north of Toronto, issued a statement effectively rebuking more than 9,000 people who signed a petition demanding that the children in a family recently returned from China be kept from their classes.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">[Read: </em><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/30/world/asia/coronavirus-chinese-racism.html" title=""><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">As Coronavirus Spreads, So Does Anti-Chinese Sentiment</em></a><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">]</em></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">As I write this, four cases of coronavirus have been reported in Canada and the anti-Chinese sentiment appears limited. The health care system is working smoothly, and officials have been open about what they’re doing and what’s going on. That’s a marked contrast to SARS, where chaos and mistakes, all cloaked in secrecy, dominated.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The extent of the turmoil in 2003 had dimmed in my memory until I recently read the report from an inquiry Ontario did after the outbreak.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“Our public health and emergency infrastructures were in a sorry state of decay, starved for resources by governments of all three political parties,” Justice Archie Campbell wrote in his <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="http://www.archives.gov.on.ca/en/e_records/sars/report/v1-pdf/Volume1.pdf" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">final report released in 2006</a>. “The only thing that saved us from a worse disaster was the courage and sacrifice and personal initiative of those who stepped up — the nurses, the doctors, the paramedics and all the others — sometimes at great personal risk, to get us through a crisis that never should have happened.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Looking back, two things stand out about Toronto’s SARS outbreak. First, hospitals became the place where most people contracted SARS, 72 percent of them. And of the those patients, 45 percent were health care workers who became infected on the job.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Then, after officials believed the crisis had turned the corner — to the point where Health Canada ran advertisements to that effect — they were forced to acknowledge under questioning at a news conference that a second lethal round of infections was underway.</p>, <h1 class="g-headline" id="g-inlineguide-headline">The Coronavirus Outbreak</h1>, <h2 class="g-inlineguide-list-header g-optimize-type">What do you need to know? Start here.</h2>, <p class="g-inlineguide-date">Updated Feb. 10, 2020</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">SARS was even less understood than the coronavirus, which is nevertheless surrounded by many unknowns. There was not, among other things, any diagnostic test available for SARS during the outbreak.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“The commission has not heard of any country or any health system that foresaw SARS,” the 2006 inquiry found. “SARS taught us that we must be ready for the unseen.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">As the report repeatedly notes, Canada had an example of the right way to handle outbreaks during SARS. Vancouver’s infection control systems, its well-developed systems for protecting health care workers and its clearly defined hospital protocols for dealing with outbreaks, made it possible for the city to successfully contain its five cases, only one of which involved a health care worker.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The coronavirus, so far, isn’t as virulent as SARS, and the number of admissions related to it here remains relatively low.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“When I compare this to what I experienced as an emergency physician during SARS, this is a different situation and a better situation,” Dr. Daniel Kollek, a professor of emergency medicine at McMaster University in Hamilton told me. “I think we are more ready.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The changes over the last 17 years include better training, better systems for identifying infected patients and more hospital rooms with air filtering equipment. Additionally, clear and consistent updates and instructions from health authorities are now being given promptly to doctors, nurses and hospital administrators.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Canada does still lag, Dr. Kollek said, in planning for handling large-scale emergencies. Among other things, he said, in an era when many hospitals are regularly running at or beyond capacity, there is still no way to discharge patients who are not as seriously ill to free up beds during a crisis. He also said that large-scale health crises could be better handled by initially assessing patients outside of hospitals.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Times journalists from around the world, including me, are following the coronavirus situation as it develops.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Among the results of that is a regularly updated map of infections worldwide and a constantly revised briefing. You can find the most recent live briefing via the link at the top of <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2020/world/asia/china-wuhan-coronavirus-maps.html" title="">every article we’ve published related to the outbreak, including the map.</a></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">[Read: </em><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2020/world/asia/china-wuhan-coronavirus-maps.html" title=""><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">Coronavirus Map: Tracking the Spread of the Outbreak</em></a><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">]</em></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Our correspondents based in China and Hong Kong have, of course, been following developments there closely.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Steven Lee Myers visited the shadowy world of Chinese markets that illegally sell live wildlife. As with SARS, coronavirus appears to have jumped from animals to humans through the consumption of wildlife, which, he writes, is “driven as much by the desire to flaunt wealth a<em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">s </em>by a mix of superstition and belief about the health benefits of wildlife.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">[Read: </em><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/25/world/asia/china-markets-coronavirus-sars.html" title=""><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">China’s Omnivorous Markets Are in the Eye of a Lethal Outbreak Once Again</em></a><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">]</em></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The wildlife delicacy that appears to have distributed the coronavirus to people is bats. James Gorman, a Times Science writer, explains that bats have a unique ability among mammals to carry many viruses with no ill effects to themselves.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">[Read: </em><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/28/science/bats-coronavirus-Wuhan.html" title=""><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">How Do Bats Live With So Many Viruses?</em></a><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">]</em></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Finally, the question on many of our minds: Where is this outbreak headed? Knvul Sheikh, Derek Watkins, Jin Wu and Mika Gröndahl have looked at six factors that will direct the course of the outbreak.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">[Read: </em><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2020/world/asia/china-coronavirus-contain.html" title=""><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">How Bad Will the Coronavirus Outbreak Get? Here Are 6 Key Factors</em></a><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">]</em></p>, <h2 class="css-3ez4hu eoo0vm40" id="link-b4a7c02">Trans Canada</h2>, <p class="css-15hwz5e evys1bk0">When Rhona Wurtele and her identical twin, Rhoda, were 5 years old, their father strapped skis on them before sending them downhill in Montreal’s Westmount neighborhood. Rhona died last month at age 97. In her obituary, Richard Goldstein write that the “Flying Twins” went on to <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/26/obituaries/rhona-wurtele-dead.html" title="">become the pioneers of women’s skiing</a> in Canada.</p>, <p class="css-15hwz5e evys1bk0">As Parliament began considering <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/29/business/economy/usmca-trump.html" title="">the new trade deal that will replace NAFTA</a> this week, President Trump signed it into American law in Washington. Ana Swanson and Jim Tankersley <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/29/business/economy/usmca-deal.html" title="">looked into the key changes it will bring</a>.</p>, <p class="css-15hwz5e evys1bk0">The fashion sensation, or at least the most exclusive bit of fashion, at the Sundance Film Festival was a <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/28/style/sundance-film-festival-official-coat.html" title="">special edition jacket from Canada Goose</a>.</p>, <p class="css-15hwz5e evys1bk0">Prince Harry and his wife, Meghan, have renounced British taxpayer money as they embark on their new lives as non-royals and part-time residents of Canada. But, as Benjamin Mueller reports, their multimillion-dollar income, while ostensibly private, will come from “<a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/26/world/europe/harry-meghan-charles-duchy-of-cornwall.html" title="">a generous mix of public giveaways</a>: medieval landholdings passed from one male heir to the next, sweeping tax relief, indemnity from some laws and exemptions from others, ownership of long stretches of coastline and all the treasure buried in Cornwall.”</p>, <p class="css-15hwz5e evys1bk0">Travel’s popular <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/30/travel/what-to-do-36-hours-in-whistler-british-columbia.html" title="">36 Hours series visited Whistler </a>where the high level of the skiing is paired with similarly high prices.</p>, <p class="css-15hwz5e evys1bk0">Shaun the Sheep and <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/31/world/canada/Watch-Netflix-February.html" title="">the world of Mossy Bottom Farm </a>are among the offerings streaming this month in Canada on Netflix.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">A native of Windsor, Ontario, Ian Austen was educated in Toronto, lives in Ottawa and has reported about Canada for The New York Times for the past 16 years. Follow him on Twitter at @ianrausten.</em></p>, <h3 class="css-1ldy5g8 e1gnsphs0" id="link-678e087d"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">How are we doing?</strong></h3>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">We’re eager to have your thoughts about this newsletter and events in Canada in general. Please send them to <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="mailto:nytcanada@nytimes.com?%20subject=Canada%20Letter%20Newsletter%20Feedback" title="">nytcanada@nytimes.com</a>.</p>, <h3 class="css-1ldy5g8 e1gnsphs0" id="link-5ca86465"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Like this email?</strong></h3>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Forward it to your friends, and let them know they can sign up <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/newsletters/canada-letter?smid=nytemail&amp;smvar=canadaletter&amp;te=1&amp;nl=canada-today&amp;emc=edit_cnda_20190622" title="">here</a>.</p>, <p>Advertisement</p>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd" id="site-index-label">Site Index</h2>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-0">news</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-1">opinion</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-2">arts</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-3">living</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-4">more</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-subscribe-label">Subscribe</h3>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd">Site Information Navigation</h2>]
[<p>Advertisement</p>, <p>Supported by</p>, <h1 class="css-1s4ffep e1h9rw200" id="link-8256276" itemprop="headline"><span>California and Coronavirus: Six Cases Are Confirmed in the State</span></h1>, <p class="css-1ifw933 e1wiw3jv0" id="article-summary">The state is home to half the confirmed cases in the United States and has two military bases picked as possible quarantine sites.</p>, <p class="css-1fv7b6t e1jsehar1" itemprop="author" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">By<!-- --> <a class="css-brehiz e1jsehar0" href="https://www.nytimes.com/by/thomas-fuller"><span class="css-1baulvz last-byline" itemprop="name">Thomas Fuller</span></a></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">[</em><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/newsletters/california-today" title=""><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">Sign up for our daily newsletter</em></a><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0"> about news from California.]</em></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">SAN FRANCISCO — Health officials on Sunday confirmed three more cases of coronavirus in California, raising questions about the state’s vulnerability in the outbreak as measures to quarantine people who had traveled to China came into effect.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">There are now six cases in California, two of which are in Southern California and four in the San Francisco Bay Area. Two of the new patients were a married couple, only one of whom had traveled to China, the California Department of Public Health said.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“The novel coronavirus is a serious public health concern, however the risk to the general public in California remains low,” Dr. Sonia Angell, the director of the state’s public health department, said in a statement. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">California not only has the most cases of any state, it is also on the forefront of quarantine efforts in the United States. On Friday, the federal government imposed a 14-day quarantine for 195 people who<a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/31/health/quarantine-coronavirus.html" title=""> were evacuated</a> to March Air Reserve Base in Riverside County after fleeing the outbreak’s epicenter in Wuhan, China.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">And Americans whose flights took off from China after 5 p.m. Eastern time on Sunday and who had spent time recently in Hubei Province, where Wuhan is the provincial capital, will be subject to a quarantine of up to two weeks under <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/02/02/us/coronavirus-airports.html" title="">restrictions announced by the Trump administration</a>.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The State Department selected two other military bases in California — Travis Air Force Base in Solano County and Marine Corps Air Station Miramar in San Diego County — to house some of the estimated 1,000 people who might need to be quarantined upon arrival after having traveled overseas.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Though the disease has killed more than 360 people worldwide, the outbreak remains limited in the United States.</p>, <h2 class="css-3ez4hu eoo0vm40" id="link-3769f6ca">The confirmed cases were in Santa Clara, San Benito, Los Angeles and Orange Counties.</h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The case of the married couple, who live in San Benito County, was the first involving the household person-to-person transmission of coronavirus in California, public health officials said.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">In the four other cases — two in Santa Clara County and one each in Los Angeles and Orange Counties — the patient is believed to have picked up the infection in Wuhan, China, the center of the outbreak, before traveling to California.</p>, <h1 class="g-headline" id="g-inlineguide-headline">The Coronavirus Outbreak</h1>, <h2 class="g-inlineguide-list-header g-optimize-type">How Is the U.S. Being Affected?</h2>, <p class="g-inlineguide-date">Updated Feb.10, 2020</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Dr. Angell said in a recorded video message last week that the health risk to the general public in California was low. “But we still consider this a serious public health concern,” she said. Around 40 people in California have been tested for the disease, according to the department.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">But understanding the specific risks to the state center on questions that have not yet been answered: How transmissible is the disease? And how long is its incubation period? Estimates of the incubation period range from two days to two weeks.</p>, <h2 class="css-zd32qr">How Bad Will the Coronavirus Outbreak Get? Here Are 6 Key Factors</h2>, <p class="css-1uuihdo">Here’s what early research says about how the pathogen behaves and the factors that will determine whether it can be contained.</p>, <h2 class="css-3ez4hu eoo0vm40" id="link-66faa920">Airlines are canceling flights between the U.S. and China.</h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Christine Kreuder Johnson, an infectious disease expert at the University of California, Davis, said California is more vulnerable than some other places in the United States because of the large number of people in the state traveling back and forth to China.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“It does put us right on that front line,” she said.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Many flights from China entered the state before the disease was recognized and screenings at the San Francisco, Los Angeles and New York airports were put into place on Jan 17.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">It is an open question, Dr. Johnson said, whether any passengers on the earlier flights were infected and transmitted the disease to others.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">On Friday, Delta Air Lines, United Airlines and American Airlines said they were <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/31/travel/travel-coronavirus-airlines.html" title="">suspending all service to mainland China</a>.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Dr. Johnson said she was optimistic based on the previous outbreaks like SARS that the coronavirus can be extinguished.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“There is good hope for it to be controlled,” she said.</p>, <h2 class="css-3ez4hu eoo0vm40" id="link-4b96ecd8">Almost 200 people are under quarantine at the military base.</h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Among the 195 people quarantined on the military base in Southern California were diplomats, infants, a football player and a theme-park designer.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Their flight was the only one organized by the State Department leaving Wuhan.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“It’s not Club Med, but we’re fortunate to be here,” said Matthew McCoy, the theme-park designer who lives in Shanghai but was in Wuhan working on a mall he is refashioning. “I try to stay busy with my work, social media and my hotel workout regimen.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The evacuees have their temperatures taken regularly and their noses swabbed. They have been advised against shaking hands or hugging.</p>, <h2 class="css-3ez4hu eoo0vm40" id="link-4f7ccf34">Colleges are taking precautions, and some events have been called off.</h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">While the spread of the disease has been limited in California, it has already had a social impact.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/31/us/coronavirus-college-campuses.html?action=click&amp;module=RelatedLinks&amp;pgtype=Article" title="">College students</a> from mainland China as well as Americans in California of East Asian descent are reporting suspicious glances on public transport and rising xenophobia.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">At the University of California, Berkeley, which has a large Chinese student population, officials apologized after the university health center posted <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://pbs.twimg.com/media/EPjrc1YXsBgqTyF.jpg" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">an image that included “xenophobia”</a> among a list of “common reactions” to the coronavirus. It was condemned as giving legitimacy to racism.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Dr. Stacie San Miguel, the director of medical services at the University of California, San Diego’s student health center, said students and others had been flocking to physicians for checkups.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“Especially the people who have been to China and had a runny nose, they’re not sure — is this something or not something? — so there has been some anxiety,” Dr. San Miguel said.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">In Northern California, multiple cities canceled their Lunar New Year celebrations, including Stockton and <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://twitter.com/CityofElkGrove/status/1221962903412256771?" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">Elk Grove</a>.</p>, <p class="css-jwz2nf etfikam0">Adeel Hassan and Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs contributed reporting from New York, and Miriam Jordan from Los Angeles.</p>, <p>Advertisement</p>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd" id="site-index-label">Site Index</h2>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-0">news</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-1">opinion</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-2">arts</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-3">living</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-4">more</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-subscribe-label">Subscribe</h3>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd">Site Information Navigation</h2>]
[<p>Advertisement</p>, <p>Supported by</p>, <h1 class="css-1s4ffep e1h9rw200" id="link-14825411" itemprop="headline"><span>3 Major U.S. Airlines Suspend China Flights Over Coronavirus</span></h1>, <p class="css-1ifw933 e1wiw3jv0" id="article-summary">American, Delta and United will halt service to the Chinese mainland, widening the impact of the outbreak on business and travel.</p>, <p class="css-1fv7b6t e1jsehar1" itemprop="author" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">By<!-- --> <a class="css-brehiz e1jsehar0" href="https://www.nytimes.com/by/niraj-chokshi"><span class="css-1baulvz last-byline" itemprop="name">Niraj Chokshi</span></a></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Delta Air Lines, American Airlines and United Airlines said on Friday morning that they were suspending service between the United States and China — drastically limiting service just hours before the Trump administration issued new travel restrictions of its own.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">American Airlines said it was suspending all flights to and from mainland China immediately through March 27. Delta and United said they would suspend service starting on Feb. 6 to accommodate customers and employees. United said it expected to resume operations on March 28. Delta said its suspension would last through April 30.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">American Airlines and United<span class="css-8l6xbc evw5hdy0"> </span>said they would still operate flights between the United States and Hong Kong. Delta does not fly to that city.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Share prices in all three airlines were down for the day — nearly 4 percent for United, more than 3 percent for American and nearly 2.5 percent for Delta — as concerns about the virus led to a broad market decline. The S&amp;P 500 was down nearly 2 percent.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">In a statement, Delta said that its last flight to China from the United States would depart on Monday and that its last flight to the United States from China would leave on Wednesday. United said its last flight to China would be on Tuesday, while the last flight from China to the United States would depart on Wednesday.</p>, <h1 class="g-headline" id="g-inlineguide-headline">The Coronavirus Outbreak</h1>, <h2 class="g-inlineguide-list-header g-optimize-type">What do you need to know? Start here.</h2>, <p class="g-inlineguide-date">Updated Feb. 10, 2020</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">On Friday afternoon, the Trump administration said it was <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/31/business/china-travel-coronavirus.html" title="">suspending entry</a> into the United States by any foreign nationals who have traveled to China in the last 14 days, excluding the immediate family members of American citizens or permanent residents. It also said<span class="css-8l6xbc evw5hdy0"> </span>it would funnel all flights from China to just a few airports, including Kennedy International in New York, O’Hare in Chicago, and San Francisco International Airport.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Countries surrounding China, including Mongolia, Russia and Singapore, have moved to shut their borders. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">On Thursday, the State Department raised its <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/30/world/asia/Coronavirus-travel-advisory-.html" title="">travel advisory</a> to Level 4 — “Do not travel” — a rating reserved for situations in which the government expects to have very limited ability to help citizens abroad. The World Health Organization declared a global health emergency because of the spreading virus, though it opposed restrictions on travel or trade with China.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Airlines had already begun limiting service to China this week, offering fee waivers for those traveling to the country. Delta said customers whose flights were affected by the suspension could visit the My Trips section of its website to learn how to request a refund and rebook travel.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Travelers who bought trip insurance could find that in general, most plans won’t protect against trip cancellations in scenarios like the coronavirus outbreak.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“Fear of travel, travel advisories and destinations being inaccessible due to this illness are typically not covered risks under travel insurance,” Carol Mueller, vice president for marketing at Berkshire Hathaway Travel Protection, said in an email. To be covered, travelers would have to buy more expensive “cancel for any reason” coverage, and even then, it would cover only about half of the total trip cost.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">In 2018, more than 8.5 million passengers traveled between the United States and China, according to data from the United States Transportation Department. United carried about 17 percent of those passengers, second only to Air China’s 19 percent. Delta flew about 10 percent of those passengers, while American Airlines accounted for about 9 percent.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Nearly two-thirds of those who traveled between the two countries in 2018 flew on a handful of Chinese airlines, none of which immediately responded to requests for comment Friday on any plans to halt or modify service.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Major cargo companies — United Parcel Service, FedEx and DHL — said that they were monitoring the spread of the virus and that they had urged employees to take basic safety precautions. DHL said services in Hubei Province — which includes Wuhan, the city at the center of the virus outbreak — had been suspended because of strict controls put in place by the local government.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">In a <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.resilience360.dhl.com/resilienceinsights/the-wuhan-coronavirus-impact-on-supply-chain-operations-amid-the-lunar-new-year/" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">research report</a> this week, DHL warned that should local lockdowns in China extend into February, they could affect the supply chains of sectors including automotive, pharmaceutical and medical supplies, and high-tech manufacturing for the optical electronics and semiconductors industries. This week, Tesla, the electric-car maker, said production at its new Shanghai factory could be affected by a local order calling for a temporary halt to operations.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">On Friday, Cruise Lines International Association, an industry group that represents some of the world’s largest cruise operators, including Carnival and Royal Caribbean, said in a statement that its members would deny boarding to any person who has traveled through mainland China within the past 14 days.</p>, <p class="css-jwz2nf etfikam0">Tariro Mzezewa, Mike Arnot and Sarah Firshein contributed reporting.</p>, <p>Advertisement</p>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd" id="site-index-label">Site Index</h2>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-0">news</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-1">opinion</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-2">arts</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-3">living</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-4">more</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-subscribe-label">Subscribe</h3>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd">Site Information Navigation</h2>]
[<p>Advertisement</p>, <h2 class="css-1sj8ssj"><a aria-label="Comments Panel" href="#commentsContainer" tabindex="-1">Comments </a></h2>, <h1 class="interactive-heading css-1s4ffep e1h9rw200" id="interactive-heading" itemprop="headline">How Bad Will the Coronavirus Outbreak Get? Here Are 6 Key Factors</h1>, <p class="interactive-byline e1n4ps4i0 css-ua5ckx e1jsehar1" id="interactive-byline" itemprop="author" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">By<!-- --> <a class="css-brehiz e1jsehar0" href="https://www.nytimes.com/by/knvul-sheikh"><span class="css-1baulvz" itemprop="name">Knvul Sheikh</span></a>, <a class="css-brehiz e1jsehar0" href="https://www.nytimes.com/by/derek-watkins"><span class="css-1baulvz" itemprop="name">Derek Watkins</span></a>, <a class="css-brehiz e1jsehar0" href="https://www.nytimes.com/by/jin-wu"><span class="css-1baulvz" itemprop="name">Jin Wu</span></a> and <a class="css-brehiz e1jsehar0" href="https://www.nytimes.com/by/mika-grondahl"><span class="css-1baulvz last-byline" itemprop="name">Mika Gröndahl</span></a><time class="css-wcxsge">Updated <!-- -->Feb. 7, 2020</time></p>, <p class="g-body ">
	As the coronavirus outbreak continues to spread across China, a flurry of early research is drawing a clearer picture of how the pathogen behaves and the key factors that will determine whether it can be contained.
</p>, <p class="g-body ">
	While the virus is a serious public health concern, the risk to most people outside China remains very low, and seasonal flu is a more immediate threat. To avoid any viral illness, experts advise <a href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/28/opinion/coronavirus-prevention-tips.html">washing your hands</a> frequently and avoiding your office or school when you’re sick. Most healthy people don’t need masks, and hoarding them may contribute to <a href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/29/health/coronavirus-masks-hoarding.html">shortages</a> for health workers who do need them, experts say.
</p>, <h2 class="g-subhed g-optimize-type " id="transmission">
<span class="g-balancer" data-id="1">How contagious is the virus?</span>
</h2>, <p class="g-body g-summary ">
	It seems moderately infectious, similar to SARS.
</p>, <p class="g-body ">
	The scale of an outbreak depends on how quickly and easily a virus is transmitted from person to person. While research has just begun, <a href="https://www.nejm.org/doi/full/10.1056/NEJMoa2001316">scientists</a> <a href="https://www.imperial.ac.uk/mrc-global-infectious-disease-analysis/news--wuhan-coronavirus/">have</a> <a href="https://papers.ssrn.com/sol3/papers.cfm?abstract_id=3524675">estimated</a> that each person with the new coronavirus could infect somewhere between 1.5 and 3.5 people without effective containment measures.
</p>, <p class="g-body ">
	That would make the virus roughly as contagious as SARS, another coronavirus that circulated in China in 2003 and was contained after it sickened 8,098 people and killed 774. Respiratory viruses like these can travel through the air, enveloped in tiny droplets that are produced when a sick person breathes, talks, coughs or sneezes.
</p>, <p class="g-body ">
	These droplets fall to the ground within a few feet. That makes the virus harder to get than pathogens like measles, chickenpox and tuberculosis, which can travel a hundred feet through the air. But it is easier to catch than H.I.V. or hepatitis, which spread only through direct contact with the bodily fluids of an infected person.
</p>, <h3 class="g-caption_heading ">How far viruses travel</h3>, <p><span class="g-cstyle0">Coronaviruses</span> can travel only about six feet from the infected person. It’s unknown how long they live on surfaces.</p>, <p>Some other viruses, like <span class="g-cstyle0">measles</span>, can travel up to 100 feet and stay alive on surfaces for hours.</p>, <p><span class="g-cstyle0">Coronaviruses</span> can travel only about six feet from the infected person. It’s unknown how long they live on surfaces.</p>, <p>Some other viruses, like <span class="g-cstyle0">measles</span>, can travel up to 100 feet and stay alive on surfaces for hours.</p>, <p><span class="g-cstyle0">Coronaviruses</span> can travel only about six feet from the infected person. It’s unknown how long they live on surfaces.</p>, <p>Some other viruses, like <span class="g-cstyle0">measles</span>, can travel up to 100 feet and stay alive on surfaces for hours.</p>, <p><span class="g-cstyle0">Coronaviruses</span> can travel only about six feet from the infected person. It’s unknown how long they live on surfaces.</p>, <p>Some other viruses, like <span class="g-cstyle0">measles</span>, can travel up</p>, <p>to 100 feet and stay alive on surfaces for hours.</p>, <p class="g-body ">
	If each person infected with the new coronavirus infects two to three others, that may be enough to sustain and accelerate an outbreak, if nothing is done to reduce it.
</p>, <p class="g-body ">
	Here’s how that works. In the animation below, a group of five infected people could spread the virus to about 368 people over just five cycles of infection.
</p>, <p class="g-body ">
	Compare that with a less contagious virus, like the seasonal flu. People with the flu tend to infect 1.3 other individuals, on average. The difference may seem small, but the result is a striking contrast: Only about 45 people might be infected in the same scenario.
</p>, <p class="g-body ">
	But the transmission numbers of any disease aren’t set in stone. They can be reduced by effective public health measures, such as isolating sick people and tracking individuals they’ve had contact with. When global health authorities methodically tracked and isolated people infected with SARS in 2003, they were able to bring the average number each sick person infected down to 0.4, enough to stop the outbreak.
</p>, <p class="g-body ">
	Health authorities around the world are <a href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/29/health/china-coronavirus-outbreak.html">expending enormous effort</a> trying to repeat that.
</p>, <p class="g-body ">
	So far, the number of cases outside China has been small. But in recent days, cases have turned up in several countries, including the United States, with people who have not visited China. And the number of cases within China far surpassed the rate of new SARS cases in 2003:
</p>, <p class="g-pstyle0">14,000 reported cases</p>, <p class="g-pstyle1">New coronavirus</p>, <p class="g-pstyle0">12,000</p>, <p class="g-pstyle0">10,000</p>, <p class="g-pstyle0">8,000</p>, <p class="g-pstyle0">6,000</p>, <p class="g-pstyle2">SARS</p>, <p class="g-pstyle0">4,000</p>, <p class="g-pstyle0">2,000</p>, <p class="g-pstyle3">Numbers rose after SARS </p>, <p class="g-pstyle3">cases from mainland </p>, <p class="g-pstyle3">China were reported.</p>, <p class="g-pstyle0">0</p>, <p class="g-pstyle4">Day 20</p>, <p class="g-pstyle4">40</p>, <p class="g-pstyle4">60</p>, <p class="g-pstyle4">80</p>, <p class="g-pstyle4">100</p>, <p class="g-pstyle4">120</p>, <p class="g-pstyle4">140</p>, <p class="g-pstyle5">The first day that W.H.O. received reports of the outbreaks</p>, <p class="g-pstyle0">14,000</p>, <p class="g-pstyle0">reported</p>, <p class="g-pstyle0">cases</p>, <p class="g-pstyle1">New coronavirus</p>, <p class="g-pstyle0">12,000</p>, <p class="g-pstyle0">10,000</p>, <p class="g-pstyle0">8,000</p>, <p class="g-pstyle0">6,000</p>, <p class="g-pstyle2">SARS</p>, <p class="g-pstyle0">4,000</p>, <p class="g-pstyle0">2,000</p>, <p class="g-pstyle3">Numbers rose after SARS </p>, <p class="g-pstyle3">cases from mainland </p>, <p class="g-pstyle3">China were reported.</p>, <p class="g-pstyle0">0</p>, <p class="g-pstyle4">Day 20</p>, <p class="g-pstyle4">40</p>, <p class="g-pstyle4">60</p>, <p class="g-pstyle4">80</p>, <p class="g-pstyle4">100</p>, <p class="g-pstyle4">120</p>, <p class="g-pstyle4">140</p>, <p class="g-pstyle5">The first day that W.H.O. received reports of the outbreaks</p>, <h2 class="g-subhed g-optimize-type " id="virulence">
<span class="g-balancer" data-id="2">How deadly is the virus?</span>
</h2>, <p class="g-body g-summary ">
	It’s hard to know yet. But the fatality rate is probably less than 3 percent, much less than SARS.
</p>, <p class="g-body ">
	This is one of the most important factors in how damaging the outbreak will be, and one of the least understood.
</p>, <p class="g-body ">
	It’s tough to assess the lethality of a new virus. The worst cases are usually detected first, which can skew our understanding of how likely patients are to die. About a third of the first <a href="https://www.thelancet.com/journals/lancet/article/PIIS0140-6736(20)30183-5/fulltext">41 patients reported in Wuhan</a> had to be treated in an I.C.U., many with symptoms of fever, severe cough, shortness of breath and pneumonia. But people with mild cases may never visit a doctor. So there may be more cases than we know, and the death rate may be lower than we initially thought.
</p>, <p class="g-body ">
	At the same time, deaths from the virus may be underreported. The Chinese cities at the center of the outbreak face a shortage of testing kits and hospital beds, and many sick people have not been able to see a doctor.
</p>, <p class="g-body ">
	“There’s still a lot of uncertainty about what this virus is like and what it is doing,” said Dr. Allison McGeer, an infectious disease specialist at Mount Sinai Hospital in Toronto, who was at the frontlines of the Canadian response to SARS.
</p>, <p class="g-body ">
	Early indications suggest the fatality rate for this virus is considerably less than another coronavirus, MERS, which kills about 35 percent of people who become infected, and SARS, which kills about 10 percent. All of the diseases appear to latch on to proteins on the surface of lung cells, but MERS and SARS seem to be more destructive to lung tissue.
</p>, <p class="g-body ">
	Among 17,000 people who were infected in China, 82 percent had mild infections, 15 percent had severe symptoms and 3 percent were classified as critical, said Dr. Maria Van Kerkhove, acting head of emerging diseases at the World Health Organization, on Feb. 7. Less than 2 percent of the people with confirmed infections had died. Many of those who died were older men with underlying health problems, Dr. Van Kerkhove said.
</p>, <p class="g-body ">
	Here’s how the new coronavirus compares with other infectious diseases:
</p>, <p class="g-pstyle0">Fatality rate</p>, <p class="g-pstyle0">(log scale)</p>, <p class="g-pstyle1">100%</p>, <p class="g-pstyle2">Bird flu</p>, <p class="g-pstyle2">Ebola</p>, <p class="g-pstyle3">MERS</p>, <p class="g-pstyle4">50</p>, <p class="g-pstyle2">Smallpox</p>, <p class="g-pstyle5">More</p>, <p class="g-pstyle5">deadly</p>, <p class="g-pstyle4">20</p>, <p class="g-pstyle6">Spanish flu</p>, <p class="g-pstyle1">10</p>, <p class="g-pstyle7">SARS</p>, <p class="g-pstyle4">5</p>, <p class="g-pstyle8">New coronavirus</p>, <p class="g-pstyle9">Most estimates put the</p>, <p class="g-pstyle9">fatality rate below 3%,</p>, <p class="g-pstyle9">and the number of</p>, <p class="g-pstyle9">transmissions between</p>, <p class="g-pstyle9">1.5 and 3.5.</p>, <p class="g-pstyle4">2</p>, <p class="g-pstyle10">Spreads faster</p>, <p class="g-pstyle1">1</p>, <p class="g-pstyle11">Swine flu</p>, <p class="g-pstyle11">Measles</p>, <p class="g-pstyle1">0.1</p>, <p class="g-pstyle2">Polio</p>, <p class="g-pstyle11">Seasonal</p>, <p class="g-pstyle11">flu</p>, <p class="g-pstyle6">Common</p>, <p class="g-pstyle6">cold</p>, <p class="g-pstyle6">Chickenpox</p>, <p class="g-pstyle12">0</p>, <p class="g-pstyle12">1</p>, <p class="g-pstyle12">5</p>, <p class="g-pstyle12">10</p>, <p class="g-pstyle12">15</p>, <p class="g-pstyle0">Average number of people infected by each sick person </p>, <p class="g-pstyle0">Fatality rate</p>, <p class="g-pstyle0">(log scale)</p>, <p class="g-pstyle1">100%</p>, <p class="g-pstyle2">Bird flu</p>, <p class="g-pstyle2">Ebola</p>, <p class="g-pstyle3">50</p>, <p class="g-pstyle4">MERS</p>, <p class="g-pstyle5">Smallpox</p>, <p class="g-pstyle6">More</p>, <p class="g-pstyle6">deadly</p>, <p class="g-pstyle3">20</p>, <p class="g-pstyle7">Spanish flu</p>, <p class="g-pstyle1">10</p>, <p class="g-pstyle8">SARS</p>, <p class="g-pstyle3">5</p>, <p class="g-pstyle3">2</p>, <p class="g-pstyle9">New coronavirus</p>, <p class="g-pstyle10">Most estimates put the</p>, <p class="g-pstyle10">fatality rate below 3%,</p>, <p class="g-pstyle10">and the number of</p>, <p class="g-pstyle10">transmissions between</p>, <p class="g-pstyle10">1.5 and 3.5.</p>, <p class="g-pstyle11">Spreads faster</p>, <p class="g-pstyle1">1</p>, <p class="g-pstyle12">Measles</p>, <p class="g-pstyle13">Swine flu</p>, <p class="g-pstyle1">0.1</p>, <p class="g-pstyle2">Polio</p>, <p class="g-pstyle2">Seasonal</p>, <p class="g-pstyle2">flu</p>, <p class="g-pstyle14">Common</p>, <p class="g-pstyle14">cold</p>, <p class="g-pstyle14">Chickenpox</p>, <p class="g-pstyle15">0</p>, <p class="g-pstyle15">1</p>, <p class="g-pstyle15">5</p>, <p class="g-pstyle15">10</p>, <p class="g-pstyle15">15</p>, <p class="g-pstyle0">Average number of people infected by each sick person</p>, <p class="g-pstyle0">Fatality rate</p>, <p class="g-pstyle0">(log scale)</p>, <p class="g-pstyle1">100%</p>, <p class="g-pstyle2">Bird flu</p>, <p class="g-pstyle3">50</p>, <p class="g-pstyle2">Ebola</p>, <p class="g-pstyle4">More</p>, <p class="g-pstyle4">deadly</p>, <p class="g-pstyle5">Smallpox</p>, <p class="g-pstyle6">MERS</p>, <p class="g-pstyle3">20</p>, <p class="g-pstyle7">Spanish flu</p>, <p class="g-pstyle8">Spreads faster</p>, <p class="g-pstyle1">10</p>, <p class="g-pstyle9">SARS</p>, <p class="g-pstyle3">5</p>, <p class="g-pstyle3">2</p>, <p class="g-pstyle10">New coronavirus</p>, <p class="g-pstyle11">Most estimates put the</p>, <p class="g-pstyle11">fatality rate below 3%,</p>, <p class="g-pstyle11">and the number of</p>, <p class="g-pstyle11">transmissions between</p>, <p class="g-pstyle11">1.5 and 3.5.</p>, <p class="g-pstyle1">1</p>, <p class="g-pstyle7">Measles</p>, <p class="g-pstyle12">Swine flu</p>, <p class="g-pstyle1">0.1</p>, <p class="g-pstyle2">Seasonal</p>, <p class="g-pstyle2">flu</p>, <p class="g-pstyle2">Polio</p>, <p class="g-pstyle13">Common</p>, <p class="g-pstyle13">cold</p>, <p class="g-pstyle14">Chickenpox</p>, <p class="g-pstyle15">0</p>, <p class="g-pstyle15">1</p>, <p class="g-pstyle15">5</p>, <p class="g-pstyle15">10</p>, <p class="g-pstyle15">15</p>, <p class="g-pstyle0">Avg. number of people infected by each sick person</p>, <p class="g-body ">
	The chart above uses a <a href="https://blog.datawrapper.de/weeklychart-logscale/">logarithmic</a> vertical scale: data near the top is compressed into a smaller space to make the variation between less-deadly diseases easier to see. Diseases near the top of the chart are much deadlier than those in the middle.
</p>, <p class="g-body ">
	Pathogens can still be very dangerous even if their fatality rate is low, Dr. McGeer said. For instance, even though influenza has a case fatality rate below one per 1,000, roughly 200,000 people end up hospitalized with the virus each year in the United States, and about 35,000 people die.
</p>, <h2 class="g-subhed g-optimize-type " id="contagiousperiod">
<span class="g-balancer" data-id="3">How long does it take to show symptoms?</span>
</h2>, <p class="g-body g-summary ">
	Possibly between 2 to 14 days, allowing the illness to go undetected.
</p>, <p class="g-body ">
	The time it takes for symptoms to appear after a person is infected can be vital for prevention and control. Known as the incubation period, this time can allow health officials to quarantine or observe people who may have been exposed to the virus. But if the incubation period is too long or too short, these measures may be difficult to implement.
</p>, <p class="g-body ">
	Some illnesses, like influenza, have a short incubation period of two or three days. People may be shedding infectious virus particles before they exhibit flu symptoms, making it almost impossible to identify and isolate people who have the virus. SARS, however, had an incubation period of about five days. In addition, it took four or five days after symptoms started before sick people could transmit the virus. That gave officials time to stop the virus and effectively contain the outbreak, Dr. McGeer said.
</p>, <p class="g-body ">
	Officials at the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention estimate that the new coronavirus has an incubation period of 2 to 14 days. But it is still not clear whether a person can spread the virus before symptoms develop, or whether the severity of the illness affects how easily a patient can spread the virus.
</p>, <p class="g-body ">
	“That concerns me because it means the infection could elude detection,” said Dr. Mark Denison, an infectious disease expert at Vanderbilt University in Nashville, Tenn.
</p>, <h2 class="g-subhed g-optimize-type " id="travel">
<span class="g-balancer" data-id="4">How much have infected people traveled?</span>
</h2>, <p class="g-body g-summary ">
	The virus spread quickly because it started in a transportation hub.
</p>, <p class="g-body ">
	Wuhan is a difficult place to contain an outbreak. It has 11 million people, more than New York City. On an average day, 3,500 passengers take direct flights from Wuhan to cities in other countries. These cities were among the first to report cases of the virus outside China.
</p>, <h3 class="g-caption_heading g-has-leadin ">Passengers flying from Wuhan to other countries</h3>, <p class="g-pstyle0">Russia</p>, <p class="g-pstyle1">United Kingdom</p>, <p class="g-pstyle0">Italy</p>, <p class="g-pstyle1">France</p>, <p class="g-pstyle2">United</p>, <p class="g-pstyle2">States</p>, <p class="g-pstyle3">8,000</p>, <p class="g-pstyle2">Japan</p>, <p class="g-pstyle3">23,000</p>, <p class="g-pstyle3">passengers</p>, <p class="g-pstyle4">CHINA</p>, <p class="g-pstyle0">Turkey</p>, <p class="g-pstyle5">Wuhan</p>, <p class="g-pstyle6">South Korea</p>, <p class="g-pstyle6">Taiwan</p>, <p class="g-pstyle6">U.A.E.</p>, <p class="g-pstyle6">Philippines</p>, <p class="g-pstyle6">Malaysia</p>, <p class="g-pstyle7">Thailand</p>, <p class="g-pstyle8">55,000</p>, <p class="g-pstyle1">Indonesia</p>, <p class="g-pstyle9">5,000</p>, <p class="g-pstyle9">25,000</p>, <p class="g-pstyle10">Australia</p>, <p class="g-pstyle9">50,000</p>, <p class="g-pstyle9">passengers</p>, <p class="g-pstyle0">Russia</p>, <p class="g-pstyle1">United Kingdom</p>, <p class="g-pstyle0">Italy</p>, <p class="g-pstyle1">France</p>, <p class="g-pstyle2">United</p>, <p class="g-pstyle2">States</p>, <p class="g-pstyle3">8,000</p>, <p class="g-pstyle4">CHINA</p>, <p class="g-pstyle0">Turkey</p>, <p class="g-pstyle5">Wuhan</p>, <p class="g-pstyle2">Japan</p>, <p class="g-pstyle3">23,000</p>, <p class="g-pstyle3">passengers</p>, <p class="g-pstyle6">U.A.E.</p>, <p class="g-pstyle6">Philippines</p>, <p class="g-pstyle6">Malaysia</p>, <p class="g-pstyle7">Thailand</p>, <p class="g-pstyle8">55,000</p>, <p class="g-pstyle1">Indonesia</p>, <p class="g-pstyle9">5,000</p>, <p class="g-pstyle9">25,000</p>, <p class="g-pstyle10">Australia</p>, <p class="g-pstyle9">50,000</p>, <p class="g-pstyle9">passengers</p>, <p class="g-pstyle0">Japan</p>, <p class="g-pstyle1">23,000</p>, <p class="g-pstyle1">passengers</p>, <p class="g-pstyle0">United</p>, <p class="g-pstyle0">States</p>, <p class="g-pstyle1">8,000</p>, <p class="g-pstyle2">Wuhan</p>, <p class="g-pstyle3">Thailand</p>, <p class="g-pstyle4">55,000</p>, <p class="g-pstyle5">5,000</p>, <p class="g-pstyle5">50,000</p>, <p class="g-pstyle5">passengers</p>, <p class="g-body ">
	Wuhan is also a major transportation hub within China, linked to Beijing, Shanghai and other major cities by high-speed railways and domestic airlines. In October and November of last year, close to two million people flew from Wuhan to other places within China.
</p>, <p class="g-pstyle0">Beijing</p>, <p class="g-pstyle1">136,000</p>, <p class="g-pstyle2">CHINA</p>, <p class="g-pstyle3">Wuhan</p>, <p class="g-pstyle4">Shanghai</p>, <p class="g-pstyle5">119,000</p>, <p class="g-pstyle6">Passengers flying from Wuhan</p>, <p class="g-pstyle6">to other cities in China</p>, <p class="g-pstyle7">October to November 2019</p>, <p class="g-pstyle8">5,000</p>, <p class="g-pstyle8">25,000</p>, <p class="g-pstyle4">Hong Kong</p>, <p class="g-pstyle5">18,000</p>, <p class="g-pstyle0">Kunming</p>, <p class="g-pstyle1">95,000 passengers</p>, <p class="g-pstyle8">50,000</p>, <p class="g-pstyle8">passengers</p>, <p class="g-pstyle0">Passengers flying from Wuhan to other cities in China</p>, <p class="g-pstyle1">October to November 2019</p>, <p class="g-pstyle2">Beijing</p>, <p class="g-pstyle3">136,000</p>, <p class="g-pstyle4">Wuhan</p>, <p class="g-pstyle5">Shanghai</p>, <p class="g-pstyle6">119,000</p>, <p class="g-pstyle7">5,000</p>, <p class="g-pstyle7">25,000</p>, <p class="g-pstyle7">50,000</p>, <p class="g-pstyle7">passengers</p>, <p class="g-pstyle2">Kunming</p>, <p class="g-pstyle3">95,000 passengers</p>, <p class="g-pstyle5">Hong Kong</p>, <p class="g-pstyle6">18,000</p>, <p class="g-pstyle0">Passengers flying from Wuhan to</p>, <p class="g-pstyle0">other cities in China</p>, <p class="g-pstyle1">Oct. to Nov. 2019</p>, <p class="g-pstyle2">Beijing</p>, <p class="g-pstyle3">136,000</p>, <p class="g-pstyle4">Wuhan</p>, <p class="g-pstyle5">Shanghai</p>, <p class="g-pstyle6">119,000</p>, <p class="g-pstyle7">5,000</p>, <p class="g-pstyle7">50,000</p>, <p class="g-pstyle7">passengers</p>, <p class="g-pstyle2">Kunming</p>, <p class="g-pstyle3">95,000 passengers</p>, <p class="g-pstyle5">Hong Kong</p>, <p class="g-pstyle6">18,000</p>, <p class="g-body ">
	China was not nearly as well-connected in 2003 during the SARS outbreak. Large numbers of migrant workers now travel domestically and internationally — to Africa, other parts of Asia and Latin America, where China is making an enormous infrastructure push with its Belt and Road Initiative. This travel creates a high risk for outbreaks in countries with health systems that are not equipped to handle them, like Zimbabwe, which is facing a worsening hunger and economic crisis.
</p>, <p class="g-body ">
	Over all, China has about four times as many train and air passengers as it did during the SARS outbreak:
</p>, <p class="g-pstyle0">4 billion travelers</p>, <p>Passenger traffic has quadrupled, opening more routes for infection.</p>, <p class="g-pstyle0">3</p>, <p>When SARS broke out, there were about 1 billion travelers.</p>, <p class="g-pstyle0">2</p>, <p class="g-pstyle1">Train</p>, <p class="g-pstyle1">passengers</p>, <p class="g-pstyle2">1</p>, <p class="g-pstyle3">Air passengers</p>, <p class="g-pstyle0">1990</p>, <p class="g-pstyle4">’00</p>, <p class="g-pstyle4">’10</p>, <p class="g-pstyle5">2019</p>, <p>Passenger traffic has quadrupled, opening more routes for infection.</p>, <p class="g-pstyle0">4 billion travelers</p>, <p class="g-pstyle0">3</p>, <p>When SARS broke out, there were about 1 billion travelers.</p>, <p class="g-pstyle1">2</p>, <p class="g-pstyle2">Train</p>, <p class="g-pstyle2">passengers</p>, <p class="g-pstyle1">1</p>, <p class="g-pstyle3">Air passengers</p>, <p class="g-pstyle0">1990</p>, <p class="g-pstyle4">’00</p>, <p class="g-pstyle4">’10</p>, <p class="g-pstyle5">2019</p>, <p class="g-body ">
	China has taken the unprecedented step of imposing travel restrictions on tens of millions of people living in Wuhan and nearby cities. But <a href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/26/world/asia/coronavirus-wuhan-china-hubei.html">experts warned</a> that the lockdown may have come too late and limited access to food and medicine. Wuhan’s mayor acknowledged that five million people had left the city before the restrictions began, in the run-up to the Lunar New Year.
</p>, <p class="g-body ">
	“You can’t board up a germ. A novel infection will spread,” said Lawrence O. Gostin, a law professor at Georgetown University and director of the World Health Organization Collaborating Center on National and Global Health Law. “It will get out; it always does.”
</p>, <h2 class="g-subhed g-optimize-type " id="response">
<span class="g-balancer" data-id="5">How effective will the response be?</span>
</h2>, <p class="g-body g-summary ">
	The W.H.O. has praised China’s efforts, but critics fear lockdown measures may not be enough.
</p>, <p class="g-body ">
	In addition to closing off transportation, officials shut down a market in Wuhan selling live poultry, seafood and wild animals, which was thought to be the origin of the coronavirus, and later suspended the trade of wild animals nationwide. Schools have been closed, Beijing’s Great Wall is off limits and tourist packages from China have been halted. World Health Organization officials have praised China’s aggressive response to the virus.
</p>, <p class="g-body ">
	But the measures have also had unintended effects. Residents in Wuhan who are unwell must walk or cycle for miles to get to hospitals. There, many complain that they are being turned away because of shortages of hospital beds, staff and supplies that have been made worse by the lockdown.
</p>, <p class="g-body ">
	Until recently, researchers abroad were also concerned by the fact that China was not admitting experts who could help track the virus and prevent its spread.
</p>, <p class="g-body ">
	On Thursday, the W.H.O. declared the outbreak a <a href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/30/health/coronavirus-world-health-organization.html">global health emergency</a>, acknowledging that the disease represents a risk beyond China.
</p>, <p class="g-body ">
	The United States and Australia are temporarily denying entry to noncitizens who recently traveled to China, and several major airlines said they expect to halt direct service to mainland China for months. Other countries — including Kazakhstan, Russia and Vietnam — have temporarily restricted travel and visas. But critics fear that these measures will not be enough.
</p>, <h2 class="g-subhed g-optimize-type " id="vaccine">
<span class="g-balancer" data-id="6">How long will it take to develop a vaccine?</span>
</h2>, <p class="g-body g-summary ">
	A vaccine is still a year away — at minimum.
</p>, <p class="g-body ">
	A coronavirus vaccine could prevent infections and stop the spread of the disease. But vaccines take time.
</p>, <p class="g-body ">
	After the SARS outbreak in 2003, it took researchers about 20 months to get a vaccine ready for human trials. (The vaccine was never needed, because the disease was eventually contained.) By the Zika outbreak in 2015, researchers had brought the vaccine development timeline down to six months.
</p>, <p class="g-body ">
	Now, they hope that work from past outbreaks will help cut the timeline even further. Researchers have already studied<a href="https://ncbiinsights.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/2020/01/13/novel-coronavirus/"> </a><a href="https://ncbiinsights.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/2020/01/13/novel-coronavirus/">the genome of the new coronavirus</a> and found the proteins that are crucial for infection. Scientists from the National Institutes of Health, in Australia and at least three companies are working on vaccine candidates.
</p>, <p class="g-body ">
	“If we don’t run into any unforeseen obstacles, we’ll be able to get a Phase 1 trial going within the next three months,” said Dr. Anthony Fauci, director of the National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases.
</p>, <p class="g-body ">
	Dr. Fauci cautioned that it could still take months, and even years, after initial trials to conduct extensive testing that can prove a vaccine is safe and effective. In the best case, a vaccine may become available to the public <a href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/28/health/coronavirus-vaccine.html">a year from now</a>.
</p>, <p class="css-1fq2n5g interactive-source" data-testid="source" id="interactive-source"><strong>Sources:</strong><br/>Data on daily reported cases from the Health Commission of Hubei Province, National Health Commission of the People’s Republic of China and World Health Organization.<br/><br/>Data on fatality rates and number of transmissions per sick person from the World Health Organization, U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, Johns Hopkins University, Global Health Data Exchange, Food and Agriculture Organization of the United States, Global Mapping of Infectious Disease Risk, National Institutes of Health, European Centre for Disease Prevention and Control, University of Oxford, Korea Institute of Oriental Medicine, Inserm, Imperial College, Harvard University, Hong Kong University, Lancaster University and University of Bern.<br/><br/>Travel volume data from International Air Transport Association DDS and, via CEIC, China Railway Corporation, National Railway Administration and Civil Aviation Administration of China.</p>, <p class="css-1fq2n5g interactive-credit" data-testid="credit" id="interactive-credit"><strong>Sources: </strong>Data on daily reported cases from the Health Commission of Hubei Province, National Health Commission of the People’s Republic of China and World Health Organization. <br/>Data on fatality rates and number of transmissions per sick person from the World Health Organization, U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, Johns Hopkins University, Global Health Data Exchange, Food and Agriculture Organization of the United States, Global Mapping of Infectious Disease Risk, National Institutes of Health, European Centre for Disease Prevention and Control, University of Oxford, Korea Institute of Oriental Medicine, Inserm, Imperial College, Harvard University, Hong Kong University, Lancaster University and University of Bern.<br/>Travel volume data from International Air Transport Association DDS and, via CEIC, China Railway Corporation, National Railway Administration and Civil Aviation Administration of China.</p>, <p>Advertisement</p>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd" id="site-index-label">Site Index</h2>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-0">news</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-1">opinion</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-2">arts</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-3">living</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-4">more</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-subscribe-label">Subscribe</h3>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd">Site Information Navigation</h2>]
[<p>Advertisement</p>, <p>Supported by</p>, <h1 class="css-1s4ffep e1h9rw200" id="link-7e0b07ed" itemprop="headline"><span>State Department Warns Against Traveling to China Amid Coronavirus Outbreak</span></h1>, <p class="css-1ifw933 e1wiw3jv0" id="article-summary">Americans who are currently in China should consider leaving, United States officials said.</p>, <p class="css-1fv7b6t e1jsehar1" itemprop="author" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">By<!-- --> <a class="css-brehiz e1jsehar0" href="https://www.nytimes.com/by/neil-vigdor"><span class="css-1baulvz last-byline" itemprop="name">Neil Vigdor</span></a></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The State Department on Thursday night issued an advisory telling Americans not to travel to China because of the public health threat posed by the coronavirus, as world health officials grappled with the expanding footprint of the outbreak.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Secretary of State Mike Pompeo confirmed the travel advisory on Twitter, saying that the department had raised its advisory for China to Level 4, and to red from orange — meaning do not travel there.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Mr. Pompeo cited a decision by the World Health Organization earlier Thursday to declare the coronavirus a public health emergency of international concern.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“Travelers should be prepared for travel restrictions to be put into effect with little or no advance notice,” the advisory said. “Commercial carriers have reduced or suspended routes to and from China.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The State Department said Americans who were in China should consider leaving via commercial transportation. It also requested that all nonessential United States government personnel hold off on traveling to China.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">In China, at least 213 people had died from the virus as of early Friday, the authorities said. The total number of cases worldwide was approaching 10,000, according to Chinese and World Health Organization data. The vast majority of cases were in China.</p>, <h1 class="g-headline" id="g-inlineguide-headline">The Coronavirus Outbreak</h1>, <h2 class="g-inlineguide-list-header g-optimize-type">What do you need to know?
