Start here.</h2>, <p class="g-inlineguide-date">Updated Feb. 10, 2020</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The warning by the State Department came on the same day that the first person-to-person transmission of the coronavirus in the United States was reported. An Illinois man had contracted the virus from his wife, who had recently visited Wuhan, China, the epicenter of the virus. Both were hospitalized.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Also on Thursday, the union for 15,000 American Airlines pilots filed a lawsuit in Dallas County Court in Texas seeking a temporary restraining order to suspend flights to China. The union, the Allied Pilots Association, said that British Airways, Air Canada and Lufthansa had already suspended service to China.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“We estimate that as many as 300 passengers and crew travel to DFW alone from Chinese cities on each American Airlines flight,” Eric Ferguson, the union’s president and a captain for American, said in a statement, referring to Dallas-Fort Worth International Airport, the airline’s largest hub. “To us, that level of risk is unacceptable.’’</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The union said it had directed American Airlines pilots to decline flight assignments to China unless they were part of a return trip. It said that airline regulations required pilots to remain on the ground in China for about 32 hours so that they could get adequate rest.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The State Department has previously issued Level 4 advisories warning Americans not to travel to at least 12 other countries, including Iraq, Afghanistan, Syria, Yemen, North Korea and Iran, where the department cited the risk of kidnapping and the arbitrary arrest and detention of United States citizens.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Other countries placed under a Level 4 travel advisory include Mali, because of crime, terrorism, and kidnapping; Venezuela, because of crime, civil unrest, poor health infrastructure, kidnapping and the arbitrary arrest and detention of Americans; and Burkina Faso, because of terrorism, crime and kidnapping.</p>, <p class="css-jwz2nf etfikam0">Michael Levenson contributed reporting.</p>, <p>Advertisement</p>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd" id="site-index-label">Site Index</h2>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-0">news</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-1">opinion</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-2">arts</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-3">living</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-4">more</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-subscribe-label">Subscribe</h3>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd">Site Information Navigation</h2>]
[<p>Advertisement</p>, <p>Supported by</p>, <p class="css-tsacue e6idgb70">The New New World</p>, <h1 class="css-1s4ffep e1h9rw200" id="link-79c7bff9" itemprop="headline"><span>China Targets the Coronavirus, and Farmers Pay a Price</span></h1>, <p class="css-1ifw933 e1wiw3jv0" id="article-summary">The government’s efforts to stop the outbreak could push the country’s already struggling small businesses over the edge.</p>, <p class="css-1fv7b6t e1jsehar1" itemprop="author" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">By<!-- --> <a class="css-brehiz e1jsehar0" href="https://www.nytimes.com/by/li-yuan"><span class="css-1baulvz last-byline" itemprop="name">Li Yuan</span></a></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The fifth day of the Lunar New Year holiday, which fell on Wednesday, is when people in China welcome the god of fortune into their homes. This year, business owners like Qiu Xiangjian would be grateful if the god merely helped them get by.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Mr. Qiu, a 50-year-old farmer in Jiangsu Province, woke up that day to some troubling news. To battle the coronavirus outbreak spreading across China, the provincial government had ordered businesses except those necessary for daily life, such as utilities, pharmacies and supermarkets, to close until Feb. 10.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">He can’t sell his chickens to slaughterhouses or meat markets. He had only two days of feed left for his 40,000 chickens, but all the feed factories had been shut down. If he can’t stock up on feed, he will watch his chickens starve.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“For me, it’s not a matter of losing some money,” he said. “It’s a matter of losing everything.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">China’s giant and tireless business machine came to a sudden halt last week. Many parts of the country started official and voluntary lockdowns to combat the pneumonialike outbreak, which has killed over 200 people and infected thousands. <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/29/business/china-coronavirus-economy.html" title="">Big companies like Apple, General Motors, Ikea and Starbucks</a> are closing operations, changing the way they do business or preparing for financial hits.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">They won’t be the businesses hit the hardest. Those would be China’s entrepreneurs — the farmers, shopkeepers, noodle stand owners and millions of others who delivered China out of the chaos of the Cultural Revolution and turned it into an economic powerhouse.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Many were already struggling with China’s <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/01/business/economy/china-economy-reserve-requirement-ratio.html" title="">slowing economic growth</a> and increased <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2018/10/03/business/china-economy-private-enterprise.html" title="">government meddling</a>. The virus outbreak exacerbated the situation — or, as people in China say, added frost on top of snow.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“My goal for 2020 isn’t growth but survival,” said Zhang Huan, an investor and entrepreneur in Guangzhou, a port city just northwest of Hong Kong. “We’re all one or two months away from bankruptcy.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Their problems could be felt around the world. China’s small and medium-size businesses are an important part of its growth engine. Vice Premier <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="http://www.gov.cn/guowuyuan/2018-08/20/content_5315204.htm" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">Liu He</a>, the country’s economic czar, has repeatedly said they contribute more than half of China’s tax revenues, 60 percent of its economic output and nearly three-quarters of its technological innovation.</p>, <h1 class="g-headline" id="g-inlineguide-headline">The Coronavirus Outbreak</h1>, <h2 class="g-inlineguide-list-header g-optimize-type">What do you need to know? Start here.</h2>, <p class="g-inlineguide-date">Updated Feb. 10, 2020</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The Chinese government has tried to ease their anxiety. Officials on Sunday ordered banks to go easy on people hit by the crisis who are struggling to repay their mortgage and credit card debt. It also encouraged more loans and lower interest rates for businesses that have been severely affected.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The guidance was vague, however, and it doesn’t begin to address the breadth of problems.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Those problems go beyond officials forcing businesses to close. Routes from one part of the country to another have been frozen. Some cities require companies to pay employees for their idle time. Those efforts could help keep people content, but they still represent a cost for business.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Wang Chenyun, an internet entrepreneur, complained in his personal blog that the Shanghai municipal government not only extended mandated holidays to Feb. 9 but also required businesses to pay double wages to employees working from home.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“The Shanghai government pays too much attention to big enterprises,” he wrote. “It doesn’t care whether small businesses can survive.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Their plight speaks to China’s lack of checks and balances. The government’s firm control of the levers of power lets it mobilize resources to build huge infrastructure projects and combat an epidemic. It can also empower officials to go too far. Without an independent court system or a free news media, businesses have few ways to protest a policy or ask for help.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Speaking out would be difficult even in better circumstances. Broadly, businesses from hotels, restaurants and department stores to farmers like Mr. Qiu believe Chinese officials are justified in moving forcefully to stop the spread. (The government has also been criticized for its <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/21/world/asia/china-coronavirus-wuhan.html" title="">slow response</a> and for punishing those who tried to sound <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/22/health/virus-corona.html" title="">early warnings</a>, so it feels tremendous pressure from the public to act.)</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">But the government’s top-down, command-and-control approach doesn’t take into account the transformations within the country’s vibrant and dynamic economy, and may make it slow to respond to signs of distress from entrepreneurs.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">New highways and rail lines have made even the most rural parts of China dependent on other places. Mr. Qiu, for example, has problems beyond closed slaughterhouses and supply sources. Even if he could find supplies in other provinces, roads are closed for all nonlocal vehicles. The roads to his village have been blocked with piles of dirt.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“If this continues, it will affect the chicken, eggs and the other meat supplies nationally in a few months,” <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2003/08/24/world/a-chinese-robin-hood-runs-afoul-of-beijing.html" title="">Sun Dawu</a>, a prominent businessman in Hebei Province who owns a company that supplies chicken farmers, wrote on Weibo, a social media site. “It can lead to market panic and affect social stability. I urged the government to take measures immediately.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">China depends more on consumption and personal services than it did during the 2003 outbreak of SARS, another dangerous disease, which had a significant but short-lived impact on China’s growth.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Many of the country’s restaurants have closed for the time being. Haidilao, one of China’s biggest restaurant chains, shut down all of its 550 branches in the mainland. Beijing Dadong Roast Duck, a high-end chain, shut all of its 20-plus restaurants but two in Beijing.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“If things can’t resume to normal in two months, we’ll probably have to shut down our business,” Dadong’s owner, Dong Zhenxiang, said in an interview. He hopes the government can lower taxes, lower rent and provide some subsidies.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Travel is another hard-hit industry, since the Lunar New Year holiday, which began last Saturday, is usually the busiest travel season of the year. Mr. Sun, the businessman in Hebei, said he had to close a hot spring resort and send all 1,500 workers on holiday. He estimated that he could lose over $7 million from that business alone.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Xu Zhihua, chief executive of sportswear brand Peak, wrote on his Weibo account: “The whole society has come to a standstill with almost zero consumption.” He worries that a lot of small and medium-size companies won’t be able to pay back their loans. “Then the whole economy will be finished!” he added.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">More broadly, the coronavirus crisis emerged when many small and medium-size businesses were already struggling. China’s growth has eased to its slowest pace in nearly three decades. The trade war with the United States has rippled through parts of the country. Many people complain that the state-run banking system won’t lend them money at a reasonable rate.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The Chinese government is also crowding them out. Big state-run companies are taking an increasingly important role in the economy, in a reversal of the trend of opening up to private enterprise that helped drive China’s success. The government interferes more online and increasingly demands that businesses pay greater heed to directives from the Communist Party.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">As the coronavirus has spread, Beijing officials have taken a heavier hand to control prices. For example, the government in Baoding, in the central province of Hebei, fined a shopping mall company nearly $300,000 for selling cabbages and cauliflowers at higher prices. Of course, China is hardly alone in punishing price gouging, and it won public praise for fining some pharmacies for raising prices of face masks, which are in short supply all over China.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“If cabbages were easily available, the store wouldn’t be able to charge higher prices — nobody would buy it,” said Liu Xuanhua, an economist. “If the outbreak continues, our ignorance about the market economy could end with us having nowhere to buy vegetables.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Some industries, like chicken farmers, are trying to get the government’s attention. Farmers have created a sort of social media campaign to petition the government to open special transportation channels for their supplies.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Even the agricultural bureau in Huangmei County in Hubei Province, the epicenter of the coronavirus outbreak, filed an official plea to the local virus prevention headquarters to ease traffic controls so local farmers could buy feed and medicine, according to a document circulated online.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Mr. Qiu, who hoists a Chinese national flag next to his enormous chicken coops and wears a national flag badge on his black winter coat, said he wholeheartedly supported everything the Jiangsu government had done to combat the virus.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“But I also have real difficulties that require the government’s help,” he said.</p>, <p>Advertisement</p>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd" id="site-index-label">Site Index</h2>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-0">news</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-1">opinion</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-2">arts</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-3">living</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-4">more</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-subscribe-label">Subscribe</h3>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd">Site Information Navigation</h2>]
[<p>Advertisement</p>, <p>Supported by</p>, <h1 class="css-1s4ffep e1h9rw200" id="link-4ed56d88" itemprop="headline"><span>Masks Are On. Games Are Canceled. Fear of the Coronavirus Comes to U.S. Colleges.</span></h1>, <p class="css-1ifw933 e1wiw3jv0" id="article-summary">There has only been one confirmed case of the virus at a college campus, but anxiety is palpable in classes and dorms.</p>, <p class="css-1fv7b6t e1jsehar1" itemprop="author" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">By<!-- --> <a class="css-brehiz e1jsehar0" href="https://www.nytimes.com/by/nicholas-bogel-burroughs"><span class="css-1baulvz last-byline" itemprop="name">Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs</span></a></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">At the University of Wisconsin-Platteville, two undergraduates from Wuhan, China, were moved to a special dorm room and told to regularly take their temperatures. At Arizona State University, a student-led petition called for classes to be canceled after a confirmed case of coronavirus. Basketball games were postponed at Miami University in Ohio after two students who had recently returned from China displayed possible symptoms.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The global alarm over the coronavirus is particularly intense on American college campuses, where students from around the world are packed in tightly and illnesses <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4823483/" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">sweep through</a> dormitories and classrooms even in normal winters.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“This virus has sent off some panic bells for me,” said Sarah Linck, 22, a junior at Arizona State, in Tempe. She began shielding herself from the virus as soon as she heard that someone affiliated with her campus — perhaps a student, perhaps an instructor, perhaps someone else — was one of six people confirmed to have the virus in the United States.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">At A.S.U., which has one of the largest student bodies in the country, students have been streaming into the campus health center in larger-than-usual numbers. A cough in the back of a classroom now brings nervous glances. Students who had planned to study abroad this semester are furiously rejiggering schedules.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Ms. Linck said she had a weak immune system and had gotten pneumonia more than once before, so she has been especially cautious. Just before stores near campus <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.statepress.com/article/2020/01/spcommunity-coronavirus-tempe-asu" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">sold out of face masks</a>, she had a friend who worked at a drugstore buy her one, which she now wears nonstop.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“I don’t know if I should be as worried about it as I am, but with this being the only thing on our minds, it’s difficult not to worry,” said Ms. Linck, who studies construction management.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">[</em><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/02/01/world/asia/coronavirus-china.html" title=""><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">Read about the latest developments in the coronavirus outbreak here</em></a><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">.]</em></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Alarm over coronavirus heightened on Friday as Delta Air Lines, United Airlines and American Airlines said they are <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/31/travel/travel-coronavirus-airlines.html" title="">suspending all service to mainland China</a>, leaving travelers stranded.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">At colleges across the country, administrators quickly made plans to protect the spread of the virus on their campuses and discourage travel to China. Boston University <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.bu.edu/articles/2020/bu-postpones-shanghai-program-amid-coronavirus-fears/" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">postponed</a> its study abroad program in Shanghai that had been planned to begin in February.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Hundreds of students are being screened for the virus, either because they recently passed through Wuhan or because flulike symptoms sent them to a campus nurse. Possible cases at many schools — <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.star-telegram.com/news/state/texas/article239680953.html" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">Baylor</a>, <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.middletownpress.com/middletown/article/University-Wesleyan-student-tests-negative-for-15007305.php" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">Wesleyan</a> and <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.tennessean.com/story/news/health/2020/01/24/coronavirus-tennessee-test-results-negative-individual-tested-cookeville-tech-student-cdc-says/4572158002/" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">Tennessee Tech</a> — have turned out to be false alarms after testing, but that has not stopped the anxiety.</p>, <h1 class="g-headline" id="g-inlineguide-headline">The Coronavirus Outbreak</h1>, <h2 class="g-inlineguide-list-header g-optimize-type">How Is the U.S. Being Affected?</h2>, <p class="g-inlineguide-date">Updated Feb.10, 2020</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Carolyn Kleve, 20, a junior at Arizona State who is 13 weeks pregnant, is afraid — for herself, but even more so for her unborn child and the 5-year-olds she works with every week as a student teacher.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Ms. Kleve has already skipped one day of classes, but said she cannot miss another without affecting her grades. Before she steps on campus each day, she puts on a mask and snaps on latex gloves. She also washes her hands furiously, but worries it is not enough.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“We’re trapped in a room of 20 to 30 people and I don’t know who has what illness,” Ms. Kleve said of her classes. “Have I already come into contact with it? Who knows.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">At the University of Wisconsin-Platteville, six students who were recently in Wuhan arrived this month for classes and were told to self-monitor their health in their dorm rooms. Two of the students, who were natives of Wuhan, have been rooming with each other instead of with American students, as was originally planned.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Melissa Gormley, dean of the college of liberal arts, said that the students had not showed any symptoms, and that she hoped to move the two from Wuhan into dorms with noninternational students soon.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">In the meantime, they have been free to rove about campus and attended the semester’s first day of classes on Monday. The incubation <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/article/what-is-coronavirus.html" title="">period for the virus is about two weeks</a>, meaning people can appear healthy for some time after they are exposed.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Dr. Gormley said she had met with all of the students who had traveled through Wuhan and tried to make them feel welcome.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“We would do whatever we have to do to take care of our people in our community here, whether they were from Wuhan, whether they had traveled to Wuhan, or whether they were another student,” Ms. Gormley said. “And I hope they know that. But I can imagine that being an exchange student in this context would be really scary.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Students have described a rising anti-Chinese sentiment on their campuses that has extended to anyone of Asian descent. Some students have posted online about avoiding all Asian classmates or steering clear of Chinatowns.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Aaron Li, a senior at Cornell from China, said that he had created a form for Chinese students to anonymously submit concerns or questions about the virus and that one troubling response stuck out. It was from a student who said he had lied to his friends about spending winter break in California; he had actually returned home to China.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“He was worried about what his friends would think,” Mr. Li said, adding that some Chinese students had to simultaneously worry about the health of family members back home.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">A campus satire publication <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="http://cunooz.com/2020/01/29/asian-student-asked-if-he-visited-wuhan-over-break/?fbclid=IwAR0AB-Abp_jit9ulG-V2vyuXwT6js9ANzfh6Mmpng2iyTFAZ1qtsjltuzd8" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">dryly pushed back</a> against the rising sentiment with an article under the headline, “Asian Student Asked If He Visited Wuhan Over Break.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Charles Bui, 18, a freshman at the University of Houston, said he had scrolled past “dehumanizing” jokes online about the deadly virus and had personally seen people express relief after they stepped off an elevator with him.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“The environment doesn’t feel the same as it used to, and so it’s unsettling,” said Mr. Bui, who is Vietnamese-American and plans to major in business. He added that he had sometimes questioned his own reactions, asking, “Is this really about my race or am I overassuming?”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">At the University of California, Berkeley, which has a large Chinese student population, officials apologized after the university health center posted <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://pbs.twimg.com/media/EPjrc1YXsBgqTyF.jpg" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">an image that included “xenophobia”</a> among a list of “common reactions” to the coronavirus. It was condemned as giving legitimacy to racism.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">As the frenzy surrounding the virus grows, campus health officials are taking on two challenges: informing the public about the virus while managing exaggerated fears, and continuing to handle the flu viruses that typically spread this time of year.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Rachel Herman, the director of the Platteville school’s health center, said that members of her staff were in frequent contact with the local health department, but that they still consider influenza to be more concerning than the coronavirus.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Dr. Stacie San Miguel, the director of medical services at the University of California, San Diego’s student health center, said students and others had been flocking to physicians for checkups. The college has one of the <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.sandiegouniontribune.com/news/education/sd-me-ucsd-foreignstudents-20190207-story.html" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">largest international student populations</a> — about 19 percent — in the United States, most of whom are Chinese.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“Especially the people who have been to China and had a runny nose, they’re not sure — is this something or not something? — so there has been some anxiety,” Dr. San Miguel said.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">So far, the campus has not diagnosed anyone as having the virus, but at a conference on United States and China relations hosted by the college this week, officials introduced a novel standard for meet-and-greets that was aimed at calming nerves: no handshakes.</p>, <p class="css-jwz2nf etfikam0">Julie Bosman, Matt Furber, Roni Caryn Rabin, Vanessa Swales and Ana Swanson contributed reporting.</p>, <p>Advertisement</p>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd" id="site-index-label">Site Index</h2>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-0">news</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-1">opinion</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-2">arts</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-3">living</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-4">more</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-subscribe-label">Subscribe</h3>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd">Site Information Navigation</h2>]
[<p>Advertisement</p>, <p>Supported by</p>, <h1 class="css-1s4ffep e1h9rw200" id="link-7ce65d89" itemprop="headline"><span>195 Quarantined in California After Fleeing Coronavirus Epicenter</span></h1>, <p class="css-1ifw933 e1wiw3jv0" id="article-summary">The U.S. government took the rare step with American evacuees flown home from Wuhan, China, and said it would quarantine others returning from recent travel in the region.</p>, <p class="css-1fv7b6t e1jsehar1" itemprop="author" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">By<!-- --> <a class="css-brehiz e1jsehar0" href="https://www.nytimes.com/by/denise-grady"><span class="css-1baulvz" itemprop="name">Denise Grady</span></a> and <a class="css-brehiz e1jsehar0" href="https://www.nytimes.com/by/roni-caryn-rabin"><span class="css-1baulvz last-byline" itemprop="name">Roni Caryn Rabin</span></a></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The United States government has imposed a two-week federal quarantine on 195 people who were evacuated on Wednesday from Wuhan, China, to a California military base, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention said on Friday.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.cdc.gov/media/releases/2020/s0131-federal-quarantine-march-air-reserve-base.html" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">action means that the group will be held</a> at March Air Reserve Base in Riverside, Calif., to ensure they are not infected with the Wuhan coronavirus, which has sickened more than 9,800 people in China and killed more than 200. The 14-day period is dated from when their plane left Wuhan.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“While we recognize this is an unprecedented action, we are facing an unprecedented health threat,” Dr. Nancy Messonnier, director of the National Center for Immunization and Respiratory Diseases, said at a news conference on Friday.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">A federal quarantine order in the United States is rare; the last one was imposed in the 1960s, but it was limited.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Dr. Messonnier called the federal order on Friday “science-based,” saying it was warranted because of the worsening epidemic in China. She cited the widening, rapid spread of the disease there, the increase in person-to-person transmission and the rising death toll. In addition, evidence has been emerging that people can transmit the disease even before they show symptoms of the illness, which can cause pneumonia in severe cases.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Another concern was that the passengers evacuated had been in Wuhan, the epicenter of the outbreak. At a news conference later on Friday, Alex M. Azar II, the secretary of health and human services, announced that other citizens of the United States who were returning from Hubei Province, which includes Wuhan, would also be quarantined for up to two weeks. Mr. Azar declared a public health emergency for the United States, and said foreign nationals who had been to China during the last 14 days would not be allowed into the United States.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“This is a very serious public health situation, and the C.D.C. and federal government have and will continue to take aggressive action to protect the public,” Dr. Messonnier said. “If we take strong measures now, we may be able to blunt” the impact of the virus in the United States.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Dr. Messonnier said that the people who were quarantined did not pose a threat to the surrounding community.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Since the 195 evacuees arrived in Riverside, they<a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/30/us/coronavirus-americans-evacuate.html" title=""> have had their noses and throats swabbed</a> to test for the virus, and their temperatures taken several times a day. They were initially told that they would be detained for at least 72 hours, and possibly 14 days. Two weeks is thought to be the upper limit of the incubation period; if symptoms don’t start by then, a person can be cleared as not infected.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Not all the virus tests have been completed, but even if the results are negative, that does not mean a person is not infected, Dr. Messonnier said. It is possible to test too early for the virus, so a person who tests negative could still become ill and infect others. Therefore, officials said it was safer to detain people for the entire incubation period.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Dr. Martin Cetron, director of the C.D.C.’s global migration and quarantine division, said the evacuees would benefit from the quarantine, which would prevent them from infecting their families and would provide close monitoring so that they could receive medical treatment quickly if symptoms developed.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Citing quarantines in Toronto during the SARS outbreak there in 2003, he said that most people being quarantined accept it as “part of their civic responsibility to protect their community,” once they understand the reasons. He also said that many people flown home from Wuhan were diplomats who understood this as part of their duty.</p>, <h1 class="g-headline" id="g-inlineguide-headline">The Coronavirus Outbreak</h1>, <h2 class="g-inlineguide-list-header g-optimize-type">What do you need to know? Start here.</h2>, <p class="g-inlineguide-date">Updated Feb. 10, 2020</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Until Friday, the evacuees’ detention at the air base had been unofficial. The group had stayed voluntarily for testing, except for one member, who tried to leave on Wednesday and was quarantined by Riverside County.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Federal law <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.cdc.gov/quarantine/aboutlawsregulationsquarantineisolation.html" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">authorizes the C.D.C. to impose quarantines</a>, but the power is rarely used. The last large-scale quarantine was imposed during the Spanish flu pandemic of 1918-19. The limited one in the 1960s that Dr. Cetron mentioned involved a possible case of smallpox.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Last week, China took the extreme measure of halting public transit and imposing a quarantine on Wuhan, a city of 11 million people. But people were already traveling extensively in and out of the country for celebrations of the Lunar New Year, prompting concerns that the virus would spread widely around the globe.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">So far, <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/cases-in-us.html" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">six people in the United States</a> are known to be infected. Five had been to Wuhan and the sixth is the husband of one of those patients. He had not traveled to Wuhan, but contracted the illness from his wife after she returned home to Chicago. The other cases have been in Washington State, California and Arizona.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">More than 100 people in 36 states are being monitored as “patients under investigation,” because they have symptoms like fever and cough and had been to Wuhan or in contact with patients.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Hundreds of other contacts of patients have been told to notify doctors or health officials immediately if they become ill.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">At the briefing, Dr. Messonnier cited a new report from Germany as part of the evidence that pushed the C.D.C. to impose the quarantine.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Physicians there who identified the first coronavirus case in their country have reported that the patient was infected by a colleague visiting from China who was not yet sick.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">That the disease may be transmitted before infected people show symptoms will make the disease harder to contain, experts said.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">A letter published in the <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nejm.org/doi/full/10.1056/NEJMc2001468" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">New England Journal of Medicine said the German patient was</a> a healthy 33-year-old businessman who developed a sore throat, chills and muscle aches on Jan. 24, with a fever spiking to 102.4 the next day, along with a cough. He felt better a day later and returned to work on Jan. 27.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Before he became ill, he had met with a Chinese business partner from his company near Munich, on Jan. 20 and 21. She was a resident of Shanghai who had been in Germany from Jan. 19 to 22. Though she was healthy during the visit, she got sick during her flight back to China, where she tested positive for the new coronavirus on Jan. 26. She informed her company, which traced her contacts to alert anyone she might have exposed.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The businessman was contacted, and although he was already recovering, he tested positive for the virus.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">On Jan. 28, three more employees of the company in Germany tested positive for the coronavirus, only one of whom had contact with the woman from Shanghai. The others were apparently infected by their male colleague, before he developed symptoms. All of them were admitted to the hospital, where they were isolated and monitored, and none have developed severe symptoms.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The authors of the letter in the New England Journal of Medicine, who are from Munich and Berlin, said it was “notable that the infection appears to have been transmitted during the incubation period” of the woman from Shanghai, who shortly afterward had only a brief, mild illness.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“It does mean that transmission is more readily achieved than it was in SARS,” an earlier coronavirus disease, said Dr. William Schaffner, an infectious disease specialist at Vanderbilt University Medical Center. “The report from Germany indicates quite conclusively that spread during the incubation period when the person is not sick themselves can take place.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">But, he added, “We don’t know how frequently it happens.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“This is a kind of natural experiment, where people were nicely shown to be in a chain of transmission, and it sounds very, very plausible,” Dr. Schaffner said.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">A scientific paper about the first patient in the United States to test positive for the coronavirus revealed more details about the course the illness takes.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The patient, a 35-year-old from Snohomish County, Wash., returned to the United States on Jan. 15 from a visit to Wuhan, and developed a cough and fever as soon as he got home.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">After reading about the latest coronavirus in news reports, he sought medical treatment and informed his health care providers about his travel, although he had not been to an animal market or had contact with sick people.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">He was tested and sent home, but was called back in on Jan. 20 when the test came back positive. He was hospitalized in an isolation unit on Jan. 21, and was still in the hospital on Thursday.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The Washington resident did not become severely ill until nine days after his symptoms started. An X-ray then revealed pneumonia, and he received an experimental antiviral drug called remdesivir on a compassionate basis, for which the Food and Drug Administration allows use of a drug not yet approved.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">By the 12th day of his illness, he no longer had symptoms, according to a <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nejm.org/doi/full/10.1056/NEJMoa2001191?query=RP" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">description of his case published</a> on Friday in the New England Journal of Medicine.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10"><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">[</em></strong><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10"><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="http://on.fb.me/1paTQ1h" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title=""><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">Like the Science Times page on Facebook.</em></a></strong><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10"><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0"> </em></strong><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">| Sign up for the </em><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10"><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="http://nyti.ms/1MbHaRU" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title=""><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">Science Times newsletter.</em></a></strong><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10"><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">]</em></strong></p>, <p>Advertisement</p>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd" id="site-index-label">Site Index</h2>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-0">news</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-1">opinion</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-2">arts</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-3">living</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-4">more</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-subscribe-label">Subscribe</h3>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd">Site Information Navigation</h2>]
[<p>Advertisement</p>, <p>Supported by</p>, <h1 class="css-1s4ffep e1h9rw200" id="link-390c1935" itemprop="headline"><span>Inside the California Military Base a Coronavirus Evacuee Tried to Flee</span></h1>, <p class="css-1ifw933 e1wiw3jv0" id="article-summary">The 195 Americans who flew from China to California were first told they must clear medical tests that could take 72 hours or many days. Now they are all being quarantined for two weeks.</p>, <p class="css-1fv7b6t e1jsehar1" itemprop="author" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">By<!-- --> <a class="css-brehiz e1jsehar0" href="https://www.nytimes.com/by/miriam-jordan/"><span class="css-1baulvz last-byline" itemprop="name">Miriam Jordan</span></a></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">LOS ANGELES — This week, a group of strangers came together under a warm Southern California sun. They played ball with their children. They took jogs down tree-lined paths. They watched movies in the afternoon.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">They also had their temperatures taken several times a day by medical personnel. And they are not allowed to leave the premises.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">This makeshift community on a military base in Riverside, Calif., is made up of evacuees from Wuhan, the city in China that is the epicenter of the coronavirus outbreak. The 195 people, including diplomats, infants, a football player and a theme-park designer, are among Americans who have managed to leave Wuhan since a quarantine was imposed.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">[</em><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/02/01/world/asia/coronavirus-china.html" title=""><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">Read about the latest developments in the coronavirus outbreak here</em></a><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">.]</em></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Now they find themselves stuck in place in the United States. The federal government on Friday imposed a 14-day quarantine, retroactive to when the plane left Wuhan. The patients were initially told they had to wait at least 72 hours for medical testing to be completed.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The group arrived in the United States on Wednesday aboard the only chartered plane the State Department has flown to carry evacuees from China. As they passed time on the March Air Reserve Base, waiting until they can be cleared to leave by medical officials, some recalled unsettling, eerie final days in Wuhan and a jarring scene as the plane finally carried them away.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“It was surreal,” said Matthew McCoy, a theme-park designer, recalling the airplane crew members in hazardous material suits tending to passengers in masks. “They were trying to keep us calm, but they had these guys covered from head to toe taking your temperature. It felt like a C.I.A. cargo plane.”</p>, <h1 class="g-headline" id="g-inlineguide-headline">The Coronavirus Outbreak</h1>, <h2 class="g-inlineguide-list-header g-optimize-type">How Is the U.S. Being Affected?</h2>, <p class="g-inlineguide-date">Updated Feb.10, 2020</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">To contain the spread of the virus, which has killed more than 200 people and infected thousands, people have been quarantined on a cruise ship, in hospital wards and on an island.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Late Wednesday, hours after the plane arrived in California, a passenger tried to leave the base and was intercepted, local officials in Riverside County said. A quarantine order was issued to that passenger, a spokeswoman for the county said, because of “the unknown risks to the public should someone leave the base without undergoing a full health evaluation.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">With ample time on their hands, the passengers performed mundane tasks.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“I’m working out, watching movies, eating well,” said Jarred Evans, 27, a football player from New York City who has been living in Wuhan for two years, where he plays for the Chinese National Football League champions, the Wuhan Berserkers. He has also been through numerous checks. “I’ve never had my temperature taken so many times in my life,” he said.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">From his room at an inn on the military base, Mr. McCoy said, “It’s not Club Med, but we’re fortunate to be here. I try to stay busy with my work, social media and my hotel workout regimen.” The Spanish-style hotel, which boasts stucco archways and a large courtyard, faces a verdant lawn.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">After a stopover in Anchorage for refueling and medical screening, the passengers were greeted in California by experts from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention who conducted medical tests and offered psychological counseling. Noses and throats were swabbed. Blood was drawn. Temperatures were taken, again.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Some recalled bleak, sometimes terrifying, last days in Wuhan.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Mr. Evans, a former quarterback at the University of Cincinnati, moved to Wuhan when he was recruited to play for the city’s American football team.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">It had been a good season: His team had won the national championship in Shanghai on Jan. 8.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“I fell in love with Chinese culture,” he said, “and I got to be the face of American football in China.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">But when the coronavirus began spreading through Wuhan, Mr. Evans shut himself inside his apartment, stocked up with rice, noodles, eggs and disinfectant.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“I did exactly what every Chinese person did,” he said.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“I locked myself in. The city turned into a ghost town,” Mr. Evans said. But he felt isolated, he said, and his mother, back in the United States, was worried for his safety.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">When he heard of a flight out of the country, he quickly filled out the online forms. An email from the United States Embassy in Beijing arrived, which read: “Space on this flight is extremely limited and we respectfully request that you not share details regarding the flight, including on social media.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Mr. Evans learned that he was No. 171 on a flight that could accommodate about 200, he said. “I felt very lucky to be chosen out of all U.S. residents in Wuhan,” he said. Some Americans reported that they had tried to get a seat on the flight but were told there was no room.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Mr. McCoy, who lives in Shanghai, was in Wuhan working on a mall he is refashioning into a theme park when he got caught in the lockdown.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The atmosphere in the city was “just short of panic,” he recalled.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">A former Marine who has run 12 marathons and stays in good shape, Mr. McCoy said he was convinced he had not contracted the virus. But he still took the outbreak seriously. He decided it was worth plunking down $1,100 for a one-way ticket to the United States.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">When the American group left Wuhan, it had been made aware it would have to remain in an isolated location for at least 72 hours.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“This quarantine will occur for a minimum of 72 hours and may extend through 14 days or may be followed by conditional release with health monitoring,” said an email that he received before the flight. Mr. McCoy said that had not troubled most people. “Everyone was cool with that. We are trying to be patriots, trying to help,” he said. “We’re a captive audience here.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">On Thursday morning, their first full day back in the United States, the group downed breakfast burritos, juice and coffee. For lunch, they received a hearty taco salad with chicken. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">An invitation slipped under the doors of the hotel rooms promised a “town hall discussion.” Federal health officials urged the group to remain on the base until receiving full medical clearance.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Now it was a matter of waiting.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Outside, there were refreshments, chips, cookies and toys. Scooters, footballs, soccer balls and Frisbees were available.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“People here have been really nice,” Mr. Evans said. “Everybody is in great spirits. Nobody is panicking or freaking out.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">There is no shaking hands or hugging, though, and most people were keeping on their masks.</p>, <p class="css-jwz2nf etfikam0">Susan C. Beachy contributed research from New York.</p>, <p>Advertisement</p>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd" id="site-index-label">Site Index</h2>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-0">news</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-1">opinion</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-2">arts</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-3">living</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-4">more</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-subscribe-label">Subscribe</h3>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd">Site Information Navigation</h2>]
[<p>Advertisement</p>, <p>Supported by</p>, <h1 class="css-1s4ffep e1h9rw200" id="link-61d97632" itemprop="headline"><span>As Virus Spreads, U.S. Temporarily Bars Foreigners Who’ve Visited China </span></h1>, <p class="css-1ifw933 e1wiw3jv0" id="article-summary">Most foreign nationals will not be allowed to enter the United States if they’ve been to China in the preceding two weeks.</p>, <h3 class="css-k42qd2 e1gnsphs0">Here’s what you need to know:</h3>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">[This briefing has ended. </em><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/02/01/world/asia/coronavirus-china.html" title=""><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">Read about the latest developments in the coronavirus outbreak here</em></a><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">.]</em></p>, <h2 class="css-3ez4hu eoo0vm40" id="link-72ad15d3">U.S. restrictions will keep out most foreigners who’ve recently been to China.</h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The Trump administration is imposing temporary <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/02/10/business/china-coronavirus-philippines-travel.html" title="">travel restrictions</a> that bar entry into the United States by any foreign national who has traveled to China in the past 14 days, officials said Friday.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The restrictions, a reaction to the <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/02/10/business/china-coronavirus-philippines-travel.html" title="">coronavirus</a> that has been declared <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/30/health/coronavirus-world-health-organization.html" title="">a public health emergency</a> by the World Health Organization, will be put into place at 5 p.m. on Sunday. The United States on Friday also declared the coronavirus, which has sickened nearly 12,000 people and has spread to the United States and other countries, a public health emergency.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Friday’s action exempts immediate family members of American citizens and permanent residents.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">In addition, officials said, any United States citizen returning home who has been in the Hubei province of China within the past 14 days will be quarantined for up to 14 days. Wuhan, the epicenter of the outbreak, is in Hubei.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Those who have been to other parts of China within the past 14 days will be subject to “proactive entry screening” and up to 14 days of monitoring and self quarantine.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The United States will also funnel all flights from China to just a few airports, including Kennedy Airport, Chicago’s O’Hare and San Francisco International Airport.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The travel restrictions were announced Friday by Alex Azar, the secretary of health and human services, who declared that the coronavirus posed “a public health emergency in the United States.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Dr. Anthony S. Fauci, the director of the National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases, said the actions were being taken because there were “a lot of unknowns” surrounding the virus and its transmission path.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“The number of cases have steeply inclined with every day,” Dr. Fauci said.</p>, <h2 class="css-3ez4hu eoo0vm40" id="link-66f879b9">Stocks sink again after airlines cancel flights to China.</h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The broadening outbreak has roiled stock markets and raised alarms about possible harm to global economic growth.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The S&amp;P 500 suffered its sharpest decline of the year on Friday after major airlines in the United States said they would cancel flights to and from mainland China. It was the worst daily decline since October, and pushed the markets into negative territory for the year.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The cancellations by Delta Air Lines, American Airlines and United Airlines were the latest example of economic disruption wrought by the coronavirus, just as the global economy had begun to recover from the trade war tensions that dominated 2019. Companies have restricted travel to the region, shut stores in China and warned of the possible financial impact.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Economists seem certain that the travel shutdowns, factory closures and quarantines in mainland China will dampen economic activity there, but have said it is too soon to know the impact elsewhere.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“It is a wild card — I think even the experts would confirm that it’s too soon to tell,” said Richard Clarida, the vice chair of the Federal Reserve, during an interview on Friday on Bloomberg Television. The Fed is “monitoring closely,” he said.</p>, <h2 class="css-zd32qr">How Bad Will the Coronavirus Outbreak Get? Here Are 6 Key Factors</h2>, <p class="css-1uuihdo">Here’s what early research says about how the pathogen behaves and the factors that will determine whether it can be contained.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Concerns about global growth sent oil prices down below $52 a barrel. That pushed shares of energy companies down: Exxon Mobil and Chevron dropped by roughly 4 percent. Tech stocks also suffered, with particular weakness in the semiconductor sector, which is closely linked to supply chains based in and around China.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Economists have only begun to sketch out estimates on the potential effects of the outbreak. Many have taken comfort from the economic record of the SARS outbreak in China in 2002 and 2003, which suggests that any downturn might be limited in scope. SARS coincided with a relatively brief slowdown of global growth in early 2003, that was followed by a sharp rebound.</p>, <h1 class="g-headline" id="g-inlineguide-headline">The Coronavirus Outbreak</h1>, <h2 class="g-inlineguide-list-header g-optimize-type">What do you need to know? Start here.</h2>, <p class="g-inlineguide-date">Updated Feb. 10, 2020</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">SARS, however, is an imperfect comparison. Some economists have suggested the ripple effects could be larger this time. At the time of the SARS outbreak, China represented just 5 percent of the global economy. In 2019, that number was 18 percent, according to JPMorgan economists.</p>, <h2 class="css-3ez4hu eoo0vm40" id="link-577f2f0a">Delta, United and American Airlines are suspending all flights between the U.S. and mainland China.</h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Delta Air Lines, United Airlines and American Airlines all said on Friday that they were <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/31/travel/travel-coronavirus-airlines.html" title="">suspending all service to mainland China</a> as concerns about the coronavirus spread internationally.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">American said it was suspending all flights to and from mainland China immediately through March 27. American and United will continue flights to Hong Kong.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Delta and United said they would suspend service starting on Feb. 6. United said it expected to resume operations on March 28.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Delta, which does not fly to Hong Kong, said it would suspend service through April 30. Delta said in a statement that its last flight to mainland China from the United States would depart on Monday, and that its last flight to the United States from mainland China would leave on Wednesday.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Delta was the first American airline to completely suspend service to China because of the virus. United Airlines had already reduced its service to the country this week.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Share prices in all three airlines had fallen by midday.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Airlines outside the United States are also clamping down on travel. In Rwanda and Kenya, RwandAir and Kenya Airways said they would cancel all flights to and from Guangzhou, the southern Chinese metropolis, until further notice. There have been no confirmed cases in Africa.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Poland’s national airline, LOT Polish Airlines, has suspended flights to China until Feb. 9, a<a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://twitter.com/MAPGOVPL/status/1223219993556455425" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title=""> deputy prime minister said on Twitter.</a> More than a dozen people suspected of having the coronavirus are hospitalized in Poland, and over 500 people are being monitored by health services.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Iran has suspended all flights to China because of the coronavirus outbreak, according to Reuters. Iran’s semiofficial Tasnim news agency reported on Friday that all flights from China to the Islamic Republic have also been banned.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Several Canadian companies have suspended employee travel to China after Air Canada’s decision on Wednesday to suspend service to Shanghai and Beijing. The Montreal-based carrier normally operates 33 flights a week to and from the two Chinese cities.</p>, <h2 class="css-3ez4hu eoo0vm40" id="link-646166f3">Americans evacuated from Wuhan are quarantined.</h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The United States government has imposed a federal <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/31/health/quarantine-coronavirus.html" title="">quarantine</a> on 195 people who were evacuated on Wednesday from <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/31/health/quarantine-coronavirus.html" title="">Wuhan, China, to a California military base</a>, officials said on Friday.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The group will be held at March Air Reserve Base in Riverside, Calif., for 14 days, to ensure that they are not infected with the coronavirus that has sickened more than 9,800 people in China and killed more than 200 people.</p>, <h2 class="css-3ez4hu eoo0vm40" id="link-6c3fcf70">More than 250 people have died, with nearly 12,000 infections confirmed.</h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Chinese officials on Saturday reported the highest death toll so far in a 24-hour period.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">◆ The 46 new deaths in China raised the toll to 259.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">◆ About 2,100 new cases were also recorded in the country in the past 24 hours, raising the worldwide total to nearly 12,000, according to Chinese and World Health Organization data. The vast majority of the cases are inside China; about 100 cases have been confirmed in 21 other countries.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">◆ All of China’s provinces and territories have now been touched by the outbreak.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">◆<span class="css-8l6xbc evw5hdy0"> </span>Countries and territories that have confirmed cases: Thailand, Japan, Hong Kong, Singapore, Taiwan, Australia, Malaysia, Macau, Russia, France, the United States, South Korea, Germany, the United Arab Emirates, Canada, Britain, Vietnam, Italy, India, the Philippines, Nepal, Cambodia, Sri Lanka and Finland.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">◆ Cases recorded in Thailand, Taiwan, Germany, Vietnam, Japan, France and the United States involved patients who had not been to China.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">◆ No deaths have been reported outside China.</p>, <h2 class="css-3ez4hu eoo0vm40" id="link-79109630">Fear of coronavirus comes to U.S. college campuses.</h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">A call has been issued for classes to be canceled at Arizona State University. Basketball games were postponed at Miami University in Ohio. And at the University of Wisconsin-Platteville, two students from Wuhan were moved to a special dorm.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">On <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/31/us/coronavirus-college-campuses.html" title="">college campuses across the United States</a>, the global alarm over coronavirus is particularly intense. Hundreds of students are being screened for the virus. Suspected cases at many colleges — <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.star-telegram.com/news/state/texas/article239680953.html" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">Baylor</a>, <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.middletownpress.com/middletown/article/University-Wesleyan-student-tests-negative-for-15007305.php" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">Wesleyan</a> and <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.tennessean.com/story/news/health/2020/01/24/coronavirus-tennessee-test-results-negative-individual-tested-cookeville-tech-student-cdc-says/4572158002/" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">Tennessee Tech</a> — have turned out to be false alarms, but the anxiety continues.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">At A.S.U., where there is one confirmed case of coronavirus, a cough in the back of a classroom now brings nervous glances. Students who had planned to study abroad this semester are furiously adjusting schedules.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Carolyn Kleve, 20, a junior at Arizona State who is 13 weeks pregnant, is afraid.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“We’re trapped in a room of 20 to 30 people and I don’t know who has what illness,” Ms. Kleve said of her classes. “Have I already come into contact with it? Who knows?”</p>, <h2 class="css-3ez4hu eoo0vm40" id="link-4e210e6f">A Chinese official feels ‘guilty and remorseful’ about the outbreak.</h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">A high-ranking Chinese official said on Friday that he felt responsible for the spread of the coronavirus, offering his most direct expression of responsibility for the crisis. Many residents and experts have said that the reluctance by the government in Wuhan to warn the public about the spreading disease created dangerous complacency.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“Above all, I feel guilty and remorseful and I reproach myself,” said Ma Guoqiang, the Communist Party secretary of Wuhan. “I’ve been constantly thinking that if I’d made the decision earlier to take the kind of strict controls we have in place now, the outcome would have been much better than now.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Mr. Ma was asked about his feelings in <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="http://www.bjnews.com.cn/news/2020/01/31/682371.html" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">an interview on China’s main television</a> network, CCTV.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Wuhan’s mayor, Zhou Xianwang, who is less powerful than Mr. Ma, said the government’s own laws hindered faster public disclosure.</p>, <h2 class="css-3ez4hu eoo0vm40" id="link-36c544f5">The State Department tells Americans not to travel to China.</h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The State Department on Thursday night issued a travel advisory <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://travel.state.gov/content/travel/en/traveladvisories/traveladvisories/china-travel-advisory.html" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">telling Americans not to travel to China</a> because of the public health threat posed by the dangerous new coronavirus. The department set the new advisory at Level 4, or red — its highest alert, reserved for the most perilous situations.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“Travelers should be prepared for travel restrictions to be put into effect with little or no advance notice,” the State Department said. “Commercial carriers have reduced or suspended routes to and from China.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">A spokeswoman for the Chinese foreign ministry, Hua Chunying, called the advisory an unfriendly act at a difficult time for China.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“True feeling shines through in hardship,” Ms. Hua said on Friday. “Many countries have shown their support and help for China’s fight against the epidemic. By contrast, the United States’ words and deeds are not in keeping with the facts and less are they in keeping with friendship.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The World Health Organization on Thursday declared the outbreak a global emergency after cases were discovered in more than a dozen countries.</p>, <h2 class="css-3ez4hu eoo0vm40" id="link-5f2c3c08">Singapore and Mongolia will bar entries from China.</h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Singapore on Friday announced a sweeping ban on Chinese visitors and other foreigners who had been to China in the past 14 days, in an escalation of travel restrictions by the Southeast Asian transportation hub.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The city-state will also stop issuing all forms of visas to people holding Chinese passports, Lawrence Wong, the minister for national development, said on Friday.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Singapore has 13 confirmed cases of the coronavirus. The outbreak and the entry shutdown will be another blow to its economy, which was already hit by the fallout from the United States-China trade war.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Regional neighbors and airlines from countries that have not had any confirmed cases are also taking extra precautions to cope with the rapidly spreading epidemic.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The government of Mongolia said on Friday that it would close its border with China until March 2.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The authorities said they would work to bring home 30 Mongolian nationals from Wuhan, and its citizens in China would have until Feb. 6 to return. Non-Chinese foreigners visiting Mongolia will also not be able to enter through China.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Russia, which shares a 2,600-mile border with China, has also been racing to prevent the spread of the disease. The country reported its first two coronavirus cases on Friday, both in Siberia and among Chinese nationals who had recently traveled to China.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Russia closed the border to pedestrians and cars on Thursday, and Deputy Prime Minister Tatyana A. Golikova said that Russia’s border with Mongolia would be closed to Chinese citizens. Russia will also temporarily stop issuing work visas to Chinese citizens, she added.</p>, <h2 class="css-3ez4hu eoo0vm40" id="link-558ef584">The first two confirmed cases are reported in Britain.</h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">On Friday, Britain’s chief medical officer, Chris Whitty, said two residents had tested positive for coronavirus, the first known cases in the country.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.gov.uk/government/news/cmo-confirms-cases-of-coronavirus-in-england" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">In a statement, </a>Mr. Whitty said the patients were members of the same family.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The announcement came as a flight carrying 83 British and 27 foreign nationals from Wuhan landed in Britain on Friday afternoon.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The Britons were to be quarantined at Arrowe Park Hospital in Wirral, in northwest England, <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-51314028" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">according to the BBC.</a> The others will be flown on to Spain.</p>, <h2 class="css-3ez4hu eoo0vm40" id="link-75127e55">Italy declares an emergency, and Germany confirms a sixth case.</h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The Italian government declared a six-month state of emergency on Friday after the first two cases of coronavirus were confirmed in Rome, according to a government official.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">In a statement, the government said that it had allocated the “necessary funds” to begin precautionary measures. A government official said on Friday that five million euros, about $5.5 million, had been set aside for the effort.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Two Chinese nationals, a husband and wife, were being held in isolation at Rome’s Spallanzani Hospital, which specializes in infectious diseases, after they tested positive for the virus.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The couple arrived in Milan a week ago and traveled to Parma and other cities before getting to Rome, where the husband began showing flu symptoms, the official said.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">A group of Chinese tourists who had been traveling with the couple were also being held in isolation at the hospital, Italian officials said Friday.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">At present, none of the other Chinese visitors showed any symptoms, said the Lazio region’s councilor for health, Alessio D’Amato, at a news conference on Friday.Three people who had come in contact with the infected couple were also being monitored at home, he also said.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">On Thursday, <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/30/world/europe/italy-coronavirus-cruise.html" title="">thousands of passengers had been blocked </a>from leaving a cruise ship that docked at an Italian port for more than 12 hours over concerns that someone aboard might have had the virus. That episode was ultimately found to be a false alarm.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">In Germany, the Bavarian state Health Ministry confirmed a sixth case of the virus on Friday — the first child to be infected in the country. The child is related to another coronavirus patient identified this week. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">On Friday, a German<span class="css-8l6xbc evw5hdy0"> </span>passenger jet left for China to evacuate more than 100 German citizens from Wuhan and Hubei province, according to the German foreign ministry. Although none of the people on the passenger list appear to be infected, they will spend two weeks in quarantine once they arrive in Germany.</p>, <h2 class="css-3ez4hu eoo0vm40" id="link-4a96f41c">In a twist, China to evacuate Wuhan residents from foreign countries.</h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">As foreign governments evacuated their citizens from China this week, China said it was arranging chartered flights to bring Wuhan residents who were overseas back to the epicenter of the outbreak.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Citing the “practical difficulties recently encountered” by residents abroad, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs said in a statement on Friday that evacuations would begin as soon as possible.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Five million people from Wuhan left the city last week before travel restrictions were enforced. Unnerved by the exodus, some regional countries and territories have banned entry to people from Wuhan or Hubei province.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Travel restrictions across China and the suspension of international flights to the country have left Chinese travelers stranded around the world.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">But it was unclear if the Chinese government was also targeting those who had intentionally fled the center of the outbreak. It was similarly unknown where the residents had traveled.</p>, <h2 class="css-3ez4hu eoo0vm40" id="link-5efc4d3a">A mask heist occurs in Hong Kong amid a desperate shortage.</h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Someone stole 25,000 face masks from a warehouse in Hong Kong on Friday as the city, still haunted by memories of SARS, is struggling with a severe shortage.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The police said 500 boxes containing 50 masks each were reported missing from a building in an industrial neighborhood. The warehouse mostly supplied an e-commerce platform in the city, The Apple Daily newspaper reported.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The theft came as residents in Hong Kong desperately searched for the item, often displayed at inflated prices, in pharmacies and retailers. In a dangerous practice, families that cannot afford new disposable masks have resorted to reusing them, according to local reports.</p>, <p class="css-jwz2nf etfikam0">Reporting was contributed by Chris Buckley, Gerry Mullany, Elaine Yu, Li Yuan, E. Justin Swanson, Kate Conger, Miriam Jordan, Emma Bubola, Elisabetta Povoledo, Jason Horowitz, Geneva Abdul, Richard C. Paddock, Alex Marshall, Anton Troianovski, Joanna Berendt, Christopher Schuetze, Niraj Chokshi, Tariro Mzezewa, Mike Arnot, Denise Grady, Roni Caryn Rabin, Matt Phillips and Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs. Elsie Chen, Zoe Mou, Albee Zhang, Amber Wang, Yiwei Wang and Claire Fu contributed research.</p>, <p>Advertisement</p>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd" id="site-index-label">Site Index</h2>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-0">news</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-1">opinion</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-2">arts</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-3">living</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-4">more</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-subscribe-label">Subscribe</h3>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd">Site Information Navigation</h2>]
[<p>Advertisement</p>, <p>Supported by</p>, <h1 class="css-1s4ffep e1h9rw200" id="link-edd0c93" itemprop="headline"><span>European Economic Growth Slows Almost to Zero</span></h1>, <p class="css-1ifw933 e1wiw3jv0" id="article-summary">Unexpectedly bad data leaves Europe with little margin for error as Brexit takes effect and the coronavirus looms.</p>, <p class="css-1fv7b6t e1jsehar1" itemprop="author" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">By<!-- --> <a class="css-brehiz e1jsehar0" href="https://www.nytimes.com/by/jack-ewing"><span class="css-1baulvz last-byline" itemprop="name">Jack Ewing</span></a></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Friday was not a good day for Europe. As the European Union officially became smaller, <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/31/world/europe/brexit-britain-eu.html" title="">losing Britain</a> as a member, new data showed that economic growth in the bloc came almost to a standstill and that it is in danger of slipping into recession.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The 28 countries in the European Union grew only 0.1 percent during the last three months of 2019 compared with the previous quarter, according to <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://ec.europa.eu/eurostat/documents/2995521/10159272/2-31012020-BP-EN.pdf/435a608a-c9f9-9043-52a1-43ee8cb03d8f" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">official statistics</a>. The eurozone, the region that includes 19 of those countries that use the euro, grew by the same amount in that period.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">It was the European Union’s worst performance since the beginning of 2013, and leaves Europe with little margin for error as it braces for the <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/31/travel/travel-coronavirus-airlines.html" title="">economic impact of the coronavirus</a>. Compounding the problem: The <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/30/business/economy/gdp-numbers.html" title="">American economy</a> has also slowed, with growth at its lowest rate since 2016. The United States is Europe’s largest trading partner.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">A number of factors contributed to the unexpectedly bad growth figures, economists said. They include widespread strikes in France, political confusion in <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/26/world/europe/italy-election-Salvini.html" title="">Italy</a> and slumping world trade.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">But <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/31/world/europe/brexit-remainers.html" title="">Brexit hasn’t helped</a>. With the future terms of cross-channel trade still to be negotiated, some businesses may be hesitant to hire new workers or spend money on expansion.</p>, <h1 class="g-headline" id="g-inlineguide-headline">The Coronavirus Outbreak</h1>, <h2 class="g-inlineguide-list-header g-optimize-type">What do you need to know? Start here.</h2>, <p class="g-inlineguide-date">Updated Feb. 10, 2020</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“It is one of the uncertainties weighing on investment,” said Rosie Colthorpe, European economist at Oxford Economics in London. “It’s still quite uncertain what both sides want.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Growth at the end of the year was significantly slower than during previous quarters. The eurozone countries grew just 1.2 percent during 2019, according to a preliminary estimate by Eurostat, the European Union’s official statistics agency. The bloc as a whole, which includes countries that aren’t in the eurozone, like Sweden, Poland and Romania, grew 1.4 percent.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“The specter of recession is back,” Christoph Weil, an economist at Commerzbank in Frankfurt, said in a note to investors on Friday.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2020/world/asia/china-coronavirus-contain.html" title="">coronavirus is another big unknown</a>. China is a major customer for German cars and other European products. A slowdown in China would spill over to the eurozone. Europeans are also nervous that President Trump could follow through on threats to put punitive tariffs on cars manufactured there.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Output in Italy, Europe’s most troubled big economy, unexpectedly shrank 0.3 percent in the fourth quarter. For the full year, Italian growth was zero, signaling more of the stagnation that has plagued the country for more than a decade.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2019/world/europe/what-is-brexit.html" title="">Brexit</a> has already hurt trade between Britain and the rest of Europe.
