Germany missed out on about 16.2 billion euros, or $18 billion, in exports to Britain because of Brexit, according to the Ifo Institute for Economic Research in Munich, which measured how much more Germany would have sold to Britain if trade had remained as high as it was in 2015, before the Brexit referendum.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Some economists expressed optimism that the fourth quarter of 2019 was a low point and that European growth will begin to recover. Only a few months ago, Britain appeared to be headed for a disorderly exit from the European Union. That danger, at least, seems to be past.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">France, where the economy <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.insee.fr/en/statistiques/4300183" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">unexpectedly shrank 0.1 percent</a> in the fourth quarter, could bounce back now that the strikes that paralyzed transportation have largely ended.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Unemployment in the eurozone, at 7.4 percent in December, is at its lowest since before the financial crisis began in 2008, according to <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://ec.europa.eu/eurostat/documents/2995521/10159296/3-30012020-AP-EN.pdf/b9a98100-6917-c3ea-a544-ce288ac09675" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">figures released Thursday</a>. When people have jobs, they spend more money and contribute to growth.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“Our hope is that the fourth quarter marks the bottom,” Ms. Colthorpe of Oxford Economics said. “We are little bit positive about 2020. But with uncertainties about Brexit and so forth it’s not going to be a massive rebound.”</p>, <p>Advertisement</p>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd" id="site-index-label">Site Index</h2>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-0">news</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-1">opinion</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-2">arts</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-3">living</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-4">more</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-subscribe-label">Subscribe</h3>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd">Site Information Navigation</h2>]
[<p>Advertisement</p>, <p>Supported by</p>, <h1 class="css-1s4ffep e1h9rw200" id="link-702db4d0" itemprop="headline"><span>Trump Administration Restricts Entry Into U.S. From China</span></h1>, <p class="css-1ifw933 e1wiw3jv0" id="article-summary">The travel disruption sent shocks through the stock market and rattled industries that depend on the flow of goods and people between the world’s two largest economies.</p>, <p class="css-1fv7b6t e1jsehar1" itemprop="author" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">By<!-- --> <a class="css-brehiz e1jsehar0" href="https://www.nytimes.com/by/michael-corkery"><span class="css-1baulvz" itemprop="name">Michael Corkery</span></a> and <a class="css-brehiz e1jsehar0" href="https://www.nytimes.com/by/annie-karni"><span class="css-1baulvz last-byline" itemprop="name">Annie Karni</span></a></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/02/02/world/asia/china-coronavirus.html" title=""><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">Read about the latest developments in the coronavirus outbreak here</em></a><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">.</em></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Moving to counter the spreading <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/02/10/business/china-coronavirus-philippines-travel.html" title="">coronavirus</a> outbreak, the Trump administration said Friday that it would bar entry by most foreign nationals who had recently visited China and put some American <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/02/10/business/china-coronavirus-philippines-travel.html" title="">travelers</a> under a quarantine as it declared a rare public health emergency.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The temporary restrictions followed announcements by American Airlines, Delta Air Lines and United Airlines that they would suspend air service between the United States and China for several months.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/02/10/business/china-coronavirus-philippines-travel.html" title="">travel</a> disruption sent shocks through the stock market and rattled industries that depend on the flow of goods and people between the world’s two largest economies. Planning was upended for companies across a vast global supply chain, from Apple to John Deere, the tractor company.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The S&amp;P 500 suffered its worst loss since October, falling 1.8 percent, as the spread of the virus — and the increasingly urgent efforts by companies and governments to contain it — fanned fears of an economic slowdown.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The government travel restrictions, which will take effect on Sunday evening, were announced by Alex Azar, the secretary of health and human services, who declared that the coronavirus posed “a public health emergency in the United States.”</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The administration’s action will restrict all foreign nationals who have been to China in the past 14 days from entering the United States. The restriction does not include immediate family members of American citizens and permanent residents. Nearly three million Chinese residents traveled to the United States in 2018, according to <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://travel.trade.gov/view/m-2017-I-001/index.asp" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">federal data based on travel records</a>.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The travel restrictions and the airline’s announcements showed how rapidly concerns about the virus have escalated into a grave test of the global economy, for which there is no recent precedent. Three weeks after the first virus-related death was reported, China has found itself increasingly cut off from its biggest trading partner, the United States, and many other nations.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Chinese officials said on Saturday that there had been an additional 46 deaths in the country, the most so far in a 24-hour period, raising the death toll to 259. It said confirmed infections had grown to nearly 12,000, from 1,300 a week earlier.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">About 100 cases have been <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/02/01/nyregion/coronavirus-new-york-city.html" title="">confirmed across 21 other countries</a>, including seven reported cases in the United States. Russia, Italy and Britain each reported their first infections on Friday, two from each country. The four patients in Italy and Russia were Chinese citizens, the authorities there said; Britain did not release any details.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">To address the outbreak, China has extended the Lunar New Year holiday, which was to have ended Thursday, into next week. In cities across the country, <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/25/world/asia/china-wuhan-coronavirus.html?searchResultPosition=2" title="">including those far from the center of the outbreak</a>, there were eerie scenes Friday of all-but-empty streets and highways, closed shops, trains without passengers and nearly deserted public spaces that are normally packed.</p>, <h1 class="g-headline" id="g-inlineguide-headline">The Coronavirus Outbreak</h1>, <h2 class="g-inlineguide-list-header g-optimize-type">What do you need to know? Start here.</h2>, <p class="g-inlineguide-date">Updated Feb. 10, 2020</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The slowdown in activity has raised fears that essential supplies, including food, will run short, which the government insists it will not allow to happen.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">And it is unclear when China’s economic engine — a huge producer of both consumer goods and industrial components — might return to anything resembling normal.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Many companies said they were relatively well positioned for the disruption, thanks in part to the recent easing of the trade tensions between China and the United States. Faced with the threat of tariffs, many companies — particularly retailers — had stocked up on imports from China, or found suppliers in other parts of Asia.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">But if the restrictions in China are kept in place for many months and the virus keeps spreading, profits will suffer.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Forsake, a footwear company based in Boston, has most of its supply chain and production facility in Zhongshan in southeastern China. The company received its spring orders before the annual holiday closing and is stocked through July. After that, said Sam Barstow, the president and chief operating officer, who knows?</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“We don’t really know what we’re planning for,” Mr. Barstow said.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Tim Cook, Apple’s chief executive, said on an earnings call this week that many of its suppliers’ factories in China would remain closed until Feb. 10.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Apple had closed one retail store in China, and said traffic into its stores across China had decreased in recent days. Apple is frequently “deep cleaning” its stores and regularly checking the temperature of its employees there, Mr. Cook said.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The airlines are also braced for prolonged turmoil. American said all of its flights between the United States and mainland China were being suspended immediately, through March 27.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">United and Delta said their flights on those routes would be suspended by next Thursday. United said it expected to resume operations on March 28, while Delta said its suspension would last through April 30. The three airlines accounted for more than a third of all travel between China and the United States in 2018.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">In 2018, more than 8.5 million passengers traveled between the United States and China, according to data from the United States Transportation Department. Most flew on a handful of Chinese airlines, none of which immediately responded to requests for comment Friday on any plans to halt or modify service.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The coronavirus has already sickened more people than the outbreak of the SARS virus did in the eight-month outbreak of 2002 and 2003.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The SARS outbreak coincided with a relatively brief slowdown of global growth in early 2003, which was followed by a sharp rebound.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">SARS, however, is an imperfect comparison because at the time China represented just 5 percent of the global economy. In 2019, China accounted for about 18 percent, according to JPMorgan Chase economists.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“The much larger role of China in the global economy versus 2003 implies much greater global spillover risks,” the bank wrote in a research note on Friday.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">On Wednesday, the JPMorgan Chase economists cut their forecast for Chinese economic growth sharply for the first quarter to incorporate the impact of the virus. They now expect that the Chinese economy will grow at an annualized rate of 4.9 percent in the first quarter, down from the 6.3 percent pace they previously predicted.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The new forecasts reflect the expectation of sharp decelerations in retail sales, industrial production and business investment. But the forecast also calls for a strong rebound in economic activity in the second quarter, as the impact of the outbreak dissipates.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Concerns about global growth have pushed the benchmark American oil price below $52 a barrel, from more than $60 at the start of the year, and have sent the shares of energy companies lower. Tech stocks have also suffered, with particular weakness in the semiconductor sector, which is closely linked to supply chains based in and around China.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">On Thursday, the State Department raised its <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/30/world/asia/Coronavirus-travel-advisory-.html" title="">travel advisory</a> to Level 4 — “Do not travel” — a rating reserved for situations in which the government expects to have very limited ability to help citizens abroad. The World Health Organization declared a global health emergency because of the spreading virus, though it opposed restrictions on travel or trade with China.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Mr. Azar, the United States health secretary, and other members of a Trump administration task force emphasized on Friday that the current risk to the American public from the coronavirus was low.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">But the drastic travel restriction suggested that the risks in the United States could grow quickly and unpredictably.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Dr. Anthony S. Fauci, the director of the National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases, said at a Washington briefing that the actions were being taken because there were “a lot of unknowns” surrounding the virus and its transmission path. Unlike influenza, which is fairly predictable in terms of infection and mortality, Dr. Fauci said there was not the same certainty about the rate and path of the coronavirus transmission.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“The number of cases have steeply inclined with every day,” Dr. Fauci said.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">In addition to the restrictions on foreign nationals traveling from China, the United States will begin funneling all flights from China to just a few airports, including Kennedy International in New York, O’Hare in Chicago and San Francisco International.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Officials said any American citizen returning to the United States from the Hubei Province in China, where the outbreak is centered, would be subject to up to 14 days of mandatory quarantine. Any American returning to the country who has visited the rest of mainland China within the last 14 days will undergo proactive health screening at selective ports of entry.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The government also <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/31/health/quarantine-coronavirus.html" title="">imposed a two-week quarantine</a> on 195 people who were evacuated on Wednesday from Wuhan, China, to a California military base.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Some public health and policy experts said the restrictions announced Friday, weeks after the virus was discovered in China, might not do as much officials hoped in containing the contagion.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">At this point, sharply curtailing air travel to and from China is more of an emotional or political reaction, said Dr. Michael T. Osterholm, an epidemiologist and director of the Center for Infectious Disease Research and Policy at the University of Minnesota.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“The cow’s already out of the barn,” he said, ”and we’re now talking about shutting the barn door.”</p>, <p class="css-jwz2nf etfikam0">Reporting was contributed by Matt Phillips, Patricia Cohen, Niraj Chokshi, Jack Nicas, Knvul Sheikh, Russell Goldman, Chris Buckley, Elaine Yu, Richard C. Paddock, Richard Perez-Peña, Elisabetta Povoledo and Jason Horowitz.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"></p>, <p>Advertisement</p>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd" id="site-index-label">Site Index</h2>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-0">news</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-1">opinion</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-2">arts</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-3">living</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-4">more</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-subscribe-label">Subscribe</h3>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd">Site Information Navigation</h2>]
[<p>Advertisement</p>, <p>Supported by</p>, <h1 class="css-1s4ffep e1h9rw200" id="link-356d0466" itemprop="headline"><span>The Week in Tech: London Hands Washington a Loss on Huawei</span></h1>, <p class="css-1ifw933 e1wiw3jv0" id="article-summary">The White House couldn’t persuade Boris Johnson to keep Huawei out of Britain’s 5G network.</p>, <p class="css-1fv7b6t e1jsehar1" itemprop="author" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">By<!-- --> <span class="css-1baulvz last-byline" itemprop="name">David McCabe</span></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">Each week, we review </em><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/section/technology?module=inline" title=""><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">the week’s news</em></a><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">, offering analysis about the most important developments in the tech industry.</em></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Hi, this is David McCabe. I report on tech policy from The Times’s bureau in Washington. But this past week, one of the biggest stories began with an announcement an ocean away.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">For weeks, we had been waiting to see whether Prime Minister Boris Johnson would allow Huawei equipment to be used in Britain’s 5G wireless network or follow American officials in shutting the company out. The United States has said for years that the company’s networking gear could give the Chinese government access to key infrastructure.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">On Tuesday, Mr. Johnson <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/28/technology/britain-huawei-5G.html" title="">revealed his decision</a>: Huawei is in. The company’s equipment can be used in a portion of the 5G, or fifth-generation, network.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">This is a big setback for the Trump administration’s global anti-Huawei push. The White House had sent top officials to London to try to sway Mr. Johnson, a close ally. Shortly after the British announcement, the European Union <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/29/world/europe/eu-huawei-5g.html" title="">told its members</a> to limit but not totally eliminate Huawei’s role in their network.</p>, <h1 class="g-headline" id="g-inlineguide-headline">The Coronavirus Outbreak</h1>, <h2 class="g-inlineguide-list-header g-optimize-type">What do you need to know? Start here.</h2>, <p class="g-inlineguide-date">Updated Feb. 5, 2020</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">I messaged Adam Satariano, who covers tech in Europe from The Times’s London bureau, to find out more about the fallout from Mr. Johnson’s choice.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Why did Boris Johnson make the decision to allow Huawei to stay involved in building Britain’s 5G network, despite all the pressure he was under from the Trump administration?</strong></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">There are a few key reasons. First, a practical one. Huawei has been part of the British telecom network for years. 5G will be built on top of that existing system. To implement a ban now would be extraordinarily costly and delay the rollout of the faster network because a lot of that old kit would have to be ripped out.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Second, British intelligence and cybersecurity officials believe the risks of Huawei can be mitigated. As part of allowing Huawei to be part of its network, British officials years ago required the company to subject its products and code to tests. There’s a lab near Cambridge where this is done. For British officials, this gives them a level of confidence that the problem can be managed. Of course, American officials think this is wishful thinking. With 5G, software plays a much bigger role, meaning it will be harder to keep harmful code from slipping through.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Finally, as Britain exits the European Union, it can’t afford to alienate China, which is a big investor in the country and a growing buyer of British exports. From an economic standpoint, it would be a big risk. Britain also sees 5G as a key to the country’s economic future, and any delays could put it at a disadvantage to other countries.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Here in Washington, Mr. Johnson’s decision set off a paroxysm of concerned statements from the administration and hawkish members of Congress. What has the reaction been like in Britain?</strong></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">I think it was expected. The statement from the White House was actually quite mild. Secretary of State Mike Pompeo still went forward with a trip to Britain during the week. Perhaps harsher words were shared behind closed doors.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">This Huawei decision is also just one example of a split between how tech is regulated in the United States and in Britain. What’s the future of the special relationship when it comes to tech?</strong></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Complicated. Like many countries in Europe, Britain is very frustrated with Big Tech. It doesn’t think the companies pay their fair share in taxes. And with Facebook and Google/YouTube, not enough is done to limit the spread of harmful content. Attempts to address taxes and harmful content will gain momentum this year, potentially setting up more tension with the United States.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">It’s late in London, so I’ve got just one more: You cover all of Europe, not just Britain. Where does the American campaign to keep Huawei out of 5G networks go next?</strong></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Germany is another country where the United States has been applying a lot of pressure. But as our colleagues Katrin Bennhold and Jack Ewing <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/16/world/europe/huawei-germany-china-5g-automakers.html" title="">recently reported</a>, it also faces a tough decision. China has threatened to retaliate if Huawei is banned. That is not an insignificant threat for Germany, which sells a lot of BMWs and VWs to China. Chancellor Angela Merkel has signaled she doesn’t want a ban, but she is facing pressure from others in government who want to take a more aggressive approach.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">It’s a fascinating issue, touching on tech, trade, politics, foreign policy and national security.</p>, <h2 class="css-3ez4hu eoo0vm40" id="link-372a3def">How tech is shaping the coronavirus story</h2>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Three stories during the week underscored how the news around the coronavirus that originated in Wuhan, China — and the way the public has responded — is being mediated by online platforms.</p>, <p class="css-15hwz5e evys1bk0">The Times’s Raymond Zhong <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/27/technology/china-coronavirus-censorship-social-media.html" title="">reported</a> from Shanghai on the way that anger over the Chinese government’s handling of the outbreak has boiled over on social media.</p>, <p class="css-15hwz5e evys1bk0">Not surprisingly, the virus has also been the subject of online disinformation. BuzzFeed News’s Jane Lytvynenko <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.buzzfeednews.com/article/janelytvynenko/coronavirus-disinformation-spread" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">had a good roundup</a>, including posts with false statements about how many people are affected and the authorities’ response.</p>, <p class="css-15hwz5e evys1bk0">But in The Atlantic, Alexis Madrigal <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.theatlantic.com/technology/archive/2020/01/china-coronavirus-twitter/605644/" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">noted</a> that it was important to remember that while “out-and-out conspiracies and hoaxes will draw some attention, it’s really the stuff that’s close to the boundaries of discourse that grabs the most eyeballs.”</p>, <h2 class="css-3ez4hu eoo0vm40" id="link-1cca7f28">Some stories you shouldn’t miss</h2>, <p class="css-15hwz5e evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Workers in Amazon or Walmart </strong>warehouses often sort through bins of random objects, looking for the right one to send off for packaging and delivery to consumers. Now, the robots are catching up, <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/29/technology/warehouse-robot.html" title="">Adam Satariano and Cade Metz reported</a>.</p>, <p class="css-15hwz5e evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Eduardo Porter </strong><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10"><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/27/business/economy/portland-maine-economy.html" title="">filed an article</a></strong> from Portland, Maine, where local officials and a wealthy donor are hoping to build out a greater tech presence.</p>, <p class="css-15hwz5e evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Facebook reported </strong>its <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/29/technology/facebooks-earnings.html" title="">lowest quarterly growth ever</a>.</p>, <p class="css-15hwz5e evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Lyft </strong><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10"><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/29/technology/lyft-layoffs-restructuring.html" title="">is restructuring</a></strong> and will lay off about 90 employees.</p>, <p class="css-15hwz5e evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Apple’s </strong><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10"><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/28/technology/apple-iphone-sales-earnings.html" title="">profit grew</a></strong> 11.4 percent to $22.3 billion, thanks to stronger iPhone, wearable and services revenue.</p>, <h3 class="css-1ldy5g8 e1gnsphs0" id="link-678e087d">How are we doing?</h3>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">We’d love your feedback on this newsletter. Please email thoughts and suggestions to <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="mailto:bits_newsletter@nytimes.com" title="">bits_newsletter@nytimes.com</a>.</p>, <h3 class="css-1ldy5g8 e1gnsphs0" id="link-5ca86465">Like this email?</h3>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Forward it to your friends, and let them know they can sign up <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="http://www.nytimes.com/newsletters/bits?te=1&amp;nl=bits&amp;emc=edit_tu_20190620" title="">here</a>.</p>, <p>Advertisement</p>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd" id="site-index-label">Site Index</h2>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-0">news</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-1">opinion</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-2">arts</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-3">living</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-4">more</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-subscribe-label">Subscribe</h3>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd">Site Information Navigation</h2>]
[<p>Advertisement</p>, <p>Supported by</p>, <p class="css-tsacue e6idgb70">letters</p>, <h1 class="css-1qskr30 e1h9rw200" id="link-c2502d1" itemprop="headline"><span>As Fears of Wuhan’s Coronavirus Spread</span></h1>, <p class="css-1ifw933 e1wiw3jv0" id="article-summary">Readers say Americans should be more concerned about the flu and that the U.S. is not well equipped to handle a public health disaster.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">To the Editor:</strong></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Re “<a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/29/health/coronavirus-masks-hoarding.html" title="">Mask Hoarders May Raise the Risk of the Virus Spreading in the U.S.</a>” (news article, Jan. 30):</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Your coverage of coronavirus reflects a real concern as well as an overreaction in the West to this outbreak. When I walk through our Phoenix hospital’s emergency department, I’m reminded of the global outbreak we really should be worried about: influenza.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">We are at a high point in the flu season, with <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.contagionlive.com/news/us-flu-cases-climb-to-15-million-with-54-pediatric-deaths-recorded-in-201920-season" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">15 million cases</a>, 140,000 hospitalizations, and 8,200 deaths in the United States alone, according to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. Every day dozens of people with flu symptoms come through our emergency department.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Coronavirus is a serious disease, and we must be vigilant in monitoring its spread while working to find solutions. But at this writing, there have been only a handful of confirmed cases of the coronavirus in this country, mostly in recent travelers to Wuhan, China. Rather than rushing out to buy masks and fretting over the unlikely chance of contracting the coronavirus, Americans should get their flu shots, and wash their hands often to avoid the flu.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Michael D. White<br/>Phoenix<br/><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">The writer is chief medical officer at Valleywise Health.</em></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">To the Editor:</strong></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">While it is far too early to make concrete predictions about the lethality of the coronavirus that is now spreading around the globe, the media has overlooked one critical risk factor that is present in China: <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://grist.org/cities/chinas-smog-city-what-wuhan-looks-like-with-20-times-the-u-s-dust-limit/" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">high levels of PM 2.5 </a>in the air. PM 2.5 refers to particles of pollution that are small enough to pass through the lung and enter the bloodstream, causing damage to the immune system as well as other organ systems, such as the lungs.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Thus far, it appears that the virus produces a severe infection primarily in those with weakened lungs and immune systems, such as the elderly, diabetics and smokers. One important consideration is that the citizens of Wuhan are exposed to unusually high levels of PM 2.5, typically 20 times the current “acceptable” limit set by the Environmental Protection Agency. The virus is likely to be less lethal in less polluted areas of the world.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">As the Environmental Protection Agency relaxes air quality standards, we should be mindful of the broad benefits of a breath of fresh air.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Peter Muennig<br/>New York<br/><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">The writer is a professor of health policy and management at Mailman School of Public Health, Columbia University.</em></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">To the Editor:</strong></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Re “<a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/27/world/asia/27china-coronavirus-health.html" title="">Feeble Health System in China Strains to Combat Deadly Virus</a>” (front page, Jan. 28):</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Your article describing the Chinese health system as being “feeble” in its ability to deal with the coronavirus epidemic in Wuhan depicts an overwhelmed medical infrastructure in China. Sadly, in the event of a pandemic, our hospitals would be similarly overwhelmed.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">After the anthrax scare in 2001, my hospital held a medical staff meeting to review emergency procedures if there were an outbreak in Philadelphia. It was sobering to hear how few excess intensive care unit beds and even hospital beds were available in our city for an outbreak of anthrax due to bioterrorism.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Apparently, in the event of a public health disaster, the supply of antibiotics available to a large city is limited to a few days. We were told that all vacant hospital beds would be filled in days, and patients would be boarded in the hallways. Also, excess ventilator capacity was fairly limited, and that in short order, no ventilators would be available to support critically ill patients.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">At the time of 2009 H1N1 flu pandemic, we had a similar sobering review of our capacity to handle a widespread outbreak. In summary, I don’t know that cities in the United States would do much better than Wuhan.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Bernard A. Mason<br/>Philadelphia</p>, <p>Advertisement</p>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd" id="site-index-label">Site Index</h2>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-0">news</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-1">opinion</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-2">arts</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-3">living</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-4">more</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-subscribe-label">Subscribe</h3>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd">Site Information Navigation</h2>]
[<p>Advertisement</p>, <p>Supported by</p>, <p class="css-c2jxua e6idgb70"></p>, <h1 class="css-1j5ig2m e1h9rw200" id="link-708da2d9" itemprop="headline"><span>Germany Identifies Fifth Case of Coronavirus</span></h1>, <p class="css-1fv7b6t e1jsehar1" itemprop="author" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">By<!-- --> <span class="css-1baulvz last-byline" itemprop="name">Reuters</span></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">BERLIN — German health officials said on Thursday they had identified the country's fifth case of the coronavirus in an employee working at the same firm as the other four infected individuals in the southern state of Bavaria.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">"This concerns an employee at the company in Starnberg at which the other four known cases work," said Bavaria's health ministry in a statement, adding further details would be made available on Friday.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"> (Reporting by Madeline Chambers; Editing by Chris Reese)</p>, <p>Advertisement</p>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd" id="site-index-label">Site Index</h2>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-0">news</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-1">opinion</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-2">arts</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-3">living</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-4">more</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-subscribe-label">Subscribe</h3>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd">Site Information Navigation</h2>]
[<p>Advertisement</p>, <p>Supported by</p>, <p class="css-c2jxua e6idgb70"></p>, <h1 class="css-1j5ig2m e1h9rw200" id="link-265f1f01" itemprop="headline"><span>Latest on the Coronavirus Spreading in China and Beyond</span></h1>, <p class="css-1fv7b6t e1jsehar1" itemprop="author" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">By<!-- --> <span class="css-1baulvz last-byline" itemprop="name">Reuters</span></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">(Reuters) - A coronavirus outbreak that began in Wuhan, the capital of China's central province of Hubei, has spread to more than 9,800 people globally, surpassing the total from the 2002-2003 SARS epidemic. The new virus has killed 213 people.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Here is what we know:</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"> * There are 131 confirmed cases in 23 countries and regionsoutside mainland China, including Australia, Britain, France,Germany, Hong Kong, Japan, Thailand and the United States. * No deaths have been reported outside China. * The World Health Organization declared the outbreak apublic health emergency of international concern on Thursday. * The United States reported its first case ofperson-to-person transmission. Germany, Japan, Thailand, Vietnamand South Korea have also recorded similar transmissions, whichsuggest greater potential for the virus to spread. * Several Chinese cities have levied strict travel curbs. * The U.S. State Department told Americans not to travel toChina. * Japan advised its citizens to put off non-urgent travel toChina and brought forward special measures to stem the spread ofthe coronavirus. * Global airlines have suspended or scaled back directflights to China's major cities. * Countries including Australia, Canada, France, Germany,Indonesia, Italy, Japan, Singapore, South Korea and the UnitedStates are working to evacuate citizens from Wuhan or havealready started. * A charter flight carrying 368 South Koreans from Wuhanlanded in Seoul. The evacuees were taken to quarantine centers. * A plane carrying 83 British and 27 other foreign nationalsleft Wuhan, the British government said. * Authorities in Myanmar turned back a China Southern flightfrom Guangzhou with almost everyone on board after one of thepassengers was found with flu symptoms similar to thecoronavirus, a government spokesman said. * Hong Kong leader Carrie Lam rejected calls from a medicalunion to close the border with mainland China to contain thespread of the coronavirus. * China's aviation authority sent two flights to bring backits tourists stranded in Thailand and Malaysia. * China will release winter and spring vegetable reserves inmajor northern cities to ease supply shortages amid the newcoronavirus outbreak, state news agency Xinhua reported. * The Chinese Football Association said it would postponedomestic games in 2020. * The World Athletics Indoor Championships scheduled in theChinese city of Nanjing in March have been postponed until 2021. * The coronavirus should have little impact on the U.S.economy, President Donald Trump's chief economic adviser said. * China's capital Beijing said that companies in theprovince will postpone reopening until Feb. 10 in order to helpprevent the spread of a new coronavirus, government newspaperBeijing Daily reported. * Some experts believe the virus is not as dangerous as the2002-03 Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome (SARS) that killednearly 800 people, or the Middle East Respiratory Syndrome(MERS), which has killed more than 700 people since 2012. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"> (Compiled by Stephen Coates, Editing by Bill Berkrot, Christopher Cushing and Timothy Heritage)</p>, <p>Advertisement</p>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd" id="site-index-label">Site Index</h2>, <h3 [<p>Advertisement</p>, <p>Supported by</p>, <p class="css-c2jxua e6idgb70"></p>, <h1 class="css-1j5ig2m e1h9rw200" id="link-573cfb11" itemprop="headline"><span>France Confirms Sixth Case of Infection With Coronavirus</span></h1>, <p class="css-1fv7b6t e1jsehar1" itemprop="author" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">By<!-- --> <span class="css-1baulvz last-byline" itemprop="name">Reuters</span></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">PARIS — France has confirmed a sixth case of infection by the new coronavirus from China, a French health official said on Thursday.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">France confirmed its first three cases of the Wuhan coronavirus on Friday, a fourth case on Tuesday and a fifth case on Wednesday.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"> (Reporting by Benoit Van Overstraeten; Editing by Chris Reese)</p>, <p>Advertisement</p>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd" id="site-index-label">Site Index</h2>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-0">news</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-1">opinion</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-2">arts</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-3">living</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-4">more</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-subscribe-label">Subscribe</h3>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd">Site Information Navigation</h2>]
[<p>Advertisement</p>, <p>Supported by</p>, <p class="css-c2jxua e6idgb70"></p>, <h1 class="css-1j5ig2m e1h9rw200" id="link-619b0e42" itemprop="headline"><span>Coronavirus Causes Slump in Chinese Travel: Study</span></h1>, <p class="css-1fv7b6t e1jsehar1" itemprop="author" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">By<!-- --> <span class="css-1baulvz last-byline" itemprop="name">Reuters</span></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">LONDON — The coronavirus outbreak in China caused a slump in outbound travel from China around its New Year period, data from travel analytic firm ForwardKeys showed on Thursday, a setback from what would otherwise have been a record year.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">ForwardKeys data showed that up to Jan 19, outbound travel bookings were 7.3% ahead compared to the equivalent period of last year, but a week later, they were 6.8% behind after travel restrictions were introduced.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Bookings to China have also suffered, dropping from being 4.5% ahead to 7.2% behind the previous year over the same time period.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Deaths from the virus have risen to 170 and markets have shuddered at the impact of an inevitable big hit to the world's No. 2 economy. Travel stands to be a key sector impacted by the outbreak, with British Airways suspending all of its flights to mainland China for a month.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">ForwardKeys said the travel impact might have been greater if it the outbreak had happened earlier, as many travelers had already left for Chinese New Year celebrations.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">"Fortunately, most Chinese holidaymakers managed to get away in time and as of now, we don’t see the collapse in travel to China spreading to other countries in the region," Olivier Ponti, Vice President Insights at ForwardKeys, said.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">"However, with the crisis evolving rapidly from day to day and a growing number of airlines cancelling flights to China, close monitoring is needed."</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"> (Reporting by Alistair Smout and Laurence Frost, Editing by William Maclean)</p>, <p>Advertisement</p>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd" id="site-index-label">Site Index</h2>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-0">news</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-1">opinion</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-2">arts</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-3">living</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-4">more</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-subscribe-label">Subscribe</h3>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd">Site Information Navigation</h2>]
[<p>Advertisement</p>, <p>Supported by</p>, <p class="css-c2jxua e6idgb70"></p>, <h1 class="css-1j5ig2m e1h9rw200" id="link-1ac41c7c" itemprop="headline"><span>What Do We Know About the New Coronavirus?</span></h1>, <p class="css-1fv7b6t e1jsehar1" itemprop="author" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">By<!-- --> <span class="css-1baulvz last-byline" itemprop="name">Reuters</span></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">(Reuters) - A new coronavirus that has killed 170 people in China is spreading to other countries, alarming health experts.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Here is some of what we know - and don't know - about the virus:</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">WHERE DID THE VIRUS COME FROM?</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The virus is believed to have originated late last year in a food market in the Chinese city of Wuhan that was illegally selling wildlife. Health experts think it may have originated in bats and then passed to humans, possibly via another animal species.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The World Health Organization (WHO) was alerted to several cases of pneumonia in Wuhan at the end of December. Chinese authorities confirmed they had identified a new virus a week later.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">HOW DANGEROUS IS IT?</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The new virus, identified by scientists as 2019-nCoV, is a coronavirus, a family of viruses that include the common cold and more serious diseases such as Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome (SARS).</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Coronavirus infections have a wide range of symptoms, including fever, cough, shortness of breath, and breathing difficulties.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">It is unclear how deadly the new virus is. Although severe cases can cause pneumonia and death, there may be many cases of milder disease going undetected. Many of those who have died had pre-existing medical conditions or were elderly, those with weakened immune systems.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">HOW IS IT TRANSMITTED AND HOW CAN IT BE PREVENTED?</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The new coronavirus can be transmitted from person to person, although it is not clear how easily that happens. Most cases so far are in people who have been in Wuhan, family members of those infected, or medical workers.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Transmission is most likely through close contact with an infected person via particles in the air from coughing or sneezing, or by someone touching an infected person or object with the virus on it and then touching their mouth, nose or eyes.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">In order to reduce the likelihood of transmission, the WHO recommends that people frequently wash their hands, cover their mouth and nose when sneezing or coughing, and avoid close contact with those who are sick.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention says those who develop symptoms such as coughing and fever who have been in China in the last 14 days should call ahead to a healthcare professional to establish if they need to be tested.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">WHERE HAS IT SPREAD TO SO FAR?</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The vast majority of the more than 8,000 cases so far identified have been in China, mostly in and around Wuhan. The other countries with confirmed cases include Australia, Cambodia, Canada, France, Germany, Japan, Malaysia, Nepal, Sri Lanka, Singapore, Thailand, South Korea, the UAE, the United States, and Vietnam.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The WHO is looking very closely at cases of person-to-person transmission outside of Wuhan, which would suggest that it may have the potential to spread further.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">WHAT ARE AUTHORITIES DOING?</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The Chinese government has put Wuhan into virtual quarantine to try to stop the spread of the virus. A number of foreign governments have advised against non-essential travel to China and have begun flying their citizens out of Wuhan.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">IS THIS LIKE SARS?</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The new virus is a strain of coronavirus, like SARS, which killed nearly 800 people globally in 2002 and 2003.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Unlike SARS, which also originated in China, it is believed the new virus can spread during the incubation period of one to14 days, possibly before an infected person is showing symptoms.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">So far, the new virus does not appear to be as deadly as SARS, but there have been more cases overall.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"> (Compiled by Alex Richardson and Rosalba O'Brien; Edited by Bill Berkrot)</p>, <p>Advertisement</p>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd" id="site-index-label">Site Index</h2>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-0">news</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-1">opinion</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-2">arts</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-3">living</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-4">more</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-subscribe-label">Subscribe</h3>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd">Site Information Navigation</h2>]
[<p>Advertisement</p>, <p>Supported by</p>, <p class="css-c2jxua e6idgb70"></p>, <h1 class="css-1j5ig2m e1h9rw200" id="link-1ac41c7c" itemprop="headline"><span>What Do We Know About the New Coronavirus?</span></h1>, <p class="css-1fv7b6t e1jsehar1" itemprop="author" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">By<!-- --> <span class="css-1baulvz last-byline" itemprop="name">Reuters</span></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">(Reuters) - A new coronavirus that has killed 170 people in China is spreading to other countries, alarming health experts.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Here is some of what we know - and don't know - about the virus:</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">WHERE DID THE VIRUS COME FROM?</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The virus is believed to have originated late last year in a food market in the Chinese city of Wuhan that was illegally selling wildlife. Health experts think it may have originated in bats and then passed to humans, possibly via another animal species.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The World Health Organization (WHO) was alerted to several cases of pneumonia in Wuhan at the end of December. Chinese authorities confirmed they had identified a new virus a week later.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">HOW DANGEROUS IS IT?</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The new virus, identified by scientists as 2019-nCoV, is a coronavirus, a family of viruses that include the common cold and more serious diseases such as Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome (SARS).</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Coronavirus infections have a wide range of symptoms, including fever, cough, shortness of breath, and breathing difficulties.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">It is unclear how deadly the new virus is. Although severe cases can cause pneumonia and death, there may be many cases of milder disease going undetected. Many of those who have died had pre-existing medical conditions or were elderly, those with weakened immune systems.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">HOW IS IT TRANSMITTED AND HOW CAN IT BE PREVENTED?</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The new coronavirus can be transmitted from person to person, although it is not clear how easily that happens. Most cases so far are in people who have been in Wuhan, family members of those infected, or medical workers.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Transmission is most likely through close contact with an infected person via particles in the air from coughing or sneezing, or by someone touching an infected person or object with the virus on it and then touching their mouth, nose or eyes.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">In order to reduce the likelihood of transmission, the WHO recommends that people frequently wash their hands, cover their mouth and nose when sneezing or coughing, and avoid close contact with those who are sick.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention says those who develop symptoms such as coughing and fever who have been in China in the last 14 days should call ahead to a healthcare professional to establish if they need to be tested.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">WHERE HAS IT SPREAD TO SO FAR?</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The vast majority of the more than 8,000 cases so far identified have been in China, mostly in and around Wuhan. The other countries with confirmed cases include Australia, Cambodia, Canada, France, Germany, Japan, Malaysia, Nepal, Sri Lanka, Singapore, Thailand, South Korea, the UAE, the United States, and Vietnam.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The WHO is looking very closely at cases of person-to-person transmission outside of Wuhan, which would suggest that it may have the potential to spread further.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">WHAT ARE AUTHORITIES DOING?</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The Chinese government has put Wuhan into virtual quarantine to try to stop the spread of the virus. A number of foreign governments have advised against non-essential travel to China and have begun flying their citizens out of Wuhan.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">IS THIS LIKE SARS?</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The new virus is a strain of coronavirus, like SARS, which killed nearly 800 people globally in 2002 and 2003.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Unlike SARS, which also originated in China, it is believed the new virus can spread during the incubation period of one to14 days, possibly before an infected person is showing symptoms.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">So far, the new virus does not appear to be as deadly as SARS, but there have been more cases overall.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"> (Compiled by Alex Richardson and Rosalba O'Brien; Edited by Bill Berkrot)</p>, <p>Advertisement</p>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd" id="site-index-label">Site Index</h2>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-0">news</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-1">opinion</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-2">arts</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-3">living</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-4">more</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-subscribe-label">Subscribe</h3>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd">Site Information Navigation</h2>]
[<p>Advertisement</p>, <p>Supported by</p>, <p class="css-c2jxua e6idgb70"></p>, <h1 class="css-1j5ig2m e1h9rw200" id="link-3e546be" itemprop="headline"><span>Healthcare Company Novacyt Launches New Coronavirus Test</span></h1>, <p class="css-1fv7b6t e1jsehar1" itemprop="author" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">By<!-- --> <span class="css-1baulvz last-byline" itemprop="name">Reuters</span></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">PARIS — Healthcare company Novacyt said on Friday it had launched a new molecular test for the coronavirus currently afflicting China and other parts of the world.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The company said its Primerdesign coronavirus test could detect the 2019 strain of the virus, adding it believed this would differentiate it from other current tests which it said were less specific.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">"Over the last few days, we have seen significant early demand for our 'genesig® 2019-nCoV' test from over 10 countries," CEO Graham Mullis said in a statement.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">"We believe our assay is the first European test to be made available and will be introduced this weekend at the Medlab Expo in the Middle East," added Mullis.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">More than 200 people have been killed by the virus, with some 9,820 people infected around the world.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The virus is believed to have originated in a food market illegally selling wildlife in Wuhan. About 60 million people in Hubei province are living under virtual lockdown.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"> (Reporting by Sudip Kar-Gupta; editing by Jason Neely and David Evans)</p>, <p>Advertisement</p>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd" id="site-index-label">Site Index</h2>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-0">news</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-1">opinion</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-2">arts</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-3">living</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-4">more</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-subscribe-label">Subscribe</h3>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd">Site Information Navigation</h2>]
[<p>Advertisement</p>, <p>Supported by</p>, <p class="css-c2jxua e6idgb70"></p>, <h1 class="css-1j5ig2m e1h9rw200" id="link-496933a6" itemprop="headline"><span>Factbox: What Do We Know About the New Coronavirus?</span></h1>, <p class="css-1fv7b6t e1jsehar1" itemprop="author" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">By<!-- --> <span class="css-1baulvz last-byline" itemprop="name">Reuters</span></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">(Reuters) - A new coronavirus that has killed 213 people in China is spreading to other countries, alarming healthexperts.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Here is some of what we know - and don't know - about thevirus:</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">WHERE DID THE VIRUS COME FROM?</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The virus is believed to have originated late last year in afood market in the Chinese city of Wuhan that was illegallyselling wildlife. Health experts think it may have originated inbats and then passed to humans, possibly via another species.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The World Health Organization (WHO) was alerted to severalcases of pneumonia in Wuhan at the end of December. Chineseauthorities confirmed they had identified a new virus a weeklater.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">HOW DANGEROUS IS IT?</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The new virus, identified by scientists as 2019-nCoV, is acoronavirus, a family of viruses that include the common coldand more serious diseases such as Severe Acute RespiratorySyndrome (SARS).</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Coronavirus infections have a wide range of symptoms,including fever, cough, shortness of breath, and breathingdifficulties.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">It is unclear how deadly the new virus is. Although severecases can cause pneumonia and death, there may be many cases ofmilder disease going undetected. Many of those who have died hadpre-existing medical conditions or were elderly, those withweakened immune systems.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">HOW IS IT TRANSMITTED AND HOW CAN IT BE PREVENTED?</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The coronavirus can be transmitted from person toperson, although it is not clear how easily that happens. Mostcases are in people who have been in Wuhan, familymembers of those infected, or medical workers.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Transmission is most likely through close contact with aninfected person via particles in the air from coughing orsneezing, or by someone touching an infected person or objectwith the virus on it and then touching their mouth, nose oreyes.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">In order to reduce the likelihood of transmission, the WHOrecommends that people frequently wash their hands, cover theirmouth and nose when sneezing or coughing, and avoid closecontact with those who are sick.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention saysthose who develop symptoms such as coughing and fever who havebeen in China in the last 14 days should call ahead to ahealthcare professional to establish if they need to be tested.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">There is no vaccine.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">WHERE HAS IT SPREAD?</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The vast majority of the almost 10,000 cases identified have been in China, mostly in and around Wuhan. Theother countries with confirmed cases include Australia,Britain, Cambodia, Canada, France, Germany, India, Japan, Malaysia, Nepal, Sri Lanka, Singapore, Thailand, South Korea, the UAE, the United States, and Vietnam.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The WHO is looking closely at cases of person-to-persontransmission outside of Wuhan, which would suggest that it mayhave the potential to spread further. The WHO says there have been at least eight cases of human-to-human transmission in four countries outside China: the United States, Germany, Japan and Vietnam. Thailand has also reported a case of human-to-human transmission.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">WHAT ARE AUTHORITIES DOING?</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The Chinese government has put Wuhan into virtual quarantine to try to stop the spread of the virus. A number of foreigngovernments, including the United States, have advised against travel to China and have begun flying their citizens out of Wuhan.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The WHO has not recommended curbs on travel or trade with China.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">IS THIS LIKE SARS?</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The new virus is a strain of coronavirus, like SARS, whichkilled nearly 800 people globally in 2002 and 2003.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Unlike SARS, which also originated in China, it is believedthe new virus can spread during the incubation period of one to14 days, possibly before an infected person is showing symptoms.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The new virus does not appear to be as deadly as SARS, but there have been more cases overall.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"> (Editing by Robert Birsel)</p>, <p>Advertisement</p>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd" id="site-index-label">Site Index</h2>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-0">news</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-1">opinion</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-2">arts</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-3">living</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-4">more</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-subscribe-label">Subscribe</h3>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd">Site Information Navigation</h2>]
[<p>Advertisement</p>, <p>Supported by</p>, <p class="css-c2jxua e6idgb70"></p>, <h1 class="css-1j5ig2m e1h9rw200" id="link-617c471e" itemprop="headline"><span>RwandAir Suspends Flights to China Amid the Coronavirus Outbreak</span></h1>, <p class="css-1fv7b6t e1jsehar1" itemprop="author" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">By<!-- --> <span class="css-1baulvz last-byline" itemprop="name">Reuters</span></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">KIGALI — RwandAir has halted flights to and from China until further notice amid a coronavirus outbreak that has so far killed 213 in China and spread to 18 countries. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">"RwandAir is to suspend flights with immediate effect between the Rwandan capital, Kigali, and the Chinese city of Guangzhou," the airline said in a statement on Friday. "The decision will be reviewed later in February." </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"> (Reporting by Clement Uwiringiyimana; writing by Omar Mohammed; Editing by Christian Schmollinger)</p>, <p>Advertisement</p>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd" id="site-index-label">Site Index</h2>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-0">news</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-1">opinion</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-2">arts</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-3">living</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-4">more</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-subscribe-label">Subscribe</h3>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd">Site Information Navigation</h2>]

[<p>Advertisement</p>, <p>Supported by</p>, <p class="css-c2jxua e6idgb70"></p>, <h1 class="css-1j5ig2m e1h9rw200" id="link-176b2a10" itemprop="headline"><span>China’s U.N. Envoy Says Beijing Assessing WHO Coronavirus Declaration</span></h1>, <p class="css-1fv7b6t e1jsehar1" itemprop="author" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">By<!-- --> <span class="css-1baulvz last-byline" itemprop="name">Reuters</span></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">UNITED NATIONS — China's U.N. ambassador, Zhang Jun, said on Thursday Beijing was assessing the World Health Organization's declaration that the coronavirus outbreak was a global emergency.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">"We are still at a very critical stage in fighting the coronavirus. International solidarity is extremely important and for that purpose all countries should behave in a ... responsible manner," Zhang said.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">"While we understand the concerns of other countries, we should also listen to the advice of WHO director-general ... He said he had full confidence in China's efforts," Zhang said.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">He said it was important to avoid "overreactions which may result in spill over negative effects."</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"> (Reporting by Michelle Nichols; Editing by Eric Beech)</p>, <p>Advertisement</p>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd" id="site-index-label">Site Index</h2>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-0">news</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-1">opinion</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-2">arts</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-3">living</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-4">more</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-subscribe-label">Subscribe</h3>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd">Site Information Navigation</h2>]
[<p>Advertisement</p>, <p>Supported by</p>, <p class="css-c2jxua e6idgb70"></p>, <h1 class="css-1j5ig2m e1h9rw200" id="link-496933a6" itemprop="headline"><span>Factbox: What Do We Know About the New Coronavirus?</span></h1>, <p class="css-1fv7b6t e1jsehar1" itemprop="author" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">By<!-- --> <span class="css-1baulvz last-byline" itemprop="name">Reuters</span></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">(Reuters) - A new coronavirus that has killed 170 people in China is spreading to other countries, alarming health experts.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Here is some of what we know - and don't know - about thevirus:</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">WHERE DID THE VIRUS COME FROM?</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The virus is believed to have originated late last year in afood market in the Chinese city of Wuhan that was illegallyselling wildlife. [<p>Advertisement</p>, <p>Supported by</p>, <p class="css-c2jxua e6idgb70"></p>, <h1 class="css-1j5ig2m e1h9rw200" id="link-49bd47fe" itemprop="headline"><span>Explainer: Rapid Spread of China Coronavirus Fuels Global Alarm</span></h1>, <p class="css-1fv7b6t e1jsehar1" itemprop="author" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">By<!-- --> <span class="css-1baulvz last-byline" itemprop="name">Reuters</span></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">(Reuters) - International alarm over the coronavirus that emerged in Wuhan, China in December is driven by its rapid spread and the fact that infectious disease experts cannot yet know how deadly or contagious it is.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Within weeks, the virus has infected nearly 8,000 people in China and killed 170. Close to 100 cases have been confirmed in other countries, from Japan to the United States. On Thursday, the World Health Organization declared the outbreak a global emergency.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Statistics from China indicate that just over 2% of people known to be infected with the virus have died, suggesting that it may be less deadly than the coronaviruses behind Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome (SARS) and Middle East Respiratory Syndrome (MERS). </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">But disease experts caution that it will take several more weeks to be confident of how the new virus behaves given how quickly it has spread and the fact that a reliable diagnostic test has only recently been introduced.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">"Not everybody is being seen, not everybody is being tested," Dr. William Schaffner, professor of preventive medicine and infectious diseases at Vanderbilt University Medical Center in Nashville, told Reuters. "All the experts, myself included, tell the public that there is much we don't know about this virus and we are learning as we go along. That is not so reassuring."</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Some experts question whether the new virus shares similarities with seasonal flu, which has a low mortality rate but infects so many people that more than half a million may die from it each year, according to global health estimates. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><span class="css-8l6xbc evw5hdy0">    </span></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">HOW DEADLY IS IT?</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The latest statistics indicate a fatality rate of about 2.2%, but the actual rate may be higher or lower as there are likely more unconfirmed cases, he said.<span class="css-8l6xbc evw5hdy0">      </span></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The SARS virus killed about 10% of all infected individuals, while the MERS outbreak identified in 2012 had a fatality rate of around 35%.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">In emerging infectious disease outbreaks, the most serious cases are identified first. Coronavirus infections can range from mild cold-like symptoms to severe cases that cause pneumonia, acute respiratory illness and death.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">About 20% of confirmed cases in the China coronavirus outbreak are classified as severe, similar to SARS and MERS, Schaffner said.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">HOW INFECTIOUS IS IT?</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The previously unknown strain is believed to have originated late last year from illegally traded wildlife at an animal market in Wuhan. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Within weeks it appeared capable of being transmitted from one person to another via droplets when an infected person breathes out, coughs or sneezes. It can also spread via contaminated surfaces such as door handles or railings. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">"The rapidity of this outbreak is startling and certainly much more rapid than SARS," said Jonathan Ball, a professor of molecular virology at Britain's University of Nottingham. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The incubation period is estimated between one and 14 days, and there have been anecdotal accounts of "symptomless spreading" by someone who is infected but unaware of it. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Neil Ferguson, an infectious disease specialist at Imperial College London, says that is too early to know if so-called "super-spreader" events seen with MERS and SARS is happening with the new coronavirus.<span class="css-8l6xbc evw5hdy0">    </span></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><span class="css-8l6xbc evw5hdy0">         </span></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">HOW ARE COUNTRIES RESPONDING?</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Some 60 million people are under virtual lockdown in China's Hubei province – of which Wuhan is the capital. Australia, South Korea, Singapore, New Zealand and Indonesia are quarantining evacuees from China for at least two weeks. Many global airlines have suspended or scaled back direct flights to China's major cities.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Experts say China has been more forthcoming with information than it was during its 2003 SARS outbreak, but there are still concerns about how much data they are sharing. Some also questioned the effectiveness of the quarantine attempt on millions of people.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">"That kind of thing can backfire. It can make it harder to get resources in," said Dr. Amesh Adalja, from the Johns Hopkins University Center for Health Security.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Graphic - Tracking the novel coronavirus: https://graphics.reuters.com/CHINA-HEALTH-MAP/0100B59S39E/index.html</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"> (Reporting by Deena Beasley in Los Angeles and Kate Kelland in London; Editing by Michele Gershberg and Lisa Shumaker)</p>, <p>Advertisement</p>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd" id="site-index-label">Site Index</h2>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-0">news</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-1">opinion</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-2">arts</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-3">living</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-4">more</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-subscribe-label">Subscribe</h3>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd">Site Information Navigation</h2>]
[<p>Advertisement</p>, <p>Supported by</p>, <p class="css-c2jxua e6idgb70"></p>, <h1 class="css-1j5ig2m e1h9rw200" id="link-4d43119f" itemprop="headline"><span>First Two Coronavirus Cases Confirmed in Italy-Prime Minister</span></h1>, <p class="css-1fv7b6t e1jsehar1" itemprop="author" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">By<!-- --> <span class="css-1baulvz last-byline" itemprop="name">Reuters</span></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">ROME — Italian Prime Minister Giuseppe Conte said on Thursday that two cases of coronavirus had been confirmed in Italy, the first in the country since the outbreak in Wuhan, China.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Two Chinese tourists who were visiting Italy had contracted the virus, Conte said. Checks were being made to reconstruct the path of the two people to avoid further risks.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The head of the national institute for infectious diseases said their condition was good.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">"We have two confirmed cases of coronavirus in Italy," the prime minister told a news conference, adding that the government had decided to close air traffic to and from China.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">"As far as we know we are the first country in the EU to adopt such a measure" Conte said. </p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">A cabinet meeting has been called on Friday to decide further measures, Conte said.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">On Thursday, the World Health Organization declared that the coronavirus outbreak that has killed 170 people in China constituted a global public health emergency.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Both Chinese tourists were in an isolation unit of Rome's Spallanzani institute, a centre specializing in infectious diseases and viruses.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">"The two people have been under observation in the hospital since yesterday ... The diagnosis was certified by the National Institute of Health," said Giuseppe Ippolito, scientific director of the Spallanzani institute.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"> (Reporting by Angelo Amante and Elvira Pollina; Editing by Sandra Maler and Grant McCool)</p>, <p>Advertisement</p>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd" id="site-index-label">Site Index</h2>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-0">news</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-1">opinion</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-2">arts</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-3">living</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-4">more</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-subscribe-label">Subscribe</h3>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd">Site Information Navigation</h2>]
[<p>Advertisement</p>, <p>Supported by</p>, <p class="css-c2jxua e6idgb70"></p>, <h1 class="css-1j5ig2m e1h9rw200" id="link-1cabb594" itemprop="headline"><span>Coronavirus to Have Little Impact on U.S. Economy-Trump Adviser</span></h1>, <p class="css-1fv7b6t e1jsehar1" itemprop="author" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">By<!-- --> <span class="css-1baulvz last-byline" itemprop="name">Reuters</span></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">WASHINGTON — The fast-spreading coronavirus, which has killed 170 people in China and infected six in the United States, should have little impact on the U.S. economy, President Donald Trump's chief economic adviser said on Thursday.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">"We see no material impact on our economy," Larry Kudlow, director of the National Economic Council Director, told Fox Business Network.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Kudlow said the Trump administration had taken a look at the outbreak of SARS, or Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome, in the early-2000s and found the economic impact on the United States had been negligible. SARS was first reported in Asia and spread to more than two dozen countries.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">"There was no material impact," he said, adding, "This may or may not be worse."</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Cases of coronavirus globally surpassed 8,100 on Thursday, outstripping the total number of infections in the SARS epidemic of 2003.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The coronavirus crisis is forecast to sharply dent China's economy, the world's second-largest.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Kudlow said the United States stood ready to help, but said Beijing should not expect relief from U.S. trade tariffs.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">"These are separate matters," he said. "This is completely separate from issues of trade or related matters."</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"> (Reporting by Tim Ahmann; Editing by Leslie Adler)</p>, <p>Advertisement</p>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd" id="site-index-label">Site Index</h2>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-0">news</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-1">opinion</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-2">arts</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-3">living</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-4">more</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-subscribe-label">Subscribe</h3>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd">Site Information Navigation</h2>]
[<p>Advertisement</p>, <p>Supported by</p>, <p class="css-c2jxua e6idgb70"></p>, <h1 class="css-1j5ig2m e1h9rw200" id="link-1cabb594" itemprop="headline"><span>Coronavirus to Have Little Impact on U.S. Economy-Trump Adviser</span></h1>, <p class="css-1fv7b6t e1jsehar1" itemprop="author" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">By<!-- --> <span class="css-1baulvz last-byline" itemprop="name">Reuters</span></p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">WASHINGTON — The fast-spreading coronavirus, which has killed 170 people in China and infected six in the United States, should have little impact on the U.S. economy, President Donald Trump's chief economic adviser said on Thursday.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">"We see no material impact on our economy," Larry Kudlow, director of the National Economic Council Director, told Fox Business Network.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Kudlow said the Trump administration had taken a look at the outbreak of SARS, or Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome, in the early-2000s and found the economic impact on the United States had been negligible. SARS was first reported in Asia and spread to more than two dozen countries.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">"There was no material impact," he said, adding, "This may or may not be worse."</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Cases of coronavirus globally surpassed 8,100 on Thursday, outstripping the total number of infections in the SARS epidemic of 2003.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The coronavirus crisis is forecast to sharply dent China's economy, the world's second-largest.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Kudlow said the United States stood ready to help, but said Beijing should not expect relief from U.S. trade tariffs.</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">"These are separate matters," he said. "This is completely separate from issues of trade or related matters."</p>, <p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"> (Reporting by Tim Ahmann; Editing by Leslie Adler)</p>, <p>Advertisement</p>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd" id="site-index-label">Site Index</h2>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-0">news</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-1">opinion</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-2">arts</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-3">living</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-section-label-4">more</h3>, <h3 class="css-rxqrcl" id="site-index-subscribe-label">Subscribe</h3>, <h2 class="css-vz7hjd">Site Information Navigation</h2>]
